text: This study introduces a novel deep learning architecture, the Harmonic-Voicing Variational Autoencoder (HV-VAE), for the unsupervised analysis of tonal harmony. By leveraging a disentangled latent space, our model separates the abstract harmonic function from its concrete chordal voicing. We trained the HV-VAE on a large corpus of digitized Bach chorales represented as piano-roll matrices. The model learns a continuous, low-dimensional manifold where one axis corresponds to diatonic function (e.g., tonic, dominant) and orthogonal axes represent parsimonious voice-leading transformations. Quantitative evaluation demonstrates superior performance in chord labeling and functional analysis tasks compared to traditional Hidden Markov Models and standard VAEs. Furthermore, qualitative analysis of the latent space reveals topologically coherent structures mirroring established music-theoretic concepts, such as the circle of fifths and neo-Riemannian transformations. This approach provides a powerful computational framework for exploring the hierarchical relationship between abstract harmonic syntax and surface-level acoustical realization.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangling Harmonic Function and Voicing in a Variational Latent Space

text: The perceptual phenomenon of orchestral timbre blending, central to the art of orchestration, has remained computationally elusive. This research investigates the acoustic correlates of successful instrumental blending through a hybrid psychoacoustic and machine learning methodology. We compiled a dataset of dyadic instrumental combinations, rated for their blend quality by expert listeners. A comprehensive set of audio features—including spectral centroid, spectral flux, harmonic entropy, and Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs)—was extracted from each audio sample. A Support Vector Machine (SVM) classifier, trained on these features, achieved high accuracy in predicting perceptual blend ratings. Feature importance analysis revealed that similarity in spectral envelope and temporal attack characteristics are primary predictors of successful blending. The findings challenge traditional orchestration treatises that emphasize harmonic series alignment, suggesting instead that dynamic spectral congruence is the dominant factor. This model provides a quantitative tool for composers and a new empirical basis for orchestration theory.
subject: Müzik
title: A Psychoacoustic and Machine Learning Approach to Orchestral Timbre Blending

text: Generating stylistically coherent polyphonic music with deep learning models remains a significant challenge, particularly in maintaining long-range contrapuntal integrity. This paper proposes a novel generative architecture, the Polyphonic Graph Transformer (PGT), which models musical voices as nodes in a dynamic graph. By explicitly representing the relationships between concurrent melodic lines, the model can apply attention mechanisms not only temporally but also inter-vocally. We trained the PGT on the complete J.S. Bach Well-Tempered Clavier, encoding the music in a symbolic piano-roll format augmented with voice-crossing and intervallic information. The model learns to respect species counterpoint rules implicitly, minimizing parallel fifths and octaves while promoting melodic independence. Objective evaluation using statistical measures of voice-leading smoothness and harmonic dissonance shows a significant improvement over standard LSTM and Transformer-based models. Subjective listening tests confirm that compositions generated by the PGT possess a higher degree of musical coherence and stylistic authenticity.
subject: Müzik
title: Contrapuntal Consistency in Polyphonic Music Generation using Graph-Based Attention Networks

text: Iannis Xenakis's pioneering work in spectral and stochastic music challenges conventional analytical paradigms. This study presents a computational analysis of his seminal orchestral piece, *Metastaseis*, focusing on the quantification of its characteristic mass effects and glissandi. We employ a non-stationary Gabor transform, a variant of the Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) with adaptive windowing, to achieve high temporal and frequency resolution simultaneously. This allows for precise tracking of the microtonal trajectories of individual instrumental lines within the dense orchestral texture. By analyzing the time-varying spectral density, we algorithmically segment the work into distinct textural clouds and mathematically model their evolutionary dynamics. Our results provide empirical validation for Xenakis's own sketches, which map glissandi to ruled surfaces, and reveal a deeper structural logic based on the statistical distribution of spectral energy. This methodology offers a new lens for the analysis of post-tonal, texture-based compositions.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectral-Temporal Analysis of Xenakis's 'Metastaseis' through Non-Stationary Gabor Transforms

text: The complex rhythmic structures (talas) of South Indian Carnatic music present a significant challenge for automated analysis due to their improvisatory nature and micro-rhythmic variations. This paper introduces an unsupervised method for the discovery and classification of tala patterns directly from audio recordings. The approach utilizes an onset detection function to extract a percussive event time-series. Subsequently, we employ a novel subsequence Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) algorithm to identify recurring rhythmic motifs without prior knowledge of tempo or meter. These motifs are then clustered using a density-based algorithm (DBSCAN) to group performances by their underlying tala. The system was tested on a large dataset of Carnatic percussion solos, demonstrating high accuracy in identifying the principal talas such as Adi, Rupaka, and Misra Chapu. This data-driven methodology transcends the limitations of template-based approaches, offering a robust tool for large-scale cross-corpus analysis in computational ethnomusicology.
subject: Müzik
title: Unsupervised Discovery of Rhythmic Cycles (Tala) in Carnatic Music using Subsequence Dynamic Time Warping

text: Musical expression is conveyed through nuanced deviations from a score's nominal instructions. This research proposes a hierarchical Bayesian model to disentangle the sources of expressive variation in piano performance, specifically microtiming and dynamics. We model a performer's rendering of a note's onset time and velocity as being drawn from distributions whose parameters are conditioned by multiple hierarchical levels of musical structure: the individual note's metrical position, the local harmonic context, and the global phrase structure. The model was trained on a corpus of expert performances of Chopin mazurkas, aligned to their symbolic scores. Through Bayesian inference, we can estimate the relative contributions of these structural factors to expressive choices, such as phrase-final lengthening or agogic accents on harmonically significant chords. This probabilistic framework not only provides a powerful descriptive tool for performance analysis but also functions as a generative model capable of synthesizing stylistically plausible, expressive performances from a neutral score.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hierarchical Bayesian Model of Microtiming and Dynamics in Expressive Piano Performance

text: The predictive coding theory of brain function posits that perception arises from minimizing prediction errors. We apply this framework to model the experience of tonal expectation in music. Our model, implemented as a hierarchical recurrent neural network, learns the statistical regularities of Western tonal harmony from a large symbolic corpus. Crucially, the input representation is not symbolic pitch-classes but a psychoacoustically-motivated auditory spectrogram, allowing the model to learn relationships based on acoustic, rather than abstract, features. The model continuously generates predictions about the forthcoming auditory stream. The magnitude of the prediction error—the discrepancy between the predicted and actual input—is interpreted as a neural correlate of musical surprise. We validated our model by correlating its prediction error signal with listener ratings of surprise for a series of harmonically ambiguous chord progressions. The results demonstrate a strong positive correlation, supporting the hypothesis that predictive processing is a core mechanism of music cognition.
subject: Müzik
title: Modeling Tonal Expectation and Surprise using a Predictive Coding Framework with Auditory Representations

text: Automatic Music Transcription (AMT) and source separation are intrinsically linked but often addressed as separate tasks. We propose a unified, multi-task deep learning framework that performs them jointly. Our model utilizes a U-Net architecture, common in image segmentation, adapted for time-frequency representations of audio. The network takes a mixed audio spectrogram as input and outputs multiple channels simultaneously: an estimated spectrogram for each target instrument and a multi-pitch piano-roll activation map. By learning to separate sources and transcribe notes in a shared latent space, the model leverages synergistic information; knowledge of an instrument's presence aids transcription, and detected pitches inform the separation mask. Trained on the MedleyDB dataset, our joint model significantly outperforms pipelined systems where separation and transcription are performed sequentially. This end-to-end approach demonstrates superior robustness in highly polyphonic and dense instrumental textures, marking a substantial advance for complex audio analysis tasks.
subject: Müzik
title: Multi-Instrument Polyphonic Transcription via Joint Source Separation and Pitch Detection with a U-Net Architecture

text: Geometric models of music theory provide powerful abstractions for understanding voice-leading and harmonic structure. This paper extends these models to the analysis of post-tonal repertoires by employing methods from Topological Data Analysis (TDA). We construct point-cloud datasets from the pitch-class sets present in compositions by Schoenberg, Webern, and Ligeti, embedding them within a toroidal voice-leading space. Using persistent homology, we analyze the topological features (e.g., loops, voids) of these point clouds across multiple scales. Our analysis reveals distinct topological signatures for different composers and stylistic periods. For instance, Webern's music exhibits a high prevalence of one-dimensional cycles corresponding to his frequent use of inversionally-related trichords, a feature not prominent in Ligeti's micropolyphonic textures. This TDA-based approach quantifies intuitive notions of musical coherence in atonal music, providing an empirical method for comparing compositional strategies not captured by traditional set-theoretic analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Data Analysis of Voice-Leading Spaces in Post-Tonal Music

text: The transition between vocal registers (e.g., chest and head voice) is a critical aspect of vocal pedagogy, yet its acoustic markers are complex. This study employs glottal inverse filtering to separate the vocal source (glottal airflow) from the vocal tract filter (formants) in recordings of elite operatic and pop singers performing ascending scales. We analyze changes in glottal source parameters, including the open quotient (OQ), speed quotient (SQ), and harmonic richness factor (HRF), in conjunction with vocal tract resonance (formant) tuning strategies. Results indicate that operatic singers execute register transitions with minimal perceptible change by maintaining a consistent glottal adduction and strategically tuning F1 and F2 formants. In contrast, pop singers often utilize an abrupt shift in glottal configuration, resulting in a distinct timbral change. These findings provide quantitative, production-based evidence for different pedagogical approaches to register management and offer a robust framework for computational analysis of vocal technique.
subject: Müzik
title: Acoustic Correlates of Vocal Register Transitions in Operatic and Pop Singing using Glottal Inverse Filtering

text: This paper introduces a novel computational framework for automating Schenkerian analysis from symbolic music representations. Traditional approaches struggle to capture the multi-level hierarchical nature of Schenkerian graphs. We reconceptualize the problem as a graph-to-graph translation task, modeling musical scores as primary graphs and their corresponding Schenkerian reductions as target graphs. Our proposed model employs a hierarchical Graph Neural Network (GNN) with iterative attention mechanisms to learn the complex prolongational and contrapuntal relationships that define structural levels (foreground, middleground, background). Trained on a curated corpus of expert analyses, our system demonstrates high fidelity in identifying fundamental structures (Ursatz) and key prolongational spans. The GNN-based approach significantly outperforms previous rule-based and statistical methods, offering a scalable solution for large-scale structural analysis and providing new empirical insights into the principles of tonal coherence and hierarchical listening.
subject: Müzik
title: Automated Schenkerian Analysis via Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks

text: The precise tuning systems, or temperaments, used in historical performance practice are often a subject of scholarly debate. This research presents a probabilistic method for identifying historical temperaments directly from polyphonic audio recordings. We formulate a Bayesian inference model where the temperament is a latent parameter set governing the fundamental frequency relationships of concurrent tones. Using a sophisticated pitch-tracking front-end, we extract partial frequencies and model their likelihood given various historical temperament specifications (e.g., Pythagorean, quarter-comma meantone, well-temperaments). A Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm is used to efficiently explore the parameter space and estimate the posterior probability distribution over a dictionary of temperaments. When applied to recordings of historically informed performances, our model correctly identifies the documented temperament with high confidence, providing an empirical tool for musicologists to verify performance practice and analyze the sonic consequences of historical tuning decisions.
subject: Müzik
title: Bayesian Inference of Historical Temperaments from Polyphonic Audio Recordings

text: The relationship between orchestration and harmonic function remains a theoretically rich but computationally underexplored domain. We propose a deep learning model to quantify this relationship by mapping instrument combinations to a structured latent space. A β-Variational Autoencoder (β-VAE) is trained on a large dataset of orchestral excerpts, learning a continuous, low-dimensional embedding from spectro-temporal audio features. Our results demonstrate that this learned timbral latent space is highly organized: distinct clusters emerge corresponding to specific harmonic functions (e.g., tonic, dominant preparations). Furthermore, geodesic paths between points in the manifold correspond to perceptually smooth timbral interpolations. This geometric representation allows for a quantitative analysis of orchestrational conventions, providing a novel empirical framework for theories of instrumentation and enabling generative applications such as timbre-aware harmonization and automatic orchestration based on harmonic context.
subject: Müzik
title: The Timbral Latent Space: A Variational Autoencoder for Probing Orchestrational-Harmonic Covariance

text: The concept of metric dissonance, encompassing both grouping and displacement dissonance, provides a theoretical framework for rhythmic complexity but lacks robust quantitative models. This study introduces a data-driven method for decomposing and quantifying metric dissonance from musical onsets. We represent rhythmic passages as high-resolution inter-onset interval (IOI) histograms, capturing the periodicities present in the signal. We then apply a constrained Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) algorithm to these histograms. The NMF decomposes the complex IOI distribution into a set of basis vectors, or 'rhythmic prototypes,' and their corresponding temporal activations. Our findings show a strong correspondence between these learned prototypes and the constituent pulse streams that create metric dissonance (e.g., 3-against-2). This unsupervised decomposition provides a granular, quantitative measure of dissonance types and their evolution, offering a powerful analytical tool for complex polyrhythms in diverse musical idioms.
subject: Müzik
title: Decomposition of Metric Dissonance using Constrained Non-Negative Matrix Factorization on Inter-Onset Interval Histograms

text: Neo-Riemannian theory offers a powerful group-theoretic model for understanding chromatic harmony, yet its standard operators (P, L, R) are limited in scope. We propose a generalized geometric framework that measures the distance between any two chords based on the principle of optimal transport. Chords are represented as probability distributions on a continuous toroidal Tonnetz manifold. The Wasserstein distance, a metric from optimal transport theory, is then computed between these distributions, quantifying the minimal 'work' required to transform one chord into another. This metric intrinsically models parsimonious voice-leading for transformations of any complexity, subsuming canonical Neo-Riemannian operations as special cases. Empirical evaluation against datasets of Western tonal music demonstrates that the Wasserstein distance correlates more strongly with established principles of harmonic syntax and perceptual smoothness than traditional voice-leading distance metrics, offering a more nuanced and extensible model for harmonic analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: A Geometric Framework for Neo-Riemannian Analysis using Optimal Transport on the Tonnetz

text: The analysis of music featuring indeterminacy, particularly that of composers like Witold Lutosławski, presents a significant challenge due to the semantic gap between the graphical score and its sonic realization. This paper introduces a cross-modal deep learning architecture to align these two domains. We employ a convolutional neural network (CNN) to extract geometric features from scanned images of Lutosławski's 'aleatoric counterpoint' sections, coupled with a recurrent neural network (RNN) processing spectro-temporal features from corresponding audio performances. An attention-based alignment mechanism learns the correspondence between specific graphical gestures and resultant sonic textures across multiple interpretations. Our model successfully identifies consistent performance strategies associated with notational elements, revealing latent performance conventions. This methodology provides the first scalable computational tool for the systematic analysis of the graphical score-performance relationship in aleatoric music, bridging the domains of optical music recognition and performance analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Aleatoric Analysis: Aligning Indeterminate Graphical Scores and Performance Audio with a Convolutional Recurrent Network

text: The classification of microtonal tuning systems from audio signals is a challenging task due to the immense diversity of possible scales. We present a novel approach that eschews precise frequency measurement in favor of analyzing the global geometric structure of pitch relationships. Audio signals are transformed into time-series of chroma vectors, which are then aggregated into a high-dimensional point cloud. We apply techniques from Topological Data Analysis (TDA), specifically persistent homology, to compute a 'topological fingerprint' of this point cloud. The resulting persistence diagram, which captures the lifespan of topological features like loops and voids at different spatial resolutions, serves as a robust, scale-invariant signature. Our experiments demonstrate that this signature can effectively distinguish between various classes of tuning systems—including different equal temperaments, just intonation systems, and non-octave scales—without any prior knowledge of their theoretical construction.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Fingerprinting of Microtonal Systems via Persistent Homology of Chroma Point Clouds

text: This study formalizes a computational model of musical expectation grounded in information theory. We move beyond static n-gram models by implementing an adaptive prediction algorithm based on a K-Trie data structure, which dynamically adjusts its context length to optimize predictive accuracy. Trained on a large symbolic corpus of Western tonal music, the model computes the information content (or surprisal) for each event in a novel musical passage. This quantitative measure reflects the cognitive effort required to process an event given the learned statistical regularities of the style. In a series of listening experiments, we found a significant positive correlation between the model's calculated information rate and human subjects' real-time ratings of tension and surprise. This provides strong empirical support for the hypothesis that musical affect is deeply intertwined with the information-theoretic processing of probabilistic melodic structures, validating Leonard Meyer's seminal theories in a quantitative framework.
subject: Müzik
title: An Information-Theoretic Approach to Musical Expectation using Adaptive K-Trie Prediction Models

text: The identification of recurring contrapuntal schemata in dense Renaissance polyphony is a fundamental yet arduous task in musicology. We present a computational methodology that automates this discovery process using graph-theoretic principles. Each polyphonic excerpt is encoded as a directed acyclic graph where nodes represent notes and edges represent melodic and harmonic intervals, weighted by their rhythmic context. The problem of finding a specific contrapuntal pattern (e.g., an imitative motive) is then cast as a weighted subgraph isomorphism problem. By employing a state-of-the-art constraint-solving algorithm, we can efficiently search a large corpus of motets by composers like Josquin des Prez for instances of a query pattern, including transformations such as inversion and retrograde. The system successfully rediscovers known contrapuntal devices and uncovers previously unannotated structural relationships, demonstrating the efficacy of graph-based representations for scalable, deep analysis of complex polyphonic textures.
subject: Müzik
title: Contrapuntal Pattern Discovery in Renaissance Polyphony via Weighted Subgraph Isomorphism

text: The accuracy of automated harmonic analysis is often degraded by timbral mixing in complex audio signals. Conversely, source separation can benefit from high-level musical knowledge. We propose a synergistic model that performs both tasks simultaneously within a unified joint optimization framework. Our approach is based on Non-negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) of the audio spectrogram. The framework is constrained by two interconnected priors: a harmonicity prior that encourages source spectra to consist of harmonically related partials, and a music-theoretic prior that biases the temporal activations of sources toward combinations that form coherent chord progressions according to a hidden Markov model (HMM) of tonal syntax. By jointly optimizing the source spectra, their activations, and the underlying chord sequence, our model significantly outperforms pipelined approaches. It achieves cleaner source separation and more accurate chord labeling on dense orchestral and jazz recordings, demonstrating the power of integrating low-level signal processing with high-level musical structure.
subject: Müzik
title: Synergistic Source Separation and Harmonic Analysis through Joint Spectrogram Factorization

text: We report a loophole-free experimental violation of a Bell inequality tailored for continuous-variable systems. By generating entangled twin beams via parametric down-conversion, we prepare a two-mode squeezed vacuum state distributed between two spatially separated, non-communicating laboratories. High-efficiency homodyne detection is employed to measure quadrature amplitudes, allowing for the reconstruction of the joint phase-space Wigner function, which exhibits significant negativity. The experiment rigorously closes the detection and locality loopholes by ensuring a minimal detection efficiency of 98.7% and enforcing spacelike separation of the measurement events. We evaluate the Clauser-Horne-Shimony-Holt (CHSH)-like inequality generalized for continuous variables, observing a violation of S = 2.51 ± 0.04, which exceeds the classical limit by more than twelve standard deviations. This result provides definitive evidence against local realism in a macroscopic regime and demonstrates a robust platform for quantum communication protocols that rely on continuous-variable entanglement, such as quantum key distribution and teleportation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Violation of a Continuous-Variable Bell Inequality with Spatially Separated Squeezed-State Entangled Systems

text: The experimental realization of non-Abelian anyons is a principal objective for topological quantum computation. We present theoretical and numerical evidence for the existence of Fibonacci anyons in the ν=12/5 fractional quantum Hall (FQH) state. Using exact diagonalization on a sphere and torus geometry, we analyze the ground state manifold and its low-energy excitations. The resulting quasihole states exhibit the characteristic quantum dimension predicted by the Z_3-parafermion conformal field theory, d = (1+√5)/2. We propose a Fabry-Pérot interferometry experiment to directly probe the non-Abelian braiding statistics. Our transport calculations show that the interference pattern of quasihole currents will exhibit a distinct signature consistent with the Fibonacci fusion rules, τ ⊗ τ = 1 ⊕ τ. This confirmation would not only solidify the ν=12/5 state as a prime candidate for hosting non-Abelian excitations but also pave the way for constructing topologically protected qubits for universal fault-tolerant quantum computing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Braiding Statistics of Fibonacci Anyons in a ν=12/5 Fractional Quantum Hall State

text: We investigate the holographic duality between a two-site Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) model with a deformed quartic coupling and a two-dimensional Jackiw-Teitelboim (JT) gravity theory on a spacetime with an eternal traversable wormhole. By calculating the Rényi and von Neumann entanglement entropies on the boundary quantum system, we demonstrate that the results precisely match the bulk geometry predictions derived from the Ryu-Takayanagi formula. The deformation term in the SYK Hamiltonian corresponds to a specific matter field in the bulk that violates the averaged null energy condition, thereby stabilizing the wormhole throat. Our analysis of the out-of-time-order correlator (OTOC) reveals a suppression of maximal chaos, consistent with the non-trivial causal structure of the traversable wormhole. This work strengthens the ER=EPR conjecture by providing a concrete, calculable model where quantum entanglement dynamics directly construct a persistent bridge in the emergent spacetime geometry, offering insights into the black hole information paradox.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Wormhole Geometry in a Deformed SYK Model

text: Achieving the fundamental Heisenberg limit in quantum metrology offers an unparalleled advantage in precision measurement. We propose and analyze a multi-pass interferometric scheme using path-entangled N00N states (|N⟩_a|0⟩_b + |0⟩_a|N⟩_b)/√2 to achieve Heisenberg-limited sensitivity. The protocol involves injecting an N-photon N00N state into an interferometer where one arm accumulates a phase shift φ. By recycling the photons through the interferometer M times, the effective phase shift is amplified to MNφ. We calculate the quantum Fisher information for this protocol, demonstrating that the phase sensitivity δφ scales as 1/(MN), saturating the Heisenberg limit for the total number of resource probes. A detailed analysis of decoherence, particularly photon loss and phase diffusion, indicates that while fragility increases with N and M, a significant quantum advantage remains achievable with current photonic technologies. This protocol has direct applications in gravitational wave detection, magnetometry, and quantum imaging.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Phase Estimation via Multi-Pass Interferometry with N00N States

text: We theoretically investigate the ground-state phase diagram of a harmonically trapped, two-component Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) subject to both long-range dipolar interactions and Rashba-Dresselhaus spin-orbit coupling. By solving the coupled Gross-Pitaevskii equations and performing quantum Monte Carlo simulations, we identify a rich phase diagram containing distinct quantum phases. For specific parameter regimes, we report the emergence of a stable supersolid phase, characterized by the simultaneous breaking of U(1) gauge symmetry (superfluidity) and continuous translational symmetry (crystal structure). The supersolid manifests as a lattice of density modulations immersed in a superfluid background. The roton-maxon excitation spectrum, calculated via Bogoliubov-de Gennes analysis, shows a characteristic softening at a finite momentum, heralding the transition from a uniform condensate to the modulated supersolid phase. Our findings provide a concrete roadmap for the experimental realization of this exotic state of matter, bridging condensed matter and quantum gas physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergence of a Supersolid Phase in a Dipolar Bose-Einstein Condensate with Spin-Orbit Coupling

text: Quantum error correction (QEC) is indispensable for fault-tolerant quantum computing, yet most codes are designed for simple, Markovian noise. We introduce a novel QEC scheme, the Dynamically Decoupled Floquet Code (DDFC), which leverages Floquet engineering to protect a logical qubit against a broad spectrum of non-Markovian noise. The code is defined by a set of time-periodic stabilizer operators derived from a parent stabilizer code, with the periodic driving chosen to dynamically decouple the logical subspace from dominant environmental noise channels. Using a filter-function formalism, we demonstrate that the DDFC can suppress noise up to a high order in the Floquet-Magnus expansion. Numerical simulations of a logical qubit encoded in a five-qubit DDFC subjected to 1/f noise show a coherence time enhancement of over two orders of magnitude compared to its static counterpart and other standard dynamical decoupling sequences. This paradigm offers a promising route towards building resilient quantum memories in realistic solid-state architectures.
subject: Kuantum
title: A Dynamically Decoupled Floquet Code for Robust Quantum Memory

text: Macroscopic quantum superpositions, or 'Schrödinger cat' states, are crucial for fundamental tests of quantum mechanics and for certain quantum computing architectures. We present a deterministic protocol for generating and verifying multi-photon cat states within a high-Q 3D microwave cavity coupled to a transmon qubit. Operating in the strong dispersive regime of cavity QED, our protocol utilizes a sequence of conditional qubit rotations and cavity displacements to deterministically grow a coherent state into a superposition of two coherent states with opposite phases, |α⟩ ± |-α⟩. We perform full quantum state tomography of the resulting cavity field using Wigner function reconstruction, clearly observing the characteristic interference fringes and negative regions for states up to |α|² ≈ 16. The high fidelity (F > 92%) and scalability of this protocol establish a powerful new tool for quantum state engineering and provide a platform for implementing Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill (GKP) qubits for hardware-efficient quantum error correction.
subject: Kuantum
title: Deterministic Generation and Tomography of Multi-Photon Schrödinger Cat States in a 3D Transmon-Cavity System

text: We analyze the performance of a quantum Otto engine whose working medium consists of a two-level system coupled to two squeezed thermal reservoirs. Our analysis, conducted within a completely positive and trace-preserving (CPTP) map formalism, goes beyond the quasi-static limit to explore far-from-equilibrium operation. We demonstrate that the quantum coherence injected by the squeezed baths acts as a thermodynamic resource. Specifically, the engine can achieve efficiencies exceeding the classical Carnot limit for an equivalent engine operating between standard thermal baths at the same effective temperatures. This efficiency enhancement is directly correlated with the degree of squeezing and the non-zero quantum discord established between the system and the baths. Furthermore, we find a fundamental trade-off between power output and efficiency, identifying optimal operating cycles that maximize power for a given efficiency bound. This work elucidates the non-trivial role of quantum coherence in non-equilibrium thermodynamics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Coherence-Fueled Quantum Otto Engine Operating Far from Equilibrium

text: Entanglement is a fragile resource, known to degrade for observers in non-inertial reference frames due to the Unruh effect. We investigate the dynamics of a maximally entangled Bell state shared between an inertial observer, Alice, and a uniformly accelerated observer, Rob. The Unruh thermal noise experienced by Rob transforms the quantum channel into a depolarizing and dissipative one, leading to entanglement sudden death at a finite acceleration. Here, we propose a protocol to counteract this degradation. By characterizing the Bogoliubov transformation that links the Minkowski vacuum to the Rindler vacuum, we model the Unruh effect as a specific quantum channel. We then construct a pre-compensating unitary operation that Alice can apply to her qubit before Rob's acceleration begins. This operation effectively 'inverts' the future effects of the Unruh channel, allowing for the perfect preservation of a specific entangled state for any finite acceleration. This demonstrates a principle of relativistic quantum state protection.
subject: Kuantum
title: Preservation of Bipartite Entanglement for Accelerated Observers via Unruh Channel Inversion

text: The correspondence between classical chaos and quantum mechanics is a foundational question, often probed via the spectral statistics of quantum systems. We investigate the signatures of quantum chaos in a periodically driven quantum kicked rotor model, realized with a Bose-Einstein condensate in a pulsed optical lattice, where time-reversal symmetry is explicitly broken by a synthetic gauge field. By numerically diagonalizing the Floquet operator, we analyze the level spacing distribution of the quasi-energy spectrum. We observe a clear transition in the spectral statistics from a Poissonian distribution, characteristic of an integrable system, to a Wigner-Dyson distribution of the Gaussian Unitary Ensemble (GUE) as the kicking strength is increased beyond a critical threshold. This transition provides unambiguous evidence for the onset of quantum chaos. The results are universal and independent of microscopic details, confirming predictions from random matrix theory and establishing ultracold atoms as a highly tunable platform for studying quantum chaology.
subject: Kuantum
title: Spectral Statistics Transition in a Driven Floquet System with Synthetic Gauge Fields

text: This paper addresses the challenge of estimating the average treatment effect (ATE) in high-dimensional settings where confounding variables are numerous. We introduce a doubly robust and debiased machine learning framework that leverages Neyman-orthogonal moments to mitigate regularization bias and model mis-specification. Our proposed method employs a cross-fitting procedure, utilizing flexible machine learning algorithms like LASSO or random forests to estimate the nuisance functions—the conditional outcome and propensity score models. By constructing an orthogonalized moment condition, our estimator for the ATE remains consistent and asymptotically normal even when the nuisance function estimators converge at slower, non-parametric rates. We establish the semiparametric efficiency of our estimator under mild sparsity assumptions on the underlying linear models. Extensive Monte Carlo simulations demonstrate superior finite-sample performance, achieving nominal coverage probabilities for confidence intervals where other high-dimensional methods fail. The methodology is applied to a genomic dataset to estimate the causal effect of a gene expression on a clinical phenotype.
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Machine Learning for Causal Inference in High-Dimensional Partially Linear Models

text: We propose a novel Bayesian nonparametric framework for clustering functional data, addressing the geometric complexities of function spaces. The method models the distribution of functions as a Dirichlet Process Mixture Model where the base measure is defined on a space of probability measures, equipped with the Wasserstein metric. This Wasserstein-Dirichlet Process Mixture (WDPM) naturally accommodates variations in both amplitude and phase (warping) by clustering the distributions of functional observations rather than the functions themselves. The stick-breaking construction of the Dirichlet Process is adapted to this metric space setting. We derive theoretical results concerning the posterior contraction rates, demonstrating that our model achieves optimal rates for density estimation in the Wasserstein space. An efficient Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm is developed for posterior inference, utilizing a Gibbs sampler with an embedded slice sampler for the infinite-dimensional random measure. The superiority of our approach is demonstrated on synthetic data and real-world applications in proteomics and electrocardiogram signal analysis.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Nonparametric Clustering of Functional Data via Wasserstein-Dirichlet Process Mixtures

text: Topological Data Analysis (TDA) provides powerful tools for characterizing the shape of data, yet rigorous statistical inference on topological features remains a nascent field. This paper introduces a comprehensive framework for constructing confidence regions for persistent homology features. We represent topological summaries as persistence diagrams and embed them in a separable Hilbert space to define a Fréchet mean and variance. Our primary contribution is a multi-scale bootstrap procedure that correctly accounts for the complex dependence structure between persistence points, enabling the construction of valid confidence sets for Betti numbers at different scales. We prove the asymptotic validity of our bootstrap confidence regions under general conditions on the underlying data-generating process. The method is computationally feasible and robust to topological noise. Through simulations, we show our method provides superior coverage compared to existing subspace and permutation-based tests. We apply the framework to a cosmological dataset to test for the significance of filamentary structures in the cosmic web.
subject: İstatistik
title: A Statistical Framework for Inference on Persistent Homology using Multi-scale Bootstrap

text: We introduce a robust methodology for estimating high-dimensional sparse covariance matrices from data following a general class of elliptical distributions, which includes heavy-tailed cases like the multivariate t-distribution. Our procedure is a two-stage method that first computes a robust scatter matrix using a computationally efficient M-estimator, specifically a re-weighted version of Tyler's shape matrix, and then applies an adaptive thresholding operator to enforce sparsity. We provide a rigorous non-asymptotic analysis, deriving explicit convergence rates for our estimator in the operator norm. These theoretical guarantees hold under significantly weaker moment conditions compared to standard methods based on the sample covariance matrix. The key technical innovation involves leveraging concentration inequalities for random matrices from elliptically symmetric distributions. Simulation studies confirm the theoretical results, showing that our estimator substantially outperforms competing methods like graphical LASSO and CLIME in the presence of outliers and heavy tails. The utility is illustrated in a portfolio optimization application with financial returns data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Robust High-Dimensional Covariance Matrix Estimation under Elliptical Distributions

text: This work develops a general methodology for constructing asymptotically efficient confidence intervals for parameters of M-estimators while satisfying the stringent constraints of differential privacy. Our approach is based on a calibrated objective perturbation technique. We perturb the empirical objective function with a carefully chosen Gaussian process and then derive the M-estimator from this privatized objective. We demonstrate that, with a properly scaled noise level, the resulting estimator is asymptotically normal and its variance approaches the Cramér-Rao lower bound as the privacy budget ε grows. The crucial step is the calibration of the perturbation variance to the Fisher information of the model, which optimizes the statistical utility for a given privacy level. This allows for the construction of Wald-type confidence intervals with asymptotically correct coverage. Our method bypasses the need for complex and often sub-optimal post-processing or bootstrap techniques, providing a direct and theoretically grounded approach to private inference for a wide class of statistical models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Asymptotically Efficient Confidence Intervals under Differential Privacy via Calibrated Objective Perturbation

text: Gaussian processes (GPs) provide a principled framework for spatio-temporal modeling but are hindered by prohibitive computational costs for large datasets. We propose a scalable and flexible variational inference (VI) framework for spatio-temporal GPs with non-stationary covariance kernels. The model's non-stationarity is achieved by defining the kernel parameters as a function of spatial and temporal covariates through a deep neural network. To ensure scalability, we employ a doubly stochastic variational inference approach, utilizing inducing points in both space and time. The key innovation is a structured inducing point parameterization based on a Kronecker product of spatial and temporal basis functions, which exploits the spatio-temporal structure to render the evidence lower bound (ELBO) and its gradients computationally tractable. This structure avoids the cubic complexity of standard VI for GPs. We demonstrate through extensive experiments on synthetic and large-scale climate science datasets that our method achieves state-of-the-art predictive performance while being orders of magnitude faster than competing methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Scalable Variational Inference for Spatio-Temporal Gaussian Processes with Non-Stationary Kernels

text: In longitudinal studies, subjects may experience recurrent non-fatal events in the presence of a terminal event, such as death, which censors the recurrent event process. Analyzing these correlated processes is challenging. We propose a flexible semiparametric joint model that connects a multiplicative frailty model for the recurrent event rate with a proportional hazards model for the terminal event. The dependence structure between the shared frailty and the survival time is explicitly modeled using a copula function, accommodating a wider range of association patterns than standard shared frailty models. We develop a penalized partial likelihood estimation procedure, where the baseline hazard functions are approximated by cubic B-splines. We establish the asymptotic properties of the proposed estimators, including consistency and asymptotic normality, using modern empirical process theory. The finite-sample performance is evaluated through simulation studies, which show minimal bias and good coverage rates. The model is applied to a clinical trial dataset to analyze hospital readmissions and mortality in heart failure patients.
subject: İstatistik
title: Semiparametric Joint Frailty-Copula Models for Recurrent and Terminal Events in Survival Analysis

text: We propose a dynamic extension of the stochastic block model (SBM) for analyzing the temporal evolution of community structures in longitudinal network data. Unlike existing dynamic SBMs that assume discrete community transitions, our model posits that each node possesses a continuous latent trajectory within a low-dimensional Euclidean space. The probability of an edge between two nodes at any given time point is a function of their positions in this latent space, thereby inducing a time-varying community structure. We introduce a variational expectation-maximization (VEM) algorithm for scalable inference, which simultaneously estimates the latent trajectories and the model parameters. The methodology naturally handles missing edges and node arrivals/departures. We prove the consistency of our estimators under a high-dimensional asymptotic regime where the number of nodes and time points grow. The model’s effectiveness in capturing smooth community evolution and identifying change points is demonstrated on synthetic networks and a real-world network of international relations.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Stochastic Block Models with Node-Specific Latent Trajectories for Longitudinal Networks

text: This paper introduces a novel framework for regression analysis where the response variable is a probability distribution, a common scenario in fields like computer vision and meteorology. We frame the problem of distributional regression using the theory of optimal transport (OT). The proposed method models the Wasserstein barycentric projection of the response distributions as a function of covariates. This approach provides a geometrically meaningful way to define a conditional mean in the space of probability measures. To overcome the computational burden of traditional OT, we employ an entropically regularized version of the Wasserstein distance, leading to a computationally efficient estimation procedure based on the Sinkhorn algorithm embedded within a gradient-based optimization scheme. We establish the statistical consistency of our estimator and demonstrate its robustness to noise and outliers compared to methods based on quantile regression or moment-based approaches. The utility is showcased by modeling the distribution of pixel intensities in medical images as a function of clinical predictors.
subject: İstatistik
title: Distributional Regression using Optimal Transport and Entropic Regularization

text: Variable selection using non-convex penalties like SCAD and MCP is known to possess superior theoretical properties compared to the LASSO. However, performing valid statistical inference (e.g., p-values, confidence intervals) on the selected model parameters remains a formidable challenge. This paper develops a rigorous framework for post-selection inference for models fitted with a general class of non-convex regularizers. We construct a debiased or desparsified estimator by projecting the initial penalized estimator onto a low-dimensional subspace defined by the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions of the optimization problem. We prove that this debiased estimator is asymptotically normal under standard regularity conditions, enabling the construction of valid confidence intervals and hypothesis tests for the regression coefficients. Our theory extends the polyhedral-based approaches for selective inference to the non-convex domain. We demonstrate via simulations that our method maintains nominal coverage probabilities and provides higher power than competing methods, offering a powerful tool for interpretable and reliable inference in high-dimensional sparse linear models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Post-Selection Inference for Sparse Regression with Non-Convex Penalties: A Desparsification Approach

text: We present a comprehensive theoretical analysis of decoherence pathways for non-abelian anyons, specifically Majorana zero modes, in a ν=5/2 fractional quantum Hall state during topological quantum computation. Our model, based on a microscopic Hamiltonian incorporating quasi-particle tunneling and coupling to bulk phononic modes, goes beyond simple phenomenological descriptions. By employing a Keldysh non-equilibrium Green's function formalism, we calculate the fidelity of braiding operations as a function of temperature, magnetic field inhomogeneity, and gate-voltage noise. The results reveal a non-trivial power-law dependence of the logical error rate on temperature, deviating from the expected exponential suppression and highlighting the critical role of non-local charge fluctuations. We demonstrate that dynamic gate tuning can mitigate these effects, suggesting a viable error-correction strategy that preserves the intrinsic topological protection. This work quantifies the primary environmental obstacles for realizing fault-tolerant quantum computation in FQHE systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence Dynamics of Braided Majorana Fermions in a ν=5/2 Fractional Quantum Hall System

text: We investigate the connection between entanglement structure in a two-dimensional conformal field theory (CFT₂) and the emergence of bulk spacetime geometry within the AdS₃/CFT₂ correspondence. Utilizing a tensor network approach based on the Multiscale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (MERA), we demonstrate how the radial dimension of the Anti-de Sitter (AdS) space is holographically encoded in the entanglement scale of the boundary theory. We explicitly construct bulk local operators deep within the AdS geometry from boundary CFT operators, showing that their commutation relations are preserved up to corrections exponentially suppressed in the bulk depth. Our construction reveals that the Ryu-Takayanagi formula for entanglement entropy is a direct consequence of the minimal cut-surface in the MERA tensor network. This work provides a concrete realization of the ER=EPR conjecture and substantiates the interpretation of gravitational dynamics as a manifestation of quantum information processing on the holographic boundary.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Renormalization and Bulk Reconstruction in AdS₃/CFT₂

text: We introduce a novel twin-field quantum key distribution (TF-QKD) protocol that overcomes fundamental rate-distance limitations and exhibits enhanced security against practical attacks. By employing phase-post-selection on single-photon-level coherent states sent from two independent sources to an untrusted central relay, our protocol's key rate scales with the square root of the channel transmittance (η¹/²), rather than η. This paper presents a rigorous security proof within the composable security framework, demonstrating robustness against both photon-number-splitting and Trojan-horse attacks. We further analyze the protocol's performance under realistic conditions, including finite-key effects and detector saturation. Our numerical simulations show that secure key exchange is achievable over 600 km of standard optical fiber without quantum repeaters, surpassing existing protocols. This advancement represents a critical step toward building a global, unconditionally secure quantum communication network.
subject: Kuantum
title: A Twin-Field Quantum Key Distribution Protocol Resilient to Side-Channel and Saturation Attacks

text: The search for quantum spin liquids (QSLs), exotic states of matter with long-range entanglement and fractionalized excitations, is a central challenge in condensed matter physics. Here, we present high-resolution resonant inelastic X-ray scattering (RIXS) measurements on α-RuCl₃, a leading candidate for realizing the Kitaev honeycomb model. By tuning the incident photon energy to the Ru L₃-edge, we selectively probe dynamic spin correlations. Our data reveal a broad, V-shaped continuum of magnetic excitations, a hallmark signature of itinerant Majorana fermions emerging from fractionalized spins. This continuum persists above the magnetic ordering temperature, indicating the presence of robust fractionalized excitations in the paramagnetic phase. By comparing our experimental spectra with theoretical calculations based on density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) methods, we extract key parameters of the underlying Kitaev-Heisenberg Hamiltonian and provide compelling evidence for the proximate Kitaev QSL state in this material.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Fractionalized Excitations in a Kitaev Spin Liquid Candidate via Resonant Inelastic X-ray Scattering

text: We investigate the phase diagram of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) at finite temperature and non-zero isospin chemical potential (μI) using first-principles lattice simulations with highly improved staggered quarks. Our calculations, performed on lattices with temporal extents Nτ = 8, 12, and 16, enable a reliable continuum extrapolation. We map the transition line in the T-μI plane, identifying a crossover from a hadronic phase to a pion-condensed phase and subsequently to a quark-gluon plasma. We precisely locate the pseudo-critical temperature for chiral symmetry restoration, observing its decrease with increasing μI, consistent with chiral perturbation theory predictions at low μI. Furthermore, we analyze the Polyakov loop and its susceptibility to probe the deconfinement transition, finding a strong correlation with the chiral crossover. Our results provide stringent constraints on effective field theory models and are relevant for the physics of neutron stars.
subject: Kuantum
title: Chiral Symmetry Restoration and Deconfinement in (2+1)-Flavor QCD at Finite Isospin Density

text: Graph states are a critical resource for measurement-based quantum computing. We propose and theoretically analyze a deterministic protocol for the sequential generation of arbitrarily large, one-dimensional graph states using a single quantum emitter (e.g., a quantum dot) strongly coupled to a photonic crystal cavity. The protocol leverages the Purcell-enhanced, spin-selective optical transitions of the emitter. A carefully designed sequence of resonant laser pulses deterministically adds single photons to the growing graph state, with entanglement mediated by the emitter's spin state. We perform a full quantum master equation simulation, including realistic noise sources such as cavity loss, spontaneous emission, and spin dephasing. The analysis demonstrates that high-fidelity (>98%) generation of graph states with over 20 photons is feasible with current technology. This scalable, on-demand source of entangled photons could pave the way for fault-tolerant photonic quantum information processing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Deterministic Generation of Multi-Photon Graph States using a Cavity-Coupled Quantum Emitter

text: We numerically investigate the dynamics of entanglement and transport in a one-dimensional Heisenberg spin-1/2 chain with a quasiperiodic potential, a system realizing a transition between thermalizing and many-body localized (MBL) phases. Using time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (t-DMRG) simulations for systems up to L=64 spins, we study the evolution of an initial product state. In the MBL phase, we observe the characteristic logarithmic growth of entanglement entropy and the freezing of local observables, confirming the breakdown of the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH). Critically, we identify a many-body mobility edge—an energy density threshold separating localized and thermal eigenstates within the same system. We demonstrate that the long-time dynamics depend crucially on the energy density of the initial state, showing ergodic behavior above the edge and localized behavior below. Our findings provide strong evidence for the existence of a mobility edge in quasiperiodic systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Spreading and Many-Body Mobility Edge in a Quasiperiodic Spin Chain

text: We present a quantum metrology protocol that experimentally demonstrates phase estimation precision surpassing the Heisenberg limit (1/N). Our scheme employs an adaptive Bayesian algorithm controlling a Mach-Zehnder interferometer probed by non-Gaussian states, specifically photon-subtracted squeezed vacuum states. The adaptive strategy iteratively updates the phase estimate and modifies the interferometer's reference phase to maximize the Fisher information gained in each measurement. This feedback loop allows the protocol to dynamically allocate resources to the most sensitive phase regions. For N ≈ 4 average photons, we achieve a phase uncertainty scaling as N⁻¹·⁵, significantly outperforming the N⁻¹ Heisenberg limit for coherent or squeezed states. This result challenges conventional quantum limits by exploiting the non-linear relationship between photon number and quantum Fisher information in highly non-classical states, opening new avenues for ultra-sensitive measurement technologies.
subject: Kuantum
title: Adaptive Bayesian Phase Estimation Surpassing the Heisenberg Limit with Non-Gaussian States

text: We analyze the phenomenon of entanglement harvesting, where two initially uncorrelated particle detectors can extract entanglement from the quantum vacuum, focusing on the fermionic Dirac field in (1+1)-dimensional curved spacetime. Using a non-perturbative Unruh-DeWitt detector model, we calculate the harvested concurrence for two comoving detectors in a spacetime featuring a collapsing dust shell that forms a black hole. Our results show that, unlike the scalar field case, entanglement harvesting from the Dirac field is highly sensitive to the spin degrees of freedom and the local spacetime curvature. We find a non-monotonic dependence of harvested entanglement on the detectors' separation and proximity to the forming event horizon. Notably, the fermionic nature of the field fundamentally alters the conditions under which entanglement can be extracted, providing a new probe into the vacuum structure of quantum fields in gravitational backgrounds.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Harvesting from the Dirac Field in Curved Spacetime

text: We report the experimental realization of a single-atom quantum heat engine based on a laser-cooled ¹⁷¹Yb⁺ ion in a linear Paul trap. The thermodynamic cycle, analogous to the classical Otto cycle, consists of two quantum isochoric and two quantum adiabatic strokes, implemented through coherent laser-ion interactions and controlled coupling to engineered thermal reservoirs. We operate the engine far from the quasistatic limit, investigating the trade-off between power output and efficiency. By directly measuring the work statistics and heat exchange on a single-shot basis, we characterize the engine's performance and verify fluctuation theorems in the quantum regime. We demonstrate a maximum power output of 2.1 x 10⁻²² W with an efficiency of 28%, limited by non-adiabatic transitions during the compression and expansion strokes. This work provides a versatile platform for exploring the foundations of quantum thermodynamics and designing nanoscale thermal machines.
subject: Kuantum
title: A Single-Atom Quantum Otto Engine Operating Beyond the Quasistatic Limit

text: This paper introduces a novel framework, Proximal Debiased Machine Learning (PDML), for estimating causal effects in high-dimensional settings where unobserved confounding violates classical identifiability assumptions. We extend the double/debiased machine learning (DML) paradigm by integrating it with proximal causal inference, which leverages proxy variables for the treatment and outcome to control for unobserved confounders. The proposed method employs Neyman-orthogonal moment functions to mitigate the regularization bias induced by machine learning-based estimation of nuisance parameters, such as conditional expectations of proxies. We establish the asymptotic normality and semi-parametric efficiency of the PDML estimator under specific sparsity and identifying assumptions related to the proxy-confounder relationship. Our framework accommodates a wide range of machine learning estimators for the nuisance components, providing a doubly robust approach to causal estimation. Monte Carlo simulations and an empirical application to a large-scale genomic dataset demonstrate the method's superior performance in terms of bias reduction and confidence interval coverage compared to existing instrumental variable and DML techniques.
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Machine Learning for High-Dimensional Causal Inference with Unobserved Confounding

text: Statistical inference on outputs from Topological Data Analysis (TDA), such as persistence diagrams, is complicated by the non-Euclidean geometry of their native metric spaces. This work proposes a novel kernel-based framework for the statistical analysis of persistence diagrams by embedding them into a reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS). We construct a positive definite kernel derived from the Wasserstein-barycenter representation of diagrams, effectively linearizing the space of persistence diagrams and enabling the application of classical multivariate statistical techniques. This Wasserstein-Barycentric Kernel (WBK) captures the similarity of topological features with greater fidelity than existing persistence-based kernels. We demonstrate how this framework facilitates robust two-sample hypothesis testing via permutation tests on kernel-induced distances, as well as supervised learning tasks like regression and classification. The efficacy of the WBK method is validated on synthetic data from dynamical systems and real-world data from protein structure classification, where it exhibits superior discriminatory power and interpretability over existing TDA statistical methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Wasserstein-Barycentric Kernel Methods for Statistical Inference on Persistent Homology

text: Conventional topic models often assume static topic structures and document independence, failing to capture the self-exciting temporal dynamics inherent in relational event data such as citation networks or social media interactions. We introduce the Hierarchical Dirichlet-Hawkes Process (HDHP), a Bayesian nonparametric model that jointly discovers latent topic structures and models their temporal co-dependencies. The HDHP integrates a Hierarchical Dirichlet Process for inferring a shared set of topics with a multivariate Hawkes process to model the intensity of topic occurrences as a self-exciting point process. The arrival of an event associated with a specific topic endogenously increases the probability of future events of related topics, thus capturing influence and temporal clustering. We derive an efficient collapsed Gibbs sampler for posterior inference. Applied to corpora of academic citations and social media communications, the HDHP provides more coherent topic evolution narratives and demonstrates superior predictive likelihood compared to static and discrete-time dynamic topic models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Hierarchical Dirichlet-Hawkes Processes for Dynamic Topic Modeling in Relational Event Networks

text: Functional Principal Component Analysis (FPCA) is a cornerstone of Functional Data Analysis (FDA), but its classical formulation presupposes densely sampled data, a condition rarely met in longitudinal studies characterized by sparse and irregular subject-specific observation schedules. This paper develops a novel methodology, Sparse Penalized FPCA (SP-FPCA), which robustly estimates functional principal components under such challenging data structures. Our approach employs a penalized spline smoothing framework to reconstruct individual trajectories and formulates the estimation of the population-level covariance structure within an iterative expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm. The core innovation lies in the conditional expectation step, which optimally pools information across subjects to estimate the underlying smooth functions. We establish theoretical guarantees, including the consistency and convergence rates for the estimated eigenfunctions and scores under mild regularity conditions. Extensive simulations and an application to longitudinal clinical trial data demonstrate the method's superior accuracy in trajectory reconstruction and dimension reduction compared to principal components analysis through conditional expectation (PACE) and imputation-based alternatives.
subject: İstatistik
title: Sparse Functional Principal Component Analysis for Longitudinally Observed Data with Irregular Sampling

text: Modeling high-dimensional spatiotemporal panels requires capturing both low-dimensional latent dynamics and complex cross-sectional dependence. Standard dynamic factor models (DFMs) often impose overly simplistic assumptions on the idiosyncratic error covariance structure. We propose the Graph-Regularized Dynamic Factor Model (GR-DFM), which enhances the classical DFM by incorporating prior network information. The model specifies a sparse precision matrix for the idiosyncratic components, estimated via a graphical LASSO penalty that reflects a known or estimated underlying network structure (e.g., geographic or economic proximity). Estimation proceeds via a novel block-coordinate descent algorithm that alternates between Kalman filtering/smoothing for extracting latent factors and a penalized likelihood optimization for the graph-structured covariance. This approach yields more efficient factor estimates and more interpretable loadings. We derive the asymptotic properties of the estimator under increasing cross-sectional and temporal dimensions. An application to a large panel of regional US economic indicators demonstrates superior forecasting performance and provides insights into the propagation of shocks through the network.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Factor Models with Graph-Regularized Covariance Estimation for High-Dimensional Spatiotemporal Data

text: Variational Inference (VI) is a principal method for scalable Bayesian computation, yet its performance is often limited by simplistic approximating distributions and high computational costs. Geometric VI improves accuracy by exploiting the Riemannian geometry of the variational family but exacerbates the computational burden. We introduce Amortized Geometric Variational Inference (AGVI), a framework that marries the accuracy of geometric VI with the efficiency of amortized inference. AGVI trains a deep neural network (an inference network) to map observations directly to the parameters of the variational posterior on a Riemannian manifold. Optimization of the evidence lower bound (ELBO) is performed using natural gradient updates, which are efficiently approximated via properties of the inference network without requiring explicit inversion of the Fisher information matrix. This procedure learns an inference map that generalizes to new data, making posterior approximation nearly instantaneous at test time. We demonstrate AGVI's superior performance on complex hierarchical models and deep generative models, where it achieves posterior approximations that are substantially more accurate than standard amortized VI and orders of magnitude faster than non-amortized geometric methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Amortized Geometric Variational Inference for High-Dimensional Bayesian Models

text: Analyzing time-to-event data in the presence of competing risks is a fundamental challenge in biostatistics, particularly with complex, time-varying covariates. Classical methods, such as cause-specific Cox models or the Fine-Gray model, are limited by proportional hazards assumptions and their inability to capture non-linear relationships. We propose the Deep Kernel Competing Risks (DKCR) model, a flexible, non-parametric framework that leverages the strengths of deep learning and kernel methods. The DKCR model uses a recurrent neural network to learn a rich, time-dependent feature representation from the covariate history. This learned representation is then input to a kernel-based regression model to non-parametrically estimate the cause-specific hazard functions, thereby avoiding restrictive modeling assumptions. A novel loss function based on the composite partial likelihood for competing risks enables end-to-end training. On synthetic and real-world clinical datasets, DKCR demonstrates superior predictive accuracy for cumulative incidence functions and improved model calibration compared to traditional and existing machine learning survival models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Deep Kernel Survival Models for Competing Risks Analysis with Time-Varying Covariates

text: The Minimum Covariance Determinant (MCD) estimator is a highly robust method for parameter estimation and outlier detection in multivariate data. However, its direct application to matrix-variate data via vectorization is suboptimal, as it ignores the inherent row and column covariance structure and is vulnerable to cell-wise, rather than case-wise, contamination. This paper introduces the Matrix-MCD (M-MCD) estimator, which extends the MCD principle to matrix-variate distributions. The M-MCD objective is to find the data subset of a given size that minimizes the determinant of a structured covariance matrix, assumed to be the Kronecker product of two scatter matrices corresponding to row and column dependencies. We develop a bespoke concentration-step (C-step) algorithm for this non-convex problem and prove its convergence. The resulting estimators are shown to be affine equivariant. We derive the asymptotic breakdown point and influence function, demonstrating high robustness. Simulations confirm that M-MCD significantly outperforms vectorized MCD and other robust estimators under various contamination scenarios.
subject: İstatistik
title: Minimum Covariance Determinant Estimation for Matrix-Variate Data with Cell-wise Contamination

text: Generalized partially linear single-index models (GPLSIM) provide a powerful framework for balancing model flexibility and interpretability. However, simultaneous estimation and variable selection within the parametric, non-parametric, and single-index components present significant statistical and computational challenges, particularly when the number of covariates is large. We propose a unified estimation procedure that integrates P-splines for the non-parametric function, a profile likelihood approach for the single-index vector, and an adaptive LASSO penalty for simultaneous variable selection in both the linear and index parts. The methodology is implemented through an efficient iterative algorithm that alternates between penalized generalized estimating equations for the non-parametric component and a penalized profile likelihood optimization for the parametric components. Under mild regularity conditions, we prove that the resulting estimators possess the oracle property, performing as well asymptotically as if the true sparse model structure were known beforehand. The method’s practical utility is illustrated through an analysis of a biomedical dataset, where it identifies key biomarkers and non-linear exposure-response relationships.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Penalized Spline Regression for Generalized Partially Linear Single-Index Models

text: Estimating causal treatment effects from observational data on networks is profoundly challenged by interference (treatment spillovers) and network-induced confounding (homophily), which violate the Stable Unit Treatment Value Assumption (SUTVA). Traditional propensity score methods are ill-equipped to adjust for the high-dimensional, relational nature of network confounding. We propose Network-Embedded Propensity Score Stratification (NEPS), a novel two-stage approach. First, we employ unsupervised graph representation learning techniques, such as node2vec or Graph Neural Networks, to generate low-dimensional vector embeddings for each unit that capture complex topological features, including local neighborhood structure and global network position. Second, these embeddings are used as covariates in a propensity score model to estimate the probability of treatment assignment conditional on network structure. Stratification on the resulting network-aware propensity scores creates balanced sub-populations where network confounding is mitigated. We demonstrate how direct and indirect (spillover) effects can then be estimated within these strata. Application to a large-scale social network dataset validates NEPS's ability to produce less biased estimates of peer effects compared to methods that ignore or use simplistic summaries of the network structure.
subject: İstatistik
title: Propensity Score Stratification on Network Embeddings for Causal Inference in Observational Network Data

text: This paper presents a novel methodology for hierarchical key and chord estimation directly from raw audio waveforms, circumventing traditional feature engineering steps like chromagram extraction. We propose a deep convolutional autoencoder architecture trained on a large corpus of polyphonic music. The encoder network learns a compressed latent space representation that effectively disentangles tonal features from timbral and dynamic variations. By analyzing the geometric structure of this latent space, we demonstrate its isomorphism to music-theoretic tonal spaces, such as the circle of fifths and toroidal models of key relationships. A subsequent recurrent neural network (RNN) with an attention mechanism operates on time-series trajectories within this latent space to decode a multi-level hierarchy of local chords, intermediate key regions, and the global tonic. Our results show a significant improvement in accuracy for both instantaneous and structural tonality detection over state-of-the-art systems, particularly in harmonically complex and ambiguous musical passages.
subject: Müzik
title: A Deep Convolutional Autoencoder for Hierarchical Tonality Estimation from Raw Audio Waveforms

text: The computational analysis of non-Western microtonal music presents significant challenges for conventional audio analysis frameworks predicated on twelve-tone equal temperament. This study introduces a specialized sparse Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) model for the unsupervised decomposition of musical audio from the Arabic Maqam tradition. By applying biologically-inspired sparsity constraints on the encoding matrix, our algorithm learns a dictionary of spectral templates corresponding to the unique pitch sets and characteristic intervals (jins) of different maqamat. The corresponding activation matrix reveals the temporal evolution of these microtonal structures. We evaluate our method on a new dataset of Taqasim recordings, demonstrating its ability to accurately identify the operative maqam and segment the improvisation into constituent jins. This component-based analysis provides a robust quantitative foundation for musicological inquiry into melodic development and modal grammar in microtonal performance, offering a powerful alternative to pitch-centric quantization methods that fail to capture aperiodic spectral content.
subject: Müzik
title: Decomposing Microtonal Spectra: A Sparse Non-Negative Matrix Factorization Approach to Maqam Analysis

text: We investigate the complex voice-leading structures of late-Romantic music through the lens of Topological Data Analysis (TDA). Traditional geometric models of voice leading often fail to capture the high-dimensional and non-Euclidean nature of chromatic harmony. This paper models musical passages as point clouds in a multi-dimensional pitch-class space, where each point represents a simultaneity. We then apply persistent homology to this point cloud to compute its topological features, such as connected components (Betti-0) and tunnels (Betti-1), across multiple scales. These features serve as quantitative descriptors of harmonic coherence and cyclical motion. Analyzing excerpts from Wagner, Strauss, and Mahler, we demonstrate that the persistence diagrams reveal distinct topological signatures corresponding to functional versus non-functional chromaticism. Specifically, the proliferation of long-lived 1-cycles (tunnels) provides a robust biomarker for the kind of parsimonious, cyclical voice leading that characterizes the dissolution of common-practice tonality, offering a novel empirical tool for music theory.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Data Analysis of Voice-Leading Spaces in Late-Romantic Chromaticism

text: This research bridges the gap between Schenkerian analysis and algorithmic composition by formalizing Heinrich Schenker's theory of tonal structure as a Probabilistic Context-Free Grammar (PCFG). We define a grammar where non-terminal symbols represent abstract structural levels (Ursatz, middleground prolongations) and terminal symbols correspond to foreground musical events. The production rules and their associated probabilities are learned from a manually annotated corpus of Schenkerian graphs. The system operates generatively: starting from the axiomatic Ursatz, it recursively applies production rules to derive a complete, structurally coherent tonal composition. We evaluate the generated outputs using a combination of computational metrics (e.g., tonal tension models, voice-leading parsimony) and formal listening tests. The results indicate that the compositions produced by our Schenkerian PCFG are perceived as significantly more coherent and goal-directed than those generated by n-gram or simple Markov models, demonstrating the efficacy of hierarchical generative models for tonal music.
subject: Müzik
title: Generative Schenkerian Parsing: A Probabilistic Context-Free Grammar for Algorithmic Tonal Composition

text: Orchestrational practice involves the sophisticated manipulation of timbre, yet its computational modeling remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a data-driven approach to uncovering the perceptual and structural logic of orchestration using manifold learning. We represent a large dataset of orchestral instrument samples as points in a high-dimensional space of spectral features (e.g., MFCCs, spectral flux, roughness). We then apply the diffusion map algorithm, a non-linear dimensionality reduction technique, to embed these points into a low-dimensional manifold that preserves the diffusion distances between timbres. The geometric arrangement of instruments within this learned 'timbre space' reveals perceptually salient relationships and blending possibilities. Furthermore, by analyzing the trajectories of musical works through this space, we can quantitatively model orchestrational strategies, such as timbral contrast and gradual transformation.
