This methodology provides a powerful visualization and analytical tool for computational musicology, moving beyond discrete instrument labels to a continuous, perceptually-grounded representation of the orchestral palette.
subject: Müzik
title: Manifold Learning for Timbral Semantics: Unveiling Orchestrational Logic via Diffusion Maps on Spectral Descriptors

text: This study explores the intricate coupling between musical structure and a performer's physical gestures. We present a cross-modal analytical framework that combines audio analysis with kinematic data captured from instrumentalists using high-resolution motion capture. Structural event boundaries in the audio signal (e.g., phrase endings, sectional changes) are first identified using a hierarchical segmentation algorithm based on self-similarity matrices. Simultaneously, the performer's kinematic data is represented as a high-dimensional time series. We then employ Cross-Recurrence Quantification Analysis (CRQA) to investigate the non-linear correlations and temporal dependencies between the audio-derived structural features and the kinematic data streams. Our findings reveal statistically significant increases in deterministic patterning (DET) and laminarity (LAM) in the performer's movements preceding formal musical boundaries. This suggests a form of anticipatory motor planning that is tightly coupled with the unfolding musical architecture, providing empirical evidence for the deep embodiment of musical form in expert performance.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Correlation of Musical Structure and Performer Kinematics using Recurrence Quantification Analysis

text: We address the problem of discovering the hierarchical structure of musical form from an audio signal without prior knowledge of the number of structural levels or segments. This paper introduces a novel unsupervised learning model based on the Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Hidden Markov Model (HDP-HMM). The model treats musical form as a nested sequence of states, where states at a higher level group sequences of states at a lower level. By operating on a sequence of audio features, such as mel-frequency cepstral coefficients or chroma vectors, the HDP-HMM autonomously infers the multi-layered structure through Bayesian inference. The nonparametric nature of the Dirichlet process allows the model to learn the appropriate complexity (i.e., the number of distinct segments at each hierarchical layer) directly from the data. We demonstrate the model’s efficacy on a corpus of classical and popular music, showing its ability to recover musically meaningful structures corresponding to phrases, themes, sections, and movements.
subject: Müzik
title: A Bayesian Nonparametric Approach to Unsupervised Discovery of Hierarchical Musical Form

text: Classical psychoacoustic models of dissonance, based on harmonic beating and critical bandwidths, fail to account for several perceptual phenomena. This paper presents a novel computational model of sensory dissonance grounded in neural synchrony. We utilize a detailed biophysical model of the auditory periphery to simulate the stochastic firing patterns of a population of auditory nerve fibers in response to complex musical intervals. Our central hypothesis is that dissonance is a direct correlate of the temporal asynchrony and irregularity of neural spike trains across the tonotopically organized nerve population. We propose a new metric, Neural Asynchrony Index (NAI), calculated from the variance of inter-spike intervals across frequency channels. Simulating responses to intervals from just intonation, equal temperament, and various microtonal systems, our model's NAI predictions show a stronger correlation with empirical listener ratings of dissonance than traditional models. This neuro-dynamic approach provides a more robust, physiologically plausible foundation for understanding the perception of harmonicity.
subject: Müzik
title: A Neuro-Dynamic Model of Consonance and Dissonance Based on Inter-Spike Interval Asynchrony in Auditory Nerve Simulations

text: This paper introduces a quantitative framework for tracing the evolution of harmonic language using tools from information theory. We analyze a large-scale diachronic corpus of digitized scores spanning the Common Practice Period (c. 1650-1900). Each composition is parsed into a sequence of chord symbols, which are then modeled as a higher-order Markov chain. We compute key information-theoretic metrics for each composer's oeuvre, including the Shannon entropy of the chord distribution (harmonic variety) and the mutual information between adjacent chords (harmonic predictability). By tracking these metrics over historical time, we can objectively measure stylistic trends, such as the gradual increase in harmonic complexity and the decrease in syntactical constraint. Furthermore, we use the concept of Kullback-Leibler divergence to quantify the stylistic 'distance' between composers and to identify specific harmonic innovations that deviate from the established norms of a given period, providing an empirical basis for claims of musical influence and originality.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Harmonic Innovation: An Information-Theoretic Approach to Diachronic Stylistic Analysis of the Common Practice Period

text: The separation of individual melodic lines in complex polyphonic and contrapuntal music is a formidable challenge for source separation algorithms. This paper reframes the problem within the domain of Graph Signal Processing (GSP). We model the magnitude spectrogram of a musical piece as a weighted undirected graph, where each time-frequency (TF) bin is a node. Edge weights between nodes are defined by a learned affinity metric incorporating principles of auditory scene analysis, such as harmonicity, pitch continuity (common fate), and timbral similarity. The task of segregating musical streams is then formulated as a spectral clustering problem on this TF-adjacency graph. By computing the eigenvectors of the graph Laplacian (the graph's 'Fourier basis'), we can embed the TF bins into a space where individual melodic lines are linearly separable. This approach demonstrably outperforms conventional methods like NMF and deep learning-based architectures on challenging fugal and choral repertoires, preserving melodic integrity with fewer artifacts.
subject: Müzik
title: Contrapuntal Stream Segregation via Graph Signal Processing on a Time-Frequency Adjacency Graph

text: The realization of fault-tolerant topological quantum computation hinges upon the coherent manipulation of non-Abelian anyons, such as Majorana zero modes (MZMs). We propose and theoretically analyze a protocol for high-fidelity braiding of MZMs in a two-dimensional semiconductor-superconductor heterostructure. By applying periodic microwave driving fields, we dynamically induce a transient p+ip superconducting phase, creating and manipulating a sparse array of MZMs without requiring fine-tuned gate voltages or complex T-junction geometries. Our Floquet engineering approach effectively opens a robust topological gap, suppressing quasi-particle poisoning and enhancing coherence. We calculate the non-Abelian Berry phase acquired during a braiding cycle using the Floquet-Magnus expansion and demonstrate that the resulting unitary transformation corresponds to a topologically protected Clifford gate. Numerical simulations incorporating realistic disorder and dissipation models predict gate fidelities exceeding 99.8%, paving the way for robust topological information processing based on Floquet-Majorana qubits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence-Resilient Braiding of Majorana Zero Modes via Floquet-Engineered Topological Superconductivity

text: The AdS/CFT correspondence suggests a profound connection between quantum entanglement and spacetime geometry. We investigate this duality by constructing a novel class of tensor network states, termed Hyperbolic Multiscale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (hMERA), that discretizes the spatial slice of an Anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime. By interpreting the network's logical indices as a boundary conformal field theory (CFT), we demonstrate that the geometric entanglement entropy, calculated via the min-cut max-flow theorem on the tensor network graph, precisely reproduces the Ryu-Takanagi formula. Furthermore, we show that our hMERA construction inherently embeds a quantum error-correcting code, where bulk logical operators are protected from boundary erasures. This provides a concrete toy model for the emergence of a local bulk effective field theory from the non-local entanglement structure of the boundary CFT, solidifying the link between quantum information and gravitational dynamics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Spacetime Emergence from a Tensor Network Model of Quantum Gravity

text: Non-Hermitian systems, characterized by complex energy spectra, exhibit unique topological features such as exceptional points (EPs) where eigenvalues and eigenvectors coalesce. While second-order EPs (EP2s) have been explored for enhanced sensing, higher-order EPs promise even greater sensitivity scaling. Here, we report the experimental observation of a third-order exceptional point (EP3) in a coupled-resonator photonic crystal slab. By engineering spatially tailored gain and loss profiles via optical pumping, we tune the system’s non-Hermitian Hamiltonian to the EP3 degeneracy. Transmission spectroscopy reveals a characteristic E^(1/3) frequency splitting in response to external perturbations, confirming the EP3's topological nature. We leverage this enhanced response to demonstrate a nanoparticle sensor with a sensitivity enhancement proportional to the cube root of the perturbation strength, significantly outperforming devices based on Hermitian degeneracies and EP2s. This work opens avenues for ultra-sensitive optical sensing and novel topological photonics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Observation of a Higher-Order Exceptional Point in a Non-Hermitian Photonic Crystal

text: Higher-order topological insulators (HOTIs) host protected boundary states at dimensions lower than their boundaries, such as corner or hinge modes. We theoretically propose a scheme to dynamically generate a second-order topological insulating phase in a periodically driven three-dimensional system, initially a trivial insulator. Using Floquet theory, we derive an effective time-independent Hamiltonian that exhibits a bulk quadrupolar moment, the hallmark of a second-order topological phase. Our Floquet engineering protocol breaks time-reversal symmetry, resulting in chiral hinge modes that propagate unidirectionally along the system's vertical edges. We characterize the topological phase diagram as a function of driving frequency and amplitude, identifying robust regions supporting these anomalous one-dimensional edge states. The predicted chiral hinge modes can be detected via momentum-resolved spectroscopy, offering a flexible platform for controlling multidimensional topological transport in synthetic quantum matter.
subject: Kuantum
title: Dynamical Generation of Chiral Hinge Modes in a Floquet-Engineered Second-Order Topological Insulator

text: We investigate the thermodynamic role of quantum coherence as a resource in a minimal quantum heat engine. Our experimental implementation utilizes a transmon qubit coupled to two distinct thermal microwave reservoirs, whose effective temperatures are controlled via noise injection. The engine cycle consists of four strokes: two isochoric processes where the qubit interacts with the reservoirs, and two 'iso-coherent' strokes where the qubit's energy gap is modulated while preserving coherence in a specific basis. We demonstrate that the presence of coherence during the iso-coherent strokes allows for positive work extraction, even when the qubit population remains in a thermal Gibbs state with respect to the instantaneous Hamiltonian. The measured work output and efficiency are in excellent agreement with a quantum thermodynamic model based on a collision-based master equation. Our results experimentally verify that coherence is a genuine thermodynamic resource, distinct from heat, for powering quantum machines.
subject: Kuantum
title: Work Extraction from Quantum Coherence in a Non-Equilibrium Superconducting Qubit Engine

text: Many-body localization (MBL) describes the breakdown of thermalization in isolated, disordered quantum systems, characterized by the persistence of local memory and slow, logarithmic growth of entanglement entropy. We report on the experimental observation of MBL dynamics in a one-dimensional chain of interacting nitrogen-vacancy centers in diamond, which realize a disordered Heisenberg model with long-range dipolar interactions. Using quantum state tomography on subsystems of varying sizes, we directly measure the time evolution of the second Rényi entropy following a global quench. Our results reveal a clear logarithmic growth of entanglement, a hallmark of MBL, which persists for timescales exceeding the local decoherence time by two orders of magnitude. Furthermore, we find evidence for Hilbert space fragmentation, where the system dynamics are confined to disconnected subspaces, signaled by suppressed scrambling of certain initial product states. These findings provide insight into the fundamental mechanisms of ergodicity breaking in quantum systems with long-range interactions.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Spreading and Hilbert Space Fragmentation in a Disordered Dipolar Spin Chain

text: Quantum metrology promises enhanced measurement precision by leveraging non-classical resources. While single-parameter estimation has been extensively studied, many applications require the simultaneous measurement of multiple parameters. Here, we propose and analyze a scheme for multi-parameter quantum thermometry capable of simultaneously estimating the temperature and spectral width of a thermal reservoir with Heisenberg-limited precision. Our protocol utilizes path-entangled N00N states in a Mach-Zehnder interferometer, where one arm is coupled to the thermal environment. We compute the quantum Fisher information matrix for this open quantum system and show that its determinant scales as N^4, indicating a 1/N^2 advantage in the joint estimation uncertainty over classical strategies. We identify an optimal measurement basis that nearly saturates the quantum Cramér-Rao bound. This approach enables ultra-precise, non-invasive characterization of thermal environments, crucial for quantum computing and condensed matter physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Multi-Parameter Quantum Thermometry with Entangled N00N States

text: When the light-matter coupling rate (g) becomes comparable to or exceeds the resonator frequency (ω), cavity quantum electrodynamics (QED) enters the deep-strong coupling (DSC) regime, where the rotating-wave approximation fails completely. In this regime, the system's ground state, or 'dressed vacuum,' is a highly entangled state containing a cloud of virtual photons. We report on the spectroscopic probing of this exotic ground state in a circuit QED architecture comprising three flux qubits galvanically coupled to a superconducting resonator, achieving a normalized coupling ratio g/ω ≈ 1.3. By applying a two-tone spectroscopy technique, we observe parity-forbidden transitions originating directly from the dressed vacuum to the first excited state manifold. The measured transition frequencies and their vacuum Rabi splittings show excellent agreement with theoretical predictions from a full quantum Rabi Hamiltonian model, providing unambiguous evidence of the virtual-photon-populated, entangled nature of the ground state in a multi-emitter DSC system.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing the Dressed Vacuum of a Multi-Qubit System in the Deep-Strong Coupling Regime of Cavity QED

text: Chiral quantum optics, where the direction of light propagation is locked to its polarization or pseudo-spin, offers a powerful platform for building non-reciprocal quantum devices. We demonstrate deterministic, non-reciprocal single-photon routing using quantum emitters coupled to a photonic crystal waveguide. The waveguide is engineered to possess a linear dispersion with a transverse spin-momentum lock, meaning left- and right-propagating modes carry opposite circular polarizations. By selectively exciting a coherently-driven quantum dot with circularly polarized light, we achieve directional emission into the waveguide with a measured contrast ratio exceeding 95:5. This directionality is switchable on nanosecond timescales via the optical drive polarization. Conversely, an incoming single photon's absorption by the emitter is strongly dependent on its propagation direction. This work establishes a scalable building block for integrated quantum networks, enabling the creation of single-photon isolators, circulators, and deterministic spin-photon interfaces without magnetic fields.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Reciprocal Single-Photon Transport Mediated by Spin-Momentum Locked Emitters in a Photonic Crystal Waveguide

text: Lattice gauge theories are fundamental to our understanding of high-energy physics, but their simulation is notoriously difficult for classical computers, particularly for non-Abelian groups like SU(3) of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). We propose a digital quantum simulation of SU(3) lattice gauge theory using a chain of trapped ions. We develop a resource-efficient encoding of the SU(3) degrees of freedom onto the qudit states of the ions and construct a sequence of laser-induced gates to implement the Trotterized time-evolution of the Kogut-Susskind Hamiltonian. Our protocol allows for the study of fundamental QCD phenomena. We present numerical simulations demonstrating the feasibility of observing quark-antiquark string formation and its subsequent breaking via particle-antiparticle pair creation. This requires controlling the evolution of the Wilson loop operator, which we show is experimentally accessible. This work provides a concrete blueprint for exploring the real-time dynamics of non-Abelian gauge theories on near-term quantum processors.
subject: Kuantum
title: Digital Quantum Simulation of SU(3) Lattice Gauge Theory and String Breaking with Trapped Ions

text: Convergent evolution provides a powerful framework for understanding the predictability of adaptation. Here, we investigate the molecular underpinnings of convergent craniofacial morphologies in multiple lineages of cichlid fishes adapted to similar durophagous niches. Through comparative phylogenomics and ATAC-seq analysis, we identified thousands of cis-regulatory elements (CREs) exhibiting accelerated evolution specifically within the convergent lineages. A significant subset of these parallel-evolving CREs are located near key developmental genes, including bmp4 and sp7, and display concordant signatures of positive selection. Functional validation using CRISPR-dCas9 epigenome editing in a model species demonstrates that sequence variation within these convergent CREs directly modulates gene expression, altering pharyngeal jaw morphology. Our findings reveal that convergent phenotypic evolution is predominantly driven by parallel, independent mutations within a constrained set of non-coding regulatory loci, highlighting the deterministic role of pre-existing gene regulatory network architecture in shaping adaptive trajectories.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Convergent Trophic Specialization Driven by Parallel Shifts in Cis-Regulatory Architecture

text: The Red Queen hypothesis posits that antagonistic coevolution drives continuous reciprocal adaptation. We tracked the real-time evolutionary dynamics of Escherichia coli and its lytic bacteriophage λ over 2,000 generations in a controlled chemostat environment. Whole-genome, time-series sequencing revealed recurrent selective sweeps targeting phage receptor-binding proteins and bacterial outer membrane proteins, consistent with an evolutionary arms race. Critically, we observed a pattern of 'genomic escalation,' where both partners evolved increasingly complex defense and counter-defense mechanisms, including the horizontal acquisition and modification of CRISPR-Cas systems in the host and the evolution of anti-CRISPR proteins in the phage. The emergent dynamics demonstrate that coevolutionary trajectories are not simple cycles of allele substitution but involve the progressive layering of novel genetic innovations, leading to a net increase in genomic complexity and a constantly shifting, high-dimensional fitness landscape.
subject: Evrim
title: Antagonistic Coevolution and Genomic Escalation in a Bacteriophage-Host System Revealed by Long-Term Experimental Evolution

text: Non-genetic inheritance mechanisms may facilitate rapid adaptation to novel environmental pressures. We investigated the role of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance in Arabidopsis thaliana's response to osmotic stress. Parental exposure induced the production of specific 24-nucleotide small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) that guide de novo DNA methylation in the CG, CHG, and CHH contexts at hundreds of stress-responsive loci, including key transcription factors and metabolic genes. These epialleles, and the associated stress-tolerant phenotype, were heritably transmitted for at least three generations in the absence of the initial stressor, mediated by a self-reinforcing RNA-directed DNA Methylation (RdDM) loop. Progeny of stressed plants exhibited significantly higher survival rates under subsequent osmotic challenge. Our results provide direct evidence that environmentally induced epigenetic modifications can function as a heritable substrate for selection, potentially buffering populations against rapid environmental change before genetic adaptation can occur.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance Mediated by Small RNA-Directed DNA Methylation Confers Rapid Adaptation to Abiotic Stress

text: Understanding morphological innovation requires elucidating the evolution of developmental gene regulatory networks (GRNs). We generated stage-specific transcriptomes across the development of 25 arthropod species, spanning chelicerates, myriapods, crustaceans, and hexapods. By integrating these data into a phylogenetic framework, we computationally reconstructed the ancestral GRN for appendage patterning. Our analysis confirms the deep homology of a core set of transcription factors, including Distal-less (Dll) and dachshund (dac), which retain conserved upstream regulation. However, the downstream target genes of this conserved kernel have diverged extensively among lineages, a phenomenon known as developmental systems drift. This network rewiring correlates directly with major morphological transitions, such as the evolution of uniramous versus biramous limbs and the specialization of mouthparts. These findings demonstrate that morphological diversification is driven less by the evolution of new patterning genes and more by changes in the connectivity of ancient, conserved regulatory modules.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylo-transcriptomic Reconstruction of Arthropod Appendage Gene Regulatory Networks Reveals Deep Homology and Developmental Systems Drift

text: Gene flow between distinct species, or introgression, can be a potent source of adaptive variation. We analyzed high-coverage whole-genome sequences from high-altitude Himalayan populations and discovered a divergent haplotype spanning the Endothelial PAS domain-protein 1 (EPAS1) gene, a key regulator of hypoxia response. Phylogenetic analysis confirms this haplotype introgressed from Denisovans, an archaic hominin sister group to Neanderthals, into modern humans approximately 40,000 years ago. The introgressed allele is found at nearly 90% frequency in Tibetan populations but is virtually absent from adjacent low-altitude populations, and it exhibits an extended block of linkage disequilibrium, a classic signature of a recent, strong positive selective sweep. This represents a clear case where a pre-adapted allele from an extinct, high-altitude-adapted population enabled rapid, profound physiological adaptation in colonizing modern humans, underscoring the creative role of admixture in evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Evidence of Adaptive Introgression from an Archaic Hominin Lineage Facilitating High-Altitude Adaptation

text: Canalization, the buffering of phenotypes against genetic and environmental perturbation, is a fundamental property of developmental systems. The molecular chaperone Hsp90 is a key agent of canalization, stabilizing metastable protein clients. We tested the hypothesis that Hsp90 acts as an 'evolutionary capacitor' by transiently inhibiting its function in multiple isogenic lines of Drosophila melanogaster under novel thermal stress. This decanalization treatment unveiled a wide spectrum of previously cryptic, heritable morphological phenotypes affecting bristle number, wing venation, and eye structure. The specific phenotypes revealed were dependent on the underlying genetic background of the line. Subsequent selection on these novel traits in the absence of Hsp90 inhibition led to their genetic assimilation within a few generations. Our results demonstrate that environmental stress can compromise cellular buffering systems, releasing stores of cryptic genetic variation that can fuel rapid and substantial evolutionary change.
subject: Evrim
title: Decanalization by Environmental Stress: Hsp90 as an Evolutionary Capacitor Releasing Cryptic Genetic Variation

text: The evolution of eusociality, characterized by reproductive division of labor, represents a major evolutionary transition where the colony becomes the primary unit of selection. This transition requires the suppression of individual-level conflict. We developed a theoretical model predicting that colony-level selection should favor host mechanisms that silence selfish genetic elements (SGEs), whose proliferation is detrimental to colony fitness. We tested this prediction with a comparative genomic analysis across 50 species of Hymenoptera with varying levels of sociality. Our findings show a strong negative correlation between the degree of eusociality and the genomic load of active retrotransposons and segregation distorters. Lineages exhibiting advanced eusociality, such as leaf-cutter ants, possess significantly expanded and more potent RNA interference (RNAi) pathways. This provides compelling evidence that the evolution of a superorganismal state is contingent upon the emergence of higher-level selection regimes capable of resolving intragenomic conflict.
subject: Evrim
title: The Resolution of Intragenomic Conflict via Multilevel Selection and the Origin of Eusociality

text: The impact of key innovations on macroevolutionary dynamics remains a central question in evolutionary biology. Traditional phylogenetic comparative methods are often hampered by incomplete taxon sampling and biases in the fossil record. We introduce a new Bayesian state-dependent speciation and extinction (SSE) model, BiSSE-Fossil, that explicitly incorporates stratigraphic data from fossils to jointly infer trait evolution and diversification rates. Applying this model to the early gnathostome phylogeny, we demonstrate that the evolution of the jaw was a pivotal event that irreversibly increased the rate of speciation (λ) by an order of magnitude while simultaneously decreasing the background extinction rate (μ). This shift created a new adaptive zone, precipitating the explosive radiation of jawed vertebrates. Our results highlight the asymmetric and contingent nature of macroevolution, where single evolutionary events can fundamentally and permanently alter the rules governing the proliferation and persistence of clades.
subject: Evrim
title: A Fossil-Calibrated Bayesian State-Dependent Diversification Model Reveals Asymmetric Macroevolutionary Dynamics Following a Key Innovation

text: Adaptation to new environments is often polygenic, involving subtle frequency shifts at many loci. We investigated the genomic basis of freshwater adaptation in multiple, independent populations of threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus) using a combination of pooled whole-genome sequencing (Pool-Seq) and quantitative trait mapping. In contrast to the classic model of hard selective sweeps on a few major-effect loci, our analysis revealed a highly polygenic architecture. We identified over 1,500 small-effect loci where allele frequencies were consistently differentiated between marine and freshwater ecotypes. These loci are enriched in genes associated with ion transport, kidney function, and metabolic regulation. A polygenic score constructed from these loci accurately predicts the salinity tolerance phenotype of individuals. These results demonstrate that rapid adaptation can proceed via a 'soft sweep' mechanism acting on standing genetic variation, leading to a diffuse, genome-wide signature of selection that reshapes complex physiological traits.
subject: Evrim
title: The Diffuse Genomic Architecture of Polygenic Adaptation to Salinity in Threespine Stickleback

text: The extinction of megafauna during the late Pleistocene remains a contentious subject. We sequenced 74 new woolly mammoth (Mammuthus primigenius) mitochondrial and nuclear genomes from across their Holarctic range, spanning from 50,000 to 4,000 years before present. Bayesian demographic modeling and admixture graph analyses reveal a complex demographic history far exceeding simple models of climate-driven decline. We identified at least three distinct metapopulations—Beringian, West Eurasian, and a cryptic Siberian lineage—that experienced asynchronous population expansions and contractions linked to Dansgaard-Oeschger cycles. During periods of climatic amelioration and range expansion, these metapopulations admixed, but they became severely fragmented during the Last Glacial Maximum. The terminal decline was characterized by serial local extirpations and a dramatic loss of genetic diversity, suggesting that population fragmentation, exacerbated by climatic instability and potential anthropogenic pressure, precipitated the final extinction of this iconic species.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Reconstruction of Late Pleistocene Woolly Mammoth Demography Reveals a Spatiotemporal Mosaic of Admixture and Extirpation

text: This paper introduces a scalable Bayesian nonparametric framework for simultaneous clustering and feature selection in high-dimensional data. We propose a hierarchical Dirichlet process mixture model augmented with spike-and-slab priors on the component-specific parameters to induce sparsity. A key contribution is the development of a stochastic variational inference algorithm that scales to massive datasets by leveraging natural gradient updates and data subsampling. This approach circumvents the computational bottlenecks associated with traditional MCMC methods while effectively inferring the number of clusters and their relevant features. We provide theoretical guarantees on the convergence of our algorithm and establish posterior contraction rates under standard regularity conditions, demonstrating that the posterior distribution concentrates around the true data-generating density. The utility of our method is demonstrated on single-cell RNA sequencing data, where it successfully identifies cell populations and their corresponding marker genes with higher accuracy and computational efficiency than existing methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Variational Inference for Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Mixture Models with Spike-and-Slab Priors

text: We address the problem of causal inference using instrumental variable (IV) regression in high-dimensional settings where many instruments may be invalid. We propose a novel, doubly robust estimation framework that integrates debiased machine learning with a penalized two-stage least squares procedure. The first stage employs a sparse regularization technique to select a subset of potentially valid instruments, while the second stage utilizes a Neyman-orthogonal moment function to construct an estimator for the causal effect that is insensitive to first-stage estimation errors. This debiasing step ensures that our estimator is asymptotically normal and permits valid statistical inference. We establish theoretical results demonstrating that our method provides consistent estimation and valid confidence intervals even when a significant fraction of the instruments violate the exclusion restriction, provided a plurality rule holds. Extensive simulations and an application to a Mendelian randomization study validate the superior performance and robustness of our approach compared to conventional IV methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Machine Learning for High-Dimensional Instrumental Variable Regression with Invalid Instruments

text: This paper develops a rigorous framework for conducting statistical inference on parameters of a Generalized Linear Model (GLM) selected by the Lasso. Classical inference is invalidated by the data-driven model selection step; we propose a novel approach that extends the Post-Selection Inference (PoSI) framework by constructing a symmetrized pivot statistic conditional on the selection event. This technique bypasses the need to characterize complex polyhedral selection regions, which is a major limitation of existing selective inference methods. We prove that our proposed test achieves exact Type I error control in finite samples for Gaussian covariates and asymptotically correct coverage under broader distributional assumptions for the canonical GLM family. Through comprehensive simulations, we show our method provides substantially higher power than data-splitting approaches while strictly controlling the false coverage rate. The methodology is applied to a logistic regression model for genomic risk prediction, illustrating its utility in scientific discovery.
subject: İstatistik
title: Post-Selection Inference for Generalized Linear Models via a Selective Symmetrized-PoSI Framework

text: We introduce a novel framework for statistical inference on data lying on unknown, non-Euclidean manifolds using multiscale persistent homology. The method constructs a sequence of Vietoris-Rips filtrations over a range of scales and analyzes the resulting persistence diagrams as functional data objects. A key innovation is the definition of a new metric on the space of persistence diagrams that is robust to noise and sensitive to subtle topological changes. We prove a corresponding stability theorem with respect to Gromov-Hausdorff perturbations of the underlying metric space, which provides theoretical justification for our inferential procedures. We then develop permutation-based hypothesis tests for comparing manifold topologies without requiring manifold alignment or correspondence estimation. The methodology is illustrated by differentiating between protein folding trajectories and classifying materials based on their porous microstructures, demonstrating its capacity to capture intrinsic geometric and topological features intractable for standard manifold learning methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Multiscale Persistent Homology for Characterizing Non-Euclidean Data Manifolds

text: We propose a novel regression framework for functional data exhibiting significant phase and amplitude variability, termed Elastic Geodesic Regression. By representing functions as elements of a nonlinear Riemannian manifold under the elastic metric, we model the geodesic path of a functional response as a function of scalar or vector covariates. This intrinsically separates phase from amplitude variation, allowing for simultaneous modeling of their respective dependencies on external variables. We derive estimators using a Riemannian Newton-Raphson algorithm and establish their asymptotic consistency and normality under suitable regularity conditions on the manifold structure. The method's efficacy is demonstrated in analyzing human growth curve data, where it successfully disentangles and quantifies the effects of nutritional factors on both the timing (phase) and magnitude (amplitude) of adolescent growth spurts, providing insights unattainable with standard functional regression models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Elastic Geodesic Regression for Functional Data with Extrinsic Covariates

text: This paper introduces a computationally efficient, robust covariance matrix estimator for high-dimensional data from elliptical distributions with heavy tails. Our method, Adaptive Huber Covariance Estimation (AHCE), integrates the principles of robust M-estimation with adaptive thresholding. It first applies a data-driven Huber loss function to pairwise observations to truncate the influence of outliers, then employs a tapering or thresholding step to enforce sparsity and ensure positive definiteness of the final estimate. We establish non-asymptotic deviation bounds for the proposed estimator under sub-exponential assumptions, demonstrating that its convergence rate is nearly optimal and, critically, does not depend on the existence of the fourth moment. Simulations and an application to portfolio optimization with financial asset returns show AHCE’s superior performance over existing methods like graphical LASSO and Tyler’s M-estimator, particularly when data are contaminated or inherently leptokurtic.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Huber Covariance Estimation for High-Dimensional Heavy-Tailed Data

text: We present a flexible hierarchical Bayesian model for capturing non-stationary and anisotropic spatio-temporal dependencies. The core of our approach is a Gaussian process model whose covariance kernel is itself a function of space and time, parameterized by a secondary, latent Gaussian process with a deep prior structure. This architecture allows the model to learn local characteristics of the process—such as correlation length, variance, and anisotropy—directly from the data. To overcome the computational intractability of full Bayesian inference, we develop a hybrid scheme combining the Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA) for the top-level process with stochastic variational inference for the latent kernel parameters. This yields a scalable and accurate approximation to the full posterior. We demonstrate through synthetic examples and an application to sea-surface temperature modeling that our method provides more accurate predictions and better-calibrated uncertainty quantification than models assuming stationarity or employing simpler parametric non-stationary kernels.
subject: İstatistik
title: Non-Stationary Spatio-Temporal Modeling via Latent Gaussian Process Kernels with Deep Priors

text: We propose a novel regression model for settings where both predictors and responses are probability distributions, a structure increasingly common in fields like single-cell genomics and neuroimaging. Our Wasserstein Barycentric Regression (WBR) framework models the conditional Fréchet mean of the response distribution in the 2-Wasserstein space of probability measures. The model specifies the response barycenter as a geodesic combination of predictor distributions, where the regression coefficients define the weights in this barycentric average. We introduce an efficient computational algorithm based on entropic-regularized optimal transport and alternating minimization schemes. Theoretical contributions include establishing the consistency of our estimators and deriving their rates of convergence under mild regularity conditions. The utility of WBR is showcased by modeling the evolution of gene expression distributions over time in response to a treatment, revealing dynamic distributional shifts not captured by conventional mean-based regression models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Wasserstein Barycentric Regression for Distributional Data Analysis

text: This work addresses the challenge of community detection in dynamic multilayer networks, where node-community assignments may evolve over time and across network layers. We propose a unified framework, Tensor Spectral Co-Clustering (TSCC), that represents the network as a third-order adjacency tensor. By analyzing the leading eigenvectors of a suitably defined tensor operator, TSCC simultaneously clusters nodes and identifies temporal or cross-layer community allegiance patterns. We derive non-asymptotic error bounds for the mis-clustering rate under a degree-corrected multilayer stochastic block model, establishing theoretical guarantees for clustering consistency. Our analysis reveals critical thresholds for the signal-to-noise ratio required for accurate recovery as a function of network size, density, and temporal dependence. The method's effectiveness and scalability are validated on synthetic benchmarks and a real-world legislative co-sponsorship network, demonstrating superior performance in tracking evolving political coalitions.
subject: İstatistik
title: Consistent Community Detection in Dynamic Multilayer Networks via Tensor Spectral Co-Clustering

text: Standard conformal prediction methods provide distribution-free prediction intervals with marginal coverage guarantees, but their reliance on data exchangeability and production of uniform-width intervals limits their applicability. We introduce Adaptive Conformalized Quantile Regression (ACQR), a method yielding conditionally valid prediction intervals that adapt to local heteroscedasticity and are robust to certain forms of distribution shift. ACQR works by conformalizing the pinball loss from quantile regression to produce a locally-aware non-conformity score. We prove that, under mild assumptions on the data-generating process, ACQR achieves asymptotically valid conditional coverage. We further integrate this with an online learning framework using exponential weighting to handle concept drift in non-exchangeable data streams. Empirical results on time-series forecasting and financial volatility datasets demonstrate that ACQR produces tighter, more informative prediction intervals than existing conformal methods while rigorously maintaining the desired coverage level.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Conformal Prediction for Heteroscedastic and Non-Exchangeable Data Streams

text: We investigate the real-time thermalization dynamics of a strongly coupled conformal field theory (CFT) using the AdS/CFT correspondence. The system is driven far from equilibrium by a spatially inhomogeneous quantum quench, modeled gravitationally by the infall of a non-uniform null dust shell into an AdS-Schwarzschild black hole. We compute the time evolution of the holographic entanglement entropy for various boundary subregions to probe the propagation of correlations and the approach to local equilibrium. Our numerical results, derived from solving the geodesic equation in the perturbed spacetime, reveal a two-stage thermalization process: an initial 'tsunami' propagation of an entanglement front, whose velocity is dependent on the local energy density, followed by a slower diffusive spreading that homogenizes the system. The saturation timescale exhibits a non-trivial dependence on both the quench amplitude and its spatial wavelength, providing a holographic benchmark for far-from-equilibrium dynamics in strongly interacting quantum matter.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy Dynamics Following a Spatially Inhomogeneous Quantum Quench

text: We theoretically propose and analyze a scheme for robustly suppressing decoherence in a multi-qubit register by engineering the spectral density of its bosonic environment. Moving beyond standard dynamical decoupling protocols, which are often limited by Markovian assumptions, our approach utilizes structured photonic-crystal reservoirs to create a non-Markovian bath with a pronounced phononic bandgap. By tuning the qubit transition frequencies into this gap, we demonstrate a transition from exponential to power-law decay of quantum coherence, effectively freezing entanglement evolution. Using a time-convolutionless master equation formalism, we calculate the dynamics of the concurrence and quantum mutual information for a two-qubit system. The results show a significant enhancement in the lifetime of Bell states, exceeding that of conventional spin-echo techniques by orders of magnitude. This reservoir engineering paradigm offers a passive, hardware-level solution for protecting fragile quantum states in solid-state quantum information processors.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Markovian Decoherence Suppression in a Multi-Qubit System via Engineered Reservoir Coupling

text: The interplay between topology and disorder in Weyl semimetals gives rise to exotic transport phenomena. We present a comprehensive quantum transport theory for a disordered, time-reversal symmetric Weyl semimetal with tilted Dirac cones. Utilizing the Kubo-Stakgold formula within a self-consistent Born approximation, we calculate the anisotropic magnetoconductivity tensor. Our analysis reveals that cone tilt fundamentally alters the manifestation of the chiral anomaly, inducing a non-trivial planar Hall effect even in the absence of orbital magnetoresistance. This effect arises from the chiral-anomaly-induced charge pumping between Weyl nodes, which projects differently onto the electric field and current directions due to the tilted geometry. We provide analytical expressions for the planar Hall conductivity as a function of magnetic field strength, tilt parameter, and internode scattering rate, proposing a distinct experimental signature to disentangle topological contributions from classical transport artifacts.
subject: Fizik
title: Chiral Anomaly and Planar Hall Effect in a Disordered Weyl Semimetal with Tilted Cones

text: We investigate the imprint of primordial gravitational waves (PGWs) on the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) from inflationary models featuring a temporary violation of rotational invariance. Such anisotropies, potentially sourced by a background vector field, generate a statistically anisotropic stochastic gravitational-wave background. We compute the full angular power spectrum of the CMB temperature and polarization anisotropies, including the B-modes, which are a primary target for next-generation observatories. Our analysis demonstrates that statistical anisotropy introduces non-zero TB and EB correlations and modifies the BB power spectrum with a characteristic quadrupolar (and higher multipole) angular dependence. We formulate a set of unique observables beyond the standard tensor-to-scalar ratio, r, that can be used to distinguish these models from standard isotropic inflation. These signatures provide a novel observational window to probe the fundamental symmetries of the universe during its earliest moments.
subject: Fizik
title: Primordial Gravitational Wave Signatures in the CMB from Anisotropic Inflationary Models

text: Standard fluctuation theorems, such as the Jarzynski equality, are foundational to non-equilibrium statistical mechanics but rely on assumptions of classical dynamics or weak system-bath coupling. We derive an exact quantum work fluctuation theorem applicable to systems arbitrarily strongly coupled to a non-Markovian thermal reservoir. Using a Feynman-Vernon path integral approach, we define quantum work as a two-time measurement protocol on the composite system-plus-bath entity. The resulting expression for the characteristic function of work explicitly incorporates the role of initial system-bath correlations and the non-local temporal memory of the reservoir. Our formulation demonstrates that strong coupling introduces significant non-Gaussian corrections to the work distribution. This rigorous generalization provides a framework for understanding energy exchange and entropy production in nanoscale quantum systems, with direct implications for the design and efficiency of quantum heat engines and thermal machines.
subject: Fizik
title: Quantum Fluctuation Theorems and Work Relations in Strongly Coupled Open Quantum Systems

text: We present a comprehensive numerical study of the creation, dynamics, and annihilation of topological defects in a two-dimensional active nematic fluid. By solving the full hydrodynamics equations for an active system, derived from a generalized Toner-Tu model with nematic order, we explore the interplay between active stress, elastic forces, and viscous dissipation. Our simulations reveal that the system self-organizes into a chaotic state characterized by the spontaneous proliferation of ±1/2 disclination pairs. We analyze the defect kinetics, finding that the annihilation rate deviates significantly from the diffusive scaling observed in passive liquid crystals, a direct consequence of the self-propulsion of defects driven by active flows. The spatial correlation function of defect density exhibits a power-law behavior, suggesting a critical-like state governed by non-equilibrium dynamics. These results provide fundamental insights into the universal statistical properties of active turbulence.
subject: Fizik
title: Topological Defect Dynamics and Annihilation in Active Nematic Liquid Crystals

text: We present results from a suite of high-resolution numerical relativity simulations of binary black hole mergers with significant initial eccentricity (e > 0.1) and spin-induced precession. The simulations solve the full Einstein field equations using the moving-puncture formalism with adaptive mesh refinement. We extract the gravitational waveforms and analyze their distinct morphological features compared to quasi-circular, non-precessing inspirals. Eccentricity introduces periodic amplitude and frequency modulations, while precession generates complex modulations dependent on the orbital and Lense-Thirring frequencies. We demonstrate that the interplay between these two effects breaks key parameter degeneracies in gravitational wave data analysis, particularly between mass ratio and spin components. Furthermore, the quasi-normal mode spectrum of the remnant Kerr black hole is excited differently by eccentric mergers, providing a powerful null test of the no-hair theorem in the strong-field regime for next-generation detectors.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Wave Signatures of Eccentric, Precessing Binary Black Hole Mergers in Numerical Relativity

text: We theoretically investigate the emergence of a supersolid ground state in a dipolar Bose-Einstein condensate confined in an anisotropic, pancake-shaped trapping potential. By performing large-scale quantum Monte Carlo simulations of the extended Bose-Hubbard model, which includes both contact and long-range dipole-dipole interactions, we map out the system's quantum phase diagram. For strong dipolar interactions, the roton mode in the excitation spectrum softens, signaling a transition from a coherent superfluid to a state with spontaneous density modulation. We demonstrate that the resulting phase simultaneously exhibits the crystalline order of a solid, evidenced by a non-zero structure factor at a finite wavevector, and the off-diagonal long-range order of a superfluid, characterized by a finite condensate fraction. The anisotropic confinement is crucial for stabilizing this delicate quantum phase against collapse, offering a viable route for its experimental realization.
subject: Fizik
title: Supersolid Phase Formation in a Dipolar Bose Gas with Anisotropic Confinement

text: We develop a quantum field theoretical framework for axion-photon conversion in a resonant microwave cavity that explicitly includes dissipative effects and thermal noise from the cavity walls. Standard haloscope search analyses are based on idealized classical electrodynamics. Our approach, utilizing the Caldeira-Leggett model for dissipation, quantifies the quantum back-action of the measurement apparatus and the entanglement between photonic and phononic modes. We derive the complete power spectrum of the cavity output, showing that finite temperature effects and non-zero wall conductivity not only contribute to the noise floor but also modify the axion conversion signal line shape, inducing a measurable asymmetry. This rigorous treatment provides a more accurate projection of the signal-to-noise ratio for next-generation axion dark matter experiments, such as ADMX, and is essential for optimizing search strategies in the quantum-limited, high-frequency regime.
subject: Fizik
title: Axion Electrodynamics in a Dissipative Cavity and the Search for High-Frequency Dark Matter

text: We propose a novel platform for realizing non-Abelian quantum Hall states using monolayer graphene subjected to a periodically modulated strain field. The application of a triaxial strain pattern creates a synthetic pseudo-magnetic field with zero spatial average but large local fluctuations, leading to the formation of pseudo-Landau levels. In the presence of a real, uniform perpendicular magnetic field, the interplay between the real and pseudo-fields dramatically reconstructs the electronic spectrum. By performing exact diagonalization on a torus geometry, we demonstrate that for specific strain amplitudes and filling factors within the N=0 Landau level, the ground state of the interacting system becomes a non-Abelian Moore-Read Pfaffian state. We calculate the quasiparticle excitation gap and the topological entanglement entropy, providing robust evidence for this exotic fractional quantum Hall phase, which could be realized and probed via scanning tunneling microscopy.
subject: Fizik
title: Fractional Landau Levels and Non-Abelian Excitations in Graphene under Strain Engineering

text: This paper presents a novel deep learning architecture for performing automated Schenkerian analysis directly from polyphonic audio. Traditional approaches to computational Schenkerian analysis rely on symbolic inputs (e.g., MIDI, MusicXML), creating a significant gap between theoretical modeling and acoustical reality. Our proposed framework bridges this divide by integrating a Constant-Q Transform (CQT) frontend with a hybrid Convolutional-Recurrent Neural Network (CRNN). The convolutional layers are trained to extract salient polyphonic features and identify harmonically stable tones, while a subsequent Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network models the temporal dependencies inherent in voice-leading and structural prolongation. By training the model on a curated dataset of expert-annotated recordings, we demonstrate its capacity to identify foreground melodic elaborations and infer middleground linear progressions with high accuracy. This research represents a significant step towards computationally modeling the hierarchical perception of tonal structure from complex, real-world audio signals, offering new avenues for music information retrieval and computational musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: A Deep Convolutional-Recurrent Framework for Automated Schenkerian Analysis from Polyphonic Audio Recordings

text: Neo-Riemannian theory has provided a powerful geometric framework for analyzing triadic relationships in post-tonal music, yet its application has largely ignored the parameter of timbre. This study investigates the interplay between harmonic transformation and timbral evolution in ambient electronic music. We construct a dual feature space wherein harmonic progressions are represented as paths on the Tonnetz, while simultaneous timbral shifts are mapped as trajectories based on their spectral centroid and flux. Using a corpus of works by seminal artists in the genre, we apply canonical correlation analysis (CCA) to uncover latent relationships between specific neo-Riemannian operators (P, L, R) and quantifiable changes in timbral brightness and texture. Our results reveal statistically significant correlations, suggesting that composers intuitively pair parsimonious harmonic shifts with gradual timbral modulations. This work formalizes the symbiotic relationship between harmony and timbre, proposing an integrated analytical model that extends transformational theory beyond the pitch domain.
subject: Müzik
title: Timbral Trajectories in Neo-Riemannian Space: A Correlational Study of Spectral Centroids and Harmonic Transformations in Ambient Electronic Music

text: Metrical dissonance, encompassing both grouping and displacement dissonance, is a crucial component of rhythmic complexity and tension. This paper proposes a computational model to predict the perceived intensity of metrical dissonance directly from an audio signal. We first extract a multi-dimensional feature set from audio, including onset detection functions, spectral flux, and autocorrelation-derived tempo estimates, designed to capture rhythmic pulse and subdivision layers. A Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) is then employed to cluster these features into states corresponding to different levels of metrical stability. Subsequently, a Support Vector Regression (SVR) model is trained on listener ratings of perceived tension from a controlled stimulus set. The model demonstrates high predictive accuracy, outperforming simpler metrics based solely on beat-level deviation. The findings provide empirical validation for theoretical concepts of rhythmic tension and offer a robust tool for analyzing rhythmic structure in performance and for applications in generative music systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Modeling Perceptual Correlates of Metrical Dissonance using Gaussian Mixture Models and Supervised Learning

text: The automated analysis of contrapuntal music is critically dependent on accurate voice separation from a polyphonic mixture. This study introduces a novel source separation algorithm based on Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) specifically tailored for baroque polyphony. We incorporate harmonic constraints into the NMF decomposition by initializing the spectral basis vectors with templates derived from period-appropriate instrumental timbres and penalizing spectrally non-harmonic activations. This 'harmonically-aware' NMF significantly improves voice-leading integrity compared to standard NMF variants. In a second stage, the separated voices, represented as piano-roll matrices, are subjected to a dynamic time warping (DTW) based algorithm to automatically detect canonic imitation, inversion, and stretto. When applied to recordings of J.S. Bach’s Well-Tempered Clavier, our cascaded system achieves high precision in both voice separation and the subsequent identification of core fugal devices, enabling large-scale computational analysis of contrapuntal structures.
subject: Müzik
title: Non-Negative Matrix Factorization with Harmonic Constraints for Voice Separation and Contrapuntal Pattern Discovery in J.S. Bach's Fugues

text: This research explores the application of deep generative models to the creation of novel microtonal and spectral compositions. We propose a Beta-Variational Autoencoder (β-VAE) architecture trained on a dataset of short-time Fourier transform (STFT) magnitudes from the spectral music repertoire. The β-VAE learns a compressed, disentangled latent representation of complex timbral and harmonic structures. By performing structured interpolations and arithmetic operations within this learned latent space, we can generate novel sound spectra that exhibit coherent yet original characteristics. The disentanglement property of the β-parameter allows for more intuitive control over generative features, separating timbral qualities from harmonic density. Subjective listening tests confirm that the generated audio is perceived as possessing high structural integrity and aesthetic novelty. This methodology provides a powerful tool for composers, enabling the exploration of complex sound worlds that bridge the gap between existing spectral works through semantically meaningful latent space navigation.
subject: Müzik
title: Latent Space Interpolation for Microtonal Spectral Composition using a Beta-Variational Autoencoder

text: The analysis of atonal music relies heavily on segmentation and the identification of pitch-class (PC) sets, a process that is laborious and subjective. This paper presents a fully automated pipeline for PC-set analysis directly from audio recordings of atonal works. The methodology first computes a chromagram-based self-similarity matrix (SSM) from the audio. A novel checkerboard kernel is applied to the SSM to detect structural boundaries, facilitating robust temporal segmentation. Each resulting segment is then converted into a normalized chroma vector, which serves as input to a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) trained to classify the segment's predominant PC set, outputting its Forte number. We evaluate the system on a newly created, ground-truth dataset of annotated recordings from the Second Viennese School. The system achieves high accuracy in both segmentation and classification, providing a viable, objective method for large-scale computational analysis of atonal repertoires.
subject: Müzik
title: Automated Atonal Segmentation and Pitch-Class Set Classification using Self-Similarity Matrices and Convolutional Neural Networks

text: Historical performance practice studies have long debated the stylistic evolution of string playing, yet rely predominantly on qualitative descriptions. This paper provides a quantitative, data-driven analysis of portamento and vibrato in early 20th-century violin recordings. We utilize a high-resolution pitch extraction algorithm based on the YIN estimator, followed by a robust sinusoidal model to decouple the vibrato component from the underlying pitch contour. We then extract key parameters: vibrato rate, extent, and portamento duration and slope. Applying this methodology to a corpus of recordings by violinists from the Auer and Franco-Belgian schools (c. 1910-1940), we employ statistical analysis to identify significant differences between the pedagogical lineages. Our findings reveal distinct, quantifiable stylistic 'fingerprints' in the use of these expressive devices, demonstrating that computational audio analysis can provide objective, empirical evidence to refine and substantiate claims in the field of performance practice research.
subject: Müzik
title: A Quantitative Acoustical Analysis of Portamento and Vibrato Idioms in Early 20th-Century Violin Recordings: A Comparative Study

text: The relationship between a conductor's gesture and the resulting musical expression is a central, yet poorly quantified, aspect of performance. This study presents a cross-modal deep learning framework to model this interaction. We use OpenPose, a computer vision library, to extract high-dimensional kinematic data from video recordings of conductors. Concurrently, we extract audio features from the corresponding orchestral recordings, including a continuous tempo curve, RMS energy for dynamics, and spectral information for articulation. A dual-stream neural network, comprising a temporal convolutional network (TCN) for gesture and a CRNN for audio, learns modality-specific representations. A cross-modal attention mechanism is then employed to identify salient gestural features that maximally correlate with specific sonic outcomes. The model demonstrates a strong predictive capacity, successfully forecasting dynamic changes and rubato from gestural input alone. This work provides a new empirical paradigm for studying musical leadership and ensemble interaction.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Correlation of Conductorial Gesture and Orchestral Expressivity: A Deep Learning Approach

text: Transformational theory, particularly its neo-Riemannian instantiation, has offered profound insights into harmonic structures by modeling relationships as operations within a mathematical group. This paper proposes a generalization of this approach beyond the domain of pitch. We construct analogous transformational networks for rhythm and timbre. For rhythm, a 'metrical state space' is defined using beat-synchronous onset probability vectors, with transformations representing operations like metric shift and subdivision layering. For timbre, we use Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) to create a reduced-dimensionality timbre space, where transformations represent timbral brightening or textural changes. By formalizing these non-pitch parameters within a unified group-theoretic framework, we demonstrate the analytical power of tracking musical development as a trajectory through these multiple, interacting geometric spaces. This generalized approach enables a more holistic and integrated method for computational music analysis, applicable to a wide range of musical styles.
subject: Müzik
title: Generalized Transformational Networks for Rhythmic and Timbral Analysis: An Extension of Neo-Riemannian Theory

text: This research presents a sophisticated probabilistic model of harmonic expectation that synthesizes multiple tenets of music cognition. Moving beyond simple N-gram models, our hierarchical Bayesian framework computes the probability of a musical event conditioned on three interacting factors: voice-leading parsimony (a likelihood term favoring minimal pitch motion), learned tonal schemata (a prior distribution over common chord progressions derived from corpus analysis), and metrical context (which weights expectations based on an event's position within the metrical grid). The model dynamically updates its predictions, generating a continuous stream of information content (surprisal) values for a given musical surface. We validate the model by demonstrating a high correlation between its output surprisal and empirical data from cognitive experiments, including reaction times and ERP components like the ERAN. This framework provides a more psychologically plausible and musically nuanced account of how listeners generate expectations, integrating rule-based and statistical learning perspectives.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hierarchical Bayesian Model of Harmonic Expectation Integrating Pitch Proximity, Tonal Schemata, and Metrical Structure

text: The precise editing of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) has been a formidable challenge due to the difficulty of importing guide RNAs into the mitochondrial matrix. Here, we report the development and application of a novel TALE-based deaminase, engineered by fusing a transcription activator-like effector (TALE) protein to a split DddA-derived cytosine deaminase half. This RNA-free system directly recognizes target mtDNA sequences and induces C•G-to-T•A transitions with high specificity. We systematically optimized the linker regions and deaminase variants to achieve efficiencies up to 47% at the ND4 locus in human HEK293T cells. Whole-mitochondrial genome sequencing revealed minimal off-target editing, an order of magnitude lower than nuclear-targeted CRISPR base editors. Application of this TALE-deaminase system successfully corrected a pathogenic G11778A point mutation associated with Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) in a patient-derived cybrid cell line, restoring complex I activity. This technology represents a significant advance in mtDNA editing, offering a promising therapeutic avenue for a range of currently intractable mitochondrial genetic diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cytosine Base Editing of Mitochondrial DNA using a DddA-derived TALE-fusion Deaminase

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are increasingly recognized as critical regulators of nuclear architecture and gene expression, yet their precise molecular mechanisms remain largely elusive. Utilizing a combination of Chromatin Isolation by RNA Purification (ChIRP-seq) and Hi-C analysis, we systematically mapped the genome-wide interactions of the lncRNA FIRRE. Our data reveal that FIRRE establishes a trans-chromosomal interaction hub, binding to specific loci on multiple chromosomes that are enriched for the architectural protein CTCF. Depletion of FIRRE via antisense oligonucleotides results in a significant disruption of these long-range interactions and a concomitant alteration of topologically associating domain (TAD) boundaries near its binding sites. Furthermore, we demonstrate that a conserved tandem repeat element within FIRRE is essential for its interaction with the nuclear matrix protein hnRNPU, which facilitates its architectural function. These findings elucidate a specific mechanism by which a lncRNA acts as a molecular scaffold to organize higher-order chromatin structure, thereby influencing the spatial and regulatory landscape of the genome.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrative Mapping of lncRNA-Chromatin Interactions Reveals a Conserved Role for FIRRE in Topologically Associating Domain Organization

text: Intratumoral heterogeneity is a primary driver of therapeutic resistance in glioblastoma (GBM). To deconstruct this complexity, we performed simultaneous single-cell transcriptomic (scRNA-seq) and chromatin accessibility (scATAC-seq) profiling on over 25,000 cells from patient-derived xenograft models. Our integrative analysis identified four distinct cellular states, including a rare, slow-cycling population characterized by a unique epigenetic landscape and a transcriptomic signature enriched for SOX2, POU3F2, and genes associated with developmental neural stem cells. This quiescent stem-like (QSL) population exhibited high expression of ABC transporters and DNA repair enzymes, consistent with a pre-existing chemoresistant phenotype. Longitudinal analysis following temozolomide treatment revealed a significant enrichment of QSL cells in recurrent tumors. Targeted inhibition of the transcription factor SOX9, a key upstream regulator of the QSL state identified by our multi-omic analysis, successfully re-sensitized resistant tumors to chemotherapy in vivo. Our study provides a high-resolution blueprint of GBM heterogeneity and pinpoints a therapeutically targetable driver of resistance.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dissecting Glioblastoma Heterogeneity via Single-Cell Multi-Omic Profiling Reveals a Quiescent, Chemoresistant Stem-like Population

text: Quality control during protein synthesis is essential for cellular homeostasis. Ribosome stalling on problematic mRNA sequences provides a critical window for nascent polypeptide chain folding and inspection. We used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of a eukaryotic 80S ribosome stalled at a polyproline motif, captured at 2.8 Å resolution. The structure reveals that the nascent polypeptide chain adopts a specific helical conformation within the ribosomal exit tunnel, which makes direct contact with ribosomal RNA elements of the peptidyl transferase center (PTC). This interaction induces an allosteric conformational change in the PTC, uncoupling A-site tRNA accommodation from peptide bond formation and thereby halting translation elongation. We further show that the ribosome-associated quality control factor Rqc2 specifically recognizes this stalled conformation. Our findings delineate a structural mechanism for a co-translational folding checkpoint, where the ribosome itself senses nascent chain conformation to ensure proteome fidelity and trigger downstream quality control pathways if folding is aberrant.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structures of a Stalled Ribosomal Complex Reveal a Checkpoint for Co-translational Protein Folding

text: Membraneless organelles, such as stress granules (SGs), are biomolecular condensates formed through liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS). The RNA-binding protein Fused in Sarcoma (FUS) is a key component of SGs, and its mutations are causative for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Using in vitro reconstitution assays with purified FUS, NMR spectroscopy, and super-resolution microscopy in living cells, we dissected the molecular grammar governing FUS-driven LLPS. We demonstrate that the phase separation of FUS is primarily mediated by its low-complexity domain (LCD) through a network of multivalent cation-π interactions between arginine and tyrosine residues. Isotopic labeling and NMR experiments confirm these specific contacts, while mutagenesis studies show that substituting either arginine or tyrosine residues dramatically elevates the saturation concentration required for LLPS. Importantly, ALS-associated mutations in the FUS LCD disrupt these critical interactions, leading to the formation of irreversible, solid-like amyloid aggregates instead of dynamic liquid droplets, providing a direct molecular link between aberrant phase transition and neurodegeneration.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of FUS drives Stress Granule Assembly through Multivalent Arginine-Tyrosine Interactions

text: The RAG1/RAG2 recombinase initiates V(D)J recombination to generate antigen receptor diversity, but its off-target activity can lead to oncogenic genomic rearrangements. Current methods lack the sensitivity to map off-target RAG cleavage events genome-wide. Here, we developed RAG-CUT&RUN, an antibody-targeted nuclease-based method, to map RAG1 binding and cleavage at single-nucleotide resolution in pre-B cells. Our analysis uncovered thousands of previously unannotated off-target sites, which preferentially occurred within active enhancers and super-enhancers marked by H3K27ac. These cryptic sites often possess degenerate recombination signal sequences (RSSs) but are rendered accessible by the local chromatin environment. Importantly, a meta-analysis of genomic data from T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) patients revealed a significant overlap between these off-target sites and the breakpoints of oncogenic translocations involving proto-oncogenes like LMO2 and TAL1. These findings suggest that RAG-mediated off-target activity is far more pervasive than previously understood and is a key contributor to genomic instability during lymphoid development.
subject: Biyoloji
title: High-Resolution Mapping of RAG1 Off-Target Cleavage Reveals Cryptic Recombination Signals in Lymphoid Malignancies

text: The circadian clock relies on a transcriptional-translational feedback loop whose timing is precisely regulated by post-translational modifications (PTMs) of core clock proteins. To comprehensively map this regulatory layer, we performed time-resolved, quantitative phosphoproteomic analysis of the murine suprachiasmatic nucleus. Our data revealed a complex temporal network of phosphorylation events, leading us to uncover a previously unknown PTM crosstalk on the PERIOD2 (PER2) protein. We demonstrate that phosphorylation of PER2 at serine 662 by Casein Kinase 1δ (CK1δ) creates a binding motif for the E3 ubiquitin ligase β-TrCP, targeting PER2 for proteasomal degradation. However, we identified a competing SUMOylation event at the adjacent lysine 665, which sterically hinders β-TrCP binding and stabilizes PER2. Genetic or chemical inhibition of the SUMO E2 ligase UBE2I accelerates PER2 degradation and significantly shortens the circadian period in both cell culture and live animals. This phosphorylation-dependent SUMO switch represents a critical molecular rheostat that fine-tunes the period of the mammalian circadian oscillator.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phospho-proteomic Analysis Identifies SUMOylation as a Critical Regulator of PER2 Stability and Circadian Periodicity

text: G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) are premier drug targets, yet achieving subtype selectivity remains a major challenge. Allosteric modulators, which bind to topographically distinct sites, offer a promising solution. We screened a DNA-encoded library (DEL) of over 4.2 billion unique compounds against a stabilized, purified human A2A adenosine receptor (A2AAR). This campaign identified a novel chemical scaffold that acts as a potent and selective negative allosteric modulator (NAM). The lead compound, ZK-7b, inhibited G-protein activation with nanomolar potency but did not displace orthosteric radioligands. A 3.1 Å cryo-electron microscopy structure of the A2AAR-Gs complex bound to ZK-7b and an agonist revealed that the NAM binds to a previously uncharacterized cryptic pocket on the intracellular face of the receptor, involving transmembrane helices 2 and 4. Molecular dynamics simulations show that ZK-7b stabilizes an inactive conformation of the Gα-interacting intracellular loop 2, thereby uncoupling the receptor from its cognate G-protein. This discovery highlights the power of DEL screening for identifying novel allosteric sites and chemical matter for GPCR modulation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A DNA-encoded Chemical Library Screen Identifies a Novel Allosteric Modulator of the A2A Adenosine Receptor

text: Metastasis is a complex process involving intricate communication between tumor cells and distant microenvironments. Here, we demonstrate that cancer-derived exosomes are critical mediators in establishing a pre-metastatic niche. Using an orthotopic mouse model of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), we found that highly metastatic cancer cells secrete exosomes significantly enriched in microRNA-200c (miR-200c). Through in vivo lineage tracing, we show these exosomes are preferentially taken up by hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) in the liver. Upon uptake, miR-200c directly targets and represses transcription of SEC23A, a key component of the COPII vesicle transport system. SEC23A downregulation impairs collagen secretion from HSCs, leading to a profound remodeling of the liver extracellular matrix. This altered matrix architecture promotes the extravasation and subsequent proliferation of circulating tumor cells. In vivo administration of exosomes lacking miR-200c failed to promote liver metastasis, confirming the functional role of this specific exosomal cargo in orchestrating organotropic colonization.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Exosome-mediated Transfer of miR-200c Promotes Metastatic Colonization by Reprogramming the Pre-Metastatic Niche

text: The engineering of autotrophic carbon fixation in heterotrophic organisms is a paramount goal in synthetic biology for sustainable bioproduction. We report the functional implementation of a novel, orthogonal CO2-fixation pathway, the Formolase-Glucolase-Xylose (FGX) cycle, in *Escherichia coli*. The primary rate-limiting step, catalyzed by Ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (RuBisCO), was addressed by subjecting a Form II RuBisCO from *Rhodospirillum rubrum* to multiple rounds of directed evolution. Using a custom-designed fluorescent biosensor responsive to the downstream metabolite glycolaldehyde, we screened over 10^8 mutants and isolated a variant, RuBisCO-EVO8, with a 7-fold improvement in carboxylation efficiency (kcat/Km) and a substantially reduced oxygenase side-reaction. Integration of the FGX pathway with RuBisCO-EVO8 into the *E. coli* chromosome enabled sustained, CO2-dependent growth on methanol as a co-substrate. This work establishes a robust framework for evolving carbon-fixing enzymes and constructing synthetic autotrophy in a tractable industrial chassis, paving the way for converting CO2 and C1 feedstocks into valuable chemicals.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Engineering an Orthogonal CO2-Fixation Pathway in Escherichia coli using a Directed Evolution-optimized RuBisCO

text: This work theoretically investigates the stability of non-Abelian anyonic excitations in a Kitaev honeycomb lattice model subject to spatially modulated anisotropic exchange couplings.
