We employ a combination of exact diagonalization and density-matrix renormalization group (DMRG) techniques to map the system's topological phase diagram. Our results reveal the emergence of an expanded, robust gapped spin-liquid phase that hosts Majorana fermion zero modes at engineered lattice dislocations. We simulate braiding operations on these localized modes and calculate the fidelity of the resulting unitary transformations. The engineered anisotropy is shown to significantly increase the energy gap protecting the topological ground state manifold, leading to an exponential suppression of decoherence from local thermal and magnetic field fluctuations. This suggests a viable materials-by-design pathway towards intrinsically fault-tolerant quantum computation platforms, mitigating the stringent requirements for external quantum error correction.
subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence-Resistant Topological Qubits via Engineered Anisotropy in a Perturbed Kitaev Honeycomb Model

text: We explore the profound connection between quantum information and spacetime geometry within the framework of the AdS/CFT correspondence. This paper extends the Ryu-Takayanagi formula by investigating the structure of multipartite entanglement in the boundary conformal field theory (CFT) and its holographic dual in the anti-de Sitter (AdS) bulk. Utilizing the concept of entanglement negativity and the 'bit thread' formulation, we demonstrate how specific configurations of N-party entanglement, particularly the GHZ and W states, correspond to distinct bulk spacetime topologies, including wormholes connecting multiple asymptotic regions. Our analysis suggests that the connectivity of spacetime is not a fundamental property but rather an emergent feature derived from the underlying entanglement architecture of the quantum state. This provides compelling evidence for the ER=EPR conjecture and frames bulk locality as an approximate concept derived from the quantum error-correcting code structure inherent in the holographic mapping.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent Spacetime Geometry from Multipartite Entanglement in the AdS/CFT Correspondence

text: We present a high-precision calculation of the properties of the doubly charmed tetraquark state T_cc+ using lattice quantum chromodynamics (LQCD). The simulation is performed on a set of (2+1)-flavor QCD gauge field ensembles with physical quark masses, employing a relativistic heavy quark action for the charm quarks. We utilize a large basis of spatially extended two- and four-quark interpolating operators to robustly extract the ground-state energy level from the correlation functions. By analyzing the finite-volume energy spectrum below and above the D*+D0 threshold, we apply Lüscher's formalism to determine the scattering phase shifts and extract the resonance parameters. Our final result for the mass, referenced to the D*+D0 threshold, and the decay width into this channel, are presented with a full systematic error budget, including uncertainties from lattice spacing, finite volume, and chiral extrapolation, providing a stringent test of quark model predictions for exotic hadrons.
subject: Kuantum
title: First-Principles Lattice QCD Calculation of the Mass and Decay Width of the T_cc+ Tetraquark State

text: We propose and theoretically analyze a novel interferometric scheme for precision measurement that surpasses the standard quantum limit (SQL) and approaches the Heisenberg limit. Our design integrates a Mach-Zehnder interferometer with a high-Q optomechanical cavity, where the position of a movable end mirror is continuously monitored via a weakly coupled probe field. This continuous measurement induces a quantum Zeno effect, effectively 'freezing' the mirror's quantum state and suppressing radiation pressure shot noise—the primary obstacle at the SQL. We introduce squeezed vacuum states at the input port to further reduce photon number uncertainty. A full quantum analysis using the input-output formalism and solving the corresponding Langevin equations demonstrates a significant enhancement in phase sensitivity. The protocol is shown to be robust against moderate thermal decoherence and optical losses, paving a path towards next-generation gravitational wave detectors and ultra-sensitive force sensors.
subject: Kuantum
title: Surpassing the Standard Quantum Limit with a Quantum Zeno-Stabilized Optomechanical Interferometer

text: This study investigates the emergence of Majorana zero modes (MZMs) in a hybrid semiconductor-superconductor-ferromagnet nanowire (InAs/Al/EuS). We solve the Bogoliubov-de Gennes (BdG) equations self-consistently to account for the interplay between the proximity-induced superconductivity, the strong spin-orbit coupling, the exchange field from the ferromagnetic insulator, and a non-uniform external magnetic field. Our numerical simulations reveal a rich topological phase diagram, identifying parameter regimes where MZMs are stabilized at the nanowire ends. Crucially, the non-uniform magnetic field allows for the creation of topological regions without requiring global time-reversal symmetry breaking, offering enhanced tunability. We calculate the local density of states and the differential conductance, predicting robust zero-bias conductance peaks as a key experimental signature. This architecture provides a promising platform for realizing and manipulating non-Abelian quasiparticles for topological quantum information processing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Phase Diagram and Non-Abelian Signatures in InAs/EuS/Al Hybrid Nanowires under Non-Uniform Magnetic Fields

text: We theoretically investigate the dynamics of quantum correlations, specifically quantum discord, for a central qubit coupled to a structured bosonic reservoir exhibiting strong memory effects. By solving the exact non-Markovian master equation beyond the rotating-wave and Born approximations using a time-convolutionless projection operator technique, we demonstrate that the decay of quantum discord is non-monotonic. Our results show distinct periods of recurrence, where quantum correlations are partially restored after an initial decay phase, a phenomenon absent in Markovian descriptions. This revival is directly linked to the backflow of information from the environment to the system, quantified by the non-Markovianity measure. For certain reservoir spectral densities, we observe a transient amplification of discord above its initial value. These findings challenge the conventional view of irreversible information loss and have significant implications for preserving quantum resources in realistic noisy quantum processors and communication channels.
subject: Kuantum
title: Recurrence and Amplification of Quantum Discord in a Non-Markovian Qubit-Reservoir System

text: We investigate the transition from thermalizing to many-body localized (MBL) phases in a one-dimensional disordered spin-1/2 chain with algebraically decaying long-range interactions (1/r^α). Using large-scale exact diagonalization for small systems and a time-dependent variational principle (TDVP) approach for dynamics up to 100 spins, we map out the phase diagram as a function of disorder strength and interaction range α. For sufficiently rapid decay (α > 1), we identify a sharp ergodicity-breaking MBL transition. Deep in the MBL phase, we observe the characteristic logarithmic growth of bipartite entanglement entropy following a global quantum quench, a hallmark of MBL. Furthermore, our spectral analysis of the Hamiltonian reveals the existence of a finite-energy mobility edge, separating localized from delocalized eigenstates. Our findings constrain the theoretical conditions for the stability of the MBL phase and provide critical insights into the nature of quantum thermalization.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Growth and Mobility Edge in a Disordered Long-Range Interacting Spin System

text: We present a theoretical framework for a nanoscale thermal device functioning as a quantum thermal transistor. The proposed architecture consists of three coupled spin-boson systems (qubits), each connected to an independent thermal reservoir, representing the source, drain, and gate terminals. By solving the global Lindblad quantum master equation in the strong-coupling regime, we analyze the steady-state heat currents flowing through the system. Our analysis demonstrates that a small heat current injected into the gate terminal can coherently modulate the phononic heat transport between the source and drain, achieving a thermal amplification factor exceeding one order of magnitude. We further show that the device exhibits sharp thermal switching behavior and negative differential thermal conductance. This quantum thermal transistor concept provides a fundamental building block for phononic logic circuits and advanced nanoscale thermal management in quantum computing architectures.
subject: Kuantum
title: A Three-Qubit Quantum Thermal Transistor with Coherent Phononic Control

text: We report the experimental realization of a hybrid quantum system demonstrating strong coupling between a single nitrogen-vacancy (NV) center electron spin in diamond and a high-finesse superconducting lumped-element resonator. Operating in the Purcell-enhanced regime, we observe a coherent energy exchange, manifested as a clear vacuum Rabi splitting in the cavity transmission spectrum, with a coupling strength g/2π exceeding the combined decay rates of the spin and the cavity. Exploiting this strong interaction, we implement a protocol for the deterministic generation of arbitrary photonic Fock states within the cavity. By precisely timing a sequence of microwave pulses applied to the NV spin, we conditionally add single photons to the cavity field, verified by Wigner tomography and second-order correlation function measurements (g^(2)(0) < 0.1). This device represents a powerful node for quantum networks, capable of mapping quantum information between stationary spin qubits and flying photonic qubits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Deterministic Generation of Non-Classical Photon States from a Strongly Coupled Nitrogen-Vacancy Center in a Superconducting Cavity

text: This work analyzes the behavior of genuine tripartite entanglement, as embodied by the Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) state, from the perspective of three uniformly accelerated observers in Minkowski spacetime. We employ a relativistic quantum information framework to trace over the inaccessible field modes beyond each observer's Rindler horizon, which manifests as the Unruh effect. By calculating the three-tangle and the Peres-Horodecki criterion for the resulting mixed state shared by the observers, we quantify the degradation of entanglement as a function of their proper acceleration. Our results show that while genuine tripartite entanglement is fragile and vanishes at a finite acceleration, bipartite correlations between pairs of observers persist. Remarkably, we find that a non-zero measure of distillable entanglement survives even when one observer crosses the Rindler horizon of another, indicating that quantum correlations are not entirely severed by causal disconnection, challenging classical intuition about locality in spacetime.
subject: Kuantum
title: Relativistic Degradation of Tripartite Entanglement and the Persistence of Quantum Correlations Across the Rindler Horizon

text: We theoretically investigate the implementation of topologically protected quantum gates based on the non-Abelian braiding statistics of Majorana zero modes (MZMs). Our model considers a tri-junction network of semiconducting nanowires with strong Rashba spin-orbit coupling, proximitized by an s-wave superconductor. By employing a low-energy effective Hamiltonian solved via a non-equilibrium Green's function formalism, we simulate the adiabatic transport and braiding of MZMs localized at the nanowire ends. We demonstrate that the resulting unitary transformations on the degenerate ground-state manifold correspond to a universal set of quantum gates, including the Hadamard and phase gates. Crucially, we quantify the topological protection by calculating the gate fidelity as a function of environmental noise, modeled as local charge fluctuations. Our results show an exponential suppression of decoherence with increasing MZM separation, providing a robust pathway toward fault-tolerant topological quantum computation and validating the intrinsic error-correction capabilities of non-Abelian anyonic systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence-Resistant Quantum Logic via Braiding of Majorana Zero Modes in a Proximitized Rashba Nanowire Network

text: We explore a potential condensed matter realization of the holographic principle by numerically studying the entanglement structure of a many-body localized (MBL) system. Using large-scale density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) simulations on a disordered Heisenberg spin chain, we analyze the scaling of entanglement entropy for various subsystem bipartitions. We find that in the deep MBL phase, the entanglement entropy obeys an area law, consistent with the Ryu-Takayanagi formula for extremal surfaces in an Anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime. Furthermore, the multipartite entanglement structure, as characterized by the negativity and mutual information, is shown to be consistent with the geometric properties of a tensor network representation resembling a discretized AdS geometry. This work establishes a compelling link between the breakdown of thermalization in disordered quantum systems and the emergence of a holographic dual description, suggesting that features of quantum gravity might be experimentally accessible in solid-state systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Emergent Spacetime in a Many-Body Localized System

text: This paper reports on the observation of chiral state transfer dynamics governed by the topological properties of exceptional points (EPs) in a non-Hermitian system. We engineered a coupled-resonator optical waveguide with precisely controlled gain and loss, realizing a PT-symmetric Hamiltonian. By dynamically encircling an EP in the parameter space of the system, we demonstrate robust and asymmetric mode switching, a direct consequence of the Riemann sheet topology near the EP singularity. The state evolution is shown to depend on the encirclement direction, a hallmark of non-Hermitian chirality. Our experimental results, which are in excellent agreement with a coupled-mode theory analysis, reveal that the state transfer fidelity is topologically protected against moderate structural disorder. These findings open avenues for designing novel, robust optical devices such as topological insulators, switches, and sensors based on non-Hermitian quantum mechanics and the unique physics of exceptional points.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological State Transfer and Chiral Dynamics around Exceptional Points in a Non-Hermitian Photonic Crystal

text: We propose and analyze a quantum metrology protocol that achieves Heisenberg-limited precision by leveraging multi-mode entangled Fock states in a circuit QED platform. The protocol utilizes a network of transmon qubits coupled to multiple high-Q microwave cavities to deterministically generate multi-mode NOON states of the form (|N,0,...,0⟩ + |0,...,0,N⟩)/√2. By mapping the phase to be estimated onto the relative phase of the entangled cavity fields, a subsequent joint measurement on the qubits projects the system into a state from which the phase can be extracted with a precision scaling as 1/N. We provide a detailed theoretical analysis of the protocol's robustness against major decoherence channels, including photon loss and qubit dephasing, using a Lindblad master equation approach. Our simulations indicate that for experimentally feasible parameters with N up to 5, our scheme significantly surpasses the Standard Quantum Limit, paving the way for advanced quantum sensing applications.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Phase Estimation via Multi-Mode NOON States in a Superconducting Circuit Architecture

text: We theoretically demonstrate that a periodically driven graphene monolayer subjected to a spatially periodic potential can realize a dynamic, higher-order topological insulating phase. Utilizing Floquet theory and a tight-binding model, we show that an appropriately tuned AC electric field (circularly polarized light) opens a non-trivial band gap in the quasi-energy spectrum. The resulting Floquet-Bloch bands are characterized by a quantized bulk polarization, leading to the emergence of topologically protected, zero-dimensional corner states. These chiral corner states are robust against static disorder and manifest as localized modes at the system's corners with quantized fractional charge. We compute the topological invariant—the nested Wilson loop—to map out the phase diagram as a function of driving frequency, amplitude, and superlattice potential. This work introduces a versatile method for dynamically creating and controlling exotic topological phases of matter with no static counterpart, offering new possibilities for topological electronics and quantum information processing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Floquet Engineering of a Chiral Higher-Order Topological Insulator in a Periodically Driven Graphene Superlattice

text: We investigate the thermodynamics of a microscopic heat engine composed of a single trapped ion coupled to engineered laser reservoirs, operating in a non-quasistatic regime. By performing projective energy measurements on the ion's electronic and motional states, we experimentally reconstruct the work distribution for a four-stroke Otto cycle. Our results provide a direct verification of the Jarzynski equality and Crooks fluctuation theorem for a quantum system far from thermal equilibrium. We analyze the engine's efficiency and power output as a function of cycle duration, demonstrating a fundamental trade-off. Furthermore, we explore the role of quantum coherence, generated during non-adiabatic strokes, in the engine's performance. We find that while coherence does not enhance the average work output, it significantly alters the higher-order moments of the work distribution, revealing uniquely quantum signatures in the system's thermodynamic behavior that are inaccessible through classical descriptions.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Fluctuation Theorems and Work Extraction in a Single-Ion Heat Engine Operating Beyond the Quasistatic Limit

text: The transition from a thermalizing ergodic phase to a many-body localized (MBL) phase represents a fundamental breakdown of statistical mechanics in a closed quantum system. Here, we investigate this transition in a one-dimensional Heisenberg spin chain with a quasiperiodic potential, which evades certain theorems precluding MBL in random-disorder models. Using time-dependent variational principle (TDVP) simulations on matrix product states, we study the propagation of quantum information following a local quench. In the ergodic phase, information spreads linearly, forming a conventional light cone. Conversely, deep in the MBL phase, propagation is arrested. Critically, we identify an intermediate regime where the light cone expands logarithmically with time, a tell-tale signature of the MBL phase. By analyzing the entanglement entropy growth and correlation functions, we precisely map the phase boundary and characterize the critical exponents, providing strong numerical evidence for the universality of the MBL transition.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing the Many-Body Localization Transition with Logarithmic Light Cones in a Quasiperiodic Spin Chain

text: Quantum information scrambling describes the rapid delocalization of local information across a system's many-body degrees of freedom, a key feature of quantum chaos and black holes. We report the experimental measurement of an out-of-time-order correlator (OTOC) in a programmable quantum simulator based on a chain of 16 Ytterbium ions. The system is engineered to emulate the Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) model, a solvable model of interacting Majorana fermions exhibiting maximal chaos. By implementing a time-reversal protocol, we measure the decay of the OTOC, observing an exponential growth of the scrambling signature at early times. From this growth, we extract the quantum Lyapunov exponent, a primary quantifier of chaos, and study its dependence on temperature. Our results show that the scrambling rate approaches the universal bound predicted for maximally chaotic systems, λ_L ≤ 2πk_B T/ħ, thus providing a direct experimental verification of a fundamental aspect of quantum gravity and many-body chaos.
subject: Kuantum
title: Measurement of the Out-of-Time-Order Correlator and Scrambling Dynamics in a Trapped-Ion Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev Simulator

text: We propose a high-fidelity, single-step protocol for generating Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) states of N transmon qubits coupled to a single microwave resonator operating in the dispersive ultra-strong coupling (USC) regime. In this regime, the qubit-resonator coupling strength g is comparable to the resonator frequency ω_r, leading to a breakdown of the rotating-wave approximation and the emergence of novel interaction terms. We show that a global microwave drive applied to the resonator can selectively activate a multi-photon, multi-qubit resonance that coherently evolves an initial product state |g...g⟩ into the GHZ state (|g...g⟩ + |e...e⟩)/√2. The protocol's duration scales as 1/N and is highly robust to inhomogeneous qubit frequencies. Using a quantum master equation simulation including realistic decoherence parameters, we predict a state fidelity exceeding 98% for a five-qubit GHZ state, outperforming existing multi-pulse schemes in both speed and simplicity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Deterministic Generation of Multiqubit GHZ States in the Dispersive Ultra-Strong Coupling Regime of Circuit QED

text: We provide a comprehensive theoretical analysis of the degradation of quantum entanglement and teleportation fidelity for a bipartite system shared between an inertial observer (Alice) and a uniformly accelerated observer (Rob). By quantizing a massless scalar field in Rindler coordinates, we explicitly calculate the Bogoliubov transformation that maps the Minkowski vacuum to a thermal state in the accelerated frame. We then analyze an initially maximally entangled Bell state of two field modes. For Rob, the Unruh effect traces out the inaccessible modes behind his event horizon, resulting in a mixed density matrix for the shared state. We compute the concurrence and logarithmic negativity of this state, showing that entanglement vanishes in the limit of infinite acceleration. Consequently, the average fidelity of a standard teleportation protocol is shown to decrease monotonically with Rob's acceleration, falling below the classical limit and rendering the channel useless for quantum communication at a finite acceleration.
subject: Kuantum
title: Fidelity of Quantum Teleportation in Non-Inertial Frames and the Unruh Effect on Bipartite Entanglement

text: The distributed nature of clinical data poses significant barriers to training robust machine learning models. We introduce FedCryptDP, a novel federated learning framework that enables collaborative model training while providing rigorous, multi-level privacy guarantees. Our approach integrates partially homomorphic encryption (PHE) for the secure aggregation of model gradients with client-level ε-differential privacy for local noise injection prior to transmission. This hybrid mechanism ensures that the central server has no access to individual client updates, mitigating both direct data exposure and sophisticated inference attacks. We evaluate the framework on a simulated multi-institutional cohort for genomic risk prediction, demonstrating a negligible loss in predictive accuracy (AUC drop < 0.02) compared to a centralized, non-private baseline. The results validate FedCryptDP as a viable solution for building powerful predictive models from sensitive, siloed medical data without compromising patient confidentiality, providing a formal cryptographic and statistical privacy assurance.
subject: AI
title: Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning via Hybrid Cryptography and Differential Privacy for Multi-Centric Clinical Data Analysis

text: Standard reinforcement learning algorithms often fail to generalize when the training and deployment environments exhibit distributional shifts, primarily due to their reliance on spurious correlations. This paper introduces a Causal-Informed Policy Gradient (CIPG) framework that leverages structural causal models (SCMs) to disentangle causal factors from confounding variables in the state representation. We employ a variational autoencoder architecture with a disentanglement regularizer, derived from interventional calculus, to learn a latent space aligned with the underlying causal graph. The policy is then optimized over this robust, causal representation, rendering it invariant to non-causal statistical fluctuations. Experiments in benchmark environments with procedurally generated confounders, including contextual bandits and complex control tasks, demonstrate that CIPG significantly outperforms state-of-the-art model-free and model-based RL methods in out-of-distribution generalization and zero-shot transfer learning scenarios, achieving superior policy robustness under covariate and intervention shifts.
subject: AI
title: Causal-Informed Policy Optimization for Reinforcement Learning Agents Under Spurious Correlations

text: The automated generation of novel molecular structures with desired chemical properties represents a grand challenge in computational chemistry and drug discovery. We propose HyperGAN, a generative adversarial network architecture tailored for synthesizing realistic molecular graphs by explicitly modeling multi-atom interactions. Unlike traditional graph-based GANs that operate on pairwise edges, HyperGAN utilizes a hypergraph convolutional network (HyperGCN) within both the generator and discriminator to capture higher-order structural motifs and enforce chemical valency rules. The generator learns a distribution over a latent chemical space, conditioned on desired physicochemical properties (e.g., QED, LogP), while the discriminator enforces graph-theoretic and chemical validity constraints. Quantitative evaluations on the ZINC and QM9 datasets demonstrate HyperGAN's superiority in generating valid, unique, and novel molecules, achieving a 15% higher success rate in constrained property optimization tasks compared to existing graph generative models, thereby accelerating materials and drug discovery pipelines.
subject: AI
title: Hypergraph-Constrained Generative Adversarial Networks for De Novo Molecular Design

text: Solving NP-hard combinatorial optimization problems remains a formidable challenge for classical computation. This research investigates the application of hybrid quantum-classical algorithms, specifically the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) and Variational Quantum Eigensolvers (VQE), for this task. We introduce a novel regularization term into the problem Hamiltonian encoding to mitigate the effects of hardware noise and improve solution quality on current Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) devices. The method is benchmarked on Max-Cut and Traveling Salesperson Problems, implemented on a superconducting qubit processor. Our regularized quantum ansatz demonstrates a marked improvement in approximation ratios and convergence stability compared to standard QAOA formulations, particularly in low-depth circuits. This work elucidates a practical pathway for achieving quantum advantage by co-designing algorithms and problem formulations to be resilient to the inherent imperfections of contemporary quantum hardware, making them more amenable to near-term execution.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Algorithms for Regularized Combinatorial Optimization on Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum Hardware

text: Accurate and long-range traffic flow prediction is crucial for intelligent transportation systems but is hindered by data scarcity and complex, dynamic dependencies in road networks. We present CST-GRL, a self-supervised learning framework that pre-trains spatio-temporal graph neural networks (STGNNs) on large-scale unlabeled traffic data. CST-GRL employs a novel contrastive learning objective that maximizes mutual information between graph representations of temporally and spatially augmented traffic patterns. This pre-training phase enables the model to learn robust, generalizable representations of fundamental traffic dynamics without requiring labeled data. The pre-trained encoder is then fine-tuned on downstream tasks, such as multi-step traffic speed and volume prediction. On benchmark datasets like PeMS-BAY and METR-LA, our method significantly reduces the dependency on labeled samples and establishes a new state-of-the-art, outperforming supervised baselines by up to 8% in Mean Absolute Error for 60-minute forecasts.
subject: AI
title: Contrastive Spatio-Temporal Graph Representation Learning for Urban Traffic Flow Prediction

text: Safety in autonomous systems hinges on the ability of perception models to reliably quantify their predictive uncertainty. Traditional deep neural networks provide point estimates, failing to capture model confidence. This paper proposes a framework based on Deep Evidential Regression to learn a continuous evidential distribution over the target variable, allowing for the explicit disentanglement of aleatoric (data) and epistemic (model) uncertainty. We formulate the bounding box regression and depth estimation problems as learning the parameters of a Normal-Inverse-Gamma distribution. This approach, implemented on a LiDAR-based 3D object detection backbone, provides well-calibrated uncertainty estimates with minimal computational overhead compared to Bayesian deep learning methods like Monte Carlo dropout. Extensive experiments on the KITTI and nuScenes datasets demonstrate that our method's uncertainty metrics are highly correlated with prediction error, enabling robust failure detection and safer decision-making under novel or ambiguous conditions.
subject: AI
title: Quantifying Aleatoric and Epistemic Uncertainty in Autonomous Driving Perception via Deep Evidential Regression

text: The adaptation of large language models (LLMs) to specialized domains with scarce labeled data presents a significant few-shot learning challenge. We introduce MetaProto-MAML, a hybrid meta-learning algorithm that synergizes the optimization-based approach of Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) with the metric-based learning of Prototypical Networks. Our method learns a meta-initialization of model parameters that is primed for rapid adaptation, while simultaneously learning a discriminative embedding space where classification is performed by computing distances to class prototypes derived from the small support set. This dual objective facilitates both fast gradient-based fine-tuning and robust generalization from few examples. We evaluate MetaProto-MAML on a suite of challenging, low-resource NLP tasks, including legal and biomedical text classification. Results show our approach converges faster and achieves a 5-10% absolute accuracy improvement in 5-shot, 1-way classification scenarios over strong baselines like standard fine-tuning and vanilla MAML.
subject: AI
title: Gradient-Based Meta-Learning with Prototypical Networks for Few-Shot Domain Adaptation of Large Language Models

text: Deep learning models for Visual Question Answering (VQA) often function as black boxes, learning spurious correlations without explicit reasoning. To address this, we propose a Neuro-Symbolic VQA framework (NS-VQA) that integrates deep perceptual modules with a first-order logic reasoning engine. Our system first uses a scene graph generator to extract entities, attributes, and relations from an image, forming a knowledge base. A question parser translates the natural language query into a logical formula. The core of our innovation is a Differentiable Logic Tensor Network (DLTN) that performs reasoning over the symbolic knowledge base using a differentiable forward-chaining inference mechanism. This allows for end-to-end training of the entire pipeline with gradient descent. On the CLEVR dataset, NS-VQA not only achieves state-of-the-art accuracy but also generates a symbolic proof trace for each answer, providing full transparency and explainability for its reasoning process.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic Integration via Differentiable Logic Tensor Networks for Explainable Visual Question Answering

text: Unsupervised anomaly detection in high-dimensional, non-stationary time-series data from domains like cybersecurity and finance is challenging due to concept drift. Standard Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) struggle as their fixed latent spaces cannot adapt to evolving data distributions. We introduce the Dynamic Latent Space VAE (DLS-VAE), an architecture that models the latent space itself as a stochastic process governed by a Neural Controlled Differential Equation (NCDE). This allows the latent posterior to dynamically adapt to temporal variations in the input data stream. Anomalies are identified based on the reconstruction probability under the evolving posterior distribution. We evaluate our model on several real-world datasets, including network intrusion (KDDCup99) and credit card fraud detection. The DLS-VAE demonstrates a significant improvement in F1-score and robustness to concept drift over static VAEs and other state-of-the-art methods, effectively reducing false positive rates by dynamically adjusting its definition of normality.
subject: AI
title: Dynamic Latent Space Variational Autoencoders for Unsupervised Anomaly Detection in High-Dimensional Time-Series Data

text: The prohibitive computational cost of large transformer models impedes their deployment on resource-constrained edge devices. This work presents Hessian-Aware Pruning and Quantization (HAPQ), a unified, second-order information-based method for extreme model compression. HAPQ leverages an efficient approximation of the loss function's Hessian to jointly identify and remove redundant network structures (entire attention heads and neuron blocks) and determine optimal bit-width for weight quantization. Unlike first-order or magnitude-based methods, our Hessian-aware saliency score better approximates a parameter's impact on the loss landscape, enabling more aggressive yet accurate compression. We apply HAPQ to BERT and Vision Transformer models, achieving over 10x compression and 8x latency reduction with less than 1% degradation in downstream task performance on GLUE and ImageNet benchmarks. HAPQ provides a principled, automated framework for creating highly efficient models suitable for on-device inference without iterative, manual tuning.
subject: AI
title: Hessian-Aware Structured Pruning and Quantization for Efficient On-Device Transformer Deployment

text: This paper introduces a novel deep learning architecture for performing automated Schenkerian analysis directly from raw audio signals. Traditional computational approaches rely on symbolic score data, a significant limitation for un-transcribed corpora. Our proposed model leverages a multi-scale Constant-Q Transform (CQT) frontend to capture frequency information at varying temporal resolutions, feeding into a hierarchical transformer network. The architecture's self-attention mechanisms are specifically designed to model long-range dependencies inherent in tonal music's structural hierarchy. We train the system on a newly-curated dataset of paired audio recordings and expert-annotated Schenkerian graphs. The model learns to jointly predict fundamental line (Urlinie) descents, bass arpeggiations (Bassbrechung), and intermediate levels of melodic and harmonic prolongation (Stufen). Results demonstrate a significant improvement over baseline systems in identifying large-scale contrapuntal structures, offering a robust tool for machine-assisted structural listening and bridging the gap between Music Information Retrieval and advanced music-theoretic inquiry.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hierarchical Transformer Model for Schenkerian Analysis from Polyphonic Audio

text: The analysis of orchestration requires a nuanced understanding of how timbre and harmony interact to create musical texture. We propose a deep generative model based on a β-Variational Autoencoder (β-VAE) designed to disentangle these intertwined features from musical audio. By imposing an information bottleneck on the latent space and utilizing separate, non-overlapping latent variables for reconstructed chroma features and spectral envelope characteristics, our model learns a factorized representation. One latent subspace robustly encodes harmonic progression, exhibiting geometric properties consistent with tonal pitch space, while the other captures timbral information related to instrumentation and articulatory detail. We demonstrate the model's efficacy through re-synthesis experiments, where harmonic content can be held constant while timbral profiles are manipulated, and vice-versa. This framework provides a quantitative methodology for studying orchestration techniques, enabling large-scale comparative analysis of composers' timbral palettes and their relationship to underlying harmonic structures.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangling Timbre and Harmony: A Variational Autoencoder Approach for Computational Orchestration Analysis

text: Neo-Riemannian theory provides a powerful framework for analyzing chromatic harmony, yet its application to audio has been hampered by the complexities of polyphonic pitch estimation and the abstract nature of its transformations. This study presents a novel methodology that models harmonic progressions as paths on a dynamic graph. We first employ a multi-pitch estimation algorithm based on a probabilistic spectral model to extract pitch-class sets for short-time frames. These sets are treated as nodes in a Tonnetz-like graph structure. A Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) is then trained to classify the transitions (edges) between nodes as canonical Neo-Riemannian operations (P, L, R) or their compounds. The system effectively traces transformational pathways through complex harmonic textures, demonstrating high accuracy on a corpus of late-Romantic piano music. This approach operationalizes advanced music theory for audio analysis, enabling empirical investigations into transformational syntax at scale.
subject: Müzik
title: Graph-Theoretic Models of Neo-Riemannian Transformations in Polyphonic Audio Streams

text: This research addresses the challenge of inferring complex metrical structures, including hypermeter, from acoustic signals characterized by expressive timing variations. We formulate a Dynamic Bayesian Network (DBN) that models the hierarchical generation of musical rhythm. The model posits latent variables representing beat, tactus, and multiple hypermetric levels, which generate observed note onsets detected via a spectral flux-based algorithm. Crucially, the model incorporates a learned 'expression' component, allowing it to account for performance-specific deviations (e.g., rubato) from a mechanically precise metrical grid. Inference is performed using a particle Gibbs sampler, which estimates the posterior distribution over metrical structures given the audio. The system is evaluated on a diverse dataset of piano recordings, outperforming existing beat-tracking algorithms in both tactus identification and the plausible inference of multi-measure hypermetric periodicities, thus providing a robust probabilistic framework for analyzing rhythmic complexity in performance.
subject: Müzik
title: Bayesian Inference of Metrical Hierarchy and Hypermeter from Expressive Performance Audio

text: We investigate the application of Topological Data Analysis (TDA) for the unsupervised discovery of large-scale formal structures in musical audio. The methodology involves transforming an audio recording into a time-series of chroma vectors and embedding this series into a high-dimensional point cloud using time-delay embedding. We then analyze the topology of this point cloud using persistent homology, which captures the evolution of topological features (e.g., loops and voids) across different spatial scales. The resulting persistence diagrams and barcodes serve as a unique signature of the piece's harmonic structure. We demonstrate that significant features in the persistence diagram correspond to key structural boundaries and recurring thematic sections. By clustering segments based on the similarity of their topological signatures, our method achieves state-of-the-art performance in segmenting classical works into constituent formal sections (e.g., exposition, development, recapitulation) without prior training or musical knowledge.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Data Analysis of Chroma Feature Spaces for Unsupervised Musical Form Segmentation

text: This work explores the induction of music-theoretically meaningful representations of harmony directly from raw audio without human annotation. We adapt a contrastive self-supervised learning paradigm, treating temporally adjacent audio segments as positive pairs and non-adjacent segments as negative pairs. An encoder network, comprising a stack of strided convolutions, is trained to map audio spectrograms into a low-dimensional embedding space where positive pairs are close and negative pairs are distant. When trained on a massive, diverse corpus of Western tonal music, the learned embedding space exhibits a remarkable geometric structure isomorphic to the toroidal model of tonal pitch space. We demonstrate that distances and directions in this emergent space correlate strongly with music-theoretic concepts of harmonic distance and key relationships. Furthermore, features extracted from this pre-trained model serve as a powerful basis for downstream MIR tasks like chord recognition and key estimation, significantly outperforming fully supervised models trained on limited data.
subject: Müzik
title: Self-Supervised Learning of Tonal Pitch Space Geometry from Unannotated Audio Corpora

text: The principle of voice-leading parsimony, a cornerstone of contrapuntal and harmonic theory, has proven difficult to quantify in complex audio signals. This paper introduces a computational framework that leverages Optimal Transport (OT) theory to measure the voice-leading 'cost' between successive harmonic states extracted from polyphonic audio. Following multi-pitch estimation, each time-frame is represented as a weighted distribution of pitch classes. The Wasserstein distance (or Earth Mover's Distance) between consecutive distributions is then calculated, providing a principled measure of the minimal collective displacement of pitch content, which we posit as a robust proxy for voice-leading parsimony. We analyze a corpus spanning Renaissance polyphony to modern jazz, demonstrating that this OT-based metric effectively distinguishes between different textural and stylistic paradigms. The framework provides a continuous, perceptually relevant measure of contrapuntal efficiency, enabling fine-grained analysis of musical texture directly from an acoustic representation.
subject: Müzik
title: Modeling Voice-Leading Parsimony in Polyphonic Audio using Optimal Transport

text: The analysis of complex contrapuntal music, such as fugue, often requires concurrent examination of the score and its acoustic realization. We present a multimodal deep learning framework that jointly embeds symbolic score data and performance audio to identify and characterize contrapuntal devices. The system utilizes Optical Music Recognition (OMR) to process score images and a CQT-based CNN to process audio. A cross-modal attention mechanism learns an aligned, shared representation space where symbolic note events correspond to their acoustic counterparts. A subsequent graph-based network operates on this joint representation to detect instances of thematic imitation, inversion, and stretto. By leveraging the complementary strengths of both modalities—the precision of the score and the timbral and expressive nuance of the audio—our system achieves unprecedented accuracy in automated fugal analysis, providing a powerful tool for musicologists and theorists studying imitative counterpoint.
subject: Müzik
title: A Multimodal Framework for Contrapuntal Structure Discovery Integrating Symbolic Scores and Audio

text: This study enhances Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) for the task of source separation and instrumental identification by incorporating perceptually and music-theoretically informed constraints. Standard NMF decomposes a magnitude spectrogram into a set of spectral bases and their temporal activations, but the resulting components often lack musical coherence. Our proposed Constrained NMF (C-NMF) introduces several penalty terms into the optimization objective function. These include a harmonicity constraint that encourages spectral bases to conform to harmonic series, a temporal continuity constraint that promotes smooth activation patterns, and a sparsity constraint on activations to model intermittent instrumental entries. By optimizing this composite objective, C-NMF produces components that more closely correspond to individual instrumental lines or 'gestalts'. We demonstrate its superiority over standard NMF and other source separation techniques in identifying and isolating constituent voices in orchestral and chamber music excerpts, facilitating downstream timbral and harmonic analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Perceptually-Constrained Non-Negative Matrix Factorization for Identifying Instrumental Gestalts in Polyphonic Audio

text: This paper presents a novel approach for analyzing expressive performance by modeling deviations from a nominal score. We employ a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) architecture where the generator learns to transform a 'platonic', mechanically rendered version of a score into a plausible, expressive performance by manipulating micro-timing, dynamics, and articulation. The discriminator is trained to distinguish between these generated performances and recordings by human artists. Once trained, the generator's latent space forms a low-dimensional manifold representing a specific performance style. By projecting real performances onto this manifold, we can quantitatively characterize and compare them. We analyze a large dataset of Chopin mazurka performances, revealing distinct stylistic clusters corresponding to different pianists and historical periods. This methodology moves beyond simple statistical descriptions of expressive parameters, offering a powerful generative model of performance style that captures complex interdependencies between expressive dimensions.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Expressive Performance Deviations as a Stylistic Manifold Using Generative Adversarial Networks

text: The role of non-genetic inheritance in speciation remains a contentious frontier in evolutionary biology. Here, we investigate the contribution of transgenerational epigenetic variation to the establishment of reproductive isolation. Using whole-genome bisulfite sequencing and behavioral assays in a sympatric species pair of cichlid fish, we identify hundreds of differentially methylated regions (DMRs) associated with divergent mate preferences. Crucially, a subset of these epialleles, particularly those within CpG islands upstream of neurodevelopmental genes, are stably transmitted for at least three generations in the absence of continued environmental cues. Our cross-fostering experiments demonstrate that inherited methylation patterns, not learned behaviors, are the primary determinants of assortative mating. These findings provide compelling evidence that heritable epigenetic modifications can generate rapid and persistent behavioral isolation, thereby facilitating sympatric speciation by creating a 'soft' inheritance substrate upon which selection can act before the fixation of genetic differences.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance as a Driver of Incipient Sympatric Speciation

text: The co-evolutionary arms race between bacteria and their bacteriophage predators is a major driver of microbial diversity. While the adaptive dynamics of CRISPR-Cas immune systems are well-documented, the counter-adaptations in phages remain less understood. We conducted a large-scale comparative phylogenomic analysis of over 2,000 temperate phage genomes, focusing on the evolution of anti-CRISPR (Acr) proteins. Our results reveal that Acr loci exhibit extreme evolutionary lability and are overwhelmingly concentrated in genomic hotspots flanked by mobile genetic elements. We reconstructed numerous instances of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) of Acr cassettes between distantly related prophages, often resulting in the acquisition of a pre-adapted defense against the host's specific CRISPR-Cas subtype. These findings indicate that HGT, rather than de novo mutation, is the principal engine of Acr evolution, allowing phages to rapidly acquire novel immunomodulatory functions and fueling the perpetual Red Queen dynamics of host-parasite interactions.
subject: Evrim
title: Accelerated Evolution of Anti-CRISPR Loci via Horizontal Gene Transfer in Prophage Genomes

text: Reconstructing the deep evolutionary history of animals (Metazoa) has been plagued by conflicting phylogenetic signals, largely attributable to systematic biases and widespread gene tree discordance. We employ a phylogenomic approach, analyzing a dataset of 1,150 ultraconserved element (UCE) loci from 125 taxa representing all major metazoan phyla. Critically, we move beyond simple data concatenation by utilizing coalescent-based species tree methods (e.g., ASTRAL-III) that explicitly model incomplete lineage sorting (ILS), a major source of discordance in rapid, ancient radiations. Our results robustly support the monophyly of Porifera as the sister group to all other Metazoa and resolve the contentious placement of Ctenophora. By quantifying discordance across nodes, we demonstrate that ILS, rather than introgression, is the dominant confounding factor at the base of the animal tree. This study highlights the necessity of accommodating gene tree heterogeneity in deep phylogenetic inference to accurately resolve ancient evolutionary relationships.
subject: Evrim
title: Resolving Deep Metazoan Phylogeny: A Coalescent-Based Approach to Mitigate Gene Tree Discordance

text: The antagonistic pleiotropy (AP) hypothesis posits that senescence evolves because alleles beneficial in early life have deleterious effects later. Direct empirical evidence for this trade-off at the molecular level is scarce. We performed a longitudinal RNA-seq analysis on blood cells from a known-age cohort of a long-lived seabird, the wandering albatross (*Diomedea exulans*), spanning ages 5 to 45 years. By modeling gene expression trajectories, we identified a suite of genes whose expression patterns conform to the AP model. Specifically, genes involved in immune response and cellular proliferation showed high expression and positive selection signatures in young, reproductively active birds but were associated with pro-inflammatory pathways and reduced cellular maintenance (e.g., DNA repair, autophagy) in older individuals. These findings provide a transcriptomic-level validation of the AP hypothesis, demonstrating how life-history trade-offs are mechanistically arbitrated at the level of gene regulation.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Antagonistic Pleiotropy: Longitudinal Transcriptomics Reveals Age-Dependent Trade-offs

text: Adaptive radiations, characterized by rapid speciation and ecological diversification, are often triggered by the evolution of a key innovation. We investigated this phenomenon in the Neotropical cichlid subfamily Cichlinae, testing the hypothesis that the evolution of a functionally decoupled pharyngeal jaw apparatus catalyzed their explosive radiation. Using high-resolution 3D geometric morphometrics on craniofacial and pharyngeal skeletal elements combined with phylogenetic comparative methods, we demonstrate a significant shift in the rate of morphological evolution coinciding with the origin of this trait. This innovation facilitated a dramatic expansion of trophic morphospace, allowing descendant lineages to partition resources and occupy previously inaccessible ecological niches. Our analysis reveals a strong correlation between pharyngeal jaw disparity and species richness across clades, providing robust evidence that this key innovation was a primary catalyst for one of the most spectacular vertebrate adaptive radiations.
subject: Evrim
title: Eco-Morphological Divergence and Niche Partitioning Following a Key Innovation in Neotropical Cichlids

text: Convergent evolution, the independent origin of similar traits, provides powerful evidence for adaptation. While echolocation in bats and toothed whales is a classic example, its molecular underpinnings are thought to be restricted to a few key genes. We challenged this view by conducting a comprehensive phylogenetically controlled analysis of 2,326 orthologous genes associated with hearing and vision across 24 mammal species. Our screen for parallel amino acid substitutions revealed a statistically significant excess of convergence in dozens of genes within the auditory pathways of echolocating taxa, extending far beyond the well-documented *Prestin* and *TMC1*. These convergent substitutions were enriched in functional domains related to cochlear amplification and neural signal processing. Conversely, we identified parallel signatures of relaxed selection and pseudogenization in visual opsin genes. This study demonstrates that the evolution of a complex adaptive phenotype is underpinned by a widespread, coordinated suite of convergent molecular changes across a broad functional network.
subject: Evrim
title: Widespread Molecular Convergence in Sensory Genes Underpins the Evolution of Echolocation

text: Genomic structural variants, such as chromosomal inversions, can facilitate local adaptation by suppressing recombination between co-adapted alleles, forming 'supergenes'. We investigated the role of the cosmopolitan inversion In(3R)Payne in the climatic adaptation of *Drosophila melanogaster*. Using pooled whole-genome sequencing (Pool-Seq) from populations spanning a 2,000 km latitudinal cline in Australia, we demonstrate a steep cline in inversion frequency, strongly correlated with temperature and aridity gradients. Haplotype analysis revealed that the inverted arrangement carries a distinct suite of alleles in genes associated with stress resistance, metabolic rate, and developmental timing. Experimental evolution under simulated climatic conditions confirmed that the inversion increased in frequency significantly faster than unlinked SNPs with similar clinal patterns. Our results show how a single structural variant can capture a multi-locus adaptive complex, enabling rapid and cohesive response to spatially varying selection pressures and acting as a potent engine of local adaptation.
subject: Evrim
title: A Large Chromosomal Inversion Mediates Rapid Climatic Adaptation by Locking a Co-adapted Supergene Complex

text: The transition from unicellularity to obligate multicellularity represents a major transition in individuality, requiring the suppression of lower-level selection in favor of higher-level fitness. We developed a stochastic individual-based model to investigate the evolutionary dynamics that stabilize nascent multicellular collectives against internal conflict from 'cheater' cells that revert to selfish proliferation. Our simulations demonstrate that while clonal bottlenecking at reproduction is necessary, it is not sufficient to guarantee long-term stability. The critical evolutionary step is the evolution of a regulatory mechanism that enforces germ-soma differentiation, effectively sequestering the reproductive lineage and committing somatic cells to cooperative functions. Multilevel selection analysis shows that collectives with early and irreversible germ-soma specialization have significantly higher group-level fitness and can outcompete collectives prone to somatic cheaters. This work highlights conflict mediation via division of labor as a fundamental prerequisite for the evolution of complex organismality.
subject: Evrim
title: Conflict Mediation and the Evolution of Germ-Soma Differentiation: A Multilevel Selection Model

text: The extinction of Pleistocene megafauna is attributed to a combination of climate change and anthropogenic pressure, but the detailed population dynamics leading to their demise remain unclear. We performed shotgun sequencing on 25 ancient DNA samples from woolly mammoths (*Mammuthus primigenius*) spanning the last 50,000 years. Our analyses reveal a complex demographic history characterized by a significant admixture event with the more southerly Columbian mammoth (*Mammuthus columbi*) around 45,000 years BP, likely driven by climate-induced range shifts. Following this introgression, we used pairwise sequentially Markovian coalescent (PSMC) modeling to reconstruct a dramatic and rapid decline in effective population size (Ne) starting ~15,000 years BP, which predates the final extinction on mainland Eurasia. This demographic collapse is coincident with the Bølling-Allerød interstadial warming and the expansion of human Paleo-Indian populations, suggesting a synergistic impact of environmental and anthropogenic stressors drove this iconic species to the brink of extinction.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Reconstruction of Admixture and Demographic Collapse in Late Pleistocene Woolly Mammoths

text: The genic capture hypothesis posits that sexually selected ornaments are condition-dependent, thus acting as reliable indicators of an individual's overall genetic quality. We tested this long-standing hypothesis in a population of European starlings (*Sturnus vulgaris*), a species where male song complexity is a primary target of female choice. Using restriction site-associated DNA sequencing (RAD-seq), we correlated individual song repertoire size with genome-wide heterozygosity, a proxy for genetic diversity and fitness. We found a strong, positive relationship between song complexity and heterozygosity. Furthermore, deep sequencing of Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) class II loci revealed that males with more complex songs possessed a greater diversity of MHC alleles and carried a significantly lower endoparasite load. These results provide robust empirical support for the genic capture model, demonstrating that an elaborate sexual signal integrates information across numerous loci, thereby honestly advertising the genetic health and immunocompetence of the signaler.
subject: Evrim
title: Genic Capture in Action: Ornament Complexity Covaries with Genome-Wide Heterozygosity and Parasite Resistance

text: We investigate the emergence of spacetime geometry from quantum entanglement structures within a non-perturbative holographic duality context. This work introduces a novel tensor network model, based on a modified Multi-scale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (MERA), that maps a boundary conformal field theory (CFT) to a bulk gravitational theory. We demonstrate that the radial dimension of the emergent Anti-de Sitter (AdS) space is intrinsically linked to the renormalization group flow of entanglement in the boundary theory. By analyzing the geodesic distances between boundary regions, we reproduce the Ryu-Takayanagi formula for entanglement entropy as a direct consequence of the network's connectivity. Our results show that bulk locality and the satisfaction of the Einstein field equations at a linearized level arise from fundamental constraints on the multipartite entanglement structure of the boundary state, providing a concrete realization of the ER=EPR conjecture without relying on semi-classical approximations.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergent Spacetime from Entanglement Renormalization in a Non-Perturbative Holographic Framework

text: The persistent discrepancy between early and late-universe measurements of the Hubble constant (H₀) suggests the possibility of new physics beyond the ΛCDM model. We propose a resolution to this 'Hubble tension' through a dynamic dark energy model featuring a chameleon scalar field non-minimally coupled to the matter sector. Employing full numerical relativity simulations, we demonstrate that this coupling allows the scalar field's equation of state parameter, w(z), to evolve from w > -1 in the post-recombination era to w < -1 (the phantom divide) at low redshifts. This late-time phantom epoch provides additional acceleration, increasing the locally measured H₀ value without altering the sound horizon scale derived from CMB anisotropies. Our model satisfies observational constraints from Big Bang Nucleosynthesis and solar system tests, offering a self-consistent cosmological evolution that reconciles local and primordial observations of cosmic expansion.
subject: Fizik
title: Dynamical Resolution of the Hubble Tension via a Non-Minimally Coupled Chameleon Field

text: The fluctuation-dissipation theorem (FDT) is a cornerstone of equilibrium statistical mechanics, but its applicability to non-equilibrium systems remains limited. We derive a generalized FDT for a system of interacting particles subjected to both a time-correlated external driving force and a non-Markovian thermal bath. Using a generalized Langevin equation formalism incorporating a memory kernel, we analytically demonstrate that the traditional FDT is violated. The magnitude of this violation is shown to be directly proportional to the rate of entropy production and the information-theoretic path entropy associated with the non-conservative work performed on the system. Our results, corroborated by extensive stochastic simulations, establish a quantitative link between the breakdown of time-reversal symmetry at the microscopic level and the macroscopic thermodynamic dissipation, thereby providing a more fundamental framework for understanding the energetics and response functions of systems operating far from thermal equilibrium.
subject: Fizik
title: Generalized Fluctuation-Dissipation Relations in Driven Systems with Memory

text: We present a theoretical framework for dynamically inducing higher-order topological phases of matter via periodic driving. Specifically, we demonstrate that a conventional three-dimensional insulator, when irradiated with circularly polarized light, can be transformed into a Floquet second-order topological insulator. The periodic drive breaks time-reversal symmetry and modifies the bulk band structure, creating a non-trivial topology characterized by a dynamic second Chern number. This engineered bulk topology gives rise to protected, one-dimensional chiral hinge modes that propagate along the edges of the crystal, a phenomenon absent in the static system. We compute the quasi-energy spectrum and the local density of states to confirm the existence and chirality of these modes. Our findings suggest a novel, on-demand method for controlling topological transport phenomena in solid-state systems, opening pathways for reconfigurable topological electronic and photonic devices.
subject: Fizik
title: Floquet-Engineered Chiral Hinge Modes in a Three-Dimensional Second-Order Topological Insulator

text: The black hole information paradox highlights a fundamental conflict between general relativity and quantum mechanics. We propose a resolution within the AdS/CFT correspondence by postulating a non-isometric encoding of the black hole interior Hilbert space into the boundary CFT. This mapping evolves dynamically during evaporation, such that the entanglement wedge of the radiation system progressively includes portions of the black hole interior. We show this avoids the cloning paradox by violating assumptions of effective field theory behind the firewall argument. Our model, based on quantum extremal surface computations, naturally reproduces the Page curve for the entanglement entropy of Hawking radiation, ensuring unitarity of the evaporation process. Information is not lost but is encoded in subtle, non-local correlations in the boundary, corresponding to soft hair associated with the Bondi-Metzner-Sachs (BMS) symmetries at future null infinity, thus preserving quantum coherence.
subject: Fizik
title: Resolving the Black Hole Final State via Non-Isometric Bulk-to-Boundary Encoding

text: Quantum contextuality, the dependency of a measurement's outcome on the context of other compatible measurements, is a key feature distinguishing quantum mechanics from classical reality. We report a high-fidelity experimental violation of a novel hierarchy of Kochen-Specker (KS) inequalities using a single trapped Yb¹⁷¹⁺ ion as a qutrit (a three-level quantum system). By implementing sequences of high-fidelity single-qubit rotations and projective measurements, we test the KS inequality for an increasing number of measurement contexts. Our results demonstrate a statistically significant violation, exceeding the non-contextual hidden variable bound by 12 standard deviations for a 13-vector configuration. This experiment rigorously confirms contextuality in a single quantum system with minimal assumptions, places stringent bounds on non-contextual realistic models, and validates a crucial resource for measurement-based quantum computing and secure communication protocols.
subject: Fizik
title: Experimental Demonstration of Quantum Contextuality using a Hierarchy of Kochen-Specker Inequalities

text: We report a new experimental search for axion-like particles (ALPs) as a component of dark matter, focusing on the ALP-photon coupling, g_aγγ. Our experiment employs a spin-polarized cesium vapor as an optically pumped magnetometer to detect the oscillating effective magnetic field generated by the interaction of cosmic ALPs with a static 7-Tesla laboratory magnetic field. To surpass the standard quantum limit imposed by photon shot noise, we inject a frequency-tuned squeezed vacuum state into the detection channel of the polarimeter. This quantum enhancement technique reduces the measurement noise floor by 4.2 dB, allowing for an unprecedented level of sensitivity. We establish new, stringent upper limits on g_aγγ in the mass range from 10⁻¹² eV to 10⁻⁹ eV, constraining a significant portion of previously unexplored parameter space predicted by grand unified theories and astrophysical models, such as stellar cooling anomalies.
subject: Fizik
title: Search for Axion-Like Particles via Optically Pumped Magnetometry with Squeezed Vacuum Injection

text: Many-body localization (MBL) describes the breakdown of thermalization in isolated, disordered quantum systems. We experimentally investigate the ergodic-to-MBL transition using a programmable quantum simulator comprised of a one-dimensional array of up to 50 individually trapped ⁸⁷Rb atoms coupled via Rydberg states. Controllable disorder is introduced through a quasi-periodic potential landscape, tuning the strength of off-diagonal interactions. Following a quantum quench from an initial charge-density-wave state, we monitor the subsequent dynamics by measuring the system's population imbalance and bipartite entanglement entropy. We observe a distinct transition from ergodic behavior, characterized by rapid thermalization and volume-law entanglement growth, to an MBL phase where an initial state imbalance persists indefinitely and entanglement grows logarithmically. Our results provide a detailed characterization of this fundamental transition in a highly controlled, long-range interacting system, validating key theoretical predictions of MBL.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing the Many-Body Localization Transition in a Disordered Rydberg Atom Array

text: The energization of particles to non-thermal energies is a ubiquitous yet poorly understood phenomenon in astrophysical plasmas. Using large-scale, three-dimensional particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations of magnetic reconnection in a low-beta, weakly collisional plasma, we identify a dominant mechanism for electron acceleration. Our simulations show that the reconnection layer fragments due to the plasmoid instability, developing a turbulent state characterized by a cascade of merging magnetic islands and flux ropes. This environment generates a spectrum of kinetic Alfvén waves. We demonstrate that electrons are efficiently accelerated to relativistic energies not primarily within the reconnection exhausts, but via a stochastic second-order Fermi process as they scatter off the contracting and merging magnetic structures. The resulting particle energy spectrum naturally develops a power-law tail, f(E) ∝ E⁻ᵖ, with a spectral index p that is self-consistently determined by the turbulence level and the reconnection rate.
subject: Fizik
title: Electron Acceleration via Stochastic Fermi Mechanism in Turbulent Magnetic Reconnection

text: Chimera states, characterized by the paradoxical coexistence of synchronized and incoherent domains, represent a fundamental pattern in complex networks. Here, we report the discovery of a novel class of these states, termed spiral chimeras, in networks of non-locally coupled phase oscillators. By introducing a directed asymmetry into the network's adjacency matrix, we break the underlying rotational symmetry of the coupling kernel, a feature common in biological neural networks. Numerical simulations reveal that this asymmetry destabilizes stationary chimera states, leading to the spontaneous formation of coherent and incoherent domains organized into a rigid spiral pattern that rotates at a constant angular velocity. We develop a mean-field theory based on the Ott-Antonsen ansatz that quantitatively predicts the onset of the spiral chimera state and its rotational frequency as a function of the asymmetry and coupling range, thus expanding the known taxonomy of partial synchronization phenomena.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergence of Spiral Chimera States in Non-Locally Coupled Oscillator Networks with Asymmetric Topology

text: We investigate non-perturbative corrections to the Ryu-Takanayagi formula for holographic entanglement entropy in the context of the AdS/CFT correspondence. By employing a gravitational path integral formalism, we demonstrate that Euclidean wormholes connecting different replica manifolds contribute non-trivially to the Rényi entropy and its analytic continuation. These contributions, suppressed exponentially in the central charge and the inverse gravitational coupling, resolve apparent paradoxes in the entanglement structure of thermofield double states and offer a holographic realization of the island formula crucial for addressing the black hole information paradox. Our analysis reveals a subtle interplay between spacetime topology and the quantum error-correcting code structure of the holographic dictionary. We compute the leading-order wormhole correction for a bipartite system in AdS3/CFT2, showing it quantitatively matches expectations from gravitational fine-graining and provides a concrete mechanism for the emergence of the Page curve from the semi-classical gravity description, thereby linking quantum information theory directly to the quantum structure of spacetime.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Perturbative Corrections to Holographic Entanglement Entropy from Euclidean Wormholes

text: We theoretically investigate the thermal transport properties of a chiral spin liquid (CSL) state on the Kagome lattice, as described by a Chern-Simons-coupled fermionic parton model. By deriving an effective theory for the emergent spinons interacting with a U(1) gauge field, we compute the transverse thermal conductivity, κ_xy. Our results demonstrate the existence of a quantized thermal Hall effect, where κ_xy/T is proportional to the Chern number of the spinon band structure, even in the absence of an external magnetic field. This anomalous effect is a direct consequence of the spontaneous time-reversal symmetry breaking inherent to the CSL phase. We further analyze the role of quenched disorder, showing that while localization effects suppress the longitudinal conductivity, the topological quantization of the thermal Hall plateau remains robust. This provides a definitive experimental signature for identifying CSL phases in candidate materials like herbertsmithite, accessible via low-temperature thermal transport measurements.
subject: Fizik
title: Anomalous Thermal Hall Effect in a Chiral Spin Liquid on the Kagome Lattice

text: We propose a novel cosmological model wherein the accelerated expansion of the late-universe is driven by a scalar field coupled disformally to the metric tensor. This disformal coupling induces a modification to the gravitational dynamics that manifests as a dynamical dark energy component with a non-trivial equation of state, w(z). We derive the background Friedman equations and the equations for linear scalar perturbations in this framework. By performing a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) analysis against a combined dataset of CMB anisotropies from Planck, Baryon Acoustic Oscillations (BAO), and Type Ia supernovae (SNIa), we place constraints on the disformal coupling parameters. Our results show that the model provides a competitive fit to the data compared to the standard ΛCDM model while predicting a unique evolution for the growth of structure, δ(z), potentially alleviating tensions between local and high-redshift measurements of the Hubble constant and the σ8 parameter. Observational signatures in weak lensing surveys are discussed.
subject: Fizik
title: Dynamical Dark Energy from a Disformally Coupled Scalar Field and its Cosmological Signatures

text: We present a theoretical framework for the detection of axion-like particles (ALPs) via non-resonant inelastic scattering of high-energy photons in the presence of an intense laser field. In contrast to conventional light-shining-through-wall experiments, this approach probes the virtual ALP propagator off-shell, providing sensitivity to a broader mass-coupling parameter space. We calculate the differential cross-section for the process γ + nω → γ' where a probe photon scatters off n photons from a petawatt-class laser pulse. The calculation is performed within the framework of strong-field QED, treating the laser field non-perturbatively using the Volkov basis. We find that the angular distribution and energy spectrum of the scattered photon γ' exhibit distinctive signatures of the ALP's spin-parity and coupling strength. Our analysis indicates that upcoming facilities like the Extreme Light Infrastructure (ELI) could probe ALP-photon couplings down to g_aγγ ≈ 10⁻¹² GeV⁻¹, surpassing existing astrophysical and laboratory constraints in the sub-eV mass range.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Axion-Like Particles through Non-Resonant Inelastic Photon-Photon Scattering at High-Intensity Laser Facilities

text: We investigate the breakdown of the fluctuation-dissipation theorem (FDT) in a model system of a two-dimensional granular fluid subjected to steady-state shear forcing. Through large-scale event-driven molecular dynamics simulations, we simultaneously measure the response function R(t,t_w) from an impulsive perturbation and the time-correlation function C(t,t_w) of spontaneous fluctuations. We find a significant violation of the FDT in the low-frequency, long-wavelength limit. The data are well-described by a modified FDT relation where the thermodynamic temperature T is replaced by an effective temperature T_eff, which depends on the shear rate and particle inelasticity. We construct a kinetic theory model based on a mode-coupling approach that qualitatively reproduces the observed T_eff and its dependence on system parameters. Our results demonstrate that for this class of non-equilibrium steady states, a quasi-thermodynamic description may be partially salvaged, though it requires a frequency-dependent effective temperature, challenging the notion of a single thermodynamic-like variable for far-from-equilibrium systems.
subject: Fizik
title: Fluctuation-Dissipation Violations and Effective Temperatures in a Driven Granular Fluid

text: We introduce a geometric measure of genuine multipartite entanglement, the hyperdeterminantal tangle, and apply it to study quantum phase transitions in the frustrated J1-J2 Heisenberg spin-1/2 chain. Using density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) methods, we compute the ground state wavefunction and the corresponding reduced density matrices for various subsystem partitions. Our analysis reveals that the hyperdeterminantal tangle exhibits pronounced non-analytic behavior precisely at the quantum critical points of the model, including the Berezinskii-Kosterlitz-Thouless transition to a dimerized phase and the emergence of a vector chiral phase. Unlike bipartite measures such as concurrence, which are insensitive to the global entanglement structure, our multipartite measure acts as a sensitive order parameter for topologically complex quantum phases. This work establishes a robust connection between concepts from quantum information geometry and the characterization of many-body quantum criticality in strongly correlated systems, offering a new tool for identifying exotic phases of matter.
subject: Fizik
title: Geometric Measures of Multipartite Entanglement and Quantum Phase Transitions in Frustrated Spin Chains

text: We calculate the tensor-mode gravitational wave (GW) memory arising from anisotropic neutrino and magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) ejecta in core-collapse supernovae of highly magnetized progenitor stars (magnetars). This non-oscillatory, persistent spacetime strain is a key prediction of general relativity, sourced by the net change in the anisotropic stress-energy tensor. Using a suite of 3D general-relativistic MHD simulations, we model the explosion dynamics and compute the resulting GW memory waveform. We find that for magnetar-driven events, the memory amplitude can be up to an order of magnitude larger than in standard neutrino-driven explosions, reaching h_mem ∼ 10⁻²³ for a galactic event at 10 kpc. While undetectable by current interferometers, such an event would induce a characteristic signature in the timing residuals of millisecond pulsars. We assess the detection prospects for existing and future Pulsar Timing Arrays (PTAs), demonstrating that a single galactic magnetar event could be detectable with high significance, providing a novel probe of supernova engine physics and the asymptotic symmetries of spacetime.
subject: Fizik
title: Tensor-Mode Gravitational Wave Memory from Magnetar-Driven Supernovae and its Detection via Pulsar Timing Arrays

text: We propose a realistic scheme for realizing a bosonic analogue of the fractional quantum Hall Laughlin state using ultracold atoms in a periodically modulated optical lattice. By applying a combination of a static potential gradient and two-frequency periodic lattice shaking, we engineer a synthetic magnetic field with a large flux per plaquette and induce strong, tunable, repulsive few-body interactions via a Feshbach resonance.
