This Floquet engineering scheme dynamically generates a Hamiltonian whose ground state, within a truncated Hilbert space, exhibits high fidelity with the ν=1/2 Laughlin wavefunction. We perform exact diagonalization and density-matrix renormalization group calculations to verify the topological nature of the ground state, characterized by a fractional Chern number, a quasi-degenerate manifold of states on a torus, and a robust spectral gap. Our protocol circumvents the stringent requirements of rapidly rotating Bose-Einstein condensates and provides a flexible platform for exploring strongly correlated topological phases of matter.
subject: Fizik
title: Realization of a Laughlin-like State for Ultracold Bosons via Floquet-Engineered Artificial Gauge Fields

text: We investigate the stabilizing effects of a dynamically generated sheared-axial magnetic field on the growth of magneto-Rayleigh-Taylor (MRT) instabilities during the implosion of a cylindrical liner, a critical challenge in magnetized liner inertial fusion (MagLIF). Using three-dimensional extended-magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) simulations with the Gorgon code, we model the self-generation of an azimuthal magnetic field (B_θ) via the Seebeck effect at the liner-fuel interface, which combines with the pre-imposed axial field (B_z) to create a dynamic screw pinch configuration. Our simulations reveal that the resulting magnetic shear significantly mitigates the growth of the most destructive MRT modes. We present a linear stability analysis that quantifies the reduction in growth rate as a function of the magnetic shear, finding excellent agreement with the full simulations. This dynamic stabilization mechanism relaxes the stringent liner surface finish requirements for achieving ignition-relevant conditions, suggesting a more robust operational window for the MagLIF concept and similar magneto-inertial fusion schemes.
subject: Fizik
title: Suppression of Magneto-Rayleigh-Taylor Instabilities in Magnetized Liner Inertial Fusion through Dynamic Screw Pinch Stabilization

text: We develop a field-theoretic framework to describe the large-scale organization of interphase chromosomes, modeling chromatin as a semi-flexible polymer melt subject to active processes of loop extrusion. The model incorporates quenched disorder representing cohesin-binding sites and steric interactions between chromosomal segments. By employing polymer field theory and replica-method calculations, we analytically derive the statistical properties of the steady-state configuration. Our results demonstrate that the interplay between loop extrusion dynamics and topological constraints naturally leads to the formation of a 'fractal globule' state, characterized by a power-law decay of the contact probability P(s) ~ s⁻¹, consistent with experimental Hi-C data over a wide range of genomic distances. The model predicts a specific scaling relationship between the average size of topologically-associating domains (TADs) and cohesin processivity. This work unifies the loop extrusion and fractal globule models, providing a first-principles, physics-based explanation for the multi-scale architecture of the eukaryotic nucleus.
subject: Fizik
title: A Field-Theoretic Polymer Model of Interphase Chromatin Organization Driven by Topologically-Associating Domain Formation

text: We present a comprehensive numerical analysis of the stability and braiding fidelity of Majorana zero modes (MZMs) in realistic models of InAs-Al hybrid nanowires. Utilizing a tight-binding Hamiltonian within the Bogoliubov-de Gennes formalism, we simulate the braiding of MZMs by manipulating gate-defined potentials in a T-junction geometry. Our investigation focuses on the impact of non-adiabatic effects, quasi-particle poisoning, and bulk-state hybridization on the unitary braiding transformation. We quantify decoherence channels by coupling the system to a phononic bath and calculating the decay of the off-diagonal elements of the reduced density matrix. The results indicate that while topological protection provides inherent robustness, fidelity rapidly degrades with increased braiding velocity and thermal quasi-particle population. We identify an optimal operational regime, demonstrating that braiding operations with fidelities exceeding 99.9% are achievable under cryogenic conditions and with refined gate-voltage protocols, a critical requirement for scalable topological quantum computation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence and Non-Abelian Braiding Fidelity of Majorana Zero Modes in Semiconductor-Superconductor Heterostructures

text: This work investigates the relationship between boundary entanglement and bulk geometry in a (d+1)-dimensional de Sitter (dS) spacetime using the framework of holographic duality. We propose an extension of the Ryu-Takayanagi formula, incorporating the quantum extremal surface prescription, to calculate the entanglement entropy of subregions in the boundary conformal field theory (CFT) residing on the future timelike infinity. Our analysis reveals that the inclusion of the 'island' contribution is essential for preserving the unitarity of spacetime evolution, particularly for regions encompassing the cosmological horizon. We employ a tensor network model, specifically the Multiscale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (MERA), to provide a discrete realization of the dS/CFT correspondence. The connectivity of the tensor network is shown to directly encode the causal structure of the bulk spacetime, offering a novel, information-theoretic perspective on the emergence of gravity and the resolution of the dS information paradox.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Renormalization and Bulk Causal Structure in de Sitter Spacetime

text: We theoretically analyze the open quantum system dynamics of a multi-qubit array coupled to a structured reservoir, specifically a photonic crystal with a band-edge. By employing a time-convolutionless (TCL) master equation approach, we move beyond the Born-Markov approximation to capture non-Markovian memory effects. The reservoir's spectral density, characterized by a sharp cutoff and a van Hove singularity, induces significant information backflow, which we quantify using the Breuer-Laine-Piilo (BLP) measure. Our results demonstrate that entanglement between distant qubits can be robustly preserved and even dynamically revived due to the reservoir's memory kernel. We show that the entanglement dynamics, quantified by the concurrence, exhibits pronounced oscillatory behavior, starkly contrasting with the monotonic decay predicted by standard Lindblad master equations. These findings have profound implications for designing quantum memories and communication channels in solid-state quantum information processing architectures.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Markovian Dynamics and Entanglement Preservation in a Multi-Qubit System Coupled to a Structured Photonic Crystal Reservoir

text: We report on a large-scale numerical study using the density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) method to investigate the ground state properties of the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE) in magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene at a filling fraction of ν=12/5. By mapping the continuum Landau level problem onto a lattice Hamiltonian with a long-range Coulomb interaction, we simulate the system on an infinite cylinder geometry. Our analysis of the ground-state degeneracy, entanglement spectrum, and topological central charge provides compelling evidence for a topological phase described by the Read-Rezayi Z_3 parafermion conformal field theory. The low-lying excitations are identified as non-Abelian Fibonacci anyons, whose braiding properties are sufficient for universal topological quantum computation. This result establishes twisted bilayer graphene as a promising, non-Gallium-Arsenide platform for realizing exotic quasiparticle states essential for fault-tolerant quantum information processing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent Non-Abelian Fibonacci Anyons in the ν=12/5 Fractional Quantum Hall State in Twisted Bilayer Graphene

text: We propose and numerically verify a high-fidelity protocol for the deterministic generation of multi-component Schrödinger cat states within a high-Q superconducting microwave cavity coupled to a transmon qubit. The protocol utilizes a sequence of optimized, resonant and off-resonant microwave pulses, engineered via quantum optimal control techniques (GRAPE algorithm), to precisely steer the cavity state's evolution in phase space. The quantum state is characterized by calculating its Wigner function, which exhibits multiple, well-separated negative regions, confirming the macroscopic quantum coherence. We analyze the state's metrological potential by computing its quantum Fisher information, demonstrating a sensitivity scaling that approaches the Heisenberg limit. The protocol's robustness against qubit decoherence (T1, T2) and photon loss is evaluated, showing that state fidelities exceeding 95% for a four-component cat state are feasible with current state-of-the-art 3D cavity QED systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Deterministic Generation of High-Fidelity Multi-Component Schrödinger Cat States in a 3D Cavity QED Architecture

text: We present a first-principles calculation of the shear viscosity to entropy density ratio (η/s) for the quark-gluon plasma using lattice quantum chromodynamics (QCD). The calculation is performed on large, anisotropic lattices with 2+1 flavors of Highly Improved Staggered Quarks (HISQ) at a physical pion mass. The shear viscosity is extracted from the Euclidean vector current correlator via the Kubo formula, requiring a rigorous analytic continuation of the lattice data. To address this ill-posed problem, we employ the Bayesian Reconstruction (BR) method, constrained by perturbative QCD results at high frequencies. Our analysis, conducted over a temperature range of 180-300 MeV, yields a value for η/s that exhibits a minimum near the pseudo-critical temperature T_c. The results provide a crucial quantitative benchmark for hydrodynamic models of heavy-ion collisions and support the conjecture of the quark-gluon plasma behaving as a near-perfect fluid.
subject: Kuantum
title: Shear Viscosity of Quark-Gluon Plasma from Anisotropic Lattice QCD Simulations

text: We propose a loophole-free experimental protocol to test the Leggett-Garg inequality, a temporal analogue of Bell's inequality that constrains the validity of macrorealism. The proposed system consists of a silica nanosphere optically levitated in an ultra-high vacuum, with its center-of-mass motion cooled to the quantum ground state. A series of quantum non-demolition (QND) measurements of the nanosphere's position are performed by detecting the phase shift of a weak, reflected probe beam. This QND scheme critically mitigates the 'clumsiness' loophole inherent in many previous tests. By correlating the outcomes of measurements performed at different times, we can construct a temporal correlation function that is predicted to violate the Leggett-Garg inequality by more than 10 standard deviations. Such a result would provide a definitive refutation of macrorealism for a massive object, pushing the boundary of the quantum-classical divide.
subject: Kuantum
title: Testing Macrorealism with Quantum Non-Demolition Measurements of a Levitated Nanosphere

text: We theoretically demonstrate the existence and unique physical properties of a fourth-order exceptional point (EP4) in a non-Hermitian photonic system composed of coupled whispering-gallery-mode microresonators with precisely engineered gain and loss profiles. The system Hamiltonian exhibits a characteristic E_4 Jordan block structure, where four complex eigenvalues and their corresponding eigenvectors coalesce simultaneously. At this EP4, we observe a giant, topologically protected chiral response, where light transmission becomes unidirectional and is robust against significant structural disorder. Furthermore, we show that the frequency splitting response to a local perturbation scales as ε^(1/4), a drastic enhancement compared to the linear response in Hermitian systems or the ε^(1/2) scaling at a standard EP2. This extreme sensitivity, combined with topological protection, opens new avenues for ultra-precise sensing, robust optical switching, and novel laser mode control.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topologically Protected Chiral Transport at a Fourth-Order Exceptional Point in a Non-Hermitian Photonic Metamaterial

text: We propose a quantum metrology protocol for a distributed network of N optical sensors designed to detect a global phase shift, such as that induced by a stochastic gravitational wave background. The protocol leverages the preparation of a global N-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) state across the spatially separated nodes via a hierarchical entanglement swapping scheme. Local interaction with the signal field imprints a phase φ on each sensor, transforming the state into |GHZ_φ⟩. Subsequent collective Bell-basis measurements and classical communication allow for the extraction of the phase with a precision scaling as 1/N, achieving the fundamental Heisenberg limit. This represents a significant improvement over the standard quantum limit (1/√N) achievable with N unentangled sensors. We analyze the protocol's robustness against photon loss and phase decoherence, demonstrating its feasibility for next-generation astrophysical observatories and long-baseline interferometry.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Phase Estimation in a Distributed Sensor Network using Entangled GHZ States

text: We investigate the breakdown of thermalization in a one-dimensional disordered Bose-Hubbard model using extensive numerical simulations based on the time-evolving block decimation (TEBD) algorithm. Starting from an unentangled product state, we study the dynamics of entanglement entropy and operator spreading across the many-body localization (MBL) transition. In the ergodic, thermalizing phase, we observe a rapid, linear growth of entanglement entropy saturating at a volume-law value. Conversely, deep in the MBL phase, the entanglement entropy exhibits a characteristic slow, logarithmic growth in time, indicating the persistence of local quantum information. We further probe the system's dynamics by calculating the out-of-time-order correlator (OTOC), which reveals a logarithmic light cone in the MBL phase, in stark contrast to the ballistic propagation in the ergodic regime. These results provide a comprehensive characterization of MBL as a distinct dynamical phase of matter.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Growth and Operator Spreading in the Many-Body Localized Phase of a Disordered Bose-Hubbard Model

text: The AdS/CFT correspondence offers a non-perturbative definition of quantum gravity, yet understanding information recovery from black holes requires progressing beyond semi-classical approximations. We investigate this problem within the framework of Jackiw-Teitelboim (JT) gravity coupled to a conformal field theory. By computing the entanglement entropy of Hawking radiation, we derive a generalized island formula that incorporates non-perturbative instanton contributions, representing spacetime wormholes. Our results reveal a modified Page curve, demonstrating a late-time saturation of entropy that precisely matches the Bekenstein-Hawking entropy of the remnant black hole, thereby resolving the information paradox. This analytic framework provides a calculable model where unitarity is preserved through topological effects in the gravitational path integral. The findings underscore the critical role of non-local spacetime correlations, mediated by replica wormholes, in the dynamics of quantum information during black hole evaporation, offering a concrete realization of the holographic principle.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Non-Perturbative Corrections in JT Gravity

text: Primordial non-Gaussianity (PNG) serves as a crucial discriminant between models of cosmic inflation. We present a novel framework for constraining PNG by synergistically combining cosmic microwave background (CMB) temperature and E-mode polarization data with galaxy survey measurements of large-scale structure (LSS). Our methodology focuses on the computation of the CMB-galaxy-galaxy bispectrum, a three-point correlator that is exceptionally sensitive to the local-type PNG parameter, f_NL. Using Fisher matrix forecasts for next-generation experiments such as CMB-S4 and the Euclid survey, we demonstrate a significant improvement in the constraints on f_NL, effectively breaking parameter degeneracies inherent in CMB-only or LSS-only analyses. The formalism rigorously incorporates scale-dependent galaxy bias, redshift-space distortions, and relativistic projection effects. Our analysis establishes that cross-correlation bispectra will provide a powerful, complementary probe of the physics of the primordial universe, capable of placing stringent limits on entire classes of multi-field inflationary models.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraining Primordial Non-Gaussianity through Bispectrum Analysis of CMB-LSS Cross-Correlations

text: Majorana zero modes (MZMs), non-Abelian anyons predicted to exist in topological superconductors, are foundational for fault-tolerant quantum computation. We report on the fabrication and characterization of hybrid devices comprising an InAs nanowire with an epitaxial Al shell, electrostatically coupled to a quantum dot. Low-temperature transport spectroscopy under an axial magnetic field reveals a persistent zero-bias conductance peak. Critically, by precisely tuning gate voltages to operate in the resonant Andreev reflection regime, we observe conductance plateaus quantized at 2e²/h. This quantization is a distinctive signature of perfect Andreev reflection mediated by an isolated MZM hybridized with the quantum dot. The observation is robust over a significant range of magnetic fields and gate voltages, distinguishing it from topologically trivial Andreev bound states. This result provides compelling evidence for the topological nature of the zero-energy state, advancing beyond the ambiguity of non-quantized peaks and marking a significant step towards MZM manipulation.
subject: Fizik
title: Observation of Quantized Conductance in a Proximity-Induced Topological Superconductor-Quantum Dot Heterostructure

text: The interplay of periodic driving and strong disorder can engender novel non-equilibrium phases of matter. We investigate the stability of many-body localization (MBL) against a time-periodic drive by numerically simulating a one-dimensional disordered Heisenberg spin chain. Utilizing time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (t-DMRG) methods, we map the system's dynamical phase diagram. We identify a sharp transition from an MBL phase, characterized by logarithmic entanglement growth and the persistence of local memory, to an ergodic thermalized phase. The transition is diagnosed by analyzing the spectral properties of the system's Floquet operator; the level spacing statistics undergo a crossover from Poissonian to Wigner-Dyson, signaling the onset of quantum chaos. Our findings establish the existence of a prethermal MBL regime that resists heating for exponentially long times, providing fundamental insights into the principles of quantum thermalization and its systematic avoidance in periodically driven, strongly interacting systems.
subject: Fizik
title: Dynamical Phase Transition and Ergodicity Breaking in a Floquet-Engineered Many-Body System

text: Direct measurement of the trilinear Higgs self-coupling (λ_HHH) is paramount for probing the structure of the electroweak symmetry-breaking potential and for constraining a wide array of Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) theories. We present a comprehensive phenomenological study of di-Higgs (HH) production at a future 100 TeV proton-proton collider. Our analysis combines multiple final states, including bbγγ, bbττ, and bbbb, implementing advanced event reconstruction algorithms and multivariate analysis techniques within a realistic detector simulation framework. By performing a combined fit across these channels, we project a measurement precision of approximately 5-8% for the Standard Model Higgs self-coupling with an integrated luminosity of 30 ab⁻¹. This unprecedented sensitivity allows for the robust discrimination between the Standard Model prediction and deviations predicted by BSM scenarios such as composite Higgs models and theories of electroweak baryogenesis, demonstrating the profound discovery potential of a future hadron collider.
subject: Fizik
title: Projected Sensitivity to the Trilinear Higgs Self-Coupling at a 100 TeV Proton-Proton Collider

text: Probing the foundations of quantum mechanics necessitates testing the limits of nonlocality in increasingly complex multipartite systems. We report the generation and characterization of a ten-photon entangled state possessing a linear cluster graph topology. The state is produced via multi-source spontaneous parametric down-conversion and routed through a programmable photonic integrated circuit for state manipulation and analysis. High-fidelity quantum state tomography yields a reconstructed density matrix with a state fidelity of 0.62 ± 0.03. To demonstrate genuine multipartite nonlocality, we perform measurements in optimized bases and test a Mermin-Ardehali-Belinskii-Klyshko (MABK) inequality tailored for this state. We observe a violation of the local realistic bound by over twelve standard deviations. This experiment represents a substantial increase in the controlled complexity of photonic entanglement, pushing the boundaries of nonlocality tests and developing a critical resource for measurement-based quantum computing and sophisticated quantum communication protocols.
subject: Fizik
title: Experimental Violation of a Mermin-Ardehali-Belinskii-Klyshko Inequality with a Ten-Photon Graph State

text: The stochastic gravitational-wave background (SGWB) is a key cosmological relic predicted by numerous early-universe phenomena, including the decay of a cosmic string network. We develop a sophisticated Bayesian framework to search for characteristic anisotropies in the SGWB using simulated data from a network of next-generation gravitational-wave observatories. The SGWB from cosmic strings is predicted to be highly anisotropic, dominated by powerful but rare bursts from cusps and kinks. By modeling the angular power spectrum C(l) of these anisotropies, our analysis demonstrates that even with a null detection of the isotropic background, an anisotropic search can place exceptionally stringent upper limits on the dimensionless string tension Gμ. We forecast the potential to constrain Gμ < 10⁻¹⁴, surpassing current and projected limits from CMB and pulsar timing array observations. This work establishes anisotropic searches as a powerful, independent probe of fundamental physics in the nascent universe.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraints on Cosmic String Tension from Anisotropies in the Stochastic Gravitational-Wave Background

text: Chimera states, wherein coherent and incoherent dynamics coexist in a network of identical oscillators, are a paradigm of spontaneous symmetry breaking. We theoretically investigate the quantum analogue of this phenomenon in a one-dimensional array of non-locally coupled transmon qubits driven by a common microwave field. By numerically solving the Lindblad master equation for the N-qubit density matrix, we analyze the system's non-equilibrium steady states. We identify a robust parameter regime where the system evolves into a stable quantum chimera state, characterized by a spatial domain of phase-locked qubits coexisting with a domain of desynchronized, decohering qubits. This exotic state is diagnosed by a pronounced spatial gradient in the entanglement entropy and a bifurcation in the Wigner function distribution. We propose an experimental protocol for verifying these signatures using state-of-the-art circuit QED platforms, thus bridging classical nonlinear dynamics with quantum many-body physics.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergence of Quantum Chimera States in a Non-Locally Coupled Superconducting Qubit Array

text: The quantum spin liquid (QSL) is an enigmatic state of matter characterized by long-range entanglement and fractionalized excitations, which avoids conventional magnetic order. We present a comprehensive investigation of the candidate QSL material Yb₂Ti₂O₇ using high-resolution inelastic neutron scattering (INS) and low-temperature specific heat measurements under applied magnetic fields. Our specific heat data show no evidence of a phase transition down to 50 mK, but reveal a broad feature consistent with a quantum spin ice state. The INS data, collected at sub-kelvin temperatures, display a broad continuum of scattering, a hallmark of deconfined fractionalized excitations. The momentum-space structure of this continuum, particularly its pinch-point-like features, is quantitatively consistent with the presence of a spinon Fermi surface emerging from a U(1) QSL state. Our results provide compelling evidence for this exotic quantum state in Yb₂Ti₂O₇, establishing it as a key material platform for studying emergent gauge fields and gapless spinon quasiparticles.
subject: Fizik
title: Fractionalized Excitations and a Spinon Fermi Surface in the Pyrochlore Antiferromagnet Yb₂Ti₂O₇

text: Determining the phase diagram of strongly coupled gauge theories as a function of the number of fermion flavors (N_f) is a fundamental problem in quantum field theory with profound implications for beyond-Standard Model physics. We perform large-scale lattice QCD simulations of SU(3) gauge theory with N_f = 10 fundamental fermions, employing the domain wall fermion formulation to maintain precise chiral symmetry. Using the gradient flow to define a renormalized coupling non-perturbatively, we study its scale dependence to probe for an infrared fixed point (IRFP). Our simulations provide strong evidence for an IRFP, signifying that this theory is conformal, or at least near-conformal, in the infrared. We calculate the mass anomalous dimension γ_m at the IRFP, finding γ_m = 0.31(3). This value is critical for constraining composite Higgs and walking technicolor models. This work precisely delineates the lower edge of the conformal window, providing a vital benchmark for non-perturbative field theory.
subject: Fizik
title: Lattice QCD Investigation of the Conformal Window in SU(3) Gauge Theory with Ten Fermion Flavors

text: We investigate the connection between entanglement entropy and the emergence of spacetime geometry in a de Sitter (dS) background. By extending the Ryu-Takanayagi prescription, we propose a covariant holographic entanglement entropy formula applicable to cosmological horizons. Our analysis reveals that subregions of the dS static patch can be represented as a quantum error-correcting code, where the bulk logical operators are protected against boundary erasures. This framework provides a concrete realization of the ER=EPR conjecture in a cosmological context, suggesting that spacetime connectivity is fundamentally linked to quantum entanglement. We compute the Page curve for an evaporating black hole in dS space, demonstrating that our formalism resolves the information paradox in a manner consistent with unitarity. This work provides new insights into the quantum nature of gravity in an expanding universe by linking concepts from quantum information theory to the structure of cosmological spacetimes.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Quantum Error Correction in de Sitter Spacetime

text: We theoretically investigate the non-equilibrium dynamics of a two-dimensional chiral Bose-Einstein condensate following a rapid quench across a quantum critical point from a non-chiral to a chiral superfluid phase. Using truncated Wigner approximation simulations, we analyze the formation and evolution of topological defects, specifically vortex-antivortex pairs with a net chirality. Our results show a deviation from the standard Kibble-Zurek scaling for defect density, which we attribute to the long-range interactions mediated by the chiral edge modes. We characterize the post-quench relaxation process through the evolution of the momentum distribution and two-point correlation functions, identifying distinct temporal regimes governed by different physical mechanisms. This study elucidates the universal aspects of defect formation in systems with broken time-reversal symmetry and offers a new platform for exploring the interplay between topology and non-equilibrium quantum statistical mechanics in ultracold atomic gases.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Equilibrium Dynamics of a Chiral Bose-Einstein Condensate Quenched Across a Quantum Critical Point

text: We explore novel signatures of Lorentz Invariance Violation (LIV) in the polarization content of gravitational waves (GWs) propagating through an anisotropic cosmological background. Within the framework of the Standard-Model Extension (SME), anisotropic LIV coefficients couple the standard tensor polarizations to non-transverse vector and scalar modes, which are otherwise forbidden in General Relativity. We derive the modified geodesic deviation equation and propagation eigenvectors for GWs in a Bianchi Type I spacetime endowed with a background tensor field. Our analysis predicts a frequency-dependent rotation of the polarization plane and the generation of up to four additional polarization modes. These effects would manifest as anomalous antenna patterns in pulsar timing arrays and next-generation interferometers. We propose that observing the stochastic GW background could place stringent constraints on the SME coefficients, potentially orders of magnitude more sensitive than existing astrophysical or laboratory-based limits.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Lorentz Invariance Violation through Gravitational Wave Polarizations from Anisotropic Cosmological Backgrounds

text: We introduce a covariant framework for quantifying quantum computational complexity in curved spacetimes, bridging quantum information theory and geometrodynamics. By treating the space of quantum states as an infinite-dimensional Kähler manifold equipped with the Fubini-Study metric, we define complexity as the length of the shortest geodesic path from a simple reference state to a target state, optimized over a set of allowed unitary operations. This 'path integral optimization' approach is manifestly diffeomorphism-invariant. We apply this formalism to a scalar field theory on a Schwarzschild background, calculating the complexity of formation for a Hartle-Hawking state. The results exhibit a dual relationship to the 'Complexity=Volume' conjecture in AdS/CFT correspondence, suggesting a deep connection between the geometry of quantum state space and the geometry of spacetime itself. This framework provides a new tool for investigating black hole information paradoxes and the fundamental nature of spacetime.
subject: Fizik
title: Geometrodynamics of Quantum Information: A Covariant Framework for Complexity in Curved Spacetime

text: We present a theoretical study on the emergence of the Fractional Quantum Hall Effect (FQHE) in twisted bilayer graphene (TBG) near the magic angle, under a strong perpendicular magnetic field. Our analysis reveals the formation of robust incompressible quantum fluid states at fractional filling factors ν corresponding to non-integer effective Landau levels, a phenomenon unique to the moiré superlattice potential. We employ a composite fermion model adapted to the Dirac-like, flattened minibands of TBG. The interaction-driven gaps are computed using a modified Chern-Simons field theory that incorporates the moiré periodicity. We find that the interplay between the superlattice potential and the magnetic field leads to a unique hierarchy of FQHE states not present in conventional semiconductor quantum wells. Our predictions for the energy gaps and charge signatures of these novel correlated electron states are experimentally verifiable via transport and compressibility measurements, opening a new frontier for many-body physics.
subject: Fizik
title: Fractional Quantum Hall Effect in Twisted Bilayer Graphene at Non-Integer Landau Levels

text: We derive a generalized Thermodynamic Uncertainty Relation (TUR) for periodically driven (Floquet) open quantum systems described by a Lindblad quantum master equation. The TUR establishes a fundamental trade-off between the precision of any time-integrated current, its mean value, and the total entropy production rate. Our derivation utilizes a large deviation approach applied to the tilted master operator within the Floquet-Hilbert space. We demonstrate that for periodically driven systems, the conventional TUR bound is modified by a term dependent on the system's micromotion and non-adiabatic contributions arising from the driving protocol. We apply our formalism to a model of a quantum heat engine, showing that the TUR constrains the power-efficiency trade-off beyond classical thermodynamic bounds. This work extends the powerful framework of thermodynamic uncertainty to the quantum Floquet regime, providing critical insights into the design principles for high-precision quantum thermal machines.
subject: Fizik
title: Thermodynamic Uncertainty Relations for Periodically Driven Open Quantum Systems

text: We investigate the phenomenon of spontaneous scalarization in rapidly rotating Kerr black holes within the framework of Einstein-Gauss-Bonnet-Dilaton (EGBD) gravity. By performing a non-perturbative analysis of the scalar field equation on a fixed Kerr background, we identify a critical spin threshold above which the scalar-free solution becomes unstable to a tachyonic instability. This instability triggers the development of a non-trivial scalar field configuration, or 'hair,' which significantly modifies the multipolar structure of the spacetime. We numerically construct stationary, axisymmetric black hole solutions with scalar hair and compute their key properties, including mass, angular momentum, and quadrupole moment. The existence of these scalarized Kerr black holes represents a violation of the no-hair theorem and has profound implications for gravitational wave astronomy. We predict unique signatures in the ringdown phase of binary black hole merger signals, offering a potent test of General Relativity.
subject: Fizik
title: Spontaneous Scalarization of Kerr Black Holes in Einstein-Gauss-Bonnet-Dilaton Gravity

text: We formulate a continuum hydrodynamic theory for two-dimensional active chiral fluids characterized by non-reciprocal effective interactions. Starting from a microscopic model of self-propelled particles with chirality-dependent alignment rules, we systematically derive the macroscopic fluid equations using a coarse-graining procedure. The resulting equations exhibit novel terms that violate time-reversal symmetry, most notably an 'odd viscosity' tensor and a non-reciprocal pressure contribution. These terms lead to emergent phenomena absent in conventional fluids, such as spontaneous bulk flow in confined geometries and the formation of self-organizing traveling waves and vortices without external driving. We perform a linear stability analysis to map out the phase diagram of collective motion, identifying distinct regimes of turbulence and coherent large-scale structures. Our work provides a unified framework for understanding the unique hydrodynamics of a broad class of biological and synthetic active systems, from bacterial suspensions to robotic swarms.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergent Non-Reciprocal Hydrodynamics in Active Chiral Fluids

text: We investigate the generation of cosmological birefringence—a frequency-independent rotation of the plane of linear polarization of photons—arising from the coupling between an axion-like particle (ALP) field and electromagnetism in the presence of a primordial magnetic field (PMF). The axion-photon interaction term, g_aγγ F⋅~F, induces a parity-violating modification to Maxwell's equations. In a magnetized early universe plasma, this leads to a difference in propagation speeds for left- and right-handed circularly polarized photons. We calculate the net rotation angle of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) polarization vector as a function of the ALP mass, the coupling constant g_aγγ, and the PMF strength. This effect manifests as non-zero correlation between the E-mode and B-mode polarization of the CMB (TB and EB power spectra). Using current Planck data, we place new constraints on this parameter space, demonstrating that CMB polarimetry is a powerful probe of new physics.
subject: Fizik
title: Cosmological Birefringence as a Consequence of Axion-Electrodynamics in a Primordial Magnetic Field

text: We demonstrate that the Quantum Zeno Effect, induced by frequent projective measurements, can dynamically generate emergent conservation laws and lead to Hilbert space fragmentation in an interacting many-body system. We consider a one-dimensional chain of interacting qubits, such as a Rydberg atom array, subjected to repeated local measurements of a non-local operator. Our analytical and numerical analysis shows that for sufficiently high measurement frequency, the system's evolution is confined to a 'Zeno subspace' where the measured operator's eigenvalue is frozen. This confinement effectively shatters the Hilbert space into dynamically disconnected sectors, a hallmark of fragmentation. We show that this mechanism prevents thermalization and leads to long-lived coherence for specific initial states, mimicking features of many-body localization but without inherent disorder. This measurement-induced confinement offers a novel, controllable protocol for engineering non-ergodic dynamics and protecting quantum information in quantum simulators.
subject: Fizik
title: Quantum Zeno Effect and Subspace Confinement in a Many-Body Interacting System

text: We investigate non-perturbative corrections to the Anti-de Sitter/Conformal Field Theory (AdS/CFT) correspondence by postulating that the bulk spacetime geometry is encoded in a quantum error-correcting code. Utilizing the framework of holographic entanglement entropy and the Ryu-Takayanagi formula, we demonstrate that constraints on entanglement wedge reconstruction necessitate modifications to the semi-classical bulk effective field theory. We argue that the inclusion of wormholes, or non-trivial spacetime topologies, corresponds to sub-leading order terms in the 1/N expansion which are intrinsically non-local yet causally constrained. By modeling the boundary CFT as a tensor network, we show that the bulk metric fluctuations can be related to the bond dimension and entanglement structure of the network. This approach provides a concrete mechanism for understanding the emergence of sub-AdS locality and offers a novel perspective on the black hole information paradox, linking it directly to the fidelity of quantum state teleportation through the ER=EPR correspondence.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Perturbative Corrections to AdS/CFT Duality from Quantum Information Theoretic Constraints

text: This work explores the validity of the Eigenstate Thermalization Hypothesis (ETH) in non-Hermitian, parity-time (PT) symmetric quantum many-body systems exhibiting a transition to a many-body localized (MBL) phase. We numerically investigate a one-dimensional spin chain with quasi-periodic disorder and non-Hermitian gain/loss terms. By analyzing the spectral statistics, specifically the complex level spacing distribution, and the entanglement entropy of the eigenstates, we identify a critical disorder strength beyond which ETH breaks down. In the PT-broken phase, the emergence of complex eigenvalues correlates with a sharp delocalization-to-localization transition. We find that while ETH holds for chaotic regimes in the PT-symmetric phase, the MBL phase is characterized by non-ergodic dynamics and area-law entanglement, even in the presence of dissipation. Our results suggest that the interplay between non-Hermiticity and disorder provides a new landscape for studying quantum thermalization and its violations, with implications for driven-dissipative quantum simulators.
subject: Fizik
title: Eigenstate Thermalization Hypothesis in Non-Hermitian Quantum Systems with Many-Body Localization

text: We develop a comprehensive Bayesian inference framework to search for and characterize gravitational wave echoes following binary black hole merger events observed by the LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA detector network. Echoes are faint, repeating wave packets predicted by theories proposing quantum modifications to the near-horizon structure of black holes, such as firewall or fuzzball paradigms. Our model parameterizes the echo waveform based on the post-merger quasi-normal mode spectrum but includes additional parameters for time delay, damping, and a transfer function encoding the reflectivity of a putative Planck-scale boundary. By applying this model to simulated data and publicly available gravitational wave events, we place new constraints on the parameter space of exotic compact objects (ECOs). The analysis demonstrates that while no statistically significant evidence for echoes is found, future detector sensitivity upgrades could definitively probe near-horizon quantum gravity effects, thereby testing fundamental predictions of general relativity in the strong-field regime.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Wave Echoes from Exotic Compact Objects: A Bayesian Inference Framework

text: We investigate the possibility of detecting signatures of dynamic dark energy (quintessence) through its coupling to electromagnetism, which induces a cosmological birefringence—a frequency-independent rotation of the polarization plane of photons from the cosmic microwave background (CMB). This work considers a class of axion-like quintessence fields whose potential-driven dynamics can generate a non-zero, spatially varying rotation angle. This anisotropy in the polarization rotation leads to a non-zero B-mode power spectrum that is correlated with the temperature anisotropy (TB) and E-mode polarization (EB). We compute the predicted angular power spectra for these cross-correlations for various quintessence potentials and coupling strengths. We show that upcoming CMB experiments like the Simons Observatory and CMB-S4 will have the sensitivity to constrain these models to unprecedented levels, potentially distinguishing between a cosmological constant and dynamic dark energy, and probing fundamental physics beyond the Standard Model.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Quintessence Models with Anisotropic Cosmological Birefringence and CMB Polarization

text: We present a theoretical study of the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE) in magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene (TBG) subject to uniaxial heterostrain. The strain modifies the moiré superlattice potential, leading to a distortion of the flat electronic bands and a tunable anisotropy in the composite fermion fluid. Using a combination of density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) methods and a modified Chern-Simons-Ginzburg-Landau theory, we analyze the stability of various FQHE ground states, particularly the non-Abelian Moore-Read and Read-Rezayi states. Our calculations reveal that strain can be used as a control knob to selectively enhance or suppress competing fractional states, and can induce topological phase transitions between them. We predict specific experimental signatures in magnetotransport measurements, such as an anisotropic Hall conductivity tensor, which would provide direct evidence of this strain-induced manipulation of non-Abelian anyonic excitations, opening avenues for topological quantum computation.
subject: Fizik
title: Fractional Quantum Hall Effect in Twisted Bilayer Graphene under Strain Engineering

text: High-fidelity gyrokinetic simulations are employed to investigate the multiscale interaction between kinetic-scale turbulence and magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) instabilities in high-beta spherical tokamak plasmas. Our study focuses on the nonlinear coupling of ion-temperature-gradient (ITG) modes, trapped-electron modes (TEM), and kinetic ballooning modes (KBM). We demonstrate that at high plasma beta, the electromagnetic fluctuations driven by KBMs can significantly alter the turbulent transport cascade, leading to the suppression of ITG-driven heat flux but an enhancement of energetic particle transport. Crucially, our simulations reveal a novel mechanism for the self-regulation of turbulence through the generation of meso-scale zonal flows, which are driven not only by the Reynolds stress of electrostatic turbulence but also by the Maxwell stress of the magnetic fluctuations. These findings provide a more complete physical picture of turbulent transport in fusion-relevant regimes and have direct implications for predicting the performance of future compact fusion reactors.
subject: Fizik
title: Kinetic-Scale Turbulence and Zonal Flow Dynamics in High-Beta Spherical Tokamaks

text: We propose and analyze a protocol for the deterministic generation of large-scale, multi-photon graph states, a crucial resource for measurement-based quantum computing. The scheme utilizes an ensemble of cold atoms trapped within a high-finesse optical cavity, where strong, long-range interactions are mediated by laser-induced transitions to Rydberg states. The Rydberg blockade mechanism allows the creation of a single collective 'superatom' excitation, which can be deterministically mapped onto a single photon state leaving the cavity. By sequentially addressing individually controlled atomic sub-ensembles and applying a series of microwave pulses to manipulate the ground-state manifold, we can controllably entangle photons emitted at different times. We model the protocol's fidelity, accounting for decoherence from atomic motion and spontaneous emission, and show that graph states exceeding fifty nodes can be generated with fidelities sufficient for demonstrating quantum computational advantage in specific sampling problems.
subject: Fizik
title: Deterministic Generation of Multi-Photon Graph States using Rydberg-Blockaded Atomic Ensembles

text: We explore a class of Supersymmetric (SUSY) Grand Unified Theories (GUTs) based on the SU(5) gauge group where the condition of gaugino mass universality at the GUT scale is relaxed. This non-universality can arise naturally from the non-singlet F-term vacuum expectation values of the chiral superfield responsible for SUSY breaking. We perform a two-loop renormalization group equation (RGE) analysis to evolve the gaugino and scalar mass parameters from the GUT scale to the electroweak scale. The resulting sparticle spectrum exhibits unique phenomenological features, such as a compressed electroweakino sector or a light gluino coexisting with heavy squarks. We analyze the collider signatures of these scenarios at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), focusing on final states with multiple leptons, jets, and significant missing transverse energy. Our analysis demonstrates that current and future LHC searches can probe large regions of the parameter space, potentially distinguishing non-universal models from the more constrained CMSSM.
subject: Fizik
title: Supersymmetric Grand Unification with Non-Universal Gaugino Masses and its LHC Signatures

text: We develop a theoretical framework based on non-equilibrium stochastic thermodynamics to describe the dynamics of chromatin organization and epigenetic modifications. Chromatin is modeled as an active polymer network, where ATP-dependent remodeling enzymes act as molecular motors, driving the system far from thermal equilibrium. We formulate a Langevin-type equation for chromatin dynamics coupled to a master equation for the discrete epigenetic states (e.g., methylation, acetylation) on histone tails. This coupled system allows us to quantify the thermodynamic cost of maintaining epigenetic memory and executing state transitions. We calculate the entropy production rate associated with chromatin remodeling and demonstrate how it relates to the stability of epigenetic landscapes. Our model predicts a direct link between the metabolic state of the cell (ATP concentration) and the fidelity of epigenetic inheritance, offering a quantitative, physics-based explanation for the observed plasticity and robustness of the epigenome.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Equilibrium Thermodynamics of Active Chromatin Networks and Epigenetic State Transitions

text: This paper re-examines the foundations of quantum measurement in the presence of additive conservation laws, unifying the Wigner-Araki-Yanase (WAY) theorem with the framework of quantum contextuality. We employ the Contextuality-by-Default (CbD) theory to formalize the notion that measurements of a quantum observable in different experimental contexts (i.e., alongside different sets of co-measured observables) are stochastically unrelated. We demonstrate that the WAY theorem, which constrains the accuracy of measurements for observables that do not commute with a conserved quantity, can be reinterpreted as a form of intrinsic contextuality. Specifically, the impossibility of a perfectly accurate, repeatable measurement is shown to be equivalent to a violation of non-contextuality inequalities in the CbD framework. This approach provides a rigorous, operational meaning to the measurement limitations imposed by conservation laws and clarifies the deep connection between fundamental symmetries and the non-classical structure of quantum probabilities.
subject: Fizik
title: Contextuality-by-Default and the Wigner-Araki-Yanase Theorem: Limitations on Quantum Measurements

text: Ribosome-associated quality control (RQC) is a crucial cellular surveillance pathway that targets nascent polypeptide chains arising from stalled translation for proteasomal degradation. The E3 ubiquitin ligase Ltn1p is central to this process, yet its structural organization and mechanism of substrate recognition remain elusive. Here, we present the high-resolution cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of the yeast 80S RQC complex, captured with a stalled nascent chain, the RQC trigger factor (RQT) complex, and Ltn1p. Our structure reveals how the RQT complex remodels the ribosome to expose the peptidyl-tRNA at the P-site, facilitating Ltn1p engagement. Ltn1p adopts an extended conformation, arching over the ribosomal tunnel exit to position its RING domain for optimal ubiquitination of the nascent chain. Mutational analysis guided by our structure confirms that specific interactions between Ltn1p and both ribosomal proteins and the RQT complex are indispensable for efficient ubiquitination. These findings provide a detailed architectural framework for understanding RQC-mediated proteostasis and its dysregulation in neurodegenerative diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Ribosome Quality Control Complex Reveals the Mechanism of Nascent Chain Ubiquitination

text: The reactivation of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) expression is a promising therapeutic strategy for β-hemoglobinopathies like sickle cell disease and β-thalassemia. Transcriptional repression of the γ-globin genes is primarily mediated by the BCL11A transcription factor. Here, we engineered a potent epigenetic editor by fusing a catalytically inactive Cas9 (dCas9) to the catalytic domain of DNA methyltransferase 3A (DNMT3A). Guided by single-guide RNAs targeting the BCL11A erythroid-specific enhancer, we achieved robust, targeted DNA hypermethylation in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs). Chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) and bisulfite sequencing confirmed precise epigenetic modification without significant off-target effects. This locus-specific hypermethylation resulted in sustained transcriptional repression of BCL11A, leading to a clinically relevant elevation of HbF levels in differentiated erythroid progeny. In a murine model of β-thalassemia, transplantation of these edited HSPCs led to a significant correction of the disease phenotype, demonstrating the therapeutic potential of targeted epigenetic editing.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Locus-Specific Epigenetic Silencing of BCL11A by a dCas9-DNMT3A Fusion Protein Ameliorates Beta-Thalassemia

text: The cellular heterogeneity of the tumor microenvironment (TME) profoundly influences cancer progression and therapeutic response. We employed high-throughput single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) to profile over 100,000 individual cells from primary and metastatic lesions of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). Our analysis resolved distinct subpopulations of cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) and tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs). A novel myofibroblastic CAF subtype, characterized by high expression of POSTN and LOXL2, was significantly enriched in metastatic sites. Trajectory inference analysis suggested its differentiation from resident pancreatic stellate cells. Ligand-receptor interaction modeling predicted a robust paracrine signaling axis between these metastatic CAFs and a specific C1QC-expressing TAM subpopulation. In co-culture and xenograft models, CAF-derived POSTN was shown to induce M2-like polarization in macrophages via integrin signaling, thereby fostering an immunosuppressive and pro-angiogenic niche. Targeting this specific fibroblast-macrophage axis may represent a novel therapeutic strategy to inhibit metastatic dissemination in PDAC.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Single-Cell Transcriptomic Atlas of the Tumor Microenvironment Reveals a Pro-Metastatic Fibroblast-Macrophage Axis

text: G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) can selectively activate G-protein or β-arrestin pathways, a phenomenon known as biased agonism, which offers opportunities for developing safer therapeutics. To elucidate the structural basis of this phenomenon, we determined the cryo-electron microscopy structure of the human A2A adenosine receptor (A2AAR) in complex with a Gs-biased agonist and the heterotrimeric Gs protein at 2.8 Å resolution. Comparison with the β-arrestin-biased state reveals a distinct conformational rearrangement in the receptor's intracellular loop 2 (ICL2) and transmembrane helix 6 (TM6). The Gs-biased agonist stabilizes an outward TM6 conformation that sterically hinders the engagement of β-arrestin but creates an optimal binding surface for the α-subunit of Gs. All-atom molecular dynamics simulations corroborate that this specific conformation acts as a 'conformational lock,' preventing the receptor from sampling β-arrestin-competent states. These insights into the molecular determinants of GPCR signaling bias provide a blueprint for the rational design of pathway-selective drugs.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Biased Agonism of the A2A Adenosine Receptor Mediated by a Conformational Lock in the G-Protein Binding Interface

text: Transcription at key developmental and oncogenic genes is often characterized by high-amplitude bursts, regulated by distal super-enhancers. The underlying mechanism for concentrating transcriptional machinery at these sites remains unclear. We demonstrate that the intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs) of the bromodomain protein BRD4 and the acetyltransferase p300/CBP co-assemble into liquid-like biomolecular condensates. Using live-cell single-molecule imaging and fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP), we show these condensates form preferentially at hyper-acetylated super-enhancer regions, where they recruit RNA Polymerase II and the Mediator complex. Perturbation of the IDRs via mutagenesis or treatment with a phase-disrupting agent, 1,6-hexanediol, dissolved these condensates and attenuated transcriptional bursting without affecting basal transcription. Our results support a model in which liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) of key chromatin regulators provides a physicochemical basis for the assembly of transcriptional hubs at super-enhancers, thereby driving robust and pulsatile gene expression.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phase Separation of the BRD4-p300 Complex at Super-Enhancers Orchestrates Transcriptional Bursting

text: Local protein synthesis at synapses is critical for long-term synaptic plasticity and memory consolidation. The epitranscriptomic mark N6-methyladenosine (m6A) has emerged as a key regulator of mRNA fate, but its role in synaptic translation remains unknown. Using m6A-sequencing (MeRIP-seq) on synaptoneurosomes isolated from the hippocampus, we identified a distinct pool of m6A-modified transcripts, including those encoding critical plasticity-related proteins like CAMK2A and PSD95. We show that the m6A reader protein YTHDF1 is enriched at synapses and that its conditional knockout in excitatory neurons impairs long-term potentiation (LTP) and long-term memory formation. Ribosome profiling and polysome fractionation revealed that YTHDF1 binding promotes the translational efficiency of its target mRNAs in response to synaptic stimulation. This occurs through its interaction with the eukaryotic initiation factor 3 (eIF3) complex. Our findings establish a novel layer of epitranscriptomic control over local translation, directly linking synaptic m6A modification to the molecular machinery of memory.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The m6A Reader YTHDF1 Promotes mRNA Translation in the Synaptic Neuropil to Consolidate Long-Term Memory

text: Viral pathogens remodel host cellular machinery to facilitate their replication. A comprehensive understanding of the dynamic protein-protein interactions (PPIs) at the virus-host interface is essential for developing effective antiviral strategies. Here, we employed proximity-dependent biotinylation (BioID) coupled with quantitative mass spectrometry to create a high-resolution spatiotemporal map of the SARS-CoV-2 interactome in human lung epithelial cells. We profiled the proximal interactors of 26 viral proteins throughout the infection cycle. This yielded over 4,000 high-confidence PPIs, revealing extensive viral hijacking of key host processes, including vesicle trafficking, RNA processing, and innate immune signaling. Notably, we identified a previously uncharacterized interaction between the viral nsp14 protein and the host STRIPAK complex, which we show is critical for suppressing interferon-stimulated gene expression. Pharmacological inhibition of the STRIPAK component STRN4 resulted in potent antiviral activity in vitro, validating our interactome-driven approach for the rapid identification of host-directed antiviral targets.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mapping the SARS-CoV-2-Host Interactome via Proximity-Dependent Biotinylation Identifies New Therapeutic Targets

text: The rational design of synthetic genetic circuits with predictable behavior is a cornerstone of synthetic biology, yet achieving robust performance in mammalian cells is challenging due to crosstalk with endogenous networks. We report the construction of a fully orthogonal genetic toggle switch based on mutually repressive transcription activator-like effector (TALE) proteins. The circuit utilizes synthetic promoters with TALE binding sites that lack recognition motifs for endogenous transcription factors. To insulate the circuit from translational regulation, the TALE repressors were designed to be expressed from transcripts containing orthogonal 5' and 3' untranslated regions (UTRs). When integrated into HEK293T and CHO cells, the circuit exhibited robust bistability, with stable 'ON' and 'OFF' states that were heritable for over 50 cell divisions. The system's state could be reliably flipped using transient chemical inducers. This highly insulated design provides a foundational component for building complex, multi-layered synthetic circuits for applications in cell-based therapies and biocomputing.
subject: Biyoloji
title: An Orthogonal TALE-Based Genetic Toggle Switch for Robust Bistability in Mammalian Cells

text: Telomeres pose a significant challenge to the DNA replication machinery, leading to frequent replication fork stalling. The mechanisms that ensure fork stability and prevent collapse at these repetitive sequences are not fully understood. We show that the telomeric repeat-binding factor 2 (TRF2), a core component of the shelterin complex, plays a direct role in the replication stress response at telomeres. Using iPONDR (in situ protein-on-nascent-DNA-recognition) and super-resolution microscopy, we demonstrate that TRF2 is rapidly recruited to stalled forks within telomeric DNA. TRF2 recruitment is independent of its telomere tethering function and facilitates the localized accumulation and activation of the ATR kinase. Depletion of TRF2 leads to reduced ATR signaling specifically at telomeres, resulting in fork collapse, increased telomeric sister chromatid exchanges, and elevated chromosomal instability. Our data reveal a novel function for TRF2 as a scaffold protein that orchestrates the ATR-dependent replication stress response to maintain telomere integrity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The Shelterin Component TRF2 Modulates ATR Kinase Activity at Stalled Replication Forks to Prevent Telomere Fragility

text: Cancer stem cells (CSCs) exhibit distinct metabolic phenotypes that support their self-renewal and therapeutic resistance. We identified a novel long non-coding RNA, termed Glioma Aerobic-to-Glycolytic lnRNA (GADIR), that is highly expressed in glioma stem cells (GSCs) but not in differentiated tumor cells or normal astrocytes. GADIR knockdown in GSCs induced a metabolic shift from aerobic glycolysis towards oxidative phosphorylation, attenuated self-renewal capacity, and sensitized cells to radiation therapy. Mechanistically, chromatin isolation by RNA purification (ChIRP-seq) revealed that GADIR directly binds to the promoter regions of several key tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle enzyme genes, including SDHB and OGDH. GADIR serves as a scaffold, recruiting the polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) to these loci, leading to H3K27me3-mediated transcriptional repression. These findings uncover a lncRNA-mediated epigenetic mechanism that governs metabolic plasticity in GSCs, highlighting GADIR as a potential therapeutic target for eradicating the root of gliomas.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Metabolic Reprogramming in Glioma Stem Cells is Driven by the lncRNA GADIR via Epigenetic Silencing of the TCA Cycle

text: This paper introduces a novel computational framework for quantifying perceptual consonance in microtonal and xenharmonic harmonic structures. Traditional models of harmonicity, largely based on integer-ratio frequency relationships, fail to adequately predict subjective listener responses to non-standard tuning systems. We propose the Xenharmonic Consonance Metric (XCM), which integrates high-resolution spectral analysis via the Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) with a psychoacoustically-informed model of sensory roughness derived from critical band theory. The model's predictions are further refined by a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network trained to capture temporal dependencies in consonance perception. Validated against a corpus of listener ratings for dyads and triads in 19-TET, 31-TET, and Bohlen-Pierce scales, the XCM demonstrates a significant improvement in predictive accuracy (r > 0.92) over existing dissonance curve models. This research provides a robust, extensible methodology for the analysis of post-tonal harmony, bridging signal processing with cognitive musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: A Psychoacoustic-Computational Model for Consonance in Xenharmonic Systems using Spectral Flux and LSTM Networks

text: The study of orchestration has traditionally relied on qualitative heuristics. This paper presents a quantitative methodology for mapping the perceptual semantics of orchestral timbre using high-dimensional feature extraction and manifold learning. We construct a feature space for a large corpus of isolated instrumental samples by concatenating Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs), spectral statistics, and wavelet scattering transform coefficients. To visualize the inherent structure of this space, we apply Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP), a non-linear dimensionality reduction technique. The resultant low-dimensional embedding reveals a highly structured timbral manifold where instrumental families form distinct, continuous clusters. Furthermore, the geometric distances between points on the manifold correlate strongly with established principles of timbral blending and psychoacoustic similarity. This data-driven approach offers a new paradigm for the empirical analysis of orchestration, providing a computable representation of timbral relationships that can inform both music theory and algorithmic composition.
subject: Müzik
title: Mapping the Semantic Space of Orchestral Timbre: A Manifold Learning Approach

text: This study formalizes the principles of species counterpoint using a probabilistic graphical model. We introduce the 'Contrapuntal State Graph' (CSG), a directed acyclic graph where nodes represent discrete intervallic states between voice pairs and edges encode permissible melodic and harmonic transitions. This representation transforms voice-leading analysis into a problem of finding optimal paths through a constrained state space. We train a Conditional Random Field (CRF) on the complete corpus of J.S. Bach's four-part chorales, using the CSG as the underlying structure, to learn a probabilistic grammar of 18th-century counterpoint. The model demonstrates high accuracy in identifying stylistically anomalous passages and predicting voice-leading choices in unseen fragments. This graph-theoretic framework not only provides a powerful analytical tool for polyphonic music but also establishes a formal basis for the procedural generation of stylistically coherent contrapuntal textures, unifying historical music theory with modern machine learning techniques.
subject: Müzik
title: Contrapuntal Syntax as a Probabilistic Graphical Model: A Graph-Theoretic Analysis of Bach Chorales

text: Deviations from metronomic precision are fundamental to expressive musical performance. This paper posits a cognitive model where expressive timing is the result of Bayesian inference under a hierarchical generative model of rhythmic and harmonic expectation. We formalize this by treating performer-generated inter-onset intervals (IOIs) as posterior estimates conditioned on priors encapsulating metrical structure, phrase boundaries, and harmonic tension, the latter quantified via a spiral-array model. Using Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods on a dataset of professional piano recordings of Chopin, we infer the model's latent parameters. Our results demonstrate that phenomena like phrase-final lengthening and agogic accentuation emerge naturally as rational inferences under uncertainty, rather than being mere motor artifacts. The posterior distributions of timing parameters show strong correlations with music-theoretic features, providing a quantitative link between expressive performance practice and the underlying musical structure, and reframing musical expression as a form of probabilistic cognition.
subject: Müzik
title: Expressive Performance Timing as Hierarchical Bayesian Inference

text: This paper explores the semantic congruence between musical audio and lyrical content using a deep cross-modal retrieval architecture. We implement a dual-encoder Siamese network where a pre-trained BERT transformer processes lyrics and a Convolutional Recurrent Neural Network (CRNN) processes log-mel spectrograms from corresponding audio tracks. The network is trained on a large-scale dataset using a contrastive loss function, which minimizes the distance between congruent audio-lyric pairs while maximizing it for incongruent pairs in a shared latent embedding space. The learned space exhibits a semantically meaningful structure, with audio feature clusters (e.g., high tempo, major mode) aligning with lyrical sentiment clusters (e.g., positive valence, high arousal). The system achieves state-of-the-art performance on cross-modal retrieval tasks, demonstrating its ability to learn a robust joint representation. This provides a powerful new tool for music information retrieval, tag generation, and computational studies of text-setting.
subject: Müzik
title: Learning a Shared Semantic Space for Music and Lyrics with Deep Cross-Modal Siamese Networks

text: Schenkerian analysis posits a hierarchical structure in tonal music, yet its formalization remains a significant challenge. This work introduces 'SchenkerNet', a novel Graph Neural Network (GNN) architecture designed to learn Schenkerian reduction from symbolic musical data. We represent musical scores as graphs where notes are nodes and edges encode melodic and harmonic relationships. SchenkerNet employs a specialized graph convolutional operator and a hierarchical pooling mechanism to perform iterative graph reduction, mimicking the analytical process of reducing foreground detail to a background structure (*Ursatz*). Trained on a corpus of expert-annotated analyses, the model learns to identify structural prolongations and classify notes by their hierarchical level with high accuracy. The learned node embeddings capture musically salient features related to tonal stability and function. This research represents a significant advance in automated music theory, bridging the abstract concepts of Schenkerian thought with the concrete formalisms of geometric deep learning.
subject: Müzik
title: Automated Schenkerian Analysis via Geometric Deep Learning on Musical Graphs

text: This study investigates the neural encoding of complex polyrhythms by combining electroencephalography (EEG) with advanced signal processing techniques. We hypothesize that the brain's parsing of polyrhythmic stimuli is reflected in neural phase-locking to specific periodicities inherent in the signal's multi-resolutional structure. Steady-state evoked potentials (SSEPs) were recorded while participants listened to complex rhythmic ratios (e.g., 4:5, 5:7). A continuous wavelet transform (CWT) using a Morlet wavelet was applied to the audio stimuli to extract time-frequency phase information. Inter-trial phase coherence (ITPC) was calculated for the EEG data. We found a statistically significant correlation between the ITPC of the neural response at specific frequencies and the phase synchrony patterns revealed by the CWT of the auditory signal. These findings provide neurophysiological evidence supporting the theory that the auditory cortex performs a wavelet-like analysis to decode complex temporal structures, offering a powerful neuro-computational model of rhythm perception.
subject: Müzik
title: Neural Correlates of Polyrhythmic Perception: An EEG and Continuous Wavelet Transform Analysis

text: Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) is a standard technique for unsupervised audio analysis, but its performance in music source separation is often limited by the lack of musically-informed constraints. This paper introduces a novel variant, Timbre-Constrained NMF (TC-NMF), which incorporates two regularization terms into the objective function: temporal sparsity on the activation matrix and spectral smoothness on the basis matrix. These constraints reflect the natural characteristics of musical instrument sounds—namely, that instruments play notes sparsely over time and that their spectral envelopes are typically smooth. We evaluate TC-NMF on the MedleyDB dataset for the task of unsupervised instrumental source separation. Results show a statistically significant improvement in Signal-to-Distortion Ratio (SDR) and Signal-to-Interference Ratio (SIR) compared to standard NMF and other state-of-the-art unsupervised methods. The extracted spectral bases exhibit greater correspondence with ground-truth instrument timbres, demonstrating a more musically meaningful decomposition.
subject: Müzik
title: Timbre-Constrained Non-Negative Matrix Factorization for Unsupervised Music Source Separation

text: Quantifying harmonic ambiguity, a key feature of late-Romantic and post-tonal music, has proven elusive. This paper proposes a formal metric, 'Harmonic Entropy' (Hₑ), grounded in information theory. We first construct a probabilistic model of tonal expectation using a variable-order Markov chain trained on a large corpus of common-practice music. Harmonic Entropy is then defined as the Shannon entropy of the probability distribution of possible continuations from a given harmonic state, weighted by their tonal stability. This metric captures the degree of uncertainty or 'surprisal' an expert listener might experience. We apply the Hₑ metric to famously ambiguous passages, such as the Tristan chord, and trace its evolution through the works of Wagner, Debussy, and Schoenberg. A strong correlation (Pearson’s r = 0.88) is found between Hₑ scores and listener ratings of perceived ambiguity in a controlled psychoacoustic experiment, validating the metric as a robust tool for computational musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: An Information-Theoretic Metric for Harmonic Ambiguity in Post-Tonal Music

text: This research presents a novel framework for controllable synthesis of auditory textures using a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN). Traditional texture synthesis methods offer limited parametric control and often fail to capture complex, non-linear temporal dynamics. We propose a 'Perceptually-Conditioned WaveGAN' (PC-WaveGAN), a deep convolutional GAN that synthesizes raw audio waveforms. The generator's input is a latent vector concatenated with a conditioning vector of high-level perceptual descriptors (e.g., spectral centroid, roughness, periodicity) derived from psychoacoustic models. This allows for explicit, intuitive control over the synthesized texture's character. Trained on a diverse dataset of environmental and musical sounds, PC-WaveGAN synthesizes textures with significantly higher perceptual quality than baseline models, as verified by MUSHRA listening tests. The conditioning enables smooth interpolation within the perceptual feature space, representing a powerful new paradigm for procedural audio, sound design, and computational auditory scene analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: High-Fidelity Auditory Texture Synthesis using Perceptually-Conditioned Generative Adversarial Networks

text: This paper addresses the challenge of estimating causal effects using instrumental variables (IV) in high-dimensional settings where the number of instruments and confounders can exceed the sample size. Naive application of regularization techniques, such as LASSO, to select instruments or control for confounders induces significant bias in the causal effect estimator. We introduce a debiased machine learning framework for IV regression that leverages Neyman-orthogonal moment functions to immunize the target parameter estimation from biases arising from first-stage regularization. Our method employs cross-fitting and modern machine learning algorithms for estimating nuisance functions—the conditional expectation of the treatment and the outcome. We establish the asymptotic normality and semiparametric efficiency of our proposed estimator under standard sparsity assumptions. Monte Carlo simulations demonstrate that our method provides valid confidence intervals and substantially reduces bias compared to existing high-dimensional IV estimators. An empirical application to a genomic dataset illustrates the method's practical utility in identifying causal genetic variants for complex traits.
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Machine Learning for High-Dimensional Instrumental Variable Regression

text: We propose a novel Bayesian nonparametric framework for clustering functional data that incorporates subject-specific covariates to inform the partition structure. Traditional functional clustering methods often ignore valuable covariate information and require a priori specification of the number of clusters. Our method utilizes a Hierarchical Dirichlet Process (HDP) mixture model, which infers the number of clusters from the data. The functional observations are represented using a Karhunen-Loève basis expansion with data-driven truncation. Crucially, we link the mixing weights of the Dirichlet process to external covariates through a logistic stick-breaking construction, allowing the probability of cluster assignment to vary across subjects. Inference is performed via a computationally efficient collapsed Gibbs sampler. The model is applied to longitudinal neuroimaging data, where it successfully identifies distinct trajectories of cognitive decline, demonstrating that demographic and clinical covariates significantly predict patient subgroup membership, offering enhanced etiological insights.
subject: İstatistik
title: Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Mixtures for Clustering Functional Data with Covariate-Dependent Partitions

text: Topological Data Analysis (TDA), particularly persistent homology, provides a powerful lens for characterizing the shape of complex data. However, a fundamental challenge remains in quantifying the statistical significance of topological features observed in a persistence diagram. This work introduces a robust and computationally feasible framework for constructing confidence sets for persistence diagrams. Our approach is based on a multi-scale bootstrap procedure applied to judiciously chosen subsamples of the original data cloud. We prove the asymptotic validity of the resulting confidence regions under weak regularity conditions on the underlying data-generating distribution, thereby providing a formal basis for hypothesis testing on topological invariants like Betti numbers. This enables the principled distinction between genuine topological signals and artifacts of random sampling. We showcase the method's efficacy in analyzing cosmic web structures and protein folding dynamics, where it successfully identifies significant topological features that were previously obscured by sampling noise.
subject: İstatistik
title: Statistical Inference for Persistent Homology via a Multi-Scale Subsampling Bootstrap

text: The assumption of spatial stationarity in traditional spatio-temporal models is often violated in complex environmental and epidemiological applications, leading to biased inference and poor prediction. We develop a highly flexible class of non-stationary Gaussian process models capable of capturing spatially varying anisotropy and smoothness. Our approach models the process covariance function as a linear combination of spatially adaptive basis functions derived from local solutions to a governing partial differential equation (PDE), effectively creating a process-driven metric tensor. This construction allows the model to learn complex, non-stationary dependency structures directly from the data. For computational tractability with massive datasets, we formulate the model within the Stochastic Partial Differential Equation (SPDE) framework and leverage Integrated Nested Laplace Approximations (INLA) for fast Bayesian inference. The model's superior predictive performance and ability to characterize heterogeneous dynamics are demonstrated through an analysis of satellite-derived sea surface temperature data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Non-Stationary Gaussian Process Models for High-Resolution Spatio-Temporal Data
