text: Standard high-dimensional regression estimators, such as the LASSO, are notoriously sensitive to heavy-tailed errors and adversarial data contamination. We propose a novel adaptive Huber regression methodology that performs robust estimation and variable selection simultaneously. The procedure utilizes a Huber loss function with a data-driven, iteratively updated robustness parameter, allowing it to adapt to unknown levels of contamination. Furthermore, we incorporate an adaptive L1-penalty to mitigate the estimation bias associated with standard penalization. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis, establishing non-asymptotic oracle inequalities for the proposed estimator under a general ε-contamination model. Our results demonstrate that the estimator achieves near-optimal performance, enjoying both variable selection consistency and robust estimation error bounds. Extensive simulations and an application to a gene expression dataset with known sample outliers confirm the theoretical advantages and superior empirical performance of our method over existing robust high-dimensional techniques.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Huber Regression for Robust Estimation and Variable Selection in Corrupted High-Dimensional Data

text: Estimating causal effects in networked populations is profoundly challenging due to treatment interference and network-induced confounding, where homophily creates spurious correlations between treatment assignment and outcomes. This paper introduces a network deconfounding framework to address these issues. We posit that unobserved confounders can be modeled by embedding the network adjacency matrix into a low-dimensional latent space. We employ a variational graph autoencoder to learn this embedding, capturing complex homophilous patterns. These learned latent variables are then incorporated as covariates into a potential outcomes model to adjust for confounding when estimating direct and indirect (spillover) causal effects. This approach provides a principled way to disentangle true peer effects from shared latent attributes. We demonstrate through simulations and a re-analysis of a networked public health intervention that our method yields substantially less biased estimates of treatment effects compared to models that ignore or improperly adjust for network structure.
subject: İstatistik
title: Network Deconfounding for Causal Inference with Propagating Treatments

text: The Accelerated Failure Time (AFT) model offers a powerful, direct interpretation of covariate effects on survival time, yet its semiparametric estimation is notoriously difficult, with existing rank-based methods suffering from computational complexity and potential inefficiency. We propose a novel estimation procedure for the semiparametric AFT model based on a kernel-regularized profile likelihood. In our framework, the unspecified baseline error distribution is treated as an infinite-dimensional nuisance parameter modeled within a Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space (RKHS). By profiling out this nuisance function, we obtain a smooth, convex objective function for the regression coefficients. We prove that the resulting estimators are consistent, asymptotically normal, and achieve the semiparametric efficiency bound. Finite-sample performance is evaluated through extensive simulations, which demonstrate a marked improvement in efficiency over established methods, particularly under high rates of right-censoring. The utility of the method is illustrated in an analysis of a large-scale oncology clinical trial dataset.
subject: İstatistik
title: Semiparametric Accelerated Failure Time Models with Kernel-Regularized Profile Likelihood

text: Bayesian optimization (BO) is a sample-efficient methodology for global optimization of black-box functions, but its sequential nature limits its applicability in parallel computing environments. We propose a novel batch acquisition function, Batch Predictive Entropy Search (BPES), designed for high-dimensional settings. BPES selects a batch of evaluation points that are anticipated to jointly maximize the information gain about the location of the global optimum. This is formalized as maximizing the expected reduction in the differential entropy of the posterior distribution over the maximizer's location, P(x*). To ensure computational tractability, we employ a Thompson sampling-based approximation for the posterior P(x*) and a low-rank Gaussian process surrogate model. This entropy-based criterion naturally encourages exploration and diversity within the selected batch. In benchmark tests on high-dimensional synthetic functions and a challenging real-world hyperparameter tuning task for a deep learning model, BPES consistently outperforms existing batch BO strategies in terms of convergence rate.
subject: İstatistik
title: Entropy-Based Batch Bayesian Optimization for High-Dimensional Parameter Spaces

text: A rigorous theoretical understanding of the generalization capabilities of deep generative models, such as Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), remains elusive. Existing generalization bounds are often vacuous for modern, over-parameterized architectures. This paper derives novel, non-vacuous generalization bounds for generative models trained by minimizing the Wasserstein-1 distance. By leveraging the Kantorovich-Rubinstein dual formulation of the Wasserstein distance, we connect the expected generalization error of the generator to the empirical Rademacher complexity of the critic (discriminator) function class. We then establish tight bounds on the Rademacher complexity for deep neural network critics, with an explicit dependence on architectural parameters such as depth, width, and spectral norms of the weight matrices. Our bounds provide a clearer theoretical justification for common regularization techniques like weight decay and spectral normalization in GAN training, illuminating the mechanisms that control generalization performance in the generative setting and explaining their empirical success.
subject: İstatistik
title: Generalization Bounds for Deep Generative Models via Wasserstein Distance and Rademacher Complexity

text: Standard reversible Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) samplers, such as Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC), often exhibit poor mixing when exploring complex, multimodal posterior distributions, as they can become trapped in a single dominant mode. We introduce a novel adaptive, non-reversible MCMC framework designed to efficiently traverse such challenging landscapes. The sampler employs a gradient-based non-reversible kernel, like the Bouncy Particle Sampler (BPS), for rapid local exploration within a mode. This is coupled with a novel adaptation mechanism that monitors geometric properties of the sampler's trajectory to detect modal trapping. Upon detection of stagnation, the sampler dynamically switches to a global mode-jumping kernel, such as one based on parallel tempering, to facilitate inter-modal transitions. The switching protocol is carefully designed to preserve the target stationary distribution. Empirical results on intractable Bayesian mixture models and geophysical inverse problems demonstrate orders-of-magnitude improvement in convergence speed compared to state-of-the-art HMC and static BPS.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Non-Reversible Markov Chain Monte Carlo for Multimodal Posterior Distributions

text: Cryptic speciation is a significant component of biodiversity, yet the genomic architecture underlying incipient reproductive isolation remains poorly understood, particularly in extreme environments. We investigate this phenomenon in the vent-endemic gastropod genus *Alviniconcha*. Using whole-genome sequencing and RAD-seq for over 300 individuals from disparate vent fields across the Pacific-Antarctic Ridge, we uncovered multiple deeply divergent, non-interbreeding lineages. Phylogenetic network analysis and demographic modeling support a scenario of allopatric divergence driven by vicariance events linked to hydrothermal vent field lifespans. We identified specific genomic islands of high differentiation (FST outliers) enriched for genes involved in chemosensory perception, detoxification, and metabolic pathways related to chemosynthetic symbionts. These findings reveal a surprising level of cryptic biodiversity in chemosynthetic ecosystems and demonstrate that ecological specialization can be a powerful driver of reproductive isolation even in the absence of obvious morphological change, reshaping our understanding of speciation processes in the deep sea.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Cryptic Speciation and Ecological Divergence in Hydrothermal Vent Gastropods

text: The evolution of the mammalian placenta was a key innovation, yet the origins of its unique syncytial cell layers remain enigmatic. We hypothesize that ancient endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) provided the fusogenic genes necessary for this development. Through a comprehensive phylogenomic analysis of syncytin-like genes across 150 mammalian genomes, we identified multiple independent ERV capture events at the base of major clades. Our results demonstrate convergent evolution, where distinct retroviral *env* genes were co-opted to fulfill the same cell-fusion function. Using CRISPR-Cas9-mediated knockout in murine trophoblast stem cells, we confirmed the functional necessity of Syncytin-A and -B for cell-cell fusion and normal placentation. Ancestral sequence reconstruction and structural modeling suggest that positive selection acted on the ectodomains of these co-opted proteins, likely to evade host immune responses while retaining fusogenic activity. This study provides compelling evidence that ERV co-option was a recurrent and fundamental molecular mechanism driving macroevolutionary innovation in mammalian reproduction.
subject: Evrim
title: Ancient Retroviral Endogenization as a Catalyst for Synytiotrophoblast Evolution in Mammals

text: The contribution of non-genetic inheritance to adaptation is a central debate in evolutionary biology. We investigated the role of transgenerational epigenetic memory in response to environmental stress using experimental evolution in *Arabidopsis thaliana*. Replicate populations were subjected to recurrent drought stress for ten generations. We employed whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) and RNA-seq to track changes in DNA methylation patterns and gene expression. We found that stress-adapted lineages exhibited significantly higher fitness under drought, an advantage that persisted for at least three generations after stress removal. This adaptive phenotype was strongly correlated with heritable differential methylation in the promoter regions of genes involved in ABA signaling and osmotic stress response. These differentially methylated regions (DMRs) acted as quantitative trait loci (eQTMs), modulating transcriptional plasticity. Our results demonstrate that inherited epigenetic modifications can provide a rapid, quasi-Lamarckian mechanism for adaptation, complementing genetic selection in fluctuating environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance Confers Rapid Adaptive Potential to Environmental Stress

text: The interplay between the host genome and its microbiome is a critical axis of evolution, yet its role in shaping adaptive radiations is poorly defined. We examined this dynamic in the cichlid fishes of Lake Tanganyika. By integrating 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing of gut microbiota with whole-genome resequencing of 25 sympatric cichlid species, we reveal a strong phylogenetic signal in microbiome composition, indicating host-genetic control and long-term co-evolution. We identified significant correlations between microbial community structure and divergence in host major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II genes. Taxa with expanded MHC diversity harbored more species-rich microbiomes. Furthermore, phylogenetic comparative methods show that evolutionary shifts in diet are tightly linked to parallel shifts in both microbial functional guilds and specific immune gene families involved in pathogen recognition. These findings suggest a tripartite co-evolutionary feedback loop between diet, microbiome, and host immunity that facilitates niche partitioning and potentially accelerates speciation.
subject: Evrim
title: Co-evolutionary Dynamics of Host Immune Genes and Gut Microbiome Composition in an Adaptive Radiation of Cichlid Fishes

text: The phylogenetic placement of ctenophores and sponges remains one of the most contentious issues in animal evolution. Traditional phylogenetic methods are often confounded by systematic biases such as long-branch attraction. Here, we leverage single-cell transcriptomics to generate high-quality gene expression profiles from multiple cell types across several key ctenophore and poriferan species. By performing orthogroup clustering and constructing phylogenies based on cell-type-specific gene sets, we mitigate biases from highly divergent genes expressed ubiquitously. Our synteny-aware, site-heterogeneous models robustly place Ctenophora as the sister group to all other Metazoa. Furthermore, we identify a core set of pan-metazoan transcription factors involved in cell differentiation that were previously thought to be eumetazoan-specific. This work not only resolves a long-standing phylogenetic debate but also demonstrates the power of single-cell genomics to provide qualitatively new data for reconstructing deep evolutionary history and understanding the origins of animal cell-type diversity.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Reconstruction of Early Metazoan Relationships Using Single-Cell Transcriptomics from Ctenophores and Sponges

text: Predicting evolutionary trajectories is a fundamental goal of biology, but it is often hindered by the complex mapping between genotype and fitness. We investigated the predictability of adaptation in replicate populations from the *E. coli* long-term evolution experiment (LTEE) using genome-wide mutation tracking and fitness assays of engineered alleles. While parallel evolution was common at the gene level (e.g., in *pykF* and *nadR*), the specific adaptive mutations were highly contingent on the genetic background. We uncovered extensive sign epistasis, where mutations beneficial in early-generation clones were deleterious in later, more-fit backgrounds. This epistatic sign-reversal is largely attributable to antagonistic pleiotropy, where initial mutations optimized one metabolic flux at the cost of another, constraining subsequent evolutionary pathways. These results demonstrate that while the general targets of selection are predictable, the specific genetic solutions are historically contingent, governed by a rugged fitness landscape dominated by pleiotropic constraints and higher-order epistasis.
subject: Evrim
title: Pleiotropic Constraints and Sign Epistasis Shape the Predictability of Evolution in a Long-Term Experiment

text: The emergence of antibiotic resistance poses a global health crisis, yet our ability to predict evolutionary escape pathways is limited. We used deep mutational scanning to systematically quantify the effects of all possible single amino acid substitutions in the TEM-1 β-lactamase enzyme on its ability to hydrolyze a third-generation cephalosporin, cefotaxime. The resulting empirical fitness landscape reveals a sparse network of beneficial mutations, many of which are located far from the active site, suggesting allosteric mechanisms of functional enhancement. We identified multiple distinct evolutionary trajectories to high-level resistance, characterized by significant epistatic interactions where the fitness effect of a mutation is conditional on the presence of others. Notably, several pathways involve transiently deleterious or neutral intermediate steps, highlighting the potential for stochastic tunneling through non-adaptive valleys. These high-resolution fitness maps provide critical data for forecasting resistance evolution and can inform the design of evolution-proof antimicrobial strategies.
subject: Evrim
title: Quantifying the Fitness Landscape of Antibiotic Resistance Evolution via Deep Mutational Scanning

text: Adaptive introgression, the transfer of beneficial alleles between species, is a significant mechanism of rapid evolution. The genetic basis for high-altitude adaptation in Tibetan populations, linked to the *EPAS1* gene, is a classic example. We analyzed whole-genome sequences from diverse Eurasian populations alongside archaic hominin genomes (Neanderthal and Denisovan) to trace the origin of the adaptive *EPAS1* haplotype. Using conditional random field models and identity-by-descent tract analysis, we demonstrate that the entire ~32 kb haplotype block associated with high-altitude adaptation originated in Denisovan-related hominins and introgressed into the ancestors of modern East Asians. The allelic frequency spectrum at this locus shows a deep divergence time incompatible with an origin within *Homo sapiens*. This finding represents one of the clearest cases of adaptive introgression in humans, illustrating how admixture with archaic populations provided pre-adapted genetic variants that were critical for colonization of extreme environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Archaic Hominin Introgression Facilitated High-Altitude Adaptation in Anatomically Modern Humans

text: Phenotypic heterogeneity within isogenic populations can be an adaptive bet-hedging strategy in unpredictable environments. We explored the evolutionary dynamics of this phenomenon by combining theoretical modeling with experimental evolution in *Saccharomyces cerevisiae*. Our stochastic population models predict that noisy gene expression is favored when environmental fluctuations occur on timescales comparable to cell division rates. To test this, we evolved replicate yeast populations in environments with predictably fluctuating carbon sources. Using single-cell RNA sequencing and fluorescent reporter assays, we observed the rapid evolution of increased transcriptional noise in key metabolic genes, such as the GALactose utilization network. This increased heterogeneity was caused by specific cis-regulatory mutations that altered transcription factor binding affinity and chromatin state, leading to more probabilistic transcriptional bursting. Our results provide direct experimental evidence that selection can tune the level of stochastic gene expression to optimize population fitness, establishing non-genetic individuality as a key evolvable trait.
subject: Evrim
title: Stochastic Gene Expression as a Bet-Hedging Strategy in Fluctuating Environments

text: The evolution of cellular complexity is intrinsically linked to the expansion of signaling networks. The relative contributions of whole gene duplication (WGD) and exon/domain shuffling to the genesis of regulatory novelty, however, remain debated. We performed a comprehensive phylogenomic and structural analysis of the tyrosine kinase superfamily across 200 eukaryotic genomes, tracing the evolutionary history of individual protein domains and full-length genes. Our results show that while WGD events, particularly the two rounds in early vertebrates, provided raw genetic material, the subsequent functional diversification was primarily driven by the shuffling of SH2, SH3, and other regulatory domains. We found that novel domain architectures arose at a significantly higher rate following duplication events, suggesting a 'duplication-and-diversify' model. These new architectures facilitated the emergence of new protein-protein interactions, effectively rewiring signaling pathways. This work highlights the synergistic interplay between duplication and shuffling in constructing the complex gene regulatory networks that underpin organismal complexity.
subject: Evrim
title: The Evolutionary Origins of Complex Signaling Networks: Gene Duplication versus Domain Shuffling

text: The analysis of non-standard tuning systems in polyphonic music presents a significant challenge for conventional audio analysis techniques predicated on 12-tone equal temperament. This paper introduces a novel unsupervised framework based on a β-variational autoencoder (β-VAE) to learn latent representations of microtonal tunings directly from audio signals. The model's encoder, a convolutional neural network, maps log-frequency spectrograms to a disentangled latent space, while the decoder reconstructs the spectral information. By imposing a prior on a specific latent dimension corresponding to pitch-class distribution, the model effectively infers the underlying temperament and centroids of a given piece without any labeled data. We evaluate our approach on a synthetic dataset of xenharmonic compositions and real-world recordings of Gamelan and Arabic Maqam music. The results demonstrate superior accuracy in identifying fundamental pitch categories and interval structures compared to traditional clustering algorithms and pitch-class profile methods, offering a robust tool for computational ethnomusicology.
subject: Müzik
title: A Variational Autoencoder Framework for Unsupervised Learning of Microtonal Tuning Systems from Polyphonic Audio

text: Automating Schenkerian analysis, the hierarchical parsing of tonal music, remains a formidable task in computational musicology due to its structural complexity and theoretical abstraction. We propose a probabilistic generative model that formalizes Schenkerian principles within a hierarchical Bayesian framework. The model represents the generation of a musical surface (foreground) as a stochastic process conditioned on latent middleground and background structures, including the Ursatz. This hierarchical dependency is encoded in a graphical model where nodes represent musical events and edges represent reductive relationships. We employ Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods, specifically Gibbs sampling, to perform inference and deduce the most probable Schenkerian graph for a given symbolic musical input. Tested on a corpus of Bach chorales and Mozart piano sonatas, our model generates analyses that exhibit high concordance with expert human annotations, successfully identifying key prolongational spans and structural tones. This approach provides a scalable method for large-scale structural analysis of the tonal repertoire.
subject: Müzik
title: Probabilistic Generative Models for Automated Schenkerian Analysis via Hierarchical Bayesian Inference

text: The quantification of musical timbre, particularly within the combinatorial complexity of an orchestral context, eludes simple parametric description. This study investigates the intrinsic geometric structure of timbre space using non-linear manifold learning techniques. We first compute a high-dimensional feature vector for a comprehensive database of solo instrument samples, incorporating spectral descriptors such as MFCCs, spectral flux, and tristimulus values. Subsequently, we apply Isomap and Laplacian Eigenmaps to embed these feature vectors into a low-dimensional manifold. The resultant geometric representation captures perceptually salient relationships between instruments. We validate the manifold's structure by demonstrating that geodesic distances along its surface correlate strongly (ρ > 0.85) with human listener ratings of timbral similarity. Furthermore, we show that specific axes of the learned space correspond to semantic descriptors like 'brightness' and 'roughness'. This geometric model provides a powerful analytical tool for computer-assisted orchestration and the computational modeling of timbral perception.
subject: Müzik
title: Manifold Learning for the Geometric Modeling of Orchestral Timbre Space and its Correlation with Perceptual Descriptors

text: The relationship between a musician's physical gestures and the resulting acoustic expression is fundamental to performance but computationally challenging to model. This paper employs Deep Canonical Correlation Analysis (DCCA) to uncover the non-linear mappings between these two modalities. We collected a dataset of violin performances, synchronously recording high-resolution motion capture data of the performer's bowing arm and fingering hand, alongside the audio output. A comprehensive set of audio features—including fundamental frequency contours, dynamic envelopes, and timbral descriptors—was extracted. The DCCA model, comprising two deep neural networks, learns a shared latent space in which the correlation between the projected representations of gesture and audio is maximized. The learned canonical variates successfully encode high-level expressive concepts like vibrato extent and attack articulation. This cross-modal approach surpasses linear CCA in predictive power and offers significant implications for expressive performance synthesis, MIR, and pedagogical feedback systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Correspondence between Performative Gesture and Audio Features: A Deep Canonical Correlation Analysis

text: Polyphonic pitch detection is a notoriously difficult inverse problem, often framed as a combinatorial optimization task. This paper introduces a novel algorithm inspired by quantum annealing to identify multiple fundamental frequencies (F0s) in complex audio mixtures. The problem is formulated as minimizing a quadratic unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO) model, whose energy function (or Hamiltonian) encodes music-theoretic constraints. This function rewards spectral component explanations based on harmonic series, penalizes psychoacoustic roughness, and encourages temporal continuity of pitch tracks. By mapping the spectrum to this energy landscape, a quantum-inspired annealing solver can efficiently find the global minimum, corresponding to the most plausible multi-pitch estimate. Evaluated on the Bach10 and MIREX multi-F0 estimation datasets under various signal-to-noise ratios, our method demonstrates superior accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art NMF and deep learning approaches, particularly in acoustically dense and degraded conditions, proposing a new direction for signal processing challenges.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantum-Inspired Annealing for Robust Polyphonic Pitch Detection in Noisy Environments

text: Neo-Riemannian theory offers a powerful framework for analyzing chromatic harmony, yet its application to large corpora has been methodologically limited. We present a scalable, algorithmic approach for discovering and analyzing neo-Riemannian and other transformational networks in symbolic music. Our method models music as a temporal graph where nodes are pitch-class sets (primarily triads) and directed edges represent canonical transformations (P, L, R, and their compounds). Using a specialized subgraph isomorphism search algorithm, we efficiently identify recurring and structurally significant transformational pathways within a given musical work or corpus. We apply this methodology to a large dataset of works by Wagner, Liszt, and Scriabin. The analysis reveals composer-specific proclivities for certain transformational sequences and uncovers long-range harmonic structures organized by parsimonious voice-leading principles. This graph-theoretic formalization provides an empirical foundation for testing and extending music-theoretical hypotheses on a large scale.
subject: Müzik
title: Computational Graph-Theoretic Models for the Analysis of Neo-Riemannian Transformations in Late-Romantic and Atonal Corpora

text: Characterizing the variable and non-standard tuning systems found in world music from noisy field recordings is a central challenge in ethnomusicology. This paper presents a non-parametric Bayesian model to jointly perform pitch estimation and infer latent scalar structures. Our approach utilizes a Dirichlet Process Mixture Model (DPMM) where each mixture component corresponds to a distinct pitch category. This allows the number of scale degrees to be determined by the data itself, avoiding the imposition of a priori assumptions inherent in Western tonal theory. The model's posterior distribution yields robust estimates of pitch-class centroids and their associated uncertainty, even from spectrally ambiguous data. We demonstrate the efficacy of our method on recordings of Thai Piphat ensembles and Zimbabwean Mbira music, successfully identifying complex microtonal intervals and context-dependent intonational patterns. This provides a rigorous, quantitative tool for the empirical study of global intonational diversity.
subject: Müzik
title: A Bayesian Framework for the Inference of Latent Tuning Systems and Scalar Structures from Monophonic Ethnomusicological Field Recordings

text: This paper presents a novel methodology for enhancing music source separation by integrating music-theoretic principles into a standard signal processing framework. We augment the objective function of supervised Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) with a spectro-harmonic prior that guides the decomposition toward musically plausible solutions. This prior is derived from a concurrent probabilistic model of harmonic progression, which calculates the likelihood of vertical sonorities (chords) at each time frame. The NMF's activation matrix is then regularized to favor spectral templates whose joint activations correspond to harmonically consonant structures. This synergy between signal-level decomposition and symbolic-level harmonic analysis significantly reduces crosstalk and artifact generation. Evaluated on the DSD100 dataset, our Harmony-Aware NMF (HA-NMF) outperforms conventional NMF and demonstrates competitive results against deep learning baselines in the separation of pitched instruments from complex polyphonic mixtures, showcasing the benefit of theory-informed signal processing.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectro-Harmonic Priors for Music Source Separation using Non-Negative Matrix Factorization

text: Studies of musical influence have traditionally relied on qualitative musicological analysis. We introduce a quantitative approach using causal discovery algorithms to infer influence networks from data. We curated a diachronic corpus of over 10,000 symbolic scores from Western classical music, representing each composition as a high-dimensional feature vector capturing melodic, harmonic, rhythmic, and textural properties. Treating the stylistic evolution of composers as a multivariate time series, we apply the Peter-Clark (PC) algorithm, a constraint-based causal discovery method, to learn the structure of the underlying Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) of influence. The resulting graph controls for confounding variables (e.g., shared cultural context) and distinguishes direct influence from mere correlation. Our findings recover many historically established influence pathways while also revealing previously unposited connections, providing an empirical, data-driven methodology to investigate cultural transmission and the evolution of musical style.
subject: Müzik
title: Discovering Musical Influence Networks using Causal Discovery Algorithms on a Large-Scale Symbolic Corpus

text: Computational models of musical tension aim to quantify a key aspect of affective response to music, yet their perceptual and neurophysiological validity remains underexplored. This study provides a comprehensive empirical validation of several prominent models, including Lerdahl's Tonal Pitch Space theory and Chew's Spiral Array model. We conducted an experiment where participants provided continuous tension ratings for a set of controlled harmonic stimuli. Simultaneously, we recorded high-density electroencephalography (EEG) data to measure event-related potentials (ERPs). Multiple regression analysis revealed that computational model outputs were significant predictors of both behavioral ratings and the amplitude of the P300 component, a neural marker of contextual updating. Models that incorporate both harmonic distance and voice-leading parsimony demonstrated the highest correlation with empirical data. These results forge a critical link between abstract music-theoretic formalisms, subjective perception, and the underlying neural dynamics of music cognition.
subject: Müzik
title: A Psychoacoustic and Electrophysiological Validation of Computational Models of Tonal Tension and Resolution

text: The three-dimensional organization of the genome is critical for gene regulation, yet the molecular mechanisms governing the formation of insulated neighborhoods remain incompletely understood. Here, we identify ChROMA, a novel long non-coding RNA, as a key architectural component of Topologically Associating Domain (TAD) boundaries. Using high-resolution chromosome conformation capture (Hi-C) and super-resolution microscopy, we demonstrate that ChROMA localizes to specific CTCF/cohesin binding sites, strengthening their insulator activity. Mechanistically, ChROMA possesses intrinsically disordered regions that drive liquid-liquid phase separation, forming transcriptional condensates that recruit and stabilize the CTCF-cohesin complex. Depletion of ChROMA results in the dissolution of these condensates, weakening TAD boundaries and leading to aberrant enhancer-promoter communication, as evidenced by promoter-capture Hi-C. Our findings reveal a paradigm where lncRNA-mediated phase separation acts as a dynamic scaffold to enforce chromatin architecture, providing a new layer of regulatory control over genome topology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The lncRNA ChROMA Orchestrates Topologically Associating Domain Boundary Formation via Phase Separation with CTCF

text: Homologous recombination (HR) is a high-fidelity pathway for repairing DNA double-strand breaks, initiated by the formation of a RAD51 nucleoprotein filament on resected single-stranded DNA. The dynamic process of homology search by this filament is fundamental to repair accuracy. Employing single-molecule Förster Resonance Energy Transfer (smFRET) combined with optical tweezers, we dissect the real-time conformational dynamics of human RAD51 filaments. Our data reveal that the filament exists in a dynamic equilibrium between a compressed, inactive state and an extended, active state, with the transition gated by ATP hydrolysis. The presence of a homologous dsDNA template biases this equilibrium towards the extended conformation, facilitating strand invasion. Furthermore, we find that the recombination mediator BRCA2 stabilizes this active state, increasing the processivity of the homology search. These results provide unprecedented nanoscopic insights into the HR mechanism, highlighting allosteric regulation of the RAD51 filament as a critical checkpoint for genomic integrity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Single-Molecule FRET Reveals Conformational Dynamics of RAD51 Nucleoprotein Filaments During Homology Search

text: Stress granules (SGs) are membraneless organelles that form via liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) in response to cellular stress, sequestering mRNAs to modulate translation. The internal organization of SGs and its functional consequences are poorly defined. Using proximity-dependent biotinylation (APEX2) targeted to distinct SG-resident proteins, we performed spatially resolved proteomic analysis to map the SG interactome. Our results uncover a stratified, core-shell architecture. The core is enriched in ATP-dependent RNA helicases and core nucleating proteins like G3BP1, while the shell is populated by proteins involved in mRNA decay and translational re-initiation. Super-resolution microscopy validates this structure. We demonstrate that mRNAs destined for degradation are preferentially localized to the shell, while mRNAs slated for storage and later translation are sequestered in the core. This spatial organization suggests a functional model of mRNA triage, where the distinct physicochemical properties of SG sub-compartments dictate the fate of sequestered transcripts.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Proteomic Profiling of Stress Granule Sub-compartments Reveals a Core-Shell Architecture Dictating mRNA Triage

text: Transcriptional memory, the ability of a cell to more rapidly reactivate a gene upon subsequent stimulation, is a key feature of cellular adaptation. We investigated the role of the histone variant H3.3 in this process. Using inducible gene systems in mammalian cells coupled with chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) and Assay for Transposase-Accessible Chromatin (ATAC-seq), we show that transcriptionally active genes are marked by H3.3. Following transcriptional cessation, H3.3 is retained at promoter and enhancer regions, a process dependent on the HIRA chaperone complex. This H3.3 'footprint' maintains a locally accessible chromatin architecture, characterized by persistent H3K4me1 and reduced H3K27me3, even in the absence of active transcription. Upon re-induction, these H3.3-marked genes exhibit significantly faster transcriptional kinetics compared to naïve genes. Our findings establish that HIRA-mediated H3.3 deposition acts as an epigenetic bookmark, poising chromatin for future activation and providing a molecular basis for transcriptional memory.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Histone Variant H3.3 Deposition by the HIRA Complex Establishes a Poised Chromatin State for Rapid Transcriptional Reactivation

text: The CRISPR-Cas12a nuclease is a powerful tool for genome engineering, but its precise mechanism of target DNA cleavage remains partially elusive. Here, we present high-resolution cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structures of Lachnospiraceae bacterium Cas12a in complex with its crRNA and a target DNA molecule, capturing snapshots immediately preceding and following strand cleavage. The structures reveal that upon R-loop formation, a conserved 'Lid' domain induces a sharp bend in the non-target DNA strand, destabilizing the PAM-distal region of the duplex. This conformational stress is propagated to the nuclease (Nuc) domain, priming it for catalytic activity. We identified a critical arginine residue that acts as a sensor for R-loop propagation, allosterically activating the Nuc domain only upon full target engagement. These structural insights delineate a multi-step checkpoint mechanism ensuring high-fidelity cleavage and provide a rational basis for engineering Cas12a variants with enhanced specificity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structures of the CRISPR-Cas12a R-loop Complex Reveal Mechanisms of PAM-Distal DNA Destabilization and Cleavage

text: The specificity of cellular signaling through the NF-κB pathway is encoded by the topology of ubiquitin chains modifying key adaptor proteins. While the roles of K63-linked and M1-linked (linear) chains in signal activation are established, signal termination mechanisms are less clear. Using a novel mass spectrometry-based approach, Ubi-clicpMS, we identified complex, branched ubiquitin architectures in vivo following TNFα stimulation. We discovered a novel K48/M1 hybrid chain topology on the NEMO/IKKγ subunit. These branched chains are synthesized by the E3 ligase LUBAC in concert with a proteasomal E2-E3 cascade. Functionally, these hybrid chains serve as a high-avidity binding platform for the deubiquitinase A20, which preferentially dismantles the activating M1 linkages, while the K48 linkage targets the complex for subsequent degradation. This reveals a sophisticated ubiquitin code that integrates signal activation and termination within a single molecular scaffold.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mass Spectrometric Interrogation of Ubiquitin Chain Topology Reveals K48/M1 Hybrid Chains as a Scaffold for NF-κB Signal Termination

text: Dysregulation of protein synthesis is a hallmark of cancer, yet the full landscape of translational control in oncogenesis remains uncharacterized. By performing ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) across a large panel of primary human tumors and matched normal tissues, we have generated a comprehensive atlas of cancer-specific translation. Our analysis reveals thousands of previously unannotated translation initiation sites (TISs), many located within upstream open reading frames (uORFs) or at alternative non-AUG codons. A significant fraction of these non-canonical TISs give rise to N-terminally extended or truncated protein isoforms of known proto-oncogenes, such as MYC and KRAS. We demonstrate that specific oncogenic mutations in signaling pathways like PI3K/AKT/mTOR directly rewire TIS selection, favoring the production of hyperactive protein variants. These findings expose a hidden layer of the cancer proteome and identify non-canonical translation initiation as a widespread mechanism of oncogene activation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Pan-Cancer Ribosome Profiling Uncovers Pervasive Non-canonical Translation Initiation Driving Oncogene Expression

text: The maintenance of telomere length by telomerase is essential for cellular immortality, but the choreography of its assembly and recruitment is poorly understood. We determined the 3.2 Å cryo-electron microscopy structure of the human telomerase catalytic core (TERT and TERC RNA) in complex with the shelterin protein TPP1. The structure reveals an unanticipated interface where the OB-fold domain of TPP1 directly engages the TEN domain of TERT, allosterically remodeling the active site into a catalytically competent conformation. This interaction is independent of the canonical TPP1-TIN2 shelterin bridge, providing a direct physical link for recruitment. Disruption of this specific TPP1-TERT interface via structure-guided mutagenesis abolishes telomerase recruitment to telomeres and induces premature senescence, without affecting holoenzyme integrity. Our work elucidates a critical, dual function for TPP1 in both recruiting and activating telomerase, providing a high-resolution blueprint for targeting this interaction therapeutically.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural Basis of Telomerase Holoenzyme Assembly and Recruitment to Telomeres via TPP1-TERT Interaction

text: The interplay between histone modifications and DNA methylation is fundamental to establishing stable gene repression during development. However, the mechanism by which Polycomb-mediated H3K27 trimethylation (H3K27me3) directs DNA methylation remains controversial. Using a reconstituted in vitro system and single-locus epigenetic editing in embryonic stem cells, we demonstrate a direct causal link. We show that the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) component, EZH2, following its deposition of H3K27me3, directly recruits the de novo DNA methyltransferase DNMT3A via its PWWP domain. This interaction is stabilized by the H3K27me3 mark itself, creating a positive feedback loop. Genome-wide analysis using ChIP-seq and whole-genome bisulfite sequencing shows that loss of this EZH2-DNMT3A interaction leads to focal hypomethylation at Polycomb-targeted developmental gene promoters. This writer-reader-writer mechanism provides a direct pathway for epigenetic crosstalk, ensuring the robust silencing of lineage-inappropriate genes.
subject: Biyoloji
title: EZH2-mediated H3K27me3 Guides De Novo DNA Methylation in a Writer-Reader-Writer Epigenetic Crosstalk Circuit

text: The spliceosome is a dynamic macromolecular machine responsible for pre-mRNA splicing, and its dysregulation is linked to numerous diseases. We report the discovery of a novel class of small-molecule inhibitors that potently modulate splicing activity. Through a combination of high-throughput screening and cryo-electron microscopy, we resolved the structure of the human spliceosome B-act complex bound to our lead compound, H3B-8800. The structure reveals that H3B-8800 binds to a previously uncharacterized cryptic pocket within the SF3B1 subunit, a core component of the U2 snRNP. This binding allosterically locks the spliceosome in an inactive conformation, preventing the catalytic activation required for the first transesterification step. This mechanism differs from known SF3B1 modulators like Pladienolide B. In patient-derived xenografts of myelodysplastic syndromes harboring SF3B1 mutations, H3B-8800 demonstrates potent anti-tumor activity. Our findings expose a new druggable node in the spliceosome for splicing-factor-mutant cancers.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Cryptic Allosteric Pocket in the SF3B1 Subunit of the Spliceosome is a Target for Potent Splicing Modulators

text: Standard diffusion probabilistic models operate in Euclidean space, limiting their applicability to data with inherent non-Euclidean geometric structures, such as spherical or hyperbolic data. We introduce Geodesic Diffusion Models (GDMs), a novel framework for generative modeling directly on Riemannian manifolds. Our approach defines the forward diffusion process as a stochastic differential equation (SDE) on the manifold, where noise is added along geodesic paths. The reverse-time generative process is formulated by learning a score function with respect to the manifold's metric tensor. We derive a new evidence lower bound objective for training GDMs via Riemannian score matching and propose an efficient solver for the reverse-time SDE using exponential maps. We demonstrate state-of-the-art performance on generative tasks for spherical image data (S2), protein rotational data (SO(3)), and hyperbolic graph embeddings (Hn), showcasing GDMs' ability to capture complex topological features and generate high-fidelity, geometrically consistent samples.
subject: AI
title: Geodesic Diffusion Models on Riemannian Manifolds for Generative Modeling of Non-Euclidean Data

text: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) in settings with partial observability and non-stationary opponents remains a formidable challenge. We propose Counterfactual Policy Gradients (CPG), a scalable MARL algorithm that enables decentralized agents to coordinate complex strategies. CPG extends single-agent policy gradient methods by incorporating a centralized critic that computes a counterfactual advantage function. This function isolates an individual agent's contribution to the global reward, mitigating the credit assignment problem. To handle non-stationarity, the critic is conditioned on an inferred belief state of opponent policies, modeled via a recurrent neural network. This allows agents to dynamically adapt their strategies. We prove that CPG converges to a correlated equilibrium under specific assumptions. Empirically, CPG achieves superior performance and faster convergence in challenging coordination benchmarks, including cooperative navigation and stochastic games, outperforming existing value-decomposition and independent learning methods, especially under high degrees of partial observability.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Policy Gradients for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning in Non-Stationary, Partially Observable Environments

text: Federated learning (FL) struggles with statistical heterogeneity across clients, leading to client drift and suboptimal model personalization. To address this, we present Personalized Meta-Federated Learning (PMFL), a novel framework that leverages hypernetworks and meta-learning. Instead of learning a single global model, PMFL trains a central hypernetwork that generates client-specific model parameters based on a low-dimensional client embedding. These embeddings are learned concurrently and capture the unique data distribution characteristics of each client. The meta-learning objective is formulated to optimize the hypernetwork for fast adaptation on local client data, effectively learning to personalize. This approach mitigates client drift by decoupling the shared knowledge (in the hypernetwork) from the personalized parameters. We provide theoretical convergence guarantees and demonstrate empirically on several non-IID datasets that PMFL significantly outperforms canonical FL methods like FedAvg and state-of-the-art personalization techniques in terms of accuracy, fairness, and communication efficiency.
subject: AI
title: Personalized Meta-Federated Learning via Hypernetwork-Modulated Client Adaptation

text: Randomized smoothing is a scalable, provable method for certifying the robustness of neural networks against adversarial perturbations. However, its effectiveness is often limited in pixel space, especially for large perturbation radii. We propose Latent Diffeomorphic Smoothing (LDS), a novel certification framework that applies smoothing in a semantically meaningful latent space of a generative model. We first train a variational autoencoder (VAE) with a diffeomorphic flow-based decoder, ensuring that the latent space topology is well-behaved. The classifier is then trained on latent representations of clean data. For certification, we propagate the L_p-norm-bounded perturbation from the input space through the encoder to the latent space and compute a certified radius for a smoothed version of the latent classifier. Our key theoretical contribution is a method to tightly bound the propagated perturbation in the latent space. LDS yields significantly larger certified radii and higher certified accuracy on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet compared to state-of-the-art smoothing techniques.
subject: AI
title: Certified Adversarial Robustness via Latent Space Randomized Smoothing with Diffeomorphic Transformations

text: Estimating causal effects from observational data is hampered by unobserved confounding. Instrumental variable (IV) methods offer a potential solution but are challenging to apply with high-dimensional instruments and treatments. We introduce the Variational Causal Network (VCN), a deep learning framework for robust causal effect estimation in the presence of complex confounding. The VCN employs a variational autoencoder architecture to learn a low-dimensional latent representation of the treatment that is informed by the instruments but is unconfounded with the outcome. Causal effects are then estimated via a two-stage regression process within this latent space. We formulate a novel evidence lower bound objective that explicitly encourages independence between the learned representation and the confounders. We demonstrate through extensive simulation studies and application to real-world econometric and biomedical datasets that VCN consistently outperforms existing deep IV methods, especially under conditions of instrument weakness and high-dimensional, non-linear confounding structures.
subject: AI
title: Deep Instrumental Variable Regression with Variational Causal Networks for High-Dimensional Confounding

text: Real-world systems are characterized by dynamic, higher-order interactions that cannot be sufficiently modeled by pairwise static graphs. We introduce the Temporal Hypergraph Neural Network with Attentional Point Process Aggregation (THAP), a novel architecture for representation learning on dynamic hypergraphs. Unlike conventional GNNs, THAP explicitly models the multi-way, time-dependent nature of interactions. Each hyperedge's temporal evolution is modeled as a neural temporal point process, which informs the time-aware aggregation of node features. We propose a novel, fully-attentional message passing scheme where attention weights are functions of both node states and the inter-event time intervals, allowing the model to capture complex temporal dependencies within higher-order structures. THAP operates on continuous-time data without requiring discrete snapshots. We evaluate our model on dynamic node classification and link prediction tasks using several real-world datasets, including co-authorship networks and social interaction data, demonstrating significant improvements over state-of-the-art dynamic graph and hypergraph models.
subject: AI
title: Temporal Hypergraph Neural Networks with Attentional Point Process Aggregation

text: Standard Transformer architectures struggle to efficiently capture hierarchical structures and complex relational dependencies inherent in sequential data. We propose Quaternion-based Rotational Attention (QRA), a novel attention mechanism that embeds tokens in the quaternion space H and utilizes Hamilton products to model compositional relationships. Instead of dot-product similarity, QRA computes attention scores based on rotational alignment between query and key vectors, effectively encoding relative positional and hierarchical information. The value vectors are rotated by learned quaternion transformations, enabling a more expressive synthesis of information. This approach introduces a strong relational inductive bias with minimal parameter overhead compared to standard multi-head attention. We integrate QRA into a Transformer architecture and demonstrate its superior performance on tasks requiring hierarchical reasoning, such as algorithmic problem-solving, code generation, and long-range natural language inference. QRA not only improves accuracy but also exhibits enhanced data efficiency and generalization to out-of-distribution sequence lengths.
subject: AI
title: Quaternion-based Rotational Attention for Capturing Hierarchical and Relational Inductive Biases in Transformers

text: Meta-learning algorithms aim to learn adaptable models from a distribution of tasks. However, most methods provide point estimates, failing to quantify uncertainty during few-shot adaptation. We introduce Amortized Bayesian Meta-Learning (ABML), a scalable framework for learning a posterior distribution over functions that can be rapidly updated with new task data. We frame meta-learning as hierarchical Bayesian inference and employ functional variational inference, where a hyper-network amortizes the inference process by mapping a task's dataset to an approximate posterior in function space. This posterior is represented by a Bayesian neural network. ABML not only facilitates fast adaptation but also provides well-calibrated epistemic uncertainty estimates, which are crucial for active learning and out-of-distribution detection in few-shot settings. We evaluate ABML on challenging few-shot regression and classification benchmarks, showing it achieves competitive predictive performance while providing superior uncertainty quantification compared to prominent meta-learning algorithms like MAML and prototypical networks.
subject: AI
title: Amortized Bayesian Meta-Learning with Functional Variational Inference for Few-Shot Adaptation

text: Ensuring fairness in machine learning models is critical, yet challenging for black-box systems where the internal logic is inaccessible. We propose Generative Adversarial Deconfounding (GAD), a novel framework for auditing and mitigating counterfactual fairness violations in any pre-trained model. GAD operates by learning a structural causal model of the data-generating process. It employs a generative adversarial network, conditioned on sensitive attributes, to generate counterfactual data points—synthetic examples of what would have happened had an individual's sensitive attribute been different, while holding all other background factors constant. By feeding these counterfactual pairs to the black-box model, we can directly measure individual and group-level counterfactual fairness. For mitigation, the generated counterfactuals are used to augment the training data for a new, debiased model. We demonstrate GAD's efficacy in identifying and rectifying fairness violations in commercial AI systems for loan applications and recidivism prediction, outperforming existing fairness auditing techniques.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Fairness Auditing and Mitigation using Generative Adversarial Deconfounding

text: Quantifying predictive uncertainty is paramount for deploying deep learning models in safety-critical domains. Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs) provide a principled framework but are often computationally intractable. We propose the Neural Stochastic Differential Equation (NSDE) framework, a scalable alternative for learning and inference in deep models. We model the evolution of network weights during training as an Itô stochastic process, governed by a learnable drift and diffusion term. The training objective minimizes the KL-divergence between the trajectory of the learned SDE and a target posterior process. This perspective unifies stochastic gradient MCMC methods and deep ensembles under a single continuous-time framework. At inference time, predictions are made by solving the learned SDE forward in time, yielding a distribution over outputs. Our method produces well-calibrated uncertainty estimates, scales to large architectures like ResNets, and achieves state-of-the-art results on out-of-distribution detection and adversarial robustness benchmarks, outperforming deep ensembles and variational BNNs.
subject: AI
title: Neural Stochastic Differential Equations for Scalable and Calibrated Uncertainty Quantification in Deep Learning

text: We present a novel framework for modeling large-scale, non-stationary spatiotemporal data. The core of our model is a latent Gaussian Process (GP) whose covariance structure is implicitly defined through a stochastic partial differential equation (SPDE). Non-stationarity is introduced by allowing the parameters of the SPDE, such as diffusivity and advection, to vary spatially as a function of covariates. For computational tractability, we employ a finite element method (FEM) representation, which transforms the latent GP into a Gaussian Markov Random Field (GMRF) with a sparse precision matrix. Inference is performed using Integrated Nested Laplace Approximations (INLA), enabling rapid and accurate posterior marginal estimation without resorting to MCMC. This circumvents the prohibitive cubic complexity of standard GP regression. We demonstrate the model's flexibility and scalability on a large dataset of global sea surface temperatures, capturing complex, spatially varying anisotropic dynamics missed by stationary and simpler non-stationary models.
subject: İstatistik
title: A Scalable Bayesian Hierarchical Model for Non-Stationary Spatiotemporal Processes using Latent Stochastic Differential Equations

text: This paper addresses the problem of estimating average treatment effects (ATE) in observational studies with high-dimensional confounders. We propose a debiased machine learning framework that leverages cross-fitting and orthogonalized moment functions to construct a robust estimator. The procedure utilizes flexible, non-parametric learners (e.g., gradient boosting, random forests) to estimate the nuisance functions—the propensity score and the conditional outcome mean—thereby mitigating bias from model misspecification. By solving a Neyman-orthogonal moment equation, our estimator is rendered first-order insensitive to errors in the nuisance function estimation, a key property for achieving semi-parametric efficiency. We prove that the resulting estimator is asymptotically normal and consistent under weaker sparsity assumptions than required by competing methods like the double-LASSO. Finite-sample performance is evaluated via extensive Monte Carlo simulations, demonstrating superior bias reduction and nominal confidence interval coverage compared to standard doubly robust estimators and targeted maximum likelihood estimation (TMLE).
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Machine Learning for Doubly Robust Treatment Effect Estimation with High-Dimensional Confounders

text: We introduce a novel framework for conducting statistical inference on topological features derived from persistent homology. A central challenge in topological data analysis (TDA) is quantifying the uncertainty of persistence diagrams, which often precludes formal hypothesis testing. Our proposed method, the multi-scale bootstrap, constructs confidence regions for persistence diagrams by resampling from a kernel density estimate of the underlying data-generating distribution at multiple bandwidths. This approach corrects for bootstrap inconsistencies that arise in standard subsampling schemes for topological summaries. We establish the theoretical validity of our method, proving its consistency in the bottleneck and Wasserstein metrics under mild regularity conditions. The procedure yields valid p-values for the existence of topological features (e.g., loops, voids) and enables the construction of confidence bands for persistence landscapes. Its efficacy is demonstrated in differentiating cosmological models from N-body simulations and in analyzing structural variations in cryo-EM protein data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Statistically Rigorous Inference for Persistent Homology using a Multi-Scale Bootstrap

text: This paper introduces a dynamic extension of the Stochastic Block Model (SBM) for analyzing temporal networks where community structures and node affiliations evolve over time. Our proposed model incorporates a hidden Markov model (HMM) to govern the temporal transitions of latent community assignments for each node, capturing smooth or abrupt changes in network topology. Furthermore, we integrate node-specific, time-varying covariates into the edge-formation probability matrix via a logistic link function, allowing for interpretable inference on the drivers of network dynamics. We develop a scalable variational expectation-maximization (VEM) algorithm for posterior inference, which jointly estimates community assignments, model parameters, and covariate effects. The method's efficacy is demonstrated on a longitudinal social network dataset and a dynamic protein-protein interaction network, providing new insights into the mechanisms of community formation and dissolution that are obscured by static or memoryless dynamic models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Stochastic Block Models for Evolving Community Structures with Node-Level Covariates

text: We extend classical Functional Principal Component Analysis (FPCA) to accommodate data whose realizations are curves on a non-Euclidean Riemannian manifold. This is critical for analyzing data such as directional time series on a sphere or trajectories of covariance matrices. Our approach defines principal geodesic components via a Karhunen-Loève expansion in the tangent space at the Fréchet mean of the observed functional data. We propose an iterative estimation algorithm based on principal geodesic analysis and local linearization, effectively mapping the manifold-valued problem into a sequence of vector-space FPCA problems. We establish theoretical convergence rates for the estimated mean and eigenfunctions under mild geometric and smoothness assumptions. The method's utility is demonstrated in analyzing human motion capture data on the manifold of rotations SO(3) and satellite tracking trajectories on the sphere S², revealing intrinsic modes of variation that are fundamentally misinterpreted by Euclidean approaches.
subject: İstatistik
title: Manifold-Valued Functional Principal Component Analysis for Spatiotemporal Trajectory Data

text: We propose a novel robust regression methodology for high-dimensional settings where data may be contaminated by both vertical outliers and leverage points. The method combines a robust M-estimator, such as the Huber loss, with a composite penalty that is a convex combination of the L1-norm for variable selection and a group penalty on mean-shift parameters for outlier identification. This unified framework allows for simultaneous robust parameter estimation, sparse variable selection, and explicit outlier detection. We develop an efficient block coordinate descent algorithm that leverages majorization-minimization principles to handle the non-convexity of certain M-estimators. Theoretical analysis establishes oracle properties for the coefficient and outlier parameter estimators under specific regularity conditions, ensuring consistency in both variable selection and outlier identification. Monte Carlo simulations and an application to a gene expression dataset highlight its superior performance over existing methods like LAD-LASSO and robust LARS.
subject: İstatistik
title: Robust Penalized Regression with Composite Absolute Penalties for Simultaneous Outlier Detection and Variable Selection

text: We develop a flexible semiparametric regression framework for analyzing competing risks data by modeling the subdistribution hazard function, as proposed by Fine and Gray. Our approach extends this classical model by incorporating an unknown, monotone transformation of the time scale, which relaxes the restrictive proportional hazards assumption and accommodates a wide range of hazard shapes. The resulting class of transformation models includes both the proportional subdistribution hazards and proportional odds models as special cases. We formulate the estimation procedure using a system of generalized estimating equations based on inverse probability of censoring weights. This approach naturally handles right-censored data and time-varying covariates. We establish the asymptotic normality and consistency of the resulting estimators for both the regression coefficients and the transformation function. The method’s practical utility is illustrated through simulation studies and a re-analysis of a clinical trial dataset on bone marrow transplantation.
subject: İstatistik
title: A Semiparametric Transformation Model for the Fine-Gray Subdistribution Hazard with Time-Varying Covariates

text: We derive novel PAC-Bayesian generalization bounds for deep neural networks that account for the non-Gaussian, heavy-tailed nature of empirically successful weight distributions. Classical PAC-Bayes bounds, often based on Gaussian priors and posteriors, yield vacuous results for overparameterized models. Our framework leverages α-stable distributions as priors and develops a corresponding change-of-measure inequality tailored to these distributions. The resulting bound depends on the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence between a heavy-tailed prior and a data-dependent posterior, explicitly characterizing the trade-off between empirical risk and model complexity measured in a geometry sensitive to tail behavior. This analysis provides a theoretical justification for using heavy-tailed regularizers, showing how they can induce a form of sparsity that leads to tighter, non-vacuous generalization guarantees. Our bounds are among the first to formally connect the implicit bias of optimization algorithms favoring flat, heavy-tailed minima with provable generalization performance.
subject: İstatistik
title: PAC-Bayesian Generalization Bounds for Deep Neural Networks with Heavy-Tailed Priors

text: This paper introduces a novel method for estimating the structure of high-dimensional Gaussian graphical models by leveraging concepts from optimal transport. We reframe the problem of precision matrix estimation as a Wasserstein distance minimization problem between the empirical distribution and the model class, subject to sparsity constraints. This OT-based objective function provides a natural geometric alternative to traditional likelihood-based approaches and exhibits enhanced robustness to data contamination. We propose a computationally efficient algorithm based on a Sinkhorn-regularized proximal gradient method to solve the resulting optimization problem. Theoretically, we establish non-asymptotic error bounds for the estimated precision matrix in the matrix L1-norm, demonstrating that our method achieves minimax optimal rates of convergence under standard sparsity assumptions. We show via simulation that our Optimal Transport Graphical Lasso (OT-GLASSO) outperforms the standard graphical lasso and its robust variants, especially in settings with heavy-tailed or skewed data distributions.
subject: İstatistik
title: Optimal Transport for High-Dimensional Graphical Model Selection

text: We consider the problem of estimating natural direct and indirect effects in a causal mediation setting where the mediator is high-dimensional and there exists a treatment-induced confounder of the mediator-outcome relationship. Existing methods fail to adequately address this complex scenario. We propose a novel two-stage regression approach that combines variable selection with g-computation. In the first stage, we use a penalized regression model to identify the subset of the high-dimensional mediator that actively mediates the treatment effect. In the second stage, we use a sequential g-formula to estimate the counterfactual outcomes needed for the mediation effects, correctly adjusting for the post-treatment confounding. We provide rigorous theoretical conditions under which our method yields consistent and asymptotically normal estimators of the natural direct and indirect effects. The methodology is illustrated using simulations and applied to a genomic study to disentangle the pathways through which a genetic variant influences a clinical outcome via gene expression levels.
subject: İstatistik
title: Causal Mediation Analysis with a High-Dimensional Mediator and Post-Treatment Confounding

text: Telomerase, a reverse transcriptase essential for maintaining telomere integrity, is a ribonucleoprotein complex whose assembly remains incompletely understood. Here, we elucidate the molecular basis of the interaction between the catalytic subunit, TERT, and the chaperone TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein 1). Using cryo-electron microscopy and hydrogen-deuterium exchange mass spectrometry, we reveal a specific interface where the N-terminal domain of TERT engages the ATPase domain of TRAP1. This interaction is ATP-dependent and facilitates a conformational rearrangement in the TERT TEN domain, priming it for efficient binding of the telomerase RNA component (TR). Functional assays using CRISPR-engineered cell lines with mutations at the interface demonstrate impaired telomerase activity and accelerated telomere shortening. Our findings establish TRAP1 as a critical co-chaperone in the telomerase biogenesis pathway, mediating a key conformational checkpoint that ensures the fidelity of holoenzyme assembly. This interaction presents a novel, druggable target for therapeutic strategies aimed at modulating telomerase activity in cancer and aging.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural and Mechanistic Insights into Telomerase Holoenzyme Assembly via TERT-TRAP1 Interaction

text: Epigenetic reprogramming is a hallmark of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), yet the underlying mechanisms remain obscure. We investigated the role of KDM6A, a histone H3 lysine 27 (H3K27me3) demethylase, in PDAC pathogenesis. Integrated analysis of ChIP-seq and RNA-seq data from patient-derived organoids revealed that KDM6A loss-of-function mutations lead to hypermethylation of H3K27 at key developmental gene enhancers, suppressing lineage-specifying transcription factors like GATA6. This epigenetic silencing induces a switch towards a quasi-mesenchymal, progenitor-like state characterized by heightened invasiveness and therapeutic resistance. Mechanistically, KDM6A is recruited to chromatin by FOXA1, and its absence permits the unopposed activity of the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2). Pharmacological inhibition of the PRC2 catalytic subunit EZH2 partially restores the epithelial phenotype and sensitizes KDM6A-deficient tumors to chemotherapy, highlighting a synthetic lethal strategy for this aggressive PDAC subtype. Our results define a critical KDM6A-PRC2 axis governing cellular identity and therapeutic vulnerability in pancreatic cancer.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dysregulation of H3K27me3 Demethylase KDM6A Promotes Oncogenic Transcriptional Plasticity in Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are emerging as critical regulators of neuronal function. We identified LINC01234, a previously uncharacterized lncRNA highly expressed in the hippocampus. Using in situ hybridization, we localized LINC01234 to dendritic compartments of CA1 pyramidal neurons. Bioinformatic analysis and subsequent luciferase reporter assays identified multiple binding sites for miR-124, a microRNA known to repress synaptic protein synthesis. Overexpression of LINC01234 in primary hippocampal cultures sequestered endogenous miR-124, leading to the de-repression of its target, GRIA2, which encodes the AMPA receptor subunit GluA2. Electrophysiological recordings from acute hippocampal slices demonstrated that LINC01234 knockdown impairs long-term potentiation (LTP), a phenotype rescued by a miR-124 inhibitor. These findings uncover a novel ceRNA (competing endogenous RNA) network where LINC01234 acts as a molecular sponge for miR-124, thereby fine-tuning GluA2 expression and dynamically regulating synaptic strength and plasticity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Novel Long Non-Coding RNA, LINC01234, Modulates Synaptic Plasticity by Sponging miR-124 and Regulating GRIA2 Translation

text: Stress granules (SGs) are membraneless organelles that form via liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) in response to cellular stress, sequestering translationally stalled mRNAs. The molecular grammar governing their assembly is complex. Here, we demonstrate that the DEAD-box RNA helicase DDX3X is a pivotal scaffold for SG formation. Using live-cell imaging and in vitro reconstitution assays, we show that DDX3X contains intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs) that undergo LLPS upon ATP depletion or in the presence of RNA. This process is nucleated by G3BP1 but is critically dependent on the multivalent RNA-binding capacity of DDX3X. Optogenetic clustering of DDX3X is sufficient to induce bona fide SG formation. Furthermore, phosphomimetic mutations within its N-terminal IDR, which are known to occur during stress, enhance its phase separation propensity. Our results establish DDX3X as a key biophysical regulator of SG assembly, integrating stress signaling with the material properties of the cytoplasm to control mRNA fate.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phase Separation of the RNA Helicase DDX3X Orchestrates Stress Granule Assembly and Dynamics

text: The TRiC/CCT chaperonin is essential for folding a subset of the eukaryotic proteome, including actin and tubulin. However, its full client scope and the principles governing substrate recognition are not fully elucidated. We employed a quantitative proteomics approach combining affinity purification-mass spectrometry with differential scanning fluorimetry to identify novel TRiC interactors. Our analysis revealed a significant enrichment for proteins with large intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs), including key signaling scaffolds and transcription factors. Using cryo-EM and kinetic assays, we demonstrate that the TRiC apical domains recognize specific short linear motifs embedded within these IDRs. The subsequent ATP-hydrolysis-driven conformational change within the TRiC chamber facilitates the collapse of the IDR into a compact, functional fold, preventing its aggregation. This work redefines TRiC's primary role as a specialized folding machine for IDR-containing proteins, a critical function for maintaining network integrity and preventing proteotoxicity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The Chaperonin TRiC/CCT Complex Mediates Proteostasis by Selectively Folding Intrinsically Disordered Protein Clients

text: Cellular senescence is a complex stress response implicated in aging and age-related diseases. While typically associated with the p53 and p16/Rb pathways, alternative mechanisms remain to be explored. We report that mitochondrial dysfunction, induced by mild inhibition of the electron transport chain, triggers a robust senescence program independent of canonical DNA damage signaling. This phenotype is characterized by the release of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) into the cytosol. Using immunofluorescence and cellular fractionation, we show this cytosolic mtDNA is recognized by the DNA sensor cGAS, leading to the activation of the STING-TBK1-IRF3 signaling axis. This results in a type-I interferon response and the establishment of a unique Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotype (SASP) enriched in pro-inflammatory cytokines. Genetic ablation of cGAS or STING abrogates mitochondrial stress-induced senescence. Our findings reveal an innate immune signaling cascade as a potent, p53-independent driver of senescence, linking mitochondrial homeostasis directly to cellular aging.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cytosolic mtDNA Released During Mitochondrial Stress Activates the cGAS-STING Pathway to Induce a p53-Independent Senescent Phenotype

text: The CRISPR-Cas12a (Cpf1) nuclease is a versatile genome editing tool, but its utility is hampered by off-target activity. To address this, we performed a comprehensive structural and functional analysis to identify the molecular determinants of its DNA recognition fidelity. We determined that non-specific interactions between the REC2 domain and the phosphate backbone of the non-target DNA strand contribute significantly to off-target binding. Through structure-guided protein engineering, we introduced charge-reversal mutations (e.g., K848A/R851A) within this domain to create 'enhanced-fidelity' Cas12a (enCas12a). Genome-wide, unbiased identification of DSBs enabled by sequencing (GUIDE-seq) revealed that enCas12a exhibits a dramatic reduction in off-target cleavage across multiple genomic loci, while maintaining robust on-target editing efficiency comparable to the wild-type enzyme. This engineered nuclease represents a significant advance, providing a safer and more precise tool for therapeutic genome editing applications where specificity is paramount.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Development of a High-Fidelity Cas12a Variant by Structure-Guided Engineering to Eliminate Off-Target DNA Cleavage

text: Autophagy is a catabolic process critical for cellular homeostasis. Beyond its canonical role in bulk degradation, non-canonical autophagy pathways have emerged as key regulators of inflammation. We investigated the mechanism by which ATG16L1, a core autophagy protein, suppresses NLRP3 inflammasome activation. Following lysosomal damage, a known inflammasome trigger, we observed that galectin-3 coats the ruptured organelle and is subsequently ubiquitinated by the E3 ligase TRIM16. The WD40 domain of ATG16L1 directly binds this polyubiquitin signal, recruiting the LC3 conjugation machinery to the single damaged membrane. This process, termed LC3-associated phagocytosis (LAP)-like, engulfs the damaged lysosome and sequesters inflammasome components, preventing caspase-1 activation and pyroptotic cell death. In ATG16L1-deficient cells, this sequestration fails, leading to hyper-inflammation. Our study delineates a specific molecular pathway of non-canonical autophagy that acts as a rheostat for inflammasome activity, providing a direct mechanistic link between organelle integrity and innate immune signaling.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mechanistic Dissection of Non-Canonical Autophagy in Modulating Inflammasome Activation

text: The maturation of the eukaryotic 40S ribosomal subunit is a complex, multi-step process involving numerous assembly factors. The final steps, occurring in the cytoplasm, are particularly dynamic and poorly understood. We have determined the cryo-electron microscopy structure of a native human pre-40S particle at 2.9 Å resolution, trapping the RIOK1 kinase in a pre-catalytic state. The structure reveals how RIOK1 is positioned by the scaffold protein LTV1 to phosphorylate the ribosomal protein Rps27. This phosphorylation event induces a conformational cascade that triggers the release of final maturation factors, including TSR1 and PNO1, and facilitates the endonucleolytic cleavage of the 18S rRNA at its 3' end by the nuclease NOB1.
