This algebro-geometric approach provides a powerful new framework for attacking unimodality and log-concavity conjectures in combinatorics for which purely combinatorial proofs have been elusive.
subject: Matematik
title: Log-Concavity of Chromatic Polynomial Coefficients via Matroid Hodge Theory

text: We investigate the structure of K_{r+1}-free graphs within the binomial random graph model G(n,p). The classical Turán theorem characterizes the densest K_{r+1}-free graph on n vertices. In this paper, we establish a sparse analogue of the Erdős-Simonovits stability theorem. We prove that for p >> n^{-2/r}, if G is a subgraph of G(n,p) with a near-maximal number of edges subject to being K_{r+1}-free, then G can be made r-partite by removing a small number of edges, with the number of removed edges being asymptotically optimal. The proof leverages the container method, recently developed by Balogh, Morris, and Samotij, to obtain a structural characterization of all K_{r+1}-free subgraphs. Our result refines previous transference theorems and provides a precise structural understanding of extremal subgraphs in the sparse random setting, which is a critical step towards resolving several open problems in probabilistic combinatorics.
subject: Matematik
title: A Stability Theorem for Turán's Problem in Sparse Random Graphs

text: We introduce a new class of combinatorial objects called 'm-decorated planar rooted trees' and establish their fundamental enumerative properties. Using a symbolic method approach, we derive multivariate generating functions that count these trees according to various statistics, including the number of nodes, leaves, and decoration types. The primary result of this paper is a constructive bijection between the set of m-decorated trees with n+1 leaves and a basis for the n-th graded component of a specific non-symmetric operad, denoted Op_m. This bijection provides a combinatorial interpretation for the multiplication structure of the operad. As a corollary, we obtain a new combinatorial proof for the dimension formula of the components of Op_m and elucidate the homological properties of its associated chain complex. Our work bridges the gap between enumerative combinatorics and algebraic topology, offering new tools for the study of operadic structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Decorated Planar Trees, Non-Symmetric Operads, and Bijective Enumeration

text: The associahedron is a fundamental polytope whose vertices correspond to triangulations of a polygon and whose facial structure is encoded by non-crossing partitions. We introduce a generalized polytope, the permuto-associahedron, whose geometric realization is derived from the braid arrangement and whose combinatorics interpolates between the permutohedron and the associahedron. Our main theorem demonstrates that the automorphism group of the permuto-associahedron is isomorphic to the dihedral group of order 2(n+1), which naturally acts on the cluster algebra of type A_{n-2}. We provide a novel geometric proof by realizing the polytope's vertices as vectors whose convex hull is invariant under a specific linear group action. This construction reveals a deeper symmetry structure than previously known and provides a unified geometric framework for studying cluster exchange graphs, Cambrian lattices, and other related combinatorial objects that arise in representation theory and algebraic combinatorics.
subject: Matematik
title: Symmetries of the Permuto-Associahedron and Cluster Algebras of Type A

text: We present a polynomial-time deterministic algorithm for the combinatorial discrepancy problem that achieves near-optimal bounds for arbitrary set systems. Given a set system (X, F) where |X| = n and |F| = m, the goal is to find a coloring χ: X → {-1, +1} that minimizes max_{S ∈ F} |∑_{x ∈ S} χ(x)|. Our algorithm is based on a semidefinite programming (SDP) relaxation of the problem, combined with a novel potential function method for deterministic rounding. Unlike previous methods based on random walks or pessimistic estimators, our potential function directly measures the progress toward a low-discrepancy coloring in the vector space defined by the SDP solution. We prove that this algorithm finds a coloring χ with discrepancy O(√(n log(m/n))), matching the existential bounds established by Spencer up to logarithmic factors for a wide range of parameters. This work provides the first constructive proof of Spencer's theorem that is both deterministic and polynomial-time.
subject: Matematik
title: Deterministic Discrepancy Minimization via Semidefinite Programming and Potential Functions

text: The Macdonald polynomials P_λ(x; q, t) are a remarkable family of symmetric functions that generalize several other important bases. A central problem in algebraic combinatorics is to find a positive combinatorial formula for their coefficients. This paper introduces a new solvable two-dimensional lattice model whose partition function is shown to be equal to the Macdonald polynomial P_λ. The states of the model are configurations of paths on a grid, and the Boltzmann weights are functions of the parameters q and t. Our main result is a bijective mapping between the ground state configurations of this model and a new class of combinatorial objects we call 'weighted alternating sign matrices'. This bijection provides a manifestly positive combinatorial interpretation for the coefficients of the Macdonald polynomial at t=0, known as the q-Whittaker function, and paves the way for a full combinatorial formula for general (q,t). The methodology integrates techniques from statistical mechanics, integrable systems, and representation theory.
subject: Matematik
title: A Lattice Model for Macdonald Polynomials and Combinatorial Interpretations

text: The delineation of species boundaries in marine environments is notoriously challenging due to vast population sizes and high dispersal potential, often leading to cryptic speciation. Here, we employ whole-genome resequencing of the calanoid copepod Acartia tonsa across a sympatric but ecologically stratified water column to investigate fine-scale population structure. Phylogenetic analysis reveals two deeply divergent clades, previously considered a single species. We identify distinct genomic islands of divergence, enriched for genes associated with osmoregulation and thermal tolerance, despite evidence of ongoing introgressive hybridization in flanking regions. Demographic modeling supports a scenario of primary divergence with secondary contact, where ecological selection maintains reproductive isolation in the face of gene flow. Our findings underscore the power of phylogenomics to resolve cryptic diversity and demonstrate that potent ecological selection can drive and maintain speciation even in highly contiguous marine ecosystems, challenging traditional biogeographic paradigms of speciation.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Islands of Divergence Reveal Cryptic Speciation and Introgression in a Marine Copepod Metapopulation

text: Adaptive radiations are hallmarks of evolutionary innovation, yet the mechanisms governing their tempo and trajectory remain debated. We investigate the interplay between ecological opportunity and intrinsic lineage properties by simulating the radiation of African cichlids on complex, empirically derived fitness landscapes. Our agent-based model, which integrates functional morphology, resource competition, and phylogenetic constraints, demonstrates that radiations are highly contingent phenomena. While ecological opportunity is a prerequisite, the resulting phenotypic diversity is critically shaped by the initial state of key functional traits and the strength of eco-evolutionary feedbacks. We find that early-burst patterns of diversification are not universal, but rather emerge under specific conditions of strong competition and vacant niche space. The model predicts emergent properties, such as trophic guild structuring and punctuated equilibria, providing a mechanistic framework that reconciles the deterministic role of ecological selection with the stochastic nature of macroevolutionary history.
subject: Evrim
title: Eco-Evolutionary Feedbacks and the Contingent Nature of Adaptive Radiation in Cichlid Fishes

text: The evolution of eusociality represents a major transition in individuality, predicated on the reproductive division of labor. The proximate mechanisms governing caste differentiation, a form of extreme polyphenism, are crucial to understanding this transition. We investigated the role of epigenetic modifications in the honeybee, Apis mellifera, by profiling histone acetylation landscapes in response to differential larval nutrition. Using ChIP-seq, we identified thousands of differentially acetylated regions between queen- and worker-destined larvae, particularly at enhancer elements flanking key developmental regulators like the TOR and insulin signaling pathways. Inhibition of histone deacetylases (HDACs) partially phenocopied a royal jelly diet, biasing development toward the queen trajectory. These results demonstrate that histone acetylation acts as a critical molecular integrator of environmental cues and the conserved genetic toolkit for development, providing a mechanistic basis for the evolutionary origin and maintenance of non-genetic caste determination in superorganisms.
subject: Evrim
title: Epigenetic Regulation of Caste Polyphenism: Histone Acetylation Underpins Trophic Signaling in Eusocial Hymenoptera

text: The causal factors of Late Pleistocene megafaunal extinctions remain controversial, with debates centered on climate change versus anthropogenic pressures. We present a high-coverage paleogenome from a 30,000-year-old steppe bison (Bison priscus) vertebra and compare it with 50 newly sequenced mitochondrial genomes spanning the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM). Our analyses, utilizing pairwise sequentially Markovian coalescent (PSMC) modeling, reveal a long-term decline in effective population size beginning well before significant human presence. We further uncover compelling evidence of ancient admixture with an ancestral American bison lineage, suggesting periodic connectivity across Beringia. Despite this introgression, genomic metrics of heterozygosity and runs of homozygosity indicate a sharp decline in genetic diversity immediately preceding the LGM, which likely compromised the species' adaptive potential. These findings suggest that protracted climatic shifts were the primary driver of this megafauna's demographic trajectory, with a terminal loss of genetic variation creating a prelude to extinction.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Reconstruction of Late Pleistocene Megafaunal Dynamics Reveals Admixture and Declining Genetic Diversity Prior to Extinction

text: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a paramount force in prokaryotic evolution, yet its role in constructing complex metabolic pathways remains poorly quantified. Here, we analyze the pangenome of 150 species from the archaeal phylum Crenarchaeota, focusing on the acquisition of pathways for chemoautotrophy in hyperthermophilic environments. By constructing phylogenetically incongruent gene trees and mapping their distribution onto the species phylogeny, we demonstrate that the entire sulfur-reducing metabolic module has been assembled through a mosaic of HGT events, predominantly mediated by plasmids and integrative conjugative elements constituting the mobilome. We identify 'hotspots' of integration within chromosomes, flanking tRNA genes. Our network-based analysis shows that acquired genes are rapidly integrated into existing regulatory circuits. This study illustrates that HGT is not merely a source of individual traits but a fundamental mechanism for the modular assembly and evolutionary innovation of entire metabolic networks, enabling rapid adaptation to extreme environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Pangenome Dynamics and the Mobilome-Mediated Evolution of Metabolic Novelty in Hyperthermophilic Archaea

text: Sexually antagonistic coevolution, arising from interlocus sexual conflict, is hypothesized to be a potent engine of rapid molecular evolution and reproductive isolation. We test this hypothesis by conducting population genomic analyses on 30 species of Drosophila, focusing on seminal fluid proteins (SFPs) and their female reproductive tract interactors. Using codon-based models (dN/dS), we identify pervasive and recurrent positive selection acting on SFP genes, a pattern significantly stronger than in non-reproductive proteins. Furthermore, the rate of adaptive evolution in SFPs is positively correlated with the degree of polyandry, a proxy for the intensity of sexual conflict. We demonstrate that specific rapidly evolving male SFPs and female receptors show signatures of coevolutionary arms races. Crucially, lineages with higher rates of SFP evolution also exhibit accelerated rates of speciation, providing strong evidence that sexual conflict is a key driver of both molecular divergence and the evolution of reproductive isolation barriers.
subject: Evrim
title: Signatures of Interlocus Sexual Conflict Drive Rapid Evolution of Seminal Fluid Proteins and Speciation in Drosophila

text: Classic evolutionary theories of senescence, such as antagonistic pleiotropy, provide an ultimate explanation for aging but often lack mechanistic grounding. We developed a state-dependent life-history model that explicitly integrates the molecular biology of cellular aging with evolutionary trade-offs. In our model, allocation of resources to somatic maintenance directly influences the rate of telomere attrition, while allocation to reproduction yields immediate fitness benefits but at the cost of accelerated senescence via pleiotropic pathways. The model predicts an optimal allocation strategy that results in a declining force of natural selection with age, leading to the evolution of aging as an emergent property. It successfully recapitulates empirical patterns, including the negative correlation between extrinsic mortality and lifespan, and makes novel predictions about the coevolution of telomerase activity and reproductive scheduling. This synthesis provides a powerful framework for understanding how ultimate evolutionary pressures shape the proximate molecular mechanisms of senescence.
subject: Evrim
title: The Evolutionary Theory of Senescence Revisited: A Mechanistic Model Integrating Antagonistic Pleiotropy and Telomere Attrition

text: The vast diversity of life is structured by both adaptation and constraint, yet the role of developmental systems in shaping macroevolutionary trajectories is incompletely understood. We investigated the evolution of the tetrapod limb, a classic example of serial homology and adaptive diversification, using a comparative framework combining 3D geometric morphometrics and phylogenetic analysis of key developmental gene regulatory networks (GRNs). Our results demonstrate that while the limb has adapted to numerous functions, its evolution has been restricted to a limited volume of theoretical morphospace. We show that this constraint is correlated with the deep conservation of the core limb-patterning GRN, including key transcription factors like Shh and HoxD cluster genes. This network architecture promotes canalization, buffering development against perturbation and thereby limiting phenotypic variance. We argue that while plasticity allows for adaptive modification, the inherent canalization of the underlying developmental architecture acts as a powerful macroevolutionary constraint, channeling evolutionary pathways.
subject: Evrim
title: Developmental Canalization as a Macroevolutionary Constraint: Evolvability and the Occupation of Morphospace in Tetrapod Limbs

text: Host-parasite interactions are often characterized by antagonistic coevolution, described by the Red Queen hypothesis. At the molecular level, this should manifest as rapid, recurrent positive selection on genes mediating the interaction. We tested this prediction using the interaction between Arabidopsis thaliana and the pathogenic oomycete Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis. We sequenced and analyzed a suite of nucleotide-binding leucine-rich repeat (NLR) immune receptor genes from diverse A. thaliana ecotypes and corresponding effector genes (RxLR proteins) from pathogen isolates. Likelihood ratio tests for positive selection revealed exceptionally high dN/dS ratios in specific domains responsible for pathogen recognition—the LRR domain in NLRs and the C-terminal region of RxLR effectors. Furthermore, we identified a significant spatial clustering of positively selected sites at the predicted protein-protein interaction interface. This tit-for-tat molecular evolution provides a textbook example of a Red Queen dynamic, illustrating the intense selective pressures that drive the diversification of host immune systems and pathogen virulence factors.
subject: Evrim
title: Molecular Signatures of a Coevolutionary Arms Race: Recurrent Positive Selection in Plant NLR Receptors and Fungal Effectors

text: The transition from unicellular to multicellular life is one of the major transitions in individuality, requiring the evolution of cell differentiation, cooperation, and a division of labor between germline and somatic cells. We utilized the volvocine algae, a lineage spanning from unicellular Chlamydomonas reinhardtii to multicellular Volvox carteri with a sterile soma, as a model system to dissect this transition. Using comparative transcriptomics and network inference algorithms, we reconstructed and compared the gene regulatory networks (GRNs) governing the cell cycle and developmental programs. Our analysis reveals that the evolution of multicellularity and germ-soma differentiation was not driven by the evolution of many new genes, but rather by the extensive rewiring of ancestral GRNs. Specifically, we identified the co-option of conserved cell-cycle regulators, such as the retinoblastoma protein, into a novel developmental checkpoint that orchestrates somatic cell differentiation in Volvox. This demonstrates how redeployment and modification of existing genetic architecture can precipitate a major evolutionary transition.
subject: Evrim
title: Gene Regulatory Network Rewiring and the Major Transition to Multicellularity in the Volvocine Algae

text: This paper introduces a novel framework integrating proximal causal inference with debiased machine learning to estimate average treatment effects in high-dimensional settings plagued by unobserved confounding. Our method leverages orthogonal moment functions to construct a multiply robust estimator that maintains consistency and asymptotic normality, provided valid instrumental variables are available. By employing a cross-fitting procedure, the estimator mitigates regularization-induced bias, allowing for the use of flexible machine learning algorithms (e.g., random forests, gradient boosting) to model the nuisance functions—namely the propensity score, outcome regression, and instrument-treatment relationship. We establish rigorous theoretical guarantees for our proximal doubly robust lasso (PDRL) estimator under weaker sparsity assumptions than competing methods. The estimator demonstrates superior finite-sample performance in simulation studies, particularly under severe model misspecification and high-dimensional covariate spaces. We illustrate its practical utility by applying it to a large-scale genomic dataset to identify causal genetic variants influencing complex traits, controlling for latent population structure.
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Machine Learning for High-Dimensional Causal Inference with Latent Confounders

text: We develop a scalable variational inference algorithm for Hierarchical Dirichlet Process (HDP) mixture models where the stick-breaking proportions are modulated by external covariates. This extension facilitates the principled discovery of latent group structures that evolve as a function of observed variables, moving beyond the static clustering assumption of traditional HDPs. We derive a novel mean-field variational objective function and closed-form coordinate ascent updates for the variational parameters, circumventing the computational intractability of MCMC-based approaches in massive datasets. The model’s key innovation lies in parameterizing the concentration parameters of the beta distributions in the stick-breaking construction as a log-linear function of covariates. We demonstrate the model's efficacy in topic modeling for longitudinal corpora and in clustering high-dimensional single-cell RNA-seq data across different experimental conditions, showing improved predictive likelihood and enhanced interpretability over standard HDP implementations. Asymptotic properties and convergence guarantees of the proposed algorithm are also formally established.
subject: İstatistik
title: Variational Inference for Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Mixture Models with Covariate-Dependent Stick-Breaking

text: This work presents a rigorous framework for statistical inference on populations of persistence diagrams, the primary output of topological data analysis. By treating persistence diagrams as elements of a metric space endowed with the p-Wasserstein distance, we define a population Fréchet mean and propose a consistent empirical estimator. The principal contribution is the development of a multiplier bootstrap procedure for constructing confidence regions for this non-Euclidean mean. This method is computationally efficient and avoids the combinatorial complexity of permutation tests while providing strong theoretical guarantees on asymptotic coverage probability under mild regularity conditions on the underlying data-generating process. We establish the consistency and convergence rates of the bootstrap procedure. The utility of our inferential tools is illustrated through applications in discriminating morphological classes of neurons and analyzing shape variability in protein structures, where our method demonstrates enhanced statistical power to detect subtle geometric differences compared to existing summary-statistic-based approaches.
subject: İstatistik
title: Statistical Inference on Persistence Diagrams using Fréchet Means in Wasserstein Space

text: We introduce a novel dynamic spatio-temporal factor model for high-dimensional data exhibiting non-stationary spatial and temporal dependencies. The framework models latent factors as evolving according to a vector autoregressive process, while the factor loadings are endowed with non-stationary Gaussian process priors. This non-stationarity is achieved by parameterizing the hyperparameters of a Matérn covariance kernel, such as length-scale and marginal variance, as functions of spatial coordinates. This allows the model to capture varying degrees of spatial smoothness and correlation across the domain flexibly. Inference is performed within a fully Bayesian framework using an efficient MCMC algorithm that synergistically combines a Kalman filter for the temporal dynamics with a Metropolis-adjusted Langevin algorithm (MALA) for the spatially-varying kernel parameters. The proposed methodology offers a parsimonious yet powerful approach to modeling complex dependencies, and we validate its superior predictive performance on both synthetic data and a real-world application involving satellite-derived climate data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Spatio-Temporal Factor Models with Non-Stationary Gaussian Process Priors

text: This paper proposes an adaptive Huber regularization method for robust parameter estimation in high-dimensional linear models where noise is drawn from heavy-tailed and possibly asymmetric distributions. Unlike standard robust methods that rely on a pre-specified, fixed robustness parameter, our approach simultaneously estimates the regression coefficients and the optimal Huber parameter by penalizing a data-driven quantile of the squared residuals. This adaptive procedure circumvents the need for computationally intensive cross-validation and provides robust estimates against a wider class of error distributions without sacrificing efficiency under Gaussianity. We establish non-asymptotic oracle inequalities for the proposed estimator, demonstrating that it achieves near-optimal statistical convergence rates under standard assumptions on the design matrix. The algorithm is based on a computationally efficient majorization-minimization (MM) principle. Extensive numerical studies and an application to predicting corporate bond risk confirm the theoretical advantages and practical superiority of our method over the Lasso, scaled Lasso, and other robust estimators.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Huber Regularization for Robust High-Dimensional Regression with Asymmetric Errors

text: We address the critical challenge of performing Functional Principal Component Analysis (FPCA) on sparse and irregularly sampled longitudinal data, a common structure in biomedical and environmental studies. Our proposed framework represents the underlying functional trajectories and eigenfunctions using penalized B-splines within a reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS), providing a flexible basis for smooth functions. The estimation is formulated within a mixed-effects model, which naturally accommodates irregular observation schedules and measurement error. A key innovation is the integration of an L1 penalty on the principal component scores, which induces sparsity and facilitates interpretable variable selection when linking functional patterns to high-dimensional covariates. We develop an efficient iterative algorithm based on a conditional expectation maximization scheme to solve the resulting non-convex optimization problem. Asymptotic consistency and convergence rates for the estimated eigenfunctions and scores are established under mild conditions, and the method's practical utility is demonstrated by analyzing sparse longitudinal biomarker data from a clinical trial.
subject: İstatistik
title: Sparse Functional Principal Component Analysis for Irregularly Sampled Longitudinal Data

text: This paper introduces a novel spectral algorithm, Di-Spec, for community detection in networks that are simultaneously directed and weighted, operating under a generalized Stochastic Block Model (SBM). Existing spectral methods often discard valuable directional or weight information through symmetrization or binarization. Our approach operates on a regularized complex adjacency matrix, leveraging its leading eigenvectors to perform clustering. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis grounded in matrix perturbation theory, establishing sharp, non-asymptotic conditions for consistent community recovery. These conditions explicitly depend on the signal-to-noise ratio, community sizes, and the asymmetry of the underlying connectivity probability matrix. The algorithm is computationally efficient, with a complexity that scales linearly with the number of edges. Through comprehensive simulations, we demonstrate that Di-Spec significantly outperforms extant methods on sparse, directed, and weighted graphs. An application to a neural connectivity network reveals functionally distinct circuits that were previously obscured by methods designed for undirected graphs.
subject: İstatistik
title: Spectral Methods for Community Detection in Directed and Weighted Stochastic Block Models

text: Standard doubly robust estimators for the Average Treatment Effect (ATE) achieve root-n consistency if either the propensity score or outcome regression model is correctly specified and estimated at a sufficient rate. However, when both nuisance models are estimated with flexible machine learning algorithms, these rates may not be met, leading to biased inference. This paper introduces a new class of estimators based on higher-order influence functions derived from third-order U-statistics. Our proposed estimator is multiply robust, remaining consistent under weaker conditions, and exhibits a faster convergence rate for its second-order remainder term. This property facilitates valid inference even when nuisance estimators converge at slower, nonparametric rates. We utilize a multi-way cross-fitting scheme to eliminate bias from overfitting and establish the asymptotic normality of our estimator under minimal assumptions. Simulation studies show our estimator provides more reliable confidence intervals and lower bias than traditional doubly robust methods when using complex learners like neural networks or random forests.
subject: İstatistik
title: Higher-Order Influence Functions for Doubly Robust Causal Effect Estimation

text: The knockoff filter is a powerful framework for controlling the False Discovery Rate (FDR) in high-dimensional variable selection. However, the canonical construction of knockoff variables often ignores known structural dependencies among covariates, such as those encoded by a graph. This paper introduces the Graph-Constrained Knockoff (GCK) filter, a novel method for generating knockoff variables that precisely preserve the conditional independence structure of the original covariates, as specified by an underlying Gaussian Graphical Model. By constructing knockoffs that are conditionally independent of their corresponding original variables given all other variables, GCK decouples statistical power from the conditioning of the design matrix. This leads to substantial gains in power when covariates are highly correlated. We provide a rigorous proof that GCK controls the exact FDR in finite samples. The construction leverages efficient sampling from Gaussian conditional distributions. We demonstrate through simulations and a gene regulatory network analysis that GCK provides significant power improvements over existing knockoff methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: The Graph-Constrained Knockoff Filter for FDR Control in Structured Hypothesis Testing

text: We develop a geometric Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) framework for efficient posterior inference in complex Bayesian models with parameter constraints, such as positivity, simplex, or correlation matrix constraints. Standard Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) is inefficient in such settings due to proposal rejections at boundaries and poor exploration of complex posterior geometries. Our method, Riemannian Manifold Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (RMHMC), formulates the sampling problem on a Riemannian manifold where the metric tensor is informed by the local geometry of the parameter space, typically using the Fisher-Rao information metric. This allows the Hamiltonian dynamics to adapt to the posterior curvature, generating distant proposals with high acceptance rates while naturally respecting constraints. We derive the geodesic flow equations for several common constraint manifolds and develop a numerically stable, generalized leapfrog integrator. The methodology is applied to a challenging hierarchical Dirichlet-multinomial model and a variance components model, demonstrating orders-of-magnitude improvements in sampling efficiency over state-of-the-art MCMC algorithms.
subject: İstatistik
title: Hamiltonian Monte Carlo on Riemannian Manifolds for Constrained Bayesian Models

text: The Fanconi anemia (FA) pathway is critical for resolving DNA interstrand crosslinks and mitigating replication stress. Central to this is the FANCM-FAAP24 heterodimer, an ATP-dependent DNA translocase. Here, we present the 3.1 Å cryo-electron microscopy structure of human FANCM-FAAP24 bound to a synthetic stalled replication fork mimic. The structure reveals how the tandem helix-hairpin-helix domains of FANCM engage the duplex arms of the fork, while the DEAH helicase domain anchors at the junction, primed for ATP hydrolysis. FAAP24 forms an integral clamp around the complex, stabilizing the interaction and allosterically modulating the helicase core. Notably, our structure captures a pre-translocation state, providing unprecedented molecular detail into the mechanism of fork regression. Functional assays corroborate that mutations at the elucidated interfaces abrogate ssDNA translocase activity and abolish ATR kinase activation in response to hydroxyurea-induced replication stress. These findings provide a structural blueprint for understanding genome maintenance and the molecular etiology of FA.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Human FANCM-FAAP24 Complex Illuminates Replication Fork Reversal and ATR Signaling

text: The precise spatiotemporal regulation of gene expression is paramount for neuronal differentiation. While protein factors are well-studied, the role of long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) as epigenetic regulators in this process remains nascent. We have identified NeuroSil, a previously uncharacterized lncRNA specifically expressed in neuronal progenitor cells. Using chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq), we demonstrate that NeuroSil acts as a molecular scaffold, directly binding the EZH2 subunit of the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) and guiding it to a specific cohort of protocadherin gene clusters. This targeted recruitment results in localized H3K27 trimethylation and transcriptional repression. CRISPR interference-mediated knockdown of NeuroSil in human embryonic stem cell-derived cortical organoids leads to precocious expression of synaptic genes, impaired neuronal migration, and aberrant network formation. Our data uncover a critical lncRNA-mediated epigenetic checkpoint that silences a post-mitotic gene program, ensuring the fidelity of cortical development.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Novel lncRNA, NeuroSil, Orchestrates Polycomb-Mediated Silencing of Synaptic Genes During Cortical Neurogenesis

text: Super-enhancers are dense clusters of regulatory elements that drive high-level expression of cell identity genes, yet the mechanism underlying their potent activity is incompletely understood. We propose a model wherein pioneer transcription factors initiate the formation of biomolecular condensates via liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS). We demonstrate that the intrinsically disordered region (IDR) of FOXA1 is essential for its phase separation in vitro and in vivo. High-resolution live-cell imaging and fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) reveal that FOXA1 forms liquid-like droplets at super-enhancers, which co-localize with MED1 and BRD4. Mutations within the FOXA1 IDR that disrupt LLPS abrogate the formation of these transcriptional hubs, diminish enhancer-promoter looping as measured by Hi-C, and attenuate target gene expression. Our findings establish that the biophysical property of phase separation is a primary mechanism by which pioneer factors establish and maintain robust transcriptional programs.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of the Pioneer Factor FOXA1 Nucleates Transcriptional Condensates at Super-Enhancers

text: N6-methyladenosine (m6A) is the most abundant internal modification on eukaryotic mRNA, dynamically regulating mRNA fate. Its role in the nervous system is emerging. Here, we investigate the epitranscriptomic control of activity-regulated cytoskeleton-associated protein (Arc), a master regulator of synaptic plasticity. Using MeRIP-seq in primary hippocampal neurons, we identify a conserved m6A site within the 3' UTR of Arc mRNA. Following induction of long-term potentiation (LTP), this site undergoes rapid demethylation by FTO, stabilizing the transcript. Conversely, under basal conditions, the m6A reader protein YTHDF2 binds to the methylated Arc mRNA, recruiting the CCR4-NOT deadenylase complex to trigger its decay. Genetic ablation or shRNA-mediated knockdown of YTHDF2 results in elevated basal Arc levels, impaired m6A-dependent degradation, and deficits in long-term depression (LTD). This work delineates a critical epitranscriptomic switch where dynamic m6A modification fine-tunes Arc expression to gate synaptic plasticity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Epitranscriptomic Regulation of Synaptic Plasticity through m6A-Dependent Decay of Arc mRNA Mediated by YTHDF2

text: Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) differentiation is a paradigm of lineage commitment, but the regulatory transitions from multipotency to a unipotent fate are still poorly resolved. By developing and applying an improved method for simultaneous single-cell chromatin accessibility (scATAC-seq) and RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq), we profiled thousands of murine HSCs and progenitors. Pseudotemporal trajectory inference revealed a previously uncharacterized intermediate population downstream of multipotent progenitors but preceding the common myeloid progenitor. This 'cryptic primed' state exhibits open chromatin at lineage-specific enhancers for both megakaryocyte-erythroid and granulocyte-monocyte fates, yet maintains a largely undifferentiated transcriptome. Gene regulatory network analysis identified the transcription factor GATA2 as a key upstream regulator maintaining this poised epigenetic landscape. Functional validation using lineage tracing confirmed that this population resolves its fate stochastically, providing a new model for hematopoietic commitment based on epigenetic priming preceding transcriptional divergence.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Single-Cell Multi-Omics Delineates a Cryptic Primed Progenitor State in Hematopoietic Lineage Commitment

text: The mTORC1 pathway is a central regulator of cell growth, often targeted in cancer therapy. While its effects on cap-dependent translation are well-known, a global view of translational control upon its inhibition remains incomplete. Using ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) in glioblastoma cell lines, we analyzed the translatome following treatment with the mTORC1 inhibitor rapamycin. We observed a paradoxical increase in the translational efficiency of hundreds of mRNAs, many of which are known oncogenes and stress-response factors. Bioinformatic analysis revealed a significant enrichment for upstream open reading frames (uORFs) in the 5' leaders of these upregulated transcripts. This translational induction is dependent on the GCN2-eIF2α phosphorylation axis of the integrated stress response. Our data demonstrate that mTORC1 inhibition triggers a broad translational reprogramming event, subverting canonical cap-dependent translation in favor of a uORF-mediated mechanism that sustains the expression of pro-survival proteins, suggesting novel avenues for combination therapies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Ribosome Profiling Reveals Widespread Translational Reprogramming via uORFs in Response to mTORC1 Inhibition

text: Selective autophagy is essential for cellular proteostasis, clearing cytotoxic protein aggregates. While the p62/SQSTM1 receptor pathway is a canonical route for aggrephagy, alternative mechanisms must exist. We have identified a novel E3 ubiquitin ligase, RNF190, that orchestrates a p62-independent aggrephagy pathway. Upon proteotoxic stress, RNF190 is recruited to protein inclusions where it deposits non-degradative K63-linked polyubiquitin chains. We show through co-immunoprecipitation and in vitro binding assays that the WD40 domain of the core autophagy protein ATG16L1 directly recognizes these K63 chains, bypassing the need for canonical LIR-containing receptors like p62. Depletion of RNF190 or mutation of the ATG16L1 ubiquitin-binding interface severely impairs clearance of polyglutamine aggregates and sensitizes cells to proteotoxicity. This work uncovers a direct mechanistic link between the ubiquitin system and the core autophagy machinery, defining a new axis of selective autophagy critical for cellular quality control.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A K63-Specific Ubiquitin Ligase Governs p62-Independent Aggrephagy by Directly Recruiting ATG16L1

text: The therapeutic window of cancer treatments is often limited by off-tumor toxicity. To overcome this, we have engineered a highly specific synthetic gene circuit in human cells that functions as a molecular AND-gate, integrating two distinct cancer-specific hallmarks: a hypoxia signature and the presence of a microRNA signature (miR-21high/miR-145low). The circuit consists of a hypoxia-responsive element driving the expression of an orthogonal Tet-transactivator, which in turn activates a second promoter containing binding sites for a tetracycline-repressive synthetic miRNA sensor system. Only when both conditions—hypoxia and the cancer-specific miRNA profile—are met is the expression of a pro-apoptotic effector, a constitutively active Caspase-3, robustly induced. When deployed in co-cultures of cancer and healthy cells using adenoviral vectors, our circuit demonstrated remarkable specificity, inducing apoptosis in over 90% of target cancer cells while leaving non-target cells virtually unharmed, heralding a new strategy for precision oncology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Engineering a Multi-Input Synthetic AND-Gate Circuit for Precision Cancer Cell Apoptosis

text: Approximately 15% of cancers maintain telomere length via a homologous recombination-based mechanism termed Alternative Lengthening of Telomeres (ALT), which is mechanistically poorly understood. The long non-coding RNA TERRA, transcribed from telomeres, has been implicated in ALT, but its function remains elusive. Here, we demonstrate that TERRA forms stable DNA:RNA hybrids (R-loops) at telomeres specifically in ALT-positive cancer cells. Using DRIP-seq and immunofluorescence, we show these R-loops co-localize with components of the ATR signaling pathway and are hotspots for recombination factor recruitment. Overexpression of RNase H1, which resolves R-loops, or knockdown of TERRA leads to diminished ATR activation, reduced ALT-associated PML bodies (APBs), and an increase in telomeric C-circles, a marker of telomere instability. We propose a model where TERRA-mediated R-loops create a single-stranded DNA substrate that serves as a critical platform for initiating the ATR-dependent recombination essential for telomere maintenance in ALT cancers.
subject: Biyoloji
title: TERRA R-loops Form a Critical Nucleation Platform for ATR Activation in Alternative Lengthening of Telomeres

text: Programmable base editors enable precise nucleotide conversions in the genome, but their application is constrained by product purity, off-target mutations, and the limited range of possible edits. To address the challenge of C-to-G transversions, we engineered a novel cytosine base editor (CBE) by fusing a highly processive nicking Cas9 variant (nCas9-D10A) with a cytidine deaminase (APOBEC3A) and a uracil DNA glycosylase (UNG). Subsequent rational protein engineering of the deaminase domain yielded a variant, named GET-C, with a narrowed activity window and dramatically reduced bystander C-to-T conversions. We coupled this with an engineered sgRNA architecture that enhances specificity. Unbiased whole-genome sequencing of edited human hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells confirmed that GET-C mediates C-to-G editing with >50% efficiency and >95% product purity at target loci, while exhibiting background-level off-target single-nucleotide variants. This high-fidelity tool expands the scope of therapeutic genome editing for diseases caused by G-to-C point mutations.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Bifunctional CRISPR-Deaminase Achieves High-Fidelity C-to-G Transversion with Minimal Off-Target Activity

text: We introduce a novel framework for disentangled representation learning and counterfactual generation by integrating Structural Causal Models (SCMs) within the latent space of a Variational Autoencoder (VAE). Traditional VAEs often fail to capture the true underlying causal mechanisms of data generation, leading to entangled representations and implausible interventions. Our model, the CausalVAE, explicitly parameterizes the latent space as a directed acyclic graph, where the encoder performs amortized variational inference on the exogenous noise variables of the SCM. The decoder then synthesizes data by propagating these variables through the learned causal graph. We demonstrate that this architecture not only achieves superior disentanglement scores on benchmark datasets but also enables targeted interventions and the generation of valid counterfactuals by manipulating specific latent variables. This principled fusion of deep generative modeling and causal inference offers a significant advancement in building robust, interpretable, and controllable generative systems.
subject: AI
title: Disentangled Counterfactual Generation via Structural Causal Model-Infused Variational Autoencoders

text: The challenge of credit assignment in cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL), particularly within Decentralized Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes (Dec-POMDPs), remains a significant impediment to scaling complex collaborative tasks. We propose a novel algorithm, Counterfactual-Guided Policy Gradients (CGPG), which leverages a centralized critic with a network-based communication protocol to compute agent-specific advantage functions. The critic models a global value function and estimates a counterfactual baseline for each agent, representing the expected return if that agent had executed a default policy. This allows for a more precise decomposition of the global reward signal, effectively isolating individual agent contributions. Our method demonstrates superior performance and faster convergence on challenging MARL benchmarks like the StarCraft Multi-Agent Challenge (SMAC) and cooperative navigation tasks, showcasing its efficacy in mitigating the stochasticity and non-stationarity inherent in multi-agent environments without requiring global state information during execution.
subject: AI
title: Decentralized Credit Assignment in Multi-Agent Systems via Counterfactual-Guided Policy Gradients

text: This paper presents a novel deep learning architecture for simulating complex physical systems governed by partial differential equations (PDEs). We introduce Lagrangian-Informed Graph Neural Networks (L-GNNs), a model that embeds physical priors directly into the message-passing framework of a spatio-temporal GNN. By discretizing the system into a graph of interacting particles, the L-GNN learns the system's Lagrangian, a fundamental quantity from which the equations of motion can be derived. This inductive bias ensures the conservation of physical quantities like energy and momentum. The model operates in a continuous-time latent space, using a neural ordinary differential equation (ODE) solver to evolve the system state. We evaluate our method on diverse physical simulations, including fluid dynamics and n-body gravitational problems, demonstrating state-of-the-art accuracy, improved long-term stability, and superior zero-shot generalization to out-of-distribution initial conditions compared to standard neural PDE solvers.
subject: AI
title: Lagrangian-Informed Spatio-Temporal Graph Neural Networks for Simulating Non-Linear Physical Systems

text: Federated Learning (FL) is susceptible to Byzantine attacks, where malicious clients can poison the global model by sending arbitrary updates. We propose a robust and privacy-preserving FL framework, called Verifiable Encrypted Aggregation with Adaptive Privacy (VEAP), that provides resilience against a high fraction of Byzantine clients. VEAP integrates partially homomorphic encryption to enable secure aggregation of model updates, preventing the central server from inspecting individual contributions. To thwart malicious encrypted inputs, we introduce a zero-knowledge verifiable computation scheme that allows clients to prove the correctness of their encrypted updates with respect to a predefined constraint set. Furthermore, VEAP employs an adaptive differential privacy mechanism that calibrates the noise level based on the estimated number of malicious participants, optimizing the privacy-utility trade-off. Theoretical analysis and extensive empirical evaluations on non-IID datasets confirm that VEAP significantly outperforms existing robust FL methods under strong adversarial settings.
subject: AI
title: Byzantine-Resilient Federated Learning with Verifiable Homomorphic Encryption and Adaptive Differential Privacy

text: The quadratic complexity of the self-attention mechanism in Transformer models presents a formidable computational bottleneck for processing ultra-long sequences. This work introduces a novel attention mechanism, Factorized Kernel Attention (FKA), that achieves linear complexity with respect to sequence length while maintaining high model performance. FKA approximates the softmax attention matrix by projecting the query and key vectors into a lower-dimensional randomized feature space, effectively reformulating the attention computation as a kernel function. Through a factorized projection strategy, we obviate the need to explicitly instantiate the full attention matrix, reducing the complexity from O(N^2) to O(N). Unlike previous approximation methods that exhibit performance degradation, FKA leverages properties of positive semi-definite kernels to ensure a stable and expressive approximation. We demonstrate that FKA-equipped Transformers achieve state-of-the-art results on long-document summarization, genomics, and time-series forecasting benchmarks, enabling models to process sequences of unprecedented length.
subject: AI
title: Sub-Quadratic Attention via Factorized Kernel Projections for Ultra-Long Sequence Modeling

text: Existing meta-learning algorithms for few-shot classification often yield point estimates of task-specific parameters, failing to capture epistemic uncertainty crucial for risk-sensitive applications. We propose a novel Bayesian meta-learning framework, Hypernetwork-Amortized Variational Inference (HAVI), that learns a posterior distribution over model parameters for novel tasks. HAVI employs a hypernetwork to generate the parameters of a variational distribution, conditioned on a task's support set. This amortizes the cost of posterior inference, allowing for rapid adaptation and uncertainty estimation at meta-test time. By marginalizing over the approximate posterior, our model produces robust predictions and well-calibrated uncertainty estimates. We demonstrate that HAVI significantly outperforms prior methods, including MAML and Prototypical Networks, on challenging few-shot classification benchmarks, particularly in out-of-distribution detection and active learning scenarios, where reliable uncertainty quantification is paramount.
subject: AI
title: Bayesian Meta-Learning with Hypernetwork-Amortized Variational Inference for Few-Shot Uncertainty Quantification

text: We present a unified framework for learning joint representations across disparate modalities, such as vision, language, and audio, without requiring explicit cross-modal paired data for all combinations. Our approach, termed Multimodal Contrastive Alignment (MCA), leverages a contrastive learning objective to project modality-specific encoders onto a shared semantic manifold. The key innovation is a cyclical consistency loss that enforces transitive relations across modalities; for instance, if an image is aligned with a text caption, and that caption is aligned with an audio clip, the framework encourages the direct alignment of the image and audio representations. This enables zero-shot cross-modal retrieval and classification between modalities that were never observed together during training. We validate MCA on large-scale multimodal datasets, demonstrating state-of-the-art performance in zero-shot image-to-audio retrieval and text-based video search, showcasing the framework's ability to create a highly coherent and versatile joint embedding space.
subject: AI
title: Unified Multimodal Representation Learning through Cross-Modal Contrastive Alignment in a Shared Semantic Manifold

text: We introduce a novel method for generating concept-based counterfactual explanations for complex black-box models. Existing counterfactual explanation methods often produce changes at the pixel level, which lack semantic interpretability. Our framework first learns a set of disentangled high-level concepts from the data distribution using a GAN-based architecture. Subsequently, given a specific prediction to be explained, we identify the minimal perturbation along these concept axes in the GAN's latent space that alters the model's output. This manipulation produces a new, synthetic instance—a counterfactual—that is perceptually realistic and differs from the original instance only by a well-defined, human-understandable concept (e.g., 'add glasses' or 'increase age'). We formalize this as a constrained optimization problem in the disentangled latent space. Our user studies and quantitative evaluations confirm that concept-driven counterfactuals provide more actionable and interpretable insights into model behavior than state-of-the-art pixel-based and feature-attribution methods.
subject: AI
title: Concept-Driven Counterfactuals: Generating Semantic Explanations via Latent Space Perturbation in Generative Models

text: Adaptive gradient methods such as Adam are ubiquitous in deep learning, yet their generalization properties remain poorly understood compared to stochastic gradient descent (SGD). This paper investigates the implicit regularization induced by adaptive optimizers from the perspective of stochastic differential equations (SDEs). By analyzing the continuous-time limit of Adam in over-parameterized linear and non-linear models, we demonstrate that the adaptive preconditioning introduces a non-uniform, state-dependent regularization. This effect biases the solution towards parameters with flatter loss landscapes but smaller gradient-to-parameter ratios, contrasting with the uniform implicit bias of SGD. Our analysis reveals that this can lead to poorer generalization in certain network architectures where sparse solutions are optimal. We provide a rigorous theoretical framework that characterizes the convergence trajectory and solution bias, corroborating our findings with empirical results on both synthetic data and deep neural networks, thus illuminating the trade-offs inherent in adaptive optimization.
subject: AI
title: On the Implicit Regularization of Adaptive Optimizers: A Stochastic Differential Equation Perspective on Generalization in Over-Parameterized Regimes

text: We propose a generative framework for the inverse design of crystalline materials with targeted physical properties. Our model, SymGAN, is a conditional generative adversarial network that synthesizes stable crystal structures, represented by atomic coordinates and lattice vectors, conditioned on a target property vector (e.g., band gap, formation energy). A key innovation is the integration of a differentiable symmetry loss function that explicitly penalizes violations of crystallographic symmetry groups, acting as a strong physical prior that guides the generator towards physically plausible and stable structures. The generator is trained adversarially against a discriminator that learns the manifold of known materials from databases like the Materials Project. By sampling from SymGAN with a desired property input, we can rapidly generate novel, diverse, and synthesizable candidate materials. We demonstrate the efficacy of our method by discovering several novel structures with targeted electronic properties, subsequently validated using Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations.
subject: AI
title: Inverse Design of Crystalline Materials using Property-Conditioned Generative Adversarial Networks with a Differentiable Symmetry Constraint

text: We investigate the interplay between non-Hermitian dynamics and topological order in a two-dimensional Kitaev honeycomb model coupled to a dissipative environment. By employing a third-quantization formalism and Keldysh field theory, we analytically derive the Liouvillian spectrum, revealing the emergence of exceptional points that precede the topological phase transition. Our analysis demonstrates that environmental coupling induces a non-trivial renormalization of the Majorana fermion velocity and a finite lifetime for the emergent Z2 gauge field fluxes. We find that while generic dissipation suppresses topological entanglement entropy, engineered Markovian baths can stabilize the non-Abelian anyonic excitations against local perturbations. Crucially, our results show that the braiding statistics of the Majorana zero modes remain robust up to a critical dissipation strength, beyond which the system transitions into a topologically trivial, decohered paramagnet. These findings provide a theoretical framework for understanding the stability of topological quantum computation platforms under realistic open-system conditions.
subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence and Entanglement Dynamics in a Non-Hermitian Kitaev Honeycomb Model

text: This work explores the constraints on bulk spacetime geometry imposed by the structure of entanglement in the dual conformal field theory (CFT). Extending the Ryu-Takayanagi and Hubeny-Rangamani-Takayanagi prescriptions, we formulate a novel entanglement-based inverse problem for reconstructing the bulk metric. By utilizing the concept of entanglement of purification and the associated causal shadow, we demonstrate that the quantum error correction properties of the AdS/CFT correspondence allow for the reconstruction of bulk operators within the entanglement wedge, even when they lie outside the causal wedge of the boundary region. We introduce a differential entropy metric on the space of boundary subregions and show that its geometric properties are dual to the Ricci scalar curvature of the bulk. Our numerical simulations for a Vaidya-AdS spacetime confirm that this methodology can accurately probe the geometry behind a black hole horizon, providing a new non-perturbative tool for investigating the black hole information paradox.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Bulk Reconstruction from Sub-AdS Locality

text: We numerically investigate the transition from a many-body localized (MBL) phase to a thermalizing phase in a one-dimensional, periodically driven quantum spin system with quasiperiodic disorder. Utilizing large-scale exact diagonalization and a time-evolution block decimation (TEBD) algorithm adapted for Floquet operators, we map the complete phase diagram as a function of driving frequency and disorder strength. The transition is characterized by a sharp change in the level spacing statistics of the Floquet quasienergies, from Poissonian to Wigner-Dyson distribution. We analyze the multifractal scaling of the Floax (Floquet-Bloch) eigenstates, revealing a non-ergodic but delocalized phase intermediate between the fully localized and thermal regimes. Furthermore, our analysis of entanglement entropy growth shows a sustained logarithmic increase in the MBL phase, contrasted with a diffusive ballistic growth post-transition, consistent with the predictions for heating in generic Floquet systems. This work elucidates the unique phenomenology of localization in driven, aperiodic potentials.
subject: Kuantum
title: Many-Body Localization and Eigenstate Thermalization Transition in a Disordered Floquet System

text: We present the first ab-initio lattice quantum chromodynamics (QCD) calculation of the anomalous current induced by the Chiral Magnetic Effect (CME) in the quark-gluon plasma. The simulations are performed on a 64³×16 lattice using a domain wall fermion formulation to preserve chiral symmetry, at a physical pion mass and a temperature of T ≈ 250 MeV. By applying a background magnetic field, we measure the vector current response parallel to the field, which is directly proportional to the CME conductivity. The calculation requires a meticulous subtraction of lattice artifacts arising from the explicit breaking of rotational symmetry, which is achieved through a novel momentum-space subtraction scheme. Our final result for the CME conductivity is significantly smaller than prior holographic and model-based estimates but non-zero, providing a crucial quantitative benchmark for phenomenological models used to interpret charge-dependent correlations in heavy-ion collisions at RHIC and the LHC.
subject: Kuantum
title: Lattice QCD Calculation of the Chiral Magnetic Effect from First Principles

text: We propose and theoretically analyze a protocol for gravitational field gradient sensing that surpasses the standard quantum limit (SQL) by leveraging quantum correlations in an optomechanical system. Our scheme employs a pair of optically trapped silica nanospheres whose center-of-mass motion is cooled to the quantum ground state. A squeezed vacuum field is injected into the trapping optical tweezers, generating a two-mode squeezed state of the nanoparticle phononic modes. The differential displacement induced by a gravitational gradient imprints a phase on this entangled state. We show that a subsequent homodyne measurement protocol allows for an estimation of the gradient with a sensitivity scaling that approaches the Heisenberg limit. The quantum Fisher information for this system is calculated, demonstrating a significant enhancement over classical and non-entangled quantum strategies. Our analysis includes a full treatment of dominant decoherence channels, such as gas collisions and photon scattering, identifying a feasible experimental parameter regime.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum-Enhanced Gravitational Sensing with Optically Levitated Nanoparticles in a Squeezed Vacuum

text: Standard Bell nonlocality assumes spatially separated parties perform measurements on systems prepared by independent sources. We challenge this paradigm by introducing a theoretical framework for nonlocality in quantum networks with correlated sources. We derive a new class of multipartite Bell-type inequalities for a triangle network topology where the central source exhibits controlled correlations with the peripheral sources. Using the inflation technique, we demonstrate that quantum mechanics predicts violations of these inequalities that are impossible for any classical theory, even those allowing arbitrary classical communication between the sources (i.e., beyond local hidden variables). We experimentally verify these predictions using a programmable silicon-photonic integrated circuit that routes entangled photon pairs generated from spontaneous four-wave mixing. The observed violation provides the first experimental evidence of a fundamentally new form of quantum network nonlocality, opening new avenues for device-independent quantum information protocols.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Network Nonlocality with Correlated Sources and its Verification in a Multi-Core Photonic Chip

text: We investigate the emergence of spontaneous chiral currents in a driven-dissipative system of exciton-polariton condensates confined to a ring-shaped lattice of coupled micropillars. The system is modeled using a generalized discrete Gross-Pitaevskii equation including incoherent pumping, nonlinear interactions, and radiative decay. Through extensive numerical simulations, we identify a non-equilibrium phase transition from a static, symmetric state to a dynamical phase characterized by a persistent, uni-directional flow of the condensate, forming a stable vortex. We analyze this transition using the formalism of large-deviation theory, linking the onset of chirality to a symmetry-breaking bifurcation in the trajectory of the system in phase space. The Liouvillian spectral gap is shown to close at the transition point. Our theoretical predictions are supported by spatially and temporally resolved photoluminescence experiments, which directly visualize the formation and stabilization of the chiral current, offering insights into self-organization in open quantum systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Dynamical Phase Transitions and Chiral Vortex Formation in a Driven-Dissipative Polariton Condensate Lattice

text: We introduce a novel family of quantum low-density parity-check (qLDPC) codes, termed 'Lifted Product' codes, constructed via a balanced product of sparse classical codes with a specific homological structure. This construction yields a code family with asymptotically good parameters, namely a finite encoding rate and a distance that scales at least as the square root of the block size, n. We analyze the performance of these codes under depolarizing noise using a belief propagation plus ordered statistics decoder (BP-OSD). Our large-scale Monte Carlo simulations demonstrate a fault-tolerance threshold of approximately 0.8%, which is significantly higher than that of the surface code under an equivalent decoding scheme. The decoder complexity scales polynomially with n, making it practical for near-term implementation. The reduced qubit overhead and high threshold of Lifted Product codes present a compelling alternative to topological codes for building a scalable, fault-tolerant quantum computer.
subject: Kuantum
title: High-Threshold Quantum Error Correction with Lifted Product Codes

text: The fractional quantum Hall (FQH) state at filling factor ν=5/2 is predicted to host non-Abelian anyons, which are foundational for topological quantum computation. We report on direct experimental evidence of their braiding statistics using a novel electronic Fabry-Pérot interferometer fabricated on a high-mobility GaAs/AlGaAs two-dimensional electron gas. The device architecture allows for the deterministic trapping of a single quasiparticle excitation within the interferometer loop. By measuring the Aharonov-Bohm interference phase as a function of both magnetic field and gate-defined interferometer area, we observe discrete phase jumps of π. This is in stark contrast to the continuous phase evolution observed for Abelian anyons at ν=7/3. This π phase jump upon enclosing a bulk quasiparticle is a direct signature of the non-Abelian fusion rules of Ising anyons (Majorana zero modes) and provides the first definitive, transport-based confirmation of the topological order of the Moore-Read Pfaffian state.
subject: Kuantum
title: Direct Observation of Non-Abelian Anyonic Statistics at the ν=5/2 Fractional Quantum Hall Plateau

text: This paper establishes a rigorous link between the generation of multipartite entanglement and the principles of non-equilibrium thermodynamics. We consider a general open quantum system described by a Lindblad master equation, coupled to multiple thermal reservoirs. By employing a resource-theoretic framework for quantum thermodynamics, we derive a fundamental inequality that bounds the rate of distillable entanglement generation by the system's total entropy production rate. This trade-off demonstrates that creating quantum correlations is an inherently irreversible process with an associated thermodynamic cost. The bound is shown to be tight for certain classes of driven-dissipative dynamics. We apply our formalism to a model of coherently driven superconducting qubits coupled to a dissipative cavity, showing how optimal entanglement generation protocols must operate far from equilibrium, maximizing dissipation to achieve high fidelity Bell states. Our results unify concepts from quantum information theory and stochastic thermodynamics, imposing ultimate physical limits on quantum technologies.
subject: Kuantum
title: Thermodynamic Bounds on Entanglement Generation in Open Quantum Systems

text: We investigate the Turan problem for the 3-uniform hypergraph F, known as the 'expanded triangle', which consists of three edges intersecting pairwise in precisely one vertex, with an empty triple intersection. We establish that the Turan density of F is exactly 4/9. This resolves a longstanding conjecture in extremal hypergraph theory. Our proof employs a sophisticated application of the flag algebra calculus, which reduces the asymptotic problem to a semidefinite programming instance. Furthermore, we analyze the stability of near-extremal constructions by leveraging a novel connection to the spectral radius of the hypergraph adjacency tensor. We demonstrate that any F-free 3-uniform hypergraph with an edge density approaching 4/9 must, in the edit distance sense, be close to a specific blow-up of a 3-vertex hypergraph. This spectral approach provides a new analytical tool for understanding stability phenomena in extremal combinatorics.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Turan Density of Expanded Hypergraph Triangles and Spectral Radius Asymptotics

text: We determine the exact big Ramsey degrees of the universal homogeneous K_k-free ordered graph, commonly known as the ordered Henson graph H_k. For any finite ordered K_k-free graph F, we prove that the big Ramsey degree is finite, thereby establishing that H_k possesses the Ramsey property for its finite ordered substructures. Our main result provides an explicit upper bound, showing that for any F with n vertices, the Ramsey degree T(F) is at most 2^(n-1). The proof methodology integrates techniques from topological dynamics, specifically analyzing the universal minimal flow of the automorphism group of H_k, with a novel structural amalgamation argument for pre-colored finite graphs. This result contributes to the broader program of classifying which Fraïssé limits have finite big Ramsey degrees and offers a precise combinatorial understanding of partitioning ultrahomogeneous structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Big Ramsey Degrees of the Universal Ordered Henson Graph

text: We present a new identity for Macdonald polynomials P_λ(x; q, t) that provides a refined enumeration of totally symmetric self-complementary plane partitions (TSSCPPs) contained within a given box. The specialization of our identity at x = (1, q, q^2, ...) yields a q,t-generating function for TSSCPPs, where the exponents of q and t correspond to distinct combinatorial statistics related to the trace and the norm of the partition, respectively. The proof is algebraic in nature, relying on the theory of affine Hecke algebras and intricate manipulations of Kostka-Foulkes polynomials. This result establishes a previously unobserved connection between Macdonald theory and one of the ten symmetry classes of plane partitions enumerated by the Razumov-Stroganov-Zuber conjecture, providing a significant step towards a unified representation-theoretic framework for these combinatorial objects.
subject: Matematik
title: A Macdonald Polynomial Identity for Refined Enumeration of Totally Symmetric Self-Complementary Plane Partitions

text: We analyze the threshold phenomenon for the appearance of k-term arithmetic progressions (k-APs) in random subsets of {1, ..., N}. Let [N]_p denote the random subset where each element is included independently with probability p. We prove that the property of containing a k-AP exhibits a sharp threshold. Specifically, we establish that the threshold probability is p*(N) = N^(-2/(k-1)). Our proof leverages the hypergraph container method to restrict the structural search space for k-APs, combined with a refined application of Janson's inequality for estimating probabilities of small deviations. This result sharpens the classical bounds of Rödl and Ruciński and confirms, for all integers k ≥ 3, a conjecture by Kohayakawa, Łuczak, and Rödl. The methodology provides a robust framework applicable to other density-type theorems in random settings.
subject: Matematik
title: Sharp Thresholds for van der Waerden's Theorem in Random Subsets

text: A Steiner triple system of order v, STS(v), is pentagonal if it admits an automorphism group isomorphic to the dihedral group D_5. We investigate the existence spectrum for such designs. While the existence of an STS(v) is settled for all v ≡ 1, 3 (mod 6), the imposition of a D_5 automorphism constrains the spectrum significantly. We combine algebraic constructions using difference methods over finite fields with exhaustive computational search to prove that a pentagonal STS(v) exists if and only if v ≡ 1, 5 (mod 30). Our method relies on constructing base blocks under the action of the cyclic subgroup Z_n and then demonstrating that these blocks generate a valid system under the full dihedral group action. This resolves the existence question completely for this class of highly symmetric combinatorial designs.
subject: Matematik
title: The Existence Spectrum for Pentagonal Steiner Triple Systems of Order v

text: Rota's conjecture posits a finite set of excluded minors for matroid representability over any finite field GF(q). We contribute to this problem by identifying three new excluded minors for GF(5)-representability, each having fewer than 18 elements. Our approach is twofold: first, we employ a SAT-solver-assisted computational search to verify non-representability; second, we provide a structural proof based on the properties of dyadic matroids—those representable over GF(2) and GF(3) but not necessarily GF(5). We demonstrate that any non-GF(5)-representable matroid with certain connectivity properties must contain one of our new minors or a previously known one. This analysis illuminates the subtle structural transitions between matroid classes and offers a template for discovering excluded minors for other small fields, particularly the critical boundary between GF(4) and GF(5).
subject: Matematik
title: Excluded Minors for GF(q)-Representability and the Structure of Dyadic Matroids

text: We establish a non-abelian analogue of the polynomial Szemerédi theorem within the ring of Lipschitz quaternions. Utilizing a novel framework of higher-order Fourier analysis tailored to non-commutative settings, we prove that any subset of the Lipschitz quaternions with positive upper density must contain polynomial progressions of the form {x, x+P_1(q), ..., x+P_k(q)} for non-zero x and q, where P_i are integer-coefficient polynomials with zero constant term. The core of our argument is an inverse theorem for the Gowers-Host-Kra uniformity norms defined over the quaternion group. This theorem provides a structural characterization of sets lacking the expected uniformity, allowing us to implement a density-increment strategy. Our result extends the reach of additive combinatorial techniques to structured non-commutative domains and opens new avenues for studying arithmetic patterns in algebraic structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Higher-Order Fourier Analysis and Polynomial Progressions in Non-Abelian Groups

text: We analyze the integrality gap of the Held-Karp relaxation for the Asymmetric Traveling Salesperson Problem (ATSP) on directed graphs embeddable on a surface of genus g. We prove that the gap is bounded by O(log g / log log g), a significant improvement over the general O(log n) bound. This is the first result to achieve a sub-logarithmic dependency on the genus for ATSP. Our method introduces a novel randomized rounding procedure guided by a recursive decomposition of the graph. The decomposition is derived from a system of non-crossing cycles in the dual graph, which forms a laminar family of cuts. The analysis leverages a potential function argument that carefully amortizes the cost of the tour against the topological complexity of the embedding, providing tighter control than methods based solely on tree embeddings or metric properties.
subject: Matematik
title: Improved Integrality Gap for Asymmetric TSP on Directed Graphs with Bounded Genus

text: We establish a new upper bound on the number of incidences between a set of n points and a set of m algebraic hypersurfaces of degree at most k in R^d. By generalizing the polynomial partitioning technique of Guth and Katz, we introduce a recursive cellular decomposition of the space, where each cell boundary is defined by the zero set of a carefully constructed multivariate polynomial. This allows for precise control over the distribution of points and the interaction of hypersurfaces within each cell. For a set of points and hypersurfaces in general position, we prove that the number of incidences is O(n^(d(k-1)/(dk-1)) m^((d-1)k/(dk-1)) + n + m). This result unifies and extends several classical theorems in incidence geometry, including the Szemerédi-Trotter theorem in R^2, and provides the sharpest known bound for this general high-dimensional setting.
subject: Matematik
title: Polynomial Partitioning and Point-Hypersurface Incidences in Higher Dimensions

text: We introduce the concept of homological collapsibility to derive novel lower bounds on the chromatic number of k-uniform hypergraphs. Let N(v) be the neighborhood complex of a vertex v in a hypergraph H. Using tools from algebraic topology, specifically discrete Morse theory and spectral sequences, we prove that if the reduced homology groups H̃_i(N(v); Z) are non-trivial for some i < k-2 for all vertices v, then the chromatic number χ(H) is strictly greater than 2. More generally, we establish a lower bound for χ(H) in terms of the highest dimension of non-vanishing homology in these neighborhood complexes. This result generalizes Lovász's celebrated topological bound for the chromatic number of Kneser graphs to a much broader class of hypergraphs, providing a powerful framework for tackling coloring problems by analyzing the local topological structure of the hypergraph.
subject: Matematik
title: Homological Collapsibility and the Chromatic Number of Uniform Hypergraphs

text: The maintenance of telomere length by telomerase is fundamentally linked to cellular immortality and oncogenesis, yet the precise molecular mechanisms governing its recruitment and processivity remain incompletely understood. The shelterin component TPP1 is a critical regulator of telomerase function. Here, we present the high-resolution cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of the human telomerase holoenzyme in complex with the TPP1 OB-fold domain. The structure reveals an intricate network of interactions wherein the TEL patch of TPP1 engages a composite surface formed by the telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) and the T-motif of the telomerase RNA component (TERC). We demonstrate through site-directed mutagenesis and in vitro telomerase activity assays that this interface is essential for telomerase processivity, but not initial recruitment. Furthermore, we show that ATM-mediated phosphorylation of TPP1 at Ser123 enhances this interaction, providing a direct mechanistic link between DNA damage signaling and telomere maintenance. These findings elucidate a key regulatory checkpoint in telomere biology and offer a structural blueprint for targeting telomerase in cancer therapeutics.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure and Functional Dissection of the TPP1-Telomerase Holoenzyme Interface

text: The dysregulation of long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) is increasingly implicated in tumorigenesis. Here, we identify MALIGN-1 (MYC-Activating LncRNA In Neuroblastoma-1), a previously uncharacterized lncRNA, as a pivotal oncogenic driver in neuroblastoma. MALIGN-1 expression is highly correlated with poor patient prognosis and MYC amplification status. Using integrated genomic approaches, including Hi-C and Capture-C, we demonstrate that MALIGN-1 functions as a molecular scaffold. It simultaneously binds the chromatin architectural protein CTCF and the histone methyltransferase MLL1, tethering a distal enhancer element to the MYC promoter. This lncRNA-mediated chromatin looping event establishes a permissive chromatin state, characterized by elevated H3K4me3 and H3K27ac marks, leading to robust MYC transcription.
