Antisense oligonucleotide-mediated knockdown of MALIGN-1 in patient-derived xenograft models dismantled this chromatin architecture, abrogated MYC expression, and induced profound tumor regression. Our study uncovers a precise mechanism of lncRNA-dependent transcriptional control and highlights MALIGN-1 as a potent therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The lncRNA MALIGN-1 Orchestrates Chromatin Looping to Drive Oncogenic MYC Expression in Neuroblastoma

text: The tumor microenvironment (TME) of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is characterized by a dense desmoplastic stroma that fosters immunosuppression and therapeutic resistance. Deconvolving the cellular and molecular heterogeneity of the TME is critical for developing effective immunotherapies. By integrating single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) with high-plex spatial transcriptomics, we generated a comprehensive cellular atlas of human PDAC. We identified three distinct cancer-associated fibroblast (CAF) subtypes, including a novel apCAF (antigen-presenting CAF) population characterized by expression of MHC class II molecules. Spatially resolved ligand-receptor interaction modeling revealed a specific signaling axis wherein apCAFs present tumor antigens to regulatory T cells (Tregs) via the CD86-CTLA4 checkpoint, while simultaneously secreting CXCL12 to recruit and polarize M2-like tumor-associated macrophages. In vivo functional studies confirmed that selective depletion of apCAFs alleviates immunosuppression and enhances anti-PD-1 immunotherapy efficacy. This work deciphers a critical immunosuppressive niche and identifies a novel CAF subset as a potential therapeutic target.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatiotemporal Profiling of the Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma Microenvironment Reveals Fibroblast-Macrophage Crosstalk Driving Immunosuppression

text: Translational control is a rapid and potent mechanism for cellular adaptation to stress. While the concept of 'specialized ribosomes' has been proposed, the molecular mechanisms governing their assembly and function are poorly defined. Here, we demonstrate that under hypoxic conditions, the ribosomal protein RACK1 is phosphorylated at Thr50 by AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK). Using ribosome profiling and quantitative mass spectrometry, we show that phosphorylated RACK1 (p-RACK1) is preferentially incorporated into a subpopulation of ribosomes. These 'hypoxia-specialized' ribosomes exhibit altered translational fidelity and enhanced affinity for mRNAs containing a distinct 5' terminal oligopyrimidine (TOP) motif, including transcripts encoding key glycolytic enzymes and HIF-1α. Cryo-EM analysis of p-RACK1-containing ribosomes reveals a conformational shift in the mRNA entry channel that likely mediates this translational preference. Ablation of the RACK1 phosphorylation site impairs metabolic reprogramming and cell survival under hypoxia. Our findings establish a direct link between a signaling kinase and the core ribosomal machinery, defining a mechanism for translational specialization in stress adaptation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mechanistic Basis for Ribosome Specialization through RACK1 Phosphorylation in Hypoxic Stress Response

text: Biomolecular condensates formed via liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) are increasingly recognized as hubs for transcriptional regulation. Here, we investigate the role of the RNA-binding protein Fused in Sarcoma (FUS) in this process. We discover that FUS undergoes LLPS with core subunits of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex, notably BRG1, forming nuclear condensates at super-enhancer regions. These FUS-SWI/SNF condensates are enriched in enhancer RNAs (eRNAs) and the Mediator complex. Using live-cell single-particle tracking and super-resolution microscopy, we show that these condensates act as dynamic hubs that physically bridge enhancers and their cognate gene promoters. The intrinsically disordered low-complexity domain of FUS is essential for phase separation, and ALS-associated mutations within this domain disrupt condensate formation and abrogate enhancer-promoter communication. Our results reveal that LLPS of a FUS-chromatin remodeler complex provides a biophysical mechanism for organizing higher-order chromatin structure and coordinating transcriptional activation, which is disrupted in neurodegenerative disease.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of the FUS-SWI/SNF Complex Regulates Enhancer-Promoter Communication

text: The Fanconi Anemia (FA) pathway is a cornerstone of genomic stability, coordinating the repair of DNA inter-strand crosslinks (ICLs). A critical, yet poorly understood, step in this process is the nucleolytic 'unhooking' of the ICL from one parental DNA strand. We reconstituted the ICL unhooking reaction in vitro using purified human proteins and identified the FAN1 nuclease as the principal enzyme responsible for the incision 5' to the lesion. Using time-resolved cryo-EM, we captured snapshots of FAN1 engaged with a stalled replication fork mimic containing an ICL. The structures reveal how the monoubiquitinated FANCD2-FANCI clamp acts as a loading platform, recruiting FAN1 via its UBZ domain and positioning its catalytic domain precisely at the 5' flank of the ICL adduct. This recruitment induces a conformational change in FAN1, activating its nuclease activity and ensuring strand- and position-specific cleavage. These findings provide a definitive molecular movie of ICL unhooking, clarifying the central enzymatic step in the FA pathway.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural Basis of Inter-strand Crosslink Unhooking by the FAN1 Nuclease within the Fanconi Anemia Pathway

text: Mitochondrial quality control via mitophagy is critical for neuronal health, and its failure is a hallmark of Parkinson's disease (PD). The E3 ubiquitin ligase Parkin and the deubiquitinase USP30 act antagonistically to regulate this process. Here, we uncover a pathogenic feedback loop centered on this axis. We demonstrate that Parkin not only ubiquitinates mitochondrial outer membrane proteins to initiate mitophagy but also directly monoubiquitinates USP30, targeting it for p97-dependent extraction from the mitochondrial membrane and subsequent degradation. This action creates a positive feedback loop that amplifies the mitophagy signal. We identified a cohort of PD patients with mutations in the Parkin-binding domain of USP30 that render it resistant to this regulation. In patient-derived dopaminergic neurons, these mutant USP30 variants are hyper-stable at the mitochondria, leading to excessive deubiquitination of mitophagic substrates and a profound defect in mitochondrial clearance. Pharmacological inhibition of USP30 restores mitophagy in these patient cells, highlighting this feedback mechanism as a therapeutic target.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dysregulation of Mitophagy Autoregulation by a Pathogenic Parkin-USP30 Feedback Loop in Parkinson's Disease

text: The therapeutic potential of CRISPR-based gene editing is hampered by challenges in safe and efficient in vivo delivery. Here, we report the development of an integrin-targeted lipid nanoparticle (LNP) platform for non-viral delivery of a cytosine base editor (CBE) mRNA and a chemically modified sgRNA. The LNP surface is functionalized with a cyclic RGD peptide ligand that targets αvβ5 integrins, which are highly expressed on lung airway epithelia. Following intravenous administration in a murine model of cystic fibrosis (CF) harboring the G542X nonsense mutation, these LNPs accumulate preferentially in the lung. We achieve up to 40% C-to-T base editing in airway epithelial cells, successfully converting the premature stop codon into a cysteine codon (CGA) and restoring CFTR protein function, as evidenced by normalized transepithelial chloride conductance. The platform demonstrates minimal off-target editing and a low immunogenic profile compared to AAV-based delivery systems. This work represents a significant advance in targeted, non-viral delivery of gene editors for treating monogenic lung diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Non-viral Delivery of a Base Editor via Integrin-Targeted Lipid Nanoparticles for In Vivo Correction of Cystic Fibrosis Mutations

text: Cellular differentiation requires precise spatiotemporal modulation of the epigenetic landscape to establish lineage-specific gene expression programs. While the role of DNA methylation in silencing pluripotency genes is well-established, the mechanisms driving active demethylation at lineage-specific regulatory elements remain elusive. Combining genome-wide bisulfite sequencing with chromatin immunoprecipitation in a model of human hematopoietic stem cell differentiation, we show that the commitment to the erythroid lineage is preceded by targeted demethylation of a specific subset of enhancers. We demonstrate that the pioneering transcription factor GATA1 directly recruits the Ten-Eleven Translocation 2 (TET2) enzyme to these GATA1-binding motifs. This interaction facilitates iterative oxidation of 5-methylcytosine, leading to enhancer activation and subsequent expression of key erythroid genes like β-globin. Disruption of the GATA1-TET2 interaction abrogates enhancer demethylation and blocks erythroid differentiation. Our findings elucidate a direct mechanism for transcription factor-guided active demethylation, providing a paradigm for how cell fate decisions are epigenetically encoded.
subject: Biyoloji
title: TET2-Mediated Demethylation of Lineage-Specific Enhancers is Directed by GATA1 during Erythroid Differentiation

text: The hyperphosphorylation and aggregation of the microtubule-associated protein Tau are pathological hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease. Molecular chaperones play a critical role in maintaining proteostasis, but their specific involvement with Tau remains contested. Here, we demonstrate that the Hsp90 chaperone system directly regulates Tau pathology by controlling the activity of its primary kinase, GSK-3β. Using a combination of NMR spectroscopy, single-molecule FRET, and cellular assays, we show that Tau exists in a dynamic equilibrium between a closed, aggregation-resistant conformation and an open, aggregation-prone state. The Hsp90/Cdc37 co-chaperone complex preferentially binds and stabilizes the inactive conformation of GSK-3β, thereby reducing Tau phosphorylation. Conversely, inhibition of Hsp90 releases active GSK-3β, leading to Tau hyperphosphorylation and a conformational shift towards the aggregation-prone state. This work reveals that Hsp90 acts as a critical regulator of the Tau phosphoproteome, not by directly binding Tau, but by conformationally gating its upstream kinase, offering new therapeutic avenues for tauopathies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Conformational Gating of the Hsp90 Chaperone Cycle Modulates Tau Phosphorylation State and Aggregation Propensity

text: We address the critical challenge of estimating heterogeneous treatment effects in observational studies. This paper introduces a novel Bayesian nonparametric framework based on a hierarchical Dirichlet process mixture model to flexibly estimate the Conditional Average Treatment Effect (CATE). The proposed model circumvents restrictive parametric assumptions by clustering subjects into latent subpopulations with distinct treatment responses, where the number of subpopulations is inferred from the data. We utilize the potential outcomes framework and develop a collapsed Gibbs sampler for efficient posterior computation. Theoretical properties of the model are investigated, establishing posterior concentration rates for the CATE function under standard regularity conditions. The methodology is validated on synthetic datasets, demonstrating superior performance in capturing complex, nonlinear treatment effect heterogeneity compared to conventional methods like causal forests and BART. An application to a large-scale electronic health record dataset illustrates the model's utility in identifying patient subgroups with differential responses to a common medical intervention, providing actionable insights for personalized medicine.
subject: İstatistik
title: Nonparametric Bayesian Inference for Heterogeneous Causal Effects via Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Mixtures

text: This research proposes a new methodology for estimating sparse high-dimensional covariance matrices when data originate from non-Gaussian, heavy-tailed distributions. Standard methods like graphical Lasso rely on sub-Gaussian assumptions that are frequently violated in practice, leading to suboptimal performance. We introduce a robust adaptive thresholding estimator that operates on a rank-based correlation matrix, such as Kendall's tau, and employs a data-driven threshold selection procedure that is resilient to outliers and heavy tails. The theoretical analysis establishes minimax optimal convergence rates in the spectral norm for a broad class of elliptical distributions. Our estimator avoids computationally intensive matrix inversions, rendering it highly scalable. Extensive Monte Carlo simulations demonstrate that our proposed method significantly outperforms existing robust and non-robust techniques in terms of estimation accuracy and support recovery, particularly under conditions of severe tail contamination. The practical advantages are showcased through an analysis of a high-dimensional financial asset returns dataset, revealing a more stable and interpretable dependency structure.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Thresholding for Sparse Covariance Matrix Estimation under Non-Gaussian Heavy-Tailed Distributions

text: Topological Data Analysis (TDA) offers powerful tools for characterizing the shape of complex data, yet formal statistical inference remains a key challenge. This paper develops a rigorous inferential framework for persistent homology, enabling hypothesis testing on the topological features of datasets. We introduce a novel and computationally efficient multiplier bootstrap procedure for constructing confidence regions for persistence diagrams and their functional summaries, such as persistence landscapes. This technique facilitates robust two-sample tests to determine if observed differences in topological summaries (e.g., Betti numbers) are statistically significant. We establish the asymptotic validity of our bootstrap method under weak dependence assumptions, making it applicable to time-series data. The framework's efficacy is demonstrated by differentiating between dynamical regimes in simulated chaotic systems and by analyzing functional brain connectivity networks from fMRI data, where it uncovers significant topological distinctions between patient cohorts that are invisible to conventional statistical methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Statistical Inference on Persistent Homology for Differentiating Complex System Dynamics

text: We present a doubly robust causal forest algorithm for nonparametric estimation of conditional average treatment effects (CATE) in the presence of high-dimensional confounders. The proposed method enhances the causal forest framework by incorporating doubly robust score functions directly into the tree-splitting criterion and final predictions. Specifically, each split is chosen to maximize the heterogeneity in the estimated CATE, where the local CATE is derived from locally weighted regression adjustments of the outcome and propensity score. This construction ensures that the resulting CATE estimates are consistent and asymptotically normal if either the outcome regression or the propensity score model is consistently estimated, a crucial property in high dimensions where model misspecification is likely. We derive the asymptotic distribution of our estimator and provide a consistent variance estimator based on the influence function. Empirical results on both synthetic and real-world observational data demonstrate a marked reduction in bias and mean squared error compared to existing causal forest and meta-learner approaches.
subject: İstatistik
title: Doubly Robust Causal Forest for Estimating Conditional Average Treatment Effects with High-Dimensional Confounders

text: This paper introduces a novel statistical model for regressing a scalar response on a spatio-temporal functional predictor, designed for high-resolution environmental data. Our approach models the coefficient function using a tensor product of penalized B-splines over the temporal, spatial, and functional domains, effectively capturing smooth interactions and avoiding the information loss inherent in two-stage dimension reduction techniques like functional PCA. Estimation is performed within a penalized likelihood framework, with smoothing parameters selected efficiently via Restricted Maximum Likelihood (REML). This integrated approach provides interpretable estimates of how the influence of the functional predictor varies smoothly across space and time. We establish the asymptotic consistency of the proposed estimator. The methodology is applied to predict agricultural yield using intra-annual satellite-derived vegetation index curves across a large geographical region, demonstrating superior predictive accuracy and enhanced inferential capabilities over existing functional and spatio-temporal models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Spatio-Temporal Functional Regression for High-Resolution Environmental Data via Penalized Spline Tensor Products

text: We propose Amortized Stein Variational Gradient Descent (ASVGD), a novel method for fast and scalable posterior inference in complex Bayesian hierarchical models. Traditional MCMC methods are often prohibitively slow for large datasets, while standard variational inference can yield poor approximations. ASVGD combines the particle-based flexibility of Stein Variational Gradient Descent (SVGD) with the efficiency of amortized inference. We train an inference network to map observations from the data distribution directly to a set of particles that approximate the posterior, thereby amortizing the cost of inference. A key contribution is a new training objective based on the Kernelized Stein Discrepancy, which drives the particles to match the true posterior without requiring an explicit variational family. We provide theoretical guarantees on the convergence of the procedure. On several challenging hierarchical models, including spatial statistics and mixed-effects models, ASVGD achieves posterior approximations of comparable quality to long-run MCMC but with orders-of-magnitude reduction in computation time.
subject: İstatistik
title: Amortized Stein Variational Gradient Descent for Scalable Bayesian Hierarchical Models

text: Detecting multiple change-points in high-dimensional time series with serial dependence is a formidable statistical problem. We propose a multiscale method, High-Dimensional Wild Binary Segmentation (HD-WBS), which extends the WBS framework to this challenging setting. HD-WBS addresses the limitations of standard binary segmentation by analyzing a large number of randomly drawn sub-intervals, which significantly increases its power to detect short-lived changes and multiple closely-spaced change-points. To handle temporal and cross-sectional dependencies, our test statistic is a CUSUM-type statistic built upon a projection of the high-dimensional series and is normalized by a consistent estimator of the long-run covariance matrix. We rigorously prove that, under mild mixing conditions and sparsity assumptions on the change-points, HD-WBS consistently estimates the number and locations of the change-points. Through simulations and an application to identifying structural breaks in a panel of financial volatility series, we demonstrate its superior empirical performance over competing methods in both accuracy and localization precision.
subject: İstatistik
title: Multiscale Wild Binary Segmentation for Dependent and High-Dimensional Time Series

text: Understanding the generalization capabilities of deep residual networks (ResNets) is a fundamental problem in statistical learning theory. This paper derives novel generalization error bounds for ResNets that are sensitive to their unique architectural structure and depend polynomially, rather than exponentially, on network depth. Moving beyond standard Rademacher complexity analysis, which often yields vacuous bounds for deep models, we leverage the concept of local Rademacher complexity conditioned on low-loss function classes. Our primary technical contribution is a refined analysis of the network's Lipschitz constant, exploiting the contractive properties of residual blocks under mild regularization. This allows us to prove tighter, data-dependent bounds that incorporate norms of the weight matrices and the spectral properties of the data covariance matrix. These bounds provide theoretical justification for the empirical observation that deeper ResNets can generalize well and offer new insights into the role of skip connections in controlling model complexity, guiding more principled architectural design.
subject: İstatistik
title: Generalization Bounds for Deep Residual Networks via Local Rademacher Complexity

text: We study the problem of estimating sparse precision matrices for high-dimensional Gaussian graphical models when the data is corrupted by cell-wise contamination, a challenging scenario where arbitrary entries in the data matrix can be outliers. Standard estimators like the graphical Lasso are notoriously brittle to such contamination. This paper introduces a novel, computationally efficient procedure, the Co-ordinate-wise Adaptive Robust Thresholding (CART) estimator. The method iteratively estimates the precision matrix and identifies potentially contaminated cells by inspecting the magnitude of the scaled residuals. A key innovation is an adaptive thresholding step that robustifies the empirical covariance matrix used in each iteration of a graphical Lasso-type algorithm. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis showing that our estimator achieves near-optimal rates of convergence under a cell-wise contamination model, provided the contamination is sufficiently sparse. Extensive simulations and a real-world application in gene expression network inference demonstrate that our method substantially outperforms existing robust estimators in both graph recovery and estimation accuracy.
subject: İstatistik
title: Robust Precision Matrix Estimation in Gaussian Graphical Models with Cell-wise Contamination

text: This paper investigates the asymptotic behavior of Turan numbers for non-uniform hypergraphs, or set systems, constrained by forbidden intersection patterns. We introduce a generalized framework for `F`-free systems where `F` is a family of set configurations defined by their pairwise intersection cardinalities. By leveraging a combination of the delta-system method, probabilistic refinements of Zykov's symmetrization, and techniques from spectral hypergraph theory, we establish a new upper bound on the Turan density `π(F)`. Our main result provides a tight bound for `F` corresponding to a `(k, t)`-daisy, resolving a longstanding conjecture. The proof hinges on a novel stability argument which demonstrates that any near-extremal configuration must be structurally close to a multi-layered sunflower construction. This work unifies several disparate results in extremal set theory and provides a robust methodology for analyzing problems where the uniformity constraint is relaxed, with direct implications for combinatorial geometry and coding theory.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Turan Density of Non-Uniform Hypergraphs with Forbidden Intersection Patterns

text: The Kronecker coefficients `g(λ, μ, ν)` of the symmetric group `S_n` remain one of the most challenging problems in algebraic combinatorics. This research focuses on the stable Kronecker coefficients involving partitions `λ` of hook shape. We introduce a novel combinatorial object, the 'plethystic tableau', and develop a weight-preserving bijection to a specific class of Schur-positive symmetric functions. This correspondence allows us to derive a new recurrence relation for `g(λ, μ, ν)` when `λ` is a hook. Our methodology combines the representation theory of `GL_m x GL_n` with combinatorial techniques on Young diagrams, specifically utilizing the RSK algorithm's variants. We provide a manifestly positive combinatorial formula for these coefficients in the stable limit, thereby giving a combinatorial proof for a previously conjectured identity. This result offers new insights into the asymptotic behavior of Kronecker products and their connections to quantum information theory and geometric complexity theory.
subject: Matematik
title: Plethystic Decompositions and the Kronecker Coefficients for Hook-Shaped Partitions

text: We study the topological and combinatorial structure of random `d`-dimensional simplicial complexes in the Linial-Meshulam model `Y_d(n, p)`. This paper precisely characterizes the phase transition for the emergence of a 'giant shadow,' which we define as a `(d-1)`-dimensional subcomplex whose `(d-1)`-th homology group has rank linear in `n`. Utilizing a carefully constructed exploration process analogous to the breadth-first search for random graphs, we analyze the growth of homology cycles. The analysis relies on coupling the process with a multi-type branching process and applying advanced concentration inequalities, particularly Azuma-Hoeffding for martingale difference sequences derived from the boundary operator's matrix representation. Our results establish the sharp threshold `p = c/n` for this topological phase transition, determining the constant `c` as a function of `d`. We further demonstrate that, subcritically, all homology is local, while supercritically, a unique giant cycle dominates the complex's topology.
subject: Matematik
title: Phase Transitions in Random Simplicial Complexes: The Emergence of High-Dimensional Giant Components

text: The sum-product problem in a finite field `F_q` posits that for any small set `A ⊂ F_q`, either the sumset `A+A` or the product set `A·A` must be large. We present a novel approach that improves upon existing lower bounds for `max(|A+A|, |A·A|)`. Our method translates the problem into an incidence geometry question concerning a point-line configuration derived from `A` and then analyzes the spectral properties of the associated bipartite incidence graph. By leveraging a refined spectral graph expander mixing lemma and establishing new bounds on the second eigenvalue through Weil's character sum estimates, we show that `max(|A+A|, |A·A|) ≥ c|A|^(1+1/4-ε)` for `|A| ≤ p^(5/8)`. This represents a significant improvement on the exponent for a wide range of set sizes. The technique avoids reliance on the Szemerédi-Trotter theorem's finite field analogues, offering a more direct algebraic-geometric pathway to sum-product phenomena.
subject: Matematik
title: Improved Sum-Product Estimates in Finite Fields via Spectral Graph Excitations

text: This work employs methods from equivariant algebraic topology to establish lower bounds on the chromatic number of geometric hypergraphs. We consider `r`-uniform hypergraphs whose vertices are points in `Z^d` and whose hyperedges are defined by containment in translates of a fixed finite 'pattern' set `P`. The primary tool is the construction of a configuration space `C` and a test map `f: C → R^m` whose properties are constrained by the hypergraph's colorability. Using the Fadell-Husseini index and advanced spectral sequence arguments, we prove that the existence of a `k`-coloring implies the vanishing of certain topological invariants. For a broad class of centrally symmetric patterns `P`, we derive a general lower bound on the chromatic number that grows logarithmically with the diameter of `P`. This extends the classical Borsuk-Ulam theorem's combinatorial applications and resolves a conjecture regarding the chromatic number of octane-distance hypergraphs in `Z^3`.
subject: Matematik
title: Topological Obstructions to `k`-Coloring in Geometric Hypergraphs on Lattices

text: We investigate the structural properties of minor-closed classes of matroids that exclude a fixed planar graph minor. A central result of Geelen, Gerards, and Whittle shows that such classes have a bounded branch-width, implying a structure theorem involving grafts on surfaces. This paper refines this decomposition by providing a more precise characterization of the constituent building blocks. We prove that any matroid in such a class can be constructed via a sequence of `k`-sums (for a bounded `k`) from matroids that are 'almost' graphic or cographic, with their non-representable parts confined to a finite set of templates. As a key application, we determine the growth rate function for the number of non-isomorphic matroids on `n` elements in the class, showing it is of the form `c n^α 2^βn`. This confirms a conjecture on the combinatorial complexity and enumerative behavior of these structured matroid classes.
subject: Matematik
title: The Structure and Growth Rate of Minor-Closed Classes of Matroids with Bounded Branch-Width

text: The multicolor Ramsey number `R_k(H)` is the minimum integer `n` such that any `k`-coloring of the edges of `K_n` contains a monochromatic copy of `H`. This paper focuses on the case where `H` is a sparse, bipartite graph. We develop a novel extension of the dependent random choice lemma combined with a sparse regularity method tailored for multicolor settings. Our main result establishes an asymptotically tight bound for the Ramsey number of the `d`-dimensional hypercube `Q_d`, showing that `R_k(Q_d) = (k+o(1))2^(d-1)d`. This significantly improves previous exponential bounds in `k`. The proof involves a recursive coloring strategy and demonstrates that any coloring of a sufficiently large complete graph must contain a dense, structured subgraph that is amenable to embedding `Q_d`. This technique provides a general framework applicable to other sparse bipartite graphs with sublinear separators, advancing the state-of-the-art in structural Ramsey theory.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotic Determination of the Multicolor Ramsey Number for Sparse, Bipartite Graphs

text: We study the enumeration of bipolar-oriented planar maps where the degrees of the faces are constrained to a specific finite set `S`. By employing bijective methods linking these maps to decorated plane trees, we derive an exact functional equation for the corresponding multivariate generating function. The core of our work involves a detailed analytic combinatorics approach to this equation. We perform a singularity analysis of the generating function, identifying the critical points and determining the asymptotic behavior of the enumeration sequence. For a wide class of allowed degree sets `S`, we prove that the scaling limit of these random maps, when properly renormalized, converges in the Gromov-Hausdorff sense to a specific instance of the Brownian map. This result is achieved by demonstrating the convergence of discrete snake-like structures within the bijections to continuous snake processes driven by a Lévy process, linking discrete enumeration to continuous random geometry.
subject: Matematik
title: Enumeration and Scaling Limits of Bipolar-Oriented Planar Maps with Controlled Face Degrees

text: The facial structure of the symmetric traveling salesperson polytope `P_n` is fundamental to polyhedral approaches for solving the TSP. We introduce a new, infinite class of valid inequalities, termed `k`-parity wheel inequalities, derived from a decomposition of `K_n` into edge-disjoint subgraphs with specific parity constraints on their cuts. These inequalities generalize the classical comb and clique-tree inequalities. Our main contribution is a rigorous proof, using non-trivial lifting arguments and affine geometry, that these `k`-parity wheel inequalities define facets of `P_n` under mild, verifiable conditions on the underlying graph structure. We further develop a polynomial-time separation algorithm for a subclass of these inequalities, demonstrating their practical utility within a branch-and-cut framework. This discovery enriches our understanding of the combinatorial complexity of `P_n` and provides stronger linear programming relaxations for this canonical NP-hard problem.
subject: Matematik
title: A New Class of Facet-Defining Inequalities for the Symmetric Traveling Salesperson Polytope from `k`-Parity Decompositions

text: A large set of `t-(v,k,λ)` designs, denoted `LS[N](t,k,v)`, is a partition of the set of all `k`-subsets of a `v`-set into `N` disjoint `t-(v,k,λ)` designs. The existence of such structures is a central and difficult problem in combinatorial design theory. This paper presents a new recursive construction method based on the automorphism groups of affine planes and their extensions. We prove the existence of a new infinite family of large sets of `2-(q^2, q, q-2)` designs for prime powers `q ≡ 3 (mod 4)`. The construction leverages cyclotomic properties of finite fields and the structure of Paley graphs. Furthermore, we analyze the ternary error-correcting codes spanned by the incidence matrices of the constructed designs. We determine the weight distribution, minimum distance, and covering radius of these codes by employing techniques from association schemes and character theory, establishing a direct link between these extremal combinatorial objects and optimal coding structures.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Existence of Large Sets of `t-(v,k,λ)` Designs and Their Associated Codes

text: Cryptic species complexes present a significant challenge to biodiversity assessment and conservation. Here, we employ a phylogenomic approach, utilizing ultraconserved elements (UCEs) from over 300 specimens, to dissect the evolutionary history of the marine gastropod genus *Nucella*. Our coalescent-based species delimitation analyses robustly identify five previously unrecognized lineages, masked by conserved shell morphology. Time-calibrated phylogenetic inference places the primary divergence events in the late Pliocene, aligning with the final closure of the Central American Seaway and subsequent oceanographic shifts. Notably, we uncover evidence of asymmetric introgression between two parapatric lineages in the Northeast Pacific, likely facilitated by post-Pleistocene secondary contact. Our findings demonstrate that integrative taxonomic approaches are crucial for uncovering hidden biodiversity and reveal how historical biogeographic barriers and recent climatic oscillations synergistically shape the genomic architecture of marine invertebrates. This work underscores the complexity of speciation processes in high-dispersal marine environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Resolution of a Cryptic Species Complex Reveals Pliocene Vicariance and Post-Glacial Introgression

text: The origin of morphological novelty is a central theme in evolutionary developmental biology. We investigated the genomic basis for the evolution of the posterior crossvein (PCV), a key innovation in the wing venation of *Drosophila*. Through comparative transcriptomics, ATAC-seq, and functional genomics across multiple drosophilid species, we demonstrate that the recruitment of a novel cis-regulatory element (CRE) upstream of the *Distal-less* (Dll) gene was instrumental in establishing a new domain of expression. This CRE is bound by the transcription factor Engrailed, linking the anteroposterior patterning system to a pre-existing vein-patterning gene regulatory network (GRN). Our results illustrate a classic case of regulatory co-option, where the evolution of a single CRE re-wires a deeply conserved GRN to generate a discrete, adaptive morphological trait. This provides a mechanistic understanding of how developmental pathways are modified to produce evolutionary novelties without compromising ancestral functions.
subject: Evrim
title: Cis-Regulatory Evolution of the *Distal-less* Gene Regulatory Network Underpins Novelty in Insect Wing Venation

text: The Red Queen hypothesis posits that antagonistic coevolution drives perpetual adaptation. We tracked the real-time evolutionary dynamics of *Pseudomonas aeruginosa* and its lytic phage φPa1 through 500 generations of experimental coevolution. Whole-genome, time-series sequencing revealed reciprocal selective sweeps in bacterial surface receptor genes and phage tail fiber genes. We observed fluctuating selection dynamics, where resistance and infectivity alleles cyclically replaced one another. Crucially, fitness assays in ancestral host/phage environments demonstrated significant pleiotropic costs associated with both resistance and infectivity mutations. These trade-offs prevent the fixation of universally superior genotypes, thereby maintaining genetic polymorphism and sustaining the coevolutionary arms race. Our results provide empirical support for the role of fitness costs in mediating Red Queen dynamics and highlight the molecular architecture of rapidly evolving host-parasite interactions.
subject: Evrim
title: Antagonistic Coevolution in a Host-Phage System Is Mediated by Fitness Costs of Resistance and Infectivity

text: The extinction of Pleistocene megafauna represents a major paleoecological event, yet the demographic processes preceding their disappearance remain poorly understood. We generated 52 complete mitochondrial genomes and 12 nuclear genomes from subfossil remains of the Steppe Bison (*Bison priscus*) spanning the last 50,000 years. Our demographic modeling, using Bayesian skyline plots and Sequential Markovian Coalescent (SMC++) methods, reveals a dynamic population history characterized by a significant decline in effective population size coinciding with the Bølling-Allerød interstadial warming. We also identify multiple instances of admixture with archaic lineages of American Bison, suggesting a complex history of connectivity across Beringia. Our data indicate that the terminal decline of *B. priscus* was not a sudden event but a prolonged process of population fragmentation and decreasing genetic diversity, exacerbated by rapid climate change long before significant human demographic expansion in the region.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Reconstruction of the Steppe Bison Metapopulation Reveals a History of Admixture and Climate-Driven Decline

text: Explaining the evolution of altruism remains a foundational quest in biology. We integrate inclusive fitness and multilevel selection theories by examining the genomic basis of reproductive division of labor in the paper wasp *Polistes dominula*. Using comparative transcriptomics on queens and workers across multiple colonies with varying degrees of relatedness, we identified a core suite of genes involved in fertility and behavior that are differentially regulated. Crucially, the expression plasticity of these 'cooperation genes' is modulated by both individual genotype and colony-level social environment. Path analysis demonstrates that while kin selection (indirect fitness benefits) is a primary driver, colony-level productivity (a component of group selection) explains significant additional variance in altruistic helping behavior. Our results provide a unified framework, showing that gene regulatory networks respond to selective pressures operating simultaneously at multiple levels, thereby facilitating the evolution of complex sociality.
subject: Evrim
title: Sociogenomic Architecture and the Interplay of Kin and Multilevel Selection in a Eusocial Wasp

text: Adaptive radiations provide powerful systems for studying the mechanics of speciation. We analyzed whole-genome sequences from over 200 individuals representing the entire species flock of Lake Victoria cichlid fishes. We uncovered a highly complex pattern of genomic differentiation, where phylogenetic signals are largely incongruent across different genomic regions due to extensive incomplete lineage sorting (ILS) and post-speciation hybridization. Despite this, we identified distinct genomic islands of divergence associated with trophic ecology (e.g., dentition, jaw morphology) that are shared among phenotypically convergent, but distantly related, ecomorphs. These islands are enriched for genes in developmental pathways and harbor signatures of positive selection. Our findings support a model where rapid speciation and parallel evolution are fueled by the differential sorting of ancient, standing genetic variation, allowing for rapid and repeated adaptation to newly available ecological niches.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Architecture of an Adaptive Radiation: Parallel Trophic Specializations Driven by Divergent Sorting of Ancestral Variation

text: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a potent evolutionary force in prokaryotes, yet its role in structuring entire microbial ecosystems is debated. Through deep metagenomic sequencing of microbial consortia from Mid-Atlantic Ridge hydrothermal vents, we reconstructed thousands of metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs). Phylogenetic analysis reveals extensive HGT, with nearly 20% of genes in an average MAG having a detectable xenologous origin. We found that entire metabolic pathways, particularly those for chemosynthesis using sulfur and methane compounds, are frequently transferred as discrete mobile genetic elements (MGEs) across phyla. This rampant exchange facilitates rapid niche expansion and creates a distributed metabolism within the community, where metabolic functions are partitioned among lineages. Our study demonstrates that HGT acts as a key mechanism of ecological scaffolding, enabling microbial communities to colonize and thrive in extreme environments by sharing metabolic innovations across the microbial tree of life.
subject: Evrim
title: Metagenomic Evidence for Horizontal Gene Transfer as a Primary Driver of Metabolic Innovation in Deep-Sea Hydrothermal Vent Communities

text: Sexual conflict over reproductive outcomes can fuel a coevolutionary arms race between male and female traits. We performed population genomic and proteomic analyses of seminal fluid proteins (SFPs) and female sperm-storage organs across 15 species of the *Drosophila melanogaster* subgroup. We identified a suite of proteins exhibiting exceptionally high rates of positive selection (dN/dS > 1), indicative of adaptive evolution. Functional assays using RNAi reveal that specific male SFPs enhance fertilization success at a cost to female remating rate and longevity, while certain female-expressed proteins counteract these manipulative effects. The phylogenetic pattern of gain and loss for these interacting proteins suggests a rapid turnover consistent with ongoing sexually antagonistic coevolution. This work provides a molecular portrait of genomic conflict, illustrating how interlocus contest drives the rapid evolution of reproductive genes and potentially contributes to reproductive isolation between diverging lineages.
subject: Evrim
title: Sexually Antagonistic Coevolution Drives Rapid Diversification of Seminal Fluid and Female Reproductive Proteins in *Drosophila*

text: The hypothesis of genetic assimilation, where an environmentally induced trait becomes genetically encoded, provides a potential mechanism for rapid adaptation. We tested this hypothesis in *Arabidopsis thaliana* by subjecting a genetically diverse population to repeated cycles of heat shock, selecting for individuals exhibiting a novel, stress-induced leaf morphology. After 10 generations of selection, the trait was constitutively expressed even in the absence of the heat-shock stimulus. Whole-genome sequencing of the selected and control lines revealed significant allele frequency shifts at several quantitative trait loci (QTLs). These QTLs contain genes with known roles in developmental pathways, which harbored initially rare alleles (cryptic genetic variation) in the base population. Our results provide strong empirical evidence for Waddington's model of genetic assimilation, demonstrating how environmental stress can unveil cryptic genetic variation, which selection can then act upon to convert a plastic phenotype into a fixed, heritable trait.
subject: Evrim
title: Experimental Demonstration of Genetic Assimilation of a Heat-Shock Induced Phenotype via Cryptic Genetic Variation

text: The tempo and mode of evolution remain a central debate, epitomized by the controversy between phyletic gradualism and punctuated equilibria. We leveraged a dense fossil record dataset of over 2,000 Cenozoic marine bivalve species, combined with a new time-calibrated phylogeny, to rigorously test these models. Using high-dimensional geometric morphometrics to quantify shell shape, we applied novel phylogenetic comparative methods that fit different models of trait evolution (e.g., Brownian Motion, Ornstein-Uhlenbeck, and punctuated models) to the data. Our model-fitting results overwhelmingly support a punctuated mode of evolution, where the majority of morphological change is statistically associated with cladogenetic events (speciation). Periods of morphological stasis within lineages are interrupted by rapid, geologically instantaneous shifts. This study provides one of the most robust quantitative validations of the punctuated equilibrium model in a major animal clade, challenging the paradigm of gradualistic change in the fossil record.
subject: Evrim
title: A Macroevolutionary Test of Punctuated Equilibria: Phylogenetic Comparative Analysis of Cenozoic Bivalve Morphospace

text: The spatial organization of chromatin is critical for precise gene regulation, yet the mechanisms governing the formation of enhancer-promoter loops remain elusive. Here, we demonstrate that the POK family transcription factor ZBTB7A undergoes liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) to form transcriptional condensates. Utilizing a combination of super-resolution microscopy, Hi-C, and CUT&RUN, we show that ZBTB7A condensates preferentially form at super-enhancers, driven by multivalent interactions between its BTB/POZ domain and acetylated histones. These condensates act as hubs, physically tethering multiple distal enhancers to target promoters within a shared topologically associating domain (TAD). Perturbation of ZBTB7A's phase separation capacity via mutagenesis of its intrinsically disordered region abrogates loop formation, disrupts the integrity of transcriptional condensates containing RNA Polymerase II and Mediator, and leads to a profound downregulation of oncogenic target genes. Our findings propose a model where transcription factor LLPS provides the biophysical basis for the assembly and function of super-enhancers, acting as a key regulator of 3D genome architecture.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phase Separation of the Transcription Factor ZBTB7A Orchestrates Chromatin Looping and Super-Enhancer Function

text: Cellular proteostasis is maintained by intricate quality control mechanisms that identify and degrade aberrant proteins. We report the cryo-electron microscopy structure of a novel ribosome-nascent chain complex (RNC) bound to the E3 ubiquitin ligase RQT1. The structure reveals that RQT1 engages the ribosomal exit tunnel and specifically recognizes stalled nascent polypeptides bearing C-terminal alanines and threonines (CAT-tails), a hallmark of nonstop decay. In vitro reconstitution assays combined with mass spectrometry demonstrate that RQT1, in concert with the E2 enzyme Ube2j1, polyubiquitinates the stalled nascent chain with K48-linked chains, targeting it for immediate proteasomal degradation. Furthermore, ribosome profiling in RQT1-knockout cells shows widespread ribosome pausing at cryptic polyadenylation sites, leading to proteotoxic stress. This work elucidates a molecular snapshot of co-translational quality control, defining a specific E3 ligase-RNC interface that ensures the timely elimination of potentially harmful proteins during their synthesis, thereby safeguarding cellular protein homeostasis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural and Functional Characterization of a Ribosome-Associated E3 Ligase in Co-translational Protein Triage

text: Mitochondrial dynamics are fundamental to cellular bioenergetics and signaling. We have identified a mitochondrial-associated long non-coding RNA, which we term *Mitofissin*, that functions as a critical regulator of mitochondrial fission. Through a combination of RNA-protein interaction screens and cellular fractionation, we show that *Mitofissin* directly binds to the SUMO E3 ligase PIAS3, localizing it to the mitochondrial outer membrane. This localization facilitates the targeted SUMOylation of Dynamin-related protein 1 (Drp1) at lysine residue 126, a post-translational modification that significantly enhances Drp1's GTPase activity and its assembly into fission-competent oligomers. Depletion of *Mitofissin* results in hyperfused mitochondrial networks, impaired mitophagy, and increased sensitivity to apoptotic stimuli. Conversely, its overexpression promotes mitochondrial fragmentation. These findings unveil a novel regulatory axis where a non-coding RNA acts as a spatial scaffold for a post-translational modification enzyme, thereby directly controlling organellar morphology and cellular fate.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Long Non-Coding RNA Governs Mitochondrial Fission Dynamics by Modulating Drp1 SUMOylation

text: Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) differentiation is a tightly regulated process, but the interplay between chromatin accessibility and transcriptional programs at fate decision points is poorly resolved. By applying simultaneous single-cell ATAC-seq and RNA-seq, we mapped the regulatory landscape of thousands of murine HSCs as they commit to either myeloid or lymphoid lineages. Our trajectory inference analysis revealed a transient, unstable intermediate progenitor state characterized by broad multi-lineage chromatin priming. We identified the transcription factor PU.1 as a pivotal regulator that resolves this ambiguity by selectively closing chromatin at lymphoid-affiliated enhancer regions while concurrently activating myeloid-specific cis-regulatory elements. Computational modeling and functional validation using CRISPR-based epigenome editing confirm that PU.1-mediated differential enhancer decommissioning constitutes an irreversible checkpoint. This work provides a high-resolution blueprint of lineage commitment, demonstrating how dynamic epigenetic remodeling executed by a master regulator enforces cellular identity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated Single-Cell Multi-Omics Delineates an Epigenetic Checkpoint in Hematopoietic Stem Cell Lineage Commitment

text: Pre-mRNA splicing, executed by the spliceosome, is a dynamic process involving two sequential transesterification reactions. While the first catalytic step is structurally well-characterized, the exon ligation step has remained enigmatic. Here, we present the 2.9 Å resolution cryo-electron microscopy structure of the human post-catalytic P complex, captured immediately following exon ligation. The structure reveals the ligated exon product threaded through a channel formed by the PRP8 and EFTUD2 proteins, poised for release. Critically, the lariat intron-2nd exon intermediate is held in a strained conformation by the step II factor PRP17, positioning the 3'-hydroxyl of the 5' exon for nucleophilic attack on the 3'-splice site phosphate. This conformation is stabilized by a coordinated network of magnesium ions and protein-RNA interactions within the catalytic core. Our findings provide a definitive structural basis for the second chemical step of splicing, revealing the intricate molecular choreography that ensures fidelity and efficiency in mRNA maturation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Human Spliceosome in the Act of Exon Ligation

text: The FET family protein TAF15 is implicated in neurodegenerative diseases and forms liquid-like condensates crucial for transcription. The regulation of its biophysical properties remains poorly understood. Here, we uncover a competitive post-translational modification (PTM) switch that governs TAF15 phase behavior. Using Phos-tag mobility shift assays and targeted mass spectrometry, we show that phosphorylation of a specific tyrosine residue (Y386) within the prion-like domain by SRC kinase inhibits TAF15's ability to undergo liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS). Conversely, methylation of an adjacent arginine (R384) by the arginine methyltransferase PRMT1 enhances LLPS and promotes the formation of hydrogel-like, less dynamic condensates. Strikingly, Y386 phosphorylation prevents subsequent R384 methylation, creating a hierarchical PTM checkpoint. In neuronal cells, synaptic activity induces SRC-mediated phosphorylation, dissolving TAF15 condensates and releasing associated transcripts. This study reveals a sophisticated PTM-based regulatory mechanism controlling the material state and function of an RNA-binding protein.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dynamic Crosstalk between Arginine Methylation and Phosphorylation on TAF15 Controls its Phase Separation and Transcriptional Activity

text: Translational control is paramount for rapid cellular adaptation to environmental cues like hypoxia. The expression of Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor A (VEGFA) is potently induced by low oxygen, partly through relief of translational repression. We demonstrate that the human *VEGFA* 5' UTR contains a highly conserved G-rich sequence that folds into a stable parallel G-quadruplex (G4) structure. Using SHALiPE-seq and NMR spectroscopy, we confirmed the G4's existence in vitro and in vivo. In vitro translation assays and polysome profiling reveal that this G4 structure potently inhibits translation initiation by acting as a steric block to 43S preinitiation complex scanning. Under hypoxic conditions, we observe a marked increase in the G4-resolving helicase DHX36 binding to the *VEGFA* 5' UTR, which leads to G4 unwinding and a concomitant surge in VEGFA protein synthesis. This mechanism constitutes a precise oxygen-sensitive molecular switch, where an RNA secondary structure acts as a cis-regulatory rheostat for protein production.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Conserved RNA G-Quadruplex in the 5' UTR of the VEGFA mRNA Functions as a Translational Repressor during Normoxia

text: Aberrant activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome is linked to numerous inflammatory diseases, and mitochondria are central hubs for its regulation. We report an unexpected role for the mitochondrial i-AAA protease YME1L in directly suppressing NLRP3 activity. Using unbiased proximity-dependent biotinylation (BioID), we found that inactive NLRP3 is recruited to the mitochondrial intermembrane space where it directly interacts with YME1L. In vitro cleavage assays and neo-N-terminal peptide mapping demonstrate that YME1L proteolytically processes full-length NLRP3 at a specific site within its NACHT domain. This cleavage event generates two fragments that are subsequently degraded, preventing NLRP3 oligomerization and inflammasome assembly. Cells lacking YME1L exhibit heightened and prolonged NLRP3 activation in response to canonical triggers. Our results identify a novel mitochondrial checkpoint for inflammation, where an inner membrane protease acts as a direct negative regulator of a key cytosolic immune sensor, preventing excessive inflammatory responses.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The Mitochondrial Inner Membrane AAA-Protease YME1L Cleaves NLRP3 to Attenuate Inflammasome Activation

text: The segregation of metabolic pathways and gene regulation into distinct cellular compartments is a fundamental principle of eukaryotic biology. Here, we show that the canonical glycolytic enzyme glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) moonlights as a nuclear histone acetyltransferase (HAT). Upon high glucose influx, a fraction of GAPDH is acetylated on lysine 117, which masks a nuclear export signal and promotes its nuclear accumulation. Within the nucleus, GAPDH utilizes its substrate-derived cofactor 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate as a donor for the non-enzymatic acetylation of histone H2B on lysine 5 (H2BK5ac). ChIP-seq analysis reveals that H2BK5ac is enriched at the promoters of glucose-responsive genes, including those involved in lipogenesis. This modification facilitates the recruitment of the transcription factor ChREBP. A non-acetylatable GAPDH mutant fails to enter the nucleus or promote H2BK5ac and target gene expression. This study uncovers a direct, unexpected link between glycolytic flux and epigenetic regulation, mediated by a metabolic enzyme acting as a transcriptional cofactor.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Metabolic Enzyme Moonlighting: Nuclear GAPDH Functions as a Transcriptional Co-activator by Acetylating Histone H2B

text: The MRE11-RAD50-NBS1 (MRN) complex is the primary sensor and processor of DNA double-strand breaks. The ATP-dependent conformational changes in RAD50 are known to regulate MRN's functions, but the allosteric mechanism linking ATP hydrolysis to MRE11's nuclease activity remains unclear. Using a combination of small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), hydrogen-deuterium exchange mass spectrometry (HDX-MS), and cryo-EM, we characterized the conformational states of the human MR complex. We show that ATP binding induces a rigid, zinc-hook-mediated dimerization of two RAD50 coiled-coil domains, forcing a concomitant conformational change in the MRE11 homodimer. This 'engaged' state repositions a key leucine residue in MRE11's nuclease domain, unlocking its catalytic site and increasing its processivity on DNA substrates by an order of magnitude. A non-hydrolyzable ATP analog traps the complex in this hyperactive state, while ATP hydrolysis disengages the RAD50 dimer, resetting MRE11 to its basal activity. This allosteric switch ensures that robust nuclease activity is spatially and temporally coupled to initial break recognition.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Allosteric Regulation of the DNA Repair Nuclease MRE11 by ATP-mediated Dimerization of its RAD50 Partner

text: We investigate the cosmological constant problem through the lens of the AdS/CFT correspondence, proposing a non-perturbative mechanism for its suppression. By treating the bulk spacetime as a dynamical entity subject to holographic renormalization group flow, we demonstrate that quantum fluctuations of conformal fields on the boundary induce a running of the bulk vacuum energy. Our model employs a functional Schrödinger formalism to derive the Wheeler-DeWitt equation for the boundary-dual field theory coupled to gravity. We show that the zero-point energy contributions, typically responsible for the large discrepancy, are absorbed into the redefinition of coupling constants in the boundary theory's effective action. The resultant emergent cosmological constant is dynamically driven towards a stable, near-zero fixed point without fine-tuning. This approach suggests that the observed small value of Λ is a consequence of the infrared properties of a strongly coupled quantum system, offering a novel resolution paradigm rooted in holographic duality.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Renormalization and the Cosmological Constant in a Non-Perturbative Framework

text: Topological phases of matter are typically associated with non-interacting or weakly correlated electronic systems. Here, we demonstrate the generation of a robust, topologically non-trivial state within a strongly correlated doped Mott insulator. Utilizing Floquet engineering, we subject a two-dimensional Hubbard model to a high-frequency, circularly polarized electromagnetic field. Through a combination of non-equilibrium dynamical mean-field theory (DMFT) and a high-frequency expansion, we derive an effective static Hamiltonian. Our results show that the periodic drive opens a gap in the electronic spectrum and induces a non-zero Chern number, characteristic of a quantum anomalous Hall phase. This dynamically-generated topological state supports chiral edge modes that are resilient to disorder and local perturbations, even in the presence of strong electronic correlations. This theoretical framework provides a pathway for realizing dissipationless transport phenomena in correlated materials, such as cuprate superconductors, by purely optical means, bridging the fields of strong correlations and topological physics.
subject: Fizik
title: Floquet-Engineered Chiral Edge States in a Doped Mott Insulator

text: We propose a novel experimental scheme for detecting axion-like particles (ALPs), a well-motivated dark matter candidate, by exploiting non-linear electrodynamic effects in vacuum. The axion's coupling to photons, typically described by the term gₐγγ E⋅B, is supplemented by higher-order terms from the Euler-Heisenberg Lagrangian in the presence of strong background fields. Our analysis shows that in a high-field (B > 10 T) environment, the effective axion-photon coupling is significantly enhanced, leading to a modified vacuum magnetic birefringence and dichroism. We calculate the expected rotation and ellipticity induced on a probe laser beam traversing a resonant microwave cavity embedded in a strong magnetic dipole field. The predicted signal scales quadratically with the background field strength, offering a substantial improvement in sensitivity over existing haloscope and light-shining-through-wall experiments. This method provides a new observational window into the 1 µeV–1 meV axion mass range, directly probing the fundamental quantum structure of the vacuum.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Axionic Dark Matter through Non-Linear Electrodynamic Couplings in Strong Magnetic Fields

text: The fluctuation-dissipation theorem (FDT) is a cornerstone of statistical mechanics, linking the linear response of a system at thermal equilibrium to its spontaneous fluctuations. However, for systems driven far from equilibrium or those exhibiting non-Markovian dynamics, this relation breaks down. We derive a generalized FDT applicable to classical Langevin systems subjected to arbitrary time-dependent driving and coupled to a thermal bath with a memory kernel. Using a path integral formalism based on the Martin-Siggia-Rose-Janssen-De Dominicis (MSRJD) action, we establish an exact relation between the integrated response function and a spatio-temporal correlation function involving the system's state variable and the fluctuating entropy production rate. This result extends the Harada-Sasa and Hatano-Sasa relations to systems with memory, providing a direct, experimentally accessible method for probing the energetics and information flow in complex non-equilibrium systems, such as active matter and biological molecular motors.
subject: Fizik
title: Generalized Fluctuation-Dissipation Relations for Driven Systems with Memory Kernels

text: Resolving the black hole information paradox requires a consistent description of the entanglement entropy of Hawking radiation. We extend the 'island' paradigm by calculating the fine-grained entropy in the background of an evaporating, charged, rotating (Kerr-Newman) black hole. Our semi-classical analysis incorporates gravitational backreaction and one-loop corrections from bulk quantum fields. We locate the quantum extremal surface (QES) and demonstrate that its area, plus the entanglement entropy of bulk fields in the entanglement wedge, adheres to a unitary Page curve. We find that both charge and angular momentum delay the Page time and suppress the growth rate of the island. Crucially, the location of the QES is sensitive to the greybody factors of the emitted radiation, explicitly connecting the spacetime geometry to the quantum information content. This work reinforces the universality of the QES prescription and provides a quantitative framework for understanding information release from realistic astrophysical black holes.
subject: Fizik
title: Quantum Extremal Surfaces and Entanglement Entropy Corrections in Evaporating Kerr-Newman Black Holes

text: Metasurfaces have enabled unprecedented control over the properties of light, yet most are static. We introduce and numerically validate a reconfigurable anisotropic metasurface capable of independent and dynamic control over the amplitude, phase, and polarization of light across the near-infrared spectrum. The design integrates a plasmonic nanoantenna array with a sub-layer of the phase-change material Ge₂Sb₂Te₅ (GST). By locally controlling the crystallization state of GST pixels via thermal or optical stimuli, we modulate the dielectric environment of each antenna, thereby altering its resonant response. Full-wave finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) simulations demonstrate that this hybrid architecture can function as a high-efficiency, multi-functional optical element, switching between a holographic projector, a focusing metalens, and a polarization-resolved beam-splitter. The sub-nanosecond switching speed of GST enables spatiotemporal wavefront shaping, paving the way for advanced applications in adaptive optics, solid-state LiDAR, and high-capacity optical communications.
subject: Fizik
title: Dynamically Tunable Anisotropic Metasurfaces for Spatiotemporal Wavefront Shaping

text: Turbulence in astrophysical plasmas, such as those in accretion disks and pulsar winds, often occurs in relativistic regimes where magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) provides a guiding framework. We present results from ultra-high-resolution direct numerical simulations of forced, compressible, relativistic MHD turbulence. Our analysis focuses on the statistical properties of the inertial range cascade. We demonstrate a clear scale-dependent anisotropy, where the energy cascade proceeds primarily perpendicular to the local mean magnetic field, consistent with the critical balance conjecture. Furthermore, we quantify the intermittency by calculating high-order structure functions of the Elsasser variables. The resulting scaling exponents deviate significantly from the predictions of both Kolmogorov's K41 and Iroshnikov-Kraichnan theories, indicating that energy dissipation is concentrated in spatially intermittent, sheet-like structures. These findings have profound implications for particle acceleration mechanisms and the interpretation of synchrotron emission from extreme astrophysical environments, highlighting the breakdown of classical turbulence phenomenology in the relativistic limit.
subject: Fizik
title: Intermittency and Anisotropy in the Inertial Range of Relativistic Magnetohydrodynamic Turbulence

text: Quantum error correction codes typically require significant resource overhead, motivating the development of hardware-efficient decoherence mitigation strategies. We propose a hybrid passive-active scheme to protect quantum information in a multi-qubit processor. The passive component involves engineering the spectral density of the electromagnetic environment to which the qubits are coupled, creating a 'protective' frequency band-gap that inhibits spontaneous emission. The active component utilizes rapid, periodic projective measurements, leveraging the quantum Zeno effect to freeze the system's evolution away from a desired subspace. Using a Lindblad master equation formalism, we model a system of coupled superconducting transmon qubits and demonstrate a two-orders-of-magnitude increase in the coherence time of a Bell state. Our results show that the engineered reservoir suppresses low-frequency noise, while the Zeno pulses effectively combat high-frequency dephasing. This synergistic approach offers a scalable pathway towards fault-tolerant quantum computation by embedding protection directly into the system's Hamiltonian and control sequence.
subject: Fizik
title: Decoherence Mitigation in Multi-Qubit Systems via Engineered Reservoir Coupling and Quantum Zeno Dynamics

text: The discovery of topological phases of matter has revolutionized condensed matter physics, with analogues being explored in photonic, mechanical, and acoustic systems. Here, we report the first experimental observation of topological Weyl points in the band structure of a three-dimensional chiral phononic crystal. The crystal, fabricated via additive manufacturing, lacks both inversion and mirror symmetries. Using Brillouin light scattering and angle-resolved ultrasonic transmission spectroscopy, we directly mapped the bulk phononic dispersion relations, identifying pairs of topologically protected linear touching points—the Weyl points. As predicted by the bulk-boundary correspondence, these Weyl points give rise to topologically protected surface acoustic waves, which we observed as frequency-isolated, one-way propagating modes on the crystal surface. This demonstration of non-reciprocal acoustic propagation in a passive, time-reversal-invariant system opens new avenues for creating acoustic diodes, isolators, and robust waveguides for applications in ultrasonic imaging and signal processing.
subject: Fizik
title: Observation of Topological Weyl Points and Non-Reciprocal Acoustic Propagation in a Chiral Phononic Crystal

text: The mechanical behavior of the cellular cytoskeleton is governed by the non-equilibrium dynamics of active filaments and motor proteins. We develop a continuum field theory for active gels that unifies hydrodynamic interactions, nematic liquid crystal elasticity, and ATP-driven stresses. The model is formulated in terms of a tensor order parameter for filament alignment and a velocity field for the cytoskeletal fluid. Renormalization group analysis of the resulting stochastic partial differential equations reveals a rich phase diagram. Depending on the activity level and filament concentration, the system exhibits transitions from an isotropic, quiescent state to a spontaneously flowing nematic phase, and further to a state of active turbulence characterized by the proliferation of topological defects. Our theoretical predictions for the velocity correlation functions and defect dynamics are in quantitative agreement with in-vitro experiments on reconstituted actin-myosin networks, providing a robust framework for understanding cellular morphogenesis, motility, and mechanosensing.
subject: Fizik
title: A Continuum Field Theory of Active Cytoskeletal Networks Exhibiting Non-Equilibrium Phase Transitions

text: We investigate the off-diagonal Ramsey numbers for loose cycles in r-uniform hypergraphs, denoted R(C_k^r, C_l^r). Previous work has focused predominantly on the symmetric case. This paper establishes a new polynomial lower bound for these numbers when r is fixed and k, l grow. Our primary method involves a novel alteration of the standard random coloring argument, incorporating a container-based approach to control the number of monochromatic subgraphs. By defining a specific potential function during a derandomization process, we demonstrate the existence of a 2-coloring of the edges of the complete r-uniform hypergraph K_n^r with no monochromatic C_k^r or C_l^r for n = Ω((kl)^(r/2)). This result significantly improves upon the trivial bounds and suggests that the asymmetric behavior of hypergraph Ramsey numbers is more pronounced than in the graph case. We further conjecture that this lower bound is tight up to a polylogarithmic factor for r=3.
subject: Matematik
title: On Asymmetric Ramsey Numbers for Loose Hypergraph Cycles

text: We determine the exact Turán number, ex_o(n, T), for any oriented tree T with k vertices that possesses a kernel, i.e., an independent set with an edge to every other vertex. This generalizes classical results on directed paths and stars. Our proof employs a refined version of Zykov symmetrization adapted for directed graphs and establishes that the unique extremal construction is a specific orientation of the complete bipartite Turán graph. Furthermore, we prove a corresponding stability theorem. We show that any T-free oriented graph with e(G) > ex_o(n, T) - εn^2 edges can be made into the extremal digraph by adding and removing O(εn) edges. The proof of the stability result leverages the digraph regularity lemma and a counting argument that bounds the number of copies of T in digraphs that are close to the extremal configuration, providing a structural characterization of near-extremal digraphs for this family of oriented trees.
subject: Matematik
title: The Turán Density of Oriented Trees and Stability Results

text: This work examines the decomposition of Foulkes modules, which arise from the plethysm of Schur functions s_μ[s_ν], into irreducible representations of the symmetric group. We introduce a new combinatorial basis for these modules indexed by multi-set tableaux and derive a combinatorial rule for the action of the generators of S_n. Our main result provides a positive, combinatorial formula for the multiplicity of the Specht module S^λ in the Foulkes module corresponding to s_(m)[s_(n)] for two-row shapes λ. This gives a new perspective on the notoriously difficult Kronecker coefficients g(λ, μ, ν), as these multiplicities are sums of such coefficients. The methodology combines techniques from the representation theory of the symmetric group, the theory of symmetric functions, and combinatorial Hopf algebras, shedding new light on the stability phenomena observed in plethystic compositions and their connection to geometric complexity theory.
subject: Matematik
title: Plethystic Decompositions of Foulkes Modules and the Kronecker Problem

text: We analyze the existence of Hamilton cycles in a random k-uniform hypergraph model where vertex codegrees are constrained. Let H(n, M; d) be a hypergraph chosen uniformly at random from all k-uniform hypergraphs on n vertices with M edges and minimum codegree δ(H) ≥ d. We establish a sharp threshold for Hamiltonicity in this model. Utilizing the second moment method combined with the absorption technique, we show that if M is slightly above a certain critical value M_0(n,k,d), the model asymptotically almost surely contains a Hamilton cycle. Our proof strategy relies on developing hypergraph container lemmas tailored to this specific probability space, allowing us to control the structure of small independent sets. This result provides a finer understanding of how local density conditions, such as minimum codegree, influence global properties like Hamiltonicity, contrasting with the purely edge-density-driven behavior in the binomial random hypergraph model H(n,p,k).
subject: Matematik
title: Sharp Thresholds for Hamiltonicity in Random Hypergraphs with Fixed Codegrees

text: We report on the computational construction and classification of a new affine plane of order 16, adding to the known list of such structures. The plane is derived from a pre-semifield of order 16 that is not isotopic to any previously known semifield. The construction process involved an exhaustive, computer-assisted search for commutative semifields satisfying specific algebraic properties over GF(2). We prove that the resulting affine plane is non-Desarguesian by demonstrating that its collineation group does not act transitively on the points of any line. Furthermore, we analyze the kernel of the associated pre-semifield and the structure of the full automorphism group of the plane, showing it to be a solvable group of order 1920. This discovery underscores the rich combinatorial landscape of finite projective and affine planes and highlights the efficacy of combining algebraic theory with sophisticated computational search algorithms for resolving long-standing existence problems in finite geometry.
subject: Matematik
title: Existence of a Non-Desarguesian Affine Plane of Order 16 via Semifield Construction

text: We investigate the enumerative properties of involutions avoiding permutation patterns of length 4. This paper provides a unified framework for several classes of such involutions by analyzing their corresponding generating functions. For the class of involutions avoiding the pattern 1342, we prove that the generating function is D-finite but not algebraic, resolving a conjecture by Bóna and Smith. The proof utilizes the kernel method on a functional equation derived from a catalytic variable decomposition of the combinatorial class. Furthermore, we perform a detailed singularity analysis on the resulting differential equation to derive a precise asymptotic formula for the number of such involutions of length n, which is of the form c * n^γ * μ^n. Our results extend the understanding of the boundary between algebraic and D-finite generating functions in the realm of pattern avoidance and demonstrate the power of analytic combinatorics in solving complex enumerative problems.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotics and D-Finiteness of Pattern-Avoiding Involutions

text: This paper establishes a crucial structural result for binary matroids, providing a splitter theorem for the class of internally 4-connected binary matroids. A matroid M is a splitter for this class if any internally 4-connected binary matroid N with an M-minor contains an element e such that either N\e or N/e is also internally 4-connected. We prove that the unique splitter for this class is the cycle matroid of the wheel graph W_4. This result is a key step towards a complete excluded-minor characterization for the class of internally 4-connected binary matroids, analogous to Tutte's Wheels-and-Whirls Theorem for 3-connected matroids. The proof is inductive and relies on a deep analysis of the connectivity properties of matroids, particularly how minors affect path-like structures within the matroid. This theorem has potential applications in advancing towards Rota's Conjecture for the binary field.
subject: Matematik
title: A Splitter Theorem for Internally 4-Connected Binary Matroids

text: We prove a quantitative version of the Polynomial Szemerédi Theorem in sparse pseudorandom sets. Let P_1(t), ..., P_k(t) be integer polynomials with zero constant term. We show that any subset A ⊂ F_p^n with positive relative density inside a δ-pseudorandom set S ⊂ F_p^n contains a non-trivial polynomial progression {x, x+P_1(y), ..., x+P_k(y)} for y ≠ 0, provided that S is sufficiently dense and pseudorandom. Our approach is based on the density increment strategy using higher-order Fourier analysis. A key innovation is the development of a Gowers uniformity norm that is relativized to the sparse pseudorandom set S, allowing the transference of arguments from the dense setting. This result significantly extends the reach of additive combinatorial theorems to sparse environments, which are prevalent in number theory and computer science, and provides a framework for tackling similar problems for other linear and non-linear configurations.
subject: Matematik
title: Polynomial Progressions in Sparse Pseudorandom Subsets of Finite Fields

text: We consider the Asymmetric Traveling Salesman Problem (ATSP) in the node-weighted setting, where the objective is to find a tour of minimum total node weight. We present a new Held-Karp style linear programming relaxation for this problem and prove an improved upper bound on its integrality gap. Our main contribution is a randomized rounding algorithm that achieves an O(log n / log log n) approximation factor, improving upon the previous best O(log n) factor. The algorithm is based on a novel hierarchical decomposition of the support graph of the fractional LP solution, combined with a randomized sampling procedure that respects the structural properties of the decomposition. The analysis leverages a refined charging scheme that carefully accounts for the cost distribution across different levels of the hierarchy.
