This result narrows the gap between the best-known algorithms and the conjectured constant-factor approximability for node-weighted ATSP and introduces techniques applicable to other network design problems.
subject: Matematik
title: Improved Integrality Gaps for Asymmetric TSP on Node-Weighted Digraphs

text: We establish new lower bounds on the chromatic number of Kneser hypergraphs K(n,k,r), which are r-uniform hypergraphs whose vertices are k-subsets of {1, ..., n} and whose edges are collections of r pairwise disjoint k-subsets. Our approach utilizes methods from topological combinatorics. We study the neighborhood complex N(G), which is the flag complex built on the graph of non-adjacent vertices. By analyzing an associated spectral sequence and leveraging discrete Morse theory, we compute a tight lower bound on the Z_p-homological connectivity of the neighborhood complex of K(n,k,r). Invoking a topological lower bound on the chromatic number, which generalizes the Lovász-Kneser theorem, our connectivity result directly implies χ(K(n,k,r)) ≥ (n - r(k-1))/r + 1. This provides a purely combinatorial proof for a known bound and a unified framework for analyzing the chromatic numbers of various Kneser-like structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Homological Connectivity of Flag Complexes and Chromatic Numbers of Kneser Hypergraphs

text: We investigate the off-diagonal Ramsey number R(K_k^t; K_l^t), denoting the minimum integer n such that any 2-coloring of the edges of the complete t-uniform hypergraph on n vertices contains either a monochromatic K_k^t or K_l^t. Utilizing a novel algebraic construction based on norm graphs over finite fields, we establish a new lower bound R(K_4^3; K_l^3) > c(l/log l)^3, improving upon previous probabilistic arguments for this specific case. For the upper bound, we refine the stepping-up lemma of Erdős and Hajnal by incorporating a dependent random choice argument, yielding R(K_k^t; K_l^t) < 2^(c(R(K_{k-1}^t; K_{l-1}^t))^{t-1}). This combined approach narrows the asymptotic gap for several fundamental hypergraph Ramsey problems and suggests that pseudorandom constructions may outperform purely probabilistic methods in specific asymmetric regimes. The methodology further provides a framework for analyzing multicolor Ramsey numbers involving non-complete hypergraphs with dense core structures.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Asymptotics of Off-Diagonal Hypergraph Ramsey Numbers

text: This paper establishes a deep connection between the representation theory of the symmetric group and the combinatorics of parking functions. We construct a new bi-graded S_n-module M_{n,k} whose dimension is the (n,k)-th super-Catalan number and whose Frobenius characteristic is conjectured to be given by a plethystic transformation of the modified Macdonald polynomial basis. Our main result proves this conjecture for k=2 by defining an explicit cellular basis for the module and analyzing the action of the Young-Jucys-Murphy elements. The proof involves a novel application of the Shuffle Theorem and provides a representation-theoretic interpretation of the compositional refinement of the (q,t)-Catalan numbers. This framework unifies several disparate results concerning diagonal harmonics, provides a combinatorial rule for certain plethystic coefficients, and opens a new avenue for exploring the structure of modules whose dimensions are given by higher-order Catalan generalizations.
subject: Matematik
title: A Plethystic Interpretation of Diagonal Harmonics and Super-Catalan Numbers

text: We determine the exact Turan number ex(n, F) for a family of graphs F, where F is a theta graph θ_{a,b,c} in which one path is replaced by a sequence of vertex-disjoint cliques. Such configurations, termed decorated theta graphs, generalize several classical extremal problems. Our approach employs the stability method, first establishing an approximate structure theorem for F-free graphs using techniques from graph regularization. We then leverage flag algebra computations to pin down the precise asymptotic density. For the exact result, a detailed analysis of the extremal configuration, which is a blow-up of a specific bipartite graph, is conducted using Zykov symmetrization and local subgraph analysis. This result resolves a conjecture by Nikiforov and provides a robust methodology for determining Turan numbers for graphs that are not edge-critical but possess a specific hierarchical structure.
subject: Matematik
title: The Turan Density of Theta Graphs with Decorated Paths

text: We extend the theory of Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials from matroids to the more general setting of q-matroids, combinatorial objects defined over finite fields. We prove that the coefficients of these polynomials form a log-concave sequence, thereby affirmatively answering a conjecture by Gedeon, Proudfoot, and Young. The proof is geometric in nature; we realize the q-matroid Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomial as the intersection cohomology Poincare polynomial of a specially constructed Schubert variety within an affine Grassmannian. By establishing that this variety is rationally smooth and its corresponding toric variety admits a convex polytope decomposition, we apply the Hodge-Riemann relations for intersection cohomology to deduce the desired log-concavity. This result provides the first geometric proof of log-concavity for any class of combinatorially defined Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials and suggests a deep connection between matroid theory and the geometry of flag varieties.
subject: Matematik
title: Log-Concavity of the Kazhdan-Lusztig Polynomials of q-Matroids

text: We analyze the enumeration of lattice paths in Z^d confined to regions whose boundaries are defined by systems of polynomial inequalities. The corresponding multivariate generating function is generally not D-finite, precluding standard analytic techniques. We develop a framework based on analytic combinatorics in several variables (ACSV) and stratified Morse theory to derive precise asymptotic formulae for the number of paths of a given length. The dominant singularity of the generating function is shown to correspond to a minimal point of the defining polynomial on the positive real torus. Our primary contribution is a rigorous method to handle singularities arising from the intersection of multiple algebraic surfaces, which yields asymptotic terms with non-rational critical exponents. This work extends the applicability of ACSV beyond the rational cone case and provides tools for analyzing a broad class of constrained combinatorial models.
subject: Matematik
title: Multivariate Asymptotics for Lattice Paths Confined to Cones with Algebraic Boundaries

text: We establish a quantitative version of Roth's theorem for finite simple groups G of Lie type with bounded rank. We prove that any subset A ⊂ G of density δ lacking non-trivial three-term arithmetic progressions x, xy, xy^2 must satisfy δ < (log log |G|)^(-c) for some absolute constant c > 0. The proof integrates techniques from additive combinatorics and representation theory. We develop a non-abelian Fourier analysis framework tailored to the specific conjugacy class structure of G, defining uniformity norms that are sensitive to arithmetic progressions. A density increment argument is then implemented, using a generalized Bogolyubov-Ruzsa lemma adapted to the approximate subgroup structure of these groups. This result provides the first polynomial-type upper bound for this problem in a non-abelian setting and makes progress towards understanding the threshold for Szemeredi-type phenomena in non-commutative environments.
subject: Matematik
title: A Quantitative Roth's Theorem in Finite Simple Groups of Lie Type

text: We investigate the threshold for the existence of a Hamiltonian cycle in a d-uniform random hypergraph G^(d)(n, p) under an additional local sparsity condition. Define H(n,p,Δ) as the random hypergraph G^(d)(n,p) conditioned on having maximum codegree at most Δ. We prove that for d ≥ 3, the property of containing a Hamiltonian cycle exhibits a sharp threshold. Specifically, we use the second moment method and a multi-round exposure technique to demonstrate that the hitting time for Hamiltonicity coincides with the hitting time for minimum vertex degree k, where k is a function of d and Δ. This resolves a question about whether local geometric constraints significantly alter the global properties of random hypergraphs. The proof pivots on a robust decomposition lemma and a novel connecting argument that works even in the sparse, locally constrained setting, extending the seminal results of Bollobas and Frieze to a new random hypergraph model.
subject: Matematik
title: Sharp Threshold for Hamiltonicity in Random Hypergraphs with Local Conditions

text: This paper establishes strong non-existence criteria for symmetric (v, k, λ)-designs admitting a regular automorphism group. Let G be a multiplicative group of prime order p acting regularly on a putative symmetric design D. Using a combination of character theory of finite fields and module theory over the group ring Z[G], we derive stringent constraints on the parameters v, k, and λ. Our main theorem asserts that if a certain cyclotomic integer, derived from the design's parameters, is not a perfect square in the p-th cyclotomic field, then no such design exists. This criterion is applied to resolve several long-standing open cases in the classification of cyclic difference sets and affine planes. The proof technique involves lifting the incidence equation to the group ring and analyzing its image under irreducible characters, linking combinatorial existence to deep results in algebraic number theory, specifically the Stickelberger relations for Gauss sums.
subject: Matematik
title: Non-existence of (v, k, λ)-Designs with Multiplicative Automorphisms of Prime Order

text: We investigate the Chvatal-Gomory closure of the fractional stable set polytope for the class of claw-free perfect graphs. While the stable set polytope of a perfect graph is integral, its description by clique inequalities can be complex. We prove that for any claw-free perfect graph, the Chvatal rank of its stable set polytope is exactly one. This means the integral hull is obtained after a single round of applying all possible Chvatal-Gomory cutting planes. The proof relies on a structural decomposition theorem for claw-free perfect graphs due to Chvatal and Sbihi, combined with a polyhedral argument showing that any non-integral vertex of the fractional polytope can be separated by a rank-1 cut derived from an odd hole or antihole in an auxiliary graph construction. This result provides a concise polyhedral characterization and implies that integer programs on this class can be solved by adding a polynomial number of cutting planes.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Chvatal Rank of the Stable Set Polytope for Claw-Free Perfect Graphs

text: We introduce a novel topological approach to the graph coloring problem by analyzing the homological properties of associated simplicial complexes. For a graph G, we study the Dowker complex D(G, k), whose simplices correspond to subsets of vertices that cannot be properly colored with k colors. We prove that the non-vanishing of the (k-2)-nd reduced homology group H̃_{k-2}(D(G, k); Z) is an obstruction to (k-1)-colorability. This generalizes Lovasz's neighborhood complex theorem. The core of our argument involves constructing a Z_k-equivariant chain map from the standard chromatic complex to the chain complex of the nerve of a specific covering of D(G, k). By applying discrete Morse theory and spectral sequence arguments, we show this homological obstruction is computationally more tractable than determining the chromatic number directly and strictly stronger than obstructions based on the box complex for certain graph families.
subject: Matematik
title: Homological Obstructions to k-Colorability of Dowker Complexes

text: We present a comprehensive theoretical analysis of decoherence mechanisms affecting non-Abelian anyons, specifically Ising anyons realized as Majorana zero modes in p-wave superconducting wires. Our investigation focuses on the environmental coupling of topological qubits, whose quantum information is encoded non-locally in the braiding statistics of these quasiparticles. By employing a spin-boson model generalized for non-local degrees of freedom and solving the corresponding Lindblad master equation, we characterize the decay of off-diagonal density matrix elements. We identify two primary decoherence channels: quasi-particle poisoning and phononic dephasing. Our results quantify the exponential suppression of local error rates with increasing inter-anyon separation, but reveal a persistent, albeit polynomially suppressed, non-local correlated error channel. These findings establish critical constraints on the physical implementation of fault-tolerant topological quantum computation architectures and inform the development of error correction codes tailored to the unique error phenomenology of anyonic systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence Dynamics in Non-Abelian Anyonic Systems for Topological Quantum Computation

text: This work explores the non-perturbative vacuum structure of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) utilizing the gauge/gravity duality, specifically the AdS/CFT correspondence. We compute the holographic entanglement entropy (HEE) for various spatial bipartitions in a 5D gravitational background engineered to model key features of QCD, including confinement and chiral symmetry breaking. The HEE, calculated via the Ryu-Takayanagi formula, serves as a proxy for quantum correlations within the boundary field theory. Our analysis reveals a distinct phase transition in the HEE, corresponding to the confinement-deconfinement transition, which manifests as a topological change in the minimal surface configuration within the bulk spacetime. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the entanglement entropy scaling behavior provides a quantitative measure of the chiral condensate, offering a novel, information-theoretic order parameter for chiral symmetry breaking. This holographic approach provides profound insights into the entanglement structure of the strongly-coupled QCD vacuum, bridging concepts from quantum information and high-energy nuclear physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Quantum Chromodynamic Vacuum Structure via Holographic Entanglement Entropy

text: We investigate the emergence of many-body localization (MBL) in a periodically driven (Floquet) quantum system, specifically a one-dimensional disordered Heisenberg spin chain subjected to a time-periodic magnetic field. Through large-scale exact diagonalization and time-evolution simulations, we demonstrate a robust violation of the Eigenstate Thermalization Hypothesis (ETH). Instead of thermalizing to an infinite-temperature state as predicted for generic non-integrable Floquet systems, the system retains local memory of its initial state indefinitely. We characterize the MBL phase by examining the level statistics of the Floquet operator's quasi-energies, the long-time behavior of local observables, and the logarithmic growth of entanglement entropy following a quantum quench. Our findings confirm the existence of a stable, non-ergodic MBL phase in a driven, interacting quantum system, extending the MBL paradigm beyond static Hamiltonians and opening new avenues for controlling quantum matter far from equilibrium.
subject: Kuantum
title: Many-Body Localization and Eigenstate Thermalization Hypothesis Violation in a Disordered Floquet System

text: We propose and numerically simulate a high-fidelity protocol for the deterministic generation of multi-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) states in a circuit quantum electrodynamics (cQED) architecture using three-level quantum systems (qutrits). Our scheme utilizes superconducting transmon circuits, where the first two excited states form the computational qutrit, coupled via a common microwave resonator. By applying a sequence of precisely timed microwave pulses that selectively drive transitions in the qutrit-resonator Jaynes-Cummings ladder, we can engineer the target entangled state with minimal population of non-computational leakage states. The protocol's robustness against decoherence and parameter fluctuations is analyzed. We further detail a full quantum state tomography procedure, adapted for the qutrit Hilbert space, to verify the state's fidelity and characterize its genuine multi-partite entanglement through the evaluation of a Svetlichny inequality. This work demonstrates the potential of higher-dimensional Hilbert spaces for enhancing quantum information processing tasks.
subject: Kuantum
title: Generation and Characterization of Multi-partite GHZ States using Superconducting Qutrit Resonators

text: We report the experimental observation and theoretical modeling of a Parity-Time (PT) symmetry breaking phase transition in a non-Hermitian photonic system. Our platform consists of two coupled whispering-gallery-mode optical microcavities, where PT-symmetry is realized by balancing optical gain in one cavity with an equivalent loss in the other. Below a critical coupling strength, the system exhibits a purely real eigenspectrum, characteristic of the PT-symmetric phase. As the inter-cavity coupling is reduced past an exceptional point, the system undergoes a spontaneous phase transition into a PT-broken phase, marked by the emergence of complex conjugate eigenfrequencies. This transition is observed through high-resolution transmission spectroscopy, which reveals both the coalescence of resonant frequencies and the bifurcation of their linewidths. Our results, which are in excellent agreement with a non-Hermitian coupled-mode theoretical framework, provide a controllable platform for exploring the rich physics of exceptional points and their potential applications in enhanced sensing and unconventional laser dynamics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Hermitian Quantum Mechanics and PT-Symmetry Breaking in Coupled Optical Microcavities

text: This study investigates the behavior of quantum entanglement as perceived by observers in relative, uniform acceleration. We analyze a maximally entangled Bell state of two scalar field modes, where one mode is observed by an inertial partner (Alice) and the other by a uniformly accelerating partner (Rob). By tracing over the field modes inaccessible to Rob behind his Rindler horizon, we compute the reduced density matrix for the bipartite state in the combined Alice-Rob frame. We employ Bogoliubov transformations to relate the Minkowski vacuum to the Rindler particle basis, revealing that Rob's accelerated trajectory causes him to perceive the Minkowski vacuum as a thermal bath—the Unruh effect. Our calculations explicitly show that the entanglement, as quantified by concurrence, is degraded as a function of Rob's acceleration. For infinite acceleration, the entanglement vanishes completely. This research highlights the frame-dependent nature of entanglement and underscores the profound connection between quantum information theory, quantum field theory in curved spacetime, and thermodynamics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Relativistic Quantum Information: Entanglement Degradation in Non-Inertial Frames and the Unruh Effect

text: We theoretically propose and analyze a novel method for protecting quantum information encoded in arrays of neutral Rydberg atoms from decoherence due to spontaneous emission. Our approach leverages the Quantum Zeno Effect (QZE), wherein frequent projective measurements onto a desired subspace can inhibit the system's natural Hamiltonian evolution. In our scheme, a global microwave field continuously attempts to drive a transition out of the Rydberg manifold, while a strong, resonant laser beam, coupled to a short-lived auxiliary state, effectively performs a continuous measurement to project the atom back into the manifold. We derive an effective master equation for this driven-dissipative system, demonstrating that the effective spontaneous emission rate is quadratically suppressed by the measurement strength. This Zeno-based protection scheme offers a passive, in-situ method to extend the coherence times of Rydberg-based quantum simulators and gate-based quantum computers, overcoming a primary obstacle for scaling these promising platforms.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Zeno Effect as a Control Paradigm for Suppressing Spontaneous Emission in Rydberg Atom Arrays

text: We formulate a novel model of intrinsic decoherence induced by the fundamentally discrete nature of spacetime, as posited by Causal Set Theory. In this framework, the unitary evolution prescribed by standard quantum mechanics is modified by a stochastic process arising from the microscopic causal structure. We derive a master equation describing the evolution of a quantum system's density matrix, where the non-unitary Lindblad operators are uniquely determined by the fundamental parameters of the causal set: the discreteness scale and the rate of spacetime 'births'. Our model predicts a universal, energy-dependent decoherence rate that does not require coupling to an external thermal environment. We apply this formalism to a macroscopic quantum superposition of a center-of-mass position, showing that the decoherence time scale is consistent with observational bounds and provides a potential explanation for the quantum-to-classical transition. This work presents a concrete, falsifiable model connecting quantum gravity phenomenology with foundational questions in quantum mechanics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Gravitational Decoherence and the Quantum-to-Classical Transition: A Causal Set Theoretic Approach

text: We introduce a hybrid quantum-classical algorithm for the simulation of systems with strong electron-phonon coupling, a notoriously challenging problem in condensed matter physics. Our approach extends the Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) framework to handle the combined electronic and phononic degrees of freedom described by the Holstein model. We design a chemically-inspired, hardware-efficient ansatz for the quantum circuit that effectively captures the intricate correlations in the polaron-dressed electronic ground state. The bosonic phonon modes are encoded using a compact mapping onto the qubit Hilbert space. We perform numerical simulations of the VQE algorithm for a small system, demonstrating its ability to accurately compute the ground state energy and key observables, such as the phonon number and electron spectral function, across weak and strong coupling regimes. This work establishes a viable pathway for near-term quantum devices to tackle complex, multi-component problems in materials science, potentially elucidating phenomena like charge-density waves and high-temperature superconductivity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Variational Quantum Eigensolver for Simulating Electron-Phonon Coupling in Strongly Correlated Materials

text: We theoretically propose a new class of three-dimensional higher-order topological insulators (HOTIs) exhibiting quantized hinge states without the need for an external magnetic field. Our model breaks time-reversal symmetry intrinsically, leading to a quantum anomalous Hall effect on surfaces that are gapped by magnetization. The crucial finding is that the sign of this surface anomalous Hall conductivity is determined by the surface orientation, leading to a configuration where chiral, one-dimensional modes necessarily emerge along the hinges where these gapped surfaces meet. We characterize this phenomenon through a bulk topological invariant, the axion polarizability vector, and explicitly calculate the hinge-state spectrum using a low-energy effective theory and tight-binding lattice models. We further predict that in a cubic geometry, these hinge states give rise to a quantized, two-terminal hinge conductance of e²/h. This work provides a concrete theoretical framework and a clear experimental signature for detecting these exotic higher-order topological phases of matter.
subject: Kuantum
title: Higher-Order Topological Insulators: Probing Hinge States and Corner Modes with Quantum Anomalous Hall Effect

text: We introduce Stochastic Manifold Diffusion Models (SMDMs), a novel class of generative models designed for high-dimensional data constrained to non-Euclidean manifolds, such as protein structures or molecular conformations. Conventional diffusion models operating in Euclidean space fail to respect the intrinsic geometric priors of such data, leading to invalid or low-quality generations. Our framework redefines the forward diffusion process as a stochastic differential equation on a Riemannian manifold, and the reverse-time denoising process is learned as a neural network that predicts a score function in the tangent space at each point. This ensures that the entire generative trajectory remains on the manifold. We employ a novel self-conditioning mechanism based on the Riemannian metric tensor to improve sampling efficiency. Empirical results on benchmark datasets for 3D protein backbone generation and shape synthesis demonstrate that SMDMs significantly outperform state-of-the-art generative models in structural validity and distributional fidelity, establishing a new paradigm for geometry-aware deep generative modeling.
subject: AI
title: Stochastic Manifold Diffusion Models for Geometric Structure Generation

text: This paper investigates emergent communication protocols in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) through the lens of causal inference and information theory. We propose Causal Entropic Policy Gradients (CEPG), a novel MARL algorithm that explicitly optimizes for communication efficiency and causal influence. CEPG models inter-agent communication as a structured causal model and maximizes a policy objective regularized by the causal effect of an agent's message on the recipient's actions, rather than mere correlation. Furthermore, we incorporate an information-theoretic bottleneck, minimizing the mutual information between messages and agent states while preserving task performance, thereby encouraging the emergence of minimal, sufficient communication protocols. We demonstrate in a series of cooperative and competitive tasks that CEPG agents develop more robust, generalizable, and interpretable communication strategies compared to agents trained with standard policy gradient methods. Ablation studies confirm that both the causal regularization and the entropic bottleneck are critical for achieving this advanced communicative competence.
subject: AI
title: Causal Entropic Policy Gradients for Multi-Agent Emergent Communication

text: Modeling dynamic heterogeneous graphs is a critical challenge, as existing temporal graph neural networks (GNNs) often struggle with evolving relational semantics and multi-type node interactions. We propose Hyper-Relational Temporal Graph Convolutions (HR-TGC), a novel architecture that captures the complex, time-varying interplay between entities. HR-TGC operates on a hypergraph representation where edges (hyper-relations) are themselves dynamic entities with learnable temporal embeddings. The core of our model is a dual-stream attention mechanism: one stream computes temporal attention over the evolution of a specific hyper-relation, while the other computes cross-relational attention at each timestamp. This allows the model to learn not only how relations evolve but also how they influence each other over time. Extensive experiments on large-scale benchmarks for financial transaction networks and academic collaboration graphs show that HR-TGC significantly surpasses state-of-the-art baselines in dynamic link prediction and node classification tasks, especially in non-stationary environments.
subject: AI
title: Hyper-Relational Temporal Graph Convolutions for Dynamic Heterogeneous Networks

text: We introduce Latent-Space Perturbative Counterfactuals (LSPC), a model-agnostic method for generating high-fidelity, human-interpretable explanations for Transformer-based models. Existing methods often generate counterfactuals by perturbing discrete input tokens, which can result in out-of-distribution artifacts and semantically incoherent explanations. LSPC operates by identifying minimal, cohesive perturbations within the model's contextualized latent embedding space (e.g., the output of a specific attention layer) that are sufficient to alter the model's prediction. These latent perturbations are then projected back to the input space via a learned inversion mapping, ensuring semantic plausibility. We formalize this as a constrained optimization problem solved with a projected gradient descent algorithm. Our empirical evaluation on natural language inference and sentiment analysis tasks demonstrates that LSPC generates more plausible and compact counterfactuals than existing token-based methods, providing deeper insights into the nuanced reasoning mechanisms of large language models.
subject: AI
title: Latent-Space Perturbative Counterfactuals for Transformer Explainability

text: Meta-learning algorithms traditionally assume a stationary task distribution, a limitation that hampers their applicability in real-world scenarios characterized by continual, non-stationary shifts. We propose a novel framework, Bayesian Hypernetwork Meta-Learning for Non-Stationary Tasks (B-HENT), which explicitly models and adapts to temporal drifts in the task manifold. B-HENT employs a recurrent neural network to process a sequence of task-specific loss gradients and update a latent representation of the current task distribution. This latent representation conditions a Bayesian hypernetwork, which in turn generates posterior distributions over the parameters of a target few-shot learner. This hierarchical Bayesian approach allows the model to capture uncertainty about the task distribution itself, enabling rapid adaptation and preventing catastrophic forgetting when the distribution shifts. We demonstrate through extensive experiments on evolving-character-set classification and time-varying regression problems that B-HENT significantly outperforms state-of-the-art meta-learning algorithms in non-stationary environments.
subject: AI
title: Non-Stationary Task Adaptation via Bayesian Hypernetwork Meta-Learning

text: Standard federated learning (FL) is vulnerable to Byzantine attacks and fails to provide rigorous privacy guarantees for data with inherent spatiotemporal correlations. We introduce Fed-STDP, a novel FL framework that ensures Byzantine robustness and provides formal differential privacy (DP) for correlated data. Our approach employs a robust aggregation rule based on the geometric median in a high-dimensional feature space, effectively filtering malicious model updates. For privacy, we propose a correlated noise-addition mechanism where the DP noise scale is dynamically calibrated based on a learned model of spatiotemporal data dependencies, providing a tighter utility-privacy trade-off than conventional client-level DP. Theoretical analysis proves the convergence of Fed-STDP under an ε-fraction of Byzantine clients. Empirical validation on real-world mobility and sensor network datasets demonstrates superior model accuracy and resilience compared to state-of-the-art robust FL methods, while satisfying stringent (ε, δ)-DP constraints for structured data.
subject: AI
title: Byzantine-Robust Federated Learning with Spatiotemporal Differential Privacy

text: Second-order optimization methods offer superior convergence properties but are often computationally prohibitive for large-scale deep learning due to the cost of computing and inverting the Hessian matrix. This paper introduces Adaptive Low-Rank Hessian Approximation (ALRHA), a memory-efficient, second-order-like optimization algorithm. ALRHA maintains a running low-rank decomposition of the Hessian, updated at each step using a randomized block-coordinate singular value decomposition. Crucially, the rank of the approximation is not fixed but is dynamically adapted based on a measure of local curvature and the optimizer's progress, allocating more resources to regions of high non-convexity. This dynamic rank allocation allows ALRHA to flexibly interpolate between first-order and quasi-Newton methods. We provide theoretical convergence guarantees in the stochastic non-convex setting and demonstrate empirically on large-scale vision and language tasks that ALRHA achieves faster convergence and finds superior local minima compared to Adam and other adaptive first-order methods.
subject: AI
title: Adaptive Low-Rank Hessian Approximation for Non-Convex Stochastic Optimization

text: Machine learning models trained on observational data are susceptible to learning spurious correlations induced by unobserved confounders, limiting their causal generalizability. We present Variational Instrumental Variable Learning (VIVL), a deep generative framework for performing instrumental variable (IV) regression in high-dimensional, non-linear settings where valid instruments are not explicitly known. VIVL posits a latent variable model where a subset of the latent space acts as a valid instrument, i.e., it is correlated with the treatment but independent of the confounders. We formulate a variational lower bound on the data log-likelihood that includes a penalization term, derived from kernel-based independence tests, to enforce the IV conditions in the latent space. This allows for end-to-end learning of both the instrument and the causal relationship. We show that VIVL successfully recovers causal parameters in synthetic benchmarks and significantly improves out-of-distribution generalization in real-world healthcare and economic datasets.
subject: AI
title: Variational Instrumental Variable Learning for Causal Debiasing in High-Dimensional Regressions

text: We propose a self-supervised learning paradigm, Cross-Modal Invariant Representation Learning (CMIRL), for learning unified representations from multimodal data, such as paired video and audio. Unlike existing contrastive methods that rely on instance discrimination within a single modality, CMIRL directly maximizes the mutual information between the latent representations of different modalities corresponding to the same semantic event. The core innovation is a novel information-theoretic objective, based on the Jensen-Shannon divergence, which is robust to noise and modality-specific nuisance variables. Furthermore, we introduce a technique of non-isomorphic data augmentations—applying semantically distinct augmentations to each modality (e.g., time-stretching audio and color-jittering video)—to force the model to learn higher-level, abstract concepts rather than low-level statistical correlations. On downstream tasks such as action recognition and sound source localization, representations learned by CMIRL achieve new state-of-the-art performance, demonstrating superior robustness and transferability compared to both supervised and other self-supervised pre-training strategies.
subject: AI
title: Cross-Modal Invariant Representation Learning via Information Maximization

text: Training Quantum Boltzmann Machines (QBMs) on noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices is hampered by the prohibitive cost of sampling from the Gibbs state. We introduce a hybrid quantum-classical algorithm, Variational Quantum Thermalization (VQT), that circumvents this challenge. VQT frames the problem of preparing the thermal Gibbs state as a variational optimization problem. A parameterized quantum circuit is trained to minimize the free energy of the target Hamiltonian, a cost function efficiently estimated on a quantum computer. The gradients for the variational parameters are computed classically, allowing for robust optimization. This approach avoids the long coherence times required for natural thermalization or quantum phase estimation. We demonstrate the efficacy of VQT by training small-scale QBMs on a superconducting quantum processor to learn probability distributions from classical data. The results show that VQT can successfully train generative models on current NISQ hardware, outperforming classical simulation and other hybrid approaches in sample fidelity.
subject: AI
title: Variational Thermalization for Hybrid Quantum Boltzmann Machine Training

text: This paper introduces a novel deep learning framework for the automated analysis of harmonic progressions in tonal music, grounded in neo-Riemannian theory. We employ a convolutional autoencoder (CAE) trained on a large corpus of chromagrams derived from symbolic and audio data. The CAE learns a compressed, continuous latent space where proximity corresponds to parsimonious voice-leading transformations (P, L, R). We demonstrate that paths within this latent space approximate canonical neo-Riemannian operations and can be used to classify complex harmonic shifts beyond simple triadic relationships. By projecting the learned embeddings onto a 2D toroidal manifold, we generate a 'Latent Tonnetz' that visually represents harmonic structure. Our model significantly outperforms traditional template-matching and HMM-based approaches in identifying non-diatonic progressions in works by Wagner, Liszt, and Scriabin. This methodology provides a powerful bridge between data-driven audio analysis and abstract algebraic music theory, enabling scalable, nuanced harmonic investigation.
subject: Müzik
title: Latent Tonnetz Representations: A Convolutional Autoencoder for Neo-Riemannian Harmonic Analysis

text: Algorithmic composition, particularly the generation of rule-compliant counterpoint, presents a combinatorial optimization problem of immense complexity. This research explores the application of quantum annealing to solve problems in species counterpoint. We formulate the Fuxian rules of first and second species counterpoint as a Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) problem. Melodic contours and intervallic constraints are encoded into the Hamiltonian of a quantum annealing system, where the ground state solution corresponds to a stylistically valid contrapuntal line against a given cantus firmus. We benchmark the performance of a D-Wave quantum annealer against classical algorithms like simulated annealing and integer linear programming. Results demonstrate that the quantum approach can explore a larger solution space more efficiently, yielding a diverse set of musically plausible solutions that adhere to stringent harmonic and melodic constraints. This work represents a pioneering step in leveraging quantum computation for complex, rule-based creative tasks.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantum Annealing for Constrained Counterpoint Generation

text: The analysis of microtonal music from audio signals poses significant challenges for conventional fundamental frequency (f0) estimation algorithms, which presuppose integer-multiple harmonic relationships. This paper presents a novel methodology for identifying underlying tuning systems directly from audio recordings. Our approach, termed Sub-harmonic Cepstral Analysis (SCA), modifies the standard cepstrum by searching for periodicities corresponding to a hypothetical generator interval, rather than an f0. By analyzing the rahmonic series derived from prominent spectral peaks, the algorithm computes a lattice of potential tuning system generators and evaluates their fit against the observed partials. This method successfully identifies and differentiates between various just intonation, meantone, and well-tempered systems with high accuracy, even in polyphonic contexts with moderate inharmonicity. The proposed technique provides a robust tool for ethnomusicological analysis and the study of historical temperaments, enabling empirical validation of theoretical tuning models from extant recordings.
subject: Müzik
title: Sub-harmonic Cepstral Analysis for High-Resolution Microtonal System Identification

text: This study proposes a geometric framework for modeling the perceptual similarity and blending of musical instrument timbres. We utilize manifold learning techniques, specifically Isomap, to embed a high-dimensional feature space—comprising MFCCs, spectral centroids, and attack/decay descriptors—into a low-dimensional Riemannian manifold. Each instrument from a large orchestral sample library is represented as a point on this manifold. We hypothesize that the perceptual quality of an orchestral blend corresponds to the geodesic distance between its constituent timbres on the learned manifold. We validate this model through MUSHRA-style listening tests where subjects rate the 'blend quality' of various instrumental pairs and triads. The results show a strong negative correlation (r < -0.85) between perceived blend quality and geodesic distance. This geometric approach provides a more intuitive and perceptually relevant model of timbral interaction than traditional acoustic descriptor-based methods, offering predictive power for orchestration and automated timbral analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Geodesic Trajectories on Timbral Manifolds: A Geometric Model for Orchestral Blending

text: Traditional automatic music transcription systems often treat pitch detection and voice-leading analysis as sequential, independent tasks, leading to musically incoherent outputs. We propose an integrated framework that models a polyphonic piece as a multi-layer temporal network. Pitches, represented as nodes in a time-frequency grid, are linked through intra-layer edges representing harmonic simultaneity and inter-layer edges representing melodic continuity. The problem is then framed as finding a set of K disjoint paths (where K is the number of voices) that maximizes a global objective function incorporating acoustic evidence from a probabilistic pitch detector and music-theoretic constraints on voice-leading parsimony. We employ a message-passing algorithm on the graph to efficiently approximate the optimal voice assignment. Evaluated on the Bach10 dataset, our model demonstrates a significant reduction in voice-leading errors compared to state-of-the-art transcription systems, producing musically coherent polyphonic scores directly from audio.
subject: Müzik
title: A Multi-Layer Network Approach for Integrated Polyphonic Transcription and Voice-Leading Analysis

text: Research on expressive music performance has largely relied on correlational models, failing to distinguish causation from spurious association. This paper introduces a structural causal model (SCM) to investigate the causal pathways influencing micro-timing and dynamics. We formulate a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) where variables such as harmonic tension (derived from Tonal Pitch Space theory), metrical strength, and melodic contour act as causal antecedents to performer actions. Using the do-calculus and instrumental variable analysis on a dataset of piano performances, we estimate the causal effects of these structural parameters, controlling for confounding factors like performer-specific tendencies. Our findings reveal that harmonic tension has a direct causal effect on dynamic intensity, independent of its correlation with metrical position. This causal approach provides a more robust framework for understanding performance practice and building more musically intelligent generative models of expression.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangling Expressivity: A Structural Causal Model for Musical Performance

text: The completion of fragmented musical scores is a critical task in historical musicology, often relying on subjective expert intuition. We present a deep learning system for stylistic inpainting of polyphonic music using a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) architecture with a Transformer-based generator. The model is trained on a large corpus of J.S. Bach's chorales, learning the deep statistical regularities of Baroque counterpoint. To ensure historical plausibility, the discriminator is conditioned not only on the raw symbolic data but also on a set of music-theoretic features, including voice-leading smoothness and interval class distributions. We further introduce a spectral-plausibility loss function for tasks involving audio inpainting. In a double-blind evaluation, musicology experts rated the model's completions as stylistically indistinguishable from human expert completions in over 60% of cases. This work demonstrates the potential of conditional deep generative models as a powerful assistive tool for musicological reconstruction.
subject: Müzik
title: Historically-Informed Stylistic Completion of Musical Fragments using Adversarial Transformers

text: This paper posits that the perceptual complexity of a melody is quantifiable through its algorithmic information content, or Kolmogorov complexity. As this measure is uncomputable, we approximate it using Lempel-Ziv compression algorithms and predictive information rate from statistical n-gram models. We analyze a diverse corpus of melodies, from Western folk tunes to serialist compositions, and compute their information content profiles. These quantitative metrics are then correlated with perceptual complexity ratings obtained from human listeners. Our results show a strong positive correlation between algorithmic complexity and perceived complexity, outperforming traditional metrics based on interval size or contour entropy. Furthermore, we demonstrate that local minima in the predictive information rate align with points of high musical tension and surprise, as identified by listeners. This information-theoretic framework provides a robust, psychologically grounded method for analyzing melodic structure and the cognitive processing of musical expectation.
subject: Müzik
title: Algorithmic Information Content as a Metric for Melodic Complexity and Expectation

text: The independent manipulation of pitch and timbre in polyphonic audio remains a formidable challenge in signal processing. This research introduces a novel unsupervised learning model based on a beta-variational autoencoder (β-VAE) to learn disentangled latent representations of these core musical attributes. The model's encoder, a deep convolutional network, processes complex spectrograms and maps them to a structured latent space, where specific dimensions are encouraged, via a modified objective function, to exclusively encode variations in pitch (f0) while others encode timbral characteristics. The decoder can then reconstruct the audio from manipulated latent vectors. We demonstrate the model's efficacy on the URMP dataset, showing state-of-the-art performance in tasks such as instrument timbre transfer across different melodies and pitch-shifting without significant timbral artifacts. This approach enables intuitive, high-fidelity sound manipulation and provides a powerful new tool for computational musicology and audio production.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangled Timbre and Pitch Representations in Polyphonic Audio via a Beta-Variational Autoencoder

text: Conventional methods for analyzing musical form often rely on heuristic-based segmentation or pre-defined templates, limiting their applicability to non-standard structures. This paper introduces a novel, parameter-free approach using topological data analysis (TDA). We transform a musical piece into a point cloud by constructing a self-dissimilarity matrix from time-lagged chroma features. We then apply persistent homology to this point cloud to study its topological features (connected components, loops) across different scales. The resulting persistence diagram serves as a unique 'topological signature' of the piece. We demonstrate that the lifespans of 0-dimensional homology classes (connected components) correspond directly to the salience and duration of recurring thematic sections, while 1-dimensional classes (loops) capture large-scale cyclic structures like ABA forms. This TDA-based method provides a mathematically rigorous and robust framework for discovering hierarchical structure and formal archetypes across a wide range of musical styles.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Signatures of Musical Form: A Persistent Homology Approach to Structural Analysis

text: We investigate the holographic principle in a de Sitter (dS) spacetime background, proposing a novel correspondence between a central Euclidean conformal field theory (CFT) and the static patch of dS space. Central to our formalism is the role of entanglement entropy as a thermodynamic entropy, linking the Gibbons-Hawking entropy to the entanglement of degrees of freedom across the cosmological horizon. By employing tensor network techniques, specifically the Multiscale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (MERA), we construct a holographic geometry that qualitatively reproduces the hyperbolic foliation of the dS static patch. Our analysis reveals that the quantum-corrected Ryu-Takayanagi formula, when applied to specific bipartite entanglements in the boundary CFT, correctly computes the horizon area. This work extends the AdS/CFT dictionary to cosmological settings, suggesting that spacetime geometry is an emergent property derived from the quantum entanglement structure of a non-gravitational boundary theory, and provides a potential framework for addressing the information paradox in an expanding universe.
subject: Fizik
title: Entanglement Thermodynamics and Spacetime Emergence in de Sitter Holography

text: This paper theoretically proposes and numerically verifies a mechanism for generating higher-order topological insulators (HOTIs) in non-Hermitian photonic systems via periodic driving. We analyze a two-dimensional coupled resonator lattice subjected to spatially modulated, time-periodic gain and loss, described by a Floquet Hamiltonian. The interplay between the synthetic gauge fields induced by the driving protocol and the non-Hermitian terms leads to the emergence of exceptional points and a complex band structure with a gapped bulk spectrum. We demonstrate the existence of robust, zero-dimensional corner states with complex eigenfrequencies, a hallmark of non-Hermitian HOTIs. These states are topologically protected by a quantized bulk polarization and are resilient to local, symmetry-preserving perturbations. Our findings establish Floquet engineering as a versatile tool for controlling topological phases in open quantum systems, paving the way for novel applications in robust, non-local energy transport and advanced laser array design.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Hermitian Floquet Engineering of Higher-Order Topological Phases in Photonic Lattices

text: We propose a novel inflationary paradigm wherein the inflaton field is kinetically coupled to an ultralight axion, leading to a modified cosmic expansion history that can alleviate the persistent Hubble tension. During inflation, quantum fluctuations of the axion field induce a time-varying effective Planck mass, which subtly alters the primordial power spectrum of scalar perturbations. This modification introduces a scale-dependent feature that is degenerate with changes in the effective number of relativistic species (N_eff) at the time of recombination. Our numerical analysis, utilizing a modified Boltzmann code and confronting the model with Planck CMB, BAO, and SH0ES data, demonstrates that this mechanism can yield a higher H0 value without compromising the excellent fit to CMB anisotropies. The model predicts a specific, non-Gaussian signature in the bispectrum and a distinct spectrum for primordial gravitational waves, offering testable predictions for future cosmological surveys.
subject: Fizik
title: Resolving the Hubble Tension with a Kinetically-Coupled Axion-Inflaton Model

text: We formulate a generalized framework for stochastic thermodynamics in systems of active Brownian particles (ABPs) characterized by non-Boltzmann stationary state distributions. By decomposing the entropy production rate into adiabatic and non-adiabatic contributions, we derive an integral fluctuation theorem that remains valid far from thermal equilibrium. This formalism is applied to an information ratchet model, where a Maxwell's demon rectifies the fluctuations of an ABP by performing feedback control based on noisy measurements. We demonstrate that the generalized second law of thermodynamics holds, provided the informational entropy associated with the measurement and feedback loop is properly accounted for. Our results connect microscopic dissipation, information acquisition, and macroscopic work extraction in autonomous, self-propelled systems, providing fundamental thermodynamic bounds for the efficiency of synthetic micro-machines operating in complex, non-equilibrium environments.
subject: Fizik
title: Fluctuation Theorems and Information Ratchets in Active Matter Systems

text: We explore the phenomenological implications of a Minimal Composite Higgs Model based on the SO(5)/SO(4) symmetry breaking pattern, which predicts the existence of a light CP-odd pseudoscalar singlet (η) in addition to the Standard Model-like Higgs boson. This new particle arises as a pseudo-Nambu-Goldstone boson and naturally acquires a mass below the electroweak scale through explicit symmetry breaking terms. We analyze its production cross-sections and decay channels at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), focusing on gluon-gluon fusion production and subsequent decays into diphoton or tau-lepton pairs. By performing a detailed analysis of current experimental constraints from Run 2 data, we delineate the allowed parameter space in the m_η vs. coupling strength plane. We find that a significant portion of the parameter space remains unprobed, presenting a compelling search target for the high-luminosity LHC phase.
subject: Fizik
title: Phenomenology of a Composite Higgs Model with a Light Pseudoscalar at the LHC

text: We report the experimental generation and characterization of hyperentangled photon pairs, simultaneously entangled in polarization, orbital angular momentum (OAM), and energy-time degrees of freedom. The source, based on spontaneous parametric down-conversion in a periodically poled KTP crystal, is engineered to produce a high-purity, multi-modal quantum state. By employing mode-selective holograms and fast single-photon detectors, we project the high-dimensional state onto various measurement bases. We demonstrate a strong violation of a CGLMP-type Bell inequality for a d=4 Hilbert space constructed from the OAM modes, achieving a violation parameter of S_4 = 2.91 ± 0.04, well above the classical limit of 2. This robust demonstration of high-dimensional non-locality not only reinforces the foundational principles of quantum mechanics against local-realist theories but also provides a critical resource for advanced quantum communication protocols, enabling higher information capacity and enhanced security.
subject: Fizik
title: Violation of High-Dimensional Bell Inequalities using Spatiotemporal Entangled Photon Pairs

text: This study investigates the nonlinear gravitational wave memory effect within the framework of Jordan-Brans-Dicke (JBD) scalar-tensor theories of gravity. We calculate the permanent displacement of test masses in a laser interferometer detector arising from a burst of gravitational radiation, accounting for contributions from both the tensorial (spin-2) and scalar (spin-0) degrees of freedom. Our analysis shows that the scalar field, sourced by the trace of the stress-energy tensor, generates a distinct memory component with a different polarization signature compared to the standard memory effect in General Relativity. For astrophysical sources like asymmetric core-collapse supernovae, the anisotropic emission of neutrinos provides a significant source for this scalar radiation. We predict observational signatures for current and future gravitational wave observatories, such as LIGO and the Einstein Telescope, demonstrating how memory detection could place stringent constraints on the Brans-Dicke parameter ω_BD.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Wave Memory from Anisotropic Stresses in Scalar-Tensor Theories

text: We present first-principles particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations of magnetic reconnection in a collisionless, relativistically hot electron-positron (pair) plasma with a guide field, parameters relevant to pulsar wind nebulae and active galactic nuclei jets. Our simulations span an unprecedentedly large domain, resolving both the electron inertial length and the macroscopic system size, allowing the plasmoid instability to fully develop. We find that the reconnection layer fragments into a chain of magnetic islands, whose subsequent mergers and contractions are primary sites of particle acceleration. The resulting particle energy spectrum develops a distinct non-thermal power-law tail, f(E) ∝ E^(-α), with an index α that depends sensitively on the magnetization parameter σ and the guide field strength. This kinetic-scale energization process, dominated by Fermi-type acceleration within contracting plasmoids, provides a self-consistent physical mechanism for the production of high-energy synchrotron and inverse-Compton radiation observed in astrophysical sources.
subject: Fizik
title: Relativistic Kinetic Simulations of Electron-Positron Plasma Reconnection and Non-Thermal Particle Acceleration

text: We theoretically investigate the creation of a two-dimensional quantum Hall system using an ultracold atomic gas in a one-dimensional optical lattice. The second dimension is synthetically generated by coupling multiple internal atomic spin states via a Raman-assisted hopping scheme, which simultaneously imprints a uniform magnetic flux. By solving the many-body Hamiltonian for a bosonic Mott insulator in the presence of this synthetic magnetic field, we demonstrate the emergence of a fractional quantum Hall-like ground state, characterized by a gapped excitation spectrum and a fractionally quantized Hall conductance. We analyze the system's topological properties through its Chern number and the entanglement spectrum, identifying robust edge modes localized at the boundaries of the synthetic dimension. This work provides a concrete blueprint for realizing and probing strongly correlated topological phases of matter, such as Laughlin states, with the high degree of control afforded by atomic systems.
subject: Fizik
title: Quantum Hall Physics with Synthetic Dimensions in a Spinor Bose-Einstein Condensate

text: We propose a novel experimental protocol to test the validity of quantum mechanics for macroscopic objects by generating and verifying a spatial superposition state of a mesoscopic mechanical resonator. The scheme utilizes a pulsed optomechanical interaction in a high-finesse cavity to entangle the position of a gram-scale mirror with a single photon. A subsequent measurement on the photon in a specific basis projects the mirror into a superposition of two distinct spatial locations, separated by a distance exceeding its zero-point motion. We detail a verification procedure involving a second interaction pulse that reverses the entanglement, mapping the mirror's coherence onto the photonic state for readout. Our analysis includes a rigorous treatment of dominant decoherence channels, such as thermal noise, air molecule collisions, and photon scattering, demonstrating that the superposition is maintainable within current experimental capabilities in cryogenic, ultra-high vacuum environments, thereby pushing the quantum-classical boundary into a new mass regime.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Quantum Superposition at Macroscopic Scales via Pulsed Optomechanics

text: The neo-Darwinian synthesis posits genetic mutation as the primary substrate for natural selection. However, this paradigm struggles to explain instances of rapid adaptation. We investigated the role of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance (TEI) in driving phenotypic diversification in the cyclical parthenogen *Daphnia magna*. Utilizing whole-genome bisulfite sequencing and chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq), we tracked DNA methylation and histone H3K27ac modification patterns across three generations exposed to simulated predation cues. Our findings reveal heritable epigenetic marks, termed 'epialleles,' that are stochastically induced by environmental stress and correlate strongly with adaptive morphological traits, such as defensive crest height. These epialleles exhibit Mendelian-like segregation patterns in subsequent asexual generations but are partially reset during sexual reproduction. We propose a model where TEI provides a transient reservoir of non-genetic variation, facilitating rapid adaptation to fluctuating environments and acting as a potentiating mechanism for subsequent genetic assimilation, thereby bridging Lamarckian and Darwinian evolutionary frameworks.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance as a Mechanism for Rapid Phenotypic Diversification Under Environmental Stress

text: Cryptic species complexes, characterized by morphological stasis despite significant genetic divergence, challenge traditional taxonomic frameworks and conservation efforts. We employed an integrative taxonomic approach, combining high-throughput sequence data from ultraconserved elements (UCEs) with morphometric and bioacoustic analyses, to dissect a purported panmictic population of the neotropical treefrog *Hypsiboas minutus*. Our coalescent-based species delimitation analyses robustly identified three deeply divergent, sympatric lineages, whose divergence times are estimated to the late Pliocene. Despite lacking overt morphological differentiation, these lineages exhibit significant differences in advertisement call frequency and subtle, yet statistically significant, variations in cranial morphometrics. Playback experiments indicate strong pre-zygotic reproductive isolation via female acoustic preference. This study highlights the inadequacy of morphology-centric alpha taxonomy and demonstrates how phylogenomics can uncover hidden biodiversity, revealing ancient evolutionary histories and incipient speciation processes that have profound implications for biogeography and conservation.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Resolution of a Cryptic Species Complex Reveals Pre-Pleistocene Divergence and Incipient Reproductive Isolation

text: The introgression of archaic hominin DNA into the modern human gene pool is a recognized evolutionary force, yet the functional significance of many introgressed haplotypes remains elusive. We analyzed high-coverage whole-genome sequences from geographically diverse Eurasian populations, identifying a large, deeply divergent haplotype on chromosome 1 encompassing the Endothelial PAS domain-containing protein 1 (*EPAS1*) gene. This haplotype shows extreme frequency elevation in Tibetan populations and is phylogenetically sister to the Denisovan genome, indicating an archaic origin. Using luciferase reporter assays and CRISPR-Cas9-mediated genome editing in human endothelial cell lines, we demonstrate that specific non-coding variants within this haplotype act as potent enhancers, augmenting *EPAS1* expression under hypoxic conditions. Our results provide a mechanistic link between archaic admixture and a key high-altitude adaptation, illustrating how introgression can be a critical source of pre-adapted allelic variants that facilitate rapid colonization of novel, extreme environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Adaptive Introgression of an Archaic Denisovan Haplotype Modulates Hypoxic Response in Tibetan Populations

text: Eusociality, a major evolutionary transition, has evolved independently multiple times, most notably in haplodiploid Hymenoptera and diploid termites. To disentangle the roles of phylogeny and convergent selection, we performed a comparative transcriptomic and epigenomic analysis of caste differentiation across ten species of ants, bees, and termites. Despite vast phylogenetic distance and different ploidy systems, we identified a core set of convergently recruited regulatory genes and pathways governing caste determination, including vitellogenin-like proteins and insulin/TOR signaling. Furthermore, our analysis of chromatin accessibility (ATAC-seq) revealed that the regulatory elements controlling these core genes have evolved convergently, often arising from exapted transposable elements. These findings challenge the singular importance of the haplodiploidy hypothesis, suggesting instead that eusociality arises through the repeated co-option of conserved ancestral molecular toolkits governing reproductive physiology and nutritional sensing, canalized into distinct developmental fates.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Architecture of Eusociality: Convergent Evolution of Regulatory Networks in Hymenoptera and Termites

text: Predicting the pandemic potential of emerging zoonotic viruses requires a granular understanding of their evolutionary and epidemiological dynamics during the initial spillover phase. We applied Bayesian phylodynamic methods to a dense genomic dataset from an avian influenza H5Nx outbreak in a mammalian host population. By integrating viral sequences with spatial and temporal metadata under a structured coalescent model, we simultaneously inferred transmission routes, effective reproductive numbers (R₀), and site-specific selection pressures. Our analysis reveals cryptic transmission chains and identifies a key substitution in the viral polymerase PB2 subunit that significantly increased replication fitness in mammalian cells, confirmed via reverse genetics. This substitution arose multiple times independently, indicating strong parallel adaptation. This work demonstrates the power of integrating genomic surveillance with sophisticated phylodynamic modeling to dissect viral adaptive pathways in real-time, providing critical parameters for public health intervention strategies.
subject: Evrim
title: Real-Time Phylodynamics of a Zoonotic Spillover: Bayesian Inference of Viral Transmission and Adaptation

text: Convergent evolution, the independent origin of similar traits, provides powerful evidence for adaptation. While morphological convergence is well-documented, its molecular underpinnings are less understood. We conducted a comprehensive phylogenetically controlled analysis of 2,326 orthologous genes from echolocating bats and toothed whales, alongside non-echolocating sister taxa. By reconstructing ancestral sequences and quantifying amino acid substitution rates (dN/dS), we identified a statistically significant excess of parallel, non-synonymous substitutions in a suite of 37 genes associated with auditory function, including *Prestin*, *Otoferlin*, and *Cadherin-23*. These convergent changes were not attributable to neutral processes like biased gene conversion or mutational hotspots. Homology modeling indicates that many of these parallel substitutions cluster at key functional protein domains. Our results provide robust molecular evidence that complex phenotypic convergence is driven by parallel evolution at the sequence level, following predictable adaptive trajectories on the protein fitness landscape.
subject: Evrim
title: Molecular Convergence in Auditory Genes Reflects Parallel Evolution of Echolocation in Bats and Cetaceans

text: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a major evolutionary force in prokaryotes, but its role in shaping complex eukaryotic genomes remains controversial. We performed a rigorous phylogenomic screening of 170 complete eukaryotic genomes, identifying over 8,500 high-confidence instances of HGT from bacteria to eukaryotes, excluding events linked to endosymbiosis of organelles. Our analysis reveals that HGT is not merely a rare curiosity but a pervasive and ongoing process, particularly in protists and invertebrates inhabiting microbe-rich environments. Functional annotation of transferred genes shows a significant enrichment for metabolic enzymes, especially those involved in carbohydrate catabolism and secondary metabolite biosynthesis. Experimental validation in the tardigrade *Hypsibius exemplaris* confirms that a horizontally acquired bacterial enzyme confers tolerance to abiotic stressors. These findings establish HGT as a significant and recurring source of evolutionary innovation in eukaryotes, enabling rapid acquisition of novel metabolic capabilities from the surrounding microbiome.
subject: Evrim
title: Pervasive Horizontal Gene Transfer from Symbiotic Bacteria Drives Metabolic Innovation in Eukaryotic Genomes

text: Understanding the interplay between ecological and evolutionary processes is crucial for predicting species' responses to anthropogenic change. Using a resurrection ecology approach, we germinated dormant propagules of the freshwater cladoceran *Daphnia galeata* from precisely dated sediment core layers spanning 150 years of industrial pollution. By competing 'ancestral' (pre-industrial) and 'descendant' (post-industrial) populations in a common garden experiment under varying heavy metal concentrations, we quantified rapid evolutionary change in metal tolerance. Whole-genome sequencing of resurrected clones revealed selective sweeps at multiple loci, including a metallothionein gene and a P-type ATPase transporter. The evolution of increased tolerance came at a cost of reduced competitive ability in pristine conditions, demonstrating antagonistic pleiotropy. Our results empirically link a known environmental stressor to a rapid adaptive response at the phenotypic and genomic levels, showcasing the tight coupling of ecological and evolutionary dynamics in human-altered ecosystems.
subject: Evrim
title: Eco-Evolutionary Dynamics in Response to Anthropogenic Forcing: A Resurrection Ecology Approach

text: In environments characterized by high temporal stochasticity, diversified bet-hedging strategies, which reduce the variance in fitness at the expense of mean fitness, are predicted to evolve. We investigated the genetic architecture of seed dormancy, a classic bet-hedging trait, in the desert annual *Arabidopsis-relative, Brassica tournefortii*. Using a genome-wide association study (GWAS) on a panel of natural accessions phenotyped for germination fraction across multiple simulated years, we identified two major quantitative trait loci (QTL) controlling within-genotype germination variance. The primary QTL contains a homolog of the *DELAY OF GERMINATION 1* (*DOG1*) gene, where allelic variation in cis-regulatory elements appears to induce probabilistic, rather than deterministic, gene expression. A stochastic gene expression model, parameterized with our empirical data, confirms that this molecular noise can generate the optimal germination fractions predicted by theoretical bet-hedging models. This provides a direct link between molecular mechanisms and the evolution of a risk-diversification strategy.
subject: Evrim
title: The Evolution of Diversified Bet-Hedging: Genomic Basis of Variable Seed Dormancy in an Unpredictable Environment

text: Sexual selection often leads to the evolution of sexually dimorphic traits, but when optimal phenotypes differ between sexes, sexually antagonistic selection can arise, constraining adaptation. We explored the genomic basis of this conflict by performing artificial selection for a masculine trait (abdominal pigmentation) in female *Drosophila melanogaster* and a feminine trait (thorax size) in males. Using evolve-and-resequence (E&R) methodology, we tracked allele frequency trajectories over 50 generations. Our results show that response to selection was constrained and highly polygenic. The loci under selection were significantly enriched in regions of low recombination and exhibited strong signatures of pleiotropy, affecting both the selected trait and fitness components in the opposite sex. This genomic architecture, characterized by tightly linked alleles with antagonistic pleiotropic effects, perpetuates intralocus sexual conflict, thereby maintaining genetic variation for fitness-related traits and acting as a powerful brake on sexually dimorphic adaptation.
subject: Evrim
title: Sexual Conflict and the Genomic Architecture of Sexually Antagonistic Traits in *Drosophila melanogaster*

text: This paper introduces a hybrid quantum-classical framework for solving NP-hard combinatorial optimization problems, specifically the Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) class. We leverage a Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) parameterized by a hardware-efficient ansatz, executed on a noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) device. The classical optimization loop, traditionally reliant on gradient-based methods, is replaced by a novel gradient-free neuro-evolutionary algorithm. This approach mitigates the barren plateau problem and enhances robustness to device noise by exploring the parameter landscape more effectively. We demonstrate the efficacy of our method on Max-Cut and Traveling Salesman problems, showing superior approximation ratios and faster convergence compared to standard VQE implementations and classical heuristics like simulated annealing. Our results underscore the potential of integrating advanced classical machine learning techniques to overcome critical bottlenecks in near-term quantum computing applications, paving the way for practical quantum advantage in optimization.
subject: AI
title: Accelerating Combinatorial Optimization through Hybrid Quantum-Classical Variational Eigensolvers with Gradient-Free Neural Optimization

text: We propose a novel Generative Adversarial Network architecture, Hyperbolic-GAN (H-GAN), which embeds the latent space in a Poincaré ball model of hyperbolic geometry. This non-Euclidean representation is inherently suited for modeling hierarchical data structures. The generator network utilizes Möbius transformations for affine operations and hyperbolic convolutions, enabling it to learn complex, tree-like data distributions more efficiently than its Euclidean counterparts. A key innovation is a geodesic loss term that encourages smooth interpolations along shortest paths in the curved latent manifold, significantly improving the semantic coherence and perceptual quality of generated samples. We evaluate H-GAN on high-resolution image datasets like CelebA-HQ and FFHQ, demonstrating state-of-the-art Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) scores and superior disentanglement properties. Our findings reveal that geometric inductive biases in latent spaces are critical for advancing generative modeling beyond the limitations of flat, Euclidean assumptions.
subject: AI
title: Geodesic Latent Space Traversal in Hyperbolic Generative Adversarial Networks for High-Fidelity Synthesis

text: This work investigates emergent communication as a mechanism for scalable coordination in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL). We introduce a novel algorithm, Multi-Agent Protocol-driven Policy Iteration (MAPPI), which enables decentralized agents to co-develop a compositional communication protocol while simultaneously optimizing their individual policies. The architecture employs a Gumbel-Softmax estimator to facilitate differentiable learning of discrete message tokens, and a shared attention mechanism to contextualize messages based on local observations. The policy optimization is formulated within a decentralized actor-critic framework, where the value function is conditioned on the communicated messages, effectively resolving non-stationarity issues. We demonstrate MAPPI's superior performance in complex cooperative tasks, including StarCraft II micromanagement and coordinated navigation benchmarks. The learned protocols exhibit remarkable semantic structure and enable zero-shot generalization to unseen tasks and novel team compositions, highlighting the efficacy of learned communication for robust multi-agent coordination.
subject: AI
title: Decentralized Policy Optimization via Emergent Communication Protocols in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning

text: We present the Latent Process Diffusion Graph Neural Network (LPD-GNN), a novel deep learning framework for forecasting in complex, non-stationary dynamic systems. Traditional spatio-temporal GNNs struggle with irregularly sampled data and underlying processes that evolve over multiple timescales. Our model addresses this by explicitly parameterizing a latent diffusion process that governs the evolution of the graph's nodal dynamics. The architecture combines a graph convolutional network for spatial dependency capture with a neural ordinary differential equation (Neural ODE) solver that models the temporal evolution in a continuous latent space. This continuous-time formulation naturally handles missing data and provides uncertainty quantification through a probabilistic interpretation of the diffusion process. We validate LPD-GNN on challenging real-world datasets, including sea surface temperature prediction and epidemiological forecasting, achieving significant improvements in prediction accuracy and long-range forecast stability over state-of-the-art recurrent and attention-based models.
subject: AI
title: Dynamic Spatio-Temporal Graph Neural Networks with Latent Process Diffusion for Complex System Forecasting

text: Existing post-hoc explanation methods in XAI, such as saliency maps, often highlight correlational features rather than causal drivers of a model's prediction. This paper introduces Causal Recourse Explainer (CaRE), a framework for generating actionable and causally-faithful counterfactual explanations. CaRE integrates a deep structural causal model (SCM) with the target black-box model. Given an input instance, it solves a constrained optimization problem to find a minimal perturbation to the input that inverts the model's prediction, while respecting the causal graph's constraints. This process, termed algorithmic recourse, ensures that the generated counterfactuals are not only plausible but also causally valid. We formalize the properties of sparsity, actionability, and causal fidelity for explanations and demonstrate through quantitative and qualitative evaluations on tabular and image classification tasks that CaRE significantly outperforms gradient-based and heuristic counterfactual methods in providing robust, human-interpretable insights.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Causal Explanations for Deep Neural Networks via Algorithmic Recourse

text: We address the dual challenges of statistical heterogeneity and system heterogeneity in federated learning (FL) with a novel framework, Federated Privacy-Preserving Asynchronous learning (Fed-PA). To preserve privacy, Fed-PA integrates hybrid homomorphic encryption for secure gradient aggregation with client-level differential privacy, providing rigorous ε-differential privacy guarantees. To combat staleness and system heterogeneity inherent in asynchronous updates, we introduce an adaptive server-side optimizer that dynamically adjusts learning rates for client updates based on their delay and estimated contribution significance. Furthermore, to mitigate client drift due to non-IID data, we incorporate a server-side momentum term and a client-side regularization term that corrects for local optimization biases. Extensive empirical evaluation on benchmark datasets like CIFAR-10 and Shakespeare demonstrates that Fed-PA achieves faster convergence and higher final model accuracy compared to synchronous baselines (FedAvg, FedProx) and existing asynchronous methods, while maintaining strong privacy protections.
subject: AI
