title: Fed-PA: A Privacy-Preserving Asynchronous Federated Learning Framework with Adaptive Optimization for Heterogeneous Data

text: Transformer models, despite their success, exhibit limited compositional generalization, particularly in few-shot learning scenarios. This paper proposes a novel neuro-symbolic architecture, the Hyper-dimensional Transformer (HD-T), which integrates Vector-Symbolic Architectures (VSAs) based on Hyper-dimensional Computing (HDC) into the self-attention mechanism. In our model, concepts are represented as high-dimensional, quasi-orthogonal vectors (hypervectors). The self-attention mechanism is modified to operate on bundled hypervector representations, allowing it to perform explicit symbolic operations like binding and superposition. This enables the model to learn and manipulate compositional structures in a transparent and robust manner. We evaluate HD-T on compositional generalization benchmarks such as SCAN and COGS, demonstrating substantial improvements over standard Transformer models and other neuro-symbolic approaches, especially in zero-shot settings. Our results suggest that endowing neural models with algebraic structure via VSAs is a promising path towards more human-like language understanding.
subject: AI
title: Compositional Generalization in Transformers via Hyper-dimensional Computing and Vector-Symbolic Architectures

text: This paper presents a self-supervised framework for learning video representations by explicitly decoupling appearance and motion features. Our approach, named Decoupled Motion-Appearance Predictive Coding (DMAPC), leverages a dual-encoder architecture. An appearance encoder, based on a convolutional neural network, processes individual frames to capture static spatial features. A motion encoder, using a 3D residual network, processes short frame sequences to capture temporal dynamics. The core of our method is a cross-modal contrastive loss function. It forces the model to predict future appearance features from current motion features, and vice versa, thereby encouraging the two encoders to learn complementary, disentangled representations. We demonstrate that this explicit decoupling leads to more robust and transferable features. When finetuned on downstream tasks like action recognition (on UCF101 and HMDB51) and video retrieval, our pretrained DMAPC model significantly outperforms state-of-the-art self-supervised methods that learn entangled spatio-temporal representations.
subject: AI
title: Decoupled Spatio-Temporal Representation Learning for Videos via Cross-Modal Contrastive Predictive Coding

text: We introduce Stochastic Weight Averaging Gaussian Processes (SWAGP), a scalable and efficient method for accurate uncertainty quantification in deep neural networks. Standard Bayesian deep learning methods like variational inference or MCMC are computationally intensive and difficult to implement. SWAGP bridges the gap between deep ensembles and Bayesian methods by fitting a Gaussian process over the posterior distribution of network weights, approximated by the first two moments of the stochastic weight averaging (SWA) procedure. This approach captures a richer posterior approximation than a simple diagonal Gaussian, allowing it to model complex function-space correlations. SWAGP requires only a single model training run followed by a brief SWA phase, making it computationally comparable to standard training. We demonstrate its superior performance on calibration and out-of-distribution detection benchmarks, including CIFAR-100 and ImageNet-C, showing that SWAGP provides well-calibrated uncertainty estimates and outperforms deep ensembles and other scalable Bayesian methods.
subject: AI
title: Stochastic Weight Averaging Gaussian Processes for Scalable and Reliable Uncertainty Quantification in Deep Learning

text: This paper proposes a neuro-symbolic framework for Visual Question Answering (VQA) that combines the perceptual power of deep neural networks with the formal reasoning capabilities of probabilistic logic programming. Our model, Logical-Perceptual Reasoner (LPR), first employs object detectors and relation classifiers to transform an image into a structured probabilistic scene graph. This symbolic representation, which includes uncertainty estimates for each detected entity and relation, serves as a knowledge base for a probabilistic logic program (e.g., ProbLog). Questions are parsed into logical queries that are executed against this probabilistic knowledge base to infer an answer distribution. This architecture offers full transparency in its reasoning process and is inherently robust to adversarial perturbations. We evaluate LPR on the CLEVR-CoGenT and GQA datasets, demonstrating that it not only achieves competitive accuracy but also provides superior compositional generalization and explainability compared to end-to-end neural VQA models.
subject: AI
title: Integrating Deep Perceptual Modules with Probabilistic Logic Programming for Robust Visual Question Answering

text: Resolving the evolutionary relationships within rapid, ancient radiations remains a formidable challenge due to pervasive gene tree discordance caused by incomplete lineage sorting (ILS) and introgression. Here, we investigate the controversial suprafamilial relationships within Neoaves, an explosive avian radiation. By generating a novel dataset of over 5,000 ultraconserved element (UCE) loci for 198 species, we employ both concatenated supermatrix approaches with partition-based models and coalescent-based species tree methods (e.g., ASTRAL-III). Our phylogenomic analyses robustly resolve several key nodes previously considered intractable, supporting a novel sister relationship between Strisores and Columbaves. We demonstrate that while concatenation can yield high bootstrap support for spurious topologies under conditions of high ILS, coalescent methods provide a more consistent and theoretically sound framework. Stochastic mapping of key morphological innovations onto this new topology suggests a more complex pattern of trait evolution than previously hypothesized, highlighting the critical importance of accurate phylogenetic backbones for macroevolutionary inference.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Resolution of Rapid Radiations Using Orthology-Inferred Supermatrices and Coalescent-Based Species Tree Methods

text: Transposable elements (TEs), long considered 'junk DNA,' are increasingly recognized as potent sources of evolutionary innovation. We explored the role of TE exaptation in the spectacular adaptive radiation of African cichlid fishes. Through a comparative transcriptomic and epigenomic analysis (ATAC-seq, ChIP-seq) across five Malawi cichlid species exhibiting distinct craniofacial morphologies, we identified thousands of lineage-specific, TE-derived regulatory elements. These elements, primarily from SINE and LINE families, function as enhancers and insulators, significantly rewiring gene regulatory networks associated with pharyngeal jaw development. We show that the activation of these cryptic regulatory sites is correlated with differential expression of key developmental genes like *pax9* and *runx2*. Our findings provide compelling evidence that TE mobilization and subsequent co-option into host regulatory architecture is a fundamental mechanism facilitating rapid morphological diversification and niche exploitation, acting as a crucial substrate for natural selection.
subject: Evrim
title: Transposable Element Exaptation as a Major Driver of Regulatory Network Rewiring and Adaptive Innovation

text: The role of non-Mendelian inheritance in adaptive evolution is a subject of intense debate. This study investigates the contribution of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance (TEI) to phenotypic plasticity in *Arabidopsis thaliana*. We subjected isogenic lines to simulated drought stress for three generations and subsequently assessed the phenotype and epigenome of unexposed F4 progeny. Using whole-genome bisulfite sequencing and RNA-seq, we identified hundreds of differentially methylated regions (DMRs) that were stably inherited in the absence of the initial stressor. These inherited DMRs are significantly enriched near genes involved in ABA signaling and osmotic stress response, and their methylation status correlates with enhanced drought tolerance and altered root architecture in the F4 generation. Our results demonstrate that inherited epigenetic modifications can prime future generations for anticipated environmental challenges, representing a Lamarckian-like mechanism that can significantly influence the rate and trajectory of adaptation by modulating heritable reaction norms.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance Modulates Phenotypic Plasticity and Adaptive Potential in Response to Environmental Stress

text: Cryptic speciation, where genetically distinct lineages are morphologically indistinguishable, is thought to be widespread in microorganisms, complicating our understanding of biodiversity and ecosystem function. We investigated cryptic diversity within the ubiquitous marine cyanobacterium *Prochlorococcus*. By combining single-cell amplified genomics (SAGs) with large-scale marine metatranscriptomics, we resolved multiple deeply divergent, co-occurring clades previously classified as a single ecotype. These cryptic species exhibit distinct metabolic potentials encoded in their genomes, including differential utilization of nitrogen sources and vitamins. In situ gene expression profiles confirm fine-scale niche partitioning, with expression of key metabolic genes tightly correlated with specific physicochemical parameters of the water column. Our findings reveal that microbial biodiversity is substantially underestimated by traditional markers and that sympatric divergence, driven by competition for limiting resources, is a key process structuring microbial communities and their role in global biogeochemical cycles.
subject: Evrim
title: Cryptic Speciation and Niche Partitioning in Marine Picoplankton Revealed by Single-Cell Genomics and Metatranscriptomics

text: The timing and tempo of the Cambrian explosion, the rapid emergence of most animal phyla, remains a central question in evolutionary biology. Discrepancies between molecular clock estimates and the fossil record have fueled extensive debate. We present a new timescale for early animal evolution by integrating a comprehensive new morphological matrix of Ediacaran and Cambrian fossils with a 250-gene phylogenomic dataset. Using Bayesian total-evidence dating under the fossilized birth-death process, our analysis places the initial divergence of major metazoan clades deeper in the Cryogenian period than previously thought. However, the rates of morphological evolution and cladogenesis show an unprecedented spike during the early-to-mid Cambrian (Series 2-3), consistent with fossil evidence for an 'explosion' of anatomical disparity. This integrated approach reconciles molecular and paleontological data, suggesting a 'long fuse' of cryptic evolution followed by a burst of ecological opportunity and developmental innovation driving the Cambrian radiation.
subject: Evrim
title: Re-evaluating the Cambrian Explosion via Integrated Paleontological and Molecular Clock Analyses with Fossilized Birth-Death Models

text: Host-parasite coevolution is often characterized by reciprocal selective pressures, leading to Red Queen dynamics. However, the genetic architecture underlying coevolutionary traits can impose significant constraints. We developed a stochastic individual-based model to investigate the coevolutionary trajectory of a host-parasite system where a single host locus confers resistance but also carries a pleiotropic fitness cost (antagonistic pleiotropy). Our simulations demonstrate that high pleiotropic costs prevent the fixation of resistance alleles, leading to stable, long-term polymorphisms instead of classic arms-race dynamics or recurrent selective sweeps. We observe sustained oscillations in both host and parasite allelic frequencies, but the amplitude and period of these cycles are critically dependent on the cost of virulence in the parasite and the cost of resistance in the host. These findings suggest that pleiotropic constraints are a key factor in maintaining genetic variation in natural populations and can shift coevolutionary dynamics from directional selection to balancing selection.
subject: Evrim
title: Antagonistic Pleiotropy Constrains the Coevolutionary Dynamics of Host Resistance and Parasite Virulence

text: Hybridization can facilitate rapid adaptation by introducing pre-adapted alleles across species boundaries. We investigated the role of adaptive introgression in the evolution of drought and frost tolerance in two hybridizing species of alpine wildflowers, *Polemonium viscosum* and *P. brandegeei*. Using whole-genome sequencing of individuals sampled across an elevational and hybrid-zone gradient, we identified discrete genomic regions with steep clines in allele frequency, indicative of strong differential selection. These regions, which show significant introgression from the high-elevation specialist *P. brandegeei* into the lower-elevation *P. viscosum*, contain genes associated with osmotic regulation and cold-acclimation pathways. Loci within these introgressed blocks exhibit reduced nucleotide diversity and extended linkage disequilibrium, consistent with recent selective sweeps. Our study provides strong genomic evidence that introgression of key functional alleles is a potent mechanism for rapid adaptation to climatic stressors, potentially enhancing the resilience of populations in the face of environmental change.
subject: Evrim
title: Adaptive Introgression and the Evolution of Climate Resilience in Montane Flora: A Genomic Cline Analysis

text: Understanding the evolutionary assembly of complex morphological structures requires robust phylogenetic comparative methods. We investigated the macroevolutionary history of the avian cranial system, a highly integrated structure, using 3D geometric morphometric data from 250 bird species and a novel time-calibrated phylogeny. By applying multivariate phylogenetic comparative methods, including Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models and stochastic character mapping, we reconstructed the evolutionary trajectory of cranial shape across morphospace. Our results reject a model of simple, concerted evolution. Instead, we reveal a pattern of mosaic evolution, where distinct cranial modules (e.g., rostrum, neurocranium) exhibit semi-independent evolutionary rates and trajectories. Rate-shift analyses identify significant accelerations in rostrum evolution correlated with diversification events in clades undergoing specialized feeding adaptations, such as finches and shorebirds. This modularity likely provided the evolutionary flexibility that facilitated the immense ecological and functional diversity of the avian skull.
subject: Evrim
title: Stochastic Character Mapping of Complex Morphological Traits Reveals Mosaic Evolution in the Avian Cranium

text: Convergent evolution provides a powerful framework for studying the predictability of evolutionary change. Electric organs have evolved independently six times in teleost fishes, offering a classic example of phenotypic convergence. We investigated the underlying genomic architecture by sequencing and analyzing the genomes of three independently evolved electric fish lineages. Our comparative genomic analysis revealed that the evolution of electrogenesis is consistently linked to the repurposing of the *Scn4a* gene, which encodes a voltage-gated sodium channel subunit expressed in skeletal muscle. We identified a striking pattern of parallel evolution at the molecular level, with numerous identical and equivalent amino acid substitutions occurring in key functional domains of the Scn4a protein across independent lineages. These parallel substitutions alter channel gating kinetics, a crucial modification for generating electric organ discharge. This study demonstrates that despite vast phylogenetic distances, the evolution of a complex physiological novelty can be constrained to repeatable changes in a single gene.
subject: Evrim
title: Convergent Evolution of Electrogenesis in Teleost Fishes Is Underpinned by Parallel Amino Acid Substitutions in Ion Channel Genes

text: The transition from unicellular to multicellular life represents a major transition in individuality, requiring the evolution of mechanisms to suppress conflict among constituent cells. A key innovation is the evolution of a sterile soma and a segregated germline. Using a multi-level selection framework and agent-based modeling, we explored the conditions favoring the evolution of germ-soma differentiation. Our model demonstrates that the evolution of a sterile soma is favored when the fitness benefits of specialized somatic function (e.g., resource acquisition, motility) are high and when the cost of producing germline cells is substantial. Critically, we find that high genetic relatedness among cells is a necessary but not sufficient condition; the transition also requires the emergence of 'policing' mechanisms that suppress cellular cheating. The model predicts a nonlinear relationship between organism size and the optimal proportion of somatic cells, providing testable hypotheses for experimental evolution studies with organisms like *Volvox*.
subject: Evrim
title: The Evolutionary Dynamics of Germ-Soma Differentiation and the Major Transition to Multicellularity

text: We theoretically investigate the emergent non-Abelian statistics of Majorana zero modes (MZMs) localized at vortex cores in a p-wave superconductor proximity-coupled to a ν=5/2 fractional quantum Hall system. By simulating the time-evolution of the Bogoliubov-de Gennes Hamiltonian, we model the adiabatic braiding of these MZMs and compute the resulting unitary transformation on the degenerate ground-state manifold. Our numerical analysis explicitly demonstrates that the braiding operators form a representation of the Braid group, confirming their non-Abelian character. We further quantify the robustness of the topological protection by introducing realistic sources of decoherence, such as quasiparticle poisoning and thermal fluctuations. The calculated gate fidelity for a Hadamard gate operation exceeds 99.9% for experimentally accessible parameters. These findings provide a concrete blueprint for implementing topologically protected quantum gates, a critical step toward scalable fault-tolerant quantum computation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Braiding Dynamics of Non-Abelian Anyons in a Fractional Quantum Hall-Superconductor Heterostructure

text: This work explores the dS/CFT correspondence by modeling a two-dimensional de Sitter (dS2) cosmology with a holographic dual described by the Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) model. We compute the entanglement entropy of a subregion in the boundary SYK theory and demonstrate its correspondence to the Ryu-Takayanagi formula in the dual static patch of the dS bulk. By employing a tensor network-based algorithm for bulk operator reconstruction, we show how local bulk operators deep within the dS horizon can be represented as complex, non-local operators in the boundary theory. Our results reproduce the Page curve for an observer in dS space, providing a resolution to the information paradox in a cosmological context. This study provides compelling evidence for the holographic principle in spacetimes with a positive cosmological constant, linking quantum chaos on the boundary to gravitational dynamics in the bulk.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Entropy and Bulk Reconstruction in de Sitter Spacetime via the SYK Model

text: We investigate the dynamics of entanglement and the breakdown of thermalization in a periodically driven, disordered one-dimensional Heisenberg spin chain. Using large-scale time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (t-DMRG) simulations, we identify a stable many-body localized (MBL) phase characterized by the logarithmic spreading of quantum information and the preservation of local memory. We map the phase diagram as a function of driving frequency and disorder strength, pinpointing the MBL transition through finite-size scaling of entanglement variance. A key finding is the existence of a long-lived prethermal plateau preceding the eventual localization, governed by an emergent effective static Hamiltonian. This prethermal MBL regime displays slow, power-law entanglement growth before saturating at a value determined by the system's proximity to the transition. These findings elucidate the intricate interplay between disorder, interactions, and periodic driving in non-equilibrium quantum systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Light Cones and Prethermalization in a Disordered Floquet Spin System

text: We propose a quantum metrology protocol that achieves Heisenberg-limited precision in optical phase estimation. The scheme utilizes a multi-pass Mach-Zehnder interferometer injected with a twin-Fock state, a highly non-classical N-photon state with definite photon number in each arm. By deriving the Quantum Fisher Information for this system, we demonstrate that the phase sensitivity scales as 1/N^2, a quadratic improvement over the standard quantum limit. Our protocol involves an adaptive measurement strategy where the number of passes through the interferometer is dynamically adjusted based on intermediate measurement outcomes. We perform a detailed analysis of the protocol's resilience to photon loss and detector inefficiency, identifying a critical loss threshold beyond which the quantum advantage is nullified. This work provides a practical route towards surpassing classical measurement limits in applications like gravitational wave detection and biological sensing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Phase Estimation via Multi-Pass Interferometry with Correlated Photonic States

text: This work explores the topological properties of non-Hermitian systems. We theoretically model and numerically simulate a two-dimensional photonic crystal with spatially modulated gain and loss, engineered to possess parity-time (PT) symmetry. Within the parameter space, we identify exceptional points (EPs), non-Hermitian degeneracies where both eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the system's Hamiltonian coalesce. We demonstrate that by encircling an EP in parameter space, the system undergoes a chiral mode-switching phenomenon. Furthermore, we reveal a topological phase transition across a line of EPs, characterized by a change in a winding number invariant defined for the complex band structure. This transition manifests as the appearance of robust, unidirectional topological edge states that are immune to backscattering from PT-symmetric defects. Our results bridge non-Hermitian physics and topological photonics, offering a new paradigm for designing non-reciprocal optical devices.
subject: Kuantum
title: Exceptional Points and Topological Phase Transitions in a Parity-Time-Symmetric Photonic Crystal

text: We present a high-fidelity protocol for the deterministic generation of multipartite entangled W-states using a one-dimensional lattice of superconducting transmon qubits coupled via a common microwave resonator. The protocol leverages a sequence of optimally controlled resonant and off-resonant microwave pulses, exploiting the collective Jaynes-Cummings interaction to coherently map a single excitation from a control qubit onto a symmetric superposition of N target qubits. Through master equation simulations incorporating realistic decoherence rates, crosstalk, and control field errors, we predict a state fidelity exceeding 96% for an 8-qubit W-state, achievable within 200 nanoseconds. The protocol's scalability and robustness to parameter fluctuations mark a significant advance in engineered quantum state synthesis. This architecture provides a fundamental building block for quantum networking and certain quantum algorithms, enabling robust entanglement distribution over a chip-scale quantum processor.
subject: Kuantum
title: Deterministic Generation of Multi-Qubit W-States in a Superconducting Circuit QED Lattice

text: We report the experimental realization of a fault-tolerant logical qubit with suppressed error rates using a concatenated [[5, 1, 3]] quantum error-correcting code. The experiment is implemented on a linear chain of seven Ytterbium-171 ions, where a logical qubit is encoded in five data ions, and two ancillary ions are used for syndrome extraction. By applying repeated stabilizer measurement cycles interleaved with encoding and decoding operations, we actively correct for arbitrary single-qubit errors. The logical qubit demonstrates a coherence time T2* enhanced by a factor of 6.2 compared to the best physical qubit in the register. We perform logical process tomography on a set of universal Clifford gates, achieving an average logical gate fidelity of 99.4(2)%. This experiment demonstrates the suppression of logical error rates below the physical error threshold, a critical milestone for scalable quantum computing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation with a Concatenated Five-Qubit Stabilizer Code on a Trapped-Ion Architecture

text: We investigate the ground state and low-energy excitations of the extended Kitaev-Heisenberg model, a candidate for describing the physics of iridate compounds like Na2IrO3 and α-RuCl3. Using large-scale density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) on cylindrical geometries up to 10 sites in circumference, we identify a quantum spin liquid (QSL) phase intervening between the Néel and zigzag ordered phases. We calculate the dynamic spin structure factor, revealing a broad continuum of excitations consistent with the presence of fractionalized Majorana fermions. Crucially, our analysis of the entanglement spectrum and non-local string order parameters provides strong evidence for the existence of a gapless spinon Fermi surface in a significant portion of this QSL phase. These results provide a comprehensive theoretical characterization of a prominent QSL candidate, offering direct comparison points for future inelastic neutron scattering and thermal transport experiments.
subject: Kuantum
title: Fractionalized Excitations and Spinon Fermi Surface in a Kitaev-Heisenberg Model on the Honeycomb Lattice

text: Fluctuation theorems generalize the second law of thermodynamics to small systems far from equilibrium. Here, we present an experimental verification of the Jarzynski equality in a fully quantum regime. We utilize a single Rubidium-87 atom strongly coupled to the motional mode of a high-finesse optical cavity. The system is prepared in thermal equilibrium and then driven out of equilibrium by a rapid, non-adiabatic change in the cavity-atom detuning. Projective energy measurements of the phononic state of the atom's motion are performed at the beginning and end of the protocol. By reconstructing the work distribution function from over 10^5 experimental repetitions, we confirm that the exponential average of the work performed, <exp(-βW)>, converges to the equilibrium free energy difference exp(-βΔF), verifying the Jarzynski equality with a precision of 3%. This work validates a fundamental tenet of non-equilibrium statistical mechanics in a canonical quantum system.
subject: Kuantum
title: Experimental Verification of the Quantum Jarzynski Equality in a Single-Atom Optomechanical System

text: Quantum contextuality, a pillar of quantum mechanics distinct from non-locality, asserts that measurement outcomes cannot be predetermined independently of the measurement context. We report a loophole-free experimental test of contextuality using the spin-1 triplet ground state of a single nitrogen-vacancy (NV) center in diamond, which forms a natural qutrit. We implement a state-independent Kochen-Specker set of 18 projectors on this three-level system, which is the minimal set known to reveal contextuality in three dimensions. Utilizing high-fidelity microwave and radio-frequency control, we perform sequential projective measurements and test the non-contextual inequality. Our results show a violation of the inequality by over 90 standard deviations, conclusively ruling out all non-contextual hidden-variable models. This robust demonstration of a fundamental quantum property in a solid-state system highlights its potential as a resource for quantum information processing, such as in measurement-based quantum computation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Quantum Contextuality with an Optimal Kochen-Specker Set on a Nitrogen-Vacancy Center Qutrit

text: We investigate the relationship between the spectral radius of the adjacency tensor of a k-uniform hypergraph and its saturation properties with respect to the complete hypergraph K_r^k. This study establishes a sharp lower bound on the spectral radius for any K_r^k-saturated hypergraph, extending the classical theorems of Turan and Bondy to the spectral domain. Our approach leverages a novel hypergraph symmetrization technique, analogous to Zykov symmetrization for graphs, and applies interlacing arguments to the spectral components of the tensor. Furthermore, we explore the implications of these spectral bounds on the list-chromatic number, demonstrating that hypergraphs with a spectral radius proximate to the extremal Turan-type bound exhibit significantly constrained chromatic behavior. This work bridges a critical gap between extremal hypergraph theory and spectral methods, offering new algebraic tools for analyzing the delicate structure of saturated combinatorial objects and their coloring properties.
subject: Matematik
title: Spectral Radius and Chromatic Properties of K_r-Saturated Hypergraphs

text: This paper investigates the threshold for the existence of k-term arithmetic progressions (k-APs) in sparse random subsets of {1, ..., N}. We employ techniques from higher-order Fourier analysis, specifically adapting Gowers uniformity norms to the probabilistic setting. By defining a Gowers U^k-norm for functions on random sets and proving a corresponding generalized von Neumann theorem, we establish a sharp threshold for the property that every subset of a random set with a certain relative density contains a k-AP. This result refines the seminal work of Roth, Szemerédi, and Gowers by quantifying the resilience of their theorems to random sparsification. Our analysis hinges on a delicate coupling between the discrete Fourier transform on Z_N and the expectation over the probability space of the random set, providing a robust framework for studying arithmetic structures within sparse random environments.
subject: Matematik
title: Higher-Order Fourier Analysis on Sparse Random Sets and Thresholds for Arithmetic Progressions

text: We study the homological stability of ordered configuration spaces of n points on a finite simplicial complex X. While classical results address this for smooth manifolds, the combinatorial setting presents unique challenges due to local singularities. We introduce a new chain complex model based on discrete Morse theory, which facilitates the analysis of the requisite boundary maps. Our main result establishes a stable range for H_i(Conf_n(X); Q) that depends explicitly on the connectivity and local vertex-link structure of X. Furthermore, we frame this stability within the theory of representation stability and FI-modules, showing that the sequence of homology groups {H_i(Conf_n(X); Q)}_n forms a finitely generated FI-module. This provides a unified perspective on the stable homology and demonstrates that the characters of the symmetric group actions on these homology groups are given by a single character polynomial for sufficiently large n.
subject: Matematik
title: Homological Stability of Configuration Spaces on Simplicial Complexes and Representation Stability

text: We present a novel, purely combinatorial formula for the modified Macdonald polynomials H_mu(X; q, t). The formula expresses H_mu as a weighted sum over a set of decorated lattice paths constrained by the partition mu, where the weights are monomials in q and t determined by local path geometry. This construction provides a direct combinatorial interpretation of the (q, t)-coefficients, unifying and generalizing previous formulas for specialized cases. The proof relies on establishing a weight-preserving bijection between these lattice paths and a specific class of fillings of the Ferrers diagram of mu, which we term 'inversion-ordered multicomplexes'. Our framework not only recovers the celebrated shuffle conjecture (now a theorem) in the specialized case mu=(1^n) but also offers a new algorithmic approach for computing Macdonald polynomials, deepening the connection between the algebraic theory of symmetric functions and enumerative combinatorics.
subject: Matematik
title: A Combinatorial Formula for Macdonald Polynomials via Multicomplexes and Lattice Path Enumeration

text: This paper extends the classical Nešetřil-Rödl theorem to a broad class of ordered relational structures, with a specific focus on layered partially ordered sets (posets). We establish that for any finite layered poset P, the class of all finite layered posets has the P-Ramsey property. The proof methodology diverges from traditional part-by-part amalgamation arguments. Instead, we construct a universal object—the Fraïssé limit of the class of layered posets—and analyze the dynamics of its automorphism group. By leveraging results from topological dynamics, particularly the concept of extremely amenable groups and their connection to structural Ramsey theory, we demonstrate the existence of monochromatic copies of P in any finite coloring of the substructures of a sufficiently large host poset. This approach provides a unified framework for proving Ramsey-type results for various ordered combinatorial objects and their derivatives.
subject: Matematik
title: Structural Ramsey Theory for Layered Posets and the Nešetřil-Rödl Theorem for Ordered Structures

text: We investigate the distinguishing power of continuous-time quantum walks for the graph isomorphism problem. While quantum walks can distinguish certain non-isomorphic cospectral graphs, their full capability remains an open problem. Our work focuses on the challenging class of strongly regular graphs (SRGs). We introduce a new invariant, the 'projected evolution fidelity matrix,' derived from the quantum walk evolution operator projected onto the irreducible submodules of the graph's adjacency algebra. We prove that this invariant is sufficient to distinguish all non-isomorphic SRGs within the Johnson and Hamming association schemes. The proof involves a detailed analysis of the Terwilliger algebra of the graph and its irreducible representations. This result provides a polynomial-time isomorphism test for a significant subclass of SRGs and suggests a new pathway for tackling graph isomorphism using principles of quantum mechanics.
subject: Matematik
title: Quantum Walks on Graphs and a Refined Isomorphism Test for Strongly Regular Graphs

text: Recent breakthroughs have connected the geometry of polynomials to efficient counting and sampling in discrete structures. This paper extends this theory to the fundamental problem of matroid intersection. We demonstrate that the multivariate generating polynomial for common independent sets of two matroids is not generally log-concave, but satisfies a related property we term 'directional log-concavity'. By leveraging this property and the theory of strongly log-concave polynomials, we develop a new analysis of the natural down-up random walk on the bases of the intersection of two matroids. We prove that this Markov chain is rapidly mixing, providing the first fully polynomial-time randomized approximation scheme (FPRAS) for counting common bases of two matroids whose union is connected. This result establishes a unified framework that encompasses both sampling from a single matroid base polytope and approximating the solution to weighted matroid intersection.
subject: Matematik
title: Log-Concave Polynomials and a Unified Framework for Matroid Intersection and Base Polytope Sampling

text: The classical Frankl-Wilson theorem provides an upper bound on the size of a family of sets with restricted intersections using linear algebra methods. We generalize this seminal result to a higher-dimensional setting by considering families of subspaces within a vector space over a finite field. We prove a tight upper bound on the size of a family of k-dimensional subspaces of F_q^n where the dimension of the intersection of any two distinct subspaces is restricted to a specific set L of integers. Our proof adapts the polynomial method to functions defined on Grassmannians, utilizing exterior algebra products. As a primary application, we resolve a long-standing problem in geometric Ramsey theory. We establish a new exponential lower bound for the chromatic number of n-dimensional Euclidean space, showing that χ(R^n) > (c + o(1))^n for a constant c > 1.2, significantly improving upon previous bounds.
subject: Matematik
title: Higher-Dimensional Frankl-Wilson Type Theorems and Applications to Geometric Ramsey Theory

text: We analyze the structure of the graph generated by the K_4-free process, wherein edges are added sequentially at random provided they do not create a copy of the complete graph K_4. Extending the seminal work on the triangle-free process, we determine the asymptotic number of edges in the final graph G_final. A key challenge is the asymmetric nature of K_4, whose subgraphs have varying densities. Our proof combines the differential equations method with a novel, dynamic application of the hypergraph container method, tailored for evolving graph processes. We demonstrate that, with high probability, G_final is structurally close to a complete tripartite graph, but with a complex, fractal-like distribution of edges within one of the vertex partitions. This provides a detailed structural description that goes beyond simply counting edges and offers new insights into the behavior of semi-random graph processes constrained by non-uniform forbidden subgraphs.
subject: Matematik
title: The Asymmetric K_4-Free Process and the Structure of Late-Stage Random Graphs

text: The polynomial Bogolyubov-Ruzsa-Gowers theorem provides structural information about sets A in F_p^n where the number of k-term arithmetic progressions is significantly larger than in a random set. This paper extends these results to finite fields F_q^n where the characteristic q is small and fixed. The low characteristic setting introduces significant technical hurdles, as standard polynomial method arguments depending on high-degree derivatives fail. We introduce a new technique based on 'derivational operators' which circumvents these issues by analyzing the Wronskian of certain polynomials associated with the set A. We prove that if a set A ⊆ F_q^n has density δ, then its sumset 2k A - 2k A contains an affine subspace of codimension bounded by a polynomial in k and 1/δ, where the polynomial's degree is independent of q. This result provides a robust structural description for approximate subgroups in low-characteristic vector spaces.
subject: Matematik
title: Polynomial Bogolyubov-Ruzsa-Gowers Theorem in Finite Fields of Small Characteristic

text: Conventional self-supervised learning methods often capture spurious correlations, leading to poor out-of-distribution generalization. We introduce a novel framework, Interventional Contrastive Learning (ICL), designed to learn causally invariant representations by disentangling causal factors from confounders. ICL leverages a generative model to synthesize interventional data augmentations that simulate controlled manipulations of underlying causal variables. We formulate a new contrastive objective that maximizes mutual information between representations of an anchor and its interventionally-augmented positive pairs, while minimizing it with respect to observational augmentations that preserve confounders. By integrating a variational information bottleneck, our model explicitly regularizes the learned latent space to encode minimal, sufficient causal information. We demonstrate through extensive experimentation on synthetic and real-world benchmarks, including Colored-MNIST and ImageNet-R, that ICL significantly enhances downstream task performance under distributional shifts, establishing a new state-of-the-art in robust self-supervised representation learning.
subject: AI
title: Causal Disentanglement in Self-Supervised Learning via Interventional Contrastive Divergence

text: Generative modeling of high-dimensional data is hampered by the curse of dimensionality. We propose Quantum-Inspired Tensor Ring Networks (QTRNs), a novel class of generative models that leverages the expressive power of tensor network formalisms. By representing the joint probability distribution as a Tensor Ring (also known as Matrix Product State), our model achieves an exponential compression of the parameter space. We introduce a Riemannian optimization scheme based on the density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) algorithm, enabling efficient and stable training on the tensor manifold. This approach circumvents the vanishing gradient problems prevalent in deep generative models. Empirical evaluation on complex image datasets like CelebA-HQ and synthetic quantum state tomography tasks demonstrates that QTRNs provide superior sample fidelity and log-likelihood scores while maintaining a logarithmic scaling of parameters with respect to data dimensionality, significantly outperforming VAEs and GANs.
subject: AI
title: Quantum-Inspired Tensor Ring Networks for High-Dimensional Probabilistic Modeling

text: We address the dual challenges of statistical heterogeneity and data privacy in cross-silo federated learning. This paper introduces FedCrypt, a novel framework that synergistically combines client-level differential privacy with partial homomorphic encryption for secure gradient aggregation. To combat the performance degradation caused by non-IID data distributions, FedCrypt integrates a personalized meta-learning objective, allowing each client to learn a tailored model while contributing to a global model. The protocol encrypts only a carefully selected, low-dimensional projection of the gradients, minimizing computational overhead while providing formal privacy guarantees against an honest-but-curious server. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis of the privacy-utility trade-off and demonstrate empirically on benchmark datasets like CIFAR-100 and FEMNIST that FedCrypt achieves state-of-the-art model accuracy under significant data heterogeneity, surpassing existing secure aggregation and personalized federated learning methods.
subject: AI
title: FedCrypt: Hybrid Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning with Homomorphic Encryption and Personalized Meta-Learning

text: We present GeomFold, a novel SE(3)-equivariant graph neural network for end-to-end ab-initio protein structure prediction. Departing from methods that rely on 2D distance maps, our model operates directly on the non-Euclidean manifold of protein backbone geometries, naturally preserving roto-translational invariance. GeomFold employs an iterative refinement process where inter-residue interactions are modeled as messages in a graph representation of the amino acid sequence. The core innovation lies in our use of steerable filters and a Riemannian attention mechanism that captures long-range dependencies in 3D space. This geometric-aware architecture allows for the direct prediction of atomic coordinates without expensive template matching or alignment procedures. On the challenging CASP14 benchmark, GeomFold demonstrates a significant reduction in backbone RMSD for template-free modeling targets, establishing a new paradigm for computationally efficient and accurate protein folding.
subject: AI
title: Geometric Deep Learning on SE(3) Manifolds for Ab-Initio Protein Structure Prediction

text: Accelerating the acquisition of new motor skills is a fundamental challenge in robotics. We propose ProMP-MAML, a novel meta-reinforcement learning algorithm for rapid, few-shot adaptation in complex manipulation tasks. Our approach parameterizes policies as a distribution over Probabilistic Movement Primitives (ProMPs), which provides a structured, low-dimensional representation for exploration. We leverage Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) to train the prior distribution over ProMP parameters across a distribution of related tasks. This meta-trained prior enables the agent to adapt its policy to a novel task with only a handful of gradient updates by efficiently inferring the posterior over the primitive's parameters. We demonstrate in simulated and real-world settings, including peg-in-hole insertion and tool use, that ProMP-MAML achieves unprecedented sample efficiency and superior generalization to unseen object geometries and positions compared to state-of-the-art meta-RL techniques.
subject: AI
title: ProMP-MAML: Meta-Learning Probabilistic Movement Primitives for Few-Shot Robotic Manipulation

text: Accurate uncertainty quantification in deep neural networks remains a significant challenge, particularly in large-scale settings. We introduce Stochastic Gradient Hamiltonian Monte Carlo with Amortized Variational Inference (SG-HMC-AVI), a highly scalable Bayesian deep learning framework. Our method constructs an expressive variational posterior using a normalizing flow, which is trained to approximate the true posterior. We leverage the geometric properties of Hamiltonian dynamics via SG-HMC to generate high-quality samples for training the flow, mitigating the mode-seeking behavior of traditional variational inference. Crucially, we amortize the inference process, allowing a single trained inference network to parameterize the variational distribution for any given data point, enabling fast test-time prediction. On large-scale regression and out-of-distribution detection benchmarks, SG-HMC-AVI provides well-calibrated, robust uncertainty estimates, significantly outperforming Deep Ensembles and Mean-Field VI approaches.
subject: AI
title: Stochastic Gradient Hamiltonian Monte Carlo with Amortized Variational Inference for Scalable Uncertainty Quantification

text: Randomized smoothing has emerged as a state-of-the-art technique for providing certifiable guarantees of robustness against adversarial attacks. However, its efficacy diminishes significantly in high-dimensional input spaces. We propose Latent Space Smoothing (LSS), a novel certified defense that operates in the low-dimensional, disentangled latent space of a pre-trained generative model, such as a Variational Autoencoder (VAE). Our method applies Gaussian smoothing to the latent vector representation of an input before decoding and classification. This strategy circumvents the curse of dimensionality and allows for substantially larger certified radii. We derive a tight theoretical bound that relates the certified L2 radius in the latent space to a corresponding, non-trivial robustness guarantee in the high-dimensional pixel space. Empirically, we demonstrate on CIFAR-10 and CelebA that LSS achieves a certified accuracy that is orders of magnitude better than smoothing applied directly to the input space.
subject: AI
title: Certified Adversarial Robustness via Randomized Smoothing in Disentangled Latent Spaces

text: We introduce Abductive Logic-Tensor Networks (A-LTN), a novel neuro-symbolic framework for complex, multi-hop reasoning over incomplete knowledge graphs. A-LTN synergizes the perceptual capabilities of graph neural networks for entity embedding with the formal reasoning power of first-order logic. The core of our framework is a differentiable abductive reasoning module that learns to hypothesize missing links (lemmas) in the knowledge graph to complete a logical proof path for a given query. This process is guided by a probabilistic logical consistency loss, which ensures that hypothesized facts cohere with the existing knowledge base. This architecture allows for end-to-end training from question-answer pairs while generating fully interpretable, symbolic proof-trees for its inferences. A-LTN establishes a new state-of-the-art on complex reasoning datasets like MetaQA and WebQuestionsSP, demonstrating superior performance in handling sparse and noisy knowledge graphs.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic Reasoning over Knowledge Graphs via Abductive Logic-Tensor Networks

text: Predicting the future trajectories of multiple interacting agents is critical for autonomous systems. This paper introduces the Spatio-Temporal Graph Attention Network (STGAT), a novel architecture for modeling complex, non-linear agent interactions. We represent the scene as a dynamic graph where nodes are agents and edges encode their spatial and social relationships. STGAT employs a dual-head graph attention mechanism to learn anisotropic interaction weights, dynamically distinguishing between social influence and spatial proximity. A Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) architecture propagates the temporal dynamics of the agent states and the graph structure itself. To capture the inherent uncertainty of human behavior, the model outputs a multimodal probabilistic distribution over future trajectories using a Mixture Density Network. Evaluated on the challenging nuScenes and Argoverse autonomous driving datasets, STGAT demonstrates significant improvements in prediction accuracy and realism over current state-of-the-art methods, particularly in dense, interactive scenarios.
subject: AI
title: Spatio-Temporal Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Trajectory Prediction

text: To address catastrophic forgetting in neural networks, we propose a bio-inspired continual learning algorithm, Synaptic Metaplasticity with Orthogonal Projection (SMOP). Our framework maintains a dynamically updated trace of parameter importance for previous tasks, modeled after the principles of synaptic metaplasticity. When learning a new task, SMOP projects the calculated gradients onto the orthogonal complement of the subspace spanned by the most important features of past tasks. This null-space projection rigorously prevents interference with previously acquired knowledge while allowing for maximal plasticity in orthogonal directions for learning new information. The metaplastic importance measure allows for efficient online updates without storing past data. We demonstrate on challenging class-incremental benchmarks, including Split-ImageNet and CORE50, that SMOP significantly outperforms state-of-the-art replay-free and regularization-based methods, achieving superior knowledge retention and forward transfer.
subject: AI
title: Continual Learning with Synaptic Metaplasticity and Orthogonal Gradient Projection

text: Morphological stasis in marine invertebrates often conceals substantial genetic diversity, complicating biogeographic and evolutionary analyses. We employed restriction site-associated DNA sequencing (RAD-seq) to interrogate the systematics of the circum-Antarctic ophiuroid species complex, Ophionotus victoriae. Coalescent-based species delimitation models and phylogenomic inference robustly identified at least five deeply divergent, reproductively isolated lineages, previously unrecognized based on morphology. Divergence time estimation using fossil-calibrated molecular clocks places the primary cladogenic events in the late Pliocene and early Pleistocene. These periods correlate with major shifts in the Antarctic Circumpolar Current and the expansion of ice sheets, suggesting allopatric speciation driven by oceanographic barriers. Our findings demonstrate that polar biodiversity is significantly underestimated and highlight the efficacy of genomic approaches in uncovering cryptic speciation patterns sculpted by paleo-climatic dynamics. These results necessitate a taxonomic revision and a reassessment of conservation priorities for Antarctic benthic fauna.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Resolution of a Cryptic Species Complex Reveals Pliocene-Pleistocene Vicariance in Circum-Antarctic Ophiuroids

text: The role of non-Mendelian inheritance in rapid adaptation remains a contentious frontier in evolutionary biology. This study investigates the contribution of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance to adaptive evolution in the mangrove killifish, Kryptolebias marmoratus. We exposed isogenic lineages to sustained hypo- and hyper-salinity stress over five generations and performed whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) on F5 offspring. We identified hundreds of differentially methylated regions (DMRs) that were stably inherited in the absence of the initial stressor. These heritable DMRs were significantly enriched in the promoter regions of genes associated with osmoregulation and ion transport, including key ion-pump ATPases. Crucially, offspring from pre-exposed lineages exhibited significantly higher survival rates and more stable gill Na+/K+-ATPase activity when challenged with acute salinity stress. These findings provide compelling evidence that heritable DNA methylation can act as a substrate for rapid adaptive evolution, facilitating physiological pre-adaptation to fluctuating environmental conditions.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational DNA Methylation Mediates Rapid Adaptive Response to Salinity Stress in a Mangrove Killifish

text: The extinction dynamics of Pleistocene megafauna are central to understanding the interplay of climate change and anthropogenic pressures. We generated shotgun sequencing data from 14 subfossil remains of the woolly rhinoceros (Coelodonta antiquitatis) spanning from 50,000 to 14,000 years BP. Using pairwise sequentially Markovian coalescent (PSMC) analysis, we reconstructed a demographic history characterized by a high effective population size (Ne) throughout the Middle Pleistocene, followed by a precipitous decline beginning approximately 25,000 years ago, coinciding with the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM). D-statistic tests reveal significant evidence of archaic introgression from a ghost sister lineage that diverged over 1.5 Ma. The terminal decline post-LGM was not correlated with human population expansion but with increased climatic volatility inferred from paleoclimatic proxies. Our paleogenomic data suggest that extreme climatic instability, rather than direct human overkill, was the primary driver of this iconic megafauna's extinction.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Reconstruction of Late Pleistocene Woolly Rhinoceros (Coelodonta antiquitatis) Demography Reveals Introgression and Climatic Decline

text: Antagonistic coevolution is hypothesized to maintain genetic polymorphism via negative frequency-dependent selection (NFDS), a cornerstone of Red Queen dynamics. We tested this hypothesis directly using resurrection ecology, reviving dormant eggs of the water flea Daphnia longispina and spores of its parasite Pasteuria ramosa from dated sediment core layers spanning 20 years. Whole-genome sequencing of resurrected host and parasite populations revealed temporally lagged cyclical dynamics in allele frequencies at key host immune loci (e.g., pattern recognition receptors) and parasite infectivity loci (e.g., spore-surface glycoproteins). Time-shift infection assays confirmed that parasites were most infective against common contemporary host genotypes and least infective against future common genotypes. This demonstrates a persistent coevolutionary arms race driven by strong NFDS, providing empirical genomic evidence for the Red Queen process as a powerful mechanism for the long-term maintenance of host and parasite genetic diversity in natural ecosystems.
subject: Evrim
title: Time-Shifted Genomic Analyses Uncover Negative Frequency-Dependent Selection in a Daphnia-Parasite Coevolutionary Arms Race

text: The evolution of eusociality, characterized by reproductive division of labor, is classically explained by kin selection theory. However, this framework often overlooks intragenomic conflict between maternally and paternally derived alleles. We investigated this conflict's role in the primitively eusocial sweat bee, Lasioglossum albipes, using parent-specific expression analysis (PSE) in developing queen and worker larvae. We identified over 200 genes exhibiting significant parent-of-origin expression bias, many of which are homologues of known insect growth and development regulators like Insulin/TOR pathway components. Critically, we observed a significant excess of paternally expressed genes promoting worker-like traits and maternally expressed genes promoting queen-like development, consistent with theoretical predictions of parental conflict over caste fate. Our results suggest that the evolutionary trajectory towards obligate eusociality is not merely a consequence of maximizing inclusive fitness but is also shaped by the resolution of this profound intragenomic conflict.
subject: Evrim
title: Intragenomic Conflict Over Caste Determination Underpins the Evolutionary Trajectory of Eusociality in Halictid Bees

text: Convergent evolution provides powerful evidence for adaptation, yet its molecular underpinnings are often complex. We performed a large-scale comparative phylogenomic analysis across 63 avian genomes, including 15 high-altitude lineages, to identify the molecular basis of convergent adaptation to hypoxia. Using codon-based models of evolution and controlling for phylogenetic non-independence, we detected strong signals of recurrent positive selection in two key genes of the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) pathway: EGLN1 (prolyl hydroxylase 2) and EPAS1 (HIF-2α). We identified multiple parallel amino acid substitutions at specific, functionally important sites within these proteins across independent high-altitude radiations. These recurrent substitutions, confirmed to alter protein function in vitro, indicate that adaptation to high-altitude environments is highly predictable at the molecular level. The evolution of hypoxia tolerance in birds has repeatedly navigated a constrained adaptive landscape, targeting the same regulatory pathway to achieve a convergent physiological phenotype.
subject: Evrim
title: Recurrent Adaptive Substitutions in the Hypoxia-Inducible Factor Pathway Facilitated Convergent Evolution of High-Altitude Homeostasis in Avians

text: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a primary driver of prokaryotic evolution, but its role in shaping eukaryotic genomes is considered more limited. Here, we challenge this view through single-cell genomics and metagenomics of benthic foraminifera from an anoxic marine basin. We assembled near-complete genomes for three species of the genus Stainforthia, revealing a mosaic architecture. Phylogenetic analyses demonstrate that over 10% of their protein-coding genes are of bacterial or archaeal origin, acquired through multiple independent HGT events. These laterally acquired genes are not randomly distributed but are functionally integrated into core metabolic pathways, including denitrification and anaerobic respiration, which are absent in their aerobic relatives. This massive influx of prokaryotic genes has fundamentally reconfigured foraminiferal metabolism, enabling their colonization and diversification within oxygen-depleted environments. Our findings posit HGT as a major, underappreciated engine of metabolic innovation and adaptive radiation in microbial eukaryotes.
subject: Evrim
title: Massive Prokaryotic-to-Eukaryotic Horizontal Gene Transfer Drove the Metabolic Diversification of Anaerobic Foraminifera

text: Macroevolutionary patterns of long-term morphological stasis present a challenge to conventional microevolutionary theory. We investigated the stasis observed in the Devonian trilobite Phacops rana over a 5-million-year interval using high-resolution 3D geometric morphometrics and homology-based inference of developmental gene regulatory networks. Our morphometric analysis of 350 fossil specimens reveals that despite environmental fluctuations, phenotypic variation was highly constrained along a single, dominant axis of allometric change. The cephalic and pygidial tagmata showed exceptionally low morphological disparity. Comparative analysis of inferred developmental gene expression domains, based on conserved arthropod patterning, indicates deep conservation of the Hox and segment polarity gene networks. We propose that strong developmental canalization, governed by a deeply entrenched and pleiotropic gene regulatory architecture, rather than persistent stabilizing selection, was the primary mechanism buffering the Phacops bauplan against evolutionary change, thus providing a developmental-genetic explanation for punctuated equilibrium.
subject: Evrim
title: Geometric Morphometrics and Developmental Gene Expression in Devonian Trilobites Support a Model of Canalization-Driven Morphological Stasis

text: Complex sexual ornaments are key to understanding sexual selection, but their genetic basis remains poorly understood. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) for carotenoid-based plumage coloration in a wild, pedigreed population of 1,200 house finches (Haemorhous mexicanus). The trait is highly polygenic, with over 300 loci of small effect collectively explaining 45% of the phenotypic variance. Genes at associated loci were enriched for functions in lipid transport and oxidative stress response, supporting the condition-dependence hypothesis. However, we uncovered significant evidence for sexual antagonism: a polygenic score for high male coloration was negatively correlated with key female fitness components, including clutch size and lifespan, likely due to widespread pleiotropy. These findings indicate that the evolution of this canonical sexual ornament is constrained not only by its honesty-signaling function but also by intralocus sexual conflict, which may limit its response to directional selection and maintain genetic variation.
subject: Evrim
title: The Polygenic Architecture of a Nuptial Plumage Trait Reveals Widespread Pleiotropy and Sexual Antagonism in a Passerine

text: The transition to multicellularity is one of the major evolutionary innovations, yet its initial genetic steps are difficult to resolve. We subjected the unicellular flagellate Chlamydomonas reinhardtii to long-term daily selection for increased size via gravitational settling. Within 500 generations, all 10 replicate populations evolved obligately clonal multicellular clusters, or 'snowflake' phenotypes. Whole-genome sequencing of evolved clones from independent lineages revealed a striking pattern of convergent evolution: a majority of lineages acquired mutations within a single gene encoding a membrane-anchored protein containing a conserved cadherin-like domain. Re-introduction of the most common non-synonymous substitution via CRISPR-Cas9 into the ancestral strain was sufficient to induce facultative cell-cell adhesion. This result indicates that a single point mutation in a pre-existing cell adhesion domain acted as a key potentiating step, creating the necessary phenotypic substrate upon which subsequent modifiers for more complex organismal integration could act.
subject: Evrim
title: Experimental Evolution of De Novo Multicellularity Identifies a Conserved Cadherin Domain as a Potentiating Locus for Clonal Aggregation

text: Standard F0 estimation algorithms, optimized for 12-tone equal temperament (12-TET), exhibit significant fallibility when analyzing microtonal music. This paper introduces a hybrid architecture for fundamental frequency estimation that combines a deep convolutional neural network (CNN) with a probabilistic YIN estimator (pYIN) to accurately capture cents-level pitch deviations. The model is trained on a novel, expertly annotated corpus of Turkish Makam and Persian Dastgâh performances. Pre-processing via spectral reassignment sharpens harmonic peaks, providing a more robust input to the CNN feature extractor. Our hybrid approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art multi-pitch estimators, demonstrating a lower gross error rate and higher accuracy in identifying the precise intervallic structures central to these modal traditions. This methodology facilitates more nuanced computational musicology, enabling large-scale analysis of microtonal systems previously intractable due to the constraints of Western-centric analytical tools.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hybrid Deep Learning-Probabilistic Model for Microtonal F0 Estimation in Non-Western Musics

text: The perceptual space of musical timbre remains a challenging domain for quantitative modeling. This research employs a β-Variational Autoencoder (β-VAE) to learn a disentangled latent representation of instrumental timbre from audio signals. The model was trained on a comprehensive feature set, including Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs) and spectral centroids, derived from the RWC Musical Instrument Sound Database. Through controlled manipulation of the β hyperparameter, we achieve a latent space where individual dimensions correspond strongly to orthogonal semantic descriptors (e.g., brightness, roughness, attack sharpness) as validated by correlation with subjective listening tests. We demonstrate the model's generative utility by interpolating between disparate points in the latent space to synthesize novel, perceptually coherent timbres. This framework provides a robust mapping between acoustic features and timbral semantics, offering new pathways for automatic orchestration, sound morphing, and perceptually-aware audio synthesis.
subject: Müzik
title: Modeling Timbral Semantics: A Disentangled Representation via β-Variational Autoencoders

text: Schenkerian analysis, a cornerstone of tonal music theory, has largely resisted computational automation due to its reliance on expert intuition. This paper presents a novel system for generating Schenkerian graphs from symbolic music representations (MusicXML). Our approach employs a probabilistic context-free grammar (PCFG) whose rules are informed by the well-formedness principles of Lerdahl and Jackendoff's Generative Theory of Tonal Music (GTTM). The system parses musical surfaces to infer hierarchical prolongational structures, recursively identifying elaborations of fundamental harmonic and melodic paradigms. When tested on a ground-truth corpus of J.S. Bach chorales annotated by multiple experts, our algorithm generates plausible middleground (Mittelgrund) and background (Hintergrund) reductions that achieve a high F1-score for structural event detection. This work represents a significant step toward bridging qualitative music theory with quantitative computational methods, enabling scalable structural analysis of large tonal corpora.
subject: Müzik
title: Automating Schenkerian Analysis: A Probabilistic Context-Free Grammar Approach to Hierarchical Structure

text: This study investigates the intricate coupling between a performer's physical gestures and the resulting acoustic signal. We utilize Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCA) to explore the shared variance between two high-dimensional data streams: kinematic data from motion-capture of a concert pianist's hands and torso, and a corresponding audio feature space comprising spectral flux, onset detection functions, loudness estimates, and MFCCs. The analysis was performed on a corpus of Chopin mazurkas, known for their expressive temporal flexibility. The resulting canonical variates reveal strong, statistically significant correlations linking specific kinematic parameters to acoustic attributes. For instance, we found a primary mode of covariance linking wrist velocity and finger articulation height to note-level staccato and micro-dynamic shaping. These findings provide empirical evidence for the deeply embodied nature of musical expression, challenging analytical paradigms that treat the acoustic signal in isolation from its biomechanical genesis.
subject: Müzik
title: Embodied Expression: Cross-Modal Analysis of Pianistic Gesture and Acoustic Performance via Canonical Correlation

text: This paper proposes a novel geometric framework for the analysis of harmonic progressions by applying non-linear dimensionality reduction to audio features. We utilize the Isomap algorithm to learn a low-dimensional manifold from a high-dimensional space of beat-synchronous chromagrams extracted from the McGill Billboard corpus. Each point on the resulting manifold represents a specific chord, with geodesic distances corresponding to perceptually and theoretically informed measures of harmonic distance. The emergent geometric structure reveals clusters and pathways that align remarkably well with established music-theoretic concepts, including the circle of fifths, diatonic functional relationships, and neo-Riemannian parsimonious voice-leading. Trajectories through this 'harmonic space' provide a powerful visualization of syntactical flow in popular music. This approach offers a unified model that captures principles from disparate harmonic theories within a single, empirically-derived geometric representation, enabling new modes of comparative and stylistic analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Geometric Modeling of Harmonic Syntax: Manifold Learning on Chromagram Vector Spaces

text: Unsupervised source separation remains a formidable challenge in audio signal processing, particularly for complex polyphonic mixtures. We introduce a novel hierarchical Bayesian model for Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) designed for this task. The framework posits that instrument-specific spectral templates are drawn from a shared Gamma Process prior, which allows the model to learn instrument dictionaries while simultaneously adapting to timbral variations within each source class. This Hierarchical Gamma Process NMF (HGP-NMF) approach avoids the need for extensive supervised training data. Evaluated on the MedleyDB dataset, our unsupervised method achieves signal separation quality (measured by Signal-to-Distortion Ratio, SDR) competitive with, and in some instrument-class cases superior to, contemporary supervised deep learning architectures. The model's probabilistic nature also provides a principled measure of uncertainty for the separated components, advancing the state-of-the-art in robust, unsupervised music information retrieval.
subject: Müzik
title: Unsupervised Polyphonic Source Separation using a Hierarchical Gamma Process NMF Model

text: Existing metrics for rhythmic complexity often conflate syncopation with structural intricacy and fail to generalize across diverse musical cultures. This paper introduces a more robust, perceptually-grounded metric based on the Lempel-Ziv (LZ76) compression algorithm. We define rhythmic complexity as the ratio of a rhythm's Kolmogorov complexity (approximated by the size of its LZ-compressed inter-onset interval sequence) to its Shannon entropy. This Lempel-Ziv/Entropy Ratio (LZER) quantifies the degree of structural redundancy relative to the rhythm's unpredictability. We validate LZER against expert human ratings of rhythmic complexity across a stylistically diverse corpus including Bebop jazz solos, Balkan folk dances, and minimalist compositions. Results show that LZER significantly outperforms established metrics like the syncopation index of Longuet-Higgins and Lee, providing a more nuanced and culturally-agnostic tool for computational rhythm analysis and music cognition research.
subject: Müzik
title: An Information-Theoretic Metric for Rhythmic Complexity Based on Lempel-Ziv Compression

text: In many genres of electronic dance music (EDM), formal structure is conveyed as much through textural evolution as through harmonic progression. Conventional segmentation algorithms that rely solely on harmonic features often fail in this context. We propose a dual-stream recurrent neural network (RNN) with an attention mechanism for robust EDM segmentation. One stream, a GRU, processes a sequence of spectro-temporal features (e.g., spectral novelty, MFCCs) to model textural dynamics. The second stream processes beat-synchronous chroma features to model harmonic content. A subsequent attention layer learns to dynamically weight the importance of each stream for predicting formal boundaries. Evaluated on a large corpus of annotated EDM tracks, our model significantly improves F-scores over single-modality baselines. The attention weights provide interpretability, revealing that the model correctly prioritizes textural cues for 'breakdown' sections and harmonic cues for 'chorus' sections, thus effectively disentangling form and texture.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangling Form and Texture in Electronic Music via a Dual-Stream Attentional RNN

text: Accurate alignment between an audio performance and its symbolic score is a prerequisite for computational analysis of expressive timing, dynamics, and articulation. Traditional Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) methods using chroma features are brittle in the face of significant ornamentation or timbral variation. This paper presents a novel alignment methodology wherein DTW operates on a cross-modal similarity matrix derived from a learned embedding space. A Siamese convolutional neural network is trained using triplet loss to project short audio frames and symbolic note representations (encoded as piano-roll images) into a shared latent space. In this space, the Euclidean distance between an audio excerpt and its corresponding score segment is minimized. This learned-distance DTW demonstrates unprecedented robustness to extreme rubato, agogic accentuation, and non-notated ornamentation, achieving a 20% reduction in alignment error on the MazurkaBL dataset compared to state-of-the-art chroma-based approaches.
subject: Müzik
title: Robust Audio-to-Score Alignment Using a Learned Cross-Modal Embedding Space for DTW

text: Tonal music theory traditionally treats pitch and timbre as orthogonal parameters. This study challenges that axiom by investigating how a sound's intrinsic spectral characteristics influence its perceived harmonic function. We conducted a large-scale listening experiment where participants rated the perceived stability of tones with systematically varied timbres when placed within a C major diatonic context. The synthesized timbres were controlled for various acoustic features, including inharmonicity, spectral centroid, and spectral irregularity. Using partial least squares regression (PLSR), we modeled the relationship between these timbral features and the stability ratings. The analysis revealed a highly significant predictor: the inherent sensory dissonance of a timbre's partial series, calculated using the Plomp-Levelt model. Timbres with more harmonically consonant partial structures were consistently perceived as more tonally stable, irrespective of their scale degree. These results provide strong empirical evidence that timbre is not tonally neutral but actively participates in shaping harmonic perception.
subject: Müzik
title: The Tonality of Timbre: Empirical Links Between Spectral Dissonance and Perceived Harmonic Stability

text: We explore the profound connection between quantum entanglement and spacetime geometry, motivated by the ER=EPR conjecture. This work presents a theoretical framework wherein the connectivity of a holographic spacetime is derived directly from the entanglement structure of a boundary conformal field theory (CFT). We employ tensor network models, specifically the Multiscale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (MERA), as a discrete realization of the AdS/CFT correspondence. Our analysis demonstrates that the geodesic distance between two boundary regions is proportional to the minimal number of tensor disentanglers required to separate them, providing a concrete algorithmic interpretation of the Ryu-Takayanagi formula for holographic entanglement entropy. We further investigate the consequences for spacetime dynamics, showing how local perturbations in the entanglement structure manifest as gravitational ripples in the bulk geometry. This research reinforces the paradigm that spacetime is not fundamental but rather an emergent property of the underlying quantum information of a holographic system.
subject: Kuantum
title: Geometric Entanglement and Spacetime Emergence from ER=EPR

text: The realization of non-Abelian anyons is a paramount objective for developing fault-tolerant topological quantum computation. We theoretically investigate the braiding statistics of Majorana zero modes (MZMs) in a Y-junction network of hybrid InAs semiconductor nanowires proximity-coupled to an s-wave superconductor. By solving the Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations self-consistently within this complex geometry, we map the phase diagram as a function of external magnetic field and chemical potential, identifying a robust topological phase hosting localized MZMs at the wire ends. We perform numerical simulations of adiabatic braiding operations by manipulating gate voltages to shuttle the MZMs. The resulting non-Abelian statistics are confirmed by calculating the unitary transformation on the degenerate ground-state manifold, which is shown to be proportional to the generators of the braid group. Our findings demonstrate the feasibility of performing topological qubit rotations and provide a blueprint for constructing scalable non-Abelian quantum computing architectures.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Braiding Statistics of Majorana Zero Modes in a Hybrid Superconductor-Semiconductor Nanowire Network

text: We propose and analyze a scheme for realizing a two-dimensional topological insulator with ultracold fermionic atoms in a periodically modulated optical lattice. The system is described by a time-dependent Hubbard model, where a circular shaking of the lattice potential opens a non-trivial band gap at the Dirac points of the honeycomb lattice's Floquet quasi-energy spectrum. By calculating the Bott index, a topological invariant for driven systems, we demonstrate the emergence of a robust quantum Hall-like state without an external magnetic field. We characterize the topologically protected, chiral edge states and their resilience to local perturbations and interaction effects. Our analysis, based on Floquet theory and time-dependent density matrix renormalization group simulations, establishes a viable pathway for dynamically controlling topological phases of matter and engineering exotic quantum states with applications in spintronics and quantum information processing.
subject: Kuantum
title: A Floquet-Engineered Topological Insulator in a Driven Optical Lattice

text: The interplay between periodic driving, disorder, and interactions can lead to novel non-equilibrium phases of matter. We investigate the dynamics of a one-dimensional spin-1/2 Heisenberg chain subjected to a quasiperiodic potential and a high-frequency periodic drive. Using large-scale time-dependent variational principle simulations, we demonstrate the existence of a stable many-body localized (MBL) phase that resists thermalization. In this phase, the entanglement entropy exhibits a characteristic slow, logarithmic growth in time following a quantum quench, a key signature of MBL. We further identify a long-lived prethermal state governed by an effective time-independent Floquet Hamiltonian.
