Perturbation of the BRD4 IDR dissolves these condensates and abrogates the characteristic transcriptional bursting of SE-driven genes like MYC. Our findings propose that phase separation of BRD4 provides a physical basis for the formation of transcriptional hubs at super-enhancers, potentiating robust gene expression.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of the Transcription Factor BRD4 at Super-Enhancers Creates Dynamic Hubs for Transcriptional Condensate Formation and Gene Bursting

text: We introduce a novel framework for gradient-based meta-learning that accelerates adaptation to new tasks by optimizing the inner-loop learning process itself. Current methods, such as MAML, employ a fixed, manually-tuned optimizer for task-specific fine-tuning. Our approach, termed Hyper-Solver Meta-Learning (HS-ML), parameterizes the inner-loop solver using a small hypernetwork that dynamically generates optimal solver parameters conditioned on task-specific gradient information. The hypernetwork is trained concurrently with the meta-parameters via a bilevel optimization objective, maximizing the outer-loop meta-objective. This allows the model to learn an optimal, non-stationary optimization trajectory for few-shot adaptation. We derive an efficient training algorithm using implicit differentiation to bypass computationally expensive second-order derivatives. Empirical validation on challenging few-shot regression and classification benchmarks, including Mini-ImageNet and Tiered-ImageNet, demonstrates that HS-ML achieves superior asymptotic performance and faster convergence compared to state-of-the-art meta-learning algorithms, effectively learning to learn how to optimize.
subject: AI
title: Gradient-Based Meta-Learning with Hyper-Solvers for Accelerated Task Adaptation

text: This paper addresses the critical privacy-utility trade-off in cross-silo federated learning, particularly under non-IID data distributions. We propose a novel adaptive framework, Federated Learning with Calibrated Rényi Differential Privacy (FL-CRDP), that dynamically allocates the privacy budget (ε, δ) based on client-level data heterogeneity and contribution significance. Unlike traditional approaches that apply a uniform privacy guarantee, our method uses a meta-learning agent to predict the sensitivity of model updates, enabling finer-grained noise calibration via the Gaussian mechanism. The calibration is optimized to minimize the impact on the global model's convergence while satisfying rigorous Rényi Differential Privacy constraints. We provide a formal privacy proof for our adaptive mechanism and demonstrate through extensive experiments on federated benchmarks like FEMNIST and Shakespeare that FL-CRDP significantly outperforms standard DP-FedAvg and other adaptive privacy methods, achieving higher model accuracy for equivalent or stronger privacy guarantees, thereby enabling more effective and secure collaborative machine learning.
subject: AI
title: Optimizing Privacy-Utility Trade-offs in Federated Learning via Calibrated Rényi Differential Privacy

text: The prohibitive size of Large Language Models (LLMs) impedes their deployment on resource-constrained devices. We propose a novel compression methodology based on quantum-inspired Tensor Ring (TR) decomposition, which factorizes the high-dimensional weight tensors of transformer layers into a circular product of smaller, three-dimensional cores. This approach exploits the low-rank structure inherent in the parameter space, achieving an exponential reduction in parameter count relative to the number of decomposed dimensions. We introduce an efficient, layer-wise TR factorization algorithm based on sequential singular value decomposition and a variational fine-tuning stage that jointly optimizes the TR cores to recover performance loss from the initial compression. Applied to BERT and T5 architectures, our method achieves compression ratios exceeding 95% with minimal degradation in perplexity and downstream task performance on the GLUE benchmark. This work demonstrates the viability of tensor network methods for creating highly efficient, portable LLMs.
subject: AI
title: Compressing Large Language Models using Quantum-Inspired Tensor Ring Networks

text: We present a neuro-symbolic agent designed to discover the underlying structural causal model (SCM) of an environment through efficient, targeted interventions. The agent integrates a deep reinforcement learning (RL) policy with a symbolic causal reasoning module. The RL component, trained via proximal policy optimization, proposes interventions to maximize information gain about the causal graph structure. The symbolic module maintains a posterior distribution over possible directed acyclic graphs (DAGs), which is updated using a Bayesian approach upon observing the outcomes of interventions. This tight coupling allows the symbolic reasoner to guide the RL agent's exploration, pruning the intervention space and avoiding redundant experiments. We validate our framework on a suite of benchmark causal discovery tasks, demonstrating that it learns ground-truth SCMs with significantly higher sample efficiency and accuracy than purely neural or traditional constraint-based causal discovery methods, offering a robust approach to autonomous scientific discovery.
subject: AI
title: Causal Disentanglement via Neuro-Symbolic Reinforcement Learning for Structural Model Induction

text: The generation of realistic, high-dimensional medical data is crucial for data augmentation and privacy-preserving sharing. We introduce a novel generative model, the Latent Diffusion-Generative Adversarial Network (LD-GAN), specifically for synthesizing 3D volumetric medical images like CT and MRI scans. Our model operates in a compressed latent space learned by a variational autoencoder to ensure computational tractability. The core of our contribution is a hybrid generator architecture that combines a denoising diffusion process for robust mode coverage with a GAN framework for enhanced sample fidelity. This generator incorporates 3D self-attention mechanisms to effectively capture long-range spatial dependencies inherent in anatomical structures. Quantitative evaluations using Fréchet Inception Distance and qualitative assessments by expert radiologists on the BraTS and LIDC-IDRI datasets show that LD-GAN synthesizes images with superior detail and anatomical plausibility compared to state-of-the-art GANs and diffusion models, setting a new benchmark for synthetic medical data generation.
subject: AI
title: High-Fidelity Synthesis of Volumetric Medical Images using Latent Diffusion-GANs with 3D-Attention Mechanisms

text: Reliable uncertainty estimation is paramount for deploying neural networks in safety-critical applications. We introduce a novel, scalable framework for Bayesian inference in deep neural networks that combines functional priors with amortized variational inference. Traditional Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs) often rely on simplistic, factorized priors in weight space, limiting their expressive power. Our method specifies priors directly over the function space using Gaussian Processes, which induces a rich, non-diagonal covariance structure in the weight space. To circumvent the computational intractability of posterior inference, we employ an amortized inference network that learns a direct mapping from data to the parameters of the variational distribution. This avoids costly iterative optimization per data point. Experiments on out-of-distribution detection and regression tasks demonstrate that our model provides better-calibrated and more robust uncertainty estimates than deep ensembles, MC-Dropout, and mean-field BNNs, while maintaining computational efficiency.
subject: AI
title: Scalable Uncertainty Quantification in Bayesian Neural Networks via Amortized Stochastic Variational Inference with Functional Priors

text: We introduce HyperMoco, a self-supervised framework for learning rich node representations from heterogeneous hypergraphs, which capture complex, multi-way relationships between entities of different types. Existing graph contrastive learning methods are designed for pairwise edges and homogeneous nodes, failing to leverage the higher-order and heterogeneous information in hypergraphs. HyperMoco addresses this by creating two distinct, correlated views of the input hypergraph. One view is generated by structural augmentations (e.g., hyperedge masking), while the other is formed through modality-specific feature perturbations. It then maximizes the agreement between these views using a momentum-based contrastive learning objective, which allows for a large dictionary of negative samples without excessive memory requirements. On several real-world heterogeneous hypergraph datasets, pre-training with HyperMoco and fine-tuning on downstream tasks like node classification and link prediction yields new state-of-the-art results, demonstrating its efficacy in capturing complex relational structures.
subject: AI
title: Self-Supervised Contrastive Learning on Heterogeneous Hypergraphs via Multi-Modal View Generation

text: This work introduces Geodesic Adversarial Training (GAT), a novel defense mechanism that leverages the intrinsic geometry of the data manifold to improve adversarial robustness. Standard adversarial training methods, like PGD, generate perturbations in the ambient Euclidean space, which may not align with the underlying data distribution. In contrast, GAT synthesizes adversarial examples by approximating geodesics on the data manifold, which is locally modeled using a Riemannian metric derived from the Jacobian of the neural network's feature extractor. This forces the model to learn a decision boundary that is robust to more plausible, on-manifold perturbations. We further introduce a manifold-aware regularization term that promotes local isometry, discouraging distortions in the learned feature space. Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and ImageNet demonstrate that GAT significantly enhances robustness against a wide array of white-box and black-box attacks, surpassing state-of-the-art defenses like TRADES and PGD-AT.
subject: AI
title: Geodesic Adversarial Training: Enhancing Model Robustness through Manifold Regularization

text: We propose a hybrid deep learning architecture, the Physics-Informed Spatiotemporal Graph Network (PI-STGN), for accurate and physically consistent long-range climate forecasting. The model represents the Earth's surface as a graph, where nodes are grid points and edges encode dynamic dependencies. It integrates a graph convolutional network (GCN) to capture complex spatial teleconnections and a gated recurrent unit (GRU) to model temporal evolution. The key innovation is the incorporation of a physics-informed loss term that penalizes deviations from known physical laws, such as the conservation of mass and energy, formulated as soft constraints based on discretized partial differential equations (PDEs). This regularization guides the learning process towards physically plausible solutions, mitigating overfitting and improving generalization beyond the training data distribution. Evaluated on the ERA5 reanalysis dataset for forecasting temperature and geopotential height, PI-STGN demonstrates superior skill and physical consistency over purely data-driven baselines and establishes a new benchmark for deep learning-based weather prediction.
subject: AI
title: Physics-Informed Spatiotemporal Graph Convolutional Networks for Multi-Step Climate Forecasting

text: We introduce a novel continual learning framework, Hebbian-Gated Rehearsal Memory (HGRM), designed to mitigate catastrophic forgetting in neural networks. Inspired by synaptic plasticity, HGRM utilizes a small, dynamically managed memory buffer for experience rehearsal. A key component is a Hebbian-based gating mechanism that selectively stores samples that are both informative and diverse, thus maximizing the utility of the limited memory budget. This gate prioritizes experiences that induce significant gradient updates, indicative of surprising or novel information. Furthermore, during rehearsal, we employ a task-aware regularization scheme that modulates plasticity based on parameter importance estimates derived from the Fisher Information Matrix, protecting knowledge critical for past tasks. Through extensive experiments on challenging benchmarks like Split-CIFAR-100 and a 5-task CUB-200 sequence, HGRM demonstrates superior performance in knowledge retention and forward transfer compared to leading continual learning methods, including GEM and AGEM, while requiring a smaller memory footprint.
subject: AI
title: Overcoming Catastrophic Forgetting in Continual Learning via Hebbian-Gated Rehearsal Memory

text: Transcriptional regulation in eukaryotes is orchestrated by distal enhancers, yet the mechanism coupling enhancer activity to promoter firing remains elusive. Here, we demonstrate that the bromodomain protein BRD4 and the Mediator complex subunit MED1 undergo liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) to form transcriptional condensates at super-enhancers. Using super-resolution microscopy and chromosome conformation capture (Hi-C), we show these biomolecular condensates are dynamic, spatially distinct nuclear bodies that stabilize enhancer-promoter loops. Perturbation of phase separation via mutagenesis of intrinsically disordered regions in BRD4 abrogates loop stability and diminishes transcriptional output. Furthermore, single-molecule fluorescence in situ hybridization (smFISH) reveals that condensate formation directly correlates with an increase in transcriptional burst frequency, rather than burst size. Our findings posit that LLPS of key transcriptional coactivators serves as a physical principle for concentrating the transcriptional machinery, thereby tuning the kinetics of gene expression in a stochastic nuclear environment.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of BRD4 and MED1 Modulates Enhancer-Promoter Looping and Transcriptional Bursting

text: CRISPR-based epigenome editing offers a powerful tool for modulating gene expression, but achieving long-term, heritable silencing remains a significant challenge. We have engineered a tripartite fusion effector, dCas9-KRAB-MeCP2, designed to initiate and lock in a silenced chromatin state. The KRAB domain initiates heterochromatin formation via recruitment of KAP1 and SETDB1, leading to H3K9 trimethylation (H3K9me3). Subsequently, the fused MeCP2 domain binds to the de novo methylated DNA, which is a downstream consequence of the H3K9me3 mark, and recruits histone deacetylase complexes to reinforce a repressive state. Using this system to target the MYC oncogene promoter, we demonstrate robust and durable silencing that persists through multiple cell divisions even after cessation of dCas9-KRAB-MeCP2 expression. ChIP-seq and ATAC-seq analyses confirm progressive heterochromatin spreading from the target locus, establishing a mitotically stable epigenetic memory. This 'initiate-and-lock' strategy provides a novel therapeutic avenue for permanently silencing disease-associated genes.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Durable Silencing of Oncogenic Loci via dCas9-KRAB-MeCP2 Mediated Heterochromatin Spreading

text: Cellular adaptation to hypoxia requires rapid proteomic remodeling, much of which is controlled at the level of mRNA translation. To dissect these mechanisms globally, we performed ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) coupled with parallel RNA-seq on human endothelial cells subjected to acute hypoxia. Our analysis revealed a dramatic uncoupling of transcription and translation, with hundreds of mRNAs exhibiting altered translational efficiency. A predominant mechanism of repression was the increased translation of upstream open reading frames (uORFs), which sterically inhibits initiation at the main protein-coding sequence. We identified novel uORF-regulated transcripts critical for cell survival, including the vascular permeability factor ANGPTL4. This regulation is contingent upon GCN2-mediated phosphorylation of eIF2α. These data provide a high-resolution map of the hypoxic translatome and establish uORF-mediated translational control as a pervasive and critical node in the cellular response to oxygen deprivation, offering new targets for modulating ischemic injury.
subject: Biyoloji
title: System-wide Analysis of Translational Reprogramming During Hypoxic Stress Reveals Pervasive uORF-mediated Regulation

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are emerging as critical architects of nuclear organization. During X-chromosome inactivation (XCI), the lncRNA Xist initiates silencing, but how the inactive X (Xi) establishes its unique compact structure remains unclear. Here, we identify the lncRNA *Firre* as a key structural component that tethers the Xi to the nuclear periphery. Using RNA antisense purification coupled with mass spectrometry (RAP-MS), we show that *Firre* directly interacts with both the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) and the inner nuclear membrane protein Lamin B1. Chromosome conformation capture (4C-seq) demonstrates that *Firre* depletion disrupts long-range contacts on the Xi and detaches it from the lamina. Consequently, H3K27me3 marks, deposited by PRC2, are improperly distributed, leading to leaky expression of X-linked genes. Our results reveal *Firre* as a molecular scaffold that physically links chromatin modifiers to a specific nuclear subdomain, thereby defining the spatial topography of facultative heterochromatin.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The lncRNA Firre Orchestrates X-Chromosome Inactivation Topography by Anchoring the PRC2 Complex to the Nuclear Lamina

text: Understanding cell fate decisions during organogenesis requires dissecting the interplay between chromatin accessibility and gene expression at single-cell resolution. We generated a joint single-cell ATAC-seq and RNA-seq dataset from murine embryonic pancreatic tissue to reconstruct the developmental trajectory of islet cell lineages. By integrating these multi-omic modalities, we identified a transient, multipotent progenitor state characterized by broad chromatin accessibility at lineage-specific enhancer elements. Pseudotemporal ordering revealed that commitment to alpha- or beta-cell fates is preceded by changes in the accessibility of distal regulatory elements bound by key transcription factors, including ARX and PDX1, respectively. This epigenomic priming event occurs prior to detectable divergence in the corresponding transcriptomes. Our high-resolution developmental map uncovers the regulatory logic of cell fate bifurcation and demonstrates that epigenetic plasticity is a critical determinant of endocrine cell specification, providing a valuable resource for regenerative medicine.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated Single-Cell Transcriptomic and Epigenomic Atlas Unveils Bifurcation Dynamics During Pancreatic Islet Development

text: The choice between non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) and homology-directed repair (HDR) for DNA double-strand breaks is a critical determinant of genome stability. The protein 53BP1 promotes NHEJ and inhibits end resection, a prerequisite for HDR. Here, we elucidate a molecular switch that antagonizes 53BP1 function. We show that following ATM-mediated phosphorylation of 53BP1 on serine 1778 within its ubiquitination-dependent recruitment motif, the E3 ligase RNF168 is recruited. RNF168 subsequently deposits K63-linked ubiquitin chains directly onto 53BP1. Using in vitro reconstitution and cell-based assays, we demonstrate this ubiquitination sterically hinders the interaction of 53BP1 with its downstream effector RIF1, effectively dismantling the inhibitory complex. This exposes the DNA end, allowing BRCA1 and CtIP to initiate resection and commit the cell to HDR. This phosphorylation-ubiquitination cascade represents a key regulatory node that fine-tunes DNA repair pathway choice based on cell cycle context and chromatin state.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phosphorylation-dependent Ubiquitination of 53BP1 by RNF168 Governs the NHEJ-to-HDR Switch

text: The glucagon receptor (GCGR) is a class B G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) crucial for glucose homeostasis and a major target for type 2 diabetes therapies. Understanding its activation mechanism has been hampered by a lack of high-resolution structural information. Here, we present the 2.8 Å resolution cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of the full-length human GCGR bound to its cognate Gs protein, glucagon, and a novel positive allosteric modulator (PAM), NNC0640. The structure reveals that the PAM binds to a previously unknown cavity at the extracellular-transmembrane interface, distant from the orthosteric peptide-binding site. PAM binding induces a subtle conformational rearrangement in transmembrane helix 6 and 7, which stabilizes the receptor in an active state and enhances Gs-protein coupling efficiency. This allosteric mechanism provides a structural blueprint for designing biased agonists and modulators with improved therapeutic profiles for metabolic diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Class B GPCR Glucagon Receptor in Complex with Gs and a Positive Allosteric Modulator

text: N6-methyladenosine (m6A) is the most abundant internal modification on eukaryotic mRNA, dynamically regulating mRNA fate. Its role in tumorigenesis is increasingly apparent but remains mechanistically ill-defined. We investigated the m6A landscape in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and found significant upregulation of the m6A methyltransferase METTL3. By performing m6A-sequencing and integrating it with transcriptome analysis of patient-derived xenografts, we identified a cohort of tumor suppressor transcripts, including PTEN and SOCS2, that are hypermethylated in HCC. Using PAR-CLIP, we show these m6A-marked transcripts are preferentially recognized by the m6A 'reader' protein YTHDF2. This interaction recruits the CCR4-NOT deadenylase complex, leading to accelerated mRNA decay. Knockdown of either METTL3 or YTHDF2 in HCC cells restored the stability of these tumor suppressor mRNAs, reduced cell proliferation, and attenuated tumor growth in vivo. Our findings demonstrate that a dysregulated METTL3-YTHDF2 epitranscriptomic axis promotes oncogenesis by destabilizing key anti-cancer transcripts.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dysregulation of the METTL3-YTHDF2 Axis Accelerates mRNA Decay of Tumor Suppressors in Hepatocellular Carcinoma

text: Cullin-RING E3 ligases (CRLs) are the largest family of ubiquitin ligases, responsible for targeting a vast number of proteins for degradation. Their activity must be tightly regulated to prevent spurious ubiquitination. Using quantitative proteomics and hydrogen-deuterium exchange mass spectrometry (HDX-MS), we uncovered a novel autoinhibitory mechanism within the CRL4 complex containing the substrate receptor DCAF8. We found that binding of a bona fide substrate to DCAF8 induces a significant allosteric conformational change in a C-terminal helix of the receptor itself. This conformational switch weakens the DCAF8-DDB1 interface, decreasing the processivity of the ligase and preventing hyper-ubiquitination of the substrate. Mutating key residues in this C-terminal helix abrogates this feedback, leading to uncontrolled substrate degradation. This work reveals a substrate-centric negative feedback loop that ensures precise temporal control over protein turnover, adding a new layer of complexity to the regulation of the ubiquitin-proteasome system.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Autoinhibitory Feedback Loop in the CRL4-DCAF8 E3 Ligase Complex Regulated by Substrate-Induced Conformational Switching

text: A subset of cancers maintains telomere length through the Alternative Lengthening of Telomeres (ALT) pathway, a homology-directed repair mechanism. ALT relies on break-induced replication (BIR), but the molecular machinery that processes complex telomeric DNA structures to enable BIR remains poorly understood. Here, we identify the Fanconi Anemia Complementation Group M (FANCM) helicase as a critical component of the ALT mechanism. We show that FANCM is enriched at telomeres and co-localizes within ALT-associated PML bodies (APBs) specifically during the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle. Using in vitro helicase assays, we demonstrate that FANCM efficiently resolves G-quadruplex (G4) structures, which are prevalent at telomeres and are potent blocks to DNA replication. Depletion of FANCM in ALT-positive cells leads to increased replication fork stalling, C-circle accumulation indicative of telomeric stress, and eventual cell death. Our findings establish FANCM as a key G4-resolving helicase essential for BIR at telomeres, identifying it as a promising therapeutic target for ALT-dependent cancers.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The FANCM Helicase Resolves Telomeric G-Quadruplexes to Facilitate Break-Induced Replication in ALT-Positive Cancers

text: Meiotic drive systems, where selfish genetic elements bias their transmission into gametes, represent potent evolutionary forces creating intralocus conflict. We investigate the population genomics of the Segregation Distorter (SD) system in Drosophila simulans. Using whole-genome sequencing from multiple African populations, we identify a broad, non-recombining chromosomal inversion containing the driver locus, characterized by extremely low nucleotide diversity and a significant skew in the site-frequency spectrum, indicative of a recent selective sweep. We further identify several unlinked suppressor loci showing signatures of balancing selection, consistent with frequency-dependent dynamics predicted by antagonistic coevolution models. Haplotype network analysis reveals that resistance alleles have arisen multiple times independently. Our findings demonstrate how a meiotic driver can restructure genomic architecture and maintain polymorphism at responder loci, providing a compelling empirical example of Red Queen dynamics operating at the intragenomic level, shaping the evolutionary trajectory of host populations.
subject: Evrim
title: Intralocus Antagonistic Coevolution Driven by a Segregation Distorter in Drosophila simulans

text: Cryptic species complexes pose a significant challenge to biodiversity assessment and conservation. Here, we employ a phylogenomic approach using several thousand ultra-conserved elements (UCEs) to resolve the evolutionary history of the Amphiprion ocellaris clownfish complex. Bayesian species delimitation analyses robustly support the existence of three distinct, deeply divergent lineages previously unrecognized by morphological or mitochondrial markers. Our nuclear phylogeny reveals a pattern of cytonuclear discordance, where pervasive mitochondrial introgression has obscured species boundaries. Coalescent-based modeling indicates that this introgression is ancient and asymmetrical, likely following secondary contact after a period of allopatric divergence. Ecological niche modeling further demonstrates significant divergence in environmental tolerances among the delimited cryptic species, suggesting that ecological specialization has played a crucial role in their maintenance. This study underscores the power of genomic-scale data to unravel complex evolutionary histories masked by morphological stasis and mitochondrial gene flow.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Resolution of a Cryptic Species Complex Reveals Pervasive Mitochondrial Introgression and Ecological Divergence

text: Host-parasite interactions are classic models of antagonistic coevolution, often characterized by reciprocal selective pressures driving rapid molecular evolution at immunity loci. We investigated the immunogenetic architecture of the co-evolutionary arms race between passerine birds and haemosporidian parasites. Through comparative genomics across 50 avian species, we identified significant expansion and diversification of the Toll-like receptor (TLR) gene family, key components of the innate immune system’s Pattern Recognition Receptors (PRRs). Codon-based models of evolution revealed pervasive, episodic positive selection acting on specific codons within the extracellular leucine-rich repeat domains of TLR4 and TLR7, regions critical for pathogen recognition. Furthermore, the rate of TLR evolution was positively correlated with haemosporidian parasite prevalence and diversity. These results strongly suggest that parasite-mediated selection is a primary driver of PRR gene family dynamics, shaping the host's capacity to recognize and respond to a diverse parasite community.
subject: Evrim
title: Co-evolutionary Arms Race Dynamics Mediated by PRR Gene Family Expansion in an Avian-Haemosporidian System

text: The role of phenotypic plasticity in facilitating macroevolutionary innovation remains a central, yet contentious, topic in evolutionary biology. We investigated the link between developmental plasticity and the origin of insect wings using a comparative transcriptomic and functional genomic approach in Neopteran insects. By experimentally manipulating nymphal rearing density, a known plastic trait inducer, we uncovered a conserved gene regulatory network (GRN) involving vestigial (vg) and scalloped (sd) that is environmentally sensitive. Ancestral state reconstruction suggests this plastic response predates the evolution of powered flight. CRISPR-Cas9 knockdowns confirm that key nodes in this GRN are essential for wing pad development and exhibit altered expression profiles under different environmental cues. We propose a model of 'plasticity-first' evolution, where an ancestral, environmentally-induced protuberance was canalized and elaborated upon through genetic accommodation, providing the developmental substrate for the subsequent evolution of a major morphological novelty.
subject: Evrim
title: The Role of Environmentally-Induced Phenotypic Plasticity in Facilitating Macroevolutionary Transitions: A Neopteran Wing Development Model

text: Adaptive introgression, the transfer of beneficial alleles between species via hybridization, can be a potent source of evolutionary innovation. This study investigates the genomic basis of rapid salinity adaptation in a sympatric species pair of Lake Tanganyika cichlids. We utilized whole-genome resequencing data from populations across a steep salinity gradient to perform genomic cline analysis and identify loci with exceptional patterns of ancestry. Our results pinpoint a narrow genomic region containing the ion-channel-kinase (ICK) gene, which shows a significant excess of ancestry from the halotolerant species within the genome of its salt-sensitive sister taxon. This introgressed haplotype is associated with a strong selective sweep, nearly fixed in high-salinity populations, and functional assays confirm its role in enhanced osmoregulatory capacity. This case provides compelling evidence for adaptive introgression facilitating rapid adaptation to a novel environmental challenge, demonstrating how hybridization can reshape fitness landscapes.
subject: Evrim
title: Adaptive Introgression of an Allelic Variant at a Key Osmoregulatory Locus Confers Salinity Tolerance in a Clade of Cichlid Fishes

text: The analysis of ancient biomolecules offers an unprecedented window into the phylogenetic relationships and evolutionary dynamics of extinct taxa. Here, we apply paleoproteomic techniques to investigate the phylogeny of Late Pleistocene megafauna from Beringia. Using high-resolution liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS), we successfully sequenced collagen type I (COL1) peptides from exceptionally well-preserved fossil specimens, including extinct species of horse (Equus) and bison (Bison). Bayesian phylogenetic inference based on these ancient protein sequences resolved several long-standing ambiguities in megafaunal systematics, revealing a previously unrecognized sister-group relationship between the North American giant horse and modern Przewalski's horse. Furthermore, minor amino acid variations provided sufficient resolution for phylogeographic reconstructions, tracing population movements across the Bering Land Bridge. Our study demonstrates that paleoproteomics is a robust tool for deep-time evolutionary inference, capable of elucidating complex relationships beyond the current temporal limits of ancient DNA preservation.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleoproteomic Analysis of Pleistocene Megafauna Collagen Reveals Novel Phylogenetic Relationships and Biogeographic Histories

text: While natural selection is a primary driver of adaptation, the roles of stochastic processes like genetic drift in shaping evolutionary trajectories are less understood. We tracked the real-time evolution of antibiotic resistance in replicate experimental populations of Escherichia coli under sub-inhibitory drug concentrations. Using deep sequencing time-series data, we quantified the fixation probabilities of de novo mutations conferring low-level resistance. Our results show that while beneficial mutations were prevalent, their fixation was highly stochastic, with a significant proportion lost from the populations despite their positive selection coefficients. We observed the operation of an epistatic ratchet, where the stochastic fixation of initial, slightly deleterious or neutral mutations constrained subsequent evolutionary pathways. These findings highlight the critical interplay between selection and drift, demonstrating that stochastic events can fundamentally alter adaptive landscapes and lead to path-dependent, and often suboptimal, evolutionary outcomes.
subject: Evrim
title: Stochastic Fixation and Epistatic Ratchets: Quantifying the Role of Genetic Drift in the Evolution of Antibiotic Resistance

text: Understanding the origin of complex biological systems is a fundamental challenge in evolutionary biology. We investigated the evolutionary assembly of the gustatory signaling pathway in Lepidoptera, a multi-component system crucial for host-plant recognition. Through comparative genomic analysis of 30 species, we reconstructed the evolutionary history of key gene families, including gustatory receptors (GRs) and ionotropic receptors (IRs). Our phylogenetic analyses reveal that the core components of the pathway arose through a series of ancient gene duplication events. We find compelling evidence for both neofunctionalization, where duplicates acquired novel ligand specificities, and subfunctionalization, where ancestral functions were partitioned among paralogs. Synteny analysis indicates that co-expressed pathway components are often maintained in conserved gene clusters, suggesting regulatory co-evolution. This work provides a detailed molecular reconstruction of how duplication, divergence, and regulatory linkage facilitated the step-wise assembly of a complex, adaptively significant signaling network.
subject: Evrim
title: The Evolutionary Assembly of a Multicomponent Chemosensory Pathway Through Neofunctionalization and Subfunctionalization of Duplicate Genes

text: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a major evolutionary force in prokaryotes, but its impact on eukaryotic innovation is less established. We conducted a comprehensive comparative genomic analysis across 150 phytoplankton genomes to investigate the role of HGT in shaping metabolic diversity. Using rigorous phylogenetic incongruence tests, we identified over 2,000 instances of HGT from bacteria into diverse eukaryotic phytoplankton lineages, particularly within haptophytes and diatoms. The transferred genes are significantly enriched for functions related to nutrient acquisition and cofactor biosynthesis, including pathways for vitamin B12 synthesis and iron scavenging. We demonstrate that many of these horizontally acquired genes are integrated into existing eukaryotic metabolic networks and are transcriptionally responsive to environmental nutrient limitation. Our findings reveal that HGT from endosymbiotic and free-living bacteria is a pervasive and ongoing mechanism for metabolic innovation in eukaryotes, facilitating their ecological success in nutrient-poor marine environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Pervasive Horizontal Gene Transfer from Endosymbiotic Bacteria Shapes Metabolic Innovation in Eukaryotic Phytoplankton

text: Life-history trade-offs, such as the inverse relationship between fecundity and longevity, are central to evolutionary theory, yet their underlying genetic mechanisms remain elusive. We investigated the genomic architecture of this trade-off in Caenorhabditis elegans using a panel of recombinant inbred lines. Quantitative Trait Locus (QTL) mapping identified a major-effect locus on Chromosome II strongly associated with both traits, but with opposing allelic effects. Fine-mapping and genome-wide association studies implicated a polymorphism within the daf-16 gene, a key transcription factor in the Insulin/IGF-1 signaling (IIS) pathway. Allelic replacement experiments confirmed that this polymorphism causally mediates the trade-off: the allele enhancing fecundity simultaneously reduces lifespan and stress resistance. This provides a clear empirical demonstration of antagonistic pleiotropy at a single locus as a core mechanism for maintaining a fundamental life-history trade-off, highlighting how pleiotropic constraints at key regulatory nodes shape organismal evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: The Genomic Architecture of Life-History Trade-offs: Antagonistic Pleiotropy at Insulin/IGF-1 Signaling Loci

text: Understanding the drivers of diversification in alpine ecosystems is critical for predicting biodiversity responses to climate change. Here, we investigate the evolutionary history of the *Androsace alpina* species complex using a phylogenomic approach based on ultraconserved elements (UCEs). Our analyses, incorporating coalescent-based species delimitation and demographic modeling, robustly reject the single-species hypothesis, revealing at least three deeply divergent, cryptic lineages. These lineages correspond to distinct glacial refugia in the Pyrenees, Alps, and Carpathians, identified through paleoclimatic niche modeling. We detect significant post-divergence gene flow, but genomic cline analysis points to strong reproductive isolation maintained by loci under divergent selection. These loci are enriched for functions related to UV radiation tolerance and flowering phenology. Our findings underscore the role of Pleistocene climatic oscillations in promoting allopatric speciation and highlight the substantial 'dark diversity' that can be concealed within morphologically conservative alpine taxa, with profound implications for conservation planning.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Pliocene-Pleistocene Refugia Reveal Cryptic Speciation in an Alpine Plant Endemism

text: Phenotypic innovation often arises from modifications to conserved gene regulatory networks (GRNs). We investigated the role of cis-regulatory element (CRE) evolution in the diversification of arthropod appendages by performing comparative ATAC-seq and ChIP-seq across four pancrustacean species. We focused on the GRN controlled by the Hox gene *Ultrabithorax* (Ubx), a key determinant of thoracic versus abdominal identity. Our results reveal a deeply conserved core of Ubx-responsive enhancers, but demonstrate rampant turnover in transcription factor binding sites within these regions. Using massively parallel reporter assays (MPRAs), we functionally validated divergent CRE activities, showing that subtle sequence changes can quantitatively alter enhancer output. Furthermore, phylogenetic footprinting identified lineage-specific CREs that correlate with the emergence of novel appendage morphologies. This study demonstrates that the combinatorial evolution of CREs provides a powerful mechanism for developmental modularity, allowing for the fine-tuning of appendage patterning while preserving the core function of the Hox GRN.
subject: Evrim
title: Cis-Regulatory Evolution of a Core Hox Gene Regulatory Network Underlies Appendage Diversification in Pancrustacea

text: Hybridization can be a potent evolutionary force, facilitating rapid adaptation through the transfer of pre-adapted genetic material. We document a compelling case of adaptive introgression between two sympatric species of *Heliconius* butterflies that are co-evolving with their toxic *Passiflora* host plants. Using whole-genome resequencing data from populations across a hybrid zone, we identified a large, 1.5-Mbp chromosomal inversion that has introgressed from *H. cydno* into *H. melpomene*. The introgressed haplotype is associated with a near-complete switch in host plant preference and detoxification capability. Haplotype-based selection scans reveal a strong selective sweep within the inversion, centered on a cluster of cytochrome P450 genes. Admixture mapping and population simulations confirm that the introgression event was recent and driven by intense positive selection. Our results illustrate how structural variants can act as 'supergenes', facilitating the transfer of complex adaptive traits between species and accelerating evolutionary responses in antagonistic coevolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Adaptive Introgression of an Inversion Polymorphism Confers Toxin Resistance in a Coevolutionary Arms Race

text: The recovery of ecosystems following mass extinctions provides a natural experiment for understanding macroevolutionary dynamics. We examined the evolution of post-cranial skeletal morphology in early placental mammals following the Cretaceous-Paleogene (K-Pg) boundary. By applying phylogenetic K-means clustering to a high-dimensional morphospace derived from 3D laser scans of over 500 fossil specimens, we identified distinct ecomorphological guilds. Our disparity-through-time (DTT) analyses reveal a rapid, early burst of morphological diversification, filling vacant ecological niches within the first 10 million years of the Paleocene. However, when incorporating biomechanical functional proxies, we find a significant lag in functional diversification. Stochastic character mapping of locomotor modes onto our phylogeny suggests that functionally versatile, generalized forms persisted long after initial morphological disparity peaked. This decoupling of form and function suggests that early placental radiation was characterized by extensive morphological experimentation preceding subsequent ecological specialization, challenging classic models of adaptive radiation.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenetic K-means Clustering and Disparity-Through-Time Analysis Reveal Decoupled Macroevolutionary Dynamics of Form and Function Following the K-Pg Extinction

text: Antagonistic coevolution is a primary driver of biodiversity, yet direct genomic evidence for reciprocal, escalating selection remains scarce. We investigated the coevolutionary dynamics between the wild flax, *Linum marginale*, and its fungal pathogen, *Melampsora lini*, using a landscape genomics approach. We sequenced genomes from 20 sympatric host-pathogen populations, identifying a suite of plant resistance (R) genes and pathogen avirulence (Avr) effectors. Population-genetic analyses revealed strong signatures of balancing selection at R gene loci, consistent with frequency-dependent selection. Conversely, Avr loci exhibited recurrent selective sweeps, indicative of an escalatory 'arms race' dynamic. We found a significant spatial correlation between the frequencies of specific R-Avr allele pairs, demonstrating geographically structured co-adaptation. Our findings provide robust genomic support for a multi-locus 'matching-alleles' model, but also suggest that Red Queen dynamics are punctuated by escalatory events, driving the continual evolution of novel genetic specificities in this intimate interaction.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Evidence for Reciprocal Selection and Escalatory Coevolution in a Plant-Pathogen System

text: Phenotypic plasticity, the ability of a single genotype to produce multiple phenotypes, is a key mechanism of adaptation to variable environments. We explored the genetic basis of developmental plasticity in carnivore-omnivore polyphenism in spadefoot toads (*Spea* spp.), a classic model system. By integrating quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping in a laboratory-reared F2 hybrid population with population genomics from a natural hybrid zone, we dissected the genetic architecture of this complex trait. We identified three major QTLs influencing the plastic response to diet cues. One QTL contains a thyroid hormone receptor gene, a known regulator of metamorphosis, while the others map to novel candidate genes involved in lipid metabolism. Analysis of allele frequencies across the environmental gradient of the hybrid zone reveals clinal variation at these loci, suggesting they are under spatially varying selection. Our results demonstrate that major-effect loci can underlie adaptive plasticity and that introgression in hybrid zones may facilitate its evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Deconstructing the Genetic Architecture of Phenotypic Plasticity in a Spadefoot Toad Hybrid Zone

text: Gene duplication is a major source of evolutionary novelty, but the processes governing the functional divergence of paralogs are complex. We investigated the molecular evolution of conotoxin gene superfamilies in the venomous marine gastropod genus *Conus*. Using a newly assembled reference genome and transcriptomic data from multiple species, we reconstructed the phylogenetic history of the A- and O-superfamilies. Our analysis revealed multiple rounds of tandem duplication, followed by rapid divergence. Codon-based models of evolution (e.g., PAML, HyPhy) detected pervasive positive selection (dN/dS > 1) acting on sites within the mature toxin region, particularly after duplication events. We infer that an initial phase of subfunctionalization, partitioning the ancestral expression pattern across different venom duct regions, was followed by neofunctionalization driven by positive selection. This process generated functional diversity, allowing for the targeting of novel neuromuscular receptors in prey, and exemplifies a 'duplication-divergence-selection' cascade for generating biochemical innovation.
subject: Evrim
title: Accelerated Evolution and Functional Divergence of Toxin Gene Families Following Subfunctionalization in Cone Snails

text: Disentangling the effects of selection and demography is a central challenge in evolutionary biology. We investigated the genomic basis of local adaptation in the montane grasshopper *Melanoplus montanus* across complex environmental gradients in the Rocky Mountains. Using redundancy analysis (RDA) and latent factor mixed models on a dataset of over 200,000 SNPs from 480 individuals, we identified distinct signatures of polygenic adaptation. We found that a large proportion of genomic variance is significantly associated with environmental variables, primarily minimum winter temperature and summer precipitation. Adaptive loci were broadly distributed across the genome, with small individual effect sizes, consistent with a polygenic architecture. Candidate genes underlying these associations are enriched for functions related to diapause regulation, metabolic rate, and desiccation tolerance. After correcting for isolation-by-resistance, these genotype-environment associations remained significant, providing strong evidence for selection over neutral demographic processes in shaping the species' genomic landscape.
subject: Evrim
title: Landscape Genomics Reveals Polygenic Adaptation to Temperature and Aridity Gradients in a Montane Grasshopper

text: The prevalence of sexual reproduction despite its inherent costs remains a central paradox in evolutionary biology. Theoretical models suggest that sex accelerates adaptation by combining beneficial mutations and purging deleterious ones. We tested these hypotheses using experimental evolution in *Saccharomyces cerevisiae*, competing sexual and engineered asexual lineages in a novel, stressful environment. We tracked genome-wide allele frequency trajectories over 500 generations via pooled sequencing. Asexual populations exhibited classic signatures of clonal interference, where multiple beneficial mutations arose in different lineages but competed, slowing the rate of adaptation. In contrast, sexual populations showed more rapid fixation of beneficial mutations. Furthermore, by reconstructing haplotypes, we found evidence for significant negative epistasis among deleterious mutations, which were purged more efficiently by recombination in sexual lines. Our results provide direct empirical support for both the Fisher-Muller and Kondrashov's Hatchet mechanisms, demonstrating that sex provides a crucial advantage in complex adaptive landscapes.
subject: Evrim
title: The Interplay of Clonal Interference and Negative Epistasis Constrains the Evolution of Asexuality in Experimental Yeast Populations

text: The predictability of evolution is a fundamental question, revolving around the relative importance of determinism versus historical contingency. We addressed this by initiating 12 replicate adaptive radiations of *Pseudomonas fluorescens* from a single ancestral clone in a spatially structured environment. All populations diversified into wrinkly spreader and smooth morphotypes, representing a convergent adaptation to occupy distinct niches at the air-liquid interface and in the broth phase. However, whole-genome sequencing at multiple timepoints revealed that the genetic solutions underlying this phenotypic convergence were highly variable. While parallel evolution occurred at the gene level (e.g., mutations in the *wsp* operon), the specific mutations were unique to each replicate. Furthermore, the temporal order of mutations in key regulatory pathways created historical contingencies that constrained subsequent evolutionary trajectories and influenced the relative frequencies of the emergent morphotypes. This experiment demonstrates how evolution is a composite of predictable responses to ecological opportunity and stochastic, contingent genetic events.
subject: Evrim
title: Historical Contingency and Ecological Opportunity Shape Convergent Adaptive Radiations in a Long-Term Microbial Evolution Experiment

text: We investigate the application of Variational Quantum Eigensolvers (VQEs) to navigate the complex, non-convex loss landscapes of deep neural networks. Traditional stochastic gradient-based optimizers are susceptible to local minima, whereas quantum annealing has shown promise but requires specialized hardware. Our hybrid quantum-classical approach maps the neural network's loss function to a QUBO (Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization) problem, which is then formulated as an Ising Hamiltonian. A parameterized quantum circuit, or ansatz, is optimized using a classical outer loop to find the Hamiltonian's ground state, corresponding to a global minimum of the loss function. We employ a hardware-efficient ansatz and the SPSA optimizer to update circuit parameters. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our VQE-based optimization strategy discovers superior minima compared to Adam and SGD, yielding models with improved generalization performance. This work bridges the gap between near-term quantum computing and foundational deep learning challenges, suggesting a viable path towards quantum-assisted model training.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Eigensolvers for Non-Convex Optimization in Deep Neural Networks

text: Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit impressive generative capabilities but lack formal mechanisms for verifiable reasoning and logical consistency. To address this, we introduce Logic-Tensor Networks (LTNs), a neuro-symbolic framework that integrates first-order logic (FOL) constraints directly into the latent embedding space of transformer architectures. By representing logical predicates and axioms as differentiable functions operating on tensor representations, our framework enforces semantic consistency during both pre-training and fine-tuning. We employ a real-valued fuzzy logic semantics, enabling the model to handle uncertainty and soft constraints. A novel semantic unification algorithm, implemented via attention mechanisms, allows the model to perform multi-hop deductive reasoning over learned symbolic facts. We demonstrate that LTN-augmented LLMs significantly outperform baseline models on tasks requiring robust logical inference, such as commonsense question answering (CSQA) and knowledge base completion, while providing auditable reasoning paths for its conclusions, thereby enhancing model transparency and trustworthiness.
subject: AI
title: Logic-Tensor Networks for Verifiable Reasoning in Large Language Models

text: This paper presents FedARP, a novel federated learning framework designed for resilience against Byzantine adversaries and statistical heterogeneity while providing rigorous privacy guarantees. To counteract malicious clients, our aggregation protocol eschews simple averaging in favor of a robust geometric median estimator, provably converging even under significant data poisoning attacks. To handle non-IID data distributions across clients, FedARP incorporates a meta-learning based personalization layer, allowing each client to learn a tailored model that adapts a shared global representation. Crucially, we formalize the privacy-utility trade-off using (ε, δ)-Rényi Differential Privacy, applying calibrated Gaussian noise to client updates and providing a tight compositional analysis over communication rounds. Empirical evaluation on diverse benchmarks demonstrates that FedARP maintains high model accuracy under attack scenarios where methods like FedAvg collapse, while achieving superior personalization and certifiable client-level privacy protection compared to existing robust and private FL algorithms.
subject: AI
title: Byzantine-Robust Federated Learning with Adaptive Personalization and Rényi Differential Privacy

text: De novo molecular design for drug discovery presents a formidable challenge in navigating the vast chemical space to identify novel compounds with desired pharmacological properties. We propose HyperMolGAN, a generative adversarial network that represents molecules as hypergraphs to explicitly model multi-atom functional groups and complex relational structures. The generator, a hypergraph convolutional network, learns a distribution over valid molecular hypergraphs, while a multi-objective discriminator evaluates candidates on predicted binding affinity, ADMET properties, and synthetic accessibility. To guide the generator towards regions of the chemical space satisfying Pareto-optimal criteria, we integrate a policy gradient reinforcement learning strategy. The generator's objective is augmented with a reward function derived from the discriminator's multi-faceted evaluation. Our results show that HyperMolGAN generates a higher proportion of novel, valid, and synthesizable molecules with superior predicted bioactivity profiles compared to state-of-the-art graph- and string-based generative models.
subject: AI
title: Hypergraph-based Generative Adversarial Networks for De Novo Molecular Design

text: Off-policy evaluation in reinforcement learning is critical for deploying agents in high-stakes domains, yet existing methods often fail in Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes (POMDPs) where latent confounders influence both actions and outcomes. We introduce a novel framework, Causal-POMDP, that integrates a Structural Causal Model (SCM) of the environment's latent variable structure into the policy evaluation process. By leveraging variational inference and techniques from do-calculus, our method estimates counterfactual state-action values, effectively adjusting for the confounding bias introduced by unobserved variables. This allows for robust policy evaluation from observational data where the behavior policy is correlated with latent environmental states. We demonstrate empirically in simulated healthcare and robotics environments that Causal-POMDP provides significantly more accurate policy value estimates and rankings than traditional importance sampling, doubly robust estimators, and standard model-based RL approaches, enabling more reliable decision-making under partial observability.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Policy Evaluation in Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes via Structural Causal Models

text: We address the challenge of unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) for semantic segmentation between different medical imaging modalities, such as MRI and CT, where paired data is unavailable. We propose a novel framework, Cycle-Disentangled UDA (CD-UDA), that learns to separate modality-specific appearance features from modality-invariant anatomical content. Our architecture combines a cycle-consistent adversarial network for image-to-image translation with a mutual information-based regularization loss. This loss explicitly minimizes the statistical dependency between the learned content and style representations, enforcing a robust disentanglement. The segmentation network is trained exclusively on the modality-invariant content space, enabling it to generalize seamlessly to the unlabeled target domain. Extensive experiments on public datasets for brain and abdominal organ segmentation demonstrate that CD-UDA significantly outperforms state-of-the-art UDA techniques by preserving anatomical fidelity, reducing negative transfer, and achieving segmentation accuracy approaching that of fully supervised models.
subject: AI
title: Disentangled Representation Learning for Cross-Modality Unsupervised Domain Adaptation in Medical Image Segmentation

text: Training deep Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) using backpropagation is challenged by the non-differentiable nature of spiking neurons and the difficulty of assigning credit across long temporal sequences. We propose a Recurrent Surrogate Gradient (RSG) learning algorithm that addresses these issues. Instead of using a fixed heuristic for the derivative of the spiking activation, we model the surrogate gradient as a small, learnable recurrent neural network. This allows the gradient to be dynamically shaped and propagated through both spatial layers and temporal steps, effectively learning the optimal credit assignment for complex spatio-temporal patterns. This mechanism mitigates the vanishing and exploding gradient problems inherent in BPTT for deep SNNs. We demonstrate on challenging neuromorphic datasets, including DVS-Gesture and the Spiking Heidelberg Digits, that RSG-trained deep SNNs achieve state-of-the-art accuracy and enhanced temporal processing capabilities while maintaining low-power event-driven computation.
subject: AI
title: Spatio-Temporal Credit Assignment in Deep Spiking Neural Networks with a Recurrent Surrogate Gradient

text: Few-shot learning on graph-structured data is a critical but challenging problem due to the complex, non-Euclidean nature of the data. We introduce the Prototypical Graph Meta-Learner (ProtoGML), a novel framework that adapts prototypical networks to graph domains. ProtoGML employs a graph neural network (GNN) backbone to learn a powerful embedding function that maps graphs into a metric space. During our episodic meta-training phase, the model learns to construct class prototypes from a small support set of labeled examples and classify query examples based on their proximity to these prototypes. A key innovation is a task-aware attention mechanism that allows the GNN to focus on the most discriminative substructures for each specific few-shot task. We evaluate ProtoGML on multiple benchmark datasets for both few-shot node and graph classification, demonstrating that it significantly outperforms existing GNN fine-tuning strategies and other graph meta-learning approaches, establishing a new state-of-the-art.
subject: AI
title: Prototypical Graph Meta-Learner for Few-Shot Node and Graph Classification

text: Graph neural networks typically operate in Euclidean space, which imposes a structural bottleneck when modeling data with inherent hierarchical or cyclical geometries. We propose Mixed-Curvature Graph Convolutional Networks (MCGCNs), a novel architecture that learns a node-specific latent geometry as a product of Euclidean, hyperbolic, and spherical spaces. Our model performs parallel message passing using geodesic convolutions native to each geometry and employs a learnable gating mechanism to dynamically aggregate these multi-curvature representations. This allows MCGCNs to adaptively capture tree-like hierarchies (hyperbolic) and cyclical structures (spherical) within a single graph, overcoming the representational limitations of fixed-curvature models. We formulate operations within the framework of Riemannian geometry and derive a stable optimization procedure. Empirical results on node classification and link prediction tasks on datasets with heterogeneous structures, such as social networks and biological pathways, demonstrate that MCGCNs significantly outperform state-of-the-art Euclidean and pure-hyperbolic GCNs.
subject: AI
title: Mixed-Curvature Graph Convolutional Networks for Hierarchical Representation Learning

text: Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (SGLD) is a scalable method for posterior inference in Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs), yet its sampling efficiency is hindered by the isotropic noise injection, which ignores the local geometry of the loss landscape. We propose AdaPre-SGLD, an adaptive preconditioning method that significantly improves sampling in high-dimensional parameter spaces. Our method maintains a low-rank approximation of the Fisher Information Matrix, which serves as a preconditioning matrix to rescale the stochastic gradient updates and inject anisotropic, curvature-aware noise. This transforms the challenging posterior geometry into a more tractable one, accelerating convergence and improving mixing. We provide a theoretical analysis demonstrating faster convergence rates for AdaPre-SGLD under standard assumptions. On large-scale regression and image classification benchmarks, our method yields BNNs with superior uncertainty quantification and improved out-of-distribution detection compared to standard SGLD, K-FAC, and modern variational inference techniques.
subject: AI
title: Adaptive Preconditioning for Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics in High-Dimensional Bayesian Neural Networks

text: This paper introduces a novel methodology for automated Schenkerian analysis directly from symbolic musical data. Traditional computational approaches often fail to capture the recursive, hierarchical nature of tonal prolongation. We propose a Hierarchical Attentive Graph Neural Network (HA-GNN) that models musical structure as a nested graph. Pitch events are represented as nodes, and their relationships are encoded as edges weighted by music-theoretic principles of consonance, dissonance, and voice leading. The model employs a multi-head attention mechanism to learn dependencies across different structural levels, from foreground diminutions to the background Ursatz. By training on a curated corpus of expert analyses, our HA-GNN learns to infer prolongational hierarchies and generate complete Schenkerian graphs that are structurally coherent and theoretically plausible. Results demonstrate a significant improvement in F1-score for identifying fundamental structures compared to baseline recurrent neural network and conditional random field models, offering a powerful new tool for large-scale computational musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: Computational Schenkerian Analysis: A Hierarchical Attentive Graph Neural Network Approach

text: Neo-Riemannian theory provides a robust geometric model for chromatic harmony, yet its relationship with musical timbre remains largely unexplored. This study investigates potential isomorphisms between the transformational spaces of harmony and timbre. We employ Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP) to construct low-dimensional timbral manifolds from a high-dimensional space of spectro-temporal audio descriptors, including spectral centroid, flux, and Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs). By analyzing recordings of triadic progressions performed on various instruments, we map harmonic trajectories as paths within these timbral manifolds. Our findings reveal that canonical neo-Riemannian operations (P, L, R) correspond to statistically significant, classifiable geometric transformations within the learned timbral space. This suggests a psychoacoustic coupling between perceived timbral evolution and abstract harmonic syntax, providing an empirical basis for theories of timbre-function and offering a new, multi-modal perspective on harmonic analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Timbral Isomorphisms: Mapping Spectro-Temporal Manifolds to Neo-Riemannian Transformational Spaces

text: The analysis of non-Western and contemporary microtonal music is often hampered by the ambiguity of its underlying tuning system. This paper presents a probabilistic framework for inferring tuning systems directly from audio recordings. Our approach utilizes a high-resolution Constant-Q Transform (CQT) to obtain a precise time-frequency representation, from which fundamental frequency candidates are extracted. We then employ a Bayesian inference model with nested sampling to evaluate the posterior probability of various competing tuning system hypotheses, including different equal temperaments, just intonation ratios, and adaptive intonation models. The model intrinsically handles performance-related pitch deviations and instrumental inharmonicity by treating them as nuisance parameters. We validate our method on a diverse dataset of synthetic and real-world recordings, demonstrating its superior accuracy in identifying complex and hybrid tuning structures compared to methods based on simple pitch-class histogramming. The framework provides a quantitative tool for ethnomusicology and the analysis of experimental composition.
subject: Müzik
title: Probabilistic Modeling of Microtonal Tuning Systems using Bayesian Inference on High-Resolution CQT Spectra

text: Conventional methods for automated musical form analysis often rely on chroma-based self-similarity matrices (SSMs), which are insensitive to thematic development and timbral variation. We propose a multi-faceted approach that constructs a composite SSM derived from a fusion of deep feature vectors. A Siamese network is trained to generate embeddings that capture thematic similarity, while a separate Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) extracts a robust representation of timbral texture from the audio's spectrogram. A third vector captures rhythmic profiles. By computing a weighted combination of SSMs from these disparate feature streams, we generate a holistic representation of musical self-similarity. Novelty curves derived from this composite matrix are used to identify structural boundaries. We demonstrate that this method significantly outperforms single-feature approaches in segmenting complex forms like the sonata-allegro and fugue, providing a more musically-informed and nuanced tool for automated structural analysis across diverse musical repertoires.
subject: Müzik
title: Decomposing Musical Form: A Multi-Scale Self-Similarity Matrix Analysis Informed by Thematic and Timbral Feature Vectors

text: Expressive musical performance hinges on subtle deviations from the notated score, yet quantifying the link between these micro-variations and underlying musical structure remains a significant challenge. This research employs a high-precision phase vocoder algorithm to extract instantaneous frequency traces from monophonic and polyphonic piano recordings, enabling the measurement of agogic accents and rubato with millisecond accuracy. We then correlate this dense stream of micro-timing data with a dynamic model of harmonic tension, derived from a probabilistic implementation of the Generative Theory of Tonal Music (GTTM). Our statistical analysis, conducted across a corpus of performances by celebrated pianists, reveals strong, systematic correlations between local tempo deceleration and points of high harmonic tension, particularly at cadences and appoggiaturas. These findings empirically validate long-standing music-theoretic intuitions about performance practice and provide a quantitative framework for modeling the interaction between musical structure and expressive execution.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Expressive Agogics: A Phase Vocoder-Based Analysis of Micro-Timing Deviations and their Correlation with Harmonic Tension

text: State-of-the-art audio source separation models are often agnostic to the musical syntax governing the sources they aim to separate. This paper introduces a novel framework for polyphonic voice separation that integrates music-theoretic constraints directly into the optimization process. Our model, based on a modified Non-negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) architecture, jointly optimizes for two objectives: the accurate reconstruction of the mixed spectrogram and the contrapuntal validity of the separated melodic streams. The contrapuntal cost function penalizes musically implausible results, such as parallel octaves and fifths, unresolved dissonances, and excessive voice crossing, based on a differentiable model of species counterpoint. This hybrid approach regularizes the ill-posed separation problem, leading to a significant reduction in inter-source interference and producing separated voices that are more melodically coherent and faithful to the principles of polyphonic composition. The method shows marked improvement over baseline NMF and deep learning models, especially in dense contrapuntal textures like those found in Baroque fugues.
subject: Müzik
title: A Contrapuntally-Informed Source Separation Algorithm using Joint Optimization of Spectral and Music-Theoretic Constraints

text: The principles of orchestral blending, a cornerstone of orchestration theory, have historically been described qualitatively. We present a computational model that quantifies timbral fusion and psychoacoustic masking within an orchestral context. For a given combination of instrumental audio signals, the model first performs a spectral analysis on the Equivalent Rectangular Bandwidth (ERB) scale to simulate the frequency resolution of the human cochlea. It then applies a computational model of simultaneous masking, calculating the masking threshold exerted by each instrument's spectrum on the others. We define a 'Timbral Integration Index' based on the degree of mutual masking and spectral overlap within critical bands. This index provides a quantitative measure of perceptual blend. Validated against perceptual ratings from expert listeners and classical orchestration treatises (e.g., Rimsky-Korsakov), our model accurately predicts well-blended instrumental pairings versus those that exhibit perceptual segregation, providing a powerful analytical tool for composers and musicologists.
subject: Müzik
title: Computational Modeling of Orchestral Blending and Masking: A Psychoacoustically-Informed Approach using Equivalent Rectangular Bandwidth Analysis

text: The perception of musical meter is an embodied, cognitive process that is not fully captured by audio analysis alone. This study introduces a cross-modal framework for inferring metrical hierarchies by fusing audio features with kinematic data from human movement. We recorded participants' upper-body motion using inertial measurement units while they listened to rhythmically complex musical stimuli. A beat salience function was computed from the audio's onset detection function, while kinematic features such as velocity and acceleration peaks were extracted from the movement data. A Dynamic Bayesian Network was then used to model the joint probability of audio-visual events, inferring the most likely latent metrical structure (tactus, super-meter, and sub-division) that explains both data streams. Our results show that the cross-modal model significantly outperforms an audio-only baseline in identifying culturally-attested meters, supporting theories of rhythmic entrainment and demonstrating the crucial role of embodied cognition in structuring musical time.
subject: Müzik
title: Inferring Metrical Hierarchies from Body-Movement Data: A Cross-Modal Analysis of Kinematic Trajectories and Audio-Based Beat Salience Functions

text: Generative models of music audio often treat style as an uninterpretable latent variable. We propose a disentangled Variational Autoencoder (VAE) architecture that enables direct, semantically meaningful control over musical style by conditioning the latent space on music-theoretic descriptors. Our model learns a compressed representation of musical excerpts from their log-mel spectrograms. Crucially, the encoder is jointly conditioned on a vector of analytical features, including pitch-class set complexity metrics (e.g., Forte's R0, R1, R2), dissonance measures, and modal centricity. By fixing the content variable and traversing specific axes in the conditioned latent space, we can regenerate the input audio while systematically manipulating its harmonic and tonal characteristics. This allows for fine-grained stylistic transformations, such as 'atonally-shifting' a tonal melody or 'smoothing' the harmonic complexity of a post-tonal passage, providing a powerful tool for computational music analysis and controlled algorithmic composition.
subject: Müzik
title: Latent Space Traversal of Musical Style: A Variational Autoencoder Approach Conditioned on Tonal Pitch Class Set Complexities

text: This study operationalizes the music-theoretic concepts of harmonic surprise and ambiguity using principles from information theory. We developed a probabilistic model of tonal syntax by training a variable-order Hidden Markov Model (HMM) on a large corpus of harmonically-annotated common-practice era music. The HMM learns the transition probabilities between functional harmony states. We then use this trained model to analyze highly chromatic excerpts from late-Romantic and early 20th-century repertoires. At each harmonic event, we compute two information-theoretic metrics: the Shannon entropy of the model's predictive distribution, quantifying tonal ambiguity, and the surprisal (negative log probability) of the observed harmony, quantifying harmonic unexpectedness. The resulting time-series data provides a dynamic, quantitative profile of the music's information content. Our findings show that these metrics correlate strongly with established musicological analyses of harmonic innovation and the dissolution of tonality, offering an empirical framework to complement traditional analytical methods.
subject: Müzik
title: A Shannon-Entropy-Based Model for Measuring Harmonic Surprise and Tonal Ambiguity in Late-Romantic Chromaticism

text: The therapeutic potential of CRISPR-Cas systems is often constrained by stringent Protospacer Adjacent Motif (PAM) requirements and off-target activity. Here, we report the directed evolution and deep functional characterization of a novel Cas12f ortholog, GeoCas12f, exhibiting a minimalistic NGN PAM. Using cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM), we resolved the GeoCas12f-sgRNA-target DNA ternary complex at 2.8 Å resolution, revealing a unique conformational state of the REC2 lobe that accommodates non-canonical PAMs through altered electrostatic interactions. High-throughput, genome-wide off-target nomination assays (e.g., GUIDE-seq) demonstrate that structure-guided mutations within the HNH nuclease domain yield a hyper-accurate variant, hfGeoCas12f, with a >100-fold improvement in specificity without compromising on-target efficiency. This work elucidates a fundamental mechanism of PAM recognition and provides a compact, high-fidelity genome editing tool with a significantly expanded targeting scope for therapeutic and research applications, overcoming a critical limitation of existing effectors.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure and Mechanistic Dissection of a Hyper-accurate Cas12f Variant with Expanded PAM Compatibility

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are critical epigenetic regulators, yet the mechanisms by which they target chromatin-modifying complexes to specific genomic loci remain poorly understood. We have identified *NeuroScaff*, a nuclear-retained lncRNA specifically expressed in neural progenitor cells. Using Chromatin Isolation by RNA Purification (ChIRP-seq) and RNA Immunoprecipitation (RIP-seq), we demonstrate that *NeuroScaff* directly binds to the EZH2 subunit of the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2). Integrated analysis with CUT&RUN for H3K27me3 and H3K4me3 reveals that *NeuroScaff* localizes to bivalent promoters of key developmental transcription factors, acting as a molecular scaffold to stabilize PRC2 binding and maintain transcriptional poise. CRISPRi-mediated knockdown of *NeuroScaff* results in premature differentiation and loss of progenitor self-renewal, confirming its essential role in orchestrating the epigenetic landscape required for neurogenesis. Our findings uncover a lncRNA-mediated mechanism for precise spatiotemporal control of Polycomb-mediated gene silencing during mammalian brain development.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The lncRNA NeuroScaff Orchestrates PRC2 Recruitment to Regulate Bivalent Chromatin Domains in Cortical Progenitors

text: Epigenetic landscapes are dynamically shaped by the interplay between histone modifications and DNA methylation, but the direct molecular crosstalk remains incompletely defined. We investigate the relationship between H3K36 trimethylation (H3K36me3), a mark of active transcription, and de novo DNA methylation by DNMT3A. Using in vitro reconstituted chromatin templates and cellular models, we demonstrate that the PWWP domain of DNMT3A is sterically occluded by H3K36me3, creating a mutually exclusive relationship. Genome-wide analysis using ChIP-seq and whole-genome bisulfite sequencing in differentiating hematopoietic stem cells shows that H3K36me3 deposition by SETD2 precedes the exclusion of DNMT3A from the gene bodies of lineage-specifying factors, thereby creating hypomethylated domains permissive for transcription. Conversely, loss of SETD2 leads to aberrant hypermethylation and compromised differentiation. This study elucidates a fundamental antagonistic mechanism that safeguards transcriptional programs from ectopic silencing, providing a new paradigm for how histone methylation patterns guide DNA methyltransferases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Antagonistic Crosstalk between H3K36me3 and DNMT3A-mediated de novo Methylation Governs Cell Fate Decisions

text: Cellular function within complex tissues is dictated by intricate local signaling networks. To dissect the pancreatic islet microenvironment, we employed high-resolution spatial transcriptomics (MERFISH) combined with single-cell RNA sequencing. Our analysis resolved the precise locations of all major endocrine (α, β, δ) and non-endocrine (endothelial, immune) cell types, constructing a comprehensive 3D cellular atlas of the murine islet. By computationally modeling ligand-receptor interactions in a spatially resolved context, we identified previously unappreciated signaling gradients emanating from delta cells (somatostatin) and endothelial cells (Wnt5a) that directly modulate beta-cell insulin secretion pathways.
