We uncovered a subpopulation of peripheral beta-cells characterized by a unique transcriptional signature responsive to these local cues. In vivo functional validation using targeted receptor antagonists confirmed that disruption of this spatially organized signaling architecture impairs glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. This work provides an unprecedented molecular map of the islet niche, revealing that spatial cell-cell communication is a critical regulator of endocrine homeostasis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatiotemporal Transcriptomic Atlas of the Pancreatic Islet Niche Reveals Heterotypic Signaling Gradients Regulating Beta-Cell Function

text: Endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation (ERAD) and ER-phagy are crucial quality control pathways for eliminating misfolded proteins. While ERAD relies on ubiquitination, the mechanisms targeting specific substrates for ER-phagy are less clear. Here, we identify the ER-resident E3 ligase RNF185 as a key mediator of selective ER-phagy for misfolded glycoproteins. Surprisingly, its ligase activity is dispensable for this function. Through proximity-labeling proteomics (TurboID), we discovered that RNF185 directly binds to the lectin-like receptor ERLEC1. Upon substrate misfolding, RNF185 recruits ERLEC1 to engage the nascent autophagosome via a canonical LIR motif in the ERLEC1 cytosolic tail, independent of substrate ubiquitination. Cryo-electron tomography of isolated ER-phagosomes confirms the colocalization of this complex at the ER-autophagosome interface. Depletion of RNF185 or ERLEC1 leads to the accumulation of aggregation-prone glycoproteins, highlighting a novel, ubiquitin-independent branch of ER quality control critical for cellular proteostasis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The E3 Ubiquitin Ligase RNF185 Mediates ER-phagy of Misfolded Glycoproteins via a Novel Ubiquitin-Independent Receptor

text: The maintenance of telomere length by telomerase is essential for genomic stability and cellular longevity. Telomerase activity is tightly regulated by the shelterin complex, but the precise molecular handoffs remain elusive. We identified ACAD9, a mitochondrial acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, as a novel telomere-binding protein that directly interacts with the shelterin component TPP1. ACAD9 localizes to telomeres specifically during S-phase, and its depletion leads to progressive telomere shortening and premature senescence. Mechanistically, we show that ATM-mediated phosphorylation of ACAD9 at Serine-112 enhances its binding to TPP1 and stimulates telomerase processivity in vitro, as measured by single-molecule telomerase activity assays. A non-phosphorylatable ACAD9 mutant fails to rescue telomere shortening, demonstrating the functional importance of this post-translational modification. Our findings reveal a previously unknown link between metabolic enzymes and telomere maintenance, uncovering a regulatory switch that couples DNA damage signaling to the modulation of telomerase function.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phosphorylation-dependent Regulation of Telomerase Processivity by the Shelterin-Associated Factor ACAD9

text: The spliceosome is a highly dynamic macromolecular machine that undergoes extensive compositional and conformational rearrangements during pre-mRNA splicing. The transition from the pre-catalytic B complex to the activated B-act complex is a critical, ATP-dependent checkpoint. Using multi-color single-molecule FRET and cryo-EM, we have captured the spliceosome in transient intermediate states during this transition. Our data reveal that the DEAH-box helicase Prp2's ATPase activity is modulated by direct interaction with the scaffold protein Prp8. We show that Prp8's RNase H-like domain acts as a molecular brake, preventing premature ATP hydrolysis by Prp2 until the 5' splice site is correctly docked into the active site. Mutations in Prp8 that disrupt this interaction lead to ATP-uncoupled helicase activity and a dramatic loss of splicing fidelity, allowing for aberrant splice site usage. This work uncovers a sophisticated allosteric proofreading mechanism ensuring the precise recognition of splice sites before catalytic commitment.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Single-Molecule Dynamics Reveal a Prp8-Mediated Checkpoint Governing Spliceosome Activation and Fidelity

text: Signal transduction pathways often rely on higher-order protein assemblies for efficient and specific signal propagation. Here, we demonstrate that liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) is a core mechanistic principle in Wnt/β-catenin signaling. The key scaffold protein Dishevelled-3 (Dvl3), through its multivalent DIX and PDZ domains, undergoes LLPS both in vitro and in living cells upon Wnt stimulation. These Dvl3 condensates act as seeds to recruit and concentrate the Axin-containing destruction complex, leading to its functional sequestration and disassembly. Super-resolution microscopy and FRAP experiments reveal that Axin molecules are highly dynamic within these biomolecular condensates. Crucially, mutations that disrupt Dvl3's ability to phase separate abolish its capacity to stabilize β-catenin and activate downstream transcription. Our findings propose a revised model where Wnt signaling triggers a phase transition of Dvl3, creating dynamic, non-membranous signaling hubs that provide the amplification and specificity required for robust pathway output.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phase Separation of Dishevelled-3 Mediates Axin Condensation to Amplify Wnt/β-catenin Signaling

text: DNA inter-strand crosslinks (ICLs) are highly cytotoxic lesions whose repair is orchestrated by the Fanconi Anemia (FA) pathway. The FAN1 nuclease plays a critical late-stage role in incising the DNA backbone flanking the ICL. We present the 3.0 Å cryo-EM structure of dimeric human FAN1 bound to an ICL-mimicking DNA substrate. The structure reveals that FAN1 forms a head-to-tail dimer that extensively encircles the DNA, inducing a sharp ~90° bend at the crosslink site. This DNA distortion positions the scissile phosphates of each strand into the two respective active sites of the dimer, ensuring coordinated cleavage on both sides of the ICL. The dimer interface is mediated by a previously uncharacterized C-terminal helix bundle, and mutations within this interface abrogate dimerization, DNA bending, and nuclease activity. This work provides the first structural snapshot of an ICL being processed and reveals an elegant dimeric architecture that underpins the precision of ICL repair.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural Basis for Inter-strand Crosslink Repair by the FAN1 Nuclease Dimeric Scaffold

text: Translational dynamics are profoundly influenced by codon usage and tRNA availability, but how this is regulated under stress is unclear. Using ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) in yeast exposed to oxidative stress, we identified robust, codon-specific ribosome pausing at AAA and CAA lysine codons. This pausing was not correlated with cognate tRNA abundance but was linked to the hypomodification of the wobble uridine (U34) in tRNA-Lys-UUU, as quantified by mass spectrometry. We demonstrate that the radical S-adenosyl-L-methionine (SAM) enzyme, Elp3, responsible for the mcm5s2U34 modification, is inactivated by oxidative damage, leading to unmodified tRNAs that are less efficient at decoding. This transient pausing selectively reduces the synthesis of proteins enriched in lysine, including numerous glycolytic enzymes, thereby facilitating a rapid metabolic reprogramming. Our study reveals a direct link between tRNA modification status and codon-specific translational control, representing a swift and elegant mechanism for adapting the proteome to environmental stress.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Ribosome Profiling Uncovers Codon-Specific Translational Pausing Modulated by tRNA Hypomodification in Response to Oxidative Stress

text: We investigate the open quantum dynamics of a bipartite system of transmons coupled to a structured reservoir exhibiting non-Markovian memory effects. By employing a reaction-coordinate mapping, we derive a time-convolutionless master equation that captures the system's evolution beyond the Born-Markov approximation. Our numerical simulations demonstrate that reservoir spectral density engineering can induce significant revivals of quantum coherence and entanglement, as quantified by concurrence and quantum mutual information. We observe a direct correlation between the degree of non-Markovianity, measured via the Breuer-Laine-Piilo (BLP) quantifier, and the temporary arrest of fidelity decay in Bell states. These findings suggest that structured environments, often considered detrimental, can be strategically exploited for short-term quantum memory applications and decoherence suppression in noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) processors. The presented theoretical framework provides a robust tool for characterizing and mitigating correlated noise in multi-qubit architectures, paving the way for improved quantum information processing protocols.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Markovian Dynamics and Entanglement Preservation in Coupled Superconducting Qubits

text: The realization of fault-tolerant topological quantum computation hinges upon the unambiguous demonstration of non-Abelian statistics. Here, we report on the experimental braiding of Majorana zero modes (MZMs) in a hybrid semiconductor-superconductor heterostructure patterned into a T-junction network. By performing sequential gate-voltage manipulations, we shuttle and interchange the MZMs localized at the ends of topological nanowires. The resulting quantum state evolution is probed via non-local conductance measurements, which reveal a state transformation matrix consistent with the unitary representation of the braid group B_4. Crucially, the outcome of a two-cycle braid is path-dependent and non-commutative, a hallmark of non-Abelian anyons. We develop a rigorous statistical analysis to distinguish the non-Abelian signature from competing diabatic errors and quasiparticle poisoning events, achieving a fidelity exceeding 0.95. This work provides direct evidence for the foundational principles of topological quantum computation and establishes a viable platform for constructing topologically protected qubits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Experimental Observation of Non-Abelian Braiding Statistics with Majorana Zero Modes in a T-junction Array

text: Bosonic codes, such as the Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill (GKP) code, offer a hardware-efficient pathway to fault-tolerant quantum computing by encoding a qubit into the continuous-variable Hilbert space of a harmonic oscillator. Standard GKP error correction protocols are typically optimized for Gaussian noise. However, many dominant error channels, like single-photon loss in superconducting cavities, are inherently non-Gaussian and biased. We introduce a novel decoding scheme based on a non-linear, adaptive filtering algorithm that significantly outperforms standard decoders in the presence of photon-loss noise. By optimizing the GKP stabilizer measurements and subsequent correction operations for this biased noise model, we demonstrate a substantial increase in the break-even threshold for logical qubit lifetimes. Our results, validated through Monte Carlo simulations of a cavity-QED architecture, show that tailoring correction strategies to specific noise characteristics can dramatically reduce the resource overhead required for building a fault-tolerant quantum computer.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Error Correction with Biased-Noise Tailored Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill Codes

text: The unification of quantum mechanics and general relativity remains a paramount challenge in physics. Many quantum gravity models predict the existence of a minimal length scale, leading to a modified Heisenberg uncertainty principle, often termed the Generalized Uncertainty Principle (GUP). Such modifications imply universal decoherence mechanisms that affect all quantum systems. We propose a high-precision matter-wave interferometry experiment using Bose-Einstein condensates in a macroscopic superposition of spatially separated states to search for signatures of this GUP-induced decoherence. Our theoretical model calculates the expected loss of fringe visibility as a function of the superposition size, evolution time, and the GUP deformation parameter β_0. We show that with state-of-the-art atom interferometers, it is possible to constrain β_0 to a level that probes phenomenological models inspired by string theory and loop quantum gravity. This experiment provides a tangible, low-energy window into the quantum structure of spacetime, pushing the boundaries of experimental tests of fundamental physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Planck-Scale Spacetime Fluctuations with Macroscopic Matter-Wave Interferometry

text: We numerically investigate the many-body localization (MBL) transition in a one-dimensional chain of interacting spins subjected to a periodic drive (a Floquet system) and long-range, power-law decaying interactions. Using Krylov subspace methods and time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (t-DMRG) techniques, we map the phase diagram as a function of disorder strength, interaction range, and drive frequency. In the MBL phase, we observe a robust breakdown of thermalization, characterized by the persistence of local memory and area-law entanglement for eigenstates of the Floquet unitary. Critically, we find that for sufficiently slow-decaying interactions (α < 2), the system exhibits a slow, logarithmic growth of entanglement entropy even deep in the localized phase, indicative of a novel 'MBL-like' regime distinct from the non-interacting Anderson insulator. This logarithmic drift challenges the conventional picture of MBL and suggests a mechanism of many-body dephasing that does not lead to full thermalization.
subject: Kuantum
title: Ergodicity Breaking and Logarithmic Entanglement Growth in a Disordered Floquet System with Long-Range Interactions

text: Lattice gauge theories (LGTs) are fundamental to the Standard Model, yet their simulation on classical computers is notoriously difficult, particularly for real-time dynamics. We present a hybrid quantum-classical algorithm for simulating (2+1)D SU(2) LGT on near-term quantum hardware. Utilizing a variational quantum eigensolver (VQE) framework combined with a compact Hamiltonian encoding based on the loop-string-hadron formulation, we prepare the ground state of the pure gauge theory. We successfully simulate the system up to a 2x2 plaquette lattice, observing the transition from a deconfined to a confined phase by varying the coupling constant. The string tension is extracted from Wilson loop expectation values, showing good agreement with classical lattice Monte Carlo results. We analyze the algorithm's performance on a noisy quantum simulator, investigating the impact of gate errors and readout noise and applying mitigation techniques. This work demonstrates the feasibility of probing non-Abelian physics, a key step toward addressing problems like hadronization in quantum chromodynamics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Variational Quantum Simulation of SU(2) Lattice Gauge Theory in the non-Abelian Regime

text: Neutral atoms in optical tweezer arrays have emerged as a leading platform for quantum simulation due to their scalability and programmability. We demonstrate a high-fidelity controlled-Z (CZ) gate between two Cesium atoms separated by 4 μm, exploiting the Rydberg blockade mechanism. By employing adiabatic pulses and meticulously canceling Stark shifts with a precisely tuned magic-wavelength trap, we achieve a gate fidelity of 0.995(2), benchmarked via interleaved randomized benchmarking. We leverage this high-performance entangling gate to construct a programmable quantum simulator on a 24-atom triangular lattice. We experimentally realize the ground state of the triangular lattice Ising antiferromagnet, a canonical model of frustrated magnetism. By measuring multi-site correlators, we directly observe the characteristic 'weathervane' spin configurations and quantify the residual entropy, providing insights into the highly degenerate ground-state manifold of this complex quantum system.
subject: Kuantum
title: High-Fidelity Entangling Gates and Quantum Simulation of Frustrated Magnetism in a Rydberg Atom Array

text: The precision of optical phase estimation is fundamentally bounded by the Heisenberg limit (HL), which scales as 1/N for N photons. Surpassing this limit is generally considered impossible without non-linear Hamiltonians. Here, we propose and theoretically analyze a quantum metrology protocol that leverages entangled photon catalysis to achieve super-Heisenberg scaling. Our scheme injects a two-mode squeezed vacuum state into a Mach-Zehnder interferometer, where one ancillary mode undergoes a non-deterministic, number-resolving catalysis operation conditioned on a specific photon number detection. We show that the quantum Fisher information of the resulting state scales as N^4, leading to a phase sensitivity scaling of 1/N^2 for a successful catalysis event, where N is the mean photon number of the initial state. While the probabilistic nature of the protocol limits its practical repetition rate, it fundamentally demonstrates that projective measurements and quantum state engineering can circumvent conventional scaling limits, opening a new paradigm for ultra-high-precision measurements.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Metrology with Entangled Photon Catalysis: Achieving Super-Heisenberg Scaling

text: The Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) model, a system of randomly interacting Majorana fermions, is a maximally chaotic quantum system with holographic duality to a 2D black hole. We propose a realizable scheme to simulate the N=4 SYK model using a small chain of trapped ions. The all-to-all random four-body interactions are synthesized using a sequence of laser-induced spin-dependent forces, where the random couplings are engineered via optical-frequency combs. We numerically show that the system exhibits key signatures of quantum chaos, including Lyapunov exponents that saturate the chaos bound and spectral statistics matching the Gaussian Orthogonal Ensemble. Furthermore, we outline an experimental protocol to measure out-of-time-order correlators (OTOCs) via interferometric reversal of the system's dynamics, providing a direct probe of information scrambling. This work bridges condensed matter physics, quantum gravity, and quantum information, establishing a concrete platform for experimentally investigating holographic principles and the physics of quantum black holes.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Quantum Simulation of a Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) Model with Trapped Ions

text: The preparation of non-classical states of macroscopic mechanical objects is a central goal in quantum physics, enabling tests of fundamental theories and novel sensing applications. We report the deterministic generation of a squeezed state of a gigahertz-frequency mechanical resonator in a silicon optomechanical crystal. Our protocol utilizes a sequence of strong, detuned optical pulses derived from a single laser, which first cools the resonator near its quantum ground state via sideband cooling and then executes a two-mode squeezing interaction between the optical and mechanical modes. The resulting mechanical quadrature squeezing is verified by homodyning the transmitted optical field, revealing mechanical fluctuations 3.2 ± 0.2 dB below the zero-point level. The generated state's Wigner function is reconstructed via quantum state tomography, confirming its non-classical character with a negative region. This work provides a crucial component for quantum acoustic sensing and the development of hybrid quantum systems where mechanical elements act as transducers.
subject: Kuantum
title: Generation of Mechanical Squeezed States via Pulsed Quantum Optomechanics

text: Conventional Bayesian deep learning methods, particularly stochastic gradient MCMC, often neglect the intrinsic geometric structure of the parameter space, leading to inefficient posterior exploration and suboptimal uncertainty quantification. We introduce Stochastic Manifold Langevin Dynamics (SMLD), a novel sampling algorithm that operates directly on the Riemannian manifold of neural network parameters defined by the Fisher Information Metric. By leveraging a computationally efficient approximation of the metric tensor to construct a preconditioning matrix, SMLD guides the sampling process along geodesics, effectively navigating the complex, high-dimensional, and non-convex posterior landscape. Our theoretical analysis demonstrates superior convergence rates compared to isotropic SGLD. Empirically, we show that SMLD provides significantly better-calibrated uncertainty estimates and improved out-of-distribution detection on challenging regression and classification benchmarks. The proposed method represents a significant step towards geometrically-aware Bayesian inference in deep learning, mitigating issues arising from parameter symmetries and redundancies.
subject: AI
title: Stochastic Manifold Langevin Dynamics for Bayesian Deep Learning with Intrinsic Geometric Priors

text: Learning disentangled representations that align with the underlying causal factors of data generation remains a formidable challenge. We propose the Counterfactual Graph Neural Network (CF-GNN), a framework that learns causally-invariant representations by explicitly modeling the data generation process as a Structural Causal Model (SCM). The model comprises two key components: a GNN-based module that learns the latent causal graph structure from observational data, and a variational autoencoder that enforces disentanglement through a novel counterfactual objective. This objective minimizes the representational variance under hypothetical interventions on the learned causal graph, compelling the latent variables to correspond to independent causal mechanisms. We demonstrate through extensive experiments on synthetic and semi-synthetic datasets that CF-GNNs can successfully identify ground-truth causal variables and exhibit superior out-of-distribution generalization compared to state-of-the-art disentanglement methods that rely solely on statistical independence.
subject: AI
title: Causal Disentanglement via Counterfactual Graph Neural Networks

text: Statistical heterogeneity across clients presents a primary obstacle in federated learning (FL), limiting the performance of a single global model. To address this, we introduce Federated Meta-Learning with Hypernetwork-Modulated Task Priors (FedMeta-HMT), a novel hierarchical framework for enhanced personalization. A central hypernetwork learns a low-dimensional embedding of each client's data distribution, which in turn modulates a globally shared, low-rank task prior to generate client-specific model parameters. This mechanism allows for efficient communication of personalization information without transmitting raw data or large models. The meta-objective is formulated to optimize both the hypernetwork and the shared prior for rapid adaptation on new clients or tasks. On highly non-IID benchmarks, FedMeta-HMT demonstrates significant improvements in personalized accuracy, convergence speed, and robustness to client dropout over prominent FL and federated meta-learning baselines like FedAvg, Per-FedAvg, and Reptile.
subject: AI
title: Federated Meta-Learning with Hypernetwork-Modulated Task Priors for Personalized Models

text: Deep reinforcement learning (RL) agents often fail to satisfy complex, long-horizon safety and liveness constraints, hindering their deployment in safety-critical domains. We propose a neuro-symbolic framework that integrates Linear Temporal Logic (LTL) specifications directly into the policy optimization loop via differentiable programming. We first compile an LTL formula into a differentiable finite automaton (DFA), which serves as a symbolic layer providing a quantitative satisfaction score for a given state-action trajectory. This score is then used to construct a dense, temporally-aware reward signal. The policy, represented by a neural network, is trained using a hybrid objective that combines extrinsic task rewards with a satisfaction gradient derived from the DFA. This tight integration of symbolic reasoning and deep RL enables the synthesis of policies that are provably correct with respect to the given LTL specification while maximizing task performance on complex robotic manipulation benchmarks.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic Policy Synthesis using Temporal Logic-Guided Differentiable Programming

text: Incorporating discrete latent variables into Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) is notoriously difficult due to the non-differentiability of the sampling process, which breaks standard backpropagation. We introduce a novel gradient-free optimization scheme, termed Evolutionary Policy Gradient for GANs (EPG-GAN), to effectively train GANs with complex, discrete latent structures. In our framework, the generator is decomposed into a stochastic policy network that samples from a categorical latent space and a conditional deterministic network that maps latent codes to data. We employ a zeroth-order gradient estimator, specifically an evolutionary strategy, to update the policy parameters, using the discriminator's output as a fitness signal. This approach circumvents the need for biased, high-variance estimators like Gumbel-Softmax or REINFORCE. EPG-GAN enables stable training of generators with hierarchical discrete latents, achieving superior mode coverage, sample diversity, and controllable generation on ImageNet and CLEVR.
subject: AI
title: Gradient-Free Optimization of Discrete Latent Structures in Generative Adversarial Networks

text: Predicting the future trajectories of multiple interacting agents in dynamic environments requires sophisticated modeling of evolving spatio-temporal dependencies. We present the Dynamic Spatio-Temporal Graph Transformer (DSTGT), a novel architecture that captures these complex relationships. At each timestep, a dynamic spatial graph is constructed where nodes represent agents and edges encode social interactions, which are processed by a graph transformer to model intra-frame relational dependencies. The resulting sequence of agent-centric graph embeddings is then fed into a temporal transformer, which leverages self-attention to capture long-range dynamics and inter-agent influences over time. Our model introduces a learned interaction-type embedding that modulates the attention mechanism, allowing it to differentiate between various social behaviors. DSTGT establishes a new state-of-the-art on the Argoverse and nuScenes motion forecasting benchmarks, demonstrating superior performance in generating accurate, multi-modal, and socially compliant trajectory predictions.
subject: AI
title: Dynamic Spatio-Temporal Graph Transformers for Multi-Agent Trajectory Prediction

text: The propensity of neural networks for catastrophic forgetting in continual learning settings remains a critical limitation. We propose Bayesian Online Meta-Plasticity (BOMP), a framework that mitigates forgetting by maintaining an online Bayesian posterior over a set of meta-parameters governing synaptic plasticity. This approach uses efficient variational inference to update the distribution over these meta-parameters, which control per-synapse learning rates. The model's epistemic uncertainty, derived from the posterior, is used to dynamically modulate plasticity; synapses deemed important for previous tasks exhibit lower plasticity, thereby protecting consolidated knowledge. This mechanism obviates the need for storing exemplars from past tasks. We demonstrate that BOMP significantly reduces catastrophic forgetting on challenging class-incremental benchmarks like Split-CIFAR100 and 5-dataset, outperforming prominent regularization-based methods and achieving performance competitive with rehearsal-based approaches, but with substantially lower memory overhead.
subject: AI
title: Uncertainty-Aware Continual Learning with Bayesian Online Meta-Plasticity

text: Aligning representations from heterogeneous modalities like vision and language is a central challenge in building powerful foundation models. We propose a novel self-supervised pre-training objective, the Cross-Modal Information Bottleneck (CMIB), designed to learn abstract, shared concepts. Unlike contrastive learning which pushes representations of paired instances together, CMIB trains a multimodal encoder to produce a compressed latent representation that is maximally informative about the semantics of one modality (e.g., text caption) while being minimally informative about the instance-specific details of the other modality (e.g., the specific image pixels), subject to a joint representation constraint. This variational objective forces the model to discard modality-specific noise and distill the core semantic content that is common across modalities. Models pre-trained using CMIB demonstrate superior zero-shot and few-shot transfer capabilities on a suite of downstream tasks, including VQA and image-text retrieval, outperforming SOTA contrastive methods.
subject: AI
title: Self-Supervised Pre-training of Multimodal Foundation Models via Cross-Modal Information Bottleneck

text: The reliability of Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) in safety-critical applications is hindered by their lack of robust uncertainty quantification. We introduce a principled framework for PINNs to simultaneously estimate epistemic and aleatoric uncertainty. Epistemic uncertainty is captured through a Monte Carlo dropout-based deep ensemble, representing uncertainty in the model parameters. Crucially, we address aleatoric uncertainty by augmenting the PINN architecture with a second output head that predicts a location-dependent variance (heteroscedasticity) for the data-driven component of the loss. The network is trained by minimizing a composite loss function comprising the PDE residual and a negative log-likelihood term that accounts for this predicted data noise. Our Heteroscedastic PINN (H-PINN) provides well-calibrated uncertainty bounds when solving complex partial differential equations, correctly identifying regions of high prediction error attributable to both insufficient physics constraints and noisy observational data.
subject: AI
title: Heteroscedastic and Aleatoric Uncertainty Estimation in Physics-Informed Neural Networks

text: Modeling physical systems with many-body (N > 2) interactions, such as those in molecular dynamics, poses a challenge for standard GNNs which are inherently pairwise. To address this, we introduce Equivariant Hypergraph Neural Networks (EHNNs), a novel architecture that explicitly models N-ary relations while preserving fundamental physical symmetries. Our model operates on hypergraphs where hyperedges directly represent multi-body interactions. We formulate SE(3)-equivariant message passing operations between nodes and hyperedges, leveraging irreducible representations (irreps) of the SO(3) group to ensure that feature vectors transform correctly under rotations and translations of the input coordinates. This geometric deep learning approach enables the model to learn interaction potentials from data without violating physical laws. EHNNs demonstrate superior sample efficiency and predictive accuracy on complex N-body simulation tasks compared to state-of-the-art equivariant GNNs, accurately capturing higher-order physical effects.
subject: AI
title: Equivariant Hypergraph Neural Networks for N-Body Interaction Systems

text: The definitive experimental verification of non-Abelian statistics in topological phases of matter remains a paramount objective for realizing fault-tolerant quantum computation. We theoretically propose and numerically simulate a quasiparticle interferometry experiment in the ν=5/2 fractional quantum Hall state to directly probe the non-Abelian braiding of Ising anyons. Our model employs a Fabry-Pérot interferometer defined by two quantum point contacts. We calculate the transport characteristics, specifically the backscattered current's dependence on magnetic flux and gate voltage. The simulations reveal specific interference patterns, including a characteristic π-phase shift in conductance oscillations, that are uniquely determined by the non-Abelian fusion rules and braiding matrices of the Pfaffian or anti-Pfaffian state. Crucially, our analysis demonstrates how to distinguish these signatures from confounding effects like Coulomb charging and Aharonov-Bohm interference of Abelian quasiparticles, offering a concrete roadmap for experimentally validating the non-Abelian nature of excitations in this exotic quantum fluid.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Non-Abelian Anyonic Statistics via Quasiparticle Interferometry in a Fractional Quantum Hall System

text: The transition from an ergodic, thermalizing phase to a non-ergodic many-body localized (MBL) phase represents a fundamental breakdown of equilibrium statistical mechanics in isolated quantum systems. We investigate this phenomenon in a one-dimensional spin-1 Bose-Hubbard model with quenched random on-site potentials. Utilizing large-scale exact diagonalization and time-evolving block decimation (TEBD) methods, we comprehensively map the phase diagram. We characterize the MBL transition by analyzing the gap ratio from the energy level statistics, which transitions from Wigner-Dyson to Poissonian distributions. Furthermore, we study the dynamics of entanglement entropy following a quantum quench, observing a hallmark logarithmic growth in time within the MBL phase, contrasted with linear growth in the ergodic regime. Our results indicate that the additional spin degree of freedom significantly alters the localization properties compared to the spinless case, providing new insights into the mechanisms that stabilize the MBL phase against thermalization in multi-component quantum systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Many-Body Localization and the Breakdown of Eigenstate Thermalization in a Disordered Spin-1 Bose-Hubbard Model

text: Decoherence induced by non-Markovian noise environments poses a significant obstacle to scalable quantum information processing. We present a theoretical analysis of coherence protection in a multi-qubit register of superconducting transmons utilizing advanced dynamical decoupling (DD) pulse sequences. The environment is modeled as a structured bath with a 1/f^α spectral density, capturing prevalent low-frequency noise. Employing the filter function formalism, we design and evaluate the performance of concatenated and Uhrig DD sequences. Our results demonstrate that these protocols create sharp frequency combs in the filter function, effectively decoupling the qubit dynamics from the dominant noise modes. We quantify the coherence lifetime enhancement, showing a multi-order-of-magnitude improvement over free-induction decay. Furthermore, we analyze the impact of finite pulse widths and inter-qubit crosstalk on sequence fidelity, establishing practical performance bounds and providing a robust framework for mitigating decoherence in next-generation multi-qubit quantum processors.
subject: Kuantum
title: Dynamical Decoupling and Coherence Protection of a Multi-Qubit Register Coupled to a Non-Markovian Environment

text: Objective collapse models, which postulate a fundamental, non-unitary modification to Schrödinger's equation, offer a potential resolution to the quantum measurement problem and a link between quantum mechanics and gravity. We propose a novel experimental scheme to test the Diósi-Penrose (DP) model of gravitationally-induced wave function collapse. The protocol involves generating and maintaining a macroscopic quantum superposition (a Schrödinger cat state) of the center-of-mass motion of a cryogenically cooled, high-Q silicon nitride membrane resonator. We calculate the predicted decoherence rate induced by the DP mechanism for this mesoscopic system. Our analysis shows that with state-of-the-art optomechanical control and environmental noise suppression, the experimental sensitivity can reach levels sufficient to probe the parameter-free version of the DP model. This experiment would place stringent new bounds on collapse model parameters, potentially falsifying specific formulations of gravity-related objective collapse and pushing the quantum-classical boundary into an untested regime.
subject: Kuantum
title: Gravitational Decoherence and Objective Collapse Models: A Test via High-Precision Optomechanical Resonators

text: The Multi-scale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (MERA) provides a powerful tensor network representation for the ground states of critical quantum systems, embodying a discrete realization of the AdS/CFT correspondence. However, standard MERA is optimized for systems with local interactions. We introduce a generalized MERA architecture tailored for one-dimensional critical systems governed by Hamiltonians with algebraically decaying long-range interactions. This long-range MERA (lr-MERA) modifies the causal cone structure by incorporating non-local isometries whose range is adjusted at each renormalization scale. We apply this ansatz to the transverse-field Ising model with 1/r^α interactions. Numerical simulations demonstrate that lr-MERA accurately captures the key physical properties, including the logarithmic violation of the entanglement area law and the power-law decay of correlation functions, with significantly higher fidelity and computational efficiency than both standard MERA and DMRG, particularly in the regime where long-range effects are dominant.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Renormalization for Critical Quantum Spin Chains with Long-Range Interactions

text: The Leggett-Garg inequality (LGI) tests the conflict between quantum mechanics and the worldview of macroscopic realism, which posits that a macroscopic system possesses definite properties independent of observation. We report on the experimental violation of the LGI using a superconducting phase qubit. Central to our experiment is the implementation of a non-invasive measurement protocol based on quantum weak measurements. By weakly coupling the qubit to a microwave resonator and continuously monitoring the cavity's phase shift, we reconstruct the qubit's quantum trajectory with minimal back-action, satisfying the criterion of non-invasive measurability. We then perform correlations between measurement outcomes at three distinct times and demonstrate a violation of the LGI by more than five standard deviations. This result provides compelling evidence against macroscopic realism and confirms the persistence of quantum coherence through a sequence of measurements in a solid-state macroscopic quantum system.
subject: Kuantum
title: Violation of a Leggett-Garg Inequality Using Non-Invasive Weak Measurements on a Superconducting Phase Qubit

text: Periodically driven quantum systems, described by Floquet theory, provide a dynamic route to engineer novel topological phases of matter not found in static equilibrium. We theoretically demonstrate the induction of a topological phase transition in a graphene nanoribbon by irradiation with circularly polarized light. Using a combination of Floquet-Bloch theory and numerical calculations of the Floquet Hamiltonian, we show that the off-resonant driving field dynamically opens a non-trivial band gap at the Dirac points. The resulting gapped system is characterized by a non-zero Floquet Chern number, rendering it a Floquet topological insulator, analogous to the quantum anomalous Hall effect. We calculate the emergent chiral edge states and the corresponding quantized Hall conductance. Our analysis identifies the critical driving amplitude and frequency required to induce the transition, providing a clear pathway for the experimental realization and optical control of topological transport in graphene-based devices.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Phase Transition in a Floquet-Engineered Graphene Nanoribbon

text: Strong and continuous interactions can confine a quantum system's evolution to a decoherence-free subspace, a phenomenon known as quantum Zeno dynamics. We investigate this effect in an ultracold atomic gas where strong, long-range Rydberg-Rydberg interactions provide the constraining mechanism. We show that the Rydberg blockade effect projects the many-body dynamics onto a constrained Hilbert subspace, effectively creating a kinetic constraint that inhibits simultaneous excitation of nearby atoms. This leads to a dramatic fragmentation of the Hilbert space and a breakdown of thermalization, distinct from MBL. Using master equation simulations and an effective Hamiltonian formalism, we characterize the emergent constrained dynamics and predict the existence of long-lived, non-ergodic oscillations between specific many-body states. We propose experimental protocols using electromagnetically induced transparency to prepare and probe these Zeno-confined dynamics, highlighting their potential for simulating constrained models like lattice gauge theories.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Zeno Dynamics and Subspace Confinement in a Multi-Atom Rydberg Gas

text: The real-time evolution of quantum field theories presents a computationally prohibitive challenge for classical computers, yet it is a natural application for quantum simulators. We report a variational quantum simulation of the dynamics of the (1+1)-dimensional Schwinger model, a quantum electrodynamics analogue, on a programmable trapped-ion quantum computer. Our method employs a hybrid quantum-classical algorithm where the time-evolution operator is approximated by a parameterized quantum circuit whose parameters are optimized using a variational principle. We successfully simulate the phenomenon of electron-positron pair creation from a bare vacuum state, observing the expected density oscillations and entanglement propagation between lattice sites. By comparing our experimental data with exact theoretical predictions, we verify the high-fidelity simulation for short time-scales and characterize the primary sources of algorithmic and hardware errors, demonstrating the capability of near-term quantum devices for probing fundamental problems in high-energy physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Variational Quantum Simulation of Lattice Schwinger Model Dynamics on a Trapped-Ion Processor

text: Non-Hermitian Hamiltonians, which effectively describe open quantum systems with gain or loss, can host topological phenomena without Hermitian counterparts. We report the direct experimental observation of the non-Hermitian skin effect (NHSE) in a discrete-time photonic quantum walk. By engineering asymmetric hopping amplitudes in a one-dimensional lattice of coupled optical modes using polarization-dependent beam displacers, we implement a non-reciprocal system. We directly image the light distribution after a number of walk steps, providing unambiguous evidence for the NHSE: an extensive number of bulk-band eigenstates become localized at the system's boundary. This phenomenon leads to a breakdown of the conventional bulk-boundary correspondence, where the bulk topological invariant fails to predict the existence of edge states. Our results demonstrate the robust experimental control of non-Hermitian topological properties in a photonic platform, opening avenues for developing novel light-trapping devices and sensors with enhanced sensitivity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Hermitian Skin Effect and Anomalous Bulk-Boundary Correspondence in a Photonic Quantum Walk

text: We introduce a novel Bayesian nonparametric approach for function-on-scalar regression, addressing the challenge of modeling infinite-dimensional functional responses. The core of our methodology is the representation of the unknown functional coefficient through a projection onto a data-driven basis derived from a Gaussian Process (GP) prior. A hierarchical structure is imposed, wherein a sophisticated hyper-prior on the GP's covariance kernel parameters (e.g., length-scale and amplitude) effectively regularizes the smoothness and intrinsic dimensionality of the functional coefficient, thus performing adaptive model selection within a coherent Bayesian framework. We develop an efficient Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm, integrating Gibbs sampling with Hamiltonian Monte Carlo steps, for posterior computation. Theoretical results establishing the posterior consistency of the functional coefficient estimator under mild regularity conditions are provided. The method's efficacy in capturing complex functional relationships and delivering robust uncertainty quantification is demonstrated on simulated datasets and magnetoencephalography (MEG) data analysis.
subject: İstatistik
title: Function-on-Scalar Regression via Gaussian Process Projections with Hyper-Prior Regularization

text: Standard statistical summaries often fail to capture the multi-scale geometric and topological features inherent in complex data. This paper develops a rigorous framework for statistical inference on persistence diagrams, the primary output of persistent homology. We define a population-level Fréchet mean of persistence diagrams within the 2-Wasserstein space and propose a consistent estimator. To circumvent the instability of bootstrapping diagrams directly, we leverage a geometric bootstrap procedure on the initial point-cloud data to construct confidence regions for topological features, such as Betti numbers at specific filtration scales. We prove the convergence of our bootstrap distribution to the true sampling distribution of the persistence diagram estimator. This framework facilitates formal hypothesis testing for differences in topological structure between populations, enabling novel insights. We showcase its power in differentiating classes of dynamical systems from time-series data and in analyzing neuronal morphology, revealing significant geometric differences not detectable by conventional methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Persistence-Homology-Based Statistical Inference for Complex Data Geometries

text: Classical robust estimators are designed for casewise outliers and perform poorly under cellwise contamination, a prevalent scenario in modern high-dimensional datasets where only specific entries are corrupted. We introduce the Penalized Minimum Covariance Determinant (PMCD) estimator, a novel method for robust covariance and precision matrix estimation under cellwise contamination. The PMCD jointly seeks a subset of clean observations and a sparse precision matrix by minimizing a penalized determinant criterion. This objective function integrates an elastic net penalty on the precision matrix elements, promoting both sparsity and stability. We propose an efficient iterative algorithm that alternates between subset selection and penalized covariance estimation and establish its convergence. Theoretical properties, including the estimator's breakdown point and consistency under a cellwise contamination model, are derived. Extensive simulations show that PMCD outperforms state-of-the-art robust methods and graphical LASSO variants in both estimation accuracy and outlier identification.
subject: İstatistik
title: Cellwise-Robust Covariance Estimation via a Penalized Minimum Covariance Determinant

text: Performing online Bayesian inference in complex, non-linear state-space models is computationally demanding. Sequential Monte Carlo methods can suffer from particle degeneracy, while MCMC is often too slow. We propose Amortized Stein Variational Gradient Descent (ASVGD), a scalable algorithm for sequential inference that synergizes the particle-based optimization of Stein Variational Gradient Descent (SVGD) with the efficiency of amortized inference. A recurrent neural network is trained to propose a variational distribution by mapping the history of observations to the distribution's parameters. At each time step, a set of particles initialized from this proposal is refined via a few SVGD update steps, which deterministically transport the particles to better approximate the true posterior by minimizing the Kernelized Stein Discrepancy. This amortized initialization substantially accelerates convergence. We provide theoretical guarantees on the particle system's behavior and demonstrate empirically on challenging filtering problems that ASVGD achieves higher log-likelihoods and more accurate state estimation than competing VI and SMC methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Amortized Stein Variational Gradient Descent for Sequential Bayesian Inference

text: In survival analysis with competing risks, directly modeling the cumulative incidence function (CIF) offers greater interpretability than modeling cause-specific hazards, but existing methods are ill-suited for high-dimensional settings. We propose a two-stage regression framework based on jackknife pseudo-values of the CIF. In the first stage, a non-parametric Aalen-Johansen estimator is used to compute the CIF for each event type. In the second stage, pseudo-values are generated and employed as the response variable in a penalized regression model, such as the LASSO or elastic net, enabling simultaneous variable selection and effect estimation. This approach circumvents the restrictive proportional hazards assumption of cause-specific models and directly quantifies covariate effects on the marginal event probability. We establish the asymptotic properties of the estimators, including oracle inequalities for variable selection under high-dimensional sparsity. Simulation studies and an application to a cancer genomics dataset validate the method's superior selection and estimation performance.
subject: İstatistik
title: Pseudo-value Regression for Direct Modeling of the Cumulative Incidence Function with High-Dimensional Covariates

text: Estimating heterogeneous treatment effects (HTEs) in the presence of unmeasured confounding is a central challenge in causal inference. We develop a novel semiparametric framework for estimating the conditional average treatment effect (CATE) function using instrumental variables (IV). Our approach is founded on the construction of an orthogonal score function for the CATE parameter, which makes the final estimator first-order insensitive to regularization biases in non-parametric nuisance function estimates. The method leverages flexible machine learning algorithms to estimate these nuisance components—including conditional expectations and propensity scores—and then computes a debiased CATE estimate by solving the orthogonal moment equations. We derive the efficient influence function for the CATE in the IV setting and demonstrate that our estimator is asymptotically normal and semiparametrically efficient. The resulting CATE estimates are robust to machine learning errors, and we provide a method for constructing uniform confidence bands, advancing rigorous personalized inference from observational data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Orthogonal Score-Based Semiparametric Inference for Personalized Treatment Effects with Instrumental Variables

text: Classical functional data analysis (FDA) assumes data reside in a Euclidean vector space, an invalid premise for data constrained to non-linear spaces like symmetric positive-definite matrices or spheres. We introduce a comprehensive framework for Fréchet regression with functional data whose values are points on a Riemannian manifold. Our model defines the conditional Fréchet mean of the manifold-valued response as a geodesic path parameterized by scalar covariates. Estimation proceeds by minimizing the sum of squared geodesic distances between the observed and fitted values. We develop a computationally tractable algorithm based on tangent space projections; it iteratively alternates between using the logarithmic map to project data onto a tangent space, performing linear estimation, and using the exponential map to project results back to the manifold. We derive the asymptotic properties, including consistency and convergence rates, of the estimated geodesic regression curve under appropriate geometric conditions, and showcase its utility by modeling diffusion tensor brain imaging data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Fréchet Regression for Functional Data on Riemannian Manifolds

text: Estimating large-scale Vector Autoregressive (VAR) models is hampered by the curse of dimensionality. We propose a hierarchical Bayesian framework for sparse VAR estimation and Granger causal network inference in high-dimensional time series. The methodology centers on a continuous spike-and-slab prior imposed on the VAR coefficients, which induces sparsity and facilitates adaptive shrinkage, pulling negligible coefficients towards zero while preserving influential ones. Crucially, this prior is structured hierarchically to enable group-wise variable selection, directly testing for Granger causality from one entire time series to another, a key objective in multivariate time series analysis. This approach provides direct posterior inclusion probabilities for both individual coefficients and Granger causal links. We establish posterior consistency for parameter estimation and network structure recovery under sparsity assumptions. Comparisons with penalized likelihood methods on simulated and macroeconomic data demonstrate superior performance in both forecasting and network reconstruction.
subject: İstatistik
title: Sparse Vector Autoregression with Granger Causal Structure Learning via a Hierarchical Bayesian Prior

text: Resolving the species boundaries and evolutionary history of rapidly radiating lineages is a persistent challenge, often confounded by incomplete lineage sorting (ILS) and post-speciation gene flow. Here, we employ whole-genome sequencing and phylogenomic inference to dissect the relationships within the cryptic species complex of the green anole, Anolis carolinensis. Our analysis, leveraging both concatenation and multispecies coalescent methods, reveals profound cytonuclear discordance. While mitochondrial DNA supports a clear geographic clade structure, nuclear phylogenies exhibit widespread topological incongruence. D-statistics and related ABBA-BABA tests provide robust evidence for historical introgression, particularly at ecological transition zones. We argue that reticulate evolution, rather than ILS alone, is the predominant force shaping genomic variation in this group. These findings highlight the necessity of integrative, genome-scale approaches to accurately reconstruct the complex branching and merging patterns that characterize the evolutionary history of many adaptive radiations.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Incongruence and Reticulate Evolution in the Anolis carolinensis Cryptic Species Complex

text: The emergence of phenotypic novelty is a central theme in evolutionary developmental biology (evo-devo). We investigate the molecular origins of iridescent wing scales, a key innovation in Heliconius butterflies. Through comparative ATAC-seq and ChIP-seq analyses across multiple species, we identified a novel, lineage-specific cis-regulatory element (CRE) adjacent to the aristaless-like homeobox gene, Alx1. This CRE exhibits strong enhancer activity exclusively in developing wing scale progenitor cells. Functional validation using CRISPR-Cas9-mediated deletion of the enhancer results in a complete loss of iridescent scale morphology, reverting to the ancestral, non-iridescent state without affecting other pleiotropic functions of Alx1. Our results demonstrate that the co-option of a pleiotropic developmental gene for a novel function was mediated not by changes in the coding sequence, but by the de novo evolution of a modular enhancer, providing a compelling case study of cis-regulatory evolution driving morphological innovation.
subject: Evrim
title: Cis-Regulatory Evolution of a Novel Enhancer Drove the Origin of a Key Morphological Innovation in Lepidoptera

text: Hybridization can facilitate rapid adaptation by introducing pre-adapted alleles across species boundaries. We investigated the genomic basis of high-altitude adaptation in a community of Andean passerine birds, identifying a shared, non-coding haplotype upstream of the EGLN1 gene, a key regulator of the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) pathway. Using phased whole-genome data, we demonstrate that this haplotype originated in a high-altitude specialist species and subsequently introgressed into several recently diverged, colonizing congeners. The introgressed haplotype is associated with enhanced hemoglobin-oxygen affinity and lies within a region of exceptionally high population differentiation (FST) and reduced nucleotide diversity, consistent with a hard selective sweep. This study provides strong evidence for adaptive introgression as a mechanism for rapid environmental adaptation, illustrating how gene flow can circumvent the slower process of de novo mutation in response to strong ecological selection pressures.
subject: Evrim
title: Adaptive Introgression of a High-Altitude Hypoxia-Response Allele in Andean Passerines

text: Whole-genome duplication (WGD) events provide raw genetic material for evolutionary innovation, but the mechanisms governing the subsequent rewiring of gene regulatory networks (GRNs) remain poorly understood. We analyzed the genomic architecture of Brassica rapa, a species with a well-characterized paleopolyploidy event. Our integrated analysis of genomic, transcriptomic, and epigenomic data reveals that a significant fraction of retained ohnologs have diverged in their expression patterns due to the insertion of proximal transposable elements (TEs). We demonstrate that these exapted TEs, particularly LTR retrotransposons, introduce novel transcription factor binding sites, effectively rewiring the cis-regulatory landscape and creating new connections within the GRN. This TE-mediated neofunctionalization and subfunctionalization of duplicated genes appears to be a critical, predictable mechanism for resolving genetic redundancy and facilitating evolutionary innovation in the aftermath of polyploidization, contributing substantially to the diversification of angiosperms.
subject: Evrim
title: Transposable Element Exaptation as a Primary Driver of Gene Regulatory Network Rewiring Following Paleopolyploidy in Brassica

text: Antagonistic coevolution, often described by Red Queen dynamics, is a fundamental driver of biodiversity. However, directly observing the genomic signatures of this process in real time is challenging. We conducted a long-term chemostat experiment with Escherichia coli and its lytic bacteriophage T4, collecting time-series genomic data from both populations over 1,000 generations. Our analysis reveals recurrent, reciprocal selective sweeps targeting host cell surface receptors and phage tail fiber proteins, respectively. We observed patterns consistent with negative frequency-dependent selection, where rare host and phage genotypes exhibit a transient fitness advantage. Furthermore, we tracked the dynamic evolution of the host's CRISPR-Cas loci, which rapidly incorporated phage-derived spacers, followed by the emergence of phage escape mutants. This high-resolution genomic time-series provides a direct observation of the molecular arms race, confirming the central tenets of antagonistic coevolution and quantifying the tempo and mode of adaptation in a tightly coupled biotic interaction.
subject: Evrim
title: Reciprocal Antagonistic Coevolution Manifested in Time-Series Genomes of a Bacteriophage and its Host

text: Sensory systems are primary interfaces between an organism and its environment, and their evolution is often tightly linked to ecological shifts. Using paleogenomic data retrieved from well-preserved mammoth specimens spanning the Late Pleistocene, we reconstructed the functional olfactory receptor (OR) gene repertoire of this extinct lineage. By comparing the mammoth OR repertoire to those of extant elephants, we identified a significant expansion in a specific OR subfamily associated with the detection of herbaceous plant volatiles, alongside a contraction of subfamilies related to fruiting plants. The rate of pseudogenization in certain OR genes correlates with paleoclimatic data, suggesting a dynamic response to shifting floral communities during glacial-interglacial cycles. Our findings demonstrate that ancient DNA can illuminate the sensory ecology of extinct megafauna, providing a molecular basis for inferring paleo-ecological interactions and the adaptive pressures shaping sensory modality evolution over geological timescales.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Reconstruction of Olfactory Receptor Gene Repertoires in Pleistocene Mammoths Reveals Ecological Niche Shifts

text: The structure of genetic pleiotropy is a critical determinant of evolutionary trajectories, yet its role in constraining adaptation remains difficult to quantify. We employed a deep mutational scanning approach to measure the fitness effects of thousands of mutations in the essential transcription factor HAP4 across diverse environmental conditions in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. This allowed us to construct a high-dimensional, empirical fitness landscape. We found pervasive antagonistic pleiotropy, where mutations beneficial in one environment were frequently deleterious in others. By simulating adaptive walks on this landscape, we demonstrate that pleiotropic constraints severely limit the number of accessible evolutionary pathways, often trapping populations on suboptimal fitness peaks. The degree of constraint was directly proportional to the dimensionality of the environment. Our results empirically validate the theoretical prediction that pleiotropy is a powerful conservative force in evolution, channeling adaptation along specific, genetically-determined paths and shaping the reproducibility of evolutionary outcomes.
subject: Evrim
title: Quantifying Pleiotropic Constraints on the Adaptive Walk of Saccharomyces cerevisiae on a Complex Fitness Landscape

text: Rapid evolutionary radiations often produce complex patterns of genomic variation that are difficult to interpret with standard phylogenetic methods. In this study, we analyze a dataset of over 2,000 ultraconserved elements (UCEs) from a recent, rapid radiation of South American flycatchers (Tyrannidae). Traditional concatenation-based phylogenies yield poorly supported nodes and conflicting topologies. To resolve this, we implemented multispecies coalescent network (MSCN) models, which simultaneously estimate species relationships and reticulation events. Our results indicate that while incomplete lineage sorting (ILS) is pervasive across the genome, a significant portion of the observed phylogenetic incongruence is better explained by post-speciation gene flow, particularly between sympatric sister lineages. The MSCN framework identifies specific 'admixture edges' with high posterior probability. This work underscores the importance of moving beyond simple bifurcating models to account for the semi-permeable nature of species boundaries during the early stages of diversification, providing a more nuanced view of reticulate speciation.
subject: Evrim
title: Disentangling Incomplete Lineage Sorting and Post-Speciation Gene Flow in a Rapid Avian Radiation Using Coalescent-Based Models

text: Waddington's hypothesis of genetic assimilation posits that environmentally induced traits can become genetically encoded over evolutionary time. We investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying this process using the butterfly Bicyclus anynana, which exhibits a temperature-induced wing pattern polyphenism. By combining experimental evolution under constant high-temperature selection with whole-genome bisulfite sequencing, we tracked changes in DNA methylation and genetic variation. Initially, the novel phenotype was associated with altered methylation patterns in cis-regulatory regions of key developmental genes, acting as an epigenetic scaffold. Over subsequent generations of selection, we observed the accumulation of SNPs and small indels within these same differentially methylated regions (DMRs), which eventually stabilized the phenotype even in the absence of the environmental cue. Our findings provide strong molecular evidence that heritable epigenetic variation can precede and guide genetic changes, facilitating the canalization of ancestrally plastic traits and offering a mechanistic basis for genetic assimilation.
subject: Evrim
title: Epigenetic Scaffolding and Genetic Assimilation: The Role of DNA Methylation in the Evolution of a Temperature-Induced Polyphenism

text: The concept of the holobiont posits that a host and its symbiotic microbial community function as a single evolutionary unit. We investigated the co-evolutionary signatures within the coral Acropora digitifera and its associated microbiome using a coupled metagenomic, meta-transcriptomic, and host genomic approach. Our analysis reveals a strong pattern of phylosymbiosis, where the structure of the microbial consortium mirrors the host's population genetic structure across a broad geographic range. We reconstructed metabolic pathways for the entire holobiont, identifying critical metabolic handoffs and co-dependencies, particularly in nutrient cycling and stress-response pathways. Under thermal stress, coordinated shifts in gene expression were observed between the coral host and specific bacterial and archaeal symbionts, suggesting a functionally integrated response. These results demonstrate deep evolutionary integration and metabolic co-dependency, highlighting that the adaptive capacity and resilience of corals to environmental change are emergent properties of the holobiont as a whole.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylosymbiosis and Metabolic Co-dependency in the Coral Holobiont: A Multi-omic Perspective on Acclimatization and Resilience

text: The precise orchestration of gene expression during cellular differentiation depends on the dynamic remodeling of chromatin. While long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are implicated in this process, their specific mechanisms remain largely elusive. Here, we identify LncRNA-SPATIAL, a nuclear-retained transcript essential for mesodermal specification. Using chromatin isolation by RNA purification (ChIRP-seq) and Hi-C, we demonstrate that LncRNA-SPATIAL directly binds to both the BAF chromatin remodeling complex and specific distal enhancer elements. Its depletion abrogates BAF recruitment, leading to failed enhancer-promoter looping and the collapse of local topological-associated domain (TAD) architecture. Consequently, key mesodermal transcription factors like T-box and MESP1 fail to activate. Our findings reveal a model where a lncRNA acts as a structural scaffold, physically tethering epigenetic machinery to target loci to poise them for rapid transcriptional activation, thereby ensuring fidelity in cell fate decisions. This architectural role highlights a fundamental principle of lncRNA-mediated control over the three-dimensional epigenome.
subject: Biyoloji
title: LncRNA-SPATIAL scaffolds the BAF complex to distal enhancers for lineage-specific gene poising

text: Cytosine base editors (CBEs) enable precise C•G-to-T•A conversions in genomic DNA but can suffer from off-target deamination and undesirable bystander mutations within the editing window. To enhance specificity, we engineered a high-fidelity CBE by fusing a Cas9 nickase (nCas9) to an optimized APOBEC3A deaminase domain and a rationally designed, high-affinity Uracil DNA Glycosylase Inhibitor (UGI) variant. Using deep mutational scanning of the UGI protein interface, we identified variants that exhibit dramatically increased binding affinity for uracilated DNA, effectively shielding the edited base from repair pathways without compromising on-target efficiency. Comprehensive, unbiased whole-genome sequencing of edited cell populations demonstrated a >50-fold reduction in Cas9-independent off-target mutations compared to existing CBE architectures. This engineered construct, termed hiFi-CBE, provides a superior tool for therapeutic gene correction and functional genomics, significantly mitigating the genotoxic risks associated with previous-generation base editors and expanding their applicability.
subject: Biyoloji
title: High-fidelity cytosine base editing via Cas9-nuclease deamination domain fusion with engineered UGI variants

text: Transcription factors often contain intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs), but their functional contributions to gene regulation are poorly understood. We show that the N-terminal IDR of the B-cell transcription factor EBF1 mediates liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS), forming biomolecular condensates at target super-enhancers. In vitro reconstitution assays combined with fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) in vivo demonstrate that these EBF1 condensates are liquid-like and highly dynamic. Deletion or mutation of key aromatic residues within the IDR abrogates phase separation, prevents stable association with super-enhancers, and disrupts transcriptional bursting of target genes. Furthermore, we find that the stoichiometry of EBF1 and its cofactor, RUNX1, modulates the material properties of the condensate, suggesting that regulatory hubs can be fine-tuned. Our results posit that transcription factor-driven phase separation is a primary mechanism for assembling the requisite machinery at enhancers to ensure robust and cell-type-specific gene expression programs.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The intrinsically disordered region of transcription factor EBF1 drives phase separation to form dynamic transcriptional condensates

text: Cells respond to diverse stresses by activating the Integrated Stress Response (ISR), characterized by the phosphorylation of the eukaryotic initiation factor 2 alpha (eIF2α). While this is known to cause global translation attenuation, the mechanisms governing the selective translation of stress-response mRNAs remain unclear. Employing ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) across multiple stress paradigms, we uncovered a conserved translational reprogramming signature. We found that transcripts containing specific upstream open reading frames (uORFs) with suboptimal Kozak sequences are preferentially translated under ISR activation. This selective translation is not solely dependent on uORF presence but also on codon optimality within the main coding sequence. Computational modeling and polysome profiling validation show that phosphorylated eIF2α-GTP-tRNAi ternary complex limitation creates a kinetic bottleneck, allowing ribosomes to bypass inhibitory uORFs on specific transcripts. This reveals a multi-layered code of translational control that permits cellular adaptation and survival under adverse conditions.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Ribosome profiling reveals a conserved translational reprogramming mechanism mediated by eIF2α phosphorylation during integrated stress response

text: Telomere attrition eventually triggers a DNA damage response (DDR) that can lead to either cellular senescence or apoptosis. We investigated the molecular events at critically short telomeres by focusing on the CST (CTC1-STN1-TEN1) complex, a key replisome component and telomere-capping factor. We demonstrate that the ataxia-telangiectasia mutated (ATM) kinase, a central DDR transducer, directly phosphorylates CTC1 and STN1 on multiple serine residues upon telomere deprotection. Using phosphomimetic mutants, we show that this phosphorylation event is a molecular switch that inhibits the fill-in synthesis activity of Polα-primase, promoting excessive 3' overhang resection by the EXO1 nuclease. This altered processing generates a substrate for aberrant homologous recombination, leading to the telomere fusions characteristic of replicative crisis. Our findings elucidate a critical mechanism whereby the DDR, when activated at telomeres, paradoxically promotes genomic instability by coopting and functionally altering a canonical DNA replication and protection complex.
subject: Biyoloji
title: ATM-dependent phosphorylation of CST complex components dictates telomeric overhang processing during replicative crisis

text: Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) differentiation is a paradigm for understanding cell fate decisions, yet the interplay between chromatin accessibility and transcriptional programs at the single-cell level remains incompletely mapped. We performed concurrent single-cell profiling of the transcriptome (scRNA-seq) and chromatin accessibility (scATAC-seq) on thousands of murine bone marrow progenitor cells. By integrating these multi-modal data, we constructed a high-resolution developmental trajectory of myelopoiesis. Pseudotemporal ordering revealed waves of transcription factor (TF) activity, where pioneer factors such as PU.1 establish chromatin accessibility at lineage-specific enhancers precedes the expression of downstream master regulators like GATA1 and CEBPA. We computationally inferred gene regulatory networks (GRNs) demonstrating that transient, low-affinity TF binding events are crucial for priming chromatin for subsequent, stable lineage commitment. This integrative approach provides unprecedented insight into the hierarchical regulatory logic governing hematopoietic differentiation, resolving long-standing questions about lineage priming and plasticity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated single-cell ATAC- and RNA-seq dissects hematopoietic stem cell fate trajectories during myelopoiesis

text: The transition from neural progenitors to mature neurons requires a profound remodeling of the cellular transcriptome, driven largely by alternative splicing (AS). The RNA-binding protein PTBP1 is a well-known repressor of neuronal AS programs in non-neuronal cells. Here, we demonstrate its paralog, PTBP2, functions not as a simple replacement but as an active orchestrator of a secondary, neuron-specific splicing cascade. Using iCLIP-seq and deep RNA-seq in differentiating cortical neurons, we show that downregulation of PTBP1 allows for the inclusion of a poison exon in PTBP2 pre-mRNA, leading to a controlled switch in their expression. Newly expressed PTBP2 then targets a distinct set of pre-mRNAs, including those encoding critical synaptic scaffolding proteins and ion channels. This PTBP1-to-PTBP2 handover establishes a temporal logic that first unlocks a generic neuronal program and then refines it, ensuring the precise molecular composition required for synaptogenesis and neuronal excitability.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The RNA-binding protein PTBP2 orchestrates a cascading alternative splicing network essential for neuronal differentiation

text: The covalent attachment of ATG8 family proteins (e.g., LC3B) to phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) on the nascent autophagosome is a central event in autophagy. This ubiquitin-like conjugation system involves the E1-like enzyme ATG7, the E2-like enzyme ATG3, and the E3-like ATG12-ATG5-ATG16L1 complex. We report the 3.1 Å resolution cryo-electron microscopy structure of the complete human ATG16L1-WIPI2 subcomplex in the act of transferring LC3B to ATG3. The structure reveals how the WD40 propeller of WIPI2, a PtdIns(3)P effector, positions the ATG12-ATG5-ATG16L1 E3-like ligase on the membrane. Critically, we identify a conserved C-terminal alpha-helix in ATG16L1 that directly contacts ATG3, orienting its catalytic cysteine towards the membrane to facilitate efficient PE lipidation. This structural snapshot provides a mechanistic basis for how membrane recognition is coupled to the catalytic transfer of ATG8, explaining the spatial regulation of autophagosome biogenesis during processes like PINK1/Parkin-mediated mitophagy.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM structure of the human ATG8-conjugation machinery reveals the molecular basis of ubiquitin-like lipidation in mitophagy

text: Diabetic complications often persist even after glycemic control is achieved, a phenomenon known as metabolic memory. The epigenetic basis for this memory remains poorly defined. We exposed primary human endothelial cells to transient high glucose and performed time-course chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq). We discovered that transient hyperglycemia induces de novo establishment of bivalent chromatin domains, marked by both the activating H3K4me3 and repressive H3K27me3 histone modifications, at the promoters of key pro-inflammatory genes like NF-κB and IL-6. These bivalent marks persist for multiple cell divisions after the return to normoglycemia, poising the genes for hyper-induction upon a secondary stimulus. Mechanistically, high glucose promotes the transient dissociation of the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) while allowing Trithorax group protein recruitment. This study reveals bivalent domains as a key epigenetic carrier of metabolic memory, providing a molecular rationale for the long-term vascular inflammation in diabetes.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Transient hyperglycemic stress induces persistent H3K4me3-H3K27me3 bivalent chromatin domains at inflammatory gene loci

text: Proteostasis failure leading to the accumulation of misfolded protein aggregates is a hallmark of neurodegenerative diseases. We investigated the role of chaperone-assisted selective autophagy (CASA) in clearing early, soluble amyloidogenic oligomers of huntingtin (Htt). Using super-resolution microscopy and in vitro reconstitution, we show that the co-chaperone BAG3, in complex with HSP70, recognizes exposed hydrophobic patches on oligomeric Htt species but not mature fibrils. This recognition event induces a conformational change in BAG3, unmasking a binding site for the autophagy receptor p62/SQSTM1. The subsequent BAG3-p62 interaction facilitates the ubiquitination-independent recruitment of the nascent autophagosome via p62's LIR motif. Depletion of BAG3 or disruption of its interaction with p62 leads to the accumulation of toxic oligomers and accelerated cellular degeneration. Our findings define a specific CASA-mediated quality control pathway that acts as a first line of defense against proteotoxicity by selectively targeting aggregation-prone intermediates for lysosomal degradation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Chaperone-assisted selective autophagy (CASA) targets early-stage amyloidogenic oligomers via a BAG3-p62 signaling axis

text: We investigate the saturation number for Berge cycles in r-uniform hypergraphs. Let sat(n, H) be the minimum number of edges in an H-free r-uniform hypergraph on n vertices such that adding any new edge creates a copy of H. We establish a new upper bound for sat(n, C_k^(r)), where C_k^(r) is the family of r-uniform Berge cycles of length k. Our primary method employs a refined application of the dependent random choice lemma, augmented with a vertex-coloring argument to control short cycles in an auxiliary graph structure. This approach circumvents the limitations of standard supersaturation results, which are ineffective for sparse saturation problems. For r=3 and k≥5, our result improves upon the previously best-known bounds by a polynomial factor in n. The construction provides a nearly tight bound for specific regimes of k relative to r, and we conjecture that the leading term of our asymptotic formula is optimal for all fixed k and r.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Chromatic Saturation of Hypergraphs via Dependent Random Choice
