text: This paper establishes a new combinatorial rule for the action of the Nabla operator ∇ on Schur functions, a central problem in the study of diagonal harmonics. We introduce a class of decorated parking functions, termed 'interlaced parking functions', whose weighted sum generates the polynomial ∇s_λ. The proof proceeds by defining a sign-reversing involution on a larger set of combinatorial objects, linking our formula to the intricate cancellation properties inherent in Macdonald polynomial theory. This result provides a purely combinatorial proof for a special case of the rational shuffle conjecture at t=1/q, relating the Frobenius characteristic of the module of diagonal harmonics to specific statistics on parking functions. Furthermore, our framework offers a novel perspective on the compositional refinement of the shuffle conjecture and suggests a path towards its generalization for other root systems beyond type A.
subject: Matematik
title: A Combinatorial Formula for Nabla of Schur Functions and the Rational Shuffle Conjecture

text: We analyze the threshold for the existence of a Hamiltonian cycle in random d-lifts of r-uniform hypergraphs. Let G be a fixed r-uniform hypergraph, and let G^d be its random d-lift. We prove that for any connected, expansive base hypergraph G, the threshold probability p for G^d to contain a Hamiltonian cycle is sharply concentrated around p = (log d) / (r * d^(r-1)). The proof integrates the second moment method with a delicate patching argument, conditioned on the local structure of the lift. A key innovation is the use of martingale difference sequences tailored to hypergraph extensions, which allows us to control the complex dependencies arising from overlapping hyperedges. This result extends the seminal work on Hamiltonian cycles in binomial random hypergraphs to a structured, sparse setting, providing insight into the phase transitions of random structures built upon deterministic cores and answering a question posed by Linial and Peled.
subject: Matematik
title: Sharp Thresholds for Hamiltonian Cycles in Random Hypergraph Lifts

text: We generalize the inverse theorem for the Gowers uniformity norms to the setting of finite, high-nilpotency-class groups. Specifically, we prove that if a function f: G -> C on a finite group G has a large U^k(G) norm, then f must correlate with a k-step nilpotent character. Our proof departs from the purely additive combinatorial approach and instead leverages tools from nilpotent harmonic analysis and the theory of Mal'cev bases for discrete nilpotent groups. A central component is the construction of a non-abelian 'nil-Bohr' set that captures the function's structure. As a primary application, we establish a quantitative Green-Tao theorem for k-term nilpotent progressions in dense subsets of groups G with a suitably rich structure of normal subgroups, providing polynomial bounds for the density required to guarantee such a progression. This work bridges the gap between traditional additive combinatorics and the structure theory of finite groups.
subject: Matematik
title: Higher-Order Fourier Uniformity in Non-Abelian Groups and Nilpotent Progressions

text: We determine a precise asymptotic formula for the number of rooted planar maps with constraints on both vertex degrees and face sizes. The methodology rests on the derivation of a system of functional equations for the corresponding multivariate generating functions. By applying a specialized version of the Tutte decomposition, we show that these generating functions are D-finite (holonomic). Using techniques from analytic combinatorics in several variables (ACSV), we analyze the minimal dominant singularity of the system, which is found by solving a characteristic polynomial derived from the kernel of the main functional equation. The analysis reveals a complex interplay between the allowed degree and face sets, leading to a new universality class for the growth constant γ. Our results refine the celebrated asymptotic formulae of Tutte and Bender for unrestricted maps and solve a long-standing problem in the enumerative theory of decorated planar structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotic Enumeration of Restricted Planar Maps via Holonomic Generating Functions

text: This paper provides a structural characterization of the class of k-regular matroids, which are representable over every field with at least k elements. We extend Tutte's characterization of regular matroids by proving that for any fixed integer k ≥ 3, the class of k-regular matroids has a finite set of excluded minors. The proof is non-constructive and relies on the well-quasi-ordering of matroids of bounded branch-width, a result stemming from the Robertson-Seymour graph minors project. The core of the argument involves showing that any minor-minimal non-k-regular matroid must have a highly structured and rigidly connected internal representation, which limits its complexity. As a corollary, we demonstrate that for any prime power q, the class of matroids representable over GF(q) but not GF(p) for some smaller prime p is minor-closed, thereby providing a new structural lens on matroid representability.
subject: Matematik
title: Excluded Minors and the Structure of k-Regular Matroids

text: We investigate the topological properties of independence complexes of grid graphs on a torus, denoted I(C_m x C_n). Using discrete Morse theory, we provide a nearly complete description of the homotopy type of I(C_m x C_n) for various values of m and n. We establish that for m ≥ 3, n ≥ 3, the complex is homotopy equivalent to a wedge of spheres of potentially different dimensions. A key lemma establishes a recursive relationship for the Betti numbers by analyzing the local structure around a fixed vertex and its effect on the nerve of the associated link complex. Our results reveal a surprising connection between the torsion in the homology groups of these complexes and certain cyclotomic polynomials evaluated at -1. This work settles a conjecture by A. Björner regarding the connectivity of these specific independence complexes and provides new tools for analyzing the topology of combinatorial configuration spaces on graphs with high symmetry.
subject: Matematik
title: Homology of Independence Complexes of Toroidal Grid Graphs

text: We study the star-critical Ramsey number R_*(K_t, S_n), defined as the smallest integer k such that any K_t-free graph on n vertices with independence number less than k must contain the star S_n = K_{1,n-1}. This parameter lies at the intersection of Ramsey theory and extremal graph theory. By leveraging a geometric embedding of the vertices in a high-dimensional Euclidean space and applying a theorem of Baranyai on convex bodies, we establish a new upper bound R_*(K_t, S_n) ≤ (t-2)n + O(1) for fixed t. This bound is asymptotically tight and significantly improves the previous results obtained through purely combinatorial arguments. The core of our method involves partitioning the vertex set based on its geometric configuration, and then using a density increment argument within each partition to either find a large clique or demonstrate the existence of a high-degree vertex. This geometric perspective opens a new avenue for attacking related problems in Ramsey-Turan theory.
subject: Matematik
title: A Geometric Approach to the Star-Critical Ramsey Number R(K_t, S_n)

text: This work generalizes the concept of Sturmian words to higher dimensions by studying the combinatorial properties of discrete planes. We define a d-dimensional word as balanced if the counts of any factor of a given shape differ by at most one throughout the word. We prove that a d-dimensional word is balanced if and only if it arises as a coding of a d-dimensional irrational hyperplane rotation. The proof relies on constructing a substitution rule on a multi-dimensional alphabet which is derived from the continued fraction expansion of the hyperplane's normal vector. This establishes a direct analogue of the classical characterization of Sturmian words. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the complexity function, which counts the number of distinct rectangular blocks of size n_1 x ... x n_d, is given by n_1...n_d + 1, thus resolving a conjecture on the complexity of aperiodic tilings with minimal combinatorial complexity.
subject: Matematik
title: Balanced Words and Tilings: The Structure of Multi-dimensional Sturmian Sequences

text: We analyze the strength of the Chvátal-Gomory (CG) closure for the set covering problem. Let P be the standard linear programming relaxation of the set covering polytope, and let P_1 be its first CG closure. We construct an infinite family of set covering instances for which the integrality gap of P_1 is Ω(log n), where n is the number of elements in the ground set. This matches the known upper bound and proves that a single round of CG cuts is no more effective in the worst case than the original LP relaxation for approximating the integer optimum. The construction is probabilistic, based on a random hypergraph model where edges correspond to variables. The analysis requires a delicate application of the Lovász Local Lemma to demonstrate the existence of a fractional vertex in P_1 that is far from the integer hull, thereby establishing the lower bound on the gap. This result settles the question of the one-round efficacy of CG cuts for this fundamental problem.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Integrality Gap of the Chvátal-Gomory Closure for the Set Covering Polytope

text: We investigate the decoherence dynamics of a central qubit coupled to a disordered spin-chain environment, extending beyond the conventional Markovian approximation. By employing a time-convolutionless master equation approach and numerical simulations based on matrix product states, we analyze the quantum Zeno and anti-Zeno effects under strong coupling regimes. The spectral density of the spin bath is engineered to exhibit sub-Ohmic and super-Ohmic characteristics, revealing a profound impact on the revival of quantum coherence. We demonstrate that information backflow from the environment, quantified by the Breuer-Laine-Piilo (BLP) measure of non-Markovianity, is directly correlated with the transient behavior of entanglement entropy. Our results show that the decoherence rate exhibits a non-monotonic dependence on the coupling strength, a hallmark of non-Markovian dynamics, offering a pathway for preserving quantum states in solid-state quantum information processing architectures by leveraging structured environmental memory effects.
subject: Fizik
title: Decoherence Dynamics in Non-Markovian Quantum Systems Coupled to a Spin Bath

text: This study presents a comprehensive framework for constraining anisotropic primordial non-Gaussianity by analyzing the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) bispectrum. We move beyond the standard statistically isotropic paradigm to consider inflationary models with a quadrupolar modulation of the primordial power spectrum, characterized by a g_NL parameter. Utilizing a separable mode expansion and a KSW estimator, we perform a high-resolution analysis on simulated CMB temperature and polarization maps, mimicking data from the Planck satellite and future CMB-S4 experiments. Our analysis reveals that anisotropic non-Gaussianity induces unique off-diagonal correlations in the harmonic-space bispectrum. We establish that these signatures can effectively break degeneracies between different inflationary models, particularly distinguishing between single-field slow-roll and multi-field curvaton scenarios. We derive forecasted constraints on the g_NL parameter, demonstrating that next-generation CMB surveys possess the sensitivity to detect or rule out such anisotropies at a high confidence level, thereby probing fundamental symmetries of the early universe.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Primordial Non-Gaussianity through Anisotropic Signatures in the Cosmic Microwave Background Bispectrum

text: We theoretically investigate the emergence of Majorana zero modes (MZMs) in a heterostructure comprising a three-dimensional topological insulator (TI) thin film proximitized by an s-wave superconductor under an in-plane magnetic field. By solving the Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations self-consistently, we map the topological phase diagram as a function of chemical potential, magnetic field strength, and TI film thickness. The hybridization between the top and bottom surface states of the TI film opens a gap, which can be closed and reopened by the Zeeman field, driving the system into a topological superconducting phase. We calculate the local density of states and predict distinct zero-bias conductance peaks in scanning tunneling spectroscopy (STS) measurements, which serve as a primary signature of MZMs localized at the ends of a vortex line or the edge of the sample. Our findings provide a concrete materials-based blueprint for realizing non-Abelian anyons suitable for fault-tolerant topological quantum computation.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergent Majorana Fermions in a Proximity-Coupled Topological Insulator-Superconductor Heterostructure

text: We examine the critical behavior of the q-state Potts model with quenched bond disorder on a two-dimensional random lattice with fixed coordination number. Utilizing large-scale Monte Carlo simulations employing a cluster-based Swendsen-Wang algorithm, we analyze the system's thermodynamics for q > 2. The introduction of quenched disorder fundamentally alters the phase transition, which, according to the Harris criterion, is expected for systems with a positive specific heat exponent. Through a rigorous finite-size scaling analysis of the magnetic susceptibility and Binder cumulant, we demonstrate that the transition for q ≤ 4 remains second-order but migrates to a new, disorder-controlled universality class, distinct from the pure model. For q > 4, where the pure system exhibits a first-order transition, sufficient disorder softens the transition to a continuous one. Our results provide compelling evidence against the Imry-Wortis argument in this context and clarify the interplay between thermal and disorder-driven fluctuations in systems with discrete symmetries.
subject: Fizik
title: Phase Transitions and Critical Phenomena in a Disordered q-State Potts Model on a Random Lattice

text: We present a detailed analysis of gravitational waveforms from the inspiral, merger, and ringdown of eccentric binary black hole systems, focusing on the contribution of higher-order spherical harmonic modes. Using a combination of post-Newtonian theory for the early inspiral and high-accuracy numerical relativity simulations for the late-stage dynamics, we generate a catalog of hybrid waveforms for binaries with varying mass ratios, spins, and initial eccentricities up to e ≈ 0.8. We demonstrate that eccentricity significantly amplifies the power radiated in higher-order modes, such as (l, |m|) = (3,3), (4,4), and (2,1). By performing Bayesian parameter estimation on simulated signals injected into synthetic detector noise for LIGO, Virgo, and KAGRA, we show that including these modes is crucial for unbiased recovery of source parameters. Neglecting them leads to significant systematic errors in the estimation of the mass ratio, effective spin, and luminosity distance, highlighting their indispensability for precision gravitational-wave astronomy.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Wave Signatures of Eccentric Binary Black Hole Mergers: Higher-Order Mode Contributions and Parameter Estimation

text: This paper re-examines the viability of supersymmetric Grand Unification within the flipped SU(5) x U(1) model, focusing on predictions for proton decay. We perform a two-loop renormalization group equation analysis to trace the evolution of gauge and Yukawa couplings from the electroweak scale to the unification scale, incorporating threshold corrections from the full supersymmetric particle spectrum. The flipped SU(5) model naturally incorporates a seesaw mechanism for neutrino masses and avoids the problematic dimension-five proton decay operators that plague minimal SU(5). We calculate the partial decay widths for the dominant decay modes mediated by dimension-six operators, particularly p -> e+ pi^0 and p -> K+ nu_bar. Our results indicate that while the p -> e+ pi^0 mode is suppressed, the kaon decay channel falls within the discovery reach of next-generation experiments like Hyper-Kamiokande, offering a distinct and testable prediction that could differentiate this GUT framework from its alternatives.
subject: Fizik
title: Supersymmetric Grand Unification and Proton Decay Signatures in a Flipped SU(5) x U(1) Framework

text: We propose and theoretically analyze a scheme for realizing a photonic topological insulator in a two-dimensional array of coupled optical ring resonators. A synthetic magnetic field for photons is generated through spatially dependent phase modulation of the inter-resonator coupling links, which breaks time-reversal symmetry without magneto-optic materials. By solving the tight-binding Hamiltonian for this system, we demonstrate the existence of a complete photonic bandgap hosting topologically protected, chiral edge states. These states facilitate robust, backscatter-immune propagation of light along the perimeter of the array, even in the presence of significant structural disorder and defects. We calculate the Chern number for the bulk photonic bands, confirming the non-trivial topology of the system. Our design operates at telecommunication wavelengths and is compatible with standard silicon-on-insulator fabrication, paving the way for the development of resilient on-chip photonic devices, including topological lasers and delay lines.
subject: Fizik
title: Topological Photonics in a Coupled-Resonator Array with Synthetic Gauge Fields

text: We investigate the collective behavior of self-propelled, active Brownian particles suspended in a complex fluid exhibiting viscoelastic properties. The dynamics are modeled via a generalized Langevin equation, incorporating a memory kernel for the frictional force to capture the fluid's viscoelastic response, coupled with far-field hydrodynamic interactions mediated by the Oseen tensor. Using large-scale numerical simulations, we explore the phase diagram as a function of particle density and activity. We find that the viscoelastic nature of the medium significantly alters the onset and characteristics of motility-induced phase separation (MIPS). The long-range hydrodynamic coupling and fluid memory introduce non-local spatiotemporal correlations that suppress large-scale cluster formation and promote the emergence of novel collective states, such as swirling flocks and dynamic lane formation. Analysis of the mean squared displacement and velocity autocorrelation functions reveals distinct regimes of super-diffusive and sub-diffusive behavior, deviating markedly from the Newtonian fluid case.
subject: Fizik
title: Hydrodynamic Interactions and Collective Dynamics of Active Brownian Particles in a Viscoelastic Medium

text: This work explores the thermodynamics of a periodically driven open quantum system strongly coupled to a thermal reservoir, focusing on the statistics of work and heat. We derive a generalized quantum fluctuation theorem that remains valid far from thermal equilibrium and for non-Markovian environmental interactions. Employing a Floquet-Born-Markov approach, we compute the full probability distribution of work performed on the system over many driving cycles. The analysis reveals that quantum coherence, induced by the driving protocol, contributes a non-classical component to the dissipated heat, leading to deviations from the standard Jarzynski and Crooks relations. For a paradigmatic model of a driven two-level system, we demonstrate that these quantum effects are most pronounced in the low-temperature, strong-driving regime. Our findings establish a rigorous connection between quantum information concepts and non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, providing a deeper understanding of entropy production in nanoscale quantum engines.
subject: Fizik
title: Fluctuation Theorems and Quantum Work Statistics in Periodically Driven Open Quantum Systems

text: We present a comprehensive study of turbulence driven by kinetic Alfvén waves (KAWs) and its role in anomalous particle heating in tokamak plasmas. Using large-scale, three-dimensional gyrokinetic simulations with the GENE code, we model the nonlinear interaction and cascade of KAWs in a realistic magnetic geometry. The simulations resolve both ion and electron kinetic scales, capturing crucial wave-particle interactions such as Landau damping. Our results show that an anisotropic energy cascade develops, predominantly in the direction perpendicular to the background magnetic field, consistent with theories of strong Alfvénic turbulence. We analyze the velocity-space structure of the particle distribution functions and demonstrate that the turbulent electromagnetic fields lead to efficient, non-collisional energization of both ions and electrons. This process provides a robust mechanism for anomalous heating that can significantly impact the energy confinement and overall performance of future fusion reactors like ITER.
subject: Fizik
title: Kinetic Alfvén Wave Turbulence and Particle Energization in Magnetically Confined Fusion Plasmas

text: We address the tripartite challenge of communication efficiency, data privacy, and system heterogeneity in asynchronous federated learning. We introduce Asynch-CryptFL, a novel framework that integrates partially homomorphic encryption with a dynamic, error-feedback-based gradient quantization scheme. Our approach permits model updates from heterogeneous clients to be aggregated on-the-fly without awaiting slower participants, mitigating straggler effects. The homomorphic encryption scheme ensures that the central server can aggregate encrypted gradients without decrypting them, providing robust privacy guarantees against server-side threats. Concurrently, our adaptive quantization algorithm dynamically adjusts the bit-width for gradient compression based on channel conditions and gradient variance, significantly reducing the communication bottleneck. Theoretical analysis establishes convergence guarantees for non-IID data distributions under standard convexity assumptions. Empirical results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that Asynch-CryptFL achieves competitive model accuracy with up to a 60% reduction in communication overhead and a 40% decrease in training time compared to synchronous, unquantized baselines, without compromising privacy.
subject: AI
title: Asynchronous Federated Learning with Homomorphic Encryption and Dynamic Gradient Quantization

text: Predicting the synergistic effects of drug combinations is a critical challenge in pharmacology, complicated by the multi-modal nature of biomedical data. We propose the Hypergraph Attention Network for Drug Synergy (HADS), a novel architecture designed to model higher-order interactions between drugs, proteins, and cell lines. Unlike conventional graph neural networks that are limited to pairwise relationships, HADS explicitly models multi-way interactions by constructing a heterogeneous hypergraph from diverse data sources, including chemical structures, protein-protein interaction networks, and gene expression profiles. The core of our model is a dual-level attention mechanism: an intra-hyperedge attention module weighs the importance of nodes within a given multi-modal interaction, and an inter-hyperedge attention module aggregates information across different synergistic pathways. Evaluated on large-scale datasets such as DrugCombDB and NCI-ALMANAC, HADS demonstrates state-of-the-art performance in predicting drug synergy, providing interpretable attention weights that elucidate the underlying biological mechanisms driving combinatorial therapies.
subject: AI
title: Hypergraph Attention Networks for Synergistic Drug Combination Prediction from Multi-Modal Data

text: Learning disentangled representations that align with the true causal factors of data generation is a fundamental step towards robust and generalizable machine learning models. We introduce the Interventional Variational Autoencoder (I-VAE), a deep generative model that learns to separate causal variables from observational data without requiring explicit interventional labels. The I-VAE is built upon a structural causal model (SCM) prior and leverages a novel objective function that combines the standard evidence lower bound (ELBO) with a causal disentanglement regularizer. This regularizer encourages the latent space to be structured such that small, localized perturbations correspond to interventions on single causal factors (a soft-do-operation). We demonstrate theoretically that under identifiable conditions, the I-VAE can recover the underlying causal graph structure up to its Markov equivalence class. Empirically, on both synthetic and semi-synthetic benchmarks, our model successfully disentangles causal mechanisms and demonstrates superior performance in downstream counterfactual reasoning tasks compared to state-of-the-art disentanglement methods.
subject: AI
title: Disentangling Causal Factors from Observational Data via Interventional Variational Autoencoders

text: Adversarial attacks pose a significant threat to the deployment of deep neural networks in safety-critical applications. While numerous defenses have been proposed, many lack formal robustness guarantees. Randomized smoothing is a scalable technique that provides high-probability certified robustness, but its effectiveness is often limited by the high-dimensional geometry of the input space. We introduce Manifold-based Randomized Smoothing (MRS), a novel certified defense that operates on a low-dimensional data manifold learned by a generative model. By applying Gaussian smoothing in the latent space of a pre-trained variational autoencoder and propagating the resulting distribution through the decoder, MRS achieves significantly larger certified radii in the ambient input space. We provide a rigorous theoretical framework for deriving these certifications and demonstrate that MRS is agnostic to the downstream classifier architecture. Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet show that our method substantially outperforms existing state-of-the-art certified defenses against L2-norm bounded adversarial perturbations, establishing a new benchmark for provable robustness.
subject: AI
title: Manifold-Based Randomized Smoothing for Provably Robust Certified Defenses

text: Meta-learning aims to develop models that can rapidly adapt to new tasks from limited data. However, conventional gradient-based meta-learners often yield point estimates, neglecting the uncertainty crucial for decision-making in low-data regimes. We propose Bayesian Amortized Meta-Learning (BAML), a probabilistic framework that learns a posterior distribution over task-specific model parameters. BAML employs a hyper-network, trained via amortized variational inference, to directly map a task's support set to the approximate posterior parameters (e.g., mean and covariance) of a target network's weights. This amortization strategy enables efficient, feed-forward adaptation to new tasks at meta-test time, bypassing the need for iterative optimization. Our framework naturally quantifies both epistemic and aleatoric uncertainty, providing well-calibrated predictions. We demonstrate on challenging few-shot regression and classification benchmarks, such as Mini-Imagenet and Omniglot, that BAML not only achieves competitive predictive accuracy but also provides superior uncertainty estimates, a critical advantage for active learning and out-of-distribution detection.
subject: AI
title: Bayesian Meta-Learning with Amortized Variational Inference for Task-Adaptive Posterior Estimation

text: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) have emerged as the state-of-the-art in high-fidelity image synthesis but suffer from high computational costs due to their iterative nature in pixel space. We propose the Latent-Quantized Diffusion Model (LQDM), a novel generative framework that performs the diffusion process in a compressed, discrete latent space learned by a vector-quantized variational autoencoder (VQ-VAE). By operating in this lower-dimensional manifold, LQDM significantly reduces computational complexity. A key innovation is the use of a transformer-based architecture as the denoising network, which is conditioned on the VQ-VAE discrete codes, enabling it to model complex dependencies within the latent space. This hybrid approach synergizes the perceptual richness of VQ-VAE with the powerful score-matching capabilities of diffusion models. Our extensive experiments on ImageNet and FFHQ demonstrate that LQDM achieves FID scores comparable to leading DDPMs while reducing training and inference time by an order of magnitude, setting a new Pareto frontier for generative model efficiency and quality.
subject: AI
title: Latent Diffusion Models with Vector-Quantized Adversarial Priors for High-Fidelity Image Synthesis

text: Solving long-horizon tasks with sparse or delayed rewards remains a central challenge in reinforcement learning. We present Hierarchical Empowerment-driven Skill Acquisition (HESA), a framework that learns a repertoire of intrinsically motivated skills for efficient exploration and planning. HESA operates on two levels: a high-level meta-policy learns to sequence sub-goals, while a low-level skill-policy learns to reach those sub-goals. Crucially, the skill discovery process is not driven by the extrinsic task reward but by an intrinsic motivation signal based on empowerment—the channel capacity between an agent's actions and future states. This encourages the agent to learn a diverse set of controllable and predictable skills. The meta-policy then composes these discovered skills to solve the extrinsic task. We demonstrate that by decoupling skill acquisition from task-specific rewards, HESA can solve complex, sparse-reward robotic manipulation and navigation tasks where standard hierarchical and intrinsic motivation methods fail, exhibiting superior sample efficiency and generalization to unseen goals.
subject: AI
title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning with Information-Theoretic Empowerment for Sparse-Reward Tasks

text: Aligning representations from disparate data modalities like natural language and structured tabular data is crucial for many real-world applications, yet typically requires large-scale, explicitly paired datasets. We propose Cross-modal Alignment using Contrastive Projections (CACP), a novel self-supervised framework that learns a shared semantic embedding space for text and tabular data without any direct pairings. CACP leverages two modality-specific encoders and a non-linear projection head. The training objective is a symmetric contrastive loss function optimized over batches containing samples from both modalities. By treating samples with similar semantic meaning (determined via a weak, auxiliary signal like co-occurrence in documents) as positive pairs and others as negatives, CACP learns to map text descriptions and corresponding tabular rows to nearby points in the joint embedding space. Experiments on public datasets from finance and healthcare demonstrate that our approach enables effective zero-shot cross-modal retrieval and classification, outperforming methods that rely on generative or reconstruction-based objectives.
subject: AI
title: Cross-Modal Contrastive Learning for Unpaired Text and Tabular Data Alignment

text: Accurate uncertainty quantification is paramount for deploying machine learning models in high-stakes domains. While deep ensembles are a popular heuristic for estimating model uncertainty, they lack formal coverage guarantees. We introduce Conformalized Deep Ensembles (CDE), a hybrid method that combines the strong predictive performance of deep ensembles with the rigorous, distribution-free coverage guarantees of conformal prediction. The CDE method first trains a standard deep ensemble model. Then, during a calibration phase, it uses a holdout dataset to compute non-conformity scores based on the variance of the ensemble's predictions. These scores are used to calibrate a prediction interval that is guaranteed to contain the true outcome with a user-specified probability (e.g., 95%) on future data points, without making any distributional assumptions about the data or model. We demonstrate empirically on several benchmark regression tasks that CDEs produce reliable, well-calibrated prediction intervals that adapt to heteroscedastic noise, achieving robust marginal coverage while maintaining smaller interval sizes compared to other conformal methods.
subject: AI
title: Distribution-Free Uncertainty Quantification via Conformalized Deep Ensembles

text: Modeling complex physical systems governed by partial differential equations (PDEs) is computationally intensive for traditional numerical solvers. We introduce the Spatio-Temporal Fourier Neural Operator Transformer (ST-FNOT), a novel architecture for learning the solution operators of time-dependent PDEs directly from data. Our model synergizes the global receptive field of the Fourier Neural Operator (FNO) with the temporal modeling capabilities of Transformers. The ST-FNOT treats a sequence of spatial fields as a sequence of tokens. At each time step, an FNO block processes the spatial information by performing convolutions in the Fourier domain, capturing global spatial dependencies efficiently. A subsequent self-attention block operates along the temporal dimension, modeling the long-range evolution of the system's dynamics. This hybrid approach makes our model discretization-invariant in space and robust in time. Evaluated on challenging benchmarks including the Navier-Stokes and Schrödinger equations, ST-FNOT demonstrates significant improvements in accuracy and speed over both traditional solvers and previous neural operator baselines.
subject: AI
title: Learning Spatio-Temporal Dynamics of PDEs with Fourier Neural Operator Transformers

text: We investigate the non-perturbative corrections to the inflationary gravitational wave spectrum arising from M-theory compactified on Calabi-Yau three-folds. Utilizing a hybrid approach combining large-volume scenario (LVS) moduli stabilization with non-perturbative worldsheet instanton contributions to the superpotential, we derive a modified tensor-to-scalar ratio, r, and a scale-dependent tensor spectral index, n_t. Our analysis reveals that quantum corrections from Euclidean D2-branes wrapping exceptional cycles introduce logarithmic modifications to the standard slow-roll predictions, leading to a characteristically blue-tilted gravitational wave background at high frequencies. These signatures are potentially distinguishable from standard single-field inflationary models by next-generation interferometers like LISA and the Einstein Telescope. The derived constraints on the Calabi-Yau volume and the flux integers provide a direct observational window into the geometry of extra dimensions, linking macroscopic cosmological observables to the microscopic structure of string compactifications.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Perturbative Effects of Calabi-Yau Compactifications on Primordial Gravitational Wave Signatures

text: The pairing mechanism in high-T_c cuprate superconductors remains a central problem in condensed matter physics. We present a theoretical framework that posits spin-orbital fluctuations, rather than purely spin-based interactions, as the primary mediator of Cooper pairing in hole-doped Mott insulators. By extending the three-band Hubbard model to include explicit spin-orbit coupling and crystal field effects, we employ a determinantal quantum Monte Carlo (DQMC) simulation on finite clusters. Our results demonstrate the emergence of a robust d_{x^2-y^2}-wave pairing symmetry, consistent with experimental observations. However, we identify a subdominant extended s-wave component with a non-trivial phase structure, driven by anisotropic orbital correlations. This mixed-symmetry state manifests as a distinctive gap anisotropy in simulated angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) data. This work suggests that the interplay between spin and orbital degrees of freedom is crucial for a complete description of unconventional superconductivity.
subject: Fizik
title: Anisotropic Pairing Symmetry in Doped Mott Insulators Mediated by Spin-Orbital Fluctuations

text: We explore a class of holographic dark energy models characterized by a non-minimal derivative coupling to the Einstein tensor, aiming to alleviate the coincidence problem. The holographic principle, instantiated via the future event horizon as the IR cutoff, is modified by a coupling term G_{\mu\nu}\phi^{;\mu}\phi^{;\nu}, which dynamically alters the effective equation of state, w_{DE}(z). We perform a comprehensive Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) analysis to constrain the model parameters using a combination of CMB data from Planck, Baryon Acoustic Oscillations (BAO), and Type Ia supernovae (SN Ia). Critically, we incorporate tomographic data from the cross-correlation of CMB temperature anisotropies with large-scale structure tracers, specifically probing the integrated Sachs-Wolfe (ISW) effect. Our results indicate that the non-minimal coupling significantly suppresses late-time ISW power, providing tighter constraints on the holographic parameter c and favoring a phantom-like behavior (w_{DE} < -1) at low redshifts without invoking exotic matter.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Dark Energy Models with Non-Minimal Derivative Coupling and Constraints from ISW Tomography

text: We analyze the topological properties of entanglement in N-qubit GHZ and W states subjected to localized, non-Markovian decoherence channels. By employing the geometric measure of entanglement (GME) as an order parameter, we demonstrate the existence of sudden, discontinuous changes in the entanglement geometry, which we interpret as entanglement phase transitions. The critical points of these transitions are found to depend on the non-Markovianity of the environment, quantified via the Breuer-Laine-Piilo (BLP) measure. We calculate the quantum Fisher information for the decohered states, revealing that the metrological advantage afforded by multipartite entanglement exhibits singular behavior at these critical points. Our findings suggest that the robustness of quantum states against localized noise is not a monotonic function of entanglement but is instead governed by the topological structure of the state space manifold, with profound implications for designing fault-tolerant quantum information protocols.
subject: Fizik
title: Geometric Phase Transitions in Multipartite Entangled Systems under Localized Decoherence Channels

text: Scalar leptoquarks (LQs) represent a compelling extension of the Standard Model, providing a potential explanation for observed lepton flavor universality anomalies. This paper presents a phenomenological study of third-generation scalar leptoquarks at the High-Luminosity Large Hadron Collider (HL-LHC) with a center-of-mass energy of 14 TeV. We investigate two complementary channels: t-channel LQ exchange leading to asymmetric top-quark pair production with associated tau leptons (pp -> t\bar{t}\tau^+\tau^-), and pair production of LQs decaying into a top quark and a neutrino (pp -> LQ\overline{LQ} -> t\bar{t}\nu\bar{\nu}), which manifests as a t\bar{t} + missing transverse energy (MET) final state. Utilizing a comprehensive set of kinematic variables within a boosted decision tree (BDT) framework, we project the discovery potential and exclusion limits for LQ masses up to 2.5 TeV. Our results demonstrate that the combination of these channels provides enhanced sensitivity over existing searches and can robustly distinguish different LQ representations.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Leptoquark-Mediated Signatures via Asymmetric Top-Quark Pair Production at High-Luminosity LHC

text: We investigate the non-equilibrium steady states of a uniformly heated granular gas using large-scale event-driven molecular dynamics simulations. The system is characterized by a constant coefficient of restitution, e, and is driven by a stochastic thermostat. We report the discovery of a universal scaling relation for the granular temperature T_g and the kurtosis of the velocity distribution, independent of the driving mechanism, when particle velocities are normalized by the thermal velocity. Crucially, we probe the violation of the fluctuation-dissipation theorem (FDT) by comparing the mobility, measured from the response to a small external perturbation, with the diffusion coefficient obtained from the velocity autocorrelation function. The FDT violation ratio X is found to scale as (1-e^2), providing a quantitative measure of the system's departure from equilibrium. This result supports the concept of an effective temperature framework for athermal systems, but only in the quasi-elastic limit.
subject: Fizik
title: Universal Scaling Laws and Fluctuation-Dissipation Theorem Violations in Driven Granular Gases

text: The no-hair theorem of general relativity is a cornerstone of black hole physics, yet it is violated in many alternative theories of gravity. We explore the observational consequences of Kerr black holes endowed with scalar hair within the framework of Einstein-scalar-Gauss-Bonnet gravity. By numerically solving the linearized field equations on this modified spacetime background, we compute the complex frequencies of the dominant l=m=2 quasinormal modes (QNMs). The presence of scalar hair is shown to systematically shift the QNM frequencies and damping times relative to their Kerr counterparts. Furthermore, the modified effective potential near the event horizon can create a cavity that traps gravitational waves, leading to a predictable train of 'echoes' following the primary ringdown signal. We argue that correlating the primary QNM spectrum with the echo time delay in future gravitational wave detections by third-generation observatories could provide a smoking-gun signature for physics beyond general relativity.
subject: Fizik
title: Quasinormal Mode Spectroscopy of Kerr Black Holes with Scalar Hair: Constraints from Gravitational Wave Echoes

text: Topological insulators (TIs) provide a physical realization of axion electrodynamics, characterized by a quantized topological magnetoelectric effect. We theoretically investigate the emergence of fractional quantum Hall (FQH) states in a heterostructure composed of a magnetically doped TI thin film proximitized with a high-mobility two-dimensional electron gas (2DEG). The broken time-reversal symmetry in the TI induces an image magnetic monopole for each electron in the 2DEG, fundamentally altering the many-body ground state under an external magnetic field. By solving the composite fermion Hamiltonian modified by the axion coupling term, we demonstrate the stabilization of exotic FQH states at unconventional filling fractions, such as \nu=1/4 and 1/5, which are fragile or absent in conventional semiconductor 2DEGs. We propose specific magnetotransport signatures, including a re-entrant integer quantum Hall effect and a quantized thermal Hall conductance, as definitive experimental probes of this unique interplay between topological matter and strongly correlated electrons.
subject: Fizik
title: Axion Electrodynamics and Fractional Quantum Hall Effect in Magnetically Doped Topological Insulator Heterostructures

text: The conformal bootstrap program offers a powerful non-perturbative approach to constraining and solving conformal field theories (CFTs). We apply this methodology to study 3D N=2 superconformal field theories (SCFTs) by analyzing the crossing symmetry of four-point correlators involving chiral and anti-chiral supermultiplet operators. Our analysis leverages the full N=2 superconformal algebra to decompose super-correlators into a finite number of conformal blocks. By imposing unitarity bounds on the scaling dimensions of operators appearing in the operator product expansion (OPE), we carve out allowed regions in the space of OPE coefficients and scaling dimensions. We identify a sharp kink in the bound for the leading chiral operator dimension, which we conjecture corresponds to the 3D N=2 Wess-Zumino model. The study provides precise numerical predictions for the anomalous dimensions of several low-lying operators in this theory, demonstrating the efficacy of the bootstrap in solving strongly coupled quantum field theories.
subject: Fizik
title: Bootstrapping N=2 Superconformal Field Theories in Three Dimensions via Crossing Symmetry

text: Anomalous electron thermal transport remains a major obstacle in achieving high-performance scenarios in reversed-field pinch (RFP) magnetic confinement devices. We present results from large-scale, high-fidelity gyrokinetic simulations using the GENE code, adapted for RFP geometry, to investigate the role of kinetic Alfven wave (KAW) turbulence. Our simulations, spanning a range of realistic plasma parameters, demonstrate that in the core of RFP plasmas, electromagnetic turbulence driven by the electron temperature gradient is dominated by KAWs. The analysis of the turbulent cascade reveals a highly anisotropic energy spectrum, with perpendicular wave numbers k_\perp greatly exceeding parallel wave numbers k_\parallel. We calculate the resulting electron heat flux and find it to be in quantitative agreement with experimental measurements of anomalous transport. A synthetic magnetic fluctuation diagnostic shows that the KAW activity is consistent with experimental observations, solidifying the KAW turbulent cascade as the principal mechanism governing electron energy confinement in RFPs.
subject: Fizik
title: Kinetic Alfven Wave Turbulence and its Role in Anomalous Electron Thermal Transport in Reversed-Field Pinch Plasmas

text: The CRISPR-Cas13d system, an RNA-guided ribonuclease, exhibits potent programmable RNA-targeting capabilities but also non-specific collateral cleavage activity upon target recognition, a feature harnessed for diagnostics. The molecular basis for this promiscuous activity remains poorly understood. Here, we present cryo-electron microscopy structures of the Ruminococcus flavefaciens Cas13d (RfxCas13d) effector in its pre-target, target-bound, and catalytically active states. Target RNA binding induces a profound conformational rearrangement, allosterically activating the two HEPN nuclease domains by positioning them for catalysis. Importantly, the activated conformation reveals an open, solvent-accessible catalytic pocket distal to the guide-target duplex, providing a structural rationale for its ability to cleave non-target bystander RNAs. Mutational analysis of the inter-domain linkers corroborates this allosteric model and allows for the decoupling of on-target binding from collateral activity. These findings provide a high-resolution blueprint of Cas13d function, informing the rational engineering of CRISPR-based tools with enhanced specificity for therapeutic and diagnostic applications.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural Basis for Collateral RNA Cleavage by the CRISPR-Cas13d Effector RfxCas13d

text: The precise targeting of Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) to specific genomic loci is critical for epigenetic silencing and cell fate determination, yet the mechanisms governing its recruitment remain incompletely defined. We have identified CHROME, a conserved long non-coding RNA, as a key scaffold for PRC2 localization. Using comprehensive chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) and chromatin isolation by RNA purification (ChIRP-seq), we demonstrate that CHROME physically associates with the SUZ12 and EZH2 subunits of PRC2. Its selective expression during neurogenesis directs the complex to hundreds of developmental gene promoters, facilitating robust trimethylation of histone H3 at lysine 27 (H3K27me3). Genetic ablation of the CHROME locus results in aberrant PRC2 distribution, loss of repressive chromatin marks, and ectopic expression of non-neuronal genes. Our results uncover a fundamental mechanism of lncRNA-mediated epigenetic regulation, where CHROME acts as a molecular beacon to ensure the fidelity of Polycomb-mediated gene silencing during cellular differentiation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Conserved lncRNA, CHROME, Orchestrates Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 Targeting and H3K27me3 Deposition

text: The DNA damage response (DDR) requires the spatiotemporal concentration of repair factors at sites of DNA lesions. We demonstrate that key DDR proteins 53BP1 and its effector RIF1 undergo liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) to form biomolecular condensates at DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs). Utilizing in vitro reconstitution assays and super-resolution microscopy in cells, we show these condensates are initiated by the multivalent interactions of phosphorylated 53BP1 oligomers. These phase-separated droplets selectively partition components of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway while excluding homologous recombination factors. Critically, we find that the unique heterochromatic environment of telomeres enhances 53BP1/RIF1 condensation, thereby promoting pathway choice towards NHEJ for repairing telomeric DSBs. Disruption of 53BP1's condensation capacity via mutagenesis impairs NHEJ efficiency and leads to telomere fusion events. Our findings reveal that LLPS is a primary organizing principle in the DDR, creating localized reaction crucibles that enhance the fidelity of DNA repair pathway selection.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of 53BP1 and RIF1 Promotes Non-Homologous End Joining at Telomeric DNA Double-Strand Breaks

text: Intratumoral heterogeneity is a major obstacle in treating pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). To deconstruct this complexity, we performed simultaneous single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and single-cell assay for transposase-accessible chromatin using sequencing (scATAC-seq) on patient-derived xenograft models of PDAC. Our integrated multi-omic analysis resolved distinct cancer cell subpopulations, including a quasi-mesenchymal state characterized by a unique chromatin accessibility profile at enhancers of key epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) transcription factors like ZEB1 and SNAI2. Pseudotemporal trajectory inference delineated a continuous spectrum of cellular plasticity from classical epithelial to metastatic mesenchymal states, governed by a hierarchical network of transcription factors. We further identified a chemoresistant subpopulation with pre-existing open chromatin at drug efflux pump loci, providing an epigenetic basis for intrinsic resistance. This high-resolution atlas of the PDAC ecosystem uncovers novel markers and regulatory circuits driving tumor progression and chemoresistance, offering new avenues for therapeutic intervention.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated Single-Cell Transcriptomic and Epigenomic Atlas Reveals Cellular Plasticity During Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma Progression

text: The ribosome is often considered a static macromolecular machine, yet emerging evidence suggests compositional heterogeneity. Using precise quantitative mass spectrometry, we reveal that the stoichiometry of specific ribosomal proteins (RPs) is dynamically modulated in response to oxidative stress and nutrient deprivation. We identified a subset of RPs, including RPL3L and RPS27L, whose incorporation into translating ribosomes is significantly altered under stress conditions. Ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) demonstrated that these 'specialized ribosomes' exhibit altered translational fidelity and preferentially translate specific cohorts of mRNAs, notably those containing upstream open reading frames (uORFs) and encoding stress-response proteins like ATF4. Genetic manipulation of these RP paralogs confirmed their non-redundant roles in tuning the cellular stress response. Our findings challenge the paradigm of a uniform ribosome population, proposing a model where dynamic RP stoichiometry generates specialized translational machinery to rapidly adapt the proteome to environmental cues.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dynamic Stoichiometry of Ribosomal Proteins Regulates Translational Fidelity and Cellular Stress Responses

text: Histone variants play pivotal roles in defining chromatin states, but the functions of many remain unknown. We characterize a previously unannotated histone variant, H3.X, which is specifically deposited at active enhancer elements by a novel chaperone complex, CXC. Using CUT&RUN and native ChIP-seq, we show H3.X enrichment correlates with enhancer activity and transcription factor binding. Biophysical assays reveal that H3.X-containing nucleosomes are intrinsically unstable, exhibiting increased DNA breathing and unwrapping dynamics. Chromosome conformation capture (Hi-C) experiments demonstrate that H3.X deposition is associated with local chromatin decompaction and facilitates long-range enhancer-promoter looping. Depletion of H3.X leads to a reduction in chromatin accessibility at enhancers, diminished expression of cognate target genes, and impaired cellular differentiation. Our study establishes H3.X as a key architectural component of active enhancers, mechanically linking histone variant deposition to the regulation of cis-regulatory element function and gene expression.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The Histone Variant H3.X Mediates Chromatin Decompaction and Transcriptional Activation at Enhancer Elements

text: Ubiquitin chains with distinct linkages constitute a complex code that regulates diverse cellular processes, but the function of atypical linkages remains largely cryptic. Here, we investigate the signaling role of lysine 6 (K6)-linked polyubiquitin chains in mitophagy. We identified the E3 ligase RNF144 as the primary catalyst for K6-chain synthesis on the mitochondrial outer membrane protein VDAC2 following mitochondrial depolarization. Using linkage-specific antibodies and quantitative mass spectrometry, we show that these K6 chains serve as a specific docking signal for the autophagy receptor NDP52, but not Optineurin or p62. Structural studies of the NDP52-ubiquitin interface reveal a unique binding pocket that confers high specificity for the K6 linkage topology. Conversely, the deubiquitinase USP30 antagonizes this interaction by selectively cleaving K6 chains. Our work deciphers a precise ubiquitin-based signaling axis where a specific linkage type dictates receptor engagement, thereby ensuring the fidelity of selective organelle clearance.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Deciphering a K6-Linked Ubiquitin Code that Licenses Mitophagic Receptors for Selective Autophagy

text: Human telomerase is a ribonucleoprotein (RNP) complex essential for maintaining genome integrity by synthesizing telomeric DNA repeats at chromosome ends. Its dysregulation is a hallmark of cancer and aging. We report the cryo-electron microscopy structure of the reconstituted, catalytically active human telomerase holoenzyme at 3.1 Å resolution. The structure reveals the intricate architecture of the telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) bound to the telomerase RNA component (TERC), including the pseudoknot/template domain and the CR4/5 domain. It details how the TERC scaffold organizes the TERT catalytic core and accessory proteins, including the processivity factor TEP1. The RNA template is precisely positioned within the active site, and a conserved structural motif, the 'template boundary element', is shown to be crucial for defining the telomeric repeat sequence. These structural insights provide a definitive mechanistic framework for telomerase function and a high-resolution blueprint for the development of targeted anti-cancer therapeutics.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Active Human Telomerase Holoenzyme Reveals the Catalytic Core and RNA Templating Mechanism

text: Pre-mRNA splicing is tightly coupled to transcription, but the molecular mechanisms that ensure its efficiency and fidelity remain debated. By employing native elongating transcript sequencing (NET-Seq) and single-molecule imaging, we investigated the kinetics of spliceosome assembly on nascent transcripts in real time. Our data reveal that the phosphorylation status of the RNA Polymerase II (RNAPII) C-terminal domain (CTD) directly modulates splicing rates. Specifically, phosphorylation of Serine 2 (Ser2-P) by CDK9 serves as a recruitment platform for the U2AF splicing factor complex, accelerating splice site recognition and intron commitment. Conversely, inhibiting CTD phosphorylation or inducing transcriptional pausing leads to a significant delay in co-transcriptional splicing, increasing the frequency of alternative splicing events. Our findings support a kinetic coupling model where the transcriptional elongation rate, governed by the RNAPII CTD code, synchronizes with splicing machinery recruitment to ensure precise and efficient intron excision from the nascent pre-mRNA.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Co-transcriptional Splicing Kinetics are Modulated by RNA Polymerase II Phosphorylation State

text: Ribosome-associated quality control (RQC) is a crucial surveillance pathway that degrades aberrant nascent polypeptides arising from stalled translation. The mechanism by which the RQC complex extracts stalled nascent chains from the ribosomal exit tunnel is poorly understood. Using time-resolved cryo-electron microscopy, we have captured multiple intermediate states of the yeast RQC complex engaged with stalled 80S ribosomes. Our structures show that the E3 ubiquitin ligase Ltn1 and the ATPase Vms1 assemble into a helical filament that encircles the nascent chain. ATP hydrolysis by Vms1 induces a concerted conformational change, driving a rotational, screw-like motion of the filament. This torsional force is transmitted to the nascent polypeptide, progressively pulling it from the exit tunnel. Molecular dynamics simulations and mutagenesis data support this 'torsional extraction' model. This work uncovers a novel, rotation-based mechanical principle for polypeptide translocation, providing fundamental insights into cellular protein quality control machinery.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The Ribosome-Associated Quality Control Complex Employs a Helical Torsion Mechanism for Stalled Nascent Chain Extraction

text: Morphological stasis can conceal significant genetic diversity, posing challenges for conservation and our understanding of speciation. We investigated the evolutionary history of the Hyalinobatrachium fleischmanni species complex using ultraconserved elements (UCEs) and whole-genome resequencing from 124 individuals across its Mesoamerican range. Multispecies coalescent models and phylogenetic network analyses robustly identify at least five distinct, deeply divergent lineages, warranting species-level recognition despite their phenotypic uniformity. Demographic modeling reveals a history of climatic vicariance followed by secondary contact and asymmetric introgression. Analyses of genomic islands of divergence using FST and dXY scans pinpoint loci associated with thermal tolerance and call acoustics that may contribute to reproductive isolation. Our findings demonstrate that integrative phylogenomic approaches can uncover cryptic biodiversity and reveal complex patterns of gene flow, highlighting the insufficiency of morphology-based taxonomy for accurately delineating evolutionary units and informing conservation priorities in hyperdiverse tropical ecosystems.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Resolution of Cryptic Speciation and Introgression in Neotropical Glass Frogs (Centrolenidae)

text: The role of non-Mendelian inheritance in adaptation remains a central question in evolutionary biology. We explored the contribution of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance to rapid adaptation by exposing isogenic Arabidopsis thaliana lineages to fluctuating salinity stress for ten generations. Using whole-genome bisulfite sequencing and RNA-seq, we identified hundreds of differentially methylated regions (DMRs) that were stably inherited for at least three generations post-stress. These heritable epimutations were significantly enriched in the promoter regions of stress-responsive genes and were strongly correlated with altered transcriptional profiles and enhanced salt tolerance phenotypes. Critically, reversion to ancestral methylation states occurred at a higher rate than de novo epimutation, suggesting a plastic yet heritable mechanism. Our results provide direct evidence that DNA methylation can act as a parallel inheritance system, providing a reservoir of selectable phenotypic variation that accelerates adaptation to novel environmental challenges on contemporary timescales.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance Facilitates Rapid Adaptation to Salinity Stress in Arabidopsis thaliana

text: The theory of antagonistic pleiotropy posits that alleles with beneficial effects on early-life fitness are favored by selection despite having deleterious late-life consequences, thus driving the evolution of senescence. We tested this hypothesis through a genome-wide association study (GWAS) for fecundity and lifespan in a large panel of Drosophila melanogaster. We identified several loci exhibiting strong signatures of antagonistic pleiotropy, where alleles positively correlated with early-life reproductive output were significantly associated with accelerated age-related mortality. A polygenic risk score analysis confirmed that a genetic predisposition for high early fecundity predicts a shorter lifespan. Functional annotation of candidate genes implicates pathways related to TOR signaling and mitochondrial metabolism. These findings provide robust genomic evidence supporting antagonistic pleiotropy as a key mechanism underlying life-history trade-offs, demonstrating how selection in early life casts a long shadow that shapes the evolution of aging.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Evidence for Antagonistic Pleiotropy as a Primary Driver of Senescence in Drosophila melanogaster

text: Ring species provide a compelling natural experiment for observing speciation in action. We investigated the genomic consequences of secondary contact in the greenish warbler (Phylloscopus trochiloides) ring species complex using high-coverage whole-genome data. By applying formal tests for admixture, including Patterson's D-statistic and f4-ratio estimation, we characterized a gradient of introgression around the Tibetan Plateau. While most of the genome shows evidence of extensive historical gene flow, we identified multiple discrete genomic regions with sharply reduced introgression between divergent northern forms. These 'genomic barriers' are significantly enriched for genes related to plumage patterning (e.g., Agouti-signaling protein) and neural development associated with song learning, suggesting a primary role for divergent selection on mating signals in maintaining reproductive isolation. Our analysis reveals that species boundaries can be porous and heterogeneous, with specific loci acting as key anchors of reproductive isolation long before genome-wide incompatibility evolves.
subject: Evrim
title: Heterogeneous Genomic Introgression Across an Avian Ring Species Complex

text: Host-parasite interactions often escalate into a coevolutionary arms race, vividly exemplified by bacteria and their bacteriophages. We tracked the real-time molecular evolution of Streptococcus thermophilus and its lytic phage 2972 over 500 generations of serial co-culture. Deep sequencing of bacterial CRISPR loci and phage genomes revealed rapid, reciprocal evolutionary dynamics consistent with the Red Queen hypothesis. Bacteria rapidly acquired new phage-targeting spacers, leading to transient selective sweeps. In response, phages evolved mutations in protospacer adjacent motifs (PAMs) or, more frequently, acquired and diversified anti-CRISPR (Acr) genes that directly inhibit Cas9 function. Phylogenetic analysis of Acr variants showed signatures of strong positive selection. This study demonstrates a dynamic interplay where the bacterial adaptive immune system drives viral counter-adaptation, illustrating how molecular arms races can fuel rapid diversification and the evolution of novel biochemical functions within microbial communities.
subject: Evrim
title: Reciprocal Coevolutionary Dynamics of CRISPR-Cas Immunity and Viral Anti-CRISPR Counter-Defense

text: The evolution of complex morphological structures is shaped by the interplay of functional integration and modularity. We quantified patterns of phenotypic integration in the cranium of 428 species of African cichlid fishes using high-dimensional geometric morphometrics and phylogenetic comparative methods. By comparing evolutionary covariance matrices (G-matrices), we identified a conserved modular architecture across the radiation, partitioning the skull into oral jaw, neurocranial, and suspensorial units. While strong integration exists within modules, the weaker covariation between them facilitates semi-independent evolution. Lineage-specific shifts in evolutionary rates are disproportionately concentrated in the oral jaw module, directly corresponding with trophic specialization. Our results suggest that this modular architecture acted as a key innovation, channeling morphological diversification by allowing rapid adaptation in feeding mechanics without compromising the functional integrity of other cranial systems, thereby facilitating one of the most explosive adaptive radiations known.
subject: Evrim
title: Macroevolutionary Modularity and Phenotypic Integration Constrain and Facilitate the Cichlid Cranial Radiation

text: Distinguishing molecular convergence from shared ancestry is a fundamental challenge in evolutionary biology. We investigated the evolution of venom peptides (conotoxins) in cone snails (Conus), a hyperdiverse genus of marine predators. Using a robust, time-calibrated phylogeny of 150 species and a novel Bayesian stochastic character mapping approach, we reconstructed the evolutionary history of conotoxin gene superfamilies. Our analysis reveals at least six independent origins of neurotoxins targeting the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. Despite originating from different ancestral gene families via repeated gene duplication and neofunctionalization events, these toxins evolved functionally equivalent pharmacophores through distinct structural pathways. Patterns of dN/dS > 1 along convergent branches indicate strong positive selection driving this functional homoplasy. This study demonstrates how strong ecological selection for specific pharmacological targets can repeatedly guide molecular evolution down predictable paths, providing a powerful example of convergent evolution at the protein level.
subject: Evrim
title: Convergent Molecular Evolution of Conotoxin Gene Superfamilies Revealed by Stochastic Character Mapping

text: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a major evolutionary force in prokaryotes, but its impact on eukaryotic genomes is considered limited. We conducted a systematic, phylogenetically-informed screen for HGT across 300 high-quality eukaryotic genomes, employing rigorous filters to exclude contamination and gene loss artifacts. We identified over 2,000 high-confidence HGT events, revealing that the acquisition of prokaryotic genes is a widespread and ongoing process, particularly in microbial eukaryotes and certain invertebrate metazoans like bdelloid rotifers and tardigrades. Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis shows that transferred genes are disproportionately involved in novel metabolic pathways, carbohydrate utilization, and stress tolerance (e.g., anhydrobiosis). Our findings challenge the paradigm of purely vertical inheritance in eukaryotes, suggesting that HGT acts as a crucial and recurring source of adaptive innovation, enabling lineages to acquire novel ecological capabilities and colonize previously inaccessible niches.
subject: Evrim
title: Pervasive Horizontal Gene Transfer from Prokaryotes Shapes the Adaptive Landscape of Eukaryotic Genomes

text: Inferring the behavior of extinct species is a formidable challenge, yet crucial for understanding human origins. We applied phylogenetic comparative methods to reconstruct the evolution of mating systems within the hominoid lineage. Using a comprehensive primate phylogeny and a multivariate dataset of sexually dimorphic traits (body mass, canine size, pelvic morphology) from extant and fossil species, we employed Bayesian ancestral state reconstruction via Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC). Our models indicate a high posterior probability (>0.95) for a polygynandrous (multi-male, multi-female) mating system in the last common ancestor of Pan and Homo, similar to modern chimpanzees. A significant shift towards social monogamy and reduced dimorphism is detected along the terminal branch leading to Homo sapiens. These results support the hypothesis that fundamental changes in social structure and reproductive strategy, including the emergence of pair-bonding and cooperative breeding, were pivotal events in the evolution of our genus.
subject: Evrim
title: Bayesian Ancestral State Reconstruction of Mating Systems in Early Hominins

text: Parallel evolution, the independent evolution of similar traits in different populations, provides powerful evidence for natural selection. We investigated the genomic basis of parallel adaptation in multiple freshwater populations of threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus) derived from a common marine ancestor. Population genomic analysis using whole-genome sequencing revealed that adaptation to freshwater environments is predominantly fueled by standing genetic variation present in the ancestral marine population. We observed recurrent soft selective sweeps at numerous loci, where the same ancestral haplotypes rose to high frequency in independent freshwater populations. FST outlier analyses identified key genes, including Ectodysplasin (Eda) for armor plate reduction and Pitx1 for pelvic reduction, as primary targets of this parallel selection. Our findings demonstrate that evolutionary trajectories can be highly predictable, as adaptation repeatedly co-opts pre-existing genetic variants, allowing for more rapid responses to environmental change than would be possible if reliant on new mutations alone.
subject: Evrim
title: Adaptation from Standing Genetic Variation Drives Parallel Evolution in Threespine Stickleback

text: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have demonstrated profound success in learning representations on graph-structured data. However, existing self-supervised methods often rely on local structural augmentations, rendering them vulnerable to topological noise and perturbations. We introduce Topological Graph Contrastive Learning (TopoGCL), a novel framework that leverages principles from topological data analysis to guide representation learning. TopoGCL employs persistent homology to compute topological invariants, such as Betti numbers and persistence diagrams, from graph filtrations. These multi-scale topological signatures serve as a supervisory signal within a contrastive objective, forcing the model to learn embeddings that are invariant to homologically trivial structural changes while remaining sensitive to significant topological shifts. We evaluate TopoGCL on several benchmark node classification and link prediction tasks under various noise models. Our results demonstrate a marked improvement in robustness and generalization performance over state-of-the-art GNN baselines, highlighting the efficacy of integrating higher-order topological features into the self-supervised learning paradigm.
subject: AI
title: Topological Graph Contrastive Learning for Robust Node Representation

text: Inferring causal relationships from high-dimensional, non-stationary time series is a formidable challenge due to confounding factors and distribution shifts. We propose CausalVAE-TS, a deep generative framework that learns a disentangled latent representation of time series data to facilitate causal discovery. Our model utilizes a structured variational autoencoder with a factorized latent space, separating time-invariant causal mechanisms from time-varying, non-causal dynamics. We introduce a temporal-spectral regularizer to enforce smoothness in the dynamic latent variables and employ a differentiable Granger causality test within the static latent space to infer the underlying causal graph. The entire model is trained end-to-end using stochastic variational inference. Experiments on synthetic benchmarks and real-world econometric and climatological datasets show that CausalVAE-TS significantly outperforms existing methods in recovering ground-truth causal structures and in forecasting under interventions, providing a robust tool for causal analysis in complex dynamical systems.
subject: AI
title: Causal Disentanglement in Non-Stationary Time Series via Structured Variational Inference

text: Federated Learning (FL) is susceptible to Byzantine attacks, where malicious clients can arbitrarily corrupt their local model updates to poison the global model. Simultaneously, data privacy remains a paramount concern. We introduce Byz-ProofFed, a novel FL aggregation protocol that provides formal guarantees of robustness against a fraction of Byzantine clients while preserving client privacy through homomorphic encryption (HE). Byz-ProofFed operates on HE-encrypted gradients and computes a geometric median, a provably robust aggregation rule, in the encrypted domain. A key innovation is a lightweight, zero-knowledge proof mechanism that allows the server to verify the well-formedness of client ciphertexts without decryption, effectively thwarting malicious encryption attacks. Theoretical analysis demonstrates convergence under Byzantine threat models where standard methods fail. Empirical results on non-IID data distributions show that Byz-ProofFed maintains high model accuracy in the presence of strong adversaries, establishing a new state-of-the-art in secure and robust distributed machine learning.
subject: AI
title: Byz-ProofFed: Byzantine-Resilient Federated Learning with Verifiable Homomorphic Encryption

text: The prohibitive size of Large Language Models (LLMs) impedes their deployment on resource-constrained hardware. We propose TensorLLM, a novel compression technique that leverages the expressive power of Tensor Train (TT) decomposition, a paradigm originating from quantum many-body physics. By reformulating the dense weight matrices within transformer attention and feed-forward layers as low-rank tensor networks, we achieve exponential compression with respect to the model's depth. Our method involves a layer-wise TT decomposition followed by global fine-tuning with a rank-adaptivity scheduler that dynamically allocates resources across layers. This approach significantly reduces the parameter count and computational complexity while preserving model performance. On benchmarks like LLaMA-2 and Falcon, TensorLLM demonstrates a superior Pareto frontier between perplexity and compression ratio compared to established methods like pruning and quantization, enabling efficient inference with minimal degradation in downstream task accuracy.
subject: AI
title: TensorLLM: Compressing Large Language Models with Quantum-Inspired Tensor Networks

text: Sample inefficiency remains a critical barrier for applying deep reinforcement learning (RL) to complex robotic manipulation tasks. We introduce a meta-learning framework, Probabilistic Latent Skill-Graphs (PLSG), designed for rapid adaptation to novel tasks from sparse demonstrations. PLSG learns a structured probabilistic latent space of reusable motor primitives, or 'skills,' using a graph-based variational autoencoder. The nodes of the graph represent skills, while the edges capture transition probabilities, forming a policy prior. During meta-training, this skill-graph is learned across a distribution of tasks. For a new task, the agent performs rapid posterior inference over the graph to identify the optimal sequence of skills, enabling few-shot adaptation. We demonstrate PLSG on a suite of challenging simulated and real-world contact-rich manipulation tasks, showing substantial improvements in sample efficiency and zero-shot generalization over leading gradient-based and black-box meta-RL algorithms.
subject: AI
title: Probabilistic Latent Skill-Graphs for Few-Shot Robotic Reinforcement Learning

text: Unsupervised Domain Adaptation (UDA) is crucial for medical imaging, where labeled data in a target modality (e.g., CT) is scarce, but plentiful in a source modality (e.g., MRI). We propose WOT-Med, a novel UDA framework that leverages the geometry of feature spaces through Gromov-Wasserstein (GW) optimal transport. Our model learns a domain-invariant feature representation by minimizing the GW distance between the feature distributions of the source and target domains, which effectively aligns their relational structures without requiring direct sample-to-sample correspondence. This alignment is integrated into a generative adversarial network architecture with a cycle-consistency loss to ensure semantic fidelity during translation. We apply WOT-Med to cross-modality brain tumor and abdominal organ segmentation tasks. The results demonstrate state-of-the-art performance, outperforming methods based on maximum mean discrepancy and standard Wasserstein distance by preserving fine-grained anatomical structures during adaptation.
subject: AI
title: Unsupervised Multi-Modal Domain Adaptation via Gromov-Wasserstein Optimal Transport

text: Knowledge Graph (KG) embedding models excel at capturing statistical correlations but often fail to adhere to logical constraints and lack interpretability. We propose Logic-Tensor, a neuro-symbolic framework that integrates first-order logic rules directly into the training of KG embeddings. Logic-Tensor represents entities and relations in a continuous vector space while modeling logical rules as soft constraints within a novel differentiable forward-chaining mechanism. This mechanism allows the model to perform multi-hop reasoning by iteratively applying rules to deduce new facts, with the entire process being end-to-end differentiable. The loss function combines a standard link prediction objective with a logical consistency term derived from the rule-based inference. On standard KG completion benchmarks (FB15k-237, WN18RR), Logic-Tensor not only improves prediction accuracy but also provides traceable reasoning paths for its inferences and exhibits enhanced robustness against adversarial attacks compared to purely connectionist models.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic Knowledge Graph Reasoning via Differentiable Forward-Chaining

text: Deep learning provides a promising avenue for emulating computationally expensive climate simulators, but quantifying the uncertainty of these emulators is critical for their scientific utility. We introduce BayesClimateNet, a Bayesian deep learning framework for climate model emulation that provides principled uncertainty quantification. Our approach employs stochastic variational inference with a novel, physics-constrained prior on the neural network's latent space.
