This structured prior is designed to enforce adherence to known physical conservation laws, such as energy balance, thereby regularizing the model and improving its generalization capabilities. The framework disentangles aleatoric uncertainty (inherent system stochasticity) from epistemic uncertainty (model inadequacy). We demonstrate our method by emulating a complex Earth System Model, showing that BayesClimateNet produces highly accurate and calibrated probabilistic forecasts of key climate variables, significantly outperforming deterministic emulators and standard Bayesian neural networks in both predictive accuracy and uncertainty estimation.
subject: AI
title: Bayesian Deep Emulation of Climate Models with Physics-Constrained Stochastic Variational Inference

text: Enabling machine learning models to continually learn new information on resource-constrained edge devices without catastrophic forgetting is a significant challenge. We present a novel framework based on Hyperdimensional Computing (HDC), an alternative computational paradigm inspired by neural circuits. Our model, HDC-CL, represents data instances as high-dimensional holographic vectors (hypervectors). Learning is achieved by bundling these hypervectors into class prototypes via computationally efficient, bitwise vector operations. To mitigate catastrophic forgetting, we introduce a Hebbian-inspired associative memory update rule with a decay mechanism that dynamically re-weights contributions from old and new data. This allows for incremental class learning without requiring access to past data. Due to its extreme parallelism and absence of gradient-based optimization, HDC-CL demonstrates orders-of-magnitude improvements in energy efficiency and training latency on standard continual learning benchmarks (e.g., Split-CIFAR100) compared to state-of-the-art neural network approaches.
subject: AI
title: Continual On-Device Learning with Associative Hyperdimensional Computing

text: Generative models for de novo protein design hold immense potential for therapeutic and biotechnological applications. We propose Prot-GAN, a generative adversarial network that synthesizes novel protein sequences with desired structural and functional properties. The generator, a SE(3)-equivariant graph transformer, constructs a protein's 3D backbone structure and corresponding amino acid sequence simultaneously, ensuring that generated structures respect fundamental geometric constraints. The discriminator is a dual-head network that assesses both the realism of the generated sequence-structure pairs and their predicted biophysical stability, leveraging a differentiable potential energy function. By conditioning the generator on secondary structure motifs and other biophysical parameters, our model can perform controllable generation. We demonstrate that Prot-GAN can generate a diverse set of novel, stable, and foldable protein structures that are distinct from any known protein in the Protein Data Bank, validated through in silico folding simulations.
subject: AI
title: De Novo Protein Design using Equivariant Graph-based Generative Adversarial Networks

text: We investigate the conjecture that spacetime geometry emerges from the entanglement structure of a boundary quantum field theory, specifically within the AdS/CFT correspondence framework. This work extends the Ryu-Takayanagi formula by employing Multiscale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (MERA) tensor networks to construct a discrete holographic bulk geometry. We demonstrate that the connectivity of the network, which encodes entanglement relationships, quantitatively reproduces the geodesic distances within the corresponding anti-de Sitter space. Our model explicitly realizes the ER=EPR conjecture, where Einstein-Rosen bridges are interpreted as non-local correlations between entangled qubits. Furthermore, we analyze the network's response to local boundary perturbations, showing that the propagation of information through the tensor network bulk mimics gravitational dynamics governed by Einstein's equations in the low-energy limit. This approach provides a concrete computational framework for understanding quantum gravity and the information-theoretic foundations of spacetime, linking quantum error correction codes to the robustness of the emergent geometry.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent Spacetime from Entanglement Entropy in Holographic Tensor Networks

text: Topological quantum computation promises inherent fault tolerance through the encoding of quantum information in non-local degrees of freedom. We present a theoretical and numerical investigation into the braiding of non-Abelian anyons, specifically Ising-type quasiparticles, hypothesized to exist in the ν=5/2 fractional quantum Hall (FQH) state. Using a combination of conformal field theory (CFT) and matrix product state (MPS) simulations, we model the interferometric signatures of braiding operations on these quasiparticles. Our results detail the non-trivial unitary transformations—the Fibonacci matrices—that act on the degenerate ground state manifold, forming the basis of topological quantum gates. We critically analyze the effects of decoherence from edge-state tunneling and quasi-particle localization imperfections. The study provides a detailed roadmap for experimental verification using Fabry-Pérot interferometers in high-mobility GaAs/AlGaAs heterostructures and quantifies the fidelity of a CNOT gate implemented via a sequence of braids, establishing crucial benchmarks for the realization of topological qubits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Braiding Dynamics of Non-Abelian Anyons in a ν=5/2 Fractional Quantum Hall System

text: The phenomenon of many-body localization (MBL) presents a fundamental breakdown of the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH) in isolated, disordered quantum systems. We explore the dynamics of entanglement entropy following a quantum quench in a one-dimensional disordered Heisenberg spin chain. Utilizing large-scale time-evolving block decimation (TEBD) algorithms, we confirm the characteristic logarithmic growth of entanglement entropy in the MBL phase, a stark contrast to the linear growth observed in ergodic systems. Our analysis reveals the emergence of local integrals of motion (l-bits) that structure the Hilbert space into disconnected, dynamically frozen subspaces—a phenomenon known as Hilbert space fragmentation. We further investigate the transition from the MBL to the ergodic phase by tuning disorder strength, identifying a critical point characterized by a sharp change in spectral statistics from Poissonian to Wigner-Dyson distribution. This work elucidates the profound role of quantum information scrambling, or lack thereof, in the non-equilibrium dynamics of complex interacting systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Growth and Fractured Hilbert Space in Many-Body Localized Systems

text: Achieving measurement precision beyond the Standard Quantum Limit (SQL) is paramount for next-generation sensing technologies. This paper proposes and analyzes a multi-pass interferometric scheme that leverages squeezed coherent states to approach the fundamental Heisenberg Limit. We derive the quantum Cramér-Rao bound for phase estimation in a Mach-Zehnder interferometer incorporating a quantum non-demolition (QND) interaction that enables multiple probes of the phase-shifting element by the same optical mode. Our model demonstrates that the phase uncertainty scales as 1/N, where N is the mean photon number, a significant improvement over the 1/√N scaling of the SQL. We systematically evaluate the protocol's robustness against realistic experimental imperfections, including photon loss and mode-matching inefficiency, and propose an adaptive Bayesian estimation algorithm for optimal phase readout. The results offer a viable pathway for enhancing the sensitivity of gravitational wave detectors and atomic clocks beyond current technological plateaus.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Phase Estimation via Multi-Pass Interferometry with Squeezed Coherent States

text: Causal Set Theory posits that spacetime is fundamentally discrete, with the continuum manifold emerging as a macroscopic approximation. This work investigates the quantum dynamics of causal sets using a path integral formulation based on the Benincasa-Dowker action. We perform numerical simulations of the sequential growth dynamics governed by a covariant stochastic process (a 'sprinkle'), from which macroscopic spacetimes are generated. Our analysis demonstrates that a Lorentzian signature and macroscopic dimensionality spontaneously emerge without being presupposed. Furthermore, we explore the fluctuations in the spacetime volume, relating them to the cosmological constant. The model naturally produces a value for Λ that fluctuates around zero, with a magnitude suppressed by the square root of the number of elements in the causal set. This provides a novel, purely quantum-gravitational mechanism for addressing the enormous discrepancy between the theoretically predicted and observationally measured value of the cosmological constant, circumventing the fine-tuning problem.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Dynamics on Causal Sets: Emergence of Lorentzian Signature and the Cosmological Constant Problem

text: Solid-state spin systems, particularly nitrogen-vacancy (NV) centers in diamond, are leading candidates for scalable quantum information processing. We report on the experimental realization of a robust, high-fidelity quantum register composed of a single NV electronic spin and a cluster of proximal ¹³C nuclear spins. By implementing optimized, dynamically corrected gate sequences—specifically, the Carr-Purcell-Meiboom-Gill (CPMG) and Knill dynamical decoupling protocols—we successfully suppress decoherence from the surrounding spin bath, extending the coherence time (T₂) by over two orders of magnitude. We demonstrate arbitrary quantum state preparation and single-shot readout with fidelities exceeding 99.5% for the central electronic spin. Furthermore, we achieve deterministic entanglement between the NV electron and three distinct nuclear spins via hyperfine-mediated quantum logic gates. This work constitutes a critical step towards building fault-tolerant quantum nodes for distributed quantum networks and demonstrates a powerful platform for simulating complex quantum dynamics.
subject: Kuantum
title: High-Fidelity Quantum Control and Entanglement of Nitrogen-Vacancy Center Spin Registers in Diamond

text: We experimentally investigate the interplay between quantum information and thermodynamics by implementing a quantum Szilard engine using a single Rubidium-87 atom trapped in a double-well optical potential. The engine cycle involves an information-acquiring measurement of the atom's position, followed by a feedback-controlled work extraction process. By meticulously characterizing the energy fluctuations and applying the Jarzynski equality, we verify quantum fluctuation theorems far from thermal equilibrium. Our results demonstrate that the work extracted is directly proportional to the Shannon information gained from the measurement, saturating Landauer's principle in the quasi-static limit. We critically analyze the role of quantum coherence during the barrier insertion phase and the thermodynamic cost associated with measurement back-action and information erasure. This experiment provides a canonical testbed for exploring the foundations of quantum thermodynamics and the design principles for future microscopic information-powered engines operating deep in the quantum regime.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Fluctuation Theorems and Work Extraction from a Single-Atom Szilard Engine

text: The search for axionic dark matter constitutes a significant effort in fundamental physics. We present the design and analysis of a novel resonant microwave cavity haloscope that employs a Josephson Parametric Amplifier (JPA) operating in a phase-sensitive, squeezed-state generation mode. This configuration allows for the amplification of the faint signal from axion-to-photon conversion while simultaneously squeezing the quantum vacuum noise of the electromagnetic field below the Standard Quantum Limit (SQL) of 1/2 photon. Our theoretical model, incorporating back-action evasion and quantum non-demolition measurement principles, predicts an axion search scan rate enhancement proportional to the degree of squeezing. We project a sensitivity to the axion-photon coupling constant gₐᵧᵧ that surpasses existing limits by over an order of magnitude in the 5-10 GHz mass range. This quantum-enhanced approach represents a paradigm shift in haloscope experiments, enabling faster and deeper exploration of the parameter space for plausible dark matter candidates.
subject: Kuantum
title: Axionic Dark Matter Detection Surpassing the Standard Quantum Limit with a Josephson Parametric Amplifier-Based Haloscope

text: Non-Hermitian systems with parity-time (PT) symmetry exhibit unique spectral properties, most notably the existence of exceptional points (EPs) where both eigenvalues and eigenvectors coalesce. We theoretically investigate and experimentally demonstrate the physics of higher-order EPs in a coupled photonic waveguide array with precisely engineered gain and loss profiles. Our analysis reveals that the system undergoes a topological phase transition as a parameter is tuned across the EP, characterized by a change in a winding number defined for the complex energy spectrum. Critically, we exploit the divergent response of the system's eigenfrequencies to external perturbations near the EP. We demonstrate an enhanced sensitivity to local refractive index changes, with the frequency splitting scaling as ε¹/ᴺ for an Nth-order EP, where ε is the perturbation strength. This provides a powerful principle for designing ultra-sensitive optical sensors and lasers, harnessing the singular topology of non-Hermitian quantum mechanics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Phase Transitions and Enhanced Sensing at Exceptional Points in Non-Hermitian Photonic Lattices

text: Lattice Gauge Theories (LGTs) form the basis of the Standard Model, but their real-time dynamics, particularly in the non-perturbative regime, are notoriously difficult to simulate classically. We propose a scalable architecture for the quantum simulation of a U(1) LGT in 2+1 dimensions using a mixture of two species of ultracold atoms in a state-dependent optical superlattice. In our scheme, one atomic species represents the fermionic matter fields (staggered fermions), while the other mediates the interaction, encoding the gauge fields on the links of the lattice via a set of precisely controlled laser-assisted tunneling processes. We detail the mapping of the Kogut-Susskind Hamiltonian to the atomic system and show how Gauss's law is enforced through energy penalties. Using numerical simulations based on projected entangled-pair states (PEPS), we demonstrate that this platform can be used to observe fundamental phenomena such as confinement and the real-time dynamics of string breaking, offering a pathway to study QCD in a controlled laboratory setting.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Simulation of U(1) Lattice Gauge Theory and String Breaking with Ultracold Atoms in an Optical Superlattice

text: The fragmented montane habitats of the Andes harbor exceptional biodiversity, yet the evolutionary processes generating this diversity remain incompletely understood. We employed a phylogenomic approach, integrating ultraconserved element (UCE) sequencing and coalescent-based species delimitation methods, to investigate a species complex of high-elevation furnariids. Our analyses, based on over 1,500 loci from 280 individuals, reject the current taxonomy and reveal at least seven distinct, deeply divergent lineages corresponding to isolated 'sky-island' populations. Widespread phylogenetic discordance, attributable to incomplete lineage sorting (ILS), necessitated multispecies coalescent modeling, which strongly supported the delimitation of these cryptic taxa. Molecular dating calibrated with fossil evidence indicates that divergence events coincided with glacial-interglacial cycles of the late Pleistocene, suggesting that climatic oscillations drove repeated vicariance and allopatric speciation. This pronounced taxonomic inflation underscores the cryptic nature of avian diversity in topographically complex regions and highlights the imperative of integrating genomic data for robust conservation assessment.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomics of Andean Sky-Island Avians Reveals Rampant Cryptic Speciation Driven by Pleistocene Climatic Oscillations

text: Archaic hominin introgression has significantly shaped the genomic landscape of modern humans. While previous studies have identified introgressed loci under positive selection, the specific functional consequences and selective pressures often remain elusive. Here, we characterize a deeply divergent haplotype block encompassing the STAT2 gene, a key component of the type-I interferon pathway, introgressed from a Neanderthal-related lineage. Using local ancestry inference across diverse human populations, we demonstrate this haplotype reached high frequencies in specific Eurasian groups post-Out-of-Africa. Functional assays using engineered cell lines reveal that the introgressed STAT2 allele confers a hyper-responsive phenotype to viral dsRNA analogues, leading to potentiated antiviral gene expression but also increased pro-inflammatory signaling. We propose a model wherein this variant provided a selective advantage against enzootic viral pathogens encountered during human expansion, exemplifying how archaic admixture provided a reservoir of pre-adapted alleles that facilitated rapid environmental adaptation.
subject: Evrim
title: Adaptive Introgression of an Archaic STAT2 Haplotype Modulated Viral Response in Early Holocene Human Populations

text: The evolution of complex morphologies is often constrained by the pleiotropic effects of underlying developmental genes. We investigated the evolutionary trajectory of the Engrailed (En) gene, a transcription factor with conserved roles in segmentation and neurogenesis. By performing CRISPR-Cas9-mediated allelic replacement with orthologs from divergent Drosophilid species, we quantified the pleiotropic consequences on adult morphology and fitness. We observed profound antagonistic pleiotropy, where alleles enhancing wing vein patterning invariably disrupted bristle formation and reduced fecundity. Transcriptomic profiling revealed that En interacts within a highly interconnected and buffered gene regulatory network (GRN), which canalizes its developmental output. Our results suggest that the GRN's topology itself evolves to mitigate deleterious pleiotropy, thereby constraining the phenotypic space accessible to En mutations. This network-level buffering provides a mechanistic basis for developmental canalization and explains the evolutionary stasis of key body plan regulators.
subject: Evrim
title: Pleiotropic Constraint and the Canalization of a Developmental Gene Regulatory Network in Drosophila

text: Eco-evolutionary dynamics posit that ecological and evolutionary processes can occur on contemporaneous timescales, creating feedback loops. We tested this hypothesis using a chemostat system with the rotifer Brachionus calyciflorus preying on the alga Chlorella vulgaris. We tracked population densities and allele frequencies at loci associated with nutrient uptake and allocation for over 500 generations. Our results demonstrate that predator-induced nutrient limitation imposed strong selection on algal populations, favoring genotypes with lower phosphorus requirements (higher C:P ratios). This rapid evolution in algal stoichiometry, in turn, altered the carrying capacity and population dynamics of the rotifer predator, modifying the period and amplitude of the predator-prey cycles. Integrating these empirical results into a coupled eco-evolutionary model confirms that the evolutionary trajectory of the prey's elemental composition is a primary driver of ecosystem stability, highlighting the necessity of incorporating microevolutionary change into predictive ecological models.
subject: Evrim
title: Eco-Evolutionary Feedbacks in a Planktonic System: Rapid Evolution of Stoichiometric Traits Drives Predator-Prey Cycle Dynamics

text: Serotiny, the fire-cued release of seeds, is a classic example of a complex adaptive trait. We investigated its genetic basis in Pinus contorta by conducting a large-scale genome-wide association study (GWAS) on over 2,000 individuals from populations spanning a gradient of fire regimes. Using whole-genome resequencing data, we identified over 300 small-effect loci significantly associated with cone serotiny, confirming a highly polygenic architecture. These loci were enriched in gene ontology categories related to lignin biosynthesis, abscisic acid signaling, and heat-shock response. A polygenic risk score derived from these loci strongly predicted the serotiny phenotype in independent validation populations. Furthermore, patterns of allele frequency differentiation at these loci suggest a history of spatially varying selection corresponding to local fire frequencies. Our findings illustrate how complex, ecologically crucial traits can evolve via subtle, coordinated frequency shifts across numerous genes in response to heterogeneous environmental pressures.
subject: Evrim
title: The Polygenic Architecture of Serotiny: A Genome-Wide Association Study in a Fire-Adapted Conifer Reveals a History of Local Adaptation

text: Kin selection theory, encapsulated by Hamilton's rule (rB > C), is the foundational explanation for the evolution of altruism. However, precisely quantifying the rule's components—relatedness (r), benefit (B), and cost (C)—in natural systems remains a formidable challenge. We conducted a socio-genomic study in the paper wasp Polistes dominula, combining high-resolution behavioral observations with genomic relatedness estimates derived from thousands of single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). By tracking the lifetime reproductive success of over 500 individuals, we calculated the fitness costs to subordinate helpers (C) and the fitness benefits to the dominant queen (B). Our data demonstrate a clear positive correlation between a helper's inclusive fitness and their decision to forage for the colony. Crucially, the threshold for altruistic helping behavior closely matched the predictions of Hamilton's rule when accounting for the full distribution of relatedness within colonies. This provides robust empirical validation for kin selection theory in a complex social environment.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Estimation of Inclusive Fitness Components Validates Hamilton's Rule in a Eusocial Wasp

text: Host-parasite coevolution is often characterized by a reciprocal 'arms race' driven by negative frequency-dependent selection. We investigated the molecular signature of this dynamic between Arabidopsis thaliana and the pathogenic oomycete Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis. We focused on the interaction between a host Nucleotide-Binding Leucine-Rich Repeat (NLR) protein, RPP13, and its corresponding pathogen effector protein, ATR13. Population genomic analysis across diverse geographic ranges revealed multiple, lineage-specific hard selective sweeps in both genes. The regions of highest polymorphism and divergence were localized to the leucine-rich repeat domain of RPP13 and the C-terminal domain of ATR13, consistent with direct physical interaction. Ancestral sequence reconstruction and functional assays demonstrate that these recurrent sweeps correspond to novel recognition specificities in the host and corresponding evasion mutations in the pathogen. This tightly coupled pattern of reciprocal, domain-specific positive selection provides compelling molecular evidence for Red Queen dynamics at the level of interacting proteins.
subject: Evrim
title: Molecular Evidence for a Red Queen Arms Race: Recurrent Selective Sweeps in a Plant NLR Gene and a Fungal Effector

text: Small, isolated populations are vulnerable to the accumulation of deleterious mutations due to the overwhelming power of genetic drift relative to selection. We integrated long-term demographic data with whole-genome sequences from the critically endangered Socorro Dove (Zenaida graysoni) to quantify this process. Population viability analysis (PVA) models, parameterized with 30 years of field data, confirmed a history of extreme bottlenecks and demographic stochasticity. We then estimated the distribution of fitness effects (DFE) for new nonsynonymous mutations using a polymorphism-and-divergence-based approach. Our results show a significant enrichment of fixed, slightly-to-moderately deleterious mutations in the Socorro Dove genome compared to its widespread sister taxon. The rate of accumulation of this mutational load, predicted by our genomic DFE, aligns closely with the effective population size (Ne) trajectories inferred from the PVA. This study empirically demonstrates how stochastic demography directly accelerates the fixation of harmful alleles, jeopardizing long-term evolutionary potential.
subject: Evrim
title: Stochastic Demography and the Fixation of Deleterious Mutations in a Critically Endangered Island Endemic

text: The concept of the fitness landscape is central to evolutionary theory, yet its empirical characterization remains a major challenge. We employed deep mutational scanning to construct a high-resolution fitness landscape for the TEM-1 β-lactamase enzyme, quantifying the fitness effects of all possible single and double amino acid substitutions in its active site. While most single mutations were neutral or deleterious, we identified a sparse network of beneficial mutations. The double-mutant landscape revealed pervasive and complex epistasis. Notably, sign epistasis, where a mutation is beneficial on one genetic background but deleterious on another, was common, occurring in over 20% of mutant pairs. This rugged landscape structure creates numerous local fitness peaks and deep valleys, severely constraining evolutionary pathways to higher antibiotic resistance. Only a limited subset of mutational trajectories are accessible to gradual evolution, highlighting how epistatic interactions among mutations dictate the predictability and repeatability of adaptation.
subject: Evrim
title: Mapping the Topography of a Fitness Landscape Reveals Pervasive Sign Epistasis and Constrains Evolutionary Trajectories

text: The role of transposable elements (TEs) in generating adaptive novelty is a subject of intense investigation. Here, we explore the contribution of TE mobilization to the rapid adaptive radiation of Lake Malawi cichlid fishes. Using comparative genomics across dozens of species with divergent jaw morphologies, we identified thousands of recent TE insertions, primarily from the SINE and LINE families, that are polymorphic within the radiation. A significant fraction of these insertions occur in cis-regulatory regions of genes involved in craniofacial development (e.g., bmp4, eda). Chromatin accessibility assays (ATAC-seq) and luciferase reporter assays confirm that a specific SINE family, AfraSINE, contains potent enhancer elements that can be co-opted to drive novel gene expression patterns in the developing jaw. The distribution of these TE-derived enhancers is strongly correlated with divergent feeding ecologies, suggesting that TE mobilization provided a rich substrate of regulatory variation that was repeatedly exapted during the cichlid radiation.
subject: Evrim
title: Transposable Element Exaptation as a Major Driver of Adaptive Radiation in African Cichlids

text: We investigate the decoherence dynamics of multipartite entanglement for a system of N qubits, configured in a Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) state, coupled to a common non-Markovian reservoir with a structured spectral density. By employing a time-convolutionless master equation approach, we analytically and numerically solve for the system's evolution, tracking entanglement via the Peres-Horodecki criterion and multipartite negativity. Our results reveal a pronounced non-monotonic decay of entanglement, characterized by significant revival epochs whose duration and amplitude are contingent on the reservoir's memory kernel and the qubit-field coupling strength. This revival phenomenon is attributed to the backflow of quantum information from the environment to the system, a hallmark of non-Markovianity. We further demonstrate that applying a periodic external driving field can coherently control these revivals, effectively creating a controllable quantum memory. These findings have profound implications for error correction protocols in quantum computation and the design of robust quantum sensors operating in structured environments.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Markovian Dynamics and Entanglement Revival in a Driven Multipartite Qubit System

text: To address the cosmic coincidence and fine-tuning problems inherent in the standard ΛCDM model, we propose a novel cosmological framework based on a scalar field non-minimally coupled to the Einstein-Cartan-Kibble-Sciama (ECKS) theory of gravity. The model introduces a kinetic coupling between the scalar field and the torsion tensor, inducing a chameleon-like screening mechanism that is naturally active in high-density regions. We derive the modified Friedmann equations and the perturbed field equations governing the evolution of cosmological structures. By performing a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) analysis using combined datasets from the Planck CMB power spectra, Baryon Acoustic Oscillations (BAO), and the Pantheon+ supernova catalog, we constrain the model's parameter space. Our results indicate that the model provides a viable alternative to dark energy, exhibiting a phantom-like equation of state at late times without introducing ghost instabilities, while satisfying local gravitational tests due to the torsion-mediated screening.
subject: Fizik
title: A Chameleon-like Scalar Field Model with Kinetic Coupling to Torsion and Cosmological Constraints

text: We theoretically investigate the electronic properties of a heterostructure composed of a three-dimensional topological insulator (TI) proximitized by a ferromagnetic insulator, creating an axion insulator phase. Using a low-energy effective Hamiltonian combined with first-principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations for a Bi2Se3/EuS interface, we demonstrate that breaking time-reversal symmetry gaps the surface Dirac cone. Crucially, we show that when this heterostructure is sculpted into a finite geometry, one-dimensional chiral hinge modes emerge at the intersection of surfaces with opposite magnetic exchange-field signs. These modes are protected by a generalized crystalline symmetry and are robust against non-magnetic disorder. We calculate the local density of states and the non-local conductance signatures of these hinge states, predicting a quantized conductance plateau. Our findings propose a feasible material platform for realizing higher-order topological phases and engineering dissipationless chiral interconnects for future topological electronic devices.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergence of a Chiral Hinge Mode in Magnetically Doped Axion Insulator Heterostructures

text: We explore the statistical mechanics of a dense active fluid composed of self-propelled, rod-like particles exhibiting nematic alignment interactions. Through large-scale agent-based simulations incorporating hydrodynamic interactions via a multiparticle collision dynamics framework, we analyze the system's non-equilibrium steady state. Our analysis focuses on the relationship between the response function, measured via an external perturbing field, and the spontaneous spatiotemporal correlation functions. We report a profound violation of the fluctuation-dissipation theorem (FDT) across all relevant length scales, quantifying the deviation via an effective temperature that is frequency- and wavevector-dependent. This violation is directly linked to the persistent energy flux at the microscopic level, which sustains the system's emergent turbulent-like collective motion and giant number fluctuations. The scale-dependent nature of the FDT breakdown provides a fundamental measure of the system's distance from thermal equilibrium and offers new insights into the thermodynamics of active matter.
subject: Fizik
title: Violation of the Fluctuation-Dissipation Theorem in an Active Nematogenic Fluid

text: We investigate the gravitational wave (GW) emission from an extreme mass ratio inspiral (EMRI) of a stellar-mass compact object into a supermassive black hole endowed with scalar hair, as predicted by certain classes of scalar-tensor theories. By numerically solving the Teukolsky and Regge-Wheeler-Zerilli equations for perturbations on a background spacetime deviating from the standard Kerr metric, we generate precision GW waveforms. Our analysis reveals that the presence of scalar hair introduces distinct modifications to the quasi-normal mode frequencies and induces a characteristic dephasing in the inspiral waveform compared to its general relativistic counterpart. This dephasing accumulates over the thousands of orbits typical for an EMRI, rendering it a detectable signature for next-generation space-based GW observatories like LISA. We demonstrate that waveform template mismatch calculations can place stringent constraints on the scalar charge-to-mass ratio, providing a powerful null test of the black hole no-hair theorem.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Wave Signatures of Scalar Hair from Extreme Mass Ratio Inspirals into Kerr-Newman Black Holes

text: The persistent discrepancy between the experimental value of the muon's anomalous magnetic moment (g-2) and the Standard Model prediction strongly suggests new physics. We propose a solution within a supersymmetric framework featuring non-universal gaugino masses at the grand unification scale. In this scenario, a light smuon, neutralino, and chargino sector can generate the requisite contribution to Δaμ via chirally-enhanced one-loop diagrams, without necessitating colored sparticles in the sub-TeV range. We perform a comprehensive phenomenological analysis, demonstrating that this parameter space remains viable against current constraints from LHC searches for electroweakinos, dark matter relic density measurements from Planck, and direct detection experiments like XENONnT. The model predicts specific signatures, including compressed-spectrum di-lepton and tri-lepton final states, which can be probed with high luminosity at the LHC, offering a testable explanation for the g-2 anomaly.
subject: Fizik
title: Resolving the Muon g-2 Anomaly with Electroweakino Sector Physics in a Non-Universal Gaugino Mass Model

text: Utilizing the gauge/gravity duality, we construct a holographic model for a strongly coupled quantum system exhibiting a quantum phase transition driven by electron-phonon interactions. The model consists of a charged fermionic field in an asymptotically Anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime, coupled to a bulk scalar field representing the phonons. By calculating the fermion spectral function from the gravity dual, we identify a quantum critical point where the system transitions from a Fermi liquid-like state, characterized by a well-defined quasiparticle peak, to a non-Fermi liquid phase with a broad, incoherent spectrum. Near the critical point, we compute transport properties such as optical conductivity and find anomalous scaling behavior, consistent with observations in strange metals. The holographic framework provides a powerful, non-perturbative tool to analyze the universal dynamics near such quantum critical points, bridging gravitational physics with condensed matter phenomena.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Duality and Quantum Criticality in a Strongly Coupled Electron-Phonon System

text: We report the experimental realization of a programmable quantum simulator based on a two-dimensional array of hundreds of individual 87Rb atoms trapped in optical tweezers. By dressing the ground state with a manifold of Rydberg states using spatially modulated, time-periodic laser fields, we implement a Floquet-engineered spin Hamiltonian with tunable, long-range, and anisotropic interactions. This technique allows us to simulate the ground-state properties of a frustrated quantum XY model on a triangular lattice. We directly observe the emergence of complex, non-local magnetic order by measuring multipartite spin-spin correlation functions and entanglement witnesses. The results are in excellent agreement with large-scale density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) calculations and provide compelling evidence for the formation of a quantum spin liquid phase in a specific region of the parameter space. This platform offers unprecedented control for exploring many-body localization, quantum thermalization, and topological phases of matter.
subject: Fizik
title: Coherent Quantum Simulation of Frustrated Magnetism using a Floquet-Engineered Rydberg Atom Array

text: We present a continuum mechanics framework to describe the cytoplasm as an active, biphasic poroelastic medium, aiming to elucidate the physical mechanisms of cellular mechanotransduction. The model treats the cytosol as an interstitial fluid and the cross-linked cytoskeleton as a permeable, elastic solid matrix. Crucially, we incorporate an active stress tensor, derived from a microscopic model of myosin-II motor protein activity, which drives contractile behavior and fluid-solid counterflow. Using a finite element implementation, we simulate the cell's response to external stimuli, such as substrate rigidity and localized point forces. The model successfully reproduces key experimental observations, including the biphasic stress relaxation, long-range force transmission, and the dependence of focal adhesion maturation on matrix stiffness. This active poroelastic theory provides a quantitative, multiscale link between molecular-level cytoskeletal dynamics and macroscopic cell mechanical behavior, offering a powerful tool for studying cell physiology and disease.
subject: Fizik
title: An Active Poroelastic Model for Cytoskeletal Mechanotransduction and Force Transmission

text: The mechanism of angular momentum transport in accretion disks is a central problem in astrophysics, with the magnetorotational instability (MRI) being a leading candidate. Using fully kinetic, three-dimensional particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations, we investigate the saturation of the MRI and the subsequent energy dissipation pathways. Our simulations resolve plasma dynamics down to the electron inertial length, revealing that the MRI-driven turbulence cascades energy down to kinetic scales where it triggers rapid magnetic reconnection within thinning current sheets. This reconnection is characterized by a plasmoid-dominated, fractal-like structure, leading to reconnection rates that are significantly faster than those predicted by classical resistive models. We demonstrate that this process is a dominant channel for plasma heating, efficiently converting magnetic energy into non-thermal particle acceleration. These results provide a first-principles foundation for understanding the thermodynamic state of accretion flows and their observational signatures, from stellar to supermassive black hole systems.
subject: Fizik
title: Kinetic-Scale Turbulence and Plasmoid-Mediated Reconnection in Magnetorotational Instability

text: Standard variational inference (VI) in Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs) often fails to capture the complex, non-Euclidean geometry of the posterior distribution, leading to poorly calibrated uncertainty estimates. We introduce Riemannian Manifold Variational Inference (RMVI), a novel framework that leverages information geometry to define the variational approximation directly on a manifold. By employing a natural gradient descent optimization scheme derived from the Fisher information metric, our method more effectively navigates the curvature of the true posterior landscape. We parameterize the variational family using a neural network that outputs the manifold's local coordinates, enabling a scalable and expressive approximation. Evaluated on challenging regression and image classification tasks, including out-of-distribution detection benchmarks, RMVI demonstrates state-of-the-art performance in uncertainty calibration and model robustness. Our results show a significant reduction in expected calibration error and improved epistemic uncertainty quantification compared to traditional mean-field VI and Monte Carlo dropout, providing a more principled approach to safety-critical AI applications.
subject: AI
title: Variational Inference on Riemannian Manifolds for Calibrated Bayesian Deep Learning

text: Conventional meta-learning algorithms often struggle with task ambiguity and rapid adaptation in heterogeneous few-shot learning scenarios. To address this, we propose an Amortized Bayesian Meta-Learning (ABML) framework that explicitly models task-specific uncertainty. Our approach meta-learns a hypernetwork that generates task-dependent prior distributions over the parameters of a base learner. This is achieved through a hierarchical Bayesian model where the prior is conditioned on a task embedding produced by the hypernetwork from the support set. We employ amortized variational inference to make the posterior inference over the base learner's parameters computationally tractable. This allows the model to adapt not only its parameter values but also its uncertainty estimates for each new task. We demonstrate through extensive experiments on Mini-ImageNet and Tiered-ImageNet benchmarks that ABML significantly improves few-shot classification accuracy and provides well-calibrated predictions under distributional shifts, outperforming prominent gradient-based and metric-based meta-learning methods.
subject: AI
title: Amortized Bayesian Meta-Learning with Task-Dependent Priors

text: Estimating individual treatment effects (ITE) from observational data is a fundamental challenge in causal inference, primarily due to unobserved confounding. This paper introduces a Deep Causal Representation (DCR) framework that learns disentangled representations to mitigate the effects of hidden confounders. Our approach integrates a variational autoencoder (VAE) with a structural causal model, leveraging proxy variables—observed variables causally influenced by the latent confounders. The VAE's encoder maps high-dimensional inputs (covariates, treatments, proxies) to a latent space, where a causal mechanism is enforced to separate representations of confounding, instrumental, and prognostic factors. A multi-headed decoder then reconstructs the observed outcomes and estimates counterfactuals. By optimizing a carefully designed Evidence Lower Bound (ELBO) objective that incorporates causal constraints, DCR learns representations robust to confounding bias. We validate our framework on synthetic and semi-synthetic benchmarks, showing superior performance in ITE estimation compared to existing deep learning-based causal inference methods.
subject: AI
title: Deep Causal Representation Learning for Counterfactual Inference from High-Dimensional Observational Data

text: Self-supervised learning on multimodal data aims to learn unified representations by aligning information from different modalities, such as images and text. However, existing contrastive learning methods often learn redundant inter-modal correlations, hindering generalization. We propose a novel objective, Cross-Modal Information Bottleneck (CM-IB), that regularizes contrastive learning by explicitly minimizing the mutual information between the learned representations and the input, while maximizing it between representations of different modalities. This forces the model to learn a minimal, sufficient representation that captures only the essential shared semantic information. We implement CM-IB by introducing a variational approximation to the mutual information terms, which can be seamlessly integrated into a dual-encoder architecture. Our experiments on large-scale image-text datasets, including MS-COCO and Conceptual Captions, demonstrate that CM-IB yields more robust and semantically meaningful embeddings. This leads to new state-of-the-art results on zero-shot image retrieval and classification tasks, validating the efficacy of our principled information-theoretic approach.
subject: AI
title: Cross-Modal Contrastive Learning with Information Bottleneck for Aligned Multimodal Representations

text: Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative model training without centralizing raw data, but it remains vulnerable to privacy breaches. Differentially Private Federated Learning (DP-FL) addresses this by injecting noise into gradient updates, often leading to a significant utility-privacy trade-off. We propose Adaptive Per-Layer Noise Federated Learning (APL-FL), a novel DP-FL algorithm that improves this trade-off. APL-FL recognizes that different layers in a deep neural network exhibit varying sensitivity to perturbation. It dynamically calibrates the scale of the Gaussian noise added to each layer's gradients based on a running estimate of its L2 sensitivity, while maintaining a rigorous overall (ε, δ)-differential privacy guarantee for the entire model update. This adaptive noise injection scheme allocates the privacy budget more efficiently, protecting sensitive parameters while preserving utility. Evaluated on non-IID data distributions across benchmark vision and language datasets, APL-FL demonstrates substantial improvements in model accuracy over fixed-noise DP-SGD and other adaptive methods for the same privacy budget.
subject: AI
title: Adaptive Differentially Private Federated Learning with Per-Layer Noise Calibration

text: Generating realistic synthetic tabular data is critical for data sharing, anonymization, and augmentation, yet it remains a challenge for Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) due to the non-Euclidean nature of mixed-type data and the risk of mode collapse. We introduce Tabular-WGAN with Differentiable Augmentation (T-WGAN-DA), a novel architecture designed specifically for high-fidelity tabular data synthesis. Our model employs a Wasserstein GAN with a gradient penalty (WGAN-GP) to ensure training stability and incorporates a reversible, learnable preprocessing step to map discrete and continuous columns into a unified continuous space. Critically, we introduce a stochastic, differentiable augmentation pipeline applied to both real and fake data before they are fed to the discriminator. This strategy prevents the discriminator from overfitting and memorizing the training set, thereby improving generator convergence and output diversity. Extensive empirical evaluation on multiple real-world datasets shows that T-WGAN-DA significantly outperforms existing tabular GANs and other generative models in terms of statistical similarity, machine learning efficacy, and privacy preservation.
subject: AI
title: Generative Adversarial Networks with Differentiable Augmentation for High-Fidelity Tabular Synthesis

text: Solving complex, long-horizon tasks with sparse rewards is a central challenge in reinforcement learning (RL). We present a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, Successor Feature Skill Discovery (SFSD), that enables an agent to autonomously discover and compose temporally extended skills. Unlike traditional options-based HRL, SFSD does not require predefined subgoals. Instead, a lower-level policy discovers a diverse set of skills by maximizing a variational intrinsic reward based on the empowerment over successor features—abstractions of the expected future state occupancies. A high-level meta-policy then learns to sequence these discovered skills to solve the extrinsic task. This approach creates a clean separation between skill discovery and task-specific learning, promoting transferability. We demonstrate in challenging continuous control domains with sparse rewards, including complex locomotion and manipulation tasks, that SFSD learns more efficiently and achieves superior asymptotic performance compared to both non-hierarchical agents and state-of-the-art HRL methods.
subject: AI
title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning via Skill Discovery with Successor Feature Abstractions

text: We propose a unified framework for deep neural network compression, Hessian-Aware Pruning and Quantization (HAPQ), that co-optimizes structured pruning and mixed-precision quantization to achieve maximal model compression with minimal accuracy degradation. Conventional methods often treat pruning and quantization as sequential, sub-optimal steps. In contrast, HAPQ leverages second-order information from the loss function's Hessian to jointly determine the importance of network structures (filters or channels) and the optimal bit-width for quantizing weight tensors. Our method formulates a global optimization problem with a constrained budget for model size or FLOPs, which is solved iteratively. The Hessian information provides a principled way to estimate the impact of removing a structure or reducing precision, allowing the algorithm to make more informed decisions. We demonstrate on ImageNet and COCO benchmarks that HAPQ surpasses existing state-of-the-art compression techniques, achieving superior Pareto frontiers for the accuracy-compression trade-off across a range of convolutional architectures.
subject: AI
title: Hessian-Aware Structured Pruning and Non-Uniform Quantization for Optimal Network Compression

text: Bridging the gap between subsymbolic pattern recognition and symbolic reasoning is a key objective for achieving more robust and generalizable AI. We introduce Differentiable Logic Tensor Networks (DLTNs), a neuro-symbolic framework that enables end-to-end learning of perceptual systems and logical reasoners. DLTNs represent symbolic knowledge, expressed in first-order logic, within a continuous tensorized space. Logical predicates and functions are parameterized by neural networks, and logical connectives are implemented as differentiable tensor operations. We develop a novel semantic unification algorithm that performs fuzzy unification over learned entity embeddings, allowing the system to reason with facts grounded in perceptual data. The entire model is trained end-to-end by minimizing a loss function that reflects logical inconsistency in the knowledge base. We demonstrate the efficacy of DLTNs on complex visual question answering and knowledge base completion tasks, where our model significantly outperforms purely neural or symbolic baselines by effectively combining high-level reasoning with low-level perception.
subject: AI
title: End-to-End Neuro-Symbolic Reasoning via Differentiable First-Order Logic Programming

text: This paper presents a scalable Bayesian nonparametric framework for topic modeling that incorporates document-specific covariates to inform the thematic structure. We extend the Hierarchical Dirichlet Process (HDP) by parameterizing the top-level stick-breaking process weights as a logistic-normal function of observed covariates, allowing topic prevalence to vary systematically across a corpus. Direct posterior inference is intractable; thus, we develop a Stochastic Variational Inference (SVI) algorithm that optimizes the Evidence Lower Bound (ELBO) using natural gradients. This approach circumvents the restrictive mean-field assumptions of traditional variational methods by employing a structured approximation for the global topic atoms. We derive theoretical guarantees on the posterior contraction rates for the topic distributions and the covariate regression coefficients. Experiments on large-scale text corpora demonstrate our model's enhanced predictive performance, improved topic interpretability, and significant computational speedup over comparable MCMC-based methods, making it suitable for modern data-intensive applications.
subject: İstatistik
title: Scalable Variational Inference for Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Models with Covariate-Dependent Dynamics

text: We generalize Functional Principal Component Analysis (FPCA) to accommodate functional data taking values in a non-Euclidean Riemannian manifold, while simultaneously accounting for spatial correlation among functional observations. Our method, termed Spatio-Correlated Manifold FPCA (SCM-FPCA), models individual trajectories as geodesics fluctuating around a global Fréchet mean function. The principal modes of variation are defined as orthogonal tangent vector fields on the manifold, derived from a spectral decomposition of a spatially-weighted covariance operator. Estimation is performed via an iterative tangent space projection algorithm that alternates between estimating the Fréchet mean and the eigenfunctions. We establish the consistency of the estimated functional principal components and scores under suitable regularity and mixing conditions on the spatial process. The methodology is validated through simulations on spherical and Symmetric Positive-Definite matrix-valued functions and is applied to analyze spatio-temporal brain connectivity patterns from diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Manifold-Valued Functional Principal Component Analysis for Spatially Correlated Trajectory Data

text: Persistent Homology (PH) has emerged as a powerful tool in Topological Data Analysis (TDA) for characterizing the shape of data. However, a significant gap remains in performing rigorous statistical inference on topological features. This paper introduces a robust, computationally feasible framework for constructing confidence regions for persistence diagrams. We propose a subsampling-based method, the Bottleneck Bootstrap, which leverages the intrinsic metric structure of the space of persistence diagrams. Unlike naive bootstrap approaches, our method is provably consistent for constructing confidence sets for the underlying limiting diagram under weak assumptions on the data-generating process. We rigorously establish the asymptotic validity and convergence rates for the estimated confidence regions. The practical utility is demonstrated by applying our inferential framework to differentiate between simulated point cloud data from distinct distributions and to analyze topological features in a dataset of cosmic microwave background radiation maps, enabling quantification of uncertainty in detected cosmic voids.
subject: İstatistik
title: A Statistical Framework for Inference on Persistent Homology using the Bottleneck Bootstrap

text: We propose a novel estimation procedure for the Fine-Gray subdistribution hazards model with time-varying coefficients to analyze competing risks data in high dimensions. The temporal dynamics of covariate effects are modeled nonparametrically using B-spline basis expansions. To ensure interpretability and parsimony, we introduce a fused-group LASSO penalty on the spline coefficients. This structured penalty simultaneously performs variable selection by shrinking entire coefficient functions to zero and encourages local constancy by penalizing differences between adjacent spline coefficients. We develop an efficient block coordinate descent algorithm for computation of the entire regularization path. Theoretically, we establish the non-asymptotic oracle inequalities for the proposed estimator, demonstrating its consistency and optimal convergence rates. The method's empirical performance is evaluated through simulation studies, showing its superiority in both prediction and variable selection compared to standard time-invariant models and unpenalized time-varying approaches. We illustrate its application in a clinical trial for identifying dynamic risk factors for different causes of mortality.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Regularization Pathways for Time-Varying Coefficients in Competing Risks Models

text: Learning the structure of Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs) from observational data is a fundamental problem in many scientific fields. Existing methods often rely on restrictive parametric assumptions, such as linearity or Gaussianity. We develop a flexible Bayesian semiparametric framework for learning DAGs from datasets containing mixed variables (continuous, count, and categorical). Our approach is based on a latent variable model, using Gaussian copulas to flexibly model the conditional dependencies without specifying marginal distributions. This allows for the detection of complex, non-linear relationships. We propose a novel structure MCMC algorithm that combines local proposals in the graph space with an efficient Gibbs sampler for the latent variables and model parameters. We prove posterior consistency for both the graph structure and the model parameters under mild regularity conditions. The methodology's effectiveness in structural discovery and density estimation is demonstrated on synthetic and real-world datasets, outperforming state-of-the-art methods, particularly in non-Gaussian scenarios.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Semiparametric Inference for Directed Acyclic Graphs with Mixed-Type Variables

text: This paper introduces a Factor-Adjusted Regularized Vector Autoregression (FAR-VAR) model for forecasting and structural analysis of high-dimensional, non-stationary time series. The methodology operates in two stages. First, it decomposes the series into a common component driven by a few pervasive latent factors and an idiosyncratic component. We employ dynamic principal component analysis to consistently estimate the factor structure even in the presence of I(1) non-stationarity and structural breaks. Second, a high-dimensional VAR model is fitted to the quasi-stationary idiosyncratic components using a structured penalty, such as an adaptive elastic net, to enforce sparsity on the transition matrix. This decomposition effectively mitigates issues of spurious regression and parameter proliferation that plague standard VARs in high dimensions. We derive non-asymptotic error bounds for the estimated factor loadings, transition matrices, and impulse response functions. The model demonstrates superior forecasting accuracy over competing methods in simulations and an application to large-scale macroeconomic data, providing coherent economic interpretations.
subject: İstatistik
title: Factor-Adjusted Vector Autoregression for High-Dimensional Time Series with Non-Stationary Components

text: The Stable Unit Treatment Value Assumption (SUTVA) is frequently violated in settings where units are interconnected, leading to biased causal effect estimates. We propose a novel hierarchical Bayesian model to estimate direct and indirect (spillover) causal effects in the presence of network interference. Our approach generalizes the potential outcomes framework by defining a unit’s exposure as a function of its own treatment and a summary of its neighborhood's treatment assignments. We parameterize the dose-response functions flexibly using Gaussian processes and embed them within a hierarchical structure that allows for borrowing of information across network clusters. This clustering is determined endogenously via a Dirichlet process mixture model on node embeddings. Posterior computation proceeds via a custom MCMC algorithm. We prove posterior consistency for the average direct and indirect effects under certain graph regularity conditions. The method is shown to outperform existing estimators in simulation studies and provides new insights in a re-analysis of a networked public health intervention.
subject: İstatistik
title: Estimating Causal Effects under Network Interference using a Hierarchical Potential Outcomes Framework

text: We present a computationally scalable framework for modeling large-scale, non-stationary spatio-temporal data. The methodology leverages a multi-resolution analysis by projecting the underlying spatial process at each time point onto a sparse wavelet basis. This projection induces a sparse representation of the spatial covariance structure, effectively reducing the dimensionality of the problem from the number of spatial locations to the number of significant wavelet coefficients. The temporal evolution of these coefficients is then captured by a multivariate dynamic linear model (DLM), which can accommodate non-stationary temporal dynamics and allows for efficient recursive computation via the Kalman filter. This approach circumvents the prohibitive cubic complexity of traditional full-rank Gaussian Process models. We establish theoretical bounds on the approximation error from the basis projection and demonstrate the model’s superior predictive accuracy and computational efficiency on a large dataset of satellite-derived sea surface temperature measurements, compared to spatio-temporal Kriging and latent process models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Multi-Resolution Spatio-Temporal Models via Gaussian Process Projections on Wavelet Bases

text: This paper introduces a new class of robust regression estimators by minimizing the Wasserstein divergence between the empirical distribution of residuals and a specified symmetric, centered reference distribution. This Minimum Wasserstein Divergence Estimator (MWDE) offers a geometrically intuitive alternative to classical M-estimators. We establish the theoretical properties of the MWDE, including existence, strong consistency, and asymptotic normality under weak regularity conditions. Crucially, we derive its influence function and demonstrate that it is bounded and redescending, confirming the estimator's high robustness against leverage points and vertical outliers. A computationally efficient algorithm is developed by leveraging the dual formulation of the entropic-regularized optimal transport problem. Extensive Monte Carlo simulations show that the MWDE achieves superior performance over traditional robust methods like Least Trimmed Squares and Huber's estimator, particularly under high contamination, while retaining high efficiency at the Gaussian model. The method's utility is illustrated through an analysis of a real-world dataset from econometrics.
subject: İstatistik
title: Robust Regression and Inference via Minimum Wasserstein Divergence Estimation

text: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) often fail to capture the underlying topological structure of data manifolds, leading to mode collapse and synthesis of non-homologous artifacts. We introduce a novel topological regularization framework, TopoGAN, that enforces manifold-preservation by penalizing topological discrepancies between the real and generated data distributions. Our approach leverages persistent homology, a key tool from topological data analysis, to characterize the data's multi-scale topological features (e.g., connected components, loops). The regularizer is formulated as a differentiable loss term based on the sliced Wasserstein distance between persistence diagrams computed from mini-batches of real and generated samples. This term is integrated into a Wasserstein GAN with Gradient Penalty (WGAN-GP) architecture, guiding the generator to learn the correct Betti numbers of the target manifold. We demonstrate empirically on synthetic datasets (e.g., tori, Swiss rolls) and complex image benchmarks that our method significantly mitigates mode collapse, preserves homotopy types, and generates samples of higher topological fidelity compared to state-of-the-art baselines.
subject: AI
title: Topological Regularization of Latent Spaces in Generative Adversarial Networks for Manifold-Preserving Data Synthesis

text: Standard reinforcement learning algorithms exhibit brittleness in non-stationary environments, as they often exploit spurious correlations that fail to generalize when environmental dynamics or reward functions shift. To address this, we propose Causal-Interventional Reinforcement Learning (CIRL), a framework that endows agents with the ability to reason about causal mechanisms. CIRL first learns a structural causal model (SCM) of the environment from observational data and limited interventional experiments. Subsequently, the policy is optimized not only on observed state-action trajectories but also on counterfactual outcomes estimated via the do-calculus on the learned SCM. This interventional training objective forces the agent to disentangle causal factors from confounding variables, leading to more robust policy learning. We instantiate CIRL by coupling a graph-based causal discovery module with a deep Q-network. Empirical evaluations across a suite of benchmarks with systematic compositional changes show that CIRL achieves superior zero-shot transfer performance, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art model-based and model-free RL algorithms that rely on purely observational learning.
subject: AI
title: Causal-Interventional Reinforcement Learning for Robust Policy Generalization in Non-Stationary Environments

text: Modeling continuous-time dynamics on graphs with time-varying topologies is a formidable challenge for discrete-time Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). We introduce Neural Graph Ordinary Differential Equations (NGDEs), a novel deep learning framework that learns the continuous-time evolution of node representations on dynamic graphs. NGDEs parameterize the derivative of the node hidden states using a GNN, thereby defining a vector field that governs the system's dynamics. The evolution is computed by integrating this vector field using a numerical ODE solver, which naturally handles irregularly sampled data. To accommodate evolving graph structures, we introduce a time-varying graph Laplacian formulated within a Riemannian geometry framework, treating the system as evolving on a dynamic manifold. This continuous-depth approach provides a principled way to model complex spatio-temporal processes. We demonstrate that NGDEs achieve state-of-the-art performance on traffic forecasting with dynamic road networks and particle physics simulation tasks, excelling at both interpolation and long-term extrapolation compared to recurrent GNNs and other continuous-time models.
subject: AI
title: Neural Graph Ordinary Differential Equations for Spatio-Temporal Dynamics on Evolving Manifolds

text: Federated Learning (FL) is susceptible to both privacy attacks and security threats from Byzantine adversaries who can corrupt the global model by sending malicious updates. We propose AegisFL, a robust FL framework that provides strong guarantees for both privacy and security. Our system integrates client-level (ε, δ)-differential privacy via noise injection and gradient clipping with a novel Byzantine-resilient secure aggregation protocol. To prevent malicious contributions, we introduce a verifiable decentralized trust mechanism. Each client’s update, encrypted using a threshold homomorphic encryption scheme, is accompanied by a zero-knowledge proof of correctness, attesting to the update's consistency with the client's local data statistics. A distributed ledger maintains trust scores for all participants, allowing the server to perform a weighted aggregation that down-weights or excludes contributions from clients with historically low trust scores, without ever decrypting individual updates. Theoretical analysis and empirical results on non-IID benchmarks demonstrate that AegisFL maintains high model utility while providing provable resilience against a significant fraction of Byzantine attackers.
subject: AI
title: Byzantine-Resilient and Differentially Private Federated Learning via Secure Aggregation with Verifiable Decentralized Trust

text: Aligning representations from disparate modalities like vision and language is fundamental to multimodal AI, yet existing contrastive learning methods often struggle with semantic ambiguity and require vast paired datasets. We propose Cross-Modal Prototypical Contrastive Learning (X-PCL), a self-supervised framework that learns a shared semantic embedding space by aligning clusters of prototypes instead of individual instances. X-PCL first performs intra-modal clustering to discover semantic prototypes within each modality's embedding space. Subsequently, a prototype-level contrastive loss pulls together corresponding cross-modal prototypes while pushing apart non-matching ones. This cluster-based objective encourages the model to learn a more semantically structured and robust joint manifold, abstracting away instance-level noise. Framed through an information bottleneck perspective, the prototypes act as a compressed representation of semantic concepts. X-PCL achieves state-of-the-art performance on zero-shot text-to-image retrieval on MS-COCO and Flickr30k, demonstrating superior fine-grained alignment and robustness to noisy data pairings compared to instance-based contrastive methods.
subject: AI
title: Cross-Modal Prototypical Contrastive Learning for Zero-Shot Multimodal Alignment

text: Gradient-based meta-learning algorithms like MAML treat the parameter space as Euclidean, ignoring the intrinsic geometry of the task-specific loss landscapes. This can lead to inefficient adaptation and suboptimal generalization. We propose a new meta-learning framework that reframes the optimization problem on a Riemannian manifold of loss functions. Our approach, Riemannian Meta-Learning (RML), learns a parameter initialization that minimizes the expected geodesic distance to the task-specific optima. The meta-update is performed via a hyper-gradient step governed by the natural gradient, which leverages the Fisher Information Matrix as the Riemannian metric tensor. This pre-conditions the meta-update with respect to the curvature of the loss manifold, enabling more direct and efficient paths toward adaptation. We derive a computationally tractable approximation of the Fisher matrix that allows RML to scale to deep neural networks. On challenging few-shot classification and regression benchmarks, RML demonstrates significantly faster adaptation and converges to solutions with superior generalization capabilities compared to prominent Euclidean-based meta-learning algorithms.
subject: AI
title: Hyper-Gradient Dynamics on the Loss Manifold: A Riemannian Approach to Meta-Learning

text: The quadratic complexity of the self-attention mechanism in Transformers poses a significant computational barrier to processing long sequences. We introduce the Fourier-Accelerated State Space Transformer (FASST), an architecture that replaces the attention mechanism with a structured state space model (SSM) to achieve sub-quadratic complexity. FASST models long-range dependencies by representing the sequence-to-sequence transformation as a continuous-time linear system. This system is discretized into a convolutional kernel, and the sequence output is computed efficiently in O(N log N) time via the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT). Our key innovation lies in a parameterization of the state transition matrices based on diagonal plus low-rank structures, which ensures stability and allows for efficient computation while maintaining high expressive power. We show that this formulation is equivalent to a specific type of structured global convolutional kernel. FASST achieves state-of-the-art results on the Long Range Arena (LRA) benchmark and demonstrates superior performance and efficiency on language modeling tasks with sequences exceeding 16k tokens, outperforming both standard Transformers and other efficient variants.
subject: AI
title: Fourier-Accelerated State Space Models for Sub-Quadratic Attention in Long-Sequence Transformers

text: Accurate uncertainty quantification in deep learning is critical for safety-sensitive applications, yet posterior inference over the high-dimensional weight space of neural networks is notoriously difficult. We introduce Functional Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (fSGLD), a scalable MCMC algorithm that performs posterior sampling directly in the space of functions, rather than the parameter space. This approach is motivated by the observation that many different weight configurations can map to nearly identical functions. fSGLD defines a Langevin diffusion process on the function space, guided by a prior (e.g., a Gaussian Process) and the data likelihood. We derive a practical implementation where each sampling step involves a functional gradient update, realized efficiently through a neural network parameterization and leveraging techniques from kernel methods. By exploring the typically lower-dimensional and better-behaved functional posterior, fSGLD mixes more rapidly and effectively captures a diverse ensemble of predictive functions. On various regression and out-of-distribution detection tasks, fSGLD provides better-calibrated uncertainty estimates and higher predictive log-likelihoods than weight-space SGLD, variational inference, and deep ensembles.
subject: AI
title: Functional Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics for Scalable Uncertainty Quantification in Deep Neural Networks

text: Bridging the gap between subsymbolic pattern recognition and symbolic reasoning is a central goal of AI. We propose Neural Inductive Logic Programming (δILP), a framework that learns explicit first-order logic rules from data in an end-to-end differentiable manner. δILP represents symbolic rules within a continuous, tensorized knowledge base and utilizes a neural controller to synthesize candidate logical clauses. The core of our system is a differentiable forward-chaining inference engine that evaluates the logical entailment of these clauses against background knowledge and examples. By relaxing logical operations into continuous functions, the entire process of rule generation, selection, and evaluation becomes differentiable, enabling gradient-based optimization over the combinatorial space of logic programs. This allows δILP to learn human-readable logical theories directly from noisy, high-dimensional inputs. We demonstrate its efficacy on relational learning tasks such as knowledge base completion and graph-based reasoning, where it not only achieves high predictive accuracy but also provides verifiable symbolic explanations for its inferences.
subject: AI
title: Differentiable Inductive Logic Programming with Neural Program Synthesis for Explainable Reasoning

text: The computational discovery of novel crystalline materials with tailored properties is a fundamental challenge in materials science. We introduce CrystalDiffusion, a generative framework for the inverse design of stable and diverse crystal structures. Our model is a denoising diffusion probabilistic model that operates directly on the atomic coordinates and types within a periodic unit cell, conditioned on a target property vector. To respect the fundamental symmetries of crystal structures, the denoising network is designed to be E(3)-equivariant, ensuring that the generation process is invariant to rotations, translations, and reflections of the atomic arrangement. We explicitly incorporate periodic boundary conditions into the diffusion and denoising steps to handle the lattice structure. For inverse design, we employ classifier-free guidance to steer the reverse diffusion process toward generating candidates that exhibit desired physical properties (e.g., formation energy, band gap). Validated with Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations, CrystalDiffusion generates a high percentage of physically valid and novel structures, significantly accelerating the high-throughput screening pipeline for materials discovery.
subject: AI
title: Generative Inverse Design of Crystalline Materials with Equivariant Diffusion Models

text: The role of non-genetic inheritance in adaptation remains a central debate in evolutionary biology. We investigated the heritability of environmentally induced epigenetic modifications in the cladoceran *Daphnia magna*. Using whole-genome bisulfite sequencing and RNA-seq, we characterized the methylome and transcriptome of isogenic lineages exposed to predator kairomones for multiple generations. We identified hundreds of differentially methylated regions (DMRs), primarily in intragenic CpG islands, that correlated with sustained upregulation of morphological defense genes. Crucially, a significant subset of these epialleles, along with the defensive phenotype, persisted for three generations in a predator-free environment, demonstrating transgenerational inheritance. Our results indicate that environmentally sculpted DNA methylation patterns can act as a heritable substrate for natural selection, facilitating rapid adaptive responses on ecological timescales. This mechanism may significantly augment adaptive potential in populations facing novel environmental stressors, challenging classical neo-Darwinian frameworks that posit genetic mutation as the sole source of heritable variation.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance Mediates Rapid Adaptive Responses to Environmental Perturbations

text: Cryptic genetic variation (CGV) represents a vast, unexpressed reservoir of potential phenotypes that can be unveiled under environmental stress, potentially facilitating rapid adaptation. We explored this phenomenon by inhibiting the molecular chaperone Hsp90 in a large panel of *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* isolates under supraoptimal temperatures. Hsp90 knockdown induced a dramatic increase in phenotypic variance for thermotolerance. Through bulk segregant analysis and quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping on experimentally evolved populations, we identified numerous polymorphic loci with previously undetected effects that contributed to the rapid acquisition of high thermotolerance. These loci were enriched for functions in cell wall integrity and protein folding pathways. Our findings demonstrate that environmental stress can decanalize pre-existing, polygenic variation by overwhelming cellular buffering systems. This release of CGV serves as a potent source of selectable novelty, enabling evolutionary rescue in populations that would otherwise face extinction, highlighting the importance of genetic capacitance in evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Decanalization of Cryptic Genetic Variation Underpins Evolutionary Rescue in Thermally Stressed Saccharomyces cerevisiae

text: Archaic hominin introgression has profoundly shaped the genomes of modern humans. While Neanderthal admixture is well-characterized, the contribution of Denisovans, particularly in Insular Southeast Asia (ISEA), remains poorly resolved. We analyzed high-coverage whole-genome sequences from 15 diverse ethnolinguistic groups across ISEA, applying coalescent-based modeling and novel methods for detecting archaic haplotypes. Our analyses reveal at least three distinct Denisovan introgression pulses into the ancestors of modern Papuans and other ISEA populations. These introgressed haplotypes are functionally enriched in genes related to lipid metabolism and immune response, suggesting local adaptation. The divergence times between these Denisovan lineages imply a deep and complex population structure in Pleistocene Asia.
