Our results indicate that low-level mtDNA heteroplasmy is not phenotypically silent but acts as a rheostat, fine-tuning cellular metabolism and stress responses, with profound implications for understanding aging and metabolic disease.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Low-Level Mitochondrial DNA Heteroplasmy Acts as a Rheostat for Metabolic and Transcriptional Reprogramming

text: This paper introduces a doubly robust, debiased machine learning framework for estimating average treatment effects (ATE) in high-dimensional observational studies. Standard machine learning estimators for nuisance functions—the propensity score and conditional outcome mean—exhibit regularization bias that contaminates the final ATE estimate. We overcome this by employing Neyman-orthogonal moment functions, which are insensitive to first-order perturbations in the nuisance parameter estimates. Our method utilizes cross-fitting, a sample-splitting technique that prevents overfitting and enables the use of arbitrary supervised learning algorithms (e.g., random forests, gradient boosting) for nuisance function estimation while preserving root-n consistency and asymptotic normality of the ATE estimator. We establish that under standard sparsity and regularity conditions, our estimator attains the semiparametric efficiency bound. Through extensive simulations and an application to a genomic dataset, we demonstrate the method's superior performance in terms of bias reduction and nominal confidence interval coverage compared to existing plug-in or inverse probability weighting estimators.
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Machine Learning for High-Dimensional Confounder Adjustment in Causal Inference

text: The computational burden of Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods has limited the application of Hierarchical Dirichlet Process (HDP) mixture models to massive datasets. We propose a scalable stochastic variational inference (SVI) algorithm for HDPs that optimizes a novel, tighter evidence lower bound (ELBO). Our approach leverages the stick-breaking construction of the Dirichlet process and introduces an auxiliary parameterization that facilitates efficient, closed-form updates within the SVI framework. This obviates the need for complex truncation schemes common in previous variational treatments. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis of the algorithm's convergence properties and derive posterior contraction rates for the variational approximation, demonstrating its asymptotic consistency. Empirical results on large-scale text corpora for topic modeling show that our method significantly outperforms existing Gibbs sampling and collapsed variational Bayesian methods in terms of both computational efficiency and predictive likelihood (perplexity), enabling Bayesian nonparametric analysis at an unprecedented scale.
subject: İstatistik
title: Scalable Variational Inference for Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Mixture Models

text: Topological Data Analysis (TDA), particularly persistent homology, has emerged as a powerful tool for characterizing the shape of data. However, its application has been largely descriptive due to a lack of inferential machinery. This work develops a rigorous statistical framework for hypothesis testing on persistence diagrams. We introduce a novel subsampling bootstrap procedure for constructing confidence regions for persistence diagrams, which respects their geometric structure. A test statistic based on the Wasserstein distance between the empirical diagram and a null distribution is formulated, allowing for formal inference on the underlying data-generating manifold's topology. We prove the asymptotic validity of our bootstrap confidence regions under mild regularity conditions on the data sampling process. The method's power is demonstrated in differentiating complex geometric structures, such as tori versus spheres, from noisy point cloud data, providing a crucial bridge between descriptive TDA and confirmatory statistical analysis.
subject: İstatistik
title: Statistically Rigorous Inference on Persistent Homology for Manifold Learning

text: We propose a novel statistical framework, Dynamic Functional Principal Component Analysis (DFPCA), for analyzing functional data collected longitudinally. Traditional FPCA methods are ill-suited for datasets where functional observations evolve over time for each subject. Our DFPCA model decomposes variation into three components: a cross-sectional mean function, subject-specific yet time-invariant functional principal components, and subject-specific but time-varying scores. The scores are modeled using a mixed-effects framework, capturing individual temporal trajectories. The eigenfunctions of the covariance operator are estimated using a two-dimensional penalized spline smoother on a pooled covariance surface. This integrated approach simultaneously characterizes both the dominant modes of functional variation and their temporal dynamics. We establish the asymptotic consistency of the estimated eigenfunctions and scores under mild conditions. The utility of DFPCA is illustrated by analyzing longitudinal brain imaging data, revealing new insights into developmental trajectories of neural connectivity.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Functional Principal Component Analysis for Longitudinally Observed Functional Data

text: The assumption of stationarity in conventional Gaussian Process (GP) models is often violated in complex spatio-temporal applications. We introduce a highly flexible and scalable non-stationary GP model leveraging deep kernel learning. The core idea is to warp the spatio-temporal input coordinates through a deep neural network, whose parameters are learned jointly with the GP hyperparameters. This non-linear transformation allows a standard stationary kernel (e.g., Matérn) in the warped space to induce a complex, non-stationary covariance structure in the original space. For computational tractability with large datasets, we embed this model within a stochastic variational inference framework using inducing points, which obviates the need for manipulating the full covariance matrix. We demonstrate on large-scale satellite remote sensing and climate datasets that our deep kernel learning approach provides superior predictive accuracy and more realistic uncertainty quantification compared to stationary GPs and other state-of-the-art non-stationary methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Non-Stationary Gaussian Process Models for Spatio-Temporal Data via Deep Kernel Learning

text: This paper addresses the critical problem of sparse linear regression in a high-dimensional setting where data are corrupted by both heavy-tailed error distributions and adversarial contamination. Standard estimators like the LASSO are notoriously fragile to such deviations. We propose a novel, computationally efficient procedure that integrates robust M-estimation with a coordinate-wise median-of-means approach. Our estimator, termed the Huber-MOM LASSO, can tolerate a significant fraction of arbitrary outliers while requiring only minimal moment conditions on the inlier distribution. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis, deriving non-asymptotic oracle inequalities that match, up to logarithmic factors, the optimal rates for sub-Gaussian designs, thereby establishing its statistical robustness and efficiency. Simulation studies and an application to a cancer genomics dataset with known sample contamination issues confirm the superior performance of our method over existing robust high-dimensional regression techniques.
subject: İstatistik
title: A Robust Penalized Estimator for High-Dimensional Linear Models with Heavy-Tailed and Adversarially Contaminated Data

text: In survival analysis with competing risks, directly modeling the covariate effects on the cumulative incidence function (CIF) offers a clinically interpretable alternative to cause-specific or subdistribution hazard models. We propose a novel semiparametric additive model for the CIF, which posits that covariates additively influence the cumulative incidence probability over time. This formulation avoids the proportionality assumption and leads to straightforward interpretations of covariate effects. To handle high-dimensional settings, we develop a penalized estimation procedure using a combined L1 and L2 (elastic net) penalty, which performs simultaneous variable selection and coefficient estimation. An efficient iterative algorithm based on minorization-maximization is derived for computation. We establish the theoretical properties of our estimator, including selection consistency and the oracle property, under suitable regularity conditions. The method’s practical utility is showcased through an analysis of a large-scale clinical trial dataset, identifying key prognostic factors for specific failure types.
subject: İstatistik
title: Semiparametric Regression on Cumulative Incidence Functions with High-Dimensional Covariates

text: We develop a comprehensive Bayesian framework for modeling dynamic, multilayer networks, which are increasingly prevalent in social and biological sciences. Our model embeds nodes in a shared latent Euclidean space, where their positions evolve over time according to a vector autoregressive process, capturing temporal dependency. Crucially, the model incorporates layer-specific parameters and node-specific random effects to account for varying connectivity patterns across layers and inherent node-level heterogeneity, respectively. This extends classical latent space models to a more realistic and flexible setting. Posterior inference is performed using a custom-designed Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm that integrates Gibbs sampling with efficient Metropolis-Hastings steps. Post-processing via Procrustes transformation resolves identifiability issues inherent in latent space models. We demonstrate the model's capacity to uncover evolving community structures and inter-layer dependencies through applications to a multi-year international trade network and a multi-modal brain connectivity study.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Latent Space Models for Dynamic Multilayer Networks with Node-Specific Heterogeneity

text: Optimizing experimental designs for complex non-linear models is a formidable challenge due to the computational intractability of maximizing expected utility functions. We present a novel, computationally efficient methodology for fully Bayesian optimal design. Our approach employs a sequential design strategy that adaptively selects design points to maximize the expected information gain. The core innovations are twofold: first, we use a Gaussian Process (GP) emulator as a surrogate for the computationally expensive model likelihood, drastically reducing the cost of utility estimation. Second, we approximate the intractable sequence of posterior distributions using Sequential Monte Carlo (SMC) methods, which are more robust than traditional MCMC in this adaptive context. This synergistic combination of GP emulation and SMC facilitates the rapid identification of highly informative designs. We illustrate the method's effectiveness on a challenging pharmacokinetic model, showing that our designs yield substantially lower posterior parameter uncertainty compared to conventional design criteria.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Optimal Design for Non-Linear Models via Sequential Monte Carlo and Gaussian Process Emulation

text: Estimating causal effects when network interference is present—i.e., one unit's treatment affects another's outcome—violates the stable unit treatment value assumption (SUTVA) and poses significant methodological challenges. We propose a general framework for estimating direct and spillover effects under arbitrary interference structures. We introduce a flexible hierarchical exposure mapping that parameterizes a unit's exposure as a function of treatment assignments within multi-level network neighborhoods. Based on this mapping, we construct a doubly robust estimator for the average potential outcomes under different exposure conditions. This estimator uses two nuisance models: a generalized propensity score model for the exposure and a regression model for the outcome. It remains consistent if either model is correctly specified. We prove the estimator's asymptotic normality and demonstrate through simulations its superior robustness to model misspecification compared to IPW or outcome-regression estimators alone. The framework is applied to re-evaluate a networked public health intervention.
subject: İstatistik
title: Doubly Robust Estimation of Causal Effects under Network Interference using Hierarchical Exposure Models

text: Conventional computational music theory, largely predicated on equal-tempered pitch-class sets, lacks robust methodologies for analyzing microtonal harmony. This paper introduces a novel framework that bridges this gap by establishing an isomorphism between the spectral representation of microtonal sonorities and abstract harmonic spaces. Utilizing a high-resolution Constant-Q Transform (CQT), we map audio signals into a point-cloud representation within a multi-dimensional feature space. We then employ techniques from topological data analysis, specifically persistent homology, to identify stable geometric structures within these point clouds that are invariant under different tuning systems. Applied to the works of Xenakis, Haas, and other microtonal composers, our method algorithmically reveals latent harmonic objects and transformational networks that elude traditional analysis. This spectrally-grounded approach provides a generalized and empirically verifiable paradigm for harmonic analysis, capable of quantitatively exploring the complex sonic architectures of post-tonal and microtonal music directly from the audio signal.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectral Isomorphism and the Computational Analysis of Microtonal Harmonic Structures

text: The automated generation of Schenkerian analyses from audio signals represents a grand challenge in computational musicology, requiring the inference of deep, multi-level tonal structure. We propose a novel deep learning architecture, the Hierarchical Schenkerian Network (HS-Net), to tackle this problem. The model operates on a multi-scale chromagram derived from polyphonic audio and employs a series of nested Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) units to explicitly model the foreground, middleground, and background levels of the tonal hierarchy. Preceded by a harmonic-percussive source separation front-end to enhance tonal clarity, the network is trained end-to-end on a newly created corpus of expert-annotated Bach chorales. Our system significantly outperforms existing rule-based and monolithic machine learning approaches in identifying fundamental lines (Urlinien) and key prolongational spans. The results demonstrate a substantial step towards computational systems capable of deep music-theoretic reasoning directly from an acoustic input, moving beyond surface-level feature extraction.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hierarchical Recurrent Neural Network for Automated Schenkerian Analysis from Polyphonic Audio

text: The relationship between timbre and harmonic function, while central to the art of orchestration, has remained largely unquantified. This research employs a deep co-embedding model to learn a shared latent space for timbral and harmonic information from a large corpus of 19th-century orchestral music. Timbral features, represented by Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs), and symbolic harmonic labels are projected into a common high-dimensional vector space where proximity indicates semantic relatedness. By training the network to minimize a contrastive loss function, we enforce a mapping where specific instrumental combinations become associated with particular harmonic functions. Visualization of the latent space via t-SNE reveals distinct, interpretable clusters showing, for example, a strong affinity between brass textures and dominant prolongations. This methodology provides robust empirical evidence for the syntactical role of timbre and offers a new computational framework for analyzing the perceptual fusion of orchestral color and harmonic structure.
subject: Müzik
title: Timbral Semantics and Harmonic Function: A Corpus-Based Study of Orchestral Music Using Deep Co-embedding

text: Existing computational models of metric complexity often rely on symbolic data, failing to capture the perceptual nuances inherent in audio recordings. We introduce a novel, psychoacoustically-informed model that operates directly on an audio-derived Onset Detection Function (ODF). The model comprises two components: a metrical clarity index and a rhythmic density index. Metrical clarity is quantified using the peak magnitude of a modified autocorrelation function of the ODF, which reflects the periodicity and stability of the underlying pulse. Concurrently, rhythmic density and syncopation are measured via the spectral entropy of the ODF’s short-term Fourier transform, capturing the predictability of rhythmic events. When evaluated against human listener ratings on a diverse corpus of musical stimuli, our composite model demonstrates a significantly higher correlation (r > 0.85) than prominent symbolic models. This framework provides a more perceptually valid and ecologically robust tool for the analysis of rhythmic feel and complexity in performed music.
subject: Müzik
title: A Psychoacoustically-Grounded Computational Model of Metric Complexity via Autocorrelation and Spectral Entropy

text: The subtle interplay between a performer's physical gestures and expressive musical timing remains a critical but computationally elusive aspect of performance studies. This paper presents a cross-modal analysis framework to explicitly map pianist kinematics to agogic expression. We collected a dataset of synchronized, high-resolution motion capture data and fine-grained MIDI velocity and timing information from professional pianists. Using dimensionality reduction techniques, we construct two separate low-dimensional manifolds, one representing the gestural space (e.g., wrist velocity, torso rotation) and the other representing the musical expression space (e.g., micro-timing deviations, dynamic articulations). We then apply manifold alignment algorithms to learn a non-linear mapping between these two spaces. Our results show that this learned mapping can predict agogic timing with remarkable accuracy from kinematic data alone, revealing the biomechanical correlates of expressive devices like rubato. This quantifies the embodiment of musical expression and informs more realistic performance synthesis models.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Analysis of Pianist Kinematics and Agogic Timing Using Manifold Alignment

text: The computational analysis of polyphonic voice-leading is fraught with combinatorial complexity, particularly in texturally dense music. We propose a novel paradigm based on graph theory that reframes voice-leading analysis as a search for optimal Hamiltonian paths. For a given sequence of chords, we construct a multipartite graph where nodes represent notes and edges represent potential voice-leading connections. Edges are weighted according to a multi-faceted cost function incorporating principles of pitch proximity, registral coherence, and avoidance of forbidden parallels. An optimal voice-leading solution for the entire passage is then defined as the set of disjoint paths that visit each note exactly once, analogous to a Hamiltonian path problem. We present an efficient approximation algorithm based on integer linear programming to solve this NP-hard problem. Applied to a corpus of Josquin's motets, our method successfully disambiguates complex contrapuntal textures and identifies voice-leading structures that correspond closely with established music-theoretic interpretations.
subject: Müzik
title: Graph-Theoretic Representations of Polyphonic Voice-Leading: A Hamiltonian Path Approach to Contrapuntal Analysis

text: Standard unsupervised audio source separation methods, such as Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF), often fail to produce musically meaningful results because they lack domain-specific knowledge. We introduce a music-theoretically informed NMF variant that incorporates principles from neo-Riemannian theory to guide the separation process. Our model, NR-NMF, constrains the temporal activation functions of harmonic dictionary atoms based on a probabilistic transition matrix. This matrix assigns higher probabilities to chord progressions that are parsimonious in neo-Riemannian tonal space (i.e., connected by P, L, or R transformations). The optimization objective is a modified Kullback-Leibler divergence that penalizes harmonically incoherent temporal activations. When applied to the task of separating piano from orchestra in Romantic concerti, NR-NMF achieves a statistically significant improvement in Signal-to-Distortion Ratio (SDR) over conventional NMF and other semi-supervised approaches, demonstrating the efficacy of integrating high-level musical structure into low-level signal processing frameworks.
subject: Müzik
title: Neo-Riemannian-Guided Non-Negative Matrix Factorization for Harmonic Source Separation

text: Expressive intonation is a cornerstone of artistic performance in chamber music, yet its systematic quantification in polyphonic contexts presents a formidable signal processing challenge. This study utilizes a state-of-the-art deep learning model for multi-pitch estimation to extract high-resolution fundamental frequency (F0) contours for each instrument from a corpus of professional string quartet recordings. Following the demodulation of vibrato, we calculate the cent deviation of each note from its equal-tempered theoretical target. These deviations are then analyzed using a linear mixed-effects model to assess the influence of harmonic context, melodic function (e.g., leading-tone), and performer-specific tendencies. The statistical analysis reveals robust patterns of expressive tuning, including systematically sharpened leading tones and compressed minor thirds, that are consistent across performers. This work provides a rigorous methodology for the empirical analysis of ensemble intonation strategies and offers quantitative insights into the micro-tonal subtleties of musical expression.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Expressive Intonation in String Quartet Performance: A Multi-Pitch Estimation and Statistical Modeling Approach

text: Automated analysis of musical form requires the integration of multiple, often conflicting, cues across different temporal scales. We propose a hierarchical Bayesian framework that infers formal structure by synthesizing evidence from harmonic, timbral, and rhythmic domains. At the lowest level, novelty functions are computed from chroma features, MFCCs, and a rhythmic onset pattern, respectively, identifying moments of significant change within each feature stream. These novelty curves serve as observations for a higher-level switching hidden Markov model (HMM), where the hidden states correspond to 'segment' or 'boundary'. The model learns the conditional probabilities of a structural boundary given concurrent novelty peaks, effectively performing multimodal data fusion. Priors can be incorporated to favor common formal archetypes. Evaluated on the SALAMI dataset, our integrative model significantly outperforms single-modality approaches on both boundary detection (F-measure) and segment clustering (Adjusted Rand Index), demonstrating its robustness and superior modeling capacity.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hierarchical Bayesian Framework for Musical Form Analysis Integrating Harmonic, Timbral, and Rhythmic Novelty

text: The perceptual phenomenon of 'groove' is notoriously difficult to quantify, with research often focusing on microtiming deviations. We propose an alternative hypothesis: that groove perception is highly correlated with the degree of phase synchrony between the infrasonic (<20 Hz) amplitude envelopes of spectrally distinct instrumental layers. Using a continuous wavelet transform, we decompose audio signals into bass, chordal, and percussive frequency bands. We then compute a time-varying phase synchrony index based on the cross-correlation of these band-limited amplitude envelopes. An analysis of a corpus of rhythms with human-annotated groove ratings reveals a strong positive correlation between our synchrony index and perceived groove. These findings are corroborated by an electroencephalography (EEG) experiment showing that high-groove stimuli elicit significantly stronger phase-locking of low-frequency neural oscillations in listeners. This research provides a new theoretical and quantitative framework for understanding rhythmic feel, shifting the focus from event timing to the interaction of continuous energy contours.
subject: Müzik
title: The Role of Infrasonic Phase Synchrony in the Perception of Rhythmic Groove

text: We propose a novel scheme for achieving fault-tolerant quantum computation by dynamically suppressing decoherence in a topological quantum computer based on Fibonacci anyons. Our methodology utilizes Floquet engineering, applying a periodic drive to the system Hamiltonian to manipulate the effective interactions and energy landscape. By solving the time-dependent Schrödinger equation for the braiding of Ising anyons, which constitute a universal gate set, we demonstrate that carefully tuned drive parameters can create a dynamically stabilized subspace resilient to quasiparticle poisoning and non-adiabatic errors. The analysis, performed using a combination of Magnus expansion and numerical simulations on a matrix product state representation, reveals a significant reduction in logical error rates, scaling polynomially with the driving frequency. This approach circumvents the stringent material requirements for a large topological gap, providing a more viable pathway toward scalable topological quantum computation by leveraging temporal control to engineer robust quantum information processing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Dynamical Error Suppression in a Fibonacci Anyon-Based Topological Quantum Computer via Floquet Engineering

text: The application of the AdS/CFT correspondence to cosmological spacetimes remains a profound challenge. This paper investigates the nature of holographic entanglement entropy in a de Sitter (dS) background. We analyze the limitations of the standard Ryu-Takayanagi formula in a non-asymptotically AdS context and propose a modified covariant prescription based on extremal surfaces in the dS bulk, consistent with the observer-dependent nature of the cosmological horizon. Using this formulation, we calculate the entanglement entropy for various subregions of the boundary conformal field theory (CFT) and explore its connection to the dS entropy. Furthermore, we demonstrate how these entropy calculations constrain the reconstruction of the bulk geometry from boundary CFT correlators via the principle of subregion-subregion duality. Our findings suggest that the entanglement structure of the boundary state encodes critical information about the bulk geometry, providing a potential resolution to the information paradox within a holographic description of de Sitter space.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Bulk Reconstruction in de Sitter Spacetime

text: Verification of non-Abelian quasiparticle statistics is a cornerstone for topological quantum computation. We present a detailed theoretical proposal for an experiment to unambiguously detect the non-Abelian nature of the Moore-Read Pfaffian state, a leading candidate for the ν=5/2 fractional quantum Hall effect. Our proposed device is a Fabry-Pérot interferometer realized in a dual-gated, hexagonal boron nitride-encapsulated graphene heterostructure. We perform a comprehensive calculation of the transport characteristics, focusing on the Aharonov-Bohm interference pattern of charge e/4 quasiparticles. By analyzing the dependence of the conductance oscillations on the magnetic field and gate voltage, we show that the braiding of non-Abelian quasiparticles introduces a distinctive π-phase shift in the interference pattern that is absent for Abelian alternatives. This signature, robust against moderate thermal broadening and decoherence, provides a definitive experimental protocol for confirming the Pfaffian topological order and its exotic excitations.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Non-Abelian Statistics of the Moore-Read Pfaffian State using Interferometric Signatures in a Graphene Heterostructure

text: We present a high-precision, non-perturbative calculation of the renormalization constants for local and non-local quark bilinear operators within the framework of lattice Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). The computation employs the RI/MOM (Regularization Independent/Momentum Subtraction) scheme on a suite of N_f=2+1+1 twisted mass fermion ensembles, spanning multiple lattice spacings and pion masses. A key feature of our work is the meticulous control of systematic uncertainties, including discretization effects addressed through continuum extrapolation and non-perturbative chiral corrections. Our results for the vector, axial-vector, scalar, and tensor current renormalization constants provide crucial inputs for phenomenological studies, enabling the precise determination of fundamental Standard Model parameters from hadronic matrix elements. This significantly reduces theoretical uncertainties in calculations of quark masses, the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix elements, and nucleon structure functions, thereby strengthening the predictive power of lattice QCD.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Perturbative Renormalization of Quark Bilinears in Lattice QCD with Wilson-Clover Fermions

text: We investigate the continuous evolution of an open quantum system under weak, time-resolved measurement, bridging the conceptual gap between projective von Neumann measurements and unitary Schrödinger evolution. By applying the formalism of Aharonov's weak values within a stochastic master equation framework, we reconstruct the conditional evolution, or 'quantum trajectory,' of a superconducting transmon qubit. Our analysis demonstrates that post-selecting on a specific final measurement outcome reveals anomalous trajectory statistics and average pointer shifts that defy classical intuition but are rigorously predicted by quantum theory. This protocol allows for the direct observation of the system's state evolution conditioned on its past and future. The results provide a powerful experimental tool for probing the foundations of quantum measurement and have significant implications for quantum feedback control, state estimation, and precision metrology beyond the standard quantum limit.
subject: Kuantum
title: Characterizing Quantum Trajectories via Continuous Weak Measurement and Post-Selection

text: The stability of the many-body localized (MBL) phase against thermal fluctuations remains a critical open question. We investigate this issue by studying the dynamics of a one-dimensional disordered Heisenberg spin chain coupled to a finite-sized thermal inclusion. Utilizing large-scale numerical simulations based on the time-dependent variational principle (TDVP) for matrix product states (MPS), we track the propagation of entanglement and energy from the thermal region into the MBL bulk. Our simulations reveal a sharp delocalization transition driven by an 'avalanche' instability. Above a critical coupling strength, the thermal region triggers a cascade of resonant transitions that ergodically melts the MBL phase, with entanglement spreading logarithmically in time. We map out the phase diagram as a function of disorder strength and system-bath coupling, providing compelling numerical evidence that the MBL phase is unstable in the thermodynamic limit against coupling to a thermal bath, even if infinitesimally small.
subject: Kuantum
title: Avalanche-Induced Delocalization in a Disordered Many-Body System: A Time-Dependent Variational Principle Study with Matrix Product States

text: We theoretically explore the ground-state properties and excitation spectrum of a quantum emitter operating in the ultrastrong coupling regime with a multi-mode photonic crystal cavity. By employing a non-perturbative, numerically exact diagonalization of the generalized quantum Rabi Hamiltonian, our analysis reveals a quantum phase transition characterized by the spontaneous breaking of the system's Z_2 (parity) symmetry. Beyond a critical coupling strength, the ground state becomes twofold degenerate, manifesting as a Schrödinger cat state—a macroscopic superposition of coherent photonic fields with opposite phases. This broken-symmetry phase is accompanied by emergent chirality in the photonic field distribution. We demonstrate that the second-order photon correlation function g^(2)(0) and the spectrum of the emitted field serve as unambiguous experimental signatures of this phase transition. This work opens new avenues for engineering non-classical states of light and matter with applications in quantum metrology and information processing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Parity-Symmetry Breaking and Emergent Chirality in a Multi-Mode Ultrastrong Coupling Cavity-QED System

text: We report on the design, commissioning, and initial results of a novel haloscope experiment searching for axion dark matter. The detector comprises a phased array of four coupled, high-Q superconducting radio-frequency cavities immersed within the 14 T bore of a solenoidal magnet. By coherently combining the signals from individual cavities and employing a quantum-limited Josephson parametric amplifier, our configuration significantly enhances the scan rate and sensitivity to the axion-photon coupling, g_{aγγ}. We present a new data analysis pipeline based on a Bayesian framework to search for a persistent, narrow-band power excess. The results from our initial data run, spanning the 0.8-1.2 μeV mass range (200-300 MHz), place the most stringent new limits on the existence of axions in this parameter space, excluding couplings down to 1.5 times the benchmark Kim-Shifman-Vainshtein-Zakharov (KSVZ) model sensitivity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing the Axion-Photon Coupling in the Sub-μeV Mass Range with a Superconducting Resonant Cavity Array

text: We analyze the thermodynamic performance of a quantum Otto cycle using a single qubit as the working substance, where the hot thermal reservoir is replaced by a squeezed thermal bath. Our model, formulated within the quantum master equation framework, demonstrates that the injected quantum coherence from the non-thermal reservoir can be harnessed to significantly boost the engine's power output and efficiency. We show that for specific parameter regimes of squeezing and thermal occupation, the engine's efficiency can surpass the standard Carnot limit defined by the effective temperatures of the two reservoirs, without any violation of the second law of thermodynamics. This supra-Carnot efficiency is attributed to the extraction of work from the non-passive, coherent component of the squeezed state. This highlights the potential of quantum reservoir engineering as a powerful resource for designing next-generation thermodynamic machines operating beyond classical constraints.
subject: Kuantum
title: Enhanced Efficiency of a Quantum Otto Engine via Coherence Injection from a Squeezed Thermal Reservoir

text: This work explores the phenomenon of entanglement harvesting, whereby two spatially separated, initially uncorrelated particle detectors can extract entanglement from the vacuum fluctuations of a quantum field. We extend this formalism from Minkowski space to curved spacetimes, focusing specifically on the Schwarzschild metric describing a non-rotating black hole. Employing the Unruh-DeWitt detector model and treating the light-matter interaction perturbatively, we compute the concurrence of the final two-detector state. Our results demonstrate that spacetime curvature profoundly modifies the entanglement harvesting protocol. The amount of harvested entanglement is a non-monotonic function of the detectors' proximity to the event horizon, revealing a complex interplay between vacuum correlations, gravitational redshift, and the thermal noise associated with Hawking radiation. This analysis establishes a theoretical framework for utilizing quantum entanglement as a non-local probe of spacetime geometry and its quantum-gravitational properties.
subject: Kuantum
title: Relativistic Entanglement Harvesting and Spacetime Curvature: A Unruh-DeWitt Detector Analysis

text: We investigate the non-perturbative corrections arising from Euclidean D-brane instantons in Calabi-Yau compactifications and their consequential impact on the primordial gravitational wave background. Our analysis, grounded in type IIB string theory, demonstrates that these corrections induce a scale-dependent modulation of the tensor-to-scalar ratio, *r*. This effect, distinct from standard single-field slow-roll inflation predictions, generates a unique, non-Gaussian signature in the B-mode polarization spectrum of the cosmic microwave background. We derive an explicit form for the bispectrum *f*<sub>NL</sub><sup>tensor</sup>, linking it directly to the geometric moduli of the compactification manifold. Utilizing a refined string gas cosmological model, we calculate the expected anisotropy power spectrum *C*<sub>l</sub><sup>BB</sup> and show that next-generation CMB observatories, such as CMB-S4 and LiteBIRD, possess the requisite sensitivity to probe these string-theoretic imprints, potentially providing the first observational evidence for extra dimensions and the quantum nature of gravity. This framework offers a falsifiable link between abstract string theory constructs and precision cosmological data.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Perturbative Effects of Calabi-Yau Compactifications on Primordial Gravitational Wave Anisotropies

text: We present a theoretical study of a spin-1/2 Heisenberg antiferromagnet on a Kagome lattice, incorporating Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interactions and an external magnetic field. By employing large-scale density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) simulations on cylindrical geometries, we map out the system's quantum phase diagram. We identify a robust zero-field quantum spin liquid phase characterized by a topological entanglement entropy consistent with a Z₂ state. Upon application of a sufficiently strong magnetic field, we observe a field-induced quantum phase transition into a chiral spin state with a non-zero scalar spin chirality. This emergent phase is a topological skyrmion crystal, hallmarked by a quantized topological Chern number, which we compute directly from the ground-state wavefunction. Our findings suggest that frustrated quantum magnets under external fields provide a fertile platform for realizing and manipulating exotic topological states of matter, with direct implications for spintronics and fault-tolerant quantum computation.
subject: Fizik
title: Topological Phase Transitions in a Frustrated Kagome Lattice Antiferromagnet under High Magnetic Fields

text: The paradigm of Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND) is subjected to a rigorous test using gravitational lensing time delays from six quadruply-imaged quasar systems. We perform a detailed lens mass modeling, contrasting the predictions of standard ΛCDM, incorporating a Navarro-Frenk-White (NFW) dark matter halo, with those of MOND, including the crucial external field effect (EFE) from nearby large-scale structures. Our analysis reveals a significant tension. MOND models, even with the EFE, consistently fail to reproduce the observed time delays and flux ratios simultaneously without invoking unphysical stellar mass-to-light ratios or violating constraints from stellar kinematics. The Bayesian evidence overwhelmingly disfavors the MOND hypothesis relative to ΛCDM for our sample, with a Bayes factor exceeding 10⁴. These results challenge the viability of MOND as a complete alternative to dark matter on galactic and group scales, highlighting the diagnostic power of time-delay cosmography for fundamental physics.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraining Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND) with Gravitational Lensing Time Delays from Quasar Systems

text: We report on the generation and controlled decoherence of a macroscopic quantum superposition state involving two spatially separated Bose-Einstein Condensates (BECs), each containing approximately 10⁴ Rubidium-87 atoms. Utilizing a Ramsey-type interferometry sequence with state-dependent microwave potentials, we create a Schrödinger's cat-like state described by the superposition |*N*<sub>L</sub>, 0<sub>R</sub>⟩ + *e*<sup>*iφ*</sup>|0<sub>L</sub>, *N*<sub>R</sub>⟩. The subsequent decay of quantum coherence is monitored via interference fringe visibility. We find the decoherence rate scales quadratically with the effective separation of the condensates, a hallmark of environmentally-induced dephasing. Our experimental results are in excellent agreement with a Caldeira-Leggett model that incorporates phononic coupling to the thermal background. This work probes the quantum-to-classical boundary at an unprecedented mass and particle-number scale and establishes a robust platform for testing objective collapse models and quantum gravity-induced decoherence mechanisms.
subject: Fizik
title: Decoherence and the Quantum-to-Classical Transition in a Macroscopic Superposition of Bose-Einstein Condensates

text: We present a novel search for proton decay via the channel *p* → *K*⁺ν̄, a hallmark prediction of minimal supersymmetric SU(5) Grand Unified Theories (GUTs). This analysis utilizes 270 kton·years of exposure from the Super-Kamiokande IV detector. Our methodology introduces a sophisticated multivariate likelihood estimator, incorporating Cherenkov ring topology, particle identification variables, and the kinematics of the prompt de-excitation gamma-ray from the remnant nucleus. This technique significantly improves signal-to-background discrimination over previous counting-based analyses, particularly against the dominant atmospheric neutrino background. No significant excess of events is observed, leading to a new lower limit on the partial lifetime of the proton of τ(*p* → *K*⁺ν̄) > 8.2 × 10³³ years at 90% confidence level. This result places stringent constraints on the parameter space of minimal SUSY GUTs and other models of baryon number violation, pushing the relevant unification energy scale above 10¹⁶ GeV.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Supersymmetric Grand Unification Theories through Proton Decay Signatures in Large-Volume Neutrino Detectors

text: We develop a continuum field theory for dense systems of self-propelled particles with alignment interactions, deriving hydrodynamic equations of motion from a microscopic Vicsek-style model. Through a dynamic renormalization group analysis, we demonstrate that the system exhibits a transition from a disordered, gas-like phase to an ordered, flocking phase. Crucially, the long-wavelength behavior of the ordered phase is governed by a new non-equilibrium fixed point, distinct from previously known universality classes. We compute the critical exponents associated with this transition, finding that the system's fluctuations are described by anisotropic scaling laws that fundamentally differ from those of the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang (KPZ) equation or equilibrium models. Our results establish the existence of a new dynamic universality class for active matter, suggesting that collective motion in systems far from thermal equilibrium generates emergent symmetries and conservation laws not present in their equilibrium counterparts.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergence of Universal Scaling Laws in Active Matter Systems Far from Thermal Equilibrium

text: The final ringdown phase of a binary black hole merger is predicted by general relativity to be a superposition of damped sinusoids, characteristic of a Kerr black hole. We investigate the possibility of gravitational wave 'echoes'—faint, periodic, late-time pulses following the main ringdown signal—as a definitive signature of physics beyond the classical event horizon. We develop a robust Bayesian analysis pipeline to search for these echoes in public data from the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA collaboration. By modeling the echoes as a train of wavelets with a characteristic time delay, we analyze the post-merger data of GW150914 and subsequent high-signal-to-noise events. While we find no statistically significant evidence for echoes, we establish stringent upper limits on their amplitude as a function of their time delay and damping factor. These limits constrain a broad class of exotic compact object (ECO) models, including gravastars and firewall paradigms, pushing quantum gravity effects to higher energy scales.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Wave Echoes as Probes of Exotic Compact Object Geometries and Quantum Black Hole Horizons

text: We demonstrate the quantum simulation of a U(1) lattice gauge theory using a one-dimensional array of individual ⁸⁷Rb atoms trapped in optical tweezers. Gauge fields are encoded in the atomic hyperfine states, while matter fields are represented by the motional states of the atoms. By applying tailored global laser fields, we engineer the required gauge-invariant Hamiltonian and coherently control the real-time dynamics following a quantum quench. We directly observe fundamental phenomena such as particle-antiparticle pair production and string breaking, monitoring the evolution of local gauge constraints by measuring site-resolved atomic populations. The system fidelity is validated by comparing the experimental dynamics with exact diagonalization results for small system sizes. This work represents a significant step towards realizing scalable quantum simulators for tackling intractable problems in high-energy physics, such as the confinement mechanism in quantum chromodynamics, on a programmable quantum hardware platform.
subject: Fizik
title: Coherent Control of Rydberg Atom Arrays for Quantum Simulation of Lattice Gauge Theories

text: The transition to turbulence in magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) Taylor-Couette flow is investigated via three-dimensional direct numerical simulations. We analyze the flow's Lagrangian transport topology by computing the finite-time Lyapunov exponent (FTLE) field, which reveals the underlying Lagrangian coherent structures (LCSs). Our results show that prior to the onset of turbulence, the primary axisymmetric Taylor vortices are delineated by robust LCSs that act as transport barriers. The transition is initiated by a secondary instability, driven by the magnetic field, which causes these barriers to fold and stretch, creating chaotic advection in localized regions. This process seeds turbulent spots that subsequently grow and fill the entire domain. A quantitative analysis demonstrates a direct correlation between the spatial average of the maximal FTLE and the growth rate of turbulent kinetic energy. This framework identifies the Lagrangian skeleton of the flow as the fundamental organizing principle governing the spatiotemporal intermittency of the subcritical transition to MHD turbulence.
subject: Fizik
title: Lagrangian Coherent Structures and the Onset of Turbulence in Magnetohydrodynamic Taylor-Couette Flow

text: We propose a first-principles polymer physics model to explain the large-scale architecture of the interphase cell nucleus. Chromatin is modeled as a semi-flexible, self-avoiding polymer chain subject to confinement within the nucleus and topological constraints imposed by inter-chain entanglements. We introduce an active 'loop extrusion' process, mimicking the action of SMC protein complexes like cohesin, as a non-equilibrium driving force. Using large-scale Brownian dynamics simulations, we demonstrate that this minimal model, without sequence-specific interactions, is sufficient to reproduce key experimental observations from Hi-C maps. Specifically, our model correctly predicts the emergence of micro-phase separation into A/B compartments and the formation of topologically associating domains (TADs) whose size distribution matches experimental data. Our results suggest that the characteristic multi-scale organization of the genome arises primarily from a competition between entropic repulsion, polymer connectivity, and non-equilibrium motor activity, providing a unified physical framework for chromatin folding.
subject: Fizik
title: Entropic Forces and Chromatin Organization: A Polymer Physics Model of Interphase Nucleus Architecture

text: We present a theoretical framework for the controlled braiding of non-abelian Fibonacci anyons, predicted to exist in the ν=12/5 fractional quantum Hall state. Our model, based on a conformal field theory description coupled with time-dependent gate potentials, simulates the adiabatic transport of quasiparticles to realize unitary transformations on a topologically protected qubit subspace. We compute the resulting Berry matrices for elementary braid operations, demonstrating their correspondence with the Fibonacci representation of the braid group B_n. The analysis includes a rigorous treatment of decoherence sources, such as diabatic transitions and quasiparticle tunneling, to establish fidelity benchmarks for implementing a universal set of quantum gates. Our results indicate that quantum computation based on the Jones polynomial at a fifth root of unity is experimentally feasible with current mesoscopic device technology, provided stringent thermal and material purity conditions are met. This work provides a concrete roadmap for realizing fault-tolerant topological quantum computation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Braiding Dynamics of Fibonacci Anyons in a ν=12/5 Fractional Quantum Hall State

text: We investigate the phenomenon of many-body localization (MBL) in a periodically driven, disordered one-dimensional Heisenberg spin chain. Using large-scale exact diagonalization and time-evolving block decimation (TEBD) methods, we analyze the system's dynamics under a Floquet Hamiltonian. Our results demonstrate a clear transition from an ergodic thermal phase, which rapidly heats to infinite temperature as predicted by the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH), to a non-ergodic MBL phase. The MBL phase is characterized by the suppression of transport, the preservation of local memory, and, most critically, a slow logarithmic growth of bipartite entanglement entropy following a quantum quench. We identify the existence of local integrals of motion (LIOMs) that structure the localized phase and explain the breakdown of thermalization. This work elucidates the robust nature of MBL in out-of-equilibrium quantum systems, highlighting its potential for protecting quantum information in periodically driven platforms.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Growth and Ergodicity Breaking in a Disordered Floquet System

text: We introduce a novel decoding algorithm for the topological toric code based on deep reinforcement learning (RL), specifically optimized for spatially correlated and anisotropic Pauli noise models. Conventional decoders, such as minimum-weight perfect matching (MWPM), exhibit degraded performance when noise deviates from the idealized independent and identically distributed assumption. Our RL agent, structured as an actor-critic neural network, learns an optimal policy for applying correction operators directly from stabilizer measurement outcomes (syndromes). By training the agent on physically motivated noise configurations, we demonstrate a significant improvement in the logical error rate threshold, surpassing state-of-the-art decoders by up to 15% in high-anisotropy regimes. The decoder's policy implicitly learns the underlying noise correlations, adapting its corrective strategy without explicit modeling. This machine learning-based approach offers a scalable and adaptable pathway for achieving fault-tolerant quantum computation in realistic hardware environments.
subject: Kuantum
title: A Reinforcement Learning Approach to Decoding the Toric Code under Anisotropic Noise

text: This paper presents a calculation of the one-loop quantum corrections to the Hawking radiation spectrum for a non-minimally coupled, massive scalar field propagating on a Kerr-Newman black hole background. Utilizing the Euclidean path integral approach and heat kernel methods, we compute the effective action and derive the renormalized stress-energy tensor for the quantum field. The non-minimal coupling term, ξRφ², where R is the Ricci scalar, introduces significant modifications to the greybody factors and the particle emission rate. Our results show that for ξ > 1/6 (conformal coupling), the radiation flux is suppressed, effectively lowering the black hole's evaporation rate, while for ξ < 1/6, it is enhanced. These findings have profound implications for the late stages of black hole evaporation and the black hole information paradox, suggesting that interactions between quantum fields and spacetime curvature can fundamentally alter the semiclassical picture.
subject: Kuantum
title: One-Loop Corrections to Hawking Radiation from Non-Minimally Coupled Scalar Fields on a Kerr-Newman Background

text: We report the experimental realization of stationary quantum entanglement between the motional state of a silicon nitride nanobeam (f_m ≈ 10 MHz) and a propagating microwave field within a superconducting cavity. Operating in the resolved-sideband regime and employing a strong red-detuned pump tone, we induce ponderomotive squeezing of the mechanical motion below the zero-point fluctuation level. A second, weaker blue-detuned tone facilitates a two-mode squeezing interaction that generates robust entanglement. We quantify the entanglement using the logarithmic negativity, inferring a value of N = 0.41 ± 0.05 from the measured output field correlations, satisfying the inseparability criterion N > 0. This demonstration of deterministic, continuous-variable entanglement between disparate macroscopic and photonic degrees of freedom provides a fundamental resource for hybrid quantum networks and tests of quantum mechanics at macroscopic scales, pushing against the quantum-classical boundary.
subject: Kuantum
title: Ponderomotive Squeezing and Stationary Entanglement of a Nanomechanical Resonator with a Microwave Field

text: We investigate the pairing mechanism in high-temperature cuprate superconductors by solving the three-band Emery (copper-oxygen) model using a combination of dynamical mean-field theory (DMFT) and the fluctuation exchange (FLEX) approximation. Our calculations self-consistently determine the electronic Green's functions and the effective pairing interaction mediated by spin and charge fluctuations. We find that strong antiferromagnetic spin fluctuations, arising from the on-site Coulomb repulsion on the copper sites, generate a robust attractive potential in the d_x²-y² pairing channel. The calculated superconducting transition temperature (T_c) and the momentum-space structure of the superconducting gap show excellent quantitative agreement with experimental data from angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES). This work strongly supports the spin-fluctuation-mediated pairing paradigm, providing a microscopic, material-specific explanation for the origin of high-T_c superconductivity without invoking exotic mechanisms, and elucidates the interplay between magnetism and unconventional superconductivity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergence of d-wave Pairing from Antiferromagnetic Fluctuations in a Three-Band Emery Model for Cuprates

text: We derive new, computationally tractable upper bounds on the quantum capacity of channels exhibiting temporal correlations, a critical challenge in quantum communication. Focusing on a model of a qubit channel subject to Pauli errors with Markovian memory, we formulate the problem of calculating the single-letter coherent information, maximized over an n-extension of the channel, as a series of semi-definite programs (SDPs). By leveraging the block-diagonal structure of the Choi-Jamiołkowski representation of the correlated channel and applying novel convex relaxation techniques, we are able to tighten existing bounds for n>2. Our method demonstrates that memory effects can, paradoxically, increase the quantum capacity beyond the memoryless limit in certain parameter regimes. These results provide a powerful numerical tool for benchmarking the performance of quantum communication protocols and designing optimal error correction codes for realistic, non-Markovian noise environments found in solid-state and photonic systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Tightening Bounds on Quantum Channel Capacity for Correlated Pauli Channels via Convex Optimization

text: We propose a novel experimental test of local realism using entangled neutral kaon pairs produced at a φ-factory, such as the KLOE experiment. The unique feature of the K⁰-K⁰ bar system is its intrinsic connection to CP violation, which we exploit to formulate a new type of Bell inequality. This Bell-Clauser-Horne-Shimony-Holt (BCHSH) inequality is constructed from observables related to the time-dependent decay rates into semileptonic and pionic final states. The violation of the inequality is contingent on both quantum entanglement and the non-zero value of the CP-violating parameter ε_K. Our theoretical analysis shows that the predicted quantum mechanical violation is robust against typical sources of decoherence in this system, such as CPT violation and the ΔS = ΔQ rule violation. A successful experimental verification would not only constitute a loophole-free Bell test in a new physical domain but also demonstrate a profound link between fundamental symmetries and the non-local nature of quantum reality.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Local Realism with Entangled Neutral Kaon Systems and CP Violation

text: We present a quantum metrology protocol that achieves Heisenberg-limited precision in phase estimation despite the presence of Markovian dephasing. The scheme utilizes N-qubit Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) states as probes and integrates optimal quantum control (OQC) techniques to actively suppress decoherence during the sensing interval. By applying a sequence of rapid, high-fidelity control pulses derived from a gradient-ascent algorithm (GRAPE), we dynamically decouple the system from environmental noise, effectively creating a decoherence-free subspace. We calculate the quantum Fisher information (QFI) for the controlled system and show that it scales as N², the hallmark of the Heisenberg limit, whereas the unprotected QFI scales as N. The protocol's robustness is demonstrated through numerical simulations incorporating realistic control errors and photon loss. This work provides a practical path toward attaining the ultimate limits of quantum-enhanced measurement precision in noisy, intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices for applications in atomic clocks, magnetometry, and gravitational wave detection.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Phase Estimation in Decohering Environments using Dynamically Corrected GHZ States

text: The prevalence of cryptic species complexes poses a significant challenge to biodiversity assessment and evolutionary studies. Here, we employ a phylogenomic approach, utilizing sequence capture data targeting thousands of ultraconserved elements (UCEs), to dissect the species boundaries within the intertidal gastropod genus Nucella. Coalescent-based species delimitation analyses, including BPP and MSC-based methods, consistently identify multiple deeply divergent, yet morphologically cryptic, lineages previously subsumed under a single taxonomic entity. Calibrated phylogenetic inference places these divergence events in the mid-to-late Miocene, temporally correlating with major paleogeographic shifts in coastal habitats. Analyses of genomic admixture suggest that while historical gene flow occurred, contemporary reproductive isolation is nearly complete. These findings underscore the inadequacy of traditional morphological markers in this clade and highlight how ancient vicariant events, rather than recent ecological divergence, have been the primary drivers of speciation, necessitating a significant taxonomic revision with profound implications for conservation biogeography.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Resolution of Cryptic Lineages in the Nucella Gastropod Clade Reveals Pervasive Miocene-Era Vicariance

text: The physiological adaptations of Pleistocene megafauna to extreme environments remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of hemoglobin in the woolly mammoth (Mammuthus primigenius) using shotgun-sequenced paleogenomes from multiple Holarctic specimens. By identifying nonsynonymous substitutions unique to the mammoth lineage in both alpha- and beta-globin genes and performing ancestral sequence reconstruction, we identified key variants under positive selection. In vitro functional assays of resurrected recombinant hemoglobin proteins demonstrate a significant left-shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, indicating increased oxygen affinity, a crucial adaptation for cold tolerance and hypoxia. Strikingly, the identified substitutions are functionally analogous to those found in extant high-altitude adapted artiodactyls, providing a remarkable case of convergent molecular evolution. Our results illustrate how paleogenomics can directly elucidate the molecular underpinnings of physiological adaptation in extinct taxa, revealing the precise mechanisms of environmental selective pressures.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Reconstruction of Mammoth Hemoglobin Adaptation Reveals Convergent Evolution with High-Altitude Ruminants

text: The Red Queen hypothesis posits that antagonistic coevolution drives recurrent selective sweeps in host and pathogen populations. We tested this prediction by conducting temporal genomic analysis of an experimental coevolution study involving Arabidopsis thaliana and the bacterium Pseudomonas syringae. Leveraging time-series population sequencing, we tracked allele frequency trajectories of plant resistance (R) genes and pathogen effector proteins. We observed rapid, cyclical dynamics characterized by the fixation of novel R-gene alleles followed by counter-adaptive sweeps in corresponding effector loci, often leading to functional loss. This process is mediated by strong balancing selection at the metapopulation level, maintaining a diverse repertoire of recognition specificities. Our findings provide direct empirical evidence of a coevolutionary arms race at the molecular level, demonstrating that the tight genetic linkage between host receptors and pathogen effectors generates a highly dynamic selective landscape, driving rapid and perpetual adaptation.
subject: Evrim
title: Rapid Antagonistic Coevolution Driven by Effector-Receptor Dynamics in a Plant-Pathogen System

text: Major morphological innovations are often attributed to changes in the regulation of deeply conserved developmental genes. We investigated the role of cis-regulatory evolution in the vertebrate fin-to-limb transition by performing comparative ATAC-seq and Hi-C analysis on the developing appendages of zebrafish (Danio rerio), catshark (Scyliorhinus canicula), and mouse (Mus musculus). Our results reveal a profound reorganization of the 3D chromatin architecture around the HoxD gene cluster. While the genic content is highly conserved, the transition to tetrapods is correlated with the emergence of novel topologically associating domains (TADs) that bring distant enhancer elements into spatial proximity with posterior HoxD genes. This rewiring alters the spatiotemporal expression dynamics during limb bud development, enabling the patterning of autopod structures. This study demonstrates that the evolution of novel cis-regulatory landscapes, rather than the origin of new genes, was a principal mechanism driving a key macroevolutionary transition.
subject: Evrim
title: Cis-Regulatory Evolution of HoxD Cluster Architecture Underpins the Fin-to-Limb Transition

text: The predictability of evolution is limited by stochastic mutation events and the complex interplay of genetic interactions. We analyzed the genomic dynamics of replicate populations from a 50,000-generation experiment with Escherichia coli to dissect the role of epistasis in shaping adaptive pathways. By reconstructing mutational histories via deep sequencing, we found that early beneficial mutations often had negative epistatic interactions with later available mutations, effectively constraining evolutionary trajectories. This phenomenon of 'epistatic ratcheting' channels populations down specific genetic paths, from which escape is improbable. Furthermore, clonal interference between competing beneficial mutations exacerbates this effect by favoring mutations with high immediate fitness gains, even if they lead to evolutionary dead ends on the rugged fitness landscape. Our results empirically demonstrate that historical contingency, mediated by a rugged epistatic landscape, profoundly restricts evolutionary outcomes, challenging simplistic models of adaptation.
subject: Evrim
title: Epistatic Ratcheting and Clonal Interference Constrain Adaptive Trajectories in a Long-Term Experiment

text: The persistence of sexual reproduction, despite its inherent two-fold cost, is a central enigma in evolutionary biology. A leading hypothesis posits that recombination facilitates the efficient purging of deleterious mutations (i.e., Kondrashov's Hatchet). We developed sophisticated agent-based models to investigate how population structure influences this mechanism. Our simulations, incorporating varying levels of population viscosity and migration rates, reveal that the benefits of recombination are highly contingent on demographic context. In panmictic populations, recombination effectively reduces genetic load. However, in structured metapopulations with limited gene flow, Muller's Ratchet can operate efficiently within local demes, diminishing the relative advantage of sex. We show that a critical migration threshold exists, below which the benefits of recombination in breaking down negative genetic associations are nullified by spatial structuring. This finding suggests that the evolutionary maintenance of sex is not a universal constant but is instead dependent on the ecological and demographic landscape.
subject: Evrim
title: Stochastic Simulation Models Demonstrate Recombination's Efficacy in Purging Deleterious Mutations is Modulated by Population Structure

text: Explaining the vast heterogeneity in species richness across the tree of life is a fundamental goal of macroevolution. We investigated the drivers of angiosperm diversification using a newly synthesized, time-calibrated phylogeny of over 50,000 species. Applying state-dependent speciation and extinction (SSE) models within a Bayesian framework, we tested competing hypotheses regarding the influence of key innovations (e.g., flower symmetry, pollination syndromes) versus extrinsic abiotic factors. Our analyses, incorporating paleoclimatic proxy data, reveal that shifts in global temperature and atmospheric CO2 are the primary correlates of diversification rate variation. While key innovations show localized effects, their influence is dwarfed by climate-driven, clade-wide accelerations and decelerations in speciation and extinction rates. These results challenge the 'key innovation' paradigm, suggesting that for angiosperms, macroevolutionary dynamics are predominantly governed by ecological opportunity as dictated by the global abiotic environment, with intrinsic traits playing a secondary, facilitating role.
subject: Evrim
title: Diversification Rate Heterogeneity in Angiosperms is Tightly Linked to Paleoclimatic Shifts: A Bayesian Phylogenetic Comparative Analysis

text: The evolution of complex biological systems is shaped by the interconnectedness of their components. We explored the evolutionary constraints on the protein-protein interaction network (interactome) of Saccharomyces yeasts by integrating comparative genomics with high-throughput affinity purification-mass spectrometry data across multiple species. Our analysis of orthologous protein interactions reveals a highly conserved network core, with peripheral nodes showing significantly higher rates of gain and loss. The evolutionary rate of a protein is strongly and inversely correlated with its degree centrality (number of interaction partners) within the network. This pattern is consistent with the pleiotropic constraint hypothesis, whereby highly connected 'hub' proteins are under stronger purifying selection due to their involvement in multiple biological processes. These findings illustrate how systems-level properties, specifically network topology, impose fundamental constraints on molecular evolution, preserving the functional integrity of core cellular machinery over millions of years.
subject: Evrim
title: Evolution of the Yeast Interactome Reveals Pleiotropic Constraints on Hub Protein Diversification

text: Urbanization creates novel selective pressures that can drive rapid evolutionary change. To investigate the genomic basis of adaptation to urban environments, we performed pooled whole-genome sequencing (Pool-Seq) of Peromyscus leucopus populations from multiple urban-rural transects across North America. By applying FST outlier analyses and environmental association methods, we identified numerous genomic regions exhibiting signatures of parallel selection in independent urban populations. Candidate genes within these regions are significantly enriched for functions related to xenobiotic metabolism, immune response, and lipid biosynthesis, suggesting convergent adaptation to anthropogenic pollutants, novel pathogens, and modified diets. These results provide strong evidence for replicated, rapid adaptation at the molecular level, demonstrating that urban landscapes act as powerful and predictable agents of selection. Our study highlights how contemporary evolution can be dissected in situ, revealing the genetic architecture of adaptation to human-induced environmental change.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Parallel Adaptation to Urban Environments in the White-footed Mouse (Peromyscus leucopus)

text: The evolution of complex societies with sterile worker castes represents a major evolutionary transition. We investigated the molecular basis of caste differentiation in the ant Pheidole morrisi using an integrated transcriptomic and epigenomic approach. RNA-sequencing and whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) of queens, minor workers, and major workers (soldiers) revealed distinct, caste-specific molecular profiles. Thousands of genes exhibited differential expression, yet few were taxonomically novel, supporting the 'reproductive ground plan' hypothesis, which posits that social pathways evolve via the co-option and rewiring of ancestral solitary behaviors. We found that differential DNA methylation, particularly in promoter regions of developmental and metabolic genes, is strongly associated with caste-specific gene expression. This indicates a key role for epigenetic regulation in establishing and maintaining caste phenotypes from a shared genome, providing a mechanistic link between genotype and the complex social phenotype that defines eusociality.
subject: Evrim
title: Subcaste-Specific Gene Expression and Epigenetic Modifications Underpin the Division of Labor in an Eusocial Hymenopteran

text: This paper introduces a novel graph-theoretic framework for the computational analysis of harmonic progressions across multiple tuning systems. We model pitch-class sets as vertices in a weighted, directed graph, where edge weights are derived from a composite function of voice-leading parsimony and psychoacoustic consonance metrics. By representing musical excerpts as paths within this multi-scalar graph, we employ Dijkstra's algorithm and Hamiltonian path-finding to identify structurally significant tonal trajectories and modulatory pivots. The methodology extends beyond conventional neo-Riemannian or diatonic spaces, accommodating microtonal and xenharmonic structures by dynamically generating the graph's topology from a given scale's interval vector. We validate our model against a corpus of late-Romantic and 20th-century compositions, demonstrating its superior explanatory power in modeling ambiguous or non-functional harmony compared to traditional Roman numeral or transformational analyses. The results provide a generalized computational tool for exploring complex tonal syntax and inter-stylistic harmonic relationships.
subject: Müzik
title: A Graph-Theoretic Framework for Multi-Scalar Harmonic Analysis and Voice Leading Parsimony

text: Automated Schenkerian analysis remains a formidable challenge in computational musicology. This research proposes a novel approach using a Bayesian inference framework built upon Probabilistic Context-Free Grammars (PCFGs). We formalize Schenkerian theory as a set of recursive grammatical rules where terminal symbols correspond to surface-level musical events and non-terminal symbols represent abstract prolongational and contrapuntal structures. Given a symbolic musical surface, our model utilizes a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm, specifically Gibbs sampling, to efficiently explore the posterior distribution of possible analytic derivations. This probabilistic approach inherently manages analytical ambiguity by yielding a distribution of plausible readings rather than a single deterministic output. The model is trained and evaluated on a hand-annotated corpus of Bach chorales and Mozart piano sonatas, demonstrating its capacity to generate analyses that exhibit high concordance with expert human interpretations, particularly in identifying the fundamental line (Urlinie) and bass arpeggiation (Bassbrechung).
subject: Müzik
title: Bayesian Inference of Schenkerian Structure via Probabilistic Context-Free Grammars

text: This study presents a novel methodology for audio structural segmentation that achieves invariance to instrumentation and timbral characteristics. We employ a convolutional autoencoder (CAE) architecture, trained adversarially to reconstruct chromagram features while simultaneously being unable to classify the instrument source from its latent space representation. This process forces the latent embedding to prioritize harmonic and rhythmic content over timbral information. Structural boundary detection is then performed by applying a kernel-based novelty function to the time-series of these timbre-invariant latent vectors. Evaluated on a diverse dataset including orchestral works, jazz improvisations, and electronic music, our system significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, especially on challenging tasks such as identifying formal sections across different arrangements or cover versions of the same piece. The findings suggest that disentangling timbre from pitch and temporal structure is a critical step towards robust, musically-meaningful machine listening and music information retrieval systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Timbre-Invariant Structural Segmentation using Adversarially Trained Convolutional Autoencoders

text: We explore the application of Topological Data Analysis (TDA) for the unsupervised discovery and classification of musical form. By representing a musical piece as a high-dimensional point cloud derived from Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs) and chroma features, we utilize persistent homology to extract robust topological features at multiple scales. These features, captured in persistence diagrams and barcodes, quantify the lifespan of topological attributes like connected components and loops, which correspond to recurring motifs and developmental sections. We then employ a kernel-based machine learning model on the space of persistence diagrams to cluster a large, unannotated corpus of Western classical music. The resulting clusters demonstrate a strong correlation with canonical forms (e.g., sonata, rondo, theme and variations), revealing emergent structural archetypes without prior training. This TDA-based approach provides a powerful, representation-invariant lens for analyzing musical architecture, transcending the limitations of conventional sequence-matching algorithms.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Data Analysis for Unsupervised Classification of Musical Form

text: This paper posits a computational model of meter perception grounded in the theory of predictive coding and hierarchical Bayesian inference. The model, implemented as a hierarchical recurrent neural network, continuously attempts to predict future auditory events based on an internal generative model of rhythmic structure. Prediction errors propagate up the hierarchy, adjusting the model's internal representation of beat, tactus, and hypermetrical levels to minimize future surprise. This process allows for the dynamic, online inference of a metrical grid from a sequence of event onsets without recourse to predefined templates or explicit rules. We test the model's behavior on rhythmically complex and ambiguous stimuli, including syncopated patterns and polymetric textures. The model's inferred metrical structures and its reported 'surprise' at rhythmically unexpected events show strong correlation with human listener judgments, offering a neurally plausible account of how stable metrical percepts emerge from a continuous sensory stream.
subject: Müzik
title: A Predictive Coding Model of Emergent Metrical Hierarchy Perception

text: We introduce a novel semi-supervised Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) algorithm for automated polyphonic music transcription. Our approach incorporates musically-informed priors into the factorization process to improve source separation and pitch estimation accuracy. Specifically, we enforce a temporal prior based on an explicit note event model (attack-sustain-decay) and a harmonic prior that favors spectrally consonant pitch combinations, derived from a pre-trained probabilistic model of tonal harmony. The factorization is optimized via a multiplicative update rule algorithm that integrates these constraints. The system decomposes a magnitude spectrogram into a set of spectral templates corresponding to instrument notes and their time-varying activations. Evaluated on the MAPS dataset, our Constrained NMF (CNMF) model significantly reduces transcription errors—particularly octave errors and spurious note detections—compared to both standard NMF and recent deep learning-based systems, demonstrating the continued value of hybrid systems integrating domain-specific knowledge.
subject: Müzik
title: Non-Negative Matrix Factorization with Temporal-Harmonic Priors for Polyphonic Music Transcription

text: This theoretical paper proposes a novel method for audio feature extraction leveraging quantum signal processing (QSP) principles. We outline an algorithm for a Quantum Chroma Feature (QCF) extractor based on the Quantum Fourier Transform (QFT).
