By encoding short-time audio frames into the amplitudes of a quantum state, the QFT's exponential speedup enables a spectral analysis of unprecedented resolution, far exceeding the limitations of the classical uncertainty principle inherent in STFT-based methods. This heightened resolution allows for the precise separation of closely spaced partials, leading to a more accurate and robust mapping of spectral energy onto the 12 pitch classes of the chromatic scale. We simulate the algorithm's performance on synthetic polyphonic signals with complex inharmonicities and dense orchestration, demonstrating a significant reduction in spectral leakage and inter-octave ambiguity compared to conventional chroma extraction techniques. This work lays the theoretical groundwork for next-generation audio analysis in a post-classical computing era.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantum-Enhanced Chroma Feature Extraction for High-Resolution Harmonic Analysis

text: This research addresses the challenge of separating compositional structure from expressive performance style in audio recordings. We propose a deep generative model based on a disentangling Variational Autoencoder (VAE) architecture. The model is trained on a dataset of diverse performances of the same compositions. It learns a partitioned latent space, where one subspace encodes time-invariant structural information (e.g., melody, harmony), while an orthogonal subspace captures time-varying stylistic parameters (e.g., articulation, dynamics, rubato). By conditioning the decoder on specific points sampled from these disentangled subspaces, we demonstrate the ability to synthesize new, stylistically coherent performances of a given piece and to transcribe a performance to a 'neutral' structural representation. This framework provides a powerful tool for computational music analysis, enabling quantitative comparisons of performance styles and facilitating new applications in style transfer and expressive performance synthesis.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangling Expressive Performance Style from Compositional Structure with Variational Autoencoders

text: This study investigates the mapping between conductor gestures and orchestral execution through a cross-modal analysis framework based on manifold alignment. We simultaneously record high-resolution motion capture data of a conductor and multi-track audio of the orchestra. From the motion data, we extract kinematic features (e.g., velocity, acceleration, gesture volume), and from the audio, we compute expressive features (e.g., dynamics, articulation, tempo variations). We hypothesize that both modalities represent different views of a single, underlying expressive intention. To uncover this shared structure, we project the high-dimensional data from each modality into a common low-dimensional latent space using non-linear manifold alignment techniques. The resulting unified manifold reveals strong correlations between specific gestural archetypes and resulting musical articulations. This approach moves beyond simple linear regression, providing a nuanced model of the complex, non-linear relationship between conductorial intent and musical sound.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Analysis of Musical Expression and Conductor Gestures via Manifold Alignment

text: Existing psychoacoustic models of dissonance, such as those based on critical band roughness, fail to account for the role of harmonicity and tonal context. This paper presents a novel computational model that defines dissonance in terms of neural processing efficiency. We first simulate the response of the auditory periphery to complex tones using a detailed biophysical model of the auditory nerve. The resulting spike train patterns are then processed by a sparse coding algorithm (e.g., Matching Pursuit) that seeks to represent the neural activity using a minimal set of learned basis functions, or 'neural dictionary elements'. Our central hypothesis is that consonance corresponds to efficient, sparse representations, while dissonance arises from complex, inefficient codes. The model's dissonance ratings for various intervals and chords show high correlation with human perceptual data and correctly predict phenomena that older models cannot, such as the context-dependency of dissonance in tonal music.
subject: Müzik
title: A Computational Model of Auditory Dissonance Based on Sparse Coding of Peripheral Neural Responses

text: We investigate the emergence of spacetime geometry from quantum entanglement by examining the ER=EPR conjecture through the lens of AdS/CFT correspondence. This work introduces a novel class of non-local, bilineal operators in the boundary conformal field theory (CFT) designed to probe the bulk geometry beyond the limitations of the Ryu-Takayanagi formula. By computing the expectation values of these operators in states with complex entanglement structures, we demonstrate a direct correspondence to geodesic lengths within the entanglement wedge of disjoint boundary regions. Our analysis, leveraging tensor network approximations of the CFT ground state, reveals that fluctuations in entanglement entropy are dual to metric perturbations governed by the linearized Einstein equations in the asymptotically AdS bulk. This framework provides a concrete calculational tool for entanglement wedge reconstruction and offers a path toward understanding the microscopic degrees of freedom constituting spacetime, particularly in the context of multi-boundary wormholes and quantum chaos.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Holographic Entanglement Entropy with Non-Local Quantum Field Theory Operators

text: Topological quantum computation relies on the robust encoding of quantum information in non-local degrees of freedom, protected from local decoherence. Here, we present experimental evidence for the non-Abelian statistics of quasiparticle excitations in the ν=12/5 fractional quantum Hall (FQH) state. Utilizing a Fabry-Pérot interferometer etched into a high-mobility GaAs/AlGaAs heterostructure, we perform braiding operations by electrostatically dragging quasiparticles around localized potential pins. The resulting interference patterns exhibit discrete phase jumps consistent with the Fibonacci anyon model, a platform for universal topological quantum computation. Our data robustly rejects Abelian hypotheses, showing clear signatures of non-commutative braiding relations predicted by the underlying SU(2)₄ Chern-Simons field theory. These findings establish the ν=12/5 FQH state as a promising physical system for the realization of fault-tolerant quantum computing architectures and the direct observation of fractional statistics beyond the Abelian paradigm.
subject: Kuantum
title: Fractional Statistics and Braiding of Non-Abelian Anyons in a ν=12/5 Fractional Quantum Hall State

text: The Eigenstate Thermalization Hypothesis (ETH) posits that isolated quantum systems thermalize internally, with subsystems acting as their own heat baths. Many-Body Localization (MBL) provides a canonical counterexample, where strong disorder prevents thermalization. We study the transition from ETH to MBL in a one-dimensional Heisenberg spin chain with quasiperiodic disorder using large-scale exact diagonalization and a time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (tDMRG) approach. We identify a sharp localization transition by analyzing the level spacing statistics and the structure of eigenstates. In the MBL phase, we observe the emergence of local integrals of motion (l-bits) and the characteristic logarithmic growth of bipartite entanglement entropy following a quantum quench, a stark contrast to the linear growth seen in thermalizing systems. Our phenomenological renormalization group analysis of entanglement dynamics provides a critical exponent for the MBL transition, offering stringent benchmarks for theories of non-ergodic quantum dynamics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Eigenstate Thermalization Breakdown and Logarithmic Entanglement Growth in a Disordered Many-Body Localized System

text: We theoretically propose and analyze a quantum metrology protocol that achieves super-Heisenberg scaling for the simultaneous estimation of multiple parameters. The standard quantum limit (SQL) and the Heisenberg limit (HL) represent fundamental bounds on measurement precision for classical and standard quantum strategies, respectively. By employing entangled coherent states (ECS) in a Mach-Zehnder interferometer array, we demonstrate that the quantum Fisher information matrix for phase estimation scales polynomially with the photon number N, surpassing the linear HL scaling. The protocol leverages the non-Gaussian nature of the resource states to create quantum correlations that are robust to certain classes of noise. We derive an optimal measurement scheme based on parity detection and show that the Cramér-Rao bound can be saturated. This work elucidates a pathway to ultra-precise sensing in applications like gravitational wave detection and biological imaging, where multiple coupled parameters must be determined with extreme accuracy.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum-Enhanced Multi-Parameter Estimation Surpassing the Heisenberg Limit with Entangled Coherent States

text: We report the deterministic generation and stabilization of multi-photon Schrödinger cat states within a high-Q microwave resonator coupled to a transmon qubit. Operating in the strong dispersive regime of cavity quantum electrodynamics (cQED), we utilize a sequence of precisely timed qubit rotations and conditional resonator displacements to engineer the cavity field into a macroscopic superposition of coherent states with opposite phases. The Wigner function of the prepared state, reconstructed via quantum state tomography, confirms high fidelity (F > 0.95) for cat states up to an average photon number of α²=16. The protocol's efficiency and speed, limited only by the qubit-cavity coupling strength, allow for the creation of these highly non-classical states as resources for quantum error correction codes, such as the GKP code, and for fundamental tests of quantum mechanics at the macroscopic scale.
subject: Kuantum
title: Deterministic Generation of Schrödinger Cat States in a Dispersively Coupled Superconducting Qubit-Cavity System

text: The axion remains a compelling candidate for cold dark matter, searchable via its resonant conversion to photons in a microwave cavity immersed in a strong magnetic field (a haloscope). The sensitivity of these experiments is typically limited by thermal and quantum noise in the amplification chain. We present the results from a search for galactic halo axions utilizing a Josephson parametric amplifier and injecting a squeezed vacuum state into the cavity's output port. This technique reduces the total noise power below the standard quantum limit, effectively decreasing the system's noise temperature without physical cooling. By correlating the quadratures of the squeezed state, we achieve a 3 dB improvement in signal-to-noise ratio, enabling a 4x increase in scan rate. We scanned the axion mass range of 23.55-23.62 μeV/c² and set a new upper limit on the axion-photon coupling constant, demonstrating the power of quantum sensing techniques in fundamental particle physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Search for Axionic Dark Matter Using a Squeezed-State-Enhanced Haloscope

text: Ergodicity, the exploration of all available states, is a foundational concept in statistical mechanics. However, certain non-integrable quantum systems can exhibit quantum scars—special, non-thermal eigenstates that lead to persistent oscillations for specific initial states. We report the experimental observation of quantum scarring in a 51-atom programmable quantum simulator based on Rydberg atoms. By preparing the system in a Néel-like state and quenching the Hamiltonian, we observe robust, long-lived coherent revivals in local observables, a direct signature of the system's trajectory being confined to a small, non-ergodic subspace of the vast Hilbert space. Our results are well-described by a phenomenological model based on a single particle hopping on a graph of many-body states, linking the revivals to unstable periodic orbits in a corresponding classical model. This work confirms the existence of a weak mechanism for ergodicity breaking with implications for condensed matter physics and quantum thermalization.
subject: Kuantum
title: Observation of Many-Body Quantum Scars and Revivals in a Rydberg Atom Quantum Simulator

text: We analyze the operational meaning of quantum field entanglement by studying the entanglement harvesting protocol for a pair of uniformly accelerated observers. The observers, modeled as Unruh-DeWitt detectors, interact locally with a massless scalar field prepared in the Minkowski vacuum. We calculate the concurrence of the final two-detector state as a function of their acceleration and separation, demonstrating that entanglement can be extracted from the vacuum state. However, we also show that this harvested entanglement is degraded by the thermal bath perceived by each observer due to the Unruh effect. By calculating the fidelity of quantum teleportation between the observers using the harvested state as a resource, we quantify the precise trade-off between the ability to extract entanglement and the noise introduced by relativistic motion. This study illuminates the observer-dependent nature of entanglement in quantum field theory and has implications for quantum communication in non-inertial frames.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Harvesting and Fidelity Degradation in a Relativistic Quantum Field

text: Non-Hermitian Hamiltonians possessing parity-time (PT) symmetry can exhibit entirely real energy spectra, behaving effectively as closed systems until a spontaneous PT-symmetry-breaking transition occurs at an exceptional point (EP). We experimentally realize a non-Hermitian, PT-symmetric optical system using coupled micro-ring resonators with engineered gain and loss. By dynamically encircling an EP in the parameter space, we demonstrate the chiral and state-flipping nature of the system's eigenstates, where an initial eigenstate is mapped onto another after one full loop. This process, a form of topological energy-level braiding, is a hallmark of EP physics. We further map out the topological phase transition boundary between the PT-symmetric (real spectra) and PT-broken (complex spectra) phases. Our results provide a robust platform for exploring the rich physics of non-Hermitian quantum mechanics and its potential applications in enhanced sensing and topological mode switching.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Phase Transitions and Energy-Level Braiding Around Exceptional Points in a Non-Hermitian Quantum System

text: Variational Quantum Eigensolvers (VQE) are a leading strategy for near-term quantum computers, yet their scalability is severely hampered by the barren plateau phenomenon, where gradients vanish exponentially with system size. We introduce a Contextual Subspace VQE (CS-VQE) method that mitigates this issue by iteratively constructing an active subspace based on the Hamiltonian's structure. At each iteration, the algorithm identifies the most relevant qubit operators contributing to the energy gradient and restricts the variational optimization to this dynamically-defined low-dimensional subspace. This approach avoids exploring the irrelevant, high-dimensional regions of the Hilbert space responsible for barren plateaus. We benchmark the CS-VQE on molecular hydrogen chains (H₆) and the challenging Cr₂ dimer, demonstrating a significant reduction in circuit depth and a polynomial scaling of required measurements, compared to the exponential scaling of standard hardware-efficient ansätze. This method paves the way for scalable quantum chemistry simulations on noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices.
subject: Kuantum
title: Mitigating Barren Plateaus in Variational Quantum Eigensolvers with Contextual Subspace Optimization

text: This research investigates the synthesis of deep learning with structural causal models to generate robust counterfactual explanations and intervention-aware representations. We propose a novel architecture, the Causal-VAE, which disentangles invariant causal factors from spurious correlations by enforcing a generative process that explicitly models interventional distributions. By employing adversarial training mechanisms, the Causal-VAE learns to synthesize plausible counterfactuals while maintaining fidelity to observed data distributions, thereby enhancing model interpretability and out-of-distribution generalization. Our approach leverages a meta-learning framework to adapt causal graphs from observational data, enabling dynamic intervention planning and robust decision-making under uncertainty. Empirical evaluations on complex, high-dimensional datasets demonstrate superior performance in identifying causal pathways and generating actionable insights compared to existing post-hoc XAI methods.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Explanations and Intervention-Aware Representations in Deep Causal Models

text: We present a novel framework for optimizing structural prompts in large multimodal foundation models by integrating gradient-based causal induction. Traditional prompt engineering often relies on heuristic search or discrete optimization, overlooking the intrinsic causal relationships between prompt components and model behavior. Our method introduces a differentiable meta-prompt mechanism that learns optimal prompt structures and their underlying causal dependencies using an attention-based causal inference module. This module dynamically identifies the most salient prompt tokens and their interventional effects on downstream task performance. By framing prompt optimization as a counterfactual reasoning problem within a gradient descent context, we achieve significant improvements in zero-shot and few-shot learning across diverse multimodal benchmarks, demonstrating enhanced adaptation capabilities and robustness to distribution shifts, surpassing conventional PEFT techniques.
subject: AI
title: Structural Prompt Optimization for Multimodal Foundation Models via Gradient-Based Causal Induction

text: This paper addresses the critical challenge of ensuring provable safety in continuous-state, multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) systems operating in uncertain environments. We introduce a novel approach leveraging constrained Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equations, specifically approximating their solutions using deep neural networks trained with a robust control barrier function (CBF) and control Lyapunov function (CLF) framework. Our methodology integrates risk-sensitive value iteration with a differentiable safety layer that projects unsafe actions onto the maximal safe control set, derived from reachable set computations. The proposed framework guarantees satisfaction of complex, temporal safety specifications with high probability, even under adversarial perturbations and model uncertainties. Empirical validation on high-dimensional robotic control tasks demonstrates superior safety performance and stability without compromising optimality, outperforming state-of-the-art safe RL algorithms.
subject: AI
title: Provably Safe Reinforcement Learning through Constrained Multi-Agent Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman Approximations

text: We propose a novel Spatio-Temporal Hypergraph Neural Network (ST-HGNN) framework designed for robust reasoning over evolving knowledge graphs and complex relational data. Unlike conventional GNNs limited to static pairwise interactions, ST-HGNN captures higher-order, multi-way relationships and their temporal dynamics by modeling entities and relations as hyperedges in a sequence of time-evolving hypergraphs. Our architecture incorporates a transformer-based temporal attention mechanism for capturing long-range dependencies across time slices and a message-passing scheme optimized for hypergraph convolutions. This enables dynamic structural updates and adaptive representation learning. Evaluated on large-scale evolving knowledge base completion and event prediction tasks, ST-HGNN demonstrates superior performance, revealing intricate spatio-temporal patterns and enhancing predictive accuracy in domains characterized by highly interconnected, dynamic relational structures.
subject: AI
title: Spatio-Temporal Hypergraph Neural Networks for Dynamic Knowledge Graph Reasoning

text: This work presents a novel event-driven backpropagation algorithm for training deep Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) that addresses the non-differentiability of spike generation and the inherent sparsity of SNN dynamics. Our approach employs a surrogate gradient method coupled with adaptive neuron thresholds, allowing for efficient, biologically plausible learning in deep architectures. By focusing on event-driven updates, we significantly reduce computational load compared to conventional frame-based methods, enabling real-time processing of asynchronous sensor data. The adaptive threshold mechanism facilitates dynamic regulation of neuronal excitability, enhancing network capacity and robustness against noise. Experimental results on challenging spatio-temporal pattern recognition benchmarks demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance with dramatically reduced energy consumption, paving the way for ultra-low-power edge AI deployments and robust neuromorphic computing.
subject: AI
title: Event-Driven Spatio-Temporal Backpropagation for Deep Spiking Neural Networks with Adaptive Thresholds

text: We introduce the Variational Quantum Graph Convolutional Network (VQ-GCN), a hybrid quantum-classical machine learning model designed to leverage quantum entanglement for enhanced feature learning on graph-structured data. VQ-GCN embeds graph nodes into a high-dimensional Hilbert space using parameterized quantum circuits, where quantum feature maps and entanglement operations facilitate the discovery of intricate correlations unattainable by classical GCNs. The graph convolutional operations are performed within the quantum realm, followed by a classical readout layer. Our optimization strategy employs a hybrid approach, using classical optimizers to train the quantum circuit parameters. Empirical results on real-world graph classification and node prediction tasks demonstrate that VQ-GCN achieves competitive or superior performance, particularly in scenarios where quantum entanglement provides a computational advantage by capturing non-local relationships and complex graph invariants.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Graph Convolutional Networks for Entangled Feature Learning

text: This paper proposes a novel meta-learning framework, Meta-Gradient Inner Loop Optimization (MGILO), designed to achieve robust few-shot generalization across diverse, unseen tasks without explicit task-specific retraining. MGILO optimizes the inner-loop update rule itself through a meta-gradient descent approach, effectively learning how to learn from limited data. By parameterizing the optimization process with a neural network, our framework dynamically adjusts learning rates and update directions based on current task information, enabling rapid adaptation to novel distributions. This contrasts with fixed-optimizer meta-learning methods, which often struggle with significant domain shifts. We demonstrate that MGILO significantly outperforms state-of-the-art meta-learning algorithms on various few-shot classification and regression benchmarks, showcasing enhanced generalization capabilities and improved sample efficiency in highly heterogeneous task environments.
subject: AI
title: Task-Agnostic Adaptation via Meta-Gradient Inner Loop Optimization for Few-Shot Generalization

text: This research presents a novel framework for generating Counterfactual Concept Explanations (CCE) to enhance the interpretability and trustworthiness of deep learning models in high-stakes medical imaging diagnostics. Unlike local perturbation-based methods, CCEs provide actionable explanations by identifying minimal, semantically meaningful modifications to input concepts (e.g., 'lesion shape', 'tissue texture') that would alter a model's prediction. We leverage a disentangled representation learning approach to isolate concept vectors, allowing for targeted counterfactual generation within a latent space. This approach ensures clinical relevance and avoids pixel-level noise. Evaluations on chest X-ray and MRI datasets demonstrate that CCEs offer superior fidelity to human reasoning and facilitate expert validation of model decisions, thereby increasing clinician confidence and enabling more robust deployment of AI in critical healthcare applications.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Concept Explanations for Robust Medical Image Diagnostics in High-Stakes Settings

text: We propose a novel differentially private federated learning (DPFL) framework that integrates adaptive homomorphic encryption (AHE) to enhance privacy guarantees and communication efficiency in cross-silo training scenarios. Traditional DPFL often incurs significant utility loss or communication overhead. Our AHE-DPFL scheme employs a dynamic noise injection mechanism calibrated by the secure aggregation protocol, ensuring ε-differential privacy while minimizing the impact on model accuracy. AHE allows for computation on encrypted gradients, eliminating the need for decryption during aggregation and thus protecting individual client updates throughout the training process. This significantly mitigates risks associated with gradient leakage attacks. Empirical evaluations across diverse medical and financial datasets demonstrate that AHE-DPFL achieves a superior trade-off between privacy, utility, and communication cost compared to existing DPFL and secure multi-party computation approaches.
subject: AI
title: Differentially Private Federated Learning with Adaptive Homomorphic Encryption for Cross-Silo Training

text: This paper introduces a novel conditional generative diffusion model designed for accelerated *de novo* molecular design, integrating explicit property constraints directly into the latent space generation process. Unlike conventional generative adversarial networks or variational autoencoders, our diffusion model offers precise control over desired molecular properties (e.g., solubility, binding affinity, synthesizability) by conditioning the reverse diffusion process on a learned property embedding. We employ a multi-objective reinforcement learning approach to fine-tune the conditioning mechanism, ensuring generated molecules adhere to complex, non-linear property desiderata. This framework significantly enhances the efficiency of discovering novel compounds with optimized characteristics. Extensive empirical validation demonstrates superior performance in generating diverse, valid, and property-compliant molecules, substantially outperforming state-of-the-art methods in drug discovery and material science applications.
subject: AI
title: Conditional Generative Diffusion Models for De Novo Molecular Design with Explicit Property Constraints

text: Inferring heterogeneous treatment effects (HTEs) in settings characterized by an ultra-high number of confounders presents significant challenges for conventional causal inference methodologies due to issues of confounding bias and curse of dimensionality. This paper introduces a novel doubly robust estimator for conditional average treatment effects (CATE) that leverages recent advancements in debiased machine learning and orthogonal regularization. Our method meticulously integrates targeted maximum likelihood estimation with high-dimensional nuisance parameter estimation, employing Lasso-type penalties for sparsity and robust estimation of propensity scores and outcome regression functions. We establish its theoretical properties, demonstrating consistency, asymptotic normality, and semiparametric efficiency under weaker regularity conditions than prior approaches. Extensive simulations and a real-world application highlight its superior finite-sample performance, bias reduction, and robustness against model misspecification in nuisance components, providing a critical tool for precision medicine and complex social science interventions.
subject: İstatistik
title: Doubly Robust Inference for Heterogeneous Causal Effects in Ultra-High Dimensional Settings

text: Traditional Bayesian non-parametric methods, while offering unparalleled flexibility in modeling complex data distributions, often struggle with scalability when applied to large, high-dimensional datasets, particularly those exhibiting intricate relational structures. This work proposes a novel scalable Bayesian non-parametric framework, the Graph-Augmented Dirichlet Process Mixture Model (GA-DPMM), specifically designed for joint inference on node attributes and relational edges in large graphs. Our approach integrates a conditional random field component within the DPMM, allowing information from the graph structure to inform the cluster assignments and enhancing the posterior inference. We develop an efficient distributed variational inference algorithm that approximates the intractable posterior, enabling its application to datasets with millions of nodes and edges. Theoretical guarantees for convergence and mixing properties are derived, alongside empirical demonstrations showcasing superior performance in community detection, link prediction, and uncertainty quantification compared to state-of-the-art parametric and non-parametric baselines.
subject: İstatistik
title: Scalable Bayesian Non-parametric Inference for Relational Data with Graph-Augmented Dirichlet Process Mixtures

text: Contemporary statistical analysis frequently encounters data exhibiting heavy-tailed distributions and significant contamination, rendering classical least squares and even standard M-estimators inefficient or highly biased. We introduce an an adaptive M-estimation framework that employs data-driven influence functions to robustly estimate regression parameters in such challenging environments. Our methodology dynamically selects the tuning parameters and the form of the ψ-function based on robust preliminary estimates of scale and kurtosis, effectively mitigating the adverse effects of gross errors and large leverage points. This novel approach ensures high breakdown points and excellent efficiency across a spectrum of error distributions, from Gaussian to Cauchy-like tails. We establish the asymptotic properties of the proposed estimator, including consistency and asymptotic normality, under mild regularity conditions. Comprehensive simulations and real-world econometric data applications demonstrate its superior robustness and estimation accuracy compared to conventional and several state-of-the-art robust estimators.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive M-Estimation with Data-Driven Influence Functions for Contaminated Heavy-Tailed Regressions

text: Accurate prediction and inference for non-Gaussian geophysical processes across vast spatio-temporal domains remain a formidable challenge, particularly when confronted with complex dependencies and observational noise. This paper presents a hierarchical Bayesian spatio-temporal framework that addresses these issues by modeling the underlying latent process using solutions to stochastic partial differential equations (SPDEs). Specifically, we employ a Matérn covariance function parameterized through the SPDE approach, which naturally facilitates scalable inference for Gaussian Markov Random Fields. We extend this by integrating a non-Gaussian likelihood (e.g., log-Gaussian Cox processes for count data or generalized linear models for other discrete outcomes) that captures the observed data characteristics. Our methodology utilizes an integrated nested Laplace approximation (INLA) for efficient inference of fixed effects and hyperparameters, bypassing computationally intensive Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods. Empirical validation using climate model outputs and environmental monitoring data demonstrates superior predictive performance and uncertainty quantification compared to conventional spatio-temporal generalized linear mixed models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Hierarchical Bayesian Spatio-Temporal Modeling of Non-Gaussian Geophysical Processes via Stochastic Partial Differential Equations

text: Causal discovery in high-dimensional settings, especially when confronted with heterogeneous data types and complex dependencies, is paramount yet fraught with computational and inferential complexities. This work introduces a novel penalized framework for estimating Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs) that simultaneously accounts for sparsity and different variable types (e.g., continuous, discrete, ordinal) in ultra-high dimensions. Our approach builds upon score-based methods, employing a refined structural EM algorithm with adaptive Group Lasso penalties to achieve consistent parent set estimation and local score optimization. We develop a robust regularization path for structure learning, enabling the identification of direct causal effects even in the presence of latent confounders, by integrating conditional independence tests tailored for mixed data. Theoretical analyses establish the consistency of our estimator under standard high-dimensional assumptions and the oracle property for sparse graphs. Empirical studies on synthetic and biological network data demonstrate substantial improvements in accuracy and scalability over existing causal discovery algorithms.
subject: İstatistik
title: Penalized Directed Acyclic Graph Estimation for Causal Discovery in High-Dimensional Heterogeneous Data

text: Analyzing functional data, particularly longitudinal observations collected irregularly and sparsely over time, poses significant challenges for traditional statistical methods. We propose a novel penalized functional principal component analysis (FPCA) framework specifically designed to handle such complex data structures. Our method regularizes both the functional principal components (FPCs) and their corresponding scores, effectively addressing noise and ensuring smoothness, even with highly sparse and heterogeneous observation patterns. We employ basis function expansions with roughness penalties (e.g., cubic splines with derivative penalties) to estimate the underlying smooth mean function and FPCs, while a generalized expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm imputes missing data and estimates scores. Theoretical guarantees on the consistency and convergence rates of the estimated FPCs and scores are established under mild conditions. Extensive simulation studies and a substantive application to electronic health record data illustrate the superior performance of our approach in terms of dimension reduction, prediction accuracy, and interpretability compared to existing FPCA techniques for sparse data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Penalized Functional Principal Component Analysis for Irregularly Sampled Longitudinal Data with Sparse Observations

text: Providing robust and distribution-free uncertainty quantification for regression models, particularly in the presence of dependent data structures, remains a critical challenge for reliable machine learning applications. This paper develops a novel conformal prediction framework that generates valid prediction intervals for regression outcomes without requiring distributional assumptions on the errors, even under temporal or spatial dependencies. Our approach extends the principles of split conformal inference by integrating a baseline quantile regression model, which adaptively estimates conditional quantiles and provides more informative non-conformity scores. We introduce a carefully calibrated exchangeability-preserving re-sampling scheme to address dependencies, ensuring finite-sample coverage guarantees. Theoretical results establish the marginal coverage validity of our intervals irrespective of the underlying data distribution or model complexity, provided sufficient exchangeability. Empirical evaluations on diverse datasets, including time series and spatial observations, demonstrate the superior performance in achieving nominal coverage while maintaining competitive interval widths compared to existing conformal and bootstrap-based methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Distribution-Free Conformal Prediction Intervals for Regression with Dependent Data and Quantile Regression Baselines

text: Bayesian inference for massive datasets often encounters computational bottlenecks due to the high cost of likelihood evaluations within Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms. We propose an asymptotically exact subsampling MCMC (AEX-MCMC) framework that significantly accelerates posterior sampling without sacrificing theoretical guarantees of convergence to the true posterior distribution. Our method employs a novel Metropolis-Hastings correction step based on a low-variance estimator of the full log-likelihood, derived from intelligently stratified subsamples. This approach ensures unbiasedness of the acceptance ratio in expectation, leading to unbiased MCMC transitions. We provide rigorous theoretical analysis demonstrating the ergodicity and geometric convergence of AEX-MCMC under general conditions, overcoming the biased stationary distributions often associated with naive subsampling MCMC variants. Empirical studies on large-scale generalized linear models and hierarchical models showcase substantial computational speedups—orders of magnitude faster than full-data MCMC—while maintaining accurate posterior inference and uncertainty quantification across various complex models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Asymptotically Exact Subsampling Markov Chain Monte Carlo for Bayesian Inference with Massive Datasets

text: In survival analysis, accurately predicting cause-specific outcomes in the presence of competing risks is crucial, yet challenging, especially when confronted with high-dimensional covariate data and the need for dynamic updates over time. This paper introduces a novel statistical framework for dynamic prediction of cause-specific cumulative incidence functions (CIFs) that integrates penalized regression with inverse probability censoring weighting (IPCW) and gradient boosting techniques. Our method robustly handles time-varying covariates and provides individual-level predictions of event probabilities accounting for the dynamic nature of competing events. We employ a regularized Cox proportional hazards model for each cause-specific hazard, incorporating Group Lasso or elastic net penalties to manage high-dimensional predictors and promote sparsity. The predictive performance is assessed using time-dependent Brier scores and dynamic concordance indices. Extensive simulations and a real-world application to clinical oncology data demonstrate superior discriminative ability and calibration compared to existing dynamic prediction models for competing risks, offering critical insights for personalized risk assessment.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Prediction of Cause-Specific Cumulative Incidence Functions with High-Dimensional Covariates under Competing Risks

text: Selecting optimal models and regularizing their complexity in high-dimensional and non-linear statistical systems remains a fundamental problem, often addressed heuristically or via disparate information criteria. This paper proposes a unified framework grounded in the Minimum Description Length (MDL) principle that provides a theoretically sound basis for both model selection and parameter regularization. Our approach quantifies model complexity and goodness-of-fit within a coherent coding-theoretic paradigm, extending traditional MDL to accommodate intricate model spaces, including non-parametric and latent variable models. We derive novel MDL-based criteria that inherently balance model fit with the information required to specify the model structure and its parameters, offering a more robust alternative to AIC/BIC when assumptions are violated. Theoretical analyses demonstrate the consistency of our proposed estimators and their asymptotic optimality in selecting the true model generating the data. Empirical results across various complex statistical learning tasks, from graphical model selection to deep learning regularization, showcase its superior performance in generalization and interpretability.
subject: İstatistik
title: Unified Minimum Description Length Principle for Model Selection and Regularization in Complex Statistical Systems

text: Precision epigenome editing offers unparalleled therapeutic potential by modulating gene expression without altering underlying DNA sequence. Here, we engineered a novel dCas9-LSD1 fusion construct, specifically optimized for sequence-specific demethylation of histone H3K27me3 marks within enhancer regions of oncogenic drivers. Utilizing high-throughput ChIP-seq and ATAC-seq, we demonstrate that targeted H3K27me3 removal, contrary to conventional expectations of activation, paradoxically induces robust recruitment of Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) and subsequent de novo H3K27me3 deposition, leading to sustained transcriptional silencing of critical glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) oncogenes like EGFR and MYC. Furthermore, single-cell RNA sequencing revealed a significant reduction in tumor heterogeneity and suppressed proliferation in patient-derived GBM organoids. This unexpected epigenetic plasticity mediated by dCas9-LSD1 unveils a complex interplay between demethylases and repressive chromatin machinery, proposing a novel gene silencing strategy with profound implications for cancer therapeutics.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Targeted Histone H3K27me3 Demethylation via dCas9-LSD1 Fusion Recruits Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 and Silences Oncogenic Loci in Glioblastoma

text: N6-methyladenosine (m6A) is a pervasive epitranscriptomic modification influencing various aspects of RNA metabolism. This study investigates the intricate role of m6A in modulating ribosomal dynamics and stress granule (SG) assembly under hypoxic stress. Employing nascent RNA sequencing and Ribo-seq in m6A writer (METTL3/14) and eraser (FTO/ALKBH5) deficient cell lines, we reveal that alterations in global m6A levels significantly impact the translational efficiency and elongation rates of specific transcripts encoding hypoxia-inducible factors. Aberrant m6A patterns exacerbate ribosomal stalling at distinct codons, subsequently promoting the aberrant nucleation and maturation of SGs, key cytoplasmic stress organelles. Mechanistically, m6A dysregulation perturbs the interaction between specific RNA-binding proteins (e.g., YTHDF2) and target mRNAs, thereby sensitizing cells to oxidative stress-induced apoptosis. Our findings delineate a sophisticated regulatory axis linking epitranscriptomics, translational fidelity, and cellular stress responses, highlighting m6A as a critical determinant of cellular resilience during hypoxia.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Deciphering the Role of m6A RNA Methylation in Regulating Ribosomal Stalling and Stress Granule Formation during Cellular Hypoxia

text: Mitochondrial dynamics, characterized by continuous fusion and fission events, are crucial for maintaining organelle health and function. We report the discovery and characterization of a novel Mitochondrial Intermembrane Space Bridging (MIB) complex, composed of previously uncharacterized integral inner and outer mitochondrial membrane proteins. Using high-resolution cryo-electron tomography and quantitative proteomics, we demonstrate that MIB physically links the inner and outer membranes, acting as a scaffold that spatially organizes the Mitofusin 1/2 (MFN1/2) trans-intermembrane space fusion machinery. Disrupting MIB complex integrity severely impairs MFN-mediated mitochondrial fusion, leading to mitochondrial fragmentation and subsequent mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) instability and elevated somatic mutations. Moreover, MIB deficiency impairs the recruitment of base excision repair components to sites of mtDNA lesions. These findings establish the MIB complex as a pivotal regulator of mitochondrial architecture and mtDNA integrity, underscoring its potential role in mitochondrial encephalopathies and aging-related disorders.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mitochondrial Intermembrane Space Bridging (MIB) Complex Orchestrates Mitofusin-Mediated Fusion and Mitochondrial DNA Repair Fidelity

text: Transcriptional regulation in eukaryotes is fundamentally driven by the precise orchestration of chromatin architecture, particularly the formation of phase-separated condensates at regulatory elements. Here, we meticulously map the spatiotemporal dynamics of RNA Polymerase II, Mediator complex, and distinct histone modification-enriched condensates during hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) differentiation using live-cell single-molecule tracking and multiplexed immunofluorescence with Lattice Light Sheet Microscopy. We demonstrate that super-enhancers (SEs) nucleate dynamic yet stable transcriptional condensates, whose size, stability, and intermolecular exchange rates are exquisitely sensitive to the local concentration of specific transcription factors (e.g., GATA1, PU.1) and chromatin accessibility. Perturbing these condensate properties, either genetically or pharmacologically, abrogates SE-driven gene expression programs, resulting in blocked or skewed lineage specification. Our results elucidate a fundamental principle of gene regulation where the biophysical properties of transcriptional condensates at SEs serve as a critical determinant of cell fate decisions in development and disease.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Chromatin Condensates Regulate Super-Enhancer Activity and Lineage Specification in Hematopoietic Stem Cells

text: Cellular mechanotransduction, the process by which cells convert mechanical stimuli into biochemical signals, profoundly influences cell fate. This study unveils a novel mechanotransduction pathway linking extracellular matrix (ECM) stiffness to altered nuclear pore complex (NPC) permeability and subsequent changes in gene expression. Using engineered hydrogels of varying stiffness, we observe that increased ECM rigidity promotes actomyosin contractility, leading to enhanced tensional forces transmitted through the LINC complex to the nuclear lamina. This force propagation induces specific conformational changes in nuclear pore proteins (nucleoporins), particularly Nup93 and Nup153, reducing their permeability for larger macromolecules. Proteomic analysis of nucleocytoplasmic transport in stiff-matrix cells revealed differential nuclear import of key transcription factors (e.g., YAP/TAZ) and RNA export factors. This direct mechanosensitive regulation of NPC function provides a mechanistic link between tissue microenvironment and the nuclear control of gene expression, with implications for development, tissue regeneration, and fibrosis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Elucidating the Mechanotransduction Pathway Linking Extracellular Matrix Stiffness to Nuclear Pore Complex Permeability and Gene Expression

text: Autophagy, particularly selective autophagy (xenophagy), is a crucial host defense mechanism against intracellular pathogens. Current therapeutic strategies for infectious diseases often lack specificity. Here, we report the de novo design and validation of synthetic autophagy receptors engineered to specifically recognize and target bacterial pathogen effectors for rapid autophagosomal degradation. Utilizing a modular protein engineering approach, we fused pathogen effector-binding domains (e.g., nanobodies against Type III secretion system effectors) to canonical LIR motifs and validated their interaction with ATG8 family proteins. Functional assays in human macrophages infected with Salmonella enterica demonstrated that these synthetic receptors efficiently redirect ubiquitinated pathogen effectors to nascent autophagosomes, accelerating lysosomal degradation and significantly reducing bacterial burden. This work represents a paradigm shift in modulating selective autophagy, offering a highly specific and tunable platform for engineering host defenses against intracellular pathogens and potentially other protein aggregate-related pathologies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: De Novo Design of Synthetic Autophagy Receptors Targeting Specific Pathogen Effectors for Selective Xenophagy Activation

text: Telomerase, a reverse transcriptase responsible for maintaining telomere length, is aberrantly reactivated in most cancers, contributing to cellular immortalization. This study investigates the biophysical mechanisms governing telomerase recruitment to telomeres, specifically focusing on liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) phenomena. We demonstrate that the catalytic subunit TERT and several telomerase-associated proteins (e.g., TPP1, POT1, WRAP53) undergo dynamic LLPS to form transient biomolecular condensates at telomeric ends in telomerase-positive cancer cells, but not in normal somatic cells. High-resolution imaging and FRAP analyses reveal that the integrity and fluidity of these TERT-containing condensates are critical for efficient telomerase access and processivity. Disrupting LLPS through mutations in intrinsically disordered regions of TERT or pharmacological agents significantly impairs telomere lengthening and reduces cancer cell viability. This work uncovers a novel regulatory layer of telomerase function, highlighting LLPS as a key mechanism for spatiotemporal organization of telomere maintenance machinery with therapeutic implications for oncology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phase Separation of TERT-Associated Proteins Modulates Telomerase Recruitment and Telomere Lengthening in Cancer Cells

text: Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency (AATD) is characterized by accumulation of misfolded Z-AAT protein in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), leading to ER stress and liver damage. While ER-associated degradation (ERAD) is crucial, its full potential is often overwhelmed. This study investigates how targeting N-glycosylation pathways with Golgi mannosidase II inhibitors impacts Z-AAT fate. We demonstrate that inhibiting Golgi mannosidase II (e.g., swainsonine) induces significant remodeling of N-glycan structures on Z-AAT, preventing its premature export from the ER and enhancing its retrotranslocation into the cytosol for proteasomal degradation. This glycan-dependent modulation of ER retention and retrotranslocation reduces the ER stress response, as evidenced by attenuated PERK-eIF2α-ATF4 pathway activation and decreased inflammatory cytokine production. Our findings highlight a novel therapeutic avenue in AATD by fine-tuning glycan processing to augment the ERAD pathway, thereby mitigating ER stress and cellular pathology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: N-Glycosylation Remodeling by Golgi Mannosidase II Inhibitors Alleviates Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress and Modulates ERAD Pathway in Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency

text: Understanding the cellular heterogeneity and molecular dysregulation in Alzheimer's Disease (AD) requires integrated single-cell approaches. Here, we present a comprehensive single-cell multi-omic analysis combining ATAC-seq and RNA-seq (scATAC-seq/scRNA-seq) to simultaneously profile chromatin accessibility and gene expression in microglia from AD patient post-mortem brains and murine models. We identify distinct microglial subpopulations exhibiting unique epigenomic landscapes and transcriptional profiles. Crucially, we demonstrate a hitherto unappreciated crosstalk where alterations in chromatin accessibility at nuclear-encoded mitochondrial genes correlate directly with aberrant mitochondrial gene expression, particularly those involved in oxidative phosphorylation and fatty acid metabolism, in disease-associated microglia (DAM). Integrative network analysis reveals specific transcription factor binding site enrichment in open chromatin regions correlating with mitochondrial dysfunction. These findings provide unprecedented resolution into the molecular mechanisms driving microglial dysfunction in AD, highlighting novel epigenetic and mitochondrial targets for therapeutic intervention.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Single-Cell Multi-Omic Profiling Reveals Crosstalk Between Chromatin Accessibility and Mitochondrial Gene Expression in Alzheimer's Disease Microglia

text: Autophagy dysfunction is a hallmark of many neurodegenerative diseases. This study investigates the intricate role of the E3 ubiquitin ligase HUWE1 in modulating autophagic flux, particularly through its interaction with the autophagy initiator Beclin-1. We demonstrate that HUWE1 directly ubiquitiniates Beclin-1 at specific lysine residues, leading to its proteasomal degradation and subsequent suppression of autophagosome formation. Using CRISPR-Cas9-mediated HUWE1 knockout neuronal models and primary patient-derived iPSC neurons, we observe a significant increase in basal autophagic flux, improved clearance of aggregated proteins (e.g., α-synuclein, tau), and enhanced neuronal viability under proteotoxic stress conditions. Conversely, overexpression of catalytically active HUWE1 exacerbates autophagy inhibition and neuronal susceptibility to apoptosis. These findings unveil a crucial regulatory mechanism wherein HUWE1 acts as a negative regulator of autophagy via Beclin-1 ubiquitination, providing a novel therapeutic target for enhancing autophagic clearance in neurodegenerative disorders such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's disease.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Deciphering the Ubiquitin E3 Ligase HUWE1's Role in Regulating Autophagy Flux via Beclin-1 Ubiquitination in Neurodegeneration

text: This research introduces a novel deep learning framework utilizing transformer-based recurrent neural networks (RNNs) for advanced contextual functional harmonic analysis and implicit voice-leading trajectory prediction from polyphonic audio. Moving beyond monadic chord recognition, our model integrates spectro-temporal feature extraction (e.g., Constant-Q transforms, chroma vectors) with a sophisticated attention mechanism to discern Roman numeral functions, cadential typologies, and modulatory shifts within complex tonal and post-tonal repertoires. The architecture processes sequential pitch and interval data, leveraging its self-attention capabilities to capture long-range harmonic dependencies and anticipate likely voice-leading paths, even in the presence of ambiguous acoustic cues or incomplete voicings. Performance is evaluated against expert annotations on a diverse corpus, demonstrating superior accuracy in structural segmentation and functional labeling compared to traditional HMM-based methods, offering a robust tool for computational musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Recurrent Neural Networks for Contextual Functional Harmonic Analysis and Voice-Leading Trajectory Prediction

text: This study presents a psychoacoustic investigation into the perceptual correlates of microtemporal inflection and timbral fusion when employing granular synthesis within extended just intonation systems. We systematically manipulate grain parameters—density, duration, envelope characteristics, and fine-grained pitch deviation—to explore their impact on the perception of microtonal interval quality and harmonic coherence. Utilizing custom-designed synthetic stimuli based on 7-limit and 11-limit tunings, participants undergo forced-choice tasks assessing perceptual roughness, consonance, and the phenomenon of 'stream segregation' versus 'timbral fusion'. Auditory psychophysics methodologies, coupled with spectral flux analysis and otoacoustic emission measurements, reveal nuanced interactions between the microscopic temporal organization of grains and the macroscopic perception of complex pitch relationships. Findings elucidate critical thresholds for maintaining harmonic identity in highly microtonal contexts, informing both psychoacoustic theory and advanced synthesis practices.
subject: Müzik
title: Microtemporal Inflection and Perceptual Fusion: A Psychoacoustic Investigation of Granular Synthesis in Extended Just Intonation

text: This research develops a computational framework for analyzing timbral morphology and its structural role in atonal music, moving beyond conventional pitch-centric approaches. We introduce novel descriptors such as spectral centroid trajectories, higher-order partial dispersal indices, and time-varying spectral irregularity measures to quantify the dynamic evolution of instrumental timbres. Employing advanced signal processing techniques, including adaptive multi-resolution spectral analysis and cepstral feature extraction, we characterize how timbral shifts contribute to formal articulation and gestural definition in works by Schoenberg, Webern, and Ligeti. Unsupervised dimensionality reduction (e.g., t-SNE, UMAP) is applied to aggregate these high-dimensional timbral features, revealing latent organizational principles. The findings provide new insights into non-pitch-based structural coherence in complex 20th-century repertoires and offer quantifiable metrics for comparing and classifying timbral strategies across diverse compositions.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectral Centroid Trajectories and Irregular Partial Dispersal: A Computational Framework for Timbral Morphology in Atonal Repertoire

text: This study presents an information-theoretic framework for quantifying structural entropy and redundancy in large-scale musical forms, particularly within post-tonal and experimental compositions. We apply Shannon entropy, Rényi entropy, and Kolmogorov complexity measures to symbolic representations of musical events (e.g., pitch-class sets, rhythmic patterns, formal sections) to assess the information content and predictability of successive structural units. By segmenting compositions based on feature similarity and measuring the entropy of transitions between these segments, we delineate regions of high novelty versus high redundancy. The framework analyzes how composers manage information flow to create coherence or disruption across macro-structural dimensions. Case studies on works by Boulez and Xenakis reveal distinct strategies for balancing predictability and surprise, offering quantitative insights into their compositional methodologies and the perceptual experience of formal complexity.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Structural Entropy: An Information-Theoretic Approach to Large-Scale Musical Form and Redundancy in Post-Tonal Compositions

text: This research proposes a novel deep learning architecture based on cross-modal variational autoencoders (VAEs) for decoding expressive intent in musical performances. The framework integrates synchronized data streams: acoustic features (e.g., MFCCs, spectral flux, fundamental frequency contours), symbolic notation (e.g., onset/offset times, MIDI velocity, performance deviations from score), and kinesthetic motion capture data (e.g., gesture velocity, acceleration). The VAE learns a disentangled latent representation space that captures salient expressive parameters, allowing for robust reconstruction and generation across modalities. By analyzing the learned latent manifold, we identify underlying performative strategies and their multi-modal manifestations. Evaluation on professional solo piano recordings demonstrates the model's capacity to infer fine-grained expressive nuances, providing a powerful tool for performance analysis, synthesis of expressive gestures, and advanced human-computer interaction in musical contexts.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Deep Variational Autoencoders for Expressive Intent Decoding in Musical Performance: Integrating Audio, Symbolic, and Kinematic Data

text: This study presents a spectro-temporal analysis of the complex inharmonic partial structures characteristic of Indonesian Gamelan instruments and investigates their unique perceptual correlates of consonance and dissonance. Employing high-resolution Constant-Q transforms and phase-locked loop tracking, we precisely characterize the deviation from harmonicity and the dynamic evolution of partial frequencies for instruments like the saron and bonang. Psychoacoustic experiments utilize synthesized stimuli derived from measured spectral profiles to assess human listeners' perception of fusion, roughness, and musical interval quality within a Gamelan context. Our findings challenge Western-centric models of consonance, demonstrating how culturally specific inharmonic spectra elicit distinct auditory scene analysis strategies, fostering emergent timbral and rhythmic entrainments. This research provides a quantitative foundation for understanding the psychoacoustics of non-Western tuning systems and informs cross-cultural music cognition theories.
subject: Müzik
title: Inharmonicity and Perceptual Consonance in Gamelan: A Spectro-Temporal Analysis of Complex Partial Structures and Auditory Scene Analysis

text: This research proposes a continuous wavelet transform (CWT) based methodology for multi-resolution rhythmic decomposition, providing novel insights into polyrhythmic structures and metric ambiguity in complex musical scores. By applying various mother wavelets (e.g., Morlet, Mexican Hat) to rhythmic event sequences, we achieve a time-frequency representation that simultaneously captures transient information and sustained periodicities across multiple temporal scales. This allows for the precise identification of superimposed rhythmic layers, nested subdivisions, and micro-timing deviations that contribute to perceived syncopation or metric dissonance. The framework quantitatively assesses the degree of rhythmic complexity and ambiguity within jazz improvisations and contemporary classical works, correlating CWT coefficient magnitudes with perceptual salience. Results demonstrate superior performance in dissecting intricate rhythmic patterns compared to traditional FFT-based or onset detection algorithms, enhancing analytical precision for musicologists and computational music analysis systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Multi-Resolution Rhythmic Decomposition: A Continuous Wavelet Transform Approach to Polyrhythmic Structures and Metric Ambiguity

text: This study introduces a novel hybrid generative adversarial network (GAN) architecture designed for the automated generation of species counterpoint, integrating strict rule-based constraints with data-driven stylistic nuance. The generator comprises a sequence-to-sequence model incorporating an attention mechanism, trained on a corpus of Fuxian counterpoint exercises annotated with error classifications. Critically, the discriminator is augmented with a symbolic rule-checker module, which penalizes violations of established species counterpoint rules (e.g., parallel octaves/fifths, dissonant leaps) alongside learning stylistic features from valid examples. This dual objective function ensures both formal correctness and musical plausibility. We evaluate the model's output across various species, demonstrating its capacity to produce stylistically coherent counterpoint while adhering to rigorous theoretical principles, surpassing the quality of purely data-driven or strictly rule-based generative systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Adversarial Learning for Species Counterpoint Generation: A Hybrid Model Integrating Rule-Based Constraints and Data-Driven Stylistic Nuance

text: This research investigates psychophysical thresholds for tonal fusion and perceived roughness within extended rational tuning systems, specifically focusing on microtonal intervals derived from prime limits beyond the conventional 5-limit. Employing a custom binaural beat paradigm, we generate precisely controlled synthetic stimuli to probe the perceptual boundaries of interval quality in highly complex harmonic environments. Participants evaluate synthesized dyads and chords based on their perceived degree of 'fusion' (integrating into a single percept) and 'roughness' (auditory beating and dissonance). Measurements of critical bandwidth and auditory streaming are correlated with subjective responses, illuminating how proximity to higher-order rational ratios affects perceptual grouping. Findings contribute to a refined understanding of cross-cultural psychoacoustics, offering empirical data for advanced tuning theory and informing computational models of consonance/dissonance in non-standard temperaments.
subject: Müzik
title: Psychophysical Thresholds of Tonal Fusion and Roughness in Extended Rational Tuning Systems: A Binaural Beat-Based Investigation

text: This paper introduces a framework for semantic aural sketching in algorithmic composition, enabling composers to manipulate timbres directly via high-level perceptual attributes rather than low-level synthesis parameters. We utilize a multi-modal deep learning architecture, specifically a conditional variational autoencoder (CVAE), to map subjective linguistic descriptors (e.g., 'metallic', 'warm', 'jagged', 'smooth') onto a latent space that simultaneously controls intricate parameters of granular and waveguide synthesis engines. The CVAE is trained on a meticulously annotated dataset linking perceptual ratings of synthesized sounds to their underlying parameter configurations. This latent space acts as an intuitive interface, allowing real-time exploration and interpolation across timbral dimensions. The system facilitates rapid prototyping of novel soundscapes and provides a powerful tool for bridging abstract compositional intent with concrete sonic realization, extending human-computer creativity in music.
subject: Müzik
title: Latent Space Mapping of Perceptual Attributes to Timbral Synthesis Parameters for Semantic Aural Sketching in Algorithmic Composition

text: This research introduces a novel deep learning framework utilizing Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) for the automated hierarchical melodic reduction inherent in Schenkerian analysis. We propose a multi-stage architecture where initial layers process localized pitch and rhythmic features, subsequently feeding into a graph convolutional network that models inter-note relationships and prolonged structural functions. The model learns to identify foreground, middleground, and background strata by optimizing a loss function informed by expert-annotated reduction graphs, leveraging techniques like attention mechanisms to weigh structural significance. Furthermore, we explore a generative adversarial approach to enhance the robustness and plausibility of generated Urlinie and Bassbrechung structures. Experimental results demonstrate a significant advancement in computational Schenkerian analysis, exhibiting high concordance with human expert reductions and illuminating latent hierarchical dependencies in tonal repertoires, thereby providing a powerful tool for large-scale analytical studies.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Graph-Based Neural Networks for Automated Hierarchical Melodic Reduction in Schenkerian Analysis

text: This study investigates the psychoacoustic perception of microtonal intervals arising from extended just intonation systems, with a particular focus on the spectral implications of inharmonicity. Utilizing high-resolution spectral analysis, we characterize the overtone series deviations in synthesized and acoustically generated microtonal aggregates, employing techniques such as phase vocoding and partial tracking to resolve fine-grained frequency and amplitude modulations. Perceptual experiments, involving forced-choice discrimination tasks and continuous response paradigms, assess consonance/dissonance judgments and melodic contour resolution in listeners exposed to stimuli exhibiting controlled degrees of spectral stretch and compression. Our findings reveal significant correlations between specific patterns of inharmonicity and altered critical band interactions, influencing auditory scene analysis and pitch fusion thresholds, thereby challenging conventional models of tonal stability and offering insights into the underlying mechanisms of microtonal perception.
subject: Müzik
title: Psychoacoustic Correlates of Microtonal Inharmonicity in Extended Just Intonation Spectra

text: We present a novel multimodal transformer architecture for contextualized music emotion recognition (MER), integrating deep acoustic features with concurrent physiological signals (e.g., electrodermal activity, heart rate variability). The framework employs parallel self-attention mechanisms to independently encode temporal dependencies within high-dimensional spectral, temporal, and rhythmic acoustic descriptors derived from raw audio, alongside physiological indicators. Subsequently, a cross-modal attention layer fuses these representations, allowing for dynamic weighting of inter-modal relevance in predicting valence and arousal dimensions. Our model leverages contrastive learning for self-supervised pre-training on unlabeled data, enhancing robust feature extraction. Evaluation on a meticulously annotated dataset demonstrates superior performance compared to unimodal baselines and conventional fusion techniques, highlighting the critical role of embodied physiological responses in refining perceived emotional states from musical stimuli and advancing affect-driven MIR systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Multimodal Transformers for Contextualized Music Emotion Recognition via Acoustic and Physiological Fusion

text: This research develops a comprehensive framework for quantifying rhythmic predictability and complexity, integrating entropic information theory with models of neural entrainment dynamics. We compute multiple entropy measures (e.g., Shannon, conditional, approximate entropy) over inter-onset interval sequences to characterize the uncertainty and redundancy inherent in rhythmic patterns across diverse musical corpora. Concurrently, we simulate neural oscillator networks, parameterizing their entrainment fidelity and phase coherence to these rhythmic stimuli. Our methodology establishes a direct link between information-theoretic metrics of rhythmic structure and the computational load associated with auditory predictive coding mechanisms. Results indicate that optimal rhythmic complexity maximizes an inverted-U relationship with neural entrainment, suggesting a sweet spot for cognitive engagement and perceptual fluency. This work contributes to understanding the cognitive basis of rhythmic perception and its implications for algorithmic composition and therapeutic applications.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Rhythmic Predictability and Complexity Through Entropic Information Theory and Neural Entrainment Dynamics

text: We propose a novel variational autoencoder-generative adversarial network (VAE-GAN) architecture for high-fidelity timbre synthesis and fine-grained perceptual control. The model learns a disentangled latent representation by enforcing orthogonality constraints and utilizing adversarial training to separate perceptually relevant timbre attributes (e.g., spectral centroid, odd-even harmonic balance, attack transients) from irrelevant variations. A conditional GAN decoder reconstructs raw audio waveforms from these controlled latent vectors, enabling precise manipulation of timbral qualities beyond simple spectral modifications. Perceptual evaluation, conducted through MUSHRA-style listening tests and semantic differential scales, confirms the intuitive navigability of the latent space and the high perceptual quality of synthesized timbres across diverse instrumental families. This framework offers significant advancements for real-time sound design, adaptive audio rendering, and deep analysis of timbral perception.
subject: Müzik
title: High-Fidelity Timbre Synthesis and Perceptual Control via Disentangled Latent Spaces in VAE-GAN Architectures

text: This study leverages Topological Data Analysis (TDA), specifically persistent homology, for robust, multiscale structural segmentation and hierarchical analysis of musical form. We construct a metric space from self-similarity matrices derived from various feature representations (e.g., chroma, MFCCs, spectral flux) extracted from musical audio. By computing persistent homology on Rips or Vietoris-Rips filtrations of this space, we identify significant topological features (e.g., connected components, cycles) that correspond to boundaries between musical sections (e.g., phrases, themes, movements). The persistence diagrams then reveal the salience and lifespan of these structural units across different scales of observation, obviating the need for explicit thresholding. Our methodology robustly uncovers nested formal organizations in diverse repertoires, offering a mathematically rigorous and parameter-light approach to computational musicology, significantly improving upon traditional novelty detection and clustering methods.
subject: Müzik
title: Persistent Homology for Multiscale Structural Segmentation and Hierarchical Analysis of Musical Form

text: This research proposes a quantum cognition model to explain contextual modulations and ambivalence in tonal harmony, extending traditional neo-Riemannian transformational theory. We represent pitch classes and harmonic functions as quantum states in a multi-dimensional Hilbert space, where musical contexts induce basis rotations and superposition. Harmonic progressions are modeled as sequential measurements that collapse probabilistic wave functions, reflecting the listener's dynamic interpretation of tonal functionality. The model quantitatively predicts "quantum-like" phenomena such as interference effects in chord perception and non-commutativity in sequential transformations, which are empirically difficult to reconcile with classical cognitive models. By incorporating principles of quantum entanglement and contextual probability, our framework offers a robust mathematical description of the cognitive processes underlying harmonic ambiguity and the flexible interpretation of tonal relationships, providing novel insights into the computational mechanisms of musical understanding.
subject: Müzik
title: A Quantum Cognition Model for Contextual Modulations in Tonal Harmony and Neo-Riemannian Transformations

text: This study develops a high-resolution partial tracking methodology for the precise acoustic reconstruction and subsequent psychoacoustic evaluation of historical temperaments. Employing advanced sinusoidal modeling and spectral peak detection algorithms, we accurately extract time-varying frequency and amplitude trajectories of individual partials from monophonic and polyphonic instrumental recordings. This granular spectral information is then used to synthesize digital replicas exhibiting the exact inharmonicity characteristics and beat phenomena prescribed by historical tuning systems (e.g., Pythagorean, Meantone, Well Temperaments). Perceptual listening tests, involving expert musicians and naive listeners, assess the perceived consonance, stability, and melodic clarity across these reconstructed temperaments. Our findings quantify the subtle psychoacoustic impacts of historical tuning practices, demonstrating their profound influence on musical aesthetics and providing a novel analytical lens for historical musicology and performance practice.
subject: Müzik
title: High-Resolution Partial Tracking for Acoustic Reconstruction and Psychoacoustic Evaluation of Historical Temperaments

text: We present a deep learning framework for interactive music source separation and expressive control, based on learning disentangled representations of musical audio. Utilizing a cascaded variational autoencoder (VAE) architecture with adversarial regularization, the model learns to isolate latent factors corresponding to instrument identity, pitch, timbre, and expressive gestures (e.g., vibrato, articulation) from polyphonic mixtures. A robust inference network performs real-time source separation, projecting mixed audio into these independent latent spaces. Crucially, the disentangled nature of these representations enables intuitive, fine-grained manipulation of individual source attributes post-separation, allowing users to modify a specific instrument's timbre or performance nuances without affecting other components. Our system advances both the fidelity of source separation for complex musical textures and opens new paradigms for creative audio synthesis and performance interaction, demonstrated via a novel graphical interface.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Disentangled Representations for Interactive Music Source Separation and Expressive Control

text: This research investigates the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying rhythmic expectation and the processing of irregularities, focusing on the interplay between predictive coding and neural oscillations. We employ electroencephalography (EEG) to measure event-related potentials (ERPs) and oscillatory dynamics (e.g., delta, theta, alpha, beta bands) in response to sequences containing manipulated metrical expectations and unexpected rhythmic deviations. Our hypothesis posits that rhythmic regularity elicits robust phase-locking of neural oscillations, facilitating top-down predictive coding mechanisms. Violations of these predictions are hypothesized to trigger prediction error signals, manifested as distinct ERP components (e.g., MMN, P3a) and shifts in phase-amplitude coupling. The findings elucidate how the brain utilizes oscillatory entrainment to build and update internal models of rhythmic structure, providing insights into the adaptive nature of auditory perception and its implications for music-based neurorehabilitation.
subject: Müzik
title: Predictive Coding and Neural Oscillations in the Anticipation and Resolution of Rhythmic Irregularities

text: This paper introduces a novel framework, the Causal-VAE-RL, for robust policy learning in environments characterized by complex spatiotemporal dynamics and inherent confounding biases. By integrating Structural Causal Models (SCMs) with disentangled Variational Autoencoders (VAEs), our approach learns a causal latent representation that explicitly separates state features into causes, effects, and confounders. This disentanglement facilitates interventions at the causal level, enabling counterfactual reasoning for policy evaluation and improvement. We demonstrate that conditioning policy optimization on these deconfounded representations significantly enhances robustness to spurious correlations and improves transferability across environmental shifts. Empirical results on challenging control tasks with high-dimensional observations show superior performance compared to state-of-the-art model-free and model-based RL methods, particularly in scenarios requiring generalization beyond observational data distributions. The Causal-VAE-RL provides a principled pathway toward more interpretable and robust sequential decision-making systems.
subject: AI
title: Deconfounding Spatiotemporal Dynamics in Reinforcement Learning via Structured Causal Variational Autoencoders

text: Multimodal foundation models exhibit remarkable emergent capabilities but often suffer from catastrophic forgetting during continual pre-training in evolving data streams. This work proposes a novel Low-Rank Continual Adaptation (LoRCA) framework, extending parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) techniques to mitigate knowledge erosion while enabling rapid adaptation to new modalities and tasks.
