LoRCA leverages low-rank updates to a small subset of model parameters, specifically focusing on cross-attention mechanisms and modality-specific encoders, significantly reducing computational overhead and memory footprint associated with full model updates. By dynamically allocating and regularizing these low-rank matrices based on task relevance and knowledge distillation losses, our method effectively balances knowledge retention of previous tasks with the acquisition of new information. Extensive experiments on a suite of dynamic multimodal benchmarks demonstrate that LoRCA outperforms existing continual learning strategies, maintaining high performance across diverse modalities with superior parameter efficiency.
subject: AI
title: Low-Rank Adaptation for Continual Pre-training of Multimodal Foundation Models in Dynamic Environments

text: Offline Reinforcement Learning (RL) presents a formidable challenge due to distributional shift between the static dataset and the learned policy's visitation. This paper introduces a novel framework, Robust Distributional Offline Policy Optimization (RD-OPO), which addresses this by explicitly modeling distributional uncertainty within the Bellman operator and integrating an adversarial training paradigm. RD-OPO employs a critic that learns a distribution over Q-values, leveraging Wasserstein distances to quantify and minimize the discrepancy between estimated and target return distributions. Furthermore, a learnable adversary perturbs state-action pairs to explore regions of high uncertainty and drive the policy away from unreliable out-of-distribution (OOD) actions. This implicit regularization induces a conservative yet robust policy. Empirical evaluations across diverse D4RL benchmarks demonstrate that RD-OPO significantly outperforms state-of-the-art offline RL algorithms in terms of both sample efficiency and robustness to data quality variations.
subject: AI
title: Adversarially Robust Offline Reinforcement Learning with Distributional Uncertainty-Aware Policy Optimization

text: Predicting dynamic events in complex relational systems, such as social networks or biological pathways, necessitates modeling high-order interactions and temporal dependencies. This paper introduces a novel Spatio-Temporal Hypergraph Neural Network (ST-HGNN) that effectively captures both within-group multi-order relationships and their evolution over time. ST-HGNN represents entities and their interactions as a sequence of dynamic hypergraphs, where hyperedges capture complex group-level associations. A message-passing mechanism aggregates information across varying hyperedge cardinalities, while a recurrent neural network component processes temporal sequences of hypergraph embeddings. We incorporate an attention mechanism to weigh the influence of different spatio-temporal contexts, enhancing predictive power for future events. Experiments on several real-world datasets involving dynamic group interactions and event forecasting tasks demonstrate that ST-HGNN significantly outperforms conventional graph neural networks and time-series models, showcasing its capacity to uncover intricate patterns in evolving hypergraph structures.
subject: AI
title: Spatio-Temporal Hypergraph Neural Networks for Dynamic Event Prediction in Complex Relational Systems

text: Federated Learning (FL) faces critical challenges in preserving privacy while maintaining model utility, particularly with non-IID client data distributions. This work proposes a novel framework for Differentially Private Federated Learning (DPFL) that synergistically combines adaptive client sampling with latent representation alignment to enhance performance on non-IID datasets. Our approach dynamically weights client contributions based on their data distribution characteristics and model gradient divergence, ensuring more representative global aggregation. Crucially, we introduce a privacy-preserving mechanism for aligning client-side latent feature spaces, mitigating client drift caused by local model optimization on diverse data. By integrating a carefully calibrated differentially private aggregation layer, the framework achieves robust privacy guarantees without severely compromising accuracy. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method significantly improves upon existing DPFL algorithms in terms of both privacy-utility trade-offs and convergence speed under challenging non-IID data regimes.
subject: AI
title: Differentially Private Federated Learning with Adaptive Client Sampling and Latent Representation Alignment for Non-IID Data

text: Automating scientific discovery requires systems capable of both learning from data and generating interpretable, generalizable hypotheses. This paper presents Neuro-Symbolic Program Synthesis (NSPS), a novel framework for inductive program synthesis guided by deep neural abstractions, aimed at generating scientific hypotheses in the form of symbolic programs. NSPS leverages a neural module to learn expressive, low-dimensional representations from raw experimental data, which then inform and constrain the search space of a symbolic program synthesizer. By incorporating differentiable components that bridge the neural and symbolic domains, our system iteratively refines both the data abstraction and the candidate symbolic programs. This synergy enables NSPS to synthesize human-readable programs that represent underlying scientific laws or mechanisms, demonstrating superior generalizability and interpretability compared to purely neural or purely symbolic methods. We validate NSPS on tasks involving inferring physical laws and biological interactions from observed data.
subject: AI
title: Inductive Program Synthesis Guided by Neural Abstraction for Automated Scientific Hypothesis Generation

text: Generating robust and plausible counterfactual explanations for predictions from complex multimodal generative models remains a significant challenge, particularly in high-stakes domains. This paper introduces a novel method that leverages latent space interventions within multimodal variational autoencoders (M-VAEs) to synthesize coherent counterfactuals. Our approach identifies crucial latent dimensions influencing a specific model output and constructs minimal, causally-informed perturbations in these dimensions. By employing causal proxies inferred from observational data, we ensure that generated counterfactuals adhere to realistic data distributions and satisfy both proximity to the original input and validity with respect to the desired counterfactual outcome. This method specifically addresses the coherence problem in multimodal explanations, ensuring that changes in one modality are consistently reflected across others. Empirical evaluations demonstrate the generation of high-fidelity and semantically meaningful counterfactuals for image-text and audio-video models, providing enhanced transparency for complex decision-making processes.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Explanations for Multimodal Generative Models via Latent Space Perturbations and Causal Proxies

text: Combinatorial optimization problems with intricate graph-theoretic constraints are notoriously intractable for classical algorithms. This work proposes a Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) approach to address such problems, specifically targeting the Maximum Cut (MaxCut) problem with additional connectivity requirements. We develop a novel ansatz design that inherently encodes the graph structure and enforces connectivity constraints through penalty terms in the Hamiltonian. Our parameterized quantum circuit architecture leverages problem-specific symmetries to reduce circuit depth and parameter count, enhancing suitability for noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices. The classical optimization loop iteratively refines the ansatz parameters, minimizing the expectation value of the Hamiltonian. We demonstrate the efficacy of our VQE formulation on various graph instances, showing its potential to find near-optimal solutions, outperforming classical heuristic benchmarks and providing a path toward quantum advantage for complex constrained optimization.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Eigensolver for Combinatorial Optimization with Graph-Theoretic Constraints

text: Accurate prediction of protein structures and their interaction with small-molecule ligands is pivotal for drug discovery and molecular biology. This paper introduces an E(3)-equivariant geometric deep learning framework, GeoFold-Binder, designed for de novo protein structure prediction and simultaneous ligand binding affinity estimation. GeoFold-Binder operates directly on 3D atomic coordinates and biochemical features, employing a novel message-passing neural network that respects Euclidean symmetries. This allows for robust learning of protein folding dynamics and intricate protein-ligand interaction patterns. The model predicts the 3D backbone and side-chain conformations while also outputting a binding score for candidate ligands, bypassing traditional docking simulations. Benchmarking on CASP and PDBbind datasets demonstrates that GeoFold-Binder achieves state-of-the-art accuracy in both structure prediction and binding affinity estimation, offering a unified, end-to-end approach with significant implications for high-throughput drug screening and protein engineering.
subject: AI
title: Geometric Deep Learning for De Novo Protein Structure Prediction and Ligand Binding Affinity Estimation

text: Deploying high-performance deep neural networks on resource-constrained edge devices necessitates simultaneous optimization of multiple, often conflicting, objectives such as accuracy, latency, memory footprint, and energy consumption. This paper presents Pareto-NAS-Edge, a novel Neural Architecture Search (NAS) framework that discovers Pareto-optimal architectures for heterogeneous edge hardware targets. We formulate the search problem as a multi-objective reinforcement learning task, where an agent learns to generate network architectures optimized for specific hardware constraints. A key innovation is the integration of a highly accurate, hardware-aware latency prediction model that guides the search process efficiently, obviating expensive on-device evaluations. Pareto-NAS-Edge employs an evolutionary search strategy combined with an explicit Pareto front maintenance mechanism to explore the trade-off landscape effectively. Extensive experiments on diverse edge AI benchmarks demonstrate that Pareto-NAS-Edge significantly outperforms existing NAS methods by identifying superior architectures that achieve better accuracy-latency-memory trade-offs.
subject: AI
title: Pareto-Optimal Neural Architecture Search for Edge Devices via Multi-Objective Reinforcement Learning and Latency Prediction

text: This paper investigates the Turan problem for k-uniform hypergraphs H that do not contain a copy of the complete k-uniform hypergraph K_r^(k) and possess a bounded independence number α(H) ≤ c. We establish novel lower bounds for the maximum number of edges ex(n, K_r^(k)) under this additional constraint, particularly for k ≥ 3. Our methodology employs a sophisticated combination of the density increment method and regularity lemma arguments, adapted for higher uniformity. We demonstrate that for certain regimes of r and c, the traditional Turan number is significantly perturbed, revealing a richer structural landscape. Specifically, we provide explicit constructions leveraging finite field geometries to achieve these bounds, challenging long-standing conjectures regarding the generalized Turan problem in sparse settings.
subject: Matematik
title: Sharp Asymptotic Bounds for k-Uniform Hypergraphs Avoiding Cliques with Bounded Independence Number

text: We analyze the emergence of complex graph properties within the context of locally sparse random hypergraphs G(n, p, k), focusing on the k-uniform setting. Our primary contribution is the precise determination of threshold functions for the existence of non-trivial H-minors and specific induced subhypergraphs with high girth. Employing a refined second moment method, coupled with martingale concentration inequalities tailored for dependencies arising from local sparsity, we establish sharp phase transitions. The analysis extends to the identification of the giant component structure and its critical exponent in these random models, offering insights into their robustness against random perturbations. This work provides a unified framework for understanding the interplay between local density and global structural properties in high-dimensional random graph models.
subject: Matematik
title: Threshold Phenomena for Graph Properties in Locally Sparse Random Hypergraphs

text: This research delves into the combinatorial properties of q-analogues of Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials associated with affine root systems of type Ã•_n-1. We provide a novel interpretation of their coefficients as generating functions for certain decorated permutations, extending known results for finite types. A central result is a new proof of Schur positivity for a class of symmetric functions arising from the character theory of quantum groups, utilizing a sophisticated application of the Littlewood-Richardson rule and crystal bases theory. This approach unveils deep connections between representation theory, canonical bases, and enumerative combinatorics, offering new perspectives on the structure constants of the Hall algebra and paving the way for further generalizations to other Lie types.
subject: Matematik
title: Schur Positivity and the q-Analogue of Kazhdan-Lusztig Polynomials for Affine Root Systems

text: We present quantitative improvements to Behrend's construction of large sum-free sets in ℤ_N and extend its implications to higher-dimensional settings. By refining the parameter choices in Behrend's original method, based on sets of integers without arithmetic progressions, we derive sharper lower bounds on the size of sum-free subsets in ℤ_N^d. Our analysis leverages advanced techniques from Fourier analysis on finite groups and probabilistic methods to optimize the selection of "digit sets." This work contributes to the inverse problems of additive combinatorics, specifically addressing the structure of sets with restricted sums, and has ramifications for problems related to Salem-Spencer sets and density bounds for arithmetic progression-free sequences.
subject: Matematik
title: Quantitative Bounds for Behrend's Construction in Higher Dimensions and Sum-Free Sets

text: This paper generalizes the theory of impartial games to scenarios where moves can have probabilistic outcomes, modeling stochastic game states on directed acyclic graphs (DAGs). We develop a framework for computing expected Nim-sums and extending the concept of Grundy numbers (or nim-values) to accommodate these uncertainties. Our approach utilizes expectation operators and dynamic programming on the game DAG, yielding polynomial-time algorithms for calculating the expected nim-value for specific classes of games. This provides a robust theoretical foundation for analyzing and optimally playing stochastic combinatorial games, with potential applications in artificial intelligence and decision theory under risk, where traditional deterministic game theory falls short.
subject: Matematik
title: Nim-Sums and Grundy Numbers for Games on Directed Acyclic Graphs with Probabilistic Outcomes

text: We investigate the combinatorial topology of certain integral polytopes derived from classical root systems, specifically focusing on their regular unimodular triangulations. The central objective is to establish connections between the h-vector of these triangulations and the Ehrhart polynomial, shedding light on the integer point enumeration within dilations of these polytopes. Utilizing techniques from toric geometry and the theory of Hilbert series for graded rings, we derive explicit formulas for the h-vector in terms of specific combinatorial invariants of the associated hyperplane arrangements. This work contributes to the interplay between algebraic geometry, combinatorics of convex polytopes, and provides new insights into the enumeration of lattice points.
subject: Matematik
title: The h-Vector and Ehrhart Polynomials of Polytopes Arising from Root Systems and Triangulations

text: This paper presents a refined enumeration of permutations subject to specific positional descendant restrictions, a generalization of classical ascent/descent statistics. We develop a multivariate generating function framework, utilizing formal power series techniques and the method of exponential generating functions, to derive explicit formulas for the number of such permutations. Our approach involves the intricate interplay of inclusion-exclusion principles, combinatorial species, and the theory of linear recurrence relations with polynomial coefficients. The results extend beyond simple permutations to pattern-avoiding permutations with constrained cycle structures, offering new combinatorial identities and providing deeper insights into the enumerative properties of permutation classes relevant to algebraic combinatorics and theoretical computer science.
subject: Matematik
title: Refined Enumeration of Permutations with Restricted Positional Descendants via Multivariate Generating Functions

text: We explore the cryptomorphic characterizations of matroids, focusing on the interplay between their various axiomatic systems (e.g., independent sets, circuits, bases, flats, rank function). This work introduces a generalization of the Tutte polynomial, sensitive to additional structural properties beyond connectivity and graphicness, allowing for finer distinctions between non-isomorphic matroids. Specifically, we demonstrate how this generalized polynomial can uniquely identify specific minor-closed classes of matroids, particularly those related to projective planes over finite fields. The methodology combines results from oriented matroid theory, lattice theory, and delves into the structural decomposition of matroids using highly connected components, providing new invariants for matroid isomorphism.
subject: Matematik
title: Characterization of Cryptomorphic Classes of Matroids via Generalized Tutte Polynomials

text: This research addresses the challenging problem of determining generalized multicolor Ramsey numbers R_k(H_1, …, H_r) for k-uniform hypergraphs, where each H_i is subject to additional structural constraints such as bounded maximum degree or acyclicity. We establish novel lower and upper bounds using a combination of the probabilistic method, sophisticated graph constructions (e.g., Behrend's construction, finite field constructions), and iterated application of the Regularity Lemma for hypergraphs. Our focus is on the asymptotic behavior of these numbers, particularly for sparse target hypergraphs, demonstrating how structural constraints can significantly alter the growth rate compared to classical Ramsey numbers. This work deepens our understanding of unavoidable monochromatic substructures in highly structured discrete systems.
subject: Matematik
title: Generalized Multicolor Hypergraph Ramsey Numbers with Structural Constraints

text: This paper applies discrete Morse theory to the order complex of specific partially ordered sets (posets) arising from matroid theory, specifically the poset of bases ordered by a suitable local exchange property. We compute the homotopy type of these complexes, demonstrating that for certain classes of matroids (e.g., graphic matroids, uniform matroids), these complexes are contractible or have the homotopy type of a wedge of spheres. Our methodology involves constructing explicit discrete Morse functions whose critical cells correspond to well-defined combinatorial invariants. This work establishes a topological framework for understanding matroid structures, offering a new perspective on their combinatorial properties and connections to higher-dimensional topology.
subject: Matematik
title: Homotopy Type and Discrete Morse Theory for Posets of Matroid Bases

text: Histone demethylases profoundly influence cellular identity by shaping dynamic epigenomic landscapes. Our study delineates the precise molecular mechanisms by which KDM5B, a H3K4me3/me2 demethylase, orchestrates chromatin architecture and transcriptional plasticity crucial for maintaining naive pluripotency. Utilizing multi-omics approaches including Hi-C, ChIP-seq for active histone marks and transcription factors, and nascent RNA sequencing, we reveal that KDM5B depletion leads to aberrant H3K4me3 accumulation at super-enhancers, causing premature lineage priming. Mechanistically, KDM5B's catalytic activity is indispensable for the spatiotemporal regulation of specific enhancer-promoter long-range interactions, facilitated by its interaction with the Mediator complex subunit MED1. This intricate interplay dictates the stability of the pluripotent state by fine-tuning transcriptional burst kinetics of key developmental genes. Our findings establish KDM5B as a pivotal epigenetic rheostat in maintaining cell fate decisions, offering novel therapeutic avenues for regenerative medicine and oncogenesis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Deconstructing the Role of KDM5B in Enhancer-Promoter Looping and Transcriptional Plasticity in Naïve Pluripotency

text: The N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modification profoundly impacts mRNA fate, yet its role in regulating mRNA granule dynamics remains enigmatic. This study elucidates the mechanism by which the m6A reader protein YTHDF2 mediates the formation and resolution of stress granules (SGs) and processing bodies (P-bodies) via modulation of liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS). Through quantitative proteomics, cryo-electron microscopy, and single-molecule RNA imaging, we demonstrate that m6A-modified mRNAs preferentially localize to SGs, and YTHDF2 directly interacts with key SG components. Depletion of YTHDF2 leads to impaired SG assembly kinetics and compromised cellular stress responses, attributed to altered protein-RNA interaction networks and aberrant condensate properties. Furthermore, YTHDF2 promotes the disassembly of SGs by facilitating m6A-dependent mRNA decay within these structures. Our data position YTHDF2 as a critical modulator of epitranscriptomic-driven mRNA granule dynamics, providing a molecular link between RNA modification, cellular stress adaptation, and potential neurodegenerative pathophysiology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: N6-Methyladenosine (m6A) Reader YTHDF2 Regulates mRNA Granule Dynamics and Stress Response Through Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation Modulation

text: Targeted modulation of DNA methylation holds immense therapeutic potential, yet achieving locus-specific erasure without off-target effects remains challenging. We present a novel precision epigenome editing tool leveraging a catalytically-inactive Cas9 (dCas9) fused to the catalytic domain of Ten-Eleven Translocation 1 (TET1), guided by single guide RNAs (sgRNAs), to induce site-specific DNA demethylation. Through rigorous genome-wide profiling using whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) and reduced representation bisulfite sequencing (RRBS), we demonstrate robust and precise demethylation within promoter and enhancer regions, leading to targeted transcriptional reactivation of epigenetically silenced genes. This dCas9-TET1 system exhibits superior specificity and efficiency compared to conventional CRISPR-based epigenetic activators, with minimal bystander methylation changes. Our findings establish a powerful platform for dissecting the causal roles of DNA methylation in gene regulation and disease pathogenesis, offering a refined strategy for therapeutic epigenome reprogramming in conditions such as cancer and neurological disorders.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Precision Epigenome Editing with Catalytically-Inactive Cas9-TET1 Fusion for Site-Specific DNA Demethylation and Transcriptional Reactivation

text: Mitochondrial dysfunction and impaired protein quality control are hallmarks of neurodegenerative disorders, particularly Parkinson's Disease (PD). This study investigates the molecular mechanisms by which mutations in the E3 ubiquitin ligase Parkin, an RBR-family enzyme, compromise mitochondrial quality control and synaptic integrity in familial PD models. Using patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) neurons and genetically engineered mouse models, we demonstrate that pathogenic Parkin variants exhibit reduced ubiquitination activity towards canonical substrates such as Mfn2 and VDAC1, leading to impaired mitophagy initiation and accumulation of damaged mitochondria. Quantitative mass spectrometry-based proteomics reveals dysregulation of synaptic protein turnover, including SNARE complex components and presynaptic scaffolding proteins, contributing to observed synaptic dysfunction and neuronal vulnerability. Rescue experiments utilizing optogenetic activation of alternative mitophagy pathways ameliorate these phenotypes. Our findings underscore the critical role of Parkin's E3 ligase activity in maintaining neuronal proteostasis and mitochondrial health, providing novel therapeutic targets for PD.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dysregulated E3 Ubiquitin Ligase RBR-Family Parkin Contributes to Mitophagy Impairment and Synaptic Dysfunction in Familial Parkinson's Disease Models

text: Elucidating the intricate cellular architecture and intercellular communication within the developing human brain is paramount for understanding neurodevelopmental disorders. We present a comprehensive, spatially-resolved single-cell multi-omics atlas of the fetal human cortex, integrating single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq), single-nucleus ATAC sequencing (snATAC-seq), and spatial transcriptomics. Our analysis delineates novel cell states and trajectories across cortical layers and germinal zones, revealing a highly diverse population of progenitor cells and differentiating neurons. By correlating gene expression with chromatin accessibility in a spatial context, we identify distinct regulatory networks governing neurogenesis and gliogenesis in specific microenvironments. Furthermore, ligand-receptor interaction analyses uncover critical cell-cell communication pathways that define niche-specific developmental cues, particularly highlighting novel interactions between radial glia and intermediate progenitors. This unprecedented resource provides a foundational molecular framework for understanding human cortical development and identifies potential vulnerabilities in neurodevelopmental pathologies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatially-Resolved Single-Cell Multi-Omics Atlas Reveals Cellular Heterogeneity and Niche-Specific Interactions in the Developing Human Cortex

text: Mitochondrial quality control mechanisms, particularly mitophagy, are critical for metabolic homeostasis, yet their precise role in adipocyte function remains incompletely understood. Our investigation elucidates how the PINK1-Parkin pathway orchestrates metabolic reprogramming in adipocytes by selectively clearing dysfunctional mitochondrial subpopulations. Through advanced live-cell imaging, respiration assays, and isotope tracing coupled with quantitative mass spectrometry, we demonstrate that activation of PINK1-Parkin-mediated mitophagy in response to metabolic stress promotes a shift from oxidative phosphorylation to glycolysis, concomitantly enhancing lipid droplet formation and insulin sensitivity. This metabolic rewiring is contingent upon the targeted degradation of specific mitochondrial protein complexes, identified by differential proteomic analysis of mitophagosomes. Impairment of this selective mitophagy exacerbates mitochondrial heterogeneity and dysfunctional lipid metabolism, contributing to adipocyte insulin resistance. These findings reveal a nuanced role for PINK1-Parkin in fine-tuning adipocyte metabolism, offering novel therapeutic strategies for obesity and type 2 diabetes.
subject: Biyoloji
title: PINK1-Parkin-Mediated Mitophagy Drives Metabolic Reprogramming in Adipocytes through Selective Clearance of Subpopulations of Mitochondria

text: Senescent cells, characterized by a senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), contribute to aging and age-related pathologies. We report the development of a synthetic receptor system engineered to autonomously detect and selectively eliminate senescent cells. This system comprises a modular synthetic Notch (synNotch) receptor designed to recognize specific cell-surface markers upregulated in senescent cells (e.g., uPAR), coupled to an inducible apoptotic effector module (e.g., Caspase-3). Upon recognition of senescent cells, the synNotch receptor triggers the release of an intracellular domain, activating a transcriptional cascade that culminates in the expression of pro-apoptotic genes. In vitro and in vivo studies using murine models of accelerated aging demonstrate that systemic administration of cells harboring this synthetic circuit leads to significant reduction in senescent cell burden, alleviating inflammatory responses and improving tissue homeostasis without off-target cytotoxicity. This platform represents a paradigm shift in senotherapeutics, offering a precise and programmable approach to combat aging-related diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Engineering an Autonomous Synthetic Receptor System for Real-Time Detection and Targeted Elimination of Senescent Cells

text: Glycogen Synthase Kinase-3 Beta (GSK-3β) is a crucial, constitutively active kinase involved in diverse cellular processes, and its dysregulation is implicated in numerous pathologies, including Alzheimer's disease and diabetes. While active site inhibitors exist, allosteric modulation offers superior specificity and reduced off-target effects. Our study combines advanced computational modeling, hydrogen-deuterium exchange mass spectrometry (HDX-MS), and kinetic analysis to identify and characterize novel cryptic allosteric pockets on GSK-3β. We demonstrate that small molecule binding to these newly identified sites induces conformational changes propagating to the catalytic domain, leading to potent and selective inhibition or activation of kinase activity. Crucially, these allosteric modulators exhibit distinct pharmacological profiles compared to active-site inhibitors, selectively impacting specific downstream signaling pathways. This work unveils a complex allosteric regulatory network for GSK-3β, opening unprecedented avenues for developing highly selective therapeutics targeting specific pathological contexts while preserving essential physiological functions.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Elucidating the Allosteric Regulatory Network of Glycogen Synthase Kinase-3 Beta (GSK-3β) via Cryptic Pockets and Their Therapeutic Exploitation

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are emerging as critical regulators of gene expression, frequently by guiding chromatin-modifying complexes to specific genomic loci. This study focuses on ANRIL (Antisense Non-coding RNA in the INK4 Locus), a nuclear-retained lncRNA known to be highly implicated in oncogenesis and cardiovascular disease. Employing CRISPR-based RNA targeting, 3C/4C-seq, and proteomic profiling, we demonstrate that ANRIL directly interacts with and recruits Polycomb Repressor Complex 2 (PRC2) to the INK4/ARF tumor suppressor locus. This interaction facilitates the formation of higher-order chromatin loops, leading to robust H3K27me3 deposition and subsequent transcriptional silencing of key cell cycle inhibitors p15INK4b, p16INK4a, and ARF. Perturbation of ANRIL's association with PRC2 abrogates these chromatin contacts, resulting in derepression of the INK4/ARF locus and reduced cellular proliferation. Our findings uncover a precise molecular mechanism by which ANRIL acts as a scaffold for PRC2, establishing a critical link between lncRNA function, 3D genome organization, and tumor suppression.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Nuclear-Retained lncRNA, ANRIL, Directs Polycomb Repressor Complex 2 to Mediate Chromatin Looping and Gene Silencing at the INK4/ARF Locus

text: Viral pathogens frequently hijack host cellular machinery to evade immune surveillance and facilitate replication. This study dissects the intricate molecular mechanisms by which Herpes Simplex Virus 1 (HSV-1) immediate-early protein ICP0, a RING-finger E3 ubiquitin ligase, subverts host DNA damage response (DDR) pathways by mimicking human Cullin-RING Ligase 4 (CRL4) complexes. Through comprehensive quantitative proteomics and interaction mapping (e.g., AP-MS), we identify novel host substrates of ICP0, revealing its capacity to directly target key DDR components, including specific factors involved in homologous recombination and non-homologous end joining, for proteasomal degradation. This targeted ubiquitination not only disables intrinsic antiviral signaling but also generates a chromatin environment permissive for viral gene expression and robust lytic replication. Our findings highlight a sophisticated viral strategy of E3 ligase mimicry that compromises host genome integrity and antiviral defenses, offering critical insights into herpesviral pathogenesis and potential pan-herpesvirus therapeutic targets.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Viral E3 Ubiquitin Ligase Mimicry: Herpesvirus ICP0 Exploits Host CRL4 Substrates to Disable DNA Damage Response and Promote Lytic Replication

text: This paper introduces a novel regularization framework for estimating parameters in ultra-high dimensional Generalized Linear Models (GLMs) where covariates exhibit complex group and overlap structures. We propose a composite penalty that amalgamates hierarchical group Lasso and fused Lasso penalties, enabling simultaneous variable selection and structural learning. A majorized-proximal algorithm, coupled with an accelerated proximal gradient descent, is developed for efficient optimization, circumventing challenges posed by non-separability and non-smoothness. Theoretical guarantees establish the oracle properties of our estimator, including asymptotic consistency in variable selection and parameter estimation under diverging p-to-n ratios. Extensive simulations and real-world genomic data analyses demonstrate superior empirical performance in terms of prediction accuracy, sparsity recovery, and computational efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods, particularly in scenarios with heterogeneous group effects and high correlation.
subject: İstatistik
title: Scalable Regularization for Ultra-High Dimensional Generalized Linear Models with Grouped and Overlapping Covariates

text: We present a novel Bayesian nonparametric approach for modeling collections of dependent functional data, leveraging Gaussian Process Latent Variable Models (GP-LVMs). Our methodology posits that each functional observation is generated from a latent low-dimensional Gaussian process, whose parameters are themselves endowed with a Dirichlet process mixture prior. This hierarchical construction allows for flexible clustering of functional trajectories while simultaneously capturing complex intra-cluster dependencies and inter-cluster variations. Inference is conducted using an efficient collapsed Gibbs sampler augmented with slice sampling for the infinite-dimensional components. Theoretical properties, including the convergence of the posterior distribution and consistency in functional estimation, are derived under mild regularity conditions. Empirical evaluations on synthetic and neuroimaging datasets showcase the method's superior performance in functional clustering, denoising, and prediction compared to existing parametric and semi-parametric functional data analysis techniques.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Nonparametric Priors for Dependent Functional Data via Gaussian Process Latent Variable Models

text: This research addresses the pervasive challenge of estimating heterogeneous treatment effects in dynamic panel data settings, particularly in the presence of unobserved confounders and complex interaction dynamics. We propose a novel Counterfactual Generative Network (CFGN) framework, which synergistically integrates recurrent neural networks with adversarial learning principles. The CFGN learns to synthesize realistic counterfactual trajectories for treated units by mapping observed pre-treatment covariates and endogenous interactions onto a latent space, thereby deconfounding treatment assignment. This approach eschews parametric assumptions common in traditional difference-in-differences or synthetic control methods, offering enhanced flexibility for non-linear relationships and time-varying confounding. Rigorous theoretical analysis demonstrates identification under sequential ignorability assumptions, while extensive simulations and an application to macroeconomic policy evaluation underscore its robustness and superior performance in uncovering nuanced and dynamic treatment heterogeneity.
subject: İstatistik
title: Deconfounding Treatment Effects in Panel Data with Heterogeneous Impact Dynamics using Counterfactual Generative Networks

text: We investigate the fundamental limits and achievable rates of robust estimation in high-dimensional linear regression under joint presence of adversarial data contamination and heavy-tailed innovations. Our work introduces a novel estimator, the Trimmed and Tilted Huber Estimator (TTHE), which effectively combines data trimming strategies with a refined Huber loss function adapted for high dimensions. We establish minimax optimal rates of convergence for TTHE under various contamination models, demonstrating its resilience even when a constant fraction of observations are arbitrarily corrupted. Furthermore, we characterize its breakdown point, proving its superiority over conventional robust methods in extreme contamination scenarios. The theoretical analysis is buttressed by an efficient iterative optimization algorithm with convergence guarantees. Empirical studies on synthetic and real-world datasets, including financial returns and genomic measurements, validate TTHE's enhanced robustness and accuracy in outlier-prone high-dimensional environments.
subject: İstatistik
title: Minimax Optimal Robustness in High-Dimensional Regression under Adversarial Contamination and Heavy-Tailed Noise

text: This paper develops a novel framework for spatio-temporal modeling of processes observed on general Riemannian manifolds, leveraging intrinsic Gaussian Markov Random Fields (iGMRFs). We construct iGMRFs directly on triangulated manifold domains, exploiting the local geometric structure to define sparse precision matrices that accurately capture spatial dependencies while ensuring computational tractability for large datasets. The temporal evolution is governed by a state-space model, with the iGMRF serving as a flexible prior for the spatial state at each time step. An efficient approximate Bayesian inference scheme, based on integrated nested Laplace approximations (INLA) extended for manifold settings, is proposed for parameter estimation and prediction. Theoretical properties pertaining to the spectral decomposition of the precision operator on compact manifolds are established. Applications to geophysical and medical imaging data demonstrate superior predictive accuracy and computational scalability compared to Euclidean-based or dense covariance models, particularly for irregularly sampled data on complex geometries.
subject: İstatistik
title: Intrinsic Gaussian Markov Random Fields on Manifolds for Large-Scale Spatio-Temporal Data Assimilation

text: We introduce a novel class of operator-valued kernel methods for embedding stochastic processes into Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Spaces (RKHSs) of operator-valued functions. This framework generalizes scalar-valued kernel methods, allowing for direct comparisons and statistical learning on complex functional data while preserving their intrinsic operator structure. We develop a theory for positive definite operator-valued kernels, extending Mercer's theorem and Bochner's theorem to the operator setting. Conditions for the existence and uniqueness of the corresponding RKHS are established, alongside characterizations of universal operator kernels. Applications include non-parametric estimation of covariance operators, functional principal component analysis in operator spaces, and construction of advanced statistical tests for functional data. The methodology provides a principled means to quantify dependencies and build predictive models for high-dimensional and intrinsically functional observations, showcasing advantages in hypothesis testing for spectral properties of operators and functional classification tasks.
subject: İstatistik
title: Operator-Valued Kernel Methods for Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space Embeddings of Stochastic Processes

text: This research proposes a robust semiparametric joint model for simultaneously analyzing recurrent events and a terminal event in the presence of competing risks and time-varying covariates. Our framework comprises a proportional hazards model for the recurrent event intensity, a cause-specific proportional hazards model for the competing risks, and a novel frailty component that links these processes. This frailty captures shared unobserved heterogeneity, allowing for potentially complex dependencies between the recurrent process and the terminal event type. We employ a penalized maximum partial likelihood estimation approach for the baseline hazard functions and regression coefficients, ensuring flexibility while maintaining statistical efficiency. Asymptotic properties of the estimators, including consistency and asymptotic normality, are rigorously derived under mild regularity conditions. Extensive simulations and a substantive application to chronic disease progression data demonstrate the superior prognostic accuracy and unbiased estimation of treatment effects compared to models that analyze these processes separately or ignore competing risks.
subject: İstatistik
title: Semiparametric Joint Modeling of Competing Risks and Recurrent Events with Time-Varying Covariates

text: We develop a comprehensive spectral methodology for characterizing non-stationary multivariate point processes, extending the concept of Granger causality to the frequency domain for such data structures. Our approach models the intensity functions of the point processes using a local stationary framework, allowing their spectral properties to evolve over time. We introduce a time-varying spectral matrix for marked and un-marked point processes, providing a nuanced decomposition of interactions across different frequencies. A novel estimator for this localized spectrum is proposed, based on multitaper techniques adapted for irregularly spaced events. Furthermore, we define and estimate time-varying Granger causality measures in the frequency domain, enabling the identification of directional causal influences that vary in strength and nature across time and oscillatory bands. Theoretical consistency and asymptotic distribution of the proposed estimators are established. Applications to neuronal spike train data and financial transaction logs demonstrate the method's ability to reveal dynamic causal connectivity and event predictability.
subject: İstatistik
title: Spectral Analysis of Non-Stationary Multivariate Point Processes with Granger Causality in the Frequency Domain

text: This paper addresses the challenging problem of learning dynamic causal Bayesian network (DBN) structures from mixed-type longitudinal data, particularly when faced with latent confounding and time-varying relationships. We propose a two-stage approach. First, a latent variable model is integrated with a Gumbel-Softmax reparameterization trick to infer discrete latent confounders from the observed mixed-type variables. Second, we employ an score-based structure learning algorithm, utilizing a penalized likelihood function derived from a Gaussian copula for mixed data, combined with a structural expectation-maximization (SEM) framework to iteratively refine the DBN structure and estimate parameters while accounting for latent variables. The causal identifiability of dynamic effects is established through extensions of do-calculus for longitudinal settings. Extensive simulation studies and a real-world application in clinical genomics demonstrate superior performance in recovering true causal graphs and mitigating confounding bias compared to existing constraint-based or score-based methods for static networks or complete data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Structure Learning of Dynamic Causal Bayesian Networks from Mixed-Type Longitudinal Data with Latent Confounders

text: We introduce a novel Riemannian Manifold Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (RMHMC) algorithm tailored for efficient Bayesian inference in complex state-space models characterized by non-Gaussian likelihoods and intricate posterior geometries. The method leverages the Fisher information metric as a locally adaptive geometry, enabling Hamiltonian dynamics to traverse the posterior landscape more effectively, especially in high-dimensional parameter spaces. By constructing a differentiable approximation to the posterior for the metric computation, we circumvent intractable analytical derivations of the Riemannian metric. A robust numerical integration scheme, informed by geodesic flow on the manifold, ensures improved mixing and exploration properties compared to Euclidean HMC variants. Theoretical analysis establishes the ergodicity and detailed balance of the proposed RMHMC sampler. Empirical validations across various challenging state-space models, including those with heavy-tailed observation noise and non-linear dynamics, demonstrate significant gains in sampling efficiency, convergence speed, and effective sample size per gradient evaluation, particularly for highly correlated parameters.
subject: İstatistik
title: Riemannian Manifold Hamiltonian Monte Carlo for Bayesian Inference in State-Space Models with Non-Gaussian Likelihoods

text: Aberrant c-MYC expression is a hallmark of numerous malignancies, yet its precise regulation by the non-coding transcriptome remains incompletely understood. Here, we identify lnc-MYCIRS, a novel nuclear-retained long non-coding RNA, whose expression is highly correlated with c-MYC levels and tumor progression in colorectal carcinoma. Mechanistically, lnc-MYCIRS directly interacts with the RPB1 subunit of RNA Polymerase II and recruits the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex to the c-MYC promoter region. This interaction facilitates open chromatin configuration and enhances transcriptional elongation, thereby robustly upregulating c-MYC gene expression. Furthermore, knockdown of lnc-MYCIRS significantly attenuates cell proliferation, migration, and invasion in vitro, and suppresses tumor growth in xenograft models. Our findings delineate a sophisticated regulatory axis where lnc-MYCIRS acts as a crucial scaffold linking transcriptional machinery and epigenetic modifiers to fine-tune c-MYC oncogenic output, proposing lnc-MYCIRS as a promising therapeutic target for c-MYC-driven cancers.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Long Non-coding RNA lnc-MYCIRS Modulates c-MYC Oncogenic Activity via Direct Interaction with RNA Polymerase II and Chromatin Remodeling Complexes

text: Mitochondrial positioning is critical for cellular energy homeostasis and specialized functions, particularly in highly polarized cells like neurons. We investigated the role of Miro1, an outer mitochondrial membrane GTPase, in regulating mitochondrial trafficking and its impact on synaptic plasticity in cortical neurons. Genetic ablation of Miro1 in primary neuronal cultures resulted in impaired anterograde transport of mitochondria into dendritic spines, leading to localized ATP deficits. This energy paucity profoundly diminished activity-dependent potentiation of synaptic strength, as evidenced by reduced mEPSC frequency and amplitude, and altered spine morphology. Mechanistically, Miro1 deficiency abrogated interactions with the motor protein Kinesin-1, disrupting microtubule-dependent mitochondrial movement. Our data reveal a precise spatiotemporal regulation of mitochondrial distribution by Miro1, which is indispensable for maintaining synaptic energy demands and functional integrity of dendritic spines, providing novel insights into neuroenergetics and synaptopathies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Miro1-Mediated Mitochondrial Trafficking Orchestrates Localized ATP Supply and Dendritic Spine Plasticity in Cortical Neurons

text: Establishment and maintenance of cell identity are critically dependent on coordinated epigenetic landscapes. We explore the interplay between DNA methylation and histone modifications in regulating cell fate decisions. Our findings demonstrate a novel functional interaction between de novo DNA methyltransferase DNMT3A and the H3K27me3 demethylase KDM6A (JMJD3). Through comprehensive chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) and whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) analyses, we observed that KDM6A-mediated removal of repressive H3K27me3 marks at specific enhancer elements precedes and facilitates DNMT3A recruitment. This sequential epigenetic remodeling leads to targeted hypermethylation of CpG islands within these regions, thereby solidifying transcriptional repression of lineage-inappropriate genes during cellular differentiation. Disruption of this cooperative mechanism results in aberrant gene expression profiles and impaired differentiation potential. This work uncovers a hierarchical interplay between distinct epigenetic modifiers in orchestrating stable cell lineage commitment, offering new perspectives on developmental epigenetics and disease.
subject: Biyoloji
title: De Novo Methyltransferase DNMT3A Cooperates with H3K27 Demethylase KDM6A to Establish Cell Lineage-Specific Transcriptional Reprogramming

text: Macroautophagy, a conserved catabolic process, is critical for cellular homeostasis. Canonical macroautophagy initiation requires the ATG16L1 complex; however, recent evidence suggests alternative pathways. We delineate an ATG16L1-independent macroautophagy pathway initiated by the FIP200-ULK1 complex in response to specific proteotoxic stressors. This pathway is characterized by the direct recruitment of LC3 to nascent phagophores, bypassing the ATG5-ATG12-ATG16L1 conjugation system. Crucially, this alternative mechanism exhibits a heightened specificity for the degradation of expanded polyglutamine protein aggregates, such as huntingtin, and α-synuclein fibrils, compared to bulk cytoplasmic cargo. Disruption of this ATG16L1-independent route exacerbates aggregate accumulation and cellular toxicity. Our data identify a novel, selective macroautophagy pathway that is distinctly primed for handling specific forms of proteotoxicity, suggesting its potential as a therapeutic target for neurodegenerative disorders characterized by protein aggregation, and broadening our understanding of autophagic diversity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: ATG16L1-Independent Macroautophagy Initiated by FIP200-ULK1 Complex Exhibits Selective Degradation of Pathogenic Protein Aggregates

text: Precise spatiotemporal control over endogenous gene expression remains a significant challenge in molecular biology and gene therapy. Here, we present a novel optogenetic platform for reversible and inducible gene activation based on CRISPR-Cas9 technology. Our system employs a catalytically inactive Cas9 (dCas9) fused to a light-sensitive VP64 transcriptional activator and a domain that recruits chromatin-modifying enzymes, specifically histone acetyltransferases. Upon blue light illumination, dCas9 is recruited to targeted promoter regions via guide RNAs, inducing localized chromatin decompaction and robust transcriptional activation. This optical switch enables exquisite control over gene expression kinetics and magnitude in mammalian cells, with minimal off-target effects. We demonstrate its utility in diverse cell types for activating developmental genes and therapeutic transgenes, offering a versatile tool for probing gene regulatory networks and developing advanced gene therapies with unprecedented precision. This platform represents a significant advance in synthetic biology applications for manipulating cell fate and function.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Engineering Optogenetic Control of Endogenous Gene Expression via CRISPR-Cas9-Mediated Chromatin Decompaction

text: Tumor microenvironment (TME) heterogeneity is a critical determinant of therapeutic resistance in glioblastoma (GBM), yet its spatiotemporal molecular architecture remains largely uncharacterized at single-cell resolution. We present an integrative single-cell spatial multi-omics approach combining spatial transcriptomics with CITE-seq and ATAC-seq on patient-derived GBM samples. Our analysis reveals distinct cellular subpopulations within the TME, including novel states of tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) and reactive astrocytes, exhibiting unique transcriptional programs and chromatin accessibility landscapes. Crucially, spatially resolved data unveil specific topographical associations between these cell states and areas of hypoxia, angiogenesis, and immune exclusion. Network inference further identifies key regulons governing these spatially constrained cellular phenotypes, highlighting transcription factors like HIF1A and STAT3 as central orchestrators of TME remodeling. This high-resolution molecular atlas provides unprecedented insights into GBM TME complexity, identifying potential therapeutic vulnerabilities and biomarker candidates for personalized GBM treatment strategies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrative Single-Cell Spatial Multi-Omics Reveals Heterogeneous Regulatory Programs Driving Tumor Microenvironment Remodeling in Glioblastoma

text: Post-transcriptional modifications, particularly N6-methyladenosine (m6A), critically modulate gene expression and cell function. We investigated the role of the m6A 'reader' protein YTHDF2 in the maintenance and function of regulatory T cells (Tregs), which are crucial for immune tolerance. Our studies reveal that YTHDF2 is highly expressed in Tregs and its deletion leads to significant alterations in Treg suppressive capacity. Mechanistically, YTHDF2 selectively binds to m6A-modified mRNAs encoding key immunosuppressive molecules, including CTLA-4, PD-1, and FOXP3, accelerating their degradation. This destabilization pathway fine-tunes the expression levels of these proteins, impacting Treg stability and function. Consequently, YTHDF2-deficient Tregs exhibit enhanced expression of these targets, correlating with impaired suppressive activity in vivo. These findings establish YTHDF2 as a pivotal regulator of Treg homeostasis and immune checkpoint molecule expression via mRNA decay, offering novel targets for immunomodulatory therapies in autoimmunity and cancer.
subject: Biyoloji
title: N6-Methyladenosine (m6A) Reader YTHDF2 Regulates mRNA Stability of Key Immunosuppressive Molecules in Regulatory T Cells

text: Maintenance of proteostasis is paramount for neuronal health, and its disruption is central to neurodegenerative diseases. We explored the role of chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA) in the clearance of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates, a hallmark of Parkinson's disease (PD). Our data demonstrate a specific defect in CMA activity in induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-derived dopaminergic neurons from sporadic PD patients and in α-syn overexpressing cell models. This impairment is not due to reduced expression of lysosomal receptors like LAMP2A, but rather to a compromised lysosomal membrane integrity and reduced proteolytic capacity, leading to inefficient translocation and degradation of CMA substrates. Crucially, pharmacological restoration of lysosomal acidification or enhancement of CMA flux significantly mitigates α-syn accumulation and associated neurotoxicity. These findings highlight selective lysosomal dysfunction as a critical contributing factor to α-syn pathogenesis via CMA impairment, positioning lysosomal modulators as promising therapeutic avenues for PD.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Selective Impairment of Chaperone-Mediated Autophagy via Lysosomal Dysfunction Contributes to Alpha-Synuclein Pathogenesis in Parkinson's Disease Models

text: The Wnt signaling pathway, particularly its non-canonical planar cell polarity (PCP) branch, is increasingly recognized for its role in cancer progression independent of β-catenin. We investigated the contribution of Wnt/PCP signaling to epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT), a critical driver of breast cancer metastasis. Our studies reveal that activation of Wnt/PCP, specifically through ROR1/ROR2 receptor engagement, orchestrates a robust EMT program characterized by E-cadherin repression and vimentin upregulation. Mechanistically, this occurs via a Dishevelled-dependent activation of the small GTPase RhoA, leading to profound actin cytoskeletal rearrangements and increased cellular invasiveness. Furthermore, RhoA activation synergizes with transcription factor AP-1 to remodel the epigenome at EMT-related gene loci, driving transcriptional reprogramming. Inhibition of Wnt/PCP components or RhoA significantly attenuates metastatic potential in vivo. This work defines a non-canonical Wnt/PCP-RhoA axis as a crucial regulator of EMT, offering novel therapeutic targets for metastatic breast cancer.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Non-Canonical Wnt/PCP Signaling Regulates Epithelial-Mesenchymal Transition through RhoA-Mediated Cytoskeletal Remodeling and Transcriptional Reprogramming in Breast Cancer Metastasis

text: Prime editing (PE) offers unparalleled versatility for precise, targeted genomic modifications without double-strand breaks. However, its efficiency and fidelity remain areas for optimization. We report a significant advance in PE technology through the rational engineering of the Cas9-reverse transcriptase (RT) fusion protein and targeted modulation of endogenous DNA repair pathways. By introducing specific mutations within the PE2 reverse transcriptase domain, we enhanced its processivity and template-dependent polymerization fidelity, minimizing off-target insertions and deletions. Concurrently, transient suppression of specific mismatch repair (MMR) components significantly increased prime editing efficiency at diverse genomic loci by skewing repair outcomes towards the desired edited strand. This integrated approach achieves unprecedented editing efficiency and precision, expanding the therapeutic applicability of prime editing for correcting a wide spectrum of pathogenic mutations. Our optimized PE system represents a powerful tool for next-generation gene therapy and fundamental genomic research.
subject: Biyoloji
title: High-Fidelity Prime Editing Achieved through Engineered Reverse Transcriptase and DNA Repair Pathway Modulation for Precise Genomic Interventions

text: The precise spatiotemporal regulation of chromatin architecture is paramount for pluripotent stem cell maintenance and lineage commitment. Here, we delineate the context-dependent mechanisms by which the histone H3K27me3 demethylase KDM6B orchestrates transcriptional programs during neural differentiation. Employing integrated ChIP-seq, ATAC-seq, and single-cell RNA-seq, we reveal that KDM6B exhibits dynamic nuclear localization and differential interactome profiles, influencing distinct sets of developmental regulatory genes. Our data demonstrate that KDM6B not only actively removes repressive H3K27me3 marks at bivalent promoters but also cooperates with pioneer transcription factors to establish de novo enhancers, thereby facilitating chromatin accessibility and driving the expression of neurogenic determinants. Pharmacological inhibition of KDM6B abrogates neurogenesis and perturbs neuronal network formation, underscoring its critical role in resolving developmental plasticity. These findings provide a high-resolution understanding of KDM6B's versatile epigenetic regulatory functions beyond simple demethylation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Deciphering the Epigenetic Code: A Multi-Omic Analysis of Histone H3K27me3 Demethylase KDM6B's Context-Dependent Chromatin Remodeling in Stem Cell Differentiation

text: Circular RNAs (circRNAs) are emerging as critical post-transcriptional regulators, yet their precise mechanisms in cardiovascular pathologies remain largely uncharacterized. This study elucidates a novel role for circMYO in the pathogenesis of myocardial hypertrophy. We demonstrate that circMYO acts as a molecular sponge for the RNA-binding protein (RBP) HuR, preventing its association with target mRNA 3'-UTRs, specifically those encoding contractile proteins and calcium handling enzymes. Through high-throughput RNA immunoprecipitation sequencing (RIP-seq) and CRISPR/Cas9-mediated deletion of circMYO in cardiomyocytes, we observed significant alterations in mRNA stability and translation efficiency of HuR targets. Functional assays revealed that circMYO depletion exacerbates hypertrophic responses, characterized by increased cell size, ANP/BNP expression, and impaired sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ ATPase activity. This work uncovers a sophisticated circRNA-RBP axis dictating cardiac protein synthesis and stability, providing potential therapeutic targets for heart disease.
subject: Biyoloji
title: CircRNA-Mediated Sequestration of RBP-RNA Complexes Governs Post-Transcriptional Gene Expression in Myocardial Hypertrophy

text: G-quadruplex (G4) DNA structures are pervasive in oncogene promoters and telomeres, representing promising therapeutic targets. However, the precise mechanisms by which G4-resolving helicases and ligases maintain genome integrity and influence transcriptional activity remain underexplored. This study employs single-molecule fluorescence resonance energy transfer (smFRET) and advanced cryo-electron microscopy to dissect the conformational landscape of LIG1, a key DNA ligase implicated in G4 metabolism. We reveal that LIG1 undergoes a series of dynamic structural transitions upon G4 recognition, exhibiting distinct intermediate states critical for strand ligation fidelity. Pharmacological modulation of these allosteric sites with novel small-molecule inhibitors selectively alters LIG1's G4-resolving activity, leading to persistent DNA damage and enhanced apoptosis in cancer cells but not in healthy counterparts. Our findings establish a structural basis for LIG1's G4-processing functions and provide a blueprint for developing highly specific G4-targeting therapeutics.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Unraveling the Conformational Dynamics of G-Quadruplex DNA Ligases: Implications for Selective Inhibition and Therapeutic Development

text: Cellular mechanotransduction, the conversion of mechanical stimuli into biochemical signals, fundamentally governs cell fate and tissue homeostasis. While the role of the cytoskeleton in force transmission is established, the nuclear response to mechanical cues, particularly through the nuclear envelope (NE), remains elusive. Here, we demonstrate that Filamin-A (FLNA), an actin-binding protein, directly interacts with Lamin A/C within the nucleoskeleton, mediating mechanical force transmission from the actin cortex to the chromatin. Live-cell imaging and super-resolution microscopy reveal FLNA's dynamic recruitment to areas of high nuclear strain, initiating localized NE invaginations and subsequent alterations in chromatin compaction. Loss of FLNA perturbs nuclear mechanics, impairs transcriptional responses to substrate stiffness, and abrogates stem cell differentiation under mechanical stress. This study uncovers a novel FLNA-Lamin axis that directly couples cytoskeletal forces to nuclear architecture and gene expression, providing crucial insights into mechanoregulation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatiotemporal Regulation of Mechanotransduction by Filamin-A in Nuclear Envelope Remodeling and Chromatin Organization

text: Mitochondrial networks constantly undergo fission and fusion events, crucial for maintaining organelle quality and cellular energetic homeostasis. However, the precise signaling pathways that coordinate these dynamics with metabolic demands, independent of bioenergetic output, are incompletely understood. This study identifies a novel phosphorylation site on Mitofusin 2 (MFN2) – Ser277 – that regulates mitochondrial fusion kinetics independent of its GTPase activity. Using phosphomimetic and phosphodeficient MFN2 mutants, we demonstrate that phosphorylation at Ser277 is induced by glucose deprivation and promotes hyperfusion, which selectively enhances mitochondrial contact sites with the ER without altering ATP synthesis or oxygen consumption rates. This altered morphology facilitates lipid transfer and promotes anabolic substrate utilization, crucial for cell survival under nutrient stress. Our findings reveal a nuanced regulatory mechanism for MFN2, highlighting how targeted post-translational modifications can fine-tune mitochondrial architecture to support distinct metabolic reprogramming strategies beyond bulk energy production.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Uncoupling Mitochondrial Fission-Fusion Dynamics from Bioenergetic Output in Metabolic Reprogramming via MFN2 Phosphorylation

text: Adenine base editors (ABEs) and cytosine base editors (CBEs) offer promising avenues for correcting pathogenic point mutations, yet off-target RNA deamination remains a critical limitation. Here, we engineer a novel class of CBEs by fusing catalytically impaired Cas9 to engineered human APOBEC3A (A3A) variants with enhanced DNA-specificity and attenuated RNA-binding affinity. Through comprehensive transcriptomic and genomic profiling, we demonstrate that our optimized Cas9-A3A fusion significantly reduces bystander RNA editing events while maintaining high on-target DNA editing efficiency across a diverse range of genomic loci. Furthermore, we illustrate its utility in correcting disease-relevant mutations, such as those implicated in cystic fibrosis and sickle cell anemia, in patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells. This advanced base editing platform mitigates a major safety concern, broadening the therapeutic applicability of precision genome editing for genetic disorders by offering unprecedented specificity and reduced collateral damage.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Precision Base Editing with Engineered Cas9-APOBEC3A Fusions Minimizes Off-Target RNA Deamination and Expands Therapeutic Scope

text: The tumor microenvironment (TME) is a complex ecosystem where cellular heterogeneity and intricate intercellular communication drive cancer progression and therapeutic resistance. Traditional bulk sequencing methods obscure critical spatial relationships and cell-state transitions. Here, we employ an integrated spatial transcriptomics and spatial proteomics platform to map the cellular landscape of human triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) at subcellular resolution. Our analysis identifies novel immune cell subsets, including exhausted T cells and myeloid-derived suppressor cells, exhibiting distinct spatial localization patterns and activation states within the TME. We delineate specific ligand-receptor interactions mediating immunosuppressive crosstalk between these spatially defined immune populations and cancer cells. This high-resolution spatial multi-omics approach provides an unprecedented understanding of the dynamic interplay governing immune evasion and offers a powerful framework for identifying novel biomarkers and therapeutic targets for personalized immuno-oncology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dissecting Immune Cell Heterogeneity and Intercellular Communication in Tumor Microenvironments via Spatial Multi-Omics

text: Liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) drives the formation of membrane-less organelles, critical for cellular organization and biochemical regulation. Dysregulation of LLPS, particularly involving RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) like FUS, is implicated in neurodegenerative diseases. We investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying the control of FUS phase separation. Using a combination of NMR spectroscopy, single-molecule fluorescence, and advanced microscopy, we reveal that arginine methylation by PRMT1 directly impacts the conformational ensemble of FUS, allosterically modulating its intrinsic disordered regions. Specific methylation sites reduce FUS's multivalent interactions, decreasing its propensity for phase separation and altering the material properties of formed condensates. Conversely, hypo-methylated FUS exhibits increased droplet formation and reduced turnover kinetics, leading to pathological aggregation. These findings elucidate a critical post-translational switch governing FUS's phase behavior, providing insights into both physiological condensate dynamics and disease pathogenesis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: RNA-Binding Protein FUS Undergoes Allosteric Regulation of Phase Separation by Post-Translational Arginine Methylation

text: The dynamic interplay between the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and mitochondria at membrane contact sites (MCSs) is fundamental for cellular lipid homeostasis, calcium signaling, and apoptosis. While several proteins localize to these mitochondria-associated ER membranes (MAMs), the precise molecular machinery governing their tethering and regulatory functions remains elusive. Here, we identify a novel interaction motif between the ER-resident SNARE protein VAMP2 and the mitochondrial outer membrane-anchored Rab3 protein family, crucial for establishing and maintaining ER-mitochondria contact sites. Disruption of this VAMP2-Rab3 axis through CRISPR/Cas9-mediated deletion or peptide inhibition significantly impairs phosphatidylserine synthesis and transfer to mitochondria, leading to altered mitochondrial morphology and compromised respiratory function. These findings unveil a previously uncharacterized SNARE-Rab-mediated tethering complex that precisely orchestrates ER-mitochondria communication, providing critical insights into inter-organelle lipid dynamics and their implications for metabolic diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A VAMP2-Rab3 Interaction Motif Orchestrates ER-Mitochondria Contact Sites for Lipid Flux Homeostasis

text: Super-enhancers (SEs) are crucial regulatory elements driving high-level expression of oncogenes and cell-identity genes, but their dynamic impact on higher-order chromatin organization and transcriptional kinetics in cancer remains poorly understood. Leveraging Hi-C, ChIP-seq, and live-cell single-molecule RNA FISH, we uncover that aberrant SE activity in glioblastoma stem cells orchestrates extensive reorganization of topologically associated domains (TADs), leading to de novo chromatin loops that connect distal SEs to proto-oncogene promoters. This SE-driven TAD rewiring significantly enhances transcriptional bursting frequency and amplitude of target genes, conferring a robust and sustained proliferative advantage. Pharmacological inhibition of SE-associated bromodomain and extraterminal (BET) proteins abrogates these structural changes, dampening transcriptional bursting and arresting tumor growth. Our study provides a comprehensive multi-scale view of how SEs mechanistically control gene expression through chromatin topology, offering novel therapeutic avenues targeting aberrant transcriptional programs in aggressive cancers.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Topologically Associated Domain Reorganization Driven by Super-Enhancer Activity Dictates Transcriptional Bursting in Cancer Progression

text: The unparalleled adaptive radiation of Rhagoletis pomonella onto novel host plants provides a compelling system to investigate the genomic basis of sympatric divergence. This study employs a high-resolution, long-read sequencing approach coupled with population genomics to elucidate the role of structural variants (SVs) in facilitating rapid host-plant shifts. We identified numerous fixed and polymorphic inversions, translocations, and copy number variations segregating across nascent host races. Our analyses reveal that these SVs are significantly enriched in regions harboring genes associated with chemosensation, detoxification, and diapause regulation, traits critical for host specialization. Furthermore, several large inversions act as 'supergenes', locking together adaptive allele complexes and suppressing recombination, thereby maintaining reproductive isolation despite ongoing gene flow. These findings underscore the profound, yet often underestimated, contribution of genomic structural variation to the rapid evolution of ecological specialization and the early stages of speciation.
subject: Evrim
title: Deconstructing the Genomic Architecture of Rapid Adaptive Divergence in Rhagoletis pomonella via Structural Variation

text: The evolution of eusociality presents a quintessential conundrum in evolutionary biology, traditionally explained by inclusive fitness theory. This research explores the underpinnings of cooperative phenotype plasticity and caste differentiation in the ant Formica rufa through the lens of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance. Using whole-genome bisulfite sequencing and ChIP-seq across distinct castes and developmental stages, we characterize dynamic patterns of DNA methylation and histone modifications influencing gene regulatory networks pertinent to division of labor. Our findings reveal that environmental cues experienced by foundress queens can induce heritable epigenetic marks, shaping colony-level phenotypic outcomes. These epigenetic changes act as a molecular 'Baldwin effect', facilitating rapid adaptation to fluctuating resource availability by pre-tuning gene expression profiles for specialized roles. This suggests a multi-level selection framework where environmentally-induced epigenetic plasticity at the individual level translates into enhanced fitness and adaptive potential for the entire superorganismal colony.
subject: Evrim
title: Epigenetic Modulators of Cooperative Phenotypes in Social Insect Colonies: A Multi-Level Selection Perspective

text: Evolutionary innovation often stems from mechanisms that expose cryptic genetic variation or generate novel phenotypes. This study investigates the interplay between developmental plasticity and canalization in the adaptive radiation of Darwin's finch beaks, focusing on how environmental stressors can disrupt stable developmental trajectories. Utilizing a comprehensive approach integrating ancestral reconstruction of developmental gene networks, quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping, and CRISPR-Cas9-mediated perturbations in model avian embryos, we identify key regulatory genes (e.g., BMP4, CaM) whose expression levels exhibit heightened sensitivity to nutritional stress. Our results demonstrate that such environmental perturbations can lead to a 'canalization breakdown', unveiling latent genetic variation and producing novel beak morphologies that can subsequently be stabilized by selection. This suggests a powerful mechanism where environmentally induced developmental instability can serve as a potent engine for evolutionary novelty, providing raw material for adaptive diversification in fluctuating environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Canalization Breakdown and Phenotypic Novelty: Investigating Developmental Plasticity's Role in Avian Beak Morphogenesis

text: The abrupt disappearance of numerous megafauna lineages during the Late Pleistocene remains a critical enigma. This study leverages high-coverage palaeogenomic data from 85 Ursus spelaeus individuals, spanning their geographic range and temporal distribution from 60,000 to 24,000 years ago, to reconstruct the demographic and adaptive dynamics preceding their extinction. Our analyses reveal a profound decline in effective population size (Ne) coincident with pronounced climatic fluctuations of Marine Isotope Stage 3 (MIS3), preceding widespread human expansion. We identify significant genomic signatures of purifying selection on genes related to dietary specialization and hibernation physiology, suggesting maladaptation to environmental shifts. Furthermore, evidence for limited introgression with Ursus arctos (brown bear) indicates a lack of compensatory genetic rescue. These findings underscore a complex interplay of intrinsic demographic vulnerability, habitat fragmentation driven by climate change, and potential competitive exclusion, collectively precipitating the cave bear's demise well before direct anthropogenic pressure dominated.
subject: Evrim
title: Palaeogenomic Insights into the Late Pleistocene Extinction Dynamics of Eurasian Cave Bears (Ursus spelaeus)

text: Host-parasite interactions are powerful drivers of rapid reciprocal evolution, exemplified by the Daphnia-Pasteuria pathosystem. We conducted a high-resolution, time-series genomic analysis of Daphnia magna populations undergoing selection by its obligate bacterial parasite Pasteuria ramosa. Utilizing pool-seq data from multiple experimental evolution lines, we identified numerous genomic regions exhibiting rapid allele frequency shifts indicative of selective sweeps. Key loci within the Daphnia immune response pathway (e.g., Toll-like receptors, prophenoloxidase cascade) show recurrent patterns of positive selection, coupled with parallel evolution in Pasteuria virulence genes, confirming Red Queen dynamics. Furthermore, we discovered significant population-specific linkage disequilibrium between host resistance genes and unlinked loci involved in life-history trade-offs, suggesting complex pleiotropic constraints on resistance evolution. These findings illuminate the fine-scale genomic architecture of antagonistic coevolution, demonstrating how host-parasite arms races sculpt both immune system diversity and broader adaptive landscapes.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Antagonistic Coevolution and Immune Evasion in the Daphnia-Pasteuria Pathosystem

text: Sympatric speciation, occurring without geographic barriers, necessitates strong divergent selection and mechanisms for reproductive isolation despite gene flow. This theoretical and empirical study investigates the role of pleiotropic ecological loci in facilitating this process. Using a multi-locus population genetic model incorporating varying selection strengths and recombination rates, we demonstrate that genes affecting both ecological performance (e.g., resource utilization) and assortative mating preferences can act as 'speciation genes', rapidly generating strong linkage disequilibrium between ecological divergence and pre-zygotic isolation. Empirical validation in a rapidly diverging cichlid fish species flock reveals genomic islands of divergence enriched for genes with known pleiotropic effects on diet specialization and mate choice. Our findings suggest that the genetic architecture underlying complex traits, particularly pleiotropy, significantly lowers the barrier to sympatric divergence, accelerating the formation of reproductive isolation in ecologically diverse environments.
subject: Evrim
title: The Role of Pleiotropic Ecological Loci in Initiating Sympatric Speciation Under Contrasting Selection Regimes

text: While genetic mutations are the canonical source of heritable variation, non-DNA sequence-based mechanisms like epigenetic inheritance are increasingly recognized for their evolutionary potential.
