text: This study employs massively parallel kinetic gyrokinetic simulations to elucidate the microscopic turbulent structures and associated energy dissipation mechanisms within thin current sheets undergoing magnetic reconnection in collisionless laboratory and astrophysical plasmas. We resolve the full phase-space dynamics of electrons and ions, quantifying the partitioning of reconnected magnetic energy into electron heating, ion heating, and particle acceleration. Our analysis highlights the critical role of kinetic instabilities, such as the lower-hybrid drift instability and electron-cyclotron drift instability, in generating anomalous resistivity and facilitating fast reconnection by disrupting electron orbits. We also investigate the cascade of magnetic energy to sub-ion scales, identifying the spectral signatures of turbulence-driven dissipation. These findings provide crucial insights into cosmic ray acceleration and the heating of stellar coronae.
subject: Fizik
title: Microscopic Turbulence and Energy Dissipation in Kinetic Magnetic Reconnection Layers via Gyrokinetic Simulations

text: We develop a novel methodology to constrain the existence and properties of ultracompact dark matter halos (UCDMHs) acting as exotic compact objects (ECOs) through their strong gravitational lensing effects on distant quasars. Our approach leverages time-domain astronomical observations to detect distinctive micro-lensing events and differential magnification variability, providing a unique signature to distinguish UCDMHs from conventional black holes. We numerically model light curves for various dark matter density profiles (e.g., NFW, solitonic cores) within UCDMHs, demonstrating how their extended mass distribution and potential substructure leave detectable imprints on lensed images. This work offers a powerful observational probe for beyond-standard-model physics, enabling the exploration of elusive dark matter candidates and early universe density fluctuations.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Ultracompact Dark Matter Halos with Strong Gravitational Lensing and Time-Domain Astronomy

text: This research investigates the dynamics of entanglement harvesting between two initially unentangled Unruh-DeWitt detectors interacting with a quantum field in a curved spacetime background, specifically focusing on the influence of shared environmental noise. We optimize the relativistic quantum channel parameters, including detector trajectory, interaction duration, and switching functions, to maximize the distillable entanglement. Our analysis reveals that spacetime curvature and the relativistic nature of the interaction profoundly impact entanglement generation and its robustness against decoherence. We demonstrate scenarios where entanglement can be harvested even in regimes traditionally considered detrimental, highlighting the interplay between causality, detector separation, and the quantum vacuum fluctuations. These findings have significant implications for distributed quantum computing in relativistic scenarios and understanding the fundamental nature of entanglement in cosmological contexts.
subject: Fizik
title: Entanglement Harvesting in Spacetime via Relativistic Quantum Channel Optimization

text: We conduct a comprehensive investigation into the anisotropic thermoelectric transport properties of designer Weyl semimetal superlattices, focusing on the intricate interplay between their unique electronic band structure and the emergence of topological phonon modes. Employing a combined approach of first-principles density functional theory and Boltzmann transport equations, we quantify the lattice thermal conductivity and Seebeck coefficient across various crystallographic orientations. Our analysis highlights the profound contribution of chiral anomaly-induced phonon drag effects, which significantly enhance the Seebeck coefficient in specific directions. Furthermore, we identify the role of localized phonon modes at interfaces in suppressing thermal transport without diminishing electronic mobility, leading to a substantial enhancement of the thermoelectric figure of merit (ZT). This work offers new avenues for designing highly efficient energy conversion devices.
subject: Fizik
title: Anisotropic Thermoelectric Response in Weyl Semimetal Superlattices: Role of Topological Phonons and Chiral Anomaly

text: We propose and theoretically analyze a new experimental scheme to probe objective collapse models, such as Continuous Spontaneous Localization (CSL), using levitated dielectric nanospheres in a highly optimized optomechanical trap. Our approach focuses on pushing the limits of macroscopic spatial superpositions by preparing and observing the center-of-mass motion of objects with masses exceeding 10^9 atomic mass units. By precisely monitoring the thermalization and decoherence rates of the quantum harmonic oscillator states, we quantify the achievable bounds on the CSL collapse parameters. We demonstrate how sympathetic cooling and vacuum isolation can extend coherence times sufficiently to differentiate CSL-induced diffusion from environmental decoherence, offering a pathway to stringent tests of quantum foundations and the quantum-to-classical transition.
subject: Fizik
title: Experimental Bounds on Spontaneous Localization Rates from Macroscopic Superpositions in Levitated Optomechanical Systems

text: This study investigates the intricate dynamics of quantum entanglement in non-Hermitian systems, particularly focusing on the interplay between environmental coupling and intrinsic non-Hermitian Hamiltonians. We demonstrate that engineered gain and loss mechanisms can profoundly influence the creation, sustainment, and even anomalous enhancement of bipartite and multipartite entanglement. Utilizing a Lindbladian framework, we analyze the steady-state entanglement properties of spin chains subjected to site-dependent dissipation and non-reciprocal hopping. Our findings reveal novel regimes where exceptional points catalyze robust entanglement harvesting, defying conventional wisdom rooted in Hermitian system dynamics. Furthermore, we propose experimental protocols for observing these phenomena in photonic lattices and superconducting circuits, highlighting potential applications in robust quantum communication and quantum metrology beyond standard quantum limits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Hermitian Proximity Effects on Entanglement Generation and Preservation in Open Quantum Systems

text: We present a theoretical framework for realizing and manipulating non-Abelian anyonic excitations in two-dimensional quantum materials subjected to periodic driving (Floquet engineering). By precisely tuning the frequency and amplitude of external fields, we demonstrate the emergence of synthetic gauge fields and modified band structures that host topologically protected edge states with non-trivial braiding statistics, even in systems intrinsically lacking such properties in their static limit. Specifically, we investigate a periodically modulated Rashba spin-orbit coupled semiconductor, revealing the dynamic generation of Majorana zero modes and their topological invariants. Our analysis elucidates the conditions for robust Floquet topological phases against local perturbations and provides practical guidelines for experimental realization in cold atom systems or driven semiconductor heterostructures, paving the way for fault-tolerant quantum computation schemes.
subject: Kuantum
title: Floquet Engineering of Non-Abelian Anyons in Periodically Driven Quantum Materials

text: This research explores advanced quantum metrology techniques to push the sensitivity limits of gravitational-wave observatories, specifically focusing on the integration of frequency-dependent squeezed vacuum states. We theoretically demonstrate that by injecting tailored squeezed light into a Michelson interferometer and employing a variational quantum non-demolition readout scheme, it is possible to bypass the standard quantum limit across the entire detection band. Our analysis addresses the complex interplay between opto-mechanical coupling, radiation pressure noise, and quantum back-action, illustrating how optimized squeezing profiles can selectively reduce noise contributions at different frequencies. We meticulously model the performance enhancement under realistic experimental constraints, including detector losses and finite squeezing bandwidth, providing a roadmap for implementing these quantum enhancements in current and future generation interferometric detectors.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum-Enhanced Gravitational-Wave Detection via Frequency-Dependent Squeezing and Variational Readout

text: We propose and analyze a scalable quantum simulation platform for one-dimensional U(1) lattice gauge theories using ultracold alkaline-earth atoms loaded into optical superlattices. Our scheme exploits the long-range Rydberg interactions and internal clock states of atoms to represent matter fields and gauge fields, respectively, faithfully implementing the Kogut-Susskind Hamiltonian. We detail a step-by-step experimental protocol for preparing and probing the vacuum state, and subsequently exploring phase transitions between confining and deconfining regimes by varying the gauge coupling strength. Crucially, we demonstrate how to overcome challenges associated with Gauss's law constraints and propose measurement strategies for extracting entanglement entropy and string tensions, providing critical insights into emergent gauge field phenomena relevant for high-energy physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Simulating U(1) Lattice Gauge Theories with Ultracold Atoms in Optical Lattices: From Confinement to Deconfinement

text: Mitigating decoherence remains a paramount challenge for scalable quantum computing architectures, particularly in superconducting transmon qubits. This work introduces a novel approach utilizing dynamically decoupled reservoir engineering to significantly extend qubit coherence times. By coupling the transmon qubit to a tailored ancillary resonator, whose spectral properties are dynamically modulated via parametric driving, we demonstrate a robust suppression of both energy relaxation (T1) and dephasing (T2) errors originating from low-frequency flux noise and two-level system defects. Our theoretical framework, incorporating Floquet-Lindblad master equations, predicts substantial improvements in coherence figures of merit. We outline a feasible experimental implementation, showcasing the potential for creating highly coherent quantum memories and enabling high-fidelity gate operations essential for fault-tolerant quantum computation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Engineering Coherence: Suppressing Qubit Decoherence in Superconducting Transmons via Dynamically Decoupled Reservoir Engineering

text: We present an inelastic neutron scattering investigation into the low-energy excitation spectrum of a geometrically frustrated quantum magnet, specifically targeting the signatures of fractionalized excitations indicative of a quantum spin liquid (QSL) phase. Employing high-resolution time-of-flight spectroscopy, we observe a broad continuum of excitations extending across a significant portion of the Brillouin zone, deviating sharply from conventional magnonic spin-wave descriptions. Our data analysis, combined with theoretical modeling using large-N parton mean-field theories, strongly suggests the presence of emergent spinons – fractionalized quasiparticles – and their characteristic dynamic structure factor. These findings provide compelling experimental evidence for proximity to a QSL state in a candidate material, offering crucial insights into exotic quantum criticality and topological order in strongly correlated electron systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Fractionalized Excitations and Quantum Spin Liquid Signatures in Frustrated Magnets via Inelastic Neutron Scattering

text: This work develops a non-local quantum field theory framework to describe self-interacting dark matter (SIDM) models, moving beyond effective field theory approaches to incorporate fundamental non-locality at scales relevant for dark matter interactions. We derive the cosmological implications of such non-local interactions, particularly their impact on structure formation and the dark matter halo profile, which are crucial for addressing small-scale anomalies. Through detailed numerical simulations, we demonstrate how a finite interaction range, emerging from the non-local kinetic terms, can significantly alter halo core densities and subhalo distributions. We then place stringent constraints on the parameters of this non-local SIDM model using observational data from galaxy rotation curves, cluster dynamics, and the cosmic microwave background, offering a new perspective on dark matter phenomenology.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Local Quantum Field Theory for Self-Interacting Dark Matter: Constraints from Large-Scale Structure

text: We investigate the capacity for extracting quantum entanglement from vacuum fluctuations of relativistic quantum fields by spatially separated Unruh-DeWitt detectors in dynamical spacetime geometries. Moving beyond the conventional flat-space approximation, we analyze entanglement harvesting in scenarios involving expanding universes and propagating gravitational waves. Our calculations reveal that the geometry and dynamics of spacetime profoundly influence the efficiency and robustness of entanglement acquisition, leading to novel correlations and anti-correlations between detector pairs. Specifically, we demonstrate that gravitational wave passage can induce a transient enhancement or suppression of extractable entanglement, providing a unique observable signature for quantum information processing in extreme astrophysical environments. These findings open new avenues for connecting quantum information theory with general relativity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Harvesting from Relativistic Quantum Fields in Dynamical Spacetimes: Beyond the Flat-Space Approximation

text: This paper proposes and analyzes a novel experimental scheme to test the predictions of objective collapse models, such as the Continuous Spontaneous Localization (CSL) theory, and gravitationally-induced decoherence. We leverage high-Q opto-mechanical resonators, cooled to their motional ground state, as macroscopic quantum systems susceptible to hypothesized spontaneous localization processes. By precisely monitoring the spectral linewidth and phonon occupation of the mechanical mode, we aim to detect deviations from standard quantum mechanics attributable to a non-linear, stochastic term in the Schrödinger equation. Our theoretical sensitivity analysis demonstrates that current and near-future experimental capabilities can probe regions of parameter space for CSL and similar models, offering critical insights into the fundamental limits of quantum superposition at macroscopic scales and the quantum-to-classical transition.
subject: Kuantum
title: Experimental Constraints on Gravitational Decoherence and Objective Collapse Models via Opto-Mechanical Resonators

text: We explore the utility of holographic duality (AdS/CFT correspondence) in modeling emergent quantum gravity phenomena within strongly correlated condensed matter systems exhibiting non-Fermi liquid characteristics. By constructing gravitational duals for specific critical points in quantum materials, we investigate the emergence of spacetime and gravitational dynamics from underlying microscopic degrees of freedom. Our focus is on systems near quantum critical points where effective field theories are inadequate. We demonstrate how features like anomalous scaling, entanglement entropy saturation, and the presence of "Planckian" dissipation in the boundary field theory correspond to geometric properties, horizon formation, and black hole thermodynamics in the bulk. This framework offers a profound reinterpretation of quantum gravity as an emergent property of strongly interacting quantum matter, providing calculable insights into the UV completion problem.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Duality and Emergent Quantum Gravity in Strongly Correlated Condensed Matter Systems with Non-Fermi Liquid Behavior

text: This research investigates the asymptotic behavior of saturation numbers, denoted $sat(n, \mathcal{F})$, for minor-closed families of graphs $\mathcal{F}$. Specifically, we consider families characterized by a finite set of forbidden minors. Leveraging advanced techniques from structural graph theory, including extensions of the excluded minor theorem and results concerning tree-width and clique-width, we establish new upper and lower bounds for $sat(n, \mathcal{F})$ when $\mathcal{F}$ excludes a fixed planar graph. Our primary contribution is demonstrating that for any proper minor-closed family $\mathcal{F}$ not containing all graphs, $sat(n, \mathcal{F}) = \Theta(n)$ if $\mathcal{F}$ is also apex-minor-free, and $sat(n, \mathcal{F}) = \Omega(n \log n)$ otherwise, unless $\mathcal{F}$ is the class of graphs with bounded treewidth. These findings deepen our understanding of graph saturation and its intricate relationship with graph structural parameters, offering new avenues for extremal problems in dense graph settings.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Asymptotic Behavior of Saturation Numbers for Minor-Closed Graph Families

text: This paper presents novel techniques for decomposing the irreducible characters of the symmetric group $S_n$ over fields of arbitrary characteristic. Traditionally, this is achieved via Young's natural representation over $\mathbb{C}$. We extend this framework by constructing explicit bases for Specht modules over fields where the characteristic divides $n!$, leveraging a generalized notion of semistandard Young tableaux with entries from a poset. Our methodology involves adapting combinatorial tools such as the Littlewood-Richardson rule and the Jacobi-Trudi identities to accommodate modular representation theory. We demonstrate how the structure of the character table, particularly the decomposition matrix, is influenced by the field characteristic, providing new bounds on the dimensions of the simple modules. This work opens avenues for connecting modular representation theory with the combinatorics of affine Weyl groups and Kac-Moody algebras.
subject: Matematik
title: Decomposing Characters of the Symmetric Group via Semistandard Young Tableaux over Arbitrary Fields

text: We investigate sharp threshold phenomena for various monotone properties in the context of sparse random $k$-uniform hypergraphs, specifically $G_{n,p}^{(k)}$. Employing an adaptation of the randomized greedy algorithm combined with an extension of the method of concentration of measure via martingale differences, we establish precise threshold probabilities for properties such as the existence of a perfect matching or a Hamiltonian cycle analogue. A key innovation is the development of a localized second moment method for highly correlated events, circumventing issues of dependency inherent in sparse regimes. Our results demonstrate that for a broad class of properties, the transition from 'almost surely not holding' to 'almost surely holding' occurs within a vanishingly small window of $p$. These findings refine existing coarse threshold estimates and have implications for phase transitions in complex networks and error-correcting codes.
subject: Matematik
title: Sharp Thresholds for Monotonic Properties in Sparse Random Hypergraphs

text: This paper explores the homological stability properties of various graph complexes, including the matching complex, independence complex, and generalized clique complexes. Utilizing techniques from discrete Morse theory, we construct explicit Morse matchings on the faces of these complexes, which enables computation of their Betti numbers and determines their homotopy type. Our central result establishes a strong form of homological stability for the independence complex of graphs with sufficiently large girth, showing that its homology groups stabilize as the number of vertices $n$ tends to infinity, provided certain connectivity conditions are met. This analysis reveals deep connections between the combinatorial structure of graphs and the topological invariants of their associated cell complexes, offering new perspectives on the persistent homology of combinatorial data and the study of configuration spaces.
subject: Matematik
title: Homological Stability of Graph Complexes and Discrete Morse Theory

text: This research addresses the problem of finding polynomial progressions within dense subsets of finite fields $\mathbb{F}_q^d$. We extend classical results by Roth and Szemeredi, establishing quantitative lower bounds on the number of non-trivial $k$-term polynomial progressions $x, x+P_1(y), \ldots, x+P_{k-1}(y)$ contained in any subset $A \subseteq \mathbb{F}_q^d$ with $|A| \ge \delta q^d$, where $P_i(y)$ are specified polynomial maps. Our methodology relies on advanced Fourier analytic techniques adapted for finite fields, specifically utilizing higher-order Gowers norms and the density increment method. We develop a robust structure theorem for sets avoiding such progressions, connecting their arithmetic structure to generalized arithmetic progressions. These bounds refine existing qualitative existence theorems and have significant implications for the inverse theory of additive combinatorics and the study of pseudorandomness in finite fields.
subject: Matematik
title: Quantitative Bounds for Polynomial Progressions in Dense Subsets of Finite Fields

text: We present novel recursive constructions for optimal optical orthogonal codes (OOCs) with flexible auto-correlation and cross-correlation properties. Focusing on $(\omega, \lambda_a, \lambda_c)$-OOCs, our approach leverages difference set theory over finite projective planes and cyclotomic classes to generate large families of codes that achieve the Johnson-type bounds asymptotically. The key innovation lies in a multi-level concatenation scheme, combining existing smaller optimal OOCs with carefully chosen difference families in $\mathbb{Z}_N$. We analyze the asymptotic performance of these constructions, demonstrating that the generated OOCs approach the theoretical maximum code size as the block length $N$ grows, while maintaining stringent correlation constraints essential for various optical communication systems. This work provides a systematic method for designing high-performance spread-spectrum communication sequences and advances the theory of combinatorial designs for practical applications.
subject: Matematik
title: Recursive Constructions of Optimal Optical Orthogonal Codes and Their Asymptotic Performance

text: This paper introduces and systematically investigates the class of matroids with bounded girth, defined as the minimum size of a circuit. We establish a comprehensive framework for understanding the structural properties of such matroids, drawing parallels with sparse graph theory. Our primary results include a sharp characterization of graphic matroids with girth at least $k$, a generalized version of Tutte's wheel and whirl theorems for matroids with high girth, and the determination of their excluded minor characterizations for small $k$. We further demonstrate that the class of matroids with girth at least $k$ is not minor-closed for $k \ge 3$, but rather has a complex relationship with the minor order. This work contributes to a deeper understanding of matroid sparsity and density, offering new tools for decomposing matroids and analyzing their representability over finite fields.
subject: Matematik
title: Characterizing Matroids with Bounded Girth and Their Minor-Closed Properties

text: We analyze the asymptotic number of self-avoiding walks (SAWs) on $\mathbb{Z}^d$ lattices where edges are assigned variable weights according to their local environment or state. Employing a combination of the lace expansion method and advanced techniques from analytic combinatorics, including the saddle-point method for multivariate generating functions, we derive precise asymptotic formulae for the number of $n$-step SAWs. Our analysis extends beyond the standard fixed-weight case, incorporating annealed and quenched disorder models relevant to polymer physics. We establish critical exponents and demonstrate the universality of these exponents across a broader class of weight distributions under mild regularity conditions. This research provides a rigorous combinatorial foundation for understanding polymer chain configurations in heterogeneous media and refines existing heuristic arguments regarding their growth constants and scaling limits.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotic Enumeration of Self-Avoiding Walks on Lattices with Variable Edge Weights

text: This research delves into the combinatorial properties of polytope spectra, specifically focusing on the relationship between the f-vector, h-vector, and flag f-vector of convex polytopes and their associated triangulations. We introduce the concept of a 'universal triangulation' for families of polytopes, which is shown to minimize certain entropic measures of combinatorial complexity. Our primary contribution is the development of a novel algebraic framework utilizing toric varieties to encode the entire combinatorial structure of a polytope, demonstrating that the spectrum of any simple polytope can be realized as the Hilbert function of a specific graded algebra. We prove new inequalities relating entries of the h-vector and derive criteria for the existence of unimodal h-vectors for specific classes of centrally symmetric polytopes. This work offers new tools for addressing open problems in convex geometry and algebraic combinatorics, particularly in the context of face lattice theory.
subject: Matematik
title: The Combinatorial Structure of Polytope Spectra and Universal Triangulations

text: This paper presents improved exact exponential-time algorithms for the maximum independent set problem (MIS) on $P_k$-free graphs, for fixed small $k$. Leveraging a sophisticated branching strategy combined with the 'measure & conquer' technique, we achieve sub-exponential time complexities significantly below the trivial $2^n$ bound. Our approach involves a multi-level analysis of graph decomposition based on structural properties unique to $P_k$-free graphs, specifically exploiting the bounded treewidth of their complements or specific separators. For $P_5$-free graphs, we establish an $O^*(c^n)$ algorithm, where $c < 1.18$, which substantially improves upon previous best known results. The methodology offers a blueprint for tackling other intractable graph problems on hereditary graph classes and contributes to the ongoing development of fine-grained complexity analysis in parameterized algorithms.
subject: Matematik
title: Exponential-Time Algorithms for Maximum Independent Set on P_k-Free Graphs via Branching and Measure & Conquer

text: This study introduces a novel computational framework for inferring Schenkerian fundamental structures from monophonic and polyphonic audio recordings. We leverage a multi-layered deep generative model, incorporating variational autoencoders for pitch contour extraction and a graph neural network (GNN) for modeling hierarchical dependencies within tonal prolongations. The GNN is trained on a meticulously annotated corpus of tonal repertoire, enabling the identification of Ursatz and middleground reductions by dynamically weighting structural melodic and harmonic events. Our methodology extends beyond traditional pitch-based analyses by integrating spectro-temporal features, thereby accounting for timbral and dynamic contributions to structural salience. Experimental validation demonstrates superior performance over existing symbolic-only approaches, particularly in handling ambiguous or ornamentally dense passages, offering a robust tool for large-scale computational musicological inquiry into tonal architecture.
subject: Müzik
title: Hierarchical Tonal Structure Inference via Deep Generative Models and Graph Neural Networks

text: This research presents an advanced methodology for real-time, high-resolution analysis of microtonal pitch deviations in complex audio signals, critical for ethnomusicological studies and performance practice analysis of non-Western and contemporary microtonal music. Our approach integrates a robust spectral phase unwrapping algorithm with a multi-taper spectrum estimation technique, enabling precise F0 tracking and cent-level resolution of inflections even in the presence of significant noise and vibrato. A novel adaptive windowing strategy optimizes time-frequency localization, minimizing smearing effects common in traditional STFT-based methods. The system dynamically models psychoacoustic salience metrics to differentiate intentional microtonal inflections from performance artifacts, providing a quantitative framework for analyzing intonational nuances within various tuning systems, including just intonation, historical temperaments, and arbitrary interval structures.
subject: Müzik
title: Real-Time Microtonal Pitch Deviation Analysis Using High-Resolution Spectral Phase Unwrapping

text: This paper proposes a predictive coding framework for inferring metrical hierarchies from complex polyrhythmic audio, addressing the limitations of purely beat-tracking algorithms in capturing multi-level temporal organization. Our model utilizes a hierarchical recurrent neural network architecture, processing spatio-temporal acoustic features derived from onset detection functions and fluctuation strength analysis. The system learns to predict upcoming metrical pulses and their phase relations across different periodicities, dynamically adjusting its internal representation of meter based on prediction error minimization. A key innovation is the integration of attentional mechanisms to selectively prioritize perceptually salient rhythmic streams, allowing for robust metrical inference in highly syncopated or ametrical passages. Validation against a diverse corpus of global rhythmic traditions demonstrates enhanced accuracy in identifying nested pulse structures and emergent metricities, offering new insights into cognitive rhythmic processing.
subject: Müzik
title: Predictive Coding for Metrical Hierarchy Inference in Polyrhythmic Contexts via Spatio-Temporal Acoustic Features

text: We present a novel deep manifold learning approach for constructing perceptually salient timbre spaces and facilitating cross-instrumental timbre mapping. Our methodology employs a Siamese Convolutional Variational Autoencoder (CVAE) architecture trained on a vast dataset of isolated instrument tones and orchestral excerpts. The CVAE learns a low-dimensional latent representation that robustly captures intricate timbral characteristics, optimized for perceptual similarity through triplet loss functions incorporating listener judgment data. This latent space enables quantification of timbral distance and facilitates transformations between disparate instrumental identities while preserving expressive nuance. Furthermore, we demonstrate the utility of this framework for generating synthetic timbres with specified perceptual attributes and for analyzing timbral evolution in spectral fusion contexts, offering significant implications for sound synthesis, orchestration, and music cognition research.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Manifold Learning for Perceptual Timbre Space Construction and Cross-Instrumental Mapping

text: This research formalizes a transformational grammar for algorithmic composition, specifically addressing the generation of highly constrained, yet expressively varied, post-tonal counterpoint. Drawing from neo-Riemannian theory and transformational music theory, our system employs a lexicon of pitch-class set operations and voice-leading transformations. The grammar is defined by a set of generative rules and constraints, including interval-class vector manipulation, common tone preservation, and specific registral and contour considerations. We implement this grammar within a constraint logic programming paradigm, allowing for both guided exploration of the compositional space and the generation of novel contrapuntal textures that adhere to defined stylistic parameters. This framework provides a rigorous theoretical basis for exploring the structural possibilities of post-tonal musical syntax, moving beyond stochastic models to embody specific analytical principles.
subject: Müzik
title: Transformational Grammar for Algorithmic Composition of Post-Tonal Counterpoint

text: This study investigates the intricate relationship between acoustic features and induced affective states, proposing a multimodal fusion framework for predicting continuous valence and arousal dimensions in music. We integrate high-level symbolic features (e.g., mode, tempo, harmonic density) with low-level audio features (e.g., spectral centroid, MFCCs, loudness dynamics) using a deep belief network coupled with a long short-term memory (LSTM) architecture. Physiological sensor data (e.g., GSR, HR, EEG) from listener responses are employed to refine and validate the model's emotional state predictions, establishing a robust ground truth. Our approach transcends categorical emotion models, offering fine-grained continuous regression of affective responses and revealing specific acoustic correlates driving emotional salience across diverse musical genres. This provides critical insights into the psychoacoustics of musical affect and informs applications in personalized music recommendation and therapeutic interventions.
subject: Müzik
title: Multimodal Fusion for Affective State Induction and Valence-Arousal Regression in Music

text: This paper addresses the fundamental challenge of integrating symbolic and sub-symbolic music representations within Music Information Retrieval (MIR) systems, crucial for tasks requiring both high-level semantic understanding and low-level acoustic detail. We introduce a novel contextual embedding network that simultaneously learns mappings from raw audio waveforms to symbolic representations (e.g., MIDI, score) and vice-versa, leveraging a shared latent space. The network employs a transformer-based encoder-decoder architecture for cross-modal translation, augmented with a semiotic layer that incorporates theoretical constructs like phrase boundaries, harmonic progressions, and rhythmic gestures. This allows for querying and retrieval tasks that operate fluently across different levels of abstraction, enabling sophisticated content-based analysis and synthesis operations previously unattainable with single-modality approaches, significantly advancing the conceptual foundation of MIR.
subject: Müzik
title: Bridging Symbolic and Sub-Symbolic Representations in Music Information Retrieval via Contextual Embedding Networks

text: This study explores the computational reconstruction of forgotten expressive nuances in historical musical performances through deep learning-based parametric resynthesis. Focusing on pre-Grünewald era recordings, we utilize a convolutional neural network (CNN) combined with a recurrent neural network (RNN) to analyze acoustic parameters—including micro-timing deviations, portamento characteristics, dynamic shaping, and vibrato modulation—that differentiate historically informed performance (HIP) from modern interpretations. The model learns a manifold of expressive gestures from authenticated HIP recordings, which is then used to parameterize a high-fidelity resynthesis engine. This allows for the precise articulation of performance practices documented in treatises but often lost in contemporary execution. Our methodology offers a robust analytical tool for musicologists and performers, enabling empirical verification and pedagogical dissemination of historical performance aesthetics.
subject: Müzik
title: Reconstructing Expressive Nuances in Historical Recordings via Deep Learning-Based Parametric Resynthesis

text: We propose a unified theoretical framework for the sonification of complex, multivariate datasets, moving beyond ad-hoc mappings to incorporate principles from music theory, psychoacoustics, and cognitive science. The framework leverages a hierarchical structure where data dimensions are mapped to perceptually salient musical parameters (e.g., pitch, rhythm, timbre, spatialization) based on their statistical properties and relational hierarchies. Algorithmic constraints, derived from established music-theoretical principles (e.g., common practice harmony, set theory, form), are integrated to ensure structural coherence and musical intelligibility. Furthermore, a feedback loop incorporating user perception and task-specific performance optimizes sonification strategies, ensuring both information transfer efficiency and aesthetic engagement. This interdisciplinary approach offers a principled methodology for designing sonification systems, enabling novel auditory explorations of scientific, financial, and medical data.
subject: Müzik
title: A Unified Theoretical Framework for Complex Data Sonification: Leveraging Algorithmic and Perceptual Constraints

text: This research introduces a novel analytical methodology for identifying and quantifying latent atonal coherence within stochastic and highly aleatoric musical compositions. Traditional pitch-class set theory often proves insufficient for these works, necessitating an approach that models emergent organizational principles from aggregate sonic events. We employ spectral clustering techniques on a feature space derived from instantaneous spectral centroid, spread, and irregularity, alongside event density and dynamic contours. A subsequent graph-theoretic analysis constructs weighted networks where nodes represent sonorous aggregates and edges represent temporal contiguity and timbral similarity. By analyzing graph centrality measures and community detection algorithms, we reveal underlying structural networks that dictate large-scale form and perceived cohesiveness, offering a powerful tool for post-tonal analysis beyond established serial or combinatorial paradigms.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectral Clustering and Graph-Theoretic Approaches to Atonal Coherence in Stochastic Compositions

text: This paper investigates the extremal problem of determining the maximum number of edges in an r-uniform hypergraph on n vertices that does not contain a specific forbidden configuration, F, under additional codegree constraints. We establish a novel stability theorem for the Turan number \operatorname{ex}(n, F) when F is a general r-uniform hypergraph with a non-empty core. Our approach leverages a hybrid technique combining the hypergraph Regularity Lemma with spectral methods applied to carefully constructed auxiliary graphs. We provide precise asymptotic bounds and structural characterizations for near-extremal hypergraphs, particularly for configurations like linear paths and cycles. For several classes of (r, k)-graphs, our results refine classical bounds and illuminate the fine-grained structure of such extremal objects, paving the way for advancements in generalizations of the Mantel-Turan theorem to higher dimensions.
subject: Matematik
title: Stability for Turan Numbers of Forbidden Hypergraph Configurations with Codegree Constraints

text: We explore the interplay between crystal graphs, symmetric functions, and affine Hecke algebras, focusing on their role in generalizing Schur-Weyl duality. This work introduces a novel framework for studying deformations of classical invariant theory through the lens of type A affine Hecke algebra representations. We construct explicit actions of new generalized crystal base operators on various families of semi-standard Young tableaux, demonstrating their compatibility with existing combinatorial structures such as the Littlewood-Richardson rule. Furthermore, we establish a direct connection between these deformed crystals and the structure of certain Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials, providing new insights into the character theory of quantum groups and their associated non-commutative algebras. The results offer a combinatorial realization of specific module structures for cyclotomic Hecke algebras.
subject: Matematik
title: Crystal Base Operators and Deformations of Schur-Weyl Duality via Affine Hecke Algebras

text: This paper investigates the emergence of complex structures and robustness properties in random k-uniform hypergraphs, specifically within the G(n,p) model, focusing on the intricate phase transitions associated with locally tree-like properties. We establish precise threshold functions for the appearance of specific sparse sub-hypergraphs and analyze their resilience to random edge deletions. Utilizing techniques from the second moment method and large deviation theory, we characterize the critical probabilities p_c(n) where the graph transitions from being highly disconnected to possessing non-trivial connected components exhibiting specific structural features, such as minimal codegree sequences. Our findings extend classical results for random graphs to hypergraphs, offering new insights into the robustness of decentralized networks and the fundamental limits of property testing on high-dimensional random structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Phase Transitions and Robustness in Hypergraph G(n,p) Models with Locally Tree-Like Properties

text: This work generalizes established min-max theorems from classical matroid theory to the broader context of delta-matroids, specifically exploring their connectivity properties when embedded on non-orientable surfaces. We introduce a novel definition of delta-matroid connectivity that accounts for the symmetric difference operations inherent in their structure. By leveraging tools from topological graph theory and linking systems, we derive a new family of min-max relations that connect the minimum size of a separating set to the maximum number of disjoint subsets satisfying certain independence criteria. Our results provide algorithmic implications for problems related to network reliability and generalizations of Menger's theorem. This offers a foundational framework for understanding the structural decomposition of delta-matroids, particularly those arising from combinatorial optimization problems on non-planar graphs.
subject: Matematik
title: Connectivity Functions and Min-Max Theorems for Delta-Matroids on Non-Orientable Surfaces

text: This paper presents quantitative Freiman-type theorems for subsets with small doubling constants in specific classes of non-abelian groups, extending classical results from commutative settings. We introduce a refined notion of approximate arithmetic progression suitable for non-commutative structures and develop novel Fourier analytic techniques adapted for these groups. Our main result demonstrates that any subset A of a torsion-free non-abelian group G satisfying |AA| \leq K|A| must possess a substantial subset that is structurally close to a generalized arithmetic progression, with explicit bounds on the dimension and size. This work contributes to the inverse additive problem landscape, offering a pathway to characterize the structure of sets with limited products in a broader algebraic context, shedding light on the sum-product phenomenon beyond commutative fields.
subject: Matematik
title: Quantitative Freiman-Type Theorems for Small Doubling Sets in Non-Abelian Groups

text: This research details novel constructive methods for generating large sets of mutually orthogonal Steiner triple systems S(2,3,v), extending the known spectrum of existence for such configurations. We exploit the properties of specific finite fields and their associated affine and projective planes to define a combinatorial framework. By analyzing the actions of prescribed automorphism groups on initial base blocks, we develop a systematic approach to construct families of orthogonal designs, focusing on cases where v is a prime power. Our main contribution involves demonstrating the existence of large sets of L(S(2,3,v)) for new values of v, providing explicit constructions and enumeration techniques. These findings have significant implications for the design of robust cryptographic schemes and error-correcting codes, where high degrees of orthogonality are paramount.
subject: Matematik
title: Constructing Large Sets of Mutually Orthogonal Steiner Triple Systems S(2,3,v) via Automorphism Group Actions

text: This paper establishes a comprehensive characterization of minor-closed graph classes defined by specific excluded minors, focusing on graphs with simultaneously bounded girth and treewidth. We extend the Robertson-Seymour graph minor theory by identifying minimal excluded minors for several previously uncharacterized classes. Our methodology combines structural decomposition techniques with localized connectivity arguments derived from Menger's Theorem. We prove that for any fixed k, the class of graphs with treewidth at most k and girth at least g (for sufficiently large g) can be characterized by a finite set of excluded minors. This work elucidates the intricate relationship between global topological properties (like minors) and local structural invariants (like girth), offering new insights into Hadwiger's Conjecture and graph-theoretic analogues of topological invariants.
subject: Matematik
title: Excluded Minor Characterizations for Classes of Graphs with Bounded Girth and Treewidth

text: This paper presents novel combinatorial interpretations and q-analogs for a class of alternating sum identities arising in the theory of restricted partitions and integer compositions. We establish explicit bijections between weighted lattice paths and specific configurations of partitions constrained by part size and number, thereby providing new proofs for several long-standing identities. Our main contribution is the development of a systematic framework for deriving q-analogs of these identities, utilizing generating functions based on q-binomial coefficients and elliptic functions. We demonstrate their connection to the enumeration of objects in specific crystal graphs and their role in the representation theory of affine Lie algebras. These results extend classical theorems by MacMahon and Rogers-Ramanujan, offering new tools for the study of partition theory and related areas of algebraic combinatorics.
subject: Matematik
title: Combinatorial Interpretations and q-Analogs of Alternating Sum Identities for Restricted Partitions

text: This research explores the limitations and extensions of Helly-type theorems in the context of product simplicial complexes, particularly when dealing with families of sets that exhibit non-trivial topological features. We introduce a novel definition of combinatorial convexity tailored for product spaces and investigate the nerve lemma's applicability under these relaxed conditions. Our primary result identifies specific topological obstructions, characterized by generalized Betti numbers and connectivity properties of the intersections, that preclude the satisfaction of classical Helly's theorem for such families. By leveraging concepts from discrete Morse theory and higher-order topological connectivity, we derive bounds on the Helly number for certain classes of product complexes, offering new insights into the interplay between geometric combinatorics and algebraic topology, with implications for data analysis and distributed computing.
subject: Matematik
title: Topological Obstructions to Helly-Type Theorems in Product Simplicial Complexes

text: This paper investigates the definable limits of sparse graph sequences, extending the theory of graph limits beyond dense graphs to contexts where the average degree is bounded. We introduce a new framework based on generalized Benjamini-Schramm convergence and establish its equivalence to definability in certain finite model theory settings. Our main result demonstrates that for a sequence of sparse graphs converging in this sense, the first-order properties that hold for almost all graphs in the sequence are precisely those definable by a specific class of first-order sentences. This has profound implications for the tractability of property testing algorithms on sparse random structures. We also explore connections to local tree-like convergence and the descriptive complexity of graph properties, providing a rigorous foundation for analyzing the asymptotic behavior of complex networks.
subject: Matematik
title: Definable Limits of Sparse Graph Sequences and First-Order Property Testing

text: This paper addresses the critical challenge of catastrophic forgetting in continually evolving multimodal foundation models. We propose a novel framework, Adaptive Modular Replay Network (AMoReN), which integrates a dynamic episodic memory bank with a task-agnostic, adaptively modular neural architecture. AMoReN leverages a selective knowledge distillation mechanism guided by a meta-learned importance-weighting scheme to prioritize salient information from previous tasks during replay. This approach minimizes interference while facilitating positive transfer across diverse sensory modalities and downstream tasks. Empirical evaluations on complex, sequential learning benchmarks demonstrate superior performance compared to state-of-the-art continual learning paradigms, exhibiting marked improvements in long-term knowledge retention and robust generalization capabilities without excessive parameter growth. Our findings pave the way for more biologically plausible and sustainable large-scale AI systems.
subject: AI
title: Orchestrating Incremental Knowledge Assimilation in Multimodal Foundation Models via Episodic Memory Replay and Adaptive Modularity

text: This work investigates the integration of counterfactual reasoning into deep reinforcement learning to enhance policy robustness and generalization in dynamic, non-stationary environments characterized by confounding variables and interventional shifts. We introduce a novel framework, Causal-Informed Policy Optimization (CIPO), which leverages inferred structural causal models to disentangle causal effects from spurious correlations within observational data. CIPO constructs a policy learning objective that explicitly optimizes for interventions under various counterfactual scenarios, thereby fostering invariance to distributional shifts in exogenous variables while exploiting stable causal mechanisms. Experimental validation across simulated control tasks with varying causal structures demonstrates that CIPO significantly outperforms conventional model-free and model-based RL agents in terms of sample efficiency, out-of-distribution generalization, and resilience to environmental perturbations, marking a critical step towards truly robust autonomous decision-making systems.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Reasoning for Robust Policy Generalization in Non-Stationary Causal Environments

text: Predicting the properties and stability of novel material phases remains a grand challenge in computational materials science. This paper introduces Hierarchical Multi-Relational Graph Attention Network (HMR-GAT), a sophisticated deep learning architecture designed for accelerated material discovery. HMR-GAT effectively captures complex interatomic interactions and crystal symmetries by modeling materials as multi-relational graphs, where different bond types and coordination environments are represented as distinct edge features. A multi-level attention mechanism aggregates information across local chemical environments and global crystallographic arrangements, allowing the network to discern subtle structural motifs crucial for property prediction. Benchmarked against large-scale materials databases, HMR-GAT demonstrates unprecedented accuracy in predicting formation energies and thermodynamic stability, facilitating in-silico screening of potential candidates with orders of magnitude speedup over density functional theory calculations.
subject: AI
title: Hierarchical Multi-Relational Graph Attention Networks for Accelerated Discovery of Novel Material Phases

text: The opacity of complex deep learning models necessitates advanced explainability techniques, particularly those grounded in causality. This paper presents a novel framework for generating Causal Explanations for Black-Box Models (CEBBM), moving beyond mere correlation-based saliency maps. CEBBM integrates a learnable structural explainer that infers causal relationships among input features and their influence on model predictions. By performing carefully constructed counterfactual interventional perturbations on these causally informed features, CEBBM identifies minimal and sufficient sets of interventions that alter a model's prediction to a desired outcome. This approach provides actionable, stable, and human-interpretable "what-if-things-had-been-different" explanations, demonstrating superior fidelity and robustness compared to attribution-based or gradient-based methods across diverse classification tasks. Our findings suggest a paradigm shift towards causal grounding in the quest for trustworthy AI.
subject: AI
title: Causal Explanations for Black-Box Models via Counterfactual Interventional Perturbations and Structural Explainers

text: Few-shot learning presents a significant challenge for deep neural networks, particularly when novel tasks exhibit substantial domain shift from the meta-training distribution. We introduce an Amortized Bayesian Meta-Learning (ABML) framework designed to learn highly adaptive and uncertainty-aware prediction functions from sparse data. ABML employs an amortized inference network to rapidly estimate task-specific posterior distributions over model parameters or latent representations, thereby capturing epistemic uncertainty crucial for robust generalization. By framing meta-learning as a continuous adaptation process within a probabilistic latent space, ABML effectively mitigates overfitting to limited support sets and explicitly models inter-task variability. Empirical evaluations on diverse few-shot classification and regression benchmarks demonstrate ABML's superior performance in terms of accuracy and calibration under both in-distribution and cross-domain few-shot scenarios, establishing a new benchmark for robust and generalized few-shot learning.
subject: AI
title: Amortized Bayesian Meta-Learning for Robust Few-Shot Generalization under Domain Shift

text: Federated learning (FL) promises collaborative model training without centralizing sensitive data, yet it remains vulnerable to privacy breaches and adversarial attacks from malicious clients. This paper proposes a novel framework integrating strong privacy guarantees with Byzantine fault tolerance. We introduce a Secure Aggregation and Adaptive Client Selection (SAACS) mechanism. SAACS combines a multi-party computation protocol for differentially private gradient aggregation, ensuring protection against inference attacks even from the server, with an adaptive client selection strategy based on historical contribution and anomaly detection. This strategy dynamically prunes malicious updates while preserving data diversity. Extensive simulations demonstrate that SAACS significantly enhances the privacy-utility tradeoff and resilience against data poisoning and model inference attacks, outperforming existing differentially private FL algorithms in robustness and model quality, paving the way for truly trustworthy and decentralized AI.
subject: AI
title: Differentially Private Federated Learning with Byzantine Robustness via Secure Aggregation and Adaptive Client Selection

text: Bridging the gap between the perceptual capabilities of neural networks and the symbolic reasoning strengths of traditional AI is crucial for robust commonsense intelligence. This paper introduces an Inductive Logic Programming Guided Neural-Symbolic (ILP-GNS) system for enhanced commonsense knowledge acquisition and reasoning. ILP-GNS leverages a differentiable reasoning module that integrates predicate logic rules with neural embeddings, enabling end-to-end learning of symbolic knowledge from unstructured data. Critically, an inductive logic programming component iteratively refines the symbolic rule base by generating new hypotheses and validating them against neural predictions, thereby augmenting the system's explicit knowledge graph. This iterative self-correction mechanism facilitates the discovery of complex, multi-hop logical relationships. Experimental results on challenging commonsense reasoning benchmarks demonstrate significant improvements in accuracy, interpretability, and generalization compared to purely neural or symbolic approaches.
subject: AI
title: Inductive Logic Programming Guided Neural-Symbolic Reasoning for Commonsense Knowledge Acquisition

text: Score-based generative models (SGM), particularly diffusion models, have revolutionized high-fidelity data synthesis. This work extends their capabilities to Conditional SGMs (CSGMs) for tackling complex inverse problems and guided generation in scientific and engineering domains. We propose a novel framework that learns a conditional score function by integrating problem-specific constraints and observational data directly into the denoising diffusion process. This allows for precise control over generation, enabling tasks such as inverse design, data imputation, and super-resolution. Our methodology incorporates a gradient-based conditioning mechanism within the reverse SDE/ODE, ensuring adherence to intricate conditional manifolds. Evaluations across diverse scientific datasets—including materials microstructures and biomedical imaging—demonstrate that CSGMs achieve state-of-the-art performance in generating high-fidelity, physically consistent samples while efficiently solving ill-posed inverse problems, vastly outperforming traditional optimization and sampling techniques.
subject: AI
title: Conditional Score-Based Generative Models for High-Fidelity Synthesis and Inverse Problem Solving in Scientific Domains

text: Ensuring robustness of multimodal foundation models against adversarial perturbations is paramount for their deployment in critical applications. Traditional methods often address independent perturbations, neglecting correlated semantic shifts across modalities. We propose a framework for Certifiable Robustness against Correlated Adversarial Perturbations (CRCAP) for multimodal foundation models. CRCAP employs a novel semidefinite programming-based verification technique that simultaneously bounds the output variation across distinct input modalities, accounting for inter-modal semantic consistency constraints. By leveraging a custom-designed adversarial training objective that incorporates worst-case propagation through both intra- and inter-modal perturbation subspaces, we achieve provable guarantees on model predictions. Empirical results on multimodal classification and captioning tasks demonstrate that CRCAP significantly enhances certified accuracy under joint adversarial attacks, offering an unprecedented level of security assurance for complex, real-world AI systems.
subject: AI
title: Certifiable Robustness for Multimodal Foundation Models against Correlated Adversarial Perturbations

text: The integration of quantum computing principles into classical machine learning offers promising avenues for enhanced expressive power. This paper introduces Variational Quantum Circuit-Enhanced Graph Neural Networks (VQC-GNN), a novel hybrid architecture designed for robust feature learning on quantum-inspired or quantum-generated graph data, particularly within the Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) era. VQC-GNN embeds graph nodes into a high-dimensional quantum feature space via parameterized quantum circuits, leveraging entanglement and superposition to capture non-linear, non-local correlations inaccessible to classical GNNs. A classical graph convolutional layer then operates on these quantum-encoded features, propagating information across the graph. We demonstrate VQC-GNN's superior performance in classification tasks on synthetic quantum chemistry graphs and real-world noisy quantum measurements, showcasing its potential to uncover intricate patterns and improve generalization beyond purely classical paradigms.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Circuit-Enhanced Graph Neural Networks for Expressive Feature Learning on Noisy Quantum Data

text: This study presents a novel methodology for the computational analysis of microtonal harmonic structures, transcending the inherent limitations of 12-TET-centric analytical paradigms. We employ a variational autoencoder (VAE) architecture, specifically trained on a corpus comprising synthetically generated microtonal chord progressions and expertly curated excerpts from contemporary experimental and ethnographically documented microtonal musics. Audio features are spectro-temporally processed, yielding high-resolution pitch-class distribution vectors, spectral centroids, and tristimulus values. The VAE learns a topologically coherent, low-dimensional latent space wherein proximity reflects psychoacoustically salient harmonic relationships, even across disparate intonation systems. Crucially, controlled latent space traversals demonstrate a capacity to articulate nuanced voice-leading and transformational pathways within and between non-standard temperaments. This framework offers a robust, data-agnostic computational tool for discerning underlying harmonic syntax in microtonal contexts, thus advancing quantitative musicological inquiry and informing generative compositional methodologies.
subject: Müzik
title: Latent Space Embeddings for Non-Standard Temperaments: A Deep Autoencoder Approach to Microtonal Harmonic Analysis

text: This study investigates the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying perceptual entrainment to complex polyrhythmic structures, particularly in contexts exhibiting metrical ambiguity. Utilizing simultaneous high-density electroencephalography (EEG) and magnetoencephalography (MEG), we recorded neural oscillations from participants engaged in a task involving active listening to diverse polyrhythmic stimuli, ranging from canonical 3:2 ratios to more intricate non-integer subdivisions. Subsequent analyses employed multi-taper spectral estimation and phase-locking value (PLV) computations to quantify cross-frequency coupling and inter-areal coherence. We demonstrate differential oscillatory entrainment profiles across auditory and motor cortices, indicative of hierarchical processing of constituent rhythmic streams and emergent resultant patterns. Specifically, enhanced gamma-band coherence between superior temporal gyrus and prefrontal cortex correlates with successful perceptual integration, while alpha-band desynchronization precedes shifts in attentional focus toward specific metrical interpretations. These findings illuminate the adaptive, context-dependent nature of rhythmic entrainment, offering insights into temporal organization in the human brain.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Spectral Coherence Analysis of Entrainment Dynamics in Polyrhythmic Perception

text: This research addresses the persistent challenge of automating hierarchical tonal analysis, particularly within the Schenkerian framework, by introducing a novel algorithmic approach to Ursatz derivation. We model tonal compositions as multi-layered directed acyclic graphs, where nodes represent structural pitches and edges denote permissible voice-leading operations and prolongational relationships. A constrained optimization problem is formulated, minimizing a cost function that incorporates metrics for intervallic tension, voice-leading parsimony, harmonic stability, and context-dependent structural saliency, informed by statistical distributions from the common practice repertoire. Leveraging dynamic programming and A* search variants, the algorithm iteratively prunes less salient prolongational paths, progressively converging towards a fundamental structure (Ursatz) while preserving contrapuntal integrity. This methodology offers a formal, computationally tractable means to generate and evaluate Schenkerian reductions, providing a verifiable framework for comparative analyses across corpora and potentially illuminating previously implicit theoretical principles governing tonal coherence.
subject: Müzik
title: Algorithmic Ursatz Derivation via Constrained Optimization of Voice-Leading Smoothness

text: This research formalizes an extension of Generalized Interval Systems (GIS) through the integration of fuzzy set theory, addressing limitations in analyzing post-tonal repertoires that incorporate microtonal inflections, complex timbral formations, and ambiguous pitch-class relationships. We establish an axiomatic framework where musical objects—pitches, intervals, and aggregates—are represented not as crisp sets but as fuzzy sets, each assigned membership functions across multiple parametric dimensions, including precise frequency, spectral centroid, and attack-decay envelopes. This enables the quantification of degrees of similarity and dissimilarity, providing a nuanced analytical lens for phenomena such as 'approximate' transformations, graded dissonances, and timbral-harmonic convergences. Novel fuzzy similarity metrics, leveraging Jaccard and Tversky indices adapted for multi-dimensional musical parameters, are introduced. This framework offers a mathematically robust yet perceptually attuned methodology for explicating structural coherence and transformational operations in highly complex, non-12-TET, and electroacoustic compositions, advancing theoretical discourse in contemporary music.
subject: Müzik
title: Axiomatic Foundations for Fuzzy Set Theory in Generalized Interval Systems for Atonal Music

text: This study explores the construction of robust, perceptually aligned timbral spaces using Convolutional Variational Autoencoders (CVAEs), addressing the inherent challenges of high-dimensional acoustic feature representation and non-linear perceptual mapping. We trained a CVAE on an extensive corpus of heterogeneous instrumental and synthesized audio, utilizing Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs) and spectral contrast features extracted from short-time frames. The CVAE learns a disentangled, low-dimensional latent representation, wherein specific axes correspond to salient perceptual attributes such as brightness, attack noisiness, and spectral flux. We demonstrate that distances within this latent space strongly correlate with human dissimilarity judgments and that controlled interpolations along latent dimensions yield semantically meaningful timbral transformations. This framework not only offers a powerful analytical tool for quantifying timbral characteristics but also provides an intuitive, data-driven interface for expressive sound synthesis, advancing both psychoacoustic modeling and computational sound design paradigms.
subject: Müzik
title: Convolutional Variational Autoencoders for Timbral Perceptual Space Modeling and Synthesis Control

text: This study presents a novel framework for algorithmic species counterpoint generation, leveraging Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) to synthesize compositions exhibiting both theoretical rigor and musical flexibility. We model the counterpoint generation process as a sequential decision-making task within a Markov Decision Process (MDP), where an agent learns optimal note choices against a given cantus firmus. The reward function is meticulously engineered to encapsulate multi-objective criteria, including adherence to established contrapuntal rules (e.g., consonance, voice-leading smoothness, avoidance of forbidden parallels) alongside stylistic considerations such as melodic contour and rhythmic diversity. Crucially, we introduce an adaptive rule-weighting mechanism, allowing for dynamic control over the strictness of theoretical adherence. The DRL agent, trained via proximal policy optimization, demonstrates emergent understanding of intricate contrapuntal strategies, generating highly plausible and stylistically varied outputs. This system provides a potent tool for compositional aid and a fertile ground for computational exploration of historical music theory.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Species Counterpoint Generation with Adaptive Rule Adherence

text: This study investigates the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying musical dissonance perception, positing that its processing is not solely contingent upon peripheral auditory roughness but is profoundly modulated by higher-order auditory stream segregation. Utilizing concurrent functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and electroencephalography (EEG), we examined cortical responses to harmonic intervals and complex chords manipulated across conditions designed to elicit varying degrees of auditory integration versus segregation (e.g., differential timbres, onset asynchronies, spatial separation). Neural activity in the superior temporal gyrus, inferior frontal gyrus, and amygdala demonstrated significant modulation by segregation cues, with perceived dissonance ratings exhibiting a concomitant reduction when constituent partials were perceptually streamed. Furthermore, a spectro-temporal roughness model’s predictions were significantly attenuated by segregation indices. These findings advance our understanding of the interplay between low-level psychoacoustic attributes and high-level auditory scene analysis, refining models of musical consonance and dissonance perception.
subject: Müzik
title: Cortical Correlates of Musical Dissonance Perception Modulated by Auditory Stream Segregation

text: This research introduces a novel methodology for the large-scale comparative structural analysis of global folk melodies, circumventing the limitations of notation-centric and culture-specific analytical paradigms. We represent melodies as dynamic attributed graphs, where nodes correspond to musical events (e.g., pitches, rhythmic cells) and edges encode hierarchical relationships such as melodic contour, rhythmic proximity, intervallic successions, and recurrent motivic patterns. Leveraging Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) with attention mechanisms, our model learns to extract high-level structural features that are invariant to surface-level variations in scale, meter, or specific pitch content. We demonstrate the GNN's efficacy in identifying pan-cultural melodic archetypes, differentiating regional stylistic nuances, and discovering latent structural similarities across diverse ethnomusicological corpora. A custom-designed graph kernel facilitates the quantification of structural resemblance, enabling robust clustering and classification of melodic traditions. This framework offers a potent, scalable tool for computational ethnomusicology, fostering data-driven insights into cross-cultural musical universals.
subject: Müzik
title: Graph Neural Networks for Comparative Structural Analysis of Global Folk Melodies

text: This research presents a hierarchical Bayesian modeling framework for the rigorous quantification and analysis of expressive microtiming deviations in live ensemble performances. We meticulously processed high-resolution MIDI data, extracted via advanced onset detection and beat-tracking algorithms, from a diverse corpus of professional chamber and orchestral recordings across various stylistic periods. The Bayesian model simultaneously estimates ensemble-wide tempo fluctuations, individual performer-specific timing biases (e.g., consistent leading or lagging), and context-dependent agogic accents, while rigorously disentangling these systematic deviations from stochastic performance noise. Crucially, the model incorporates latent variables representing hierarchical metrical and phrase-level structures, demonstrating their profound influence on microtiming organization. Findings reveal genre- and role-specific microtiming 'signatures' that delineate expressive intent and inter-performer synchronization strategies. This framework offers a robust statistical tool for computational performance analysis, informing cognitive models of musical timing and advancing the synthesis of expressively nuanced artificial performances.
subject: Müzik
title: Hierarchical Bayesian Modeling of Microtiming Deviations in Ensemble Performance

text: This research elucidates the neurocomputational underpinnings of musical expectancy by framing tonal hierarchy within a predictive coding paradigm, informed by information theory. We utilized magnetoencephalography (MEG) to record event-related fields in participants passively listening to acoustically controlled harmonic sequences exhibiting varying degrees of statistical predictability and theoretical 'out-of-keyness.' Measures of information-theoretic surprise (e.g., Shannon entropy, Kullback-Leibler divergence) derived from a corpus-trained statistical learning model were correlated with neural prediction error signals, specifically the N100m and P300m components. Findings demonstrate that higher prediction error, indicative of greater musical 'surprise,' robustly correlates with increased amplitudes of these evoked potentials, particularly within the auditory cortex and inferior frontal gyrus. This empirically supports a dynamic, Bayesian inference-driven model of tonal expectation, where the brain continuously updates its generative model of musical structure. The study quantifies how information-theoretic metrics align with cognitive processing of tonal attraction and resolution, advancing our understanding of musical cognition.
subject: Müzik
title: Predictive Coding of Musical Expectancy: An Information-Theoretic Approach to Tonal Hierarchy

text: This research investigates the extremal and spectral properties of k-uniform hypergraphs exhibiting strong quasirandomness. We establish novel bounds on the spectral radius of the adjacency tensor for such structures, demonstrating its intimate connection to the hypergraph’s expansion properties and underlying combinatorial regularity. By employing an adaptation of the Szemeredi Regularity Lemma for hypergraphs and leveraging tensor decomposition techniques, we derive an asymptotic formula for the largest eigenvalue of the hypergraph adjacency tensor under specific density conditions. Furthermore, we explore the implications of these spectral characteristics for Ramsey-type problems and for the existence of prescribed sub-hypergraphs, providing new insights into the interplay between local density fluctuations and global structural integrity in high-dimensional discrete systems. Our findings offer a refined understanding of quasirandomness in non-linear settings.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Asymptotic Behavior of the Spectral Radius for Quasirandom Hypergraphs

text: We present a comprehensive analysis of refined plethystic decompositions in the context of generalized coinvariant algebras for finite reflection groups. Specifically, we investigate the Garsia-Haiman conjecture's higher-dimensional analogues and explore the intricate module structure of the diagonal coinvariant algebra $\text{DR}_n$ under the diagonal action of $S_n$. Our work introduces a new family of symmetric functions, indexed by compositions, which naturally arise from the non-commutative structure of the universal enveloping algebra. By leveraging techniques from both algebraic geometry and representation theory, including the theory of character varieties and equivariant K-theory, we provide an explicit plethystic formula for the Frobenius series of certain quotient rings, establishing a novel connection to the combinatorics of Young's lattice and Macdonald polynomials. This extends classical results to a broader class of algebraic invariants.
subject: Matematik
title: Refined Plethystic Decompositions and the Structure of Coinvariant Algebras

text: This paper delves into the critical window phenomena in a novel class of random hypergraph models, where edge formation is governed by a generalized linkage rule rather than independent Bernoulli trials, while maintaining a fixed global edge density. We analyze the emergence of giant components and the structural properties of hypercores across varying linkage parameters. Using a blend of generating function techniques, first and second moment methods, and rigorous concentration inequalities, we precisely locate the critical threshold for the appearance of a linear-sized connected component. Our findings reveal a qualitatively distinct phase transition behavior compared to Erdős-Rényi hypergraphs, characterized by a broader critical window and a more complex branching process structure, offering new perspectives on robustness and connectivity in complex network architectures.
subject: Matematik
title: Critical Window Phenomena in Hypergraph Linkage Models with Fixed Edge Density

text: We develop an Ehrhart theory for tropical polytopes, defining a combinatorial polynomial whose evaluations at integer points enumerate lattice points in dilations of tropical convex bodies. Our approach involves a tropical analogue of the standard triangulation procedure, leveraging insights from geometric measure theory in tropical settings. A central result connects the coefficients of this tropical Ehrhart polynomial to the volumes of faces of the initial tropical polytope, generalizing classical theorems. Furthermore, we investigate the relationship between the Ehrhart theory of tropical polytopes and the monodromy of amoebae of algebraic varieties. By studying the argument function on the complement of amoebae, we establish a link to the winding numbers and prove new theorems on the lattice point enumeration in regions defined by tropical hypersurfaces, bridging combinatorial geometry with complex analysis.
subject: Matematik
title: Ehrhart Theory of Tropical Polytopes and Monodromy of Amoebae

text: This work refines existing sum-product estimates over finite fields $\mathbb{F}_q$, providing new quantitative bounds for sets $A \subseteq \mathbb{F}_q$ where $|A+A|$ and $|A \cdot A|$ are simultaneously small. We introduce a novel technique based on the interplay between character sum estimates and p-adic valuations of coefficients derived from polynomial expansions. Specifically, by analyzing the Frobenius automorphism's action on the algebraic closure of $\mathbb{F}_q$, we establish an improved lower bound for $\max(|A+A|, |A \cdot A|)$ under certain structural assumptions on $A$. Our method avoids the direct application of incidence theorems and offers a more robust framework for sets lacking strong arithmetic progression structure. This approach opens new avenues for addressing open problems in restricted sumsets and provides sharper constants in existing sum-product inequalities.
subject: Matematik
title: Quantitative Bounds for Sum-Product Estimates over Finite Fields via P-Adic Valuations

text: We investigate infinite Ramsey theory within the framework of general topological spaces, extending classical results for finite colorings of integers and graphs to continuous settings. Our focus is on characterizing compact metrizable spaces that admit "Ramsey-type" properties for certain classes of substructures under arbitrary finite colorings.
