We introduce a novel notion of a "Ramsey metric embedding" and establish conditions on a compact space $X$ for the existence of monochromatic subsets that are isometric or bi-Lipschitz to a given template space $Y$. This work generalizes the Gowers' dichotomy theorem to non-linear settings, offering powerful tools for analyzing metric geometry. We utilize ultrafilters and non-standard analysis to provide a unified approach for both combinatorial and topological interpretations of monochromatic configurations, shedding light on their structural richness.
subject: Matematik
title: Infinite Ramsey Theory for Topological Spaces and Metric Embeddings

text: This paper introduces novel q-analogues for alternating sign matrices (ASMs) by establishing a combinatorial bijection with a specific class of refined plane partitions under certain boundary conditions. We derive generating functions for these q-ASMs using both recurrence relations and direct enumeration via determinantal identities, revealing deep connections to Macdonald polynomials and the statistical mechanics of the six-vertex model. Our approach provides a new perspective on the enumeration of ASMs, circumventing the need for the famous Dodgson condensation method. By analyzing the pole structure of these q-series, we offer new insights into the asymptotic behavior of ASM numbers and their higher-dimensional generalizations, furthering the understanding of combinatorial objects arising from algebraic geometry and physics.
subject: Matematik
title: q-Analogues of Alternating Sign Matrices via Refined Plane Partitions

text: We establish homological stability for the configuration spaces of points on graphs, specifically focusing on the unordered configuration space of $k$ distinct points on a graph $G$, denoted $C_k(G)$. Employing a novel application of discrete Morse theory to cell complexes derived from these spaces, we construct a Morse function whose critical points correspond to specific combinatorial configurations. This allows us to explicitly compute the homology groups in certain ranges and prove that the homology groups $H_i(C_k(G); \mathbb{Z})$ stabilize as $k \to \infty$ for fixed $i$. Our results extend classical homological stability theorems for manifolds to the realm of discrete structures, providing new tools for analyzing the global topological properties of discrete configuration spaces relevant in areas such as robotics and data analysis.
subject: Matematik
title: Homological Stability of Graph Configuration Spaces via Discrete Morse Theory

text: This research investigates extremal lifting operations on combinatorial polytopes, focusing on their impact on integrality gaps for associated linear programming relaxations. We introduce a family of "sparse liftings" that preserve essential combinatorial properties while significantly improving the approximation ratio for specific NP-hard problems, such as the maximum cut problem on non-planar graphs and Steiner tree variants. By analyzing the facial structure and vertex description of these lifted polytopes, we characterize the conditions under which these operations yield optimal or near-optimal integral solutions. Our methodology relies on advanced polyhedral combinatorics, including Chvátal-Gomory cuts and Lovasz-Schrijver operators, providing a constructive framework for generating stronger relaxations and effective bounds for challenging combinatorial optimization problems beyond traditional cutting plane approaches.
subject: Matematik
title: Extremal Lifting Operations on Combinatorial Polytopes and Integrality Gaps

text: We investigate the rank moduli of finite projective planes $\text{PG}(2,q)$, particularly focusing on their incidence matrices over various fields of characteristic $p$. This work extends classical results on the rank of incidence matrices by considering higher-order moduli, yielding a more granular understanding of their algebraic structure. We establish novel connections between the rank properties of these designs and the parameters of quantum error-correcting codes, constructing new families of stabilizer codes with optimal minimum distance. By analyzing the decomposition of the ambient vector space into submodules under the action of the collineation group, we derive explicit bounds on code dimensions and minimum distances. Our findings offer a constructive method for leveraging the rich combinatorial structure of finite geometries to advance the design of robust quantum information processing protocols.
subject: Matematik
title: Rank Moduli of Finite Projective Planes and Their Applications to Quantum Codes

text: Eukaryotic gene expression is exquisitely regulated by chromatin architecture, with histone modifications playing a pivotal role. This study elucidates the molecular mechanism by which a previously uncharacterized protein complex, designated "Chromatin Compaction Factor 1" (CCF1), interacts with the histone methyltransferase SETD2 to establish and maintain repressive chromatin states. We demonstrate that CCF1 selectively recruits SETD2 to specific genomic loci, facilitating the tri-methylation of histone H3 at lysine 36 (H3K36me3) within heterochromatic regions. Loss-of-function studies employing CRISPR-mediated depletion of CCF1 reveal a significant reduction in H3K36me3 levels, concomitant with decreased heterochromatin density, aberrant transcription of silenced genes, and altered nuclear lamina associations. Mechanistically, CCF1 acts as a scaffold, bridging SETD2 to core nucleosomes and enhancing its catalytic efficiency, thereby driving localized chromatin compaction. These findings uncover a critical regulator of H3K36me3 deposition and provide novel insights into the dynamic interplay between histone modifiers and higher-order chromatin organization, with implications for transcriptional fidelity and genome stability.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Novel SETD2-Associated Complex Orchestrates H3K36me3-Mediated Chromatin Compaction and Transcriptional Silencing

text: Circular RNAs (circRNAs) constitute a burgeoning class of non-coding RNAs implicated in various cellular processes, often acting as miRNA sponges. Here, we identify circFOXO3 as a crucial regulator of autophagy in response to nutrient deprivation. Utilizing RNA sequencing and interactome analyses, we demonstrate that circFOXO3 is significantly upregulated under starvation conditions and functions as a molecular sponge for miR-29a. This sequestration liberates the target mRNA of miR-29a, ATG7 (autophagy related 7), leading to increased ATG7 protein translation and subsequent enhancement of autophagosome formation and flux. Overexpression of circFOXO3 promotes autophagic vesicle maturation and degradation, while its knockdown impairs these processes, rendering cells more susceptible to nutrient stress-induced apoptosis. Our data reveal a novel circRNA-miRNA-mRNA regulatory axis involving circFOXO3, miR-29a, and ATG7, which precisely tunes autophagy activity to maintain cellular homeostasis. This mechanism highlights the intricate post-transcriptional control exerted by circRNAs in stress adaptation and offers potential therapeutic targets for metabolic disorders.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Circular RNA circFOXO3 Modulates Autophagy Flux by Sponging miR-29a and Inhibiting ATG7 Expression in Nutrient Stress

text: Intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) are increasingly recognized for their critical roles in mediating transient interactions and forming biomolecular condensates via liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS). This study investigates the IDR-driven phase separation behavior of the transcription factor SOX2, a key regulator of pluripotency. We demonstrate that specific low-complexity domains within SOX2’s intrinsically disordered regions are indispensable for its ability to undergo LLPS, forming dynamic transcriptional condensates enriched with co-activators and Mediator complex components. Mutational analyses disrupting these motifs abrogated condensate formation and significantly impaired SOX2’s transcriptional activity on downstream targets. Furthermore, super-resolution microscopy revealed that SOX2 condensates spatially organize enhancer elements, promoting their clustering and facilitating long-range chromatin interactions essential for robust gene expression. Our findings unveil a sophisticated mechanism where SOX2’s intrinsic disorder governs its biophysical properties, driving the formation of functional phase-separated compartments that are critical for enhancer organization and the precise spatiotemporal regulation of gene networks during development.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Deciphering the Role of Intrinsic Disorder in SOX2's Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation and Transcriptional Enhancer Organization

text: The precise and programmable manipulation of DNA methylation patterns holds immense potential for understanding gene regulation and therapeutic interventions. Here, we present a novel epigenome editing tool leveraging a catalytically inactive Cas9 (dCas9) fused to the catalytic domain of DNA methyltransferase 3A (DNMT3A) for sequence-specific methylation. This dCas9-DNMT3A system enables targeted de novo methylation at guide RNA-directed genomic loci, leading to robust and stable CpG methylation without inducing DNA double-strand breaks or off-target insertions. We demonstrate its efficacy in inducing methylation-dependent gene silencing of endogenous reporters and oncogenes in human cell lines. Furthermore, quantitative methylation analysis and transcriptomic profiling confirm the precision and specificity of the induced epigenetic marks, revealing minimal collateral methylation. This advanced platform offers a precise, versatile, and highly specific approach for studying the causal roles of DNA methylation in transcriptional control, disease pathogenesis, and provides a promising avenue for therapeutic epigenome engineering.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Targeted Epigenome Reprogramming Using a Deactivated Cas9-DNMT3A Fusion for Precision DNA Methylation

text: G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) mediate diverse cellular functions, and their signaling can be biased towards specific downstream pathways. This study characterizes a novel synthetic small molecule, designated "CMX-412", as a biased agonist for the chemokine receptor CXCR4. Unlike canonical agonists, CMX-412 selectively promotes beta-arrestin recruitment and activation, while showing significantly reduced Gαi-mediated signaling and subsequent calcium mobilization. Using advanced optogenetic tools and single-molecule tracking, we elucidated the spatiotemporal dynamics of CMX-412-induced beta-arrestin interactions, revealing prolonged receptor-arrestin complexes localized to clathrin-coated pits, distinct from the transient interactions elicited by unbiased agonists. Furthermore, transcriptomic analysis revealed a unique gene expression signature induced by CMX-412, emphasizing its potential to selectively modulate inflammation and cell migration without undesirable G-protein dependent effects. These findings underscore the therapeutic potential of biased agonism in GPCR pharmacology, providing a blueprint for designing precision therapeutics that decouple beneficial beta-arrestin signaling from potentially deleterious G-protein activation pathways.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatiotemporal Profiling of Beta-Arrestin Biased Signaling by a Novel Agonist of the Chemokine Receptor CXCR4

text: Alternative splicing is a critical post-transcriptional regulatory mechanism often dysregulated in cancer, generating proteomic diversity that can drive oncogenesis. Here, we identify a novel oncogenic splice variant of the Rho-GEF PREX2 (PREX2-ΔExon11) in MYC-amplified glioblastoma (GBM). This variant, characterized by the exclusion of exon 11, exhibits enhanced GEF activity towards Rac1 and Cdc42, leading to sustained activation of downstream MAPK and PI3K/Akt pathways, which are critical for GBM proliferation and invasion. Mechanistically, we show that MYC amplification directly upregulates the splicing factor RBMX, which in turn promotes PREX2-ΔExon11 expression. Inhibition of RBMX or targeted knockdown of PREX2-ΔExon11 significantly attenuates tumor growth and sensitizes GBM cells to temozolomide both in vitro and in orthotopic xenograft models. These findings establish PREX2-ΔExon11 as a driver of MYC-amplified GBM progression and identify the RBMX-PREX2-ΔExon11 axis as a promising therapeutic target for this aggressive brain tumor.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Aberrant Alternative Splicing of PREX2 Drives Oncogenic Signaling in MYC-Amplified Glioblastoma

text: Coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) is an essential electron carrier in the mitochondrial electron transport chain and a potent antioxidant. While dietary intake and ubiquitous synthesis are known, the specific role of the mitochondrial solute carrier SLC25A46 in regulating CoQ10 homeostasis and its impact on cellular bioenergetics remains underexplored. This study reveals that SLC25A46, a protein localized to mitochondrial outer-inner membrane contact sites, facilitates the de novo synthesis of CoQ10 by mediating the import of its precursor, 4-hydroxybenzoic acid, into the mitochondrial matrix. Loss-of-function of SLC25A46 leads to significant depletion of endogenous CoQ10 levels, resulting in compromised mitochondrial complex I and II activity, reduced ATP production, and heightened susceptibility to oxidative stress and lipid peroxidation. Reconstitution of SLC25A46 restores CoQ10 levels and rescues respiratory defects. Our findings uncover a critical and previously unrecognized role for SLC25A46 in controlling mitochondrial CoQ10 synthesis, linking its transport function to cellular redox balance and the regulation of mitochondrial bioenergetics.
subject: Biyoloji
title: SLC25A46-Mediated De Novo Synthesis of Coenzyme Q10 Regulates Mitochondrial Respiration and Lipid Peroxidation

text: Telomeres, nucleoprotein structures capping chromosome ends, are essential for genome stability, yet their repetitive G-rich sequences pose significant challenges to DNA replication. This study identifies RecqL4, a member of the RecQ helicase family, as a critical factor in resolving replication obstacles at telomeres. We demonstrate that RecqL4 is recruited to telomeric regions during S-phase in a TRF2-dependent manner. Mechanistically, RecqL4 unwinds G-quadruplex (G4) structures, which are prone to form within telomeric DNA, thereby preventing replication fork stalling and collapse. Depletion of RecqL4 leads to increased telomere fragility, accumulation of single-stranded DNA gaps, and enhanced activation of the ATR-CHK1 DNA damage response pathway specifically at telomeres. Furthermore, we show that RecqL4’s helicase activity is crucial for its function, as mutation of its catalytic domain abrogates its ability to maintain telomere integrity. These findings uncover a novel role for RecqL4 in facilitating efficient telomere replication through G4 resolution, safeguarding genomic stability.
subject: Biyoloji
title: RecqL4 Helicase Facilitates Telomere Replication Fork Progression by Resolving G-Quadruplex Structures

text: Viral pathogens have evolved sophisticated mechanisms to evade host innate immune responses, particularly the cGAS-STING pathway. Here, we investigate the molecular strategy employed by the accessory protein VPx from HIV-1 group O to counteract host defenses. We discover that VPx functions as a novel E3 ubiquitin ligase, directly targeting and promoting the proteasomal degradation of STING (Stimulator of Interferon Genes). This interaction is mediated by a conserved motif within VPx that specifically recognizes STING and tags it with K48-linked polyubiquitin chains, leading to its rapid turnover. Overexpression of VPx abrogates type I interferon production in response to cytosolic DNA sensing, while its deletion significantly enhances antiviral immunity. Furthermore, structural modeling and mutational analyses identify key residues in VPx crucial for its E3 ligase activity and STING interaction. These findings reveal a previously unrecognized viral strategy for immune evasion, highlighting VPx as a critical determinant of HIV-1 pathogenesis and a promising target for antiviral therapies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The Viral E3 Ligase VPx Targets STING for Degradation, Subverting cGAS-STING Innate Immunity in HIV-1 Infection

text: Human cortical organoids recapitulate key aspects of brain development but lack comprehensive understanding of their dynamic cell-cell communication landscape. Here, we employ high-resolution spatial transcriptomics to map gene expression profiles and infer intercellular communication networks throughout cortical organoid maturation. Our analysis delineates distinct cellular niches corresponding to ventricular zone, subventricular zone, and cortical plate analogues, demonstrating dynamic shifts in cell-type composition and their spatial organization over developmental time. Integrating ligand-receptor interaction databases with spatially resolved transcriptomes revealed complex communication hubs, identifying novel signaling pathways—including Wnt, Notch, and Ephrin signaling—that orchestrate neurogenesis, neuronal migration, and radial glia differentiation. Perturbation experiments targeting identified communication pathways led to specific defects in organoid lamination and cellular differentiation, validating their functional significance. This study provides an unprecedented spatiotemporal atlas of gene expression and cell-cell communication in developing human cortical organoids, offering critical insights into neurodevelopmental processes and disease modeling.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatiotemporal Cell-Cell Communication Networks Orchestrate Human Cortical Organoid Development Revealed by High-Resolution Spatial Transcriptomics

text: This research introduces a novel computational framework for the probabilistic derivation of hierarchical tonal structures, extending Schenkerian analytical principles into an algorithmic domain. We address the inherent ambiguities and subjective interpretations of traditional Schenkerian analysis by proposing a multi-layered Hidden Markov Model (HMM) architecture. This model integrates features derived from voice-leading principles, harmonic function, contrapuntal motion, and rhythmic segmentation to infer Ursatz and middleground prolongations. Probabilistic transition matrices are trained on a corpus of expert-annotated reductions, enabling the system to quantify the likelihood of various structural interpretations. Our methodology incorporates a 'structural coherence index' to evaluate reductions and employs a modified Viterbi algorithm for optimal path discovery through the reductional graph. Preliminary results demonstrate a significant congruence with expert analyses, offering a robust tool for large-scale systematic investigation of tonal masterpieces and generating quantifiable insights into Schenkerian theory's predictive power and descriptive accuracy.
subject: Müzik
title: Algorithmic Derivation of Hierarchical Tonal Structures via Probabilistic Schenkerian Reduction

text: This study develops an axiomatic extension of classical pitch-class set theory (PCSET) to encompass microtonal and non-octave-repeating tuning systems. Traditional PCSET, predicated on 12-tone equal temperament (12-TET) and octave equivalence, proves insufficient for comprehensive analysis of pitch structures in systems with alternative division counts or non-standard fundamental intervals. We propose a generalized modular arithmetic framework, Z_n, where n represents the total number of micro-intervals within the governing periodic span. Our formulation introduces novel definitions for micro-interval classes, normal form, prime form, and Z-relation equivalence, allowing for the systematic classification of sonorities irrespective of n. Furthermore, we redefine transpositional and inversional operations within this expanded theoretical landscape, examining their group-theoretic properties and their implications for symmetrical and asymmetric pitch structures. This framework offers a robust analytical toolkit for composers and theorists working with diverse intonational systems, facilitating comparative analyses of set-theoretic properties across disparate tunings.
subject: Müzik
title: Trans-Octave Equivalence in Microtonal Systems: An Axiomatic Extension of Pitch-Class Set Theory

text: This investigation delineates a comprehensive multivariate approach to mapping objective timbral features to subjective perceptual attributes, specifically focusing on musical brightness and roughness. Utilizing a corpus of synthesized and acoustic instrumental samples, we performed psychoacoustic experiments to gather perceptual ratings. Concurrently, a high-dimensional feature vector was extracted for each sound event, comprising spectral centroids, spread, skewness, kurtosis, zero-crossing rates, irregular components, odd-to-even harmonic ratios, and Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs). A Support Vector Regression (SVR) model with a radial basis function kernel was then employed to establish non-linear relationships between these acoustic descriptors and perceptual judgments. Feature importance analysis, leveraging permutation entropy, revealed critical subsets of spectral and temporal parameters predictive of perceived brightness and roughness, elucidating their complex, interdependent acoustic substrates. The findings advance our understanding of timbral perception and inform more perceptually salient synthesis algorithms and automatic instrument classification systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Multivariate Timbral Feature Space Mapping for Perceptual Correlates of Musical Brightness and Roughness

text: This research explores the application of deep generative models to the intricate domain of species counterpoint, a foundational pedagogical framework for Western tonal music. We introduce a novel Variational Autoencoder (VAE) architecture, specifically designed to learn the latent representations of melodic and harmonic interactions characteristic of 16th-century contrapuntal prolongations. The model is trained on a curated corpus of expertly crafted exercises across all five species, encoded as symbolic representations encompassing pitch, rhythm, and intervallic relationships. By optimizing a loss function that balances reconstruction fidelity with latent space regularity, our VAE generates stylistically coherent counterpoint while enabling controlled exploration of its underlying generative principles. Manipulating the latent space allows for systematic variations in melodic contour, rhythmic density, and dissonance resolution patterns. This approach provides a powerful computational tool for synthesizing novel contrapuntal textures, offering new insights into the systemic constraints and creative potential of historical counterpoint, and suggesting avenues for AI-assisted composition and musicological analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Generative Models for Contrapuntal Prolongation: A Latent Space Exploration of 16th-Century Species Counterpoint

text: This study proposes a novel wavelet-based methodology for the analysis of cross-metric phase alignment and entrainment in complex polyrhythmic structures. Traditional beat tracking algorithms often fail to robustly identify and differentiate concurrent metric strata, particularly in non-isochronous or highly syncopated contexts. Our approach leverages the multi-resolution capabilities of the Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT) to decompose rhythmic onset sequences into salient periodic components across a spectro-temporal landscape. By applying cross-correlation techniques to the phase characteristics of these components, we quantify 'metric drift' and 'entrainment strength' between co-occurring rhythmic streams. This allows for the precise detection of micro-timing variations and the identification of hierarchical metric relationships, even in the presence of metrical dissonance. The framework provides a powerful analytical tool for investigating rhythmic complexity in diverse musical traditions, from sub-Saharan African drumming to avant-garde Western compositions, offering quantifiable insights into perceptual grouping and motoric synchronization.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Metric Phase Alignment and Entrainment in Complex Polyrhythmic Structures: A Wavelet-Based Approach

text: This study presents a novel multi-modal feature fusion framework for enhanced affective state prediction in music, addressing the inherent limitations of single-modality approaches. We integrate heterogeneous data streams encompassing acoustic, symbolic, and rudimentary semantic representations. Acoustic features include spectro-temporal descriptors, MFCCs, and statistical aggregates of dynamic and rhythmic envelopes. Symbolic features are derived from MIDI data, capturing harmonic density, melodic entropy, intervallic tension, and metric regularity. Semantic features, such as genre tags and mood labels, are embedded using pre-trained language models. A deep neural network architecture, featuring parallel convolutional and recurrent layers followed by an attention-weighted fusion mechanism, is employed to learn complex inter-modal dependencies. The model predicts continuous valence-arousal dimensions, demonstrating significantly improved predictive accuracy and generalization performance compared to unimodal baselines across diverse musical corpora. This integrated approach offers a more holistic understanding of musical affect and paves the way for sophisticated MIR applications and adaptive recommendation systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Multi-Modal Feature Fusion for Affective State Prediction in Music: Integrating Symbolic, Acoustic, and Semantic Representations

text: This research introduces a novel graph-theoretic methodology for the rigorous analysis of atonal pitch structures, extending beyond the conventional capabilities of pitch-class set theory. We model pitch collections and their interrelationships as directed graphs, where nodes represent discrete pitch entities or aggregates, and edges encode specific transformational operations (e.g., transposition, inversion, complementation, and generalized interval-class vectors). By constructing 'transformational networks' for entire compositions, we employ algorithms for maximal common subgraph detection and spectral graph analysis to uncover latent symmetries, recurring structural motifs, and hidden voice-leading paradigms. The framework enables the identification of intricate organizational principles in works by composers such as Schoenberg, Webern, and Berg, often revealing non-obvious relationships between seemingly disparate sonorities. This approach provides a powerful and adaptable analytical tool for elucidating the complex, often non-hierarchical, internal coherence of post-tonal music and offers new perspectives on its generative grammar.
subject: Müzik
title: Graph-Theoretic Approaches to Atonal Pitch Structure Analysis: Identifying Generalized Symmetries and Transformational Networks

text: This study presents a novel deep learning architecture for instrument-agnostic source separation of highly polyphonic musical textures, tackling the inherent complexities of diverse timbral characteristics and overlapping spectral content. We propose a U-Net inspired convolutional neural network, WaveSep-GAN, operating directly on the raw audio waveform, thereby circumventing phase reconstruction issues common in spectrogram-based methods. A crucial innovation is the integration of an adversarial regularization loss, where a discriminator network evaluates the perceptual authenticity and source independence of the separated components. This adversarial training encourages the generator to produce disentangled audio streams that are not only accurate but also perceptually realistic, even for instruments unseen during training. Quantitative evaluations, using metrics such as Source-to-Distortion Ratio (SDR) and Source-to-Interference Ratio (SIR), demonstrate state-of-the-art performance, offering significant advancements for automatic music transcription, re-orchestration, and advanced music information retrieval applications requiring granular control over individual sonic elements.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Learning for Instrument-Agnostic Source Separation of Polyphonic Musical Textures with Adversarial Regularization

text: This research undertakes a rigorous comparative analysis of historical tuning temperaments through a multi-faceted approach combining precise digital audio synthesis and controlled psychoacoustic experimentation. Moving beyond purely theoretical discussions, we systematically generate musical excerpts, specifically focusing on cadential progressions and harmonic intervals, rendered in Pythagorean, various Meantone, and prominent Well Temperaments (e.g., Werckmeister III, Kirnberger III). Participants evaluate perceived consonance, stability, brightness, and affective valence under controlled listening conditions. Concurrently, spectral analysis techniques, including time-domain beating frequency detection and harmonic partial alignment metrics (e.g., inharmonicity index), are employed to correlate objective acoustic properties with subjective perceptual judgments. Our findings elucidate the psychoacoustic underpinnings of historical intonational choices and their impact on musical expression, providing empirical evidence that bridges music theory with auditory perception. This work offers crucial insights for historically informed performance and the digital preservation of diverse sonic aesthetics.
subject: Müzik
title: Comparative Analysis of Historical Temperaments via Digital Audio Synthesis and Psychoacoustic Evaluation of Consonance Perception

text: This research extends generalized Neo-Riemannian transformational theory to encompass post-tonal harmonic contexts, moving beyond its original triadic and tonal system specificities. We propose a formalization based on abstract group theory and geometric topology, where harmonic spaces are conceptualized as quotient spaces or orbifolds derived from permutations on pitch-class sets or interval vectors. Our framework redefines the P, L, and R operations not as transformations between major/minor triads, but as generalized group actions on arbitrary n-tuples of pitch classes, thereby accommodating non-tertian and atonal sonorities. This allows for the construction of "harmonic landscapes" where transformational pathways can be topologically characterized by their symmetry groups and adjacency relationships. Through case studies on works by composers employing synthetic scales and complex harmonies (e.g., Messiaen, Scriabin), we demonstrate the framework's capacity to reveal deep structural coherence and underlying mathematical symmetries in repertoires traditionally resistant to systematic transformational analysis. The findings offer a powerful lens for understanding harmonic motion in extended tonal and post-tonal idioms.
subject: Müzik
title: Generalized Neo-Riemannian Operations in Post-Tonal Contexts: A Topological Characterization of Harmonic Transformations

text: This work addresses the fundamental challenge of robust causal inference in high-dimensional observational data for deep learning models, where spurious correlations often impede genuine understanding. We propose a novel Counterfactual Regularization (CFR) framework that integrates a deep structural causal model with an adversarial balancing mechanism for proxy variables. Our method iteratively optimizes a variational autoencoder to learn disentangled, causally invariant representations by minimizing the average treatment effect across latent dimensions under various intervention sets, thereby disentangling confounders from true causal factors. Experimental validation on synthetic biological interaction networks and real-world medical datasets demonstrates superior performance in identifying genuine causal links, exhibiting enhanced generalization under severe distribution shifts, and improved robustness against spurious correlations compared to state-of-the-art non-causal and weakly causal deep learning approaches, marking a significant advancement towards deployable AI systems that infer rather than merely predict.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Regularization for Robust Causal Feature Learning in High-Dimensional Observational Data

text: This research focuses on the critical safety alignment problem for autonomous agents powered by large language models (LLMs) operating in complex, dynamic environments. We propose a novel framework integrating constrained reinforcement learning (CRL) with formal verification techniques to ensure provably safe LLM agent behavior. Our approach encodes safety specifications as temporal logic properties, which are then used to derive hard constraints for the agent's policy optimization via a differentiable satisfiability solver. This mechanism guides the LLM's action selection process by projecting its latent action space onto a safe manifold, ensuring strict adherence to pre-defined safety invariants and liveness properties. Empirical results in simulated high-stakes scenarios demonstrate that our method significantly reduces safety violations while maintaining competitive task performance compared to unconstrained or heuristically constrained LLM agents, paving the way for trustworthy autonomous systems.
subject: AI
title: Provably Safe Constrained Reinforcement Learning for Large Language Model Agents via Formal Verification

text: We explore the synergistic potential of quantum computing and graph neural networks (GNNs) by introducing a novel Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) based approach for optimizing GNN parameters. We map the GNN's weight optimization problem onto a parameterized quantum circuit (PQC) where the cost function is defined by a quantum observable encoding the GNN's performance metric (e.g., node classification accuracy). Our hybrid classical-quantum algorithm leverages the VQE’s capacity for exploring high-dimensional Hilbert spaces, potentially circumventing local minima common in classical optimization landscapes. Through simulations on NISQ-era hardware emulators for diverse graph datasets, we demonstrate competitive performance against classical GNN optimization techniques, particularly in scenarios exhibiting complex non-linear dependencies. This work establishes a foundational step towards quantum-enhanced graph representation learning, addressing the computational bottlenecks of large-scale, high-dimensional graph data.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Eigensolver for Graph Neural Network Parameter Optimization

text: This work addresses the challenge of integrating symbolic reasoning with sub-symbolic pattern recognition by proposing a novel neuro-symbolic architecture capable of inductive logic programming (ILP). Our framework embeds first-order logic predicates as learnable tensor representations within a deep neural network, enabling differentiable reasoning over knowledge graphs. A key innovation is the development of a 'Neuro-Symbolic Loss' function that penalizes violations of logical consistency and encourages the discovery of new logical rules from data, inspired by ILP principles. This hybrid system leverages the pattern extraction capabilities of neural networks while maintaining the interpretability and generalizability of symbolic knowledge. Experiments on complex relational reasoning tasks and rule induction from incomplete knowledge bases demonstrate superior performance in both predictive accuracy and the derivation of human-readable logical rules compared to purely neural or purely symbolic approaches.
subject: AI
title: Inductive Logic Programming via Differentiable Reasoning in Deep Neural Networks

text: This paper investigates the critical interplay between data privacy, model robustness, and adversarial resilience in federated learning (FL) settings. We propose a novel framework for Byzantine-robust FL that incorporates strong differential privacy guarantees. Our method combines secure aggregation with a gradient perturbation strategy where client-side gradients are additively perturbed using Gaussian noise, calibrated to a specific privacy budget (ε, δ), before being encrypted and aggregated. Furthermore, we introduce an adaptive robust aggregation scheme that employs a Krum-like mechanism operating on the differentially private aggregated gradients, effectively mitigating the influence of malicious clients injecting arbitrary updates. Comprehensive evaluations across various non-IID data distributions and Byzantine attack scenarios demonstrate that our approach simultaneously achieves enhanced privacy protection, maintains model utility, and significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in robustness against data poisoning and model manipulation attacks without sacrificing privacy.
subject: AI
title: Differentially Private Byzantine-Robust Federated Learning with Gradient Perturbation and Secure Aggregation

text: This research addresses the profound challenge of catastrophic forgetting in continual learning (CL) systems operating in dynamically evolving, non-stationary task streams. We introduce an 'Omniscient Meta-Learning' (OML) framework that synthesizes meta-learning with an episodic memory replay mechanism, guided by a novel task-agnostic meta-prior. Unlike conventional CL approaches, OML learns to rapidly adapt to new tasks while strategically replaying a minimal set of past experiences, parameterized by a task embedding network that dynamically weighs knowledge retention and acquisition. This adaptive replay strategy, coupled with a gradient-based meta-optimizer, enables efficient knowledge transfer and robust resistance to forgetting without requiring extensive task boundaries or storing all previous data. Empirical evaluation across diverse sequences of few-shot classification and regression tasks demonstrates superior performance in mitigating forgetting and achieving higher average accuracy compared to leading continual and meta-learning baselines.
subject: AI
title: Omniscient Meta-Learning for Catastrophic Forgetting Mitigation in Non-Stationary Task Streams

text: This work explores the representation capabilities of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) on non-Euclidean geometries, specifically focusing on hyperbolic spaces for data exhibiting hierarchical or scale-free structures. We propose Curvature-Aware Graph Neural Networks (CA-GNNs) that embed graph nodes into hyperbolic manifolds, enabling more expressive and compact representations compared to their Euclidean counterparts. Our architecture incorporates a novel hyperbolic message-passing mechanism that accounts for the constant negative curvature, utilizing Riemannian optimization techniques to learn both node embeddings and adaptive hyperbolic radius parameters. This design naturally captures long-range dependencies and intricate hierarchical relationships. Experimental validation on diverse datasets, including social networks and biological graphs, demonstrates that CA-GNNs achieve significantly improved performance in tasks such as node classification, link prediction, and anomaly detection, highlighting the superior inductive biases offered by hyperbolic geometry for complex graph structures.
subject: AI
title: Curvature-Aware Graph Neural Networks for Hyperbolic Feature Learning on Manifold Data

text: This paper addresses the imperative for robust and actionable explanations in high-stakes AI systems by proposing a novel method for generating Contrastive Counterfactual Explanations (CCEs) grounded in causal reasoning. Our approach generates minimal interventions on input features that flip a model's prediction while satisfying underlying causal constraints, ensuring the explanations are not only faithful to the model but also reflect realistic and actionable modifications. We introduce a causal regularization term into the counterfactual search objective, which leverages a learned or pre-defined causal graph of the input features to prioritize causally valid counterfactuals and avoid implausible suggestions. Extensive evaluation across diverse tabular and image classification tasks demonstrates that our CCEs are more robust to adversarial perturbations, lead to higher user trust, and provide more actionable insights than traditional perturbation-based or purely correlational counterfactual methods, advancing the state-of-the-art in trustworthy XAI.
subject: AI
title: Contrastive Counterfactual Explanations with Causal Regularization for Robust and Actionable XAI

text: This research investigates the efficacy of large language models (LLMs) as autonomous agents within complex, goal-oriented dialogue systems, focusing on robust policy learning and self-refinement. We propose an Adversarial Policy Gradient (APG) framework where an LLM agent learns to navigate intricate conversational states by interacting with a learnable, adversarial user simulator. The agent's policy is fine-tuned via reinforcement learning, where rewards are augmented by a discriminator that penalizes inconsistent or non-cohesive dialogue turns, thereby fostering more natural and task-effective responses. Crucially, the LLM agent also incorporates a self-refinement mechanism, where it critically evaluates its own dialogue history and generates corrective meta-actions to improve future interactions. Experiments on multi-turn negotiation and information-seeking tasks demonstrate that APG significantly enhances dialogue success rates, reduces user effort, and produces more robust conversational policies compared to standard RL and supervised fine-tuning approaches for LLM agents.
subject: AI
title: Adversarial Policy Gradient for Goal-Oriented Dialogue Systems with Self-Refining LLM Agents

text: This work addresses the computational and biological plausibility limitations of training deep Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) by introducing a novel spatio-temporal backpropagation algorithm. Our method, termed Event-Driven Optimization (EDO), directly optimizes SNN parameters by leveraging the precise timing of spikes and membrane potentials, eliminating the need for surrogate gradients or rate-coding approximations common in previous approaches. EDO computes gradients through the discrete spike generation process by considering the precise spike times and propagating error signals across both spatial layers and temporal sequences of neuronal activations. This enables end-to-end training of deep SNN architectures on complex spatio-temporal datasets with high temporal resolution. Experimental results on neuromorphic benchmarks and event-based vision tasks demonstrate that EDO achieves state-of-the-art accuracy with significantly reduced energy consumption and improved biological fidelity, paving the way for efficient and robust brain-inspired AI.
subject: AI
title: Spatio-Temporal Backpropagation for Biologically Plausible Spiking Neural Networks via Event-Driven Optimization

text: This work investigates the robust realization of topological quantum computation within engineered one-dimensional dimerized chains hosting non-Abelian anyonic excitations, specifically focusing on Majorana zero modes (MZMs). We detail a theoretical framework for manipulating and braiding these localized quasiparticles, demonstrating how their non-trivial exchange statistics can encode quantum information immune to local perturbations. Through detailed numerical simulations based on tight-binding models, we show that tuning inter-site couplings and introducing controlled disorder can stabilize protected degenerate ground states, crucial for fault-tolerant operations. Furthermore, we propose specific measurement protocols leveraging interferometric schemes to probe the non-Abelian nature of the MZMs and verify their suitability for implementing logical gate operations, thereby addressing a critical challenge in scalable quantum hardware development.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Protection and Error Correction via Non-Abelian Anyons in Dimerized Chains

text: We explore the non-Hermitian dynamics of open quantum systems operating near exceptional points (EPs), demonstrating their potential for enhanced quantum sensing and state manipulation. By meticulously engineering dissipative interactions, described by a Lindblad master equation with a non-Hermitian effective Hamiltonian, we reveal a critical regime where the coalescence of eigenvalues and eigenvectors at an EP leads to an amplified response to external perturbations. Our theoretical analysis, validated through numerical simulations of coupled cavity QED systems, shows that the sensitivity of spectral features to environmental parameters scales quadratically or cubically, surpassing the linear scaling of Hermitian counterparts. This work provides a rigorous framework for harnessing non-Hermiticity to optimize quantum metrology protocols and offers insights into the fundamental interplay between system-environment coupling and quantum coherence.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Hermitian Quantum Dynamics and Enhanced Sensing at Exceptional Points in Open Systems

text: We present a comprehensive theoretical and experimental study on achieving high-fidelity entangling gates in multi-qubit superconducting circuits using flux-mediated interactions. Our approach leverages tunable couplers based on a parametrically driven SQUID, enabling precise control over the qubit-qubit coupling strength and interaction time. By mitigating spurious ZZ-coupling and minimizing the Purcell effect through careful resonator engineering, we demonstrate gate fidelities exceeding 99.9% for two-qubit controlled-Z gates, as benchmarked by randomized benchmarking and quantum process tomography. We detail the optimization protocols for pulse shaping and flux tuning to reduce leakage to higher transmon levels and suppress crosstalk, highlighting the scalability potential for constructing complex quantum processors with inherent error resilience against common coherent errors.
subject: Kuantum
title: High-Fidelity Entangling Gates in Superconducting Qubit Architectures via Flux-Mediated Interactions

text: This research investigates the emergence of Many-Body Localization (MBL) and its phase transitions in disordered ultracold atomic Fermi gases trapped in optical lattices. Employing a combination of quantum gas microscopy and site-resolved detection, we experimentally probe the real-time dynamics of local observables and entanglement entropy in systems subjected to tailored quasi-periodic potentials. We identify a sharp transition from an ergodic, thermalizing phase to a non-ergodic MBL phase characterized by area-law entanglement scaling and persistent memory of initial conditions. Our numerical simulations, leveraging exact diagonalization and tensor network methods, corroborate the experimental findings, offering insights into the critical exponents and the role of interaction strength and disorder correlation in driving this fundamental quantum phase transition, with implications for quantum information storage.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent Many-Body Localization Transitions in Disordered Ultracold Atomic Fermi Gases

text: We theoretically analyze the behavior of quantum entanglement for Dirac and scalar fields in non-inertial reference frames and curved spacetimes, particularly focusing on the Unruh effect and its implications for quantum information. Utilizing techniques from quantum field theory in curved spacetime, we quantify the degradation of entanglement shared between two localized detectors when one undergoes uniform acceleration or when both interact with a gravitational field characterized by varying curvature. Our results demonstrate that the Unruh temperature and the Riemann curvature tensor significantly influence the distillability and security of quantum communication channels. We provide specific protocols for mitigating entanglement decay, suggesting novel approaches for maintaining quantum correlations in extreme relativistic environments, relevant for future quantum technologies in space.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Entanglement Dynamics in Spacetime with Varying Curvature and Accelerated Frames

text: This study employs the functional renormalization group (fRG) approach to investigate quantum critical phenomena in strongly correlated electron systems, specifically focusing on the breakdown of Fermi liquid theory in the vicinity of magnetic instabilities. We develop a comprehensive fRG scheme capable of handling multi-orbital Hubbard models and their extensions, capturing non-perturbative effects arising from strong electron-electron interactions. Our analysis reveals universal scaling laws and critical exponents associated with quantum phase transitions in two- and three-dimensional lattice systems, predicting novel ground states such as unconventional superconductivity and non-Fermi liquid phases. The fRG framework provides a powerful, unbiased tool for mapping complex phase diagrams and offers deep insights into the microscopic origins of exotic many-body states, bridging the gap between weak and strong coupling regimes.
subject: Kuantum
title: Functional Renormalization Group Analysis of Quantum Criticality in Correlated Electron Systems

text: We present a theoretical framework for generating and maintaining macroscopic quantum superposition states in mesoscopic optomechanical systems, exploring the potential role of gravitational decoupling in enhancing coherence times. By precisely engineering the coupling between a mechanical resonator and a high-finesse optical cavity, we propose a scheme to prepare "Schrödinger's cat" states of the mechanical oscillator with unprecedented size. Our model incorporates environmental decoherence mechanisms, including thermal noise and residual gas damping, alongside novel considerations for fundamental decoherence induced by spacetime fluctuations, as predicted by certain quantum gravity theories. We demonstrate that specific pulse sequences and squeezing operations can extend coherence times beyond classical limits, opening pathways for testing the foundations of quantum mechanics at the interface with gravity and exploring the Leggett-Garg inequality for massive objects.
subject: Kuantum
title: Gravitational Decoupling and Macroscopic Quantum Coherence in Optomechanical Systems

text: This research details the implementation and characterization of quantum-enhanced metrology techniques aimed at surpassing the standard quantum limit (SQL) in gravitational wave detectors. We demonstrate the practical benefits of injecting highly squeezed vacuum states into large-scale Michelson interferometers, such as LIGO, to reduce quantum shot noise and significantly improve strain sensitivity across the astrophysical frequency band. Our analysis incorporates the effects of radiation pressure noise and optical losses, revealing optimal squeezing parameters and frequency-dependent squeezing strategies for achieving the Heisenberg limit in specific spectral regions. Furthermore, we explore the potential of using entangling non-Gaussian states and quantum non-demolition measurements to unlock even greater sensitivities, paving the way for next-generation observatories and enabling the detection of fainter cosmic events.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum-Enhanced Gravitational Wave Detection via Squeezed Light and Entangled Interferometry

text: We investigate the realization and manipulation of non-Abelian anyonic excitations in fractional quantum Hall (FQH) states formed in magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene (MATBG) heterostructures. Our theoretical model predicts the stabilization of specific FQH sequences at partial fillings of flat electronic bands, leading to ground states characterized by topological order and fractionalized charge carriers with non-Abelian statistics, analogous to the `nu=5/2` state in conventional GaAs systems. Through detailed numerical studies based on exact diagonalization in the Landau gauge and density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) calculations, we delineate the phase diagram as a function of external magnetic fields and twist angle. This work proposes novel experimental signatures for detecting these elusive anyons, paving the way for intrinsic topological quantum computing platforms leveraging the tunable electronic properties of moiré superlattices.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergence of Non-Abelian Anyonic Statistics in Fractional Quantum Hall States of Moiré Graphene

text: This study explores the interplay between quantum chaos, ergodicity, and thermalization in periodically driven bosonic condensates, bridging concepts from random matrix theory (RMT) and many-body localization. We analyze the spectral statistics and entanglement properties of interacting bosonic systems subjected to Floquet driving, identifying transitions from integrable to chaotic behavior characterized by Wigner-Dyson level spacing distributions. Our work extends to investigating the emergence of "quantum scars"—atypical eigenstates that violate the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH) and lead to persistent oscillations in local observables—in specific geometries. By drawing parallels to the Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) model and leveraging exact diagonalization and time-dependent variational principles, we elucidate the mechanisms underlying these non-thermalizing phenomena, offering profound insights into the foundations of statistical mechanics in quantum systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Chaos and Ergodicity Breaking in Driven Bosonic Condensates: From SYK to Quantum Scars

text: The precise and heritable manipulation of epigenetic marks offers transformative potential for therapeutic intervention. This study elucidates the design and characterization of novel designer epigenetic editors utilizing catalytically inactive Cas9 (dCas9) fused to a diverse panel of epigenetic effector domains, including DNA methyltransferases, histone acetyltransferases, and demethylases. We demonstrate sequence-specific recruitment of these dCas9-effectors to promoter regions, inducing robust and enduring transcriptional silencing or activation without altering genomic DNA sequence. High-resolution epigenomic profiling (e.g., ChIP-seq, ATAC-seq) reveals precise alterations in local chromatin accessibility and histone modification landscapes, correlating directly with changes in gene expression. Further analysis delineates the critical linker architectures and effector domain stoichiometries for optimal epigenetic targeting efficiency and specificity, minimizing off-target effects. Our findings establish a versatile platform for programmable epigenome engineering, providing unprecedented control over gene regulation and paving the way for targeted therapeutic strategies against epigenetic dysregulation in disease.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Precision Epigenome Editing via dCas9-Effector Fusions for Targeted Gene Silencing and Chromatin Remodeling

text: Circular RNAs (circRNAs) represent a burgeoning class of non-coding RNAs implicated in diverse biological processes, yet their precise roles in neuronal function remain largely enigmatic. This research employs comprehensive RNA-sequencing, proteomics, and functional genomic approaches to map the dynamic expression profile of circRNAs across critical stages of neuronal differentiation and activity-dependent synaptic plasticity. We identify a subset of highly enriched neuronal circRNAs acting as potent microRNA (miRNA) sponges, thereby indirectly modulating the expression of key synaptic plasticity-related mRNAs. Mechanistic investigations using CRISPR-Cas13-mediated circRNA knockdown and target overexpression reveal direct impact on dendritic spine morphology, glutamatergic receptor trafficking, and long-term potentiation. Furthermore, integrative analysis of patient-derived iPSC neurons elucidates dysregulated circRNA networks in specific neurodevelopmental disorders, suggesting their potential as diagnostic biomarkers and therapeutic targets for restoring synaptic homeostasis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Deciphering the CircRNA-miRNA-mRNA Regulatory Network in Synaptic Plasticity and Neurodevelopmental Disorders

text: The CRL4DDB2 E3 ubiquitin ligase complex is a pivotal regulator of nucleotide excision repair (NER), orchestrating the ubiquitination of damaged DNA recognition factors. Despite its known role, the intricate allosteric mechanisms governing its substrate specificity and catalytic activity remain poorly defined. Utilizing a combination of cryo-electron microscopy, hydrogen-deuterium exchange mass spectrometry, and kinetic assays, we elucidate novel conformational states of the CRL4DDB2 complex in response to allosteric ligand binding. Our structural analyses reveal distinct regulatory pockets distal to the active site, whose occupancy induces substantial rearrangements in the DDB1-DDB2 interface and shifts the catalytic efficiency towards specific substrates involved in early NER pathway steps. Pharmacological modulation of these allosteric sites demonstrates precise control over DNA damage recognition and downstream repair kinetics. These findings provide fundamental insights into the intricate regulation of E3 ligases, offering a refined framework for developing targeted therapeutics against DNA repair deficiencies in cancer.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Allosteric Modulators of the CRL4DDB2 E3 Ubiquitin Ligase Complex: Implications for DNA Repair Pathway Fidelity

text: Non-canonical Wnt/Planar Cell Polarity (PCP) signaling is a critical determinant of cellular architecture and coordinated migration, yet its spatiotemporal dynamics during complex morphogenetic events remain poorly characterized. This study leverages advanced live-cell imaging coupled with Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) biosensors to delineate the activation kinetics and subcellular localization of key PCP pathway components (e.g., Frizzled, Dishevelled, RhoA) within migrating cell collectives. We reveal that localized gradients of Wnt5a elicit a polarized activation of the core PCP machinery at leading edge cells, driving actin cytoskeleton reorganization and mediating intercellular force transmission via cadherin-based adhesions. Optogenetic manipulation of Wnt/PCP pathway activity demonstrates precise control over collective cell migration speed and directionality in both 2D and complex 3D tissue models. These findings provide a high-resolution mechanistic understanding of how Wnt/PCP signaling orchestrates coherent cell movement, with broad implications for embryogenesis, wound healing, and metastatic progression.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatiotemporal Deconvolution of Non-Canonical Wnt/PCP Signaling Orchestrating Collective Cell Migration

text: Understanding the cellular heterogeneity within the tumor microenvironment (TME) is paramount for overcoming immune evasion. Here, we apply an integrated single-cell multi-omics approach (simultaneous scRNA-seq and scATAC-seq) to profile thousands of individual T cells infiltrating diverse human solid tumors. Our analysis uncovers previously unappreciated immune cell states characterized by distinct epigenetic landscapes and transcriptional programs, ranging from terminally exhausted phenotypes to highly plastic, stem-like populations. We identify novel cis-regulatory elements and transcription factor networks associated with immune checkpoint blockade resistance, revealing specific chromatin accessibility changes that precede gene expression shifts in exhausted T cells. Computational integration of chromatin accessibility and gene expression profiles provides a refined classification of T cell subsets, offering new insights into their developmental trajectories and functional plasticity within the immunosuppressive TME. These findings illuminate potential therapeutic targets for reinvigorating anti-tumor immunity by modulating epigenetic states.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Single-Cell Multi-Omics Uncovers Heterogeneous Chromatin States and Transcriptional Networks in Immune Evasion

text: Mitochondrial cristae architecture is intricately linked to optimal oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) and cellular bioenergetics, yet the molecular mechanisms governing their dynamic remodeling and functional implications remain incompletely understood. This study employs electron cryo-tomography and super-resolution microscopy to dissect the three-dimensional structural changes of mitochondrial cristae in response to various metabolic stressors. We demonstrate that the dynamin-related GTPase Opa1 plays a pivotal role in shaping cristae, with distinct isoforms differentially influencing cristae junction formation and overall membrane curvature. Functional assays reveal that precise modulation of Opa1 isoform ratios directly impacts the efficiency of ATP synthase dimerization and electron transport chain supercomplex assembly, consequently altering cellular oxygen consumption rates and ATP production. Perturbations in Opa1-mediated cristae dynamics induce a metabolic shift towards glycolysis, suggesting its critical role in metabolic adaptation. These insights advance our understanding of mitochondrial structural plasticity and its profound impact on cellular metabolism and disease pathogenesis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mitochondrial Cristae Dynamics and OXPHOS Efficiency: A Role for Opa1 in Metabolic Reprogramming

text: Selective autophagy pathways are crucial for maintaining cellular homeostasis by targeting specific organelles and protein aggregates for lysosomal degradation. This research systematically characterizes the molecular determinants governing the recruitment and cargo specificity of key selective autophagy receptors (e.g., p62, NBR1, OPTN, NDP52). Using quantitative proteomics, ubiquitin chain topology analyses, and synthetic ubiquitin mimics, we delineate the 'ubiquitin code' recognized by the UBA or LIR domains of these receptors. We demonstrate that specific polyubiquitin chain linkages (e.g., K63, K48, M1) and their spatial arrangement on the cargo dictate receptor affinity and downstream autophagosome biogenesis. Mutational analyses reveal critical residues within receptor ubiquitin-binding domains that confer selectivity, and their disruption impairs the targeted degradation of damaged mitochondria (mitophagy) and peroxisomes (pexophagy). These findings provide unprecedented insights into the precision of selective autophagy and offer avenues for therapeutic intervention in diseases driven by impaired cargo recognition.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dissecting the Ubiquitin Code Governing Selective Autophagy Receptor Recruitment and Lysosomal Degradation

text: Synthetic biology holds immense promise for developing intelligent cell-based therapeutics. This work engineers a robust, autonomous mammalian gene circuit designed for glucose-responsive insulin secretion, aiming to address limitations of current diabetes management. Our circuit integrates multiple regulatory layers: a glucose-sensing promoter driving the expression of a synthetic zinc finger transcription factor (ZF-TF), which in turn controls a novel insulin analog. We optimize component compatibility and kinetic parameters, achieving a tight feedback loop that enables sustained, physiological-range insulin release proportional to glucose concentrations, mirroring endogenous beta-cell function. In vitro validation demonstrates rapid ON/OFF switching and adjustable set-points. In vivo studies utilizing encapsulated engineered cells show efficient glucose homeostasis maintenance in diabetic murine models without hypoglycemia. This self-regulating bio-device represents a significant advancement in synthetic biology, establishing a foundational platform for programmable cell-based therapies for metabolic disorders and beyond.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Engineering Autonomous Mammalian Gene Circuits for Programmable Therapeutic Insulin Secretion

text: The cGAS-STING pathway is a crucial innate immune surveillance system detecting cytosolic DNA and initiating antiviral responses. However, many viruses have evolved sophisticated strategies to evade or suppress this pathway. This study dissects the molecular mechanisms employed by a clinically relevant herpesvirus to antagonize cGAS-STING signaling. We identify a novel viral protein, herein termed 'STING-Modulator' (SM), which directly interacts with and promotes the proteasomal degradation of STING independent of its canonical ubiquitination. Biochemical assays and co-immunoprecipitation experiments delineate the specific interaction domains and identify host E3 ligases co-opted by SM. Deletion of SM significantly enhances the host's antiviral interferon response and attenuates viral replication in primary cell cultures and in vivo. These findings reveal a critical viral immune evasion strategy targeting a central node of innate immunity, offering potential therapeutic avenues through the development of SM inhibitors or STING pathway activators.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Molecular Mechanisms of Viral Antagonism Towards cGAS-STING Signaling in Herpesvirus Infections

text: DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) arising during replication stress pose a significant threat to genome integrity, necessitating precise repair pathway choice. This study investigates the intricate molecular crosstalk and competition between homologous recombination (HR) and non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) in resolving replication fork-associated DSBs. Using single-molecule imaging and high-throughput sequencing of repair junctions, we demonstrate that replication stress differentially modulates chromatin accessibility and recruits specific end-processing nucleases, thereby dictating the repair pathway outcome. We identify a novel interplay involving the resection nuclease MRE11 and the NHEJ factor Ku70/80 that influences DSB end accessibility, biasing repair towards either error-free HR or mutagenic alternative-NHEJ. Perturbing this regulatory axis by small molecule inhibitors significantly impacts genome stability, leading to chromosomal translocations and deletions. These insights reveal critical checkpoints in DSB repair pathway choice, with implications for understanding cancer predisposition and enhancing chemosensitivity to DNA-damaging agents.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Crosstalk Between Homologous Recombination and Non-Homologous End Joining in Maintaining Genome Stability During Replication Stress

text: Investigating the drivers of unparalleled biodiversity, we present a phylogenomic analysis of an adaptive radiation in a novel clitic insect lineage endemic to the East African Rift montane 'sky-islands'. Leveraging ultra-conserved elements (UCEs) and mitochondrial genomes from over 300 operational taxonomic units, we reconstruct a robust phylogeny to ascertain the tempo and mode of diversification. Our findings reveal recurrent ecological speciation events driven by niche partitioning across elevational gradients and host plant specificity. Notably, we identify significant instances of phenotypic convergence in feeding apparatus morphology and cryptic coloration, demonstrating independent adaptation to similar selective regimes. Genomic scans for positive selection corroborate these patterns, pinpointing candidate genes underlying key adaptive traits. This study underscores the complex interplay between geographic isolation, ecological opportunity, and genomic architecture in generating and shaping species radiations.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Disentanglement of Ecological Speciation and Convergent Evolution in Montane Archipelagos

text: Intragenomic conflict arising from transposable element (TE) proliferation poses a pervasive threat to genome integrity, often leading to hybrid dysgenesis. Our research investigates the molecular mechanisms governing TE control in nascent hybrid zones of *Drosophila melanogaster* subspecies, where incompatible epigenetic regulatory systems collide. Utilizing high-throughput sequencing of small RNAs and bisulfite sequencing, we uncover a profound surge in TE transcriptional activity and widespread ectopic transposition in F1 hybrids. This 'TE burst' correlates with a breakdown in parental piRNA pathway machinery and altered DNA methylation landscapes at pericentromeric TE arrays. Furthermore, we identify specific host genes exhibiting dosage-sensitive effects on TE suppression, implying an ongoing evolutionary arms race. These findings illuminate the critical role of epigenetic surveillance in mitigating intragenomic conflict and provide insights into the genomic shock accompanying early stages of speciation.
subject: Evrim
title: Recalcitrant Transposable Element Bursts and Their Epigenetic Suppression in Hybrid Dysgenesis Zones

text: Eco-evolutionary dynamics are increasingly recognized as crucial determinants of population and community trajectories. We investigated the interplay between rapid phenotypic plasticity and adaptive genetic divergence in a freshwater system involving the planktivorous fish *Perca fluviatilis* and its primary zooplankton prey, *Daphnia magna*. Over a five-year mesocosm experiment, we observed significant predator-induced shifts in *Daphnia* life-history traits and morphology (e.g., helmet size, spine length) within single generations, indicative of phenotypic plasticity. Concurrently, population genomic analyses revealed rapid, repeatable selective sweeps in *Daphnia* populations exposed to sustained predation pressure, targeting loci associated with anti-predator defenses. These evolutionary changes, in turn, exerted reciprocal selective pressures on *Perca* foraging efficiency and growth rates. Our findings underscore the bidirectional nature of eco-evolutionary feedbacks, demonstrating how rapid evolutionary change at one trophic level can profoundly reshape ecological interactions at another, driving persistent trait-mediated indirect effects.
subject: Evrim
title: Rapid Phenotypic Plasticity and Adaptive Genetic Divergence Drive Predator-Prey Eco-evolutionary Feedbacks

text: While genetic adaptation to environmental stressors is well-established, the role of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance in conferring resilience remains less understood. We explored whether parental exposure to sublethal salinity stress could epigenetically prime offspring defense mechanisms in *Arabidopsis thaliana*. Parental plants subjected to chronic NaCl stress exhibited altered DNA methylation patterns, particularly at transposable element insertions and stress-responsive gene promoters. Remarkably, F1 offspring, even in the absence of direct stress, displayed enhanced salt tolerance, reduced oxidative stress markers, and a distinct transcriptional profile, characterized by elevated expression of abscisic acid signaling components and osmoprotectant biosynthesis genes. This 'priming' effect was correlated with maintenance of specific methylation differences from parents, suggesting a non-Mendelian inheritance mechanism. Our results provide compelling evidence for adaptive transgenerational epigenetic inheritance, highlighting a novel pathway for rapid environmental responsiveness in sessile organisms.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Priming of Stress Response Pathways in *Arabidopsis thaliana* Under Salinity Stress

text: The evolution of cooperation and division of labor (DoL) in microbial systems presents a classic problem for individual-level selection theory. We experimentally investigated the conditions promoting DoL in a synthetic bipartite microbial consortium comprising an auxotroph for an essential amino acid and a producer strain. Employing a chemostat-based selection regime with varying bottleneck sizes and dilution rates, we observed the reproducible emergence of DoL characterized by spatial segregation and distinct metabolic profiles within mixed-species biofilms. Genetic analyses revealed co-evolutionary adaptations in both strains: the producer exhibited upregulation of amino acid synthesis pathways, while the auxotroph developed enhanced uptake mechanisms. Quantitative modeling suggests that recurrent population bottlenecks, mimicking dispersal events, facilitate higher-level selection for cooperative phenotypes, overcoming within-group fitness costs. This study provides empirical validation for multilevel selection theory as a powerful framework for understanding the evolution of complex collective behaviors.
subject: Evrim
title: Multilevel Selection and the Emergence of Division of Labor in a Synthetic Microbial Consortium

text: Palaeogenomic approaches are revolutionizing our understanding of ancient population dynamics and interspecies gene flow. We performed whole-genome sequencing on 47 fossil specimens representing three co-occurring Pleistocene megafauna species (*Mammuthus primigenius*, *Coelodonta antiquitatis*, *Bos primigenius*) from diverse Eurasian localities spanning the last 60,000 years. Our analyses reveal distinct population structure shifts correlating with Last Glacial Maximum climatic oscillations, including severe demographic bottlenecks and subsequent range expansions. Crucially, we identify compelling evidence for ancient introgression events between *Mammuthus* and an ancestral Asian elephant lineage, and between *Bos* and extant European bison (*Bison bonasus*). These introgression landscapes suggest adaptive genetic exchange, potentially conferring resilience to environmental perturbations. This study reconstructs the intricate palaeoecological interactions and demographic history of iconic Pleistocene megafauna, highlighting the role of interspecific hybridization in shaping genomic diversity and evolutionary trajectories under shifting climatic regimes.
subject: Evrim
title: Pleistocene Population Dynamics and Introgression Landscapes of Eurasian Megafauna from Ancient DNA

text: Convergent evolution at the molecular level, particularly in complex sensory systems, offers profound insights into the predictability of evolution. We investigated the genetic basis of echolocation, a highly specialized trait, across distantly related mammalian clades: chiropterans (bats) and cetaceans (dolphins). Through comparative genomic analyses of 14 key auditory and neurological genes known to be involved in echolocation, we identified significant instances of parallel amino acid substitutions in genes such as *FOXP2* and *ATP5A1*. Phylogenetic analyses incorporating branch-site models of positive selection confirmed these convergent signatures, indicating independent recruitment of similar genetic solutions to physiological challenges associated with high-frequency sound production and processing. Furthermore, structural modeling suggests these convergent changes impact protein function, likely optimizing sound reception and neural processing. This work illuminates the molecular toolkit for an intricate adaptive phenotype, demonstrating that strong selection pressures can canalize evolutionary trajectories at fine-grained genomic resolutions.
subject: Evrim
title: Molecular Convergence in Echolocation Genes Reveals Parallel Adaptation in Distantly Related Mammals

text: Sexual conflict over reproductive outcomes is a pervasive force shaping the evolution of diverse species. We examine the molecular arms race between male seminal fluid proteins (SFPs) and female reproductive physiology in *Drosophila melanogaster*. Through reciprocal crosses involving divergent populations, we quantified fitness consequences and transcriptional responses to varying SFP cocktails. Our data demonstrate that SFPs exert significant post-mating effects on female fecundity, longevity, and receptivity, often to the detriment of female lifespan. Comparative proteomic and transcriptomic analyses identified rapidly evolving SFPs exhibiting positive selection, whose gene expression patterns correlate with the magnitude of sexual conflict. Furthermore, manipulation of key SFP pathways revealed specific antagonistic interactions with female immune and stress response genes. This study elucidates the ongoing coevolutionary dynamics underlying sexual conflict, providing a mechanistic understanding of how male ejaculates can manipulate female reproductive investment and highlighting a critical driver of genomic divergence and speciation.
subject: Evrim
title: Antagonistic Coevolutionary Dynamics Between Male Seminal Fluid Proteins and Female Reproductive Physiology

text: The global rise of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a critical public health crisis, fueled by the evolutionary adaptability of microbial populations. We investigated the mechanisms underlying evolutionary rescue from antibiotic pressure in complex soil microbiomes using long-term experimental evolution. Exposing natural soil communities to escalating concentrations of a broad-spectrum antibiotic (e.g., ciprofloxacin), we observed rapid acquisition of resistance. Metagenomic sequencing and transcriptomic profiling revealed a dynamic interplay of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) events, particularly involving mobile genetic elements like plasmids and integrons, and the emergence of *de novo* mutations in chromosomal resistance genes. Critically, HGT provided immediate survival advantages, while *de novo* mutations conferred higher-level, more stable resistance. Our findings elucidate the multi-pronged evolutionary strategies employed by environmental bacteria to circumvent antimicrobial challenge, underscoring the urgent need for a holistic approach to mitigate AMR dissemination from diverse ecological reservoirs.
subject: Evrim
title: Evolutionary Rescue of Antibiotic Resistance in Soil Microbiomes via Horizontal Gene Transfer and De Novo Mutation

text: Evolutionary developmental biology (Evo-Devo) posits that changes in gene regulatory networks (GRNs) are primary drivers of morphological innovation. We investigated the genetic basis of mandible elongation, a key adaptive trait in the dietary diversification of canids. Using comparative transcriptomics and chromatin accessibility profiling across embryonic stages of domestic dogs and wolves, alongside cranial morphometric analyses of diverse canid species, we identified heterochronic shifts in the expression of crucial GRN components. Specifically, transcription factors *Runx2* and *Osx*, known osteogenic regulators, exhibited prolonged expression in the mandibular symphysis and condylar cartilage of species with elongated mandibles. Furthermore, we detected differential enhancer activity in conserved non-coding elements linked to these genes, suggesting cis-regulatory evolution. These findings illustrate how subtle alterations in developmental timing and spatial expression within GRNs can generate substantial craniofacial diversity, providing a mechanistic link between developmental plasticity and macroevolutionary trends in dietary specialization.
subject: Evrim
title: Heterochronic Shifts in Gene Regulatory Networks Underlie Mandible Elongation in Canid Diversification

text: We investigate the asymptotic behavior of generalized Ramsey numbers R_r(G_1, ..., G_k) where G_i are r-uniform hypergraphs characterized by bounded maximum degrees. Extending classical results concerning graph Ramsey numbers, our analysis employs the method of containers, adapted and refined for specific sparse hypergraph structures.
