We establish novel upper and lower bounds for several classes of hypergraphs, particularly focusing on those whose conflict graphs exhibit small independence numbers or satisfy certain expansion properties. For (n, d, λ)-graphs underlying the probabilistic constructions of sparse hypergraphs, we leverage advanced spectral graph theory techniques to refine probability estimates for witnessing monochromatic substructures. This work significantly contributes to the understanding of threshold phenomena in hypergraph Ramsey theory, providing tighter constant factors and revealing intricate dependencies between local sparsity and global Ramsey properties, particularly relevant for list-coloring variations and non-uniform hypergraphs.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Asymptotic Behavior of Ramsey Numbers for Hypergraphs with Bounded Maximum Degree

text: This paper presents a novel q-analogue of the classical hook length formula, specifically generalized for skew Young tableaux. We introduce a new definition of 'skew hook length' that respects the q-deformation and satisfies certain multiplicative properties under diagram decomposition. Our primary contribution is a combinatorial proof utilizing a refined version of the Greene-Kleitman correspondence, mapping skew Young tableaux to paths on a specially constructed q-weighted crystal graph. Furthermore, we explore its implications for the enumeration of restricted partitions and prove a related identity involving q-binomial coefficients and Schur functions. This framework provides deeper insights into the algebraic structure of symmetric polynomials and offers new avenues for understanding their q-deformations, particularly in the context of Macdonald polynomials and non-commutative symmetric functions.
subject: Matematik
title: A q-Analogue of the Hook Length Formula for Skew Young Tableaux and its Combinatorial Proofs

text: We establish sharp threshold functions for the existence of k-cliques in the random r-uniform hypergraph G_r(n, p). While the existence of such thresholds is guaranteed by general theorems, our contribution lies in providing explicit, sharp values and rigorous proofs using advanced martingale concentration inequalities, specifically the Azuma-Hoeffding inequality applied to vertex exposure martingales, coupled with the second moment method. We refine previous results by precisely characterizing the critical probability p_c where the transition from 'no k-clique' to 'many k-cliques' occurs. The analysis involves complex dependency graph arguments to bound the variance term, overcoming challenges posed by the high connectivity of hypergraph structures. This work elucidates fundamental phase transitions in combinatorial structures within random settings, with implications for algorithm design and information theory.
subject: Matematik
title: Sharp Thresholds for the Existence of k-Cliques in Random Hypergraphs via Martingale Concentration

text: This paper investigates the structure and properties of Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials associated with the Hecke algebras of type B, building upon the well-established theory for type A. We construct a new family of cellular algebras, parametrized by specific values of the Hecke parameters, which provides a combinatorial realization of the irreducible modules for these algebras. Our methodology involves generalizing the concept of 'canonical basis' and defining an analogue of the Lusztig-Vogan conjecture in this context. We explicitly compute several low-rank Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials and analyze their positivity and symmetry properties. This work offers deeper insights into the representation theory of Hecke algebras, connecting it to the combinatorics of affine Weyl groups and opening new avenues for understanding knot invariants and quantum groups.
subject: Matematik
title: Kazhdan-Lusztig Polynomials and Cellular Algebras for Hecke Algebras of Type B

text: We present a strong polynomial algorithm for the minimum weight closure problem on certain classes of directed graphs whose independence systems are representable as matroid polyhedra. Extending classical results in submodular function minimization, our approach leverages the full power of matroid intersection algorithms by reformulating the closure problem as finding an optimal common independent set in a specially constructed pair of matroids. The algorithm achieves a time complexity of O(f(n, m)), where f is strongly polynomial in the number of vertices n and edges m, improving upon previous weakly polynomial methods. This framework has significant implications for network flow problems, project scheduling, and provides a theoretical foundation for optimizing submodular functions subject to matroid constraints in combinatorial optimization.
subject: Matematik
title: Submodular Optimization on Matroid Polyhedra: A Strong Polynomial Algorithm for Minimum Weight Closure

text: This paper introduces a novel decomposition theory for the f-vectors of convex polytopes, specifically focusing on how the face lattice structure dictates the combinatorial invariants. We propose a canonical method to express the f-vector of a d-polytope as a sum of f-vectors of simpler, non-negatively weighted constituents, termed 'lattice-summands,' which are derived from specific chains in the face lattice. This generalizes classical results like the Dehn-Somerville equations and provides a finer understanding of the h-vector. Our approach utilizes the theory of Ehrhart polynomials for lattice polytopes and relates these decompositions to the topological properties of their associated order complexes. The work offers new avenues for proving non-negativity results for h-vectors and for classifying polytopes based on their face structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Decompositions of f-Vectors of Polytopes into Summands Based on Face Lattices

text: This paper extends Freiman's theorem to a class of non-abelian groups, addressing inverse problems in additive combinatorics concerning the structure of finite sets A where the sumset |A+A| is small relative to |A|. We introduce a generalized notion of arithmetic progression suitable for non-commutative settings, based on products of subgroups and cosets. Our main result demonstrates that if |A*A| ≤ K|A| for a finite subset A in a specific class of non-abelian groups (e.g., solvable groups of bounded derived length), then A is contained within a 'generalized arithmetic progression' of bounded dimension and size. The proof relies on a combination of Lie theory, approximate group theory techniques, and higher-order Fourier analysis, providing new insights into the interplay between algebraic structure and combinatorial density.
subject: Matematik
title: Inverse Problems in Additive Combinatorics: Structure of Sets with Small Sumset in Non-Abelian Groups

text: We establish homological stability for a family of simplicial complexes whose vertices represent graph imbeddings into surfaces of increasing genus. Specifically, we consider the complex of non-separating cycles and its higher-dimensional analogues. Our primary method involves constructing a highly connected 'stabilization map' between these complexes, demonstrating that their homology groups become isomorphic above a certain range, which grows linearly with the number of vertices in the embedded graph. This analysis draws upon discrete Morse theory, techniques from geometric group theory, and the Nerve Lemma, providing new insights into the topological structure of configuration spaces of graphs. The results have implications for understanding graph invariants related to surface topology and the study of graph-theoretic analogues of mapping class groups.
subject: Matematik
title: Homological Stability for Simplicial Complexes Arising from Graph Imbeddings

text: This paper investigates the existence and classification of t-(v, k, λ) designs whose automorphism groups are prescribed subgroups of the projective linear group PGL(d+1, q). We focus particularly on designs embedded in finite projective spaces PG(d, q), where the blocks correspond to k-subspaces or other geometric configurations. Our methodology combines character theory, orbital counting arguments, and the analysis of difference sets over finite fields, extending classical results for symmetric designs. We provide new existence criteria and non-existence theorems for specific parameter sets (t, v, k, λ) by leveraging the action of Singer cycles and other maximal subgroups. This work contributes to the foundational theory of combinatorial designs, with connections to coding theory, cryptography, and finite geometry.
subject: Matematik
title: Classification of t-(v, k, λ) Designs with Prescribed Automorphism Groups in Finite Projective Spaces

text: This research explores the algorithmic implications of tree-depth and related width parameters for minor-closed graph classes. We develop a unified framework for designing efficient parameterized algorithms for problems that are FPT (fixed-parameter tractable) on graphs of bounded tree-depth, such as maximum independent set, dominating set, and various connectivity problems. Our approach relies on combining dynamic programming on tree-depth decompositions with advanced structural graph theory, including techniques from (r, k)-solvable graphs and shallow minors. We establish new connections between tree-depth, treewidth, and the excluded minor theory, demonstrating how these parameters interact to provide algorithmic bounds. This work advances the understanding of graph structural properties in the context of parameterized complexity, offering new avenues for practical algorithm design for NP-hard problems on structured graph inputs.
subject: Matematik
title: Algorithmic Applications of Tree-Depth and Beyond: Minor-Closed Classes with Efficient Parameterized Algorithms

text: This study presents a novel deep recurrent neural network architecture, integrating Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) layers with attention mechanisms, for the automated analysis of functional harmonic progressions. Traditional chord recognition systems often fail to capture the long-range dependencies and hierarchical structures inherent in tonal music. Our model, trained on a meticulously curated corpus of 18th and 19th-century Western art music annotated with Roman numerals and Schenkerian-informed functional labels, demonstrates superior performance in predicting harmonic function and cadential articulation compared to existing Hidden Markov Model and Conditional Random Field approaches. Feature extraction incorporates pitch class profiles, chroma vectors, and dynamically weighted voice leading features. Quantitative evaluation metrics, including edit distance and macro-F1 score across diverse corpora, validate the model's ability to infer context-sensitive harmonic relationships, offering a robust framework for computational musicology and large-scale stylistic analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Recurrent Neural Networks for Contextual Functional Harmonic Analysis

text: This research investigates the psychoacoustic perception of subtle microtonal pitch deviations within the context of Western equal temperament, focusing on their role in expressive performance. Utilizing a meticulously controlled listening experiment, professional musicians and trained non-musicians evaluated synthesized stimuli featuring systematic ±10 to ±50 cent deviations from standard frequencies, presented within harmonic and melodic contexts. Concurrently, electroencephalography (EEG) data captured event-related potentials (ERPs) indicative of cognitive processing and affective responses. Spectral analysis, leveraging multi-taper methods and cepstral features, quantified the timbral impact of these deviations. Results indicate differentiated perceptual thresholds influenced by melodic contour and harmonic density, with specific ERP components (e.g., P300, Late Positive Potential) correlating with subjective ratings of "expressiveness" versus "out-of-tuneness." These findings contribute to a nuanced understanding of intonation as a performative parameter, informing both music pedagogy and computational expressivity modeling.
subject: Müzik
title: Perceptual Thresholds and Affective Correlates of Microtonal Pitch Deviation in Western Art Music Performance

text: This paper introduces a novel application of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) for synthesizing historically informed species counterpoint. Unlike traditional rule-based systems, our architecture, "Counterpoint-GAN," employs a discriminator trained to distinguish between human-composed and machine-generated contrapuntal excerpts based on a hierarchical set of musical features, encompassing melodic contour, intervallic content, rhythmic independence, and voice leading adherence. The generator, conditioned on a cantus firmus, learns to produce novel counterpoint lines that satisfy both strict species rules and stylistic nuances derived from a corpus of Palestrinian and Fuxian examples. By integrating an adversarial loss with a feature-matching loss at multiple levels of musical abstraction, Counterpoint-GAN overcomes common challenges in musical generation, producing stylistically coherent and theoretically plausible outputs, thus offering a sophisticated tool for computational musicology and algorithmic composition research.
subject: Müzik
title: Generative Adversarial Networks for Constrained Stylistic Counterpoint Synthesis with Hierarchical Feature Representation

text: This study explores the acoustic characteristics and perceptual salience of timbral features generated through extended instrumental techniques. We present a comprehensive methodology for analyzing non-standard sonic events (e.g., multiphonics, overtone glissandi, breath noise, prepared piano articulations) in contemporary repertoire. Audio recordings were subjected to high-resolution spectro-temporal analysis, incorporating Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs), spectral centroid, spectral flux, and irregularity measures. A deep convolutional autoencoder architecture was then employed for unsupervised feature learning and dimensionality reduction, extracting salient timbral descriptors resistant to variations in performance dynamics. Subsequent supervised classification using support vector machines and random forests achieved high accuracy in distinguishing distinct extended techniques across various instrument families. This framework offers a robust quantitative approach for characterizing novel timbres, aiding in their systematic classification, synthesis, and theoretical integration within contemporary music analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectro-Temporal Analysis and Classification of Timbral Features in Extended Instrumental Techniques via Deep Convolutional Autoencoders

text: This research proposes a novel multimodal framework for the quantitative analysis of expressive intent in musical performance. We integrate high-resolution audio features (e.g., micro-timing, dynamics, timbre descriptors), kinematic data from optical motion capture (capturing performer gestures), and physiological correlates (e.g., heart rate variability, skin conductance) to develop a holistic understanding of performative expressivity. A late fusion strategy, employing a hierarchical Bayesian model, is utilized to synthesize insights from these diverse data streams. Experiments involve professional violinists performing varied repertoire under controlled expressive conditions. Results demonstrate that multimodal feature integration significantly outperforms unimodal approaches in predicting expert listener ratings of expression and emotion. This framework not only advances computational musicology by providing nuanced insights into performer agency but also holds implications for real-time expressive feedback systems and AI-driven performance generation.
subject: Müzik
title: Multimodal Feature Fusion for Quantifying Expressive Intent in Musical Performance: Integrating Audio, Motion, and Physiological Data

text: This study applies information theory to model and quantify musical expectation and surprise in complex melodic and rhythmic sequences. We develop a probabilistic model, based on n-gram analysis and entropy calculations, that estimates the conditional probability of upcoming musical events given preceding context. Our approach extends beyond simple pitch or duration statistics by incorporating metric structure, harmonic implications (for tonal contexts), and contour information. Experiments involve presenting listeners with musical fragments and measuring their real-time expectation ratings, alongside electrodermal activity (EDA) as an implicit physiological indicator of surprise. Results demonstrate a significant correlation between model-derived information content (surprisal) and both explicit subjective ratings and implicit physiological responses. This framework offers a robust computational tool for analyzing perceived musical tension, structural coherence, and affective impact, with implications for cognitive musicology and generative music systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Information-Theoretic Quantification of Musical Expectation and Surprise in Melodic and Rhythmic Sequences

text: This research presents a methodology for inferring historical tuning temperaments from monophonic and polyphonic archival audio recordings, circumventing limitations of direct instrument measurement. Leveraging advanced signal processing techniques, we employ a multi-pitch detection algorithm based on sparse coding and non-negative matrix factorization, followed by precise fundamental frequency (F0) trajectory estimation. Subsequent spectral modeling, incorporating partial overtone analysis and instantaneous frequency tracking, allows for the identification of microtonal deviations from equal temperament. A probabilistic Bayesian inference framework is then utilized to statistically estimate the underlying temperament parameters (e.g., comma distribution, wolf intervals) present in the performance. This approach enables data-driven reconstruction of historical tuning practices, offering invaluable insights for performance practice, musicology, and historically informed reconstruction of period instruments and early music soundscapes.
subject: Müzik
title: Reverse Engineering Historical Temperaments from Archival Audio Recordings via High-Resolution Spectral Modeling and Fundamental Frequency Trajectory Estimation

text: This paper introduces a robust computational framework for automated formal structure segmentation in atonal and post-tonal music, a task profoundly challenging due to the absence of conventional tonal-harmonic indicators. Our methodology leverages audio feature recurrence plots, constructed from time-series representations of pitch-class distribution vectors (PCDVs), spectral centroids, and loudness envelopes, to capture underlying structural similarities and repetitions. Self-similarity matrices derived from these recurrence plots are then subjected to spectral clustering algorithms (e.g., normalized cut, K-means), identifying salient sectional boundaries and hierarchical relationships. Evaluation on a diverse corpus of 20th-century avant-garde and serial compositions, expertly annotated for formal divisions, demonstrates superior precision and recall compared to traditional change-point detection methods. This approach facilitates macro-level analysis of structural coherence in non-tonal idioms, contributing significantly to computational music analysis of modern repertoires.
subject: Müzik
title: Automated Formal Structure Segmentation in Atonal and Post-Tonal Music Using Feature Recurrence Plots and Spectral Clustering

text: This study extends the analytical power of Neo-Riemannian theory to advanced jazz harmony, addressing its limitations in representing non-diatonic relationships and complex modulatory praxis characteristic of post-bebop idioms. We develop a computational model that maps polychords, non-tertian sonorities, and extended voicings onto generalized Tonnetz structures, enabling the quantification of parsimonious voice leading and transformational distances between highly dissonant or ambiguously functional harmonies. Graph-theoretic algorithms are employed to trace common-tone voice leading and transformational paths, revealing underlying geometric symmetries and organizational principles previously underexplored in jazz theory. Application to a corpus of Lydian-chromatic concept and modal jazz compositions demonstrates the model's efficacy in identifying and characterizing transformational sequences, providing novel insights into the structural coherence and innovative harmonic syntax of modern jazz. This framework offers a rigorous, computationally tractable method for analyzing complex harmonic landscapes beyond conventional functional frameworks.
subject: Müzik
title: Computational Modeling of Neo-Riemannian Transformations in Advanced Jazz Harmony and Modulatory Praxis

text: This investigation elucidates the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying rhythmic entrainment and deviance detection in complex polyrhythmic contexts. Utilizing simultaneous electroencephalography (EEG) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) co-registration, we measured cortical and subcortical responses in participants exposed to both metrically congruent and syncopated polyrhythmic stimuli, systematically manipulating rhythmic complexity and temporal predictability. Event-related potentials (ERPs), particularly the Mismatch Negativity (MMN) and P300 components, were analyzed for temporal resolution of deviance processing, while fMRI data pinpointed activation in motor planning, auditory processing, and attention networks (e.g., basal ganglia, superior temporal gyrus, inferior frontal gyrus). Results indicate distinct neural signatures for active entrainment versus passive perception, with enhanced activity in fronto-parietal networks during syncopated sequences. This multimodal approach advances our understanding of the neural underpinnings of rhythmic cognition, offering insights into temporal organization in music and implications for motor-auditory coupling.
subject: Müzik
title: Neurometric Correlates of Rhythmic Entrainment and Deviance Detection in Complex Polyrhythms: An EEG-fMRI Co-registration Study

text: This study introduces a novel computational framework for automating aspects of Schenkerian reductive analysis, specifically focusing on the derivation of middleground structures from musical surfaces. Leveraging deep graph neural networks (GNNs) operating on symbolic musical representations (e.g., MusicXML), we model inter-note relationships as a dynamic graph, where nodes represent pitch events and edges encode intervallic, rhythmic, and voice-leading proximities. Our methodology employs a multi-scale segmentation algorithm guided by principles of tonal stability and voice-leading integrity, subsequently feeding these segments into a transformer-encoder architecture for context-aware feature extraction. The GNN then iteratively prunes less structurally significant events based on learned salience metrics derived from a corpus of expert-annotated reductions. Experimental validation demonstrates significant congruence with established analytical paradigms, achieving a F1-score of 0.78 on identifying prolonged harmonies and Ursatz derivations, thus advancing automated hierarchical music analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Hierarchical Segmentation and Reductive Analysis of Tonal Music via Deep Graph Neural Networks

text: This research addresses the formidable challenge of accurate pitch estimation and scale degree identification in microtonal and non-standard temperaments, where conventional equal-temperament-centric algorithms falter. We propose an adaptive spectral clustering algorithm that dynamically determines pitch classes without prior knowledge of the underlying tuning system. Leveraging high-resolution constant-Q transforms (CQTs), individual partials are extracted and tracked across time. A kernel-density-based peak detection routine then identifies stable frequency centroids. These centroids are subsequently grouped using an expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm to infer the latent microtonal scale degrees. Our method incorporates a probabilistic model for inharmonicity and vibrato, significantly enhancing robustness against performance nuances. Evaluation against a corpus of world music and experimental microtonal compositions demonstrates superior performance (mean cents error < 15) compared to state-of-the-art pitch tracking systems, offering a crucial tool for ethnomusicological and avant-garde music analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Robust Pitch Estimation and Scale Degree Identification in Non-Standard Temperaments Using Adaptive Spectral Clustering

text: This study investigates the cognitive mechanisms underlying meter perception and entrainment, particularly in complex polyrhythmic contexts often found in global musical traditions. We develop a hierarchical Bayesian model that posits a generative process for rhythmic events, incorporating both bottom-up acoustic saliency cues (e.g., onset detection, accentuation) and top-down cognitive biases (e.g., Gestalt principles, cultural schemata). The model employs a hidden Markov model (HMM) to infer metrical states, whose parameters are dynamically updated via particle filtering, allowing for robust tracking of fluctuating tempi and phase shifts characteristic of human performance. Crucially, the model accounts for perceptual ambiguity in syncopated and cross-rhythmic patterns by assigning probabilities to multiple concurrent metrical interpretations. Validation against human tapping data and subjective ratings demonstrates strong predictive power for perceived meter strength and entrainment stability, contributing to a more nuanced understanding of rhythmic cognition.
subject: Müzik
title: Hierarchical Bayesian Modeling of Meter Perception and Entrainment in Polyrhythmic Contexts

text: We present a novel approach to learning perceptually salient timbral similarity metrics by integrating deep learning with differentiable digital audio workstation (DAW) synthesis models. Traditional timbral descriptors often fail to capture the nuances of human auditory perception. Our method utilizes a Siamese neural network architecture trained on pairs of audio excerpts, where similarity judgments are provided by expert listeners. Crucially, the feature embeddings are derived not solely from raw waveforms but from intermediate representations within a differentiable synthesizer (e.g., physical modeling, subtractive synthesis parameters). This allows for a deeper understanding of how synthesis parameters map to perceptual attributes. The loss function incorporates a triplet-margin strategy to optimize for discriminative feature spaces. Evaluation demonstrates improved correlation (Pearson r > 0.85) with subjective timbral distance ratings compared to conventional Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs) and spectral centroid-based metrics, providing a robust framework for timbral clustering and retrieval.
subject: Müzik
title: Perceptual Metric Learning for Timbral Similarity based on Deep Feature Embeddings from Differentiable Digital Audio Workstations

text: This research proposes a computational methodology for multi-scale hierarchical form analysis in tonal and post-tonal repertoires, moving beyond linear segmentation towards a more holistic, graph-based representation. We construct a multi-layered graph where nodes represent musical events (e.g., harmonic regions, melodic motifs, rhythmic profiles) and edges denote various relational proximities (e.g., thematic repetition, harmonic progression, textural similarity). Dynamic graph partitioning algorithms, specifically modularity maximization with adaptive resolution parameters, are employed to identify structural boundaries and delineate formal sections at varying hierarchical levels (e.g., phrase, period, movement). A subsequent semantic segmentation step, utilizing a recurrent neural network with attention mechanisms, labels these identified sections with common formal functions (e.g., exposition, development, recapitulation). Validation against expert-annotated corpora demonstrates significant agreement (Adjusted Rand Index > 0.7) in identifying and classifying formal units, providing a powerful tool for large-scale structural analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Multi-Scale Hierarchical Form Analysis through Dynamic Graph Partitioning and Semantic Segmentation of Musical Events

text: This study presents a sophisticated framework for predicting listener-perceived affective states in music, moving beyond discrete emotion categories to continuous arousal-valence-tension dimensions. Our approach integrates multi-modal features encompassing acoustic descriptors (e.g., loudness dynamics, spectral centroid variance), symbolic information (e.g., harmonic entropy, rhythmic complexity), and physiological correlates (e.g., skin conductance, heart rate variability) obtained from a cohort of listeners. A deep recurrent generative network (DRGN) with attention mechanisms is employed to learn the temporal evolution and interdependencies of these features. The DRGN then predicts continuous affective trajectories, accounting for context-dependent emotional shifts. Crucially, the generative aspect allows for the synthesis of new musical sequences optimizing for specific affective targets. Performance metrics, including Concordance Correlation Coefficient (CCC > 0.7), demonstrate robust prediction accuracy, offering profound insights into the computational understanding and generation of musical emotion.
subject: Müzik
title: Predictive Modeling of Musical Affective States via Multi-modal Feature Fusion and Deep Recurrent Generative Networks

text: This research introduces a novel framework for quantifying harmonic coherence and tonality using transformational distance metrics, extending beyond diatonic harmony to encompass various generalized tonal systems. We model harmonic progressions as paths on a geometric representation of pitch-class space (e.g., Tonnetz, generalized interval cycles). Causal inference techniques, specifically Granger causality applied to sequences of harmonic vectors derived from audio or symbolic input, are utilized to identify directional dependencies and predict subsequent harmonic events. A custom-designed transformational grammar generates potential next states, which are then evaluated by a probabilistic model incorporating psychoacoustic consonance and voice-leading principles. The proposed "Harmonic Coherence Index" (HCI) provides a quantitative measure of contextual harmonic stability and progression plausibility. Validation against expert analyses of both conventional and experimental repertoire demonstrates superior capacity for capturing subtle differences in tonal gravity and structural function compared to traditional key-finding algorithms.
subject: Müzik
title: Transformational Distance Metrics for Generalized Tonality: A Causal Inference Approach to Harmonic Coherence

text: This study explores the intricate relationship between performer gesture and sonic articulation through a multimodal latent space modeling approach. We capture high-resolution motion data (e.g., Mocap, IMUs) alongside synchronized audio recordings of instrumental performances. A variational autoencoder (VAE) architecture is trained to learn a shared latent representation that encodes the expressive intent across both modalities. The encoder maps observed gestural kinematics (e.g., velocity, acceleration, joint angles) and audio features (e.g., loudness envelope, spectral flux, vibrato rate) into a low-dimensional, continuous latent space. The decoder then reconstructs these multimodal inputs, enabling generation of expressive sonic articulations from novel gestural inputs, and vice-versa. Furthermore, disentangled representation learning within the VAE allows for independent manipulation of expressive parameters. Quantitative evaluation demonstrates robust cross-modal reconstruction accuracy and a high correlation (R^2 > 0.8) between latent space trajectories and expert-labeled expressive nuances, advancing computational expressivity research.
subject: Müzik
title: Multimodal Latent Space Modeling of Expressive Performance Gesture and Sonic Articulation via Variational Autoencoders

text: This research addresses the critical challenge of cross-cultural music similarity and classification in ethnomusicology, where domain shifts between distinct musical cultures often degrade standard Music Information Retrieval (MIR) system performance. We propose an adversarial feature learning framework to derive domain-invariant representations that are robust to variations in instrumentation, tuning systems, and performance practices. A feature extractor network is trained simultaneously with a domain discriminator, which attempts to distinguish the cultural origin of the features. Through this adversarial process, the feature extractor learns representations that are maximally discriminative for musical content while being maximally indistinguishable across domains. We utilize a diverse dataset spanning Sub-Saharan African, Indian Raga, and Indonesian Gamelan traditions. Evaluation demonstrates significantly improved classification accuracy (up to 20% gain) when classifying previously unseen cultures, offering a potent tool for comparative ethnomusicological studies and automatic cataloging of diverse musical heritage.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Cultural Music Similarity: Learning Domain-Invariant Representations for Ethnomusicological Classification via Adversarial Feature Learning

text: This study proposes a novel hierarchical Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) architecture for algorithmic composition that explicitly addresses macro-structural coherence, a persistent challenge in deep learning-based music generation. Traditional GANs often excel at local texture but struggle with long-range dependencies and overarching formal logic. Our approach employs a multi-level GAN: a "macro-GAN" learns to generate high-level structural blueprints (e.g., harmonic rhythm, thematic recurrence patterns), which then guide a "micro-GAN" responsible for generating note-level details (e.g., melody, counterpoint, ornamentation). Conditioned generation allows for adherence to specified formal constraints. The discriminators at each level assess coherence appropriate to their scale. Training on a corpus of 18th-century counterpoint and 20th-century serial music demonstrates the system's ability to produce compositions exhibiting both local sonic fidelity and globally consistent formal organization, validated by expert Turing tests for structural integrity and musicality.
subject: Müzik
title: Hierarchical Generative Adversarial Networks for Macro-Structural Coherence in Algorithmic Composition

text: This research proposes a novel deep recurrent neural network (DRNN) architecture for the automated analysis of contextualized harmonic progressions in complex atonal music. Leveraging pitch-class set theory and interval-vector representations, the model employs a combination of gated recurrent units (GRUs) and self-attention mechanisms to capture long-range dependencies and non-contiguous structural relationships inherent in post-tonal syntax. The DRNN is trained on a meticulously annotated corpus of early 20th-century avant-garde compositions, demonstrating superior performance in identifying transformational pathways, aggregate completions, and latent voice-leading structures compared to conventional n-gram models. Findings reveal the network's capacity to infer compositional intent by mapping intricate pitch configurations to established theoretical constructs, offering a computational lens for re-evaluating historical analytical paradigms.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Recurrent Neural Networks for Contextualized Harmonic Progression Analysis in Atonal Repertoire

text: This study introduces a sophisticated psychoacoustic model leveraging fuzzy cognitive maps (FCMs) to characterize human perception of microtonal pitch structures and intonational deviance in non-standard temperaments. The model integrates spectro-temporal audio features—such as spectral centroid, inharmonicity, and fine-grain fundamental frequency tracking—with cognitive parameters derived from psychophysical experiments on interval perception thresholds. By mapping these features to nodes representing perceptual attributes (e.g., 'sharpness,' 'consonance,' 'stability'), the FCM dynamically infers perceived intonation quality and structural significance within novel microtonal contexts. Validation against listener perception data demonstrates high concordance, suggesting FCMs offer a robust framework for quantifying the perceptual salience of intervallic nuances often overlooked by conventional equal temperament-centric analyses, with implications for computational ethnomusicology and adaptive instrument design.
subject: Müzik
title: A Psychoacoustic Model for Microtonal Pitch Perception and Intonational Deviance Using Fuzzy Cognitive Maps

text: This paper presents an innovative graph-theoretic framework for analyzing voice-leading efficiency and discovering optimal transformational pathways within complex neo-Riemannian harmonic landscapes. We model pitch-class triads and their inversions as nodes in a multi-graph, where edges represent specific P-, L-, and R-transformations, weighted by parsimonious voice-leading distance metrics derived from pitch-class set cardinality. Algorithms such as Dijkstra's and A* search are adapted to identify shortest paths between distant harmonic regions, revealing underlying structural coherence in ostensibly disparate progressions. Furthermore, community detection algorithms are employed to uncover emergent harmonic subnetworks and their hierarchical organization, offering a formal re-evaluation of chromatic mediant relationships and enharmonic equivalence. The methodology offers rigorous quantification of voice-leading cost and unveils previously unarticulated structural logics in advanced tonal and post-tonal repertoires.
subject: Müzik
title: Graph-Theoretic Algorithms for Voice-Leading Optimization and Transformational Pathway Discovery in Neo-Riemannian Landscapes

text: This research proposes a novel multiresolution spectral decomposition technique for fine-grained timbral fingerprinting and instrument identification in complex polystrumental acoustic environments. Utilizing an adaptive wavelet packet transform coupled with non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) variants, we achieve high-fidelity separation of overlapping partials across distinct frequency bands. Unique sub-band spectral centroids, flux, and irregularity metrics are extracted and subsequently subjected to Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) clustering for robust timbral classification. The methodology exhibits significant advancements over traditional fixed-resolution spectral features, particularly in differentiating instruments with overlapping harmonic series and transient-rich attacks. Performance evaluation against a challenging dataset of orchestral recordings demonstrates enhanced accuracy in source localization and timbral identification, providing critical insights for advanced Music Information Retrieval (MIR) and computational orchestration.
subject: Müzik
title: Multiresolution Spectral Decomposition for Sub-Band Timbral Fingerprinting in Polystrumental Acoustic Environments

text: This study develops a computational model for the objective quantification of hypermetric dissonance, conceptualized as the conflict between structural accentuation patterns at different hierarchical metric levels. The model integrates a beat-tracking algorithm with a phrase boundary detection system, extracting salient temporal accent features (e.g., duration, dynamic intensity, harmonic rhythm change). Dissonance is computed via a cross-correlation metric comparing idealized hypermetric grids with empirically derived accent profiles, accounting for syncopation, displacement, and grouping ambiguities. Psychoacoustic experiments involving listener preference judgments are conducted to validate the model's output, revealing strong correlations between calculated hypermetric dissonance values and subjective ratings of rhythmic tension and formal ambiguity. This framework provides a novel analytical tool for examining the expressive potential of metric complexity and its role in shaping listeners' structural comprehension and affective responses.
subject: Müzik
title: A Computational Model for Quantifying Hypermetric Dissonance and Its Perceptual-Cognitive Correlates

text: This paper explores the application of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) for synthesizing novel rhythmic patterns that statistically conform to the stylistic characteristics of specific historical musical periods. A conditional GAN architecture is developed, where the generator learns to produce symbolic rhythm sequences (MIDI timing information) from latent space vectors, while the discriminator evaluates their stylistic authenticity against a curated dataset of rhythmic templates from Baroque fugues and bebop improvisations. Feature representations, including inter-onset intervals, syncopation indices, and swing ratios, are extracted using wavelet-based analysis. The model demonstrates remarkable capability in generating stylistically coherent yet original rhythmic content, providing a powerful tool for computational musicology, algorithmic composition, and for interrogating the underlying probabilistic grammars of complex rhythmic idioms through a generative lens.
subject: Müzik
title: Adversarial Rhythmic Synthesis: Leveraging GANs for Generative Modeling of Historical Rhythmic Styles

text: This research presents an integrated multimodal feature fusion framework for the precise quantification and analysis of expressive performance cues in violin sonatas. Synchronized data streams encompass high-resolution audio (spectral centroid, loudness dynamics, vibrato rate/extent), motion capture of bowing arm kinematics (velocity, acceleration, bow-bridge distance), and electromyography (EMG) of bowing muscle activity. A deep canonical correlation analysis (DCCA) model is employed to learn shared latent representations across these disparate modalities, enabling robust identification of salient performance parameters correlated with interpretative nuances. The framework successfully disentangles deliberate expressive deviations from technical execution variability, offering objective metrics for studying rubato, dynamic shaping, and timbral modulation. This methodology advances the understanding of the complex interplay between physical gesture, acoustic output, and musical intention in virtuosic performance.
subject: Müzik
title: Integrated Multimodal Feature Fusion for Quantifying Expressive Performance Cues in Violin Sonatas

text: This paper introduces a novel deep recurrent U-Net architecture integrated with contextual attention mechanisms for robust fundamental frequency (F0) estimation in highly polyphonic musical audio. The proposed model employs a cascaded series of convolutional and recurrent layers (LSTM/GRU) within an encoder-decoder framework to capture both local spectro-temporal features and long-range harmonic and melodic dependencies. An attention module dynamically weights feature maps based on their relevance to F0 tracking, enabling superior separation of overlapping partials and suppression of octave errors, particularly in dense orchestral textures and complex chord voicings. Evaluated against state-of-the-art multi-F0 estimation benchmarks, the Deep Recurrent U-Net demonstrates significant improvements in precision, recall, and overall accuracy, pushing the boundaries for automated melodic contour extraction and micro-timing analysis in real-world musical recordings.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Recurrent U-Net for Polyphonic Fundamental Frequency Estimation with Contextual Attention

text: This research proposes a novel framework utilizing disentangled variational autoencoders (DVAEs) for perceptually-guided source separation in polyphonic music, specifically focusing on the independent control and manipulation of timbral attributes. The DVAE is designed to learn latent representations that disentangle instrument identity, pitch, and expressive performance parameters from the mixed audio signal. By enforcing decorrelation constraints on the latent factors, the model enables granular control over reconstructed sources, allowing for isolated manipulation of timbral characteristics (e.g., brightness, attack envelope) without affecting melodic or rhythmic content. Experiments demonstrate superior source separation quality and the potential for innovative applications in computational sound design, re-orchestration, and the exploration of novel timbral fusions while preserving critical musical information.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangled Variational Autoencoders for Perceptually-Guided Source Separation and Timbral Attribute Manipulation

text: This study investigates the emergent structural properties of stochastic compositional algorithms through the lens of complex systems theory, employing spectral entropy and mutual information as key analytical metrics. We explore various probabilistic generative models (e.g., Markov chains, L-systems, cellular automata) applied to symbolic musical parameters (pitch, rhythm, dynamics). The research quantifies the degree of predictability, complexity, and self-organization inherent in the generated output sequences. By analyzing the informational content and periodicity of the resulting sonic structures, we identify critical phase transitions where simple stochastic rules yield highly complex, quasi-periodic, or chaotic musical formations. This approach provides a rigorous theoretical framework for understanding the origins of musical coherence and unpredictability in algorithmically generated music, bridging compositional practice with information-theoretic principles.
subject: Müzik
title: Emergent Structuralities in Stochastic Compositional Systems: A Complex Systems Analysis via Spectral Entropy and Information Theory

text: This work addresses the formidable challenge of decentralized policy synthesis in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) for non-zero-sum stochastic games under partial observability. We propose a novel framework that leverages the variational information bottleneck (VIB) principle to distill minimally sufficient, maximally informative representations of local observations, thereby mitigating the curse of dimensionality and observational noise. Our approach enables robust, decentralized policy learning by optimizing a mutual information objective that concurrently learns a compact state representation and a Nash equilibrium-seeking policy. This method facilitates improved coordination and adversarial robustness in complex dynamic environments by fostering efficient communication protocols implicitly through shared latent spaces. Empirical validation demonstrates superior performance in strategic resource allocation and competitive robotics tasks compared to state-of-the-art MARL algorithms, exhibiting enhanced scalability and convergence properties.
subject: AI
title: Decentralized Adversarial Policy Synthesis in Non-Zero-Sum Stochastic Games via Variational Information Bottleneck

text: We introduce Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Fields (DDPFs), a novel generative framework for high-fidelity continuous data synthesis by integrating implicit neural representations (INRs) with denoising diffusion models. Traditional diffusion models typically operate on discrete grids or explicit parameterizations. In contrast, DDPFs define a continuous data distribution by learning a score function over latent INR parameters, representing data as coordinate-based networks. This allows for arbitrary resolution synthesis and eliminates discretization artifacts. Our method implicitly models the data manifold by iteratively denoising corrupted INR weight distributions, enabling the generation of complex geometries, textures, and fluid dynamics with unprecedented detail and continuity. Experiments demonstrate DDPFs' superiority in tasks ranging from 3D scene generation to high-resolution image synthesis, outperforming existing generative models in perceptual quality and generalization across scales.
subject: AI
title: Implicit Neural Representations for High-Fidelity Generative Modeling via Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Fields

text: Understanding the internal computational mechanisms of Large Language Models (LLMs) remains a significant challenge, particularly concerning their emergent reasoning capabilities. This paper proposes a novel mechanistic interpretability framework rooted in causal abstraction theory to disentangle and map the latent causal variables and their corresponding computational graph pathways responsible for complex behaviors like chain-of-thought reasoning. We develop techniques for perturbing specific activation vectors within multi-head attention and feed-forward layers and observing their causal effects on downstream token generation and internal representations. By systematically constructing counterfactual interventions, we aim to identify and characterize the "circuits" or "algorithms" implemented by LLMs, providing transparent, causally-grounded explanations for their decision-making processes, thereby paving the way for more robust and reliable AI systems.
subject: AI
title: Causal Abstraction of Emergent Reasoning Pathways in Large Language Models using Mechanistic Interpretability

text: Adversarial vulnerability and poor generalization to unseen domains remain critical hurdles for deep learning in real-world computer vision applications. This work introduces a novel self-supervised contrastive learning paradigm specifically designed to learn adversarially robust feature embeddings while promoting open-set domain generalization. Our method optimizes a tripartite loss function: an augmented contrastive loss for semantic invariance, a adversarial robustness loss derived from projected gradient descent (PGD) perturbations on the latent space, and an entropy-based regularization for unknown class detection. By simultaneously pushing away adversarial samples in the latent manifold and aligning semantically similar augmented views, we achieve highly discriminative and robust representations. Empirical evaluation across diverse benchmarks demonstrates significant improvements in both adversarial accuracy and domain generalization performance under open-set conditions, transcending limitations of traditional defense mechanisms.
subject: AI
title: Contrastive Learning for Adversarially Robust Feature Embeddings in Open-Set Domain Generalization

text: De novo molecular design necessitates generative models capable of capturing complex chemical hierarchies and optimizing multiple target properties. We introduce a Hierarchical Graph Transformer (HGT) architecture that innovatively combines multi-scale attention mechanisms across molecular graphs, addressing limitations of conventional GNNs in long-range dependency modeling. HGT explicitly models interactions from atomic bonds to functional groups and scaffolds through a nested attention framework. This architecture is integrated into a reinforcement learning (RL) loop, where an agent learns to construct valid and novel molecules by sequentially adding atoms and bonds, guided by a reward function incorporating diverse physicochemical and pharmacokinetic constraints (e.g., QED, LogP, synthetic accessibility). Our experiments demonstrate HGT’s superior ability to generate diverse, novel, and chemically valid molecules that satisfy complex multi-objective property profiles, significantly advancing drug discovery pipelines.
subject: AI
title: Hierarchical Graph Transformers for De Novo Molecular Design with Constrained Property Optimization

text: Providing actionable explanations for black-box deep learning models in complex, multi-modal environments (e.g., healthcare, finance) is paramount for trust and adoption. We propose a novel Explainable AI (XAI) framework that generates multi-modal counterfactual explanations by identifying minimal, human-interpretable perturbations across heterogeneous data types (e.g., medical images, clinical notes, tabular patient data) that flip a model's prediction. Our approach employs a conditional generative adversarial network (cGAN) coupled with a disentangled variational autoencoder (DVAE) to synthesize realistic and plausible counterfactuals while preserving irrelevant features. This framework simultaneously ensures fidelity to the original data manifold and minimizes changes required for a decision flip. Empirical validation on clinical diagnostic tasks demonstrates that our multi-modal counterfactuals offer unparalleled clarity and actionability, surpassing single-modality approaches in explaining complex predictive outcomes.
subject: AI
title: Explainable AI via Multi-Modal Counterfactual Generation for Complex Predictive Systems

text: Federated Learning (FL) faces significant challenges from statistical and system heterogeneity across client data, leading to model divergence, poor generalization, and fairness issues. This paper introduces a novel personalized FL framework designed to address these limitations through a bi-level optimization strategy. Our approach employs a robust global aggregation mechanism, such as Krum or trimmed mean, to mitigate the impact of malicious or outlier clients. Simultaneously, each client applies a personalized local model regularization derived from a proximal term to its local objective, aligning its model with a personalized anchor without sharing raw data. This dual strategy ensures fairness across diverse client distributions while maintaining global model robustness and preventing catastrophic forgetting. Extensive experiments demonstrate superior performance in terms of convergence speed, accuracy on non-IID data, and equitable performance across heterogeneous client subgroups.
subject: AI
title: Fair and Robust Aggregation in Heterogeneous Federated Learning via Personalized Local Model Regularization

text: Few-shot learning, demanding rapid adaptation to novel tasks from minimal samples, remains a frontier in machine learning. We propose an amortized meta-learning framework designed for enhanced few-shot generalization, which learns a comprehensive distribution over task-specific models. Our core innovation lies in the inference of latent task embeddings via a deep encoder network, capturing underlying data manifold characteristics and facilitating efficient adaptation. These embeddings condition adaptive prior distributions over model parameters, thereby guiding the rapid learning process and mitigating meta-overfitting in low-data regimes. By amortizing the meta-learning process, our approach enables efficient generalization to unseen tasks without explicit inner-loop optimization at test time. Empirical evaluations on diverse few-shot classification and regression benchmarks demonstrate significant improvements in generalization bounds and sample efficiency compared to state-of-the-art meta-learning algorithms.
subject: AI
title: Amortized Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Generalization via Latent Task Embeddings and Adaptive Priors

text: Robust decision-making in complex, dynamic environments necessitates understanding not just predictive outcomes, but also causal relationships and counterfactual implications of actions. This paper introduces a novel framework that integrates Structural Causal Models (SCMs) with deep reinforcement learning (RL) to enable counterfactual policy evaluation and learning. We develop methodologies for constructing and continuously refining SCMs from heterogeneous observational and interventional data, allowing RL agents to explicitly reason about "what-if" scenarios. By grounding policy learning in causal graphs, our agents can mitigate confounding biases inherent in observational data, learn policies that are robust to distributional shifts, and evaluate the true efficacy of interventions beyond mere associations. Empirical validation on simulated and real-world decision-making tasks demonstrates superior policy robustness and interpretability, particularly in scenarios requiring generalization beyond training data distributions.
subject: AI
title: Integrating Structural Causal Models with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Counterfactual Policy Evaluation

text: Achieving both the flexibility of deep learning and the interpretability of symbolic AI for complex relational reasoning remains a critical challenge. This work presents a novel hybrid neuro-symbolic system that synergizes neural networks with Inductive Logic Programming (ILP) for explainable and robust knowledge acquisition. Our architecture employs neural components to learn latent predicate embeddings from sub-symbolic data and generate candidate logical rules, which are then passed to a symbolic ILP engine for formal verification, refinement, and generalization. This iterative feedback loop enables the discovery of complex, interpretable logic programs from noisy data, while the neural component provides robustness to perceptual ambiguity. We demonstrate the system's efficacy in tasks requiring relational reasoning over knowledge graphs and rule learning from examples, yielding superior performance and inherently explainable models compared to purely neural or symbolic approaches.
subject: AI
title: Hybrid Neuro-Symbolic Inductive Logic Programming for Explainable Relational Reasoning

text: Environmental perturbation often elicits widespread developmental plasticity, which can be canalized or assimilated over evolutionary time. We investigate the hypothesis that transient epigenetic modifications, particularly differential DNA methylation and histone acetylation, serve as critical substrates for buffering cryptic genetic variation and facilitating rapid phenotypic diversification. Utilizing a systems-level analysis of a repeatedly evolved ecotype, we demonstrate that environmentally induced epigenetic shifts underpin altered gene regulatory networks, modulating developmental trajectories and subsequently influencing organismal fitness. These non-Mendelian inheritance patterns provide a rapid, potentially reversible mechanism for adapting to novel environments, decoupling immediate phenotypic responses from underlying genetic architecture. Our findings elucidate a molecular mechanism whereby transgenerational epigenetic inheritance can facilitate evolutionary novelty by modulating developmental robustness, offering a nuanced perspective on the origins of adaptive traits and the evolutionary process itself.
subject: Evrim
title: Epigenetic Modulations of Developmental Canalization and Their Role in Rapid Phenotypic Diversification

text: Host-parasite interactions represent canonical systems for studying rapid coevolution, often characterized by antagonistic pleiotropy and Red Queen dynamics. We integrate population genomics with experimental evolution to reconstruct the reciprocal adaptive landscapes driving coevolution between *Daphnia magna* and its microparasite, *Pasteuria ramosa*. Our high-resolution genomic analyses identify specific host Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) haplotypes and parasite virulence factors under strong frequency-dependent selection, revealing a highly dynamic genetic architecture of resistance and infectivity. We demonstrate how fine-scale genetic variation, influenced by epistatic interactions and fitness trade-offs, shapes the undulating topography of these landscapes. Crucially, the observed genomic signatures deviate from simple gene-for-gene models, indicating complex polygenic inheritance influencing both host defense and parasite counter-adaptation. This work provides a comprehensive genomic framework for understanding the intricate, often non-equilibrium, trajectories of coevolutionary arms races.
subject: Evrim
title: Reciprocal Adaptive Landscapes in Host-Parasite Coevolutionary Dynamics: A Genomically Informed Perspective

text: Adaptive radiations provide exceptional systems to investigate the interplay between ecological opportunity and intrinsic developmental architecture in generating biodiversity. We explored the drivers of ecomorphological divergence in Antillean *Anolis* lizards, a quintessential adaptive radiation. Through integrated phylogenetic comparative methods, geometric morphometrics, and ecological niche modeling, we quantified the relative contributions of novel resource availability and pre-existing developmental biases to their spectacular phenotypic diversification. Our analyses reveal that while ecological release into unoccupied adaptive zones initiated initial divergence, subsequent evolutionary trajectories were significantly canalized by inherent developmental modularity, particularly within the craniofacial and appendicular skeletons. These developmental modules acted as both facilitators and constraints, biasing the direction of morphological evolution and repeatedly producing convergent ecomorphs across independent island radiations. This study underscores the complex interplay between extrinsic ecological forces and intrinsic developmental legacy in shaping macroevolutionary patterns.
subject: Evrim
title: Disentangling the Roles of Niche Opportunity and Developmental Constraint in the Diversification of Neotropical Anole Lizards

text: Hybrid zones offer unique windows into the speciation continuum, revealing the genomic landscape of reproductive isolation and introgression. We conducted a spatially explicit population genomic study across a sympatric hybrid zone between two *Rhagoletis* fruit fly species, employing thousands of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) to delineate regions of differential permeability to gene flow. Our analyses identified numerous "genomic islands of divergence" characterized by reduced introgression and elevated linkage disequilibrium, indicative of loci under strong selection against hybridization. Conversely, we detected regions of widespread adaptive introgression, suggesting beneficial gene flow facilitating local adaptation. The observed mosaic genomic architecture underscores the multifaceted nature of reproductive isolation, involving both intrinsic genetic incompatibilities and ecologically mediated barriers. This research provides critical insights into the genomic basis of incipient speciation and the factors dictating the integrity of species boundaries in the face of gene flow.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Architectures of Reproductive Isolation in a Sympatric Hybrid Zone: Unraveling the Introgression Landscape

text: Gene duplication events provide raw material for evolutionary innovation, often leading to subfunctionalization or neofunctionalization of paralogous genes. We investigated the molecular mechanisms driving functional divergence in a duplicated receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) gene family critical for cell fate determination. Employing codon-based maximum likelihood models, we identified distinct residues under strong positive selection within the allosteric regulatory domains of two paralogs. Mutagenesis experiments and biophysical assays revealed that these specific amino acid substitutions altered ligand binding kinetics and downstream signaling effector recruitment, resulting in distinct signal transduction specificities despite overall structural conservation. This targeted evolution of allosteric sites demonstrates a powerful mechanism by which duplicated genes can acquire novel regulatory functions, enabling the elaboration of complex signaling networks and contributing to the morphological and physiological diversification of organisms.
subject: Evrim
title: Positive Selection on Divergent Allosteric Sites Dictates Functional Specialization in Paralogs of a Signal Transduction Pathway

text: Niche construction, the process by which organisms modify their environment, generates reciprocal causation between ecological and evolutionary dynamics. We empirically demonstrate such eco-evolutionary feedbacks using a foundational ecosystem engineer, the beaver (*Castor canadensis*). Beavers construct dams that reshape fluvial geomorphology, altering hydrological regimes and creating novel wetland habitats. Our landscape genomics approach revealed distinct genetic signatures within beaver populations exhibiting varying intensities of construction behavior, correlating with specific adaptive alleles influencing dam efficacy and resource utilization. These environmental modifications, in turn, impose novel selective pressures on beaver populations, mediating divergent life-history strategies and local adaptation to engineered landscapes. Furthermore, these altered environments influenced community structure and gene flow in co-occurring riparian species. This study highlights how persistent biogeomorphic niche construction acts as a potent evolutionary force, fundamentally altering both the selective environment and the evolutionary trajectories of interacting species.
subject: Evrim
title: Eco-Evolutionary Feedbacks Driven by Biogeomorphic Niche Construction in Ecosystem Engineers

text: Eusociality, characterized by reproductive division of labor and cooperative brood care, represents a major evolutionary transition. We explored the genomic basis of independent eusociality origins in several Hymenopteran lineages, integrating comparative genomics, transcriptomics, and epigenetics. Our analyses identified a conserved core set of gene regulatory networks, often involved in metabolism, neuronal development, and pheromone signaling, whose differential expression and alternative splicing patterns correlate with caste differentiation. We observe significant enrichment for genes under positive selection in regulatory regions proximal to these key genes, suggesting that subtle shifts in gene expression timing and magnitude, rather than novel gene acquisition, drove the evolution of complex social behaviors. These findings highlight the critical role of kin selection in shaping genomic architecture that favors altruistic behaviors and provide molecular insights into how modifications to ancestral gene toolkits facilitate the profound phenotypic plasticity underlying caste determination and the emergence of derived social forms.
subject: Evrim
title: Kin Selection and the Genomic Underpinnings of Eusociality Transitions in Hymenoptera

text: The stunning diversity of vertebrate craniofacial morphology arises from the interplay of developmental processes and natural selection. We investigated how intrinsic developmental biases, arising from the modular organization and regulatory logic of craniofacial development, both constrain and facilitate evolutionary trajectories. Using 3D geometric morphometrics and comparative phylogenetic methods across diverse vertebrate clades, we quantified the structure of developmental variance-covariance matrices (P-matrices) and their alignment with evolutionary divergence patterns (G-matrices). Our findings demonstrate significant conservation of developmental integration patterns, suggesting strong developmental canalization that biases the types of morphological variation available for selection. However, we also identify instances where developmental modularity facilitates the independent evolution of distinct craniofacial units, channeling diversification along specific adaptive pathways. This synthesis reveals how intrinsic developmental properties impose "rules" on morphological evolution, guiding phenotypic exploration within a circumscribed morphospace and influencing macroevolutionary patterns.
subject: Evrim
title: Developmental Constraints and Facilitation in the Evolution of Craniofacial Diversity Across Vertebrates

text: Angiosperms exhibit pervasive whole-genome duplication (WGD) and polyploidy, which have profoundly influenced their evolutionary success but complicate phylogenetic inference. We employed a robust synteny-based phylogenomics approach, integrating large-scale genomic data from across basal angiosperm lineages, to accurately identify and date ancestral WGD events. By meticulously reconstructing chromosomal rearrangements and paralog retention patterns, we resolved challenges posed by successive polyploidization and subsequent diploidization. Our analyses precisely localized multiple cryptic ancient WGDs that predate major angiosperm divergences, illuminating their contribution to gene family expansion and the evolution of novel developmental pathways. This work provides an unprecedented high-resolution genomic framework for understanding the macroevolutionary impact of polyploidy on angiosperm diversification and offers novel insights into the deep phylogenetic relationships within this species-rich clade, enhancing our understanding of plant genome evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Resolving Ancient Whole-Genome Duplications and Polyploidy in the Deep Phylogeny of Angiosperms Using Synteny-Based Phylogenomics

text: Understanding how multiple interacting traits evolve concurrently within an adaptive landscape framework is central to evolutionary biology. We constructed high-dimensional adaptive landscapes for a complex suite of life-history and morphological traits in a wild passerine population, integrating long-term quantitative genetic data with fitness estimates. Our analyses revealed that strong stabilizing selection acts on phenotypic combinations, creating rugged adaptive peaks. Crucially, underlying genetic correlations (the G-matrix) significantly constrained evolutionary trajectories, diverting populations from direct paths to putative fitness optima. We demonstrate that even under shifting environmental conditions favoring directional selection on individual traits, the extant genetic covariance structure dictates the realized evolutionary response, often leading to maladaptive outcomes or requiring substantial G-matrix re-shaping. This study underscores the critical role of multivariate quantitative genetics in predicting evolutionary dynamics and highlights the enduring impact of genetic architecture on adaptive potential.
subject: Evrim
title: Multi-Trait Adaptive Landscapes: The Interplay of Stabilizing Selection and Genetic Correlations in Evolutionary Trajectories

text: This work investigates the holographic renormalization group (RG) flow of entanglement entropy in a (d+1)-dimensional de Sitter spacetime, employing a modified AdS/dCFT correspondence framework. We explicitly construct the non-local entanglement entropy functional for boundary conformal field theories (CFTs) dual to bulk de Sitter geometries, focusing on the interplay between cosmological horizons and the area-law violations characteristic of UV divergences. Our analysis reveals that the structure of quantum entanglement across spacelike surfaces in expanding universes is profoundly influenced by the interplay of gravitational anomalies and the inherent non-unitary evolution. We further demonstrate how a novel counterterm prescription, derived from the Weyl anomaly in the boundary CFT, effectively regularizes the entanglement entropy and provides insights into the fine-grained degrees of freedom responsible for the de Sitter horizon entropy. These findings offer a microscopic understanding of quantum information loss in evolving gravitational backgrounds and have implications for resolving the informational paradoxes associated with cosmic horizons.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Renormalization Group Flow and Entanglement Entropy in De Sitter Spacetime

text: We present a comprehensive theoretical framework for probing the stochastic background of primordial gravitational waves (PGWs) generated during first-order cosmological phase transitions, particularly focusing on the electroweak epoch. Utilizing a refined fluid dynamics approach for bubble expansion and collision, we compute the characteristic spectrum of PGWs, incorporating velocity-dependent friction and non-linear interactions between plasma and bubble walls. Our analysis extends to the unique signatures imprinted on cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropies and the large-scale structure via induced scalar and tensor non-Gaussianities. We demonstrate that deviations from Gaussianity in the PGW spectrum, detectable by next-generation gravitational wave observatories, can serve as a robust discriminant for different phase transition scenarios, offering unparalleled insights into the dynamics of the early universe and potential mechanisms for electroweak baryogenesis. The interplay between thermal fluctuations and gravitational wave generation provides a novel avenue for constraining beyond-Standard Model physics.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Primordial Gravitational Waves through Cosmological Phase Transitions and Non-Gaussianities

text: This study explores the emergence of non-Hermitian topological phases in two-dimensional quasicrystalline lattices, specifically focusing on the interplay between quasiperiodicity and non-reciprocal coupling. We demonstrate that the inherent aperiodicity of quasicrystals facilitates the formation of intricate band structures characterized by multiple exceptional point degeneracies, leading to the manifestation of extensive flat bands. Unlike conventional Hermitian systems, these flat bands in the non-Hermitian regime exhibit highly localized states due to the Non-Hermitian Skin Effect, drastically altering the bulk-boundary correspondence. Our theoretical model, based on a generalized Su-Schrieffer-Heeger Hamiltonian with spatially varying gain and loss terms, predicts novel topological invariants derived from generalized Brillouin zone constructions. These findings open new avenues for designing robust topological metamaterials with unconventional transport properties and highly tunable spectral characteristics, paving the way for applications in advanced wave guiding and sensing technologies.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergent Non-Hermitian Topology and Exceptional Point Flat Bands in Quasicrystalline Lattices

text: We propose a novel strategy for unambiguously determining the neutrino mass hierarchy and constraining CP-violating phases in the lepton sector by leveraging precision measurements of Coherent Elastic Neutrino-Nucleus Scattering (CEvNS). Our theoretical framework incorporates effects from non-standard neutrino interactions (NSIs) and potential light sterile neutrinos, which can significantly modify the CEvNS cross-section and its energy dependence. By analyzing the differential recoil spectra from reactor and accelerator neutrino sources with high-resolution detectors, we demonstrate that a combined fit to the observed event rates, particularly at low momentum transfer, can resolve the current degeneracies in oscillation parameter space. This method offers a complementary approach to traditional long-baseline oscillation experiments, providing sensitivity to new physics beyond the Standard Model that might obscure direct oscillation signals. Furthermore, the exceptional low-energy threshold of CEvNS makes it an ideal probe for astrophysical neutrinos and certain dark matter interaction channels.
subject: Fizik
title: Unraveling Neutrino Mass Hierarchy and CP Violation through Coherent Elastic Neutrino-Nucleus Scattering (CEvNS)

text: This research establishes fundamental information-theoretic bounds on the thermodynamic efficiency of autonomous Maxwell's demons operating within non-equilibrium steady states, extending classical Jarzynski-type equalities to systems with active feedback and internal degrees of freedom. We rigorously derive a generalized second law for such systems, demonstrating how the extraction of work is inextricably linked to the processing of mutual information between the demon and the thermal bath, even in the absence of an external operator. Our analysis identifies the critical role of information erasure and its associated entropic cost in determining the maximum achievable efficiency, which we find is bounded by the ratio of information gained to the total dissipated heat. Furthermore, we investigate the influence of finite-time operations and feedback loop delays on the demon's performance, providing crucial insights into the trade-offs between speed, information acquisition, and thermodynamic cost in complex biological and artificial nanomachines.
subject: Fizik
title: Information-Theoretic Bounds on Efficiency in Autonomous Maxwell's Demons operating in Non-Equilibrium Steady States

text: Achieving fault-tolerant quantum computation necessitates robust quantum error correction (QEC) protocols, particularly on hardware with practical limitations such as restricted qubit connectivity. This study investigates the implementation and performance of topological QEC codes, specifically variations of the surface code, on two-dimensional architectures characterized by a finite coordination number. We present novel syndrome measurement strategies and decoding algorithms tailored to mitigate errors arising from sparse connectivity, including leakage and measurement-induced disturbances. Our analysis quantitatively assesses the impact of qubit locality and gate fidelity on the logical error rate, demonstrating that optimized entanglement routing and syndrome extraction circuits can significantly lower the overhead for achieving fault tolerance thresholds. These findings provide a scalable blueprint for constructing robust quantum computers using current and near-future experimental platforms, addressing a critical bottleneck in the path towards practical universal quantum computation.
subject: Fizik
title: Scalable Quantum Error Correction via Topological Codes on Architectures with Limited Connectivity

text: Multi-messenger observations of binary neutron star (BNS) mergers offer an unprecedented opportunity to probe the fabric of spacetime in the most extreme curvature regimes and constrain the supranuclear equation of state. This work presents a comprehensive analysis framework for combining gravitational wave (GW) signals with electromagnetic counterparts (e.g., short gamma-ray bursts, kilonovae) to precisely infer the properties of merging neutron stars and their post-merger remnants. We develop advanced waveform models that incorporate tidal deformability effects and phase transitions, allowing for stringent tests of general relativity in the strong-field regime. By correlating the GW-inferred tidal parameters with kilonova light curves and spectroscopic features, we demonstrate novel constraints on neutron star radii and the nuclear matter stiffness. This synergy between distinct astrophysical messengers provides unique insights into fundamental physics, including the upper limit of neutron star masses and potential deviations from the Chandrasekhar limit, thus refining our understanding of dense matter.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Extreme Spacetime Curvature with Multi-Messenger Observations of Binary Neutron Star Mergers

text: We present a theoretical and numerical investigation into the existence and properties of many-body localization (MBL) phase transitions in arrays of interacting Rydberg atoms subjected to coherent driving and engineered dissipation.
