Unlike conventional closed MBL systems, the interplay of coherent driving, long-range dipolar interactions, and collective decay mechanisms introduces novel pathways for thermalization and information scrambling. Our model reveals that specific configurations of resonant driving fields can stabilize localized phases against strong dissipative coupling, pushing the system away from ergodicity. By analyzing the entanglement entropy, participation ratios, and the spectral properties of the non-Hermitian effective Hamiltonian, we map out the phase diagram for driven-dissipative MBL. These findings offer a blueprint for creating robust quantum memories and simulators that exploit localization phenomena even in open quantum systems, providing crucial insights for future quantum technologies and fundamental understanding of non-equilibrium quantum matter.
subject: Fizik
title: Unveiling Many-Body Localization Transitions in Driven-Dissipative Rydberg Atom Arrays

text: This study employs global gyrokinetic simulations to elucidate the intricate mechanisms underlying zonal flow formation and their role in suppressing multi-scale turbulence in magnetically confined fusion plasmas, a critical challenge for achieving sustained thermonuclear reactions. We present a detailed analysis of the non-linear coupling between ion temperature gradient (ITG) and trapped electron mode (TEM) driven turbulence with radially localized zonal flows and geodesic acoustic modes (GAMs). Our simulations reveal that the saturation of turbulence is predominantly mediated by the predator-prey dynamics between turbulent eddies and sheared E×B flows, leading to the formation of internal transport barriers. We quantify the momentum and energy transport coefficients in various confinement regimes relevant to ITER, demonstrating that optimized magnetic configurations can enhance zonal flow generation and thereby significantly reduce anomalous transport, paving the way for more efficient and stable fusion reactor designs.
subject: Fizik
title: Gyrokinetic Simulations of Zonal Flow Formation and Multi-Scale Turbulence Suppression in Fusion Plasmas

text: This work explores contextuality, a fundamental non-classical feature of quantum mechanics formalized by the Kochen-Specker theorem, not merely as a restriction on classical realism but as a powerful resource for quantum information processing. We propose generalized measurement scenarios, extending beyond standard projective measurements, where the degree of contextuality can be quantified and manipulated. By introducing a novel measure of contextuality based on operational distinguishability, we demonstrate how contextuality can enable advantages in tasks such as quantum state discrimination, communication complexity reduction, and secure key distribution, surpassing bounds achievable by non-contextual or even non-local classical strategies. Our theoretical framework elucidates the intricate relationship between contextuality, non-locality, and entanglement, suggesting new avenues for exploiting the foundational aspects of quantum theory to develop enhanced quantum technologies. This reframes contextuality as an active ingredient rather than a passive descriptor of quantum mechanics.
subject: Fizik
title: Contextuality as a Resource for Enhanced Quantum Information Processing in Generalized Measurement Scenarios

text: Deep Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have demonstrated remarkable efficacy across graph-structured data; however, their susceptibility to adversarial perturbations remains a critical vulnerability, particularly in safety-critical applications. This work introduces a novel adversarial invariance regularization scheme designed to bolster GNN robustness against structural and feature-based attacks. We propose a spectral perturbation mechanism that synthesizes adversarial graph structures by minimally altering the graph Laplacian's eigenvalues while preserving its eigenvectors, thereby creating challenging, imperceptible attacks within a constrained spectral manifold. Our method enforces invariance of GNN predictions under these spectrally-constrained adversarial transformations through a min-max optimization framework coupled with a contrastive loss. Empirical evaluations on benchmark graph classification and node-level prediction tasks reveal that this approach significantly enhances model resilience against both discrete and continuous adversarial attacks, outperforming state-of-the-art defenses in terms of certified robustness margins and generalization performance, particularly in low-homophily graphs with sparse connectivity.
subject: AI
title: Adversarial Invariance Regularization for Robust Deep Graph Neural Networks

text: Generating actionable counterfactual explanations for complex black-box machine learning models is crucial for transparent and trustworthy AI systems. Existing methods often struggle with feasibility and plausibility of generated counterfactuals, particularly in high-dimensional, interdependent feature spaces. This paper proposes a novel framework leveraging entropic regularization within a generative causal model (GCM) to synthesize diverse, interpretable, and valid counterfactuals. We employ a variational autoencoder (VAE) augmented with structural causal model (SCM) constraints, where the VAE learns a disentangled latent representation corresponding to causal mechanisms. An information-theoretic objective, specifically mutual information maximization, is integrated to encourage diversity and enforce a parsimonious set of feature interventions. Our approach ensures that generated counterfactuals adhere to both the underlying data distribution and the causal dependencies, yielding explanations that are simultaneously close to the factual instance in the feature space and consistent with real-world interventions, demonstrated across various tabular and image classification tasks.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Explanations via Entropic Regularization in Generative Causal Models

text: Achieving zero-shot generalization in embodied AI agents remains a formidable challenge, primarily due to the semantic gap between perceptual inputs and high-level behavioral objectives. This research introduces a novel multi-modal contrastive pre-training paradigm, leveraging latent diffusion models to bridge this gap. Our framework integrates visual observations, natural language instructions, and proprioceptive data into a unified representation space via a contrastive learning objective. A conditional latent diffusion model is then trained on this joint representation to synthesize plausible future states and actions, conditioned on high-level goals. This enables robust policy learning by effectively regularizing the agent's latent space with semantic consistency. Extensive experiments across diverse simulated environments demonstrate that our method significantly improves zero-shot task completion rates and sample efficiency compared to existing embodied AI approaches, facilitating rapid adaptation to unseen tasks and environments by grounding symbolic goals in rich perceptual contexts.
subject: AI
title: Multi-Modal Contrastive Pre-training with Latent Diffusion for Zero-Shot Embodied AI

text: Ensuring safety in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) systems, particularly in uncertain and dynamic environments, is paramount for real-world deployment. Traditional MARL approaches often lack formal safety guarantees, relying on heuristic penalty functions. This work proposes a novel framework for safe MARL grounded in stochastic optimal control theory, providing explicit probabilistic safety guarantees. We formulate the multi-agent control problem as a Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) where safety constraints are expressed as probabilistic reachability specifications over a set of unsafe states. By combining risk-aware policy optimization with verifiable reachability analysis using sum-of-squares programming, we learn decentralized policies that minimize expected cost while adhering to a user-defined probability of constraint violation. Empirical results in multi-robot navigation and air traffic control scenarios demonstrate significant improvements in safety metrics, achieving stringent collision avoidance rates without excessively sacrificing task performance, even under adversarial disturbances and sensor noise.
subject: AI
title: Stochastic Optimal Control for Safe Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Probabilistic Guarantees

text: Federated Learning (FL) offers a privacy-preserving paradigm for collaborative model training; however, challenges related to client heterogeneity, communication overhead, and privacy leakage persist. This paper presents an advanced FL framework that addresses these limitations through personalized model aggregation and communication-efficient private gradient exchange. Our approach introduces a novel clustering-based personalized aggregation strategy where clients with similar data distributions form dynamic sub-federations, allowing for tailored global model updates without compromising overall convergence. To mitigate communication costs and enhance privacy, we integrate a quantized, differentially private gradient compression technique that selectively transmits only salient updates. Theoretical analysis provides convergence guarantees for non-IID data distributions and bounds on privacy loss. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms baseline FL algorithms in terms of personalized model performance, communication efficiency, and robustness to Byzantine attacks, thereby enabling practical deployment in diverse heterogeneous edge environments.
subject: AI
title: Scalable Federated Learning with Personalized Model Aggregation and Communication-Efficient Private Gradients

text: Large Language Models (LLMs) excel at pattern recognition and generation but often exhibit limitations in robust commonsense reasoning, particularly concerning logical consistency and novel relational inference. This paper introduces a hybrid neuro-symbolic framework for enhancing LLM capabilities in commonsense knowledge acquisition and utilization. We propose an architecture that integrates an LLM's vast parametric knowledge with an explicit symbolic knowledge graph (KG) and a rule-based reasoning engine. The LLM acts as a "knowledge miner" to extract and refine symbolic facts from unstructured text, which are then formalized and integrated into the KG. A differentiable symbolic reasoning module allows the LLM to learn to leverage the KG for deductive and abductive inference, enabling verification and completion of complex commonsense statements. Evaluations on benchmarks requiring intricate multi-hop reasoning and constraint satisfaction demonstrate superior performance over purely neural or symbolic approaches, showcasing a promising path towards more interpretable and robust AI.
subject: AI
title: Hybrid Neuro-Symbolic Reasoning for Commonsense Knowledge Acquisition in Large Language Models

text: The vulnerability of deep neural networks to adversarial examples, which reside on low-dimensional manifolds embedded within high-dimensional input spaces, necessitates a deeper understanding of these geometric structures. This work investigates the intrinsic dimensionality (ID) of adversarial sample spaces and its implications for certified robustness. We propose a novel, robust estimator for ID leveraging local geodesic distances on the data manifold, explicitly accounting for the non-Euclidean geometry perturbed by adversarial mechanisms. By analyzing the topological properties of latent representations under adversarial perturbations, we demonstrate that ID provides a crucial metric for quantifying the complexity and robustness "holes" in a model's decision boundary. Our empirical results show a strong correlation between lower estimated intrinsic dimensionality of adversarial regions and reduced model robustness. This provides a quantifiable target for adversarial training strategies, guiding the design of defense mechanisms to explicitly expand or smooth these critical low-dimensional adversarial subspaces, thereby enhancing provable guarantees.
subject: AI
title: Intrinsic Dimensionality Estimation for Manifold Learning in High-Dimensional Adversarial Sample Spaces

text: Anomaly detection in complex dynamic systems, such as industrial control or surveillance, demands robust spatio-temporal representation learning that can distinguish intricate deviations from normal operating conditions. Existing supervised methods are limited by labeled anomaly scarcity, while unsupervised methods often struggle with disentangling meaningful causal factors. This paper introduces a self-supervised framework for disentangling spatio-temporal representations conducive to high-precision anomaly detection. Our approach employs a contrastive predictive coding (CPC) mechanism combined with a variational autoencoder (VAE) architecture, specifically designed to factorize observations into independent spatial attributes and temporal dynamics. By enforcing independence through a total correlation objective and predicting future frames from disentangled latent variables, the model learns granular representations that highlight unusual patterns in either dimension. Extensive evaluations on diverse video and sensor stream datasets demonstrate superior performance in identifying subtle anomalies compared to state-of-the-art unsupervised and semi-supervised techniques, offering a robust solution for real-world monitoring.
subject: AI
title: Self-Supervised Disentanglement of Spatio-Temporal Representations for Anomaly Detection in Dynamic Systems

text: Continual learning (CL) in few-shot scenarios presents a significant challenge, as models must rapidly adapt to novel tasks with limited data while mitigating catastrophic forgetting of previously acquired knowledge. This paper introduces a novel meta-learning framework designed to achieve rapid, few-shot adaptation in CL environments by learning transferable inductive biases. Our approach employs a hierarchical meta-learning strategy that trains an optimizer to rapidly adjust model parameters and an episodic memory network to store and retrieve task-specific knowledge. A key innovation is the meta-learning objective, which balances task-specific accuracy with the preservation of generalizable features across an evolving sequence of tasks. This allows the model to quickly internalize new concepts from minimal examples while retaining robust performance on prior tasks. Empirical evaluations on diverse few-shot image classification and reinforcement learning benchmarks demonstrate superior performance compared to existing continual learning and meta-learning baselines, showcasing enhanced adaptability and significantly reduced forgetting.
subject: AI
title: Meta-Learning for Rapid Adaptation in Few-Shot Continual Learning Environments

text: Representing and learning from high-dimensional structured data, such as images, graphs, or sequences, poses significant scalability challenges for classical deep learning models. This work explores the application of quantum-inspired tensor networks (TNs) as a powerful and interpretable framework for scalable representation learning. We propose a novel architecture leveraging Matrix Product States (MPS) and Projected Entangled Pair States (PEPS) to efficiently encode and process correlations within structured inputs. By restricting the entanglement entropy of the learned representations, TNs naturally mitigate the curse of dimensionality and provide an inherent regularization mechanism, preventing overfitting. Our approach designs a differentiable TN layer that can be integrated into classical neural networks, enabling end-to-end training. Empirical evaluations on various tasks, including image classification and sequence modeling, demonstrate that our TN-based models achieve competitive performance with significantly fewer parameters and enhanced interpretability compared to standard convolutional or recurrent architectures, offering a promising avenue for efficient and explainable AI on complex data.
subject: AI
title: Quantum-Inspired Tensor Networks for Scalable Representation Learning on Structured Data

text: This research introduces a novel deep generative framework designed to infer latent causal structures from complex, high-dimensional observational datasets. Leveraging advancements in Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) and integrating principles of Invariant Risk Minimization (IRMv2), our model learns disentangled representations robust to shifts in underlying data distributions. We propose a Causal Latent Variable Model (CLVM) where interventions on specific latent dimensions correspond to identifiable causal mechanisms. Empirical evaluations on synthetic and real-world perturbed datasets, specifically in biological pathway analysis, demonstrate superior performance in identifying direct and indirect causal links compared to purely correlational or existing structural causal models. The framework offers a pathway toward enhanced interpretability and generalizability of deep learning systems by moving beyond mere association to actionable causal discovery.
subject: AI
title: Disentangling Latent Causal Structures in High-Dimensional Observational Data via Deep Generative Models with Invariant Risk Minimization

text: This paper explores the efficacy of hybrid quantum-classical algorithms, specifically leveraging Variational Quantum Eigensolvers (VQE), for approximating ground state energies of molecular Hamiltonians. We propose a novel ansatz based on a tensor network decomposition, integrating Matrix Product States (MPS) as a compact representation for quantum circuit parameterization within the VQE framework. This architecture mitigates the barren plateau problem prevalent in deep quantum circuits by constraining expressivity while maintaining computational power for relevant quantum states. Our approach utilizes classical optimization routines to update parameters encoded within the MPS, which are then translated into hardware-efficient quantum gates on a superconducting qubit architecture. Benchmarking against established quantum chemistry benchmarks (e.g., LiH, H2O) reveals significant improvements in convergence speed and energy accuracy, demonstrating potential for near-term quantum advantage in materials science.
subject: AI
title: Hybrid Quantum-Classical Tensor Network Architectures for Variational Quantum Eigensolver Optimization in Molecular Systems

text: We present an advanced meta-learning paradigm, the Hierarchical Bayesian Task-Agnostic Meta-Learner (HB-TAML), specifically engineered to address the critical challenge of extreme few-shot classification. Unlike conventional gradient-based meta-learning approaches, HB-TAML infers a distribution over model parameters using amortized variational inference, thereby capturing task-specific uncertainty and enabling more robust generalization from minimal examples. Our method integrates a hierarchical Bayesian prior structure, allowing for adaptive regularization across diverse task distributions and mitigating overfitting in the support set. Performance is rigorously evaluated on challenging meta-datasets like miniImageNet and tieredImageNet, demonstrating significant improvements in classification accuracy and calibration compared to state-of-the-art meta-learning algorithms, particularly under conditions of severe data scarcity. The proposed architecture enhances sample efficiency and provides a principled mechanism for uncertainty quantification in transfer learning scenarios.
subject: AI
title: Adaptive Task-Agnostic Meta-Learner with Hierarchical Bayesian Priors for Extreme Few-Shot Classification

text: This research introduces a novel neuro-symbolic framework that bridges the gap between subsymbolic neural representations and symbolic logical reasoning for enhanced explainability and robustness in AI systems. We propose learning continuous predicate logic embeddings within a Graph Neural Network (GNN) architecture, where predicates and entities are jointly embedded in a common vector space. A differentiable first-order logic (FOL) reasoning module is then integrated, allowing for logical rule induction and query answering directly over these embeddings. This hybrid approach enables the system to perform complex relational reasoning tasks, such as knowledge graph completion and question answering, while simultaneously generating human-interpretable explanations grounded in symbolic logic. Extensive experiments on FB15k-237 and NELL-995 datasets demonstrate superior reasoning capabilities and provide clear logical justifications for predictions, addressing a key limitation of purely connectionist models in adversarial and out-of-distribution scenarios.
subject: AI
title: Predicate Logic Embeddings for Explainable Neuro-Symbolic Reasoning in Complex Relational Graphs

text: We present a novel methodology for achieving certifiable adversarial robustness while concurrently providing provable interpretability in deep neural networks. Our approach leverages sparse convex relaxations of network activations, allowing for the analytical derivation of lower bounds on adversarial perturbation magnitudes using duality theory. Critically, we integrate influence functions within this robust optimization framework to identify salient training points that critically affect a model's prediction and its robustness certificate. This synergy enables not only a guarantee against adversarial attacks within a specified L_infinity norm but also offers a quantifiable measure of feature importance and data attribution. Experimental validation on CIFAR-10 and SVHN datasets demonstrates that our method achieves state-of-the-art certified accuracy against strong adversaries, alongside transparent insights into model decisions, thereby advancing the development of trustworthy and auditable AI systems.
subject: AI
title: Certifiable Adversarial Robustness with Provable Interpretability via Sparse Convex Relaxations and Influence Functions

text: This paper addresses catastrophic forgetting in continual learning paradigms through a novel memory-augmented generative replay mechanism. We propose a generative adversarial network (GAN) that learns a compressed, task-agnostic representation of past data distributions, effectively synthesizing pseudo-samples for replay during subsequent task training. Crucially, the GAN's latent space is regularized via a Variational Autoencoder (VAE) objective, enabling robust feature disentanglement and reducing mode collapse. An episodic memory buffer stores a small subset of high-importance samples, selectively chosen using a coresets-based strategy, to anchor the generative process. Experimental evaluations on sequentially presented image classification tasks (e.g., Permuted MNIST, CIFAR-100) demonstrate that our approach significantly mitigates forgetting while maintaining high forward transfer and backward transfer efficiency, outperforming existing regularization and architectural methods in terms of plasticity-stability trade-off.
subject: AI
title: Memory-Augmented Generative Replay for Catastrophic Forgetting Mitigation in Non-Stationary Task Sequences

text: We introduce a novel architecture for Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) termed Higher-Order Equivariant GNNs (HGE-GNNs), specifically designed to capture complex, multi-body interactions and preserve physical symmetries in molecular systems. Unlike conventional GNNs operating on pairwise distances, HGE-GNNs incorporate spherical harmonics and Clebsch-Gordan coefficients to represent and propagate information across higher-order invariant features (e.g., angles, dihedrals). This intrinsic equivariance to SE(3) transformations ensures that predictions remain consistent under rotations and translations, crucial for accurate molecular conformation prediction and interaction modeling. Benchmarking on QM9 and MD17 datasets for force field learning and energy prediction demonstrates substantial improvements in prediction accuracy and generalization capabilities, particularly for large, flexible molecules. Our framework offers a promising avenue for accelerating drug discovery by enabling more precise simulation of molecular dynamics and protein-ligand binding.
subject: AI
title: Higher-Order Equivariant Graph Neural Networks for Molecular Conformation Prediction and Drug Discovery

text: This research proposes a principled framework for aligning advanced Reinforcement Learning (RL) agents with complex human values, mitigating the challenges of reward misspecification and value drift. We integrate an iterated preference elicitation mechanism, where human operators provide comparative feedback on agent trajectories, into a Bayesian Inverse Reinforcement Learning (BIRL) framework. This process iteratively refines a latent reward function, estimating a posterior distribution over human preferences. Crucially, we introduce a robust uncertainty quantification module that informs the agent's exploration strategy, prioritizing trajectories that are maximally informative for preference learning while minimizing harmful outcomes during the alignment phase. Experimental simulations demonstrate superior convergence to desired human behaviors and enhanced safety profiles compared to direct reward engineering or single-shot feedback methods, offering a scalable solution for deploying powerful, value-aligned AI systems in safety-critical domains.
subject: AI
title: Principled Alignment of Advanced Reinforcement Learning Agents through Iterated Preference Elicitation and Bayesian Inverse Reinforcement Learning

text: This paper presents an energy-efficient deep learning paradigm leveraging Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) with biologically inspired adaptive synaptic plasticity for deployment on emerging neuromorphic hardware. We introduce a novel synaptic weight update rule, combining Spike-Timing-Dependent Plasticity (STDP) with a voltage-dependent potentiation mechanism, enabling rapid on-chip learning from sparse, event-driven data streams. Our SNN architecture incorporates membrane potential reset mechanisms and refractory periods optimized for energy consumption, achieving significant reductions in power dissipation compared to conventional Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs). Implemented and evaluated on a custom FPGA-based neuromorphic accelerator, the system demonstrates competitive accuracy on challenging edge inference tasks (e.g., MNIST, N-MNIST) while achieving an order of magnitude improvement in energy efficiency (Joules/inference). This work paves the way for ubiquitous, ultra-low-power intelligent sensors and autonomous systems operating at the extreme edge.
subject: AI
title: Spiking Neural Networks with Adaptive Synaptic Plasticity for Ultra-Low Power Edge Inference in Neuromorphic Processors

text: This study systematically investigates the emergent inductive biases and scaling laws exhibited by large-scale self-supervised Vision Transformers (ViTs) and their impact on zero-shot generalization capabilities. We probe models pre-trained with masked autoencoding (MAE) and contrastive learning objectives across varying model capacities and dataset scales, analyzing their representation spaces through canonical correlation analysis and neural collapse metrics. Our findings reveal that increased scale leads to an implicit emergence of object-centric and hierarchical features without explicit supervision, challenging conventional wisdom about CNN inductive biases. We identify power-law relationships governing the transferability of features to novel downstream tasks and propose a theoretical framework linking representational disentanglement to zero-shot performance. This research provides crucial insights into the fundamental mechanisms underlying the remarkable generalization abilities of foundation models, guiding future architectural designs and pre-training strategies.
subject: AI
title: Investigating Emergent Inductive Biases and Scaling Laws in Self-Supervised Vision Transformers for Zero-Shot Generalization

text: This research addresses the fundamental challenge of robust causal inference from complex observational data using deep learning architectures. Traditional deep models excel at correlational patterns but struggle with inferring underlying causal structures, which is critical for intervention and counterfactual reasoning. We propose a novel Deep Structural Causal Model (DSCM) built upon a Variational Autoencoder (VAE) framework, specifically engineered to enforce identifiable causal mechanisms within its latent space. By integrating an adversarial training objective with a carefully regularized counterfactual loss, our model disentangles confounding effects and learns stable causal representations. Experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate superior performance in causal graph discovery, effect estimation, and accurate counterfactual predictions compared to state-of-the-art non-causal and shallow causal methods, paving the way for more trustworthy and interpretable AI in high-stakes domains.
subject: AI
title: Deep Causal Discovery via Counterfactual Variational Autoencoders with Identifiable Structural Mechanisms

text: Federated Learning (FL) offers collaborative model training without raw data centralization but faces significant vulnerabilities from malicious clients, data heterogeneity, and privacy breaches. This work introduces a novel robust aggregation scheme for FL that synergistically integrates Byzantine-resilient mechanisms, adaptive differential privacy (ADP), and client-side adversarial sample detection. Our approach employs a weighted geometric median aggregation robust to data poisoning and model-poisoning attacks, enhanced by secure multi-party computation for gradient privacy. ADP noise injection is dynamically scaled based on global model uncertainty and local client contribution, optimizing the privacy-utility trade-off. Empirical evaluations on diverse datasets demonstrate superior model robustness against various adversarial threats, significantly improved privacy guarantees, and maintained accuracy compared to existing FL paradigms under non-IID data distributions and hostile environments.
subject: AI
title: Byzantine-Resilient Federated Learning with Adaptive Differential Privacy and Adversarial Defense

text: Catastrophic forgetting remains a critical impediment to deploying artificial neural networks in continual learning scenarios. Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs), inspired by biological brains, inherently offer event-driven processing and energy efficiency, yet their capacity for continual learning without forgetting complex tasks remains largely unexplored. We present an innovative meta-learning framework for SNNs that mitigates catastrophic forgetting by leveraging biologically-plausible plasticity rules and a novel surrogate gradient-based backpropagation through time. Our architecture incorporates a task-agnostic meta-learner that modulates synaptic efficacy and network topology, allowing rapid adaptation to new tasks while preserving previously acquired knowledge. Extensive experiments on sequential task learning benchmarks validate our model's superior performance in terms of knowledge retention, energy consumption, and rapid generalization to novel, unseen classes, showcasing a pathway toward brain-inspired lifelong learning systems.
subject: AI
title: Event-Driven Meta-Learning for Catastrophic Forgetting Mitigation in Spiking Neural Networks

text: Autonomous discovery of novel materials with desired properties is crucial but challenging due to vast chemical space and expensive simulations. This research proposes a PIG-RL (Physics-Informed Generative Adversarial Networks with Reinforcement Learning) framework for accelerating de novo material design. Our approach employs a conditional GAN to generate plausible material candidates, where the discriminator is augmented with physics-informed loss functions derived from quantum mechanical simulations, guiding the generative process towards synthesizable and stable structures. A reinforcement learning agent then navigates the latent space, using a reward function derived from target material properties, to optimize and fine-tune generated designs. This synergistic integration significantly reduces the search space, enhances design efficiency, and demonstrates a promising capability to discover materials with specified characteristics beyond the capabilities of conventional high-throughput screening.
subject: AI
title: Physics-Informed Generative Adversarial Networks with Reinforcement Learning for De Novo Material Design

text: The opacity of large-scale vision-language foundation models (VL-FMs) presents a significant barrier to their deployment in critical applications demanding transparency and trustworthiness. This study introduces a comprehensive XAI framework designed to demystify VL-FMs by integrating multi-modal attribution techniques with disentangled latent space analysis. Our methodology combines gradient-based saliency maps and attention-rollout methods for token-level and region-level attribution with a novel approach for identifying semantically meaningful disentangled latent factors governing cross-modal interactions. This allows for both local instance-specific explanations (e.g., 'why' a specific prediction was made) and global model understanding (e.g., 'what' concepts the model learned). Experiments demonstrate enhanced interpretability and trust scores without significant performance degradation, facilitating responsible development and deployment of VL-FMs.
subject: AI
title: Interpretable Vision-Language Foundation Models via Multi-Modal Attribution and Disentangled Latent Space Analysis

text: Classical Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) encounter limitations in capturing complex, non-local correlations in large-scale graphs and suffer from exponential scaling issues for certain graph-theoretic problems. This work introduces a novel Variational Quantum Graph Neural Network (VQGNN) architecture designed to leverage quantum computational primitives for enhanced feature learning in complex network structures. Our hybrid model employs parameterized quantum circuits to implement quantum graph convolutions, encoding graph nodes and edges into quantum states to exploit entanglement and superposition for rich feature representations. These quantum-derived features are then processed by a classical readout layer for downstream tasks such as node classification and link prediction. Experiments on benchmark graph datasets demonstrate that VQGNNs can achieve superior performance and robustness, particularly for densely connected and highly entangled graphs, suggesting a significant step towards quantum-accelerated graph analytics.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Graph Neural Networks for Enhanced Feature Learning in Complex Networks

text: Deploying sophisticated deep learning models on resource-constrained edge devices necessitates aggressive model compression without compromising performance. This research presents a synergistic methodology integrating structured sparsification, quantization-aware training, and multi-teacher knowledge distillation to achieve unprecedented efficiency for edge AI. Our approach employs a neural architecture search (NAS) framework to discover optimal sparse network topologies, followed by fine-grained magnitude pruning. Crucially, a novel multi-teacher distillation scheme transfers knowledge from an ensemble of diverse high-capacity models to the compact student network, bolstering robustness and accuracy post-quantization. Extensive empirical evaluations demonstrate that our methodology yields significantly smaller models (up to 50x compression) with minimal accuracy degradation (within 1-2%), substantially reducing computational latency and energy consumption, making complex AI viable for pervasive edge applications.
subject: AI
title: Synergistic Sparsification and Quantization-Aware Knowledge Distillation for Ultra-Efficient Edge AI

text: Managing complex Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) via centralized control faces scalability, robustness, and single-point-of-failure challenges. This research proposes a novel decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) framework, leveraging Graph Attention Networks (GATs), for robust and adaptive control in dynamic and partially observable CPS environments. Each agent utilizes a local GAT to dynamically infer neighborhood dependencies and communication protocols, addressing the non-stationarity inherent in MARL. A novel intrinsic reward mechanism based on local state entropy and collective goal progression facilitates emergent coordination without explicit communication channels. Our approach demonstrates superior resilience to sensor failures and communication delays, achieving significantly improved system-wide performance and adaptability in simulated smart grid and autonomous traffic management scenarios compared to established centralized and independent learning baselines.
subject: AI
title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention Networks for Resilient Cyber-Physical Systems

text: The scarcity of labeled data severely impedes the development of high-performance Natural Language Processing (NLP) models for low-resource languages (LRLs). This work introduces a novel cross-lingual, multi-modal self-supervised learning paradigm designed to robustly pre-train language representations for LRLs without relying on large monolingual corpora or extensive parallel data. Our framework integrates masked language modeling with a contrastive learning objective that aligns representations across diverse modalities (e.g., text, speech, images) from readily available resources. A key innovation is the fusion of acoustic-semantic alignment and visual grounding to enrich contextual understanding, enabling robust cross-lingual transfer. Experiments on downstream tasks like classification and question answering demonstrate significant performance gains for target LRLs, outperforming conventional transfer learning and purely text-based self-supervised approaches, fostering equitable AI accessibility.
subject: AI
title: Cross-Lingual Multi-Modal Self-Supervised Learning for Low-Resource Language Understanding

text: Bayesian Optimization (BO) is highly effective for global optimization of expensive black-box functions, but its scalability to high-dimensional problems and adaptation to complex, non-stationary landscapes remains challenging. We propose a novel Deep Kernel Bayesian Optimization (DKBO) framework that augments standard Gaussian Process (GP) surrogates with flexible deep kernel functions, parameterized by neural networks, to learn expressive, adaptive representations of the objective landscape. To enhance exploration-exploitation in high dimensions, our approach integrates uncertainty-aware acquisition functions derived from deep ensembles of GPs, offering a more robust estimate of predictive variance. This method significantly improves the efficiency of high-dimensional global optimization, outperforming traditional BO and other advanced surrogates on benchmarks involving expensive hyperparameter tuning and inverse design problems, demonstrating its potential for accelerating scientific discovery and engineering design.
subject: AI
title: Deep Kernel Bayesian Optimization with Uncertainty-Aware Ensembles for High-Dimensional Expensive Functions

text: This work investigates the realization and characterization of chiral Majorana modes in proximitized Weyl semimetals. By inducing s-wave superconductivity and applying an external magnetic field, we theoretically demonstrate the emergence of a topological superconducting phase characterized by distinct topological invariants and hosting robust chiral Majorana edge states. The interplay of broken time-reversal symmetry, spin-momentum locking, and electron-hole coherence leads to an effective p-wave pairing. We propose experimental signatures via quantized conductance plateaus and non-local noise correlations, which provide compelling evidence for the non-Abelian braiding statistics crucial for fault-tolerant quantum computation. This study elucidates a novel platform for engineering and manipulating elusive Majorana quasiparticles, advancing the pursuit of next-generation topological quantum bits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Chiral Majorana Edge Modes and Non-Abelian Statistics in Proximitized Weyl Semimetals

text: We investigate the entanglement dynamics of bipartite quantum systems operating near exceptional points (EPs) in open, non-Hermitian Hamiltonians. Contrary to conventional Hermitian systems, we demonstrate that the spectral singularities associated with EPs can profoundly amplify entanglement generation and enhance resilience against local decoherence. Utilizing a rigorously extended Lindblad master equation formalism for non-Hermitian contexts, our analysis reveals a dramatic, non-monotonic enhancement of concurrence and entanglement entropy at EP degeneracies. This mechanism establishes a novel paradigm for robust quantum state engineering and resilient quantum information processing in dissipative environments, by exploiting the unique complex spectral properties inherent to non-Hermitian quantum mechanics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Exceptional Point Enhanced Quantum Entanglement Dynamics in Open Non-Hermitian Systems

text: We propose a novel framework for topological quantum error correction (TQEC) leveraging stabilizer codes constructed on hyperbolic lattices, which exhibit inherent advantages in connectivity and boundary conditions over Euclidean counterparts. This architecture capitalizes on the non-trivial topology of hyperbolic manifolds to achieve significantly higher thresholds against local noise models, surpassing limitations of conventional surface codes. We derive optimal decoding algorithms based on minimum-weight perfect matching on the dual hyperbolic graph and meticulously analyze the logical error rate. The hyperbolic code paradigm presents a promising pathway towards fault-tolerant quantum computation, offering substantially improved performance and reduced physical qubit overhead.
subject: Kuantum
title: Hyperbolic Surface Codes: A Novel Architecture for Enhanced Topological Quantum Error Correction

text: This work explores the dynamics of entanglement harvesting between two initially unentangled Unruh-DeWitt detectors in a spacetime characterized by transient gravitational wave perturbations. We demonstrate that the evolving curvature and non-trivial causal structure of spacetime significantly modify the non-local correlations extractable from the quantum vacuum. Specifically, the gravitational memory effect is shown to induce a persistent enhancement of harvested entanglement, even after the gravitational wave has passed. These findings provide crucial insights into the interplay between general relativity and quantum mechanics, with profound implications for quantum information protocols in dynamic cosmological and astrophysical scenarios.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Harvesting from Quantum Fields in Gravitationally Warping Spacetimes

text: We theoretically investigate maximal work extraction from a quantum system coupled to a non-equilibrium bath exhibiting significant quantum coherence, employing a feedback control mechanism mediated by adaptive quantum measurements. Unlike classical thermodynamics, where bath coherence is typically neglected, we demonstrate that continuous weak measurements of the bath, coupled with real-time feedback operations on the system, can transiently violate conventional second law bounds. This enables conversion of bath coherence directly into usable work. This framework establishes a novel protocol for quantum heat engines and refrigerators, pushing the boundaries of thermodynamic limitations and redefining work extraction in the quantum regime.
subject: Kuantum
title: Coherence-Driven Work Extraction in Quantum Heat Engines via Adaptive Quantum Measurement Feedback

text: We present a theoretical and experimental framework for an optomechanical accelerometer utilizing squeezed light to enhance its sensitivity beyond the standard quantum limit, specifically targeting ultralight dark matter candidates. By injecting non-classical states of light into a high-finesse Fabry-Pérot cavity coupled to a mechanical resonator, we achieve a significant reduction in quantum back-action noise, yielding an unprecedented acceleration sensitivity approaching 10^-20 m/s^2/√Hz at mHz frequencies. This exquisite metrological performance opens a new observational window for axion-like particles and other feeble interactions, leveraging quantum advantages in precision measurement science.
subject: Kuantum
title: Squeezed Light Enhanced Optomechanical Accelerometry for Ultralight Dark Matter Detection

text: This research details a comprehensive theoretical and experimental study on the realization and manipulation of non-Abelian anyons in fractional quantum Hall (FQH) systems at filling fraction ν=5/2. We present compelling spectroscopic evidence of charge e/4 quasiparticles and their interferometric braiding statistics, definitively confirming the underlying non-Abelian nature of the ground state. Leveraging advanced nanofabrication techniques, we propose and outline a scalable device architecture for braiding these anyonic excitations to demonstrate topologically protected quantum gates. This work paves the way for a robust platform for fault-tolerant quantum computation, inherently immune to local decoherence sources.
subject: Kuantum
title: Spectroscopic and Interferometric Signatures of Non-Abelian Anyons in Fractional Quantum Hall Systems

text: We propose and experimentally demonstrate an analog quantum simulation platform using ultracold atoms trapped in tunable optical lattices to investigate fundamental aspects of lattice gauge theories, specifically the (1+1)-dimensional quantum electrodynamics (Schwinger model). By mapping bosonic atoms to gauge fields and fermionic atoms to matter fields, we realize the U(1) gauge symmetry and precisely probe phenomena such as charge screening, string breaking, and real-time quench dynamics. This experimental framework offers unprecedented quantum control over Hamiltonian parameters and local observables, providing a versatile tool for exploring non-perturbative regimes of high-energy physics phenomena intractable by classical computation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Analog Quantum Simulation of Lattice Gauge Theories with Ultracold Atoms in Optical Lattices

text: We investigate entanglement harvesting between two Unruh-DeWitt detectors positioned near the event horizon of a Schwarzschild black hole, analyzing implications for the information paradox. Our rigorous analysis reveals that the intense gravitational redshift and extreme spacetime curvature near the horizon significantly modify the correlation structure of the quantum vacuum, leading to a complex interplay between Hawking radiation and detector entanglement. We demonstrate how information, seemingly lost, can be encoded in subtle, non-local entanglement patterns of quantum fields, offering a new, testable perspective on the unitarity of black hole evaporation and the fate of quantum information.
subject: Kuantum
title: Black Hole Information Dynamics: Entanglement Harvesting from Quantum Fields Near Event Horizons

text: This work explores the induction and characterization of non-equilibrium quantum phase transitions (QPTs) in a network of superconducting transmon qubits, where criticality is driven solely by engineered dissipation rather than conservative Hamiltonian parameters. By precisely controlling local loss channels via tailored reservoir engineering, we experimentally demonstrate a dissipative phase transition manifesting in distinct steady-state entanglement patterns and significantly enhanced coherence lengths. This paradigm shifts the focus from unitary evolution to open quantum system dynamics for phase engineering, providing a novel avenue for realizing exotic quantum states and potentially robust quantum memory protocols, leveraging the interplay of coherence and dissipation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Dissipative Quantum Phase Transitions in Engineered Superconducting Circuits for Robust Quantum Memory

text: This research introduces a novel framework for identifying and classifying microtonal pitch class sets (PCS) under various temperamental variations using deep learning. We propose a spectro-temporal feature extraction pipeline leveraging constant-Q transforms and chroma features, specifically adapted for microtonal resolution, which are subsequently processed by a convolutional recurrent neural network (CRNN). The CRNN learns dense embeddings capable of discerning PCS identity despite shifts in tuning systems or referential pitch. We demonstrate the model's efficacy in identifying invariant structural elements within simulated and recorded microtonal repertoires, outperforming traditional interval-vector based methods in contexts of dynamic temperament and non-octave repeating structures. This approach significantly advances automated analytical capabilities for non-12-TET music.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectro-Temporal Feature Embeddings for Microtonal Pitch Class Set Invariance through Deep Learning

text: This study explores the application of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) for automated derivation and hierarchical representation of Schenkerian voice-leading structures in tonal music. We model musical scores as enriched graph structures, where nodes represent individual notes with attributes such as pitch, duration, and metric position, and edges encode various theoretical relationships (e.g., registral proximity, harmonic function, voice-leading paradigms). A multi-layered GNN, employing attention mechanisms and message-passing neural networks, is trained to identify fundamental structures (Ursatz) and their elaborations, iteratively abstracting deeper structural levels. The model learns to discern reductions while preserving contrapuntal integrity and contextual melodic-harmonic implications, offering a robust computational framework for large-scale tonal analysis that emulates expert Schenkerian interpretations.
subject: Müzik
title: Graph Neural Networks for Hierarchical Modeling of Schenkerian Voice-Leading Structures in Tonal Music

text: This research presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for modeling emergent polyphonic rhythmic entrainment and synchronization in complex musical textures. Each agent, representing an independent rhythmic voice, utilizes deep Q-networks (DQNs) to learn optimal phase adjustment strategies based on local rhythmic percepts and global ensemble coherence feedback. The MARL system is trained on diverse polyrhythmic datasets, exhibiting robust adaptation to tempo fluctuations, rubato, and micro-timing deviations characteristic of human performance. We demonstrate that the emergent synchronization strategies converge to perceptually salient beat and meter interpretations, showcasing the potential for decentralized, autonomous systems to accurately replicate and analyze sophisticated human rhythmic interactions in a computationally tractable manner.
subject: Müzik
title: A Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning Framework for Polyphonic Rhythmic Entrainment and Synchronization

text: This study develops an Explainable AI (XAI) methodology for fine-grained semantic timbral segmentation within complex orchestral audio. We employ a deep convolutional recurrent neural network (CRNN) to generate segmentations, predicting instrument families and specific timbral descriptors (e.g., 'bowed strings tremolo,' 'brassy forte'). To enhance interpretability, we integrate saliency mapping and Layer-wise Relevance Propagation (LRP) to attribute semantic predictions directly back to specific spectro-temporal features in the constant-Q transform (CQT) domain. This framework allows for quantitative assessment of which spectral centroids, flux patterns, or transient components drive a particular timbral classification, thereby providing actionable insights into perceptual correlates of instrumental identity and expressive performance, moving beyond black-box classification towards auditable musical understanding.
subject: Müzik
title: Explainable Spectro-Temporal Feature Attributions for Semantic Timbral Segmentation in Orchestral Repertoires

text: We propose a novel approach to generative counterpoint using a conditional variational autoencoder (CVAE) guided by formal species counterpoint rules. The CVAE learns a latent representation of permissible melodic and harmonic progressions by conditioning on a cantus firmus and specified species. Unlike rule-based expert systems, our model captures statistical regularities and subtle nuances of acceptable voice-leading, operating within a probabilistic framework. We introduce a post-hoc constraint satisfaction layer that ensures adherence to strict contrapuntal principles (e.g., avoidance of parallel octaves/fifths, dissonant leaps) by projecting generated outputs onto a valid solution manifold. This system demonstrates robust generation of musically coherent and theoretically sound counterpoint, offering a powerful tool for both pedagogical applications and computational musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: Generative Modeling of Species Counterpoint through Conditional Variational Autoencoders and Grammatical Constraint Satisfaction

text: This research introduces a rigorous methodology for quantifying melodic contour similarity in atonal music leveraging Persistent Homology (PH) and Topological Data Analysis (TDA). Melodic lines are transformed into point clouds in a multi-dimensional feature space, incorporating pitch, rhythm, and registral shifts. PH is then applied to derive barcode representations, encapsulating the birth and death of topological features (e.g., holes, connected components) across varying proximity scales. By comparing the resulting persistence diagrams and bottleneck distances, we provide a robust, scale-invariant measure of contour similarity that circumvents limitations of traditional interval-vector and shape-based approaches. This framework offers novel insights into motivic development, transformational processes, and structural coherence in challenging post-tonal repertoires.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Melodic Contour Similarity in Atonal Repertoires via Persistent Homology and Topological Data Analysis

text: This study investigates the intricate relationship between physical gesture and expressive sonic outcome in live instrumental improvisation using a novel cross-modal deep learning architecture. We capture high-fidelity motion capture data of performers' gestures synchronized with acoustic recordings. A multimodal fusion model, comprising convolutional LSTMs for gesture sequences and constant-Q CNNs for audio features, is trained to predict high-level expressive parameters (e.g., intensity, tension, fluidity) directly from raw gestural data and vice-versa. Through interpretability techniques (e.g., attention maps), we delineate specific gestural kinematics and their corresponding spectro-temporal correlates, revealing the embodied cognition underlying improvisatory musical expression and offering a computational lens into the performer-instrument interface.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Deep Learning for Quantifying Gestural-Sonic Affordances in Live Instrumental Improvisation

text: We present a Bayesian non-parametric approach for inferring underlying metrical and phase structures in highly polyrhythmic and ametrical musical contexts. Employing a hierarchical Dirichlet process hidden Markov model (HDP-HMM), our method robustly segments audio streams into distinct rhythmic layers and simultaneously estimates their respective tempi, phase offsets, and metrical periodicities without requiring prior knowledge of the number of active rhythmic agents or their interactions. The HDP-HMM's non-parametric nature allows for dynamic discovery of latent rhythmic states, adapting to evolving polyrhythmic densities and structural transitions. This probabilistic framework offers a significant advancement in automated beat and meter tracking, particularly for ethnomusicological analysis of non-Western and contemporary experimental repertoires.
subject: Müzik
title: Bayesian Non-Parametric Inference of Latent Meter and Phase in Complex Polyrhythmic Structures

text: This study introduces a novel spectro-temporal descriptor for quantifying harmonic tension and resolution dynamics in post-tonal music, explicitly integrating psychoacoustic principles. Our descriptor, derived from instantaneous spectral centroid deviations, weighted partial energy distributions, and onset synchronicity across critical bands, captures micro-structural dissonance fluctuations beyond traditional interval-class vectors. Leveraging a multi-resolution spectrogram representation, we compute a "dissonance potential" trajectory that correlates strongly with listener perception of harmonic flux and structural arrival points in diverse atonal and serial compositions. This provides a data-driven, perceptually grounded tool for analyzing the nuanced harmonic landscapes of complex contemporary repertoires, offering objective insights into their often-ambiguous tension-resolution profiles.
subject: Müzik
title: A Psychoacoustically Informed Spectro-Temporal Descriptor for Quantifying Harmonic Tension and Resolution in Post-Tonal Music

text: This research pioneers the application of geometric deep learning to the automated analysis of musico-textual declamation in German Lieder. We construct a multi-modal graph representation where nodes capture phonetic, prosodic, melodic, and harmonic features, with edges denoting temporal contiguity and structural dependencies. A graph convolutional network (GCN) coupled with a transformer architecture processes these contextualized embeddings, learning to identify congruence and dissonance between musical and poetic rhetorical devices. This allows for fine-grained assessment of word-level expressive alignment, identifying instances of text-painting, prosodic conflict, or semantic reinforcement. The framework offers a powerful tool for computational musicology, enabling large-scale comparative studies of performance practice and compositional approaches to Lieder interpretation.
subject: Müzik
title: Geometric Deep Learning for Automated Analysis of Musico-Textual Declamation in German Lieder through Multi-Modal Semantic Alignment

text: This work addresses the formidable challenge of inferring sparse conditional independence graphs in high-dimensional settings when latent confounders are present. We propose a novel penalized composite likelihood framework that integrates a latent variable model with a sparse precision matrix estimation regularizer, such as the `l_1` or adaptive lasso penalty. An efficient optimization algorithm is developed, leveraging block coordinate descent and proximal methods for scalable computation. We establish rigorous theoretical guarantees for consistent estimation of both the latent variable parameters and the sparse graph structure under specific sparsity and irrepresentability conditions, even with non-Gaussian error structures. Extensive simulations and an application to gene regulatory networks using genomics data demonstrate superior empirical performance over state-of-the-art methods in terms of graph recovery and parameter estimation accuracy.
subject: İstatistik
title: Penalized Composite Likelihood for High-Dimensional Graphical Model Inference with Latent Variables

text: We extend the synthetic control method to robustly accommodate dynamic treatment effects and unobserved confounding in panel data settings. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian nonparametric approach utilizing a Dirichlet Process mixture model to flexibly cluster donor units, thereby allowing for heterogeneity in counterfactual trends and dynamic treatment effects. Our framework integrates a Gaussian Process prior for the time-varying outcome trajectories, enabling robust uncertainty quantification and the estimation of heterogeneous average treatment effects on the treated (ATT) over time. This methodology effectively addresses scenarios with multiple treated units and variable intervention timings, providing more granular insights than traditional fixed-effect or difference-in-differences estimators. Extensive simulations and an application to macroeconomic policy evaluation demonstrate its superior performance in counterfactual prediction and causal inference.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Nonparametric Synthetic Control for Dynamic Treatment Effects with Unobserved Confounding

text: We introduce a novel variational inference framework for dependent Dirichlet Process mixture models, specifically tailored for scenarios where mixture components exhibit spatio-temporal dependencies modulated by covariates. Traditional DP mixtures assume conditional independence across observations given the component assignments, limiting their applicability in complex correlated data. Our approach employs a structured mean-field approximation to capture these dependencies, effectively integrating a Gaussian Process prior over the DP concentration parameter or mixture weights, which is itself indexed by spatio-temporal covariates. This enables a robust and scalable inference procedure for partitioning data into clusters whose characteristics evolve smoothly across space and time. We derive efficient coordinate-ascent update equations and demonstrate its performance in challenging problems like climate modeling and neuroimaging, offering substantial computational advantages over MCMC while preserving accuracy.
subject: İstatistik
title: Variational Inference for Dependent Dirichlet Process Mixtures with Spatio-Temporal Covariates

text: This paper addresses the formidable challenge of robust dimensionality reduction in high-dimensional data exhibiting latent manifold structures contaminated by gross outliers. We propose Geodesic Robust Principal Component Analysis (GRPCA), which extends standard Robust PCA by incorporating a Riemannian manifold perspective. GRPCA minimizes a novel objective function defined on a Grassmann manifold, penalizing both sparse corruptions and deviations from the intrinsic geometric structure of the inlier data. An alternating minimization algorithm is developed, leveraging Riemannian optimization techniques and proximal operators for the `l_1`-norm penalty. Theoretical guarantees establish robust subspace recovery under specific manifold curvature and outlier sparsity conditions. Empirical results on synthetic and real-world image datasets demonstrate superior performance in outlier detection and denoising compared to existing robust subspace learning methods, especially for data lying near low-dimensional non-linear manifolds.
subject: İstatistik
title: Geodesic Robust Principal Component Analysis for High-Dimensional Data with Manifold Structure

text: This paper develops a sophisticated framework for modeling ultra-high-frequency event streams exhibiting both spatio-temporal clustering and heavy-tailed, non-Gaussian intensity dynamics. We introduce a novel class of Hawkes processes where the excitation functions are driven by latent Lévy flights and the background intensity is modeled via a non-stationary log-Gaussian Cox process. This captures complex self-exciting and mutually-exciting behaviors prevalent in financial markets, seismic activity, and neural spiking data. A hierarchical Bayesian inference scheme employing a particle MCMC approach is proposed to estimate the highly non-linear parameters, including jump characteristics of the Lévy process and the spatio-temporal kernels. We demonstrate its ability to provide superior predictive accuracy and interpretability of underlying causal mechanisms compared to standard Gaussian Hawkes models, particularly in capturing extreme events and burst phenomena.
subject: İstatistik
title: Non-Gaussian Spatio-Temporal Hawkes Processes for Ultra-High-Frequency Event Stream Modeling

text: We develop a novel Bayesian framework for estimating causal effects when both treatment and outcome are functional data, and confounding is addressed through a functional instrumental variable (fIV). Traditional fIV methods often rely on strong linearity assumptions or large sample asymptotics that are ill-suited for complex functional relationships and rigorous uncertainty quantification. Our approach leverages a Hilbertian non-parametric model, representing functions in an orthogonal basis expansion, and specifies flexible priors on functional parameters, including the conditional expectation functions and error distributions. We introduce a Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithm designed to efficiently sample from the posterior distribution of the functional causal effect, rigorously propagating uncertainty from the fIV stage. Simulations and a neuroscience application demonstrate robust performance and credible interval estimation for functional causal effects, even in the presence of complex, non-linear functional relationships.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Functional Causal Inference via Hilbertian Instrumental Variables

text: This work investigates the fundamental limits of adversarial robustness in non-parametric regression under isotonic constraints. We establish minimax optimal rates for estimating the true regression function when faced with an adversary capable of perturbing input data within a specified `L_p` ball, ensuring the estimated function remains monotonically non-decreasing. Our theoretical analysis employs a novel variant of Fano's inequality for structured function spaces and constructs explicit robust estimators based on locally-weighted isotonic regression. We demonstrate that the inherent cost of adversarial robustness manifests as a deterioration in the estimation rate, precisely characterizing this trade-off as a function of the perturbation budget, sample size, and smoothness of the underlying function. These theoretical insights provide critical guidance for designing robust and efficient algorithms in shape-constrained statistical learning.
subject: İstatistik
title: Minimax Optimal Rates for Adversarial Robustness in Non-parametric Regression with Isotonic Constraints

text: We propose a sophisticated joint modeling framework addressing the simultaneous analysis of longitudinal biomarker trajectories, competing risks, and informative censoring, augmented by shared frailty terms. This extends traditional joint models by explicitly incorporating multiple event types and acknowledging the complex dependency structure between observation processes, event times, and censoring mechanisms. A multi-level latent frailty structure, potentially individual- or cluster-specific, is integrated to capture unobserved heterogeneity across all sub-models (longitudinal, competing risk, and censoring). Bayesian inference is employed via a computationally efficient Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithm, facilitating robust parameter estimation and individualized risk predictions for each competing event. The methodology is applied to clinical trial data, demonstrating enhanced predictive accuracy and improved understanding of disease progression compared to separate models or those neglecting competing risks or informative censoring mechanisms.
subject: İstatistik
title: Frailty-Extended Joint Models for Longitudinal Biomarkers and Competing Risks with Informative Censoring

text: This paper develops a semiparametric methodology for estimating convex regression functions exhibiting multiple unknown changepoints under potentially heteroscedastic error structures. Existing methods often assume homoscedasticity or a fixed number of changepoints, limiting their real-world applicability in fields like economics or engineering. Our approach combines a global convex optimization problem for the function shape with a localized kernel-based estimator for the variance function, iteratively refining both the changepoint locations and the convex function approximation. We establish consistency and derive rates of convergence for both the estimated changepoint locations and the convex function under mild conditions on the error distribution. A novel penalization scheme is introduced to automatically detect the number of changepoints. Extensive simulations and an economic application illustrate the robustness and efficiency of the proposed estimator.
subject: İstatistik
title: Semiparametric Estimation of Convex Regression Functions with Multiple Changepoints and Heteroscedastic Errors

text: We propose a novel Bayesian Mendelian Randomization (MR) framework designed to robustly infer causal relationships between exposures and outcomes using multi-omic data, explicitly accounting for pervasive pleiotropy. Traditional MR methods often suffer from substantial bias in the presence of horizontal pleiotropy, where genetic variants affect the outcome through pathways independent of the exposure. Our approach integrates a hierarchical sparse prior on pleiotropic effects and a latent variable model to identify valid instrumental variables across multiple omic layers (e.g., genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics). A Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithm is developed for posterior inference, providing robust estimates of causal effects and their uncertainty, even when the majority of instruments are invalid. Simulations and an application to complex disease etiology demonstrate improved accuracy and pleiotropy detection compared to existing MR methods, enhancing causal discovery in high-dimensional biological systems.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Mendelian Randomization for Pleiotropy-Robust Causal Inference with Multi-Omic Data

text: We present a theoretical framework for realizing and manipulating Majorana zero modes (MZMs) at the ends of one-dimensional semiconductor-superconductor heterostructures, specifically focusing on helical edge states in quantum anomalous Hall insulators proximitized by s-wave superconductors. Our analysis details the parameter regimes supporting topological superconductivity, characterized by a bulk topological invariant Z₂ index and a persistent spectral gap. We provide explicit protocols for non-abelian braiding operations of MZMs, crucial for fault-tolerant quantum computation, by dynamically tuning electrostatic gate potentials to facilitate adiabatic exchanges. Furthermore, we investigate the robustness of these operations against local decoherence and charge fluctuations, quantifying the fidelity of braiding statistics through a detailed numerical simulation incorporating realistic material imperfections and environmental coupling, thereby advancing the prospects for hardware implementation of topological qubits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Superconductivity and Non-Abelian Anyon Braiding in Engineered Hybrid Structures

text: This work explores the emergence of quantum many-body scars (QMBS) within periodically driven (Floquet) disordered systems, challenging the conventional paradigm of many-body localization (MBL) and thermalization. Utilizing exact diagonalization and time-evolving block decimation, we demonstrate the persistent existence of atypical eigenstates exhibiting sub-volume law entanglement scaling and high overlap with specific initial product states, even deep within the MBL phase. These 'Floquet scars' manifest as anomalous dynamical trajectories, precluding complete thermalization despite strong driving, and violate the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis. Our findings illuminate the intricate interplay between disorder, periodic driving, and integrability breaking, providing critical insights into mechanisms that preserve quantum coherence and information in highly chaotic quantum systems, with implications for designing robust quantum memories and probes of non-equilibrium dynamics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Scars and Anomalous Thermalization in Periodically Driven Many-Body Localized Systems

text: We investigate the feasibility of extracting entanglement from the vacuum of a relativistic quantum field by two causally disconnected Unruh-DeWitt detectors in analogue curved spacetimes, specifically within BEC superflow systems exhibiting an artificial event horizon. Our theoretical model quantifies the entanglement harvesting efficiency as a function of detector separation, interaction time, and the background geometry's intrinsic curvature. We demonstrate that even in highly dissipative analogue environments, entanglement can be non-locally retrieved, revealing intricate dependencies on the detector's trajectory and the Unruh temperature. This research extends fundamental concepts of relativistic quantum information to condensed matter systems, offering a testbed for quantum field theory in curved spacetime and probing the interplay of quantum correlations, causality, and gravitational analogues in a controlled laboratory setting.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Harvesting from Relativistic Quantum Fields in Curved Spacetime Analogues

text: We present a comprehensive study of non-Hermitian quantum criticality in one-dimensional lattice models subject to balanced gain and loss, demonstrating novel topological phase transitions absent in their Hermitian counterparts. Our analysis focuses on a generalized Hatano-Nelson model augmented with non-reciprocal hopping and complex potentials, revealing exceptional points and lines in the energy spectrum that dictate the system's topological properties. We introduce a non-Hermitian winding number and a generalized Berry phase to characterize these distinct phases, including skin effect dominated regimes. The critical exponents associated with these phase transitions exhibit non-universal behavior, significantly deviating from established universality classes. This work provides crucial insights into the fundamental role of non-Hermiticity in sculpting quantum phases and lays groundwork for engineering robust quantum devices exploiting open system dynamics and topological protection.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Hermitian Quantum Criticality and Topological Phase Transitions in Open Quantum Systems

text: This paper reports on the experimental implementation and theoretical analysis of optimized dynamical decoupling (DD) sequences for extending coherence times in superconducting transmon qubits subject to strong microwave driving fields. We employ concatenated CPMG and KDD pulse sequences, carefully tailored to mitigate correlated environmental noise and suppress off-resonant driving errors originating from control imperfections. Our results demonstrate a significant extension of both T₂* and T₂ Hahn coherence times by factors exceeding 5x under continuous driving, pushing the boundaries of achievable gate fidelities. A detailed noise spectroscopy analysis reveals that DD sequences effectively convert low-frequency 1/f-type flux noise into higher-frequency components, which are then spectrally filtered. This work offers a robust pathway towards high-fidelity quantum operations in the presence of strong control fields, critical for scaling up quantum processors.
subject: Kuantum
title: Dynamical Decoupling Enhanced Coherence in Superconducting Transmon Qubits Under Strong Drive

text: We theoretically investigate the realization of synthetic non-Abelian gauge fields for ultracold atoms trapped in optical lattices, leading to emergent fractional quantum Hall (FQH) physics. By rapidly shaking the lattice and leveraging specific atom-light coupling schemes, we engineer tunable Chern band structures with non-trivial topological invariants. Our protocol explicitly constructs lattice Hamiltonians that mimic the low-energy physics of Laughlin states at fractional filling factors, including the generation of strongly correlated states with anyonic excitations. We propose spectroscopic probes and interferometric measurements to unequivocally detect the characteristic energy gaps, fractionalized charges, and braiding statistics of these synthetic anyons. This research opens a pathway for simulating exotic strongly correlated phases and topological quantum computation beyond the limitations of solid-state systems, leveraging the pristine control offered by ultracold atomic platforms.
subject: Kuantum
title: Synthetic Gauge Fields and Fractional Quantum Hall Physics in Ultracold Atomic Gases

text: We explore the potential for quantum advantage in complex Bayesian inference tasks using adiabatic quantum computation (AQC). Our methodology maps instances of probabilistic graphical models, specifically Markov Random Fields (MRFs), onto the ground state of a transverse-field Ising Hamiltonian. We demonstrate a novel encoding scheme that preserves the exponential structure of the posterior distribution, allowing for efficient determination of marginal probabilities and maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimates. Numerical simulations and theoretical scaling analyses suggest that AQC can achieve quadratic speedups in sampling complex, high-dimensional probability landscapes compared to classical Monte Carlo methods for certain classes of MRFs, especially those exhibiting strong frustration. This work highlights AQC's promise for accelerating computationally intensive machine learning algorithms and provides a rigorous framework for assessing quantum speedups in real-world data analysis problems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Advantage in Bayesian Inference via Adiabatic Quantum Computation

text: We experimentally demonstrate enhanced force and displacement sensing using an optomechanical system operated in the quantum regime, surpassing the standard quantum limit (SQL) through the injection of sub-Poissonian (squeezed) light. Our experimental setup leverages a high-Q Fabry-Pérot cavity coupled to a micro-mechanical resonator, with a finesse exceeding 10⁵ and an optical spring constant of 10⁶ N/m. By optimally detuning the cavity and utilizing phase-squeezed vacuum, we achieve a quantum noise reduction of 3.2 dB below the shot-noise limit in the measurement output, translating to a 45% improvement in force sensitivity. This work not only validates theoretical predictions for quantum-enhanced metrology but also paves the way for advanced gravitational wave detectors, ultrasensitive accelerometers, and fundamental tests of quantum mechanics at macroscopic scales.
subject: Kuantum
title: Precision Optomechanical Sensing Beyond the Standard Quantum Limit Using Squeezed Light

text: We investigate the role of contextuality as a resource for non-classical correlations in multiqubit spin systems, specifically focusing on its relation to Bell non-locality and entanglement detection. Our theoretical framework extends Kochen-Specker theorems to scenarios involving incompatible measurements on entangled states, quantifying contextuality using generalized negativity and the Klyachko-Can-Binicioğlu-Shumovsky (KCBS) inequality. We experimentally realize a three-qubit system using superconducting transmons, performing sequences of projective measurements in mutually unbiased bases.
