The observed violations of non-contextual inequalities are significantly higher than predicted by classical models, directly demonstrating the context-dependent nature of quantum observables and confirming the unique quantum advantage in information processing protocols rooted in measurement incompatibility, offering a deeper understanding of the foundations of quantum mechanics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Contextuality and Non-Classical Correlations in Multiqubit Spin Systems under Measurement Incompatibility

text: This study explores deconfined quantum criticality (DQC) and emergent symmetries in two-dimensional frustrated quantum antiferromagnets on the kagome lattice. Employing large-scale quantum Monte Carlo simulations with a novel cluster update scheme, we investigate the phase transition between a spontaneously symmetry-broken Néel ordered state and a topologically ordered Z₂ spin liquid phase. Our results demonstrate evidence for a continuous transition mediated by emergent fractionalized excitations (spinons) coupled to an emergent gauge field, challenging the Landau paradigm of symmetry breaking. We characterize the critical point by universal scaling exponents and specific heat anomalies that align with DQC predictions, providing strong numerical support for scenarios beyond Landau-Ginzburg-Wilson theory. This work advances our understanding of exotic quantum phases and phase transitions in strongly correlated electron systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Deconfined Quantum Criticality and Emergent Symmetries in Frustrated Magnets

text: We theoretically investigate the practical realization of fault-tolerant quantum computation by leveraging non-Abelian anyonic statistics within a tunable Kitaev honeycomb lattice system. Our model incorporates dynamic control over local exchange interactions, enabling deterministic braiding operations of Majorana zero modes at engineered topological defects. We rigorously analyze the robust entanglement generation and inherent topological protection offered by these non-local operations against dominant local decoherence channels, quantifying residual error rates based on braiding fidelity, quasiparticle poisoning, and gate operation speeds. Furthermore, we propose a scalable architecture for a topologically protected quantum memory, detailing measurement-based strategies for ancilla-assisted state initialization and readout. This work outlines a concrete pathway toward building inherently robust quantum computers, significantly mitigating the stringent overheads associated with conventional quantum error correction protocols.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Anyonic Statistics for Enhanced Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation via Braiding Operations in a Kitaev Honeycomb Lattice

text: We present a comprehensive theoretical and numerical study of emergent spinon Fermi surfaces and fractionalized excitations in a doped Kagome lattice antiferromagnet, utilizing a U(1) gauge theory approach coupled with variational Monte Carlo simulations. Our findings reveal that carrier doping into the parent spin liquid phase induces a stable metallic state characterized by a robust spinon Fermi surface, whose topology dictates the anomalous transport properties, including a large Fermi surface volume violating Luttinger's theorem. We explicitly demonstrate the fractionalization of electrons into spinons and chargons, elucidating their distinct dynamics and signatures in spectral functions. This work provides crucial insights into the interplay of strong correlations and topology in quantum spin liquids, suggesting new avenues for exploring exotic superconductivity and non-Fermi liquid behavior in highly frustrated materials.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent Spinon Fermi Surfaces and Fractionalized Excitations in a Doped Kagome Lattice Antiferromagnet

text: We report the experimental realization of entanglement generation and subsequent collapse dynamics in a system of two coupled macroscopic superconducting flux qubits, operating in the deep quantum regime at millikelvin temperatures. Utilizing microwave spectroscopy and pulsed control sequences, we demonstrate deterministic entangling operations and characterize the entangled state through state tomography. Our observations reveal a marked transition from coherent oscillations to rapid decoherence, manifesting as a non-unitary collapse of the macroscopic superposition states. We analyze these dynamics within a Lindblad master equation framework, identifying environmental coupling and intrinsic qubit imperfections as dominant contributors. This work offers new experimental insights into the quantum-to-classical transition and the resilience of macroscopic quantum coherence against environmental perturbations, providing a critical testbed for foundational quantum mechanics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Experimental Realization of Entanglement Generation and Collapse Dynamics in Macroscopic Superconducting Flux Qubits at Millikelvin Temperatures

text: We theoretically propose and model a novel quantum metrology scheme for ultrafast time measurements, specifically tailored for picosecond and femtosecond temporal delays, leveraging non-classical light interference in a highly dispersive medium. By employing spectrally entangled photon pairs, we demonstrate that the temporal resolution can surpass the conventional shot-noise limit dictated by classical light and even the Heisenberg limit for a fixed number of photons, achieving a quantum advantage in the estimation of group velocity dispersion. Our analysis, based on quantum Fisher information and Cramér-Rao bounds, reveals the optimal spectral entanglement characteristics required for maximizing precision in the presence of realistic photonic losses and detector inefficiencies. This approach offers a pathway for developing next-generation quantum-enhanced chronoscopy tools with unprecedented temporal precision in applications ranging from biomedical imaging to fundamental physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum-Enhanced Ultrafast Chronoscopy via Non-Classical Light Interference in a Dispersive Medium

text: We develop a functional renormalization group (FRG) approach tailored for non-equilibrium quantum field theories exhibiting strong dissipation, utilizing the Keldysh formalism. Our framework allows for a non-perturbative investigation of dynamic critical phenomena and universal scaling laws in systems driven far from thermal equilibrium, where standard perturbative methods fail. We specifically apply this to a model of quantum critical dissipation, uncovering novel non-equilibrium fixed points distinct from their equilibrium counterparts. The FRG flow equations reveal how strong environmental coupling reshapes the effective potential and propagator dynamics, leading to modified spectral functions and transport coefficients. This work provides a robust theoretical tool for understanding the interplay of strong correlations, non-equilibrium dynamics, and quantum dissipation in diverse systems, from ultracold atoms to early universe cosmology.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Perturbative Renormalization Group Analysis of Non-Equilibrium Quantum Field Theories with Strong Dissipation

text: We propose a novel experimental protocol utilizing next-generation high-precision atom interferometers onboard microgravity platforms to set stringent bounds on parameters associated with quantum spacetime non-commutativity. Specifically, we analyze the sensitivity of interferometric phase shifts to modifications arising from Moyal deformations of canonical commutation relations, which manifest as momentum-dependent corrections to the dispersion relation. Our theoretical analysis predicts a unique signature in the interference pattern, distinct from known systematic effects, allowing for the isolation of non-commutative spacetime contributions. By exploiting the prolonged interrogation times and reduced gravitational gradients in microgravity environments, we project an enhancement in sensitivity capable of probing non-commutativity scales orders of magnitude closer to the Planck length than terrestrial experiments. This work offers a powerful avenue for experimentally testing foundational predictions of quantum gravity phenomenology.
subject: Kuantum
title: Constraining Spacetime Non-Commutativity Parameters via High-Precision Atom Interferometry in Microgravity

text: We present a comprehensive theoretical study investigating the emergence of correlated Chern insulator phases and enhanced superconductivity in magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene (MATBG) subjected to anisotropic strain engineering. Through a combination of Hartree-Fock mean-field theory and exact diagonalization on truncated Hilbert spaces, we reveal that tunable strain fields can selectively modify the bandwidths and effective interactions within the moiré flat bands, inducing transitions between distinct correlated electronic phases. Specifically, we identify novel ferromagnetic Chern insulators with quantized anomalous Hall conductance at fractional fillings and demonstrate a significant enhancement of the superconducting critical temperature in strained MATBG due to optimized flat band dispersion and correlation effects. This work provides a predictive framework for leveraging mechanical strain as a powerful tuning knob to explore and stabilize exotic quantum phases in twisted van der Waals heterostructures.
subject: Kuantum
title: Correlated Chern Insulator Phases and Flat Band Superconductivity in Magic-Angle Twisted Bilayer Graphene under Strain Engineering

text: We investigate the thermodynamic performance of autonomous quantum thermal machines operating in the ultrastrong coupling regime, focusing on the role of quantum coherence in enhancing their efficiency and power output. Our model, based on a three-level quantum system strongly coupled to hot and cold baths, demonstrates that persistent coherences, explicitly maintained between energy eigenstates of the machine's working medium, can lead to a significant thermodynamic advantage. We show that this coherence-driven enhancement allows the machine to operate beyond conventional efficiency limits derived under assumptions of weak coupling and classical-like heat exchange. Furthermore, we identify optimal conditions for maximizing power output and efficiency concurrently, highlighting the potential for designing highly efficient quantum engines and refrigerators by exploiting non-equilibrium quantum correlations. This research opens new avenues for quantum technologies leveraging coherence for energy conversion.
subject: Kuantum
title: Thermodynamic Advantage of Quantum Coherence in Autonomous Quantum Thermal Machines Operating in the Ultrastrong Coupling Regime

text: We theoretically propose and analyze a hybrid quantum system comprising a superconducting transmon qubit strongly coupled to a collective magnon mode in a yttrium iron garnet (YIG) sphere, mediated by a microwave cavity field. Our scheme outlines protocols for deterministic entanglement transfer between the superconducting qubit and the magnonic ensemble, leveraging resonant and dispersive interactions. We demonstrate how this robust coupling facilitates the generation of non-classical states of magnons, including squeezed and Schrödinger cat-like states, protected by the collective nature of the magnon mode against local noise. Furthermore, we investigate the fidelity and coherence of these engineered states under realistic experimental conditions, considering magnon linewidths and qubit decoherence. This work highlights the potential of qubit-magnon hybrid systems for quantum information processing and robust long-distance quantum communication via magnon-based quantum links.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Transfer and Robust Quantum State Engineering in a Superconducting Qubit-Magnon Coupled Hybrid System

text: We report an experimental verification of quantum contextuality using a heralded photonic qutrit system, probing fundamental deviations from non-contextual hidden variable theories beyond the scope of the traditional Kochen-Specker theorem. By preparing and measuring a set of generalized non-commuting observables in a sequential, measurement-dependent manner, we demonstrate a violation of a novel contextuality inequality specifically tailored for higher-dimensional systems. Our approach leverages high-fidelity preparation and projection of photonic qutrit states, enabling precise control over measurement contexts. The observed violation provides strong evidence against models where measurement outcomes pre-exist independently of the measurement context, even for non-degenerate measurements. This work pushes the boundaries of experimental tests of quantum foundations, offering crucial insights into the nature of quantum reality and the limitations of classical descriptions.
subject: Kuantum
title: Experimental Verification of Quantum Contextuality Beyond Kochen-Specker Theorem in a Photonic qutrit System

text: Adaptive introgression, the beneficial transfer of genetic material between distinct evolutionary lineages, plays a pivotal role in facilitating rapid adaptation to novel environments. This study elucidates the genomic architecture of high-altitude adaptation in Andean deer mice (*Peromyscus maniculatus balleyi*) through comparative genomics and population genetic analyses. We demonstrate that introgressed haplotypes, putatively derived from an ancestral lowland *Peromyscus* species, are significantly enriched for genes involved in oxygen transport, metabolism, and angiogenesis. Selective sweep signatures co-localize with these introgressed regions, suggesting strong positive selection post-introgression. Furthermore, transcriptomic profiling reveals significant differential expression of these introgressed alleles under hypoxic conditions. Our findings provide compelling evidence for adaptive introgression as a primary mechanism driving physiological acclimatization to extreme hypoxic stress, highlighting the crucial contribution of ancient admixture to contemporary adaptive potential in vertebrates, potentially informing conservation strategies for climate-vulnerable populations.
subject: Evrim
title: Adaptive Introgression and Its Genomic Footprints in High-Altitude Vertebrates

text: Environmental unpredictability often selects for robust phenotypic plasticity. This research investigates the role of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance (TEI) in mediating adaptive plasticity in *Daphnia pulex* in response to predator kairomones. Using a controlled multigenerational experimental design, we expose mothers and their offspring to simulated predation risk and assess morphological anti-predator defenses (e.g., helmet size, tail spine length). We find that offspring from predator-exposed mothers exhibit significantly enhanced plastic responses, even in the absence of direct predator cues, compared to control lineages. Furthermore, bisulfite sequencing and ChIP-seq analyses reveal distinct DNA methylation and histone modification patterns associated with developmental plasticity genes that persist across generations. These epialleles correlate with altered gene expression profiles, suggesting a molecular basis for TEI. Our results underscore epigenetic inheritance as a crucial mechanism enabling rapid, non-genetic adaptation to fluctuating environments, integrating within a broader eco-evolutionary developmental framework.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance of Stress-Induced Phenotypic Plasticity in *Daphnia pulex*

text: Host-parasitoid interactions represent classic systems for studying co-evolutionary arms races. This study employs a multi-omics approach to dissect the molecular dynamics underlying the escalating conflict between *Cotesia congregata* (Braconidae) and its host *Manduca sexta* (Sphingidae). Using comparative genomics, we identified rapidly evolving gene families in the wasp venom gland transcriptome, including those encoding immune suppressors and teratocytes, and their corresponding immune receptor and detoxification pathways in the host hemolymph proteome. Our data reveal distinct patterns of positive selection in genes associated with immune evasion (e.g., viral ankyrin repeats, serpin inhibitors) in the parasitoid, and complementary shifts in host cellular immunity and humoral encapsulation responses (e.g., prophenoloxidase cascade, antimicrobial peptides). Phylogenetic analyses indicate reciprocal adaptive divergence, with evidence of convergent evolution in certain host defense mechanisms. This comprehensive genomic perspective highlights the intricate and multilayered molecular interplay driving ongoing species-specific co-evolutionary trajectories.
subject: Evrim
title: Multilayered Co-evolutionary Arms Race Between Parasitic Wasps and Their Lepidopteran Hosts: A Genomewide Perspective

text: Allopolyploidy, a prominent speciation mechanism in plants, significantly influences angiosperm evolutionary trajectories. This paleogenomic study reconstructs ancient allopolyploidization events across five disparate angiosperm clades using low-coverage whole-genome sequencing of herbarium specimens and extant relatives. By resolving phylogenetic discordance patterns and quantifying coalescent times, we identify at least 12 distinct, large-scale allopolyploid formations within the last 50 million years. Bayesian phylogenetic analyses demonstrate that clades experiencing allopolyploidy exhibit significantly higher rates of net diversification (speciation minus extinction) compared to sister lineages with diploid ancestry. Furthermore, analyses of retained duplicated genes reveal enrichment for transcription factors and genes involved in secondary metabolism, potentially facilitating niche expansion and adaptive radiation post-polyploidization. Our findings provide robust paleogenomic evidence for the recurrent nature of allopolyploidy as a macroevolutionary engine, fundamentally reshaping angiosperm phylogeny and contributing substantially to their ecological dominance.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Reconstruction of Allopolyploid Speciation Events and Their Impact on Angiosperm Diversification Rates

text: Intralocus sexual conflict arises when an allele has antagonistic fitness effects between sexes. In polyandrous insects like *Drosophila melanogaster*, such conflicts are predicted to be particularly intense. This study investigates the contribution of allelic dosage and sex-specific gene regulation to the maintenance and resolution of intralocus sexual conflict for a quantitative fitness-related trait: competitive ability. Using a panel of recombinant inbred lines, we mapped sex-antagonistic quantitative trait loci (QTLs) and performed allele-specific expression analysis. Our results reveal several genomic regions where the same allele confers high fitness in one sex but reduced fitness in the other. Furthermore, we demonstrate that sex-biased gene expression and compensatory mutations in *cis*-regulatory elements mitigate these conflicts by decoupling the expression of antagonistic alleles in a sex-specific manner. These findings highlight the dynamic genomic landscape underlying sexual antagonism and the sophisticated molecular mechanisms evolving to ameliorate its pervasive fitness costs.
subject: Evrim
title: Intralocus Sexual Conflict Mediated by Allelic Dosage and Its Resolution in Polyandrous Insect Systems

text: Eusociality, characterized by reproductive altruism and complex division of labor, represents a major evolutionary transition. This study integrates ecological field observations with genomic and transcriptomic analyses to unravel the eco-evolutionary feedbacks that govern the emergence and stability of eusociality in multiple Hymenopteran lineages. We demonstrate how fluctuating resource availability and increased predation pressure act as selective sieves, favoring group defense and cooperative foraging, thereby increasing the fitness benefits of kin-selected altruism. Comparative transcriptomics between solitary, primitively social, and eusocial species reveals conserved gene modules associated with caste differentiation and reproductive skew, whose expression is modulated by ecological cues. Furthermore, phylogenetic analyses reveal repeated evolutionary transitions to eusociality correlated with specific ecological niches and genetic architectures conducive to inclusive fitness benefits. Our findings underscore a dynamic interplay between ecological context, genetic predisposition, and developmental plasticity in shaping the complex trajectory of eusocial evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Eco-evolutionary Feedbacks Shaping the Emergence and Maintenance of Eusociality in Hymenoptera

text: The remarkable diversity of vertebrate appendages, from fins to wings, often masks deep developmental homologies. This research explores the recurrent co-option of ancient gene regulatory networks (GRNs) as a fundamental mechanism for morphological innovation. Through comparative genomics, single-cell transcriptomics, and CRISPR/Cas9 mutagenesis across zebrafish, chicken, and mouse limb development, we demonstrate that a core set of *Hox* gene regulatory elements and associated transcription factor binding sites are repeatedly activated in distinct spatial and temporal contexts to pattern diverse appendage structures. Specifically, distal limb enhancers, originally critical for fin ray development, are independently re-deployed and modified to specify digits in tetrapods and contribute to wing morphology in birds. These findings illustrate that evolutionary novelty often arises not from *de novo* gene creation, but from the exaptation and rewiring of existing, deeply conserved developmental modules, providing a mechanistic basis for phenotypic convergence.
subject: Evrim
title: Recurrent Co-option of Ancient Regulatory Modules Underpinning Novel Morphological Innovations in Vertebrate Appendages

text: The holobiont, comprising a host and its associated microbiota, acts as a fundamental unit of selection. This study investigates the extent to which the intergenerational transmission of beneficial gut microbiome functionality contributes to host phenotypic evolution in the beetle *Tribolium castaneum*. We established experimental evolution lines under varying nutritional stressors, tracking host fitness components and microbiome composition across 20 generations. Our findings reveal a significant heritable component to microbiome community structure and function, transferred via maternal provisioning. Progeny inheriting beneficial microbial consortia exhibit enhanced growth rates and stress tolerance compared to those with disrupted microbiomes, even when host genetic background is controlled. Metagenomic sequencing identifies specific microbial taxa and their metabolic pathways responsible for these fitness advantages. These results provide compelling evidence that microbiome inheritance serves as a crucial, non-genetic pathway for rapid adaptation, accelerating host evolutionary responses through a holobiont-centric lens.
subject: Evrim
title: Holobiont Adaptation: Intergenerational Transmission of Microbiome Functionality and Host Phenotypic Evolution

text: The "tragedy of the commons" predicts overexploitation in unconstrained resource-consumer systems. This theoretical study employs an adaptive dynamics framework to explore how metapopulation structure and dispersal shape the evolution of prudent resource exploitation strategies. We model a consumer population distributed across patches linked by dispersal, with local populations exhibiting density-dependent resource consumption. Our analyses reveal that limited dispersal and high patch extinction rates can favor the evolution of lower, more sustainable exploitation rates, particularly when consumer fitness is strongly coupled to resource persistence. Under such conditions, "selfish" overexploitation within a patch leads to local extinction, removing maladaptive strategies from the metapopulation and selecting for more prudent phenotypes in surviving patches. Conversely, high dispersal rates can homogenize strategies, potentially leading to global overexploitation. This work highlights the critical role of spatial ecological dynamics in mediating the evolution of sustainable strategies, offering insights for managing exploited natural systems.
subject: Evrim
title: Metapopulation Dynamics and the Evolution of Prudent Exploitation in Resource-Consumer Interactions

text: Somatic evolution within tumors drives progression, metastasis, and therapeutic resistance, yet its precise population genetic dynamics remain underexplored. This study applies multi-regional sequencing and phylogenetic reconstruction to dissect clonal interference and epistatic interactions during tumor evolution in glioblastoma and colorectal cancer. We demonstrate that within spatially distinct tumor regions, multiple driver mutations frequently arise in parallel and engage in complex clonal interference, where fitter clones impede the expansion of other beneficial mutations. Furthermore, analysis of variant allele frequencies and phylogenetic branch lengths reveals significant epistatic interactions, where the fitness effect of one mutation is contingent upon the presence of others, particularly influencing resistance pathways. This intricate interplay between clonal competition and epistatic landscapes generates substantial intra-tumor heterogeneity, posing significant challenges for therapeutic intervention. Our findings underscore the necessity of considering sophisticated evolutionary dynamics when designing strategies to combat cancer progression and drug resistance.
subject: Evrim
title: Clonal Interference and Epistatic Interactions Governing Somatic Evolution in Multi-Regional Tumors

text: This research introduces a novel framework for generating robust counterfactual explanations in high-dimensional feature spaces by integrating differentiable structural causal models (DSCMs) with deep generative architectures. Traditional post-hoc Explainable AI (XAI) methods often lack causal soundness, leading to potentially misleading explanations when considering actionable interventions. Our approach leverages a learnable causal graph, optimized concurrently with a deep representation network, to synthesize counterfactual instances that adhere to identifiable causal mechanisms. This ensures practical realizability and policy relevance for AI-driven decisions. We demonstrate superior performance in generating minimally-pertinent, causally-valid counterfactuals on complex tabular and image datasets, quantified by intervention-aware fidelity metrics and robustness against adversarial perturbations. The DSCM framework offers a principled pathway towards interpretable and trustworthy AI systems capable of principled decision-making under uncertainty, addressing critical limitations in current XAI methodologies.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Explanations via Differentiable Structural Causal Models for Robust Decision-Making

text: The continual pre-training of Large Language Models (LLMs) on evolving data streams frequently encounters severe emergent catastrophic forgetting, where performance on previously learned tasks drastically degrades upon adaptation to new data. This paper proposes a novel architectural and algorithmic paradigm, termed `Elastic Synaptic Consolidation` (ESC), to mitigate this phenomenon. ESC integrates a dynamic parameter masking mechanism with a gradient-aware regularization strategy, selectively hardening critical synaptic weights identified through a neural tangent kernel approximation. Our empirical evaluation, conducted across diverse downstream tasks and varying data distributions, demonstrates that ESC significantly preserves historical knowledge while efficiently integrating new information, outperforming contemporary rehearsal-based and regularization-based continual learning approaches. The proposed method facilitates robust and adaptive LLM deployment in dynamic real-world environments, addressing a critical bottleneck in perpetual learning systems.
subject: AI
title: Mitigating Emergent Catastrophic Forgetting in Continual Pre-training of Large Language Models

text: Effective exploration in complex multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) environments remains a significant challenge, particularly when sparse rewards and high-dimensional state-action spaces necessitate sophisticated coordination strategies. This work introduces an innovative decentralized policy optimization framework that leverages epistemic uncertainty quantification to guide agents' exploration trajectories. Each agent independently maintains a Bayesian neural network for its Q-function, and the resultant uncertainty estimates are incorporated into a novel intrinsic reward function that encourages visiting under-explored regions and resolving inter-agent observation ambiguities. We demonstrate that this uncertainty-guided exploration, coupled with a novel information-sharing protocol based on mutual information maximization, significantly accelerates learning and achieves superior asymptotic performance compared to state-of-the-art MARL algorithms across various cooperative and competitive partially-observable benchmarks, including multi-robot navigation and strategic games.
subject: AI
title: Multi-Agent Deep Exploration with Epistemic Uncertainty-Guided Decentralized Policy Optimization

text: While score-based generative models (SBGMs) have achieved unprecedented fidelity in image synthesis, their robustness to adversarial perturbations during generation remains largely unexplored. This paper investigates the inherent vulnerability of SBGMs and proposes a novel regularization scheme to imbue adversarial robustness without compromising generative quality. We introduce an adversarial noise injection mechanism during the reverse diffusion process, coupled with a customized score matching loss that penalizes deviations in the generated data manifold under worst-case perturbations. Our framework, `Robust Score-Based Diffusion` (RSBD), demonstrably synthesizes high-fidelity images that are significantly more resilient to adversarial attacks compared to standard SBGMs, as evidenced by improved classifier accuracy on generated samples under various threat models. This work bridges the gap between generative realism and model security, critical for deployment in sensitive domains.
subject: AI
title: Score-Based Generative Modeling for High-Fidelity Synthesis under Adversarial Robustness Constraints

text: Forecasting dynamic events in complex, evolving systems presents a formidable challenge for conventional graph neural networks (GNNs) due to their limitations in handling temporal dependencies and heterogeneous interactions. This paper proposes a novel `Temporal Heterogeneous Relational Attention Network` (THRAN) designed for dynamic event forecasting on evolving knowledge graphs. THRAN integrates a multi-head self-attention mechanism, specialized for different relation types and temporal granularities, to capture fine-grained dependencies within and across entities over time. A learnable temporal embedding module captures long-range temporal patterns, enabling robust prediction of future events, such as link formation or attribute changes. Extensive experiments on large-scale, real-world temporal graphs demonstrate THRAN's superior performance in link prediction, node classification, and event forecasting tasks, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art spatio-temporal GNNs and deep sequence models.
subject: AI
title: Temporal Graph Neural Networks with Heterogeneous Relational Attention for Dynamic Event Forecasting

text: Achieving both adversarial robustness and fairness in machine learning models is a critical yet often conflicting objective. This work introduces a novel multi-objective optimization framework for concurrently enhancing model robustness against adversarial attacks while mitigating discriminatory outcomes across sensitive subgroups. Our approach formulates a composite loss function that simultaneously minimizes adversarial risk through robust optimization techniques and enforces various group fairness notions (e.g., equalized odds, demographic parity) via a differentiable fairness constraint. We propose an alternating optimization strategy that efficiently navigates the trade-off landscape between these competing objectives, leveraging projected gradient descent. Extensive empirical evaluations on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our `Fair-Robust AI` (FRAI) framework significantly improves both metrics compared to models optimized for either objective in isolation, providing a principled pathway towards the development of truly trustworthy and equitable AI systems.
subject: AI
title: Fairness-Aware Adversarial Robustness: A Multi-Objective Optimization Framework for Equitable AI Systems

text: The synergy between neural networks and symbolic reasoning systems holds immense promise for developing explainable and robust AI agents, yet seamless integration remains challenging. This paper introduces `Neuro-Symbolic Logic Networks` (NSLN), a novel architecture that grounds first-order logic predicates in latent neural representations and facilitates differentiable logical inference. NSLN employs a tensor-based representation for logical variables and relations, allowing for backpropagation through a specialized logical operator module that computes satisfiability and entailment. This enables end-to-end learning from both raw data and explicit knowledge bases. We demonstrate NSLN's capability to learn complex rules, perform multi-hop reasoning, and generate human-interpretable logical explanations for its decisions, outperforming purely neural or symbolic approaches on tasks requiring compositional generalization and knowledge transfer, thus advancing the paradigm of reasoning-aware deep learning.
subject: AI
title: Integrating First-Order Logic and Differentiable Reasoning for Explainable Neuro-Symbolic Agents

text: Extreme few-shot classification, where models must generalize from only one or a handful of examples per novel class, presents a significant challenge for traditional deep learning paradigms. This work proposes a novel `Gradient-Based Meta-Learner for Few-Shot Adaptation` (GBLFA) that focuses on learning a task-agnostic feature adaptation mechanism rather than merely learning an initialization. GBLFA trains a meta-network to predict optimal per-layer adaptation coefficients that re-calibrate features for novel tasks using only a few support examples. This is achieved through an outer-loop optimization that minimizes generalization error over diverse meta-training tasks, enabling rapid and efficient adaptation in the inner loop. Empirical results across challenging meta-learning benchmarks demonstrate that GBLFA significantly outperforms state-of-the-art meta-learning algorithms, particularly in the 1-shot setting, by learning more transferable and discriminative representations without requiring extensive task-specific fine-tuning.
subject: AI
title: Gradient-Based Meta-Learners for Extreme Few-Shot Classification via Task-Agnostic Feature Adaption

text: The application of quantum machine learning (QML) algorithms on Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) computers is hindered by noise sensitivity and limited qubit coherence. This paper presents a novel approach utilizing the Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) to compute quantum graph kernels, offering a potential path to robust QML on current hardware. We encode graph structures into quantum states via a parameterized quantum circuit (PQC) and then employ VQE to determine the ground state energy, which is subsequently used as a kernel value. This method implicitly captures non-linear relationships intractable for classical methods. Our theoretical analysis and numerical simulations demonstrate that this `VQE-GraphKernel` approach yields superior classification performance on synthetic and real-world graph datasets compared to classical graph kernels, while exhibiting increased resilience to hardware noise compared to direct quantum state overlap measurements.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Eigensolver for Graph Kernels: Enhancing Machine Learning on Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum Computers

text: Deploying deep learning models on resource-constrained edge devices demands ultra-low power consumption, a challenge conventional Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) often fail to meet. This paper introduces a novel `Event-Driven Plasticity` (EDP) learning rule for Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) that leverages the temporal sparsity of spikes for highly efficient, asynchronous computation. EDP integrates biologically plausible Spike-Timing Dependent Plasticity (STDP) with a differentiable loss function, enabling end-to-end training of deep SNN architectures on complex vision and audio tasks without conversion from ANNs. Our hardware-aware simulations demonstrate that SNNs trained with EDP achieve comparable accuracy to their ANN counterparts while exhibiting orders of magnitude lower energy consumption and latency on neuromorphic hardware platforms. This work represents a significant step towards enabling always-on, real-time AI at the very edge, crucial for pervasive intelligent systems.
subject: AI
title: Spiking Neural Networks with Event-Driven Plasticity for Ultra-Low Power Edge Intelligence

text: Elucidating the navigability of fitness landscapes is paramount for understanding evolutionary trajectories. Here, we quantitatively assess the topological permeability of high-dimensional adaptive landscapes, parametrically varying the genetic architecture of pleiotropic and antagonistic epistasis in silico. Utilizing a large ensemble of randomly generated genotype-phenotype maps for complex traits, we characterize the distribution of local fitness peaks, saddle points, and mutational pathways. Our findings demonstrate that the degree of landscape ruggedness and the prevalence of fitness plateaus are critically contingent upon the order and sign of epistatic interactions, rather than merely their aggregate strength. Specifically, higher-order diminishing-returns epistasis substantially increases the average shortest path length to global optima, impeding evolutionary search, whereas sign epistasis dramatically fragments the landscape into distinct basins of attraction. This work provides a rigorous framework for predicting the evolutionary accessibility of phenotypic optima given explicit genetic architectures.
subject: Evrim
title: Topological Permeability of Multilocus Adaptive Landscapes Under Varying Epistatic Architectures

text: Developmental system drift (DSD), characterized by divergent genetic mechanisms underlying conserved phenotypes, poses significant implications for evolutionary potential. This study investigates the interplay between DSD and the release of cryptic genetic variation (CGV), particularly in the context of phenotypic plasticity and reaction norm evolution. We hypothesize that DSD, by restructuring gene regulatory networks, can alter buffering capacities, thereby unmasking previously phenotypically inert genetic variation under novel environmental perturbations. Using a comparative genomics approach across sister taxa exhibiting conserved thermal reaction norms, we identify distinct cis-regulatory elements and trans-acting factors that, despite producing similar phenotypes under standard conditions, reveal latent variation upon heat stress. Our results suggest DSD acts as an evolutionary capacitor, accumulating CGV that can fuel rapid adaptation when canalization breaks down, facilitating punctuated shifts in plastic responses.
subject: Evrim
title: Developmental System Drift and the Unmasking of Cryptic Genetic Variation in Reaction Norm Evolution

text: The genetic architecture underlying reproductive isolation (RI) remains a central enigma in speciation research, particularly in the context of sympatric diversification. This study employs population genomic sequencing of ecologically divergent sympatric morphs within a rapidly radiating cichlid assemblage. We aim to delineate the genomic landscapes of divergence, identifying genomic islands of high differentiation juxtaposed with regions of ongoing gene flow. Our analyses reveal a mosaic pattern of genomic differentiation, with significant enrichments of RI-associated loci within regions encoding visual perception, trophic morphology, and mate recognition genes. Crucially, we identify a significant excess of FST outliers localized to pericentromeric regions and inversions, suggesting reduced recombination facilitates the accumulation of divergence and the maintenance of polymorphic incompatibilities. These findings provide empirical insights into the genomic architecture of incipient speciation driven by ecological divergence despite pervasive secondary contact.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Incipient Speciation: Dissecting the Architecture of Reproductive Isolation in Sympatric Radiations

text: Coevolutionary arms races, exemplified by host-parasite interactions, often manifest as Red Queen dynamics, driving continuous reciprocal adaptation. This investigation probes the genomic mechanisms underlying asymmetric coevolutionary trajectories in a natural host-parasite system. We utilize time-series population genomics to track allele frequency dynamics across multiple generations, focusing on genes implicated in immunity (hosts) and virulence/evasion (parasites). Our findings reveal that while hosts exhibit diffuse selective sweeps across large genomic regions containing innate immune receptors, parasites display more localized, rapid adaptations in specific effector genes. Furthermore, we detect evidence of soft sweeps and selection on standing genetic variation in host populations, contrasting with hard sweeps in parasite populations. This asymmetry suggests differential constraints and demographic processes impacting the evolutionary rates and genetic targets in each lineage, providing a nuanced understanding of perpetual coevolutionary change.
subject: Evrim
title: Asymmetric Coevolutionary Trajectories: Unpacking the Genomic Underpinnings of Host-Parasite Red Queen Dynamics

text: Transgenerational epigenetic inheritance (TEI) challenges traditional Mendelian paradigms, offering a mechanism for the non-genetic transmission of environmentally induced traits. This study quantitatively evaluates the fidelity and persistence of TEI in conferring adaptive plasticity across successive generations in response to variable environmental stressors. We subjected parental generations to controlled nutrient deprivation and monitored offspring performance across F1 to F3 generations, integrating whole-genome bisulfite sequencing and small RNA profiling. Our results demonstrate context-dependent TEI: adaptive phenotypes, mediated by specific differential methylation regions (DMRs) and non-coding RNA profiles, are robustly transmitted only when subsequent generations encounter similar stress, diminishing rapidly otherwise. Crucially, specific DMRs associated with stress-response genes exhibit dose-dependent inheritance, suggesting a quantitative epigenetic memory. These findings delineate the environmental conditions under which TEI can act as a bona fide mechanism for rapid, but transient, evolutionary adaptation.
subject: Evrim
title: Context-Dependent Inheritance of Acquired Traits: A Quantitative Assessment of Transgenerational Epigenetic Memory in Adaptive Responses

text: The degree to which phylogenetic relatedness predicts phenotypic similarity—the phylogenetic signal—is a fundamental metric in macroevolution. This study examines the decay of phylogenetic signal for complex morphological and behavioral traits across diverse vertebrate clades, employing novel analytical phylogenetic comparative methods. We hypothesize that highly integrated traits, subject to strong developmental and functional constraints, will exhibit a persistent phylogenetic signal, whereas more modular or plastic traits will show accelerated decay over increasing phylogenetic distance. Our multi-model inference approaches, incorporating OU models and non-linear transformations, reveal a trait-specific spectrum of signal decay. For instance, skeletal architecture maintains signal across geological timescales, while behavioral repertoires demonstrate rapid signal erosion, indicative of frequent evolutionary shifts or convergent evolution. These findings underscore the differential impacts of evolutionary constraints and adaptive plasticity on the predictability of trait evolution across deep time.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenetic Signal Decay and the Evolutionary Dynamics of Complex Traits Across Deep Time

text: The host-associated microbiome is increasingly recognized as a potent driver of host evolution, mediated by reciprocal eco-evolutionary feedback loops and niche construction. This research empirically investigates how alterations in gut microbial community structure, induced by varying dietary regimes, causally influence host metabolic phenotype and subsequent selective pressures. Using gnotobiotic murine models colonized with simplified and complex microbiomes, we demonstrate that microbial metabolites directly modulate host gene expression profiles, particularly those involved in lipid metabolism and immune response. Furthermore, hosts colonized by specific microbial consortia exhibit enhanced fitness under specific dietary challenges, driven by direct microbial contributions to nutrient assimilation and detoxification. Our findings underscore that the holobiont, rather than the host genome alone, represents the fundamental unit of selection, with microbiome-mediated niche construction significantly expanding the host's adaptive potential and accelerating eco-evolutionary divergence.
subject: Evrim
title: Eco-Evolutionary Feedback Loops: Microbiome-Mediated Niche Construction and Host Adaptive Potential

text: Polygenic adaptation, where complex traits evolve through small allele frequency shifts at numerous loci, represents a pervasive yet challenging mode of evolution to detect. This study develops and applies a novel spatial genomic analysis framework to infer signatures of polygenic adaptation from standing genetic variation in spatially structured populations. We leverage environmental gradients and corresponding phenotypic clines in a high-altitude plant species, integrating whole-genome resequencing data with detailed environmental measurements. Our method explicitly accounts for demographic history and gene flow, disentangling adaptation from drift and spatial autocorrelation. We identify hundreds of candidate polygenic loci exhibiting parallel allele frequency shifts concordant with environmental clines, predominantly involving genes related to stress tolerance and growth phenology. This approach provides robust statistical inference for detecting subtle signals of polygenic adaptation, even in the presence of strong population structure and recurrent gene flow.
subject: Evrim
title: Inferring Polygenic Adaptation from Standing Genetic Variation in Spatially Structured Populations

text: Eusociality, a pinnacle of biological complexity, fundamentally challenges individual-level selection theory, prompting explanations rooted in kin selection and multilevel selection. This theoretical and empirical investigation explores the dynamic interplay between these frameworks in the evolution and maintenance of highly integrated insect societies. We model the conditions under which high relatedness (favoring kin selection) or emergent group-level traits (favoring multilevel selection) predominate in driving the evolution of altruistic phenotypes, such as sterile worker castes. Using a comparative phylogenetic approach across Hymenoptera, we find evidence that while ancestral transitions to eusociality often correlate with high relatedness coefficients, the subsequent maintenance and diversification of complex societies show stronger evidence for selection acting on group-level traits, such as collective intelligence and division of labor. This synthesis suggests a developmental trajectory of social evolution where initial kin-selected benefits pave the way for emergent group-level adaptations.
subject: Evrim
title: The Dynamic Interplay of Kin Selection and Multilevel Selection in the Emergence and Maintenance of Eusociality

text: Compensatory evolution, the restoration of fitness following deleterious mutations by subsequent suppressor mutations, is crucial for understanding protein functional robustness and evolutionary innovation. This study investigates the prevalence and architectural determinants of compensatory evolution within protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks. We hypothesize that modularity within PPI networks facilitates compensatory evolution by localizing the effects of mutations and their suppressors, thereby reducing pleiotropic costs. Using a combination of directed evolution experiments on yeast signaling pathways and computational simulations based on empirical PPI topologies, we demonstrate that mutations within highly connected hub proteins exhibit a reduced capacity for immediate compensation compared to those in peripheral nodes. Conversely, compensatory mutations occurring within network modules are more likely to restore fitness without propagating deleterious effects across the entire system. These findings reveal how network architecture imposes both constraints and opportunities for adaptive trajectories.
subject: Evrim
title: Compensatory Evolution and the Modularity of Protein Interaction Networks: Implications for Evolutionary Innovation and Constraint

text: This research investigates the genesis of continuous spacetime metrics from fundamentally discrete pre-geometric structures, specifically within the framework of Causal Set Theory. We introduce a novel approach to define entanglement entropy across causal horizons without relying on a pre-existing manifold structure, leveraging the intrinsic non-local correlations inherent in the discrete dynamics. Our analysis posits that the informational content encoded in the causal relations among discrete events provides the requisite degrees of freedom for the emergence of both a local Lorentz-invariant geometry and a background-independent quantum field theory. We present numerical simulations demonstrating how coarse-graining of microcausal elements can lead to a continuum approximation, elucidating the transition from a non-geometric phase to a manifold-like structure, with implications for resolving the UV completeness of quantum gravity and the information paradox in black hole thermodynamics.
subject: Fizik
title: Causal Entanglement in Emergent Spacetime Geometries from a Discrete Pre-Geometry

text: We present a theoretical and numerical investigation into the definitive signatures of non-Abelian anyonic excitations in experimentally accessible fractional quantum Hall (FQH) bilayer systems. Focusing on the ν=1/2 total filling factor, we analyze the interplay between interlayer tunneling and Coulomb interactions, predicting a transition from Abelian to non-Abelian topological orders, specifically the ℤₚ parafermionic states. Our methodology involves the exact diagonalization of small systems and density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) simulations on infinite cylinders, meticulously calculating the topological entanglement entropy (TEE) and characterizing the ground state degeneracy. We demonstrate that the non-Abelian TEE provides a robust, universal identifier for these exotic phases, distinguishable from conventional Abelian orders. These findings offer critical guidance for future experimental probing of non-Abelian statistics, vital for fault-tolerant topological quantum computation.
subject: Fizik
title: Signature of Non-Abelian Anyons through Topological Entanglement Entropy in Quantum Hall Bilayers

text: We present a comprehensive statistical analysis constraining the parameter space of various dynamical dark energy models, extending beyond the standard ΛCDM paradigm. Our study integrates high-fidelity data from the latest Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) anisotropies (Planck 2018), Type Ia Supernovae (Pantheon+ sample), Baryon Acoustic Oscillations (BAO) across multiple redshifts, and weak gravitational lensing surveys (DES Y3). We explore both quintessence-like and modified gravity theories, employing Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) techniques to simultaneously fit cosmological parameters and dark energy equation of state evolution. Our results reveal tighter constraints on the time-evolution of the dark energy parameter w(z), indicating a slight preference for deviations from w=-1 at high redshifts, though remaining consistent with the ΛCDM model within 2σ confidence intervals. This multi-probe approach significantly reduces degeneracies, offering crucial insights into the nature of cosmic acceleration and the enduring Hubble tension.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraining Dynamical Dark Energy Models with Joint High-Precision Cosmological Probes

text: This work details an experimental and theoretical framework for generating and manipulating hyperentangled high-dimensional quantum states, leveraging degenerate spontaneous parametric down-conversion (SPDC) in nonlinear crystals. We utilize the interplay of orbital angular momentum (OAM) and polarization degrees of freedom to create entangled qudits, pushing beyond conventional qubit limitations. Our scheme incorporates novel spatial light modulator configurations to sculpt complex OAM superpositions, allowing for the generation of entangled states with Schmidt ranks exceeding two. We quantify the entanglement properties through generalized Bell inequalities and quantum state tomography protocols, demonstrating unprecedented fidelity for high-dimensional states. These hyperentangled states exhibit enhanced robustness against noise and offer a significantly increased information capacity, paving the way for advancements in quantum metrology, secure quantum communication, and the exploration of fundamental non-classical correlations in complex Hilbert spaces.
subject: Fizik
title: Engineering Hyperentangled High-Dimensional Quantum States via Spontaneous Parametric Down-Conversion for Enhanced Metrology

text: We present a comprehensive re-evaluation of the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM) parameter space, focusing on electroweakino production at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and its implications for dark matter phenomenology. Our analysis integrates recent LHC Run 3 data, emphasizing searches for chargino-neutralino production decaying via W/Z bosons and Higgs states, alongside updated constraints from direct detection experiments (e.g., LZ, PICO) and indirect detection (e.g., Fermi-LAT). We employ a global fitting approach utilizing high-dimensional sampling techniques to explore regions of compressed spectra and Higgsino-dominated dark matter, often evading previous limits. We identify novel allowed regions where the lightest neutralino satisfies relic density requirements and remains consistent with current experimental bounds, offering critical targets for future detector upgrades and next-generation dark matter searches. This work provides crucial guidance for extending the Standard Model through supersymmetry.
subject: Fizik
title: Revisiting Electroweakino Searches and Dark Matter Constraints in the MSSM with LHC Run 3 and Future Direct Detection Data

text: This study investigates the universal characteristics of work and heat distributions in actively driven open quantum systems far from thermal equilibrium. We extend the Jarzynski and Crooks fluctuation theorems to scenarios involving strong system-bath coupling and non-Markovian dynamics, utilizing a generalized quantum master equation approach. Our theoretical framework rigorously defines quantum work and heat observables for time-dependent Hamiltonian driving, accounting for energy exchanges with the environment. Numerical simulations on a driven spin-boson model reveal novel departures from classical fluctuation relations at short timescales, attributed to quantum coherence and entanglement with the bath. We demonstrate the emergence of universal scaling laws for the cumulants of work and heat distributions, even in the non-adiabatic regime. These findings provide fundamental insights into the thermodynamics of quantum processes and inform the design of efficient quantum heat engines and refrigerators.
subject: Fizik
title: Universal Fluctuations of Work and Heat in Driven Open Quantum Systems Far from Equilibrium

text: This research presents a rigorous framework for probing deviations from General Relativity using multi-messenger observations of binary neutron star (BNS) mergers, exemplified by GW170817 and its electromagnetic counterparts. We analyze parameterized post-Newtonian (PPN) modified gravity theories and scalar-tensor theories, focusing on observable effects on the gravitational waveform morphology during inspiral, merger, and ringdown phases, as well as the propagation of gravitational waves. Our methodology employs Bayesian inference to constrain fundamental parameters of alternative gravity models, such as the speed of gravitational waves and modifications to tidal deformability. By simultaneously fitting gravitational wave strain data and electromagnetic emission characteristics, we establish significantly tighter bounds on these parameters than achievable with gravitational waves alone. These precision tests offer unprecedented sensitivity to potential non-GR phenomena in the strong-field, highly dynamical regime, providing critical insights into the fundamental nature of spacetime and gravity.
subject: Fizik
title: Precision Tests of Gravitational-Wave Modified Gravity Theories with Multi-Messenger Binary Neutron Star Observations

text: We report on advanced spectroscopic investigations unveiling the interplay between quantum criticality and unconventional superconductivity in select Ce-based heavy-fermion intermetallic compounds. Utilizing high-resolution angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) combined with inelastic neutron scattering (INS), we probe the momentum-dependent electronic structure and spin fluctuation spectra across the quantum critical point (QCP). Our data reveal the emergence of a non-Fermi liquid state characterized by anomalous quasiparticle renormalization and enhanced antiferromagnetic fluctuations, which crucially underpin the d-wave pairing symmetry observed in the superconducting phase. The evolution of the superconducting gap structure, resolved through temperature-dependent ARPES measurements, strongly correlates with the proximity to the QCP, suggesting a magnetic fluctuation-mediated pairing mechanism. These findings provide compelling experimental evidence for a direct link between quantum critical phenomena and the genesis of unconventional superconductivity in strongly correlated electron systems, informing theories of high-temperature superconductivity.
subject: Fizik
title: Spectroscopic Signatures of Unconventional Superconductivity Driven by Quantum Criticality in Ce-based Heavy Fermions

text: This work presents a stringent experimental test of state-independent quantum contextuality using high-dimensional photonic qutrits encoded in orbital angular momentum (OAM) states. We construct an optical setup capable of generating and manipulating entangled qutrits, allowing for the measurement of non-commuting observables crucial for probing contextuality. Our experiment employs a generalized set of Mermin-type inequalities, derived from the Kochen-Specker theorem, which provides a robust method to distinguish quantum mechanics from non-contextual hidden variable theories. By measuring expectation values of products of observables over multiple settings, we achieve a violation of the non-contextual bound by more than 10 standard deviations, independent of the initial quantum state. These findings definitively rule out a broad class of non-contextual theories for systems beyond qubits, underscoring the fundamentally contextual nature of quantum reality and its implications for quantum information processing and foundations.
subject: Fizik
title: Experimental Verification of State-Independent Contextuality in High-Dimensional Photonic Qutrits via Generalized Mermin Inequalities

text: We present comprehensive multi-scale gyrokinetic simulations investigating the complex interplay between turbulent transport and zonal flow dynamics within the H-mode pedestal region of magnetically confined fusion plasmas. Our simulations, performed using the GENE code, resolve kinetic ion and electron dynamics across a broad range of spatio-temporal scales, from ion-temperature gradient (ITG) and electron-temperature gradient (ETG) driven turbulence to the meso-scale structures of zonal flows and geodesic acoustic modes. We demonstrate that the turbulent suppression mechanism in the pedestal is critically dependent on the shearing rate of the self-generated zonal flows, modulated by neoclassical effects and electromagnetic coupling. The results provide quantitative predictions for anomalous energy and particle transport coefficients, highlighting their strong correlation with the radial electric field structure. These insights are crucial for optimizing pedestal stability and confinement in next-generation tokamak reactors like ITER.
subject: Fizik
title: Multi-Scale Gyrokinetic Simulations of Zonal Flow Dynamics and Anomalous Transport in Tokamak Pedestals

text: Our investigation unveils a novel role for N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modification on histone H3 at lysine 36 (H3K36m6A) as a critical epitranscriptomic mark directly influencing chromatin accessibility and transcriptional regulation. Utilizing high-resolution mass spectrometry and ChIP-seq coupled with m6A-specific antibodies, we demonstrate H3K36m6A enrichment at active gene promoters and enhancer regions, often co-localizing with H3K4me3 and H3K27ac. Perturbation of the methyltransferase complex responsible for this mark, through CRISPR-mediated depletion, significantly alters nucleosome positioning and abrogates enhancer-promoter looping, leading to profound dysregulation of gene expression profiles crucial for cellular differentiation. Furthermore, we identify a hitherto uncharacterized "reader" protein, an m6A-binding protein (m6ABP) variant, that specifically recognizes H3K36m6A, mediating recruitment of chromatin remodeling complexes. This research posits H3K36m6A as a fundamental epigenetic determinant, expanding the epitranscriptomic lexicon and offering new avenues for therapeutic intervention in chromatin-associated pathologies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Deciphering the Role of N6-Methyladenosine on Histone H3 Lysine 36 in Chromatin Architecture and Transcriptional Output

text: Precise control over gene expression necessitates the ability to modulate chromatin states with spatiotemporal fidelity. Here, we present an advanced optogenetic CRISPR-dCas9 system, termed Opto-epiCRISPR, engineered for light-inducible, localized epigenetic perturbation. This construct fuses a photosensitive dimerizing module to dCas9 and various chromatin-modifying effector domains (e.g., p300 HAT, TET1 catalytic domain). By delivering guide RNAs targeting putative cryptic enhancer regions and exposing cells to specific wavelengths of light, we achieve rapid, reversible induction of active histone marks and DNA demethylation at designated genomic loci. Quantitative single-cell transcriptomics and ATAC-seq reveal de novo enhancer activation driving robust and cell-type-specific transcriptional programs, distinct from constitutively active elements. This innovative platform allows for dissecting the kinetic contributions of individual epigenetic modifications to gene activation, offering unprecedented resolution to study enhancer function and providing a powerful tool for synthetic biology and therapeutic gene regulation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatiotemporal Chromatin Perturbation using Optogenetically-Controlled CRISPR-dCas9 Systems for De Novo Enhancer Activation

text: Cellular heterogeneity and complex intercellular communication within the tumor microenvironment (TME) are pivotal determinants of disease progression and therapeutic resistance. Our study employs advanced high-resolution spatial transcriptomics, integrating Visium sequencing with single-cell RNA sequencing data, to generate a comprehensive molecular map of metastatic melanoma lesions. We utilize a novel computational framework for ligand-receptor pair deconvolution, identifying spatially restricted communication hubs and their signaling trajectories across distinct cellular niches—immune infiltrates, stromal cells, and malignant clones. This approach reveals previously uncharacterized paracrine and juxtacrine interactions, highlighting critical immunosuppressive circuits and pro-tumorigenic feedback loops. Validation via multiplexed immunofluorescence confirms the spatial co-localization of predicted interacting partners and their downstream effectors. These findings provide unparalleled insights into the dynamic interplay governing TME immunosuppression and neoangiogenesis, offering refined targets for precision oncology and combinatorial immunotherapies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Unraveling Intercellular Communication Networks in Tumor Microenvironments via High-Resolution Spatial Transcriptomics and Ligand-Receptor Deconvolution

text: The epitranscriptomic landscape is increasingly recognized for its role in modulating gene expression, with N1-methyladenosine (m1A) emerging as a crucial modification impacting RNA structure and function. Our research elucidates the dynamic regulation and functional significance of m1A across tRNA and mRNA species in cellular and in vivo models of Alzheimer's disease. Using m1A-specific immunocapturing followed by high-throughput sequencing (m1A-seq), we identify dysregulated m1A profiles in both mitochondrial and cytosolic tRNAs, correlating with impaired translational kinetics and codon-biased protein synthesis. Furthermore, we uncover nascent m1A modifications on specific mRNA transcripts encoding key proteostasis factors, suggesting a direct link to protein aggregation pathologies. CRISPR-Cas9-mediated knockdown of specific m1A methyltransferases exacerbates proteotoxic stress and neuronal dysfunction. This work establishes m1A as a critical regulator of translational fidelity and proteostasis, implicating epitranscriptomic dysregulation as a novel etiological factor and potential therapeutic target in neurodegeneration.
subject: Biyoloji
title: N1-Methyladenosine Dynamics in tRNA and mRNA Remodels Translational Fidelity and Proteostasis in Neurodegenerative Disease Models

text: Mitochondrial dysfunction, particularly impaired quality control, is a hallmark of neurodegenerative disorders like Parkinson's disease (PD). This study dissects the intricate interplay between mitochondrial fusion/fission dynamics and mitophagy, focusing on the reciprocal regulatory mechanisms involving the deubiquitinase USP30 and the kinase PINK1. Employing super-resolution microscopy, live-cell imaging of mitochondrial networks, and quantitative proteomics in PD patient-derived iPSCs and Drosophila models, we reveal that USP30 overexpression significantly inhibits PINK1/Parkin-mediated mitophagy by deubiquitinating outer mitochondrial membrane proteins, thereby stabilizing damaged mitochondria. Conversely, USP30 suppression enhances mitochondrial fragmentation and facilitates mitophagy. Importantly, we uncover a novel regulatory axis where PINK1 phosphorylation directly impacts USP30 stability and its catalytic activity. These findings establish a critical molecular switch governing mitochondrial health, highlighting USP30 as a compelling therapeutic target to restore mitochondrial quality control and mitigate neurodegeneration in PD.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Reciprocal Regulation of Mitochondrial Dynamics and Mitophagy by the Deubiquitinase USP30 and the Kinase PINK1 in Parkinsonian Pathogenesis

text: The rational design of custom proteins with precise functionalities remains a frontier in synthetic biology and biomedicine. We report the de novo computational design, experimental validation, and functional characterization of highly stable, self-assembling protein nanocages capable of encapsulating diverse molecular cargos. Employing Rosetta-based algorithms and deep learning approaches, we engineered tetrahedral and octahedral protein assemblies with tailored internal volumes and surface chemistries for cell-specific targeting. These nanocages demonstrate exceptional thermal and proteolytic stability, quantitative self-assembly in vitro and in vivo, and efficient internalization by target cells via receptor-mediated endocytosis. Furthermore, by incorporating catalytic domains, we demonstrate their utility in sequestering and degrading intracellular toxins, achieving localized enzymatic bioremediation. This work establishes a versatile platform for precision macromolecular engineering, opening new avenues for drug delivery, vaccine development, and synthetic organelle design, addressing critical challenges in therapeutic and environmental biotechnology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: De Novo Design of Self-Assembling Protein Nanocages for Enhanced Intracellular Cargo Delivery and Targeted Enzymatic Bioremediation

text: Acquired resistance to targeted therapies in glioblastoma (GBM) represents a major clinical challenge, often underpinned by complex molecular adaptations. This study employs an integrative multi-omics approach, combining whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS), ATAC-seq, and RNA-seq across patient-derived GBM organoids and xenograft models treated with EGFR inhibitors. Our analysis identifies a convergent remodeling of the epigenomic and transcriptomic landscapes in resistant cells, characterized by widespread shifts in DNA methylation patterns and chromatin accessibility at regulatory elements. We uncover a novel network of super-enhancers and distal regulatory elements that drive the re-activation of alternative survival pathways, including the MET signaling axis, independent of EGFR. Furthermore, single-cell multi-omics validation delineates the clonal evolution of resistance, pinpointing specific cell subpopulations that pre-exist and expand under therapeutic pressure. These findings provide a high-resolution molecular atlas of GBM resistance, offering actionable insights for developing combinatorial strategies to circumvent therapeutic failure.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrative Multi-Omics Reveals Convergent Epigenomic and Transcriptomic Landscapes Driving Acquired Resistance to Targeted Therapy in Glioblastoma

text: Biomolecular condensates formed by liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) are increasingly recognized as crucial organizers of cellular biochemistry, especially in post-transcriptional gene regulation. Our study delves into the fundamental mechanisms governing the formation of RNA granules, specifically stress granules and processing bodies, mediated by heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoproteins (hnRNPs). Using a combination of single-molecule fluorescence spectroscopy, reconstituted in vitro LLPS assays, and advanced CRISPR-engineered cellular models, we identify specific low-complexity domains (LCDs) within hnRNPs as key drivers of phase separation, dictating condensate size, dynamics, and macromolecular crowding. We demonstrate that phosphorylation and arginine methylation of these LCDs act as molecular switches, dynamically regulating LLPS and modulating the sequestration of specific mRNA targets. This work provides quantitative mechanistic insights into how hnRNP architecture and post-translational modifications govern RNA granule assembly, offering a refined understanding of their contribution to translational control and stress response pathways.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mechanistic Dissection of hnRNP-Mediated RNA Granule Formation via Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation: Role in Post-Transcriptional Gene Regulation

text: G-quadruplexes (G4s), non-canonical secondary structures formed in guanine-rich DNA and RNA sequences, represent promising therapeutic targets, particularly in oncogenic contexts. Our study investigates the impact of synthetic G4-stabilizing ligands on MYC oncogene expression and genomic integrity in colorectal cancer (CRC). Through a synergistic approach combining high-resolution G4-ChIP-seq, quantitative RNA-seq, and single-molecule footprinting, we demonstrate that small-molecule G4 ligands preferentially bind to and stabilize G4 structures within the MYC promoter and 5'-untranslated region (5'-UTR). This stabilization impedes RNA polymerase II progression and ribosome scanning, respectively, resulting in profound transcriptional repression and translational attenuation of MYC. Crucially, prolonged G4 stabilization also induces DNA replication stress, telomere attrition, and increased DNA damage response activation, culminating in genomic instability and selective induction of apoptosis in CRC cells in vitro and in vivo. This research establishes G4 stabilization as a potent dual-action strategy for anti-cancer therapy, simultaneously targeting oncogene expression and genomic maintenance pathways.
subject: Biyoloji
title: G-quadruplex Stabilization as a Therapeutic Modality: Disruption of MYC Oncogene Transcription and Induction of Genomic Instability in Colorectal Cancer

text: Synthetic biology aims to program living cells with novel functionalities, yet designing robust gene circuits capable of adaptive responses to fluctuating environments remains challenging. This study details the engineering and characterization of modular synthetic gene circuits incorporating diverse negative and positive feedback loops to confer dynamic control over target gene expression. Utilizing CRISPR-Cas9-based transcriptional activators and repressors, coupled with ligand-inducible protein degradation systems, we constructed circuits exhibiting tunable oscillatory behavior, bistability, and proportional-integral-derivative (PID) control. We demonstrate that these circuits can sense and respond to varying concentrations of multiple extracellular metabolites, maintaining precise homeostatic protein levels or executing complex differentiation programs. Quantitative modeling and single-cell time-lapse microscopy validate the robust performance and reduced cell-to-cell variability of these feedback-controlled systems. This work represents a significant advance in designing resilient biological modules, paving the way for smart cell therapies, bioproduction, and advanced biomaterial synthesis in unpredictable physiological niches.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Engineering Robust Synthetic Gene Circuits with Feedback Control for Adaptive Cellular Response to Dynamic Environmental Stimuli

text: This study investigates the role of epigenetic modifications in facilitating rapid adaptive divergence by scrutinizing natural populations of Mimulus guttatus spanning steep environmental clines. We integrate whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS), RNA-seq, and quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping to delineate the interplay between DNA methylation variation, gene expression plasticity, and fitness-related traits under contrasting edaphic conditions. Our analyses reveal widespread differential methylation regions (DMRs) highly correlated with local adaptation genes, often decoupled from underlying single nucleotide polymorphisms. Furthermore, we identify specific transposable elements as methylation hubs potentially mediating rapid regulatory recalibration. These findings suggest that epigenomic flexibility provides a critical substrate for environmentally-driven ecotypic differentiation, potentially buffering genetic load during early stages of speciation, and highlights the non-Mendelian dimensions of evolutionary potential.
subject: Evrim
title: Epigenetic Recalibration and the Genomic Architecture of Ecotypic Divergence in Mimulus guttatus

text: Host-parasite coevolution is a primary driver of immune gene diversity. This research elucidates the long-term dynamics of Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) Class II allelic variation in a 20-year longitudinal study of a wild Apodemus sylvaticus population exposed to fluctuating pathogen pressures. Utilizing next-generation sequencing, we track allelic frequencies and functional divergence, revealing strong evidence for negative frequency-dependent selection favoring rare alleles and episodic selection sweeps linked to pathogen emergence. Importantly, we uncover an asymmetry where host MHC evolution lags behind parasite antigenic shifts, leading to transient periods of increased susceptibility but also promoting novel allelic architectures. This dynamic process underscores the inherent Red Queen arms race, demonstrating how evolutionary disequilibrium can perpetually fuel immunogenetic polymorphism and potentially drive cryptic population bottlenecks.
subject: Evrim
title: Asymmetric Coevolutionary Dynamics Drive MHC Class II Allelic Turnover in a Wild Vertebrate Population

text: Phenotypic plasticity is increasingly recognized as a precursor to evolutionary innovation. This investigation examines how environmentally-induced developmental plasticity can canalize into novel adaptive traits, using Drosophila melanogaster populations subjected to distinct thermal regimes over multiple generations. We combine quantitative genetics of reaction norms with systems-level analyses of gene regulatory networks (GRNs) underpinning wing morphology and metabolic efficiency. Our findings demonstrate that sustained environmental press engenders shifts in GRN topological robustness, leading to the emergence of novel attractors that stabilize alternative developmental trajectories. Furthermore, critical 'hub genes' within these GRNs exhibit increased modularity and altered pleiotropic effects, suggesting a mechanism by which initial plastic responses can be genetically assimilated, thereby providing a substrate for macroevolutionary jumps without requiring de novo genetic mutations.
subject: Evrim
title: Integrating Reaction Norms and Gene Regulatory Networks: A Mechanistic Basis for Phenotypic Novelty via Developmental Plasticity

text: The aftermath of the Cretaceous-Paleogene (K-Pg) mass extinction event represents a pivotal period for understanding macroevolutionary diversification. This study reconstructs the temporal and phylogenetic patterns of mammalian radiation following the K-Pg boundary, employing a comprehensive dataset integrating fossil occurrences, molecular phylogenies, and paleoclimatic data. We utilize birth-death models incorporating environmental covariates to assess rates of speciation and extinction. Our results indicate a phased radiation characterized by an initial rapid burst of diversification into vacant ecological niches, followed by density-dependent slowdowns and punctuated extinction events.
