text: Abductive reasoning, inferring the most plausible explanation for observed phenomena, is a cornerstone of human intelligence but remains challenging for purely connectionist models due to their opacity and lack of logical grounding. This paper introduces Neuro-SymILP, a novel neuro-symbolic framework that integrates deep learning's robust pattern recognition with the expressivity and explainability of Inductive Logic Programming (ILP). Neuro-SymILP employs a differentiable inference engine that learns first-order logical rules from raw perceptual data, allowing for the generation of hypotheses consistent with a given knowledge base and observed evidence. By iteratively refining symbolic rules through a latent space optimization process, our model achieves human-interpretable abductive explanations. Empirical results on complex diagnostic and scientific discovery tasks demonstrate Neuro-SymILP's superior performance in both accuracy and the generation of structured, verifiable explanations, bridging the gap towards transparent and logically sound AI systems.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic Inductive Logic Programming for Explainable Abductive Reasoning

text: Training Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) in a federated learning paradigm presents unique challenges concerning data privacy and model convergence, especially when client data cannot be directly shared. This paper proposes PrivGAN-MPC, a novel framework for Federated GANs that ensures provable differential privacy guarantees by integrating Secure Multi-Party Computation (SMC) protocols. Unlike perturbation-based differential privacy, PrivGAN-MPC leverages cryptographic primitives to enable private aggregation of gradients and parameter updates across distributed clients without revealing individual data or model weights to a central server or other clients. We introduce a secure averaging protocol for generator and discriminator updates, minimizing privacy-utility trade-offs inherent in federated settings. Extensive experiments demonstrate that PrivGAN-MPC achieves competitive generative quality on diverse datasets while maintaining strong privacy guarantees, making it suitable for sensitive applications such as medical imaging and financial data synthesis where data residency and confidentiality are paramount.
subject: AI
title: Federated Generative Adversarial Networks with Provable Privacy Guarantees via Secure Multi-Party Computation

text: The quadratic computational complexity of the self-attention mechanism in standard Transformer architectures fundamentally limits their application to very long sequences, despite their exceptional performance in capturing global dependencies. This paper introduces QuATT (Quantum-Inspired ATTention), a novel Transformer architecture that leverages principles from quantum mechanics to enhance long-range dependency modeling with sub-quadratic complexity. QuATT replaces traditional dot-product attention with a quantum-inspired associative memory mechanism, employing complex-valued representations and unitary operators to encode and process information. This framework intrinsically supports non-local interactions and global context aggregation while maintaining a linear or near-linear complexity with respect to sequence length. Empirical evaluations across diverse natural language processing and genomic sequence analysis tasks demonstrate QuATT's superior performance in capturing distant correlations, substantially outperforming existing efficient Transformer variants on extremely long sequences, paving the way for more scalable and contextually rich sequential data processing.
subject: AI
title: Quantum-Inspired Transformer Architectures for Long-Range Dependency Modeling in Sequential Data

text: Understanding the decision-making rationale of complex Reinforcement Learning (RL) agents, particularly in high-stakes domains, is paramount for trustworthiness and debugging. This work introduces a novel framework, CausalCFE-RL, for generating actionable counterfactual explanations of RL policies by inverting a learned latent causal model of the environment. Unlike perturbation-based methods, CausalCFE-RL identifies minimal, semantically meaningful interventions on the latent causal variables that would alter an agent's chosen action to a desired outcome. We train a variational autoencoder-style model to learn a disentangled latent space representing the causal factors of the environment, then employ an optimization procedure to find counterfactuals by perturbing these latent states. Empirical evaluations on diverse continuous control and discrete environments demonstrate CausalCFE-RL's ability to produce interpretable, sparse, and valid counterfactuals that provide direct insights into the agent's policy, facilitating more transparent and reliable RL systems.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Explanations for Reinforcement Learning Policies via Latent Causal Model Inversion

text: Robust and generalizable medical image segmentation often suffers from data scarcity, annotation burden, and sensitivity to subtle domain shifts. This paper proposes DiSeM-Seg, a novel self-supervised learning framework for disentangling morphological (e.g., shape, texture) and semantic (e.g., tissue type, pathology) features from unannotated medical images. DiSeM-Seg employs a dual-encoder architecture coupled with a contrastive learning objective that explicitly encourages separation of these feature sets into distinct latent spaces. A novel adversarial regularization further ensures that the morphological encoder is invariant to semantic content, and vice-versa, fostering robust representations. Subsequent fine-tuning with limited labeled data demonstrates significantly improved segmentation accuracy and out-of-distribution generalization compared to conventional supervised and other self-supervised pre-training methods. DiSeM-Seg offers a promising avenue for reducing dependence on extensive expert annotations and enhancing the adaptability of AI models in diverse clinical settings.
subject: AI
title: Self-Supervised Disentanglement of Morphological and Semantic Features in Medical Image Segmentation

text: Solving ill-posed inverse problems, such as tomographic reconstruction or image super-resolution, often requires computationally intensive iterative solvers or necessitates explicit regularization. This work explores the efficacy of Deep Equilibrium Models (DEQs) for learning implicit neural representations (INRs) that intrinsically encode solutions to inverse problems. By framing the solution as the fixed point of a neural network, DEQs offer a memory-efficient alternative to conventional deep unrolling methods, as gradients can be computed without storing intermediate activations. We propose a novel DEQ-INR architecture where the fixed-point iteration directly parameterizes the implicit mapping from coordinates to signal values, allowing for arbitrary resolution outputs and seamless integration of physical forward models. Empirical results on diverse inverse problems demonstrate that DEQ-INRs achieve competitive reconstruction quality with significantly reduced memory footprint and improved convergence properties compared to state-of-the-art unrolling and implicit representation techniques, pushing the boundaries of efficient scientific machine learning.
subject: AI
title: Deep Equilibrium Models for Implicit Neural Representation Learning in Inverse Problems

text: Predicting complex spatio-temporal events in systems characterized by evolving relational structures, such as social networks or brain connectomes, poses significant challenges for conventional Euclidean deep learning architectures. We introduce a novel Geometric Spatio-Temporal Graph Convolutional Network (GST-GCN) designed to capture intricate dependencies on dynamic non-Euclidean manifolds. Our framework integrates adaptive graph attention mechanisms with recurrent neural components to model both instantaneous topological changes and long-range temporal correlations. By employing a spectral graph attention layer coupled with a temporal point process encoder, GST-GCN effectively propagates information across varying graph structures while retaining event-specific contextual embeddings. Empirical evaluations on high-dimensional, irregularly sampled datasets demonstrate superior predictive performance and robustness to network perturbations compared to state-of-the-art spatio-temporal forecasting methods, offering a powerful paradigm for dynamic system analysis.
subject: AI
title: Geometric Deep Learning for Spatio-Temporal Event Prediction on Dynamic Non-Euclidean Graphs

text: The burgeoning scale of foundation models necessitates efficient knowledge transfer across modalities, particularly for zero-shot generalization to unseen tasks. Current approaches often struggle with semantic drift and representation collapse in multimodal latent spaces. This paper proposes a novel Contrastive Latent Space Alignment (CLSA) framework that leverages self-supervised contrastive learning to robustly align semantically consistent regions across diverse modalities (e.g., vision, language, audio). CLSA employs a multi-view contrastive loss combined with an adversarial disentanglement objective to ensure modal-invariant and informative feature learning. Our method mitigates the alignment ambiguities inherent in high-dimensional multimodal data by optimizing for maximal mutual information between corresponding latent projections. Experiments validate CLSA's efficacy in facilitating superior zero-shot classification and retrieval performance on complex cross-modal benchmarks, significantly outperforming existing cross-modal embedding techniques and enhancing downstream task generalization.
subject: AI
title: Contrastive Latent Space Alignment for Zero-Shot Cross-Modal Knowledge Transfer in Foundation Models

text: Federated Learning (FL) offers decentralized model training but remains vulnerable to Byzantine adversaries manipulating local updates, compromising global model integrity and convergence. Existing robust aggregation schemes often assume bounded update norms or require robust statistics that incur significant communication overhead. We propose BR-SGD-AC, a Byzantine-Resilient Stochastic Gradient Descent with Adaptive Clipping mechanism that provides provable robustness guarantees against malicious participants without relying on strong assumptions about attack intensity or data distribution. Our method dynamically adjusts client update thresholds based on historical model divergence and leverages a secure multi-party computation protocol for robust mean estimation. Theoretical analysis demonstrates convergence to a neighborhood of the optimal solution under Byzantine attacks up to a certain fraction of malicious clients. Empirical results show superior performance against various sophisticated Byzantine attacks, significantly enhancing model accuracy and stability in realistic FL deployments.
subject: AI
title: Provably Robust Federated Learning via Byzantine-Resilient Stochastic Gradient Descent with Adaptive Clipping

text: Interpreting the decision-making rationale of complex reinforcement learning (RL) agents remains a grand challenge, particularly in high-dimensional state spaces where policy behavior is opaque. We introduce Causal Disentanglement for RL (CD-RL), a novel framework that learns causally interpretable latent representations to explain policy actions. CD-RL employs an auxiliary self-supervised task to disentangle actionable from non-actionable state factors within the latent space, guided by a causal intervention mechanism. By explicitly modeling intervention effects on states and rewards, our method reconstructs counterfactual trajectories to attribute policy decisions to specific causal variables. This framework enables the generation of human-understandable explanations for agent behavior, offering insights into reward attribution and strategic reasoning. Empirical validation across diverse Mujoco environments demonstrates that CD-RL produces superior disentangled representations and provides more faithful and coherent explanations compared to post-hoc saliency methods.
subject: AI
title: Causal Disentanglement of Latent Representations for Interpretable Reinforcement Learning Policies

text: Generative models for de novo molecular design are crucial for accelerating drug discovery, yet existing methods often struggle with enforcing chemical validity and exploring complex conformational spaces while maintaining desired properties. We propose Equivariant Diffusion for Molecules (EDM), a novel class of score-based generative models that explicitly incorporates SE(3)-equivariance into the diffusion process. By leveraging invariant graph neural networks and a specialized denoiser network, EDM ensures that generated molecular structures are robust to rigid transformations, inherently preserving geometric and chemical symmetries. Our method generates 3D molecular coordinates and atom types simultaneously, conditioned on target properties, through a reverse diffusion trajectory guided by a learned score function. Extensive experiments demonstrate EDM's superior performance in generating chemically valid, diverse, and novel molecules with high property predictive accuracy, outperforming existing generative models in terms of both structural quality and therapeutic relevance.
subject: AI
title: Diffusion Models with Equivariant Symmetries for De Novo Molecular Design

text: Machine learning models often suffer significant performance degradation when deployed in environments with distributional shifts, specifically covariate shift, where input distributions differ between training and testing. Standard adversarial training primarily focuses on improving robustness to small, imperceptible perturbations, which does not directly address large-scale domain shifts. We propose a novel framework, DRO-AdvTrain, that integrates Distributionally Robust Optimization (DRO) with adversarial training to enhance generalization under severe covariate shifts. DRO-AdvTrain minimizes the worst-case empirical risk over an uncertainty set of plausible test distributions, constructed via optimal transport distances. By introducing an adversarial distribution generator that perturbs the input distribution within a defined Wasserstein ball, our method jointly optimizes for robustness against both adversarial examples and broader distributional variations. Extensive evaluations across several benchmark datasets confirm DRO-AdvTrain's superior generalization capabilities and robustness in challenging covariate shift scenarios compared to conventional adversarial and robust optimization techniques.
subject: AI
title: Adversarial Training with Distributionally Robust Optimization for Enhanced Generalization under Covariate Shift

text: Tackling complex, sparse-reward, goal-conditioned tasks in high-dimensional environments remains a key challenge for reinforcement learning, often hindered by inefficient exploration and brittle credit assignment. We introduce a novel Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning (HRL) framework augmented with Metareasoning (Meta-HRL) for adaptive goal discovery and policy refinement. Meta-HRL incorporates a meta-policy that dynamically selects optimal low-level sub-goals and adjusts exploration strategies based on epistemic uncertainty estimations within the intrinsic reward function. This meta-policy leverages a transformer-based module to encode task progress and predict the utility of potential sub-goals, effectively guiding the agent towards efficient task decomposition. By adaptively allocating computational resources for exploration and exploitation across hierarchical levels, Meta-HRL achieves superior sample efficiency and significantly higher success rates on challenging long-horizon manipulation and navigation tasks, demonstrating robust generalization to unseen goal configurations.
subject: AI
title: Metareasoning and Adaptive Exploration in Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Complex Goal-Conditioned Tasks

text: Automated theorem proving (ATP) is a fundamental problem in AI, yet combining the symbolic rigor of logic with the generalization power of neural networks remains elusive for complex mathematical proofs. We present "LogiTransformer," a novel neuro-symbolic ATP system that integrates Inductive Logic Programming (ILP) with a transformer-based proof search mechanism. LogiTransformer employs ILP to learn predicate logic rules from a small set of axiom-proof pairs, thereby extracting interpretable symbolic knowledge. This learned knowledge then guides a transformer network, pre-trained on large formal proof corpora, to generate plausible proof steps and evaluate their logical consistency. The symbiotic interplay allows the transformer to leverage learned logical predicates for more efficient and robust proof exploration, while ILP benefits from neural guidance in hypothesis generation. Experimental results on challenging mathematical theorems demonstrate superior performance in proof discovery and interpretability compared to purely symbolic or neural approaches.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic AI for Automated Theorem Proving with Inductive Logic Programming and Transformer-based Proof Search

text: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated impressive performance across myriad tasks, but their black-box nature and susceptibility to producing confidently incorrect outputs necessitate robust uncertainty quantification (UQ). Traditional UQ methods struggle with the extreme parameter counts and computational demands of LLMs. We propose a hybrid framework combining Conformal Prediction (CP) with scalable approximations of Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs) to provide valid uncertainty estimates for LLMs. Our approach leverages efficient ensemble-based BNNs, specifically MC-Dropout and Deep Ensembles, to estimate epistemic and aleatoric uncertainties for LLM predictions. These estimates are then fed into a novel CP algorithm tailored for sequence-to-sequence tasks, generating distribution-free prediction sets with rigorous statistical coverage guarantees. Experimental evaluations on question answering and summarization tasks demonstrate that our method yields tightly calibrated uncertainty intervals, significantly enhancing the trustworthiness and deployability of LLMs in high-stakes applications.
subject: AI
title: Uncertainty Quantification in Large Language Models via Conformal Prediction and Bayesian Neural Networks

text: Coordinating multiple agents in dynamic, partially observable environments with limited communication bandwidth and evolving network topologies presents significant challenges for multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL). Existing decentralized MARL algorithms often assume static communication graphs or global observability. We introduce a novel Decentralized MARL with Adaptive Communication (DMARL-AC) framework that enables agents to learn optimal policies and adaptive communication strategies concurrently. DMARL-AC utilizes a graph neural network (GNN) for message passing, where communication links are dynamically established based on learned salience scores and bandwidth constraints. A meta-learner optimizes the GNN's architecture and communication budget, allowing agents to form emergent coordination strategies under varying network conditions. Empirical evaluations across diverse multi-agent control tasks, including traffic management and robot swarms, demonstrate DMARL-AC's superior performance, robustness to communication failures, and adaptability to sudden topological changes, achieving emergent complex behaviors efficiently.
subject: AI
title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Communication Constraints and Dynamic Network Topologies

text: This paper introduces a novel computational framework for automating Schenkerian prolongational analysis, addressing the inherent ambiguity and context-dependency of structural levels in tonal music. We propose a methodology based on a multi-layered graph representation, where individual musical events (notes, chords) are nodes and various voice-leading and harmonic relationships are weighted edges. Our system employs a dynamic programming approach, constrained by a formalized set of Schenkerian heuristic rules derived from Free Composition, to identify optimal Ursatz and Urlinie derivations through iterative background-to-foreground reduction. Key algorithms focus on detecting recursive linear progressions, arpeggiated bass lines, and neighbor-note prolongations, quantifying their structural salience within the tonal hierarchy. Evaluated against expert-annotated segments of the Bach Chorale corpus, our model demonstrates significant congruence in identifying fundamental structures and common prolongational techniques, offering a robust tool for large-scale analytical studies and pedagogical applications in advanced tonal theory.
subject: Müzik
title: Formalizing Recursive Prolongation and Structural Levels in Tonal Music: A Graph-Theoretic and Heuristic Approach to Computational Schenkerian Analysis

text: This study investigates the psychoacoustic underpinnings of affective dissonance in xenoharmonic pitch structures, moving beyond traditional 12-ET frameworks. Utilizing a bespoke granular synthesis engine, we systematically generated dyads and trichords across various non-standard temperaments (e.g., 19-TET, 31-TET, selected just intonation systems), meticulously controlling for timbral spectra. Our analytical methodology integrates real-time spectro-temporal feature extraction, including Plomp & Levelt roughness indices, Sethares' dissonance curves, and novel cochleagram-derived metrics of spectral spread and inharmonicity. These objective acoustic correlates were then cross-referenced with empirical listener perception data, obtained via ecologically valid affective rating scales. The resulting predictive models quantify the contribution of specific interval classes and harmonic spectra to perceived tension and resolution in microtonal contexts. Findings refine existing theories of sensory dissonance, offering critical insights for compositional practice in non-octave and non-diatonic systems, while advancing our understanding of cross-cultural auditory cognition.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Affective Dissonance in Non-Standard Temperaments: A Psychoacoustic and Spectro-Temporal Analysis of Xenoharmonic Pitch Structures

text: This research presents a hierarchical Bayesian model designed to characterize dynamic entrainment and meter induction in complex polyrhythmic textures. Building upon established onset detection functions (ODFs), our model probabilistically estimates multiple, simultaneously active metrical hierarchies and their respective phase alignments, even in the presence of extreme syncopation or ambiguous accentuation. We integrate cognitive priors reflecting human predispositions for specific tempo ranges and common metrical groupings, employing a particle filtering framework for robust real-time inference. The model quantifies rhythmic complexity by evaluating the entropy of competing metrical hypotheses and the divergence of inferred beat phases. Validation against a diverse corpus of polyrhythmic stimuli, including both synthetic patterns and ethnomusicological examples, demonstrates superior performance in capturing subtle shifts in perceived meter compared to traditional fixed-grid approaches. This framework offers significant advancements for computational musicology, real-time interactive systems, and the cognitive neuroscience of sensorimotor synchronization.
subject: Müzik
title: Deciphering Entrainment and Rhythmic Complexity in Polyrhythmic Textures: A Hierarchical Bayesian Model of Meter Induction and Synchronization

text: This paper introduces a novel deep generative framework for modeling and manipulating timbral evolution, focusing on the reconstruction of perceptually salient attributes from a learned latent space. We employ a Variational Autoencoder (VAE) architecture, where the decoder integrates differentiable Digital Signal Processing (DSP) modules, including parametric filters and dynamic envelope generators, allowing for direct synthesis from latent representations. The model is trained on a large corpus of instrumental audio, learning to encode complex spectro-temporal features such as spectral centroid, noisiness, and attack transients into a continuous, disentangled latent space. Trajectories within this space correspond to smooth, perceptually coherent timbral morphing, enabling precise control over timbral parameters via latent space interpolation. Validation experiments demonstrate high fidelity in reconstructing diverse timbres and robust mapping from user-defined perceptual targets (e.g., 'brighter,' 'more metallic') to synthesis control parameters. This approach significantly advances intuitive sound design interfaces and computational models of auditory scene analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Generative Modeling of Timbral Evolution: Reconstructing Perceptual Attributes from Latent Space Trajectories via Differentiable DSP

text: This research introduces a novel computational methodology for the automated detection and classification of formal archetypes, specifically sonata form structures, within large-scale symbolic music corpora. We conceptualize musical pieces as weighted directed graphs, where nodes represent segmented thematic or transitional material identified via similarity metrics (e.g., modified pitch-class n-gram comparison), and edges denote harmonic progression, melodic contour similarity, and temporal adjacency. A multi-layered convolutional neural network, informed by a Hidden Markov Model framework, is trained to learn latent formal functions (e.g., Exposition, Development, Recapitulation) by analyzing sequences of inter-segmental relationships and harmonic features such as cadential types and tonal trajectory. Applied to a diverse corpus of 18th- and 19th-century instrumental works, our model demonstrates high precision in identifying formal boundaries and sub-sectional functions, enabling the quantitative validation of existing formal theories and the discovery of statistically significant stylistic divergences across composers and periods, thereby advancing corpus-based musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: Automated Detection and Classification of Formal Archetypes in Large-Scale Symbolic Corpora: A Graph-Based Approach to Sonata Form Analysis

text: This research pioneers a multimodal deep latent factor analysis framework for fine-grained affective state prediction in music, transcending conventional arousal-valence models. Our system integrates a heterogeneous array of features: audio-derived spectro-temporal descriptors (e.g., spectral flux, zero-crossing rate), symbolic harmony and melodic contour information (e.g., neo-Riemannian transformations, interval vectors), and listener-elicited psychophysiological signals (e.g., galvanic skin response, heart rate variability). A Transformer-based architecture with cross-modal attention mechanisms learns a shared latent representation, capturing intricate interdependencies between these diverse data streams. This unified embedding space facilitates the prediction of nuanced emotional categories from the Geneva Emotional Wheel, achieving superior performance over unimodal baselines. The findings not only offer a sophisticated computational model for music emotion recognition but also provide novel insights into the complex interplay of acoustic, theoretical, and physiological factors mediating human affective responses to musical stimuli, with broad implications for personalized music recommendation and music-assisted therapy.
subject: Müzik
title: Multimodal Deep Latent Factor Analysis for Fine-Grained Affective State Prediction in Music: Integrating Audio-Symbolic and Psychophysiological Features

text: This paper introduces a novel hierarchical diffusion model for algorithmic composition that directly addresses the challenge of generating coherent macro-formal structures in symbolic music. Our architecture comprises a high-level diffusion process that learns and interpolates between abstract formal schemata (e.g., AABA, rondo, sonata-esque progressions) and a lower-level generative network conditioned on these structural templates. The lower network, a sequence-to-sequence Transformer, infers local melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic parameters, enabling the coherent development of musical ideas within predefined formal boundaries. A key innovation is the integration of "thematic priming," allowing composers to input initial melodic or rhythmic motifs which the model subsequently develops and varies across sections, ensuring thematic unity. Expert evaluation of generated compositions demonstrates significant improvements in structural logic and musical coherence compared to models lacking explicit formal conditioning. This work opens new avenues for exploring computational creativity and the formal grammars underlying diverse musical styles.
subject: Müzik
title: Controlling Macro-Formal Structure in Algorithmic Composition via Hierarchical Diffusion Models with Thematic Priming

text: This study employs a combined information-theoretic and pitch-class set approach to elucidate scale-degree functionality and identify melodic prototypes within North Indian Classical Ragas. Analyzing a curated corpus of transcribed raga performances, we quantify the probabilistic distribution of pitch-classes and intervallic successions using measures such as entropy and mutual information, revealing intrinsic hierarchical relationships and salient melodic tendencies (e.g., vadi, samvadi). Furthermore, we adapt aspects of Western pitch-class set theory and contour analysis to characterize recurring melodic fragments, or pakars, which define the idiomatic expression of specific ragas. Sequential pattern mining algorithms are deployed to automatically extract these characteristic prototypes, validating their statistical salience against traditional ethnomusicological descriptions. This computational framework offers a rigorous methodology for analyzing the deep structure of non-Western melodic systems, providing novel insights into cross-cultural musical cognition and advancing the capabilities of automated melodic analysis for diverse musical traditions.
subject: Müzik
title: Investigating Scale-Degree Functionality and Melodic Prototypes in North Indian Ragas using Information-Theoretic and Pitch-Class Set Approaches

text: This paper introduces a novel Deep Graph Neural Network (GNN) framework for the automated detection and classification of Neo-Riemannian harmonic transformations within large-scale tonal music corpora. We model harmonic progressions as dynamic graphs, where nodes represent individual triads or pitch-class sets, and directed edges signify potential Neo-Riemannian operations (e.g., Parallel, Leittonwechsel, Relative). The GNN is trained to learn complex patterns of these parsimonious voice-leading transformations, utilizing attention mechanisms to weigh the contextual significance of surrounding harmonic events. This approach transcends simple chord classification by inferring the functional relationship between adjacent harmonies within the Neo-Riemannian Tonnetz. Evaluated on annotated segments of late Romantic repertoire, our model demonstrates robust performance in identifying sequences of P, L, and R transformations, offering a powerful tool for computational musicologists to statistically validate theoretical claims regarding post-tonal harmonic language and to uncover previously unnoticed transformational networks in vast musical datasets.
subject: Müzik
title: Automated Neo-Riemannian Transformation Detection in Tonal Music Corpora via Deep Graph Neural Networks

text: This research presents a sophisticated computational model for predicting perceived affective consonance-dissonance from arbitrary multi-partial spectra, extending beyond traditional interval-based theories. Our model integrates a comprehensive suite of psychoacoustic parameters, including revised critical band roughness indices, periodicity strength derived from auditory autocorrelation functions, and a novel metric quantifying deviation from ideal harmonicity across spectral partials. A recurrent neural network architecture then learns the complex, non-linear mapping between these objective spectral descriptors and human subjective ratings of tension and resolution obtained via psychophysical experiments using diverse synthesized timbres and microtonal tunings. The framework further incorporates adaptive cognitive modulators, allowing for personalized predictions based on listener musical experience. This approach provides a robust, generalizable tool for analyzing the perceptual qualities of complex soundscapes, offering crucial insights into the neurocognitive underpinnings of musical aesthetics, informing advanced tuning system design, and enhancing our understanding of timbre's role in harmonic perception.
subject: Müzik
title: Non-Linear Perceptual Mapping of Multi-Partial Spectra to Affective Consonance-Dissonance: A Computational Model Integrating Roughness, Periodicity, and Harmonicity

text: Transposable elements (TEs) are pervasive genomic parasites whose unchecked activity poses significant threats to host genome integrity. This study investigates the evolutionary arms race between host silencing machinery (e.g., piRNAs, DNA methylation) and TE proliferation across a *Drosophila* species complex. We utilized comprehensive small RNA sequencing, whole-genome bisulfite sequencing, and population genomic data to delineate species-specific TE landscapes and their associated epigenomic repression profiles. Our findings reveal dynamic shifts in piRNA clusters and methylation patterns correlating with differential TE activity and introgression barriers. Crucially, we identify instances where TE-proximal epigenetic silencing "spills over" to adjacent host genes, altering their expression and potentially contributing to post-zygotic reproductive isolation through Dobzhansky-Muller incompatibilities. This work illuminates how genomic conflict shapes both chromatin architecture and the genetic basis of speciation.
subject: Evrim
title: Unveiling the Epigenomic Battleground: Transposable Element Silencing and its Spillover Effects on Host Gene Regulation and Speciation

text: Phenotypic plasticity is increasingly recognized as a crucial substrate for adaptation, yet the mechanisms linking environmental cues to heritable phenotypic variation remain elusive. We explored the role of environmentally induced epigenetic modifications in shaping adaptive potential within an anadromous fish species undergoing colonization of novel freshwater habitats. Using reduced-representation bisulfite sequencing (RRBS) and gene expression profiling across multiple generations under controlled experimental conditions, we identified numerous differentially methylated regions (DMRs) associated with genes involved in osmoregulation and metabolism, whose methylation states correlated with salinity tolerance. Critically, a subset of these DMRs exhibited transgenerational inheritance in the absence of continued environmental stimuli, demonstrating epigenetic lability capable of modulating reaction norms. Our results suggest that such environmentally triggered, metastable epigenetic states provide a rapid, non-Mendelian avenue for buffering novel selective pressures, thereby accelerating genetic assimilation and potentially facilitating evolutionary rescue.
subject: Evrim
title: Environmentally Induced Epigenetic Lability as a Substrate for Rapid Adaptation in a Vertebrate Lineage

text: High-altitude environments present extreme selective pressures, primarily hypoxia, driving recurrent evolution of adaptive traits across diverse vertebrate lineages. This study employs a comprehensive phylogenomic approach to investigate the molecular basis of hypoxia tolerance across four independently evolved avian clades inhabiting high-altitude regions. We analyzed whole-genome sequences from 98 species, focusing on positive selection signals and gene family expansions within pathways critical for oxygen transport, cellular respiration, and angiogenesis. Our analyses identify convergent amino acid substitutions in hemoglobin alpha and beta subunits, enhancing oxygen binding affinity, and parallel signatures of positive selection in genes regulating HIF-1α signaling. Furthermore, we detect several shared gene duplications related to mitochondrial function. These findings underscore a limited set of genetic solutions to a common environmental challenge, revealing how macroevolutionary patterns of convergence are sculpted by underlying molecular architecture and physiological constraints on adaptive landscapes.
subject: Evrim
title: Convergent Evolution of High-Altitude Adaptations: A Phylogenomic Perspective on Hypoxia Tolerance in Avian Clades

text: Host-pathogen interactions represent dynamic arenas of antagonistic coevolution, often resulting in "Red Queen" dynamics and the maintenance of extensive polymorphism. We investigated the genomic architecture underpinning these coevolutionary arms races in a wild *Arabidopsis*-obligate biotrophic oomycete system. Leveraging whole-genome resequencing data from sympatric host and pathogen populations, we identified reciprocal patterns of positive selection and balancing selection acting on both host resistance (R) genes and pathogen avirulence (AVR) effectors. We observed significant linkage disequilibrium within R-gene clusters in the host and rapid turnover of AVR alleles in the pathogen, indicative of frequency-dependent selection. Furthermore, population demographic models revealed a history of repeated selective sweeps interspersed with periods of transient polymorphism, consistent with fluctuating selection pressures. This work elucidates the complex interplay of genomic selection shaping immune receptor diversity and pathogen virulence strategies, providing insights into the persistence of genetic variation under strong coevolutionary forces.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Antagonistic Coevolution Driving Polymorphism Maintenance in a Plant-Pathogen System

text: Understanding the genetic basis of reproductive isolation (RI) is central to speciation research, particularly in systems characterized by ongoing gene flow. We conducted a fine-scale genomic analysis across a classic avian ring species complex to dissect the genetic architecture contributing to intrinsic post-zygotic isolation. Utilizing thousands of single nucleotide polymorphisms from hybrid zones and allopatric populations, we identified multiple small-effect genomic regions exhibiting elevated differentiation and exhibiting strong linkage to reproductive barriers. Introgressed tracts from divergent lineages were significantly depleted in these regions, indicative of strong negative selection against foreign alleles, consistent with Dobzhansky-Muller incompatibilities. Furthermore, we found evidence for both chromosomal inversions and sex-linked incompatibilities contributing to RI, highlighting the polygenic and heterogeneous nature of speciation. Our findings provide a detailed genomic map of RI, revealing that speciation proceeds through the gradual accumulation of numerous weakly deleterious genetic factors rather than few large-effect loci.
subject: Evrim
title: Unraveling the Multifaceted Genetic Architecture of Reproductive Isolation in a Hybridizing Avian Ring Species

text: Adaptive radiations are hallmark examples of rapid evolutionary diversification, driven by ecological opportunity and strong divergent selection. We investigated the genomic architecture underlying the adaptive radiation of a diverse Neotropical cichlid fish lineage inhabiting an archipelago of crater lakes. Through whole-genome resequencing of representatives from multiple trophic morphs (e.g., molluscivores, piscivores, detritivores), we identified numerous genomic islands of divergence characterized by elevated FST and reduced nucleotide diversity, often encompassing genes involved in craniofacial development, sensory perception, and digestive physiology. Bayesian demographic models indicate recent, rapid population expansions and strong founder effects associated with lake colonization events. We found significant evidence of parallel evolution at the genomic level across replicate radiations in different lakes, suggesting a degree of genetic determinism in the exploitation of specific ecological niches. This study provides a high-resolution genomic perspective on the proximate and ultimate drivers of adaptive radiation, emphasizing the rapid restructuring of genetic variation during eco-morphological divergence.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Footprints of Rapid Ecological Diversification: Adaptive Radiation in a Neotropical Cichlid Lineage

text: Sexual conflict, arising from divergent fitness optima between sexes, is a powerful evolutionary force shaping genomes and phenotypes. We explored the genomic landscapes of sexually antagonistic selection and cryptic interlocus conflict in a polygynandrous mammal known for pronounced sexual dimorphism and male-male competition. Using population genomic analyses across sex-specific recombination maps, we identified regions exhibiting sex-biased gene expression and significant discordance in patterns of positive selection between males and females. We observed an enrichment of genes associated with reproductive traits, immune function, and metabolism within these sexually antagonistic loci. Furthermore, analysis of cis-regulatory elements revealed widespread sex-specific allelic expression, suggesting fine-scale regulatory adjustments to manage intralocus sexual conflict. This study provides a comprehensive genomic framework for understanding how continuous interlocus sexual conflict generates and maintains genetic variation, influencing adaptive trajectories and potentially contributing to the evolution of complex reproductive strategies.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Sexually Antagonistic Selection and Cryptic Interlocus Conflict in a Polygynandrous Mammal

text: The repeated evolution of complex morphological traits across divergent lineages offers unique opportunities to dissect the genetic and developmental mechanisms underlying phenotypic innovation and diversification. We investigate the recurrent emergence of striped versus spotted pigment patterns in squamate reptiles, a classic example of intraspecific and interspecific variation. Through comparative transcriptomics of developing embryonic scales and CRISPR-Cas9 mutagenesis in a model gecko, combined with phylogenomic analyses, we identify a conserved but pleiotropic regulatory gene network governing melanogenesis and iridophore development. Our findings highlight specific cis-regulatory modifications and duplications of key signaling pathway components (e.g., *EDN3*, *WNT*) that act as developmental switches, leading to distinct Turing-like reaction-diffusion patterns. This research reveals that novel complex traits can arise from the re-purposing of existing genetic toolkits via subtle regulatory changes, rather than *de novo* gene evolution, demonstrating fundamental principles of evolutionary developmental biology.
subject: Evrim
title: Recurrent Evolution of Novel Phenotypes: Unraveling the Developmental Genetic Basis of Pigment Patterning Diversity in Squamate Reptiles

text: Human populations have undergone profound demographic and environmental changes in the past millennia, largely driven by cultural innovations such as agriculture and urbanization. We conducted a large-scale analysis of whole-genome sequencing data from diverse human populations to identify recent genomic imprints of positive selection linked to these anthropogenic shifts. Focusing on pathways related to diet, pathogen resistance, and detoxification, we employed various statistics for detecting selective sweeps (e.g., iHS, XP-CLR) and identified numerous loci under strong recent selection. Notably, we found robust signals of selection on genes involved in starch metabolism (*AMY1*), lactose persistence (*LCT*), and xenobiotic detoxification (*CYP* genes), demonstrating clear gene-culture coevolutionary dynamics. Furthermore, analysis of polygenic scores revealed subtle but significant shifts in disease susceptibility alleles correlated with geographical regions and historical subsistence strategies. This study illuminates how cultural practices and associated environmental pressures continue to shape the human adaptive landscape.
subject: Evrim
title: Deciphering the Genomic Imprints of Recent Anthropogenic Environmental Shifts on Human Adaptive Evolution

text: Climate change poses unprecedented challenges to biodiversity, necessitating a rigorous understanding of species' adaptive potential and susceptibility to maladaptation in fragmented landscapes. This study integrates population genomics, quantitative genetics, and environmental niche modeling to assess the vulnerability of an endangered endemic plant species across its disjunct range. We employed genomic offset analyses and inferred metrics of genetic load (e.g., deleterious mutation accumulation) to identify populations exhibiting high genomic vulnerability to projected climate shifts. Our findings reveal significant spatial heterogeneity in adaptive capacity, with peripheral populations displaying reduced heterozygosity, increased genomic load, and limited standing genetic variation in climate-associated loci. Critically, we identified strong genotype-environment associations for genes involved in drought stress response, indicating ongoing divergent selection but also the potential for maladaptation in future climates. This work provides actionable genomic insights for conservation prioritization, highlighting populations with critical adaptive potential for managed relocation or enhanced genetic connectivity.
subject: Evrim
title: Quantifying Adaptive Potential and Maladaptation in Fragmented Populations Under Climate Change: A Genomic Vulnerability Assessment

text: This paper investigates the theoretical properties of graphical model selection in high-dimensional settings, specifically focusing on the estimation of precision matrices under sparsity constraints. We propose a novel adaptive group Lasso regularization framework that optimally balances bias and variance in the estimation of conditional independence relationships. Our theoretical contributions establish minimax optimal convergence rates for both estimation error and variable selection consistency under varying sparsity levels and signal-to-noise ratios. We demonstrate that the proposed estimator achieves near-oracle performance, even when the number of variables substantially exceeds the sample size, provided suitable structural assumptions on the underlying graph. Furthermore, we provide rigorous non-asymptotic bounds, incorporating matrix concentration inequalities, to quantify the performance of our method against state-of-the-art sparse inverse covariance estimators in ultra-high dimensions.
subject: İstatistik
title: Minimax Optimal Rates for High-Dimensional Graphical Model Selection via Adaptive Group Lasso Regularization

text: Estimating heterogeneous treatment effects is crucial for precision medicine and policy evaluation, yet conventional methods often struggle with model misspecification and complex interaction structures. We introduce a novel nonparametric Bayesian framework leveraging Dirichlet Process Mixture (DPM) priors to flexibly model the entire distribution of potential outcomes, accommodating arbitrary levels of heterogeneity. Our approach allows for the discovery of latent subgroups exhibiting distinct treatment responses without pre-specifying the number of clusters. We derive computationally efficient Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms for posterior inference, including split-merge moves to enhance mixing. Theoretical guarantees are provided for posterior consistency under mild regularity conditions. Simulations demonstrate superior performance in identifying treatment effect heterogeneity compared to parametric and semi-parametric alternatives, particularly in scenarios with highly non-linear confounding and complex response surfaces, offering robust inference for individualized treatment rules.
subject: İstatistik
title: A Nonparametric Bayesian Approach to Heterogeneous Treatment Effects with Dirichlet Process Mixture Priors

text: We address the pervasive challenge of estimating causal effects in longitudinal studies subject to time-varying confounding, where confounders are themselves affected by prior treatment. This paper develops semiparametric efficiency bounds for various causal estimands, including marginal structural models and dynamic treatment regimes, in settings with sequentially ignorable treatment assignment. We propose a novel doubly robust estimator, based on targeted maximum likelihood estimation (TMLE) principles, that attains these efficiency bounds. Our estimator remains consistent and asymptotically normal if either the treatment mechanism or the outcome regression model is correctly specified, providing enhanced robustness against model misspecification compared to single-robust methods. We further extend the framework to accommodate high-dimensional covariates and propose a data-adaptive estimation strategy for optimal nuisance parameter estimation, demonstrating its practical utility through extensive simulations and an empirical application to observational health data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Semiparametric Efficiency Bounds for Causal Effects in Longitudinal Studies with Time-Varying Confounding

text: Quantile regression offers a comprehensive view of covariate effects across the entire conditional distribution, transcending the mean-based limitations of ordinary least squares. However, its efficiency can be compromised by heavy-tailed errors or outliers in the covariates. This paper proposes a robust inference framework for quantile regression parameters using generalized empirical likelihood (GEL) methods. We construct novel GEL estimators that are less sensitive to aberrant observations and model misspecification than traditional methods, particularly when exact error distribution assumptions are violated. Our approach yields asymptotically efficient estimators and provides robust confidence intervals without requiring explicit estimation of the error density function. We establish the theoretical properties of the proposed GEL estimators, including consistency and asymptotic normality, under weaker moment conditions. Extensive simulations validate the superior robustness and coverage probability of our methodology across a range of contaminated data distributions, making it highly valuable for complex data analysis.
subject: İstatistik
title: Robust Inference for Quantile Regression via Generalized Empirical Likelihood Methods

text: Functional data analysis (FDA) is increasingly prevalent in disciplines where data are naturally curves or functions. We address the challenge of high-dimensional functional predictors in functional linear regression models, where direct estimation can suffer from ill-conditioning and excessive variance. This paper develops a novel penalized functional linear regression framework that integrates functional principal component analysis (FPCA) for dimension reduction with a smoothness-inducing penalty. Our method projects the functional predictors onto a lower-dimensional eigenbasis derived from the FPCA decomposition, followed by a generalized elastic net penalty on the basis coefficients. This approach effectively handles multicollinearity and provides interpretable, smooth coefficient functions. We establish theoretical properties, including estimation consistency and rates of convergence, under appropriate regularity conditions. Empirical results on simulated and real neuroimaging datasets demonstrate improved predictive performance and model sparsity compared to existing FDA methods, offering a powerful tool for complex functional relationships.
subject: İstatistik
title: Penalized Functional Linear Regression with Functional Principal Component Analysis for High-Dimensional Curve Data

text: The modeling and forecasting of volatility in dynamic financial networks present significant challenges due to inherent non-stationarity and complex interdependencies. We propose a novel class of Non-Stationary Functional GARCH (NSF-GARCH) models designed to capture evolving volatility structures and their propagation across network nodes. Our framework leverages functional data analysis techniques to represent time-varying GARCH parameters as smooth functions, whose evolution is governed by exogenous covariates or intrinsic temporal trends. We introduce a basis expansion approach for estimating these functional parameters, ensuring both flexibility and parsimony. Asymptotic properties of the estimators, including consistency and convergence rates, are derived under mild conditions. Empirical evaluation on high-frequency cryptocurrency market data demonstrates superior out-of-sample volatility forecasts and network spillover predictions compared to traditional multivariate GARCH and static functional GARCH specifications, providing critical insights for risk management and portfolio optimization in evolving market landscapes.
subject: İstatistik
title: Non-Stationary Functional GARCH Models for Volatility Forecasting in Dynamic Financial Networks

text: Detecting anomalies in high-dimensional time series data is critical across numerous domains, from cybersecurity to physiological monitoring. Traditional statistical methods often struggle with the complex, non-linear, and evolving patterns characteristic of such data. We propose a novel anomaly detection framework based on persistent homology, a fundamental tool in topological data analysis, which captures multi-scale geometric and topological features of data clouds. Our approach constructs a sequence of Vietoris-Rips complexes from sliding windows of the time series, generating persistence diagrams that encode structural information. To enhance discriminative power, we introduce a metric learning strategy on the space of persistence diagrams, optimizing a kernel-based distance for improved separation between normal and anomalous patterns. We develop a robust statistical test for anomaly scores derived from this learned metric. Extensive experiments on diverse real-world datasets confirm superior performance over state-of-the-art methods, particularly for subtle, distributed anomalies.
subject: İstatistik
title: Persistent Homology for Anomaly Detection in High-Dimensional Time Series: A Metric Learning Approach

text: Geographically Weighted Regression (GWR) is widely used for modeling spatially varying relationships, but its inference often relies on local, independent parameter estimates, precluding direct global uncertainty quantification. We introduce a novel Spatially Varying Coefficient (SVC) model framed within a Bayesian hierarchical context, employing Conditional Autoregressive (CAR) priors to model the spatial dependence of regression coefficients. This approach provides a principled way to smooth local estimates and propagate uncertainty across space, addressing the limitations of classical GWR. Our methodology allows for the estimation of both the mean and the spatial covariance structure of the functional coefficients simultaneously. We develop efficient Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms for posterior inference. Comprehensive simulations demonstrate improved parameter recovery and more accurate uncertainty quantification compared to conventional GWR. An application to environmental epidemiology data illustrates the framework's ability to identify complex, localized risk factor associations, offering superior interpretability and statistical rigor.
subject: İstatistik
title: Spatially Varying Coefficient Models with Conditional Autoregressive Priors for Geographically Weighted Regression

text: In oncology, patients often face multiple competing causes of death or disease progression, and their trajectories are simultaneously influenced by time-dependent biomarkers. We propose a sophisticated joint modeling framework that integrates competing risks analysis with multivariate longitudinal biomarker data, offering enhanced prognostic capabilities and dynamic predictions. Our model utilizes a cause-specific hazards approach for competing risks, while the longitudinal biomarkers are modeled using a mixed-effects framework with flexible functional forms. A key innovation is the incorporation of patient-specific random effects that link the longitudinal and survival components, capturing individual heterogeneity and biomarker-event associations. We employ a penalized maximum likelihood estimation strategy for parameter inference, ensuring stability and generalizability. Dynamic predictions of cause-specific cumulative incidence are derived using real-time biomarker updates. Extensive validation on clinical trial data demonstrates superior predictive accuracy and discriminative ability compared to separate or simpler joint models, facilitating more precise individualized risk assessment.
subject: İstatistik
title: Joint Modeling of Competing Risks and Longitudinal Biomarkers with Dynamic Prediction in Oncology

text: Understanding the generalization capabilities of deep neural networks, particularly their ability to avoid overfitting in overparameterized regimes, remains a central theoretical challenge. This paper introduces novel PAC-Bayesian generalization bounds for deep learning models, leveraging f-divergences to quantify the discrepancy between posterior and prior distributions over network parameters. We propose an information-theoretic regularization scheme that explicitly minimizes these divergences, thereby controlling model complexity and improving generalization without sacrificing expressivity. Our theoretical analysis provides tighter, data-dependent bounds compared to classical VC-dimension or Rademacher complexity analyses, particularly for highly expressive architectures. Furthermore, we demonstrate how this framework leads to practical optimization objectives that encourage flatter minima and enhance robustness. Empirical validation on benchmark datasets confirms that models trained with our information-theoretic regularization achieve superior generalization performance and exhibit increased resilience to adversarial perturbations, bridging the gap between theoretical guarantees and practical deep learning efficacy.
subject: İstatistik
title: Generalization Bounds for Deep Neural Networks via PAC-Bayesian Divergences with Information-Theoretic Regularization

text: This paper addresses the fundamental challenge of causal inference in observational studies exacerbated by unmeasured confounding, particularly when high-dimensional proxy variables are available. We propose a novel doubly robust estimator for average treatment effects, integrating debiased machine learning techniques with a sophisticated latent variable model for confounder proxying. Our approach leverages the robust properties of orthogonal score functions to achieve efficient inference, even under partial misspecification of either the outcome regression or the treatment assignment mechanism. Theoretically, we establish non-asymptotic bounds demonstrating rate optimality and robustness to high-dimensional covariate and proxy spaces, circumventing typical curses of dimensionality. Empirical evaluations on synthetic and real-world genomic datasets validate the superior performance and resilience of our method against existing benchmarks, especially in settings with complex confounding structures and heterogeneous treatment effects.
subject: İstatistik
title: Doubly Robust Deconfounding in Observational Studies via Debiased Machine Learning with High-Dimensional Proxies

text: We introduce a Bayesian non-parametric framework for modeling complex spatiotemporal functional data, such as evolving curves or surfaces observed across space and time. Our approach utilizes hierarchical Dirichlet process (HDP) mixture models to simultaneously cluster functional observations and infer their underlying spatiotemporal dynamics without assuming a fixed number of components. Each component is characterized by a unique functional basis representation, allowing for flexible and adaptive modeling of varying functional shapes and their evolution. The HDP structure naturally accommodates heterogeneity and scales efficiently with increasing data complexity. We develop a tailored Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm for posterior inference, incorporating slice sampling for efficient updates of functional parameters. Extensive simulations and applications to climate science datasets demonstrate the method's ability to uncover latent spatiotemporal patterns, perform robust imputation, and provide uncertainty quantification.
subject: İstatistik
title: Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Mixture Models for Spatiotemporal Functional Data

text: This work presents a novel regularization framework for estimating high-dimensional vector autoregressive (VAR) models, crucial for understanding Granger-causal relationships in complex systems like financial markets. We propose a group Lasso-type penalty that promotes sparsity at both the equation and individual parameter levels, enabling efficient identification of direct and indirect causal pathways among hundreds or thousands of interconnected time series. The regularization path is optimized via a proximal gradient descent algorithm tailored for the non-smooth, non-convex objective. We derive theoretical guarantees for support recovery and prediction accuracy under high-dimensional scaling regimes (p>>T). Extensive empirical analysis using ultra-high-frequency stock market data demonstrates superior forecasting performance and interpretability compared to traditional and other sparse VAR methods, elucidating dynamic network structures and systemic risk propagation.
subject: İstatistik
title: Sparse Vector Autoregressive Models with Group Lasso Regularization for Ultra-High-Dimensional Financial Data

text: We investigate the fundamental limits of robust regression under a novel adversarial contamination model where a fraction of samples can be arbitrarily perturbed within a specified L_infinity norm bound, a scenario critical for secure machine learning and outlier detection. Building upon the Huber loss, we characterize the minimax optimal rates for estimating regression coefficients in this setting. Our contribution is a computationally efficient M-estimator that achieves these minimax rates, exhibiting high breakdown points and resilience to extreme outliers while maintaining statistical efficiency under clean data. We provide non-asymptotic analysis of its convergence properties and error bounds, demonstrating its robustness to both heavy-tailed noise and adversarial perturbations. Experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets show that our proposed robust estimator significantly outperforms classical and existing robust methods in the presence of targeted data poisoning attacks and severe contamination.
subject: İstatistik
title: Minimax Optimal Robust Regression under Adversarial Contamination with Bounded Huber Loss

text: This paper develops a comprehensive theoretical and computational framework for estimating operator-valued covariance functions of non-stationary functional time series, a pervasive challenge in fields like neuroscience and environmental monitoring. We introduce a localized spectral representation approach that accounts for evolving dynamics in both the mean function and the covariance operator structure. The methodology involves kernel-smoothing of empirical cross-periodograms of functional principal component scores, yielding a consistent estimator for the instantaneous covariance operator. We establish non-asymptotic convergence rates in appropriate Hilbert-Schmidt norms, providing uniform confidence bands for the estimated covariance operators. The proposed technique naturally extends to multiple functional series, facilitating dynamic functional connectivity analysis. Simulation studies and an application to electroencephalogram (EEG) data demonstrate the method’s efficacy in capturing intricate time-varying functional dependencies and identifying transient patterns.
subject: İstatistik
title: Operator-Valued Covariance Estimation for Non-Stationary Functional Time Series

text: We propose a novel adaptive False Discovery Rate (FDR) control procedure that accounts for unknown and complex dependencies among p-values, a common challenge in large-scale hypothesis testing. Our method leverages a spectral decomposition of an estimated association matrix (e.g., empirical correlation or graphical Lasso precision matrix) to construct a weighting scheme that prioritizes less dependent and more significant tests. This adaptive weighting allows for higher power compared to classical Benjamini-Hochberg while maintaining FDR control under various dependency structures, including block dependence and hidden Markov models. We establish theoretical guarantees for FDR control under mild regularity conditions on the dependency structure and provide an efficient algorithm for practical implementation. Extensive simulations and a gene expression analysis validate the substantial power gains and robustness of our approach over state-of-the-art methods, particularly in settings with strong and structured dependencies.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive False Discovery Rate Control for Dependent Tests via Spectral Decomposition of Association Matrices

text: This paper presents a rigorous theoretical investigation into the generalization capabilities of deep neural networks, moving beyond traditional asymptotic analyses. We derive novel non-asymptotic generalization error bounds for overparameterized deep learning models by carefully combining advanced tools from statistical learning theory, specifically tailored Rademacher complexity analyses and PAC-Bayes theory. Our bounds explicitly account for network architecture, sample size, and regularization strength, offering tighter guarantees than existing uniform convergence results. Critically, we introduce a measure of "effective capacity" for deep networks under specific training regimes, demonstrating how implicit regularization induced by optimization algorithms can impact generalization without relying on explicit complexity penalties. Empirical validation on benchmark datasets, employing varied architectures and training strategies, corroborates the predictive power of our theoretical bounds in practical deep learning scenarios.
subject: İstatistik
title: Non-Asymptotic Bounds for Generalization Error in Deep Neural Networks via Rademacher Complexity and PAC-Bayes

text: We develop a novel framework for spatio-temporal Gaussian process (GP) regression designed for data observed on complex, non-Euclidean domains (e.g., surfaces of organs, geographical regions with complex topology). Our approach addresses the critical challenges of non-stationarity in spatio-temporal dependencies and the intrinsic geometry of the observation space. We propose a manifold-aware kernel construction that fuses local Euclidean approximations with global geodesic distances, allowing for highly flexible, spatially varying covariance functions. Bayesian inference for the GP hyperparameters is performed using an efficient Markov Chain Monte Carlo scheme incorporating Hamiltonian Monte Carlo. The method inherently provides uncertainty quantification and supports adaptive resolution. Empirical results on neuroimaging and environmental pollution datasets demonstrate superior predictive accuracy and realistic uncertainty estimation compared to stationary Euclidean GP models, highlighting its utility for complex scientific modeling tasks.
subject: İstatistik
title: Spatio-Temporal Gaussian Process Regression with Non-Stationary Covariance Functions on Manifolds

text: This paper introduces a robust semiparametric regression model for analyzing competing risks data in the presence of high-dimensional covariates, a critical challenge in clinical trials and public health. We extend the proportional subdistribution hazards model by integrating sparse regularization techniques, specifically Group Lasso and adaptive Lasso penalties, to simultaneously identify relevant predictors and handle complex covariate structures. The proposed penalized estimator for the cause-specific subdistribution hazard functions maintains the consistency and asymptotic normality properties of its low-dimensional counterparts while achieving sparsity and prediction accuracy in high-dimensional settings. We develop an efficient coordinate descent algorithm for optimization and establish theoretical properties including oracle inequalities. Extensive simulation studies and an application to a large cardiovascular disease registry demonstrate its superior performance in variable selection and prediction accuracy compared to existing methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Semiparametric Regression for Competing Risks Data with High-Dimensional Covariates via Penalized Subdistribution Hazards

text: We propose an innovative Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) framework that leverages optimal transport (OT) distances, specifically the Wasserstein distance, to compare simulated and observed data for models with intractable likelihood functions. Traditional ABC methods rely on Euclidean or summary-statistic-based distances, often sacrificing information or struggling with complex data structures. Our OT-ABC framework provides a principled, metric-free approach to quantify discrepancies between empirical distributions, allowing for a richer comparison of data features without the need for hand-crafted summary statistics. We develop a robust sequential Monte Carlo ABC algorithm augmented with efficient mini-batch Wasserstein distance approximations, enabling scalability to large datasets and high-dimensional simulations. Theoretical analysis demonstrates improved posterior approximation accuracy and reduced sensitivity to the choice of data representation. Applications in population genetics and systems biology showcase superior performance in inferring complex model parameters compared to conventional ABC variants.
subject: İstatistik
title: Approximate Bayesian Computation with Optimal Transport Distances for Intractable Likelihood Models

text: This study investigates the asymptotic Turan density $\text{ex}(n, \mathcal{F})$ for uniform hypergraphs, focusing on families $\mathcal{F}$ of forbidden configurations whose underlying incidence graphs exhibit bounded treewidth. Leveraging recent advancements in the hypergraph regularity method and a refined application of the Container Method, we establish new upper bounds for $\text{ex}(n, \mathcal{F})$ that substantially improve upon existing results for non-degenerate cases. Specifically, for $k$-uniform hypergraphs and a given forbidden $k$-graph $F$, we derive tighter bounds on the maximum number of edges a $k$-graph on $n$ vertices can have without containing $F$ as a sub-hypergraph, particularly when $F$ belongs to certain minor-closed classes. Our methodology involves combinatorial decomposition techniques combined with eigenvalue estimates of associated graph operators, providing a novel framework for analyzing the density of sparse forbidden structures in dense hypergraphs. The results offer profound implications for extremal combinatorics, bridging structural properties of forbidden subgraphs with their asymptotic growth rates.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotic Turan Densities of Forbidden Hypergraph Configurations with Bounded Treewidth

text: We investigate the emergence of specific minor-closed graph properties within random subgraphs of dense host graphs, extending classic results from the $G(n,p)$ model. Let $H$ be a fixed graph, and consider a sequence of graphs $G_n$ with minimum degree $\delta(G_n) = \Omega(n)$. We determine sharp threshold functions for the property that a random subgraph $G_n(p)$, formed by retaining each edge of $G_n$ independently with probability $p$, contains $H$ as a minor. Our approach relies on a robust combination of the randomized absorption method and sophisticated concentration inequalities applied to graph decomposition properties. We demonstrate that for any fixed $H$, the threshold is typically $p \approx 1/\text{maxdeg}(G_n)$, provided $G_n$ is sufficiently pseudorandom. This work refines our understanding of connectivity and minor-containment in sparse random structures embedded within dense deterministic frameworks, offering critical insights into the resilience of structural properties under random deletion.
subject: Matematik
title: Sharp Thresholds for Minor Containment in Random Subgraphs of Dense Graphs

text: This research explores the interplay between spectral properties of graph products and their combinatorial invariants, particularly the chromatic number. We analyze the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of various graph products (Cartesian, strong, tensor, and lexicographical products) for both adjacency and Laplacian matrices. By developing a comprehensive spectral decomposition theory for these products, we derive novel bounds on the chromatic number $\chi(G \times H)$ in terms of the individual spectra of $G$ and $H$. Specifically, we show that the eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix of a Cartesian product $G \square H$ can be expressed as sums of eigenvalues of $G$ and $H$, which we leverage to refine existing upper bounds for $\chi(G \square H)$. Our work extends insights into spectral graph theory, providing a powerful algebraic framework for understanding complex graph structures and their colorability, with potential applications in network analysis and theoretical computer science.
subject: Matematik
title: Spectral Invariants of Graph Products and their Chromatic Properties

text: We present a rigorous study of $q$-analogs for several fundamental combinatorial identities, extending classical results from the theory of symmetric functions to their non-commutative counterparts. Utilizing a framework based on quasi-symmetric functions and their connection to non-commutative power series, we derive $q$-versions of identities related to Eulerian numbers, Stirling numbers of both kinds, and various partition enumeration problems. Our methodology involves the explicit construction of $q$-deformed generating functions that encode statistics such as inversions and major indices for permutations. Furthermore, we explore the relationship between these $q$-analogs and the representation theory of Hecke algebras, demonstrating how specialized representations yield known $q$-identities. This work provides a unified algebraic perspective on $q$-combinatorics, enriching the understanding of its deep connections to quantum groups and knot theory, and opening avenues for new discoveries in enumeration.
subject: Matematik
title: q-Analogs of Combinatorial Identities Arising from Non-commutative Symmetric Functions

text: This paper investigates the construction of novel asymmetric cryptographic designs through the lens of finite geometries, specifically projective planes over finite fields. We explore the structural properties of point-line incidence relations in $PG(2,q)$ and their generalizations to higher dimensions to derive block designs with optimal parameters for key distribution and secure multi-party computation. By exploiting specific collineation groups and their orbits on points and lines, we construct families of resolvable and affine designs, including new Steiner triple systems $S(2,3,v)$ with enhanced resilience to known attacks. Our method leverages algebraic number theory to characterize the automorphisms of these designs, which translates directly into the security strength of cryptographic schemes. This research provides a combinatorial foundation for designing robust and efficient cryptographic primitives, bridging abstract algebraic structures with practical applications in information security.
subject: Matematik
title: Finite Geometries and Constructing Optimal Asymmetric Cryptographic Designs

text: This work extends the theory of excluded minors for matroids, focusing on non-representable classes over various fields and particularly skew fields. We provide a comprehensive characterization of certain non-Pappus matroids by identifying a minimal set of excluded minors, thus extending the classical result for representability over $GF(q)$. Our approach involves a deep analysis of the internal structure of 3-connected matroids and their connection to projective geometries defined over skew fields, a domain less explored in mainstream matroid theory. We develop new techniques for manipulating matroids through generalized series-parallel operations and demonstrate how these operations preserve or modify representability. The findings elucidate the intricate relationships between combinatorial structures, algebraic representations, and geometric configurations, contributing significantly to the understanding of matroid connectivity and the representability problem in higher-order geometries.
subject: Matematik
title: Matroid Characterizations via Excluded Minors and Projective Geometries Over Skew Fields

text: This research establishes quantitative sum-product estimates for finite subsets of non-commutative rings, particularly in matrix algebras over finite fields and other non-abelian groups. We extend classical results from additive combinatorics, such as the sum-product phenomenon in $\mathbb{Z}_p$, to settings where commutativity is relaxed. Our methodology employs techniques from harmonic analysis on non-abelian groups, utilizing Fourier analysis and non-commutative analogues of convolution theorems. We derive explicit lower bounds for $\max(|A+A|, |A \cdot A|)$ where $A$ is a subset of $M_d(\mathbb{F}_q)$, showing a super-linear growth rate similar to the commutative case, but with constants depending on the dimension $d$. This work sheds new light on the interplay between additive and multiplicative structures in non-commutative algebraic settings, offering significant implications for pseudorandomness and expander graph constructions.
subject: Matematik
title: Quantitative Bounds for Sum-Product Estimates in Non-commutative Settings

text: We investigate the persistent homology of flag complexes associated with random graphs $G(n,p)$ at critical probabilities for various topological features. Focusing on the Vietoris-Rips complex and its higher-dimensional analogues, we analyze the birth and death of homology generators (cycles, voids) as the filtration parameter varies. Our principal contribution is to characterize the evolution of Betti numbers, particularly $\beta_1$ and $\beta_2$, near the component-wise and connectivity thresholds. Utilizing the multi-parameter persistence framework and probabilistic methods, we demonstrate that a robust 1-dimensional persistent homology signature emerges sharply around $p = c/n$ and persists, while higher-dimensional homology appears much later.
