This work provides new topological invariants for random graph models, offering deeper insights into the global structure and connectivity properties beyond traditional graph theory metrics.
subject: Matematik
title: Persistent Homology of Flag Complexes of Random Graphs at Critical Probabilities

text: This paper examines the parameterized complexity of various graph homomorphism problems, specifically focusing on cases where the input graph $G$ has a small treewidth modulator. We analyze the computational complexity of determining if there exists a homomorphism from $G$ to a fixed target graph $H$, when parameterized by the size of a vertex set $S$ such that $G-S$ has bounded treewidth. We introduce novel algorithms based on dynamic programming on tree decompositions combined with advanced techniques for handling the modulator. Our results establish new fixed-parameter tractable algorithms for several NP-hard homomorphism problems, significantly extending known boundaries of tractability. This research contributes to the theory of structural parameterization, offering practical approaches for solving intractable combinatorial problems by leveraging specific structural properties of the input graphs.
subject: Matematik
title: Parameterized Complexity of Graph Homomorphism Problems with Treewidth Modulators

text: This study delves into the combinatorial properties of reflexive polytopes and their connection to Ehrhart theory, particularly focusing on their $h^*$-vectors and lattice point enumeration. We establish new relationships between the face lattice structure of reflexive polytopes and the coefficients of their Ehrhart polynomials, extending existing results for Gorenstein cones. Our approach involves leveraging tools from algebraic geometry, specifically toric varieties associated with these polytopes, to derive novel inequalities and characterizations of their $h^*$-vectors. We demonstrate how the unimodality of the $h^*$-vector can be linked to specific geometric properties of the dual polytope. This work provides a deeper understanding of the interplay between combinatorial geometry and commutative algebra, with implications for integer programming, enumerative combinatorics, and mirror symmetry in string theory.
subject: Matematik
title: Combinatorial Polytopes and the Ehrhart Theory of Reflexive Polytopes

text: This work investigates the robust realization of fault-tolerant quantum computation via non-Abelian anyons, specifically focusing on Majorana zero modes engineered in proximitized semiconducting nanowires and fractional quantum Hall systems. We detail a comprehensive theoretical framework for encoding quantum information within topologically protected ground state degeneracies and explore the adiabatic braiding operations required for universal quantum gates. Emphasis is placed on protocols for mitigating decoherence by leveraging non-local correlations and minimizing susceptibility to local perturbations, a hallmark of topological order. Our analysis includes a novel scheme for measurement-only topological computation, outlining the requisite interferometric readout mechanisms and characterization of braiding statistics. Furthermore, we discuss the intricate interplay between disorder, interaction strength, and the topological gap, critically assessing the scalability challenges and prospects for experimental validation in contemporary solid-state platforms.
subject: Kuantum
title: Robust Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation via Non-Abelian Anyons in Topological Materials

text: We present a theoretical and numerical investigation into the emergent phenomena of Many-Body Localization (MBL) in one-dimensional disordered interacting fermionic systems, particularly focusing on the breakdown of thermalization and the persistence of local quantum information. Our analysis rigorously delineates the critical disorder strength separating the ergodic and MBL phases through entanglement entropy scaling, the growth of entanglement following a global quench, and the statistics of energy level spacing. We introduce a novel quasi-local conserved quantity formalism, demonstrating its efficacy in characterizing the non-ergodic dynamics and identifying the full set of local integrals of motion. Furthermore, we explore the role of rare-region effects and the phenomenon of 'quantum scars' within the MBL landscape, providing insights into the mechanisms that underpin the sub-ballistic spread of information and the implications for quantum memory applications. The implications for quantum thermalization and the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis are thoroughly discussed.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent Many-Body Localization in Disordered Interacting Fermionic Systems: Entanglement Dynamics and Conserved Quantities

text: This research advances the covariant dynamics of Loop Quantum Gravity, focusing on the interplay between spin network states and discrete spacetime geometries. We introduce a refined definition of the volume operator on arbitrary graphs, circumventing issues of non-uniqueness and degeneracy encountered in previous formulations, thereby facilitating a more robust quantization of geometric observables. Our framework leverages generalized holonomies and flux operators to construct a consistent kinematic Hilbert space, amenable to the imposition of the Hamiltonian constraint. We specifically investigate the derivation of the semi-classical regime, elucidating how classical geometries emerge from superpositions of discrete quantum states. Furthermore, we present a detailed analysis of black hole entropy within this quantized spacetime, demonstrating its proportionality to the horizon area and providing a microscopic derivation of the Immirzi parameter from consistency conditions. This work offers new avenues for resolving spacetime singularities and understanding the early universe within a background-independent quantum gravity theory.
subject: Kuantum
title: Covariant Dynamics and Black Hole Thermodynamics in Loop Quantum Gravity with Refined Geometric Operators

text: We explore the theoretical underpinnings and practical applications of Variational Quantum Algorithms (VQAs) within the paradigm of Quantum Machine Learning (QML), specifically focusing on their utility for solving complex optimization and classification problems on Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) devices. Our methodology centers on designing parameterized quantum circuits (PQCs) with optimal expressibility while mitigating the challenges posed by 'barren plateaus' in the loss landscape. We introduce a novel entanglement-enhanced feature mapping scheme for quantum kernel methods, demonstrating its superior capacity for separating non-linearly separable datasets in high-dimensional Hilbert spaces. Furthermore, we investigate the robustness of these algorithms against various noise models pertinent to contemporary quantum hardware, proposing adaptive error mitigation techniques tailored for VQAs. The potential for achieving quantum advantage in specific learning tasks, particularly in materials science and drug discovery, is critically assessed, providing a roadmap for developing robust and scalable QML architectures.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Advantage in Variational Quantum Algorithms: Mitigating Barren Plateaus with Entanglement-Enhanced Feature Maps

text: This study presents a comprehensive theoretical framework addressing the enigmatic mechanism of high-temperature superconductivity in cuprate materials, emphasizing the crucial role of strong electronic correlations and intertwined orders. We employ a rigorous projection operator technique within the framework of an extended t-J model to investigate the non-Fermi liquid behavior in the normal state and the emergence of d-wave superconducting pairing. Our analysis elucidates the intricate interplay between antiferromagnetic spin fluctuations, charge density waves, and the pseudogap phase, identifying quantum critical points that govern the phase diagram. We demonstrate how anomalous spectral functions and the momentum-dependent gap structure can be consistently derived, providing a unified explanation for experimental observations from angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) and tunneling measurements. The proposed mechanism offers a pathway to understanding exotic pairing symmetries and designing novel superconducting materials beyond the conventional BCS paradigm, highlighting the importance of Mott physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Strongly Correlated Electron Systems: A Projection Operator Approach to High-Tc Superconductivity in Cuprates

text: We investigate the generation and characterization of macroscopic quantum states in a novel cavity optomechanical system operating in the resolved-sideband regime, pushing the boundaries towards quantum-limited sensing and entanglement. Our experimental and theoretical analysis focuses on achieving the quantum ground state of a micro-mechanical resonator through robust feedback cooling and radiation-pressure coupling. We demonstrate the generation of ponderomotive squeezing of light, inferring the quantum correlations between optical and mechanical degrees of freedom, and exploring their utility for quantum non-demolition (QND) measurements of mechanical motion. Furthermore, we present a protocol for deterministically entangling two distant mechanical resonators via a common optical field, providing a pathway for distributed quantum information processing. The challenges associated with thermal decoherence and back-action evasion are critically addressed, paving the way for hybrid quantum systems where macroscopic oscillators serve as quantum memories or transducers in quantum networks.
subject: Kuantum
title: Macroscopic Quantum States and Entanglement in Resolved-Sideband Cavity Optomechanics

text: This work provides a rigorous re-examination of quantum contextuality as a fundamental resource for quantum information processing, transcending its traditional role as a mere indicator of non-classicality. We present an operational framework for quantifying state-dependent contextuality, extending the Kochen-Specker theorem to encompass generalized probabilistic theories and weak measurements. Our analysis rigorously delineates the boundaries between non-contextual hidden variable models and quantum mechanics, identifying novel classes of contextual inequalities violated by a broad range of quantum states, including those previously considered non-contextual under standard measurement paradigms. Furthermore, we explore the role of contextuality in measurement-based quantum computation, demonstrating its necessity for achieving universal computation in certain architectures. The implications for the measurement problem and the interpretation of quantum states are thoroughly discussed, proposing a contextuality-driven perspective on the emergence of objective reality from quantum interactions and the fundamental limits of classical simulation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Operationalizing Quantum Contextuality: Beyond Non-Classicality to a Resource for Quantum Computation

text: We report on the experimental realization and theoretical characterization of synthetic non-Abelian gauge fields for ultracold neutral atoms, opening unprecedented avenues for simulating exotic topological phases of matter. By employing precisely tuned Raman transitions in a rubidium-87 Bose-Einstein condensate trapped in an optical lattice, we engineer spatially varying spin-orbit coupling that mimics the Lorentz force experienced by charged particles in strong magnetic fields. Our methodology allows for independent control over the Abelian and non-Abelian components of the gauge potential, enabling the exploration of Chern insulating phases and the generation of artificial Landau levels. We present direct spectroscopic evidence for the induced energy bands and observe manifestations of the Hofstadter butterfly spectrum. The robustness of these synthetic fields against inhomogeneities and interatomic interactions is critically assessed, providing a blueprint for creating programmable quantum simulators to investigate fractional quantum Hall physics and quantum chromodynamics analogies.
subject: Kuantum
title: Engineering Synthetic Non-Abelian Gauge Fields in Ultracold Atomic Bose-Einstein Condensates for Topological Physics

text: This research systematically investigates the interplay between quantum entanglement and relativistic spacetime dynamics, focusing on the preservation and degradation of quantum correlations for observers in non-inertial frames. We employ relativistic quantum field theory to model entangled photon pairs exchanged between an inertial Alice and a uniformly accelerated Bob (Rindler observer), rigorously quantifying the Unruh effect's impact on Bell inequality violations. Our analysis reveals a monotonic decrease in entanglement and violations of Bell-type inequalities as Bob's acceleration increases, demonstrating a fundamental link between spacetime curvature (or acceleration) and quantum non-locality. Furthermore, we explore entanglement harvesting protocols in curved spacetimes, showing how vacuum fluctuations can be leveraged by causally disconnected detectors to establish quantum correlations. The work sheds light on the observer-dependent nature of entanglement and non-locality, offering profound insights into the foundational challenges of unifying quantum mechanics with general relativity in information-theoretic terms.
subject: Kuantum
title: Observer-Dependent Entanglement Degradation and Harvesting in Relativistic Quantum Information

text: We present a comprehensive theoretical and experimental blueprint for fault-tolerant quantum computation leveraging bosonic qubits encoded in higher-dimensional Hilbert spaces, specifically focusing on Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill (GKP) states and Schrödinger cat states. Our work details the realization of hardware-efficient error correction protocols designed to combat dominant bosonic error channels, such as photon loss and dephasing, by exploiting the continuous-variable nature of the underlying quantum system. We develop novel techniques for generating, manipulating, and non-destructively measuring these exotic bosonic states within superconducting microwave cavities, demonstrating their enhanced resilience against environmental noise compared to conventional two-level qubits. A key aspect is the design of passive error protection mechanisms intrinsic to the bosonic code, significantly reducing the active feedback requirements for quantum memory. The scalability challenges, including architectural considerations for large-scale error-corrected quantum processors and the integration of quantum control methods, are rigorously addressed, paving the way for truly fault-tolerant quantum computation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation with Bosonic Codes: Harnessing GKP and Cat States for Hardware-Efficient Error Correction

text: We present a theoretical framework for realizing fault-tolerant quantum computation leveraging non-Abelian anyonic excitations in highly frustrated spin systems. Our model exploits emergent topological order within a proposed two-dimensional lattice, where specific ground state degeneracies allow for robust encoding of quantum information. We detail braiding protocols for Majorana zero modes supported on superconducting vortices, demonstrating their non-Abelian statistics and immunity to local perturbations. The proposed architecture addresses critical challenges in decoherence by spatially separating quantum information from noise sources, inherently enabling error correction via topological protection. Furthermore, we analyze the feasibility of manipulating these anyons through engineered local perturbations and external magnetic fields, providing concrete pathways towards scalable, low-error quantum gate operations crucial for practical quantum computing paradigms.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Anyon Braiding for Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation in Frustrated Spin Systems

text: This work investigates the interplay between entanglement harvesting and the black hole information paradox, specifically within a de Sitter spacetime background. We explore how two initially uncorrelated Unruh-DeWitt detectors, interacting locally with a quantum scalar field, can extract shared entanglement. Our analysis reveals novel dependencies of the harvested entanglement on the cosmological constant and the entanglement wedge of the black hole horizon. By extending this framework to incorporate backreaction effects, we propose a holographic duality correspondence that suggests a possible resolution to the information paradox, where information seemingly lost within the event horizon is encoded in the asymptotic entanglement structure of the spacetime. This approach provides new insights into the semi-classical regime of quantum gravity and the nature of information conservation in extreme gravitational environments.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Harvesting and the Black Hole Information Paradox in De Sitter Spacetime

text: We theoretically and experimentally investigate the application of squeezed vacuum states and quantum nondemolition (QND) measurements to surpass the standard quantum limit in next-generation gravitational wave detectors. By injecting frequency-dependent squeezed vacuum into the signal port of a kilometer-scale interferometer, we demonstrate a significant reduction in quantum radiation pressure noise at low frequencies and shot noise at high frequencies, simultaneously. Our protocol integrates intracavity QND readout schemes, employing a detuned auxiliary cavity to measure one quadrature of the light field without disturbing the conjugate, thereby preserving the quantum coherence of the measurement. This approach promises a substantial improvement in strain sensitivity, crucial for detecting fainter astrophysical sources and pushing the observational frontier of gravitational wave astronomy beyond current limits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Enhanced Gravitational Wave Detection via Squeezed Vacuum Injection and Quantum Nondemolition Measurements

text: We present a comprehensive theoretical study of emergent fractionalization and topological order in doped two-dimensional Hubbard models augmented by strong spin-orbit coupling. Employing a combination of dynamical mean-field theory and variational Monte Carlo simulations, we identify exotic quantum phases exhibiting characteristics of fractionalized charge and spin excitations, analogous to those found in fractional quantum Hall systems. Specifically, we explore the phase diagram in regimes of intermediate Coulomb repulsion and Rashba-type spin-orbit interaction, uncovering evidence for a gapped topological spin liquid state with emergent U(1) gauge fields. Our findings suggest that tailored spin-orbit interactions can stabilize novel entangled states, offering new pathways for realizing unconventional superconductivity and robust quantum information processing within condensed matter systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent Fractionalization and Topological Order in Doped Hubbard Models with Spin-Orbit Coupling

text: This work explores the phenomenological implications of objective collapse models, such as the Continuous Spontaneous Localization (CSL) model, within the context of macroscopically large optomechanical resonators. We derive the modified Schrödinger equation incorporating CSL-induced stochastic and dissipative terms, predicting deviations from standard quantum mechanics in the coherence properties and spectral linewidths of mechanical modes. Specifically, we analyze the additional heating rate and decoherence timescale induced by the collapse mechanism, suggesting experimental benchmarks for probing the CSL parameters (e.g., collapse rate and localization length) using ultra-sensitive cryogenic optomechanical devices. Our calculations provide a concrete framework for distinguishing between quantum foundations interpretations through precision measurements on systems approaching the quantum-to-classical transition.
subject: Kuantum
title: Phenomenological Signatures of Objective Collapse Models in Optomechanical Systems

text: We propose a novel scheme for engineering synthetic non-Abelian SU(2) gauge fields in ultracold Bose-Einstein Condensates (BECs) using laser-dressing techniques and spatially dependent Raman coupling. By judiciously manipulating internal atomic states and their coupling to external magnetic field gradients, we demonstrate the generation of non-commutative vector potentials that mimic the dynamics of charged particles in complex gauge environments. This platform enables the quantum simulation of highly entangled topological phases, including analogs of non-Abelian anyons and novel Mott insulator states. We detail experimental protocols for preparing and probing these synthetic fields, outlining observables like persistent currents and spectral signatures indicative of topological winding numbers, thereby opening unprecedented avenues for exploring quantum field theories and exotic phases of matter in controllable atomic systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Engineering Synthetic Non-Abelian Gauge Fields in Ultracold Bose-Einstein Condensates for Topological Quantum Simulation

text: This paper presents a detailed architectural design and performance analysis for multi-node quantum repeater networks optimized for secure global quantum key distribution (QKD). We propose a hybrid repeater station incorporating long-lived atomic memories coupled to high-fidelity photonic interfaces, enabling entanglement distribution over intercontinental distances. Our analysis focuses on multiplexing strategies, including time-bin and frequency-mode encoding, to enhance key generation rates and reduce latency. We rigorously quantify the effects of channel loss, dark counts, and memory coherence times on the overall secret key rate and entanglement fidelity. Furthermore, we develop a comprehensive error correction and privacy amplification protocol tailored for entangled photon sources, demonstrating the feasibility of robust and scalable QKD networks essential for future quantum internet infrastructure.
subject: Kuantum
title: Architectural Design and Performance Analysis of Multi-Node Quantum Repeaters for Global Quantum Key Distribution

text: We report significant progress towards near-Heisenberg-limited ground state cooling of macroscopic mechanical resonators using advanced optomechanical sideband engineering. By coupling a MHz-frequency silicon nitride membrane to a high-finesse optical cavity and precisely tuning the laser drive frequency to the blue sideband, we achieve coherent energy exchange that effectively cools the mechanical mode. Our experimental results demonstrate a reduction of the mechanical occupation number to an average of \u00af\u00a0 < 0.5 quanta, pushing the system close to its quantum ground state. This work incorporates optimized detuning and feedback control protocols to mitigate back-action heating and achieve robust cooling. The achievement of near-ground-state preparation of macroscopic objects paves the way for observing quantum phenomena at unprecedented mass scales and developing ultra-sensitive quantum sensors.
subject: Kuantum
title: Near-Heisenberg-Limited Ground State Cooling of Macroscopic Mechanical Oscillators via Optomechanical Sideband Engineering

text: This study investigates two distinct experimental avenues for constraining quantum spacetime fluctuations and potential Lorentz invariance violation (LIV) arising from quantum gravity phenomenology. First, we analyze spectral and temporal dispersion of photons from distant ultra-high-energy gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), seeking signatures of energy-dependent photon velocities predicted by various LIV models. Second, we propose novel tabletop optomechanical experiments exploiting high-Q cavities to detect minute fluctuations in the refractive index of vacuum, hypothesized to arise from spacetime foam at the Planck scale. Our combined approach establishes stringent bounds on several canonical quantum gravity parameters, offering critical insights into the microscopic structure of spacetime and guiding theoretical developments beyond the Standard Model and general relativity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Constraining Quantum Spacetime Fluctuations with Ultra-High-Energy Gamma-Ray Bursts and Tabletop Optics

text: This paper investigates the Turan problem for linear k-uniform hypergraphs, specifically focusing on the asymptotic upper bounds for the maximum number of edges in a k-uniform hypergraph on n vertices that does not contain a specific linear configuration F. We generalize known results for F-free 2-graphs to the hypergraph setting, employing a novel combination of the Regularity Lemma for hypergraphs and sophisticated flag algebra techniques. Our primary contribution is a sharper upper bound for linear paths P_ell^(k) and cycles C_ell^(k) for various k, improving upon previous existential results derived from probabilistic methods. We also establish new connections between the Turan density of certain hypergraph configurations and the underlying structure of their linearizations, offering critical insights into the extremal properties of sparse hypergraphs and their intersection patterns. The analysis provides significant advancements in understanding the growth rate of ex(n, F) for complex linear uniformities.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Asymptotic Behavior of Hypergraph Turan Numbers for Linear Uniformities

text: We explore the Schur positivity of products of skew Macdonald polynomials P_{λ/μ}(x; q,t) and their connections to the representation theory of Hecke algebras and q-deformed cluster algebras. Our work establishes novel combinatorial interpretations for coefficients arising from such products when expanded in the Schur basis, utilizing extended crystal graph theory and non-symmetric Macdonald polynomials. We present a conjecture regarding the positivity criterion based on the relative shapes of partitions λ and μ, supported by extensive computational evidence and specific cases related to LLT polynomials. Furthermore, we develop a new family of q,t-analogues of generalized Littlewood-Richardson coefficients, demonstrating their role in the structural properties of these polynomial rings. This research offers deeper insights into the combinatorial intricacies of symmetric function theory and provides a powerful framework for addressing positivity problems in related algebraic structures, particularly those arising from quantum group theory.
subject: Matematik
title: Schur Positivity of Products of Skew Macdonald Polynomials and q-Deformed Cluster Algebras

text: This study investigates the emergence of monotone properties in random graph processes defined on underlying expander graphs, departing from the standard Erdős-Rényi model. We establish sharp threshold functions for a class of graph properties, including connectivity and the existence of large cliques, when edges are added stochastically to a given d-regular expander graph G_0. Leveraging Martingale difference methods and sophisticated concentration inequalities tailored for dependent processes, we demonstrate that the transition width for these properties is significantly narrower than in classical random graph settings, exhibiting a double logarithmic dependency on n. Our findings highlight how the high connectivity and spectral gap of the underlying expander G_0 critically influence the concentration of random subgraphs, providing a nuanced understanding of phase transitions in constrained random structures. This work offers crucial insights for robust network design and the analysis of fault tolerance in high-dimensional expanders.
subject: Matematik
title: Sharp Thresholds for Monotone Properties in Random Graph Processes on Expanders

text: We present a comprehensive analysis of the facial structure of generalized matroid base polytopes, focusing on their utility in robust combinatorial optimization. Our primary contribution involves characterizing novel classes of facets derived from specific matroid minors and their associated submodular functions, extending the foundational work by Edmonds. We develop a systematic procedure for generating valid inequalities that define the convex hull of solutions for problems like the minimum weight basis problem under uncertain edge costs. This characterization provides a tighter linear programming relaxation, significantly improving the performance of exact algorithms. Furthermore, we explore connections between the affine dependence of matroid bases and the existence of "robust" optimal solutions, offering a polyhedral perspective on sensitivity analysis. The insights gained are critical for developing more efficient algorithms for a broad range of matroid-constrained optimization problems arising in network design and resource allocation.
subject: Matematik
title: Facial Structure of Matroid Polytopes and Robust Combinatorial Optimization

text: This research presents novel bijective proofs for generalizations of the classical hook length formula, specifically applied to various q-analogues of Catalan numbers and their extensions to arbitrary root systems. We establish explicit bijections between weighted sets of Dyck paths (or more generally, lattice paths in restricted regions) and specific configurations of partitions with particular hook statistics. Our method introduces a new concept of "active hook decompositions" that directly links path dynamics to the q-enumerative coefficients. We resolve several open questions concerning the combinatorial interpretation of q,t-Catalan numbers and their connections to parking functions and (m,n)-cores. The techniques developed provide a unified framework for deriving q-analogues of combinatorial identities, offering deeper structural insights into the recurrence relations and generating functions governing these fundamental sequences. This work advances the field of enumerative combinatorics by providing powerful tools for proving complex identities.
subject: Matematik
title: Bijective Proofs for Generalized Hook Length Formulas in q-Catalan Numbers and Dyck Paths

text: We investigate the incidence geometry of high-dimensional convex polytopes, focusing on generalizations of Hadwiger's theorem to discrete settings and the characterization of f-vectors for specific classes of centrally symmetric polytopes. Our work establishes new bounds on the number of incidences between k-faces and j-faces (k < j) for various families of regular and semi-regular polytopes, utilizing techniques from combinatorial topology and algebraic geometry. We introduce a novel concept of "incidence rigidity" and prove that certain face-lattice structures uniquely determine the underlying polytope class up to affine equivalence. Furthermore, we develop a discrete analogue of Minkowski sums for polytopes, leading to new insights into the behavior of their mixed volumes and the structure of their face complexes. This research provides a fundamental advancement in understanding the combinatorial complexity and geometric properties of high-dimensional discrete objects, with implications for geometric packing and optimization.
subject: Matematik
title: Incidence Geometry of High-Dimensional Polytopes and Discrete Hadwiger's Theorem Analogs

text: This paper explores the homotopy type of independence complexes −Ind(G) for graphs G with bounded treewidth. We establish a comprehensive framework for computing the homology groups and Betti numbers of −Ind(G) by leveraging a novel recursive decomposition technique based on tree decompositions of G. Our main result demonstrates that for graphs with treewidth at most k, the independence complex −Ind(G) is (k-1)-connected, improving existing bounds and providing a finer understanding of its topological structure. We further show that for certain classes of graphs (e.g., partial k-trees), the independence complex has a surprisingly simple homotopy type, often retracting onto a wedge of spheres or a single point. This analysis provides critical insights into the interplay between graph structural parameters and the topological properties of their associated simplicial complexes, offering new tools for studying chromatic numbers and maximum independent sets from a topological perspective.
subject: Matematik
title: Homotopy Type of Independence Complexes of Graphs with Bounded Treewidth

text: This research presents improved bounds for the size of k-fold sumsets kA = {a_1 + … + a_k : a_i ∈ A} within finite non-abelian groups G, extending classical results from commutative settings. We employ a generalized non-commutative Fourier analysis combined with sophisticated probabilistic arguments and incidence geometry techniques. Our methodology involves adapting the sum-product phenomenon to the non-abelian context, circumventing limitations of standard Freiman-type theorems. Specifically, we establish a new lower bound for |kA| in terms of |A| and the group's structure, which is sharper than previously known results for groups with small commutator subgroups. The analysis also explores the density of A and its impact on the expansion rate of kA, providing crucial insights into the growth of sets under addition in non-commutative environments. This work contributes significantly to additive combinatorics, opening new avenues for research in non-abelian analogues of Sidon sets and arithmetic progressions.
subject: Matematik
title: Improved Bounds for k-Fold Sumsets in Non-Abelian Groups via Fourier Analysis

text: This paper investigates the existence and classification of large sets of Steiner systems S(t, k, v), denoted LS[N](t, k, v), with a particular emphasis on constructing these designs under the constraint of a prescribed automorphism group G. We develop a novel algebraic method leveraging representation theory of finite groups and computational search algorithms for finding invariant subspaces that correspond to the block structure. Our primary result establishes new existence conditions for LS[N](t, k, v) for specific parameters (t, k, v) when G acts transitively on points or blocks. We present the first known construction of an LS[2](2, 3, 13) possessing a cyclic automorphism group of order 13, settling a long-standing open problem. This research provides significant advancements in the theory of combinatorial designs, offering new techniques for constructing and classifying these fundamental structures, and deepening the understanding of their symmetry properties.
subject: Matematik
title: Existence of Large Set Steiner Systems S(t, k, v) with Prescribed Automorphism Groups

text: We establish novel decomposition theorems for classes of matroids that exclude a fixed minor representable over a finite field and also embeddable on a projective plane. Building upon the seminal work of Robertson and Seymour for graphs, we develop a matroid-theoretic analogue of tree-width decomposition, termed "projective-width," which characterizes the structural complexity of these classes. Our main theorem proves that any such matroid can be recursively decomposed into simpler matroids, each of which is either "small" or has a highly constrained planar structure, often involving configurations related to wheels or whirls. This decomposition facilitates the algorithmic solution of various matroid problems, including finding minimum weight bases and testing for specific minor containment, in polynomial time for these restricted classes. This research significantly advances the understanding of the structural theory of matroids and provides powerful tools for analyzing minor-closed classes with topological constraints.
subject: Matematik
title: Decomposition Theorems for Matroids Excluding a Fixed Minor on a Projective Plane

text: This paper addresses the critical problem of valid post-selection inference in high-dimensional sparse Generalized Linear Models (GLMs). We propose a novel debiased estimator that leverages an initial sparse estimator, derived from penalized likelihood methods (e.g., SCAD or MCP), followed by a data-splitting technique to construct asymptotically normal and efficient confidence intervals for individual regression coefficients. Our theoretical analysis establishes that these debiased estimators achieve minimax optimal rates under specific regularity conditions concerning sparsity and design matrix properties. Unlike existing methods, our approach rigorously accounts for the selection bias inherent in penalized estimation, providing uniformly valid inferential statements. Extensive simulations demonstrate the superior finite-sample coverage properties and reduced bias compared to naive post-Lasso inference or standard non-debiased methods, highlighting its practical utility in various scientific domains requiring reliable high-dimensional inference.
subject: İstatistik
title: Minimax Optimal Rates for Debiased Estimators in High-Dimensional Sparse Generalized Linear Models

text: We introduce a novel Dependent Dirichlet Process Mixture Model (DDPMM) specifically designed for the complex analysis of heterogeneous panel data, where both within-subject dynamics and between-subject variability are paramount. The proposed DDPMM extends standard nonparametric mixture models by incorporating covariate-dependent concentration parameters and atom distributions within a hierarchical framework, allowing for adaptive cluster formation and evolution of subpopulation structures over time or across different observational units. This intrinsic flexibility mitigates strong parametric assumptions, capturing intricate patterns of heterogeneity. We develop an efficient blocked Gibbs sampler for posterior inference, providing robust estimation of subject-specific latent structures. Extensive empirical evaluations on simulated and real-world econometric datasets demonstrate the model's superior performance in capturing evolving subpopulation dynamics and improved predictive accuracy compared to fixed-parameter or simpler nonparametric approaches.
subject: İstatistik
title: A Novel Dependent Dirichlet Process Mixture Model for Heterogeneous Panel Data

text: This paper presents a robust methodology for estimating optimal dynamic treatment regimes (DTRs) from observational data, explicitly accounting for time-varying and high-dimensional confounders. We develop an integrated approach combining G-computation and Targeted Maximum Likelihood Estimation (TMLE), enhanced by modern machine learning algorithms, specifically Super Learner, for nuisance parameter estimation. This strategy ensures double robustness, providing consistent and asymptotically normal estimates of the optimal DTR policy value even if one of the nuisance models (e.g., treatment mechanism or outcome regression) is misspecified. Our theoretical contributions establish uniform convergence rates and efficient influence function properties under semi-parametric settings. Through extensive simulations and an application to real-world health intervention data, we demonstrate the proposed method's superior efficiency and reduced bias compared to single-robust or purely parametric methods, offering profound implications for personalized medicine.
subject: İstatistik
title: Doubly Robust Inference for Dynamic Treatment Regimes via G-Computation and Targeted Maximum Likelihood Estimation with High-Dimensional Confounders

text: This research proposes a novel nonparametric methodology for robustly estimating extreme tail risk measures, such as Value-at-Risk (VaR) and Expected Shortfall (ES), crucial for financial risk management in markets exhibiting heavy tails and potential data contamination. We introduce an adaptive kernel density estimator (AKDE) that employs a data-driven, local bandwidth selection mechanism and integrates a robust M-estimator framework to downweight anomalous observations. This dual approach significantly enhances the estimator's resistance to outliers and model misspecification in the tails. Theoretical analysis establishes the consistency and asymptotic normality of the proposed AKDE-based VaR and ES estimators under general conditions, demonstrating improved efficiency and reduced sensitivity to noise compared to standard parametric or fixed-bandwidth nonparametric methods. Empirical results on synthetic and real financial data validate its superior performance in accurately quantifying extreme risks.
subject: İstatistik
title: Nonparametric Robust Estimation of Tail Risk Measures via Adaptive Kernel Density Estimators

text: We address the intricate problem of inferring spatio-temporal Granger causality within high-dimensional functional time series, where observations are continuum-valued functions. Our methodology extends regularized vector autoregressive (VAR) models to the functional domain, incorporating sparsity-inducing penalties (e.g., grouped Lasso or sparse group Lasso) to identify intricate lead-lag relationships and significant functional predictors across spatially distinct units. This Functional Regularized VAR (F-VAR) framework effectively handles both functional data complexities and high-dimensionality. We establish theoretical consistency guarantees for support recovery and prediction accuracy under varying sparsity regimes and demonstrate the efficacy of our approach through extensive simulations and real-world neuroimaging data analysis. The F-VAR provides interpretable insights into dynamic functional connectivity patterns, offering a powerful tool for complex spatio-temporal causal inference.
subject: İstatistik
title: Spatio-Temporal Granger Causality Inference in High-Dimensional Functional Time Series via Regularized Vector Autoregressive Models

text: This work introduces a novel deep kernel learning framework for distribution regression, a challenging task where inputs are probability measures rather than point vectors. We leverage Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space (RKHS) embeddings, such as the Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD), to robustly transform complex distribution inputs into feature representations suitable for deep learning architectures. The proposed framework then employs a multi-layer perceptron to learn a flexible, data-driven kernel function, effectively capturing intricate, non-linear relationships between input distributions and target outputs. We provide theoretical convergence guarantees for the proposed estimator under appropriate regularity conditions and empirically demonstrate its superior performance on synthetic and real-world datasets, including ecological and neuroimaging applications, outperforming traditional fixed-kernel distribution regression methods in both accuracy and generalization.
subject: İstatistik
title: Deep Kernel Learning for Distribution Regression with Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space Embeddings

text: We propose a flexible Bayesian nonparametric hierarchical model for areal data, designed to address spatial heterogeneity in disease mapping and environmental epidemiology. Our approach integrates spatially varying coefficients, modeled through a Dirichlet Process mixture of regressions, which allows for adaptive clustering of regions with similar covariate effects while accommodating local non-stationarity. This framework provides robust uncertainty quantification for local parameter estimates, crucial for targeted interventions. We develop an efficient Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm for posterior inference and demonstrate its utility in identifying high-risk areas and understanding localized risk factor associations. Empirical evaluations reveal superior performance over fixed-coefficient spatial models and standard hierarchical approaches in terms of both predictive accuracy and the interpretability of spatial covariate effects, offering granular insights into public health disparities.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Nonparametric Hierarchical Modeling for Areal Data with Spatially Varying Coefficients and Disease Mapping Applications

text: This paper develops a comprehensive framework for causal mediation analysis in time-to-event outcomes, particularly in the presence of competing risks and a high-dimensional set of potential mediators. We extend existing counterfactual approaches by explicitly integrating multi-state models to account for competing events and employ dimension reduction techniques (e.g., targeted regularization) for mediator selection. Our method provides consistent and asymptotically normal estimates for natural direct and indirect effects under sequential ignorability assumptions, even with a large number of mediators. Theoretical properties, including consistency and asymptotic linearity of the estimators, are established. Empirical evaluations using simulated and real clinical trial data demonstrate the method's capability to disentangle complex causal pathways, offering profound insights into the mechanisms underlying intervention effects and disease progression.
subject: İstatistik
title: Causal Mediation Analysis for Time-to-Event Data with Competing Risks and High-Dimensional Mediators

text: We introduce a novel sparse Functional Principal Component Analysis (FPCA) methodology specifically tailored for irregularly sampled, sparse longitudinal data, commonly encountered in electronic health records or wearable sensor studies. Traditional FPCA methods often struggle with high levels of missingness and non-uniform sampling schedules, leading to unstable or uninterpretable functional components. Our approach regularizes the functional principal components (FPCs) via a combined roughness penalty (e.g., spline-based) and an L1-type penalty, promoting both smoothness and sparsity in the estimated FPCs and their corresponding eigenvalues. This enhances interpretability and statistical efficiency by identifying core functional variations. We provide theoretical guarantees for consistency and optimality under reasonable assumptions and demonstrate superior performance in recovering underlying functional structures compared to conventional FPCA techniques in simulation studies and real data applications.
subject: İstatistik
title: Sparse Functional Principal Component Analysis for Irregularly Sampleed Longitudinal Data

text: This paper addresses the challenging problem of learning high-dimensional Gaussian Graphical Models (GGMs) in the presence of unobserved latent confounding variables, a prevalent issue in biological and social networks. We propose a novel framework that leverages conditional independence testing on observed variables to infer the latent structure and subsequently reconstruct the conditional independence graph among observed variables. Our method avoids direct estimation of the high-dimensional inverse covariance matrix, which is highly sensitive to latent confounders and prone to spurious associations. We establish theoretical guarantees for consistent edge recovery and latent variable identification under specified sparsity assumptions. Extensive simulations and a gene regulatory network analysis demonstrate the method's robustness and accuracy compared to existing GGM selection techniques that neglect latent variables, providing a powerful tool for disentangling complex dependencies.
subject: İstatistik
title: High-Dimensional Gaussian Graphical Model Selection with Latent Variables via Conditional Independence Testing

text: This study introduces a novel computational framework for robust, real-time inference of dynamic tonality in complex polyphonic audio streams. We propose a Riemannian geometric model for pitch-class distributions, enabling the representation of tonal centers as points within a higher-dimensional manifold, where melodic and harmonic progressions correspond to geodesic paths. Spectral flux and onset detection algorithms segment the audio into perceptually salient events, from which enhanced pitch-class profiles are extracted using a chromagram derived from a constant-Q transform. A hidden Markov model, informed by expert-derived functional harmonic priors and optimized via Expectation-Maximization, then traverses this geometric space to infer local and global tonal trajectories. Validation against a diverse corpus of Western art music demonstrates significantly improved F-measure scores for key estimation compared to state-of-the-art chroma-based methods, offering profound implications for computational musicology and intelligent music information retrieval systems requiring nuanced tonal understanding.
subject: Müzik
title: A Geometrical Framework for Dynamic Tonality Inference in Polyphonic Audio Streams

text: This research presents an innovative spectro-temporal decomposition methodology specifically tailored for the analysis of microtonal intonation in monophonic and sparse polyphonic audio. Moving beyond standard equal-temperament assumptions, our approach leverages a modified phase vocoder coupled with high-resolution sinusoidal modeling, enabling precise tracking of fundamental frequencies and their overtone structures at sub-cent resolution. A novel adaptive windowing function, informed by real-time signal entropy, minimizes spectral smearing while maximizing temporal precision, critical for capturing subtle pitch inflections characteristic of non-Western and experimental microtonal practices. Psychoacoustic experiments corroborate the perceptual salience of the extracted microtonal deviations, correlating with expert musical judgments. This framework provides an unprecedented level of granularity for ethnomusicological studies, advanced performance analysis, and the development of expressive synthesis algorithms capable of replicating intricate microtonal nuances.
subject: Müzik
title: Towards a Granular Spectro-Temporal Decomposition for Microtonal Intonation Analysis

text: This paper introduces Deep Self-Similarity Networks (DSN) for unsupervised, hierarchical musical form segmentation directly from unannotated audio recordings. Our method builds upon the traditional self-similarity matrix, augmenting its capabilities through a multi-scale convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture designed to learn robust structural relationships across varying temporal granularities. By processing recurrence plots derived from rhythmically-enhanced chroma features, the DSN identifies thematic repetitions, variations, and contrasts at both local (phrase, section) and global (form part) levels. The architecture incorporates attentional mechanisms to prioritize perceptually salient structural boundaries, demonstrating superior performance in benchmark datasets of classical and popular music compared to existing algorithms relying solely on low-level audio features or extensive meta-data. This work offers a significant advance in automated music analysis, facilitating large-scale structural studies and enhancing content-based music retrieval.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Self-Similarity Networks for Hierarchical Musical Form Segmentation in Unannotated Audio

text: We propose a novel framework for modeling perceptual timbre space using multiplex network analysis of high-dimensional audio features. Unlike traditional dimensionality reduction techniques, this approach constructs multiple layers of similarity graphs, each derived from distinct psychoacoustically-informed feature sets (e.g., Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients, spectral flux, zero-crossing rate, spectral centroid, harmonic richness). Inter-layer connections are established based on shared musical contexts or temporal co-occurrence, creating a robust, multi-faceted representation of timbral relationships. Topological data analysis, specifically persistent homology, is applied to characterize the intrinsic geometric and connectivity patterns within this multiplex network, revealing underlying perceptual clusters and continuous gradients that correlate strongly with human judgments of timbral similarity. This methodology offers a more nuanced understanding of timbral perception, with applications in intelligent instrument classification, expressive audio synthesis, and musicological studies of orchestration.
subject: Müzik
title: A Multiplex Network Approach to Perceptual Timbre Space Modeling from Audio Features

text: This research presents a novel cross-modal approach to robust meter and beat tracking in musical audio, employing an adversarial generative network (AGN) for learning disentangled rhythmic representations. The AGN is trained on paired audio and symbolic music (MIDI/score) data, projecting both modalities into a shared latent space where rhythmic patterns are encoded irrespective of timbre or melodic content. The generator learns to synthesize plausible rhythmic sequences from latent vectors, while the discriminator evaluates their authenticity, forcing the network to capture essential metric properties. A subsequent recurrent neural network (RNN) analyzes the rhythmically-embedded audio features to predict beat and downbeat positions with high temporal precision. This method demonstrates significantly improved resilience to polyrhythmic complexity and varied instrumentation compared to purely audio-driven methods, offering advancements for automatic transcription, performance analysis, and interactive music systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Rhythmic Embedding for Meter and Beat Tracking Using Adversarial Generative Networks

text: This study explores the application of advanced harmonic-percussive source separation (HPSS) techniques, specifically those employing sparse coding and non-negative matrix factorization (NMF), to enhance traditional music theoretical analysis. By explicitly separating harmonic and percussive components from complex polyphonic audio, we aim to overcome common ambiguities in pitch and rhythm extraction. The harmonic layer is then subjected to detailed pitch-class profiling and functional harmonic analysis, revealing diatonic tendencies and modulatory schemes with greater clarity. Concurrently, the percussive layer facilitates highly accurate onset detection and rhythmic pattern extraction, allowing for precise quantification of syncopation and metric deviation. Our results, validated against a corpus of diverse musical genres, demonstrate that this refined source separation significantly improves the efficacy of automated diatonic analysis and quantitative rhythmic studies, providing a clearer sonic substrate for musicological inquiry.
subject: Müzik
title: Harmonic-Percussive Source Separation with Sparse Coding for Diatonic and Rhythmic Analysis

text: We present a novel multimodal deep learning architecture for robust music emotion recognition (MER), explicitly integrating theoretically-grounded musical features with raw audio spectro-temporal representations. Our framework employs a dual-stream recurrent neural network (RNN) with cross-attention mechanisms. One stream processes low-level audio features (e.g., MFCCs, spectral contrast) and their temporal dynamics, while the other analyzes high-level music theoretical descriptors such as chord progression complexity, tension indices, rhythmic density, and tonal ambiguity derived from computational music theory algorithms. A late-fusion mechanism then combines these streams, allowing the network to leverage both acoustic properties and abstract musical structure for emotion prediction within the valence-arousal space. Empirical validation on large-scale annotated datasets reveals significant performance gains over purely audio-based or feature-engineered approaches, underscoring the critical role of theoretical insight in developing more perceptually aligned MER systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Bridging Affective Computing and Music Theory: A Multimodal Fusion Network for Music Emotion Recognition

text: This study introduces a variational autoencoder (VAE) approach to model and explore the latent harmonic spaces inherent in large corpora of Western tonal music. The VAE is trained on symbolic chord progressions, learning a compact, continuous representation where semantically similar harmonic sequences are clustered. By manipulating points within this latent space, we can generate novel, theoretically plausible chord progressions and analyze the "distances" and "paths" between different harmonic regions, revealing underlying grammatical structures. The encoder component provides a data-driven method for analyzing harmonic complexity and ambiguity in existing compositions, while the decoder facilitates the generation of musically coherent continuations conditioned on specific theoretical constraints (e.g., maintaining diatonicism, modulating to a related key, adhering to voice-leading principles). This framework offers a powerful tool for computational music theory, hypothesis testing, and interactive music composition.
subject: Müzik
title: Variational Autoencoders for Exploring Latent Harmonic Spaces and Generating Tonal Continuations

text: This research presents a comprehensive spatio-temporal acoustic scene analysis framework for understanding orchestral performance dynamics, integrating advanced audio signal processing with musicological perspectives. Utilizing multi-channel microphone array recordings, our system employs a combination of blind source separation and deep learning-based source localization techniques (e.g., GCC-PHAT features fed into a CNN with attention) to precisely map the positions and movements of individual instrumental sections within the soundstage. Dynamic changes in ensemble balance, inter-section phase coherence, and spatial spread are then quantified over time. This methodology provides unprecedented insights into historical performance practices, real-time acoustical properties of concert halls, and the nuanced interplay of instrumental groups, enabling objective evaluation of orchestration effectiveness and performance interpretation, bridging the gap between sonic data and musical meaning.
subject: Müzik
title: Spatio-Temporal Acoustic Scene Analysis for Orchestral Source Localization and Ensemble Dynamics

text: This study systematically explores the derivation and perceptual salience of 'hyperdiatonic' scales, specifically focusing on Lydian extensions generated through iterative application of specific interval cycles beyond the traditional circle of fifths. Employing computational methods rooted in pitch-class set theory and interval vector analysis, we formalize the construction of these complex scalar structures, assessing their internal coherence and harmonic implications. A series of psychoacoustic experiments, utilizing synthesized stimuli embodying these scales in melodic and harmonic contexts, evaluates listeners' perception of consonance, stability, and tonal gravity. Our findings suggest that certain computationally derived Lydian extensions exhibit a remarkable degree of perceptual integration, challenging conventional notions of diatonicity and offering novel insights into the psychoacoustics of extended tonality. This work opens avenues for theoretical exploration of non-standard pitch organizations and their potential for musical expression.
subject: Müzik
title: Computational Derivations and Perceptual Validation of Hyperdiatonic Scales: An Exploration of Lydian Extensions

text: This study employs whole-genome sequencing and coalescent-based phylogenomic analyses to disentangle the complex evolutionary history of the *Dendrobates* poison dart frog clade, a putative adaptive radiation characterized by substantial phenotypic variation but ambiguous species boundaries. Our analyses reveal extensive genomic introgression and evidence of reticulate evolution, challenging traditional bifurcating species tree models. Multi-species coalescent methods identify multiple instances of cryptic speciation within morphologically uniform populations, driven by allopatric fragmentation and subsequent secondary contact with limited gene flow. Demographic inference further elucidates asymmetric introgression patterns, suggesting differential fitness costs associated with genomic admixture. These findings underscore the pervasive role of genomic exchange in shaping lineage divergence and highlight the limitations of morphology-centric species delimitation in rapidly evolving systems.
subject: Evrim
title: Reticulate Evolution and Cryptic Speciation within the *Dendrobates* 'Poison Dart Frog' Complex Inferred via Whole-Genome Phylogenomics

text: The remarkable morphological diversity of crustacean appendages is a classic example of evolutionary innovation, yet the underlying genetic mechanisms remain largely unresolved. Here, we investigate the cis-regulatory evolution of *Hox* gene clusters across a phylogenetically diverse crustacean lineage using ATAC-seq and CRISPR-Cas9 reporter assays. Our findings demonstrate significant divergence in the spatial and temporal activity of *Hox* cis-regulatory elements (CREs), particularly in response to *Ubx* and *Abd-A* paralogs. We identify novel CREs that modulate the combinatorial expression profiles of these transcription factors, leading to distinct patterns of appendage segment identity and differentiation. Comparative genomics reveals that micro-chromosomal rearrangements and transposable element insertions have contributed to the birth and modification of these regulatory modules, uncoupling pleiotropic *Hox* gene functions and facilitating independent morphological evolution. This mechanistic insight underscores the profound impact of GRN plasticity on macroevolutionary transitions.
subject: Evrim
title: Cis-Regulatory Evolution of *Hox* Genes Underpins Diversification of Appendage Morphology in Crustaceans

text: The intricate fig-wasp interaction represents a dynamic coevolutionary mosaic, simultaneously involving mutualistic pollination and antagonistic seed predation. We present a comprehensive genomic analysis of *Ficus carica* and its pollinator-*Pegoscapus* sp. alongside a non-pollinating parasitic wasp *Idarnes* sp., to discern signatures of antagonistic coevolution. Population genomics reveals elevated dN/dS ratios and specific selective sweeps in host defense genes (e.g., chitinases, protease inhibitors) and corresponding virulence factors in both wasp species. Notably, *Pegoscapus* exhibits genomic regions under balancing selection associated with host recognition and oviposition strategies, distinct from the broader virulence determinants observed in *Idarnes*. This suggests a Red Queen dynamic driving rapid, reciprocal adaptation in a complex multi-species interaction. Our findings provide molecular evidence for fine-tuned coevolutionary trajectories, where mutualistic partners also engage in subtle arms races, shaping the genomic architecture of species interactions.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Antagonistic Coevolution and Red Queen Dynamics in a Fig-Wasp Mutualism-Antagonism Continuum

text: Cichlid fishes of the African Great Lakes epitomize adaptive radiation, displaying unparalleled ecomorphological diversification. This study integrates high-density genomic sequencing with detailed morphometric analyses across sympatric species pairs of *Haplochromis* cichlids from Lakes Victoria and Tanganyika, to investigate patterns of convergent and parallel evolution. We identify recurrent genomic regions under positive selection, particularly those associated with craniofacial development, trophic apparatus morphology, and sensory perception (e.g., opsins), that underlie convergent ecomorphs adapted to distinct dietary niches. Despite independent origins, these parallel genetic changes often involve orthologous genes and even shared non-coding regulatory regions, suggesting a finite number of 'evolutionary avenues' for adaptation. Our findings highlight the predictive power of ecological opportunity in channeling evolutionary trajectories, demonstrating that similar ecological pressures can lead to predictable genomic and phenotypic outcomes even across geographically distinct and independently radiating lineages.
subject: Evrim
title: Ecomorphological Convergence and Parallel Genomic Adaptation During Cichlid Adaptive Radiation in African Rift Lakes

text: Halophilic archaea, inhabiting extreme hypersaline environments, exhibit remarkable metabolic versatility, largely attributed to their fluid genomic architecture. This study elucidates the role of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) in shaping the pangenome and facilitating metabolic innovation within the genus *Haloarcula*. Comparative genomics of 20 *Haloarcula* species reveals a highly open pangenome, with approximately 60% of gene families acquired via HGT events from diverse bacterial and archaeal donors. Phylogenetic incongruence analyses coupled with functional annotation identify extensive HGT of genes encoding novel osmoregulation mechanisms, xenobiotic degradation pathways, and photosynthetic pigments. These acquisitions provide significant fitness advantages in fluctuating osmotic and trophic conditions. Our results underscore HGT as a primary driver of adaptive evolution in prokaryotic extremophiles, enabling rapid exploitation of novel ecological niches and contributing disproportionately to the functional expansion of their accessory genomes.
subject: Evrim
title: Pangenome Dynamics and Metabolic Innovation Driven by Horizontal Gene Transfer in Hypersaline-Adapted Halobacteria

text: The debate between punctuated equilibrium and gradualism in macroevolutionary patterns remains central to paleontology. This investigation employs geometric morphometrics on a high-resolution, stratigraphically constrained fossil series of planktonic foraminifera (*Globigerinoides ruber*) spanning the Neogene period (23 to 2.6 Ma) from deep-sea cores. Multivariate analyses of shell morphology reveal prolonged periods of morphological stasis interspersed with rapid, geologically instantaneous shifts in phenotypic space. Quantitative comparison of rates of evolutionary change indicates that ~80% of total morphological variation accumulates during these punctuational events, which frequently correlate with periods of major climatic perturbation or oceanographic reorganization. Conversely, gradualistic trends, when observed, are typically confined to intraspecific variation and do not contribute significantly to long-term directional evolution. This nuanced perspective highlights that both modes of evolution operate, with punctuated stasis being the dominant mode driving species-level morphological differentiation over geological timescales.
subject: Evrim
title: Quantifying Stasis and Directional Change in the Fossil Record: A High-Resolution Morphometric Analysis of Neogene Foraminifera

text: Extravagant sexual ornaments are costly signals of male quality, but the genomic basis and evolutionary maintenance of their honesty remain debated. This study investigates the costs and benefits of multimodal sexual signals (plumage coloration, tail length, and display intensity) in red-collared widowbirds (*Euplectes ardens*), a classic example of sexual selection. Transcriptomic analyses of gonadal and integumentary tissues reveal suites of genes associated with immune function, metabolic efficiency, and oxidative stress that are differentially regulated in males expressing larger ornaments. Experimental manipulation of parasite load and nutritional intake demonstrates condition-dependent signal expression, consistent with the handicap principle. Furthermore, we identify genetic correlations between signal expression and male viability via quantitative trait loci mapping, suggesting pleiotropic effects linking signal production to overall genetic quality. Our findings provide a genomic framework for understanding the maintenance of honest sexual signaling in nature.
subject: Evrim
title: Multimodal Sexual Signals as Condition-Dependent Handicaps: A Genomic and Experimental Analysis in *Euplectes* Weavers

text: Adaptation to extreme environmental conditions, such as high-altitude hypoxia, often involves complex polygenic architectures. We conducted a comprehensive population genomic analysis of the Andean hummingbird *Oreotrochilus estella* across an elevational gradient (2,500-5,000 m a.s.l.) to identify genomic regions underlying adaptation to hypoxia. Using genotype-environment association methods and phenotypic assays for hypoxia tolerance (e.g., hemoglobin-oxygen affinity, mitochondrial efficiency), we reveal a highly polygenic basis for adaptation, with numerous small-effect loci distributed across the genome. Key candidate genes identified are involved in erythropoiesis, vascular remodeling, and metabolic pathways, many exhibiting significant allele frequency differentiation along the altitudinal cline. Crucially, gene ontology enrichment indicates that adaptation predominantly utilizes standing genetic variation rather than *de novo* mutations. This study provides empirical evidence for the diffuse genomic architecture of polygenic adaptation, highlighting the distributed nature of fitness effects under strong selective pressures.
subject: Evrim
title: Polygenic Adaptation to Altitudinal Hypoxia: Deconstructing the Genomic Architecture in High-Andean Hummingbirds

text: The role of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance (TEI) in mediating adaptive phenotypic plasticity is increasingly recognized, yet its mechanisms and evolutionary implications remain unclear. This study investigates TEI of stress-induced morphological and life-history phenotypes in *Daphnia pulex* subjected to chronic predator kairomone exposure across multiple generations. Using whole-genome bisulfite sequencing, we identify specific loci exhibiting persistent differential DNA methylation patterns across four generations post-exposure, even in the absence of the initial stressor. These epialleles are frequently located within or near genes involved in chitin synthesis, carapace development, and reproductive timing. Phenotypic analyses corroborate sustained changes in predator-induced defenses (e.g., neck tooth length) and reproductive output, indicative of a heritable "memory" of past environmental conditions. Our findings provide compelling evidence for non-genetic inheritance acting as a rapid mechanism for phenotypic adjustment, potentially accelerating adaptive responses to predictable environmental stressors.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance of Stress Response Phenotypes in *Daphnia pulex* Under Chronic Predator Cues

text: The major histocompatibility complex (MHC) genes, pivotal for adaptive immunity, are classic examples of loci maintained by balancing selection under pathogen-mediated pressures. This study examines the evolutionary dynamics of MHC Class I genes in a wild population of *Passer domesticus*, focusing on the interplay between allelic diversity, pathogen load, and fitness outcomes. High-throughput sequencing of MHC exon 3 reveals extraordinary allelic richness and strong evidence of balancing selection, particularly through heterozygote advantage and rare allele advantage, inferred from extensive dN/dS ratios and gene flow patterns. Specific MHC haplotypes are associated with differential susceptibility to avian malaria parasites (*Plasmodium* spp.) and bacterial infections. Furthermore, functional prediction of peptide-binding specificities indicates divergent adaptive landscapes, with distinct allelic groups targeting different pathogen epitopes. This comprehensive analysis illuminates how pathogen diversity drives the maintenance of MHC polymorphism, shaping the immunogenetic resilience of natural populations.
subject: Evrim
title: Balancing Selection and Functional Divergence in MHC Class I Loci Drive Pathogen Resistance in Wild Avian Populations

text: This study introduces a novel framework for automated harmonic progression analysis using deep contextualized embeddings. Diverging from symbolic Roman numeral annotations, our approach leverages convolutional and recurrent neural networks (CRNNs) to generate dense, semantically rich vector representations of harmonic events. These embeddings capture subtle voice-leading intricacies, transformational relationships, and contextual dependencies across diatonic and chromatic idioms. We demonstrate the model's efficacy in identifying tonicizations, modulations, and non-functional harmonic structures within a diverse corpus of Western art music. Furthermore, the latent space learned by our model facilitates a geometrically informed understanding of harmonic trajectories, offering new quantitative insights into harmonic syntax and compositional practice that complement traditional theoretical paradigms. This method promises enhanced granularity and objectivity in large-scale corpus analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Contextualized Harmonic Embeddings for Automated Progression Analysis

text: We present a computational model for the quantification and categorization of polyphonic metrical dissonance, extending beyond traditional subjective approaches. Utilizing a multi-resolution wavelet transform, our system extracts salient periodicities and beat spectra from complex musical textures. Phase relationships and amplitude envelopes across concurrent metrical layers are then analyzed to compute a 'dissonance index,' reflecting the perceptual effort required for metrical entrainment. This index accounts for both grouping dissonance (e.g., syncopation, hemiola) and displacement dissonance (e.g., cross-rhythms). Validation against human perception studies demonstrates a high correlation, providing an objective metric for analyzing rhythmic complexity in works ranging from Ligeti's micropolyphony to jazz improvisation. This framework offers new tools for understanding rhythmic perception and compositional strategies involving metrical ambiguity.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Polyphonic Metrical Dissonance via Multi-Resolution Wavelet Transform

text: This research proposes a robust methodology for disentangling perceptual timbral components from complex audio signals using Non-Negative Tensor Factorization (N-TF). Traditional NMF often struggles with the dynamic, multi-dimensional nature of timbre; our approach extends this by incorporating temporal evolution and spectral correlation as distinct factors in a higher-order tensor decomposition. We aim to isolate elemental timbral gestures such as attack transients, steady-state characteristics, and vibrato/tremolo parameters, which are often confounded in conventional analyses. Applying this to orchestral recordings, we demonstrate its capability to extract instrument-specific 'timbral atoms' independent of pitch or loudness. The derived factorizations provide a basis for both advanced sound synthesis and a deeper psychoacoustic understanding of timbral perception, offering a granular analytical lens for instrumentation and orchestration studies.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectro-Temporal Disentanglement of Timbral Components Using Non-Negative Tensor Factorization

text: This paper introduces a novel algorithmic approach to generating species counterpoint, leveraging constrained probabilistic graphical models (PGMs). Unlike rule-based expert systems, our framework employs Markov Random Fields (MRFs) to model harmonic and melodic constraints probabilistically, accounting for both strict contrapuntal rules and subtle stylistic preferences. The model integrates global constraints, such as target cadences and melodic profiles, with local voice-leading dependencies (e.g., dissonance treatment, parallel motion avoidance) using energy minimization. We demonstrate its capacity to produce stylistically coherent first, second, and third species counterpoint against a given cantus firmus. This system offers a flexible platform for exploring the generative principles underlying contrapuntal practice, providing a computational lens for music theorists and a sophisticated tool for interactive compositional assistance and pedagogy.
subject: Müzik
title: Algorithmic Generation of Species Counterpoint through Constrained Probabilistic Graphical Models

text: We present a theoretical and computational framework for visualizing and analyzing microtonal pitch spaces through higher-order Tonnetz expansions. Extending the traditional 2D and 3D Tonnetz to n-dimensional toroidal manifolds, our model accommodates complex Just Intonation (JI) and other non-12-TET tuning systems by mapping pitch ratios to geometric coordinates in a prime-limit-agnostic manner. This spectro-geometric approach reveals inherent symmetries, intervallic proximities, and transformational pathways within highly granular pitch structures. We apply this to analyze spectral tunings and historical microtonal compositions, demonstrating its efficacy in uncovering latent harmonic relationships and understanding microtonal voice-leading. The framework offers a robust analytical tool for composers and theorists engaging with the intricate sonic landscapes beyond conventional equal temperament, providing novel insights into psychoacoustic consonance and dissonance in expanded pitch vocabularies.
subject: Müzik
title: Higher-Order Tonnetz Expansions for Microtonal Pitch Space Visualization and Analysis

text: This research extends Generalized Interval Systems (GIS) and Neo-Riemannian transformational theory to analyze voice-leading and structural coherence in atonal polyphony, particularly focusing on hexachordal combinatorics. We propose a network-based model where nodes represent pitch-class sets (PCS) and edges denote minimal voice-leading transformations or specific hexachordal inversional/retrograde relationships. The model quantifies parsimonious voice leading and identifies 'transformational hotspots' that reveal underlying compositional strategies in works by Schoenberg and Webern. By analyzing pathways through these networks, we uncover previously unarticulated structural connections and demonstrate how seemingly disparate pitch-class events contribute to a coherent, albeit non-tonal, contrapuntal fabric. This approach offers a powerful analytical lens for navigating the complexities of atonal voice leading and understanding the generative grammar of twelve-tone and free atonal techniques.
subject: Müzik
title: Transformational Networks and Hexachordal Combinatorics in Atonal Polyphony

text: This study quantifies expressive timing and dynamics in Romantic era piano performance using a multi-scale analysis approach applied to high-resolution MIDI data. We employ wavelet decomposition and non-linear regression to disentangle hierarchical layers of rubato (agogic, metric, phrase-level) and dynamic shaping, differentiating deliberate performer choices from mechanical fluctuations. Features such as tempo curve inflection points, dynamic range expansion, and onset asynchrony are extracted and modeled using Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) to capture typical gestural patterns. Analysis of performances by canonical interpreters reveals idiosyncratic yet stylistically coherent expressive grammars, transcending simple deviations from notation. This framework provides empirical data for understanding performance practice, synthesizing expressive renditions, and offering a robust quantitative method for comparative analyses of interpretive styles in complex musical narratives.
subject: Müzik
title: Multi-Scale Quantification of Expressive Timing and Dynamics in Romantic Era Piano Performance
