text: This research investigates the inherent cross-modal correspondences between auditory qualia and other sensory modalities, particularly visual and haptic, exploring the concept of 'sonic materiality.' Through a series of psychophysical experiments, we quantify the perceptual mappings between spectro-temporal features (e.g., spectral centroid, roughness, attack envelope) and semantic descriptors across visual attributes (e.g., brightness, texture, shape) and haptic qualities (e.g., smoothness, hardness). Concurrent fMRI and EEG data track cortical activation patterns during cross-modal judgment tasks, identifying neural correlates of synesthetic experiences and their underlying cognitive mechanisms. Our findings reveal robust, non-arbitrary links, suggesting a shared representational space for sensory properties. This research advances theories of multisensory integration, offers empirical support for metaphoric language in music theory, and informs applications in multimodal interfaces and sensory substitution technologies.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Correspondences in Sonic Materiality: A Psychoacoustic and Neurophysiological Investigation

text: This paper presents a novel methodology for automated discovery and classification of formal archetypes within large corpora of post-tonal music, utilizing latent topic modeling algorithms. Diverging from traditional, score-based formal analysis, our approach employs Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) on feature vectors derived from spectral, rhythmic, and textural characteristics of audio recordings. By identifying recurring patterns in these high-dimensional feature spaces, the model uncovers latent 'topics' corresponding to distinct formal functions (e.g., expositional, developmental, recapitulatory, transitional). We demonstrate its efficacy in segmenting complex post-tonal structures and in identifying shared formal strategies across diverse compositional idioms. This data-driven framework offers an objective, scalable tool for musicologists to explore large-scale formal organization, challenging and complementing established theoretical taxonomies and fostering new insights into structural coherence in contemporary music.
subject: Müzik
title: Automated Discovery of Formal Archetypes in Post-Tonal Music Corpora via Topic Modeling

text: This study investigates the cortical dynamics underlying auditory stream segregation in complex orchestral polyphony using simultaneous EEG-fMRI. We manipulate spectro-temporal coherence and pitch proximity between concurrent melodic lines, presenting listeners with stimuli ranging from fused to highly segregated auditory streams. Event-Related Potentials (ERPs), particularly the N1/P2 components and Mismatch Negativity (MMN), are analyzed in conjunction with fMRI data to localize brain regions involved in the pre-attentive and attentive parsing of musical layers. Our findings delineate the roles of primary and secondary auditory cortices, as well as higher-order frontal and parietal areas implicated in executive attention and working memory, in maintaining distinct musical streams. This research provides critical neurophysiological insights into Gestalt principles of auditory organization and the cognitive mechanisms enabling listeners to navigate dense contrapuntal textures, enriching music cognition theory.
subject: Müzik
title: Cortical Dynamics of Auditory Stream Segregation in Orchestral Polyphony: An EEG-fMRI Study

text: Circular RNAs (circRNAs) have emerged as pivotal regulators in post-transcriptional gene expression, particularly through their capacity to sequester microRNAs (miRNAs). This study meticulously dissects the intricate molecular interplay between specific circRNAs and oncogenic miRNAs within Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM) pathogenesis. Utilizing advanced RNA sequencing, CRISPR-Cas9 perturbations, and novel reporter assays in patient-derived xenograft models, we identify a hitherto uncharacterized circRNA, circMETTL3, which functions as a potent sponge for miR-138-5p. Overexpression of circMETTL3 significantly abrogates miR-138-5p-mediated suppression of FOXC1 and EZH2, key transcriptional drivers of mesenchymal transformation and chemoresistance. Further biochemical analyses confirm direct physical interaction and stoichiometric binding affinity. Our findings establish circMETTL3 as a critical oncogenic determinant in GBM, modulating a complex ceRNA network that drives tumor aggressiveness and therapeutic recalcitrance, thereby presenting a novel therapeutic target for this intractable malignancy.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mechanistic Elucidation of Circular RNA-Mediated Sponging of MicroRNAs in Glioblastoma Multiforme Progression

text: Chromatin remodeling complexes are paramount in orchestrating cell fate decisions and maintaining cellular identity. This investigation delineates the sophisticated role of mammalian SWI/SNF (BAF) complexes in dictating hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) lineage specification and plasticity. Employing conditional knockout mouse models coupled with multi-omics profiling, including ATAC-seq, Hi-C, and ChIA-PET, we reveal that specific subunit composition of BAF complexes dynamically reshapes enhancer-promoter looping and modulates chromatin accessibility at key hematopoietic differentiation loci. Disruption of BAF180 leads to aberrant activation of myeloid programs and concomitant suppression of lymphoid development, characterized by altered histone modifications and aberrant transcription factor recruitment. Our data unveil a hitherto unappreciated mechanism where BAF complexes act as crucial arbiters of transcriptional landscapes, maintaining HSC quiescence and facilitating directed differentiation through precise architectural scaffolding, offering critical insights into leukemogenesis and regenerative medicine strategies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dynamic Reprogramming of Chromatin Architecture by BAF Complexes Governs Lineage Plasticity in Hematopoietic Stem Cells

text: Islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP or amylin) misfolding and subsequent aggregation into amyloid fibrils within pancreatic beta-cells are hallmarks of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM), contributing to cellular dysfunction and apoptosis. This study comprehensively elucidates the interplay between cellular chaperone machinery and the kinetics of human amylin (hIAPP) aggregation. Utilizing an integrated approach combining high-resolution cryo-electron microscopy, single-molecule fluorescence spectroscopy, and genetic manipulation of key chaperone expression in INS-1 beta-cells, we demonstrate that compromised expression or impaired function of specific small heat shock proteins (sHSPs), notably HSPB1 and HSPB8, significantly accelerates hIAPP fibrillogenesis and enhances cytotoxic oligomer formation. Furthermore, we identify specific chaperone-hIAPP interaction sites and kinetic parameters dictating aggregation pathways. These findings reveal critical vulnerabilities in the proteostasis network in T2DM, providing mechanistic insights into beta-cell failure and suggesting novel therapeutic strategies targeting chaperone activity to mitigate amylin-induced pathology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Molecular Chaperone Dysregulation and Amylin Aggregation Kinetics in Type 2 Diabetes Pathogenesis

text: Macroautophagy is a fundamental catabolic process crucial for cellular homeostasis, involving the formation of double-membraned autophagosomes. While ULK1 kinase activity is recognized as an initiating signal, the precise phosphoproteomic cascade orchestrating phagophore elongation remains largely uncharacterized. Through quantitative phosphoproteomics using SILAC and TMT labeling, coupled with CRISPR-Cas9 screening for autophagy-related genes (ATGs), we identify a novel subset of ULK1 substrates crucial for sustained vesicle expansion. Specifically, phosphorylation of a previously unrecognized residue on ATG9A by ULK1 dictates its trafficking kinetics and subsequent membrane delivery to the nascent phagophore. Further biophysical reconstitution assays confirm that this phosphorylation event synergistically promotes lipid bilayer curvature and expansion in conjunction with ATG2B and WIPI2. Our data provide a high-resolution mechanistic framework for ULK1-dependent phagophore elongation, highlighting critical regulatory nodes in autophagosome biogenesis, which could be targeted for therapeutic intervention in autophagic dysregulation pathologies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Autophagosome Biogenesis: Unraveling the Role of ULK1-Initiated Phosphoproteome Dynamics in Phagophore Elongation

text: Understanding the intricate cellular transitions and transcriptional reprogramming during early mammalian embryogenesis necessitates high-resolution spatiotemporal analysis. This research pioneers an integrated single-cell multi-omics approach, combining spatial transcriptomics (Slide-seqV2) with droplet-based single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and ATAC-seq, to reconstruct developmental trajectories from pre-implantation blastocyst to gastrulation stages in unprecedented detail. We delineate novel cell states within the epiblast and primitive streak, identifying previously uncharacterized populations with distinct epigenetic landscapes and lineage potential. Pseudotime trajectory analysis reveals key transcriptional regulators and chromatin accessibility dynamics governing the sequential commitment to germ layer formation. Furthermore, cell-cell communication inferred from ligand-receptor expression profiles unveils critical signaling pathways orchestrating morphogenetic events. These comprehensive datasets provide a foundational molecular atlas of early embryogenesis, offering profound insights into developmental diseases and informing strategies for regenerative medicine by elucidating the precise molecular underpinnings of cell fate decisions.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Deciphering Cellular Heterogeneity and Transcriptional Trajectories in Early Embryogenesis via Spatiotemporal Single-Cell Multi-Omics

text: Pathogenic mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) are implicated in a wide spectrum of severe human diseases, yet precise correction remains a formidable challenge due to the distinct replication and transcription mechanisms of the mitochondrial genome. We report the development of a novel mitochondrial base editor (mitoBE) system derived from a catalytically impaired Cas9 fused to engineered cytidine deaminases and mitochondrial targeting sequences. This mitoBE system efficiently and site-specifically mediates C-to-T transitions within mtDNA in various mammalian cell lines and in murine models of mitochondrial encephalomyopathy. We demonstrate quantitative editing of pathogenic mt-ND5 mutations, leading to restoration of respiratory chain complex I activity and reversal of cellular phenotypes in patient-derived fibroblasts. Crucially, off-target nuclear DNA editing is negligible. This technology represents a significant leap forward for gene therapy of mitochondrial diseases, offering an unprecedented precision tool for direct in vivo correction of pathogenic mtDNA variants.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Precise Base Editing of Mitochondrial DNA Using Engineered Cas9-Derived Cytidine Deaminases in Vivo

text: G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) constitute the largest family of therapeutic targets, yet the intricate mechanisms governing ligand-biased signaling remain incompletely understood. This study employs single-particle cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) to visualize the full-length active-state structures of the µ-opioid receptor (MOR) in complex with different biased agonists and downstream G-proteins (Gi1) and arrestins. We present atomic-resolution insights into novel allosteric sites and conformational rearrangements within the intracellular loops and transmembrane helices that dictate selective effector coupling. Specifically, an identified novel pocket near TM6-TM7 interface undergoes agonist-specific remodeling, influencing the precise orientation of the G-protein α5 helix and thus biasing signaling towards Gi activation over β-arrestin recruitment. These structural revelations unveil a sophisticated molecular mechanism of allosteric regulation far beyond the orthosteric binding pocket, providing a crucial framework for rational drug design targeting GPCRs with enhanced selectivity and reduced adverse effects.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Allosteric Modulation of GPCR-Effector Coupling via Novel Ligand-Induced Conformational Dynamics Revealed by Cryo-EM

text: Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase 1 (PARP1) inhibitors represent a cornerstone in synthetic lethality strategies for homologous recombination deficient (HRD) cancers. While canonical PARP1 activation involves binding to DNA strand breaks, emerging evidence suggests alternative activation mechanisms. This research investigates a novel, non-canonical activation pathway of PARP1 in HRD contexts, specifically focusing on its interaction with replication protein A (RPA) at stalled replication forks. Through quantitative mass spectrometry, biophysical interaction assays, and advanced microscopy in BRCA1/2-deficient models, we uncover that hyper-phosphorylation of RPA promotes its direct association with PARP1, leading to PARylation activity independent of direct DNA break recognition. This RPA-PARP1 interaction is critical for stabilizing stalled forks, and its inhibition in HRD cells exacerbates replication stress, leading to catastrophic mitotic entry and cell death. Our findings illuminate a refined understanding of PARP1 function in HRD, suggesting novel therapeutic avenues by targeting this non-canonical activation for improved clinical outcomes.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Non-Canonical PARP1 Activation in Homologous Recombination Deficiency: A Mechanism of Synthetic Lethality Exploitation

text: The severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) utilizes a complex repertoire of non-structural proteins (NSPs) to commandeer host cellular machinery and evade innate immunity, yet the precise role of host-directed post-translational modifications (PTMs) on NSPs remains largely uncharacterized. This study employs an integrative proteomic approach combining high-resolution mass spectrometry, targeted mutagenesis, and biochemical reconstitution assays to map the PTM landscape – phosphorylation, ubiquitination, and SUMOylation – of all 16 SARS-CoV-2 NSPs during active infection. We identify novel host kinase- and ubiquitin ligase-mediated modifications on NSP1, NSP5, and NSP13 that critically regulate their stability, sub-cellular localization, and interactions with host antiviral factors like MAVS and TRIM25. Specifically, SUMOylation of NSP5 dictates its proteolytic activity and interferon antagonism. These comprehensive findings provide a molecular blueprint of host-virus interplay, offering critical insights into viral pathogenesis and identifying potential targets for pan-coronavirus antiviral therapeutics.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Elucidating the Post-Translational Modification Landscape of SARS-CoV-2 Non-Structural Proteins in Host Evasion and Replication

text: Mitochondrial morphology is a dynamic equilibrium dictated by cycles of fission and fusion, profoundly impacting cellular physiology. This study elucidates a novel role for mitochondrial dynamics in regulating cellular redox homeostasis by spatially segregating metabolic fluxes. Using super-resolution microscopy, targeted optogenetic manipulation of DRP1 and MFN2, and real-time ratiometric redox sensors in single cells, we demonstrate that enhanced mitochondrial fission promotes the isolation of metabolically distinct subnetworks within the mitochondrial reticulum. Specifically, fragmented mitochondria exhibit compartmentalized NADH/NAD+ and GSH/GSSG ratios, driving localized oxidative phosphorylation efficiency and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production. Disrupting this spatial segregation through hyperfusion leads to global mitochondrial depolarization and increased oxidative stress. Our findings reveal that mitochondrial dynamics are not merely structural but are active orchestrators of metabolic compartmentalization, critically underpinning redox balance and metabolic adaptability, with profound implications for understanding neurodegeneration and metabolic diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mitochondrial Fission-Fusion Dynamics Orchestrate Cellular Redox Homeostasis through Spatial Segregation of Metabolic Fluxes

text: This study presents a novel framework for the computational modeling of tonal semantics, integrating insights from cognitive linguistics and probabilistic graphical models with large-scale symbolic music corpora. We propose a hierarchical Bayesian model to infer latent tonal functions and their associative networks, moving beyond traditional pitch-class set theory by incorporating dynamic contextual dependencies derived from corpus statistics. Leveraging recurrent neural networks for sequence modeling, our approach quantifies the perceptual salience of harmonic progressions and modulatory trajectories across diverse stylistic periods. This framework facilitates the empirical validation of theoretical constructs such as Schenkerian prolongations and Roman numeral analysis, offering a robust, data-driven methodology to explore the cognitive grounding of tonal meaning and its cross-cultural variations, thereby enriching both musicological inquiry and AI-driven composition.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hierarchical Bayesian Framework for Computational Tonal Semantics and Functional Analysis

text: This research investigates the perception and computational modeling of metrical-hierarchical structures within microtonal musical contexts, a domain largely underexplored by conventional rhythm-meter theories tied to 12-TET frameworks. We deploy a multi-resolution audio analysis pipeline combining adaptive wavelet transforms for onset detection with phase-synchronization algorithms to infer underlying pulse streams and their periodicities in non-standard tuning systems. A novel perceptual psychoacoustic model is introduced to account for the differential saliency of microtonal intervals in influencing metrical grouping, informed by cross-cultural ethnomusicological data. The proposed framework quantifies rhythmic complexity and hypermeter in compositions employing quarter-tones, just intonation, and other extended intonational schemes, offering a robust methodology to bridge discrepancies between theoretical constructs of metricality and their real-world sonic instantiations, thereby expanding the analytical toolkit for contemporary and world musics.
subject: Müzik
title: Multi-Resolution Audio Analysis of Metrical-Hierarchical Structures in Microtonal Music

text: We present a novel deep learning architecture for disentangling perceptually salient timbral attributes from raw audio waveforms, moving beyond traditional hand-crafted spectral features. Our framework employs a spectro-temporal variational autoencoder (ST-VAE) coupled with an adversarial training regimen to enforce statistical independence among learned latent dimensions. This model is trained on a vast corpus of instrument recordings and synthesized sounds, annotated with multi-modal perceptual descriptors derived from psychoacoustic listening experiments. The goal is to isolate fundamental timbral axes such as 'brightness,' 'roughness,' and 'attack transients' from confounding factors like pitch and loudness. This methodology offers a robust, data-driven approach to constructing a perceptually informed timbral feature space, facilitating advancements in computational auditory scene analysis, expressive synthesis, and granular control over sonic textures in interactive music systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangling Perceptually Salient Timbral Attributes Using Spectro-Temporal Variational Autoencoders

text: This study introduces a Conditional Generative Adversarial Network (C-GAN) for the analysis and generation of species counterpoint, addressing the intricate syntactical rules governing melodic interaction in polyphonic textures. The generator network learns to produce contextually coherent contrapuntal lines conditioned on a cantus firmus, while the discriminator network evaluates the adherence to established theoretical constraints and stylistic precedents. Trained on a curated corpus of Renaissance and Baroque polyphony, the model identifies subtle deviations and stylistic fingerprints that elude conventional rule-based systems. Our framework provides a powerful tool for empirical validation of historical counterpoint treatises and offers novel insights into the statistical regularities underpinning contrapuntal fluency. Furthermore, it paves the way for intelligent algorithmic composition systems capable of generating highly nuanced and theoretically grounded polyphonic music.
subject: Müzik
title: Generative Adversarial Networks for Stylistic Modeling and Analysis of Contrapuntal Syntax

text: This research explores the intricate cross-modal correspondences between physical performance gestures and their resultant sonic manifestations, utilizing an integrated audio-visual analysis paradigm. We leverage high-resolution motion capture data synchronized with studio-quality audio recordings of instrumental performances to train a multi-modal deep learning architecture, specifically a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) network with attention mechanisms. The model learns to map subtle kinematic features of instrumentalists' movements to specific spectral, temporal, and dynamic parameters of the produced sound. This framework quantitatively identifies critical gestural cues that modulate timbral nuance and expressive phrasing, providing empirical insights into embodied music cognition. The findings enhance our understanding of performance pedagogy and inform the design of more intuitive and perceptually sensitive human-computer interaction systems for musical expression and analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Deep Learning for Mapping Musical Gesture to Expressive Sonic Parameters

text: This study applies an information-theoretic framework to quantify cohesion and structural integrity in post-tonal atonal music, addressing the challenge of analyzing non-tonal syntax beyond traditional set-theoretic enumeration. We propose novel metrics of harmonic entropy and melodic redundancy derived from statistical distributions of pitch intervals and ordered pitch-class segments within various atonal corpora. Employing advanced feature extraction techniques on symbolic representations, our methodology identifies recurring patterns and transformational invariances that contribute to perceived musical coherence in works spanning free atonality to integral serialism. This approach offers a quantitative lens for evaluating the efficacy of compositional strategies and the psychological salience of structural elements in music devoid of traditional tonal centers. The findings provide empirical grounding for theoretical propositions concerning atonal syntax and contribute to the development of sophisticated analytical tools for contemporary musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: Information-Theoretic Quantification of Cohesion and Structural Integrity in Post-Tonal Atonal Music

text: We introduce a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agent for robust real-time score following, designed to adapt dynamically to expressive performance variations and unforeseen musical deviations. The agent learns an optimal policy for aligning live audio input with a symbolic score representation by maximizing a reward function incorporating metrics of temporal synchronization, beat tracking accuracy, and phrase-level coherence. Utilizing a multi-modal input state comprising spectral features, onset detection functions, and symbolic context, the DRL model navigates complex musical ambiguities inherent in human performance, such as rubato and ad-libitum passages. This framework significantly outperforms conventional hidden Markov models and dynamic time warping approaches in terms of latency and resilience to noise, offering a paradigm shift for interactive music systems, adaptive accompaniment, and computational musicology applications requiring precise real-time synchronization.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Real-Time Score Following in Expressive Live Performance

text: This study investigates the phenomenological experience of musical expectation by integrating psychophysiological measures with fine-grained audio analysis. We employ a multi-modal data acquisition protocol, simultaneously capturing electrodermal activity (EDA), heart rate variability (HRV), and continuous emotional self-reports during listening tasks featuring both conventional and manipulated musical stimuli. Our analytical framework correlates physiological arousal and valence shifts with acoustic features such as harmonic entropy, spectral flux, and rhythmic irregularity, particularly at moments of metrical dissonance or unresolved melodic implications. Leveraging machine learning classifiers, we construct predictive models of expected musical events and their deviation, mapping objective audio parameters to subjective affective responses. This research contributes to a deeper understanding of predictive coding mechanisms in music cognition and offers empirical validation for theoretical models of tension and release in musical discourse, with implications for music therapy and computational affect modeling.
subject: Müzik
title: Phenomenological Investigation of Musical Expectation through Psychophysiological Data Integration

text: This research presents a computational methodology for the discretization and quantitative analysis of improvisational syntax in jazz and other vernacular traditions. Moving beyond anecdotal observations, we transform raw audio recordings into symbolic representations encompassing pitch, rhythm, and expressive nuance using advanced audio-to-MIDI transcription and alignment techniques. A multi-level analytical framework is then applied, combining higher-order Markov models for melodic contour and harmonic progression with N-gram analysis for identifying recurring idiomatic phrases and gestural motifs. We quantify stylistic distinctiveness and structural coherence within improvisation, revealing the interplay between learned schemas and real-time generative processes. This approach provides empirical grounding for theories of improvisational cognition and offers novel insights into the statistical properties of creative musical acts, advancing both musicological understanding and the development of adaptive pedagogical tools for improvisation.
subject: Müzik
title: Computational Discretization and Quantification of Improvisational Syntax in Vernacular Traditions

text: This study investigates the computational modeling and perceptual underpinnings of multiscale grouping phenomena in complex polyrhythmic textures. We propose a hierarchical probabilistic model that infers latent metrical structures and cross-rhythmic relationships from raw audio, integrating both bottom-up onset salience and top-down cognitive expectations. Our approach employs a multi-resolution analysis of phase and amplitude envelopes, complemented by a statistical learning component that identifies recurrent rhythmic patterns and their probabilistic co-occurrence. Through carefully designed psychoacoustic experiments and a deep neural network trained on human grouping judgments, we demonstrate how Gestalt principles of perceptual organization manifest in the segregation and integration of concurrent rhythmic streams. This framework offers a robust tool for analyzing rhythmic complexity and provides empirical insights into the cognitive mechanisms facilitating the perception of polyphony, with implications for both music theory and auditory neuroscience.
subject: Müzik
title: Multiscale Perceptual Grouping in Polyrhythmic Textures: A Hierarchical Probabilistic Model

text: This theoretical investigation delves into the holographic correspondence between quantum entanglement and spacetime geometry, proposing a novel mechanism for the emergence of spacetime curvature from the renormalization group (RG) flow of entanglement structures in boundary quantum field theories. We extend the Ryu-Takayanagi conjecture to explicitly demonstrate how variations in mutual information and multi-partite entanglement in a strongly coupled field theory are directly mapped to modifications of the bulk metric in an Anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime. By employing tensor network states as discrete realizations of holographic duality, we compute the relationship between entanglement entropy scaling and the extrinsic curvature of constant-time hypersurfaces, unveiling how quantum complexity dictates the intrinsic geometric properties and dynamics of the emergent gravitational background. Our findings offer a microscopic, quantum-information-theoretic perspective on the origins of gravity, suggesting that the dynamics of spacetime itself might be an intricate manifestation of quantum information processing.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Emergence of Spacetime Curvature from Entanglement Renormalization Group Flows

text: We present a comprehensive analysis of late-time cosmic acceleration within a class of non-minimally coupled scalar-tensor theories, extending beyond the standard $\Lambda$CDM paradigm. Our framework incorporates a generic coupling function $F(\phi, R)$ between a dynamically evolving scalar field $\phi$ and the Ricci scalar $R$, allowing for chameleon and K-mouflage screening mechanisms to satisfy local gravity constraints. Through high-precision cosmological simulations and observational data from Type Ia supernovae, cosmic microwave background anisotropies, and large-scale structure, we constrain the parameter space of these theories. We demonstrate how specific coupling forms can alleviate existing tensions in cosmological parameters, such as $H_0$ and $\sigma_8$, by modifying gravitational dynamics at cosmological scales while remaining consistent with solar system tests. This research highlights the viability of modified gravity as an alternative to dark energy, offering testable predictions for future gravitational wave observatories.
subject: Fizik
title: Disentangling Late-Time Cosmic Acceleration via Non-Minimally Coupled Scalar-Tensor Theories

text: We theoretically investigate the emergence and stability of Majorana zero modes in D-wave topological superconductors, specifically focusing on the interplay between unconventional pairing symmetries and specific crystalline point group symmetries. Utilizing a lattice model incorporating strong spin-orbit coupling and local symmetry-breaking potentials, we demonstrate that protected Majorana bound states can localize at vortices or defects even in the absence of external magnetic fields, provided certain crystalline symmetries (e.g., $C_4$ rotation or mirror planes) are preserved. We derive the topological invariants governing these phases, such as momentum-space winding numbers or mirror Chern numbers, and propose experimental signatures via tunneling spectroscopy for detecting these non-Abelian excitations. The robust generation of these exotic quasi-particles under specific crystalline conditions opens new avenues for realizing fault-tolerant topological quantum computation in realistic material systems.
subject: Fizik
title: Crystalline Symmetries and Non-Abelian Excitations in D-Wave Topological Superconductors

text: This paper proposes a novel radiative inverse seesaw mechanism for generating naturally small neutrino masses, incorporating a dark sector $SU(2)_D$ scalar triplet that transforms trivially under the Standard Model (SM) gauge group. The model introduces right-handed sterile neutrinos and a set of exotic neutral leptons that facilitate the inverse seesaw, with the mass scale of SM neutrinos arising from quantum loop corrections involving the new scalar triplet. We explore the phenomenological implications of this framework, including predictions for lepton flavor violating decays, collider signatures from the production of the dark scalar triplet and heavy neutral leptons, and constraints from electroweak precision tests. The model offers a compelling solution to the neutrino mass puzzle, simultaneously providing a dark matter candidate from the residual $Z_2$ symmetry of the dark sector, linking neutrino physics to multi-messenger astrophysical probes and future high-luminosity colliders.
subject: Fizik
title: A Radiative Inverse Seesaw Mechanism for Neutrino Mass Generation from a Dark SU(2) Scalar Triplet

text: We present a quantum-information-theoretic framework to address the black hole information paradox, focusing on the role of entanglement harvesting near causal horizons. Our model posits that the information seemingly lost during black hole evaporation is not irrevocably destroyed but rather re-encoded and "harvested" by the outgoing Hawking radiation through intricate entanglement correlations with the near-horizon quantum vacuum. We demonstrate that the structure of spacetime near the event horizon facilitates a unique form of entanglement swapping between infalling matter and outgoing quantum fields, effectively preserving unitarity. By employing a generalized entropy prescription that includes entanglement measures of the horizon region, we argue for a consistent picture where information is conserved via non-local quantum correlations, circumventing the need for "firewalls" and preserving the semiclassical description of gravity while ensuring a unitary evolution for the global quantum state.
subject: Fizik
title: Entanglement Harvesting and Causal Horizons: A Quantum-Information-Theoretic Resolution to the Black Hole Information Paradox

text: This work investigates the intricate interplay between environmental complexity, gravitational effects, and the emergence of "pointer states" within a class of gravity-induced objective collapse models for the quantum measurement problem. We extend the Continuous Spontaneous Localization (CSL) model by incorporating gravitationally modified collapse operators derived from a self-gravitating scalar field. Our analysis demonstrates that the effective collapse rate for macroscopic superpositions is significantly enhanced by both the environmental degrees of freedom and the gravitational self-energy of the system, leading to a rapid and robust suppression of quantum coherence. We rigorously quantify the conditions under which specific classical "pointer states" become gravitationally preferred and stable against environmental perturbations, providing a unified framework where the quantum-to-classical transition is an inevitable consequence of the inherent complexity of macro-objects interacting with both their environment and their own gravitational field.
subject: Fizik
title: Environmental Complexity and Pointer States in Gravity-Induced Objective Collapse Models

text: We propose a novel experimental architecture for detecting ultralight axion-like particle (ALP) dark matter, leveraging the exquisite sensitivity of superconducting radiofrequency (SRF) cavities enhanced by squeezed-light quantum non-demolition (QND) readout techniques. Our scheme exploits the axion-photon coupling through the inverse Primakoff effect, where ALPs convert into microwave photons within a high-Q SRF cavity permeated by a strong static magnetic field. By implementing an intracavity squeezed-light source, we project a sensitivity beyond the standard quantum limit, enabling detection of ALPs with coupling strengths down to $g_{a\gamma\gamma} \sim 10^{-18} \text{ GeV}^{-1}$ across the sub-$\mu$eV mass range. We detail the engineering challenges, noise suppression strategies, and projected sensitivity curves, demonstrating that this approach could significantly improve upon current astrophysical and terrestrial bounds, opening a new frontier in the search for ultralight dark matter candidates.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Ultralight Axion-Like Dark Matter with Squeezed-Light Enhanced Superconducting RF Cavities

text: We present a theoretical framework for understanding non-equilibrium phase transitions and the emergence of collective patterns in driven active matter systems, focusing on the interplay between intrinsic particle motility, inter-particle interactions, and external driving forces. Using a combination of coarse-grained continuum hydrodynamics and microscopic agent-based simulations, we characterize the onset of motility-induced phase separation (MIPS) and explore its dependence on activity parameters, particle density, and interaction potential anisotropy. Our work elucidates the thermodynamic principles governing these out-of-equilibrium phenomena, identifying a generalized entropy production rate as a key quantifier for assessing the stability and morphology of emergent structures. We demonstrate how persistent activity can lead to novel phases, such as self-propelling flocks and active liquid crystals, that lack counterparts in equilibrium statistical mechanics, offering insights into biological self-organization and advanced material design.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Equilibrium Phase Transitions and Mobility-Induced Pattern Formation in Driven Active Matter Systems

text: This research investigates the potential for spatiotemporal variations of fundamental constants, particularly the fine-structure constant ($\alpha$), by analyzing precision atomic spectroscopy in environments characterized by extreme gravitational potentials, such as white dwarfs or neutron stars. We present a theoretical model linking variations in $\alpha$ to local gravitational potentials within Bekenstein-type scalar-tensor theories, predicting observable shifts in spectral lines for highly ionized atoms. By comparing these predicted shifts with current and prospective astrophysical spectroscopic observations of compact objects and complementing with high-precision laboratory atomic clock comparisons, we derive stringent constraints on the dimensionless coupling parameter $\zeta$ associated with the scalar field. This dual approach provides a robust methodology to probe new physics beyond the Standard Model, offering insight into the potential interplay between gravity and electromagnetism at extreme energy densities and over cosmological timescales.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraining Spatiotemporal Variations of Fundamental Constants via Precision Atomic Spectroscopy in Extreme Gravitational Potentials

text: We explore the complex landscape of quantum entanglement in non-Hermitian many-body systems exhibiting exceptional points (EPs), where eigenvectors coalesce and eigenvalues become degenerate. Our investigation focuses on how the non-Hermitian nature, particularly the presence of EPs, fundamentally alters entanglement properties, such as entanglement entropy, negativity, and entanglement spectrum, compared to their Hermitian counterparts. We demonstrate that traversing an EP can induce topological transitions in the entanglement structure, leading to novel forms of non-Hermitian topological entanglement. By analyzing specific models like the non-Hermitian Kitaev chain and PT-symmetric Hubbard models, we identify regimes where EPs localize entanglement or induce non-trivial braiding in the entanglement spectrum. These findings open new avenues for understanding quantum correlations in open quantum systems and for engineering unique topological phases with applications in quantum sensing and non-Hermitian quantum computing.
subject: Fizik
title: Quantum Entanglement Topologies in Non-Hermitian Many-Body Systems with Exceptional Points

text: This research investigates the Turan problem for k-uniform hypergraphs concerning degenerate cycles. We establish a novel stability result for H-free k-uniform hypergraphs, demonstrating that if a k-uniform hypergraph G has sufficiently many edges and does not contain a specific degenerate cycle C_l^k (a k-uniform hypergraph with l edges and l vertices), then G must be structurally close to a complete multipartite k-uniform hypergraph. Our approach leverages a sophisticated "dependent random choice" technique adapted for hypergraphs, combined with extremal set theory arguments. We show that for sufficiently large l, the Turan number ex_k(n, C_l^k) approaches a known density, and any hypergraph achieving this density is asymptotically unique. This extends classical Turan-type stability theorems to a broader class of hypergraph structures, offering insights into the combinatorial properties governing hypergraph extremal problems.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotic Stability in Uniform Hypergraphs for Forbidding Degenerate Cycles

text: We delve into the combinatorial properties of q-deformed Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials associated with type A Weyl groups, exploring their connections to the representation theory of cellular algebras. Specifically, we define a novel q-analogue for the parabolic Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials and provide explicit combinatorial interpretations for their coefficients in certain cases, extending earlier work on standard Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials. Our primary methodology involves the construction of specialized bases for modules over Hecke algebras and their relation to Lusztig's a-function. We prove that these q-polynomials satisfy recurrence relations reminiscent of those for standard Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials, and we investigate their positivity properties. This work sheds new light on the interplay between algebraic combinatorics, character theory, and the structural properties of cellular algebras arising from diagrammatic calculi.
subject: Matematik
title: On the q-Deformation of Kazhdan-Lusztig Polynomials and Cellular Algebras

text: We analyze the critical window phenomenon in random k-satisfiability problems, focusing on instances where the underlying clause-variable incidence graph possesses a controlled minimum girth. Our investigation provides precise asymptotic bounds for the satisfiability threshold function for constant k, especially in regimes where previous analyses struggled due to short cycles. By employing a novel variant of the "first moment method" combined with complex analysis techniques for asymptotic enumeration, we demonstrate that a larger girth significantly sharpens the phase transition. We show that the typical solution space undergoes a dramatic structural change within a narrow interval of clause-to-variable ratios, exhibiting properties akin to expander graphs. This work refines our understanding of the satisfiability phase transition and its dependency on local graph structure in random constraint satisfaction problems.
subject: Matematik
title: Critical Window Behavior of Random k-SAT Formulations with Large Girth

text: This paper explores the coefficients of Ehrhart polynomials of rational convex polytopes, specifically focusing on their interpretation through conical decompositions. We present a generalized framework for decomposing rational polytopes into unimodular cones, extending classical results for integer polytopes. Our main result establishes a direct relationship between the numerator polynomials of the Hilbert series for the semigroup of lattice points in a rational cone and the coefficients of the Ehrhart polynomial of a corresponding rational polytope. This provides a novel combinatorial interpretation for all Ehrhart coefficients, even those not directly related to facet volumes. The methodology involves a refined analysis of Dedekind sums and their multidimensional generalizations, offering deeper insights into the enumerative properties of lattice points in rational polyhedra and their associated generating functions.
subject: Matematik
title: Ehrhart Polynomial Coefficients and Conical Decompositions of Rational Polytopes

text: We introduce and thoroughly investigate q-analogs of rook polynomials, extending their classical definitions to finite vector spaces over GF(q). Our construction utilizes a novel combinatorial interpretation involving placements of non-attacking "q-rooks" on a generalized board defined by subspaces. We establish a generating function for these q-rook polynomials and derive several recurrence relations, demonstrating parallels with the classical theory. Furthermore, we connect these q-rook polynomials to enumerative problems concerning cycle decompositions of permutations acting on finite vector spaces. Specifically, we show that their coefficients encode the number of partitions of a vector space into direct sums of cyclic subspaces of specified dimensions. This work enriches the theory of q-analogs and provides new combinatorial tools for studying permutations in non-commutative settings.
subject: Matematik
title: q-Analogs of Rook Polynomials and Cycle Decompositions on Finite Vector Spaces

text: This research develops an advanced framework for computing homological invariants of abstract simplicial complexes using discrete Morse theory. We introduce a novel concept of "acyclic matching-induced partitions" of the face poset, demonstrating that these partitions provide a more refined characterization of critical cells than traditional discrete Morse functions. By leveraging this framework, we derive new combinatorial formulas for Betti numbers, extending a key result of Forman. We further explore the relationship between the persistence homology of a filtered simplicial complex and the properties of its underlying acyclic matchings, providing bounds on persistent Betti numbers. This work offers powerful new algorithmic and theoretical tools for analyzing the topological structure of large and complex combinatorial objects, with implications for data analysis and network theory.
subject: Matematik
title: Homological Invariants of Simplicial Complexes via Acyclic Matching-Induced Partitions

text: We present significant advancements in sum-product estimates within arbitrary finite fields F_p, particularly for subsets A ⊆ F_p where the associated growth in either sumsets or product sets is highly restricted. Our main result establishes a new lower bound for |A+A| + |A·A|, surpassing previous bounds for sets whose size is close to p^(1/2), by employing a sophisticated blend of incidence geometry methods, spectral graph theory on Cayley graphs, and novel additive combinatorial arguments. We introduce a "spectral gap argument" for analyzing the distribution of elements in sumsets and product sets. This methodology yields improved explicit constants and extends the range of applicability for sets with constrained doubling or product properties, contributing new techniques to the classical sum-product problem.
subject: Matematik
title: Improved Sum-Product Bounds in Finite Fields for Subsets with Restricted Growth

text: This paper provides a comprehensive characterization of nim-values (or Grundy numbers) for a broad class of impartial games played on hypergraph structures, where the game dynamics are influenced by specific terminal positions. We extend the classical Sprague-Grundy theorem to hypergraphs by defining an appropriate generalized game state space and move function. Our key contribution is an explicit formula for nim-values based on the hypergraph's adjacency tensor and a novel "hypergraph Grundy kernel" that encodes terminal state information. We analyze the periodicity and asymptotic behavior of these nim-values for infinite families of hypergraphs, revealing intricate combinatorial patterns. This work offers new theoretical tools for analyzing complex impartial games, moving beyond traditional graph-based models to encompass richer, higher-order interaction structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Characterizing Nim-Values for Impartial Games on Hypergraph Structures with Terminal Positions

text: We investigate extremal problems concerning the spectral radius of the adjacency matrix for graphs with simultaneously constrained connectivity and girth. Specifically, we derive novel lower and upper bounds for the maximum spectral radius among graphs with a given minimum degree, edge-connectivity, and lower bound on girth. Our methodology combines results from expander graph theory with structural decompositions, leveraging properties of the graph Laplacian and its smallest eigenvalues. We identify specific graph constructions that achieve these extremal values, often involving regular graphs with large girth. This research contributes to a deeper understanding of how local and global structural properties of a graph are encoded in its spectral characteristics, with applications in network design and robust graph constructions.
subject: Matematik
title: Extremal Spectral Radii for Graphs with Prescribed Connectivity and Girth

text: This paper provides a refined characterization of matroid representability over finite fields GF(q) through the lens of forbidden minors and novel circuit axioms. We generalize Tutte's theorem for regular matroids, identifying minimal non-GF(q)-representable matroids for specific small q values by explicitly constructing their excluded minors. Our approach involves a deep combinatorial analysis of circuit structures and their projective geometric realizations. We introduce a new set of circuit axioms that are necessary and sufficient for GF(q)-representability, offering an alternative to traditional matroid theory approaches based on rank functions or bases. This work advances the understanding of the algebraic and combinatorial distinctions between different classes of matroids, with implications for coding theory and combinatorial optimization over finite fields.
subject: Matematik
title: Matroid Representability over Finite Fields via Forbidden Minors and Circuit Axioms

text: This work investigates the asymptotic behavior of fractional (k,l)-Ramsey numbers, R_f(K_k^(r), K_l^(r)), for uniform hypergraphs. We establish novel lower bounds utilizing probabilistic methods combined with sophisticated alterations of the Lovász local lemma, particularly focusing on the sparse regime where p « n^(-r+1). Our approach refines existing estimates by incorporating a novel generalized concept of graphons for hypergraphs, termed 'hypergraphons', to model dense limiting structures. We demonstrate a logarithmic improvement over previous constructions for certain parameter sets, particularly when k and l are large relative to r. Furthermore, we explore connections to the independence polynomial of hypergraphs, deriving an upper bound through spectral properties of the adjacency tensor. These findings contribute significantly to the understanding of extremal problems in hypergraph theory and offer new pathways for exploring the interplay between combinatorial structures and their fractional relaxations.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotic Bounds for Fractional (k,l)-Ramsey Numbers on Hypergraphs

text: We present a comprehensive study of Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials associated with type D Weyl groups, extending the combinatorial framework of fully commutative elements to a broader class of parabolic quotients. Our primary contribution lies in the explicit construction of a cellular basis for the Hecke algebra, parameterized by specific patterns avoiding certain subwords, which facilitates a direct computation of these polynomials via an inductive algorithm. This cellular structure elucidates intricate connections between the representation theory of the Hecke algebra and the geometry of corresponding flag varieties. Furthermore, we establish novel recurrences for the p-canonical basis elements, demonstrating their compatibility with the left cells, thereby providing a refined combinatorial understanding of the underlying affine Weyl group structures. The results offer significant insights into the deep interplay between combinatorial algebra and geometric representation theory, particularly for non-simply laced Lie types.
subject: Matematik
title: Kazhdan-Lusztig Polynomials and Cellular Structures in Type D Weyl Groups

text: This research investigates phase transitions for high-order connectivity in various models of random simplicial complexes, specifically focusing on the G(n,p) and X(n,p) models. We establish sharp thresholds for the k-connectivity of the clique complex and the Vietoris-Rips complex, demonstrating that the critical probability p_c scales as n^(-1/k) for certain homological connectivity notions. Our methodology involves adapting techniques from high-dimensional expanders and applying martingale concentration inequalities to analyze the Betti numbers. A key innovation is the development of a 'local checkability' criterion for homological cycles, which allows for robust analysis of complexes with non-local structures. The results extend existing work on random graphs to higher dimensions, providing a foundational understanding of the emergence of topological features in complex networks and contributing to the nascent field of random topology.
subject: Matematik
title: Threshold Phenomena for Connectivity in Random Simplicial Complexes

text: This paper develops a novel framework based on the theory of combinatorial species to unify the enumeration of various multi-indexed permutation classes, including restricted permutations, pattern-avoiding permutations, and permutations with cycle-restricted structures. We introduce the concept of 'generalized species of permutations' equipped with a hierarchical composition operator, leading to a universal recurrence relation applicable to a broad spectrum of enumeration problems. Our method leverages the Joyal's calculus of species, extending it to handle generating functions with multiple indeterminates and intricate dependencies on permutation statistics. We provide explicit constructions for species corresponding to permutations avoiding sets of patterns of length up to four and derive new asymptotic formulas for their enumerating sequences. This work establishes a powerful theoretical underpinning for combinatorial enumeration, offering a systematic approach to problems previously tackled on a case-by-case basis.
subject: Matematik
title: Combinatorial Species and Universal Recurrence Relations for Multi-Indexed Permutations

text: We present a comprehensive study on the structural properties of binary matroids that exclude specific projective planes as minors. Our primary contribution is a proof that any GF(2)-representable matroid not containing a particular rank-3 projective plane as a minor must be a graphic matroid or a cographic matroid with bounded treewidth. This result extends the classical forbidden minor characterization for graphic matroids (Wagner's theorem) to a more general class of binary matroids. The proof technique involves a novel decomposition theorem based on k-sums, adapting techniques from graph minor theory to the matroid setting. We establish tight bounds on the size of the excluded minors necessary to guarantee representability over certain finite fields. These findings provide significant advancements in the understanding of matroid structural theory and its interplay with graph minor theory, paving the way for new algorithmic approaches to matroid decomposition problems.
subject: Matematik
title: Excluding Projective Planes as Minors in Binary Matroids

text: This work investigates finiteness theorems for oriented matroids in the context of universal point sets for planar graphs and rectilinear drawings. We establish that for any fixed d, there exists a finite number of oriented matroids of rank d representable over the reals with a bounded number of circuits, up to isomorphism. Our primary contribution is a novel algorithmic framework for constructing these universal point sets based on the generalized wiring diagram representation of oriented matroids, leveraging tropical geometric interpretations. We prove that the smallest universal point set for all planar graphs with n vertices has size Õ(n log n / log log n), improving upon previous bounds. The methods involve a deep interplay between combinatorial geometry, order types, and the theory of zonotopes, offering new avenues for optimizing graph embeddings and understanding the geometric realization problem for abstract combinatorial structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Finiteness Theorems for Oriented Matroids and Universal Point Sets

text: This paper extends the machinery of higher-order Fourier analysis to the non-abelian group setting, providing new insights into sum-product estimates and their applications in combinatorial number theory. We introduce a generalized notion of Gowers norms for arbitrary finite groups, utilizing the representation theory of non-commutative algebras to define an appropriate notion of 'non-abelian linear forms'. Our central result establishes a non-abelian inverse theorem for these Gowers norms, linking large norms to approximate homomorphisms into nilpotent groups. This framework allows us to derive novel sum-product inequalities for subsets of non-abelian groups, generalizing established results like the Balog-Szemerédi-Gowers theorem. The implications are far-reaching, offering a new analytical toolkit for studying the structure of sets with small sumsets or product sets in highly non-commutative environments, thereby bridging additive combinatorics with abstract harmonic analysis.
subject: Matematik
title: Higher-Order Fourier Analysis on Non-abelian Groups and Sum-Product Estimates

text: We develop a discrete Morse theory for posets equipped with a specific lexicographical product order, extending Forman's original framework to non-CW complexes arising from combinatorial structures. Our primary contribution is the construction of an explicit Morse matching for the face poset of a certain class of simplicial complexes, allowing for direct computation of their homology groups. This method provides new insights into the homological stability of configuration spaces of points on graphs, demonstrating that the Betti numbers stabilize for large numbers of points. We establish general conditions under which such Morse functions exist and derive spectral sequences linking the homology of the poset to its underlying combinatorial properties. The results offer a powerful computational and theoretical tool for analyzing the topological invariants of complex combinatorial objects, with applications ranging from algebraic topology to theoretical computer science.
subject: Matematik
title: Discrete Morse Theory for Posets and Homological Stability of Configuration Spaces

text: This work investigates the decidability of various factorization properties for infinite words generated by finite automata, specifically focusing on automatic sequences over finite alphabets. We establish a deep connection between the recognizability of a language by a finite automaton and the 'finite index property' of its associated factor graph. Our main result demonstrates that the question of whether an automatic sequence is power-free (e.g., cube-free or square-free) is decidable, extending previously known results for Sturmian words. The proof relies on advanced techniques from automata theory, combinatorics on words, and effective anaysis of Minsky machines. Furthermore, we provide an algorithm for determining if an automatic sequence contains an arbitrarily long subsequence that is a Lyndon word concatenation. These findings contribute significantly to the structural theory of automatic sequences and have implications for computational linguistics and theoretical computer science.
subject: Matematik
title: Automatic Sequences and the Decidability of Factorization Properties in Regular Languages

text: This research explores the application of non-backtracking walk matrices and their spectral properties to the graph isomorphism problem, particularly for highly regular graph classes such as strongly regular graphs and distance-regular graphs. We demonstrate that the spectrum of the non-backtracking matrix, coupled with certain local structural invariants, provides a refined invariant capable of distinguishing non-isomorphic graphs where the adjacency matrix spectrum fails. Our primary contribution is the development of a polynomial-time algorithm for isomorphism testing on circulant graphs based on the distinct eigenvalues of the non-backtracking matrix and the analysis of their associated eigenvectors' support. This method offers a significant improvement in complexity for specific graph classes over existing general isomorphism algorithms. The findings highlight the power of non-local spectral information in resolving challenging combinatorial problems and advance the theoretical understanding of graph invariants.
subject: Matematik
title: Spectral Radius and Graph Isomorphism for Highly Regular Graphs via Non-backtracking Walk Matrices

text: Deep learning models often learn spurious correlations, hindering generalization to out-of-distribution data. This paper proposes a novel variational autoencoder (VAE) framework augmented with structural causal models (SCMs) and a counterfactual regularization loss to disentangle invariant causal features from observational high-dimensional data. Our mechanism enables the isolation of genuine causal factors, making learned representations robust to distributional shifts and mitigating challenges posed by dataset bias. Empirical validation on synthetic and real-world medical imaging datasets demonstrates superior out-of-distribution performance and enhanced interpretability of learned representations compared to state-of-the-art disentanglement and invariant risk minimization techniques. The framework offers a principled approach for developing robust and trustworthy AI systems in complex decision-making environments, moving beyond correlation-based learning paradigms.
subject: AI
title: Deconfounding Spurious Correlations in Deep Learning via Counterfactual Causal Disentanglement

text: Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit remarkable generative capabilities but are prone to factual inconsistency and epistemic hallucination, compromising their reliability in critical applications. This paper introduces a novel self-correction mechanism grounded in Bayesian inference and calibrated confidence estimation. Our approach employs a multi-stage decoding process where the LLM generates initial responses, estimates its own uncertainty via entropy-based metrics, and iteratively refines outputs by querying internal knowledge states or external verified sources when uncertainty exceeds a predefined threshold. Empirical evaluation across diverse question-answering and summarization benchmarks demonstrates significant reductions in hallucination rates and improved factual accuracy, alongside better calibration of predictive probabilities, thereby enhancing trustworthiness without requiring explicit human feedback during inference.
subject: AI
title: Mitigating Epistemic Uncertainty and Hallucination in Large Language Models through Calibrated Self-Correction

text: Addressing the critical challenges of scalability and credit assignment in cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) settings, we propose a novel decentralized policy optimization framework. Our method integrates a centralized critic with a factorized representation of the global Q-function, enabling efficient decomposition of value estimates across individual agents. To tackle sparse and delayed reward signals, we incorporate a temporal attention mechanism within the critic network, allowing it to dynamically weigh the influence of past interactions on current reward attribution. Experimental results in complex StarCraft II multi-agent challenge environments demonstrate superior learning efficiency and asymptotic performance compared to contemporary value-decomposition and actor-critic MARL algorithms, particularly in scenarios characterized by high-dimensional observation spaces and non-stationary agent policies.
subject: AI
title: Decentralized Policy Optimization for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems with Sparse, Delayed Rewards

text: Explainable AI for Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) remains a nascent but critical area, particularly for mission-critical applications involving complex, heterogeneous graph structures. This work introduces a novel framework for generating graph counterfactual explanations (GCX) tailored for node classification tasks. Unlike existing approaches that perturb features or edges, our method identifies the minimal, actionable changes to a node's ego-network (structural and attributive) that would flip its predicted class, while adhering to graph domain constraints. We leverage a Gumbel-Softmax reparameterization trick within an adversarial training scheme to efficiently search the combinatorial graph space. Extensive evaluations on biomedical and social network datasets demonstrate that GCX provides intuitive, parsimonious, and robust explanations, significantly enhancing the trustworthiness and interpretability of GNN predictions compared to attribution-based methods.
subject: AI
title: Graph Counterfactual Explanations for Robust and Interpretable Node Classification in Heterogeneous Networks

text: Federated Learning (FL) offers privacy-preserving distributed model training but often struggles with statistical heterogeneity (client drift) and personalization across diverse client data distributions. We propose a novel meta-learning approach for personalized FL (pFL) that learns to rapidly adapt a global model to individual client characteristics. Our framework, FedMeta-pFL, trains a meta-learner on the global server to initialize client models such that a few local gradient steps lead to highly personalized and performant models. This is achieved by optimizing for a robust initialization that facilitates efficient adaptation to each client's unique data manifold, leveraging concepts from Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML). Empirical evaluations on non-IID datasets demonstrate significant improvements in per-client model accuracy and convergence speed, outperforming existing personalized FL techniques and traditional FL baselines in real-world edge device scenarios.
subject: AI
title: Personalized Federated Learning via Meta-Learning for Heterogeneous Client Data Distributions

text: Traditional deep learning excels at perception but struggles with symbolic reasoning and knowledge extrapolation, while symbolic AI offers interpretability but lacks perceptual robustness. We present a neuro-symbolic architecture that synergistically combines a deep neural network for feature extraction with a probabilistic logic programming (PLP) framework for relational reasoning. Our approach learns latent predicates from perceptual inputs and grounds them into a PLP rule base, enabling complex inductive inferences, handling uncertainty, and facilitating knowledge transfer. A differentiable "perception-to-logic" interface allows end-to-end training and gradient propagation, ensuring coherence between learned representations and logical rules. Experimental results on visual question answering and scene graph generation tasks demonstrate superior generalization to novel compositions and improved robustness to noisy inputs compared to purely neural or symbolic methods.
subject: AI
title: Integrating Neural Perception with Probabilistic Logic Programming for Robust Inductive Reasoning

text: Catastrophic forgetting remains a primary impediment to the deployment of neural networks in lifelong learning paradigms. This paper introduces a novel continual learning framework that leverages Complementary Variational Memory Replay (CVMR) to mitigate this issue. CVMR maintains a dynamic, generative memory buffer that not only stores representative samples from previous tasks but also learns to reconstruct and synthesize counterfactual instances, effectively diversifying the replay experience. A task-aware attentional mechanism within the generative process prioritizes salient features for knowledge consolidation, while an orthogonal weight regularization ensures parameter stability. Empirical validation on sequential image classification benchmarks demonstrates significant reductions in forgetting rates and superior forward/backward transfer, achieving state-of-the-art performance without compromising model capacity or introducing prohibitive computational overhead.
subject: AI
title: Overcoming Catastrophic Forgetting in Lifelong Learning via Complementary Variational Memory Replay

text: The integration of quantum computing with machine learning holds transformative potential, particularly for complex graph-structured data. This paper proposes a novel hybrid classical-quantum algorithm, the Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) for Graph Neural Network (GNN) feature learning, designed for noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices. Our method encodes adjacency and node feature information into a parameterized quantum circuit (PQC), optimizing its parameters via VQE to minimize a cost function representing graph-specific spectral properties. The resulting quantum state encodes rich, entangled representations that are then decoded and used as enhanced node features for classical GNN layers. Numerical simulations demonstrate that this hybrid approach can capture non-local dependencies more effectively than purely classical GNNs, offering robustness to adversarial perturbations and superior performance on graph classification tasks, even under simulated NISQ noise models.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Eigensolver for Graph Neural Network Feature Learning in Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum Processors

text: Guaranteeing the robustness of deep neural networks against complex, semantic adversarial perturbations—which often go beyond pixel-level noise to include transformations like rotations, translations, or style changes—is a critical challenge. We propose a novel framework for certified robustness that operates in a learned semantic feature space rather than the raw input space. Our method leverages Lipschitz continuity constraints applied to an encoder's latent representation, effectively bounding the change in classification output for a given semantic perturbation budget in the feature space. We derive a verifiable certification procedure using convex relaxations and randomized smoothing in this projected space. Experimental results on image classification tasks against adversarial transformations demonstrate that our approach provides tighter and more meaningful certified robustness guarantees compared to methods operating solely in the input pixel domain.
subject: AI
title: Certified Robustness against Semantic Perturbations via Feature-Space Lipschitz Regularization

text: Diffusion models have revolutionized generative AI, but challenges remain in achieving both high-fidelity synthesis and precise semantic control across multiple modalities. We introduce a novel hierarchical latent diffusion model (HLDM) that disentangles global semantic control from fine-grained synthesis details. Our architecture employs a primary diffusion process in a low-dimensional latent space to generate high-level semantic layouts or abstract concepts, followed by a secondary, conditional diffusion process that upsamples and infills these latent representations into high-resolution, multi-modal outputs (e.g., images, text, audio). This hierarchical decomposition significantly improves generation quality and enables granular control over attributes at different levels of abstraction. Extensive evaluations demonstrate superior performance in tasks like conditional image generation, text-to-image synthesis, and layout-to-scene generation, yielding state-of-the-art perceptual quality and adherence to complex compositional prompts.
subject: AI
title: Hierarchical Latent Diffusion Models for Controllable and High-Fidelity Multi-Modal Content Generation

text: This work investigates the robust realization of fault-tolerant quantum computation leveraging the non-abelian braiding statistics of anyonic excitations in topologically ordered phases. We present a theoretical framework for encoding quantum information within the degenerate ground states of a 2D Kitaev spin liquid model subjected to specific perturbations, focusing on the Z2 toric code and its non-abelian generalizations. Our analysis details schemes for topological data manipulation and readout through localized vortex manipulations, demonstrating the intrinsic protection against local decoherence inherent to their non-local encoding. Furthermore, we quantify the error thresholds for various physical implementations, considering both quasi-particle poisoning and global phase errors, establishing a pathway towards scalable, hardware-agnostic topological qubits that circumvent conventional error correction overheads by design. The results underscore the critical role of exotic emergent statistics in quantum information processing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Anyon Braiding for Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation via Kitaev Spin Liquids

text: We present a rigorous theoretical investigation into quantum electrodynamics (QED) phenomena arising from the interaction of matter-free vacuum with ultra-intense electromagnetic fields, specifically focusing on prospective multi-petawatt laser facilities. Our analysis extends beyond perturbative regimes to encompass non-linear effects such as vacuum polarization and the dynamically assisted Schwinger pair production. Utilizing the Dirac-Heisenberg-Wyl equations of motion in a background field, we compute the critical field strength modifications due to higher-order loop corrections and delineate the threshold for observable electron-positron pair creation from vacuum. The study provides quantitative predictions for signatures detectable in upcoming experiments, including gamma-ray emission spectra and angular distributions of produced particles, offering a unique laboratory for probing the fundamental fabric of QED in a regime where vacuum itself becomes a non-trivial, interactive medium, shedding light on astrophysical phenomena.
subject: Kuantum
title: Vacuum Polarization and Schwinger Pair Production in Ultra-Intense Laser Fields

text: This research explores the emergence and characterization of Many-Body Localization (MBL) in strongly disordered, interacting quantum systems, which represents a profound breakdown of thermalization and ergodicity. We investigate the interplay between disorder, interaction strength, and system size on the entanglement dynamics and spectral properties of 1D and quasi-2D spin chains. Employing exact diagonalization and time-evolving block decimation (TEBD) techniques, we demonstrate the logarithmic growth of entanglement entropy and the absence of thermalization for typical initial states in the MBL phase, contrasting sharply with the volume-law entropy observed in ergodic systems. Our findings elucidate the persistence of local memory and the localization of quantum information, offering insights into the mechanisms underlying the failure of statistical mechanics in highly quantum settings and providing a theoretical foundation for designing robust quantum memories.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent Many-Body Localization in Disordered Interacting Quantum Systems: Entanglement Dynamics and Ergodicity Breaking

text: This study explores potential phenomenological signatures of quantum gravity arising from Planck-scale modifications to spacetime structure, specifically focusing on energy-dependent Lorentz violations. We analyze high-energy photon data from distant Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs) as cosmic laboratories to constrain parameters associated with quantum spacetime foam models, such as those predicted by certain approaches to Loop Quantum Gravity or string theory. The proposed framework posits a modified dispersion relation for photons propagating over cosmological distances, leading to a measurable energy-dependent time-of-flight delay. By rigorously analyzing transient astrophysical events with wide spectral coverage and rapid variability, we establish stringent bounds on the leading-order coefficients of superluminal or subluminal light propagation, offering compelling empirical tests for the fundamental discreteness of spacetime and the potential breaking of Lorentz symmetry at extreme energy scales beyond the Standard Model.
subject: Kuantum
title: Phenomenological Signatures of Spacetime Quantization from Lorentz Violation in Gamma-Ray Bursts

text: We investigate the relativistic quantum information phenomenon of entanglement harvesting, wherein two spatially separated, non-interacting Unruh-DeWitt detectors extract entanglement from the shared quantum vacuum field, even in the absence of pre-existing field excitations. This work extends prior analyses to scenarios involving curved spacetime backgrounds, specifically focusing on the vicinity of black holes and cosmological horizons. We derive analytical expressions for the mutual information and concurrence between two detectors interacting with a scalar field, quantifying the harvested entanglement as a function of their spatial separation, interaction time, and trajectory within a Schwarzschild or de Sitter metric. Our findings reveal that spacetime curvature significantly modulates entanglement harvesting capabilities, potentially enhancing or suppressing correlations depending on the gravitational field gradients, thereby offering novel perspectives on the interplay between quantum entanglement, vacuum structure, and general relativity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Relativistic Entanglement Harvesting from Vacuum Fluctuations via Unruh-DeWitt Detectors in Curved Spacetime

text: This research details the experimental realization and theoretical characterization of synthetic gauge fields in ultracold Bose-Einstein Condensates (BECs), leading to the observation of novel topological excitations. By coupling internal atomic states to spatially varying laser fields, we engineer an effective Lorentz force on neutral atoms, mimicking the behavior of charged particles in magnetic fields. Our methodology enables the creation of large uniform synthetic magnetic fluxes and the subsequent detection of vortex lattices and chiral edge states within the BEC. We present quantitative measurements of the quantized circulation and the Berry curvature associated with these engineered fields. These results establish ultracold atomic systems as versatile platforms for simulating condensed matter phenomena, including fractional quantum Hall physics and topological insulators, offering unprecedented control over Hamiltonian parameters and direct access to microscopic dynamics, thus paving the way for emergent quantum technologies.
subject: Kuantum
title: Realization of Synthetic Gauge Fields and Topological Excitations in Ultracold Bose-Einstein Condensates

text: We present an experimental and theoretical investigation into the fundamental nature of quantum contextuality, extending the canonical Kochen-Specker theorem to multi-qubit entangled systems. Utilizing a high-fidelity source of polarization-entangled photon pairs, we implement a novel sequence of projective measurements designed to test for contextuality beyond simple state-independent non-contextuality proofs. Our approach leverages the concept of generalized Bell inequalities for specific observable sets, revealing robust violations of non-contextual hidden variable models even when traditional Bell tests fail.
