The experimental results, exhibiting statistical significance exceeding 10 standard deviations, provide compelling evidence against any non-contextual, realistic interpretation of quantum mechanics for specific entangled states. This work deepens our understanding of the inherent non-classicality of quantum measurement processes and their intrinsic dependence on the measurement context.
subject: Kuantum
title: Contextuality and Non-Classicality in Extended Kochen-Specker Scenarios with Entangled Photon Qubits

text: This work explores the application of dynamically generated spin squeezing to enhance the precision of quantum metrology, particularly in atomic clock and magnetic field sensing applications. We theoretically analyze and experimentally demonstrate the generation of highly entangled, spin-squeezed states in a collective atomic ensemble via engineered non-linear interactions, specifically using one-axis twisting Hamiltonians. By carefully controlling the detuning and intensity of off-resonant light, we achieve up to 8 dB of metrological spin squeezing, corresponding to a significant reduction in the phase uncertainty below the standard quantum limit. Our findings detail the robust coherence times achieved and the resilience of these entangled states against environmental decoherence. This research opens avenues for surpassing classical measurement limits, offering a pathway to develop next-generation sensors and clocks with unprecedented sensitivity and stability, crucial for fundamental physics tests and practical applications.
subject: Kuantum
title: Enhancing Quantum Metrology via Dynamically Generated Spin Squeezing in Atomic Ensembles

text: This study presents a comprehensive investigation into the unconventional pairing symmetry and nodal gap structure of iron-based high-temperature superconductors, leveraging high-resolution scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and spectroscopic mapping of quasiparticle interference (QPI). By analyzing the momentum-space dispersion and energy dependence of Bogoliubov quasiparticles scattered from atomic impurities, we reconstruct the superconducting gap anisotropy and identify dominant pairing channels. Our experimental data, combined with theoretical modeling based on strong-coupling Eliashberg theory, strongly supports a s±-wave pairing symmetry with distinct nodeless gaps on different Fermi surface sheets, or potentially nodes in specific regions of the Brillouin zone, challenging simple isotropic s-wave scenarios. These findings provide critical insights into the microscopic mechanism of high-Tc superconductivity in these complex materials, highlighting the importance of fermiology and spin fluctuations in mediating electron pairing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Unconventional Pairing Symmetry and Nodal Gap Structure in Iron-Based Superconductors via Quasiparticle Interference

text: We report the experimental observation of the chiral anomaly and robust Fermi arc surface states in the type-II Weyl semimetal TaP, providing compelling evidence for its topological nature. Employing angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES), we directly visualize the separation of Weyl nodes in momentum space and the distinctive non-closed Fermi arcs connecting them on the sample surface. Magnetotransport measurements reveal a negative longitudinal magnetoresistance that is highly sensitive to the orientation of applied electric and magnetic fields, a hallmark signature of the chiral anomaly where parallel fields induce a current imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality. Our results validate theoretical predictions for type-II Weyl semimetals, characterized by tilted Weyl cones, and underscore their potential for fault-tolerant electronics and novel quantum computing paradigms exploiting the topological protection of their electronic states.
subject: Kuantum
title: Observation of Chiral Anomaly and Fermi Arc Surface States in Type-II Weyl Semimetal TaP

text: This research addresses an extension of the classical Turan problem, focusing on determining the maximum number of edges in an r-uniform hypergraph that does not contain a specific complete bipartite hypergraph K_s,t^(r) as a subgraph, under novel constraints on the edge partition. We explore critical thresholds for r-uniform hypergraphs where vertices are partitioned into two sets, X and Y, and edges are characterized by their intersection with these partitions. Employing a sophisticated combination of probabilistic methods and algebraic techniques, particularly polynomial method variants adapted for hypergraphs, we establish new upper bounds for the Turan number ex(n, K_s,t^(r)) when the edges must conform to a specified distribution across X and Y. Our findings refine previous asymptotic estimates and offer novel insights into the structural properties of extremal hypergraphs under specific partitioning constraints, with implications for generalized Ramsey theory.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Turan Problem for Complete Bipartite Hypergraphs with Prescribed Edge Partitions

text: This paper investigates the explicit construction and characterization of standard monomial bases for quantum Schubert varieties associated with arbitrary root systems. Building upon the foundational work in canonical bases and Lusztig's theory of quantum groups, we introduce a novel combinatorial framework that leverages advanced properties of crystal graphs for modules over quantum algebras. Specifically, we establish a direct correspondence between certain paths in modified crystal graphs and the standard monomials in the coordinate ring of quantum flag varieties. This correspondence facilitates a constructive proof of existence and uniqueness for these bases, extending known results for classical Lie types to exceptional cases. The methodology employs non-commutative Gröbner basis theory and provides new avenues for understanding the representation theory of quantum groups and the geometry of related flag manifolds.
subject: Matematik
title: Characterizing Standard Monomial Bases for Quantum Schubert Varieties via Crystal Graphs

text: We present a rigorous analysis of the emergence of Hamiltonian cycles in various models of random k-uniform hypergraphs, particularly focusing on settings where the underlying vertex set exhibits specific expansion properties. Our primary contribution involves establishing sharp threshold functions for the existence of Hamiltonian cycles in the G^(k)(n,p) model, where edges are chosen independently with probability p, by employing a refined second moment method coupled with high-dimensional concentration inequalities. Furthermore, we investigate the robustness of these thresholds under perturbations and demonstrate how local expansion conditions on the hypergraph significantly influence the connectivity properties, including the existence of long cycles. The results extend classical theorems from random graph theory to the hypergraph setting, providing precise probabilistic bounds and shedding light on the structural evolution of complex network models with high-order interactions.
subject: Matematik
title: Sharp Thresholds for Hamiltonian Cycles in Random Hypergraphs on Expanding Vertex Sets

text: This paper introduces a family of q-analogs for rook polynomials defined on arbitrary Ferrers boards, generalizing classical results and establishing novel connections to inversion numbers on permutations and partially ordered sets (posets). We develop a generating function approach using non-commutative formal power series, allowing for a refined enumeration of configurations of non-attacking rooks on generalized boards. Our main result demonstrates that specific evaluations of these q-rook polynomials yield statistics related to major index and inversion numbers for permutations restricted to certain pattern-avoiding classes. Furthermore, we explore the combinatorial interpretation of their coefficients as weighted sums over subsets of permutations with a prescribed number of inversions or descents, thereby extending the known combinatorial interpretations of q-binomial coefficients and related q-series identities.
subject: Matematik
title: q-Analogs of Rook Polynomials and their Connections to Inversion Numbers on Partially Ordered Sets

text: We present new decomposition theorems for matroids that exhibit restricted planarity or high Tutte connectivity, extending the classical results of Seymour on series-parallel networks and the structure of graphic matroids. Our framework introduces a novel notion of "k-planar representability" for matroids, based on their minor exclusion characteristics relative to certain non-planar graphic matroids. The primary decomposition identifies prime matroids via a generalized 3-separation theorem, allowing for a canonical representation as a direct sum or 2-sum of components that are either graphic, cographic, or members of a restricted family of non-representable matroids. This work refines our understanding of how connectivity constraints limit the complexity of matroid structure, with implications for efficient algorithms in combinatorial optimization and the characterization of matroids representable over finite fields.
subject: Matematik
title: Decomposition Theorems for Matroids with Restricted Planarity and Tutte Connectivity

text: This paper investigates the construction of optimal (v,k,λ)-designs possessing large automorphism groups, leveraging advanced techniques from finite field geometry and group theory. We introduce a novel methodology that correlates the existence and properties of such designs with the orbits of specific subgroups of classical groups acting on points and subspaces of projective and affine geometries over finite fields. By carefully selecting parameters and constructing incidence structures derived from these geometric configurations, we are able to generate several new families of symmetric and quasi-symmetric designs, some of which achieve known bounds for efficiency and parameters. Our constructions often yield designs with non-trivial automorphism groups, enabling more efficient computational verification and providing deeper insights into the symmetry inherent in these combinatorial structures, relevant for coding theory and cryptography.
subject: Matematik
title: Constructions of Optimal (v,k,λ)-Designs with Large Automorphism Groups via Finite Field Geometry

text: This research extends classical finite and infinite Ramsey theory to the realm of functional analysis, specifically focusing on partition regular properties of equations and structures within bounded subsets of infinite-dimensional Banach spaces. We introduce a novel combinatorial principle, the "Banach-Ramsey principle," which guarantees monochromatic solutions to systems of linear equations under specific coloring schemes of points in the unit ball of a separable Banach space. Our approach employs ultrafilter methods and topological dynamics to establish the existence of large monochromatic substructures, generalizing Hindman's Theorem and its density versions. The findings provide a unified framework for identifying Ramsey-theoretic phenomena in non-standard mathematical settings, bridging combinatorial arguments with concepts from geometry of Banach spaces and topological algebra, with implications for structural Ramsey theory and compactifications.
subject: Matematik
title: Infinite Dimensional Ramsey Theory on Bounded Subsets of Banach Spaces

text: We present an asymptotic enumeration of restricted partition functions, specifically focusing on partitions where parts satisfy congruence conditions or are drawn from sparse sets, building upon the Hardy-Ramanujan circle method and its modern adaptations. Our approach refines the classical saddle-point approximation by incorporating insights from the theory of modular forms and elliptic functions, allowing for the precise estimation of coefficients for complex generating functions. We derive explicit asymptotic formulas for several classes of restricted partitions, including those into distinct parts with specific residue classes modulo m, providing error bounds that significantly improve upon previous results. This methodology also yields new analytical relationships between partition functions and mock theta functions, illustrating deep connections between additive combinatorics, number theory, and the analytic theory of q-series.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotic Enumeration of Restricted Partition Functions via Saddle-Point Approximations and Modular Forms

text: This research delves into the polyhedral structure of several variants of the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem (CVRP) defined on metric graphs, aiming to develop more efficient exact and approximation algorithms. We introduce novel facet-defining inequalities for the associated polytopes, extending classical cutting plane techniques such from the traveling salesman problem (TSP) and generalized assignment problems. Through a detailed analysis of the underlying graph theory, we identify new families of valid inequalities, including generalizations of comb inequalities and lifted path inequalities, demonstrating their strength in cutting planes for optimal solutions. Computational experiments on benchmark instances confirm that these new inequalities significantly tighten the linear programming relaxations, leading to improved branch-and-cut algorithms. This work contributes to the theoretical understanding of NP-hard routing problems and enhances practical solution methodologies in combinatorial optimization.
subject: Matematik
title: Polyhedral Combinatorics of Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problems on Metric Graphs

text: This paper explores the intricate relationship between combinatorial invariants of hyperplane arrangements and the topological properties of their associated moduli spaces. We develop a new framework for studying the characteristic polynomial and the Orlik-Solomon algebra of arrangements by leveraging higher-order intersection lattices and matroid theory generalizations. Our main results establish novel connections between the exponents of these combinatorial invariants and the homotopy type of complements of complex hyperplane arrangements, particularly focusing on those arising from Coxeter groups and Weyl groups. We demonstrate that specific geometric properties of the arrangement, such as freeness or nearly freeness, are reflected in the algebraic structure of the Orlik-Solomon algebra, with implications for the classification of arrangements and the computation of their cohomology. This work bridges algebraic combinatorics, algebraic topology, and singularity theory.
subject: Matematik
title: Combinatorial Invariants of Hyperplane Arrangements and the Topology of Moduli Spaces

text: The ATP-dependent chromatin remodeler SWI/SNF plays a pivotal role in regulating chromatin architecture, yet its contribution to topologically associating domain (TAD) dynamics remains enigmatic. Here, we demonstrate that SWI/SNF, particularly the BAF complex, directly interacts with CTCF at specific TAD boundaries, facilitating their establishment and maintenance. Genetic ablation of key BAF subunits (e.g., SMARCA4/BRG1) leads to widespread erosion of TAD demarcation, characterized by aberrant enhancer-promoter interactions and dysregulated transcription of lineage-determining genes. Mechanistically, SWI/SNF nucleosome repositioning adjacent to CTCF binding sites is critical for establishing appropriate chromatin loop extrusion barriers. These findings reveal a novel, cooperative mechanism wherein SWI/SNF fine-tunes CTCF-mediated chromatin looping, profoundly impacting genome organization and transcriptional fidelity, with implications for developmental disorders and oncogenesis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Nucleosome Remodeling Complex SWI/SNF Orchestrates Topologically Associating Domain Boundary Dynamics via CTCF-Dependent Chromatin Looping

text: N6-methyladenosine (m6A) epitranscriptomic modification significantly influences mRNA fate. While m6A readers YTHDF1-3 are implicated in translation, their specific roles in dictating ribosomal dynamics on target mRNAs remain incompletely understood. Employing ribosome profiling and polysome fractionation, we uncover that YTHDF1 preferentially binds m6A-modified oncogenic transcripts, enhancing their translational efficiency by accelerating ribosomal elongation kinetics. Depletion of YTHDF1 leads to a discernible reduction in ribosomal occupancy on these specific transcripts, accompanied by ribosome pause accumulation at m6A sites. Furthermore, YTHDF1’s interaction with translation initiation factors and direct recruitment of elongator tRNA complexes appears to streamline protein synthesis. This mechanism reveals YTHDF1 as a critical conduit linking epitranscriptomic marks to precise control over oncogene expression, offering new therapeutic avenues.
subject: Biyoloji
title: N6-Methyladenosine (m6A) Reader YTHDF1 Directs Ribosomal Occupancy and Translational Elongation Kinetics of Oncogenic Transcripts

text: Chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA), a selective lysosomal degradation pathway, is crucial for cellular proteostasis. Its impairment is hypothesized to contribute to neurodegeneration, yet the precise mechanistic links to endolysosomal pathology remain elusive. We report that experimental dysregulation of CMA, via genetic silencing of LAMP2A or inhibition of HSP70 translocation, precipitates profound endolysosomal dysfunction characterized by reduced cargo acidification, impaired autophagosome-lysosome fusion, and accumulation of aberrant alpha-synuclein and tau aggregates. This impairment subsequently triggers the formation of cytoplasmic aggresomes, signifying overwhelmed ubiquitin-proteasome system capacity. Our findings delineate a pathogenic cascade where compromised CMA directly contributes to lysosomal proteolytic deficits, driving proteinopathy and cellular toxicity, providing a critical molecular link in the etiology of early-onset neurodegenerative disorders.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Chaperone-Mediated Autophagy Dysregulation Induces Endolysosomal Dysfunction and Aggresome Formation in Early-Onset Neurodegenerative Models

text: Mitochondrial dynamics, particularly inner membrane fusion orchestrated by OPA1, are pivotal for cellular bioenergetics. How OPA1 precisely modulates cristae ultrastructure to fine-tune oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) efficiency under metabolic stress, like hypoxia, is unclear. Our investigation reveals that acute hypoxia induces OPA1 cleavage and partial inner membrane fragmentation, leading to a transient decrease in electron transport chain (ETC) supercomplex assembly and ATP synthase activity. Paradoxically, sustained OPA1-mediated fusion under chronic hypoxia maintains cristae integrity, preserving OXPHOS efficiency and mitigating reactive oxygen species (ROS) overproduction, thereby facilitating cellular adaptation. This adaptive mechanism involves OPA1 interaction with specific ETC components, optimizing electron flow and preventing mitochondrial uncoupling. These data highlight OPA1 as a critical rheostat controlling mitochondrial bioenergetics and ROS homeostasis during hypoxic challenge.
subject: Biyoloji
title: OPA1-Mediated Mitochondrial Inner Membrane Fusion Regulates Oxidative Phosphorylation Efficiency and Reactive Oxygen Species Production in Hypoxic Adaptation

text: Targeted epigenetic reprogramming offers a powerful strategy against cancer by reactivating silenced tumor suppressor genes. We engineered dCas9-fused epigenetic modulators, specifically dCas9-KDM6A (a H3K27me3 demethylase), to precisely target promoter regions of epigenetically silenced tumor suppressors (e.g., CDKN2A, RASSF1A) in glioblastoma cell lines. Our approach demonstrates robust and locus-specific removal of repressive H3K27me3 marks, leading to significant re-expression of these critical genes without observable off-target effects on global chromatin states. Transcriptomic and functional analyses confirm restoration of cell cycle control, inhibition of proliferation, and increased apoptosis. This dCas9-KDM6A platform represents a high-precision tool for reversing oncogenic epigenetic silencing, offering a potent, sequence-specific therapeutic modality for refractory cancers by restoring endogenous tumor suppressive functions.
subject: Biyoloji
title: CRISPR-dCas9-Based Epigenetic Modulators Precisely Reprogram H3K27me3 Landscapes to Reactivate Oncogene-Silenced Tumor Suppressors

text: Mitochondria-associated membranes (MAMs) represent critical endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-mitochondria contact sites implicated in various cellular processes. While their role in lipid metabolism and calcium signaling is recognized, the precise mechanisms orchestrating these functions at MAMs, particularly regarding lipid droplet (LD) biogenesis, remain incompletely understood. We elucidated that Mfn2, a key tethering protein, dictates the proximity and functional coupling of ER and mitochondria at MAMs. Disruption of Mfn2-mediated tethering markedly impairs calcium flux through the IP3R-VDAC axis and compromises lipid transfer proteins, such as OSBP, leading to dysregulated phosphatidylserine synthesis and altered LD formation kinetics. Our findings reveal that Mfn2 is not merely a structural component but a crucial regulator integrating calcium signaling with lipid metabolism at MAMs, profoundly impacting cellular energy homeostasis and contributing to metabolic disorders.
subject: Biyoloji
title: ER-Mitochondria Interorganelle Contacts (MAMs) Modulate Lipid Droplet Biogenesis and Calcium Homeostasis via Mfn2-Dependent Tethering

text: The Werner Syndrome RecQ helicase (WRN) is essential for maintaining genomic stability, particularly at challenging replication forks and telomeres. However, its exact molecular mechanisms in resolving complex DNA structures like G-quadruplexes (G4s) during replication remain to be fully elucidated. Our study demonstrates that WRN is actively recruited to stalled replication forks, where it utilizes its helicase and exonuclease activities to remodel aberrant fork structures and promote restart. Crucially, WRN directly unwinds G4 structures within replication origins and telomeric regions, preventing their interference with DNA synthesis and minimizing replication stress. Loss of WRN function leads to increased G4-driven replication fork collapse, elevated genomic rearrangements, and accelerated telomere attrition. These data establish WRN as a pivotal guardian against G4-induced replication stress, safeguarding genome and telomere integrity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: RECQ-Helicase WRN Participates in Replication Fork Remodeling and Resolves G-Quadruplex Structures to Prevent Telomeric Instability

text: G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) are highly dynamic signaling hubs, with their activity intricately regulated by G-protein coupled receptor kinases (GRKs) and beta-arrestins. We investigated the nuanced role of GRK2 in modulating biased signaling and subsequent trafficking of chemokine receptors. Our data reveal that GRK2 not only phosphorylates CXCR4, initiating beta-arrestin recruitment, but also allosterically influences the conformational landscape of receptor-beta-arrestin complexes. This allosteric modulation dictates a distinct beta-arrestin signaling bias, preferentially promoting clathrin-mediated endocytosis over G-protein signaling, while also accelerating receptor dephosphorylation and subsequent recycling to the plasma membrane. This intricate regulatory mechanism by GRK2 fine-tunes the spatio-temporal dynamics of chemokine receptor signaling and responsiveness, profoundly impacting immune cell chemotaxis and inflammatory responses.
subject: Biyoloji
title: G-Protein Coupled Receptor Kinase 2 (GRK2) Allosterically Modulates Beta-Arrestin Bias Signaling to Fine-Tune Chemokine Receptor Internalization and Recycling Kinetics

text: The neural crest (NC) represents a multipotent stem cell population vital for vertebrate development, but the molecular heterogeneity driving its diverse differentiation pathways remains unresolved. We applied an integrative single-cell multi-omics approach, combining single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) with single-cell assay for transposase-accessible chromatin sequencing (scATAC-seq), to map the transcriptional and epigenomic landscapes of NC cell lineages during embryonic development. Our analysis delineates distinct NC subpopulations exhibiting differential chromatin accessibility at key developmental regulatory regions, correlating precisely with lineage-specific gene expression programs. Pseudotime trajectory inference reveals the sequential activation of master transcription factors governing craniofacial cartilage and peripheral nervous system differentiation. This comprehensive multi-omics atlas provides unprecedented resolution into NC cell fate decisions, uncovering novel regulatory networks orchestrating developmental plasticity and disease predisposition.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrative Single-Cell Multi-Omics Delineates Transcriptional and Chromatin Accessibility Heterogeneity in Developing Neural Crest Cell Lineages

text: The innate immune system relies on pattern recognition receptors to detect pathogen-associated molecular patterns, including cytosolic DNA. While cGAS-STING is a major DNA sensing pathway, the precise role of other interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) in potentiating this response, particularly during herpesvirus infection, is not fully elucidated. We demonstrate that IFI16, a nuclear DNA sensor, translocates to the cytosol upon herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) infection, acting as an essential adaptor for efficient cGAS-STING pathway activation. IFI16 directly binds to viral DNA in the cytosol, facilitating cGAS oligomerization and subsequent STING activation, thereby amplifying type I interferon production. Furthermore, IFI16 promotes the assembly of the NLRP3 inflammasome, leading to caspase-1 activation and IL-1β secretion. Our findings reveal IFI16 as a multi-functional host sensor critical for orchestrating a robust antiviral immune response by synergistically engaging both cGAS-STING and inflammasome pathways.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Interferon-Stimulated Gene (ISG) IFI16 Senses Cytosolic DNA to Drive cGAS-STING Pathway Activation and Inflammasome Assembly during Herpesvirus Infection

text: This study introduces a novel deep learning framework, employing a graph convolutional network (GCN) coupled with a transformer encoder, for the granular identification and localization of contrapuntal voice-leading violations within two-part Fuxian species counterpoint. Leveraging a meticulously curated dataset of annotated exercises, the model learns complex inter-voice dependencies and melodic contour constraints, surpassing traditional rule-based expert systems in adaptability and generalizability. Our methodology integrates pitch-class set theory and intervallic vector analysis within a temporal context, enabling the detection of parallel octaves/fifths, hidden parallels, improper melodic intervals, and voice crossing, even amidst metrical obfuscation. Preliminary results demonstrate a precision of 0.92 and recall of 0.88 for common violation types, offering a robust computational tool for pedagogical applications and comparative musicology, significantly advancing automated score analysis beyond symbolic representations.
subject: Müzik
title: Deep Learning for Granular Contrapuntal Violation Detection in Fuxian Species Counterpoint

text: This research explores the relationship between expressive performance gestures and resultant timbral modifications in solo violin and cello recordings. Utilizing a multi-modal approach, we combine motion capture data of bowing kinematics with high-resolution audio analysis, extracting spectral descriptors such as spectral centroid, odd-to-even harmonic ratio, and formant distribution dynamics via Constant-Q Transform (CQT) and cepstral analysis. A variational autoencoder (VAE) is employed to project these high-dimensional timbral features into a low-dimensional latent space, revealing characteristic trajectories associated with specific expressive intentions (e.g., *sforzato*, *legato*, *sul ponticello*). Furthermore, dynamic time warping (DTW) aligns these latent timbral paths with performer kinematic profiles. Findings indicate statistically significant correlations between micro-variations in bow pressure and velocity and distinct timbral cluster formations, providing quantitative evidence for the performer’s manipulation of timbre as a primary expressive parameter, thereby enriching our understanding of performance practice and informing advanced synthesis models.
subject: Müzik
title: Latent Timbre Trajectories and Expressive Intent: A Multi-Modal Analysis of String Instrument Performance

text: This paper presents a novel graph-theoretic model for automating aspects of Schenkerian structural reduction, particularly focusing on the identification of fundamental structures and prolongational patterns in tonal music. Our approach reinterprets hierarchical voice leading as a series of graph transformations applied to a pitch-time network derived from symbolic musical scores. Nodes represent pitch events, and edges denote melodic and harmonic relationships, weighted by psychoacoustic salience and Schenkerian principles of stepwise motion and consonance. A recursive algorithm identifies dominant prolongation, neighbor-note elaborations, and arpeggiations, gradually converging on a statistically salient *Ursatz* approximation. Leveraging dynamic programming for optimal path finding and probabilistic graphical models for ambiguity resolution, the system demonstrates the feasibility of computational parsing of tonal hierarchies, offering a quantifiable and reproducible method for comparative Schenkerian analysis, and paving the way for data-driven explorations of tonal coherence across diverse corpora.
subject: Müzik
title: A Graph-Theoretic Framework for Automated Structural Reduction in Tonal Music: Towards Algorithmic Schenkerian Analysis

text: This research addresses the computational challenge of identifying microtonal tuning systems and their perceptual correlates in ethnomusicological recordings and experimental compositions. We propose an unsupervised machine learning pipeline integrating an Adaptive Resonance Theory (ART) network with specialized spectral dissimilarity metrics. Audio signals are first processed via a high-resolution Constant-Q Transform (CQT), from which fundamental frequencies and salient partials are extracted. These pitch trajectories are then clustered by the ART network based on their intervallic relationships and deviation from standard equal temperament, using a novel 'spectral roughness' metric informed by psychoacoustic models of dissonance. The system robustly identifies underlying temperaments (e.g., 5-limit Just Intonation, various historical temperaments, arbitrary microtonal scales) and quantifies their consistency. This methodology provides an analytical lens for understanding non-standard pitch organization, offering insights into cross-cultural pitch perception and the structural properties of microtonal soundscapes.
subject: Müzik
title: Identifying Microtonal Tuning Systems through Adaptive Resonance Theory Networks and Spectral Dissimilarity Measures

text: This study presents a multi-scale computational framework for quantifying rhythmic complexity and metrical salience, with implications for predicting listener entrainment. We employ a wavelet-based onset detection algorithm to derive a rhythmic event sequence, which is then analyzed using information-theoretic measures (e.g., Shannon entropy, conditional entropy) across multiple temporal windows, mirroring human metrical perception. Furthermore, an autocorrelation-based periodicity analysis identifies underlying metrical layers and their interactions, quantifying metrical strength and ambiguity. Perceptual validation involves correlating these computational metrics with physiological markers of entrainment (e.g., heart rate variability, EEG alpha coherence) from human subjects engaged in rhythmic tasks. Our findings suggest that an optimal range of rhythmic entropy, coupled with clear yet flexible metrical cues, maximizes entrainment, providing a mechanistic explanation for the perceived 'groove' in complex polyrhythmic contexts and informing generative rhythmic composition algorithms.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Rhythmic Entropy and Metrical Salience: A Multi-Scale Computational Framework for Entrainment Prediction

text: This research critically re-evaluates traditional consonance/dissonance theories by exploring the role of spectral overlap and auditory scene analysis (ASA) principles in the perception of non-traditional and spectral harmonies. We analyze synthetic and acoustical stimuli featuring complex inharmonic partials, employing a psychoacoustically informed spectral modeling approach that quantifies harmonic fusion and roughness based on critical bands and the temporal dynamics of partial interactions. A novel 'spectral congruence index' is introduced, derived from the Kullback-Leibler divergence between the normalized spectral envelopes of simultaneously sounding tones. Perceptual experiments, using forced-choice judgments and continuous rating scales, correlate this index with subjective ratings of consonance, coherence, and timbral blend. Findings challenge the exclusive reliance on fundamental frequency ratios, demonstrating that the micro-structure of the spectral envelope significantly dictates perceived harmonic stability, offering a refined framework for understanding and composing with spectral resources beyond traditional intervallic considerations.
subject: Müzik
title: Re-evaluating Consonance and Dissonance through Spectral Overlap and Auditory Scene Analysis in Non-Traditional Harmonies

text: This study addresses the complex problem of formal section segmentation and function recognition in atonal music, where traditional tonal and thematic markers are often absent or obscured. We propose a transformer-based neural network architecture, pre-trained on a diverse corpus of 20th and 21st-century atonal works, to learn hierarchical representations of musical structure. Input features include time-series chroma vectors, spectral flux, onset density, and dynamically computed pitch-class set cardinality, capturing both local and global textural and timbral characteristics. The transformer's attention mechanism identifies long-range dependencies, enabling the inference of formal functions such as expositional, developmental, or recapitulatory gestures based on learned patterns of density, repetition, and textural contrast. Our methodology offers a robust, data-driven alternative to heuristic rule-based systems, yielding significant improvements in F1-score for boundary detection and section classification, thereby facilitating macro-structural analysis of complex non-tonal repertoires.
subject: Müzik
title: Hierarchical Feature Learning for Formal Section Segmentation in Atonal Music via Transformer Networks

text: This research introduces a novel deep learning approach for automated voice leading analysis in complex polyphonic textures, addressing the challenges of voice separation and melodic trajectory tracking. We utilize a Deep Graph Convolutional Network (DGCN) where nodes represent individual pitch events (derived from multi-pitch detection) and edges are weighted by melodic proximity, pitch commonality, and psychoacoustic streaming cues (e.g., loudness, timbre similarity, co-modulations). The DGCN learns optimal voice assignments and evaluates their adherence to established voice-leading principles (e.g., stepwise motion, avoidance of dissonant leaps, common tone retention) through a multi-task loss function incorporating both symbolic and audio-derived features. The model achieves high accuracy in identifying individual voice contours and detecting problematic voice-leading instances in diverse polyphonic excerpts, from Renaissance motets to contemporary jazz voicings. This provides an invaluable tool for computational musicology, enhancing our capacity for detailed structural analysis across heterogeneous musical styles.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangling Polyphonic Voice Leading via Deep Graph Convolutional Networks with Perceptual Constraints

text: This study investigates the computational modeling of hierarchical metrical ambiguity and its resolution in music featuring complex polyrhythmic structures and shifting hypermeters. We propose a probabilistic inference engine, leveraging Bayesian networks, to parse beat and meter perceptions at multiple temporal scales (tactus, measure, hypermeasure). The model integrates bottom-up audio cues (onset salience, spectral flux, periodicity) with top-down theoretical constraints (harmonic rhythm, phrase structure, melodic accent). A key contribution is the quantification of 'metrical coherence' through entropy measures across metrical hypotheses, revealing how ambiguity is created and resolved dynamically. Our experiments, conducted on rhythmic fragments and complete musical excerpts, demonstrate the model's ability to track perceived meter changes and identify instances of metrical dissonance, correlating strongly with human perception data. This framework offers a robust analytical tool for understanding metrical complexity, informing rhythmic analysis, and facilitating adaptive music information retrieval systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Computational Modeling of Hierarchical Metrical Ambiguity and Its Resolution in Polyrhythmic Contexts

text: This research introduces a novel framework for perceptually-driven timbre morphing and synthesis, bridging psychoacoustics, audio analysis, and generative models. We employ a deep variational autoencoder (DVAE) with a disentangled latent space, trained on a large corpus of instrumental sounds. The DVAE's architecture ensures that specific dimensions of the latent space correspond to perceptually salient timbral attributes, such as brightness, roughness, attack transient quality, and spectral spread, as validated through listening tests. By interpolating along these disentangled latent dimensions, we achieve precise and intuitive control over timbre evolution, facilitating seamless morphing between distinct instrument timbres or continuous exploration of a timbre space. This methodology not only offers a powerful tool for sound design and creative composition but also provides a computational model for understanding the perceptual manifold of timbre, significantly advancing the field of audio synthesis beyond traditional physical or concatenative approaches by incorporating sophisticated perceptual metrics.
subject: Müzik
title: Perceptually-Driven Timbre Morphing and Synthesis via Latent Space Interpolation of Disentangled Spectral Features

text: This paper introduces Counterfactual Deep Networks (CFDNs), a novel architecture integrating deep learning with structural causal models to address confounding bias in high-dimensional observational data. Traditional deep learning models often conflate correlation with causation, leading to spurious associations and suboptimal policy decisions. CFDNs leverage a two-headed neural network, augmented with propensity score balancing and outcome regression, to estimate individual treatment effects (ITEs) by learning counterfactual distributions. We demonstrate CFDNs' superior performance against state-of-the-art methods in synthetic datasets and real-world clinical trials, particularly in scenarios characterized by complex confounding structures and heterogeneous treatment effects. The framework explicitly disentangles prognostic factors from treatment assignment mechanisms, thereby enhancing model interpretability and reliability for critical decision-making applications.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Deep Networks for Robust Causal Effect Estimation in High-Dimensional Data

text: Few-shot learning remains a critical challenge, where models struggle to generalize from extremely limited labeled data. This work proposes a novel transductive meta-learning framework designed to exploit unlabeled instances during the fine-tuning phase, thereby enhancing generalization capabilities in extreme few-shot scenarios. Our approach focuses on learning task-agnostic feature manifolds through an episodic training paradigm, where a meta-learner acquires robust metric spaces instead of direct classifiers. During inference, a graph-based label propagation mechanism, initialized by prototypes derived from support sets, iteratively refines predictions by leveraging the structural information within the unlabeled query set. Empirical evaluations on mini-ImageNet and tiered-ImageNet demonstrate significant performance gains over inductive meta-learning counterparts, particularly under stringent k-shot settings, without incurring substantial computational overhead.
subject: AI
title: Transductive Meta-Learners for Extreme Few-Shot Classification via Task-Agnostic Feature Manifolds

text: Adversarial examples pose a significant threat to the reliability of deep neural networks, while model interpretability is crucial for trustworthiness. This paper presents Attributable Adversarial Training (AAT), a novel regularization strategy that simultaneously enhances model robustness to adversarial perturbations and improves the fidelity of feature attribution maps. AAT integrates an adversarial loss with a consistency loss on attribution maps, ensuring that salient features contributing to a prediction remain stable even under attack. We demonstrate that AAT not only achieves competitive clean and robust accuracy across various image classification benchmarks (CIFAR-10, ImageNet) but also yields attribution maps (e.g., using Grad-CAM, LIME) that are more robust and aligned with human perception, mitigating the "robustness paradox" where robust models often exhibit less interpretable internal representations.
subject: AI
title: Attributable Adversarial Training: Jointly Enhancing Robustness and Feature-Attribution Fidelity

text: The burgeoning field of quantum machine learning promises to address problems intractable for classical algorithms. This paper introduces a hybrid quantum-classical neural network architecture, the Variational Quantum Graph Neural Network (VQGNN), designed for learning robust graph embeddings and performing classification tasks. VQGNN integrates parameterized quantum circuits (PQCs) as powerful feature transformers within a classical graph neural network (GNN) framework. The PQCs leverage quantum entanglement to capture non-linear, high-dimensional relationships within graph nodes, which are then processed by classical layers for final classification. We demonstrate VQGNN's enhanced expressive power and superior performance over purely classical GNNs on specific graph datasets, particularly for tasks exhibiting complex relational patterns, while mitigating the noise sensitivity inherent in near-term intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices through an adaptive circuit design.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum-Classical Neural Networks for Graph Embedding and Classification

text: Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative model training without direct data sharing, yet privacy risks persist, especially in unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) scenarios with domain shifts. This work proposes a novel Differentially Private Federated Unsupervised Domain Adaptation (DP-FUDA) framework designed for cross-silo learning. Our approach integrates local differential privacy (LDP) mechanisms at the client level, coupled with a server-side privacy-preserving aggregation scheme, to ensure robust privacy guarantees for source and target domain data. We employ an adversarial domain confusion strategy, adapted for FL, where clients learn domain-invariant feature representations while upholding privacy budget constraints. Extensive experiments demonstrate DP-FUDA's efficacy in achieving competitive domain adaptation performance, even under strict privacy requirements, significantly outperforming baseline FL-UDA methods in terms of privacy-utility trade-off across various image and text datasets.
subject: AI
title: Differentially Private Federated Unsupervised Domain Adaptation for Cross-Silo Learning

text: Current deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agents excel in complex environments but often lack interpretability and struggle with compositional generalization. This paper proposes a novel Neuro-Symbolic Reinforcement Learning (NSRL) framework that integrates symbolic reasoning with neural network strengths for enhanced decision-making. Our NSRL agent learns a neuro-symbolic policy composed of a differentiable predicate learning module and a symbolic planner that operates on a knowledge graph. The neural component extracts propositional facts from raw observations, which are then used by the symbolic planner to infer optimal actions based on learned rules and logical constraints. This hybrid approach demonstrates superior zero-shot generalization to novel environmental configurations and provides inherent transparency through the derivable symbolic execution trace, surpassing pure DRL methods in tasks requiring compositional reasoning and adherence to explicit rules.
subject: AI
title: Neural-Symbolic Reinforcement Learning for Interpretability and Generalization in Sequential Decision Making

text: Addressing coordination challenges in decentralized stochastic games with large state-action spaces remains a formidable problem. This paper introduces Hierarchical Recurrent Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (HR-MARL), a novel framework for learning emergent coordination strategies in complex, partially observable environments. HR-MARL employs a two-level hierarchy: low-level agents learn primitive behaviors, while a high-level manager agent orchestrates their actions by setting sub-goals and issuing temporal abstractions. Critically, each agent incorporates recurrent neural networks to maintain internal state representations, enabling effective reasoning under partial observability. Through extensive experiments in benchmark multi-agent environments like StarCraft II Multi-Agent Challenge, we demonstrate HR-MARL’s superior performance in terms of collective reward attainment and scalability compared to flat MARL approaches, particularly in scenarios demanding long-term strategic planning and robust inter-agent communication.
subject: AI
title: Hierarchical Recurrent Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Decentralized Stochastic Games

text: De novo molecular design is critical for drug discovery and materials science, yet traditional methods often struggle with navigating vast chemical spaces while optimizing multiple, often conflicting, properties. This paper proposes a novel framework utilizing conditional diffusion models (CDMs) for generating molecules with desired physicochemical and biological characteristics. Our CDM learns to denoise and generate molecular graphs conditioned on target properties (e.g., QED, LogP, specific bioactivity scores), thereby enabling precise control over the design process. We integrate a multi-objective optimization loop with a reinforcement learning-based fine-tuning mechanism to efficiently explore the latent space and generate diverse, synthetically accessible molecules that simultaneously satisfy several predefined criteria. Experimental results demonstrate the CDM’s superior ability to generate novel molecular structures with tunable properties, outperforming state-of-the-art generative models in terms of both diversity and target property fulfillment.
subject: AI
title: Conditional Diffusion Models for De Novo Molecular Design with Multi-Objective Optimization

text: The quadratic complexity of standard self-attention mechanisms severely limits Transformer models' applicability to long sequences, crucial for advanced natural language understanding and generation. This paper introduces Factorized Self-Attention with Causal Masking (FSACM), a novel attention scheme that reduces computational complexity to near-linear while maintaining high representational capacity. FSACM decomposes the full attention matrix into a product of low-rank matrices and employs a hierarchical factorization, enabling efficient information propagation across extended contexts. Furthermore, a novel causal masking strategy is integrated to ensure autoregressive generation capabilities without sacrificing efficiency. Empirical evaluations across various long-sequence benchmarks, including WikiText-103 and arXiv summarization, demonstrate that FSACM achieves comparable or superior perplexity and BLEU scores to full attention Transformers, with significant reductions in training time and memory footprint, making it highly suitable for resource-constrained environments.
subject: AI
title: Factorized Self-Attention with Causal Masking for Long-Sequence Language Modeling

text: Catastrophic forgetting remains a fundamental challenge in continual learning, particularly in class-incremental settings where access to past task data (replay) is often restricted or forbidden. This paper proposes a novel replay-free class-incremental learning (RFCIL) framework that mitigates forgetting by combining prototype regularization with feature disentanglement. Our method maintains a small set of compressed prototypes for each seen class, used to regularize the feature space during subsequent task learning, preventing drastic shifts in decision boundaries. Simultaneously, a disentanglement objective encourages the model to learn features that are robust to class-specific variations while preserving generalizable representations. Extensive experiments on CIFAR-100 and ImageNet-Subset demonstrate that RFCIL significantly outperforms existing replay-free and even some replay-based methods, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy in challenging class-incremental scenarios without storing any raw past data.
subject: AI
title: Replay-Free Class-Incremental Learning via Prototype Regularization and Feature Disentanglement

text: The role of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance (TEI) in modulating adaptive trajectories remains a critical, yet often underestimated, component of evolutionary theory. We investigated how environmentally-induced epigenetic marks, specifically DNA methylation patterns and small non-coding RNA profiles, confer rapid phenotypic plasticity and accelerate adaptation in *Daphnia magna* populations subjected to cyclical thermal stress. Utilizing a multi-generational experimental evolution framework coupled with whole-genome bisulfite sequencing and small RNA-seq, we demonstrate that parental exposure induces heritable modifications that prime offspring for subsequent stressors, significantly enhancing fitness gains relative to epigenetically naive lineages. These heritable epigenetic states persist for several generations even in benign conditions, acting as a "memory" that dampens the mutational load typically associated with rapid genetic adaptation. Our findings delineate a mechanism wherein TEI precedes or complements canonical genetic evolution, refining the adaptive landscape and offering a robust strategy for immediate phenotypic responses to dynamic environmental challenges, thereby recalibrating our understanding of the tempo and mode of evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Intergenerational Epigenetic Transmission Modulates Adaptive Trajectories in Fluctuating Environments

text: Clonal interference, a pervasive evolutionary force in large asexual populations, significantly shapes the dynamics of adaptive walks, yet its quantitative impact on the predictability and rate of adaptation remains incompletely characterized. We employed a long-term experimental evolution framework with *Escherichia coli* populations experiencing varying demographic parameters to precisely dissect the influence of effective population size and intrinsic mutation rate on the prevalence and consequences of clonal interference. Our genomic analyses, combining dense temporal sampling with deep sequencing, reveal that heightened clonal interference leads to accelerated fitness gains but concurrently constrains the breadth of genetic solutions, favoring the fixation of mutations conferring larger individual fitness effects. Furthermore, we demonstrate that epistatic interactions among co-occurring beneficial mutations become increasingly pivotal under intense clonal interference, dictating the ultimate trajectory of selective sweeps and often resulting in convergent evolution at the gene-level despite divergent genotypic paths. These findings refine theoretical models of adaptation in microbial systems, emphasizing clonal interference as a key determinant of evolutionary predictability.
subject: Evrim
title: The Deterministic Impact of Clonal Interference on Adaptive Trajectories in Large Asexual Populations

text: Obligate intracellular symbiosis frequently precipitates profound genomic restructuring, characterized by extensive gene loss and metabolic specialization. We conducted a comprehensive comparative genomic analysis across multiple, phylogenetically disparate insect endosymbiont lineages (e.g., *Buchnera aphidicola*, *Wigglesworthia glossinidia*, *Candidatus Blochmannia floridanus*) to elucidate the convergent evolutionary forces driving extreme genome reduction and the retention of essential metabolic pathways. Our findings reveal a striking consistency in the classes of genes retained, predominantly those involved in the biosynthesis of essential amino acids and vitamins crucial for host provisioning, often organized into highly compact operons. Conversely, genes associated with DNA repair, cell wall synthesis, and regulatory functions exhibit widespread pseudogenization and complete loss. Transcriptomic and metabolomic analyses of host-symbiont systems further confirm that the streamlined symbiont genomes are highly transcriptionally active for the retained metabolic modules, underscoring a precise division of labor and metabolic complementarity with the host. These data provide critical insights into the minimal gene sets required for bacterial viability within eukaryotic hosts and the evolutionary trajectories of genomic erosion under stringent mutualistic selection.
subject: Evrim
title: Convergent Evolution of Extreme Genome Reduction and Metabolic Specialization in Obligate Insect Endosymbionts

text: Understanding the determinants of clade vulnerability to extinction events on macroevolutionary timescales remains a central challenge in evolutionary biology. We investigated the interplay between rates of morphological innovation, ecological niche breadth, and extinction risk across diverse marine invertebrate clades throughout the Phanerozoic Eon, integrating comprehensive fossil record data with molecular phylogenies. Utilizing Bayesian inference of ancestral character states and trait-dependent diversification models, we demonstrate a significant positive correlation between elevated rates of morphological disparity generation and accelerated net diversification during periods of environmental stability. However, these highly innovative and ecologically specialized clades exhibited a disproportionately increased susceptibility to extinction during subsequent intervals of pronounced environmental perturbation, such as the Permian-Triassic extinction event. Conversely, clades characterized by slower rates of morphological evolution and broader ecological tolerances displayed enhanced resilience. These findings suggest a profound evolutionary trade-off wherein rapid adaptive radiation, driven by key innovations and niche specialization, simultaneously elevates long-term extinction risk, providing crucial insights into the selective filters shaping the Tree of Life across geological epochs.
subject: Evrim
title: Morphological Innovation and Niche Breadth Mediate Clade Vulnerability to Macroevolutionary Extinction Events

text: Sexual conflict, characterized by divergent evolutionary interests between males and females, is increasingly recognized as a potent engine of evolutionary divergence. We hypothesize that antagonistic co-evolution, particularly over seminal fluid proteins (SFPs) and cryptic female choice mechanisms, precipitates rapid reproductive isolation and contributes to sympatric speciation. In a system of rapidly diversifying *Drosophila* species, we performed reciprocal crosses and genomic analyses to identify loci undergoing accelerated evolution under sexual conflict. Our findings demonstrate that divergence in male SFPs and female reproductive tract morphology correlates strongly with the onset of pre-zygotic isolation. Specifically, we localized several quantitative trait loci (QTL) implicated in post-copulatory, pre-zygotic barriers, where mismatched SFP-receptor interactions lead to reduced sperm viability and fertilization success in heterospecific crosses. This antagonistic arms race drives rapid evolutionary turnover at these loci, contributing significantly to reduced hybrid fitness and reinforcing assortative mating within nascent species. This mechanism provides compelling evidence for how ongoing sexual conflict can generate the necessary isolating barriers to drive speciation, even in the absence of geographic separation.
subject: Evrim
title: Sexually Antagonistic Co-evolution Accelerates Reproductive Isolation and Sympatric Speciation via Cryptic Female Choice

text: The emergence of novel complex morphological structures from pre-existing developmental toolkits represents a pivotal aspect of macroevolutionary innovation. We investigated the evolutionary mechanisms underlying the recurrent emergence of highly divergent appendages across arthropod lineages, focusing on the hypothesis that cis-regulatory element (CRE) rewiring and gene co-option within conserved developmental gene regulatory networks (GRNs) are primary drivers. Through comparative developmental genomics employing high-resolution *in situ* hybridization and CRISPR-Cas9 mediated perturbations in exemplar species, we identified lineage-specific CREs that dictate novel spatiotemporal expression patterns of ancient developmental genes (e.g., *Dll*, *Ubx*) in distinct primordia. Our findings reveal that subtle modifications to these CREs can liberate pleiotropic constraints, allowing for the deployment of conserved signaling pathways in new developmental contexts, thereby generating substantial phenotypic novelty without requiring *de novo* gene acquisition. This research elucidates a fundamental principle of evolutionary developmental biology: that complex morphological innovation often arises not from novel genes, but from the sophisticated re-orchestration of conserved genetic modules via regulatory evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Cis-Regulatory Rewiring of Conserved Developmental Toolkits Underpins the Evolutionary Emergence of Novel Appendages

text: The ongoing evolutionary arms race between RNA viruses and their mammalian hosts represents a powerful driver of genetic diversification, particularly evident in the rapid evolution of antiviral restriction factors and viral counter-antagonism genes. We performed an exhaustive comparative genomic analysis across primate lineages and their associated retroviruses, focusing on genes encoding innate immune restriction factors (e.g., TRIM5α, APOBEC3G) and cognate viral accessory proteins (e.g., HIV-1 Vif). Our phylogenetic reconstruction and dN/dS analyses reveal compelling evidence for widespread episodic positive selection driving rapid amino acid substitutions in the effector domains of host restriction factors and in key residues of viral antagonists. Functional *in vitro* assays further demonstrate that these species-specific evolutionary signatures directly modulate viral infectivity and replication kinetics, with particular amino acid variants conferring enhanced resistance or susceptibility to diverse viral strains. These findings delineate a dynamic co-evolutionary landscape where intense selective pressure fosters reciprocal genetic innovation, shaping both host antiviral defenses and viral evasion strategies, thereby contributing significantly to lineage-specific pathogen tropism and host susceptibility to emerging viral threats.
subject: Evrim
title: Reciprocal Arms Race: Positive Selection on Mammalian Antiviral Restriction Factors and Viral Antagonists Drives Species-Specific Co-evolution

text: Paleogenomics offers unprecedented opportunities to reconstruct adaptive trajectories in populations facing dramatic environmental shifts, particularly those that ultimately led to extirpation. We utilized high-coverage whole-genome sequencing of ancient DNA from Late Pleistocene megafauna (e.g., *Mammuthus primigenius*, *Coelodonta antiquitatis*) spanning periods of rapid climate fluctuation during the last glacial-interglacial transition. Our analyses, employing explicit demographic modeling and selective sweep detection algorithms, uncovered significant genomic signatures of positive selection at loci associated with thermoregulation, nutrient metabolism, and immune response, distinct from those observed in extant descendant lineages. Notably, we identified evidence of adaptive introgression from closely related, environmentally distinct populations, suggesting gene flow as a crucial mechanism for acquiring advantageous alleles during periods of heightened environmental stochasticity. These paleogenomic insights reveal how genetic architectures underpinned resilience and vulnerability in ancient populations, providing a nuanced understanding of their adaptive capacities and the ultimate genetic factors contributing to their demographic decline in the face of rapid, anthropogenically-exacerbated climate change, informing conservation genetics today.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Signatures of Adaptive Response to Quaternary Climate Fluctuations in Extinct Megafauna

text: Urbanization imposes novel and intense selective pressures, driving rapid and often parallel evolution in diverse species. We investigated the genomic and phenotypic responses of avian populations (*Parus major*) across multiple European urban-rural transects to elucidate the genetic architecture of adaptation to anthropogenic environments. Utilizing whole-genome resequencing and common garden experiments, we identified recurrent patterns of genetic differentiation at candidate loci associated with detoxification pathways, immune response, and neural plasticity across geographically separated urban populations, suggesting strong, convergent selective gradients. Phenotypic assays revealed corresponding parallel shifts in foraging behavior, stress hormone regulation, and reproductive timing in urban individuals, demonstrating a tight genetic correlation between genomic divergence and adaptive phenotypic modifications. Furthermore, analyses of gene flow indicate that despite increased fragmentation, beneficial alleles may rapidly disseminate within the urban matrix. Our findings underscore that urbanization acts as a potent, reproducible evolutionary crucible, driving predictable genomic changes that facilitate persistence in highly modified landscapes, thereby offering critical insights into contemporary adaptive processes and informing urban conservation strategies.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Convergence Under Anthropogenic Selective Gradients in Urbanized Wildlife Populations

text: The evolution of phenotypic plasticity and its subsequent genetic assimilation represents a powerful mechanism for adaptation to fluctuating environments, yet the underlying quantitative genetic dynamics remain complex. We conducted a multi-generational experimental evolution study using *Tribolium castaneum* populations exposed to varying degrees of environmental heterogeneity to delineate the interplay between environmental variability, the evolution of reaction norms, and the exposure of cryptic genetic variation. Our findings demonstrate that populations in highly heterogeneous environments evolved significantly broader reaction norms for key life-history traits, indicative of enhanced phenotypic plasticity. Subsequent stabilization of environmental conditions in a subset of these populations led to the rapid genetic assimilation of formerly plastic phenotypes, a process facilitated by the unmasking and selection on cryptic genetic variation within the evolved, plastic reaction norms. Genomic selection analyses revealed specific polygenic architectures underlying both the evolved plasticity and its subsequent assimilation, with genotype-by-environment interactions playing a pivotal role. This research provides empirical validation for theoretical models of genetic assimilation, highlighting the adaptive value of plasticity in exposing novel genetic solutions to environmental challenges.
subject: Evrim
title: Environmental Heterogeneity Drives the Evolution of Phenotypic Plasticity and Facilitates Genetic Assimilation of Complex Traits

text: This research investigates the critical challenge of robust causal inference from complex, high-dimensional observational datasets, a pervasive issue in domains like healthcare and social sciences. We propose a novel framework leveraging deep structural causal models (DSCMs) to explicitly model and identify confounding variables. Our approach integrates non-linear functional causal models with generative deep learning architectures, specifically variational autoencoders, to learn disentangled representations corresponding to latent causal factors. By imposing identifiability constraints derived from instrumental variable theory within the latent space, our DSCM can estimate unbiased treatment effects and generate accurate counterfactual predictions, even in the presence of unobserved confounders under specific assumptions. Empirical evaluations on synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate superior performance in mitigating confounding bias compared to state-of-the-art observational methods, paving the way for more reliable decision-making in data-driven systems.
subject: AI
title: Disentangling Confounding in High-Dimensional Observational Data via Deep Structural Causal Models

text: The unprecedented capabilities of large language models (LLMs) highlight the profound impact of scaling laws and emergent phenomena in deep learning. This study employs mechanistic interpretability techniques to probe the architectural underpinnings of Transformer models, specifically investigating how their self-attention mechanisms instantiate and amplify certain inductive biases with increasing scale. We hypothesize that specific wiring patterns and attention head specializations evolve deterministically, giving rise to predictable computational motifs that are pivotal for complex reasoning. Through fine-grained analysis of attention weights, neuron activations, and gradient flows across various model sizes, we identify universal emergent properties. Our findings shed light on the 'how' behind scaling laws, providing foundational insights into designing more efficient and robust foundation models by deliberately engineering beneficial inductive biases.
subject: AI
title: Emergent Inductive Biases in Transformer Architectures: A Mechanistic Interpretability Perspective on Scaling Laws

text: Offline Reinforcement Learning (RL) presents a significant challenge due to distribution shift and extrapolation error when learning from static, pre-collected datasets. This work introduces an advanced Conservative Q-Learning (CQL) variant augmented with a novel Prioritized Experience Replay (PER) mechanism to enhance sample efficiency and policy conservatism. Our method dynamically prioritizes transitions based on an uncertainty-aware Bellman error, specifically favoring states where the learned Q-value exhibits higher epistemic uncertainty or potential for optimistic overestimation. This adaptive prioritization strategically mitigates the adverse effects of out-of-distribution actions by focusing learning on informative and under-explored regions of the state-action space, without sacrificing safety. Extensive evaluations across diverse D4RL benchmarks demonstrate superior performance in achieving robust and performant policies, significantly outperforming existing offline RL algorithms under strict data budget constraints.
subject: AI
title: Conservative Q-Learning with Prioritized Experience Replay for Efficient Offline Policy Optimization

text: Bridging the chasm between connectionist and symbolic AI remains a paramount challenge. This paper proposes a novel neuro-symbolic framework that integrates Differentiable Inductive Logic Programming (DILP) with Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) for robust and interpretable relational reasoning. Our architecture uses GNNs to learn expressive, continuous representations of entities and relations, which then serve as probabilistic facts in a differentiable logic program. The DILP component performs logical inference, allowing for symbolic rule induction and structured prediction, while gradients propagate through the system, enabling end-to-end learning. This hybrid approach capitalizes on GNNs' capacity for pattern recognition in complex graphs and DILP's ability to provide human-readable explanations and explicit knowledge acquisition. Extensive experiments on knowledge graph completion and complex question answering tasks demonstrate superior performance and enhanced interpretability compared to purely neural or symbolic baselines.
subject: AI
title: Hybridizing Differentiable Inductive Logic Programming with Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Relational Reasoning

text: Interpreting predictions from Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) is crucial for trust and debugging, especially in high-stakes domains involving non-Euclidean data. This research develops a novel suite of attribution-based interpretability methods tailored for GNNs, extending classical saliency concepts to the graph domain. We introduce a message-passing decomposition framework that quantifies the contribution of individual nodes, edges, and subgraphs to a target prediction by propagating relevance scores through the GNN's computational graph. Unlike existing approaches that focus solely on node features, our methodology precisely attributes influence across the topological structure and learned feature transformations. Rigorous evaluation on diverse graph datasets (e.g., molecular graphs, social networks) demonstrates that our methods generate accurate and stable explanations, providing critical insights into the underlying reasoning mechanisms of GNNs and facilitating domain expert validation.
subject: AI
title: Attribution-Based Interpretability for Graph Neural Networks: Decomposing Predictive Contributions in Non-Euclidean Spaces

text: Ensuring the robustness of deep learning models against adversarial perturbations is critical, particularly for safety-critical applications. While pixel-level robustness has received significant attention, certified guarantees against perceptually meaningful, semantic perturbations in high-dimensional latent feature spaces remain largely unexplored. This work proposes a novel framework for achieving certified robustness against semantic attacks defined by specific manifolds or transformation groups. We leverage Lipschitz-bounded neural networks, specifically by incorporating specialized spectral normalization and constrained activation functions, to control the sensitivity of the classifier within the learned feature space. By defining semantic perturbations through an autoencoder's latent space or a pre-trained feature extractor, we derive analytical bounds on the adversarial examples, enabling verifiable robustness. Empirical validation demonstrates the efficacy of our method in providing non-trivial robustness certificates against complex, semantically meaningful transformations, advancing the state of verifiable AI.
subject: AI
title: Certified Robustness Against Semantic Perturbations in High-Dimensional Feature Spaces using Lipschitz-Bounded Classifiers

text: Catastrophic forgetting remains a primary impediment to developing truly adaptive AI systems capable of continuous learning from sequential data streams. This research introduces an innovative gradient-based orthogonal projection approach to mitigate forgetting in few-shot continual learning scenarios. Our method constructs task-specific orthogonal subspaces within the network's parameter space, dynamically identifying and projecting incoming task gradients to prevent interference with knowledge acquired from previous tasks. This ensures that critical features and decision boundaries learned for past tasks are preserved, even when exposed to limited new data. By leveraging a low-rank approximation of task-specific gradient subspaces, we achieve computational efficiency without sacrificing knowledge retention. Extensive experiments on challenging few-shot continual learning benchmarks demonstrate superior performance, significantly reducing forgetting while maintaining high forward transfer capabilities and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.
subject: AI
title: Gradient-Based Orthogonal Projection for Catastrophic Forgetting Mitigation in Few-Shot Continual Learning Settings

text: Federated Learning (FL) offers a promising paradigm for privacy-preserving distributed model training, but challenges arise from communication overhead, asynchronicity, and privacy guarantees, especially for resource-constrained edge devices. This paper presents a novel differentially private FL framework that synergistically integrates asynchronous client updates with adaptive gradient compression. Our approach employs a sophisticated noise addition mechanism at the client-side for strong (ε, δ)-differential privacy, which is then coupled with a communication-efficient gradient compression scheme (e.g., Top-K or quantization) that is provably compatible with the privacy guarantee. The asynchronous aggregation strategy handles varying client availability and computation capabilities, optimizing server-side model updates. Extensive empirical evaluations demonstrate that our framework achieves robust privacy guarantees and competitive model accuracy while substantially reducing communication latency and bandwidth requirements, making it highly suitable for heterogeneous edge computing environments.
subject: AI
title: Differentially Private Federated Learning with Asynchronous Client Updates and Gradient Compression for Edge Devices

text: High-dimensional biomedical datasets often suffer from a curse of dimensionality, necessitating effective feature selection for robust predictive modeling. This research proposes a novel quantum-classical hybrid approach leveraging the Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) for optimal feature subset selection. We formulate the feature selection problem as a Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) problem, where the objective function minimizes classification error while penalizing feature cardinality. The VQE algorithm, executed on a noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) device, is then employed to find the ground state of the resulting Hamiltonian, effectively identifying the optimal binary feature mask. Our method utilizes a parameterized quantum circuit (PQC) to encode feature selection choices and classical optimization to update PQC parameters. Empirical results on genomics and proteomics datasets demonstrate VQE's potential to discover high-quality, compact feature sets, outperforming classical heuristic and exact methods for intractable feature spaces.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Eigensolver for Feature Selection in High-Dimensional Biomedical Datasets

text: Accurately quantifying epistemic uncertainty in deep learning models is critical for reliable decision-making, particularly in safety-critical applications. This work presents a novel Bayesian Deep Learning framework that leverages variational inference within implicit generative models to provide robust uncertainty estimates. Unlike traditional approaches, which often rely on restrictive distributional assumptions or ensemble methods, our method approximates the intractable posterior over model parameters by training a deep generative model (e.g., a normalizing flow or GAN) to implicitly represent the variational distribution. This allows for a more flexible and expressive posterior approximation. The framework provides rich, sample-based uncertainty quantification, distinguishing between aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty, facilitating out-of-distribution detection and enhancing model calibration. Empirical validation demonstrates superior performance in uncertainty estimation and robustness across diverse tasks, including classification and regression, compared to established Bayesian neural networks.
subject: AI
title: Bayesian Deep Learning with Epistemic Uncertainty Quantification via Variational Inference in Implicit Generative Models

text: We theoretically investigate the potential for fault-tolerant quantum computation leveraging non-Abelian anyons hosted within synthetic fractional Chern insulator platforms. Our analysis focuses on engineered flat bands in superlattice potentials, where strong inter-particle interactions give rise to fractional quantum Hall states supporting Moore-Read Pfaffian or Read-Rezayi Z_k parafermionic order. We detail a robust braiding protocol for these quasi-particles, demonstrating its inherent topological protection against local perturbations and decoherence mechanisms. The adiabatic exchange of anyonic excitations, precisely controlled by tunable potential landscapes, encodes quantum information non-locally, significantly enhancing the coherence times of logical qubits. We provide explicit constructions for universal gate sets via braiding statistics and fusion rules, alongside proposals for experimental realization using ultra-cold atoms in optical lattices or 2D semiconductor heterostructures exhibiting strong spin-orbit coupling. This framework presents a viable pathway towards intrinsic fault tolerance, circumventing conventional error correction overheads.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Anyonic Braiding in Fractional Chern Insulators for Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation

text: We present a rigorous theoretical framework to quantify the decoherence experienced by macroscopic quantum superpositions due to fundamental fluctuations in spacetime geometry, a predicted effect from semi-classical and quantum gravity models. By employing a modified Lindblad master equation derived from an open quantum systems approach to spacetime, we investigate the induced collapse of spatial superpositions of massive objects. Our model characterizes the spectral density of metric fluctuations as a low-energy manifestation of quantum gravity, identifying specific signatures in the time evolution of the off-diagonal elements of the reduced density matrix. We propose experimental avenues, such as advanced matter-wave interferometry with gram-scale test masses or optomechanical resonators, to probe these unique decoherence channels. The predicted decoherence rates offer a critical benchmark for differentiating between competing quantum gravity theories and provide a novel, potentially testable, link between quantum mechanics and general relativity at terrestrial scales.
