subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence Signatures from Spacetime Curvature Fluctuations in Macroscopic Quantum Superpositions

text: The nature of the pairing symmetry in unconventional superconductors remains a pivotal challenge in condensed matter physics. We report a comprehensive theoretical investigation into the anisotropic thermal transport properties of candidate spin-triplet superconductors, specifically focusing on materials exhibiting p-wave or f-wave pairing. Utilizing a quasi-classical Eilenberger formalism, we calculate the thermal conductivity tensor in the presence of strong magnetic fields, which crucially modify the quasiparticle scattering and nodal structures of the superconducting gap. Our analysis reveals distinct temperature and field dependencies of the in-plane and out-of-plane thermal conductivities, serving as a decisive diagnostic for identifying the specific topological features of the nodal quasiparticle excitations. We demonstrate how angle-resolved thermal conductivity measurements can unambiguously differentiate between various spin-triplet states, such as those with point nodes versus line nodes, and distinguish them from singlet counterparts. This provides a robust methodology for determining the elusive order parameter symmetry in systems like Sr2RuO4 or heavy fermion compounds.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Nodal Quasiparticle Dynamics in Spin-Triplet Superconductors via Anisotropic Thermal Conductivity

text: We theoretically demonstrate significant improvements in the precision of optomechanical force and displacement measurements by employing broadband squeezed light injection into cavity optomechanical systems operating deep within the resolved sideband regime. Our model incorporates quantum back-action and radiation pressure noise, showing that non-classical light, specifically amplitude-squeezed input at the mechanical resonance frequency, can push measurement sensitivity beyond the standard quantum limit, approaching the Heisenberg limit. By carefully tuning the detuning and optical drive power, we optimize the parametric coupling between mechanical and optical modes to maximize the transfer of squeezing onto the mechanical observable. The enhanced signal-to-noise ratio arises from reducing the quantum noise in one quadrature, thereby circumventing the limitations imposed by shot noise and quantum radiation pressure noise. This methodology has profound implications for next-generation gravitational wave detectors, precision force sensing, and fundamental tests of quantum mechanics at macroscopic scales.
subject: Kuantum
title: Enhanced Quantum-Enhanced Metrology via Squeezed Light Injection in Optomechanical Resonators Operating in the Resolved Sideband Regime

text: We propose novel architectures for fault-tolerant logical qubits leveraging topological low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes tailored for planar connectivity hardware constraints. Moving beyond conventional surface codes, our design integrates advanced LDPC constructions, such as generalized bicycle codes, onto two-dimensional lattices, thereby enhancing the minimum distance and error-correction capabilities for a given number of physical qubits. We present a decoder architecture based on a combination of belief propagation and ordered statistics decoding, optimized for parallel execution and low latency in a cryogenic environment. Simulations demonstrate a significantly improved error threshold compared to standard topological codes, especially under biased noise channels prevalent in superconducting or trapped-ion platforms. This work details the compilation of universal gate sets for these logical qubits, focusing on methods for non-Clifford gate implementation via lattice surgery or magic state distillation with reduced resource overhead. Our approach offers a promising route to scaling quantum computers by providing more efficient and robust encoding schemes.
subject: Kuantum
title: Fault-Tolerant Logical Qubit Architectures Exploiting Low-Density Parity-Check Codes on Planar Connectivity Lattices

text: We explore the emergence of exotic SU(N) spin liquid phases in strongly correlated electron systems on the triangular lattice at commensurate fillings, particularly focusing on Mott insulating regimes where charge fluctuations are suppressed. Utilizing a sophisticated variational Monte Carlo approach combined with projected wave functions, we investigate the ground state properties of generalized Heisenberg models with anisotropic exchange interactions for arbitrary N. Our findings reveal that specific frustration parameters drive transitions from conventional magnetically ordered states to robust, gapped or gapless, SU(N) spin liquids characterized by fractionalized excitations and an absence of conventional symmetry breaking. We identify key signatures of these states, including long-range entanglement evidenced by topological entanglement entropy, and distinct features in the spin-spin correlation functions. The theoretical implications extend to a class of materials such as cold atomic gases loaded into optical lattices or certain transition metal dichalcogenides, offering a pathway to realize and experimentally probe these elusive quantum phases of matter.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent SU(N) Spin Liquid Phases in Frustrated Triangular Lattice Mott Insulators: A Variational Monte Carlo Study

text: We theoretically investigate the exotic non-Hermitian phenomena occurring in graphene-based waveguides engineered to exhibit parity-time (PT) symmetry. By introducing balanced gain and loss mechanisms within the waveguide structure, we demonstrate the formation of exceptional points (EPs) where eigenvalues and their corresponding eigenvectors coalesce. Near these EPs, the system exhibits unconventional features, including enhanced sensing capabilities and, crucially, chiral mode conversion of surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs). We show that the non-reciprocal propagation of SPPs can be precisely controlled by tuning the gain/loss parameters and the Fermi level of graphene. This tunability allows for dynamic manipulation of light flow, potentially leading to robust, isolator-like functionalities and one-way propagation without external magnetic fields. Our analysis, based on a rigorous transfer matrix formalism and coupled-mode theory, provides a blueprint for active plasmonic devices operating at optical and terahertz frequencies, harnessing the unique topological properties of EPs for advanced photonic circuits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Exceptional Point Degeneracies and Chiral Mode Conversion in Graphene-Based Parity-Time Symmetric Waveguides

text: We propose an autonomous quantum refrigerator design realized through a network of three coupled superconducting resonators, each interacting with a distinct thermal reservoir. By precisely engineering the dissipation rates and coupling strengths between these high-Q microwave cavities, we demonstrate the spontaneous generation of a thermal gradient, enabling heat extraction from a target cold reservoir to a hotter one without external work input. Our theoretical model, based on a quantum master equation within the Lindblad formalism, illustrates how specific non-reciprocal coupling pathways, achievable via tunable transmon qubits, drive the refrigeration cycle by creating directed energy flows. The system operates entirely within the quantum regime, showcasing performance metrics that can surpass classical limits under specific conditions, particularly in terms of cooling power and coefficient of performance. This research provides a foundational understanding for developing compact, intrinsically quantum thermal machines applicable to cryogenic quantum computing architectures and precision quantum sensing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Autonomous Quantum Refrigeration Utilizing Engineered Dissipation in Coupled Superconducting Resonators

text: We present a theoretical and experimental proposal for generating non-Abelian gauge fields for neutral atoms by exploiting synthetic dimensions created from internal atomic states. By applying an array of carefully tailored Raman-assisted tunneling protocols, we demonstrate how to engineer complex, non-commuting gauge potentials that mimic SU(2) or higher-order Lie group symmetries. This scheme extends beyond conventional Abelian synthetic magnetic fields, offering access to topologically rich phases of matter, such as non-Abelian quantum Hall states or lattice gauge theories, that are otherwise inaccessible with current cold atom techniques. Our approach involves coupling multiple internal states through Raman transitions, where the phase and amplitude of the laser fields control the gauge links. We detail a specific implementation using ytterbium atoms in a one-dimensional optical lattice, showing how this setup can be utilized to simulate phenomena like quark confinement or the dynamics of non-Abelian anyons, providing a powerful platform for quantum simulation of high-energy physics models.
subject: Kuantum
title: Realization of Non-Abelian Gauge Fields for Neutral Atoms in Synthetic Dimensions via Raman-Assisted Tunneling

text: We investigate the process of entanglement harvesting from the quantum vacuum by two spacelike-separated, uniformly accelerated Unruh-DeWitt detectors. Our analysis, performed within the framework of relativistic quantum field theory in flat spacetime, explores how the non-inertial motion of the detectors influences their ability to become entangled by local interactions with scalar field vacuum fluctuations. We demonstrate that the acceleration introduces a non-trivial modification to the effective interaction kernel between the detectors, significantly altering the harvesting yield and the spatial range over which entanglement can be extracted. Crucially, we identify a regime where acceleration can *enhance* entanglement harvesting compared to inertial counterparts, counteracting the usual decohering effects associated with the Unruh temperature. This phenomenon provides a unique window into the interplay between relativity, quantum entanglement, and the fundamental structure of the vacuum, with implications for quantum information processing in extreme relativistic environments and understanding the Unruh effect from an entanglement perspective.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Harvesting from Vacuum Fluctuations in Relativistic Quantum Field Theory via Accelerated Detectors

text: Precise manipulation of chromatin architecture and epigenetic states is pivotal for understanding and programming cell fate. This study leverages a catalytically inactive Cas9 (dCas9) fused to various epigenetic effectors to precisely rewrite histone modifications and DNA methylation patterns at specific enhancer elements in human induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs). We demonstrate that targeted recruitment of histone acetyltransferases (e.g., p300) and demethylases (e.g., KDM5B) to super-enhancers associated with pluripotency or differentiation markers can drive robust and sustained changes in gene expression. Our multi-omics analysis, integrating ATAC-seq, ChIP-seq for H3K27ac, and RNA-seq, reveals that site-specific epigenetic editing induces profound alterations in chromatin accessibility and transcriptional output, influencing differentiation trajectories towards mesodermal lineages. This high-resolution epigenetic engineering platform offers an unprecedented tool for dissecting causal links between chromatin states, transcriptional regulation, and cellular plasticity, with significant implications for regenerative medicine and disease modeling.
subject: Biyoloji
title: CRISPR-dCas9 Directed Epigenetic Rewriting of Enhancer Loci Modulates Cell Fate Plasticity in Human iPSCs

text: Circular RNAs (circRNAs) are emerging as critical regulators of gene expression in various pathophysiological contexts, including cancer. This study elucidates the role of a novel circRNA, Circ-Ankrd26, in modulating the immune suppressive tumor microenvironment (TME) in pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC). We demonstrate that Circ-Ankrd26 is highly expressed in PDAC-associated macrophages (TAMs) and functions as a molecular sponge for miR-145-5p, thereby de-repressing its target gene, MKK4, a key regulator of JNK signaling. Overexpression of Circ-Ankrd26 promotes M2-like macrophage polarization, characterized by elevated expression of CD163 and Arg1, and enhances T-cell anergy in co-culture systems. Mechanistically, this axis facilitates immune evasion and promotes tumor progression *in vivo*. Our findings reveal a novel circRNA-miRNA-mRNA regulatory network orchestrating macrophage plasticity within the PDAC TME, presenting Circ-Ankrd26 as a potential therapeutic target for immune modulation strategies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Circular RNA Circ-Ankrd26 Modulates Macrophage Polarization and Immune Evasion in Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma through miRNA Sponging

text: The pathological hallmark of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is the aggregation of RNA-binding proteins such as FUS and TDP-43 into cytoplasmic inclusions. This study investigates the contribution of dysregulated liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) to FUS and TDP-43 pathobiology. We provide evidence that mutations in FUS and TDP-43, or alterations in RNA chaperone activity, perturb the physiological LLPS dynamics of stress granules and other ribonucleoprotein (RNP) compartments. Specifically, ALS-associated variants induce aberrant hyper-condensation and impaired dissolution of phase-separated FUS/TDP-43 species, leading to irreversible gel-like transitions and protein insolubility. Using advanced optogenetic control of LLPS, we demonstrate that manipulating the stoichiometry and valency of these proteins profoundly impacts their aggregation kinetics and toxicity *in vitro* and in neuronal cell models. These findings underscore altered LLPS as a critical initiating event in ALS pathogenesis, offering new avenues for therapeutic intervention targeting proteostasis and RNP granule dynamics.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Aberrant Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of FUS and TDP-43 Driven by RNA Granule Defects in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis

text: Understanding cellular heterogeneity and cell-cell interactions within diseased tissues is crucial for precision medicine. Here, we present an integrated single-cell multi-omics analysis (scRNA-seq and scATAC-seq) of human psoriatic skin lesions and healthy controls. Our approach deconvolutes the transcriptional and epigenomic landscapes of diverse immune and stromal cell types, revealing distinct cellular states and lineage trajectories associated with psoriasis pathogenesis. We identify novel subsets of keratinocytes and T-cells exhibiting unique inflammatory signatures and aberrant chromatin accessibility profiles at disease-relevant loci. Furthermore, sophisticated intercellular communication inference using ligand-receptor pair analysis unveils dysregulated signaling networks, particularly involving TNF-α and IL-17 pathways, between resident immune cells, fibroblasts, and keratinocytes. This comprehensive atlas provides an unprecedented resolution of the molecular mechanisms driving psoriatic inflammation and offers a robust framework for identifying novel diagnostic biomarkers and therapeutic targets.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated Single-Cell Multi-omics Delineates Cellular State Transitions and Intercellular Crosstalk in Psoriatic Skin Lesions

text: Mitophagy, the selective degradation of damaged mitochondria via autophagy, is crucial for cellular homeostasis and preventing neurodegeneration. While PINK1/Parkin-mediated mitophagy is well-established, its intricate regulation by mitochondrial dynamics proteins remains incompletely understood. This study uncovers a novel role for Mitofusin 2 (MFN2), a mitochondrial outer membrane protein involved in fusion, in orchestrating the assembly of the mitophagy initiation complex. We demonstrate that MFN2, independent of its canonical fusion activity, directly interacts with and stabilizes mitophagy receptors such as FUNDC1 and BNIP3 on depolarized mitochondria. Loss of MFN2 impairs the recruitment of ULK1 and ATG9A, hindering autophagosome formation and subsequent lysosomal fusion. Quantitative proteomics and super-resolution microscopy reveal that MFN2 facilitates the spatial organization of mitophagy machinery, ensuring efficient engulfment of dysfunctional mitochondria. These findings establish MFN2 as a critical nexus connecting mitochondrial dynamics and quality control pathways, with implications for mitochondrial diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mitochondrial Outer Membrane Protein MFN2 Orchestrates Mitophagy Receptor Recruitment and Autophagosome Maturation

text: The nuclear pore complex (NPC) is a gatekeeper of nucleocytoplasmic transport, but its role in spatially organizing gene expression within specific nuclear domains remains largely unexplored. This study employs advanced spatial transcriptomics, coupled with super-resolution microscopy, to investigate how NPC substructures influence transcriptional gating in murine cortical neurons. We demonstrate that distinct nuclear pore subcomplexes, defined by specific nucleoporin (NUP) compositions, are enriched at active euchromatic or silenced heterochromatic regions. Furthermore, we reveal that NUP153 and NUP50, localized to the nuclear basket, establish a dynamic sieve controlling the nuclear export of specific sets of developmentally regulated mRNAs. Perturbing NUP stoichiometry leads to aberrant mRNA egress and misregulation of synaptic plasticity genes, impacting dendritic arborization. Our findings uncover a novel mechanism where region-specific NPC architecture acts as a 'transcriptional gate', spatially modulating gene expression and contributing to neuronal function and plasticity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatial Transcriptomics Reveals Nuclear Pore Complex Substructures Dictate Region-Specific Transcriptional Gating in Cortical Neurons

text: Engineering synthetic microbial consortia offers unprecedented opportunities for precision therapeutics and diagnostics. This research presents the development of a genetically engineered *Escherichia coli* consortium designed for *in situ* biosensing of tumor-associated metabolites (e.g., lactate, indole) and targeted delivery of immunomodulators within the colorectal cancer (CRC) microenvironment. One strain (sensor strain) is programmed with a synthetic genetic circuit to detect elevated lactate levels and activate the expression of a quorum-sensing autoinducer. This autoinducer, in turn, triggers a second strain (effector strain) to produce and secrete a high-affinity PD-L1 neutralizing nanobody or a TLR5 agonist. *In vivo* studies in murine CRC models demonstrate that oral administration of the consortium results in tumor-specific accumulation, robust metabolite-triggered therapeutic payload delivery, and significant tumor growth inhibition through enhanced anti-tumor immunity. This platform highlights the potential of programmable microbiotics for intelligent, localized therapeutic interventions in solid tumors.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Synthetic Microbial Consortia for *In Situ* Biosensing and Targeted Delivery of Immunomodulators in Colorectal Cancer

text: The severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) orchestrates complex molecular interactions with host machinery to facilitate its life cycle. This study investigates the role of the viral accessory protein ORF3a in modulating host endolysosomal trafficking to promote viral egress. We demonstrate that ORF3a directly interacts with components of the Endosomal Sorting Complexes Required for Transport (ESCRT) machinery, particularly ESCRT-I and ESCRT-III. This interaction reroutes multivesicular bodies (MVBs) away from lysosomal degradation, creating an intracellular niche conducive for viral assembly and budding. Specifically, ORF3a inhibits autophagosome-lysosome fusion and lysosomal acidification, leading to an accumulation of dysfunctional lysosomes and impaired degradation of cellular debris. Using genetic ablation and pharmacological inhibition of ESCRT components, we show a significant reduction in viral particle release. These findings reveal a critical mechanism by which SARS-CoV-2 exploits host ESCRT pathways and subverts lysosomal integrity to ensure efficient propagation, presenting potential antiviral targets.
subject: Biyoloji
title: SARS-CoV-2 ORF3a Recruits Host ESCRT Machinery to Modulate Endosomal Trafficking and Promote Viral Egress through Lysosomal Subversion

text: Synaptic vesicle fusion, a fundamental process underlying neurotransmission, is exquisitely regulated by SNARE protein complex assembly. This study explores the allosteric regulation of neuronal SNARE complex formation and membrane fusion by specific phosphoinositides (PIs) within the presynaptic active zone. Using a combination of single-molecule fluorescence resonance energy transfer (smFRET) and reconstituted liposome fusion assays, we demonstrate that phosphatidylinositol (4,5)-bisphosphate (PI(4,5)P2) and phosphatidylinositol (3,4,5)-trisphosphate (PI(3,4,5)P3) differentially modulate the kinetics and stability of the SNARE zippering process. PI(4,5)P2 enhances the initial docking and assembly of cis-SNAREs, whereas PI(3,4,5)P3 accelerates the complete zippering and membrane approximation. Mechanistically, these PIs interact with distinct basic residue clusters on synaptotagmin-1 and SNAP-25, inducing conformational shifts that optimize SNARE complex formation. Our findings reveal a sophisticated phosphoinositide-SNARE interplay, providing a molecular basis for the precise spatio-temporal control of neurotransmitter release at the synapse.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phosphoinositide-Mediated Allosteric Regulation of SNARE Complex Assembly Dynamics in Presynaptic Membrane Fusion

text: Accurate segregation of sister chromatids during mitosis necessitates proper chromosome condensation and decatenation, processes critically dependent on Topoisomerase IIα (TOP2A). This investigation elucidates the specific contribution of TOP2A's catalytic decatenation activity to the dynamic organization of chromatin loops during mitotic chromosome formation. Employing super-resolution imaging, Hi-C, and quantitative proteomics in TOP2A-depleted and catalytically impaired cellular models, we demonstrate that loss of TOP2A decatenase function severely impedes the timely resolution of entangled DNA catenanes, leading to compromised loop extrusion by cohesin and condensin. This results in global alterations to chromatin domain architecture, characterized by elongated axial structures and diminished radially arrayed loop domains. Furthermore, we identify novel TOP2A interaction partners involved in chromatin remodeling that are essential for regulating its decatenation specificity within mitotic chromosomes. These findings highlight TOP2A's indispensable role in orchestrating higher-order chromatin folding, providing critical insights into genomic stability during cell division.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Topoisomerase IIα Decatenation Activity Maintains Chromatin Loop Extrusion Dynamics During Mitotic Chromosome Condensation

text: Transcriptional plasticity, essential for cellular differentiation and environmental adaptation, is intricately orchestrated by dynamic chromatin architectural changes. Here, we delineate the previously uncharacterized role of the BAZ2A subunit, typically associated with NuRD complexes, in mediating enhancer-promoter looping during cellular reprogramming. Employing high-resolution Hi-C, ChIP-seq, and nascent RNA sequencing in induced pluripotent stem cells, we demonstrate that BAZ2A directly binds to active enhancers and promoters, facilitating the formation of super-enhancer associated chromatin loops. Depletion of BAZ2A leads to widespread collapse of topologically associating domains and aberrant long-range chromatin interactions, significantly impairing the precise spatio-temporal gene expression required for efficient cell fate transitions. Mechanistically, BAZ2A orchestrates ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling, modulating local nucleosome occupancy at regulatory elements. Our findings establish BAZ2A as a pivotal architectural protein, offering novel insights into the mechanotransduction of transcriptional regulatory signals within the three-dimensional nuclear landscape.
subject: Biyoloji
title: De Novo Characterization of the SWI/SNF Subunit BAZ2A as a Critical Regulator of Enhancer-Promoter Axis Remodeling in Transcriptional Plasticity

text: Endothelial cell senescence (ECS) is a critical contributor to cardiovascular aging and dysfunction, yet its intricate molecular underpinning remains incompletely understood. We investigated the role of circular RNAs (circRNAs) in ECS, identifying circFOXO3 as a significantly downregulated species during replicative senescence. Mechanistically, circFOXO3 functions as a robust endogenous microRNA (miRNA) sponge, directly sequestering miR-29a, a known pro-senescent miRNA. This sequestration alleviates miR-29a-mediated repression of Forkhead Box O3 (FOXO3), a key transcriptional regulator of antioxidant and longevity pathways. Enhanced FOXO3 activity, in turn, upregulates endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS) expression, restoring nitric oxide bioavailability and mitigating oxidative stress-induced cellular damage. Overexpression of circFOXO3 in senescent human umbilical vein endothelial cells attenuated hallmark features of ECS, including SA-β-galactosidase activity and cell cycle arrest. Our findings unveil a novel circRNA-miRNA-mRNA regulatory axis, positioning circFOXO3 as a crucial modulator of endothelial homeostasis and a potential therapeutic target for vascular aging.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Circular RNA circFOXO3 Regulates Endothelial Cell Senescence by Sponging miR-29a and Modulating FOXO3/eNOS Signaling Axis

text: The aberrant accumulation of misfolded proteins into prion-like aggregates is a hallmark of numerous neurodegenerative diseases. While macroautophagy is recognized for its role in aggregate degradation, the precise molecular mechanisms governing the selective removal of these pathological species remain elusive. Here, we reveal that LC3-associated phagocytosis (LAP), a non-canonical autophagy pathway, is critically involved in the clearance of intracellular α-synuclein and tau aggregates. Utilizing genetically modified cellular models and primary neuronal cultures, we demonstrate that LAP machinery, specifically the Rubicon-containing PI3KC3 complex, facilitates direct engulfment of aggregate-laden vesicles into lysosomes, bypassing the conventional autophagosome formation. Inhibiting LAP components, such as ATG5 or Rubicon, significantly exacerbates aggregate load and neurotoxicity, while enhancing LAP activity promotes their efficient degradation. Our study delineates a novel selective clearance mechanism for prion-like proteinopathies, highlighting LAP as a promising therapeutic avenue for mitigating proteotoxic stress in neurodegeneration.
subject: Biyoloji
title: LC3-Associated Phagocytosis Governs the Clearance of Prion-like Protein Aggregates Through Direct Lysosomal Targeting

text: Precise manipulation of the epigenome offers unprecedented opportunities for modulating gene expression in disease. Current gene editing technologies primarily focus on DNA sequence alteration, leaving vast potential in epigenetic regulation untapped. We developed a novel, highly specific epigenome editing platform utilizing catalytically inactive Cas9 (dCas9) fused to histone demethylase KDM5B to reprogram aberrant gene silencing. This dCas9-KDM5B fusion protein, guided by custom single-guide RNAs (sgRNAs), efficiently targeted hypermethylated promoter regions, leading to H3K4me3 restoration and robust reactivation of epigenetically silenced genes, including tumor suppressor genes and genes implicated in monogenic disorders. Unlike traditional pharmacologic demethylating agents, this system exhibits exquisite sequence specificity, minimizing off-target epigenetic alterations. In vitro and in vivo proof-of-concept studies demonstrate the therapeutic potential of this platform in restoring deficient protein function and inhibiting tumor growth. Our work establishes a powerful and precise strategy for targeted epigenetic intervention, advancing precision medicine approaches.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Programmable Epigenome Reprogramming via dCas9-Mediated Histone Demethylase Recruitment for Therapeutic Gene Reactivation

text: Glioblastoma (GBM), a highly aggressive brain tumor, is characterized by an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment (TME) and profound cellular heterogeneity, both contributing to therapeutic resistance. Understanding the spatial interplay between diverse immune cell subsets and malignant cells is critical for effective immunotherapies. We employed an integrated single-cell transcriptomics (scRNA-seq) and spatially resolved proteomics (GeoMx DSP) approach to comprehensively map the immune landscape of human GBM biopsies. Our analysis revealed distinct states of tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs), T-cells, and myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) co-existing within discrete spatial niches. We identified novel intercellular communication networks mediated by chemokine-receptor interactions and elucidated how these spatial arrangements influence T-cell exhaustion and resistance to checkpoint blockade. This high-resolution multi-omic spatial atlas provides unprecedented insights into the pathological architecture of the GBM TME, pinpointing actionable targets for next-generation immunotherapeutic strategies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Deciphering Immune Cell Heterogeneity and Spatial Organization in Glioblastoma via Integrated Single-Cell Transcriptomics and Spatially Resolved Proteomics

text: Mitochondrial quality control is vital for neuronal function and preventing neurodegeneration, with PINK1/Parkin-mediated mitophagy being a canonical pathway for damaged organelle clearance. However, PINK1-independent mechanisms remain poorly understood. We identified a previously uncharacterized mitochondrial ubiquitin ligase, MULAN2 (Mitochondrial Ubiquitin Ligase Associated with NIX), that orchestrates PINK1-independent mitophagy. MULAN2 is recruited to stressed mitochondria, where it ubiquitylates outer mitochondrial membrane proteins, including Mfn2 and VDAC1, serving as 'eat-me' signals. This ubiquitylation initiates a cascade involving OPTN and NDP52, leading to the formation of phagophores around dysfunctional mitochondria. Genetic ablation of MULAN2 in primary cortical neurons resulted in accumulation of damaged mitochondria, impaired mitochondrial dynamics, and increased susceptibility to oxidative stress and apoptotic stimuli. Our findings uncover a critical, parallel pathway for mitochondrial degradation, highlighting MULAN2 as a key regulator of neuronal mitochondrial homeostasis and a potential therapeutic target for mitigating mitochondrial dysfunction in neurological disorders.
subject: Biyoloji
title: PINK1-Independent Mitophagy Activation via a Novel Mitochondrial Ubiquitin Ligase Regulates Neuronal Homeostasis

text: Bacterial multidrug efflux pumps, particularly those of the Resistance-Nodulation-Cell Division (RND) superfamily like AcrB, are major contributors to antibiotic resistance by expelling diverse antimicrobial compounds. Despite extensive studies, the precise conformational changes and allosteric mechanisms governing inhibitor binding and efflux remain incompletely characterized. We report the near-atomic resolution cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of E. coli AcrB in complex with a novel small molecule inhibitor, elucidating a previously unrecognized binding pocket within the periplasmic domain. This inhibitor induces a distinct conformational state, preventing substrate translocation by locking the access and deep binding pockets into an occluded configuration. Complementary biochemical assays, including substrate accumulation and efflux kinetics, validate the allosteric inhibition. Our structural insights provide a mechanistic blueprint for rational drug design targeting AcrB, offering a promising strategy to overcome bacterial multidrug resistance by restoring antibiotic efficacy.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Multidrug Efflux Pump AcrB in Complex with a Small Molecule Inhibitor Reveals an Allosteric Inhibition Mechanism

text: Targeted protein degradation (TPD) via PROTACs or molecular glues offers a powerful modality for fundamental research and therapeutic development. However, achieving precise spatiotemporal control over degradation kinetics remains a significant challenge. We engineered a novel optogenetic degron system, "OptoDegron," enabling light-inducible and reversible targeted protein degradation in mammalian cells. This system integrates a light-sensitive FKBP-FRB interaction module with a destabilizing degron sequence, allowing rapid, localized recruitment of endogenous E3 ubiquitin ligases to specific proteins of interest upon blue light illumination. We demonstrated highly efficient and tunable degradation of diverse reporter proteins and endogenous disease-relevant targets, including oncogenic kinases, with minimal off-target effects. Furthermore, reversible light control enabled pulsatile degradation and rescue kinetics. The OptoDegron platform provides an unprecedented level of precision for dissecting protein function in vivo and holds immense promise for developing advanced gene therapies and conditional drug interventions.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Engineered Conditional Degron System for Spatiotemporally Controlled Targeted Protein Degradation in Mammalian Cells

text: N6-methyladenosine (m6A) is the most abundant internal modification on eukaryotic mRNA, playing crucial roles in RNA metabolism. While m6A is known to influence mRNA stability and splicing, its direct impact on translational dynamics, particularly under stress conditions, is less understood. We investigated the m6A reader protein YTHDC1 and discovered its novel role in modulating ribosome dynamics on specific stress response transcripts. Using ribosome profiling combined with m6A-seq and biochemical reconstitution, we show that YTHDC1 preferentially binds to m6A sites within the 5'UTR and coding regions of specific stress-induced mRNAs. This binding leads to a transient but significant increase in ribosome pausing at m6A-containing codons, which, paradoxically, enhances the translational efficiency of these transcripts under proteotoxic stress. Our findings reveal a non-canonical mechanism by which m6A, through YTHDC1, fine-tunes specialized mRNA translation, providing a rapid adaptive response to cellular perturbations and broadening the understanding of the epitranscriptome's regulatory depth.
subject: Biyoloji
title: N6-Methyladenosine (m6A) Reader Protein YTHDC1 Facilitates Ribosome Pausing and Specialized Translation of Stress Response Transcripts

text: Bacterial Type VI Secretion Systems (T6SSs) are dynamic nanomachines crucial for interbacterial competition and host-pathogen interactions, delivering diverse effector proteins into target cells. The specific mechanisms governing effector recognition, loading, and secretion by the T6SS remain a complex area of investigation. We report the high-resolution cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of a novel T6SS effector-chaperone complex, TseL-TsiL, from Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This structure reveals a previously unobserved chaperone-effector interaction interface, where TsiL cradles TseL, preventing premature oligomerization and maintaining its secretion-competent conformation. Site-directed mutagenesis and in vivo secretion assays validate critical residues within this interface for T6SS-dependent translocation. Furthermore, small-angle X-ray scattering data demonstrate how TsiL shielding facilitates TseL's stable passage through the T6SS injectisome. These findings provide fundamental insights into the intricate molecular chaperoning events critical for T6SS function, paving the way for targeted antimicrobial strategies against virulent pathogens.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural and Mechanistic Elucidation of a Novel Type VI Secretion System Effector Chaperone Complex from Pseudomonas aeruginosa

text: This study investigates the role of epigenetic mechanisms, particularly DNA methylation and histone modifications, in shaping the extraordinary phenotypic plasticity and subsequent adaptive radiation observed in East African cichlid fishes. We hypothesize that environmental heterogeneity drives the canalization of developmental pathways via context-dependent epigenetic programming, thereby modulating evolutionary potential. Utilizing comparative epigenomics across sympatric and allopatric lineages, we demonstrate significant differential methylation regions (DMRs) associated with key genes underpinning trophic morphology and reproductive timing. Our findings suggest that environmentally induced epigenetic variation provides a substrate for natural selection to act upon, facilitating rapid ecological divergence and contributing to speciation. This framework offers a novel perspective on how non-genetic inheritance can potentiate evolutionary innovation, bridging genotype-phenotype maps through developmental polyphenism.
subject: Evrim
title: Epigenetic Canalization and the Adaptive Radiation of Phenotypic Plasticity in East African Cichlid Fishes

text: Disentangling the historical dynamics of coevolutionary interactions remains a significant challenge, particularly in systems where reciprocal selection is obscured by phylogenetic signal and environmental noise. This research employs a novel phylogenetic comparative framework, integrating generalized additive mixed models with ancestral state reconstruction, to infer cryptic coevolutionary trajectories within obligate plant-pollinator mutualisms. Focusing on the Yucca-Yucca moth system, we analyze congruent evolutionary shifts in floral morphology and pollinator ovipositor length, accounting for interspecific variation in host plant chemical defense and pollinator larval nutritional requirements. Our results reveal evidence for pervasive diffuse coevolution punctuated by instances of strong reciprocal adaptation, suggesting a complex interplay between Red Queen dynamics and stabilizing selection. This approach provides fine-scale insights into the tempo and mode of coevolutionary arms races, highlighting the genomic loci potentially underlying these adaptive responses.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenetic Inference of Cryptic Coevolutionary Trajectories in Obligate Plant-Pollinator Mutualisms

text: Understanding the genomic architecture of complex adaptive traits in extreme environments is crucial for predicting species responses to climate change. This study utilizes whole-genome resequencing data from multiple populations of three desert rodent species exhibiting convergent physiological adaptations to arid conditions. Employing population genomic scans for positive selection (e.g., Fst outlier analysis, iHS, XP-CLR), we identify recurrently selected loci and characterize the genetic basis of traits such as water retention, thermoregulation, and osmoregulation. Our findings reveal a highly polygenic architecture underlying these adaptations, with evidence for both soft sweeps on standing genetic variation and novel mutations. Furthermore, we detect significant overlap in candidate genomic regions across independent lineages, suggesting shared genetic pathways for arid adaptation. This research provides a high-resolution map of the evolutionary landscape shaping extremophile phenotypes, offering insights into the predictability and constraints of adaptation.
subject: Evrim
title: Leveraging Whole-Genome Resequencing to Dissect Polygenic Adaptation to Extreme Aridity in Desert Mammals

text: The emergence of novel complex traits represents a pivotal challenge in evolutionary biology. This study investigates the developmental and genomic underpinnings of bioluminescent organ (photophore) evolution in deep-sea cephalopods, a classic example of convergent morphological innovation. Through comparative transcriptomics and chromatin accessibility profiling across distinct photophore-bearing lineages, we identify patterns of de novo gene co-option and extensive rewiring of gene regulatory networks (GRNs) associated with opsin and crystallin gene families. Our analyses reveal that pre-existing developmental modules were repeatedly recruited and subsequently diversified, leading to the complex optical machinery observed in extant species. Furthermore, we uncover evidence for transposable element-mediated cis-regulatory element creation, facilitating rapid GRN evolution. This research elucidates mechanisms of developmental modularity and plasticity, demonstrating how subtle genomic changes can drive profound phenotypic shifts and contribute to the adaptive radiation of sensory structures in extreme environments.
subject: Evrim
title: De Novo Gene Co-option and the Morphological Innovation of Bioluminescent Organs in Deep-Sea Cephalopods

text: Hybrid zones represent natural laboratories for studying the mechanisms of reproductive isolation and speciation. This study leverages dense genomic SNP data from a parapatric hybrid zone between two closely related anuran species to characterize the landscape of genomic divergence and gene flow. We identify numerous "genomic islands of speciation" – regions of exceptionally low introgression maintained despite pervasive gene flow across the majority of the genome. These islands are enriched for genes associated with prezygotic (e.g., call characteristics, pheromone signaling) and postzygotic (e.g., hybrid sterility, developmental incompatibilities) reproductive barriers. Furthermore, we detect significant asymmetry in gene flow directionality, driven by differential ecological competence and demographic histories of the parental species. Our findings underscore the complex interplay of divergent selection, genetic drift, and historical contingency in shaping nascent species boundaries, providing empirical support for the porous genome model of speciation.
subject: Evrim
title: Asymmetric Gene Flow and Genomic Islands of Speciation in Parapatric Anuran Hybrid Zones

text: Understanding the macroevolutionary processes that generate biodiversity requires methods capable of detecting shifts in diversification rates and linking them to intrinsic traits or extrinsic environmental factors. This research applies a Bayesian state-dependent diversification model to a comprehensive, time-calibrated phylogeny of deep-sea hydrothermal vent invertebrates. We infer latent evolutionary states corresponding to ecological specialization (e.g., chemosynthetic vs. non-chemosynthetic dependence) and test their impact on speciation and extinction rates. Our analyses reveal distinct diversification dynamics associated with transitions to vent-specific lifestyles, characterized by an initial burst of speciation followed by increased extinction risk, potentially indicative of adaptive radiation into a niche-limited environment. These findings highlight the utility of advanced phylogenetic comparative methods in dissecting the complex interplay between ecological opportunity, lineage-specific traits, and macroevolutionary patterns, offering new insights into the drivers of biodiversity in extreme marine ecosystems.
subject: Evrim
title: Inferring Latent State-Dependent Diversification Dynamics from Time-Calibrated Phylogenies of Marine Invertebrates

text: The evolution of eusociality, characterized by reproductive division of labor and overlapping generations, presents a fundamental paradox for individual-level selection. This study investigates the genomic underpinnings of varying degrees of sociality, from subsocial to cryptic eusocial, in a phylogenetically diverse group of gall-forming aphids. We employ pooled-sequencing and population genetic analyses to identify signatures of kin selection, particularly in genes associated with altruistic behaviors and reproductive skew within colony structures. Our findings reveal elevated relatedness coefficients and distinct genomic regions under positive selection related to caste differentiation and pheromone communication in the more socially complex lineages. Furthermore, we identify loci exhibiting differential expression patterns between reproductives and sterile defenders, suggesting regulatory mechanisms modulating developmental plasticity in caste determination. This research provides empirical genomic support for inclusive fitness theory and offers new molecular targets for exploring the evolutionary transition to sophisticated social systems.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Kin Selection and Reproductive Skew in Cryptic Eusocial Aphid Lineages

text: The late Pleistocene witnessed widespread megafauna extinctions, but the precise interplay of climatic shifts, human impacts, and intrinsic biological factors remains debated. This paleogenomic study analyzes ancient DNA (aDNA) from exceptionally preserved remains of multiple megafauna species (e.g., woolly mammoth, steppe bison) across Beringia, spanning the Last Glacial Maximum and Younger Dryas. We reconstruct demographic histories, infer genetic bottlenecks, and quantify spatiotemporal changes in population connectivity using coalescent-based phylogenetic methods. Our results indicate species-specific responses to environmental perturbations, with some lineages exhibiting precipitous declines concurrent with human arrival, while others show more gradual population fragmentation linked to vegetation shifts. Genomic data reveal reduced genetic diversity and increased inbreeding preceding extirpation for several taxa. This research disentangles the multi-causal drivers of Quaternary extinctions, providing critical insights into the ecological fragility of large mammal populations facing rapid environmental change.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Reconstruction of Pleistocene Megafauna Extirpation Events and Their Ecological Ramifications in Beringia

text: The escalating crisis of multi-drug resistance (MDR) necessitates a deeper understanding of pathogen evolutionary dynamics within clinical settings. This study employs a longitudinal metagenomic approach to track the emergence and dissemination of antimicrobial resistance genes (ARGs) across diverse bacterial populations within a large hospital environment over a two-year period. We utilize network analysis and population genomic methods to infer horizontal gene transfer (HGT) events, identify key selective pressures, and characterize the fitness costs associated with acquiring specific resistance mechanisms. Our findings reveal a dynamic resistome, with rapid clonal expansion of MDR strains and frequent transfer of mobile genetic elements, often driven by sub-inhibitory antibiotic concentrations. This research delineates critical evolutionary pathways leading to MDR, offering crucial insights for developing targeted intervention strategies and informing antimicrobial stewardship programs by predicting future resistance landscapes.
subject: Evrim
title: Unraveling the Evolutionary Trajectories of Multi-Drug Resistance via Metagenomic Longitudinal Analysis of Hospital Microbiomes

text: The long-term maintenance of genetic variation in quantitative traits under selection remains a central enigma in evolutionary genetics. This theoretical study employs a quantitative genetic modeling framework, incorporating environmental stochasticity and a non-linear genotype-phenotype map, to investigate the phenomenon of "stochastic resonance" in evolutionary dynamics. We demonstrate that optimal levels of environmental fluctuation can actively promote the persistence of genetic polymorphism by preventing fixation of maladaptive alleles, even under strong stabilizing selection. Our simulations reveal that environmental noise, when coupled with a threshold-dependent phenotypic expression, can effectively buffer the population against genetic erosion and facilitate adaptation to unpredictably changing conditions. These findings offer a novel explanation for the ubiquity of genetic variation in natural populations, challenging traditional views that emphasize mutation-selection balance alone, and highlighting the adaptive role of environmental heterogeneity in shaping evolutionary trajectories.
subject: Evrim
title: Stochastic Resonance and the Maintenance of Genetic Variation in Fluctuating Environments: A Quantitative Genetic Modeling Approach

text: We present a theoretical framework for achieving fault-tolerant quantum computation by dynamically engineering topological phases hosting non-Abelian anyons. Our approach leverages controlled local perturbations to induce transitions between distinct topological orders, facilitating the braiding of quasiparticles within a robust manifold protected against local decoherence. We detail a specific protocol for implementing universal gate sets utilizing Fibonacci anyons in a two-dimensional fractional quantum Hall system, analyzing the topological protection against depolarizing noise and single-qubit errors. Furthermore, we quantify the fidelity enhancements achievable through this dynamic topological routing, demonstrating a significant reduction in logical error rates compared to static lattice approaches, positioning it as a viable pathway toward scalable, robust quantum processors operating above the conventional error threshold.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Anyon Braiding for Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation via Dynamically Engineered Topologies

text: This work investigates the entanglement spectrum and Rényi entropies within the context of the Anti-de Sitter/Conformal Field Theory (AdS/CFT) correspondence, specifically focusing on its application to higher-spin gauge theories. We establish a holographic dictionary for the higher-spin entanglement entropy, generalizing the Ryu-Takayanagi formula by incorporating connections to bulk gauge fields. Our analysis elucidates how the structure of the entanglement spectrum in the boundary CFT reflects the gravitational dynamics of higher-spin black holes in the bulk. Through a careful examination of specific examples in AdS3/CFT2, we demonstrate that excitations in the entanglement spectrum correspond to quanta of higher-spin fields, providing new insights into the microscopic degrees of freedom contributing to entanglement and probing the limits of the geometric entanglement paradigm in non-geometric gravitational duals.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Spectrum and Rényi Entropy in the AdS/CFT Correspondence for Higher-Spin Theories

text: We present a comprehensive theoretical and numerical investigation into the many-body localization (MBL) to thermalization crossover in periodically driven (Floquet) quantum systems with quenched disorder. Our study employs exact diagonalization and time-evolving block decimation techniques to characterize the dynamical properties and entanglement growth across this phase transition. We demonstrate that Floquet driving can induce distinct MBL phases or even delocalize intrinsically localized states, depending on the driving frequency and amplitude. Specifically, we identify signatures of a Floquet MBL phase characterized by area-law entanglement entropy and logarithmic growth of entanglement, contrasting with the volume-law behavior in the ergodic phase. These findings provide crucial insights into the interplay of coherent driving, disorder, and strong interactions, illuminating the conditions under which isolated quantum systems avoid thermalization.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing the Many-Body Localization to Thermalization Crossover in Disordered Floquet Systems

text: This paper rigorously explores the implications of quantum adiabatic theorem violations on the performance metrics of nonequilibrium quantum heat engines. We specifically analyze a generalized quantum Otto cycle operating with working fluids undergoing non-adiabatic strokes, where the driving Hamiltonian parameters change rapidly. Our theoretical framework, incorporating open quantum system dynamics and quantum fluctuation theorems, reveals fundamental trade-offs between engine efficiency, power output, and the degree of non-adiabaticity. We demonstrate that while non-adiabaticity can transiently boost power, it inevitably incurs entropic costs, leading to a diminished efficiency bounded by a non-equilibrium generalization of the Carnot limit. These findings provide critical guidance for optimizing the design of high-power, high-efficiency quantum thermal machines by precisely managing their operational speed relative to internal coherence and dissipation timescales.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Adiabatic Theorem Violations in Nonequilibrium Quantum Engines: Efficiency and Power Trade-offs

text: We investigate the robustness of quantum entanglement shared between two distant observers when one or both are subject to uniform acceleration, inducing the Unruh-Davies effect, within a relativistic quantum field theory framework. Employing a scalar field model, we quantify the degradation of entanglement, specifically concurrence and entanglement negativity, for bipartite Gaussian states as perceived by inertial and uniformly accelerated Rindler observers. Our analysis reveals that while entanglement generally diminishes with increasing acceleration, certain modes and initial state preparations exhibit enhanced resilience. These findings are crucial for designing relativistic quantum communication protocols in non-inertial frames, offering insights into mitigating environmental decoherence effects intrinsically linked to the spacetime geometry and observer's trajectory.
subject: Kuantum
title: Robustness of Entanglement under Unruh-Davies Acceleration: A Field-Theoretic Approach to Relativistic Quantum Communication

text: We report the experimental realization and characterization of fractional Chern insulator (FCI) states using ultracold bosonic atoms confined in anisotropically dressed optical lattices. By engineering synthetic gauge fields via Raman-assisted tunneling and applying spatially varying laser potentials, we create a Hofstadter-like lattice geometry with tunable hopping parameters and magnetic flux. Through site-resolved imaging and correlation measurements, we directly observe signatures consistent with fractional quantum Hall physics, including a quantized Hall response and excitation gaps indicative of incompressible states. The robust observation of anyonic excitations and their fractional statistics, even in the presence of modest disorder, underscores the potential of these platforms for simulating strongly correlated topological matter, paving the way for the exploration of novel non-Abelian FCI phases.
subject: Kuantum
title: Observation of Fractional Chern Insulators in Anisotropically Dressed Lattices of Ultracold Bosons

text: This paper explores the deep connections between quantum contextuality and Bell nonlocality, presenting a unified framework based on generalized causal models that capture the intrinsic constraints on measurement outcomes in quantum mechanics. We rigorously demonstrate that any theory exhibiting Bell nonlocality must necessarily be contextual, thus solidifying the fundamental role of contextuality as a precursor to non-classical correlations. Our analysis extends beyond traditional Kochen-Specker arguments, utilizing graph-theoretic approaches to identify minimal contextual scenarios and quantify their incompatibility with non-contextual hidden variable models. This work provides a refined perspective on the foundational structure of quantum mechanics, emphasizing how the non-classical nature of reality fundamentally precludes the assignment of pre-existing definite values to observables independent of the measurement context.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Contextuality and Bell Nonlocality: Unifying Foundational Constraints on Measurement Outcomes via Causal Models

text: We theoretically and experimentally investigate the Floquet engineering of exceptional points (EPs) in periodically driven non-Hermitian photonic lattices, demonstrating their utility for ultra-sensitive metrology. By subjecting a coupled resonator array with balanced gain and loss to a high-frequency temporal modulation, we realize tunable non-Hermitian Hamiltonians exhibiting EPs. Our findings reveal that dynamic control over the driving parameters enables precise manipulation of the EP degeneracy, leading to an enhanced square-root scaling of parameter sensing around these points. We present experimental validations using coupled waveguide arrays, where small refractive index changes induce significant spectral shifts observable near EPs, substantially outperforming conventional Hermitian sensing limits. This work establishes a robust platform for exploiting non-Hermitian degeneracies for precision measurements in dynamically tunable quantum systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Floquet Engineering of Exceptional Points in Driven Non-Hermitian Photonic Lattices for Enhanced Sensing

text: This research delves into the enigmatic pseudogap phase observed in strongly correlated doped Mott insulators, particularly high-temperature superconductors, utilizing insights from the gauge-gravity duality. We construct a holographic model of a doped Mott insulator that captures the interplay between strong correlations and charge carrier dynamics, revealing an emergent pseudogap phase characterized by a suppression of low-energy spectral weight without long-range order. Our analysis identifies fractionalized excitations, distinct from conventional Landau quasiparticles, as key ingredients in this phase, suggesting a breakdown of Fermi liquid theory well above the superconducting transition temperature. The holographic description provides a robust framework to understand the non-Fermi liquid behavior and the onset of collective phenomena in these complex quantum materials, offering new avenues for uncovering the mechanism of high-Tc superconductivity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent Pseudogap Phase and Fractionalized Excitations in Doped Mott Insulators: A Gauge-Gravity Duality Perspective

text: We present a theoretical and experimental investigation into quantum information scrambling within analogue black hole systems, leveraging the framework of out-of-time-order correlators (OTOCs). Specifically, we analyze the growth of OTOCs in a one-dimensional Bose-Einstein condensate engineered to simulate a sonic black hole horizon, providing a measurable signature of information propagation and thermalization across event horizons. Our numerical simulations, complemented by proposals for experimental realization, demonstrate that the characteristic butterfly effect associated with scrambling exhibits unique features near the analogue horizon, distinguishable from conventional thermalization in flat spacetime. These findings offer a novel perspective on the black hole information paradox and the fundamental mechanisms of quantum thermalization in strongly gravitational regimes, utilizing controlled laboratory settings.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantifying Quantum Information Scrambling in Analogue Black Holes via Out-of-Time-Order Correlators

text: This research presents a novel computational framework for automated Schenkerian analysis, addressing the inherent complexities of hierarchical tonal reduction in polyphonic music. Our methodology leverages a multiscale deep graph network (MDGN) architecture, wherein individual musical events (notes, chords) are represented as nodes, and inter-event relationships (temporal proximity, harmonic function, voice leading) are encoded as weighted edges. The MDGN processes musical information across varying levels of temporal granularity, employing attention mechanisms to identify perceptually salient structural points and derive foreground, middleground, and background prolongational pathways. We introduce a novel loss function that incorporates domain-specific constraints derived from Schenkerian theory, regularizing the network's output to conform to established analytical principles. Evaluation against a curated corpus of expert-annotated reductions demonstrates superior performance in identifying fundamental structures and common prolongational techniques compared to existing symbolic and statistical approaches, offering a significant advancement in computational musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: Hierarchical Tonal Structure Extraction via Multiscale Deep Graph Networks

text: This study investigates the correlation between objective audio features and subjective timbral perception, with implications for automated instrument classification and expressive synthesis control. We propose a psychoacoustically informed feature extraction pipeline that transcends conventional low-level descriptors (e.g., MFCCs, spectral centroid). Our approach incorporates auditory nerve firing models, critical band analysis, and temporal envelope modulation spectra, aiming to capture perceptual attributes such as brightness, roughness, and attack transience more accurately. A large-scale perceptual experiment using MUlti-Dimensional Scaling (MDS) reveals a robust mapping between these novel features and human timbre similarity judgments across diverse instrumental families. Subsequent application to supervised machine learning tasks for instrument identification demonstrates a substantial improvement in classification accuracy and robustness against varying performance articulations, thereby advancing the state-of-the-art in timbral analysis and enabling more nuanced control interfaces for sound synthesis.
subject: Müzik
title: Psychoacoustically Informed Timbral Feature Extraction for Instrument Classification and Synthesis Control

text: Accurate transcription of polyphonic rhythmic structures remains a formidable challenge in music information retrieval. This paper introduces a robust computational model for multilayered polyphonic beat and meter tracking, capable of disentangling concurrent rhythmic streams. Our methodology integrates a spectral domain Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) for source separation and harmonic/percussive decomposition with a system of coupled Hidden Markov Models (HMMs). Each HMM is designed to model a distinct rhythmic stratum, incorporating probabilistic transitions between beat states and utilizing synchronously estimated Onset Detection Functions (ODFs) as observations. A novel coupling mechanism, based on inter-layer phase synchronization and tempo-coherence priors, facilitates robust inference across rhythmic layers. Evaluation on complex orchestral and jazz improvisations demonstrates superior performance in recovering concurrent beat annotations and metric hierarchies compared to independent beat-tracking algorithms, paving the way for more comprehensive polyphonic music analysis systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Multilayered Polyphonic Beat and Meter Tracking via Coupled Non-Negative Matrix Factorization and Hidden Markov Models

text: This research explores the geometric and topological properties of tonal transformations within a Neo-Riemannian framework, advancing beyond conventional group-theoretic models. We employ Topological Data Analysis (TDA), specifically persistent homology, to characterize the evolving connectivity and shape of pitch-class sets under various transformational operations (P, L, R, N, S). Our methodology constructs simplicial complexes from chord progressions, where edge weights represent intervallic distance or voice-leading parsimony. By analyzing persistence diagrams, we quantify the robustness of harmonic cycles and identify underlying geometric invariants that articulate distinct tonal regions and pathways through abstract pitch-class space. This approach reveals emergent topological structures, such as higher-dimensional holes corresponding to specific chordal relationships, offering novel insights into the perceptual salience and structural coherence of transformational networks in late-Romantic and post-tonal repertoire.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Data Analysis of Tonal Space Transformations in Neo-Riemannian Contexts

text: The precise estimation and analysis of microtonal pitch variations in musical performances, particularly those employing non-standard temperaments or intonation practices, presents significant challenges for conventional frequency tracking algorithms. This paper introduces an adaptive spectral resynthesis approach coupled with a probabilistic filtering framework for robust microtonal pitch estimation. Our method first employs high-resolution cepstral analysis and phase vocoder techniques to extract instantaneous fundamental frequencies. Subsequently, a dynamic resynthesis process, guided by a Hidden Markov Model (HMM) trained on empirical microtonal pitch distributions, refines these estimates by iteratively minimizing residual spectral error. This allows for accurate discrimination of intentional microtonal inflections from performance inaccuracies. Validation on a diverse corpus of traditional and experimental microtonal music demonstrates superior tracking precision and lower octave errors, enabling nuanced intonation analysis and precise reconstruction of complex non-equal tempered scales.
subject: Müzik
title: Robust Microtonal Pitch Estimation and Intonation Analysis in Non-Standard Temperaments Using Adaptive Spectral Resynthesis

text: This study investigates the intricate relationship between performer gestural kinetics and resultant musical expression through a multimodal deep learning framework. We collect synchronized audio, high-resolution motion capture data, and video recordings of instrumentalists performing expressive passages. A recurrent convolutional neural network (RCNN) architecture is employed, integrating visual features (derived from pose estimation networks), kinesthetic features (from skeletal joint trajectories and velocities), and spectro-temporal audio features (MFCCs, spectral flux, chroma). The RCNN is trained to predict high-level expressive parameters (e.g., intensity, tension, lyricism) and low-level audio synthesis controls. Our methodology reveals salient gestural correlates for specific expressive nuances, demonstrating that visual and kinesthetic data provide complementary information beyond acoustic cues alone. The framework not only enhances understanding of embodied musical cognition but also offers a robust mechanism for designing novel gesture-controlled interfaces and data-driven performance analysis tools.
subject: Müzik
title: Multimodal Deep Learning for Expressive Gesture-to-Sound Mapping in Live Performance Analysis

text: Automated recognition of emotional states induced by music remains a complex task, compounded by cultural variability and subjective interpretation. This paper proposes a robust cross-cultural model for predicting affective valence and arousal in musical excerpts, employing an ensemble learning strategy over a comprehensive set of multimodal features. Our feature vector encompasses psychoacoustic descriptors (e.g., loudness, tempo, spectral centroid), music-theoretic metrics (e.g., diatonicity, consonance ratio, melodic contour entropy), and high-level structural attributes (e.g., form, texture density). Leveraging a diverse corpus of music from Western, East Asian, and African traditions, we train an ensemble of deep neural networks, each specialized for a feature subset. A novel fusion mechanism, incorporating culture-specific weighting derived from listener demographics, significantly improves prediction accuracy across disparate cultural contexts, outperforming unimodal and single-classifier approaches, and offering new insights into the universal and culture-specific drivers of musical emotion.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Cultural Affective Valence and Arousal Prediction in Music via Ensemble Learning of Multimodal Features

text: Decomposing complex polyphonic music into perceptually coherent auditory streams, a core tenet of Auditory Scene Analysis (ASA), remains a frontier in music information retrieval. This study proposes a novel computational ASA framework that integrates state-of-the-art deep learning for source separation with cognitive models of perceptual grouping. Our system first employs a U-Net architecture with attention mechanisms for instrument-agnostic source separation, generating individual component masks in the time-frequency domain. Subsequently, a probabilistic grouping module clusters these separated components into distinct perceptual streams based on classical ASA cues, including common fate (onset/offset synchrony, correlated amplitude/frequency modulation), pitch proximity, and harmonic coherence. A Bayesian inference engine resolves ambiguities arising from concurrent cues. Experimental validation on orchestral and chamber music demonstrates enhanced stream segregation fidelity compared to purely data-driven separation, yielding more perceptually aligned representations crucial for advanced music understanding and analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Computational Auditory Streaming of Polyphonic Music Using Deep Source Separation and Perceptual Grouping Cues

text: This research applies principles of information theory to quantify structural complexity, redundancy, and perceived uncertainty in atonal pitch-class set compositions. We develop a novel methodology for encoding pitch-class set successions as symbolic sequences, enabling the computation of Shannon entropy, conditional entropy, and mutual information across varying analytical granularities. Our framework models pitch-class relations through graph theory, where nodes represent pitch classes and weighted edges indicate intervallic connections. By analyzing the entropy of pitch-class transitions and the statistical distribution of set-class instantiations, we characterize the information content inherent in works by Schoenberg, Webern, and Stockhausen. Results reveal distinct compositional strategies regarding redundancy management and complexity gradients across different periods and composers, offering quantitative insights into their serial procedures and providing an objective measure for structural coherence that complements traditional set-theoretic analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Information-Theoretic Entropy and Redundancy in Atonal Pitch-Class Set Structures

text: We introduce a novel non-parametric framework for causal mediation analysis in settings with complex, high-dimensional covariates and potential unmeasured confounding. Traditional mediation methods often rely on strong parametric assumptions or strict sequential ignorability. Our approach leverages deep neural networks to learn deconfounded latent representations of the exposure, mediator, and outcome. Specifically, we employ adversarial balancing techniques to achieve covariate balance and then estimate controlled direct and indirect effects via a representation-based mediator model and outcome regression. This methodology rigorously addresses non-linear relationships and heterogeneous treatment effects, providing robust inference for both average and conditional causal effects under weaker assumptions than previous methods. We demonstrate improved bias reduction and efficiency through extensive simulations and a real-world application in precision medicine, where complex omics data act as confounders and mediators.
subject: İstatistik
title: Non-Parametric Causal Mediation Analysis via Deconfounded Deep Latent Representations

text: This paper addresses the challenge of estimating time-varying Granger causality in high-dimensional multivariate time series, where the number of series (p) vastly exceeds the sample size (n). We propose a novel framework for dynamic precision matrix estimation that incorporates both L1-penalized regularization for sparsity and a smoothly varying temporal structure. Our method employs a localized kernel smoother within a time-varying graphical Lasso framework, enabling the capture of evolving conditional dependency networks. By leveraging a computationally efficient alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) algorithm, we achieve robust and consistent estimation of the dynamic inverse covariance matrices. This allows for direct inference of instantaneous and lagged conditional independence relationships, thereby providing principled Granger causality networks that adapt to structural breaks and evolving system dynamics. Empirical evaluations on synthetic data and neurophysiological signals demonstrate superior performance in network recovery and false discovery rate control compared to static or piecewise constant approaches.
subject: İstatistik
title: Sparse Dynamic Precision Matrix Estimation in High-Dimensional Time Series for Granger Causality Inference

text: We develop a novel hierarchical Bayesian non-parametric framework for discovering latent community structures in multivariate relational data, where entities exhibit multiple types of relationships and covariates. Our model extends the infinite relational model by incorporating a multi-scale Dirichlet Process prior over latent cluster assignments, allowing the number of communities to be learned adaptively from data. Critically, we introduce shared latent features across different relational matrices, enabling the borrowing of strength and identification of coherent community structures influenced by common underlying mechanisms. Inference is performed via an efficient blocked Gibbs sampler augmented with Metropolis-Hastings steps for intricate dependency structures. The proposed method excels in scenarios involving heterogeneous node attributes and multi-layer networks, providing a robust probabilistic framework for network factorization and link prediction. Empirical validation on social networks and biological interaction datasets demonstrates improved predictive performance and interpretable community detection compared to existing parametric and single-layer non-parametric methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Hierarchical Bayesian Non-Parametric Modeling of Relational Data with Latent Community Structures

text: This paper provides novel sharp generalization bounds for adversarially robust learning, specifically focusing on the trade-off between standard accuracy and adversarial robustness. We leverage advanced PAC-Bayesian theory, employing a modified Rényi divergence to quantify the discrepancy between the posterior distribution over models and a data-dependent prior tailored for robust optimization objectives. Our bounds explicitly account for the adversarial perturbation budget and the complexity of the hypothesis space under adversarial training regimes. A key contribution is the derivation of tighter, data-adaptive bounds that are sensitive to the empirical margin distribution of robust classifiers. These results illuminate the fundamental limits of robust generalization, suggesting pathways for designing algorithms that achieve better robustness-accuracy trade-offs without incurring excessive statistical complexity. Empirical validation on deep neural networks trained with various adversarial strategies confirms the practical relevance and tightness of our theoretical guarantees.
subject: İstatistik
title: Sharp Generalization Bounds for Adversarially Robust Learning via PAC-Bayesian Divergences

text: We present a novel robust functional principal component analysis (RFPCA) method specifically designed for high-dimensional functional data contaminated by outliers or heavy-tailed noise. Traditional FPCA methods, based on covariance operators, are highly sensitive to such perturbations, leading to biased estimates of eigenfunctions and eigenvalues. Our approach extends the concept of robust M-estimation to the infinite-dimensional setting, defining a robust functional covariance operator through a smoothly clipped absolute deviation (SCAD) penalty or Huber loss function applied to empirical functional distances. This yields an iterative algorithm that simultaneously estimates the robust mean function and the principal components with enhanced resistance to contamination. We derive theoretical properties, including consistency and robustness under various outlier generation mechanisms. Extensive simulations and a real-world application to electroencephalography (EEG) data demonstrate that RFPCA outperforms standard FPCA and existing robust variants in both estimation accuracy and outlier detection capabilities, particularly in high-contamination scenarios.
subject: İstatistik
title: Robust Functional Principal Component Analysis for Contaminated High-Dimensional Curves via M-Estimation

text: This paper proposes a comprehensive Bayesian spatio-temporal joint model for multivariate count outcomes exhibiting complex spatial and temporal dependencies. Addressing the limitations of separate modeling, our framework incorporates shared and outcome-specific latent Gaussian fields with both conditional autoregressive (CAR) and autoregressive (AR) components, respectively capturing fine-scale spatial and temporal residual correlation. The multivariate count data are linked to the latent fields through generalized linear mixed models with appropriate link functions (e.g., log for Poisson or negative binomial). Inference is performed efficiently using integrated nested Laplace approximation (INLA) for improved computational scalability, critical for large datasets. This joint modeling approach allows for precise estimation of cross-outcome associations, improved prediction, and better disentanglement of shared environmental drivers from outcome-specific processes. We demonstrate the utility of our model through an analysis of disease incidence rates across regions and time, revealing intricate patterns of transmission and risk factors that are obscured by univariate analyses.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Spatio-Temporal Joint Modeling of Multivariate Count Data with Shared Latent Gaussian Fields

text: We develop a novel regularized proportional hazards model specifically tailored for analyzing time-to-event data with competing risks in the presence of high-dimensional genomic predictors. Traditional methods struggle with collinearity and the "p >> n" problem, especially in multi-event scenarios. Our approach extends the Fine-Gray subdistribution hazards model by incorporating adaptive group Lasso penalties, allowing for simultaneous variable selection and grouping of functionally related genes or pathways. This not only enhances predictive accuracy but also improves interpretability by identifying biologically relevant covariate clusters. The regularization is applied separately for each cause-specific event, acknowledging distinct sets of predictors for different competing events. An efficient coordinate descent algorithm with warm starts is employed for optimization. Through simulations and a bladder cancer genomics study, we demonstrate that our method yields more parsimonious and biologically plausible risk prediction models than conventional penalized Cox or Fine-Gray models, particularly when disentangling risk factors for distinct types of events.
subject: İstatistik
