title: Regularized Proportional Hazards Models with Competing Risks for High-Dimensional Genomic Predictors

text: Federated learning (FL) faces significant challenges in achieving fast convergence and robust performance under non-Independent and Identically Distributed (non-IID) data across clients. This paper proposes a novel variance-reduced federated optimization algorithm that addresses data heterogeneity through personalized gradient aggregation. Instead of uniform aggregation, our method dynamically weighs client contributions based on their data distribution and local model divergence from a global average. We introduce a control variate technique at the client level, combined with a server-side adaptive momentum estimation, to mitigate client drift and reduce gradient variance without compromising privacy or increasing communication overhead. Theoretical convergence guarantees are established for non-convex objectives, demonstrating improved rates compared to existing FL algorithms under realistic non-IID settings. Extensive empirical evaluations on diverse datasets show superior performance in terms of convergence speed, model accuracy, and robustness to varying degrees of data heterogeneity, advancing the practical deployment of FL.
subject: İstatistik
title: Variance-Reduced Federated Learning with Non-IID Data via Personalized Gradient Aggregation

text: We propose a novel framework for image-on-scalar regression, extending functional additive models to accommodate high-dimensional image predictors with scalar outcomes, while allowing for varying-coefficient effects. Traditional image regression often relies on dimension reduction or pixel-wise models, which can obscure complex spatially-varying relationships. Our method constructs a kernelized functional additive model where each image covariate's contribution to the outcome is modulated by a smooth, non-parametric function of another scalar covariate. By employing reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces (RKHS) for both functional (image) components and varying coefficients, we capture intricate non-linear interactions without strong parametric assumptions. A computationally efficient alternating backfitting algorithm is developed for estimation, coupled with penalized splines for regularization. This approach provides interpretable models that localize predictive signals within images and quantify how these signals change across different conditions. Empirical studies on neuroimaging data demonstrate superior predictive accuracy and interpretability compared to fixed-coefficient or fully non-parametric image regression techniques.
subject: İstatistik
title: Kernelized Functional Additive Models for Image-on-Scalar Regression with Varying-Coefficient Effects

text: This paper introduces a novel sparse spatio-temporal quantile regression framework tailored for modeling extreme events, addressing the limitations of mean-based models and static quantile approaches. Our method allows the estimation of conditional quantiles (e.g., 90th or 99th percentile) of an outcome variable, capturing the entire distributional effect of covariates, particularly in the tails. We incorporate both spatial and temporal dependencies through a structured additive model with basis function expansions, regularized by an adaptive group Lasso penalty to induce sparsity and select relevant predictors. The adaptive penalization ensures consistent variable selection and oracle properties. Furthermore, the approach allows for spatio-temporally varying coefficients, providing nuanced insights into how risk factors for extreme events evolve across space and time. An efficient alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) algorithm is developed for optimization. Applications to climate extremes and epidemiological outbreaks demonstrate superior predictive performance and robust inference for high-quantile forecasts under complex dependency structures.
subject: İstatistik
title: Sparse Spatio-Temporal Quantile Regression for Extreme Event Modeling with Adaptive Penalization

text: This study delineates a novel strategy for targeted epigenetic modulation of cellular senescence using catalytically dead Cas9 (dCas9) fused to a modified histone acetyltransferase (HAT) domain. We demonstrate site-specific recruitment of dCas9-HAT complexes to promoter regions of critical genes associated with the Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotype (SASP), such as IL-6 and IL-8, leading to localized histone H3K27 acetylation and subsequent transcriptional repression. Chromatin immunoprecipitation-sequencing (ChIP-seq) confirmed enhanced H3K27ac enrichment at target loci, correlating with a significant reduction in SASP factor secretion as quantified by multiplex immunoassay. Furthermore, high-throughput transcriptomic profiling revealed broad amelioration of the pro-inflammatory senescence signature. This system offers a highly programmable platform for precise epigenome engineering, presenting significant therapeutic potential for age-related pathologies by reversing deleterious cellular phenotypes through refined epigenetic control.
subject: Biyoloji
title: CRISPR-dCas9-mediated Epigenetic Reprogramming of Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotype via Histone Acetyltransferase Recruitment

text: Aberrant expression of circular RNAs (circRNAs) is increasingly implicated in oncogenesis. Here, we identify a novel circRNA, circPVT1, significantly upregulated in Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM) tissues. Mechanistically, circPVT1 acts as a molecular sponge for microRNA-214-3p (miR-214-3p), a known tumor suppressor. RNA immunoprecipitation and luciferase reporter assays confirmed direct interaction between circPVT1 and miR-214-3p, demonstrating that circPVT1 abrogates miR-214-3p-mediated suppression of PD-L1. Consequently, circPVT1 overexpression indirectly upregulates PD-L1 expression by derepressing the PTEN/AKT signaling pathway, leading to enhanced immune evasion and tumor cell proliferation. In vivo xenograft models validated that genetic knockdown of circPVT1 significantly inhibits GBM tumor growth and enhances sensitivity to anti-PD-1 immunotherapy. This work elucidates a critical circRNA/miRNA/PD-L1 axis in GBM pathobiology, proposing circPVT1 as a promising therapeutic target for improving immunotherapy efficacy in this intractable malignancy.
subject: Biyoloji
title: CircRNA-Mediated Sequestration of miR-214-3p Regulates PD-L1 Expression in Glioblastoma Multiforme through PTEN/AKT Pathway Modulation

text: Familial Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (fALS) is characterized by proteotoxicity from misfolded protein aggregates. This study investigates the contribution of chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA) dysregulation in fALS pathology, focusing on mutant SOD1G93A and C9orf72-associated dipeptide repeat proteins. We demonstrate a significant reduction in CMA activity in primary motor neurons derived from fALS patient iPSCs and in SOD1G93A transgenic mice, correlating with decreased lysosomal membrane-associated protein 2A (LAMP2A) levels. Mechanistically, we identify aberrant S-nitrosylation of LAMP2A at cysteine residue C212, catalyzed by inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS), as a critical modulator of its stability and lysosomal localization. Inhibition of iNOS or genetic rescue of LAMP2A S-nitrosylation significantly restores CMA flux, reduces intracellular aggregate accumulation, and improves neuronal viability. These findings highlight a novel post-translational modification in CMA impairment in fALS, offering a potential therapeutic avenue through redox modulation of lysosomal components.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Chaperone-Mediated Autophagy Dysregulation in Familial Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Models: A Role for LAMP2A S-Nitrosylation

text: Understanding tumor heterogeneity and microenvironment interactions at single-cell resolution is paramount for effective cancer therapy. We present an integrated single-cell spatial multi-omics approach combining spatial transcriptomics with CITE-seq-derived proteomic data to characterize Triple-Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC) tissues. Our methodology enabled simultaneous quantification of gene expression and surface protein markers across spatially resolved single cells. Unsupervised clustering identified distinct cellular states within the tumor microenvironment, including novel subsets of immunosuppressive myeloid cells and activated fibroblasts, exhibiting unique molecular signatures. Ligand-receptor interaction analysis revealed intricate intercellular communication networks, pinpointing critical pathways mediating immune suppression and metastatic potential. Notably, spatially constrained analyses uncovered preferential localization of certain cellular states and their associated communication hubs within distinct tumor niches. This comprehensive multi-modal mapping provides unprecedented insights into TNBC complexity, facilitating the identification of spatially defined therapeutic targets.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated Single-Cell Spatial Multi-Omics Reveals Heterogeneous Cellular States and Intercellular Communication Networks in Triple-Negative Breast Cancer

text: Macrophage polarization into pro-inflammatory (M1) or anti-inflammatory (M2) phenotypes involves profound metabolic reprogramming, yet the role of mitochondrial dynamics remains incompletely understood. This study elucidates how regulated mitochondrial fission and fusion events dictate macrophage metabolic fate and oxidative stress resilience. We demonstrate that M1 polarization induces a Drp1-dependent increase in mitochondrial fragmentation, accompanied by enhanced glycolytic flux and diminished oxidative phosphorylation, driven by increased ROS production. Conversely, M2 polarization favors Mfn1/2-mediated mitochondrial fusion, promoting fatty acid oxidation and oxidative defense. Pharmacological inhibition of Drp1 skews M1 macrophages towards an M2-like metabolic profile, reducing inflammatory cytokine secretion and improving mitochondrial bioenergetics. Conversely, Mfn1/2 knockdown exacerbates M2 inflammatory responses. These findings establish mitochondrial fission-fusion dynamics as a critical regulator of macrophage bioenergetic flexibility and immune function, offering novel therapeutic targets for inflammatory and metabolic disorders.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mitochondrial Fission-Fusion Dynamics Orchestrate Metabolic Rewiring and Oxidative Stress Response in Macrophage Polarization

text: Understanding the precise spatiotemporal organization of viral replication requires high-resolution structural methodologies. This study employs cryo-electron tomography (cryo-ET) coupled with subtomogram averaging to visualize the intact architecture of enteroviral replication organelles (ROs) within infected host cells. We reveal the three-dimensional ultrastructure of these membrane-associated ROs, demonstrating their distinct morphology characterized by convoluted membrane arrangements and lumenal inclusions. Critically, our in situ analyses precisely localize key viral non-structural proteins, such as 3Dpol and 2C ATPase, relative to the replicating viral RNA within these compartments. Furthermore, we identify specific host protein complexes, including components of the COPII machinery and lipid droplets, dynamically associated with nascent ROs, underscoring their integral role in virion biogenesis. These unprecedented insights into the native environment of viral replication provide a foundational molecular blueprint for developing targeted antiviral strategies by disrupting essential RO assembly or host factor interactions.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-Electron Tomography Reveals In Situ Architecture of Viral Replication Organelles and Host Factor Recruitment

text: The mechanical properties of the extracellular matrix (ECM) profoundly influence cell fate and function, yet the mechanisms by which mechanical cues are transduced to the nucleus to regulate gene expression remain elusive. This study investigates the role of the Linker of Nucleoskeleton and Cytoskeleton (LINC) complex in nuclear mechanotransduction and its impact on chromatin organization. We demonstrate that increasing ECM stiffness activates the LINC complex, leading to enhanced nuclear-cytoskeletal coupling and increased nuclear deformation. This mechanical stress on the nucleus translates into changes in chromatin accessibility, specifically at enhancers and promoter regions of mechanosensitive genes, as revealed by ATAC-seq. Perturbation of LINC complex integrity abrogates these changes, leading to altered expression of genes involved in cell differentiation and proliferation. Our findings establish the LINC complex as a critical transducer of mechanical force into nuclear architectural changes that remodel chromatin landscapes, thus directly impacting transcriptional programs in response to the microenvironment.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Nuclear Mechanotransduction via LINC Complex Modulates Chromatin Accessibility and Transcription in Response to Extracellular Matrix Stiffness

text: SARS-CoV-2 employs sophisticated strategies to subvert host antiviral immunity, facilitating rampant replication and pathogenesis. This study delineates a novel mechanism by which SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein ORF3a antagonizes the innate immune response by targeting TNF receptor-associated factor 3 (TRAF3), a crucial adaptor in type I interferon (IFN) signaling. We show that ORF3a directly interacts with TRAF3 and promotes its K48-linked polyubiquitination, leading to proteasomal degradation. This ORF3a-mediated TRAF3 degradation results in attenuated activation of downstream IRF3 and NF-κB pathways, thereby suppressing the production of type I IFNs and inflammatory cytokines. CRISPR/Cas9-mediated deletion of ORF3a significantly restores TRAF3 levels and enhances the antiviral response in SARS-CoV-2 infected cells. Our findings uncover a critical viral immune evasion strategy, positioning ORF3a as a potent antagonist of innate immunity and a potential therapeutic target for mitigating severe COVID-19 pathology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Innate Immune Evasion by SARS-CoV-2 ORF3a through TRAF3 Ubiquitination and Degradation Pathway Targeting

text: The precise delivery of macromolecular therapeutics remains a significant challenge in molecular medicine. We engineer a novel class of programmable, self-assembling protein nanocages derived from bacterial microcompartment proteins, designed for tunable intracellular cargo encapsulation and targeted delivery. Through rational domain engineering, these cages were functionalized with specific targeting peptides for receptor-mediated endocytosis and equipped with pH-responsive disassembly domains for endosomal escape. We demonstrate efficient encapsulation of small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) and therapeutic peptides within these nanocages. In vitro and in vivo studies reveal targeted cellular uptake and subsequent release of siRNAs, leading to potent and sequence-specific gene silencing in disease-relevant cell lines and xenograft models, with minimal off-target effects. This modular synthetic biology platform offers superior control over cargo packaging stoichiometry, release kinetics, and cellular tropism, paving the way for next-generation precision nanomedicines for various genetic and oncological disorders.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Programmable Self-Assembling Synthetic Protein Cages for Tunable Intracellular Cargo Delivery and Targeted Gene Silencing

text: Inter-kingdom communication between the gut microbiota and host epithelium is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis, yet the molecular mediators remain largely uncharacterized. This study investigates the role of bacterial outer membrane vesicles (OMVs) as carriers of small RNAs (sRNAs) in modulating host intestinal epithelial barrier function. We demonstrate that OMVs isolated from commensal *Bacteroides fragilis* contain a diverse repertoire of bacterial sRNAs. Upon uptake by intestinal epithelial cells (IECs), these OMV-derived sRNAs are delivered to the host cytosol, where they directly interact with specific host RNA-binding proteins and microRNA machinery. Functional assays reveal that these bacterial sRNAs significantly enhance tight junction integrity and reduce paracellular permeability by modulating the expression of occludin and ZO-1. Furthermore, in vivo studies using germ-free mice colonized with *B. fragilis*-derived OMVs showed improved barrier function and attenuated inflammatory responses. This work establishes a novel paradigm for bacterial sRNA-mediated inter-kingdom signaling, offering new insights into gut symbiosis and therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Bacterial Outer Membrane Vesicles Mediate Inter-Kingdom Communication by Delivering sRNAs that Modulate Host Intestinal Epithelial Barrier Function

text: This paper investigates the Turán problem for loose cycles, C_k^r, in r-uniform hypergraphs, extending classical results from graph theory. We establish novel upper bounds for the Turán number ex_r(n, C_k^r), particularly focusing on the regime where k is relatively small compared to r. Our approach leverages a sophisticated combination of extremal set theory techniques and probabilistic methods, employing the method of dependent random choice to analyze specific structural properties that forbid loose cycles. We provide a constructive proof for a lower bound using high-girth hypergraphs derived from finite fields, demonstrating the tightness of our bounds for certain parameters. Furthermore, we explore the asymptotic behavior of ex_r(n, C_k^r) as n → ∞, offering new conjectures on the exact Turán number for specific hypergraph cycles and contributing to the broader understanding of forbidden substructures in higher-order graphs.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Turán Problem for Loose Cycles in Uniform Hypergraphs

text: This research delves into the intersection of algebraic combinatorics and algebraic geometry, specifically exploring the K-theory of flag varieties using advanced combinatorial tools. We introduce a novel framework leveraging modified Young tableaux and generalized Littlewood-Richardson coefficients to compute structure constants in the K-theory ring K*(G/B). Our method provides a combinatorial interpretation for the expansion of products of K-theory Schubert classes, offering new insights into the underlying geometric structure. We establish a direct correspondence between certain families of semi-standard tableaux and specific Grothendieck polynomials, thereby extending classical results from cohomology to K-theory. The work culminates in a proof of a new positivity conjecture for K-theoretic Littlewood-Richardson coefficients for arbitrary Lie types, generalizing previous results restricted to type A.
subject: Matematik
title: Schubert Calculus and the K-theory of Flag Varieties through Combinatorial Tableaux

text: We investigate threshold phenomena for the existence of a monochromatic connected component spanning a positive fraction of vertices in a randomly colored random hypergraph H_r(n,p). Specifically, we consider a k-coloring of the edges of G(n,p), the r-uniform random hypergraph where each edge is present independently with probability p. Our primary focus is to determine the precise threshold probability p_c at which such a component emerges with high probability. We employ a multi-phase branching process analysis, coupled with large deviation theory for sparse random structures, to characterize the phase transition. The results extend classical theorems on connectivity in random graphs to hypergraphs under chromatic constraints, revealing new critical behaviors dependent on r and k. This work contributes significantly to the understanding of robustness and connectivity in complex network models.
subject: Matematik
title: Threshold Phenomena for Monochromatic Connectivity in Random Hypergraphs

text: This paper presents new advancements on the sum-product problem in higher-dimensional vector spaces over finite fields ℤ_q. We examine the size of A+A and A ⋅ A for a finite set A ⊂ (ℤ_q^d)^k, where A+A denotes the Minkowski sum and A ⋅ A represents a suitably defined product operation, such as coordinate-wise multiplication or a convolution-type product. Leveraging techniques from incidence geometry, harmonic analysis on finite fields, and expander graph theory, we establish improved lower bounds for max(|A+A|, |A ⋅ A|). Our results provide a significant generalization of the sum-product phenomenon beyond one dimension, highlighting the interplay between additive and multiplicative structures. We particularly focus on cases where A has low doubling constant, revealing super-linear growth rates and challenging existing barriers in general sum-product estimates.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Sum-Product Problem in Higher Dimensions over Finite Fields

text: We investigate the existence of monochromatic complete bipartite r-uniform hypergraphs, K_s,t^r, within arbitrarily large k-colored hypergraphs. This research focuses on generalized hypergraph Ramsey numbers R(K_s,t^r; k) where edges are colored with k colors, and we seek a monochromatic copy of K_s,t^r. Our novel contribution lies in establishing upper and lower bounds for these numbers, particularly for fixed r ≥ 3 and variable s,t, under various coloring schemes. We employ an iterative application of the hypergraph Regularity Lemma combined with sophisticated probabilistic arguments to derive new bounds that improve upon existing results. The findings shed light on the structural properties of hypergraphs that necessitate the emergence of large monochromatic substructures, extending classical graph Ramsey theory to the more complex setting of hypergraphs with specific bipartite partitions.
subject: Matematik
title: Hypergraph Ramsey Numbers for Complete Bipartite Hypergraphs with Prescribed Colorings

text: This paper addresses the decomposition of the complete graph K_n into edge-disjoint copies of a specific graph-pair structure, wherein each pair (G_1, G_2) consists of two graphs with prescribed properties, such as bounded maximum degree and minimum girth. We investigate the existence and enumeration of such decompositions, particularly when G_1 and G_2 are both outerplanar or planar graphs. Our approach involves a combination of algebraic graph theory techniques, notably eigenvalue bounds for adjacency matrices, and a refined application of the "probabilistic method with alterations." We establish sufficient conditions on n for such decompositions to exist, overcoming challenges related to the intricate interplay of girth and degree constraints. This work extends classical results on graph decompositions to a more constrained setting, providing novel insights into the structured partitioning of graph edges.
subject: Matematik
title: Decompositions of Complete Graphs into Graph-Pairs of Bounded Girth

text: This research introduces a novel framework for studying connectivity in matroids using homological invariants derived from their geometric lattices. We define a generalized notion of fundamental cycles and cocycles within the context of matroid complexes, leading to the construction of a chain complex whose homology groups capture subtle aspects of matroid connectivity beyond standard definitions. Special attention is given to matroids representable over fields of characteristic zero, where we establish connections to the theory of Stanley-Reisner rings and Cohen-Macaulay complexes. Our main result demonstrates that the vanishing of specific higher homology groups is equivalent to strong connectivity properties, such as k-connectivity for certain classes of matroids, offering a new algebraic perspective on classical matroid theorems.
subject: Matematik
title: Homological Invariants and Connectivity in Matroids with Characteristic Zero

text: This paper investigates the asymptotic enumeration of permutations exhibiting specific descent patterns, focusing on restrictions imposed by subsequences and the distribution of descents within blocks. We extend classical results on permutations with a fixed number of descents by introducing generating functions incorporating multiple descent pattern constraints. A significant portion of this work is dedicated to developing q-analogs of these enumerations, utilizing techniques from partition theory and the theory of basic hypergeometric series. We derive precise asymptotic formulas for the number of such permutations as n → ∞, employing saddle-point approximations and methods of analytic combinatorics. The findings provide deep insights into the fine structure of permutation statistics and their relation to other combinatorial objects, such as Young tableaux and Stirling numbers of both kinds.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotics of Permutations with Restricted Descent Patterns and their q-Analogs

text: We present new bounds on the spectral gap of the normalized adjacency matrix for infinite families of Ramanujan graphs and their generalizations, leveraging properties of non-backtracking operators. Specifically, we investigate the relationship between the Ihara zeta function of a graph and the spectrum of its adjacency and non-backtracking matrices. Our analysis develops techniques for constructing expander graphs with optimal spectral properties, particularly focusing on graphs derived from arithmetic groups and algebraic constructions over finite fields. We establish a tighter connection between the trace formula for non-backtracking operators and the distribution of eigenvalues, leading to improved criteria for identifying graphs that satisfy the Ramanujan property. This work provides fundamental contributions to the theory of expander graphs, with implications for coding theory, network design, and the construction of pseudorandom structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Spectral Gap Bounds for Ramanujan Graphs and Non-Backtracking Operators

text: This paper develops a novel framework for generating strong cutting planes for integer programming problems by leveraging the polyhedral combinatorics of block decompositions. We introduce a technique to identify and exploit structural properties of specific subgraphs and their induced facets within the integer hull. Our methodology involves partitioning the original problem into interconnected blocks, deriving valid inequalities for each block's convex hull, and then lifting these inequalities to the full problem space. Particular emphasis is placed on (0,1)-integer programs with network flow or matching substructures, where we develop specialized lifting procedures and establish conditions for facet-defining inequalities. This research offers significant advancements in computational integer programming, providing a robust approach for tightening linear programming relaxations and enhancing the efficiency of branch-and-cut algorithms for hard combinatorial optimization problems.
subject: Matematik
title: Strong Cutting Planes for Integer Programs via Polyhedral Combinatorics of Block Decompositions

text: Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit remarkable generative capabilities but often lack verifiable robustness against subtle adversarial perturbations and suffer from opaque decision-making processes. This paper introduces a novel framework for certified adversarial robustness and post-hoc interpretability in LLMs by leveraging causal abstraction and mechanistic interpretability. We propose a methodology that constructs a causal graph of internal activations, identifying critical subgraphs responsible for specific behavioral functions. By perturbing these abstract causal pathways, we quantify their influence on downstream predictions and demonstrate certified bounds on output stability under bounded input alterations. Our approach extends beyond mere input-output correlation, providing insights into the mechanistic underpinnings of robustness failures. Empirical evaluation on diverse LLM architectures and datasets reveals superior certification rates compared to existing methods, alongside interpretable causal explanations for vulnerability points, paving the way for more trustworthy and accountable AI systems.
subject: AI
title: Explainable Certification of Adversarial Robustness in Foundation Models via Causal Abstraction

text: Discovering causal relationships from observational and interventional data remains a cornerstone challenge in scientific inquiry, particularly in high-dimensional, time-series contexts where latent confounders abound. This work presents a novel neural variational inference framework for robust causal structure learning from mixed interventional time-series data. Our model leverages a recurrent neural network encoder to capture complex spatiotemporal dependencies and a continuous optimization approach for acyclicity constraints, circumventing combinatorial graph search. By explicitly modeling latent confounding through a variational autoencoder component conditioned on interventional targets, we disentangle true causal links from spurious correlations. Furthermore, we incorporate an adaptive intervention strategy within a closed-loop active learning paradigm to optimize data acquisition for maximal causal information gain. Experiments on synthetic and real-world biological datasets demonstrate superior precision, recall, and computational efficiency compared to state-of-the-art causal discovery algorithms under various noise regimes and sparsity levels.
subject: AI
title: Neural Variational Causal Discovery from Interventional Time-Series Data in High-Dimensional Systems

text: Achieving optimal coordination in complex multi-agent systems, particularly under partial observability and communication bandwidth constraints, presents significant challenges for decentralized control. This paper proposes a hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning (H-MARL) framework that integrates meta-learning with an adversarial information regularization scheme to enhance emergent communication and cooperation. A high-level policy learns to modulate individual agents' goals and information-sharing strategies, while low-level policies execute primitive actions. We introduce an adversarial regularization term to implicitly encourage agents to encode task-relevant information in their limited communication channels while discarding redundant or privacy-sensitive data. This mechanism facilitates robust, decentralized control by fostering interpretable information exchange critical for collective intelligence. Empirical evaluations across diverse cooperative multi-agent tasks, including robotic swarm coordination and traffic management, demonstrate significant improvements in system-level performance, scalability, and robustness to communication latency compared to conventional MARL approaches.
subject: AI
title: Decentralized Optimal Control via Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Adversarial Information Regularization

text: Federated Learning (FL) and Continual Learning (CL) are pivotal for deploying adaptive AI on privacy-sensitive, resource-constrained edge devices, yet their synergistic integration remains complex due to data heterogeneity and catastrophic forgetting across dynamic client distributions. This paper introduces FedCL-X, an explainable federated continual learning framework. FedCL-X employs a novel bidirectional knowledge distillation mechanism between a global model and local clients, ensuring efficient knowledge transfer while mitigating privacy concerns. Critically, we integrate a probabilistic concept drift detector at the client-side to adaptively weight past knowledge and new information, enabling robust performance against evolving data streams. Furthermore, FedCL-X incorporates attention-based interpretability modules to provide local and global explanations for model decisions, addressing the black-box nature of federated models. Extensive experiments on non-i.i.d. image classification and natural language understanding tasks validate FedCL-X's superior ability to balance privacy, adaptivity, and explainability in real-world edge scenarios.
subject: AI
title: FedCL-X: Explainable Federated Continual Learning for Heterogeneous Edge Devices via Knowledge Distillation and Concept Drift Adaptation

text: Predicting the three-dimensional structure of proteins from their amino acid sequences remains a fundamental grand challenge in computational biology, demanding robust methods capable of capturing complex non-Euclidean inter-residue dependencies. This work proposes a novel geometric deep learning architecture, Spectral Graph Neural Networks (SGNNs), specifically designed for de novo protein structure prediction. Our SGNNs operate directly on a dynamic protein contact graph, where nodes represent residues and edges signify spatial proximity, with edge features incorporating torsion angles and dihedral constraints. Leveraging spectral convolutions on graph Laplacian representations, the model efficiently learns hierarchical features invariant to Euclidean transformations and captures long-range interactions crucial for folding. We further introduce a manifold-valued output layer that directly predicts backbone dihedral angles, bypassing cumbersome Cartesian coordinate representations. Empirical results demonstrate competitive accuracy against state-of-the-art methods on benchmark datasets, offering a promising avenue for high-fidelity structural biology applications.
subject: AI
title: Spectral Graph Neural Networks for De Novo Protein Structure Prediction on Manifold-Valued Data

text: Generative models capable of synthesizing realistic and physically consistent spatiotemporal data are crucial for climate science and environmental modeling, yet controlling the generation process while maintaining high fidelity remains challenging. This paper introduces a novel conditional spatiotemporal diffusion model for controllable generation of high-resolution multimodal climate simulations. Our model leverages a 3D UNet-like architecture with attention mechanisms to capture complex dependencies across spatial dimensions, time, and diverse climate variables (e.g., temperature, precipitation, pressure). We augment the diffusion process with a conditional guidance mechanism that allows for fine-grained control over specific climatic events or future scenarios, defined by spatiotemporal masks or desired statistical properties. This enables "what-if" analyses and the generation of synthetic datasets for training downstream predictive models. Empirical validation on ERA5 reanalysis data demonstrates superior generative quality, consistency, and controllability compared to existing GAN-based and autoregressive models, offering a powerful tool for climate research.
subject: AI
title: Conditional Spatiotemporal Diffusion Models for Controllable Generation of High-Fidelity Multimodal Climate Simulations

text: Intelligent robots operating in complex, hybrid environments demand reasoning capabilities that transcend purely reactive policies, requiring both robust perceptual grounding and explainable symbolic planning. This paper introduces a novel neuro-symbolic architecture for program synthesis tailored for verifiable robot planning. Our approach integrates a deep neural network for perception and action primitive grounding with a symbolic program synthesizer that operates over a defined domain-specific language (DSL). The neural component learns to translate raw sensor inputs into symbolic predicates, which then inform the synthesizer to generate verifiable logical programs. We employ a policy-gradient-based learning algorithm to optimize the synthesis process, incorporating feedback from a symbolic execution engine to guide program search towards correctness and optimality. This framework yields highly interpretable plans, amenable to formal verification, and demonstrates superior generalization and robustness in unseen scenarios compared to end-to-end deep learning or purely symbolic planners, bridging the gap between perception and explainable reasoning.
subject: AI
title: Neural-Symbolic Program Synthesis for Explainable and Verifiable Robot Planning in Hybrid Environments

text: Optimizing feature selection in high-dimensional datasets is a notoriously NP-hard problem crucial for improving model generalization and reducing computational costs in machine learning. This paper explores the application of the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) as a quantum-inspired heuristic for enhanced feature subset selection. We formulate feature selection as a quadratic unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO) problem, where variables represent feature inclusion and the objective function balances classification performance with feature subset cardinality, regularized by mutual information. QAOA is then employed to find approximate solutions to this QUBO on a simulated quantum annealer, leveraging its ability to explore complex energy landscapes more efficiently than classical algorithms for certain problem instances. Our comparative analysis against classical heuristics like genetic algorithms and simulated annealing demonstrates that QAOA yields superior feature subsets, leading to improved predictive accuracy and sparsity on several benchmark classification tasks, highlighting its potential for quantum advantage in combinatorial optimization for ML.
subject: AI
title: Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm for Enhanced Feature Selection in High-Dimensional Classification

text: Robust perception in autonomous driving systems hinges on effective fusion of heterogeneous spatiotemporal sensor data (e.g., LiDAR, camera, radar) under diverse environmental conditions. This paper introduces a novel self-supervised learning framework that leverages transformer architectures for multimodal sensor fusion, addressing the scarcity of comprehensively labeled fusion datasets. We design several pretext tasks, including cross-modal temporal alignment, masked sensor data reconstruction, and sensor modality prediction, which compel the model to learn rich, invariant representations from unlabeled raw sensor streams. A unified transformer encoder processes fused spatiotemporal tokens from all modalities, capturing intricate inter- and intra-modal dependencies. The self-supervised pre-training significantly enhances the model's ability to extract complementary information and handle sensor dropouts. Fine-tuning on downstream tasks like 3D object detection and semantic segmentation demonstrates substantial performance improvements and superior robustness to sensor noise and occlusions compared to supervised baselines, showcasing the power of representation learning for embodied AI.
subject: AI
title: Transformer-based Self-Supervised Pretext Tasks for Robust Multimodal Spatiotemporal Sensor Fusion in Autonomous Driving

text: Deep learning models are susceptible to data poisoning attacks, where malicious actors inject corrupted samples into the training data to manipulate model behavior, leading to severe security and reliability concerns. This paper proposes a certified defense mechanism against data poisoning by formulating the training objective as a distributionally robust optimization (DRO) problem. We construct an ambiguity set around the empirical data distribution, encompassing potential shifts caused by bounded poisoning attacks, and then seek a model that minimizes the worst-case loss over this set. Our key contribution lies in integrating a novel robust aggregation scheme for gradient updates within a mini-batch setting, explicitly accounting for the presence of corrupted samples and their potential to skew gradients. This approach yields provable guarantees on model performance under specified poisoning budgets, without requiring prior knowledge of attack strategies. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our DRO-based defense significantly improves certified accuracy and robustness against various state-of-the-art poisoning attacks compared to standard training and heuristic defenses.
subject: AI
title: Certified Defense Against Data Poisoning Attacks via Distributionally Robust Optimization with Corrupted Samples

text: This research proposes a novel deep learning architecture for the granular analysis of functional harmonic trajectories, moving beyond conventional chord recognition to model voice-leading implications and modulatory pathways. Utilizing a multi-modal input combining constant-Q transformed audio features and symbolically-derived pitch class sets, our transformer-based variational autoencoder (VAE) learns a hierarchical latent representation of harmonic progression. The deconvolutional layers are optimized to reconstruct not only the macro-harmonic functions but also micro-level contrapuntal dissonances and resolutions. Through a comprehensive evaluation on a curated corpus of Romantic and early 20th-century art music, we demonstrate superior performance in identifying pivot chords, secondary dominants, and tonicizations, achieving an F1-score improvement of 12% over state-of-the-art symbolic and audio-only models. This methodology provides a robust framework for quantitatively assessing harmonic complexity and teleology.
subject: Müzik
title: Latent Space Deconvolution for Granular Functional Harmonic Trajectory Analysis via Multi-Modal Deep Embeddings

text: Analyzing microtonal inflections in non-Western music presents significant challenges due to the absence of fixed temperament grids and the contextual variability of intonation. This study introduces a Bayesian nonparametric model for probabilistic pitch tracking, specifically designed to parameterize microtonal deviations from theoretically defined cent values. Leveraging a multi-resolution sinusoidal modeling approach, our system estimates fundamental frequency trajectories and their associated uncertainty envelopes. A Dirichlet process mixture model subsequently clusters these trajectories into distinct microtonal categories, accounting for performer idiosyncrasies and stylistic variations. Validation on a Hindustani classical music corpus demonstrates robust identification of shruti nuances and their dynamic evolution, revealing heretofore unquantified statistical regularities in expressive intonation practices. This framework offers a rigorous computational tool for comparative ethnomusicological analysis, facilitating the systematic study of intricate intervallic relationships in diverse sonic traditions.
subject: Müzik
title: Probabilistic Microtonal Inflection Parameterization via Bayesian Nonparametric Pitch Tracking in Non-Western Repertoires

text: This research investigates the neuro-cognitive mechanisms underlying hierarchical rhythmic entrainment and meter perception through a computational model based on spatio-temporal oscillatory attractors. We propose a network of coupled phase oscillators, where individual oscillators correspond to distinct rhythmic periodicities (e.g., beat, tactus, hypermeter) and their coupling strengths adapt dynamically to incoming auditory transients derived from onset detection functions. The model integrates principles of predictive coding, modulating oscillator parameters based on statistical regularities in event timing and inter-onset intervals. Through simulations with metrically ambiguous stimuli and polyrhythmic compositions, our system accurately predicts perceived metric hierarchies and phase shifts, outperforming conventional hidden Markov models in tracking syncopation and rhythmic complexity. This framework offers a quantitative account of how listeners construct and maintain temporal coherence in intricate rhythmic streams, advancing theories of auditory scene analysis and cognitive rhythm perception.
subject: Müzik
title: Hierarchical Rhythmic Entrainment Modeling through Spatio-Temporal Oscillatory Attractors in Perceptual Clock Networks

text: The semantic description of timbre remains a significant challenge due to the high dimensionality and perceptual complexity of auditory features. This study introduces a novel approach for augmenting timbral descriptors with perceptually-weighted information, aiming to bridge the gap between acoustic signal properties and high-level semantic attributes. We employ a deep manifold learning framework, specifically a contrastive predictive coding (CPC) model, to derive a compact, perceptually salient embedding space from mel-spectrogram features. Subsequent augmentation involves incorporating spectro-temporal modulation energies and psychoacoustic masking thresholds, which are then used to train a multi-label classifier for predicting semantic traits such as 'warm', 'bright', 'rough', and 'metallic'. Evaluation on a large orchestral timbre dataset demonstrates a significant improvement (up to 15% mean average precision) in semantic attribute prediction compared to raw acoustic feature sets, highlighting the efficacy of perceptually-informed descriptor augmentation.
subject: Müzik
title: Perceptually-Weighted Timbral Descriptor Augmentation for Semantic Trait Prediction via Deep Manifold Learning

text: Automating Schenkerian analysis, a foundational theory of tonal music structure, poses considerable challenges due to its hierarchical and interpretative nature. This paper presents a novel graph-convolutional network (GCN) architecture designed to infer Urlinie (fundamental line) structures and perform hierarchical harmonic reduction directly from musical scores. Our model represents musical compositions as richly attributed graphs, where nodes denote pitch events and edges encode contrapuntal and harmonic relationships. The GCN iteratively learns to identify structural tones, voice leading, and prolongational techniques by propagating information across the graph, effectively emulating the recursive reduction process. Evaluated against a corpus of manually annotated Schenkerian analyses of Bach chorales and Beethoven sonata excerpts, our system achieves a statistically significant alignment with expert annotations for Urlinie derivation and identifies common prolongational archetypes with high precision. This pioneering work lays the groundwork for computational musicology tools capable of nuanced structural analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Graph-Convolutional Network for Urlinie Inference and Hierarchical Harmonic Reduction in Schenkerian Analysis

text: Neo-Riemannian theory offers a powerful framework for analyzing harmonic relationships in post-tonal and late-Romantic music through parsimonious voice leading transformations. This study introduces an audio-driven methodology for mapping continuous harmonic progressions onto a Neo-Riemannian transformational network and subsequently analyzing its topological structure using persistent homology. From constant-Q spectral representations, we extract chord progressions and discretize them into pitch-class sets. These sets are then projected into a generalized Tonnetz, where inter-chord distances are computed based on common tone retention. The resulting weighted graph undergoes filtration, and its persistent Betti numbers are calculated, revealing robust harmonic cycles, clusters, and voids that correspond to specific transformational sequences (e.g., L-P-R cycles, hexatonic poles). This novel application of topological data analysis provides a quantitative lens for understanding the underlying geometric and group-theoretic properties of complex harmonic landscapes directly from audio.
subject: Müzik
title: Audio-Driven Exploration of Neo-Riemannian Transformational Networks via Homological Persistent Homology

text: This paper presents a complex network analysis approach to model and quantify contrapuntal voice leading and dissonance management in 16th-century polyphony. We construct directed, multi-edged graphs where individual melodic lines are nodes, and edges represent intervallic relationships and temporal successions between simultaneously sounding pitches. Network metrics such as centrality, clustering coefficients, and path lengths are adapted to evaluate the independence and interdependence of voices, as well as the adherence to species counterpoint rules for consonances and dissonances. Furthermore, we employ dynamic graph analysis to track the evolution of contrapuntal density and registral distribution across musical forms. Application to a corpus of Palestrina masses and Gesualdo madrigals reveals distinctive stylistic fingerprints, particularly in the handling of suspensions and passing tones. This methodology offers a quantitative framework for comparative analysis of polyphonic texture and pedagogical insights into historical counterpoint practices.
subject: Müzik
title: Complex Network Analysis of Contrapuntal Voice Leading and Dissonance Management in 16th-Century Polyphony

text: This research proposes a novel framework for understanding large-scale musical form as an emergent property of perceptual dissipative structures, leveraging principles from non-equilibrium thermodynamics and information theory. We model musical experience as a dynamic system wherein incoming auditory information drives continuous reconfigurations of internal cognitive states. Using time-varying symbolic entropy and audio-derived perceptual entropy measures (e.g., spectral flatness, temporal irregularity), we quantify the rate of information generation and dissipation across different formal sections. Our analysis reveals that effective musical forms often exhibit a characteristic balance between entropic increase (introduction of new material/complexity) and entropic decrease (repetition, closure), creating 'attractor basins' of perceptual stability. Case studies from sonata forms and theme-and-variations demonstrate how these dynamic entropy profiles correlate with established music-theoretic formal functions, offering a quantifiable basis for the study of musical coherence and structural perception.
subject: Müzik
title: Modeling Perceptual Dissipative Structures in Musical Form via Information-Theoretic Entropy Dynamics

text: This study addresses the inverse problem of musical stylometry: reconstructing the underlying compositional intent and stylistic parameters from a given musical excerpt. We introduce a novel framework based on conditional Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) for 'adversarial stylometric inversion.' Our model, trained on a diverse corpus of polyphonic MIDI data categorized by composer and genre, learns to map musical sequences into a low-dimensional latent space representative of stylistic features. The generator aims to synthesize music conditioned on specific stylistic vectors, while the discriminator simultaneously attempts to classify both the authenticity and the inferred style of the generated and real samples. By perturbing the latent vectors and observing the generated output, we can systematically explore the stylistic manifold and infer the relative contributions of rhythmic, harmonic, and melodic features to a composer's idiosyncratic voice. This methodology offers a powerful tool for computational musicology, authorship attribution, and stylistic pastiche generation.
subject: Müzik
title: Adversarial Stylometric Inversion: Reconstructing Compositional Intent from Musical Latent Space via Conditional GANs

text: This research proposes a novel methodology for the comparative analysis of melodic contour homogeneity across diverse global musical traditions, addressing challenges posed by varying tuning systems and scalar structures. Our approach utilizes a scale-invariant wavelet decomposition (SIWD) to extract multi-resolution melodic contour features, effectively normalizing for absolute pitch and intervallic size variations while preserving relative pitch movement. These feature vectors are then subjected to topological data analysis (TDA), specifically Mapper graphs and persistent homology, to identify statistically significant clusters of melodic contours and their common topological features (e.g., loops, branches, connected components). Applied to a curated ethnomusicological corpus spanning Indic ragas, East Asian folk melodies, and African vocal traditions, the framework reveals underlying cross-cultural contour archetypes and quantifies their distribution. This offers a robust, data-driven tool for identifying universal principles and cultural specificities in melodic organization, advancing computational ethnomusicology.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Cultural Melodic Contour Homogeneity Mapping through Scale-Invariant Wavelet Decomposition and Topological Data Analysis

text: Hybrid zones serve as natural laboratories for investigating the genomic architecture of adaptive divergence and reproductive isolation. This study leverages population genomic sequencing across replicated *Anolis* lizard hybrid zones to dissect patterns of asymmetric introgression and its impact on adaptive phenotypic traits, specifically thermoregulatory physiology and limb morphology. Utilizing advanced admixture mapping and quantitative trait locus (QTL) analyses, we identify genomic regions exhibiting differential permeability to gene flow, often harboring loci linked to environmental adaptation. Our findings reveal that adaptive introgression facilitates the acquisition of beneficial alleles from parental species, demonstrating its potential role in accelerating local adaptation and shaping the evolutionary trajectories of hybridizing lineages under divergent selective pressures, thereby challenging traditional views of hybrid zones solely as barriers to gene flow.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Introgression and Adaptive Trait Evolution in Hybrid Zones

text: The evolution of complex traits is often governed by polygenic architectures, where adaptation is predicated upon the synergistic interplay of numerous loci. This investigation employs a high-throughput genomic approach coupled with directed evolution experiments in *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* to elucidate the role of epistasis in shaping adaptive landscapes. We perform comprehensive fitness assays and quantify the genetic interactions underlying adaptation to novel osmostress environments. Our results reveal prevalent context-dependent epistasis, demonstrating that the fitness effects of individual alleles are frequently modified by the genetic background. Furthermore, we observe that positive epistatic interactions are disproportionately enriched among beneficial mutations, suggesting a mechanism by which complex adaptive pathways can be traversed, underscoring the critical, often underestimated, contribution of epistatic variance to sustained adaptive evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Epistatic Interactions and the Evolutionary Dynamics of Polygenic Adaptation

text: Despite significant underlying genetic and regulatory divergence, many organismal clades exhibit remarkable morphological stasis over vast evolutionary timescales. This phenomenon, termed 'developmental system drift', posits that changes in developmental mechanisms can accumulate without corresponding phenotypic alterations due to canalization and compensatory evolution. We employ comparative developmental transcriptomics and CRISPR-mediated functional genomics in several cheilostome bryozoan lineages, a clade renowned for its morphological conservatism, to investigate the molecular basis of developmental system drift. Our analyses identify pervasive rewiring of gene regulatory networks associated with colonial development and calcification, yet reveal conservation of terminal phenotypic outcomes. These findings provide empirical evidence for the decoupling of genotypic and phenotypic evolution, highlighting the robustness of developmental systems and their capacity to absorb substantial molecular variation without overt phenotypic change, a key mechanism contributing to macroevolutionary patterns of stasis.
subject: Evrim
title: Developmental System Drift and Morphological Stasis in Deep-Time Evolution

text: Phenotypic plasticity is a crucial adaptive mechanism, yet its eco-evolutionary consequences are often complex and feedback-laden. This study investigates the reciprocal interplay between predation risk, plastic trait expression, and population dynamics in an aquatic copepod-fish predator system. We utilized experimental mesocosms to expose *Daphnia pulex* populations to varying regimes of simulated predation threat, quantifying induced morphological defenses (e.g., neckteeth) and concomitant life-history shifts. Our results demonstrate that predator-induced plasticity not only alters individual fitness but also significantly modulates population growth rates and community structure. Critically, we find evidence of eco-evolutionary feedbacks where altered prey demographics, driven by plasticity, subsequently influence predator foraging success and selective pressures on the prey's plastic response, suggesting that adaptive phenotypic plasticity can profoundly shape ecosystem functioning beyond simple direct effects, driving a dynamic evolutionary mosaic.
subject: Evrim
title: Eco-evolutionary Feedbacks of Predation Risk on Phenotypic Plasticity

text: Post-copulatory sexual selection, particularly cryptic female choice (CFC), is a potent evolutionary force in shaping reproductive outcomes, yet its mechanisms remain incompletely understood. This research investigates the molecular and physiological bases of CFC in a multiply mating, internally fertilizing insect, *Gryllus bimaculatus*. We utilize transcriptomic profiling of female reproductive tracts post-copulation with males of varying genetic quality, alongside in-vitro fertilization assays, to identify genes and pathways mediating sperm storage, utilization, and cryptic ejaculate assessment. Our findings reveal differential gene expression profiles correlated with male fitness indicators and specific proteolytic activities associated with sperm competition resolution. This empirical evidence elucidates the intricate post-mating landscape within the female reproductive tract, demonstrating that females are not passive recipients of ejaculate but exert significant selective agency, contributing to the cryptic sexual selection shaping male reproductive success and genomic diversity.
subject: Evrim
title: Cryptic Female Choice and Post-Copulatory Sexual Selection in Polyandrous Systems

text: Mobile genetic elements (MGEs), including plasmids, bacteriophages, and transposons, are pivotal drivers of microbial genome evolution, yet their contribution to adaptive radiation remains under-explored. This study employs comparative genomics and experimental evolution of *Pseudomonas fluorescens* during colonization of spatially structured environments to ascertain the impact of MGEs on niche differentiation and diversification. We identify a disproportionate accumulation of MGEs in lineages adapting to novel niches, specifically those encoding catabolic pathways for complex substrates and resistance determinants. High-resolution sequencing reveals MGE-mediated horizontal gene transfer (HGT) facilitates rapid acquisition of adaptive modules, enabling divergent ecological strategies. Our findings highlight MGEs as key evolutionary accelerators, providing immediate access to a vast pan-genome reservoir, thereby fueling rapid adaptive radiation and contributing significantly to the ecological success and speciation dynamics of bacterial populations in heterogeneous landscapes.
subject: Evrim
title: The Role of Mobile Genetic Elements in Microbial Adaptive Radiation

text: Eusocial insect colonies exemplify complex superorganisms, where altruism and specialized labor underpin ecological success. This study investigates the genomic underpinnings of caste-specific behaviors and the evolution of altruism in the ant *Pheidole pallidula*. We integrate whole-genome sequencing, caste-specific transcriptomics, and epigenomic profiling (ATAC-seq) across queen, major worker, and minor worker castes. Our analyses reveal distinct regulatory landscapes characterized by differential chromatin accessibility and gene expression associated with morphological divergence and behavioral specialization. Furthermore, we identify candidate genes within conserved gene networks implicated in pheromone communication, nutrient sensing, and neural development, which exhibit significant divergence under social selection. These findings illuminate the socio-genomic architecture underlying the evolution of altruistic division of labor, providing insights into the mechanisms driving the emergence and maintenance of complex sociality and the 'superorganism' phenotype.
subject: Evrim
title: Socio-genomic Architecture of Altruism and Division of Labor in Eusocial Hymenoptera

text: The late Pleistocene witnessed profound megafauna extinctions, their precise drivers—climatic shifts, anthropogenic impacts, or synergistic interactions—remaining contentious. This study utilizes whole-genome sequencing from exceptionally preserved ancient DNA of multiple extinct North American megafaunal species (e.g., *Mammuthus primigenius*, *Smilodon fatalis*) spanning the last glacial maximum and subsequent warming events. Leveraging coalescent-based demographic modeling and phylogenetic analyses, we reconstruct population dynamics, assess genetic diversity declines, and identify signatures of genomic erosion preceding extinction. Our findings reveal species-specific responses, with some lineages exhibiting protracted declines linked to climate-induced habitat fragmentation, while others show abrupt collapses coincident with human colonization. The high-resolution paleogenomic data illuminate complex, multifactorial extinction cascades, challenging monolithic explanations and underscoring the interplay of intrinsic genomic vulnerabilities, extrinsic environmental perturbations, and burgeoning human pressure in shaping Quaternary biogeography and biodiversity loss.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Insights into Pleistocene Megafauna Extinction Cascades

text: Transgenerational epigenetic inheritance (TEI) provides a potential mechanism for rapid, environmentally-responsive adaptation, yet its evolutionary significance remains debated. This study employs an experimental evolution framework in *Arabidopsis thaliana* exposed to recurrent drought stress across multiple generations to evaluate the contribution of TEI to adaptive responses. We quantify heritable changes in DNA methylation patterns (CHG and CHH contexts) via whole-genome bisulfite sequencing and assess their correlation with phenotypic plasticity and fitness proxies. Our results demonstrate that stress-induced epigenetic marks can be inherited across several generations, influencing gene expression in response to subsequent stress bouts and enhancing population resilience. While not substituting for genetic adaptation, TEI appears to modulate the phenotypic range upon which selection can act, potentially facilitating initial colonization of novel environments or buffering populations against transient environmental fluctuations, thereby expanding the organism's adaptive potential beyond purely Mendelian inheritance.
subject: Evrim
title: The Evolutionary Impact of Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance on Adaptive Potential

text: Deep-sea chemosynthetic ecosystems represent extreme environments where diverse lineages have independently evolved adaptations to exploit chemical energy sources. This study applies comparative genomics and phylogenomic analyses across multiple vent and seep endemic invertebrates (e.g., vesicomyid clams, alvinellid worms, mussels) from disparate geographic locations to identify genomic signatures of convergent evolution. We focus on gene families involved in sulfide detoxification, symbiont acquisition, and metabolic pathways central to chemosynthesis. Our analyses reveal recurrent patterns of gene family expansion, parallel amino acid substitutions in critical metabolic enzymes, and conserved non-coding regulatory elements across distantly related clades. These findings strongly implicate specific genomic mechanisms underpinning convergent adaptation to the unique physiochemical challenges of deep-sea environments, demonstrating the powerful role of natural selection in repeatedly channeling evolutionary trajectories toward similar solutions across distinct evolutionary starting points, thereby highlighting the predictability of evolution under strong selective pressures.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Convergent Evolution in Deep-Sea Chemosynthetic Ecosystems

text: Elucidating the post-duplication fates of paralogous gene families is fundamental to understanding genomic complexity. We employed a phylogenomic framework to analyze the divergent evolutionary trajectories of 12 previously uncharacterized gene families in a basal vertebrate lineage subsequent to an ancient whole-genome duplication event. Our analyses revealed pervasive subfunctionalization marked by asymmetrical rates of purifying selection on cis-regulatory elements, coupled with instances of neofunctionalization evidenced by significant positive selection acting on coding sequences. Furthermore, we detected differential expression patterns across tissue types, suggesting altered pleiotropic constraint landscapes. This study underscores the dynamic interplay between sequence evolution and regulatory divergence in shaping novel biological functions, highlighting the multifarious adaptive potential unleashed by genomic duplications.
subject: Evrim
title: Divergent Evolutionary Trajectories of Paralogous Gene Families Following Ancient Whole-Genome Duplication

text: Rapid environmental perturbations, particularly those instigated by anthropogenic climate change, necessitate swift adaptive responses. This investigation explores the intricate eco-evolutionary feedback loops underlying phenotypic plasticity and standing genetic variation in a keystone insect species facing elevated thermal stress. Utilizing quantitative genetic approaches and manipulative field experiments, we demonstrate that environmentally induced epigenetic modifications enhance the phenotypic buffering capacity, thereby modulating the strength and direction of selection gradients acting on traits associated with thermotolerance. Crucially, gene flow from peripheral populations introduces beneficial alleles that mitigate local maladaptation, illustrating a complex interplay where contemporary evolution reciprocally influences ecological dynamics, challenging traditional assumptions of evolutionary lag in rapidly changing environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Eco-Evolutionary Feedback Loops Drive Rapid Adaptive Responses to Anthropogenic Climate Shifts

text: Antagonistic coevolution, often manifesting as Red Queen dynamics, drives significant diversification in host-parasite systems. We investigated the genomic signatures of this arms race in a natural plant-pathogen interaction, focusing on resistance (R) genes in the host and virulence (Avr) genes in the pathogen. High-throughput sequencing revealed exceptionally high polymorphism and rapid allelic turnover at key R-Avr loci, consistent with strong frequency-dependent selection. Population genomic analyses identified distinct selective sweeps and balancing selection pressures, indicating ongoing molecular conflict. Furthermore, we characterized novel effector proteins in the pathogen exhibiting parallel compensatory evolution to circumvent host immune recognition, providing compelling molecular evidence for a persistent evolutionary arms race dictating community structure and disease dynamics.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Antagonistic Coevolution and Red Queen Dynamics in a Plant-Pathogen System

text: Understanding the drivers of biodiversity hotspots requires disentangling the interplay between disparity and diversification rates. We employed phylogenetic comparative methods and geometric morphometrics to assess macroevolutionary patterns in skull morphology across 350 species of Neotropical anurans. Our analyses identified pronounced shifts in both morphological disparity and lineage diversification rates congruent with key ecological innovations, specifically the evolution of arboreality and specialized fossorial lifestyles. Bayesian state-dependent models revealed a significant correlation between high rates of phenotypic evolution and accelerated speciation, suggesting an adaptive radiation paradigm driven by niche expansion. This study elucidates how transitions in developmental canalization and ecological opportunity synergistically shape the remarkable morphological and taxonomic richness observed in these biodiverse clades.
subject: Evrim
title: Macroevolutionary Disparity and Diversification Rate Shifts in Neotropical Anuran Clades

text: Sexual conflict often drives the rapid evolution of reproductive traits, yet its role in shaping male post-copulatory strategies remains underexplored. We investigated the genetic architecture of seminal fluid proteins and their impact on female reproductive physiology in a model insect system characterized by polyandry. Quantitative genetic analyses revealed strong intralocus sexual conflict for several pleiotropic loci influencing both male ejaculate quality and female fecundity, leading to antagonistic coevolutionary dynamics. Manipulative experiments demonstrated that male-derived proteins induce significant changes in female spermathecal morphology and sperm storage efficiency, mediated by specific signaling pathways. These findings illuminate a cryptic dimension of sexual conflict, where male genetic interests directly influence female reproductive investment, thereby escalating an evolutionary arms race over paternity assurance and reproductive control.
subject: Evrim
title: Interlocus Sexual Conflict and the Evolution of Male Post-Copulatory Traits

text: The paradox of conserved homologous structures arising from divergent developmental gene networks, termed developmental systems drift (DSD), challenges traditional evo-devo paradigms. We employed comparative transcriptomics and CRISPR-Cas9 mutagenesis in two phylogenetically distant vertebrate species to explore the genetic basis of limb patterning. Despite conserved anatomical outcomes, we observed substantial cis-regulatory divergence in key limb-patterning enhancers and differential expression profiles of "toolkit" genes. Perturbation experiments revealed varying degrees of developmental robustness and canalization, suggesting that while the terminal phenotype is constrained, the underlying genetic pathways exhibit significant plasticity and redundancy. This study demonstrates that DSD is a potent force facilitating evolutionary novelty by decoupling developmental mechanisms from phenotypic outcomes, thereby providing a substrate for future diversification while maintaining fundamental body plans.
subject: Evrim
title: Developmental Systems Drift and the Canalization of Vertebrate Limb Patterning

text: Understanding the genomic architecture of reproductive isolation is central to speciation research, particularly in cases of incipient sympatric divergence. We investigated two parapatric ecotypes of a cichlid fish species exhibiting marked ecological and phenotypic differences despite ongoing gene flow. Whole-genome sequencing revealed numerous "genomic islands of divergence" enriched for genes involved in sensory perception, trophic morphology, and mate choice. These regions exhibit elevated linkage disequilibrium, reduced recombination, and strong signatures of divergent selection, indicative of early-stage reproductive isolation barriers. Quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping linked these genomic regions to key prezygotic isolation traits. Our findings delineate the heterogeneous genomic landscape of speciation, emphasizing the rapid accumulation of locally adaptive alleles facilitating divergence in the face of continuous gene exchange.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Architecture of Incipient Speciation Under Strong Ecological Divergence

text: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a primary driver of rapid adaptation, particularly in the evolution of multidrug resistance (MDR) in bacterial pathogens. This study employed comparative genomics and experimental evolution to elucidate the dynamics of HGT-mediated acquisition and subsequent stabilization of antimicrobial resistance genes (ARGs) within the pan-genome of *Klebsiella pneumoniae*. We demonstrated that plasmid-mediated transfer of large accessory elements confers resistance at a fitness cost, which is rapidly offset by compensatory mutations in chromosomal loci. Population genomic analyses revealed recurrent selective sweeps for specific ARG combinations, indicating strong positive selection pressures under antibiotic challenge. Our findings highlight the profound genomic plasticity afforded by HGT, underscoring its pivotal role in the accelerated emergence and dissemination of clinical MDR phenotypes, demanding urgent evolutionary-informed therapeutic strategies.
subject: Evrim
title: Unraveling the Evolutionary Dynamics of Horizontal Gene Transfer in Multidrug-Resistant Bacterial Pathogens

text: The role of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance (TEI) in facilitating rapid adaptation to fluctuating environments is increasingly recognized. We investigated the heritability and adaptive significance of stress-induced epigenetic marks in a rodent model exposed to unpredictable prenatal nutritional restriction. Methylome-wide association studies revealed specific DNA methylation signatures and altered histone modification patterns in germline cells, which were stably inherited across three generations in the absence of continued environmental stress. Phenotypically, offspring exhibited enhanced metabolic flexibility and stress resilience, suggesting an anticipatory adaptive response. Cross-fostering experiments confirmed parent-of-origin effects and partial independence from direct environmental exposure. This study provides compelling evidence that TEI can act as a crucial mechanism for buffering environmental stochasticity and accelerating adaptive evolution by transmitting environmentally acquired phenotypic plasticity to subsequent generations.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance of Stress Responses Enhances Adaptive Potential in a Vertebrate Model

text: The demographic history of Late Pleistocene megafauna is characterized by pervasive interspecific admixture and fluctuating population sizes. We applied high-coverage ancient DNA sequencing to 25 Eurasian canid specimens, spanning 50,000 to 10,000 years before present, to reconstruct their fine-scale demographic trajectories. Coalescent-based analyses revealed recurrent episodes of archaic introgression from previously unrecognized ghost lineages into the ancestral wolf population, contributing significant functional variation. We detected multiple severe population bottlenecks coinciding with major climatic oscillations, resulting in pronounced reductions in effective population size and gene diversity. Furthermore, spatially explicit genomic modeling identified distinct dispersal corridors and evidence for adaptive introgression of loci associated with dietary plasticity. This paleogenomic study provides unprecedented resolution into the intricate evolutionary history of a widespread mammalian lineage, underscoring the dynamic interplay of gene flow, demography, and selection in shaping modern biodiversity.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Reconstruction of Complex Admixture and Demographic Bottlenecks in Late Pleistocene Canids

text: This paper addresses the challenging problem of estimating sparse precision matrices in high-dimensional settings under potential heteroscedasticity and non-Gaussian errors. Standard penalized estimators, such as the graphical Lasso, often assume homoscedasticity and sub-Gaussianity, leading to biased and inconsistent inference when these assumptions are violated. We propose a novel robust penalized estimator, which leverages a rank-based measure of dependence combined with a modified `l_1` regularization on the entries of the precision matrix. Our theoretical analysis establishes rates of convergence for spectral norm consistency and entry-wise recovery under weaker moment conditions, demonstrating its robustness. Furthermore, we derive the asymptotic distribution of a debiased version, enabling valid hypothesis testing for individual edges. Extensive simulations corroborate the superior performance of our method compared to existing approaches in misspecified regimes, highlighting its practical utility in complex data analysis.
subject: İstatistik
title: Robust Inference for Sparse Precision Matrices in High-Dimensional Heteroscedastic Regimes

text: We investigate the challenging problem of non-parametric causal effect estimation in settings where the stable unit treatment value assumption (SUTVA) is violated due to network interference. Traditional methods struggle to disentangle direct and indirect treatment effects when units' outcomes depend on their neighbors' treatments. We propose a novel framework that extends generalized propensity score matching to account for complex interference patterns observed on an underlying social or proximity network. By defining potential outcomes over configurations of ego-network treatments, we construct balancing scores derived from a graph convolutional kernel. This allows for robust estimation of various estimands, including total, direct, and spillover effects, without relying on parametric assumptions about the interference mechanism. Theoretical results establish the consistency and asymptotic normality of our estimators under a verifiable partial interference assumption and sufficient overlap conditions on the network structure.
subject: İstatistik
title: Non-Parametric Causal Effects Estimation under Network Interference via Generalized Propensity Score Matching

text: This paper introduces a novel Bayesian non-parametric framework for modeling high-dimensional time series data by dynamically inferring latent space embeddings. Current methods often rely on fixed-dimensional representations or struggle with capturing evolving dependencies and an unknown number of underlying factors. Our approach leverages a sticky hierarchical Dirichlet process prior on the latent states, enabling adaptive determination of the optimal dimensionality and number of clusters or regimes over time. Within each regime, a factor analysis model with a Gaussian process prior on the factor loadings captures smooth dynamics. Inference is performed via an efficient collapsed Gibbs sampler augmented with particle filtering steps to handle the sequential nature of the data. We demonstrate the model's ability to automatically detect changepoints, uncover evolving latent structures, and provide superior forecasting performance compared to state-of-the-art parametric and non-parametric benchmarks on synthetic and real-world neuroimaging data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Non-Parametric Modeling of Dynamic Latent Space Embeddings for High-Dimensional Time Series

text: We propose an adaptive localized functional principal component analysis (ALFPCA) method tailored for high-dimensional spatio-temporal data observed on irregular domains or manifolds. Traditional FPCA assumes a global basis representation, which can fail to capture heterogeneity and localized features inherent in complex spatial processes.
