Our approach employs a novel adaptive kernel-based localization scheme that automatically determines the optimal spatial bandwidths for basis construction, allowing the principal components to vary across the domain. This method leverages concepts from manifold learning to define intrinsic distances on irregular observation grids. We establish the theoretical consistency of the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions under mild regularity conditions and derive minimax rates of convergence for the estimated functional scores. Empirical evaluations on simulated and climatological datasets demonstrate ALFPCA's superior ability to extract meaningful, locally-varying modes of variation, offering enhanced interpretability and predictive accuracy over global methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Localized Functional Principal Component Analysis for Spatio-Temporal Data on Irregular Domains

text: This paper addresses robust estimation in high-dimensional linear models where a significant fraction of observations can be arbitrarily corrupted (adversarial contamination). While `l_1`-penalized estimators are popular for sparsity, they are highly susceptible to even a small number of outliers. We introduce a novel family of median-of-means (MOM) type estimators for the regression coefficients, specifically designed for high-dimensional settings with potential adversarial noise. Our method partitions the data into blocks, computes an initial `l_1`-penalized estimator on each block, and then combines these estimates using a generalized median operator. We prove that our estimator achieves optimal statistical rates under heavy-tailed errors and maintains near-minimax performance even when up to a constant fraction of data points are adversarially corrupted. Furthermore, we provide computational strategies for implementing this estimator efficiently in high dimensions. Simulations confirm the remarkable robustness and accuracy of our proposed method compared to existing robust high-dimensional techniques.
subject: İstatistik
title: Median-of-Means Type Estimators for High-Dimensional Linear Models with Adversarial Contamination

text: This work develops novel methodology for differentially private inference in generalized linear models (GLMs), aiming for optimal asymptotic statistical efficiency while satisfying stringent privacy guarantees. Existing differentially private GLM estimators often achieve sub-optimal statistical rates or provide weak inference capabilities. We propose a perturbation-based approach that applies carefully calibrated noise to the sufficient statistics, coupled with a robust debiasing procedure. This allows us to construct private estimators that are asymptotically Gaussian and attain the semi-parametric efficiency bound under specified privacy budgets, thereby achieving optimal statistical convergence rates for a given privacy level. We provide rigorous theoretical analyses for both empirical risk minimization and score function perturbation strategies, establishing conditions for consistency and asymptotic normality. The practical utility of our method is demonstrated through simulations and applications to sensitive health datasets, illustrating valid private confidence intervals and hypothesis tests.
subject: İstatistik
title: Differentially Private Inference for Generalised Linear Models with Optimal Asymptotic Guarantees

text: We introduce a novel online change-point detection methodology for high-dimensional multivariate and functional data streams, robust to unknown marginal distributions and nuisance parameters. Existing methods often suffer from sensitivity to scaling or require tedious parameter tuning. Our approach leverages self-normalised cumulative sum (CUSUM) statistics constructed from dimension-reduced projections or functional principal components, which are intrinsically scale-invariant and distribution-free under the null. By employing a sequential kernel-based approximation for the underlying data generating process, we develop a computationally efficient algorithm capable of detecting changes in mean, variance, or correlation structure without prior knowledge of the post-change parameters. Theoretical guarantees include control of the false alarm rate and detection delay under various data generating processes. Extensive simulation studies and an application to real-time industrial process monitoring demonstrate superior performance in terms of robustness, speed, and accuracy compared to established online detection schemes.
subject: İstatistik
title: Multivariate Online Change-Point Detection via Self-Normalised CUSUM Statistics on Functional Data

text: This paper investigates the theoretical properties of Kernel Ridge Regression (KRR) in challenging scenarios involving adversarial noise and potential kernel misspecification. While KRR is a powerful non-parametric technique, its robustness and optimality guarantees under severe data corruption or model misspecification remain under-explored. We establish minimax optimal rates of convergence for KRR estimators when a fraction of responses are corrupted by arbitrary adversarial noise, extending classical results to settings with heavy-tailed and non-Gaussian errors. Furthermore, we analyze the impact of using a misspecified kernel, quantifying the degradation in performance and providing conditions under which KRR can still achieve near-optimal rates, particularly for low-dimensional features embedded in a high-dimensional RKHS. Our analysis rigorously derives novel generalization bounds leveraging localized Rademacher complexities and provides insights into optimal regularization strategies. These findings contribute to a deeper understanding of KRR's robustness and applicability in complex, real-world data environments.
subject: İstatistik
title: Minimax Optimal Rates for Kernel Ridge Regression with Adversarial Noise and Misspecified Kernels

text: This work addresses the critical challenge of modeling and estimating high-dimensional multivariate extreme value (MEV) copulas, particularly when the underlying tail dependence structure exhibits sparsity or conditional independence. Traditional MEV models become intractable in high dimensions due to the curse of dimensionality. We propose a novel regularized estimation framework that combines concepts from MEV theory with graphical modeling. By leveraging a sparse graph representation of tail dependencies, we construct a penalized composite likelihood estimator for MEV copula parameters. This approach encourages sparsity in the graphical model of extremal dependence, enabling consistent and efficient estimation even when the number of variables far exceeds the sample size. We establish theoretical guarantees for our estimator, including consistency and convergence rates under mild regularity conditions. Extensive simulations and an application to financial market data demonstrate the superior performance of our method in capturing complex tail dependence structures and providing more accurate risk assessments compared to existing non-sparse MEV approaches.
subject: İstatistik
title: Regularised Estimation of High-Dimensional Multivariate Extreme Value Copulas with Graph-Structured Dependence

text: We propose a novel semi-parametric Bayesian framework for dynamic stochastic block models (SBMs) that explicitly incorporates time-varying nodal and dyadic covariates. While SBMs are powerful for uncovering community structures, their extension to evolving networks with heterogeneous node attributes remains challenging. Our model employs a state-space formulation where the community assignments evolve according to a Markov jump process, and the block-specific edge probabilities are linked to covariates through a non-linear link function with a Dirichlet process prior on the regression coefficients. This allows for both discrete changes in community structure and continuous evolution of covariate effects. We develop an efficient MCMC algorithm combining block-Gibbs sampling with a tailored particle filter for handling the latent community dynamics. Theoretical results establish the consistency of community detection and parameter estimation under suitable conditions. We demonstrate the model's capacity for uncovering latent structural evolution and providing robust inference on real-world longitudinal network data, outperforming static and simpler dynamic SBMs.
subject: İstatistik
title: Semi-Parametric Bayesian Inference for Dynamic Stochastic Block Models with Time-Varying Covariates

text: This paper investigates the growth rate of the off-diagonal Ramsey number R(K_s, G), where K_s is a complete graph on s vertices and G is a sparse graph. We employ an advanced probabilistic method, combining the powerful Lovász Local Lemma with refined discrepancy theory techniques, to establish new lower bounds for R(K_s, G) when G belongs to certain families of graphs with bounded maximum degree or arboricity. Specifically, we construct explicit probability spaces on appropriately structured random graphs, demonstrating the existence of K_s-free graphs that do not contain G as a subgraph, even when G is relatively large. Our approach overcomes limitations of classical random graph models, particularly for cases where G exhibits complex local structures. The results offer significant improvements over existing bounds, shedding light on the intricate interplay between local sparsity and global Ramsey properties, and provide new insights into the asymptotic behavior of these critical combinatorial invariants.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Lower Bounds for the Ramsey Number R(K_s, G) for Sparse Graphs G via Novel Probabilistic Constructions

text: We delve into the combinatorial and geometric properties of Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials for affine Weyl groups, extending classical results for finite Weyl groups. Our primary focus is on establishing a precise connection between these polynomials and the intersection cohomology of Schubert varieties in the affine flag variety. Utilizing geometric representation theory, particularly the theory of perverse sheaves and D-modules, we provide a new structural decomposition of these polynomials, revealing intricate cancellation phenomena. The analysis leverages a sophisticated interplay between the Bruhat order on the affine Weyl group and the stratification of the affine flag manifold. Furthermore, we explore applications to the character formulas for irreducible representations of Lie algebras and investigate generalizations to modified Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials arising in quantum group theory. This work offers fundamental contributions to the understanding of singular varieties and their invariants in algebraic geometry and representation theory.
subject: Matematik
title: Kazhdan-Lusztig Polynomials for Affine Weyl Groups and the Geometry of Flag Varieties

text: This paper presents novel combinatorial interpretations for the coefficients of q-deformed Macdonald polynomials, Pλ(x; q, t), expanding upon the classical results for Schur and Hall-Littlewood polynomials. We introduce a new class of marked skew tableaux, equipped with specific weight functions involving both q and t parameters, and prove that their generating functions enumerate the expansion coefficients of Pλ in various symmetric function bases. Our construction meticulously aligns with the underlying Hecke algebra structure and provides a unified framework for understanding the plethystic identities in the ring of symmetric functions. We establish bijections between these marked tableaux and certain path models on the Young lattice, thereby furnishing a diagrammatic representation of the Macdonald polynomial identities. These new interpretations offer significant advancements in enumerative combinatorics and provide computational tools for characters of infinite-dimensional Lie algebras and quantum groups.
subject: Matematik
title: Combinatorial Interpretations of q-Deformed Macdonald Polynomials through Marked Skew Tableaux

text: This research investigates the combinatorial structure of centrally symmetric convex polytopes, focusing on the characterization of their f-vectors. We extend McMullen's g-theorem by establishing novel inequalities for the g-vector of centrally symmetric polytopes, leveraging results from face lattices and K-shellability of polytopal complexes. Our methodology combines techniques from convex geometry, algebraic topology, and poset theory, providing a refined understanding of the relationship between the number of faces of different dimensions. Furthermore, we explore the implications of these f-vector characterizations for high-dimensional Helly-type theorems. By constructing specific families of centrally symmetric sets, we derive new lower bounds on the Helly number for intersections of such sets, particularly under symmetry constraints. This work advances the understanding of the topological and combinatorial invariants of polytopes and their applications in discrete and computational geometry.
subject: Matematik
title: The f-Vector of Centrally Symmetric Polytopes and High-Dimensional Helly-Type Theorems

text: We analyze phase transitions in the configuration model for random k-uniform hypergraphs with prescribed degree sequences, extending classical results for graphs. Employing a sophisticated large deviation principle, we characterize the asymptotic behavior of various structural properties, including the size of the giant component and the existence of perfect matchings, as the number of vertices tends to infinity. Our approach involves deriving a rate function by optimizing over empirical distributions of component structures, leveraging techniques from statistical physics and information theory. We identify critical thresholds for degree sequences above which significant topological changes occur, showing distinct universality classes compared to simpler random graph models. This work provides a rigorous framework for understanding self-organization in complex networks, offering new insights into the robustness and connectivity of systems modeled by high-order interactions. The results have implications for diverse fields ranging from computational biology to social network analysis.
subject: Matematik
title: Phase Transitions in Random Hypergraphs with Fixed Degree Sequences: A Large Deviation Approach

text: This paper establishes new sharp bounds for the sum-product problem in finite fields F_p, focusing on the cardinality of sum and product sets derived from arbitrary subsets A ⊆ F_p. We employ a novel spectral graph theoretic approach, constructing an explicit family of Cayley graphs whose eigenvalues provide critical information about the expansion properties of sets under addition and multiplication. By analyzing the spectral gap of these graphs, particularly their second largest eigenvalue, we demonstrate improved lower bounds for |A+A| + |A·A|, surpassing previous results obtained through incidence geometry and Fourier analysis alone. The method leverages robust estimates for character sums over F_p and introduces a tensor product construction for expanding graphs. This work contributes significantly to additive combinatorics, offering a powerful unified framework for addressing problems concerning the interplay of additive and multiplicative structures in finite fields, with potential applications to pseudorandomness and explicit constructions.
subject: Matematik
title: Sharp Bounds for Sum-Product Estimates in Finite Fields via Spectral Graph Theory

text: We investigate the combinatorial properties of ultrafilters on ω under various forcing extensions, focusing on the existence of novel regularity properties beyond P-points and Q-points. Our primary contribution involves constructing specific forcing notions, derived from finite support iterations of certain matrix algebras, that add ultrafilters exhibiting prescribed combinatorial behavior with respect to partitions and covers of ω. We demonstrate that it is consistent with ZFC that there exist ultrafilters that are neither P-points nor Q-points, yet satisfy a strong form of genericity for a definable class of partial orders. The analysis heavily relies on intricate product forcing arguments and careful bookkeeping of properties preserved under generic extensions. This work advances the understanding of the zoo of ultrafilters, bridging gaps in the classification program and offering new tools for investigating the structural complexity of the Stone-Čech compactification of the natural numbers.
subject: Matematik
title: Forcing New Regularity Properties on Ultrafilters: A Combinatorial Perspective

text: This paper explores the relationship between graph immersions, linkages, and structural decompositions in the context of graph minor theory. We present a generalization of Wagner's theorem for k-immersions, characterizing graphs that do not contain a fixed graph H as a k-immersion minor. Our approach involves developing a finer notion of tree-width adapted to immersions and establishing a tight connection to the existence of k-linked subgraphs. Building upon the seminal work of Robertson and Seymour, we prove that for every fixed graph H, the class of graphs not containing H as a k-immersion minor is well-quasi-ordered by the k-immersion relation. The proof leverages intricate graph decomposition theorems and extends techniques from the theory of graph minors to the richer setting of immersions. This work provides fundamental insights into the structural complexity of graphs under different notions of containment and has implications for the algorithmic theory of graph problems.
subject: Matematik
title: Immersions and Linkages in Graph Minor Theory: A Generalization of Wagner's Theorem

text: This research delves into the structural characterization of graphic matroids and their extensions to the broader class of polymatroids, focusing on properties amenable to decomposition theory. We establish new minor-closed characterizations for specific families of graphic matroids, leveraging a detailed analysis of their excluded minors and identifying novel obstructions arising from non-planar configurations. Our methodology combines matroid connectivity arguments with insights from topological graph theory, providing a more refined understanding of the interplay between graphical representations and matroid properties. Furthermore, we explore generalizations to polymatroids, introducing a new class of "graphic-like" polymatroids that retain key decomposition features, such as tree-decompositions. This work contributes to the foundational theory of matroids and polymatroids, offering new tools for recognizing these structures and advancing their application in network theory, combinatorial optimization, and submodular function minimization.
subject: Matematik
title: Structural Characterizations of Graphic Matroids and Their Generalizations to Polymatroids

text: We investigate the Ehrhart polynomials of reflexive polytopes and establish novel combinatorial interpretations for their coefficients, particularly in relation to the h*-vector and its role in mirror symmetry. Our analysis provides an explicit formulation for the generating function of lattice points in dilations of reflexive polytopes, revealing deep connections to the underlying fan structure and its dual. By leveraging techniques from toric geometry and algebraic combinatorics, we demonstrate that the h*-polynomial of a reflexive polytope is intrinsically linked to the combinatorial properties of its associated Fano variety. Furthermore, we explore how these Ehrhart-theoretic invariants relate to the Hodge numbers and other topological data of Calabi-Yau manifolds arising from mirror symmetry in string theory. This work offers a powerful framework for interdisciplinary research at the intersection of enumerative combinatorics, algebraic geometry, and theoretical physics.
subject: Matematik
title: Ehrhart Polynomials of Reflexive Polytopes and Their Connections to Mirror Symmetry

text: This paper introduces a novel deep learning framework for performing automated Schenkerian analysis directly from raw audio signals, bypassing the need for symbolic score pre-processing. Traditional computational approaches to identifying the Ursatz and its prolongations have been confined to the symbolic domain, creating a gap between theoretical modeling and acoustic reality. We propose a Hierarchical Convolutional-Recurrent Neural Network (HCRNN) that first learns low-level spectral features via a CNN front-end, followed by a multi-layered LSTM architecture designed to model temporal dependencies at different structural levels. The model is trained on a synthetic dataset of rendered score excerpts annotated with ground-truth Schenkerian graphs. Our results demonstrate the model's capacity to successfully identify fundamental lines (Urlinie) and bass arpeggiations (Bassbrechung) with significant accuracy in moderately complex tonal works. This research represents a critical step towards integrating high-level music-theoretic concepts with audio-based music information retrieval, enabling new methodologies for computational musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hierarchical Convolutional-Recurrent Model for Schenkerian Analysis from Polyphonic Audio

text: The analysis of electroacoustic music, particularly acousmatic works, presents challenges for traditional music theory due to its focus on timbre and texture over discrete pitch and rhythm. This study proposes a methodology for the unsupervised decomposition of complex soundscapes using Convex Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (CNMF). Unlike standard NMF, CNMF constrains the resulting bases to be convex combinations of the input data points, yielding archetypal spectral templates that are directly interpretable as representative sound events within the piece. By applying this technique to a spectrogram representation of canonical acousmatic compositions, we extract a dictionary of timbral components corresponding to established spectromorphological categories (e.g., granular textures, attack-decay gestures). The temporal activations of these components provide a high-level structural overview of the work's timbral narrative. This method offers a robust, data-driven approach for quantitative timbral analysis, furnishing a new empirical tool for composers and musicologists studying texture-based music.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectromorphological Decomposition of Electroacoustic Music via Convex Non-Negative Matrix Factorization

text: Late-Romantic harmony is characterized by pervasive ambiguity, challenging conventional chord-labeling and functional analysis systems. This paper presents a probabilistic model to quantify such ambiguity. We employ a Dynamic Bayesian Network (DBN) for harmonic analysis that infers a sequence of latent harmonic states from observed acoustic chroma features. Crucially, the model's transition probabilities are not uniform but are informed by music-theoretic priors, including voice-leading parsimony derived from neo-Riemannian theory and chord progression statistics from a curated corpus of tonal music. The output is not a single chord label but a posterior probability distribution over all possible chords at each time step. We define a novel 'harmonic entropy' metric based on this distribution to quantify moment-to-moment ambiguity. When applied to works by Wagner and Scriabin, our metric correlates strongly with passages identified as functionally obscure in scholarly literature, providing an empirical validation of theoretical claims and a powerful new analytical tool.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Harmonic Ambiguity in Late-Romantic Corpora using Dynamic Bayesian Networks with Tonal Priors

text: Measuring melodic similarity in polyphonic music is confounded by textural density and voice-crossing. This research introduces a novel graph-theoretic approach that transcends simple monophonic contour algorithms. We model a polyphonic musical excerpt as a directed acyclic graph where notes are vertices and plausible melodic connections, determined by temporal proximity and pitch interval constraints, are weighted edges. The problem of identifying and comparing primary melodic lines is reframed as a community detection task. By analyzing the Laplacian matrix of the graph, we use spectral clustering to partition the note-vertices into distinct melodic streams. Melodic similarity between two musical excerpts is then calculated using graph edit distance on their corresponding primary stream subgraphs. This method demonstrates superior robustness to ornamentation, transposition, and textural variation compared to extant symbolic pattern-matching algorithms, significantly improving performance in tasks such as motif discovery and query-by-humming in complex contrapuntal repertoires.
subject: Müzik
title: A Graph-Theoretic Framework for Polyphonic Melodic Contour Similarity using Spectral Clustering

text: Bridging the semantic gap between symbolic music notation and audio recordings is a central challenge in music information retrieval (MIR). We propose a cross-modal retrieval system based on disentangled representation learning using a variational autoencoder (VAE) with a shared latent space. Our model, a β-VAE with a carefully structured inference network, is trained jointly on aligned pairs of MusicXML scores and audio recordings. By manipulating the objective function, the model learns to disentangle latent factors corresponding to core musical concepts (pitch, rhythm) from performance-specific variations (dynamics, articulation, timbre). This allows for robust retrieval across modalities; one can query a database of audio recordings using a symbolic snippet, or vice-versa. Empirical evaluation on the MazurkaBL dataset shows our approach significantly outperforms systems based on coupled feature spaces or unimodal deep embeddings, enabling more nuanced and musically aware search capabilities for digital music libraries and performance analysis tools.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangled Representation Learning for Cross-Modal Retrieval of Musical Scores and Audio Performances

text: The perception of consonance and dissonance in microtonal and xenharmonic music cannot be fully explained by traditional harmonicity-based models. This paper presents a generalized computational model of sensory dissonance applicable to arbitrary tuning systems. Our model extends the Plomp-Levelt psychoacoustic framework by calculating dissonance as the integrated roughness arising from spectral partial interactions, but without assuming a harmonic overtone series. It computes a dissonance curve for any given interval within a specific instrumental timbre, modeled via its spectral signature. We validate the model against perceptual data from listening experiments conducted with stimuli generated in various tunings, including 19-TET, 31-TET, and the Bohlen-Pierce scale. The model's predictions show high correlation (r > 0.85) with listener ratings of consonance/dissonance, providing a powerful predictive tool for composers working with non-standard tunings and a quantitative foundation for developing a psychoacoustically grounded theory of microtonal harmony.
subject: Müzik
title: A Computational Psychoacoustic Model of Consonance in Xenharmonic Tuning Systems based on Spectral Dissonance

text: Generative models for music often struggle to produce polyphony that adheres to the complex stylistic rules of voice-leading and counterpoint. We introduce a novel architecture for generating four-part chorales in the style of J.S. Bach using a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) framework. The generator is a Transformer-based sequence model conditioned on a figured bass line, enabling harmonic control. The discriminator is a multi-scale network that evaluates both local note combinations and long-range melodic coherence. Critically, we incorporate a differentiable music-theoretic loss function that penalizes common contrapuntal errors, such as parallel octaves and improper dissonance treatment. This hybrid approach, combining adversarial learning with explicit domain knowledge, produces harmonizations that are not only statistically similar to the training corpus but are also rated as significantly more musically plausible and stylistically correct by expert listeners than those produced by unconstrained recurrent or transformer-based models.
subject: Müzik
title: Style-Specific Polyphonic Synthesis via Adversarially Trained Transformer Networks with Music-Theoretic Constraints

text: Concatenative synthesis, or audio mosaicing, offers a powerful paradigm for sound design by rearranging micro-segments from a source audio corpus to match a target. However, achieving seamless, real-time performance remains challenging. This paper details a system that utilizes a pre-computed k-d tree for efficient nearest-neighbor search within a high-dimensional audio feature space (MFCCs, spectral flux, chroma). The core innovation is a dynamic feature-weighting mechanism that allows the perceptual basis of segment similarity to be modulated in real time. By shifting the weights between timbral, rhythmic, and harmonic features, the user can fluidly navigate the sonic potential of the corpus, transforming a rhythmic target into a textural drone or morphing one instrument's timbre into another's. The system achieves low latency (<30ms) and high-quality audio output, demonstrating its viability as an expressive instrument for live electronic performance and interactive sound installation.
subject: Müzik
title: Real-Time Audio Mosaicing through Perceptually-Weighted Concatenative Synthesis

text: Automated discovery of musical form is a fundamental task in computational musicology. This paper presents an unsupervised method for identifying large-scale formal sections (e.g., exposition, development, recapitulation) from audio. The approach begins by computing a self-similarity matrix (SSM) from time-series of chromagram features, revealing the work's repetition structure. We then introduce a novel factorization algorithm, Temporally-Constrained Archetypal Analysis, which decomposes the SSM into a set of basis vectors representing archetypal structural segments and their corresponding temporal activations. The temporal constraints ensure that the resulting segments are contiguous and non-overlapping. When applied to a corpus of classical sonata-form movements, the algorithm successfully identifies sections that align closely with expert manual annotations. This technique bypasses the need for labeled training data, offering a scalable solution for exploring formal structures in vast, unannotated digital music archives and revealing latent patterns in complex compositions.
subject: Müzik
title: Unsupervised Discovery of Musical Form via Factorization of Temporally-Constrained Self-Similarity Matrices

text: The realization of a figured bass line into a full polyphonic texture is a core pedagogical exercise in tonal music theory, requiring adherence to complex contrapuntal and harmonic rules. This paper formulates this task as a constrained optimization problem solved via Integer Linear Programming (ILP). Given a bass line and figures, we define a set of decision variables representing all possible pitches for the upper voices at each time step. The objective function is designed to maximize voice-leading parsimony by minimizing the sum of melodic intervals across all voices, thereby promoting smooth, conjunct motion. Stylistic and grammatical rules, such as the avoidance of parallel perfect intervals, correct dissonance resolution, and respecting voice ranges, are encoded as a system of linear inequality constraints. The ILP solver efficiently finds the optimal, rule-compliant realization. This deterministic, knowledge-based approach provides a powerful pedagogical tool and a robust baseline for evaluating statistical generative models.
subject: Müzik
title: A Parsimonious Voice-Leading Model for Automated Figured Bass Realization using Integer Linear Programming

text: We present a comprehensive theoretical framework for the emergence and manipulation of non-Abelian anyons in a two-dimensional chiral p-wave superconductor, a candidate system for topological quantum computation. By solving the Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations for a vortex core, we demonstrate the existence of zero-energy Majorana bound states. The Hilbert space of N vortices is shown to be 2^(N/2)-dimensional, constituting a topologically protected qubit subspace. We numerically simulate the adiabatic braiding of these vortices and explicitly compute the non-commuting unitary rotation matrices, confirming they form a representation of the braid group B_N. Our analysis quantifies the fidelity of these topological gates against quasi-particle poisoning and non-adiabatic effects, establishing a parameter regime for fault-tolerant operation. This work provides a concrete blueprint for realizing topologically protected quantum information processing by leveraging the intrinsic non-local properties of Majorana fermions in condensed matter systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Anyons and Braiding Statistics in a Chiral p-wave Superconductor

text: This study investigates the dynamics of entanglement entropy in a one-dimensional disordered Heisenberg spin chain, a prototypical system exhibiting many-body localization (MBL). Through extensive numerical simulations using time-evolving block decimation (TEBD), we analyze the growth of bipartite entanglement entropy following a global quantum quench. In the MBL phase, we observe a slow, logarithmic growth of entanglement, in stark contrast to the linear growth characteristic of thermalizing systems. Crucially, our results demonstrate that the long-time stationary state exhibits a volume-law scaling for entanglement entropy, a definitive violation of the area law typical for ground states of gapped local Hamiltonians. This logarithmic propagation of quantum correlations provides a fundamental phenomenological signature of MBL, indicating the preservation of local quantum information over extended timescales and highlighting the profound impact of disorder on quantum thermalization and ergodicity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Violation of the Area Law for Entanglement Entropy in a Many-Body Localized System

text: We extend the framework of stochastic quantum thermodynamics to systems where initial quantum coherence is a controllable parameter. By deriving a generalized Jarzynski equality for a quantum system coupled to a thermal bath, we demonstrate that the work extraction statistics are fundamentally altered by the presence of coherence in the initial energy eigenbasis. Our formalism reveals that coherence can be considered a thermodynamic resource, enabling work extraction beyond the limits imposed by the second law for classical or incoherent systems. We explicitly show that the irreversible work is directly related to the consumption of this coherence, quantified by the relative entropy of coherence. The findings are contextualized with a proposed experimental realization using a trapped ion system, where coherence can be precisely prepared and its contribution to the work distribution directly measured, thus elucidating the intricate interplay between quantum information and thermodynamics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Fluctuation Theorems and Coherence as a Thermodynamic Resource

text: This work posits a fundamental connection between holographic duality (AdS/CFT) and quantum error correction. We model the bulk anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime as an emergent property of an underlying quantum error-correcting code defined on the conformal field theory (CFT) boundary. It is demonstrated that the entanglement structure of the code subspace precisely reproduces the Ryu-Takayanagi formula, where the entanglement entropy of a boundary region is proportional to the area of a minimal surface in the bulk. This holographic code provides a concrete mechanism for bulk locality and protects logical bulk operators from local boundary erasures. We further show that the radial dimension in AdS corresponds to the energy scale of the CFT, with the code's structure naturally encoding the renormalization group flow. This framework provides a novel perspective on quantum gravity, suggesting spacetime itself is a geometric manifestation of optimal quantum information encoding.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement and Spacetime Emergence from a Quantum Error-Correcting Code

text: We report the experimental demonstration of phase estimation surpassing the standard quantum limit (SQL) using an SU(1,1) interferometer. Unlike conventional interferometers based on passive beam splitters, our device utilizes active nonlinear elements—specifically, four-wave mixing in a hot rubidium vapor cell—for state preparation and detection. This process generates highly correlated twin beams of light, whose quantum noise correlations enable a phase sensitivity scaling as 1/N, where N is the mean number of photons, thus achieving the Heisenberg limit. Our experimental results show a 5.8 dB improvement in signal-to-noise ratio over the SQL for an equivalent photon flux. We analyze the system's robustness to photon loss and decoherence, identifying the critical parameters for practical quantum-enhanced metrology. This work establishes SU(1,1) interferometry as a powerful platform for applications requiring ultra-high precision, from gravitational wave detection to biological sensing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Surpassing the Standard Quantum Limit with SU(1,1) Interferometry

text: We investigate the dynamics of quantum information scrambling in a chaotic spin system using the out-of-time-order correlator (OTOC). By implementing a protocol on a trapped-ion quantum simulator, we directly measure the OTOC, C(t) = ⟨W†(t)V†(0)W(t)V(0)⟩, for local Pauli operators W and V. In the chaotic regime, we observe an exponential growth of the OTOC at early times, C(t) ≈ 1 - ε exp(λ_L t), from which we extract the quantum Lyapunov exponent λ_L. Our results show a clear correlation between λ_L and the system's proximity to an integrable point, establishing the OTOC as a reliable experimental diagnostic for quantum chaos. Furthermore, the spatiotemporal propagation of correlations is shown to define a 'light cone' for information, consistent with the Lieb-Robinson bounds. This work provides direct experimental insight into the mechanisms of quantum thermalization and the holographic duality between chaotic systems and black holes.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Quantum Chaos and Information Scrambling with Out-of-Time-Order Correlators

text: This paper presents a theoretical and experimental investigation of decoherence suppression using the quantum Zeno effect. We model a qubit system subjected to environmental phase noise and apply a sequence of strong, frequent projective measurements in a basis different from the system's eigenbasis. Our theoretical analysis, based on a filter-function formalism, demonstrates that the measurement sequence effectively modifies the spectral density of the environmental noise as perceived by the qubit, leading to a quadratic suppression of decoherence. We experimentally validate this prediction using a superconducting transmon qubit, applying a series of rapid microwave pulses to enact the projective measurements. The measured coherence decay rate scales inversely with the measurement frequency, confirming the Zeno-like suppression. This technique offers a hardware-efficient method for dynamical decoupling and quantum error prevention, distinct from conventional spin-echo protocols, with broad applicability in quantum computing and sensing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Dynamical Control and Suppression of Decoherence via the Quantum Zeno Effect

text: We report the first digital quantum simulation of a U(1) lattice gauge theory coupled to matter, realized on a programmable superconducting quantum processor. The Hamiltonian dynamics are discretized using a Trotter-Suzuki decomposition, and the resulting quantum circuit is implemented to study real-time phenomena inaccessible to classical computation, such as string breaking and particle-antiparticle pair production from the vacuum. Gauge invariance is maintained throughout the evolution by formulating the dynamics in a constrained Hilbert space. We measure the local particle number and electric field flux, observing the propagation of excitations and verifying the conservation of Gauss's law to high fidelity. This work constitutes a critical step toward simulating more complex gauge theories like Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), opening avenues for exploring fundamental particle physics, quark confinement, and the phases of nuclear matter using nascent quantum computers.
subject: Kuantum
title: Digital Quantum Simulation of a U(1) Lattice Gauge Theory on a Superconducting Processor

text: We analyze the effects of uniform acceleration on bipartite quantum entanglement from the perspective of relativistic quantum information theory. By considering a maximally entangled state of two Unruh-DeWitt detectors, one held by an inertial observer (Alice) and the other by a uniformly accelerated observer (Rob), we quantify the degradation of entanglement as a function of Rob's proper acceleration. We show that from Alice's perspective, the entanglement is degraded because Rob's detector traces over a portion of the quantum field causally disconnected from him, an effect known as the Unruh effect. We compute the logarithmic negativity and concurrence for both scalar and fermionic field entanglement, revealing that the state becomes disentangled at a finite acceleration. This phenomenon demonstrates the frame-dependent nature of entanglement and highlights the fundamental interplay between quantum information theory, general relativity, and quantum field theory in curved spacetime.
subject: Kuantum
title: Relativistic Quantum Information: Entanglement Degradation in a Non-inertial Frame

text: We perform a large-scale numerical analysis of a semiconductor nanowire with strong spin-orbit coupling, proximity-coupled to an s-wave superconductor and subjected to an external magnetic field. Using the density-matrix renormalization group (DMRG) algorithm, which fully incorporates many-body electron-electron interactions, we go beyond standard mean-field treatments to compute the system's phase diagram. Our results confirm the existence of a topological phase hosting Majorana zero modes at the wire ends, but reveal significant quantitative corrections to the mean-field phase boundaries due to correlation effects. We compute the local density of states and the non-local correlation functions, providing unambiguous signatures of the Majorana modes. The interaction-induced reduction of the topological gap is quantified, posing stricter constraints on experimental parameters for realizing robust Majorana qubits. This work provides a rigorous many-body benchmark for predicting and interpreting experiments in the search for non-Abelian quasiparticles.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Superconductivity in Proximity-Coupled Semiconductor Nanowires: A Many-Body Analysis

text: This study employs Topological Data Analysis (TDA) to investigate the geometric structure of harmonic progressions in large musical corpora. We represent chords as points in a multi-dimensional pitch-class space and analyze the resulting point-cloud data using persistent homology. By tracking the birth and death of topological features (e.g., connected components, loops) across varying scales, we generate persistence diagrams that serve as unique fingerprints for different harmonic languages. Our analysis contrasts the topological signatures of Bach chorales with those of late-Romantic works by Wagner and Scriabin. The results demonstrate that the Betti numbers derived from these diagrams quantitatively capture the transition from a highly structured, cyclic diatonic space to a more densely connected, torus-like chromatic space. This TDA framework offers a novel, scale-invariant method for music-theoretical analysis, moving beyond traditional graph-based models to reveal deeper structural invariants in tonal harmony and its dissolution.
subject: Müzik
title: Persistent Homology and the Geometric Structure of Diatonic and Chromatic Harmonic Spaces

text: This paper introduces a novel framework for algorithmic composition that leverages quantum annealing to solve complex voice-leading and contrapuntal problems. We formalize the rules of species counterpoint as a set of constraints that are mapped onto a Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) problem. Variables in the QUBO formulation represent potential pitch choices at discrete time steps, and penalty terms enforce rules regarding melodic contour, harmonic consonance, and the avoidance of parallel motion. By submitting this QUBO model to a quantum annealing processor, we efficiently explore the vast solution space to find low-energy states corresponding to musically valid compositions. Comparative analysis with classical constraint satisfaction solvers demonstrates the quantum approach's efficacy in handling highly constrained, large-scale compositional tasks. This research establishes a pioneering link between computational music theory and emerging quantum computing paradigms, opening new avenues for generative music systems based on physical optimization processes.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantum Annealing for Constrained Polyphonic Composition: A QUBO-based Approach

text: The precise tuning systems used in historical keyboard performances are often a subject of scholarly debate. This study proposes a probabilistic method for temperament estimation directly from audio recordings of harpsichords and fortepianos. Our model exploits the phenomenon of string inharmonicity, where the frequencies of upper partials deviate from integer multiples of the fundamental. We construct a Bayesian hierarchical model that treats the temperament's cent deviations for each pitch class as latent variables. The likelihood function is derived from a spectral analysis of individual note recordings, comparing the observed partial frequencies against those predicted by different temperaments coupled with an inharmonicity model. Using Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods, we compute posterior probability distributions for the parameters of historical temperaments (e.g., meantone, well-tempered systems), providing a quantitative, data-driven approach to a central problem in historical performance practice and organology.
subject: Müzik
title: Inferring Historical Keyboard Temperaments from Audio Recordings using Bayesian Spectral Analysis

text: We present a novel quantitative approach to the analysis of rhythmic complexity grounded in spectral graph theory. Rhythmic patterns are modeled as directed graphs where nodes represent temporal onsets and edges are weighted by their metrical significance. This representation accommodates complex polyrhythms, syncopation, and ametrical structures. We analyze the Laplacian matrix of these rhythmic graphs to derive metrics of complexity, including the algebraic connectivity (Fiedler value), which correlates with the rhythm's structural coherence, and the spectral entropy, which quantifies its predictability and regularity. The framework is validated against a corpus of rhythms from diverse musical traditions, demonstrating its ability to distinguish between different metric structures and provide a continuous measure of complexity that aligns with perceptual studies. This graph-theoretic perspective offers a powerful alternative to traditional information-theoretic models by capturing the relational, hierarchical organization inherent in musical rhythm.
subject: Müzik
title: A Spectral Graph Theoretic Framework for Analyzing Rhythmic Complexity and Metric Structure

text: This research addresses the challenge of automatically identifying and classifying microtonal tuning systems from audio recordings. We introduce a deep learning architecture based on a hybrid Convolutional Recurrent Neural Network (CRNN) trained on constant-Q transform (CQT) spectrograms. The model learns to recognize the distinctive spectral fingerprints of various maqamat, ragas, and other microtonal scalar systems. A key innovation is the use of a custom pitch-class distribution layer that maps spectral energy to a high-resolution (1200-cent) octave representation, enabling fine-grained pitch analysis. Trained on a curated dataset of traditional Arabic, Persian, and Indian music, our model achieves high accuracy in classifying recordings by their underlying tonal system. The learned convolutional filters reveal musically salient features corresponding to characteristic intervals and melodic motifs, providing new insights into the perceptual cues that define these complex musical languages and advancing the capabilities of computational ethnomusicology.
subject: Müzik
title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Microtonal System Classification in Non-Western Musics

text: We introduce a computational framework for automating Schenkerian analysis, a cornerstone of tonal music theory. Our approach utilizes a hierarchical probabilistic generative model to infer the underlying voice-leading structure from a symbolic musical surface. The model represents a musical piece as a sequence of observations (notes) generated by a set of latent variables corresponding to structural prolongations at different Schenkerian levels (foreground, middleground, background). We employ a structured Variational Autoencoder (VAE) architecture, where the encoder maps a musical surface to a latent representation of its Ursatz, and the decoder generates the surface by recursively applying prolongational transformations. The model is trained on a corpus of expert Schenkerian analyses, learning the statistical regularities of tonal reduction. Our system not only produces complete Schenkerian graphs but also quantifies the probability of alternative analytical interpretations, offering a robust, data-driven tool for large-scale structural music analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: A Probabilistic Generative Model for Automated Schenkerian Analysis

text: This study investigates the perceptual interdependence of instrumental timbre and harmonic context in orchestral music. We challenge the traditional theoretical separation of these domains by quantifying their interaction using a deep learning framework. An extensive dataset of orchestral excerpts was analyzed by feeding audio through a pre-trained convolutional autoencoder to extract low-dimensional timbral feature vectors. Concurrently, harmonic function was annotated using a probabilistic context-free grammar. We then applied Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCA) to the timbral and harmonic feature spaces to identify maximal correlations. The results reveal statistically significant alignments, demonstrating that specific instrumental combinations are systematically correlated with specific harmonic functions. These findings empirically validate long-standing principles of orchestration and provide a quantitative methodology for exploring the fused perceptual domain where harmony and timbre are inextricably linked, yielding a computational basis for the theory of orchestral color.
subject: Müzik
title: The Timbral-Harmonic Nexus: Quantifying Interdependence in Orchestral Sonority using Deep Unsupervised Learning

text: The concept of *chiaroscuro* (light-dark) is a central tenet of classical vocal pedagogy, yet its acoustic definition remains elusive. This paper presents a systematic spectrographic investigation into the acoustic correlates of this desired vocal timbre. We analyzed audio recordings of professional opera singers performing identical phrases in Italian, German, and French. Using Linear Predictive Coding (LPC) and mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs), we extracted formant frequencies (F1-F5) and spectral envelope characteristics. Our analysis reveals that the *chiaroscuro* timbre is consistently associated with a specific acoustic signature: a lowered F1 and F2 (correlating with the *scuro* element) combined with a prominent energy peak in the 2.5-3.5 kHz region, known as the Singer's Formant Cluster (the *chiaro* element). This multi-formant strategy is maintained across different languages, suggesting it is a language-independent physiological adjustment fundamental to this elite vocal production style.
subject: Müzik
title: Acoustic Correlates of the Chiaroscuro Timbre in Operatic Singing: A Cross-Linguistic Spectrographic Analysis

text: Expressive musical performance is an embodied act where acoustic variations are intrinsically linked to physical gesture. This research presents a multimodal machine learning framework to model this relationship. We recorded pianists performing with varying expressive intentions while simultaneously capturing high-resolution audio and 3D motion data of their hands and upper body. Audio features, including dynamic envelopes, spectral flux, and micro-timing deviations, were extracted alongside kinematic features such as velocity and joint angles. A deep canonical correlation analysis (DCCA) model was trained to learn a shared latent space between the audio and motion modalities. The results demonstrate a strong, learnable correlation, revealing that specific kinematic profiles (e.g., wrist- versus arm-led motion) systematically map onto distinct acoustic realizations of articulation and dynamics. This integrated approach provides empirical evidence for theories of embodied cognition in music and yields a generative model capable of synthesizing realistic performance variations.
subject: Müzik
title: Embodied Semantics of Expressive Performance: A Multimodal Analysis Fusing Audio and Motion Capture Data

text: This paper presents a novel methodology for the sonification of high-dimensional datasets, leveraging the perceptual richness of granular synthesis. Traditional sonification techniques often suffer from auditory masking and low informational bandwidth. To overcome this, our system maps distinct data dimensions to orthogonal perceptual parameters of a granular synthesizer, including grain duration, density, pitch randomization, and spatialization, guided by principles of psychoacoustic salience. We introduce a 'semantic distance' mapping algorithm that ensures perceptually similar data points result in similar sonic textures, preserving the topological structure of the original data space. The system is evaluated through a controlled experiment where participants identify clusters and outliers in a synthetic high-dimensional dataset presented aurally. Results show a significant improvement in analytical accuracy compared to standard auditory graph and parameter-mapping sonification methods. This framework provides a robust and perceptually optimized tool for exploratory data analysis through sound.
subject: Müzik
title: Psychoacoustically-Informed Sonification of High-Dimensional Data via Parameter-Mapped Granular Synthesis

text: The intrinsic fragility of quantum states to environmental decoherence remains a primary obstacle to scalable quantum computation. Topological quantum computing proposes a fault-tolerant solution by encoding information non-locally in the degenerate ground state manifold of a topologically ordered system. Here, we present extensive numerical simulations of braiding operations on Majorana zero modes localized at the vortices of a chiral p-wave superconducting island. By solving the time-dependent Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations, we characterize the unitary transformations, or Fibonacci matrices, that constitute a universal gate set. Our analysis quantifies the fidelity of these gates, identifying non-adiabatic effects and quasi-particle poisoning as the dominant sources of error. The results demonstrate that for experimentally feasible parameters, gate fidelities exceeding 99.9% are achievable, provided the braiding process is sufficiently adiabatic. This work provides a quantitative roadmap for the physical realization of fault-tolerant quantum logic gates, reinforcing the viability of non-Abelian anyon-based architectures.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Protection of Quantum Information via Braiding of Non-Abelian Anyons in a Chiral p-wave Superconductor

text: Non-Hermitian systems, which effectively describe open quantum systems with gain and loss, exhibit a rich phenomenology not found in their Hermitian counterparts. We investigate the interplay between topology and non-Hermiticity in a one-dimensional photonic waveguide array with engineered non-reciprocal hopping. The system's Hamiltonian is intrinsically non-Hermitian and possesses a generalized chiral symmetry. We uncover a complex phase diagram featuring multiple Parity-Time (PT) symmetry broken regions and the emergence of third-order exceptional points (EP3s), where three eigenvalues and their corresponding eigenvectors coalesce simultaneously. Crucially, we demonstrate a breakdown of the conventional bulk-boundary correspondence. Instead, the localization of topological edge modes is governed by the non-Hermitian skin effect, a phenomenon we characterize by defining a new topological invariant based on the winding number in the complex energy plane. Our findings reveal a new class of topological phenomena, paving the way for designing novel photonic devices with exceptional sensitivity and topological robustness.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Hermitian Topology and Higher-Order Exceptional Points in a Synthetic Photonic Lattice

text: The holographic principle, particularly the AdS/CFT correspondence, suggests a profound connection between quantum entanglement and the geometry of spacetime. We explore this connection by modeling the vacuum state of a 2D conformal field theory (CFT) using a multiscale entanglement renormalization ansatz (MERA) tensor network. We demonstrate that the entanglement structure encoded within the MERA network gives rise to a discrete analogue of a 3D Anti-de Sitter (AdS) geometry. Specifically, we show that the minimal number of tensor network bonds connecting two boundary regions, which represents their entanglement entropy, reproduces the Ryu-Takayanagi formula for the area of a minimal surface in the bulk. Furthermore, we establish a direct mapping between the bulk causal structure and the quantum error-correcting properties of the MERA code. This work reinforces the 'It from Qubit' paradigm, providing compelling evidence that the fabric of spacetime is an emergent property of the underlying quantum information structure.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent Spacetime Geometry from Boundary Entanglement in the AdS/CFT Correspondence

text: Many-body localization (MBL) provides a robust mechanism for ergodicity breaking in isolated, disordered quantum systems, preventing them from thermalizing. We investigate the defining characteristics of the MBL phase through large-scale numerical simulations of a one-dimensional disordered Heisenberg spin chain using the time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (t-DMRG) algorithm. Following a global quantum quench, we observe the hallmark slow, logarithmic growth of bipartite entanglement entropy, which stands in stark contrast to the linear, volume-law growth in thermalizing systems. We explicitly construct the complete set of quasi-local integrals of motion (l-bits) that form the basis of the system's emergent integrability. By analyzing the exponential decay of the l-bit operators, we provide a quantitative measure of their localization. Our results offer strong numerical verification for the stability of the MBL phase and elucidate the structure of the conserved quantities that are responsible for the system's persistent memory of its initial conditions.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Growth and Emergent Integrability in the Many-Body Localized Phase

text: The interplay between thermodynamics and information is most starkly captured by the Maxwell's demon paradox. We theoretically analyze a realizable quantum Maxwell's demon implemented in a circuit QED architecture, where a superconducting transmon qubit acts as the system and a coupled microwave resonator serves as both the measurement device and information reservoir. By applying quantum feedback control contingent on the measurement outcome, we demonstrate the extraction of work from a single thermal bath, an apparent violation of the second law of thermodynamics. We derive a generalized Jarzynski equality that incorporates the information-theoretic cost of the measurement and feedback loop. Our analysis quantitatively confirms that the extracted work is bounded by the processed information, thereby validating Landauer's principle in a dynamic, non-equilibrium context. This framework provides a concrete protocol for experimentally investigating the fundamental energetic costs of information processing in open quantum systems and exploring the limits of quantum engines.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Fluctuation Theorems and Information-to-Energy Conversion in a Superconducting Maxwell's Demon

text: The engineering of strong, deterministic photon-photon interactions is a key prerequisite for advanced quantum information processing. We propose and analyze a scheme to generate highly non-classical states of light using a coupled optomechanical system. In our setup, two spatially separated optical cavities interact via a shared mechanical resonator. The radiation-pressure coupling induces an effective cross-Kerr nonlinearity between the photonic modes, which is significantly enhanced by the mechanical motion. We demonstrate that this nonlinearity leads to a robust photon blockade effect, where the presence of a single photon in the system prevents the absorption of a second, confirmed by a calculated second-order correlation function g⁽²⁾(0) ≪ 1. Under strong driving, this same interaction facilitates the deterministic generation of a two-mode entangled Schrödinger cat state. The non-classical nature of the state is verified by the pronounced negativity of its Wigner function, making this architecture a promising platform for quantum communication and computation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Generation of Entangled Schrödinger Cat States via Photon Blockade in Coupled Optomechanical Cavities

text: Topological quantum error-correcting codes offer a promising avenue toward fault-tolerant quantum computation, yet they often suffer from large resource overheads, particularly for non-Clifford gates. We introduce a novel quantum code, the 'semionic surface code,' which is a variant of the Kitaev surface code defined on a non-orientable surface. This code stabilizes a qubit on 2g holes, where g is the genus, and possesses a remarkable feature: a transversal, and thus fault-tolerant, Controlled-NOT (CNOT) gate. We perform a detailed threshold analysis using a biased noise model with a minimum-weight perfect matching decoder, finding a sustainable error threshold of p_c ≈ 10.4%. While the T gate is not transversal, the native transversal CNOT significantly reduces the complexity and resource cost of magic state distillation protocols compared to standard surface code architectures. Our results present a compelling alternative for building more efficient and robust quantum computing hardware.
subject: Kuantum
title: A Fault-Tolerant Universal Gate Set Based on the Transversal CNOT in a Weight-Four Semionic Topological Code

text: The quantum-to-classical transition remains a central puzzle in physics. We experimentally test the validity of macroscopic realism, a worldview that assumes macroscopic objects have definite properties independent of observation, by testing the Leggett-Garg inequality. Our system is a silica nanosphere with a mass of 10⁹ amu, optically levitated in an ultra-high vacuum and feedback-cooled to its quantum ground state of motion. We perform a temporal Bell-test-like experiment by implementing a sequence of weak, quantum non-demolition measurements of the particle's position. The resulting time-correlation functions show a violation of the Leggett-Garg inequality by 6.7 standard deviations. We meticulously characterize and rule out alternative classical explanations by performing control experiments that quantify the measurement back-action. Our results refute the conjunction of macroscopic realism and non-invasive measurability for this mesoscopic system, placing stringent constraints on objective collapse models and pushing the boundary of quantum mechanics into a new macroscopic regime.
subject: Kuantum
title: Violation of the Leggett-Garg Inequality Using the Center-of-Mass Motion of an Optically Levitated Nanosphere

text: Van der Waals heterostructures provide an unprecedented platform for designing materials with novel quantum properties. We investigate spin transport in a heterostructure composed of monolayer graphene encapsulated by hexagonal boron nitride and proximitized by monolayer tungsten diselenide (WSe₂). The strong spin-orbit coupling (SOC) induced in graphene from the WSe₂ is experimentally probed via non-local spin valve and Hanle precession measurements at cryogenic temperatures. We demonstrate exceptionally long spin relaxation lengths exceeding 12 µm and observe a clear gate-voltage-tunable transition between two spin relaxation mechanisms: a conventional D'yakonov-Perel' mechanism and a valley-Zeeman SOC-dominated mechanism. The latter creates an effective out-of-plane magnetic field with opposite signs for the K and K' valleys, enabling all-electrical control over spin precession. This electrically tunable, proximity-induced SOC offers a new paradigm for creating highly coherent and controllable spin-logic devices for quantum information applications.
subject: Kuantum
title: Coherent Long-Range Spin Transport and Gate-Tunable Valley-Zeeman Spin-Orbit Coupling in Graphene/WSe₂ Heterostructures

text: Quantum metrology leverages non-classical resources to achieve measurement precision beyond the standard quantum limit (SQL). We report on the experimental realization of a phase-sensing protocol that approaches the fundamental Heisenberg limit. We generate path-entangled NOON states, (|N,0⟩ + |0,N⟩)/√2, with photon numbers up to N=5 using a heralded, multiplexed spontaneous parametric down-conversion source. These states are injected into a Mach-Zehnder interferometer subjected to a phase shift φ. We develop an adaptive measurement protocol combined with a Bayesian inference algorithm to efficiently extract the phase information from the multi-photon interference fringes. Our protocol demonstrates a phase sensitivity scaling of Δφ ∝ 1/N^0.94±0.05, a significant enhancement over the SQL scaling of 1/√N. The achieved precision, validated by the quantum Fisher information, demonstrates the near-optimal performance of our scheme, paving the way for practical quantum sensors in fields such as biological imaging and gravitational wave astronomy.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Phase Estimation via Multi-Photon NOON States and Bayesian Inference

text: We investigate the emergence of spacetime geometry from quantum entanglement in cosmological horizons, extending the AdS/CFT correspondence to a de Sitter (dS) context. By employing a modified Multi-scale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (MERA) tensor network on the future boundary of a dS static patch, we demonstrate a consistent holographic mapping to the bulk geometry. The network's causal structure intrinsically encodes the bulk causal wedge, and we derive an explicit relationship between the entanglement entropy of boundary subregions and the area of extremal surfaces in the bulk, analogous to the Ryu-Takayanagi formula. Our framework addresses long-standing challenges in dS holography, particularly the problem of time and the observer-dependent nature of the horizon. The analysis reveals that local bulk operators can be reconstructed from non-local boundary correlators, providing a concrete information-theoretic foundation for the emergence of a classical bulk reality from the underlying quantum state of the cosmological horizon.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Entanglement Renormalization and Bulk Reconstruction in de Sitter Spacetime

text: The interplay between topology and hydrodynamics in condensed matter systems gives rise to novel transport phenomena. Here, we theoretically investigate the concept of Hall viscosity in a two-dimensional chiral magnet hosting a skyrmion lattice. We formulate a continuum field theory for the coupled dynamics of magnons and the underlying topological texture, revealing an off-diagonal term in the momentum-stress tensor that corresponds to a non-dissipative Hall viscosity. This term arises from the effective emergent magnetic field generated by the skyrmions' Berry curvature. Through extensive micromagnetic simulations, we demonstrate that this anomalous viscosity manifests as a transverse force on a moving skyrmion lattice, leading to a topological Hall effect for the skyrmions themselves. This work establishes a direct link between the geometric phase of magnonic excitations and macroscopic hydrodynamic transport coefficients, suggesting new avenues for controlling topological spin textures via applied mechanical strains or acoustic waves.
subject: Fizik
title: Anomalous Hall Viscosity and Non-Equilibrium Skyrmion Dynamics in Chiral Magnets

text: We propose a novel mechanism for late-time cosmic acceleration wherein the quintessence field is identified with a modulus field parametrizing the volume of a compact extra dimension in a brane-world scenario. In our model, the modulus is initially stabilized at a high-curvature point in the early universe. However, the coupling to standard model matter on the brane induces a radiative correction to the moduli potential, which dynamically destabilizes the vacuum as the universe's matter density redshifts. This triggers a slow-roll evolution of the modulus toward a new minimum at infinite volume, mimicking a thawing quintessence field. The model naturally generates a potential of the form V(φ) ~ exp(-λφ/M_pl) with λ of order unity, consistent with observational constraints from CMB anisotropies, Baryon Acoustic Oscillations, and Type Ia supernovae. This framework provides a geometrically motivated origin for dark energy, linking cosmological dynamics to the fundamental structure of spacetime.
subject: Fizik
title: Quintessence from a Geometrically Destabilized Brane-World Modulus

text: Tests of Bell's inequalities are fundamental to our understanding of quantum non-locality, yet are susceptible to experimental loopholes. We report on a loophole-free Bell test that simultaneously closes the locality and detection loopholes by leveraging hyperentanglement in the spatial and polarization degrees of freedom of photonic pairs. By preparing and measuring entangled qutrits (three-level systems), we violate a Collins-Gisin-Linden-Massar-Popescu (CGLMP) inequality, a high-dimensional generalization of the CHSH inequality. The use of qutrits offers stronger resistance to detector inefficiencies and noise. Our setup achieves an overall detection efficiency of η = 0.89 and maintains spacelike separation between measurement events. We observed a violation with a CGLMP parameter of S3 = 2.871 ± 0.015, which is more than 50 standard deviations above the classical bound of 2 and is inconsistent with local realism. This result rigorously confirms quantum non-locality and provides a robust platform for device-independent quantum information protocols.
subject: Fizik
title: Closing the Detection Loophole with High-Dimensional Entangled Photonic States

text: The Eigenstate Thermalization Hypothesis (ETH) provides a framework for understanding how isolated quantum many-body systems reach thermal equilibrium. We investigate the validity and breakdown of ETH in a one-dimensional spin-1/2 chain with both quasiperiodic disorder and tunable long-range power-law interactions (1/r^α). Using large-scale exact diagonalization and time-evolution simulations, we map out the phase diagram as a function of interaction range (α) and disorder strength. For α > 1, we observe a transition from an ergodic, ETH-obeying phase to a many-body localized (MBL) phase. For α < 1, the system remains ergodic for all disorder strengths, suggesting that long-range interactions destroy MBL. We further characterize these phases by computing out-of-time-ordered correlators (OTOCs), which quantify the scrambling of quantum information. In the ergodic phase, the OTOCs exhibit exponential growth, with a Lyapunov exponent that decreases as the MBL transition is approached, providing a dynamical signature of this critical phenomenon.
subject: Fizik
title: Eigenstate Thermalization and Quantum Scrambling in a Disordered Long-Range Interacting System

text: Many extensions of the Standard Model predict a first-order electroweak phase transition (EWPT) in the early universe, which would generate a stochastic gravitational wave background (SGWB). We argue that if a primordial magnetic field was present during the EWPT, the resulting SGWB would be statistically anisotropic. We perform large-scale magnetohydrodynamic simulations of bubble collisions, sound waves, and turbulence in the plasma, incorporating a background U(1) magnetic field. Our results show that the magnetic field induces a quadrupole anisotropy in the GW power spectrum, with an amplitude proportional to the magnetic energy density. The specific spectral shape of the anisotropy depends on the dominant GW production mechanism (sound waves vs. turbulence). We calculate the prospective sensitivity of the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) to such an anisotropy. A detection would not only provide compelling evidence for a first-order EWPT but also serve as a unique probe of primordial magnetogenesis.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing First-Order Electroweak Phase Transitions with Anisotropic Stochastic Gravitational Wave Backgrounds

text: The equation of state (EoS) of matter at supranuclear densities remains a central uncertainty in nuclear astrophysics. A strong first-order phase transition from hadronic to quark matter is a plausible scenario within neutron star cores. We present a suite of general-relativistic hydrodynamics simulations of binary neutron star mergers using a range of hybrid quark-hadron EoSs. Our simulations show that if a phase transition occurs in the post-merger remnant, it triggers a characteristic collapse of the hypermassive neutron star, leading to a distinct, high-frequency feature in the gravitational wave (GW) signal. The frequency of this feature is directly correlated with the transition density and the energy release. We compute the spectrograms of the post-merger GW signals and demonstrate that these signatures are potentially detectable by next-generation observatories like the Einstein Telescope or Cosmic Explorer, offering a unique channel to probe the existence and properties of deconfined quark matter in the cosmos.
subject: Fizik
title: Post-Merger Gravitational Wave Signatures of Quark-Hadron Phase Transitions in Binary Neutron Star Inspirals

text: Quantum simulation offers a powerful path to realizing and studying exotic phases of matter. We propose and analyze a realistic scheme to engineer a fractional Chern insulator state using a gas of ultracold dipolar fermionic atoms trapped in a time-modulated optical lattice. The long-range dipolar interactions, combined with a Floquet engineering protocol that generates a synthetic magnetic field, lead to the emergence of a correlated topological state analogous to the fractional quantum Hall effect. By employing matrix product state (MPS) simulations on a cylinder geometry, we calculate the ground-state properties, including the charge density profile and the entanglement spectrum. For a filling fraction of ν=1/3, we identify a gapped ground state with a threefold topological degeneracy and a clear chiral edge mode structure in the entanglement spectrum, providing unambiguous evidence of a fractional Chern insulator. This system provides a new, highly controllable platform for exploring the physics of fractional topological phases.
subject: Fizik
title: Synthetic Gauge Fields and Fractional Chern Insulators in a Dipolar Fermi Gas in an Optical Lattice

text: We explore the phenomenological implications of combining the Swampland Distance Conjecture (SDC) and the Trans-Planckian Censorship Conjecture (TCC) for single-field inflationary models. The SDC posits that an infinite tower of states becomes exponentially light as one traverses a geodesic distance in field space, while the TCC constrains the total duration of inflation to prevent trans-Planckian modes from becoming classical. Together, these conjectures impose powerful consistency conditions on the effective field theory of inflation. We derive a universal upper bound on the tensor-to-scalar ratio, r, that is significantly stronger than current observational limits for a broad class of potentials, including monomial and Starobinsky-like models. Specifically, we show that consistency with both conjectures requires r < 10^-9 for canonical single-field inflation. This stringent constraint suggests that a future detection of primordial B-mode polarization would either require a non-standard inflationary mechanism or challenge these foundational principles emerging from quantum gravity.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraining Inflationary Potentials with Trans-Planckian Censorship and the Swampland Distance Conjecture

text: Non-Hermitian systems, which effectively describe open systems with gain and loss, exhibit unique topological phenomena with no Hermitian counterparts. We theoretically investigate the topological band structure of a three-dimensional periodically driven photonic crystal with engineered gain and loss. The interplay of Floquet engineering and non-Hermiticity leads to the formation of exceptional points (EPs), where both eigenvalues and eigenvectors coalesce. We demonstrate that these EPs are not isolated points but form extended one-dimensional lines and two-dimensional surfaces in the combined momentum-parameter space. The topology of these exceptional nodal structures is characterized by a generalized Berry phase, which manifests in observable phenomena such as the non-adiabatic transport of light. Our analysis reveals that light propagating near these exceptional surfaces exhibits unidirectional amplification and extreme sensitivity to perturbations, opening possibilities for designing novel topological photonic devices like robust lasers and optical switches with enhanced functionalities.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Hermitian Topology and Exceptional Nodal Surfaces in a Periodically Driven Photonic Crystal

text: We theoretically propose and numerically validate a novel platform for realizing topological quantum computation based on non-Abelian Fibonacci anyons. Our model utilizes a van der Waals heterostructure comprising a fractional Chern insulator proximitized with an s-wave superconductor. Through extensive density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) simulations, we demonstrate the emergence of a gapped topological phase supporting Ising and Fibonacci anyonic excitations.
