We explicitly calculate the non-Abelian braiding statistics by simulating the adiabatic transport of quasi-holes, confirming the unitary braiding matrices predicted by Chern-Simons field theory. Furthermore, we analyze the system's resilience to local perturbations and thermal noise, establishing a viable parameter regime where decoherence rates are suppressed below the threshold required for fault-tolerant quantum computation. This work establishes a concrete material-based pathway towards constructing a universal topological quantum computer, circumventing the material challenges associated with fractional quantum Hall systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Anyonic Braiding in a Fractional Chern Insulator Heterostructure

text: We explore the conjecture that spacetime geometry emerges from the entanglement structure of a boundary quantum field theory, focusing on the ER=EPR correspondence. This work introduces a novel tensor network ansatz, the 'Entanglement Renormalization Manifold' (ERM), which dynamically generates a discretized bulk geometry consistent with the Ryu-Takayanagi formula. By interpreting the tensor network as a quantum error-correcting code, we demonstrate how logical operators deep in the bulk are protected against boundary erasures, providing a concrete realization of holographic error correction. Our model explicitly constructs a traversable wormhole connecting two entangled conformal field theories (CFTs) and shows that the transmission capacity is directly proportional to their mutual information. The ERM formalism provides a computational framework for investigating quantum gravity phenomena, such as black hole evaporation and the information paradox, from a purely quantum information-theoretic perspective.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Spacetime from Entanglement Renormalization: An ER=EPR Tensor Network Realization

text: The transition from an ergodic, thermalizing phase to a many-body localized (MBL) phase represents a fundamental breakdown of statistical mechanics in isolated quantum systems. We investigate this transition in a periodically driven (Floquet) spin chain subjected to a quasiperiodic potential, which interpolates between random and deterministic disorder. Using large-scale exact diagonalization and a time-dependent variational principle, we map the phase diagram as a function of driving frequency and disorder strength. We identify the MBL transition through multiple independent diagnostics, including the statistics of the Floquet eigenstate level spacing, the scaling of entanglement entropy, and the decay of local observables. Our results reveal a re-entrant localization phenomenon and a non-monotonic dependence of the critical disorder strength on the driving parameter, challenging existing phenomenological theories of the MBL transition and highlighting the unique role of quasiperiodicity in stabilizing non-ergodic dynamics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Signatures of the Many-Body Localization Transition in a Quasiperiodic Floquet System

text: Achieving sensitivities beyond the standard quantum limit (SQL) is paramount for the next generation of gravitational wave observatories. We propose a novel interferometric scheme that leverages multi-mode entangled squeezed vacuum states to achieve sub-Heisenberg-limited phase estimation. Our protocol involves injecting a frequency-dependent squeezed state generated by a configurable optical parametric amplifier into the dark port of the interferometer. By optimizing the entanglement spectrum and the homodyne detection angle, our theoretical model demonstrates a broadband sensitivity enhancement that surpasses existing single-mode squeezing techniques. We calculate the quantum Cramér-Rao bound for this system, showing that the phase sensitivity scales advantageously with the number of entangled modes. This approach provides a practical roadmap for developing quantum-enhanced sensors capable of probing astrophysical phenomena, such as the early universe stochastic gravitational wave background, currently obscured by quantum shot noise.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum-Enhanced Gravitational Wave Detection via Multi-Mode Squeezed State Interferometry

text: The development of robust quantum networks hinges on the ability to deterministically route quantum information carried by single photons. We present a theoretical framework for achieving near-unity chiral routing by coupling quantum emitters to nanophotonic waveguides exhibiting strong spin-momentum locking of light. In our system, the internal state of a V-type quantum emitter, such as a quantum dot or trapped atom, dictates the propagation direction of a spontaneously emitted photon. By engineering a dissipative channel via an auxiliary cavity mode, we demonstrate a protocol for preparing and stabilizing a desired dark state, enabling on-demand, high-fidelity directional photon emission. The non-reciprocal light-matter interaction forms the basis for fundamental quantum network primitives, including deterministic single-photon circulators and quantum routers. This work bridges the gap between chiral quantum optics and dissipative state engineering, paving the way for scalable, integrated quantum photonic circuits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Chiral Quantum Networks: Deterministic Single-Photon Routing with Spin-Momentum-Locked Emitters

text: We report on the experimental and theoretical investigation of non-Markovian dynamics in a superconducting qubit strongly coupled to a structured reservoir. The environment, engineered using a coupled transmission line resonator, possesses a tunable spectral density with long-lived memory effects. Using quantum process tomography, we reconstruct the dynamical map of the qubit system and observe a significant recurrence of quantum coherence, a definitive signature of non-Markovianity. Our results are accurately modeled by a time-convolutionless (TCL) master equation, which we solve numerically using a tensor network approach. We quantify the degree of non-Markovianity using the Breuer-Laine-Piilo (BLP) measure, demonstrating its direct control via external flux biasing of the reservoir. This platform provides a controllable testbed for exploring the fundamental aspects of open quantum systems, quantum thermodynamics, and the development of error mitigation strategies that exploit environmental memory.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Non-Markovian Dynamics in an Open Quantum System with a Time-Correlated Environment

text: We analyze a quantum Maxwell's demon operating a single-qubit engine coupled to two thermal reservoirs. The demon performs a projective measurement on an ancillary system entangled with the qubit, using the information gained to execute a feedback-controlled unitary operation that extracts work. Our analysis, based on a fully quantum fluctuation theorem, demonstrates that the extractable work is not solely determined by the classical information gain but can be significantly enhanced by the generation and consumption of quantum coherence. We derive a modified Jarzynski equality that explicitly includes a term corresponding to the work value of coherence. The model reveals a fundamental trade-off between information gain and coherence generation, showing that optimal work extraction protocols operate in a distinctly quantum, non-equilibrium regime. This work clarifies the intricate roles of information, entanglement, and coherence as thermodynamic resources at the quantum scale.
subject: Kuantum
title: Thermodynamic Work Extraction from Quantum Coherence in a Nonequilibrium Maxwell's Demon

text: The origin of the pseudogap phase in high-temperature cuprate superconductors remains a central unresolved problem in condensed matter physics. Utilizing a large-scale constrained-path auxiliary-field quantum Monte Carlo (AFQMC) simulation, we investigate the ground state properties of the two-dimensional Hubbard model at realistic doping levels. Our simulations reveal the spontaneous emergence of a metallic state with spectral properties characteristic of the pseudogap. Analysis of the single-particle spectral function A(k, ω) shows a clear momentum-dependent gap at the antinodes, which closes towards the nodal direction, consistent with angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) experiments. By calculating the dynamic spin and charge structure factors, we demonstrate that this pseudogap is intrinsically linked to the presence of short-range, incommensurate antiferromagnetic correlations. These results provide compelling numerical evidence that the pseudogap is a precursor to superconductivity arising from remnant magnetic correlations in a doped Mott insulator.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergence of a Pseudogap from Antiferromagnetic Correlations in a Doped Hubbard Model

text: Understanding the information paradox in black hole evaporation requires a self-consistent treatment of quantum fields and dynamic spacetime geometry. We investigate this problem within the framework of 2D Jackiw-Teitelboim (JT) gravity coupled to a conformal matter field. By solving the semiclassical field equations, we compute the expectation value of the stress-energy tensor and analyze its back-reaction on the metric. Our solution captures the formation of a black hole via gravitational collapse and its subsequent evaporation through Hawking radiation. We demonstrate that the Page curve for the entanglement entropy of the radiation is recovered, with the Page time corresponding to the moment a quantum extremal surface appears. The model explicitly shows how the inclusion of gravitational back-reaction, even at the semiclassical level, resolves the information paradox by preventing the monotonic growth of entanglement entropy, consistent with unitarity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Gravitational Back-Reaction and Black Hole Evaporation in a Semiclassical Jackiw-Teitelboim Gravity Model

text: We propose a novel experimental paradigm for detecting axion dark matter by exploiting the unique electrodynamic properties of topological magnetic materials. In materials exhibiting a chiral magnetic effect, the axion field couples not only to the standard E·B term but also to chiral magnetic currents, leading to a resonant enhancement of axion-photon conversion. We derive the modified Maxwell's equations within such a medium and show that the axion-induced effective current is significantly amplified near the material's magnetic resonance frequencies. We model a haloscope cavity filled with a candidate material, such as MnBi2Te4, and calculate the expected signal power. Our results indicate a potential enhancement factor of several orders of magnitude compared to conventional vacuum-cavity designs, allowing the exploration of previously inaccessible regions of the axion parameter space, particularly in the meV mass range. This approach synergizes condensed matter physics and cosmology.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Axion Electrodynamics and Haloscope Signatures in Chiral Magnetic Materials

text: We present a novel, non-perturbative approach to quantum gravity by extending the Causal Dynamical Triangulations (CDT) framework to include fermionic matter fields. The model discretizes spacetime into a foliated lattice of four-simplices, where the path integral is computed by summing over all possible causal geometries weighted by the Einstein-Hilbert action and a discretized Dirac action. Using large-scale Monte Carlo simulations, we observe the emergence of a de Sitter-like macroscopic spacetime with a well-defined Hausdorff dimension that dynamically transitions from D_H ≈ 2 at sub-Planckian scales to D_H ≈ 4 at cosmological scales. This dimensional flow provides a potential mechanism for asymptotic safety. Our results indicate that the back-reaction of fermionic matter non-trivially alters the fractal structure of spacetime at the quantum level, suggesting a deep interconnection between geometry and matter content that is inaccessible to perturbative methods. The framework offers a promising avenue for resolving singularities and understanding early-universe cosmology.
subject: Fizik
title: A Non-Perturbative Framework for Spacetime Quantization via Causal Dynamical Triangulations with Matter Coupling

text: This work formulates quantum mechanics as an application of entropic inference, deriving the Schrödinger equation from first principles without postulating an underlying classical reality. We treat particle positions as intrinsically uncertain variables, whose probability distributions are updated as new information becomes available. The dynamics are driven by maximizing a relative entropy functional, subject to constraints that represent physical information about phase space and conserved quantities. The central constraint is the preservation of a symplectic structure, which introduces a 'quantum potential' and leads directly to the Madelung transformation of the Schrödinger equation. This approach naturally accounts for quantum entanglement through correlations in the joint probability distribution of a multi-particle system. By reframing quantum theory as a consistent information-processing framework, our results challenge the traditional interpretation of the wave function and offer a novel perspective on the measurement problem and the quantum-to-classical transition.
subject: Fizik
title: Entropic Dynamics and the Emergence of Quantum Mechanics from Bayesian Inference

text: We derive a generalized fluctuation-dissipation theorem (FDT) for a class of active matter systems exhibiting persistent, non-equilibrium fluctuations. Standard FDT relies on detailed balance, a condition explicitly broken by the self-propulsive forces characteristic of active particles. Our approach employs a path-integral formalism on the Fokker-Planck equation, mapping the stochastic dynamics onto a field theory. We identify an effective temperature tensor, T_eff, that is frequency- and wavevector-dependent, capturing the scale-dependent energy injection from active processes. This T_eff replaces the scalar thermodynamic temperature in the response functions, thereby restoring a FDT-like structure. We demonstrate that for a model of active Brownian particles, T_eff reveals anisotropic responses and long-range correlations not present in equilibrium systems. This formalism provides a unified framework for characterizing the linear response of a broad spectrum of non-equilibrium systems, from bacterial suspensions to driven granular media, and is directly verifiable via microrheology experiments.
subject: Fizik
title: Generalized Fluctuation-Dissipation Relations in Non-Equilibrium Active Matter Systems

text: We theoretically investigate the emergence of higher-order topological insulator (HOTI) phases in non-Hermitian photonic systems. By engineering complex-valued, spatially modulated coupling coefficients in a two-dimensional lattice of optical resonators, we simultaneously realize a synthetic gauge field and gain/loss landscapes. This non-Hermiticity leads to the formation of exceptional points and a non-trivial band topology characterized by a complex Berry phase. We demonstrate the existence of a robust second-order topological phase, which manifests not as edge states but as zero-dimensional corner states that are topologically protected. The localization of these corner modes is dictated by the interplay between the synthetic magnetic flux and the non-Hermitian skin effect. Our work extends the bulk-boundary correspondence to higher-order non-Hermitian systems and proposes a concrete experimental realization in coupled-cavity arrays or laser-written waveguide structures, paving the way for novel topological lasers and robust light-trapping devices.
subject: Fizik
title: Higher-Order Topological Phases in Non-Hermitian Photonic Lattices with Synthetic Gauge Fields

text: We propose a novel dynamical mechanism to address the cosmological constant problem, positing a scalar field non-minimally coupled to the Gauss-Bonnet topological invariant, G. In our model, the vacuum energy of the matter sector, Λ, acts as a source in the scalar field's equation of motion. We show that for a wide class of coupling functions, the scalar field dynamically evolves to screen any large initial value of Λ, driving the effective cosmological constant towards a near-zero value in the late universe without fine-tuning of initial parameters. The dynamics exhibit attractor behavior, making the solution robust. The coupling to G becomes significant only in regions of high curvature, ensuring that the model remains consistent with stringent tests of General Relativity in the solar system and from binary pulsar observations. This self-tuning mechanism provides a compelling alternative to anthropic arguments for the observed smallness of the cosmological constant.
subject: Fizik
title: Cosmological Constant Relaxation via a Self-Tuning Scalar Field Coupled to the Gauss-Bonnet Invariant

text: We investigate the confining properties of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) using the AdS/CFT correspondence. By constructing a holographic dual model that incorporates key features of QCD, such as a running coupling and asymptotic freedom, we analyze the behavior of entanglement entropy as a diagnostic for confinement. A rectangular entangling region is considered on the boundary field theory, and its corresponding minimal surface area is calculated in the bulk anti-de Sitter (AdS) space. We demonstrate a phase transition in the entanglement entropy as a function of the separation length of the entangled subregions. For small separations, the entropy exhibits the characteristic area law of a conformal field theory. However, above a critical length scale, a new minimal surface configuration dominates, leading to a volume law behavior indicative of confinement. This transition provides a direct, information-theoretic signature of quark confinement and allows for a calculation of the string tension in terms of the bulk geometry parameters.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Quantum Chromodynamic Confinement using Holographic Entanglement Entropy

text: We explore the stochastic gravitational wave background (SGWB) generated by a first-order phase transition in a secluded dark sector, thermally decoupled from the Standard Model. Such a transition can proceed via extreme supercooling, leading to a significant release of latent heat and the violent collision of runaway bubble walls. We model the dynamics of this process, including bubble nucleation, expansion, and collision, and compute the resulting power spectrum of the gravitational radiation. Our analysis shows that a strongly supercooled transition can generate a detectable SGWB signal in the frequency band of future space-based interferometers like LISA, even if the dark sector is only feebly coupled to the Standard Model through gravity. The characteristic spectral shape, featuring a double-peaked structure arising from bubble collisions and subsequent sound waves, provides a distinct signature that can be distinguished from astrophysical foregrounds, offering a unique observational window into physics beyond the Standard Model.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Wave Signatures of Phase Transitions in the Early Universe from Supercooled Dark Sectors

text: We investigate the thermalization dynamics of an isolated quantum system with algebraically decaying long-range interactions, V(r) ∝ 1/r^α. Using a combination of matrix product state simulations and analytical arguments based on a Floquet-magnon expansion, we demonstrate a rich dynamical phase diagram as a function of the exponent α. For α exceeding the system's dimension d, the system thermalizes to a Gibbs ensemble, albeit with timescales that can be anomalously slow. However, for α < d, the system fails to thermalize on any accessible timescale, instead entering a long-lived prethermal state described by a quasi-local Generalized Gibbs Ensemble (GGE). In this regime, the system exhibits non-ergodic behavior and a breakdown of the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH). Our findings reveal that long-range interactions provide a robust mechanism for avoiding thermalization, with profound implications for quantum information storage and the engineering of novel non-equilibrium states of matter.
subject: Fizik
title: Anomalous Thermalization and Prethermalization in Long-Range Interacting Quantum Systems

text: We formulate a causal and stable theory of first-order relativistic hydrodynamics for fluids composed of particles with intrinsic spin. Starting from the conservation laws for energy-momentum and angular momentum, we construct the most general form of the constitutive relations for the dissipative fluxes compatible with the second law of thermodynamics. The entropy current is derived from a kinetic theory framework using the method of moments on a modified Boltzmann equation that includes spin degrees of freedom and collisional spin-orbit coupling. Unlike conventional hydrodynamics, the resulting theory features a non-symmetric energy-momentum tensor and an independent dynamical spin tensor. We demonstrate that the spin polarization vector couples to the fluid vorticity, giving rise to novel transport phenomena such as chiral vortical effects. This framework is essential for accurately modeling high-energy heavy-ion collisions and dense astrophysical systems like neutron star mergers, where spin effects are expected to be significant.
subject: Fizik
title: Relativistic Hydrodynamics with Spin: A Constitutive Theory from Entropy Current Analysis

text: We report the discovery of quantum many-body scars—atypical, non-thermalizing eigenstates with low entanglement—in a non-integrable tilted Bose-Hubbard model. While the majority of the system's eigenstates obey the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH), we identify a tower of scarred states that exhibit persistent, coherent oscillations from specific initial product states, violating ETH predictions. These revivals are protected by a constrained Hilbert space structure that emerges in the strong-tilt limit, forming a weakly broken SU(2) algebra. Using both exact diagonalization and time-dependent variational principle (TDVP) methods, we show that the scar states possess a sub-volume-law entanglement entropy and have large overlap with experimentally accessible initial states. Our results demonstrate that the mechanism of PXP-like constrained dynamics, known to cause scarring in Rydberg atom chains, can be generalized to continuous degrees of freedom in driven optical lattice systems, expanding the known classes of systems that exhibit weak ergodicity breaking.
subject: Fizik
title: Quantum Scars and Revivals in a Chaotic Many-Body System with a Tilted Field

text: We address the problem of average treatment effect estimation in high-dimensional settings where the number of confounders (p) may greatly exceed the sample size (n). We propose a doubly robust estimator that utilizes penalized spline sieves for non-parametric estimation of the propensity score and outcome regression functions. This approach avoids restrictive parametric assumptions and intrinsically performs variable selection. The key innovation lies in constructing sieve estimators that achieve oracle-like convergence rates, even when p >> n, under sparsity assumptions. We establish the theoretical properties of the proposed estimator, demonstrating its asymptotic normality and semiparametric efficiency, contingent on either the propensity score or outcome model being correctly specified. The methodology's finite-sample performance is evaluated through extensive Monte Carlo simulations, showing significant reduction in bias and variance compared to existing high-dimensional causal estimators. An application to genomic data illustrates its utility in identifying causal effects amidst a large number of potential genetic confounders.
subject: İstatistik
title: Doubly Robust Estimation in High-Dimensional Confounding Scenarios using Penalized Spline Sieves

text: This paper introduces a novel framework for statistical inference on the topological features of data sampled from a low-dimensional manifold embedded in a high-dimensional Euclidean space. We leverage persistent homology to compute multiscale topological summaries, specifically persistence diagrams, which encode the birth and death of homological features like connected components and holes. To quantify the uncertainty of these estimated features, we develop a computationally efficient subsampling-based bootstrap procedure to construct confidence regions for persistence diagrams. We prove the consistency of our bootstrap method and derive convergence rates for the Hausdorff distance between the empirical and true underlying persistence diagrams under specific assumptions on the manifold's reach and curvature. The method's efficacy is demonstrated on synthetic datasets sampled from tori and spheres, as well as a real-world application in computational biology for discriminating between protein structures based on their intrinsic topological signatures, showcasing its power beyond simple geometric measurements.
subject: İstatistik
title: Geometric Inference on Manifold Data via Persistent Homology and Subsampling

text: We propose a novel methodology for functional principal component analysis (FPCA) tailored to sparse and irregularly spaced longitudinal data, where each subject's trajectory is observed at a few, random time points. Our approach embeds the functional representation within a state-space model, allowing the underlying smooth trajectories and their derivatives to be modeled as a continuous-time stochastic process. The estimation is performed using a Kalman filter and smoother algorithm within a maximum likelihood framework, which naturally handles the irregular sampling and measurement error. This dynamic approach simultaneously estimates the population mean function, the covariance kernel, and the subject-specific functional principal component scores. We establish the asymptotic consistency and convergence rates of the estimated model components under mild regularity conditions. Through simulations and an application to modeling CD4 cell count trajectories from an HIV/AIDS clinical study, we demonstrate superior performance in trajectory reconstruction and prediction compared to conventional FPCA methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Functional Principal Component Analysis for Irregularly and Sparsely Sampled Longitudinal Data

text: We introduce a flexible and interpretable class of non-stationary spatio-temporal Gaussian process models. The core idea is to construct the non-stationary covariance function through a kernel convolution approach, where the parameters of the local smoothing kernel—such as range, variance, and anisotropy—are modeled as functions of spatially-varying covariates. This allows the dependence structure of the process to adapt to geographical or environmental factors in a physically meaningful way. For computationally tractable Bayesian inference, we employ a low-rank approximation of the Gaussian process based on predictive processes and utilize integrated nested Laplace approximation (INLA) for efficient estimation of model hyperparameters and latent field values. The model's capacity to capture complex, covariate-driven heterogeneity is illustrated through an analysis of ground-level ozone concentration data across the United States, where the spatial correlation structure is shown to depend significantly on elevation and land use patterns.
subject: İstatistik
title: Non-Stationary Spatio-Temporal Gaussian Process Models using Covariate-Driven Kernel Convolutions

text: This paper addresses the problem of jointly estimating multiple related Gaussian graphical models from heterogeneous datasets, a common task in multi-class genomic studies. We propose a novel penalized maximum likelihood method called Fused Node-wise Graphical Lasso (FNGL). The method employs a fused penalty on the node-conditional regression coefficients across different classes, encouraging similarity in the network structures while allowing for class-specific edges. This node-level penalty structure facilitates the identification of both shared conditional independence relationships and differential network hubs. We develop an efficient alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) algorithm for optimization and establish theoretical guarantees for graph recovery consistency under high-dimensional scaling where p > n. The empirical advantages of FNGL in terms of statistical power, edge selection accuracy, and interpretability are demonstrated on synthetic data and a multi-class cancer gene expression dataset, revealing shared and unique regulatory pathways.
subject: İstatistik
title: Joint Estimation of Multiple Gaussian Graphical Models with Fused Node Penalties

text: Classical robust estimators like the Minimum Covariance Determinant (MCD) offer high breakdown points but are computationally intractable and ill-defined in high-dimensional (p > n) settings. We introduce the Regularized Minimum Covariance Determinant (R-MCD) estimator, which integrates a penalty on the covariance matrix condition number directly into the MCD objective function. This regularization ensures the existence and uniqueness of the solution even when p > n, while preserving the core principle of identifying a robust core subset of the data. We derive a fast, iterative C-steps algorithm for its computation and theoretically analyze its breakdown point and influence function, demonstrating its robust properties. Monte Carlo simulations show that R-MCD consistently outperforms competing methods like the Stahel-Donoho estimator and other regularized covariance estimators in terms of both estimation accuracy and outlier detection performance, particularly in scenarios with structured, high-leverage outliers.
subject: İstatistik
title: High-Breakdown and Computationally Efficient Covariance Estimation in High Dimensions via Regularized MCD

text: We introduce Deep Survival Forests (DSF), a novel non-parametric ensemble method for survival analysis designed to handle right-censored data and time-varying covariates. The architecture synergizes the robust ensemble nature of random survival forests with the powerful representation learning capabilities of deep neural networks. Within each tree of the forest, splitting rules are determined not by exhaustive search over individual covariates, but by a small, embedded neural network that learns optimal non-linear projections of the covariate space to maximize a time-dependent survival criterion. This hybrid structure captures complex, high-order interaction effects without imposing restrictive assumptions like proportional hazards. The final prediction is an aggregated Nelson-Aalen type estimator of the cumulative hazard function. Extensive benchmarks on synthetic and real-world clinical trial datasets show that DSF significantly outperforms Cox models, standard random survival forests, and other deep learning survival models in terms of concordance index and integrated Brier score.
subject: İstatistik
title: Deep Survival Forests: A Non-Parametric Ensemble Approach for Censored Data with Time-Varying Covariates

text: This work develops the theoretical framework and implementation of targeted maximum likelihood estimation (TMLE) for the effects of stochastic interventions in longitudinal studies with time-varying confounding. Unlike static interventions, stochastic interventions set the probability of treatment at each time point conditional on the evolving covariate history. We formally define the statistical target parameter via the G-computation formula under this interventional regime. Our TMLE algorithm first obtains initial estimates of the sequential regression and treatment mechanism components (e.g., using the Super Learner ensemble), then performs a targeted fluctuation step to solve the efficient influence curve estimating equation. This procedure yields a doubly robust, asymptotically linear, and semiparametrically efficient estimator. We derive the requisite theoretical properties and illustrate the methodology by estimating the population-level effect of a dynamic antibiotic stewardship protocol in a longitudinal observational cohort study from electronic health records.
subject: İstatistik
title: Targeted Maximum Likelihood Estimation for Stochastic Interventional Effects in Longitudinal Settings

text: We derive novel, data-dependent generalization bounds for learning algorithms based on Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (SGLD), a cornerstone of Bayesian deep learning. Prevailing PAC-Bayesian bounds for SGLD often depend on a fixed prior, which can lead to vacuous results for overparameterized models. Our primary contribution is a PAC-Bayesian bound that depends on the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence between the SGLD posterior and a data-dependent prior. This prior is constructed as a Gibbs distribution centered on a reference hypothesis obtained via a pre-training phase, allowing the bound to adapt to the geometry of the loss landscape. We prove that this formulation yields tighter, non-vacuous generalization guarantees for deep neural networks. The theoretical results are substantiated by empirical evaluations on benchmark image classification tasks, demonstrating that our bound effectively tracks the generalization gap and serves as a principled tool for hyperparameter tuning in Bayesian neural networks.
subject: İstatistik
title: Data-Dependent PAC-Bayesian Generalization Bounds for Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics

text: This paper introduces a novel probabilistic generative model for automated Schenkerian analysis, leveraging deep recurrent neural networks (RNNs) with attention mechanisms. Traditional rule-based systems for computational Schenkerian analysis struggle with the inherent ambiguities of prolongational reduction and fail to capture the holistic nature of structural hearing. Our proposed model, trained on a new corpus of expert-annotated Schenkerian graphs, learns to infer latent hierarchical structures directly from a chromagram-like input representation. It conceptualizes the analytical process as a sequence-to-graph transduction problem, where the RNN sequentially generates nodes and edges corresponding to the Urlinie, Bassbrechung, and middleground prolongations. The attention mechanism allows the model to focus on salient melodic and harmonic events across different time scales. We evaluate our model against existing algorithmic approaches and a human expert baseline, demonstrating significant improvements in structural accuracy and musical plausibility, particularly in identifying the fundamental structure (Ursatz). The framework offers a robust, data-driven approach to formalizing and automating one of music theory's most influential yet complex analytical methodologies.
subject: Müzik
title: A Probabilistic Generative Model for Schenkerian Analysis Using Deep Recurrent Networks

text: This research presents a novel computational framework for the classification and analysis of microtonal tuning systems, moving beyond purely mathematical interval ratios to psychoacoustically-informed spectral metrics. We introduce a methodology termed "Spectral Tesselation," which utilizes a high-resolution Constant-Q Transform (CQT) to map the harmonic series of fundamental pitches within a given tuning system. For each system—including various forms of Just Intonation, meantone temperaments, and extended Equal Temperaments (e.g., 19-TET, 31-TET)—we compute a unique spectral centroid profile across a tessellated pitch-timbre space. This profile quantifies the aggregate sensory dissonance and timbral brightness inherent to the system's dyadic and triadic combinations. By applying machine learning classifiers (e.g., Support Vector Machines) to these spectral centroid feature vectors, we achieve high accuracy in distinguishing between tuning systems from recorded audio excerpts of synthetic and acoustic instruments. This approach provides an empirical, signal-based method for verifying and exploring the perceptual characteristics of complex microtonal sound worlds.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectral Tesselation and Centroid Analysis for the Classification of Microtonal Tuning Systems

text: The interplay between timbre and harmony is a cornerstone of orchestration, yet its perceptual effects remain computationally underexplored. This paper investigates the influence of instrumental timbre on the perception of tonal harmonic function using a signal-driven approach. We employ a supervised Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) algorithm, constrained by a dictionary of instrumental templates, to decompose polyphonic audio signals into constituent source activations and spectral bases. From the harmonic content, we extract Harmonic Pitch Class Profiles (HPCP) to model the underlying chord progressions, while the spectral bases and their temporal activations provide a quantitative representation of the active instrumentation. Listeners' ratings of harmonic stability and function were collected for stimuli where the harmony was held constant while the orchestration was systematically varied. A regression model demonstrates that timbral features, specifically spectral flux and roughness derived from the NMF components, significantly modulate perceived harmonic tension and resolution, independent of the abstract chord progression. These findings quantitatively validate long-standing music-theoretical assertions about orchestration's role in articulating harmonic structure.
subject: Müzik
title: Decomposing Timbral Influence on Harmonic Function Perception: A Non-Negative Matrix Factorization Approach

text: This paper proposes a novel, unsupervised methodology for the discovery of hierarchical musical form from audio recordings, leveraging principles from Topological Data Analysis (TDA). Traditional approaches to structural segmentation often rely on detecting novelty or homogeneity in local feature sequences, failing to capture nested relationships like those in sonata or rondo forms. Our method begins by constructing a time-lag self-similarity matrix from a sequence of learned deep audio embeddings. Instead of conventional thresholding or path-finding algorithms, we treat this matrix as a point cloud in a high-dimensional space and compute its persistent homology. The resulting persistence diagrams reveal topological features (connected components, loops) at multiple scales, which correspond directly to repetitive and developmental sections of varying lengths. By analyzing the lifespans of these topological features, we can reconstruct a hierarchical segmentation tree that robustly identifies formal units from motives and phrases to large-scale thematic sections. Evaluation on a corpus of classical symphonies shows our TDA-based approach outperforms state-of-the-art segmentation algorithms in both boundary detection accuracy and hierarchical consistency.
subject: Müzik
title: Hierarchical Musical Form Discovery using Topological Data Analysis on Self-Similarity Matrices

text: This study presents a large-scale computational analysis of performance practice evolution in Chopin's Mazurkas, focusing on expressive timing and dynamics. We compiled a corpus of over 500 commercial recordings spanning from the early 20th century to the present. A novel score-to-performance alignment technique based on parametric time warping and constrained by a hierarchical beat-tracking model was developed to extract precise note-level onset deviations and MIDI-like velocity information from the audio. Statistical analysis of the derived microtiming profiles reveals a significant historical trend: a decrease in the variance of local tempo rubato and a more pronounced adherence to notated metrical structure in post-1960s recordings. Furthermore, we identify performer-specific dynamic palettes through clustering analysis of velocity contours, revealing distinct 'schools' of interpretation. Our findings provide quantitative evidence for a shift towards a more literalist interpretation of the musical score in modern performance practice, challenging qualitative historical narratives and providing a fine-grained empirical foundation for performance studies.
subject: Müzik
title: Microtiming and Dynamics in Chopin Mazurka Performances: A Cross-Decade Corpus Study using Parametric Time Warping

text: Neo-Riemannian theory has successfully modeled parsimonious voice leading in tonal music using geometric spaces like the Tonnetz. However, extending these models to post-tonal and atonal repertoires presents significant challenges due to the absence of a diatonic background structure. This paper introduces a generalized geometric framework for analyzing voice leading in atonal contexts based on orbifold-based pitch-class spaces. We construct unique topological orbifolds for significant set-classes (e.g., hexachords) from the atonal literature, where geometric proximity corresponds to minimal voice-leading displacement under transposition and inversion (T/I operations). Using this framework, we analyze excerpts from works by Schoenberg and Webern, demonstrating that seemingly disjunct harmonic successions can be understood as maximally efficient, short-path trajectories within these bespoke geometric spaces. The methodology quantifies voice-leading parsimony in a context-sensitive manner, revealing a latent quasi-tonal coherence in early atonal compositions and providing a powerful new analytical tool for post-tonal music theory.
subject: Müzik
title: Voice-Leading Parsimony in Atonal Music: A Geometric Approach Using Orbifold-Based Pitch-Class Spaces

text: State-of-the-art Automatic Music Transcription (AMT) systems, typically based on Convolutional or Recurrent Neural Networks, often produce musically implausible errors, such as harmonically inconsistent notes or discontinuous melodic lines. This paper proposes a novel transcription model that explicitly integrates music-theoretical principles of counterpoint to enhance performance. Our approach models the input time-frequency representation (e.g., a CQT spectrogram) as a graph, where nodes are time-frequency bins and edges encode potential melodic and harmonic relationships informed by rules of voice leading. We then employ a Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) to classify node activations (i.e., note presence). The GCN's architecture allows it to learn contextually, favoring note combinations that form consonant intervals and smooth melodic contours. Trained and evaluated on the MAPS dataset, our contrapuntally-informed GCN outperforms standard CNN-based baselines, particularly in reducing musically salient errors in complex polyphonic passages, thereby bridging the gap between signal-level processing and symbolic musical knowledge.
subject: Müzik
title: Contrapuntally-Informed Polyphonic Music Transcription using a Graph Convolutional Network

text: Neo-Riemannian theory primarily focuses on a small set of canonical transformations (P, L, R) operating on major and minor triads within 12-tone equal temperament (12-TET). This paper presents a generalized algorithmic framework for the systematic enumeration and classification of all possible parsimonious, contextually-defined transformations in any N-tone equal temperament (N-TET) system. Our method utilizes principles from computational group theory to define a 'transformation search space' for a given chord type and N-TET system. It identifies all operations that preserve a maximum number of common tones while satisfying group-theoretic closure properties. Applying this algorithm to non-standard systems like 19-TET and 24-TET, we uncover novel transformation groups with rich, non-diatonic structures. The resulting exhaustive catalog of transformations provides a theoretical foundation for extending transformational analysis beyond its conventional tonal confines and serves as a compositional tool for exploring the unique voice-leading possibilities inherent in microtonal harmonic systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Algorithmic Enumeration and Classification of Non-Standard Neo-Riemannian Transformations in N-TET Systems

text: The subtle, non-notated variations in timing and dynamics are crucial components of expressive musical performance. This research introduces a method for identifying and characterizing performer-specific 'expressive gestures' from audio recordings. We first extract high-resolution contours of micro-dynamics (log-RMS energy) and agogic accents (deviations from a beat-synchronous grid) from score-aligned performance data. The Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT) is then applied to these contours. The resulting scalograms provide a multi-resolution representation that localizes expressive events in both time and scale, effectively distinguishing short, sharp accents from broader phrase-level shaping. By applying template matching and clustering algorithms in the wavelet domain, we successfully identify recurring, idiosyncratic gestural patterns unique to individual performers across different pieces. This methodology allows for a quantitative stylometry of performance, enabling objective comparisons between artists and providing a powerful tool for understanding the microstructure of musical expression beyond simple statistical measures of rubato or dynamic range.
subject: Müzik
title: Characterizing Performer-Specific Expressive Gestures using Continuous Wavelet Transform on Micro-Dynamic and Agogic Contours

text: The relationship between a conductor's gestures and the resultant orchestral sound is fundamental to ensemble performance, yet it remains poorly understood from a quantitative perspective. This paper presents a cross-modal analysis correlating high-resolution conductor motion-capture data with multi-channel orchestral audio recordings. We extract kinematic features from the conductor's gesture, including baton tip velocity, acceleration, and spatial trajectory complexity. Simultaneously, we compute a suite of audio features from the orchestral recording, such as spectral centroid, dynamic range, and inter-instrument synchronization jitter. A deep canonical correlation analysis (DCCA) model is employed to learn a shared latent space that maximizes the correlation between the two modalities. Our results reveal strong, non-linear mappings between specific gestural archetypes and measurable sonic outcomes. For example, sharp, vertical beat patterns are highly correlated with precise tutti onsets and increased high-frequency energy in the brass section. This data-driven approach provides empirical insight into the conductor-orchestra feedback loop and lays the groundwork for developing more sophisticated pedagogical tools for conductors.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Correlation of Conductor Gestures and Orchestral Audio Features using Deep Canonical Correlation Analysis

text: The glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor (GLP-1R), a Class B G-protein coupled receptor, is a critical regulator of glucose homeostasis. Therapeutic agonists exhibit signaling bias, preferentially activating G-protein pathways over β-arrestin recruitment, yet the structural basis for this phenomenon remains elusive. Here, we present the 3.1 Å resolution cryo-electron microscopy structure of human GLP-1R in a complex with the biased agonist exendin-P5 and a nucleotide-free Gαsβγ heterotrimer. The structure reveals that exendin-P5 induces a distinct outward displacement of the intracellular end of transmembrane helix 6 (TM6), which is less pronounced than that induced by non-biased agonists. This specific conformation reconfigures the cytoplasmic cavity, optimizing interactions with Gαs while simultaneously occluding key residues required for GRK-mediated phosphorylation and subsequent β-arrestin engagement. These findings provide a high-resolution blueprint for allosteric modulation at the G-protein interface and establish a structural paradigm for the rational design of biased agonists with improved therapeutic profiles.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of a Class B GPCR Reveals a Mechanism for Biased Agonism

text: Transcriptional regulation in eukaryotes is often characterized by stochastic bursts of activity, but the underlying molecular mechanisms controlling burst kinetics are poorly understood. We demonstrate that the Mediator complex, a key coactivator, undergoes liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) to form biomolecular condensates at super-enhancers. Using in vitro reconstitution, single-molecule tracking, and high-resolution microscopy in murine embryonic stem cells, we show that the intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs) of the MED1 subunit are essential for phase separation. Phosphorylation of specific serine residues within these IDRs by CDK8 modulates the material properties of the condensates, transitioning them from a dynamic liquid-like state to a more gel-like state. This transition alters the residence time of RNA Polymerase II, thereby tuning transcriptional burst frequency and amplitude. Our results posit that the tunable phase behavior of Mediator condensates acts as a biophysical switch to control the stochastic dynamics of gene expression.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of the Mediator Complex Orchestrates Transcriptional Bursting

text: The faithful propagation of epigenetic states, such as those mediated by Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2), is fundamental to cell identity. While the catalytic activity of PRC2 in establishing H3K27me3 is well-characterized, the mechanisms ensuring its robust maintenance through cell division are less clear. We have identified a previously unannotated long non-coding RNA, which we term CHRONOS (Chromatin Organizer for Noctuid Silencing), that is essential for this process. Using a combination of RNA immunoprecipitation sequencing (RIP-seq) and proximity-dependent biotinylation (BioID), we demonstrate that CHRONOS directly binds to both the EZH2 subunit of PRC2 and the H3K27me3 mark itself via a cryptic reader domain. CRISPRi-mediated knockdown of CHRONOS leads to a progressive, genome-wide erosion of H3K27me3 domains over multiple cell cycles, reactivating key developmental genes. Our findings uncover a positive feedback loop wherein a lncRNA acts as a scaffold to stabilize PRC2 on its own catalytic product, ensuring epigenetic memory.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Novel lncRNA, CHRONOS, Scaffolds PRC2 to Facilitate Polycomb Domain Maintenance

text: Cellular differentiation pathways are governed by complex interplay between the transcriptome and the epigenome. Dissecting these dynamics requires multi-modal single-cell analysis. We developed a novel computational framework to integrate single-cell RNA-seq (scRNA-seq) and ATAC-seq (scATAC-seq) data, applying it to map the developmental landscape of murine pancreatic islets. Our trajectory inference analysis revealed a previously uncharacterized, transient progenitor population co-expressing Ngn3 and Pdx1. This population exhibits a unique chromatin accessibility signature, with poised enhancers for terminal endocrine differentiation genes like Insulin and Glucagon. Gene regulatory network reconstruction identified the transcription factor MafB as a pivotal node that is activated within this state, priming cells for either α- or β-cell fates. This high-resolution lineage map provides unprecedented insight into the regulatory logic of cell fate decisions and pinpoints a critical bifurcation point in endocrine cell specification, offering new targets for regenerative medicine.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated Single-Cell Multi-Omics Delineates a Transient Progenitor State in Pancreatic Endocrine Fate Commitment

text: Cells adapt to environmental stress by rapidly remodeling their proteome, often through mechanisms of translational control. While the phosphorylation of eIF2α is a known nexus of the Integrated Stress Response (ISR), its global impact on translation initiation fidelity remains incompletely defined. Utilizing ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) in human cells subjected to ER stress, we mapped translational landscapes with codon resolution. Our analysis revealed stress-induced, preferential translation of thousands of upstream open reading frames (uORFs), many of which were previously unannotated. This uORF translation robustly repressed synthesis from the downstream, canonical coding sequence of critical housekeeping and growth-promoting genes. This reprogramming was strictly dependent on GCN2/PERK-mediated eIF2α phosphorylation. These data demonstrate that selective uORF utilization is a pervasive and potent mechanism for globally reconfiguring the translatome, allowing cells to mount an efficient and context-specific response to adverse conditions.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Ribosome Profiling Reveals Widespread Translational Reprogramming via Upstream Open Reading Frames During the Integrated Stress Response

text: The maintenance of telomere integrity is paramount for genomic stability and the prevention of cellular senescence. The CTC1-STN1-TEN1 (CST) complex is a key player in telomere metabolism, primarily known for its role in C-strand fill-in. Here, we uncover a critical, telomerase-independent function for CST in preserving telomeric replication fork stability. Using conditional knockout mouse embryonic fibroblasts combined with DNA fiber analysis and S9.6 immunofluorescence, we show that acute CST depletion results in severe replication stress localized specifically at telomeres. This is characterized by fork stalling and the accumulation of RNA-DNA hybrids (R-loops) and G-quadruplex structures. Furthermore, electron microscopy of replication intermediates reveals aberrant telomeric structures consistent with unresolved replication stress. Our data indicate that CST acts as a crucial replisome-associated factor that actively suppresses the formation of transcription-associated secondary structures, thereby preventing catastrophic replication fork collapse at the chromosome end.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The CST Complex Prevents Telomeric R-Loop Accumulation to Safeguard Replication Fork Progression

text: Adenine base editors (ABEs) represent a powerful tool for precision genome engineering, but their therapeutic application is hampered by concerns over off-target effects, including transcriptome-wide RNA deamination. We hypothesized that transient, targeted delivery could constrain editor activity, thereby increasing the on-target to off-target activity ratio. We engineered a novel lipid nanoparticle (LNP) formulation for the co-delivery of an engineered ABE8e mRNA and a guide RNA. In a mouse model of Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome, a single intravenous injection resulted in high-efficiency correction of the pathogenic LMNA c.1824C>T mutation in the liver. Crucially, comprehensive analysis using CIRCLE-seq for DNA off-targets and deep RNA-sequencing for RNA off-targets revealed a profound reduction in off-target editing compared to conventional viral delivery methods. This work demonstrates that optimizing the pharmacokinetics of base editor delivery is a viable strategy to achieve a therapeutically relevant window of high efficacy and improved safety.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Off-Target RNA Editing by Adenine Base Editors Is Mitigated by Engineered LNP Delivery

text: Proteostasis is maintained by coordinated actions of the ubiquitin-proteasome system and autophagy. While selective autophagy is known to clear toxic protein aggregates characteristic of neurodegenerative diseases, the specific molecular machinery targeting these substrates remains enigmatic. Here, we identify the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRIM50 as a critical regulator of aggrephagy. Using proximity-labeling proteomics, we found TRIM50 is robustly recruited to mutant Huntingtin (mHTT) inclusion bodies. We demonstrate that TRIM50 directly ubiquitinates aggregated mHTT with K63-linked chains, which then serve as a high-affinity binding platform for the autophagy receptor p62/SQSTM1. Depletion of TRIM50, but not other related TRIM-family members, leads to a significant accumulation of mHTT aggregates and increased cytotoxicity, a phenotype that cannot be rescued by proteasome inhibition. These findings elucidate a specific ubiquitination code for substrate selection in aggrephagy and position TRIM50 as a key mediator in the clearance of proteotoxic species.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Selective Autophagy of Protein Aggregates is Mediated by the E3 Ligase TRIM50 through K63-linked Ubiquitination

text: Synthetic lethality between PARP inhibitors and homologous recombination (HR) deficiency, particularly in BRCA1/2-mutated cancers, is a clinically validated paradigm. However, the efficacy of this approach in the context of other DNA damage response (DDR) defects, such as ATM deficiency, is less established. We characterized a novel PARP inhibitor, AZD9574, which exhibits significantly enhanced PARP1-DNA trapping activity compared to clinically approved agents. In a panel of isogenic colorectal cancer cell lines, AZD9574 induced profound synthetic lethality in ATM-deficient cells. Mechanistically, DNA fiber analysis and comet assays revealed that the potent trapping activity of AZD9574 causes widespread replication fork stalling and collapse, generating complex DNA lesions that are uniquely reliant on ATM for resolution. The resulting genomic instability leads to mitotic catastrophe and apoptosis. These results demonstrate that enhancing PARP trapping can expand the synthetic lethality landscape to include ATM deficiency, offering a promising therapeutic strategy.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A PARP1-Trapping Inhibitor Exhibits Potent Synthetic Lethality with ATM Deficiency via Replication Catastrophe

text: The precise temporal regulation of gene expression is essential for orchestrating neuronal differentiation. N6-methyladenosine (m6A) is the most abundant internal mRNA modification, but its role in neurodevelopmental timing is not fully understood. By performing m6A-sequencing (MeRIP-seq) at high temporal resolution throughout the differentiation of human embryonic stem cells into cortical neurons, we uncovered dynamic waves of m6A deposition. An early wave, catalyzed by the METTL3/METTL14 writer complex, targets transcripts encoding key neuroprogenitor maintenance factors, including SOX2 and PAX6. This methylation recruits the YTHDF2 reader protein, promoting rapid mRNA decay and facilitating a timely exit from the progenitor state. Conversely, a later wave targets mRNAs crucial for synaptic maturation. Genetic ablation of METTL3 stalls differentiation at the progenitor stage. Our findings establish the m6A epitranscriptome as a critical rheostat that choreographs the temporal succession of gene expression programs driving mammalian neurogenesis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dynamic m6A Epitranscriptomic Remodeling Governs the Temporal Cascade of Neurogenesis

text: We introduce a novel multipartite Bell-type inequality formulated within the Collins-Gisin-Linden-Massar-Popescu (CGLMP) framework, designed to probe non-local correlations in N-qubit systems beyond the standard Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) paradox. Our formalism employs a symmetric operator basis that simplifies the derivation of the classical bound, or local realism limit, which scales polynomially with N. We investigate the quantum mechanical violation of this inequality using generalized N-qubit GHZ states subjected to depolarizing noise. Numerical simulations demonstrate that the quantum prediction maximally violates the inequality by a factor proportional to 2^((N-1)/2), consistent with Tsirelson's bound for bipartite systems. Our results establish a more robust witness for genuine N-partite entanglement, exhibiting enhanced resilience to decoherence compared to previous inequalities. This work provides a scalable experimental protocol for testing macroscopic realism and has significant implications for certifying entanglement in quantum networks and measurement-based quantum computation.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Quantum Non-Locality in Multi-Partite Systems via a Generalized Bell-CHSH Inequality

text: The search for primordial B-mode polarization in the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) is a primary objective of modern cosmology, as its detection would constitute definitive evidence for an inflationary epoch. However, this faint signal is contaminated by B-modes generated through gravitational lensing of dominant E-modes by large-scale structures. We present a novel delensing algorithm based on a convolutional neural network (CNN) trained on high-fidelity hydrodynamical simulations, which reconstructs the lensing potential with unprecedented accuracy. Applying this methodology to simulated data mirroring the specifications of next-generation CMB experiments like CMB-S4, we demonstrate a significant reduction in the lensing-induced B-mode power spectrum variance. This enhances the sensitivity to the tensor-to-scalar ratio, r. Our Bayesian parameter estimation forecasts a projected upper limit of r < 5x10^-4 (95% C.L.), providing a powerful tool to constrain the energy scale of inflation and distinguish between competing inflationary models.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraints on Primordial Tensor Perturbations from CMB B-mode Polarization Delensing

text: We report a combined experimental and theoretical investigation of Cs2Cu3SnF12, a candidate material for a quantum spin liquid (QSL) state on a two-dimensional Kagome lattice. High-resolution inelastic neutron scattering (INS) experiments performed at milli-Kelvin temperatures reveal a striking absence of magnetic Bragg peaks, indicative of suppressed long-range magnetic order. Instead, we observe a broad continuum of scattering intensity, a hallmark of fractionalized excitations. To interpret these results, we employ large-scale density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) simulations on the S=1/2 Heisenberg model for the Kagome lattice. The calculated dynamical structure factor S(q,ω) shows remarkable agreement with the INS data, confirming the presence of deconfined spinon excitations. Our findings provide compelling evidence for a gapped Z2 topological QSL ground state, advancing our understanding of emergent quantum phenomena in frustrated magnetic systems and their potential application in topological quantum computing.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergent Fractionalized Excitations in a Kagome Lattice Antiferromagnet

text: We investigate the non-equilibrium quantum phase transition between a Mott insulator and a superfluid in a driven-dissipative two-dimensional Bose-Hubbard model. Using a Keldysh functional integral formalism combined with a field-theoretic renormalization group (RG) analysis, we characterize the critical behavior of the system. The interplay between coherent Hamiltonian dynamics, external driving, and incoherent dissipation due to coupling with a thermal reservoir fundamentally alters the universality class from its equilibrium counterpart. We calculate the critical exponents z, ν, and β to two-loop order, finding significant deviations from the (2+1)D XY model. Our results indicate that dissipation acts as a relevant perturbation at the quantum critical point, driving the system to a new non-equilibrium fixed point. This theoretical framework provides a comprehensive description of criticality in open quantum many-body systems, relevant to experiments with ultracold atoms in optical lattices and exciton-polariton condensates.
subject: Fizik
title: Universality and Critical Exponents of a Driven-Dissipative Mott Insulator-Superfluid Phase Transition

text: Supersymmetric extensions of the Standard Model (SM) often predict a light top squark (stop) to stabilize the Higgs mass. We explore the phenomenological implications of such scenarios, particularly in regions of the parameter space where the mass difference between the stop (t1) and the lightest neutralino (χ1^0) is small. In this compressed-mass regime, conventional search strategies lose sensitivity. We propose a new analysis leveraging monojet events, arising from initial-state radiation, in conjunction with large missing transverse energy (MET). Using Monte Carlo event generation with Pythia8 and a detailed detector simulation with Delphes, we analyze the prospects for the High-Luminosity Large Hadron Collider (HL-LHC) at √s = 14 TeV with an integrated luminosity of 3000 fb^-1. Our statistical analysis projects a 95% C.L. exclusion reach for stop masses up to 850 GeV for mass splittings below 20 GeV, significantly extending the discovery potential for challenging supersymmetric scenarios.
subject: Fizik
title: Phenomenological Constraints on Light Stop Scenarios from Monojet and Missing Energy Searches at the HL-LHC

text: We present results from a suite of fully general-relativistic numerical simulations of intermediate-mass black hole (IMBH) binary mergers, with mass ratios q = M2/M1 ranging from 0.1 to 0.5. The simulations, performed with the Spectral Einstein Code (SpEC), explore highly eccentric orbits (e > 0.7), which are expected to be prevalent in dynamically active environments like globular clusters. We compute the gravitational waveforms, including higher-order multipole modes (l > 2), and analyze their spectral features. The significant eccentricity imprints periodic power modulations in the inspiral phase and excites a burst of high-frequency radiation at periastron passages, which are distinct from quasi-circular mergers. We demonstrate that these features are detectable by the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA network and future detectors like the Einstein Telescope. The unique morphology of these eccentric waveforms provides a powerful tool to probe the formation channels of IMBHs and the dynamical evolution of dense stellar systems.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Wave Signatures from Eccentric Intermediate-Mass Black Hole Binary Mergers in Dense Stellar Clusters

text: We investigate the quantization and one-loop renormalizability of a non-Abelian SU(N) gauge theory extended with quadratic higher-derivative terms of the form F_μν (-D^2) F^μν, a model inspired by Lee-Wick quantum gravity. Utilizing the background field method and dimensional regularization, we compute the ultraviolet divergences for the gauge, ghost, and scalar fields. We demonstrate that the model is renormalizable at one-loop, with all divergences absorbed by a redefinition of the initial Lagrangian parameters and fields. The Slavnov-Taylor identities, crucial for preserving gauge invariance, are shown to hold after renormalization. Furthermore, we analyze the tree-level unitarity of the theory by examining the propagator structure. The higher-derivative terms introduce massive ghost states, whose contributions to scattering amplitudes are carefully handled via the Lee-Wick prescription to ensure unitarity of the S-matrix, providing a consistent framework for UV-complete field theories beyond the Standard Model.
subject: Fizik
title: Renormalization and Unitarity in a Non-Abelian Gauge Theory with Higher-Derivative Kinetic Terms

text: We theoretically propose and numerically demonstrate an ultra-compact, dynamically tunable biosensor based on a silicon photonic crystal nanocavity coupled to a waveguide and integrated with a monolayer of graphene. The device architecture facilitates a sharp Fano resonance, arising from the interference between a discrete cavity mode and the waveguide continuum. By electrostatically gating the graphene layer, its Fermi level can be shifted, modifying its complex conductivity and thereby tuning the resonance line shape and position via the thermo-optic effect. This active control enables optimization of the sensor's performance in real-time. Finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) simulations show that the device achieves an ultra-high quality factor (Q > 10^5) and a sensitivity of 400 nm/RIU (refractive index unit). We project a figure of merit (FOM) exceeding 10^4 and a limit of detection capable of identifying single-molecule binding events, opening new avenues for label-free diagnostics.
subject: Fizik
title: Dynamically Tunable Fano Resonances in a Graphene-Integrated Photonic Crystal Nanocavity for Ultrasensitive Biosensing

text: The Jarzynski equality provides a profound link between equilibrium free energy differences and the statistics of work performed during non-equilibrium processes governed by unitary dynamics. We derive a generalization of this fluctuation theorem for quantum systems undergoing arbitrary non-unitary evolution, described by completely positive and trace-preserving (CPTP) maps. By employing a two-point measurement protocol on an enlarged system-ancilla space, we obtain an exact equality that relates a modified free energy difference to an exponential average of a quantity we define as 'channel work'. This generalized relation incorporates the effects of both Hamiltonian driving and dissipative environmental interactions. Our result reduces to the standard Jarzynski equality in the limit of unitary evolution and provides a fundamental thermodynamic constraint on the behavior of open quantum systems. It offers a new tool for probing the thermodynamics of quantum computation and information processing protocols.
subject: Fizik
title: A Fluctuation Theorem for Quantum Channels: Generalizing the Jarzynski Equality to Non-Unitary Dynamics

text: The intermittent nature of energy dissipation in turbulent flows remains a central unresolved problem in classical physics. We investigate this phenomenon through multifractal analysis of data from a high-resolution direct numerical simulation (DNS) of the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations on a 4096^3 periodic grid, reaching a Taylor-scale Reynolds number Re_λ ≈ 1200. We compute the singularity spectrum, D(h), of the local energy dissipation rate ε(x,t) by analyzing the scaling of its moments. Our results show a broad spectrum of Hölder exponents h, confirming the multifractal character of the dissipation field and representing a significant departure from the linear scaling predicted by the 1941 Kolmogorov theory (K41). The shape of D(h) is well-approximated by a log-Poisson stochastic cascade model. These findings provide strong quantitative support for the idea that dissipation is concentrated on spatially intermittent, fractal-like structures, which are dynamically crucial for the energy cascade in fully developed turbulence.
subject: Fizik
title: Multifractal Analysis of Energy Dissipation in High-Reynolds-Number Homogeneous Isotropic Turbulence

text: The Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) is a fundamental epigenetic regulator responsible for catalyzing histone H3 lysine 27 trimethylation (H3K27me3), a hallmark of facultative heterochromatin. Its catalytic activity is allosterically modulated by various cofactors, yet the precise mechanism remains elusive. Here, we present the cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of human PRC2 in complex with a nucleosome substrate and the JARID2-AEBP2 heterodimer at 2.8 Å resolution. The structure reveals that JARID2 and AEBP2 cooperatively engage both the EZH2 catalytic subunit and the EED regulatory subunit, inducing a significant conformational rearrangement that repositions the SET domain for optimal H3 tail access. Our findings demonstrate that JARID2's C-terminal tail mimics a DNA strand, anchoring the complex to the nucleosome, while AEBP2 stabilizes the interaction with the H3 tail. This tripartite interaction provides a mechanistic framework for how sub-stoichiometric cofactors synergistically enhance PRC2 processivity, offering insights into aberrant gene silencing in developmental disorders and oncology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural Basis of Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 Allosteric Activation by JARID2-AEBP2 Heterodimers

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are increasingly recognized as architectural components of nuclear biomolecular condensates. The lncRNA NEAT1 is essential for the formation of paraspeckles, yet its role in regulating transcription remains contested. Utilizing super-resolution microscopy and fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP), we demonstrate that NEAT1 undergoes liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) with key RNA-binding proteins, including NONO and SFPQ, to form dynamic transcriptional hubs at super-enhancer sites. Chromatin interaction analysis by Hi-C reveals that these NEAT1-driven condensates physically bridge enhancers and promoters, facilitating transcriptional bursting. Depletion of NEAT1 dissolves these condensates, attenuates enhancer-promoter looping, and reduces target gene expression co-variance. Our results posit NEAT1 as a multivalent scaffold that modulates the material properties and composition of transcriptional condensates, thereby fine-tuning gene expression programs in response to cellular stress. This mechanism represents a paradigm for lncRNA-mediated spatiotemporal control of the transcriptome.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The lncRNA NEAT1 Modulates Transcriptional Condensate Dynamics via Scaffold-Mediated Phase Separation

text: Cytosine base editors (CBEs) enable precise C•G-to-T•A conversions in genomic DNA but can induce undesirable off-target mutations, hindering their therapeutic translation. Here, we developed a structure-guided, phage-assisted continuous evolution (PACE) platform to engineer novel variants of the human APOBEC3A deaminase with enhanced substrate specificity and diminished Cas9-independent deamination activity. The resulting editor, hA3A-evo, exhibits a >50-fold reduction in genome-wide off-target single-nucleotide variants compared to the widely used BE4max editor, as quantified by unbiased whole-genome sequencing. Structural analysis reveals that evolved mutations reshape the enzyme's DNA-binding interface, increasing its dependence on the R-loop structure formed by the Cas9-sgRNA complex. These high-fidelity base editors significantly improve the safety profile for somatic and germline gene correction, providing a more robust tool for both basic research and clinical applications requiring precise genomic alterations without compromising genomic integrity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: High-Fidelity Cytosine Base Editors Engineered via Phage-Assisted Continuous Evolution Mitigate Off-Target Deamination

text: The laminar organization of the mammalian neocortex is established through a complex sequence of neuronal proliferation, migration, and differentiation. To dissect the molecular underpinnings of this process, we generated a high-resolution spatiotemporal atlas of the developing human neocortex using integrated single-cell RNA sequencing and multiplexed error-robust fluorescence in situ hybridization (MERFISH). Pseudotime trajectory analysis identified distinct transcriptomic signatures demarcating the transition from radial glia to intermediate progenitors and post-mitotic neurons. We uncovered a previously unappreciated gene regulatory network, governed by the transcription factor ZEB2, that specifically controls the expression of cytoskeletal modulators crucial for inter-kinetic nuclear migration in outer radial glia. In situ validation confirmed that this network's activity spatially correlates with neuronal positioning in the cortical plate. This comprehensive dataset provides an invaluable resource for understanding corticogenesis and offers mechanistic insights into the etiology of neurodevelopmental disorders associated with neuronal migration defects.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatiotemporal Transcriptomic Atlas of the Developing Human Neocortex Reveals Lineage-Specific Regulation of Neuronal Migration

text: Maintenance of telomere integrity is paramount for genome stability, yet the mechanisms governing lagging-strand (C-strand) replication remain poorly defined. The CST complex (CTC1-STN1-TEN1) is essential for terminating telomerase activity and initiating C-strand fill-in synthesis. Using quantitative mass spectrometry-based phosphoproteomics, we identified novel ATM kinase-dependent phosphorylation sites on the CTC1 subunit that are induced upon replication stress. We show that phosphorylation of these sites is a prerequisite for CST's interaction with the Polα-primase complex at stalled replication forks near the G-overhang. Abrogation of these phosphorylation events via CRISPR-Cas9-mediated point mutations leads to unresolved C-strand under-replication, telomere fragility, and activation of an ATR-dependent DNA damage response. Our findings unveil a critical regulatory axis where ATM kinase orchestrates a switch in CST function from a telomerase-inhibitory role to a pro-replicative one, ensuring the complete duplication of chromosome ends.
subject: Biyoloji
title: ATM-Dependent Phosphorylation of the CST Complex Orchestrates Fill-in Synthesis During Telomere C-strand Replication

text: Proteostasis is critical for neuronal function, and its failure is a hallmark of neurodegenerative diseases. Chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA) selectively degrades cytosolic proteins containing a KFERQ-like motif. We investigated the role of CMA in maintaining synaptic proteostasis. Using proximity-ligation assays and synaptosome fractionation from a mouse model of CMA deficiency, we found that the core synaptic vesicle fusion machinery, including SNAP25 and VAMP2, are bona fide CMA substrates. Impaired CMA activity leads to the accumulation of these SNARE proteins, which then undergo aberrant K63-linked polyubiquitination by the E3 ligase CHIP. This modification does not target them for proteasomal degradation but instead promotes their sequestration into insoluble aggregates, resulting in impaired neurotransmitter release and significant synaptic dysfunction. These findings link CMA dysregulation directly to synaptotoxicity, revealing a novel mechanism whereby failure of selective autophagy compromises the synaptic vesicle cycle and contributes to neurodegeneration.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Chaperone-Mediated Autophagy Dysregulation Impairs Synaptic Proteostasis through Aberrant Ubiquitination of SNARE Complexes

text: The expansion of the genetic code to include non-canonical amino acids (ncAAs) offers powerful tools for protein engineering and probing molecular interactions. We report the development of a highly efficient and orthogonal ribosome-tRNA-aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase system in *Escherichia coli* for the site-specific incorporation of the photo-crosslinkable amino acid, p-benzoyl-L-phenylalanine (Bpa). By evolving the *Methanocaldococcus jannaschii* tyrosyl-tRNA synthetase and engineering a polyspecific, quadruplet-codon-recognizing tRNA(pyl), we achieved over 95% incorporation fidelity at multiple UTAG amber stop codons. We applied this system to install Bpa at the substrate-binding interface of the TEV protease. Upon UV irradiation, we captured a covalent enzyme-substrate intermediate, providing unprecedented structural snapshots of the catalytic cycle. This robust genetic code expansion platform enables the in vivo trapping of transient protein-protein interactions and facilitates the rational design of biocatalysts with novel functionalities, surpassing the limitations of conventional biochemical and structural methods.
subject: Biyoloji
title: An Orthogonal Ribosome-tRNA System Enables Site-Specific Incorporation of Photo-Crosslinkable Amino Acids into Proteolytic Enzymes
