text: N6-methyladenosine (m6A) is the most abundant internal modification on eukaryotic mRNA, influencing RNA stability, splicing, and translation. Its role in hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) fate decisions remains poorly understood. Through conditional knockout of the m6A writer component METTL3 in murine HSCs, coupled with m6A-seq and 3'-end sequencing, we demonstrate that m6A deposition is critical for maintaining HSC quiescence and self-renewal. Mechanistically, METTL3-mediated m6A marking in the 3' UTR of key splicing factor transcripts, including SRSF2 and U2AF1, recruits the reader protein YTHDF2, which paradoxically stabilizes these transcripts by preventing their cleavage at proximal alternative polyadenylation (APA) sites. Loss of m6A leads to premature cleavage and polyadenylation, producing truncated, unstable transcripts. This results in global splicing dysregulation and forces HSCs towards myeloid differentiation. Our work uncovers a novel m6A-APA-splicing regulatory cascade essential for hematopoietic homeostasis, providing a new layer of epi-transcriptomic control in stem cell biology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dynamic m6A RNA Methylation Mediated by the METTL3-METTL14 Complex Regulates Splicing Factor Alternative Polyadenylation in Hematopoietic Stem Cells

text: Pre-mRNA splicing is executed by the spliceosome, a multi-megadalton ribonucleoprotein machine that undergoes extensive compositional and conformational rearrangements. The catalytic step of exon ligation occurs within the P-complex, a transient and poorly characterized intermediate. Here, we report the 3.1 Å resolution cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of the human P-complex, purified from HeLa cell extracts. The structure captures the spliceosome immediately after intron lariat formation, with the 3'-hydroxyl of the 5' exon poised for nucleophilic attack on the 3' splice site. The catalytic core, formed by U2, U5, and U6 snRNAs, adopts a conformation distinct from that of the preceding C* complex, with the U5 snRNP protein Prp8 acting as a molecular clamp to position the two exons. This high-resolution snapshot reveals the intricate coordination of catalytic metal ions and provides a definitive structural basis for the second transesterification reaction, completing our molecular understanding of the splicing cycle.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Human Spliceosomal P-complex Captures the Active Site Poised for Exon Ligation

text: Accurate chromosome segregation during mitosis relies on the precise regulation of sister chromatid cohesion, which is maintained at the centromere until anaphase onset. The Chromosomal Passenger Complex (CPC), with its catalytic subunit Aurora B kinase, is a master regulator of this process. Using a FRET-based biosensor and quantitative phosphoproteomics, we uncovered a Plk1-dependent positive feedback loop that hyperactivates Aurora B at inner centromeres during metaphase. We show that Plk1 phosphorylates the CPC subunit INCENP, enhancing its affinity for Aurora B and triggering a surge in kinase activity. This localized hyperactivation is essential for phosphorylating the cohesin protector Sgo1, preventing its premature cleavage by separase. Inhibition of either Plk1 or this specific INCENP phosphorylation leads to catastrophic loss of centromeric cohesion and widespread aneuploidy. Our findings delineate a critical signaling circuit that reinforces the spindle assembly checkpoint and safeguards genomic stability, offering potential therapeutic targets for cancers characterized by chromosomal instability.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Aurora B Kinase Phospho-regulates the Chromosomal Passenger Complex to Ensure Centromeric Cohesion Fidelity via a Plk1-dependent Feedback Loop

text: This paper introduces a novel deep learning framework for automated Schenkerian analysis directly from audio signals. Our model employs a multi-stage architecture, beginning with a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for robust CQT-based pitch salience estimation, followed by a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) network to model temporal harmonic dependencies. The core innovation is a graph-based parsing module that interprets the network's output to reconstruct hierarchical Schenkerian structures, identifying the Urlinie, Bassbrechung, and intermediate prolongational levels. We trained the system on a newly curated dataset of annotated recordings of J.S. Bach's chorales and Chopin's preludes. The results demonstrate a significant improvement over existing symbolic-domain methods in correctly identifying fundamental structures, achieving a 78% F1-score on foreground-level reductions. This work represents a critical step towards bridging the gap between computational audio analysis and abstract music-theoretic formalisms, enabling scalable musicological inquiry without reliance on symbolic intermediaries.
subject: Müzik
title: A Deep Learning Framework for Schenkerian Analysis from Audio Signals

text: While neo-Riemannian theory has extensively modeled chromatic harmony through geometric transformations on the Tonnetz, its relationship with musical timbre remains largely unexplored. This study investigates the correlation between timbral feature trajectories and neo-Riemannian operations in late-Romantic orchestral music. We apply a suite of timbral descriptors, including Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs), spectral centroid, and spectral flux, to audio recordings of works by Wagner and Strauss. A synchronized analysis maps these timbral vectors to sequences of P, L, and R transformations derived from harmonic analysis. Using canonical correlation analysis (CCA), we reveal statistically significant covariances between specific timbral shifts and transformational types. For instance, P-transformations correlate strongly with increases in spectral brightness, while L-transformations are associated with changes in timbral homogeneity. These findings suggest that orchestration and timbre are not merely coloristic but are syntactically integrated with harmonic function, offering a new, multi-parametric dimension to transformational theory.
subject: Müzik
title: Timbral Feature Trajectories as Correlates of Neo-Riemannian Transformations in Late-Romantic Orchestral Music

text: The combinatorial complexity of verifying adherence to Fuxian principles in multi-voice counterpoint presents a significant computational challenge. This paper reconceptualizes the problem of contrapuntal rule validation as a Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) problem, solvable via quantum annealing. We formulate a novel Hamiltonian whose ground state corresponds to a maximally parsimonious and rule-compliant voice-leading solution between given harmonic pillars. Each potential melodic motion is encoded as a qubit, and constraints—such as prohibitions on parallel fifths, unresolved dissonances, and improper melodic leaps—are encoded as penalty terms in the QUBO matrix. We tested this quantum-assisted framework on a D-Wave quantum annealer, analyzing complex polyphonic excerpts from Palestrina and Lassus. Our method successfully identified subtle rule infractions and proposed optimal resolutions with a computational speedup of several orders of magnitude over classical exhaustive search algorithms, demonstrating the potential of quantum computing for rigorous music-theoretic analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: A Quantum-Assisted Approach to Contrapuntal Rule Validation via Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization

text: This research presents a Bayesian inference framework for estimating the historical tuning temperament of keyboard instruments from monophonic audio recordings. The model probabilistically reconstructs the underlying temperament by analyzing subtle deviations in the partial frequencies of recorded tones. A sophisticated pitch estimation algorithm first extracts fundamental frequencies and their prominent inharmonic partials. These observations serve as evidence in a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) simulation that samples from the posterior distribution of possible cents-deviations for each of the twelve pitch classes. The model’s prior is informed by a corpus of known historical temperaments, including Pythagorean, meantone, and various well-tempered systems. When applied to recordings of harpsichords and fortepianos, our method successfully distinguishes between different temperament families with over 90% accuracy and provides credible intervals for the tuning of each note. This approach offers a powerful, non-invasive tool for organology and historical performance practice research.
subject: Müzik
title: Bayesian Inference for Historical Temperament Estimation from Inharmonic Partials in Audio Recordings

text: Understanding large-scale musical form requires comprehending the high-dimensional relationships between constituent sections. This paper employs manifold learning techniques to visualize the latent geometric space of musical form. We first compute a self-similarity matrix from a sequence of time-localized timbral and harmonic features (chromagrams and MFCCs) extracted from an audio recording. Subsequently, we treat this matrix as a weighted adjacency graph and apply Laplacian Eigenmaps, a non-linear dimensionality reduction algorithm, to project the musical structure onto a low-dimensional manifold. The resulting embedding provides an intuitive visualization where temporally distant but thematically related sections cluster together. We apply this methodology to a corpus of classical sonata-form movements, demonstrating that the learned manifold effectively separates exposition, development, and recapitulation sections into distinct geometric regions. This topological representation of form offers a novel analytical lens that transcends conventional linear and hierarchical models, revealing deep structural symmetries.
subject: Müzik
title: Visualizing the Latent Space of Musical Form through Laplacian Eigenmaps on Audio Self-Similarity Matrices

text: Expressive performance timing is a crucial yet computationally elusive aspect of music. We propose a cross-modal attention-based neural network to model expressive microtiming deviations by jointly analyzing musical scores and their corresponding audio performances. The system utilizes Optical Music Recognition (OMR) to convert score images into a symbolic representation, which is then aligned with an audio-derived chromagram sequence via a subsequence Dynamic Time Warping algorithm. The core of our model is a transformer network with a cross-modal attention mechanism that learns to predict local tempo variations (agogic accents) in the audio based on specific notational contexts (e.g., harmonic tension, phrase boundaries, articulation marks) in the score. Trained on the Mazurka Project dataset, our model predicts expressive timing profiles that correlate highly with human performances (Pearson's r = 0.82), significantly outperforming baseline models reliant on audio features alone. This provides a robust computational model of performance practice.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Attention Networks for Modeling Expressive Microtiming from Joint Analysis of Scores and Audio

text: We introduce a graph-theoretic framework for the analysis of voice-leading parsimony in polyphonic audio signals. The methodology begins with multi-pitch estimation to extract concurrent melodic streams from a complex audio mixture. These streams are modeled as nodes in a time-varying graph, where edges represent potential voice-leading connections between successive time frames. Edge weights are computed based on a psychoacoustically informed cost function that penalizes large melodic leaps, voice crossings, and harmonic dissonance. The problem of identifying the most coherent and parsimonious voice-leading is then framed as finding the minimum-cost path through this graph sequence, solved efficiently using a Viterbi-like algorithm. Applying this technique to Renaissance and Baroque polyphony, we demonstrate its ability to disambiguate complex textures and quantitatively measure voice-leading efficiency. The results align closely with established music-theoretic principles of smooth counterpoint, providing an objective, audio-based tool for stylistic and structural analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: A Graph-Theoretic Framework for Parsimonious Voice-Leading Analysis in Polyphonic Audio

text: The analysis of orchestral texture presents a formidable challenge due to the superposition of numerous instrumental voices. This paper utilizes Non-negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) as an unsupervised method for decomposing orchestral audio signals into constituent timbral components and their corresponding temporal activations. We employ a variant of NMF with Kullback-Leibler divergence and sparsity constraints to learn a dictionary of spectral basis vectors, each corresponding to a distinct instrumental group or solo instrument. The resulting activation matrix reveals the temporal evolution and interplay of these timbral components throughout a piece. We apply this technique to Ravel's *Bolero*, successfully isolating individual instrumental families and tracing their entries and combinations. Furthermore, by correlating the activation matrices with harmonic analysis, we quantify specific orchestration strategies tied to harmonic function. This method provides a scalable, data-driven approach to computational orchestrational analysis, moving beyond subjective description to quantitative characterization of timbral structure.
subject: Müzik
title: Unsupervised Decomposition of Orchestral Texture using Sparse Non-Negative Matrix Factorization

text: Traditional models of sensory dissonance, such as Plomp-Levelt's, are based on simple sine-wave stimuli and fail to capture the complexities of musical timbre. This work presents a novel psychoacoustic model of dissonance perception using deep kernel methods applied directly to complex spectral data. We first process audio signals through a biologically-inspired Gammatone filterbank to simulate cochlear frequency analysis. The resulting time-frequency representation serves as input to a Support Vector Regression (SVR) model with a custom-designed deep radial basis function (RBF) kernel, which is pre-trained to learn a feature space that optimally separates timbres. The SVR is trained on a large dataset of listener ratings of consonance/dissonance for chords played on various instruments. Our model significantly outperforms classical and feature-based machine learning models in predicting human perception ratings (RMSE < 0.1 on a normalized scale). The model's learned feature space reveals non-linear interactions between spectral roughness, harmonicity, and timbral envelope that govern dissonance perception.
subject: Müzik
title: Psychoacoustic Modeling of Dissonance Perception using Deep Kernel Methods on Complex Spectral Data

text: This paper presents a novel approach to automatic four-part chorale harmonization using a style-conditioned Generative Adversarial Network (GAN). Our model, Tonnetz-GAN, operates within a continuous latent space structured by tonal pitch space principles. The generator, a transformer-based architecture, takes a monophonic melody line as input and proposes a full SATB harmonization. The discriminator is trained not only to distinguish generated harmonizations from real examples from the J.S. Bach corpus but also to enforce music-theoretic constraints via a multi-objective loss function. This function includes terms for penalizing voice-leading errors (parallel fifths/octaves) and a spectral loss term to ensure harmonic coherence. A key innovation is conditioning the generator on a vector representing a target location on a Tonnetz, enabling fine-grained control over the harmonic language. Objective evaluations using established metrics and a subjective listening study confirm that our model generates harmonizations that are stylistically authentic and musically superior to previous deep learning approaches.
subject: Müzik
title: Tonnetz-GAN: A Generative Adversarial Network for Style-Conditioned Harmonization in Tonal Pitch Space

text: The dynamic exchange of histone variants is a cornerstone of epigenetic regulation, yet the precise mechanisms governing their deposition and impact on chromatin architecture remain partially elucidated. Here, we investigate the role of the histone H3 variant H3.3 in orchestrating chromatin accessibility during mammalian neurogenesis. Using a combination of high-resolution ChIP-seq, ATAC-seq, and cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM), we mapped H3.3 enrichment patterns and determined the structure of H3.3-containing nucleosomes in pluripotent versus terminally differentiated neuronal cells. Our data reveal that the H3.3 chaperone complex (HIRA) specifically deposits H3.3 at active enhancers and gene bodies, creating a nucleosomal conformation characterized by increased DNA breathing dynamics. This altered topology facilitates transcription factor binding and recruitment of the BAF chromatin remodeling complex. Genetic ablation of H3.3 or its chaperones abrogates proper neuronal lineage commitment, highlighting its indispensable role in establishing and maintaining cell-type-specific transcriptional programs through direct modulation of higher-order chromatin structure.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural and Functional Dissection of H3.3-Mediated Chromatin Plasticity in Neuronal Differentiation

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) have emerged as critical regulators of gene expression, often acting as molecular scaffolds to assemble ribonucleoprotein complexes. To systematically map the lncRNA-mediated regulatory network in embryonic stem cells (ESCs), we employed comprehensive identification of RNA-binding proteins by mass spectrometry (ChIRP-MS). This approach identified a previously uncharacterized lncRNA, which we term PluriNet-1, that is robustly expressed in the pluripotent state and rapidly downregulated upon differentiation. Functional analyses, including CRISPRi-mediated knockdown, revealed that PluriNet-1 is essential for maintaining ESC self-renewal. Mechanistically, PluriNet-1 directly interacts with core pluripotency factors OCT4 and SOX2, as well as the PRC2 complex component EZH2. This tripartite interaction localizes PRC2 to key developmental gene promoters, mediating their H3K27me3-dependent silencing. Our findings expose a lncRNA-centric hub that integrates the core transcriptional and epigenetic machinery to safeguard the pluripotent identity of ESCs, providing a new axis for understanding cellular fate decisions.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Systems-Level Interrogation of the lncRNA-Protein Interactome Governing Embryonic Stem Cell Pluripotency

text: Homologous recombination (HR) is a high-fidelity DNA double-strand break repair pathway, and its dysfunction, often caused by mutations in the tumor suppressor BRCA2, leads to genomic instability and cancer predisposition. A central function of BRCA2 is to load the recombinase RAD51 onto single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) to form a nucleoprotein filament. We present the high-resolution cryo-electron microscopy structure of the human BRCA2-RAD51-ssDNA complex. The structure reveals how the conserved BRC repeats of BRCA2 engage multiple RAD51 protomers simultaneously, breaking the intrinsic RAD51-RAD51 interface to prevent premature oligomerization in solution while seeding filament nucleation on the ssDNA substrate. Furthermore, the C-terminal domain of BRCA2 stabilizes the nascent filament in a polymerization-competent conformation. These structural insights provide a complete mechanistic model for RAD51 filament assembly chaperoned by BRCA2 and offer a molecular framework for understanding how pathogenic mutations disrupt HR-mediated DNA repair.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the RAD51-BRCA2 Complex Reveals the Mechanistic Basis of Homologous Recombination Filament Assembly

text: The unfolded protein response (UPR) is a critical signaling network that maintains endoplasmic reticulum (ER) homeostasis. While the transcriptional arm of the UPR is well-studied, its translational reprogramming aspect remains less defined. Here, we combined ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) with quantitative mass spectrometry to comprehensively map the translatome and proteome of cells under acute ER stress. We discovered a cohort of mRNAs that evade the global translational attenuation mediated by PERK-eIF2α signaling. These transcripts are characterized by upstream open reading frames (uORFs) that paradoxically promote downstream initiation under conditions of eIF2α phosphorylation. One prominent target, the E3 ubiquitin ligase MARCH6, is robustly translated and orchestrates the degradation of key metabolic enzymes to conserve cellular resources. Pharmacological inhibition of PERK abrogated this selective translation and sensitized cells to ER stress-induced apoptosis, uncovering a novel pro-survival mechanism orchestrated through context-dependent translational control.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated Proteomic and Genomic Analysis of the Unfolded Protein Response Identifies a PERK-Dependent Translational Reprogramming Axis

text: Transcription factors (TFs) must efficiently locate specific binding sites within a vast excess of non-cognate DNA. This search process is profoundly influenced by chromatin structure, but the underlying dynamics are poorly understood. Using live-cell single-particle tracking (SPT) with photoactivated fluorophores, we investigated the intranuclear search dynamics of the estrogen receptor (ERα) in the presence and absence of the pioneer factor FOXA1. Our analysis of millisecond-timescale trajectories demonstrates that FOXA1 binding locally decompacts condensed chromatin, transitioning the local environment from an anomalous to a more Brownian diffusion regime. This alteration in the physical landscape significantly reduces the residence time of ERα on non-cognate sites and increases the probability of target engagement through a series of short-lived interrogations. These findings support a model of facilitated diffusion whereby pioneer factors act as allosteric modulators of the chromatin environment to kinetically guide subsequent TFs to their targets.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Single-Molecule Tracking Reveals Allosteric Regulation of Transcription Factor Search Dynamics by Pioneer Factors

text: Liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) drives the formation of membraneless organelles, including ribonucleoprotein (RNP) granules. The RNA-binding protein FUS is a key component of these condensates, and its mutation is linked to amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). We investigated the molecular grammar governing FUS phase separation using in vitro reconstitution, NMR spectroscopy, and cellular assays. Our results demonstrate that multivalent, low-affinity interactions between the arginine-rich motifs in FUS and nucleic acids are the primary drivers of LLPS, with the prion-like domain modulating the material properties of the resulting condensates. ALS-associated mutations in the FUS nuclear localization signal lead to its cytoplasmic mislocalization and prolonged residence in stress granules. These mutant proteins exhibit altered phase behavior, forming hydrogels with reduced dynamics that readily transition into irreversible, amyloid-like fibrillar aggregates. This work delineates a direct pathogenic mechanism linking aberrant phase transitions to the proteopathic aggregation observed in neurodegeneration.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Molecular Determinants of RNA-Induced Phase Separation in FUS-Family Proteins and its Dysregulation in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis

text: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are potent post-transcriptional regulators whose dysregulation is a hallmark of cancer. The oncomiR miR-21 is highly overexpressed in glioblastoma (GBM), but its complete target repertoire and functional impact remain incompletely understood. Using AGO2-CLIP-seq coupled with RNA-seq in GBM patient-derived xenografts, we identified and validated a cohort of novel miR-21 targets that act as negative regulators of the TGF-β signaling pathway, including SMAD7 and the pseudoreceptor BAMBI. By concurrently suppressing these inhibitors, miR-21 creates a potent feed-forward loop that sensitizes GBM cells to autocrine TGF-β signaling, thereby amplifying their epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and invasive capabilities. In vivo administration of a locked nucleic acid (LNA)-based anti-miR-21 oligonucleotide restored the expression of these targets, attenuated TGF-β pathway activity, and significantly impeded tumor invasion and dissemination in orthotopic mouse models. This study uncovers a critical miRNA-driven mechanism that sustains oncogenic signaling and highlights a promising therapeutic vulnerability in GBM.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dissecting the Post-Transcriptional Crosstalk between miR-21 and the TGF-β Signaling Pathway in Glioblastoma Progression

text: CRISPR-based epigenome editing offers a powerful strategy for precise and durable gene regulation. Standard dCas9-effector fusions, however, often yield transient or incomplete silencing. To achieve robust and heritable transcriptional repression, we engineered a novel tripartite fusion protein comprising a nuclease-dead Cas9 (dCas9), the potent KRAB transcriptional repressor domain, and the methyl-CpG binding protein MeCP2. When targeted to the MYC oncogene promoter by specific guide RNAs, the dCas9-KRAB moiety initiates histone deacetylation and H3K9 trimethylation, creating a docking site for the fused MeCP2. This, in turn, recruits DNA methyltransferases, leading to de novo CpG methylation and long-term epigenetic memory of the repressed state. We demonstrate that this synergistic mechanism induces profound and sustained MYC silencing in cancer cell lines, persisting through multiple cell divisions after cessation of gRNA expression. This advanced epigenetic editor provides a potent tool for therapeutic applications requiring permanent silencing of deleterious genes.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Targeted Epigenetic Silencing of Oncogene Expression via a dCas9-KRAB-MeCP2 Fusion Protein

text: Mitochondrial ribosomes (mitoribosomes) are responsible for synthesizing key subunits of the oxidative phosphorylation system. Despite their prokaryotic origin, mitoribosomes have diverged substantially, acquiring numerous mitoribosome-specific proteins (MRPs). To understand the mechanism of mitochondrial translation, we used cryo-electron microscopy to solve the structure of the 55S human mitoribosome stalled during translocation at 2.8 Å resolution. The structure captures mitochondrial elongation factor G1 (mtEFG1) in a post-translocational state, revealing its specific interactions with the sarcin-ricin loop and novel MRPs at the intersubunit interface. A remodeled polypeptide exit tunnel, lined with unique MRPs such as MRPL17 and MRPL22, appears to engage the nascent chain. This conformation, distinct from both bacterial and cytosolic counterparts, highlights specialized adaptations in the mitochondrial translation apparatus for synthesizing and co-translationally inserting hydrophobic membrane proteins into the inner mitochondrial membrane, providing a structural basis for understanding mitochondrial disease.
subject: Biyoloji
title: High-Resolution Cryo-EM Structure of the Human Mitoribosome during Nascent Chain Translocation

text: The maintenance of telomeres is essential for genome integrity, relying on the coordinated action of telomerase and shelterin-associated factors. The CTC1-STN1-TEN1 (CST) complex is critical for lagging-strand synthesis at telomeres and for suppressing aberrant DNA repair activities. Here, we report that the function of CST is regulated by post-translational modification with the Small Ubiquitin-like Modifier (SUMO). Using quantitative proteomics and biochemical assays, we identified a conserved SUMOylation site on the STN1 subunit that is modified in a cell cycle-dependent manner, peaking during S/G2 phase. Site-specific mutation of this lysine residue abrogates STN1 SUMOylation and impairs CST recruitment to telomeres following replicative stress. Consequently, cells expressing SUMO-deficient STN1 exhibit hallmarks of telomere dysfunction, including elongated C-strand overhangs, increased telomere fragility, and activation of the ATR-dependent DNA damage response. Our findings establish SUMOylation as a pivotal molecular switch that temporally controls CST function to ensure faithful telomere replication.
subject: Biyoloji
title: SUMO-Dependent Regulation of the CST Complex Controls Telomere Replication and Prevents Genomic Instability

text: We propose a generalized holographic duality wherein the bulk-to-boundary encoding map is non-isometric, a departure from the standard AdS/CFT correspondence. This framework is investigated to understand its consequences for entanglement wedge reconstruction and the nature of subregion-subregion duality. Utilizing the formalism of quantum error correction, we demonstrate that local bulk operators can still be reconstructed on boundary subregions, albeit with a fidelity that is explicitly dependent on the singular value spectrum of the encoding map. This deviation from isometry introduces a novel, state-dependent correction term to the Ryu-Takanagi formula, which we explicitly calculate. Our model offers a potential mechanism for information leakage in black hole evaporation scenarios by permitting information to escape through non-isometric channels, while preserving approximate bulk locality for low-energy observers. The theoretical results are numerically corroborated using tensor network simulations of random non-isometric holographic codes, providing a robust test of our analytical predictions.
subject: Fizik
title: Entanglement Entropy and Bulk Reconstruction in a Non-Isometric Holographic Mapping

text: We theoretically investigate the emergence of fractional Chern insulating states in magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene subjected to a high-frequency, circularly polarized laser field. Through a comprehensive analysis combining Floquet-Bloch theory and large-scale density-matrix renormalization group (DMRG) simulations, we demonstrate that the non-equilibrium driving dynamically reshapes the moiré flat bands, generating a substantial non-zero Berry curvature and an effective magnetic field. For a specific range of driving frequencies and amplitudes, the system is driven into a strongly correlated topological phase at fractional filling ν=1/3, exhibiting a precisely quantized Hall conductance. We characterize this emergent state by its ground-state degeneracy on a toroidal geometry and by calculating the braiding statistics of its anyonic quasi-particle excitations. Our findings establish Floquet engineering as a potent methodology for realizing exotic non-equilibrium topological orders of matter in solid-state systems without necessitating external magnetic fields, thereby enabling ultrafast control of topological quantum states.
subject: Fizik
title: Fractional Chern Insulators in Twisted Bilayer Graphene under Non-Equilibrium Floquet Driving

text: We explore the generation of primordial non-Gaussianities in multi-field inflationary models where the inflationary trajectory is dynamically destabilized by geometric effects on the field-space manifold. By employing the stochastic δN formalism, we demonstrate that sharp turns in the trajectory, induced by a non-trivial field-space metric, can source large, localized non-Gaussianities of both the equilateral and orthogonal types. These distinctive features arise from the transient amplification of isocurvature modes which subsequently convert to adiabatic curvature perturbations near the end of inflation. Our model predicts a unique scale-dependent signature in the bispectrum and trispectrum, potentially observable in future Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) and large-scale structure surveys. We derive the consistency relations for this class of models within an effective field theory framework, showing a clear violation of the single-field Suyama-Yamaguchi inequality. This provides a sharp observational discriminant between single-clock inflation and scenarios involving geometric destabilization, opening a new window into early universe physics.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Gaussian Signatures from Multi-Field Inflation with a Geometrically Destabilized Trajectory

text: We investigate critical phenomena on dynamic random graphs embedded in hyperbolic space, which serve as a canonical model for many real-world complex networks exhibiting scale-free and strong clustering characteristics. Using a combination of extensive Monte Carlo simulations and rigorous finite-size scaling analysis, we study the Ising model and bond percolation on these evolving network topologies. We find that the critical exponents deviate significantly from those established on static Euclidean lattices or classical Erdős–Rényi random graphs. A novel renormalization group approach, specifically formulated for hyperbolic geometries, suggests that the negative curvature acts as a relevant perturbation, driving the system towards a previously uncharacterized universality class. The dynamic nature of the graph, governed by stochastic node and edge turnover processes, introduces additional scaling corrections related to the temporal correlation length of the network structure. Our results unify disparate concepts from statistical physics and network science, providing a foundational framework for understanding phase transitions in evolving, non-Euclidean systems.
subject: Fizik
title: Universality Classes of Critical Phenomena on Dynamic, Hyperbolic Random Graphs

text: We establish a rigorous and operational connection between quantum contextuality and the ultimate achievable precision in quantum metrology. By generalizing the contextuality-by-default (CbD) framework to encompass sequences of minimally disturbing measurements, we demonstrate that the degree of contextuality inherent in a quantum system can be harnessed as a quantifiable resource to surpass the standard quantum limit (SQL). We formulate a metrological protocol where the parameter to be estimated is encoded within the contextual correlations among a set of incompatible observables. The quantum Fisher information is shown to be directly proportional to a novel, robust measure of contextuality derived from the violation of a Kochen-Specker-type inequality. This result implies that maximally contextual systems, such as a single qutrit, can be used to approach the Heisenberg limit of precision without requiring entanglement. Our work reframes quantum contextuality not merely as a foundational curiosity but as a practical resource for enhanced quantum information processing.
subject: Fizik
title: Contextuality-by-Default as a Resource for Quantum Metrology beyond the Standard Quantum Limit

text: We analyze the gravitational wave signal from the post-merger ringdown phase of an exotic compact object modeled as a Bardeen-Kiselev black hole, a regular black hole solution sourced by a quintessence field and a non-linear electrodynamic (NLED) field. By numerically solving the Regge-Wheeler and Zerilli equations governing axial and polar perturbations, we compute the quasi-normal mode (QNM) spectrum. The presence of the NLED charge and the quintessence parameter significantly alters the effective potential barrier outside the event horizon, leading to a modified QNM spectrum compared to the standard Kerr paradigm. More critically, for specific parameter regimes, the effective potential develops a secondary minimum, creating a resonant cavity that generates a train of late-time gravitational wave echoes. We provide a template for these echo waveforms and discuss their potential detectability with next-generation observatories. The detection of such echoes would provide compelling evidence for physics beyond general relativity and probe the quantum nature of the black hole horizon.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Wave Echoes from Bardeen-Kiselev Black Holes with Non-Linear Electrodynamic Sources

text: We propose a novel experimental scheme to search for axion-like particles (ALPs) by exploiting the quantum Zeno effect. In conventional light-shining-through-wall (LSW) experiments, a laser's conversion into ALPs in a magnetic field is coherently enhanced over the magnet's length. Our approach introduces periodic "measurement" stages along the magnetic field region, implemented via reflective barriers or disruptive optical elements that project the quantum state back onto the photon subspace. According to the quantum Zeno effect, these frequent interruptions disrupt the coherent evolution of the photon-ALP state vector, leading to a strong suppression of the net conversion probability. The magnitude of this suppression is a highly sensitive function of the ALP-photon coupling constant (g_aγγ) and the ALP mass (m_a). By precisely measuring the transmitted photon flux versus the interruption frequency, one can establish stringent exclusion limits on g_aγγ that are potentially orders of magnitude more sensitive than conventional LSW techniques in certain mass ranges.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Axion-Like Particles through Quantum Zeno Suppression of Coherent Photon-ALP Conversion

text: We introduce the concept of topological spacetime photonic crystals that exhibit a non-reciprocal bianisotropic response analogous to Willis coupling in continuum mechanics. The system is comprised of a dielectric lattice whose permittivity and permeability are modulated both in space and time with a carefully chosen relative phase, which explicitly breaks time-reversal symmetry without magnetic materials. Using a rigorous Floquet-Bloch mode analysis, we demonstrate that this spatiotemporal modulation induces an effective magneto-electric coupling and a momentum-asymmetric impedance, resulting in a non-reciprocal photonic band structure. For specific modulation parameters, the photonic bandgap acquires a non-trivial topological character, quantified by an integer Chern number, leading to the emergence of chiral, one-way electromagnetic edge states. These states are topologically protected against defects and disorder and exhibit robust unidirectional propagation. Our findings open a new avenue for designing integrated, all-dielectric non-reciprocal photonic devices such as topological insulators, circulators, and isolators based on dynamic modulation.
subject: Fizik
title: Topological Spacetime Photonic Crystals with Non-Reciprocal Willis Coupling

text: We investigate the dynamics of the inverse cascade of magnetic helicity in forced, three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence using high-resolution direct numerical simulations. In contrast to conventional models with continuous, homogeneous forcing, we study the system's response to intermittent, spatially localized injections of kinetic and magnetic helicity, mimicking energetic astrophysical phenomena like solar flares. Our results reveal that the inverse cascade process is fundamentally altered by the stochastic nature of the forcing. The growth of the large-scale magnetic field is not monotonic but proceeds through a series of rapid amplification events followed by periods of slow resistive dissipation. We analyze the evolving magnetic field topology using Lagrangian coherent structures and find that the inverse transfer is primarily mediated by the merger and reconnection of coherent helical flux tubes. A scale-dependent statistical analysis shows that intermittency in the forcing function generates strongly non-Gaussian probability distribution functions for magnetic field increments at large scales, a key signature absent in continuously forced systems.
subject: Fizik
title: Intermittent Helicity Injection and its Role in the Inverse Cascade of Magnetohydrodynamic Turbulence

text: We develop a theoretical framework for the dynamics of eukaryotic chromatin, treating it as an active polymer system driven far from thermal equilibrium by ATP-dependent motor proteins. By extending established polymer physics models to include non-conservative forces and stochastic activity hotspots, we derive a generalized Fokker-Planck equation describing the evolution of the chromatin conformational probability distribution. Our model predicts that these active processes generate effective long-range correlations and non-equilibrium entropic forces that can cooperatively fold or unfold entire topologically associating domains (TADs). We subsequently connect these mesoscale conformational changes to epigenetic state transitions by coupling the polymer dynamics to a bistable model of histone mark modification. The system exhibits hysteretic switching between condensed (heterochromatin) and decondensed (euchromatin) states, governed by the motor activity level. Using principles from stochastic thermodynamics, we quantify the information-theoretic cost and entropy production rate required to maintain these non-equilibrium chromatin architectures, providing a physical basis for the stability and plasticity of the epigenetic landscape.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Equilibrium Thermodynamics of Active Chromatin: Entropic Forces and Epigenetic State Transitions

text: This paper presents a novel probabilistic framework for the automated derivation of Schenkerian graphs from symbolic musical scores. Moving beyond rule-based systems and conventional parsing algorithms, we introduce a Hierarchical Bayesian Model that treats analytical layers (foreground, middleground, background) as latent variables. The model leverages a generative process wherein foreground events are stochastically derived from more abstract middleground structures, which in turn are conditioned on a fundamental Ursatz. We employ a custom Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) inference algorithm to explore the posterior distribution of possible analyses given a musical surface. The model incorporates musically informed priors that encode principles of prolongation, voice-leading parsimony, and metrical stability. We evaluate our system against a ground-truth corpus of expert human analyses using tree-edit distance metrics, demonstrating significant improvements in structural accuracy over existing computational approaches and providing a robust methodology for large-scale computational musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hierarchical Bayesian Model for Automated Schenkerian Analysis of Tonal Music

text: This study investigates the perceptual organization of orchestral timbre by applying manifold learning techniques to a high-dimensional acoustic feature space. We analyze a comprehensive database of isolated instrumental samples, extracting a suite of spectral descriptors including Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs), spectral centroid, flux, and roll-off. Traditional clustering methods often fail to capture the nuanced, continuous nature of timbral perception. Instead, we utilize Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP) to embed the high-dimensional feature vectors into a low-dimensional space that preserves both local and global topological structure. The resulting manifold reveals salient organizational principles, showing distinct clusters for instrumental families, but also continuous pathways corresponding to perceptual blending and timbral gradients. This data-driven 'timbral cartography' offers an empirical correlate to traditional orchestration theory and provides a quantitative tool for analyzing complex orchestral textures in recorded audio.
subject: Müzik
title: Timbral Semantics in Orchestral Grouping: A Manifold Learning Approach to Spectral Feature Analysis

text: Expressive performance timing, or microtiming, remains a challenging phenomenon to model computationally. This research proposes a new methodology for its quantification by combining high-resolution onset detection with constrained Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) for precise score-performance alignment. From this alignment, we extract a continuous stream of tempo and note-level durational deviations. To move beyond descriptive statistics, we employ invertible causal models to disentangle the influence of structural musical features (e.g., harmonic tension, melodic contour) from performer-specific stylistic signatures. The model is trained on a corpus of recordings by multiple concert pianists performing the same repertoire. Our results demonstrate the ability to isolate idiosyncratic rubato patterns and agogic accentuations, providing a robust performer 'fingerprint'. This framework has significant implications for computational stylometry, performance pedagogy, and the generation of more human-like computer-generated musical performances.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Expressive Microtiming in Piano Performance Using Dynamic Time Warping and Invertible Causal Models

text: Neo-Riemannian theory and its extensions have successfully geometrized aspects of triadic harmony, but a robust geometric model for post-tonal, multi-voice counterpoint remains elusive. This paper introduces a novel approach using Topological Data Analysis (TDA) to explore the structure of complex voice-leading spaces. We represent n-voice pitch-class collections as points in a toroidal configuration space. By analyzing a corpus of 20th-century contrapuntal works, we generate high-dimensional point clouds representing the realized voice-leadings. We then apply persistent homology to these point clouds to identify their underlying topological features, such as loops and voids, at various scales. These features correspond to recurring, non-trivial voice-leading transformations and cyclical patterns that are not apparent from surface-level analysis. This methodology provides a powerful new lens for understanding contrapuntal organization and systematic transformation in atonal and post-tonal repertoires.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Data Analysis of Voice-Leading Spaces in Post-Tonal Counterpoint

text: Automated harmonic analysis of jazz presents a formidable challenge due to its extended tertian vocabularies, frequent modulations, and complex chord voicings. This work presents a novel deep learning architecture for performing chord labeling directly from an audio input. Our model consists of a convolutional front-end for learning robust chroma features from the constant-Q transform of the audio signal. These features are then fed into a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) network to model long-range temporal dependencies inherent in harmonic progressions. Crucially, we incorporate a self-attention mechanism that allows the model to dynamically weight the influence of different temporal contexts when making a chord prediction. Evaluated on the Weimar Jazz Database and a newly annotated corpus of bebop solos, our attentive Bi-LSTM model significantly outperforms state-of-the-art systems in chord symbol recall, especially in correctly identifying complex alterations and functionally ambiguous harmonies.
subject: Müzik
title: A Deep Attentive Bidirectional-LSTM for Context-Aware Harmonic Analysis of Jazz Improvisation

text: Most computational rhythm analysis systems presuppose an isochronous metrical grid, a bias that limits their applicability to a vast range of world music traditions. This paper proposes an unsupervised method for discovering complex, non-isochronous metrical structures directly from audio recordings. The approach first calculates a novelty function from the signal's spectral flux. This function is then used to construct a self-similarity matrix (SSM), which reveals recurring rhythmic patterns as diagonal structures. To learn a compact representation of these patterns, we employ a 1D convolutional autoencoder trained on segments of the novelty curve. By clustering the resulting latent-space representations, our system can identify and classify characteristic rhythmic cells (e.g., tālas, usuls) without prior knowledge of the underlying metrical system. This methodology provides a more culturally-neutral tool for computational ethnomusicology and the analysis of rhythmically complex music.
subject: Müzik
title: Unsupervised Discovery of Non-Isochronous Metrical Structures using Convolutional Autoencoders and Self-Similarity Matrices

text: Classical models of sensory dissonance, based on spectral beating and critical bandwidth theory, are insufficient for explaining perceived tension in post-tonal and atonal music. We propose a hybrid psychoacoustic model that accounts for both physiological and cognitive dimensions of dissonance. The model's first component computes sensory roughness from the audio signal's partials using a time-varying extension of the Plomp-Levelt model. The second, cognitive component quantifies harmonic tension as information-theoretic surprisal. This is calculated using a probabilistic model of pitch-class set transitions, trained on a large corpus of atonal music to learn its statistical syntax. The final dissonance value is a weighted combination of the sensory and cognitive outputs. When validated against listener ratings for a curated set of atonal excerpts, our hybrid model demonstrates a significantly higher correlation with perceived dissonance than models based on either component alone.
subject: Müzik
title: Psychoacoustic Dissonance Revisited: A Hybrid Model Integrating Sensory Roughness and Information-Theoretic Surprisal for Post-Tonal Music

text: The relationship between a conductor's gestures and the resulting musical expression is a central, yet poorly quantified, aspect of orchestral performance. This study employs a multimodal approach to empirically investigate this link. We recorded a professional conductor leading an orchestra using a 3D motion capture system synchronized with a multi-channel audio recording. We extracted kinematic features from the conductor's baton trajectory (e.g., velocity, acceleration, gesture volume) and acoustic features from the orchestral audio (e.g., RMS energy, spectral centroid, attack sharpness). To model the relationship between these two feature sets, we applied Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCA), a statistical technique that finds maximally correlated linear projections of two multidimensional variables. The resulting canonical variates reveal strong correlations between gesture velocity and orchestral dynamics, and between gesture size and articulation, thus providing a quantitative mapping between gestural and acoustic expressive parameters.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Analysis of Conductor Gestures and Orchestral Dynamics via Canonical Correlation Analysis

text: Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) has emerged as a powerful technique for unsupervised source separation and transcription of polyphonic music. Standard NMF, however, often produces musically incongruous results. This paper introduces a constrained NMF framework that incorporates prior musical knowledge to improve performance. We impose a harmonicity constraint on the spectral basis vectors (the 'W' matrix), forcing them to resemble harmonic spectra, and a temporal sparsity constraint on the activation matrix (the 'H' matrix) to favor note-like events. This musically-informed factorization yields a more accurate multi-pitch transcription from complex audio mixtures. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the learned spectral bases provide a rich, data-driven representation of instrumental timbre. By clustering these bases, we can perform automatic instrument identification within the mixture, offering a unified framework for both transcription and timbral analysis of polyphonic recordings.
subject: Müzik
title: Constrained Non-Negative Matrix Factorization for Polyphonic Music Transcription and Timbral Analysis

text: This paper applies methodologies from computational linguistics and information theory to investigate the statistical structure of Western tonal harmony. We model harmonic progressions from a large, symbolically encoded corpus as a sequence of chord symbols. Unlike fixed-order n-gram models, we employ a Variable-Order Markov Model (VOMM) that adapts its context length based on the predictive power of the preceding chord sequence. This allows the model to capture both short-range voice-leading conventions and longer-range functional relationships. We analyze the model's predictive performance and calculate the information rate (entropy) of different harmonic idioms, providing a quantitative measure of their syntactic complexity and predictability. The model also allows for the identification of points of high surprisal, which often correspond to moments of significant musical interest, such as deceptive cadences or unexpected modulations, thus formalizing a key aspect of music-theoretic analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Modeling Tonal Syntax with Variable-Order Markov Models and Information Rate Analysis

text: This paper presents a graph-theoretic framework for the quantitative analysis of contrapuntal structure in polyphonic music. We model the set of possible contrapuntal states as nodes in a multi-layer directed graph, where each layer represents a voice and edges represent permissible melodic intervals. The problem of identifying coherent voice leading is then reformulated as finding a set of vertex-disjoint Hamiltonian paths, subject to constraints derived from Fuxian counterpoint and melodic contour heuristics. We apply this model to the complete corpus of J.S. Bach's 'Well-Tempered Clavier', computing metrics such as path tortuosity and inter-path harmonic dissonance. Our analysis reveals statistically significant structural isomorphisms between fugues with similar formal designs (e.g., stretto vs. non-stretto). This computationally rigorous methodology formalizes the elusive concept of linear coherence, providing an empirical tool for stylistic comparison and offering new insights into the compositional logic underlying complex polyphonic textures.
subject: Müzik
title: Graph-Theoretic Isomorphism and Contrapuntal Complexity: A Hamiltonian Path Model for J.S. Bach's Fugues

text: The analysis of historical keyboard temperaments from early audio recordings is confounded by mechanical pitch instabilities such as wow and flutter. We propose a hierarchical Bayesian model to robustly infer temperament parameters in the presence of such signal degradation. Our model treats the temperament's cent deviations from equal temperament as latent variables to be estimated. The likelihood function is based on a spectrally-informed inharmonic partial series template, while the prior distribution over temperaments can be informed by historical treatises. Crucially, instantaneous frequency drift is co-estimated as a Gaussian Process, allowing the model to distinguish between intentional tuning choices and recording artifacts. We employ Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling to derive the full posterior distribution for the temperament. Application of this methodology to early 20th-century piano recordings provides compelling quantitative evidence for the persistence of non-equal temperaments, offering a new paradigm for audio-based historical performance practice research.
subject: Müzik
title: Bayesian Inference of Historical Keyboard Temperaments from Early Audio Recordings using a Pitch-Drift-Aware Harmonic Model

text: Standard audio analysis techniques often model timbre and harmony as orthogonal phenomena. We posit that they are perceptually and structurally co-modulated and introduce a Joint Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (JNMF) framework to explicitly model this interaction. Our approach factorizes a magnitude spectrogram into three component matrices: a set of spectral bases (timbres), their temporal activations, and a time-varying harmonic context matrix. The novelty lies in the regularization of the factorization process using a tonal prior derived from a probabilistic model of harmony based on the spiral array. This prior encourages the decomposition to yield spectrally coherent bases that are also harmonically consonant. When evaluated on complex orchestral excerpts, our regularized JNMF model demonstrates superior performance on both instrument identification and chord recognition tasks compared to unconstrained NMF and deep learning baselines. This framework provides a more musically salient representation of audio, reflecting the perceptual fusion of timbral and harmonic information in auditory scene analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangling Timbre and Harmony: A Joint Non-Negative Matrix Factorization Approach with Regularized Tonal Priors

text: Schenkerian analysis posits a hierarchical basis for tonal music, yet its principles resist quantitative formalization. This study operationalizes Schenkerian theory using information-theoretic concepts. We represent the Ursatz, middleground, and foreground layers of a Schenkerian graph as distinct probability distributions of pitch and rhythmic events. The structural depth of a composition is quantified as the cumulative Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence between successive layers, measuring the information added at each level of elaboration. Furthermore, we estimate the algorithmic (Kolmogorov) complexity of the transformational rules that generate the musical surface from the background, yielding a metric of compositional efficiency. Analysis of a corpus of Beethoven piano sonatas reveals a strong correlation between our computed structural depth and traditional music-theoretic assessments of formal complexity. This methodology provides an empirical framework for testing Schenkerian hypotheses, comparing competing analyses, and quantifying the hierarchical cognitive processing of musical structure.
subject: Müzik
title: Algorithmic Complexity and Structural Depth: An Information-Theoretic Evaluation of Schenkerian Analysis

text: Classical computational models of harmonic progression, such as n-grams and Hidden Markov Models, are often inadequate for capturing the long-range dependencies and combinatorial complexity of late-Romantic chromaticism. This paper introduces a novel paradigm by framing harmonic progression as a ground-state energy minimization problem solvable via quantum annealing. We construct a quadratic unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO) model where chord states are encoded by binary variables and their relationships are defined by an energy function incorporating voice-leading parsimony, root movement probabilities, and functional harmonic constraints. By mapping this QUBO problem onto the D-Wave quantum annealer, we can efficiently sample from a Boltzmann distribution of stylistically plausible chord progressions. We demonstrate the model's capacity to generate harmonically coherent sequences in the style of Wagner and Scriabin that exhibit greater long-range structural integrity than those produced by classical counterparts, heralding a new application of quantum computing to complex music-theoretic challenges.
subject: Müzik
title: A Quantum Annealing Approach to Modeling Harmonic Progression in Chromatic Tonality

text: Musical expression is an inherently multimodal behavior, yet computational analyses have predominantly focused on the audio signal alone. This research presents a unified framework for the cross-modal analysis of expressive performance by integrating synchronous audio, high-frequency motion-capture (MoCap) data, and facial-expression video. We utilize a Deep Canonical Correlation Analysis (DCCA) model to learn a shared, non-linear latent space that maximizes the correlation between feature sets from the three modalities. Audio features include spectral shape descriptors and loudness metrics, MoCap provides detailed kinematics of instrumental gestures, and video yields affective cues from facial landmarks. Projecting performance data onto this shared latent space allows for the quantification of cross-modal mappings, such as the relationship between a violinist's bow velocity and the resulting spectral centroid. Our results, derived from a dataset of string quartet performances, empirically validate pedagogical theories of expressive technique and provide a robust method for performance synthesis and analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Fusing Audio, Motion-Capture, and Video for Cross-Modal Analysis of Expressive Musical Performance

text: Conventional algorithms for musical structure analysis often rely on supervised learning or heuristics that fail on stylistically diverse or formally ambiguous compositions. We propose a parameter-free, unsupervised method based on topological data analysis (TDA). The methodology begins by constructing a time-lagged self-similarity matrix from a sequence of tonal pitch-class distributions (chromagrams). This matrix is then interpreted as an adjacency matrix of a graph, from which a Vietoris-Rips complex is built. We then compute the persistent homology of this complex. The resulting persistence diagram provides a multi-scale signature of the piece's structure: 0-dimensional homology (Betti_0) reveals distinct thematic sections as robust connected components, while 1-dimensional homology (Betti_1) identifies large-scale cyclic structures such as recapitulations. When applied to a corpus spanning Baroque fugues to free jazz, our TDA-based approach robustly identifies structurally significant boundaries and relationships, outperforming state-of-the-art segmentation algorithms and offering a truly generalized model of musical form.
subject: Müzik
title: Persistent Homology of Self-Similarity Matrices for the Unsupervised Discovery of Musical Form

text: Computational Auditory Scene Analysis (CASA) systems frequently fail to model the human ability to segregate instrumental lines in dense orchestral music. We present a novel, two-stage computational model of auditory streaming that more closely aligns with human perception. The first stage, a bottom-up process, employs a Gaussian Mixture Model to cluster time-frequency energy partials based on common onset, harmonicity, and timbral similarity (as measured by spectral flux and centroid). The second stage, a top-down process, refines these initial streams by applying a probabilistic model of melodic and contrapuntal expectancy learned from a corpus of tonal music. We validate our model against human perceptual data from a series of psychoacoustic experiments where listeners reported the number of perceived streams in orchestral excerpts. The model's stream segregation output shows a significantly higher correlation with listener judgments (Pearson's r > 0.82) than existing CASA frameworks, representing a substantial advance in ecologically valid computational audition.
subject: Müzik
title: A Psychoacoustically-Validated Computational Model of Auditory Streaming in Complex Orchestral Textures

text: While Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) can produce locally coherent music, they typically fail to control large-scale formal architecture. This paper introduces a novel GAN framework where the latent space is not Euclidean but is instead a learned Riemannian manifold whose geometry reflects music-theoretic principles of tonal distance. The model, trained on a corpus of classical sonata form expositions, learns a metric tensor that creates 'paths of least resistance' corresponding to normative harmonic and thematic trajectories. We demonstrate that the modulation from a primary to a secondary key area corresponds to a geodesic path on this learned manifold. By sampling along extrapolated geodesics, the model can generate structurally-sound development and recapitulation sections that logically follow a given exposition. This geometric inductive bias enables unprecedented long-range structural control in a generative model, bridging the conceptual gap between statistical sequence generation and abstract, hierarchical models of musical form.
subject: Müzik
title: Geodesic Traversal in Latent Tonal Space: A Riemannian Geometry-Informed GAN for Sonata Form Extrapolation

text: This paper introduces a novel deep learning framework for automating the extraction of Schenkerian structural levels directly from polyphonic audio recordings. Traditional computational musicology has struggled with the abstraction inherent in Schenkerian analysis, largely confining efforts to symbolic data. Our proposed model circumvents this limitation by employing a hybrid architecture. A convolutional neural network (CNN) first processes a constant-Q transform of the audio to generate a robust multi-pitch representation resilient to timbral variations. This output is then fed into a recurrent neural network (RNN) with a custom attention mechanism, designed to identify long-range dependencies corresponding to melodic prolongations. Trained on a curated dataset of expert analyses aligned with audio performances, the system demonstrates significant success in identifying the fundamental line (Urlinie) and bass arpeggiation (Bassbrechung) in common-practice tonal works. This research represents a substantial step towards integrating high-level music-theoretical concepts into machine listening systems, bridging the gap between signal processing and structural musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Architecture for Automated Schenkerian Analysis from Polyphonic Audio

text: The perception of harmonic function is traditionally modeled using pitch-class information, largely neglecting the influence of timbre. This study investigates the extent to which instrumental timbre systematically modulates listeners' perception of tonal stability and harmonic progression. We constructed a stimulus set comprising identical harmonic progressions rendered with varying synthetic timbres, controlled via spectral centroid, spectral flux, and inharmonicity parameters. Audio features were extracted from these stimuli using machine listening techniques. A supervised learning model was then trained to predict human listener ratings of harmonic function, using both chroma features and the extracted timbral descriptors. Our results demonstrate that timbral features account for a significant portion of the variance in listener judgments, independent of pitch content. Specifically, higher spectral flux and inharmonicity were correlated with decreased perception of tonic stability. These findings challenge pitch-centric models of tonality and underscore the necessity of integrating timbral information into future computational models of music cognition.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Timbral Influence on Harmonic Function Perception via Machine Listening and Psychoacoustic Modeling

text: Neo-Riemannian theory provides a powerful algebraic framework for analyzing triadic relationships in tonal music. This paper proposes a novel extension of this framework to the analysis of atonal, texture-based electroacoustic music. Instead of operating on pitch-class sets, our method identifies transformations within a spectro-timbral space. We first compute short-time Fourier transforms (STFTs) of the audio signal and apply manifold learning techniques, specifically t-SNE, to project high-dimensional spectral frames into a lower-dimensional space. Unsupervised clustering algorithms are then used to identify recurring 'spectral sonority' clusters. By analyzing the geometric transformations between the centroids of these clusters, we reveal structural isomorphisms to canonical Neo-Riemannian operations (P, L, R). This methodology provides a new syntactical lens for understanding structural coherence in music devoid of traditional harmonic grammar, demonstrating that parsimonious voice-leading principles can be generalized to the continuous domain of timbre.
subject: Müzik
title: Neo-Riemannian Operations in the Spectro-Timbral Domain: A Geometric Approach to Electroacoustic Music Analysis

text: This research addresses the compositional challenge of creating stylistically coherent music within historical microtonal tuning systems. We introduce a novel Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) architecture specifically designed for this purpose. The model is trained on a synthetic corpus of polyphonic excerpts rendered in various historical temperaments, including Pythagorean, meantone, and well-tempered systems. By conditioning the generator on a one-hot vector representing the target temperament, the network learns the distinct melodic and harmonic statistical properties endemic to each system. A key innovation is the model's ability to interpolate within the latent space between different learned temperaments, enabling the generation of novel musical passages that smoothly transition between tuning systems. This not only provides a powerful tool for historically informed composition but also creates a new paradigm for exploring the vast, structured space of microtonality through machine learning.
subject: Müzik
title: Generative Adversarial Networks for Microtonal Composition Informed by Historical Temperament Systems

text: Expressive musical performance is a multimodal phenomenon involving both auditory nuance and physical gesture. This study presents a methodology for quantitatively linking performer kinematics to acoustic outcomes. We recorded pianists performing romantic-era repertoire using a synchronized system of high-resolution audio microphones and marker-based motion capture (MoCap). A robust audio-to-score alignment algorithm was used to segment the performance, after which detailed acoustic features (e.g., onset timing deviations, dynamic velocity, spectral brightness) and kinematic parameters (e.g., finger velocity, wrist elevation, torso sway) were extracted for each note event. A cross-modal correlation analysis, followed by Principal Component Analysis (PCA), reveals strong, performer-specific couplings between gestural antecedents and their sonic results. The findings demonstrate that expressive articulations and micro-timings are systematically encoded in a performer's physical approach, providing an empirical basis for understanding the embodiment of musical expression.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Analysis of Expressive Performance: Correlating Kinematic Gestures and Acoustic Articulation via Synchronized Audio and Motion Capture

text: Dominant paradigms in Automatic Music Transcription (AMT) for polyphonic audio rely on bottom-up, signal-driven deep learning models, which often produce musically implausible errors. This paper proposes a hybrid system that synergizes bottom-up spectral analysis with top-down music-theoretical constraints. The first stage employs a Convolutional Recurrent Neural Network (CRNN) to generate a preliminary piano-roll representation from the input spectrogram. The second stage refines this output using a beam search algorithm guided by a probabilistic model of common-practice harmony and voice-leading. This model, implemented as a Hidden Markov Model, assigns higher probabilities to transcriptions that adhere to principles of tonal syntax and metrical structure. Evaluated on the MAPS dataset, our hybrid approach significantly reduces musically salient errors, such as octave displacements and harmonically inconsistent notes, compared to a purely bottom-up baseline, demonstrating the efficacy of integrating abstract musical knowledge into transcription systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Integrating Top-Down Music-Theoretical Constraints into Deep Learning-Based Automatic Music Transcription

text: The analysis of late-Romantic and early 20th-century music is often complicated by pervasive harmonic ambiguity. This paper presents a novel computational framework to quantify such ambiguity directly from symbolic musical scores. Our model leverages a dynamic Bayesian network that integrates two sources of information: the pitch-class content of a given chord and the voice-leading parsimony from the preceding chord. For each harmonic event, the model calculates a posterior probability distribution over a set of possible functional interpretations within a dynamically shifting tonal space. We define a metric of harmonic ambiguity as the Shannon entropy of this probability distribution. Applying this model to excerpts from Wagner's 'Tristan und Isolde' and Scriabin's 'Poème de l'extase', we generate a continuous 'ambiguity curve' that highlights moments of tonal flux. This quantitative approach offers an objective complement to traditional qualitative analysis, providing empirical grounding for interpretations of harmonic function.
subject: Müzik
title: A Computational Model for Quantifying Harmonic Ambiguity in Late-Romantic Music using Probabilistic Voice-Leading

text: Traditional computational analysis of melodic similarity often relies on simplistic interval-based representations that fail to capture the holistic nature of contour perception. This paper reconceptualizes melodic contours as geometric curves in a two-dimensional pitch-time space, enabling the application of sophisticated geometric distance metrics. We conduct a large-scale listening experiment to establish a ground truth of perceptual similarity for a diverse set of melodic fragments. We then evaluate the correlation between these human judgments and several computational distance metrics, including Euclidean distance, Dynamic Time Warping (DTW), and Fréchet distance. Multidimensional scaling (MDS) of the perceptual data reveals a cognitive space where global shape and local interval features are co-dependent. Our results indicate that a weighted combination of the Fréchet distance, which captures global trajectory, and a local interval vector distance provides the most robust model for predicting perceived melodic similarity, significantly outperforming conventional methods.
subject: Müzik
title: Geometric Representations of Melodic Contour: A Comparative Analysis of Distance Metrics and Their Perceptual Correlates

text: This work introduces a novel unsupervised method for discovering hierarchical musical form directly from an audio signal. Conventional approaches, often based on self-similarity matrices (SSMs), typically rely on a single feature stream (e.g., chroma), which conflates thematic, harmonic, and timbral repetition. We overcome this by constructing a third-order tensor where the dimensions represent time, frequency (mel scale), and timbral characteristics (MFCCs). By applying Non-Negative Tensor Factorization (NTF) with a Kullback-Leibler divergence objective, we decompose this tensor into a set of basis vectors corresponding to recurring musical components and a temporal activation matrix that reveals their structural arrangement. This multi-aspectual decomposition allows for a more nuanced segmentation, capable of distinguishing sections based on shared instrumentation versus shared melodic content. Tested on complex orchestral works, the method yields formal analyses that more closely align with expert musicological annotations than state-of-the-art SSM-based techniques.
subject: Müzik
title: Decomposing Musical Form: A Non-Negative Tensor Factorization Approach to Unsupervised Audio Structure Analysis

text: Orchestration is the art of combining instrumental timbres, yet its perceptual effects remain difficult to quantify. We present a computational model that analyzes orchestration by simulating auditory salience and attentional focus. The model takes multi-track orchestral audio as input and first performs source-specific spectral analysis. It then applies a psychoacoustically-informed salience function to each source, integrating factors such as loudness, spectral masking, pitch register, spectral flux, and harmonicity. The output of this stage is a multi-dimensional salience map. This map is processed by a recurrent neural network with a learned attention mechanism, which simulates the listener's focus shifting between instrumental layers over time. The final output is a time-varying vector quantifying the perceptual prominence of each instrument or section. We validate the model's predictions against empirical data from listening tests, demonstrating its ability to accurately identify the primary melodic voice in complex orchestral textures, thus providing an objective tool for musicological analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Modeling Auditory Salience and Attention for the Computational Analysis of Orchestration

text: We investigate the Turán-type problem for expanded triangular configurations in k-uniform hypergraphs. Let T_k denote the 3-uniform hypergraph with 4 vertices and 3 edges forming a loose triangle. We study its k-uniform expansion, denoted T_k(exp), which is a k-uniform hypergraph on k+1 vertices. Our main result establishes a new upper bound on the Turán density π(T_k(exp)), demonstrating that π(T_k(exp)) ≤ (k-2)/(k-1)!. This improves upon previous bounds derived from general supersaturation arguments. The proof employs the method of flag algebras, which translates extremal hypergraph problems into semidefinite programming problems. We introduce a novel algebra of partially labeled k-graphs and define a set of positive semidefinite constraints based on the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality. The numerical solution to this program, verified with a formal certificate, yields the stated bound. This result provides further evidence for the conjecture that for many loose structures, the Turán density is determined by constructions avoiding specific intersection patterns.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Turán Density of Expanded Triangles in k-Uniform Hypergraphs

text: The decomposition of the Kronecker product of two irreducible characters of the symmetric group S_n remains a central open problem in algebraic combinatorics. We approach this problem by studying the plethysm of Schur functions s_μ[s_ν], specifically focusing on the structure of the corresponding Foulkes modules. Our primary contribution is a novel combinatorial rule for the multiplicity of the trivial character in the character of the Foulkes module for two-row shapes μ=(n,n) and ν=(m,m). This is achieved by constructing an explicit basis for the S_{2m}-invariants in the plethystic composition of symmetric powers of the natural S_{2n}-module. The basis elements are indexed by a specific class of non-crossing partitions decorated with integer weights. This result resolves a special case of the plethysm problem and establishes a concrete link between representation-theoretic multiplicity and tableau combinatorics, offering a new perspective on the stability properties of Kronecker coefficients.
subject: Matematik
title: Plethystic Decompositions of Foulkes Modules and Their Connection to the Kronecker Problem

text: We determine a sharp threshold for the existence of a Hamilton cycle in the stochastic block model G(n,p,q) with two balanced communities of size n/2. The classical results of Bollobás and Komlós establish a sharp threshold for Hamiltonicity in the Erdős–Rényi model G(n,p). The community structure of the SBM introduces significant analytical challenges due to its inherent inhomogeneity. We prove that if np(1+q/p) → ∞ and np ≥ log n + log log n + ω(1), where ω(1) is any function tending to infinity, then G(n,p,q) is asymptotically almost surely Hamiltonian. Our proof integrates the 'sprinkling' method with a sophisticated absorption strategy tailored to the block model structure.
