We utilize a multi-stage vertex exposure process to carefully control the growth of paths across community boundaries, leveraging spectral properties of the expected adjacency matrix to guarantee the existence of necessary connector structures. This result precisely characterizes how community density influences the emergence of global spanning structures.
subject: Matematik
title: A Sharp Threshold for Hamiltonicity in Stochastic Block Models

text: We study the spectral properties of random n-lifts of a base graph G. A key question in spectral graph theory is the construction of graphs with large spectral gaps, known as expander graphs. We prove that if G is a d-regular graph with a sufficiently large second eigenvalue gap, then a random n-lift of G is, with high probability, a Ramanujan graph, thus achieving an optimal spectral gap. Our proof deviates from standard trace methods and instead relies on a novel application of eigenvalue interlacing theorems for partitioned matrices. We analyze the characteristic polynomial of the lifted graph's adjacency matrix by relating it to a matrix-valued polynomial whose coefficients are non-commuting random variables. By establishing concentration inequalities for the norms of these matrix products, we bound the new eigenvalues away from the 'trivial' eigenvalues inherited from the base graph. This provides a new constructive approach for families of near-optimal expander graphs with significant implications for network theory.
subject: Matematik
title: Eigenvalue Interlacing and Spectral Gaps of Random Lifts of Graphs

text: We establish a new isoperimetric inequality for functions defined over finite graded posets equipped with a non-uniform product measure. Generalizing the classical edge-isoperimetry of Harper's theorem, our result relates the measure of the upper boundary of a set to a weighted sum of its elements' cardinalities. From this inequality, we derive a generalization of the Kahn-Kalai-Linial (KKL) theorem on the influence of variables. Specifically, we prove that for any Boolean function f defined on the poset, there exists an element whose influence is bounded below by Var(f) multiplied by a term depending on the poset's spectral gap and diameter. The proof involves analyzing the 'down-up' Markov chain on the poset and applying spectral techniques to its transition matrix. This result provides a powerful tool for analyzing threshold phenomena in non-uniform settings and has direct applications to the study of monotone properties on structured domains like the subset lattice with non-uniform probabilities.
subject: Matematik
title: An Isoperimetric Inequality for Weighted Posets and a KKL-type Theorem

text: We investigate the existence of polynomial progressions {a, a+P(d), ..., a+(k-1)P(d)} in subsets of integers, extending classical results from additive combinatorics. We prove a Szemerédi-type theorem for sparse sets that are pseudorandom in a Gowers uniformity sense. Let A ⊆ {1,...,N} be a set with density δ. We show that if A has a sufficiently small U^s(Z_N) uniformity norm for an appropriate s depending on the degree of the polynomial P, then A must contain a k-term polynomial progression. The proof combines the density increment strategy of Roth and Gowers with a quantitative version of the Bergelson-Leibman polynomial recurrence theorem. We develop a 'polynomial regularity lemma' that allows us to decompose the indicator function of A into a structured part, which is constant on a polynomial nilsequence, and a uniformly random part. This demonstrates the robustness of higher-order Fourier analysis in detecting algebraic configurations within sets lacking uniform global density.
subject: Matematik
title: Polynomial Progressions in Sparse Pseudorandom Sets

text: A t-(v, k, λ) design is incomplete if its block set is disjoint from a set of blocks on a smaller subset of points, called a hole. We investigate the existence of resolvable (v,4,1)-balanced incomplete block designs (BIBDs) with a hole of size h. Such designs are equivalent to group divisible designs of type h^u, where v = hu. The necessary conditions for existence are v, h ≡ 4 (mod 12) and v ≥ 4h. This paper almost completely settles the existence question by proving these necessary conditions are sufficient for all v > C*h for some absolute constant C. The proof is based on a combination of recursive PBD-closure arguments and direct constructions using finite fields. We introduce a new 'frame-based inflation' technique that combines starter blocks from base groups with resolvable structures derived from affine planes of order 4. This fills a significant gap in the design theory literature and provides new tools for related construction problems.
subject: Matematik
title: The Existence Spectrum for Incomplete Resolvable (v,4,1)-Designs with Specified Hole Sizes

text: We introduce the concept of a tropical oriented matroid, a combinatorial structure that axiomatizes the signs of the maximal minors of a real matrix whose entries are Puiseux series. This framework provides a bridge between classical oriented matroid theory and tropical geometry. A tropical oriented matroid is defined by a sign function on the cocircuits of a matroid that satisfies a tropical analogue of the Graßmann-Plücker relations. Our main result establishes a fundamental duality theorem: the set of all realizable tropical oriented matroids on a given ground set forms a polyhedral complex that is combinatorially equivalent to the secondary fan of a specific zonotope. This is proven by showing that the chirotope of a realizable tropical oriented matroid corresponds to the initial forms of the Plücker coordinates under a specific valuation. This framework unifies several disparate concepts and offers new algorithmic tools for studying matroid realization spaces.
subject: Matematik
title: Tropical Oriented Matroids and the Combinatorics of the Secondary Fan

text: We provide new asymptotic lower bounds for the off-diagonal van der Waerden-Ramsey numbers WR(k; r_1, ..., r_c), which denote the smallest integer n such that any c-coloring of {1, ..., n} contains a monochromatic k-term arithmetic progression in some color i of length r_i. Our focus is the case where k=3 and the number of colors c is large. Previous bounds relied primarily on the Lovász Local Lemma. We present a novel probabilistic construction that combines a random coloring with a carefully designed alteration phase. The initial coloring is chosen to minimize certain monochromatic substructures, and then a derandomized alteration algorithm is applied to eliminate the remaining forbidden progressions. This hybrid approach allows us to show that WR(3; r, c) > c^(r^2-r-o(1)) for fixed r and large c, significantly improving upon the existing exponential bounds. The methodology is robust and suggests potential applications to other Ramsey-type problems on integers and graphs.
subject: Matematik
title: A Probabilistic Construction Yielding New Lower Bounds for Off-Diagonal van der Waerden-Ramsey Numbers

text: We study the class of permutations avoiding the barred pattern 3-1-4-2, which corresponds to permutations sortable by a deque in a specific manner. We derive the ordinary generating function A(z) for this class by developing a functional equation based on a catalytic variable that tracks the number of active sites in the permutation's grid representation. We demonstrate that A(z) is not D-finite, precluding standard P-recursive enumeration techniques. Instead, we employ advanced methods from analytic combinatorics. By analyzing the kernel of the functional equation, we locate the dominant singularity z_c of A(z) and determine its algebraic nature. A detailed singularity analysis reveals the asymptotic behavior of the coefficients [z^n]A(z), proving that the number of such permutations of length n is asymptotically C * ρ^n * n^(-γ), where ρ and γ are algebraic constants we explicitly compute. This work showcases the power of analytic methods for non-P-recursive sequences in enumerative combinatorics.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotic Enumeration of Permutations Avoiding a Class of Barred Patterns via Singularity Analysis

text: Conventional gradient-based optimizers in deep learning often struggle with non-convex loss landscapes characterized by numerous local minima and saddle points. We introduce a hybrid quantum-classical framework that leverages a Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) to navigate these complex geometries. Our approach parameterizes a subsection of a neural network's weight space as a parameterized quantum circuit (PQC), with the loss function encoded as a problem Hamiltonian. By stochastically sampling gradients from the quantum co-processor, our method can exploit quantum tunneling phenomena to escape sharp local minima that trap classical optimizers like Adam and SGD. We provide a theoretical analysis of the algorithm's convergence properties and demonstrate its empirical superiority on benchmark optimization tasks and in training compact neural networks for combinatorial problems. The results suggest a potential quantum advantage in optimizing highly non-convex functions, paving the way for more robust deep learning training paradigms.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Optimization for Non-Convex Geometries in Deep Learning

text: We address the dual challenges of security and privacy in decentralized machine learning by proposing a novel aggregation protocol, Byzantine-Robust Federated Optimization with Calibrated Differential Privacy (Fed-CDP). Our framework is designed for federated learning environments susceptible to both data poisoning attacks and privacy breaches. Fed-CDP integrates a robust aggregation rule based on the geometric median of model updates, which provably bounds the influence of an arbitrary number of Byzantine attackers, with a client-level differential privacy mechanism. A key innovation is our adaptive noise calibration scheme, which adjusts the privacy budget based on the statistical distribution of benign client contributions, thereby optimizing the privacy-utility trade-off. We provide rigorous theoretical guarantees for convergence under non-IID data distributions and demonstrate through extensive simulations that Fed-CDP significantly outperforms state-of-the-art robust and private federated learning algorithms in terms of model fidelity and resilience to adversarial perturbations.
subject: AI
title: Byzantine-Robust Federated Optimization with Calibrated Differential Privacy

text: We introduce an E(3)-equivariant graph neural network architecture for predicting quantum mechanical properties of molecules directly from their 3D conformations. Unlike conventional GNNs that operate on invariant features, our model processes geometric data such as interatomic distances and angles through equivariant message-passing layers. This design intrinsically respects the rotational and translational symmetries of the physical system, leading to superior data efficiency and generalization. The model leverages steerable filters implemented via spherical harmonics and tensor field networks to construct high-order equivariant representations that capture complex geometric and chemical relationships. We demonstrate state-of-the-art performance on the QM9 benchmark for predicting multiple molecular properties, achieving lower mean absolute error rates with significantly fewer training parameters and epochs than non-equivariant baselines. Our work underscores the critical role of incorporating physical symmetries into model architectures for scientific machine learning.
subject: AI
title: E(3)-Equivariant Graph Neural Networks for Geometric Deep Learning on Molecular Conformations

text: We propose a novel self-supervised learning framework, Information-Theoretic Cross-Modal Contrast (ICMC), for learning disentangled and semantically rich representations from unlabeled multimodal data, such as video and audio. The core of our approach is a contrastive objective that maximizes the mutual information between corresponding representations from different modalities while simultaneously minimizing the statistical dependency among latent factors within each representation. This is achieved by augmenting a standard InfoNCE loss with a total correlation penalty term, approximated using a neural discriminator network. This dual objective forces the model to encode shared semantic information (e.g., object identity) separately from modality-specific information (e.g., visual texture or audio timbre). The resulting representations demonstrate state-of-the-art performance on downstream tasks like zero-shot classification and cross-modal retrieval, and quantitative evaluations confirm their superior disentanglement properties, enhancing both interpretability and transferability.
subject: AI
title: Disentangled Representation Learning via Information-Theoretic Cross-Modal Contrast

text: We propose a novel Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) architecture, SA-GAN, capable of synthesizing photorealistic, high-resolution images without conditional inputs. Our model integrates a self-attention mechanism with spectral normalization in both the generator and discriminator. The spectral normalization constrains the Lipschitz constant of the networks, which stabilizes training dynamics, while the self-attention mechanism enables the modeling of long-range, multi-scale dependencies across the image. We introduce a novel progressive growing strategy coupled with a modified Wasserstein loss function incorporating a R1 gradient penalty, achieving state-of-the-art Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) and Inception Scores on benchmark datasets like CelebA-HQ and FFHQ. Ablation studies confirm that the synergy between spectral normalization and self-attention is critical for generating images with high global coherence and fine-grained detail, demonstrating significant qualitative and quantitative improvements over existing unconditional GANs.
subject: AI
title: Spectral-Attention GANs for Unconditional High-Fidelity Image Synthesis

text: We address the challenge of rapid adaptation in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) under non-stationary conditions, where environmental dynamics or agent objectives change over time. Our proposed framework, Meta-Adaptive Latent State Inference (MALSI), formulates this problem as a partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP) where the environment's current dynamics constitute a latent variable. MALSI employs a recurrent variational autoencoder to infer a low-dimensional representation of the task dynamics from recent trajectory history. This latent context vector conditions a shared policy network, enabling zero-shot or few-shot adaptation to novel dynamics without explicit retraining. We demonstrate that MALSI significantly outperforms state-of-the-art meta-RL and MARL algorithms in complex cooperative and competitive domains characterized by abrupt and periodic changes in environmental parameters, showcasing superior sample efficiency and asymptotic performance.
subject: AI
title: Meta-Reinforcement Learning via Latent State Inference for Rapid Adaptation in Non-Stationary Environments

text: Modeling long-range dependencies in gigabase-scale genomic sequences remains a significant computational challenge for standard Transformer architectures due to their quadratic complexity in sequence length. We present the Genomic Long-read Transformer (GLTR), a novel architecture employing a combination of sparse attention mechanisms, including dilated, strided, and local attention patterns. This hybrid approach allows the model to capture both local sequence motifs and distal regulatory interactions over sequences exceeding 100,000 base pairs, with near-linear complexity. We apply GLTR to the task of predicting chromatin accessibility and histone modifications from raw DNA sequence. Our model significantly outperforms convolutional and recurrent neural network baselines, as well as standard Transformer models, establishing a new state-of-the-art in cis-regulatory element prediction. GLTR provides a scalable and effective framework for deciphering the long-range regulatory grammar of the genome.
subject: AI
title: Genomic Long-read Transformer (GLTR): A Sparse Attention Model for Epigenetic State Prediction

text: A fundamental challenge in machine learning is generalizing to out-of-distribution (OOD) data, a common failure mode for models that learn spurious correlations. We propose a framework for learning invariant causal predictors by explicitly modeling environmental heterogeneity. Our method, Causal Invariant Representation Learning (CIRL), leverages multiple training environments to disentangle causal mechanisms from spurious, environment-specific associations. CIRL optimizes a minimax objective where a representation encoder is trained to be invariant across environments while a set of environment-specific predictors compete to maximize predictive accuracy. We provide theoretical guarantees that under certain identifiability assumptions, the learned representation captures the true causal structure. Empirically, we demonstrate on both synthetic and real-world benchmarks, including medical imaging and natural language processing, that CIRL significantly improves OOD generalization compared to empirical risk minimization and domain-adversarial training methods.
subject: AI
title: Learning Invariant Causal Representations for Out-of-Distribution Generalization

text: We introduce a novel, computationally efficient algorithm for Bayesian inference in deep neural networks, termed Manifold Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (mSGLD). Traditional SGLD methods operate in Euclidean parameter space, which can be inefficient for navigating the complex, high-dimensional posterior landscapes of deep models. Our approach exploits the intrinsic geometry of the parameter space by performing Langevin updates on a pre-conditioned manifold, effectively adapting to the local curvature. This is achieved by using a Riemann metric tensor derived from the Fisher information matrix, resulting in faster convergence and more effective exploration of the posterior distribution. We demonstrate that mSGLD provides superior uncertainty quantification and model calibration on tasks such as image classification and regression under dataset shift, outperforming standard variational inference, MC-Dropout, and deep ensembles while maintaining computational tractability for large-scale architectures like ResNets.
subject: AI
title: Scalable Manifold Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics for Bayesian Deep Learning

text: We propose a novel neuro-symbolic framework that integrates deep generative models with a differentiable inductive logic programming (∂ILP) engine for enhanced causal reasoning and explainability. The neural component, a variational autoencoder, learns a low-dimensional latent representation from raw perceptual data. This latent space is then interfaced with the symbolic component, where the ∂ILP system induces first-order logic rules that govern the relationships between latent variables. This hybrid architecture allows for end-to-end training via backpropagation, enabling the simultaneous optimization of perception and reasoning modules. We evaluate our model on tasks requiring abstract causal inference from visual scenes, demonstrating its ability to learn interpretable rules that generalize to unseen scenarios and provide logical explanations for its predictions. Our approach significantly outperforms purely neural or purely symbolic baselines, bridging the gap between statistical pattern recognition and abstract logical reasoning.
subject: AI
title: Hybrid Neuro-Symbolic Architectures for Inductive Logic Programming and Causal Reasoning

text: Estimating heterogeneous treatment effects in high-dimensional settings is confounded by regularization bias from variable selection and the curse of dimensionality. This paper introduces a doubly robust, debiased machine learning framework for estimating the Conditional Average Treatment Effect (CATE). Our approach leverages cross-fitting and Neyman-orthogonal moments to construct an estimator that is insensitive to first-order errors in the nuisance function estimations—namely, the propensity score and conditional outcome models. We employ sparse learners, such as the LASSO, for these nuisance components. The proposed CATE estimator is shown to be asymptotically Gaussian and achieves the semi-parametric efficiency bound under standard sparsity and overlap conditions, facilitating valid confidence intervals. This theoretical guarantee holds even with imperfect nuisance models, provided one is consistently estimated at a sufficient rate. Monte Carlo simulations demonstrate superior performance in terms of bias reduction and coverage probability compared to existing methods. We illustrate the methodology by analyzing individualized treatment rules in a high-dimensional genomic dataset.
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Causal Inference for High-Dimensional Sparse Models with Heterogeneous Treatment Effects

text: Topological Data Analysis (TDA), particularly persistent homology, offers powerful tools for characterizing the shape of data. However, a significant gap remains in performing rigorous statistical inference on topological features. This paper introduces a non-parametric inferential framework for comparing persistence diagrams. We propose a test statistic based on the integrated squared Wasserstein distance between persistence diagrams, which is robust to noise and computationally efficient. To assess statistical significance, we develop a permutation testing procedure that correctly accounts for the complex dependencies inherent in the data-to-topology transformation. We formally prove that our permutation scheme provides asymptotic control over the Type I error rate under the null hypothesis of identical underlying distributions. The method's statistical power is demonstrated on synthetic data generated from distinct geometric manifolds and applied to a neuroimaging study to detect significant differences in brain functional connectivity networks between clinical populations, revealing topological biomarkers not discernible through conventional statistical tests.
subject: İstatistik
title: A Permutation-Based Framework for Statistical Inference on Persistent Homology

text: We address the statistical challenge of analyzing data where each subject provides a trajectory of high-dimensional vectors, a structure prevalent in modern biomedical studies. This paper proposes a sparse functional principal component analysis (sFPCA) method to extract dominant modes of variation. Our approach simultaneously accommodates the functional nature of the data and the high-dimensional character of each measurement. A novel penalized quasi-likelihood objective function is introduced, incorporating both a smoothing penalty on the functional principal components (FPCs) and a sparsity-inducing penalty (e.g., L1) on the loadings within each FPC. This dual regularization yields interpretable FPCs and handles the p >> n problem at each time point. We develop a computationally efficient algorithm based on iterative functional singular value decomposition. Asymptotic properties, including rates of convergence for the estimated eigenfunctions and eigenvalues, are established under high-dimensional scaling. The utility of sFPCA is showcased through an analysis of longitudinal gene expression data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Sparse Functional Principal Component Analysis for Longitudinally Collected High-Dimensional Data

text: Classical statistical inference is invalidated when hypotheses are chosen adaptively after data exploration. This paper extends the theory of post-selection inference to the domain of distributional comparisons using optimal transport (OT). We develop a framework for performing valid inference on quantities like the Wasserstein distance between two populations, subsequent to a data-driven model selection step. By conditioning on the selection event, characterized as a polyhedral set in the sample space, we derive exact conditional p-values and confidence intervals that maintain nominal coverage. Our method applies to a range of selection procedures, including choosing which pair of distributions to compare from a larger set or selecting covariates in a distributional regression model where the response is a probability distribution. The methodology is demonstrated to control the selective Type I error in flow cytometry and single-cell RNA sequencing analyses, where identifying significant distributional shifts is a primary scientific objective.
subject: İstatistik
title: Selective Inference for Optimal Transport and Distributional Regression

text: Prevailing spatiotemporal models often rely on the restrictive assumption of stationarity, limiting their applicability to complex environmental and epidemiological systems. We propose a highly flexible hierarchical Bayesian model that captures non-stationarity by allowing the parameters of a Gaussian Process (GP) covariance function to evolve over time. Specifically, the spatial range, variance, and anisotropy parameters are modeled as a latent multivariate stochastic process, governed by a dynamic linear model. This formulation induces a non-stationary spatiotemporal covariance structure capable of adapting to time-varying physical phenomena. Posterior inference is conducted efficiently using a bespoke Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) algorithm that exploits the model's state-space representation. We prove model identifiability under weak conditions and demonstrate its superior predictive performance, both in simulation and in an application to modeling atmospheric pollutant concentrations, where our model effectively captures dynamically changing dispersion patterns driven by meteorological shifts.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Spatiotemporal Gaussian Process Models with Non-Stationary Covariance Structures

text: Estimating causal effects in networked populations is challenging due to interference, where an individual's outcome depends on the treatments of their neighbors, violating the Stable Unit Treatment Value Assumption (SUTVA). This paper proposes a novel framework to estimate average causal effects under such interference. We redefine treatment exposure by creating a high-dimensional vector for each unit summarizing its neighborhood's treatment assignments. To overcome the curse of dimensionality, we employ graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn a low-dimensional embedding of each unit's joint treatment and covariate profile. A propensity score, representing the probability of observing a specific embedding, is then estimated. Stratification on this learned propensity score allows for balancing complex exposure patterns, enabling unbiased estimation of direct and indirect (spillover) effects. We establish formal conditions for identification and consistency of the estimator and demonstrate its reduced bias and variance compared to existing methods through semi-synthetic experiments on social network data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Causal Inference under Network Interference using Propensity Score Stratification on Nodal Embeddings

text: The confluence of high-dimensionality and data contamination poses a significant challenge for statistical estimation in Generalized Linear Models (GLMs). We introduce a novel robust and sparse estimator, termed the Penalized Trimmed-Likelihood Estimator (PTE), that is resilient to adversarial outliers in both the response and covariates. The PTE is defined through a joint optimization of a trimmed negative log-likelihood function and an L1-penalty. This formulation is non-convex, but we develop a computationally efficient algorithm that iterates between identifying potential outliers and solving a weighted penalized regression, which provably converges to a stationary point. Theoretically, we establish that the PTE possesses a high breakdown point and achieves near-optimal statistical error rates, matching the minimax rate for sparse GLMs under standard regularity conditions. The empirical performance of our method is validated via extensive simulations, showing a marked advantage over existing robust and non-robust sparse estimators, and through an analysis of a cancer cell-line dataset.
subject: İstatistik
title: A Computationally Efficient Robust Estimator for High-Dimensional Generalized Linear Models

text: This work investigates the statistical and computational properties of entropically regularized optimal transport (OT) as a foundational tool for modern machine learning. We demonstrate that the Sinkhorn divergence, derived from this regularization, serves as a robust and computationally tractable alternative to the Wasserstein distance, enabling stable, gradient-based optimization in high-dimensional settings. We leverage this to propose the Sinkhorn-GAN, a generative adversarial network variant that mitigates mode collapse and training instability by using the Sinkhorn divergence as its critic's loss function. Furthermore, we develop a novel unsupervised domain adaptation method by learning a barycentric projection that minimizes the OT cost between source and target distributions. We provide rigorous theoretical analysis, including generalization bounds for the learned transport maps and statistical consistency of the generative model. Empirical results on benchmark datasets for image generation and classification confirm the theoretical advantages, demonstrating state-of-the-art performance and enhanced stability.
subject: İstatistik
title: Entropically Regularized Optimal Transport for Generative Modeling and Domain Adaptation

text: Predicting patient outcomes dynamically over time using longitudinal data is a critical task in clinical research. We introduce the Competing Risk Recurrent Survival Network (CRRSN), a deep learning framework designed for dynamic prediction in the presence of competing events. The model employs a recurrent neural network (RNN) to process sequences of time-dependent covariates, effectively learning a rich representation of each patient's history. This representation is then fed into a cause-specific output layer that jointly models the hazard functions for all event types. A key innovation is our training objective, which directly minimizes a time-dependent Brier score integrated over a prediction horizon, aligning the model with its ultimate evaluation metric. This landmarking-based approach naturally handles the non-proportional hazards and complex interactions prevalent in electronic health records. On a large-scale clinical dataset, CRRSN demonstrates substantially improved discrimination and calibration for predicting multiple clinical endpoints compared to Cox models and other machine learning baselines.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Prediction in Survival Analysis using Recurrent Neural Networks with Competing Risks

text: The neo-Darwinian synthesis posits genetic mutation as the primary source of heritable variation. However, this paradigm is challenged by evidence for transgenerational epigenetic inheritance (TEI). We investigated the role of stress-induced DNA methylation dynamics in rapid adaptation in Arabidopsis thaliana. Using whole-genome bisulfite sequencing across three generations subjected to simulated drought, we identified hundreds of differentially methylated regions (DMRs) that were stably inherited, independent of genetic sequence. These epialleles were strongly correlated with altered gene expression profiles, particularly in stress-response pathways, and conferred enhanced drought tolerance in F3 progeny naive to the stressor. Our findings demonstrate that environmentally-induced epigenetic modifications can act as a quasi-Lamarckian inheritance system, providing a rapid mechanism for adaptive plasticity that precedes and potentially guides genetic assimilation. This challenges classical evolutionary models by highlighting the methylome as a crucial, heritable substrate for natural selection in fluctuating environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance Mediates Rapid Adaptive Responses to Environmental Stressors

text: Canalization, the buffering of developmental pathways against genetic and environmental perturbation, is thought to constrain evolutionary potential. We explored the role of the molecular chaperone Hsp90 as a phenotypic capacitor that masks underlying cryptic genetic variation (CGV). By systematically depleting Hsp90 function in a panel of Drosophila melanogaster isogenic lines, we uncovered a striking diversity of novel, polygenic morphological phenotypes not present in wild-type populations. Genome-wide association studies linked these emergent traits to previously neutral or weakly deleterious alleles within complex gene regulatory networks. When subjected to novel selective pressures, populations with compromised Hsp90 function exhibited accelerated rates of adaptation, effectively converting cryptic variation into adaptive innovation. This study provides empirical support for Hsp90 as a key evolutionary modulator, facilitating punctuated equilibria by releasing stored genetic potential during periods of environmental stress, thereby linking molecular-level buffering to macroevolutionary patterns.
subject: Evrim
title: Decanalization of Cryptic Genetic Variation by Hsp90 Depletion Drives Evolutionary Innovation

text: The introgression of archaic hominin DNA into modern human genomes represents a significant source of adaptive variation. We present a fine-scale paleogenomic reconstruction of the EPAS1 locus, a gene critical for hypoxia tolerance, in Tibetan populations. Using phased genomic data and novel statistical methods to distinguish introgression from incomplete lineage sorting, we demonstrate that the adaptive high-altitude EPAS1 haplotype is of Denisovan origin. The introgressed segment shows extreme allele frequency differentiation and an extended haplotype homozygosity signature consistent with a hard selective sweep post-admixture. Functional genomic analyses reveal that the archaic allele alters a key hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) binding site, leading to a blunted erythropoietic response that mitigates the risk of polycythemia at altitude. Our results provide a compelling case of adaptive introgression, where admixture with an extinct hominin species furnished a pre-adapted genetic solution to a novel and extreme environmental challenge.
subject: Evrim
title: Archaic Introgression of a Denisovan EPAS1 Haplotype Confers High-Altitude Adaptation in Tibetan Populations

text: Antagonistic coevolution is a primary driver of biodiversity, yet direct observation of its underlying molecular dynamics is rare. We investigated the coevolutionary interplay between the Arabidopsis thaliana RPP13 resistance gene and its corresponding avirulence effector ATR13 from the oomycete pathogen Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis. By combining population genomics of natural accessions with in vitro protein-protein interaction assays, we identified a molecular signature of an ongoing selective arms race. We found extensive, reciprocally-driven positive selection localized to the leucine-rich repeat (LRR) domain of RPP13 and the C-terminal domain of ATR13, regions directly involved in their physical interaction. Allelic diversity at these loci exhibits negative frequency-dependent selection, where rare resistance and avirulence alleles confer fitness advantages, consistent with Red Queen dynamics. This study elucidates the molecular architecture of coevolution, demonstrating how reciprocal selective pressures shape polymorphism and maintain genetic diversity in host-parasite systems.
subject: Evrim
title: Molecular Evidence for Red Queen Dynamics in a Plant-Pathogen Coevolutionary Arms Race

text: The evolutionary transition to multicellularity (an ETI) is a foundational event in the history of life, yet its initial genetic and ecological drivers remain contentious. We performed a long-term experimental evolution study using the unicellular alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, selecting for rapid sedimentation. Within 500 generations, all replicate populations evolved obligately multicellular 'snowflake' clusters. Whole-genome sequencing revealed that distinct, parallel mutations in cell cycle regulatory genes underpinned this convergent phenotype. However, the subsequent evolution of a germ-soma division of labor occurred in only a subset of lineages and was contingent upon the specific initial mutation and subsequent ecological feedbacks. Our results suggest that while the initial step to simple multicellularity may be genetically accessible and predictable, the evolution of complex individuality involving cellular differentiation is a highly stochastic process, constrained by historical contingency and the specific genetic architecture of the founding mutations.
subject: Evrim
title: Experimental Evolution of Multicellularity Reveals a Stochastic Path to Division of Labor

text: Resolving the deep phylogenetic relationships at the base of the animal tree of life is a persistent challenge, complicated by rapid ancient radiations. We employed a novel phylogenomic approach, integrating ultraconserved elements (UCEs) and genome-wide coding sequences from 150 taxa, to address the contentious placement of Ctenophora and Porifera. Coalescent-based species tree analyses robustly support the Ctenophora-sister hypothesis. However, analyses of individual gene trees reveal pervasive phylogenetic conflict across the genome, with a significant proportion of loci supporting the alternative Porifera-sister topology. We demonstrate that this incongruence is best explained by extensive incomplete lineage sorting (ILS) stemming from a rapid succession of cladogenic events near the Mesoproterozoic-Neoproterozoic boundary. Our findings caution against reliance on concatenated supermatrix methods for deep-time phylogenetics and highlight that the earliest animal divergences may represent a hard polytomy, a biological reality rather than an analytical artifact, challenging the notion of a simple bifurcating tree.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Conflict and Incomplete Lineage Sorting Obscure the Early Diversification of Metazoa

text: The evolution of sexual recombination is a central paradox in evolutionary biology, given its inherent costs. The Red Queen hypothesis posits that recombination is advantageous as it generates novel genotypes to combat coevolving parasites. We tested this by investigating the relationship between genome-wide recombination rates and parasite load across 50 species of passerine birds. Using high-density linkage maps and comparative phylogenetic methods, we found a strong positive correlation between a species' mean recombination rate and its prevalence of avian malaria (Plasmodium spp.). This association was particularly pronounced in genomic regions enriched for immune-related genes, such as the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC). These findings provide macroevolutionary evidence that parasite-mediated selection is a potent force shaping the genomic architecture of recombination, favoring higher crossover rates to break down linkage disequilibrium and expedite the generation of adaptive immune system variants in a coevolutionary arms race.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Recombination Landscapes Are Shaped by Parasite-Mediated Selection

text: Understanding the genetic basis of local adaptation is critical for predicting species' responses to climate change. We integrated whole-genome sequencing data with high-resolution environmental variables for 500 Populus trichocarpa individuals across a latitudinal gradient. Using multiple genotype-environment association (GEA) methods, including redundancy analysis (RDA), we identified thousands of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) associated with temperature and precipitation gradients. Contrary to a simple 'gene-for-trait' model, adaptive traits like bud set timing were highly polygenic. We developed a genomic offset model that uses the degree of mismatch between current and future projected allele frequencies to predict population vulnerability. This model demonstrates that peripheral populations at the southern range edge possess low adaptive potential and high maladaptation risk. Our study highlights the power of landscape genomics to dissect the polygenic architecture of adaptation and provides a robust framework for forecasting climate-induced evolutionary trajectories in non-model organisms.
subject: Evrim
title: Landscape Genomics Reveals Polygenic Architecture and Predictive Power for Local Adaptation to Climate

text: The origin of novel morphological structures is a hallmark of macroevolution. The insect wing, a key innovation, is hypothesized to have evolved from either the dorsal body wall or proximal leg segments of an ancestral crustacean. We used comparative transcriptomics and functional genomics (CRISPR-Cas9) in the wingless crustacean Parhyale hawaiensis and the winged beetle Tribolium castaneum to investigate the deep homology of wing development. We demonstrate that the core gene regulatory network (GRN) controlling wing specification in insects, including transcription factors like vestigial (vg) and scalloped (sd), is deeply conserved and functions in the lateral body wall of the crustacean embryo. This suggests that the entire network was co-opted from a pre-existing developmental module. Subsequent diversification, particularly the recruitment of downstream effector genes, then drove the morphogenesis of the novel wing structure, providing a clear example of how evolutionary novelty arises through the redeployment of ancient genetic toolkits.
subject: Evrim
title: Co-option and Divergence of a Conserved Gene Regulatory Network Underlies Insect Wing Evolution

text: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a major evolutionary force in prokaryotes, but its quantitative impact on eukaryotic genomes remains debated. We conducted a comprehensive phylogenomic analysis across 120 genomes of free-living protists from diverse supergroups. Using stringent phylogenetic incongruence tests and accounting for endosymbiotic gene transfer, we identified over 5,000 robust cases of bacteria-to-eukaryote HGT. These acquired genes are not randomly distributed but are significantly enriched for functions in metabolic pathways, particularly carbohydrate metabolism and detoxification, which are often absent in non-HGT-recipient sister taxa. Functional expression of a transferred bacterial cellulase in a Naegleria host confirmed its role in conferring a novel trophic capability. Our results demonstrate that HGT is a continuous and potent mechanism for eukaryotic innovation, allowing microbial eukaryotes to rapidly acquire novel metabolic functions and adapt to new ecological niches, thereby challenging the conventional view of vertically inherited genomes.
subject: Evrim
title: Pervasive Horizontal Gene Transfer from Bacteria Fuels Metabolic Innovation in Eukaryotic Protists

text: Traditional pitch estimation algorithms, optimized for 12-tone equal temperament (12-TET), exhibit significant performance degradation when applied to microtonal music, particularly works employing just intonation (JI). This paper introduces a novel deep learning architecture, the Sub-Harmonic Convolutional Neural Network (SH-CNN), designed for high-resolution pitch estimation in non-12-TET contexts. Our model operates on a finely-grained constant-Q transform (CQT) and incorporates a learnable sub-harmonic summation layer inspired by psychoacoustic models of pitch perception. This layer explicitly models the harmonic relationships inherent in JI systems. We train and evaluate the SH-CNN on a newly curated dataset of synthesized and recorded JI performances, demonstrating a substantial reduction in cent deviation error compared to state-of-the-art pitch trackers like CREPE and pYIN. The results validate the efficacy of integrating music-theoretically informed inductive biases into deep learning frameworks for nuanced audio analysis, paving the way for computational musicology of microtonal repertoires.
subject: Müzik
title: A Sub-Harmonic Convolutional Architecture for Microtonal Pitch Estimation in Just Intonation Contexts

text: The precise tuning temperament used in historical keyboard performances is a critical, yet often unrecoverable, aspect of historically informed practice. This research presents a probabilistic framework for inferring historical temperaments directly from polyphonic audio recordings. We formulate a Bayesian model where the latent variables are the fundamental frequencies of all 12 pitch classes, constrained by a prior distribution over a dictionary of well-documented historical temperaments (e.g., Meantone, Well-Tempered systems). Using a multi-pitch estimation front-end to extract spectral evidence, we employ a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm, specifically Gibbs sampling, to approximate the posterior distribution of the temperament parameters. Applied to a corpus of harpsichord recordings, our method successfully identifies the most probable temperament with high confidence, outperforming methods based on simple histogram analysis of pitch deviations. This work offers a robust computational tool for musicologists, enabling empirical investigation into historical tuning practices.
subject: Müzik
title: Bayesian Inference of Historical Keyboard Temperaments from Polyphonic Audio Recordings

text: Analyzing the intricate web of voice leading in Renaissance polyphony poses a significant challenge for traditional computational models. This paper proposes a novel representation using hypergraphs to capture the multi-part contrapuntal relationships that define the style. Unlike simple graphs that model pairwise interactions, our hypergraph model represents each simultaneous sonority as a hyperedge connecting the constituent note vertices. We then define a set of hypergraph metrics quantifying contrapuntal characteristics, such as intervallic dissonance preparation, voice-crossing frequency, and adherence to formal cadential patterns. By applying this framework to a digital corpus of motets by Josquin des Prez, we demonstrate its ability to automatically identify points of structural imitation and cadential articulation with high precision. The hypergraph representation provides a more holistic and topologically accurate model of polyphonic texture, offering new quantitative insights into compositional techniques of the era.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hypergraph-Based Model for Contrapuntal Structure and Voice-Leading Analysis in Renaissance Polyphony

text: Automatic music structure analysis has predominantly relied on harmonic and rhythmic features, often neglecting the crucial role of timbre in defining musical form. This study introduces a novel unsupervised method for structural segmentation based on sparse Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) applied to Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs). We enhance the standard NMF objective function with a temporal-group sparsity constraint (L2,1-norm regularization), which encourages the activation matrix to exhibit block-like structures corresponding to consistent timbral segments. This approach effectively identifies sections characterized by distinct instrumentation or vocal textures. We evaluate our algorithm on the SALAMI dataset, demonstrating significant improvements in F-measure scores for boundary detection over conventional chromagram-based NMF and self-similarity matrix approaches, particularly for orchestral and electronic music. The proposed method enables a more perceptually relevant and multi-faceted understanding of musical structure by explicitly modeling timbral evolution.
subject: Müzik
title: Timbre-Informed Structural Segmentation via Non-Negative Matrix Factorization with Temporal-Group Sparsity

text: The aesthetic principles of post-tonal serial music often elude traditional analytical methods rooted in tonality. This paper proposes a framework for quantifying melodic and rhythmic complexity in this repertoire using tools from information theory. We model musical surfaces as discrete time-series of pitch-class intervals, durations, and dynamic markings. We then compute several complexity metrics, including Shannon entropy, Lempel-Ziv complexity, and the mutual information between parameter streams, to characterize the degree of predictability and statistical interdependence within a composition. Analyzing Webern’s Symphony, Op. 21, and Boulez’s Structures Ia, our results reveal significant quantitative differences in their organizational strategies, despite both employing integral serialism. The analysis shows Webern’s music exhibits higher cross-parameter statistical dependencies, suggesting a more integrated compositional structure. This information-theoretic lens provides an objective methodology for comparative analysis of atonal works, complementing traditional set-theoretic approaches.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Melodic and Rhythmic Complexity in Post-Tonal Serialism: An Information-Theoretic Approach

text: The decomposition of complex orchestral recordings into constituent instrumental sources is a formidable challenge for computational auditory scene analysis (CASA). This paper presents a multi-stage system for unsupervised aural scene analysis of stereophonic orchestral audio. The first stage employs a spectro-spatial factorization model that leverages both inter-channel level and time differences to perform an initial coarse separation of sources based on their panoramic position. The resulting components are then characterized by a high-dimensional timbre feature vector derived from a pre-trained deep convolutional autoencoder. In the second stage, we apply a hierarchical agglomerative clustering algorithm to these feature vectors to group components originating from the same instrumental section (e.g., first violins, cellos). Evaluated on a dataset of annotated orchestral excerpts, our system significantly outperforms baseline methods based solely on spatial cues or monophonic NMF, demonstrating the critical synergy of integrating spatial and timbral information.
subject: Müzik
title: Computational Aural Scene Analysis for Orchestral Music via Spectro-Spatial Source Separation and Hierarchical Clustering

text: The relationship between melodic shape and lyrical meaning is a cornerstone of songwriting, yet its computational modeling remains nascent. We introduce a novel cross-modal Transformer architecture to explicitly model and quantify this alignment. Our model takes two input streams: a sequence of phoneme-level fundamental frequency (F0) contours representing the melody, and a sequence of contextual word embeddings (e.g., BERT) representing the lyrics. Through a cross-attention mechanism, the model learns to associate specific melodic gestures (e.g., rising pitch, vibrato) with semantic features of the corresponding words. We train the model on a large-scale dataset of aligned vocal tracks and lyrics. The learned attention weights serve as a quantitative measure of melo-semantic correspondence. Analysis reveals strong, statistically significant correlations between rising contours and words with positive valence, and between falling contours and words with negative valence, empirically validating long-standing music-theoretic hypotheses.
subject: Müzik
title: Aligning Melodic Contour and Lyrical Semantics in Popular Music using a Cross-Modal Attention-Based Transformer

text: Traditional models of harmonic progression often rely on discrete, rule-based systems that struggle to capture the nuances of tonal syntax. This research reconceptualizes harmonic analysis within the framework of geometric deep learning. We first construct a graph representation of tonal pitch space, where nodes are chords and edges are weighted by psychoacoustically-informed voice-leading distances, effectively defining a discrete approximation of a tonal manifold. We then employ a Graph Neural Network (GNN) to learn a continuous vector embedding for each chord that reflects its functional role within this geometric space. Trained on the chord sequences of the Bach chorales, the GNN learns embeddings that cluster according to harmonic function (e.g., tonic, dominant). This learned representation is then utilized in a downstream recurrent model for harmonic generation, which produces stylistically coherent progressions that respect voice-leading principles, significantly outperforming baseline n-gram models in qualitative evaluations.
subject: Müzik
title: Geometric Deep Learning on Tonal Pitch Space Manifolds for Harmonic Progression Analysis and Generation

text: A musical performance is a complex entanglement of the symbolic score, the performer's expressive deviations (e.g., timing, dynamics), and the instrument's timbre. This paper presents a framework for disentangling these factors using Invertible Neural Networks (INNs). We design a multi-scale INN, structured as a normalizing flow, that learns a bijective mapping between the high-dimensional audio space (spectrograms) and a structured latent space. This latent space is partitioned into three independent subspaces, each conditioned to represent score, expressive parameters, and instrument identity, respectively. Due to the invertibility of the network, we can not only encode an audio recording into its disentangled components but also synthesize new audio by manipulating one latent subspace while keeping others fixed. This enables applications like expressive performance transfer between different instruments or applying a performer's style to a synthesized score, demonstrating a powerful and principled approach to generative modeling of musical audio.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangling Score, Performance, and Instrument Timbre via Invertible Neural Networks

text: The transmission and evolution of melodies in oral traditions can be conceptualized as a memetic process analogous to biological evolution. This study introduces a computational framework for tracing these evolutionary lineages using bioinformatics algorithms. We represent melodies as sequences of quantized pitch contour symbols (e.g., PARSONS code) and employ the Needleman-Wunsch global alignment algorithm with a custom substitution matrix to measure melodic similarity. The substitution matrix is empirically derived from cognitive models of melodic perception, weighting stable intervals higher than unstable ones. By computing pairwise alignment scores for a large corpus of folk tunes, we construct a distance matrix. This matrix is then used as input to phylogenetic tree reconstruction algorithms (e.g., UPGMA, Neighbor-Joining) to generate a 'phylo-memetic tree' that visualizes the hypothetical transmission history and family relationships among melodies. This methodology provides a quantitative and reproducible tool for ethnomusicologists to investigate cultural transmission dynamics.
subject: Müzik
title: A Phylo-memetic Approach to Melodic Evolution: Tracing Contour Transmission using Needleman-Wunsch Alignment

text: This paper introduces a novel framework for estimating heterogeneous treatment effects (HTEs) using doubly robust, debiased machine learning techniques. Traditional methods for HTE estimation are often susceptible to bias from model misspecification in either the outcome regression or the propensity score model. We leverage Neyman orthogonality to construct an estimator that remains consistent and asymptotically normal even when flexible machine learning algorithms are used for nuisance function estimation and one of the nuisance models is misspecified. Our approach, termed Orthogonalized R-Learner, builds upon recent advances in debiased machine learning by incorporating a cross-fitting procedure to mitigate overfitting bias. We establish the semi-parametric efficiency bound for our estimator and demonstrate through extensive simulation studies its superior performance over existing methods, particularly in high-dimensional settings with complex interaction structures. The practical utility of our method is illustrated via an application to personalized medicine, uncovering nuanced patient responses to a novel therapeutic intervention.
subject: İstatistik
title: Doubly Robust Debiased Machine Learning for Heterogeneous Treatment Effect Estimation under Model Misspecification

text: We develop a scalable inference algorithm for Hierarchical Dirichlet Process (HDP) topic models that incorporates structured covariates, enabling the discovery of document collections' thematic structures that co-evolve with metadata. Standard HDP models assume exchangeability, which is violated when document features or temporal information are present. Our proposed model, the Covariate-Informed HDP (ciHDP), extends the stick-breaking construction to allow the atom probabilities of the global measure to depend on covariates via a logistic stick-breaking process. To overcome the computational intractability of posterior inference, we derive a stochastic variational inference (SVI) algorithm. This approach combines natural gradient updates for global parameters with local variational parameter updates, facilitating efficient processing of massive corpora. We demonstrate posterior consistency under mild regularity conditions. Empirical results on large-scale text datasets show that the ciHDP provides more coherent topics and superior predictive likelihood compared to standard HDP and other covariate-aware topic models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Variational Inference for Hierarchical Dirichlet Process-based Topic Models with Structural Covariates

text: This work investigates the theoretical properties of Sparse Canonical Correlation Analysis (SCCA) in the high-dimensional regime where the number of variables p can be much larger than the sample size n. We establish a non-asymptotic analysis for the estimation of canonical vectors under sparsity constraints, deriving sharp bounds on the estimation error that depend explicitly on the signal strength and data dimensionality. Our analysis leverages random matrix theory and concentration inequalities for empirical covariance matrices. Furthermore, we propose a de-biased or de-sparsified SCCA estimator for constructing confidence intervals and performing hypothesis tests on the individual components of the canonical vectors. We prove that the de-biased estimator is asymptotically normal, enabling valid statistical inference. The theoretical results are corroborated by simulations, which show that our inferential procedure maintains nominal coverage probabilities. We apply the method to a genomic dataset to identify sparse, interpretable correlations between gene expression levels and microRNA profiles.
subject: İstatistik
title: Asymptotic Theory and Inference for Sparse Canonical Correlation Analysis in High-Dimensional Settings

text: We introduce a statistical framework for the analysis of complex data objects using multi-parameter persistent homology, extending topological data analysis (TDA) to more nuanced data structures. Single-parameter persistence often fails to capture intricate topological features that are dependent on multiple geometric scales or functions. Our approach constructs a multi-parameter filtration on a simplicial complex, generating a persistence module whose algebraic invariants are summarized in a multi-parameter persistence diagram. We define a new stable metric, the sliced Wasserstein distance, for these diagrams, facilitating statistical operations such as computing Fréchet means and performing hypothesis tests. We develop a bootstrap procedure for constructing confidence regions for persistence diagrams, providing a rigorous method for quantifying topological uncertainty. The methodology is applied to a dataset of brain arterial networks, where it successfully discriminates between patient cohorts by capturing subtle differences in vascular branching topology that are invisible to single-parameter methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Multi-parameter Persistent Homology for Robust Shape Characterization and Statistical Inference on Manifold-valued Data

text: This paper presents a novel approach for dynamic functional principal component analysis (FPCA) tailored for longitudinally collected functional data, where each subject provides a sequence of functions over time. The method simultaneously addresses challenges of sparse, irregular sampling within functions and the temporal evolution of functional structures across observations. We propose a state-space model where the underlying functional principal components (FPCs) evolve according to a vector autoregressive process, and the FPC scores for individual subjects are modeled as a linear combination of subject-specific random effects and the dynamic FPCs. We employ a computationally efficient estimation procedure based on a Kalman filter-smoother embedded within a Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithm. This approach naturally handles missing data and provides probabilistic forecasts for future functional trajectories. We establish the asymptotic consistency of the estimators and illustrate the method's efficacy in analyzing longitudinal neuroimaging data, revealing dynamic changes in brain connectivity patterns over time.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Functional Principal Component Analysis for Longitudinally Observed Functional Data with Irregular Sampling

text: We propose a computationally efficient framework for Bayesian inference on complex spatio-temporal Gaussian processes (GPs). Traditional GP models suffer from cubic complexity in the number of observations, rendering them infeasible for large datasets. Our approach leverages the connection between GPs with Matérn covariance functions and solutions to certain stochastic partial differential equations (SPDEs). By representing the continuous GP field as a discretely indexed Gaussian Markov random field (GMRF) via a finite element method approximation to the SPDE, we drastically reduce the computational burden. We embed this SPDE-based spatial model within a dynamic linear model structure to capture temporal dependencies. Inference is performed using the Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA) algorithm, which avoids costly MCMC sampling by accurately approximating posterior marginals. This INLA-SPDE approach provides a unified and scalable framework for fitting a rich class of non-separable, non-stationary spatio-temporal models, as demonstrated on a large-scale environmental monitoring dataset.
subject: İstatistik
title: Scalable Spatio-Temporal Gaussian Process Modeling via Integrated Nested Laplace Approximations and Stochastic Partial Differential Equations

text: This paper addresses the fundamental problem of robustly estimating a high-dimensional covariance matrix when the data are subject to contamination. We propose a new estimator, the Adaptive Thresholding Minimum Covariance Determinant (AT-MCD), which is resilient to both casewise outliers (anomalous rows) and cellwise contamination (spurious entries scattered throughout the data matrix). The method integrates a robust MCD-based initial estimate with an adaptive thresholding step that identifies and corrects corrupted cells, followed by a re-weighted covariance estimation. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis, deriving non-asymptotic oracle inequalities that establish the estimator's convergence rate under sparsity assumptions on the true covariance structure and the contamination pattern. Our results show that AT-MCD achieves near-minimax optimal rates of convergence. We demonstrate through simulations that our method significantly outperforms existing robust estimators, particularly in scenarios with mixed contamination types. An application to financial portfolio optimization highlights its practical advantages in stabilizing risk estimates.
subject: İstatistik
title: Optimal Robust Estimation of High-Dimensional Covariance Matrices under Cellwise and Casewise Contamination

text: We develop a Bayesian inferential framework for dynamic Exponential Random Graph Models (ERGMs) to analyze the evolution of social networks. Existing temporal ERGMs often rely on maximum likelihood estimation, which can be computationally unstable and fails to adequately quantify uncertainty. Our approach specifies a state-space model where the ERGM parameters evolve over time according to a random walk process, allowing for smooth temporal variation in network-generating mechanisms. We incorporate both endogenous network statistics and exogenous nodal covariates to explain structural dynamics. Posterior inference is conducted via a sequential Monte Carlo (SMC) algorithm, which is well-suited for non-linear, non-Gaussian state-space models and scales effectively to large networks. This particle filtering approach provides principled estimates of parameter trajectories and their credible intervals. We introduce novel diagnostic tools for assessing model fit and convergence. The methodology is applied to a longitudinal dataset of inter-organizational collaboration, revealing evolving patterns of network homophily and centralization.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Inference for Dynamic Exponential Random Graph Models with Nodal Covariates

text: This paper introduces a flexible semiparametric transformation model for analyzing competing risks data, accommodating time-varying covariate effects on the cumulative incidence function (CIF). Existing models, such as the Fine-Gray model, typically assume proportional subdistribution hazards, an assumption that is often violated in practice. Our proposed model specifies a linear transformation of the CIF where the regression coefficients are smooth, non-parametric functions of time. This formulation provides a direct and interpretable model for covariate effects on the cumulative probability of event types over time, without imposing restrictive structural assumptions. We develop a local linear kernel-based estimation procedure for the time-varying coefficients and establish the asymptotic normality and weak convergence of the proposed estimators using modern empirical process and martingale theory. A resampling-based method is developed for simultaneous confidence band construction. The model's superior flexibility and performance are demonstrated through simulations and an analysis of clinical trial data on bone marrow transplant outcomes.
subject: İstatistik
title: A Semiparametric Transformation Model for Competing Risks Data with Time-Varying Coefficients

text: We present a novel method for causal mediation analysis in high-dimensional settings, specifically addressing the challenge of unmeasured confounding between the mediator and the outcome. Traditional mediation methods fail under such confounding, leading to biased estimates of direct and indirect effects. Our approach leverages an instrumental variable (IV) that is associated with the mediator but not directly with the outcome, except through the mediator. We formulate a two-stage estimation procedure within a structural equation modeling framework. In the first stage, we use a penalized regression model, such as the LASSO, to handle high-dimensional confounders when modeling the mediator. In the second stage, we use the predicted mediator value in a regularized outcome model to estimate the causal effects. We establish rigorous identification conditions and derive the asymptotic properties of the proposed estimators, including a method for constructing valid confidence intervals via a debiasing procedure. This framework provides robust decomposition of treatment effects even in complex observational studies.
subject: İstatistik
title: High-Dimensional Causal Mediation Analysis with an Instrumental Variable Approach

text: Estimating average treatment effects (ATE) in high-dimensional settings where confounder selection is notoriously difficult poses a significant statistical challenge. Traditional methods often suffer from regularization bias or model misspecification. We introduce a doubly robust, debiased machine learning framework that mitigates these issues. Our method leverages cross-fitting and Neyman-orthogonal score functions, enabling the use of flexible, high-performance machine learning algorithms for nuisance function estimation (e.g., propensity scores and conditional outcomes) without propagating their statistical bias into the final ATE estimate. We provide rigorous theoretical guarantees for the root-n consistency and asymptotic normality of our estimator under standard sparsity and overlap assumptions, demonstrating its robustness to moderate errors in the nuisance component estimations. Monte Carlo simulations confirm the superior finite-sample performance of our approach compared to conventional plug-in or inverse probability weighting estimators. An application to observational genomic data illustrates its utility in identifying causal effects of gene expression on clinical phenotypes amidst thousands of potential confounders.
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Machine Learning for High-Dimensional Confounder-Adjusted Treatment Effect Estimation

text: Standard topic models, including the Hierarchical Dirichlet Process (HDP), assume document exchangeability and fail to incorporate metadata, limiting their inferential power. We propose a novel extension, the Covariate-Dependent HDP (cd-HDP), that parameterizes the top-level stick-breaking process weights via a logistic-normal regression on document-level covariates. This construction allows global topic prevalences to vary systematically as a function of external information, yielding more nuanced and interpretable topical structures. Direct posterior inference is intractable; therefore, we derive a scalable stochastic variational inference (SVI) algorithm that optimizes the evidence lower bound (ELBO) using natural gradients. This approach circumvents the computational bottlenecks of MCMC-based methods, rendering the model applicable to massive corpora. On benchmark text datasets, the cd-HDP demonstrates superior predictive performance measured by perplexity and provides qualitatively more coherent, covariate-aware topics than existing HDP and supervised LDA variants, showcasing its ability to uncover richer latent thematic patterns.
subject: İstatistik
title: Variational Inference for Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Models with Covariate-Dependent Stick-Breaking Priors

text: Persistent homology, a cornerstone of Topological Data Analysis (TDA), provides a powerful multiscale summary of the shape of data, yet a comprehensive framework for statistical inference on its outputs remains underdeveloped. This paper introduces a novel method for constructing confidence regions for persistence diagrams. Our approach leverages subsampling to capture the variability of topological features and employs a multi-scale kernel density estimator on the space of diagrams to construct valid confidence sets. By exploiting the stability theorem of persistent homology and extending results from bootstrap theory, we establish theoretical guarantees for the asymptotic coverage probability of our proposed regions under mild regularity conditions on the underlying data-generating process. The method is computationally efficient and agnostic to the specific filtration used. We demonstrate its utility by detecting statistically significant differences in the topological structures of high-dimensional point clouds derived from single-cell RNA sequencing experiments, outperforming permutation-based tests in power and interpretability.
subject: İstatistik
title: Statistically Rigorous Inference for Persistent Homology via Subsampling and Multi-scale Kernel Methods

text: Classical functional principal component analysis (FPCA) typically assumes independent functional observations, a restrictive assumption for longitudinal studies involving repeated functional measurements on the same subjects over time. We propose Dynamic FPCA (dFPCA), a novel framework that explicitly models the temporal evolution of subject-specific FPCA scores through a state-space formulation. The latent score vector for each subject is assumed to follow a vector autoregressive (VAR) process, thereby capturing the serial dependence structure inherent in the longitudinal design. Estimation is performed within a unified Bayesian hierarchical model using a computationally efficient Gibbs sampler that integrates Kalman filtering and smoothing recursions. This approach not only provides a more coherent decomposition of variation but also enables principled forecasting of future trajectories and imputation of missing functional data. In both simulation studies and an application to human growth curve analysis, dFPCA demonstrates superior predictive accuracy and provides deeper insights into individual-level dynamics compared to static FPCA methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Functional Principal Component Analysis for Densely Sampled Longitudinal Trajectories

text: Estimating large, sparse covariance matrices is a fundamental problem in high-dimensional statistics. However, many state-of-the-art methods, such as the graphical Lasso, rely on Gaussian assumptions and exhibit suboptimal performance with heavy-tailed or skewed data. We introduce a robust adaptive thresholding estimator designed for such non-Gaussian settings. The procedure first constructs a robust correlation matrix estimate using Kendall's tau, which is resilient to monotonic transformations and outliers. Subsequently, a data-driven, entry-wise adaptive thresholding step is applied, where the threshold for each entry is determined by its estimated variance, thus accounting for heteroscedasticity in the sample correlation coefficients. We derive non-asymptotic error bounds for our estimator under sub-exponential distributional assumptions, demonstrating that it achieves near-optimal convergence rates in both spectral and Frobenius norms. Extensive simulations confirm its superior performance over competing methods under various challenging distributional scenarios, highlighting its practical utility in fields like finance and genomics.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Thresholding for Sparse Covariance Matrix Estimation with Heavy-Tailed and Non-Gaussian Data

text: Modeling complex non-stationary spatio-temporal phenomena with Gaussian processes (GPs) is computationally prohibitive for large datasets. We propose a highly scalable and flexible framework that addresses this challenge by modeling the non-stationary covariance structure through spatially varying coefficients in a stochastic partial differential equation (SPDE) representation of the GP. Scalability is achieved by projecting the process onto a multi-resolution basis derived from a hierarchical low-rank approximation of the covariance kernel, effectively reducing the computational complexity from cubic to near-linear in the number of data points. This Treed-GP approach combines the statistical flexibility of non-stationary modeling with the computational efficiency of low-rank methods, allowing for full Bayesian inference on massive spatio-temporal datasets. We apply the model to a large dataset of satellite-derived sea surface temperatures, demonstrating its ability to capture complex, spatially varying anisotropic dynamics and provide more accurate long-range forecasts than stationary or simpler non-stationary alternatives.
subject: İstatistik
title: A Scalable Non-Stationary Spatio-Temporal Gaussian Process using Hierarchical Low-Rank Approximations

text: Estimating causal effects in networked populations is complicated by interference, where an individual's outcome is influenced by the treatment status of their network neighbors, violating the Stable Unit Treatment Value Assumption (SUTVA). We extend the potential outcomes framework and generalize propensity score methods to accommodate such network interference. We define an individual’s exposure as a function of their own treatment and a summary of their neighbors' treatments, and introduce the generalized network propensity score (GNPS) as the conditional probability of this joint exposure. We then develop inverse probability of weighting (IPW) estimators based on the GNPS to estimate average direct and indirect (spillover) causal effects. We establish formal conditions for the identification of these effects based on network structure and exposure mappings, and derive the asymptotic properties of the proposed estimators. Simulations on various network topologies and an empirical application to a technology adoption dataset show our method effectively reduces bias from network confounding and homophily.
subject: İstatistik
title: Propensity Score-Based Estimation of Causal Peer Effects in Network Data under Interference

text: The analysis of competing risks data with high-dimensional covariates, now common in clinical genomics, presents formidable challenges for variable selection and prediction. We develop a unified regularized estimation framework for both the cause-specific hazards (CSH) model and the Fine-Gray subdistribution hazards (SDH) model. Our approach incorporates an elastic net penalty into the partial likelihood maximization procedure for each model, facilitating simultaneous variable selection and parameter estimation while accommodating highly correlated predictors. We devise efficient coordinate descent algorithms for computation and establish the oracle properties—selection consistency and asymptotic normality—of the estimators under suitable regularity conditions. This theoretical support guarantees reliable performance in the p >> n regime. The method's practical utility is demonstrated through its application to a large-scale cancer genomics dataset, where it successfully identifies sparse sets of genetic markers predictive of different causes of mortality and achieves superior predictive accuracy compared to unpenalized and single-penalty methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Regularized Estimation in Competing Risks Proportional Hazards Models with High-Dimensional Covariates

text: Detecting multiple change points in multivariate time series is a critical task, yet it is complicated when the number of change points is unknown and the within-segment data-generating process is complex. We propose a novel nonparametric Bayesian methodology that addresses these challenges. The model posits that segment-specific distributional parameters are drawn from a dependent Dirichlet process mixture, which allows for flexible, nonparametric density estimation within each segment while sharing statistical strength across segments. The change point locations themselves are assigned a prior derived from a geometric stick-breaking process, which naturally induces an ordering and an implicit penalty on the number of change points, thereby inferring their number from the data. We derive a computationally efficient blocked Gibbs sampler for posterior inference. The model's superior performance in both accuracy of change point localization and segment parameter estimation is demonstrated on synthetic data and a high-frequency financial log-return dataset, where it successfully identifies abrupt shifts in volatility and correlation regimes.
subject: İstatistik
