title: Nonparametric Bayesian Change Point Detection in Multivariate Time Series via Geometric Stick-Breaking Processes

text: Classical optimal design criteria, such as D-optimality, are acutely sensitive to pre-specified model forms and nominal parameter values, often yielding designs that are brittle in practice. We introduce a robust Bayesian optimal design framework for Generalized Linear Models (GLMs) that explicitly accounts for both parameter uncertainty and model misspecification. A new utility function is formulated that maximizes the expected information gain (e.g., minimizing posterior variance) integrated over both a prior distribution for the model parameters and a neighborhood of plausible alternative models. This model neighborhood is defined by a Kullback-Leibler divergence from the nominal GLM, ensuring robustness against local deviations. We develop an efficient computational strategy combining sequential Monte Carlo methods with stochastic gradient optimization to navigate the complex design space. In designing a dose-response study, our approach yields designs that are substantially more efficient and robust under realistic misspecification scenarios compared to traditional and standard Bayesian optimal designs.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Optimal Design for Generalized Linear Models under Model Misspecification and Parameter Uncertainty

text: We investigate non-perturbative effects in two-dimensional Jackiw-Teitelboim (JT) gravity coupled to a d-dimensional conformal field theory (CFT) via the AdS₂/CFT₁ correspondence. By employing the replica trick to calculate the entanglement entropy of spatial subregions in the boundary theory, we explicitly compute the contribution of replica wormhole geometries connecting different boundaries of the replicated manifold. Our path integral formulation demonstrates that these saddle points, which are sub-dominant in a naive semi-classical expansion, provide the dominant contribution at late times, resolving the information paradox in this toy model. The resulting Page curve for black hole evaporation is recovered without recourse to ad-hoc averaging. This analysis reveals a profound connection between spacetime topology, gravitational path integrals, and the unitarity of quantum information, showing that entanglement entropy is a sensitive probe of the underlying quantum gravitational state counting and non-perturbative completion of the effective theory.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Non-Perturbative Corrections in JT Gravity Coupled to Conformal Matter

text: We present a comprehensive forecast for constraining primordial non-Gaussianities using forthcoming Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) polarization experiments. Focusing on the B-mode power spectrum and its associated bispectrum, our analysis employs a Fisher matrix formalism incorporating instrumental noise, component separation residuals, and gravitational lensing delensing uncertainties. We demonstrate that measurements of the four-point correlation function of B-modes can place stringent, independent constraints on the local-type trispectrum parameter τNL and the equilateral-type bispectrum parameter fNL. These measurements are particularly sensitive to inflationary models with multiple fields or non-trivial kinetic terms. We show that a combination of ground-based and satellite missions could potentially achieve σ(fNL) < 1, providing a definitive test of single-field slow-roll inflation. The methodology highlights the critical importance of polarization data in breaking degeneracies and isolating the subtle statistical anisotropies indicative of primordial physics beyond the standard ΛCDM model.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Primordial Non-Gaussianities with Next-Generation CMB Polarization Anisotropy Measurements

text: We propose a novel solid-state platform for realizing and manipulating chiral Majorana modes based on a heterostructure combining an iron-based superconductor (e.g., FeTe₀.₅₅Se₀.₄₅) with a magnetic topological insulator exhibiting the quantum anomalous Hall effect. Utilizing a self-consistent Bogoliubov-de Gennes (BdG) formalism, we demonstrate that the proximity effect induces a robust, topologically non-trivial superconducting gap in the surface state of the insulator. The resulting chiral Majorana edge states propagate along the interface domain wall, protected by the underlying topology. Our numerical simulations confirm the quantization of the thermal conductance and reveal unique signatures in the tunneling density of states accessible via scanning tunneling microscopy. This architecture circumvents the need for external magnetic fields, mitigating a major source of decoherence, and offers a scalable route towards fabricating topologically protected qubits for fault-tolerant quantum computation.
subject: Fizik
title: Engineering Chiral Majorana Modes in Iron-Based Superconductor/Quantum Anomalous Hall Insulator Heterostructures

text: We perform a global analysis of the prospective sensitivity of the High-Luminosity Large Hadron Collider (HL-LHC) to physics beyond the Standard Model, parameterized by the Standard Model Effective Field Theory (SMEFT). By combining projected measurements from multiple Higgs boson production and decay channels (H→γγ, ZZ*, WW*, bb, ττ) with electroweak precision observables and diboson production data, we construct a comprehensive likelihood function to constrain the Wilson coefficients of 36 dimension-six operators in the Warsaw basis. Our fit demonstrates a significant reduction in parameter space degeneracies compared to single-channel analyses. We project constraints on individual coefficients at the per-mille level, corresponding to new physics scales up to several TeV. This study underscores the power of a global SMEFT approach to systematically search for indirect evidence of new phenomena and highlights key measurements that will maximize the physics output of the HL-LHC program.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraining Effective Field Theory Operators from Global Analysis of Higgs Boson Production and Decay at the HL-LHC

text: The interplay between periodic driving, disorder, and interactions can lead to novel non-equilibrium quantum phases. We investigate the dynamics of a one-dimensional disordered Heisenberg spin chain subject to a periodic magnetic field using time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (t-DMRG) simulations. We identify a parameter regime where the system evades thermalization, forming a prethermal Floquet many-body localized (MBL) phase. In this phase, the entanglement entropy exhibits a characteristic slow, logarithmic growth in time, and local observables fail to reach thermal equilibrium values over astronomically long timescales. This behavior contrasts sharply with both the ergodic phase, which thermalizes to an infinite-temperature state, and the static MBL phase. Our findings provide compelling evidence for ergodicity breaking in a periodically driven, interacting quantum system, challenging the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis and opening new avenues for controlling quantum matter far from equilibrium.
subject: Fizik
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Growth and Ergodicity Breaking in a Disordered, Floquet-Driven Many-Body System

text: We report the experimental implementation of dynamically corrected quantum gates for high-fidelity two-qubit operations in a scalable superconducting transmon qubit processor. By employing a gradient-ascent pulse engineering (GRAPE) algorithm, we design control pulses that are robust against both quasi-static 1/f frequency noise and spurious ZZ crosstalk, which are dominant error sources in multi-qubit systems. Using interleaved randomized benchmarking, we demonstrate a two-qubit controlled-Z (CZ) gate fidelity of 99.81%, an order of magnitude improvement over uncorrected rectangular pulses. The technique is shown to be effective across a 16-qubit array with varying spectral crowding and coupling strengths. This integrated approach of optimal control and hardware characterization provides a viable pathway for suppressing correlated and non-Markovian noise, a critical prerequisite for executing fault-tolerant quantum algorithms on near-term quantum devices.
subject: Fizik
title: Scalable Decoherence Mitigation in a Superconducting Qubit Array via Dynamically Corrected Quantum Gates

text: We present a catalog of high-resolution numerical relativity simulations of binary black hole (BBH) systems with significant initial eccentricity (e > 0.1) and misaligned spins leading to orbital precession. The resulting gravitational waveforms exhibit complex morphologies distinct from quasi-circular, non-precessing binaries. We analyze the time-frequency evolution and find characteristic power modulations in the inspiral phase, with frequencies related to both the orbital and precessional periods. Furthermore, significant eccentricity at merger enhances the excitation of higher-order spherical harmonic modes (l > 2), leading to pronounced asymmetries in the merger and ringdown signal. We develop a phenomenological model that captures these key features and discuss their observability with current and next-generation gravitational wave detectors. The detection of such signals would provide direct evidence for dynamical formation channels of BBHs in dense stellar environments and offer new tests of general relativity in the strong-field regime.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Wave Signatures of Precessing, Eccentric Binary Black Hole Mergers: A Numerical Relativity Study

text: We experimentally investigate the scaling of spatial coherence in a quasi-two-dimensional exciton-polariton condensate driven far from thermal equilibrium by a non-resonant optical pump. Using spatially resolved interferometry, we measure the first-order coherence function g⁽¹⁾(r), observing a transition from exponential decay in the uncondensed regime to an algebraic power-law decay, g⁽¹⁾(r) ∼ r⁻ᵅ, deep in the condensed phase. The measured exponent α is found to be tunable via the pump power and detuning, varying in a range consistent with predictions from the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang (KPZ) universality class for stochastic surface growth. These results suggest that the phase dynamics of the driven-dissipative condensate are governed by universal non-equilibrium phenomena rather than by equilibrium Berezinskii-Kosterlitz-Thouless physics. This system provides a new, highly controllable platform for studying universal scaling laws in non-equilibrium statistical mechanics and turbulence.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergence of Long-Range Spatial Coherence in a Non-Equilibrium Polariton Condensate

text: Biomolecular condensates formed via liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) are crucial for cellular organization, but the role of non-equilibrium active processes remains poorly understood. We reconstitute a model chromatin condensate and probe its material properties using optical tweezers-based microrheology in the presence of an ATP-dependent motor protein that generates active stress. At low activity, the condensate fluidizes, exhibiting a decreased viscosity and enhanced fusion dynamics. However, above a critical activity threshold, the system undergoes a dynamical transition into a kinetically arrested, gel-like state with a solid-like frequency response and suppressed internal rearrangement. Our theoretical model, based on active gel theory, attributes this transition to the accumulation of active stress faster than viscous relaxation allows. This activity-induced phase transition from a liquid to a non-ergodic solid provides a physical mechanism for modulating the stability and function of membraneless organelles within the cell nucleus.
subject: Fizik
title: Rheological Properties and Arrested Phase Separation in Active Chromatin Condensates

text: We report on massively parallel, five-dimensional (3D position, 2D velocity) continuum gyrokinetic simulations of plasma microturbulence in a quasi-axisymmetric stellarator configuration. The simulations, performed with the GKV code, self-consistently evolve ion-temperature-gradient (ITG) and trapped-electron-mode (TEM) instabilities from linear growth through nonlinear saturation. We observe the spontaneous formation of an internal transport barrier, characterized by a steepening of the ion temperature profile and a significant local reduction in turbulent heat flux. This barrier is sustained by the interplay between non-axisymmetric magnetic geometry, which modifies the turbulent spectrum, and the shear of E×B zonal flows. A detailed spectral analysis reveals a modified energy cascade compared to tokamaks, with energy transfer to stable, long-wavelength modes providing an effective saturation mechanism. These results provide fundamental physical insight into the suppression of turbulence in optimized 3D magnetic fields, guiding designs for future fusion reactors.
subject: Fizik
title: Multi-scale Gyrokinetic Simulation of Turbulent Transport Barriers in Optimized Stellarator Geometries

text: We investigate the correspondence between quantum entanglement and spacetime geometry within the framework of the AdS/CFT correspondence. By performing large-scale numerical simulations of a (2+1)-dimensional conformal field theory (CFT) on a dynamically evolving lattice, we compute the bipartite entanglement entropy for various subsystem geometries. Our analysis focuses on the mutual information between disjoint, accelerating regions, which, via the Ryu-Takayanagi formula, is dual to the area of an extremal surface in the bulk Anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime. We demonstrate that a phase transition in the entanglement structure of the boundary CFT, characterized by a non-analytic change in the mutual information, corresponds precisely to a topological change in the bulk extremal surface connectivity. This provides compelling evidence that the contiguity and connectivity of classical spacetime are emergent properties encoded within the entanglement structure of the underlying quantum degrees of freedom, offering a computational avenue for exploring quantum gravity.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Spacetime Emergence through Bipartite Entanglement in a Holographic Conformal Field Theory

text: Primordial Black Holes (PBHs) remain a viable candidate for dark matter. We present novel constraints on the PBH mass function by analyzing the anisotropic gravitational lensing effects on the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB). Unlike traditional methods that rely on the lensing-induced smoothing of the CMB power spectrum, our approach utilizes the non-Gaussian, direction-dependent distortions caused by a discrete population of massive compact lenses. We develop a semi-analytic formalism to calculate the full covariance matrix of the CMB lensing convergence field, accounting for the Poissonian distribution of PBHs. By applying this formalism to simulated CMB data mimicking Planck and future CMB-S4 experiments, we show that the induced anisotropy provides significantly stronger constraints than spectral methods, particularly in the 10-100 solar mass window. Our results exclude a monochromatic PBH population in this range from comprising the entirety of dark matter at high statistical significance.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraints on Primordial Black Hole Dark Matter from Anisotropic Gravitational Lensing of the CMB

text: We theoretically demonstrate the creation of a non-equilibrium topological phase of matter through Floquet engineering. Our study focuses on a pyrochlore iridate material, which in its ground state is a magnetically frustrated insulator. By applying a circularly polarized, off-resonant laser field, we show that the system can be driven into a transient Weyl semimetal state. Using Floquet-Bloch theory combined with ab initio calculations, we map out the non-equilibrium band structure and identify the emergence of topologically protected Weyl nodes. The separation and chirality of these nodes in momentum space are shown to be highly tunable via the drive frequency and polarization. This Floquet-induced phase transition is mediated by the dynamic modification of effective spin-orbit coupling and hopping parameters. Our findings propose a concrete route for optically controlling topological properties on ultrafast timescales, paving the way for novel optoelectronic and spintronic device applications.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergent Weyl Semimetal Phase in a Periodically Driven Frustrated Pyrochlore Iridate

text: We report a direct experimental measurement of the breakdown of the fluctuation-dissipation theorem (FDT) in a non-ergodic, glassy system. Using a dual-trap optical tweezer setup, we probe a dense colloidal suspension undergoing physical aging far from thermal equilibrium. One optical trap measures the spontaneous thermal fluctuations of a probe particle, quantifying the system's passive dynamics. Simultaneously, the second trap applies a weak, oscillatory perturbation to an adjacent particle, allowing for a precise measurement of the system's linear response function, or dissipation. We observe a clear, time-dependent violation of the FDT's fundamental relation between these two quantities. The extent of this violation can be characterized by an effective temperature that systematically increases with the system's age. This work provides a direct quantification of non-equilibrium dynamics in a disordered system and validates theoretical frameworks of aging based on a slowly evolving effective temperature.
subject: Fizik
title: Violation of the Fluctuation-Dissipation Theorem in an Aging Colloidal Glass: Direct Experimental Verification

text: We investigate the gravitational wave signal from the post-merger phase of a binary neutron star coalescence within the framework of Damour-Esposito-Farèse scalar-tensor theories of gravity. Through a suite of high-resolution, 3D numerical relativity simulations, we model the formation and subsequent evolution of a hypermassive neutron star remnant. For a range of scalar coupling parameters that permit spontaneous scalarization, we find that the remnant's gravitational wave emission differs markedly from the predictions of general relativity. The ringdown spectrum contains additional, distinct quasi-normal modes associated with the scalar field. The frequencies and damping times of these scalar modes are directly linked to the fundamental parameters of the modified gravity theory and the equation of state of dense matter. These unique spectral features, potentially detectable by next-generation gravitational wave observatories, offer a new and powerful observational window to constrain or detect deviations from Einstein's gravity in the strong-field regime.
subject: Fizik
title: Signatures of Scalar-Tensor Gravitational Theories in the Post-Merger Ringdown of Binary Neutron Star Systems

text: We theoretically analyze the decoherence dynamics of a quantum bit (qubit) strongly coupled to a structured bosonic reservoir characterized by a non-flat spectral density, such as that found in a photonic band-gap material. By solving the exact non-Markovian master equation using time-evolving matrix product operator (TEMPO) techniques, we demonstrate that memory effects in the reservoir lead to significant deviations from exponential decay. We observe periodic revivals of quantum coherence and, for a bipartite system, revivals of entanglement that persist for long times. These phenomena are linked to the formation of a stable qubit-polaron quasiparticle, where the qubit becomes 'dressed' by a localized cloud of reservoir excitations. Our results indicate that engineered reservoirs can function as quantum memory channels, temporarily storing and returning quantum information, which is a critical resource for developing robust quantum information processing technologies.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Markovian Dynamics and Entanglement Revivals in a Qubit Coupled to a Structured Bosonic Reservoir

text: We propose a novel, self-consistent chiral gauge theory based on an extended SU(3)_L x U(1)_X symmetry that simultaneously addresses the persistent anomaly in the anomalous magnetic moment of the muon (g-2) and recent hints of lepton flavor universality violation in B-meson decays (R_K, R_K^*). The model introduces new vector-like leptons and a Z' gauge boson whose couplings are dictated by the chiral structure, naturally suppressing dangerous flavor-changing neutral currents while providing the necessary loop-level contributions. We calculate the dominant one-loop corrections to the muon g-2 and the tree-level contributions to b→sℓ+ℓ− transitions, demonstrating a correlated parameter space that resolves both tensions with the Standard Model. The model predicts specific signatures at the LHC, including Z' decays to tau leptons, providing a clear pathway for experimental verification.
subject: Fizik
title: A Chiral Gauge Theory Explanation for the Muon g-2 Anomaly and Lepton Flavor Universality Violation

text: We investigate the collective dynamics of a reconstituted cytoskeletal network composed of actin filaments and myosin-II molecular motors, a canonical example of active matter. Using high-resolution particle imaging velocimetry, we map the spatio-temporal velocity fluctuation fields and find that the system self-organizes into a state characterized by turbulent-like flows with long-range correlations. The spatial and temporal power spectra of these fluctuations exhibit robust power-law scaling over several decades, a hallmark of a system poised at a critical point. A minimal hydrodynamic model based on active nematic theory reveals that this critical behavior emerges from a finely tuned balance between motor-driven active stress and the network's viscoelastic dissipation. Our results suggest that living cells may operate near such a non-equilibrium critical point to maintain functional robustness and enhance response to external stimuli, providing a physical mechanism for complex biological organization.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergence of Criticality in Cytoskeletal Active Matter Networks Driven by Molecular Motors

text: The nature of the pseudogap phase in cuprate high-temperature superconductors remains a central unsolved problem. Here, we utilize high-resolution, momentum-resolved resonant inelastic X-ray scattering (RIXS) at the Cu L3-edge to probe the collective electronic excitations in underdoped YBa₂Cu₃O₆₊δ. By systematically detuning the incident photon energy away from the main resonance, we selectively suppress the intense, incoherent fluorescence background and the strong paramagnon signal. This novel detuning method unmasks a previously obscured, weaker, and dispersive mode. This mode is identified as an acoustic-like phonon that is anomalously broadened and softened, indicating strong coupling to short-range charge density wave (CDW) fluctuations. The momentum dependence of this softening provides direct spectroscopic evidence for a fluctuating, symmetry-breaking electronic nematicity as a key constituent of the pseudogap state, competing with and existing alongside superconducting pairing correlations.
subject: Fizik
title: Unveiling the Pseudogap Phase in Cuprate Superconductors via Detuned Resonant Inelastic X-ray Scattering

text: We address the problem of robust uncertainty quantification in Bayesian deep learning, where conventional variational inference (VI) in Euclidean space often yields poorly calibrated posteriors. This paper introduces a novel framework, Riemannian Manifold Variational Inference (RMVI), which performs inference directly on the manifold of probability distributions. By leveraging stochastic gradient Riemannian Langevin dynamics (SGRLD) as the variational posterior, our approach inherently respects the geometric structure of the parameter space, preventing pathological updates that cross low-density regions. We formulate a tractable evidence lower bound (ELBO) objective by employing a retraction mechanism for manifold optimization. This geometric perspective enables a more faithful approximation of the true posterior, particularly for models with complex, non-isotropic uncertainty profiles. Empirical validation on challenging out-of-distribution detection benchmarks and regression tasks with heteroscedastic noise demonstrates that RMVI consistently produces better-calibrated uncertainty estimates and improved predictive performance over state-of-the-art VI techniques.
subject: AI
title: Variational Inference on Riemannian Manifolds for Calibrated Epistemic Uncertainty

text: Standard reinforcement learning algorithms often fail to generalize in non-stationary environments due to their inability to distinguish correlation from causation. We propose a novel framework, Causal-Interventional Policy Optimization (CIPO), that learns robust policies by explicitly modeling and leveraging the underlying causal mechanisms of the environment. CIPO combines deep reinforcement learning with a variational autoencoder that discovers a disentangled latent representation corresponding to an implicit structural causal model (SCM). Crucially, we derive an interventional policy gradient theorem using principles from do-calculus, enabling the agent to evaluate hypothetical interventions on the latent causal variables. This allows for optimization of policies that are robust to spurious correlations and confounding factors. We demonstrate empirically in complex simulated robotic control and healthcare treatment domains that CIPO achieves superior zero-shot transfer to environments with modified dynamics, a task where traditional policy gradient methods catastrophically fail.
subject: AI
title: Interventional Policy Gradient via Latent Causal Structure Discovery

text: Generative diffusion models have achieved remarkable success, yet their reliance on a Euclidean latent space is a fundamental limitation for data with inherent hierarchical or graphical structure. We introduce the Geodesic Latent Diffusion Model (GLDM), a novel generative framework that performs the diffusion process directly on a constant-curvature Riemannian manifold, specifically hyperbolic space. The forward noising process is defined as a geodesic random walk, and the corresponding reverse-time denoising process is learned via a score-matching objective function formulated using the Riemannian metric tensor. By operating in a latent space that faithfully represents the data's intrinsic geometry, GLDM generates high-fidelity, structurally coherent outputs. We demonstrate state-of-the-art performance on tasks of complex graph generation and molecular synthesis, showing significant improvements in capturing long-range dependencies and hierarchical organization compared to Euclidean-based diffusion models and other geometric deep learning approaches.
subject: AI
title: Geodesic Latent Diffusion Models for Generative Modeling on Hyperbolic Manifolds

text: Randomized smoothing has emerged as a state-of-the-art technique for providing certifiable robustness against L_p-norm adversarial attacks. However, its reliance on isotropic Gaussian smoothing distributions is agnostic to the underlying data manifold, often leading to a suboptimal trade-off between certified radius and clean accuracy. We propose Topological Data Smoothing (TDS), a novel certified defense that constructs the smoothing distribution based on the topological features of the data, estimated via persistent homology. By concentrating the smoothing noise in directions orthogonal to the principal data manifold and avoiding regions of high topological significance, TDS achieves substantially larger certified radii for a given level of accuracy degradation. We provide a rigorous theoretical derivation of the certification guarantee for this data-dependent smoothing process. Empirical results on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet demonstrate that TDS establishes a new Pareto frontier in the certified accuracy-robustness landscape, outperforming existing methods against strong adversarial attacks.
subject: AI
title: Topologically-Constrained Randomized Smoothing for Certified Adversarial Defense

text: We address the challenge of few-shot learning by reformulating meta-learning as a hierarchical Bayesian inference problem. Our model, Amortized Bayesian Meta-Learning (ABML), posits that task-specific parameters are drawn from a global latent prior distribution, which is itself learned from a corpus of related tasks. To make this tractable, we employ amortized variational inference, using a hypernetwork to directly map a task's support set to the parameters of an approximate posterior distribution over the task-specific model parameters. This approach not only facilitates rapid adaptation via a single forward pass but also provides a principled mechanism for uncertainty quantification, crucial for active learning and out-of-distribution task detection. ABML demonstrates superior performance and sample efficiency on challenging few-shot classification and regression benchmarks, such as Meta-Dataset, outperforming gradient-based meta-learners by effectively marginalizing over task-specific parameter uncertainty.
subject: AI
title: Hierarchical Bayesian Meta-Learning with Amortized Variational Inference for Task Adaptation

text: Self-supervised learning for video and other spatiotemporal data often relies on instance-level contrastive objectives that fail to capture the underlying system dynamics. We introduce a novel framework, Koopman Contrastive Learning (KCL), which learns representations by enforcing consistency with the linear evolution of the system's dynamics in a latent space. KCL trains a deep encoder to map high-dimensional observations to a latent space where a linear operator, approximating the Koopman operator, governs the temporal evolution. The contrastive objective maximizes the mutual information between the encoder's output for a future state and the prediction made by applying the learned linear operator to the current state's encoding. This forces the model to discover intrinsic coordinates of the system's attractor manifold. KCL yields state-of-the-art performance on downstream tasks such as action recognition and long-term video forecasting, demonstrating superior ability to model complex, nonlinear dynamical systems.
subject: AI
title: Spatiotemporal Contrastive Learning via Koopman Operator Approximation

text: Federated learning (FL) systems commonly employ uniform noise addition to satisfy differential privacy (DP), which can disproportionately degrade utility by treating all client updates equally. We propose an adaptive privacy framework, Federated Rényi-Adaptive Privacy (FedRAP), that optimizes the privacy-utility trade-off by dynamically allocating the privacy budget. Our method leverages the tighter composition guarantees of Rényi Differential Privacy (RDP) and formulates the budget allocation problem as a multi-armed bandit, where the learner (server) allocates more budget to clients whose updates are predicted to have a higher impact on the global model's accuracy. This client-and-round-specific noise calibration ensures that a global privacy guarantee (ε, δ) is met over the entire training process. Extensive experiments on non-IID datasets demonstrate that FedRAP significantly improves model convergence speed and final accuracy compared to state-of-the-art FL algorithms with uniform privacy budgets, without incurring additional privacy loss.
subject: AI
title: Adaptive Privacy Budget Allocation in Federated Learning with Rényi Differential Privacy

text: We introduce the Neural Operator Transformer (NOT), a novel deep learning architecture for learning solution operators of parametric Partial Differential Equations (PDEs). Unlike prior methods like Fourier Neural Operators that operate on fixed grid structures, NOT is mesh-agnostic and resolution-invariant. It achieves this by treating the input function query points and physical coordinates as a set of tokens. A geometric self-attention mechanism, conditioned on the relative spatial positions of these tokens, allows the model to learn the underlying Green's function of the PDE system in a permutation-equivariant manner. This operator-learning approach enables NOT to generalize to unseen parameterizations, boundary conditions, and domain geometries in a zero-shot fashion. We demonstrate that NOT achieves state-of-the-art accuracy and provides a speedup of over three orders of magnitude compared to traditional numerical solvers on a range of challenging benchmarks, including Navier-Stokes and Helmholtz equations.
subject: AI
title: Neural Operator Transformers for Solving Parametric Partial Differential Equations

text: Unsupervised Domain Adaptation (UDA) is challenged by scenarios where label distributions shift between source and target domains. Conventional UDA methods, relying on direct feature distribution alignment via metrics like Wasserstein distance, often fail in such cases. We propose Gromov-Wasserstein Domain Adaptation (GWDA), a novel framework that aligns the relational structure of the domains rather than the feature distributions themselves. By minimizing the Gromov-Wasserstein distance between the source and target latent representations, our method learns a domain-invariant mapping that preserves intra-domain geometric relationships, making it robust to label space mismatch. To prevent feature collapse, we introduce a discriminative latent space regularization term that promotes class separability. GWDA significantly outperforms existing methods on complex benchmarks for partial and open-set domain adaptation, establishing a new state-of-the-art by effectively decoupling feature geometry alignment from direct class correspondence.
subject: AI
title: Unsupervised Domain Adaptation via Gromov-Wasserstein Optimal Transport with Latent Space Regularization

text: We present a novel neuro-symbolic framework that integrates the perceptual capabilities of deep neural networks with the formal reasoning power of probabilistic logic programming. Our model, Differentiable Abductive Proving (DAP), learns to reason by finding the most probable explanation for an observed outcome given a set of facts and learnable probabilistic logical rules. The core innovation is a continuous relaxation of the symbolic backward-chaining and abductive reasoning process, which allows gradients from a reasoning task loss to flow back through the logical structure to update the neural network's perception modules and the probabilities of the symbolic rules. This enables end-to-end training from data. We demonstrate DAP's effectiveness on complex visual question answering and science QA datasets, where it not only achieves higher accuracy and systematic generalization but also produces fully interpretable, logical proofs for its predictions, bridging the gap between connectionist and symbolic AI.
subject: AI
title: Probabilistic Neuro-Symbolic Inference via Differentiable Abduction

text: This paper addresses the challenge of discovering latent group structures in complex, heterogeneous datasets where the number of clusters is unknown a priori. We introduce a novel Bayesian nonparametric framework, the Covariate-Informed Hierarchical Dirichlet Process (CI-HDP), which extends the standard HDP mixture model by allowing the atom-placing distribution of the base measure to depend on observed covariates. This modification enables the sharing of statistical strength across groups in a more structured manner, guided by external information. We derive two posterior inference schemes: a collapsed Gibbs sampler for exact inference and a more scalable stochastic variational inference (SVI) algorithm for large-scale applications. Theoretical contributions include a proof of posterior consistency for the number of latent components and the component-specific parameters under mild regularity conditions. The utility of the CI-HDP is demonstrated on synthetic data and a real-world application in genomic subtyping, where it shows marked improvements in clustering accuracy, parameter estimation, and biological interpretability compared to existing methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Mixture Models for Latent Structure Discovery in Heterogeneous Data

text: Estimating causal effects from observational data is frequently complicated by high-dimensional confounding. Standard regression adjustment using machine learning models introduces regularization bias, invalidating statistical inference. We present a general framework for debiased machine learning to estimate the average treatment effect (ATE) and other causal parameters. Our approach leverages the principle of Neyman orthogonality to construct estimators that are first-order insensitive to errors in estimating the nuisance functions—namely, the propensity score and the conditional outcome mean. By employing cross-fitting, we prevent overfitting bias and enable the use of arbitrary high-performance machine learning algorithms for nuisance component estimation. We establish the asymptotic normality and semiparametric efficiency of our proposed estimator under standard sparsity and regularity conditions, thereby facilitating valid confidence interval construction. Extensive simulations and an econometric application demonstrate that our method effectively mitigates regularization bias and provides more reliable causal estimates than conventional plug-in or doubly robust approaches in high-dimensional settings.
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Machine Learning for Robust Causal Inference in High-Dimensional Confounded Settings

text: Topological Data Analysis (TDA), particularly persistent homology, provides powerful tools for characterizing the shape of data. However, a significant limitation has been the lack of a robust framework for statistical inference on the resulting topological features. This paper introduces a novel methodology for constructing confidence regions for persistence diagrams. Our approach combines a multi-scale kernel density estimator on the space of diagrams with a computationally efficient subsampling bootstrap procedure to quantify uncertainty. We establish the asymptotic validity of our confidence sets under weak assumptions on the data-generating process, formally linking the geometry of the point cloud to the convergence rates of our estimator. Unlike permutation-based tests that assess a global null hypothesis, our method provides feature-level uncertainty quantification. The utility of this inferential framework is demonstrated by identifying significant topological structures in noisy protein folding trajectories and large-scale cosmological simulations, showcasing its power in complex scientific applications where signal and noise must be rigorously disambiguated.
subject: İstatistik
title: Statistically Rigorous Inference for Persistent Homology via Subsampling and Multi-scale Kernels

text: Estimating sparse precision matrices is fundamental for inferring conditional independence structures in Gaussian graphical models. However, popular methods like the graphical LASSO are sensitive to deviations from normality. We propose a robust, two-stage procedure designed for non-Gaussian and heavy-tailed data. The first stage involves computing a resilient estimate of the covariance matrix using a rank-based correlation metric, such as Kendall's tau, which is robust to monotonic transformations and outliers. In the second stage, we apply a novel adaptive thresholding operator to the inverse of this robust covariance estimate. The threshold level is determined in a data-driven manner, adapting to the local signal strength across the matrix. We derive non-asymptotic error bounds in the Frobenius norm for our estimator under a broad class of elliptical distributions, proving it achieves near-optimal convergence rates even under substantial contamination. Simulation studies confirm its superior performance in both graph structure recovery and estimation accuracy compared to the graphical LASSO.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Thresholding for Sparse Precision Matrix Estimation with Non-Gaussian and Heavy-Tailed Data

text: Identifying multiple change points in high-dimensional time series presents significant computational and statistical challenges, particularly when changes are sparse and occur at different scales. We introduce Multiscale Wild Binary Segmentation (M-WBS), a powerful algorithm that integrates a multiscale scanning approach with a projection-based CUSUM statistic. The method first projects the high-dimensional series onto a set of data-driven directions designed to maximize the signal-to-noise ratio. It then performs recursive binary segmentation over a large, randomized set of intervals to detect changes across various scales and locations. We establish rigorous theoretical guarantees for the consistency of the estimated number and locations of change points, providing control over the false discovery rate under assumptions of sparse, block-diagonal covariance structures. The algorithm exhibits near-linear computational complexity and demonstrates superior detection power for both dense and sparse changes in extensive simulations. Its efficacy is validated on synthetic fMRI data and financial log-return series.
subject: İstatistik
title: Multiscale Wild Binary Segmentation for Detecting Heterogeneous Change Points in High-Dimensional Time Series

text: The estimation of optimal treatment rules (OTRs) is a central goal in precision medicine. This paper investigates the inferential properties of the value function, a key metric for evaluating the efficacy of any given treatment rule. We first derive the semiparametric efficiency bound for the value function estimator, establishing the theoretical limit of estimation precision. Building on this result, we construct a novel, doubly robust and locally efficient estimator based on targeted maximum likelihood estimation (TMLE). This estimator remains consistent and asymptotically normal if either the propensity score model or the outcome regression model is correctly specified, but not necessarily both. Our one-step construction facilitates valid inference even when flexible machine learning algorithms are employed for nuisance function estimation. This work provides a rigorous foundation for constructing confidence intervals for the value of an OTR, thereby enabling robust statistical comparison and selection among candidate treatment strategies in both clinical trials and observational studies.
subject: İstatistik
title: Semiparametric Efficiency and Doubly Robust Inference for Personalized Treatment Rules under Model Misspecification

text: Standard Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods are inherently sequential, creating a computational bottleneck for Bayesian inference on massive datasets. We introduce Consensus Monte Carlo, a novel framework for embarrassingly parallel posterior computation. The methodology involves partitioning the data across multiple machines, running an independent MCMC analysis on each data subset to obtain 'sub-posteriors', and then combining these into a single approximation of the global posterior. The recombination step is formulated as finding the geometric median or barycenter in the Wasserstein space of probability measures. We propose a computationally efficient solution based on a weighted average of the sub-posterior densities, with weights inversely proportional to their asymptotic variance. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis, proving that under certain regularity conditions, the consensus posterior converges to the true posterior at a near-optimal rate. The framework's scalability and accuracy are demonstrated on large-scale logistic regression and hierarchical models, achieving substantial computational speedups with negligible loss of statistical efficiency.
subject: İstatistik
title: Consensus Monte Carlo: A Framework for Massively Parallel Posterior Computation

text: Accurate dynamic prediction of event probabilities is crucial in clinical settings with competing risks. Existing landmarking approaches often rely on the restrictive proportional hazards assumption. We propose a flexible landmarking framework based on Aalen's additive hazards model to provide updated predictions as new patient information becomes available. For a given landmark time point, we fit a series of additive models to estimate the time-varying effects of baseline and updated longitudinal covariates on the cumulative incidence function (CIF). This approach avoids proportionality assumptions and directly models the CIF without modeling the cause-specific hazards. Estimation is conducted using a robust pseudo-value regression technique, which yields non-parametric estimates of the cumulative coefficient functions. We establish the asymptotic properties of the proposed estimators and the resulting prediction probabilities. The method's superior predictive accuracy and calibration are demonstrated through simulations and an application to a bone marrow transplant dataset, where it provides more clinically interpretable predictions of mortality and relapse.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Prediction in Competing Risks using Landmark-Dependent Additive Hazards Models

text: Explaining the remarkable generalization performance of over-parameterized deep neural networks is a central challenge in statistical learning theory. We derive novel PAC-Bayesian generalization bounds by connecting the training dynamics of stochastic gradient descent (SGD) to a continuous-time stochastic differential equation (SDE). This perspective allows us to define a data-dependent prior distribution over the network weights that is centered on the SDE path corresponding to the SGD trajectory. The resulting generalization bound depends not just on the final learned parameters but on the entire optimization path. The bound explicitly incorporates the noise scale of SGD and the local geometry of the loss landscape, captured through the trace of the Hessian of the SDE's potential function. This information-theoretic approach provides a tighter, more informative alternative to complexity-based bounds. Our analysis suggests that the implicit regularization of SGD dynamics is a key driver of generalization. We empirically validate our bounds on benchmark image classification tasks, showing they are non-vacuous and correlate strongly with observed test error.
subject: İstatistik
title: PAC-Bayesian Generalization Bounds for Deep Neural Networks via Stochastic Differential Equations

text: Standard pitch estimation algorithms, optimized for equal-tempered scales, exhibit significant deficiencies when analyzing microtonal music. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Bayesian Convolutional Recurrent Neural Network (HBCRNN) designed for robust pitch contour estimation in such contexts. The model processes Constant-Q Transform (CQT) spectrograms through a CRNN backbone to extract temporal frequency representations. Crucially, a Bayesian final layer employing variational inference provides not only a point estimate for the fundamental frequency but also a corresponding epistemic uncertainty distribution. This probabilistic output allows for more nuanced interpretations of pitch, essential for analyzing the labile intonation characteristic of many traditions. We validate our framework on a newly curated dataset of Turkish Makam and Persian Dastgah recordings, demonstrating superior performance over state-of-the-art models in both accuracy and the meaningful representation of pitch ambiguity. The proposed method offers a significant advancement for the computational analysis of non-Western musical systems.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hierarchical Bayesian Deep Learning Framework for Microtonal Pitch Estimation in Non-Western Musics

text: This study introduces a novel methodology for the quantitative analysis of harmonic complexity using topological data analysis (TDA). We represent harmonic progressions from a corpus of works by Wagner, Strauss, and Mahler as weighted directed graphs, where nodes correspond to pitch-class set chords and edges represent voice-leading parsimony between them. By constructing clique complexes from these graphs, we apply persistent homology to track the evolution of topological features—specifically, Betti numbers representing n-dimensional holes—across varying scales. The resulting persistence diagrams serve as unique topological fingerprints of a composer's harmonic language, quantifying characteristics such as cyclic progressions and long-range structural dependencies that elude traditional Roman numeral or Schenkerian analysis. Our findings reveal distinct topological signatures for each composer, providing a scale-invariant, coordinate-free metric for stylistic comparison and demonstrating the underlying geometric structures governing late-romantic harmonic syntax.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Data Analysis and Persistent Homology for Characterizing Harmonic Syntax in Late-Romantic Polyphony

text: The acoustically dense and spectrally complex nature of Balinese Gamelan Gong Kebyar presents a significant challenge for traditional audio source separation and timbral analysis. This paper proposes a perceptually constrained Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) algorithm to address this. Our approach modifies the standard Kullback-Leibler divergence objective function by incorporating psychoacoustic models of auditory masking and spectral roughness, thereby biasing the factorization towards solutions that are more aligned with human perception. By decomposing complex ensemble spectrograms into a set of spectral bases (timbres) and their corresponding temporal activations, our method achieves superior isolation of constituent instruments like the metallophones (*gangsa*, *jegogan*) and kettle gongs (*reyong*). The extracted spectral templates provide a robust feature set for instrument identification and offer quantitative insights into the emergent timbral phenomena created by *kotekan* interlocking patterns, clarifying the relationship between individual instrumental timbres and the composite ensemble sound.
subject: Müzik
title: Non-Negative Matrix Factorization with Perceptual Constraints for Timbral Analysis of Balinese Gamelan Gong Kebyar

text: This research reframes Schenkerian analysis within the paradigm of algorithmic information theory, positing that the process of reduction from foreground (*Vordergrund*) to background (*Ursatz*) is fundamentally a process of data compression. We model musical scores as symbolic strings and hypothesize that a stylistically coherent tonal work exhibits minimal Kolmogorov complexity in its background structure, while the foreground elaborations maximize expressive information relative to this parsimonious skeleton. Using the Block Decomposition Method (BDM) as a practical estimator for Kolmogorov complexity, we analyze a corpus of Bach chorales and Beethoven piano sonatas. Our results demonstrate a quantifiable, inverse relationship between a reduction's hierarchical level and its algorithmic complexity. This information-theoretic perspective provides a formal, non-teleological basis for the principles of structural hierarchy and prolongation in Schenkerian theory, offering a new quantitative tool for understanding tonal coherence and compositional strategy.
subject: Müzik
title: Algorithmic Information Dynamics of Schenkerian Reduction: A Kolmogorov Complexity Approach to Tonal Structure

text: This research investigates expressive performance parameters in a corpus of 50 historical and modern recordings of Chopin's Mazurkas. We employ a Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT) with a complex Morlet wavelet to generate high-resolution scalograms, enabling precise, simultaneous analysis of frequency and time. From these representations, we extract instantaneous amplitude and frequency envelopes to quantify micro-timing deviations (expressive timing, *rubato*) and dynamic articulations at a sub-beat resolution. A novel algorithm is introduced to correlate these performance nuances with underlying harmonic tension, derived from a probabilistic model of tonal expectation (Krumhansl-Schmuckler). Statistical analysis of the resulting multi-dimensional feature space reveals distinct, performer-specific signatures in the application of expressive gestures. This methodology transcends simple note-onset deviation analysis, providing a granular, quantifiable framework for classifying interpretations and modeling the intricate relationship between musical structure and performative expression.
subject: Müzik
title: Wavelet-Based Time-Frequency Analysis of Microtiming and Dynamic Nuances in Chopin Mazurka Performances

text: This paper presents a novel generative model for species counterpoint that leverages the inherent relational structure of polyphonic music. We represent contrapuntal textures as time-varying graphs, where notes are nodes possessing pitch and duration attributes, and edges represent melodic and harmonic intervals between them. A Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) is trained as the generator, learning the topological and feature-based rules of Fuxian counterpoint from a symbolic corpus. An adversarial discriminator, structured as a relational GCN, is trained to distinguish generated excerpts from real compositions by evaluating both local intervallic constraints and global melodic contour properties. This graph-based approach moves beyond the limitations of sequential models (e.g., LSTMs) by explicitly encoding the vertical and horizontal relationships fundamental to counterpoint. The system successfully generates stylistically coherent, multi-voice fragments that adhere to complex rules of dissonance treatment and voice leading, demonstrating a superior understanding of musical syntax.
subject: Müzik
title: Contrapuntal Syntax Generation via Adversarially Trained Graph Convolutional Networks

text: Prevailing computational models of sensory dissonance, primarily rooted in Helmholtz's theory of spectral beating, inadequately account for the perceptual influence of complex timbres and auditory scene analysis. This paper proposes a unified, multiparametric model that provides a more robust prediction of perceived dissonance. The model integrates three components: (1) a baseline sensory dissonance metric derived from Plomp and Levelt's critical band theory, calculated using a gammatone filterbank; (2) a penalty term for aggregate spectral inharmonicity, quantified via a cepstral analysis that measures deviation from a harmonic series; and (3) a modulation factor based on Bregman's principles of auditory stream segregation, which attenuates dissonance when spectral components are likely to be perceived as separate sound sources. Validated against human listener ratings for a diverse stimulus set including synthetic tones and natural instrument sounds, our integrated model provides a significantly better fit to empirical data than existing models, particularly for complex, inharmonic spectra.
subject: Müzik
title: A Multiparametric Computational Model of Dissonance Perception Integrating Spectral Inharmonicity and Auditory Streaming

text: This study applies methodologies from natural language processing to the analysis of jazz improvisation, treating solos as documents composed of a vocabulary of musical patterns. We develop a robust method for quantizing melodic fragments from a large corpus of transcribed Bebop solos into a discrete 'vocabulary' by clustering them in a feature space defined by pitch-class intervals, rhythmic contour, and underlying harmonic context. Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA), a generative probabilistic model, is then applied to this quantized corpus. The model discovers latent 'topics,' which are distributions over the musical vocabulary that correspond to recurring, stylistically significant melodic-harmonic formulae or 'licks.' The analysis reveals that these algorithmically discovered topics are musically meaningful, often correlating with specific harmonic functions (e.g., ii-V-I progressions) and exhibiting clear associations with individual improvisers (e.g., Charlie Parker vs. Dizzy Gillespie). This provides a powerful data-driven approach for stylistic analysis and pattern discovery in improvisational music.
subject: Müzik
title: Probabilistic Topic Modeling of Bebop Improvisations: Discovering Latent Melodic-Harmonic Patterns using Latent Dirichlet Allocation

text: Traditional music segmentation algorithms often rely on harmonic and rhythmic features that are less salient in texture-centric genres like Electronic Dance Music (EDM). This paper presents an unsupervised segmentation method predicated on the evolution of timbre. High-dimensional Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficient (MFCC) feature vectors are projected into a low-dimensional timbral manifold using Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP). A self-similarity matrix (SSM) is constructed from the pairwise Euclidean distances within this trajectory space, revealing timbral recurrence patterns. We then apply Recurrence Quantification Analysis (RQA) to this SSM, using metrics such as determinism and laminarity to detect points of abrupt change in timbral state. This novel approach effectively identifies macro-level formal sections (e.g., intro, buildup, drop, breakdown) in a large EDM corpus with high accuracy, outperforming standard chroma-based and novelty-based methods and demonstrating the primacy of timbral evolution in shaping the perception of structure in this genre.
subject: Müzik
title: Self-Similarity and Recurrence Quantification Analysis of Timbral Trajectories for Unsupervised Structural Segmentation of Electronic Dance Music

text: This research formalizes neo-Riemannian theories of parsimonious voice-leading within the rigorous mathematical framework of Riemannian geometry. We model the tonal space of major and minor triads not as a discrete graph, but as a topological orbifold, a manifold-like space with singularities corresponding to chordal symmetries. A Riemannian metric is defined on this space where distance is proportional to the minimal sum of semitonal displacements between chord tones. We demonstrate that the canonical neo-Riemannian transformations (P, L, R) correspond to geodesic paths—the locally shortest routes—on this orbifold. This geometric perspective provides a continuous and principled foundation for voice-leading efficiency, unifying disparate transformational theories. The model is extended to encompass seventh chords, requiring a higher-dimensional geometric object, and is used to analyze complex harmonic passages in Liszt and Fauré, revealing underlying geodesic trajectories that elucidate the logic of their advanced chromatic syntax.
subject: Müzik
title: Voice-Leading Parsimony as Geodesic Motion on Orbifold Tonnetze: A Riemannian Geometric Approach to Chromatic Harmony

text: This paper introduces a novel deep learning architecture, the Convolutional-Recursive Schenkerian Network (CRSN), for the automated generation of Schenkerian graphs directly from monophonic audio signals. Traditional Music Information Retrieval (MIR) systems often segment analysis into discrete stages of pitch detection, note segmentation, and subsequent symbolic parsing. In contrast, our end-to-end model leverages a convolutional front-end to learn spectro-temporal features indicative of melodic salience and a subsequent recursive neural network to infer hierarchical relationships consistent with Schenkerian principles of prolongation and structural levels. Trained on a curated dataset of annotated Bach chorales and Lieder, the CRSN demonstrates a significant improvement in parsing accuracy for identifying the Ursatz (fundamental structure) and middleground prolongations compared to cascaded baseline models. Our results suggest that acoustic cues, such as subtle dynamic envelopes and timbral shifts, are implicitly learned by the network as correlates of structural importance, bridging the hermeneutic gap between acoustic signal and abstract tonal structure.
subject: Müzik
title: From Signal to Ursatz: A Convolutional-Recursive Neural Network for Automated Schenkerian Analysis of Monophonic Audio

text: This research investigates the semantic role of timbre in the orchestration of late-Romantic symphonic works. We propose a computational framework that correlates psychoacoustic descriptors derived from audio analysis with established music-theoretical formal functions. Utilizing a corpus of works by Mahler, Strauss, and Bruckner, we perform spectral analysis to extract a high-dimensional feature vector for orchestral tutti sections, including spectral centroid, flux, roughness, and inharmonicity. A dimensionality reduction via Principal Component Analysis reveals a consistent timbral space whose primary axes correspond to the perceptual qualities of 'brightness' and 'density'. By aligning these timbral coordinates with formal markers (e.g., exposition, development, recapitulation), we employ a Support Vector Machine classifier to demonstrate a statistically significant mapping between specific timbral palettes and formal function. Our findings provide empirical validation for orchestration theories that posit timbre as a primary articulating parameter in post-Wagnerian musical syntax, moving beyond traditional pitch-centric analytical paradigms.
subject: Müzik
title: A Psychoacoustic-Computational Framework for Mapping Timbral Semantics to Formal Function in Late-Romantic Orchestration

text: This study presents a computational model of tonal harmonic syntax using Probabilistic Context-Free Grammars (PCFGs) derived from a large-scale symbolic music corpus. We challenge the limitations of n-gram and finite-state models by proposing a hierarchical grammar that captures long-range dependencies and recursive structures inherent in functional harmony, such as nested tonic-dominant prolongations. By parsing a large annotated corpus, we automatically induce a set of production rules and associated probabilities that govern the generation of chord sequences. The resulting PCFG is capable of both parsing unseen harmonic progressions to derive their syntactic structure and generating novel, stylistically coherent sequences. A quantitative evaluation, including perplexity measures and a blind listening test against Markov-chain-generated outputs, confirms the superior structural coherence and stylistic plausibility of our grammar. This approach offers a powerful formal analytical tool and provides a robust foundation for sophisticated algorithmic composition systems.
subject: Müzik
title: Probabilistic Context-Free Grammars for Tonal Harmony: A Corpus-Based Study of Harmonic Syntax

text: Neo-Riemannian theory has traditionally been constrained by the combinatorial properties of the 12-tone equal temperament system. This paper extends its analytical power to microtonal music by proposing a method for constructing generalized, isomorphic Tonnetze from first principles. Our methodology begins with spectral analysis of audio recordings of compositions employing just intonation or extended equal temperaments to precisely identify the fundamental frequencies and overtone structures constituting the work’s pitch-class space. Using principles of abstract algebra, we then derive a unique lattice graph (Tonnetz) that accurately models the intervallic relationships and parsimonious voice-leading possibilities within that specific tuning system. We demonstrate the utility of this approach through a detailed transformational analysis of works by Ben Johnston and Harry Partch, revealing underlying voice-leading schemata and harmonic symmetries that are obscured by traditional notation. This framework unifies spectral audio analysis and algebraic music theory, providing a rigorous and adaptable tool for non-standard pitch environments.
subject: Müzik
title: Generalized Tonnetz Isomorphisms for the Analysis of Microtonal Composition: A Spectral and Group-Theoretic Approach

text: This paper introduces a novel signal processing methodology for quantifying expressive nuances in piano performance, utilizing the Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT) to create a multi-resolution representation of micro-timing and dynamic variations. Moving beyond discrete note-onset-based models, our approach analyzes the audio signal directly, capturing the continuous evolution of performance parameters across different temporal scales. By applying the CWT to the signal's amplitude envelope and instantaneous frequency, we generate a hierarchical 'tempo-dynamic spectrogram' that visualizes agogic accents, rubato, and dynamic shaping in relation to musical phrase structure. We analyze a dataset of multiple professional performances of Chopin's Nocturnes, correlating the wavelet coefficients with annotated harmonic and metric hierarchies. Our results show that performers systematically use coupled, multi-scale modulations of tempo and dynamics to articulate phrase boundaries and underscore moments of harmonic tension, providing robust empirical evidence for the hierarchical nature of performance expression.
subject: Müzik
title: Hierarchical Analysis of Expressive Performance Timing and Dynamics via Continuous Wavelet Transform

text: The precise tuning system, or temperament, of historical keyboard instruments is a critical but often indeterminate parameter in performance practice and analysis. We present a novel statistical model for estimating the most probable temperament from an audio recording. Our method employs Bayesian inference to compare the recorded spectral data against a set of candidate temperaments (e.g., Pythagorean, meantone, Werckmeister). The model's core is a likelihood function that computes the probability of observing the measured partial frequencies of harmonic intervals (thirds, fifths) given a specific temperament's theoretical frequency ratios. We incorporate prior probabilities based on the composition's historical context. Analyzing recordings of harpsichord and fortepiano music, our system successfully distinguishes between subtly different well-temperaments with high posterior probability. This approach provides a non-invasive, data-driven tool for musicologists and performers, resolving ambiguities in historical sources and offering new insights into the aural landscape of early music.
subject: Müzik
title: A Bayesian Inference Model for Historical Temperament Estimation from Polyphonic Keyboard Audio Recordings

text: The causal link between a conductor’s gestures and the resulting musical performance remains a subject of qualitative rather than quantitative inquiry. This study presents a cross-modal analysis framework to empirically model this relationship. We recorded a professional conductor leading an orchestra using a multi-camera motion capture system synchronized with a multi-channel audio recording of the ensemble. Kinematic features, including velocity, acceleration, and jerk of the baton tip, were extracted from the motion data. Corresponding acoustic features, such as onset timing, dynamic envelope, and spectral centroid, were extracted from the isolated instrumental tracks. Using Granger causality analysis and time-lagged cross-correlation, we establish statistically significant predictive relationships between specific gestural archetypes (e.g., preparatory beats, cutoffs) and immediate orchestral responses in articulation and dynamics. Our findings reveal a highly structured, co-dependent grammar of gesture and sound, providing a quantitative foundation for conducting pedagogy and performance science.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Correlation of Conductor Gestural Kinematics and Orchestral Acoustic Response

text: This paper re-conceptualizes the pedagogical tradition of species counterpoint as a cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) problem. We model each melodic line (voice) as an independent agent tasked with selecting a sequence of pitches against a cantus firmus. The agents receive a shared reward signal based on a meticulously crafted function that quantifies adherence to the rules of Fuxian counterpoint, penalizing parallel fifths/octaves and dissonant leaps while rewarding intervallic variety and contrary motion. Through iterative training using a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm, the agents collectively converge on policies that generate stylistically valid two- and three-part contrapuntal exercises. This approach not only produces musically plausible outputs but also reveals emergent strategies for resolving complex voice-leading problems. The MARL framework proves to be a powerful, flexible alternative to constraint-based systems for modeling the interactive and goal-oriented nature of contrapuntal composition.
subject: Müzik
title: Species Counterpoint as a Multi-Agent System: A Reinforcement Learning Approach to Fuxian Harmony

text: The interdependent nature of pitch and timbre in musical audio signals poses a significant challenge for Music Information Retrieval. This research presents a deep learning architecture based on a beta-Variational Autoencoder (β-VAE) designed to learn a disentangled latent representation of these core musical attributes from complex polyphonic spectrograms. By introducing a regularization term (β) in the VAE objective function, we encourage the model to factorize the latent space into independent subspaces corresponding to distinct generative factors. One subspace learns to encode pitch content while another exclusively encodes timbral characteristics. We demonstrate the model's efficacy on the URMP dataset, showing that traversal along specific latent dimensions allows for independent manipulation of timbre while preserving harmony, and vice-versa. This robust disentanglement enables novel applications in instrument-agnostic chord recognition, audio synthesis with timbre transfer, and advanced source separation tasks.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangled Latent Representations of Timbre and Pitch in Polyphonic Music via Beta-Variational Autoencoders

text: Traditional analysis of musical form relies heavily on symbolic score data and expert annotation. This paper introduces a novel, audio-based approach using Topological Data Analysis (TDA) to automatically uncover and visualize large-scale formal structures. We first transform audio recordings into a high-dimensional feature space using self-similarity matrices derived from chroma features, capturing harmonic recurrence over time. We then apply persistent homology to this point cloud representation of the musical piece. The resulting persistence diagrams reveal topological features (connected components, loops) at different structural scales. We demonstrate that the lifespans of these features serve as robust descriptors for musical form. For instance, the persistence of 0-dimensional homology groups (Betti 0) correlates strongly with sectional divisions, while 1-dimensional features (Betti 1) often correspond to large-scale thematic returns characteristic of sonata or rondo forms. This TDA framework provides a language-independent method for comparative formal analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Data Analysis for Uncovering Large-Scale Musical Form

text: We investigate the anisotropies of the stochastic gravitational-wave background (SGWB) produced during inflation as a novel probe for primordial non-Gaussianity. By computing the tensor-scalar-scalar bispectrum in single-field slow-roll inflationary models, we derive the angular power spectrum, C_l, of the SGWB. Our analysis reveals that non-Gaussian interactions induce a distinct quadrupolar (l=2) anisotropy pattern, whose amplitude is directly proportional to the non-linearity parameter f_NL. Unlike Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) constraints, which are primarily sensitive to the squeezed limit of the bispectrum, the SGWB anisotropy probes the full kinematic configuration. We demonstrate that for certain classes of non-standard inflationary models, future detectors such as LISA and the Einstein Telescope could place constraints on f_NL that are competitive with, or complementary to, existing CMB bounds. This work establishes the SGWB anisotropy as a powerful, independent cosmological observable for constraining the physics of the early universe and the mechanism of inflation.
subject: Fizik
title: Anisotropies in the Stochastic Gravitational Wave Background as a Probe of Primordial Non-Gaussianity

text: The nature of entanglement in non-Hermitian many-body systems remains an open frontier. We study the entanglement entropy scaling in a one-dimensional non-Hermitian transverse-field Ising model, which exhibits a parity-time (PT) symmetry-breaking transition. Using large-scale density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) simulations adapted for non-Hermitian operators, we compute the logarithmic negativity and the von Neumann entropy. In the PT-symmetric phase, the system obeys an area-law scaling, consistent with gapped Hermitian ground states. However, precisely at the exceptional point marking the PT-symmetry-breaking transition, we uncover a crossover to a volume-law scaling for the entanglement entropy. This transition signifies a profound structural change in the quantum state, indicating a delocalization of information across the entire system. Our results suggest that entanglement entropy serves as a potent order parameter for identifying phase transitions in non-Hermitian quantum matter and has significant implications for understanding open quantum systems and their simulation.
subject: Fizik
title: Entanglement Entropy Scaling at the PT-Symmetry-Breaking Transition in Non-Hermitian Quantum Systems

text: We employ the AdS/CFT correspondence to investigate the far-from-equilibrium thermalization dynamics of a strongly coupled gauge theory. By modeling a quantum quench as the gravitational collapse of a massless scalar field shell in an Anti-de Sitter (AdS) background, we track the formation of an apparent horizon and its subsequent approach to a final black brane equilibrium state. The system's thermalization is probed by calculating the holographic entanglement entropy and two-point correlation functions. We find that the thermalization timescale is universally governed by the imaginary part of the lowest-lying scalar quasinormal mode of the final black brane. The late-time exponential decay of perturbations towards equilibrium directly corresponds to this fundamental frequency, providing a robust connection between the hydrodynamic regime described by fluid-gravity duality and the full non-linear dynamics of gravitational collapse. This holographic framework offers a powerful analytical tool for understanding ultrafast thermalization in systems like the quark-gluon plasma.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Thermalization and Quasinormal Mode Excitations in Strongly Coupled Gauge Theories

text: We theoretically demonstrate a mechanism for achieving robust, all-optical non-reciprocity by introducing a spatiotemporal modulation of the dielectric permittivity in a photonic crystal. By applying a traveling-wave perturbation, we engineer a Floquet-Bloch system that fundamentally breaks time-reversal symmetry without magneto-optic materials. Our analysis, based on a coupled-mode theory and finite-difference time-domain simulations, reveals the opening of frequency-momentum band gaps and the emergence of an effective synthetic magnetic field for photons. This leads to a strong asymmetry in the dispersion relation, enabling unidirectional light propagation within a specified frequency window. The degree of non-reciprocity and the operational bandwidth are shown to be tunable via the modulation amplitude and frequency. This dynamic modulation scheme paves the way for integrated, on-chip optical isolators, circulators, and topological photonic devices with reconfigurable transport properties, crucial for next-generation optical computing and communication systems.
subject: Fizik
title: Spatiotemporal Engineering of Non-Reciprocal Transport in Floquet Photonic Crystals

text: We propose and numerically simulate a protocol for measuring information scrambling and diagnosing quantum chaos in a programmable quantum simulator based on a one-dimensional array of Rydberg atoms. The system is subjected to a periodic kicking potential, realizing a Floquet model that exhibits a tunable transition from a many-body localized phase to a thermalizing, chaotic phase. We compute the out-of-time-ordered correlator (OTOC) to quantify the spread of quantum information. In the chaotic regime, the OTOC displays a characteristic exponential growth, from which we extract a many-body quantum Lyapunov exponent. We investigate the scaling of this exponent with system parameters, such as interaction strength and kick period, finding a direct correspondence with the onset of level-spacing statistics described by random matrix theory. Our results establish kicked Rydberg arrays as a versatile platform for experimentally exploring fundamental aspects of quantum chaos, thermalization, and the connection between scrambling and entanglement dynamics in isolated many-body systems.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Quantum Chaos and Information Scrambling with Out-of-Time-Ordered Correlators in a Rydberg Atom Array

text: The ringdown phase of a binary black hole merger provides a pristine environment to test General Relativity (GR) in the strong-field, dynamical regime. We investigate the prospective constraints on deviations from GR that can be obtained from the spectroscopy of black hole quasinormal modes (QNMs) with third-generation gravitational-wave observatories. Using a parameterized framework that allows for generic modifications to the QNM frequencies and damping times predicted by the Kerr metric, we perform a Bayesian analysis on simulated merger signals. We demonstrate that detectors like the Einstein Telescope or Cosmic Explorer will be capable of resolving multiple ringdown modes with high signal-to-noise ratios. This fidelity enables constraints on parameters within specific scalar-tensor and dynamical Chern-Simons gravity theories that are orders of magnitude more stringent than current bounds. This work highlights the transformative potential of gravitational-wave spectroscopy as a high-precision tool for probing the fundamental nature of gravity and the validity of the no-hair theorem.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraints on Modified Gravity from Black Hole Ringdown Spectroscopy with Third-Generation Detectors

text: We extend the framework of stochastic thermodynamics to analyze entropy production in a system of interacting active Brownian particles subjected to external driving. By decomposing the total entropy production rate into contributions from particle activity, inter-particle interactions, and external work, we derive a detailed fluctuation theorem for the system. Our numerical simulations of a model system, consisting of self-propelled particles in a periodic potential, confirm that the theorem holds far from thermal equilibrium. We find that the onset of collective motion, such as swarming or laning, is marked by a distinct signature in the entropy production landscape. Specifically, the symmetry of the probability distribution of entropy fluctuations is broken in a manner that quantifies the degree of emergent order.
