This work provides a rigorous thermodynamic formalism for characterizing non-equilibrium phase transitions and self-organization in active matter, connecting microscopic irreversibility to macroscopic collective behavior.
subject: Fizik
title: Fluctuation Theorems and Entropy Production in Driven Active Matter Collectives

text: We theoretically investigate the conditions for realizing Majorana zero modes in a Josephson junction fabricated on the edge of a two-dimensional topological insulator, i.e., a quantum spin Hall (QSH) insulator. An in-plane magnetic field is applied to the junction, which gaps the helical edge states via the Zeeman effect and induces a topological phase transition. By solving the Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations self-consistently, we demonstrate that for a specific phase difference across the junction, a pair of Majorana bound states emerges at the interface between the gapped and superconducting regions. Crucially, these zero-energy states are protected by the superconducting gap and are robust against non-magnetic disorder. We calculate the local density of states, predicting a distinct zero-bias conductance peak in scanning tunneling spectroscopy experiments. This QSH-based architecture offers a promising alternative to semiconductor nanowire platforms for creating and manipulating topological qubits for fault-tolerant quantum computation.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergence of Majorana Bound States in Magnetized Quantum Spin Hall Josephson Junctions

text: We propose a novel detection strategy for axion-like particle (ALP) dark matter that utilizes the resonant conversion of ALPs into photons within the magnetized plasma of galaxy clusters. When the ALP mass, m_a, is commensurate with the plasma frequency, ω_p, of the intracluster medium (ICM), the axion-photon conversion probability is significantly enhanced. We develop a comprehensive model incorporating the turbulent magnetic field structures and inhomogeneous plasma density profiles characteristic of galaxy clusters, derived from magnetohydrodynamic simulations. By calculating the expected spectral line flux from the decay of the dark matter halo, we show that existing and upcoming radio telescopes, such as the Square Kilometre Array (SKA), can act as powerful cosmic haloscopes. Our forecasts indicate that this method can probe astrophysically motivated regions of the ALP parameter space, particularly for m_a ≈ 10⁻⁷ - 10⁻⁵ eV, providing a complementary search strategy to terrestrial experiments and constraining the nature of dark matter.
subject: Fizik
title: Axion Dark Matter Haloscopy via Resonant Photon Conversion in Magnetized Intracluster Plasma

text: The synchronization of biological oscillators like cilia and flagella is crucial for locomotion and fluid transport at the microscale. We investigate the role of fluid viscoelasticity in this process by developing a theoretical model of two stochastically beating flagellar filaments coupled through a non-Newtonian fluid. Using a combination of slender-body theory for hydrodynamic interactions and a generalized Langevin equation to account for the fluid's memory effects and thermal noise, we analyze the system's phase dynamics. Our results show that viscoelastic stresses introduce a phase-dependent memory into the hydrodynamic coupling, significantly expanding the domain of stable in-phase and anti-phase synchronization compared to a purely viscous Newtonian fluid. This elastohydrodynamic enhancement of synchronization provides a robust physical mechanism for coordinated motion in complex biological media like mucus. The findings offer new insights into the biophysics of microbial motility and have implications for the design of synthetic micro-swimmers.
subject: Fizik
title: Elastohydrodynamic Synchronization of Stochastic Flagellar Oscillators in Viscoelastic Fluids

text: This study introduces a novel graph-theoretical framework for the systematic analysis of contrapuntal voice leading in sixteenth-century sacred polyphony. We model musical works as directed multigraphs where nodes represent pitch classes and weighted edges represent intervallic transitions between voices. By computing network-theoretic metrics such as node centrality, clustering coefficients, and community structure, we quantify stylistic fingerprints of composers like Palestrina, Lassus, and Victoria. Our methodology extends beyond traditional interval-vector analysis by capturing the temporal and syntactic dimensions of polyphonic texture. Results demonstrate that Palestrina's dissonance treatment corresponds to specific topological features, including low clustering coefficients in dissonance-related subgraphs, which distinguish his style from his contemporaries. This computational approach provides an empirical, scalable method for comparative stylistic analysis, formalizing long-standing musicological observations about the evolution of Renaissance counterpoint and offering a robust tool for authorship attribution and historical music theory.
subject: Müzik
title: Graph-Theoretical Modeling of Contrapuntal Voice Leading in Renaissance Polyphony

text: We investigate the structure of musical timbre using a deep generative model, specifically a β-Variational Autoencoder (β-VAE), trained on a large-scale dataset of isolated instrumental notes. Our model learns a disentangled, low-dimensional latent representation of timbral features, independent of pitch and loudness. By analyzing the topology of this latent space, we identify continuous manifolds corresponding to perceptually salient timbral characteristics such as brightness, attack sharpness, and inharmonicity. This structured representation facilitates high-fidelity timbral interpolation and extrapolation. We demonstrate the model's efficacy through novel cross-instrumental synthesis, generating acoustically plausible sounds that smoothly transition between disparate instruments (e.g., a cello morphing into a flute). Quantitative evaluation using spectral envelope distance metrics and qualitative listening tests confirm that our VAE-based approach significantly outperforms baseline methods like autoencoder-based synthesis and traditional spectral modeling, providing a powerful tool for both sound design and computational musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: Latent Timbral Space Exploration via Variational Autoencoders for Cross-Instrumental Synthesis

text: This paper presents a computational system for automated Schenkerian analysis, a cornerstone of tonal music theory that reveals hierarchical pitch structures. We employ a Hierarchical Hidden Markov Model (HHMM) to parse symbolic musical surfaces and infer multi-level structural prolongations. The model's states correspond to Schenkerian archetypes (e.g., linear progressions, arpeggiations), and its hierarchical structure naturally captures the recursive nature of foreground, middleground, and background levels. The system is trained on a newly created corpus of expert-annotated Schenkerian graphs. We evaluate its performance by comparing generated analyses against the ground-truth corpus and established musicological interpretations of canonic works. Our probabilistic framework demonstrates a robust capacity to identify fundamental structures (Ursatz) and middleground elaborations with high accuracy, offering a significant advancement in computational modeling of complex, theory-driven musical cognition and providing a scalable tool for large-scale analytical inquiry.
subject: Müzik
title: A Probabilistic Framework for Automated Schenkerian Analysis Using Hierarchical Hidden Markov Models

text: This interdisciplinary study investigates the neural and psychoacoustic underpinnings of harmonic tension and resolution. We utilized functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to measure brain activity in musically trained subjects while they listened to specially constructed chord progressions that manipulated harmonic expectancy, including deceptive cadences, secondary dominants, and non-diatonic chords. Concurrently, we performed acoustic analysis on the stimuli, extracting features such as spectral flux, sensory dissonance (roughness), and tonal stability metrics derived from a key-finding algorithm. Our fMRI results reveal a significant correlation between activation in the inferior frontal gyrus (IFG) and amygdala and moments of high harmonic expectancy violation. Furthermore, regression analysis shows that a composite acoustic model incorporating spectral dissonance and tonal ambiguity significantly predicts both subjective tension ratings and BOLD signal intensity in these auditory-cognitive processing regions. These findings provide empirical evidence for the neurobiological basis of tonal harmony, linking abstract theoretical concepts to measurable acoustic properties and their cognitive processing.
subject: Müzik
title: Psychoacoustic Correlates of Tonal Tension and Resolution: An fMRI Study of Harmonic Expectancy Violation

text: The challenge of music source separation is amplified in densely textured orchestral music. This research explores the application of advanced Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) techniques for the unsupervised separation of orchestral sections from a single-channel audio mixture. We introduce a novel variant, Spatially Constrained Convolutive NMF (SC-CNMF), which incorporates prior knowledge of typical orchestral seating arrangements (spatial cues) and the characteristic spectral-temporal bases of instrument families (e.g., strings, brass, woodwinds). The model learns a dictionary of spectral templates and their corresponding activations, constrained to promote group-wise sparsity. Evaluated on a dataset of symphonic excerpts with corresponding multi-track recordings, our method demonstrates a marked improvement in Signal-to-Distortion Ratio (SDR) and Signal-to-Interference Ratio (SIR) for separating entire orchestral sections compared to standard NMF and other state-of-the-art unsupervised methods, enabling new possibilities for musicological analysis and intelligent audio editing.
subject: Müzik
title: Non-Negative Matrix Factorization for Unsupervised Source Separation in Densely Orchestrated Symphonic Works

text: This study presents a methodology for the high-resolution analysis of micro-rhythmic expression in jazz improvisation. We leverage the Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT) with a complex Morlet wavelet to analyze audio recordings of canonical jazz solos, yielding a precise time-frequency representation that excels at capturing fast transients and subtle temporal fluctuations. From this representation, we extract features quantifying microtiming deviations, including swing ratios, onset asynchronies, and articulation dynamics, at a sub-beat level. By correlating these expressive parameters with the underlying harmonic context and melodic contour, we develop a quantitative model of improvisational phrasing. Our analysis reveals soloist-specific timing signatures and systematic patterns where performers manipulate timing to articulate harmonic tension and release. This CWT-based approach provides a more nuanced characterization of rhythmic feel than traditional Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) methods, offering deeper insight into the embodied cognition and motor control involved in virtuosic jazz performance.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Microtiming and Expressive Performance Deviations in Jazz Improvisation via Continuous Wavelet Transform

text: We propose a novel framework for musical compositional infilling using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) that is sensitive to long-range harmonic structure. Our key innovation is the structuring of the GAN's latent space according to the Riemannian geometry of tonal pitch space, specifically using a toroidal manifold to represent pitch-class and intervallic relationships. This geometric prior biases the generator towards producing harmonically and melodically coherent sequences that respect the principles of common-practice tonality. The model, trained on the J.S. Bach chorale corpus, is tasked with generating missing measures within a given musical fragment. Both objective evaluation using metrics for tonal consistency and melodic contour, and subjective listening tests by expert musicians, confirm that our geometry-aware GAN significantly outperforms standard sequential GANs and LSTM-based models. The results demonstrate the power of incorporating music-theoretic domain knowledge into the architecture of deep generative models for stylistically consistent music creation.
subject: Müzik
title: Generative Adversarial Networks for Stylistic Compositional Infilling Based on Riemannian Geometry of Tonal Pitch Space

text: This paper provides a comparative acoustic-phonetic analysis of vowel production in classical operatic singing and normative speech. Using Linear Predictive Coding (LPC) and robust formant tracking algorithms, we analyze recordings of professional singers performing standard vocalises and matched spoken utterances. We map the F1/F2 vowel space for both production modes across a range of fundamental frequencies. Our results quantitatively confirm the phenomenon of vowel modification in singing, demonstrating a systematic migration of sung vowels towards a central acoustic space to maintain timbral consistency. Furthermore, we analyze the spectral clustering around 3 kHz to characterize the 'singer's formant,' showing its dependence on vowel type and pitch height. The findings indicate that operatic vocal training systematically reconfigures the source-filter interaction to optimize acoustic efficiency and projection, providing empirical data that bridges the gap between pedagogical treatises on vocal technique and the underlying principles of speech science.
subject: Müzik
title: Acoustic-Phonetic Analysis of Formant Trajectories in Operatic Singing versus Spoken Vowels

text: This work addresses the problem of matching musical score images to their corresponding audio performances, a key challenge in music information retrieval. We propose a cross-modal retrieval system based on a Siamese deep neural network architecture. One branch of the network, a Convolutional Neural network (CNN), processes CQT-based spectrograms extracted from audio recordings. The other branch, also a CNN, processes image patches of the corresponding sheet music. The network is trained using a contrastive loss function, which minimizes the Euclidean distance between embeddings of corresponding score-audio pairs while maximizing it for non-matching pairs. This forces the model to learn a shared, modality-invariant latent embedding space where scores and audio are represented by their essential musical content. Evaluated on a large dataset of piano music, our system achieves state-of-the-art accuracy in audio-to-score and score-to-audio retrieval tasks, significantly outperforming feature-based methods that rely on separate OMR and audio analysis pipelines.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Retrieval of Musical Scores and Audio Recordings using Siamese Convolutional Neural Networks

text: Traditional music segmentation algorithms, often reliant on tonal harmony and cadential cues, are largely ineffective for analyzing atonal and post-tonal compositions. This paper introduces a novel approach using Topological Data Analysis (TDA) to uncover robust structural patterns in such repertoires. We first compute self-similarity matrices from pitch-class distribution chromagrams of the audio. Then, instead of conventional novelty curve detection, we analyze the topology of these matrices using persistent homology. This technique captures multi-scale structural features by tracking the birth and death of topological components (e.g., loops, connected components) across changing similarity thresholds. The resulting persistence diagrams provide a rich, noise-resilient signature of a piece's formal organization. Applied to works by Schoenberg, Webern, and Ligeti, our TDA-based method successfully identifies sectional boundaries and recurring textural blocks that align with musicological analyses, demonstrating its superior efficacy for dissecting complex, non-tonal musical structures.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Data Analysis of Self-Similarity Matrices for Structural Segmentation of Atonal and Post-Tonal Music

text: This paper introduces a novel computational framework for analyzing voice-leading efficiency in post-tonal repertoires by leveraging weighted graph theory. We model pitch-class sets as vertices and Neo-Riemannian or other contextually-defined transformations as edges, with edge weights determined by a multi-faceted parsimony metric incorporating displacement, registral distance, and contour preservation. Audio-derived pitch information, extracted via a polyphonic pitch tracking algorithm, is mapped onto this theoretical graph space. By applying Dijkstra's and other shortest-path algorithms, we can computationally derive the most parsimonious pathways between non-adjacent harmonic structures, revealing latent voice-leading strategies that defy traditional surface-level analysis. The methodology is validated against canonical works by Webern and Ligeti, demonstrating its capacity to uncover deep structural coherence and quantify transformational complexity. Our results challenge established formalist interpretations by providing an empirical, audio-grounded basis for evaluating harmonic progression and intervallic economy in complex atonal textures, bridging the gap between abstract set theory and acoustic realization.
subject: Müzik
title: A Graph-Theoretic Framework for Voice-Leading Parsimony in Post-Tonal Music

text: Current music information retrieval (MIR) systems often confound compositional elements with performer-induced expressive variations. This study presents a methodology for the blind decomposition of expressive performance parameters from monophonic audio recordings. We employ Independent Subspace Analysis (ISA) on a time-frequency representation, specifically the Constant-Q Transform (CQT), to disentangle micro-timing deviations, dynamic articulations, and timbral modulations from the underlying note-pitch skeleton. The ISA model learns a basis of independent subspaces corresponding to distinct articulatory gestures (e.g., vibrato, legato, staccato) by exploiting higher-order statistical dependencies in the spectral data. The resultant activation vectors provide a high-resolution quantification of expressive choices, correlated against spectral flux and energy envelope derivatives. When applied to datasets of violin and vocal performances, the system successfully isolates agogic accents and dynamic shaping, offering a robust, data-driven tool for computational musicology and performance analysis that operates directly on the audio signal without requiring a canonical score.
subject: Müzik
title: Micro-timing and Spectral Flux: Decomposing Expressive Performance Parameters using Independent Subspace Analysis

text: The induction of meter in rhythmically complex and polymetric music poses a significant challenge for computational models. We propose a Dynamic Bayesian Network (DBN) that infers a multi-level metrical hierarchy directly from an audio onset detection function. Our model represents metrical levels (tactus, supermeter, sub-division) as latent state variables whose probabilistic transitions are conditioned by inter-onset intervals (IOIs) and acoustic accent features derived from the signal's energy envelope. Unlike beat-tracking models assuming a single, stable meter, our framework utilizes a particle filter to simultaneously track multiple competing metrical hypotheses, allowing it to robustly model nested tuplets, cross-rhythms, and metric modulations. The model's efficacy is demonstrated on a curated corpus of contemporary classical and West African drum ensemble recordings. The posterior probability distributions over the latent metrical states provide a quantitative measure of metrical ambiguity and stability over time, offering new insights into rhythmic perception and complexity.
subject: Müzik
title: Bayesian Inference of Metrical Hierarchy in Polymetric Audio Signals

text: Traditional theories of harmonic consonance are primarily based on pitch relationships, largely neglecting the role of timbre. This research investigates the modulation of perceived consonance by instrumental timbre using a deep convolutional neural network (CNN) trained on psychoacoustic data. We synthesized harmonic dyads and triads using a diverse library of instrumental samples and collected consonance ratings via a large-scale listening experiment. The CNN was trained to predict these ratings directly from the audio spectrograms. Saliency mapping and feature visualization techniques were then employed to interpret the network's learned representations, revealing that spectral characteristics such as harmonic entropy, spectral centroid, and the irregularity of the partial series significantly influence consonance judgments, often overriding simple integer frequency ratios. Our findings empirically validate that timbre is not a secondary parameter but a fundamental determinant of harmonic perception, necessitating a revision of psychoacoustic models that rely solely on pitch-based roughness and harmonicity.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Timbral Influence on Harmonic Consonance Perception through Deep Learning

text: This paper presents a hybrid computational model for automated Schenkerian analysis that integrates probabilistic context-free grammars (PCFGs) with recurrent neural networks (RNNs). We formalize the rules of Schenkerian reduction as a grammatical system, where terminal symbols are notes and non-terminal symbols represent middleground prolongational structures (e.g., linear progressions, neighbor notes). A PCFG is first trained on a hand-annotated corpus of Schenkerian graphs to learn the probabilities of various reduction rules. To overcome the PCFG's insensitivity to long-range context, an LSTM-based RNN is employed to re-rank the parse trees generated by the grammar, conditioning the probability of a structural interpretation on the broader melodic and harmonic context. This hybrid approach significantly outperforms purely grammar-based or purely neural models in generating structurally coherent and musically plausible analyses of tonal melodies. The system provides a powerful tool for large-scale musicological inquiry into structural patterns across extensive corpora of symbolic music data.
subject: Müzik
title: Computational Schenkerian Analysis via Probabilistic Context-Free Grammars and RNNs

text: The identification of recurring motives and their transformations is a cornerstone of music analysis. This work applies Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) to the problem of unsupervised motivic discovery in polyphonic audio. By decomposing a log-frequency spectrogram (V) into a set of spectral templates (W) and their corresponding temporal activations (H), our model identifies recurring spectro-temporal patterns that correspond to musical motives. We introduce a novel constraint into the NMF optimization algorithm based on temporal sparsity and harmonicity, which biases the decomposition towards musically meaningful components. This method is capable of identifying motives irrespective of their orchestration or vertical alignment within the texture, effectively capturing instances of thematic development, imitation, and fragmentation. We demonstrate its utility on complex orchestral works by Brahms and Mahler, showing how the extracted activation matrix (H) can be used to generate a high-level structural annotation of the piece based on its thematic content.
subject: Müzik
title: Non-Negative Matrix Factorization for Latent Motivic Analysis in Polyphonic Textures

text: The relationship between a conductor's gestures and the resulting musical expression is a complex, nuanced phenomenon. This study employs a cross-modal computational approach to quantify this relationship. We extract kinematic features—such as velocity, acceleration, and spatial trajectory of the baton tip—from video recordings of conductors using computer vision techniques. Simultaneously, we derive structural and expressive features from the corresponding audio recordings, including onset times, dynamic envelopes, and tempo curves. Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) is then used to establish an optimal alignment between the gestural and acoustic feature streams, accommodating non-linear temporal fluctuations. Cross-correlation analysis on the aligned data reveals strong predictive relationships between preparatory gestures and subsequent dynamic changes, and between the ictus and metric articulation. This methodology provides an empirical basis for studying performance practice and the semiotics of conducting, transforming qualitative observations into quantifiable data for musicological and pedagogical applications.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Analysis of Conductor Gestures and Musical Structure using Dynamic Time Warping

text: This research explores the empirical validity of geometrical models of tonal space by correlating them with psychoacoustic metrics derived from audio signals. We construct several prominent geometrical representations, including the toroidal lattice and orbifolds from Neo-Riemannian theory, populating them with algorithmically generated chord progressions. For each progression, we synthesize an audio equivalent and compute a vector of psychoacoustic features, including sensory dissonance (roughness), harmonicity, and tonal tension using models by Hutchinson & Knopoff and Parncutt. We then measure the geometric path length of the progression within each theoretical space. A comparative analysis reveals that specific orbifold models exhibit a significantly stronger correlation between geometric distance and psychoacoustic tension/dissonance than traditional spatial models. This suggests that the topological structure of these advanced geometrical spaces implicitly encodes perceptual principles of voice-leading and harmonic stability, providing a powerful theoretical link between abstract mathematical music theory and the perceptual experience of tonality.
subject: Müzik
title: Geometrical Tonal Space Models and their Correlation with Audio-Derived Consonance Metrics

text: We present a novel approach to the algorithmic composition of species counterpoint that combines the logical rigor of first-order logic with the flexibility of probabilistic modeling. The rules of Fuxian counterpoint are encoded as a set of weighted formulas in a Markov Logic Network (MLN), a statistical-relational learning framework. This allows for the representation of both strict prohibitions (e.g., parallel fifths) and soft stylistic preferences (e.g., favoring stepwise motion). Unlike constraint-satisfaction systems that produce a single valid solution, our MLN-based generator can sample from the probability distribution defined by the weighted rules, producing a variety of stylistically coherent yet distinct contrapuntal lines against a given cantus firmus. The weights are learned from a corpus of Palestrina's music, ensuring stylistic verisimilitude. The system's output is evaluated by both expert music theorists and statistical analysis, demonstrating a superior ability to capture the subtle nuances of sixteenth-century polyphony compared to previous rule-based methods.
subject: Müzik
title: Algorithmic Generation of Species Counterpoint using Markov Logic Networks

text: This study investigates the psychoacoustic underpinnings of harmonic perception in non-standard tuning systems through computational audio analysis. We generated a comprehensive set of triadic harmonies in various temperaments, including 19-TET, 31-TET, and adaptive Just Intonation, and subjected their audio renderings to rigorous spectral analysis. Key acoustic features, such as psychoacoustic roughness (based on the Plomp-Levelt model), harmonic entropy, and the composite spectral centroid, were calculated for each sonority. These objective metrics were then correlated with perceptual ratings of consonance and stability obtained from listening tests. Our findings indicate that while spectral roughness remains a primary predictor of dissonance, harmonic entropy emerges as a crucial factor in differentiating the affective character of microtonal chords that exhibit similar roughness profiles. The results provide a quantitative framework for composers and theorists to predict the perceptual qualities of microtonal harmonies, moving beyond the limitations of traditional diatonic-based consonance theories and grounding harmonic analysis in signal-based acoustic properties.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectral Analysis of Microtonal Harmony and its Psychoacoustic Correlates

text: We report the experimental realization of entanglement swapping with heralded, non-Gaussian Schrödinger cat states. By engineering a dual-rail continuous-variable Bell-state measurement via photon subtraction and subsequent homodyne detection, we demonstrate the teleportation of Wigner function negativity, a definitive signature of non-classicality, onto a previously uncorrelated mode pair. The resulting state exhibits a fidelity of 0.72 ± 0.04 with an ideal entangled cat state, overcoming the fidelity bounds for classical teleportation protocols. We analyze the system's robustness against decoherence, particularly photon loss, by modeling the evolution using a Kraus operator formalism. Our results establish a critical building block for distributed quantum computing architectures that leverage the enhanced error-correction capabilities inherent in non-Gaussian, continuous-variable entangled states, paving the way for fault-tolerant quantum networks based on Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill (GKP) codes and complex bosonic states.
subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence-Resistant Entanglement Swapping with Heralded Non-Gaussian States

text: We propose a novel experimental protocol to test quantum gravity-induced decoherence models by monitoring the entanglement dynamics of two spatially separated, cryogenically cooled optomechanical resonators. Our framework analyzes modifications to the canonical commutation relations predicted by generalized uncertainty principles. By preparing the resonators in a squeezed, entangled state via a pulsed quantum non-demolition (QND) interaction, we demonstrate that gravitational decoherence channels would induce a measurable decay in the logarithmic negativity at a rate distinguishable from standard environmental noise. The protocol leverages ponderomotive squeezing to operate below the standard quantum limit, enhancing sensitivity to Planck-scale effects. We derive rigorous bounds on the parameters of phenomenological models, such as the Károlyházy and Diósi-Penrose models, suggesting that current-generation optomechanical systems possess the requisite sensitivity to constrain theories of emergent spacetime and fundamental quantum-gravitational fluctuations.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Planck-Scale Physics with Entangled Optomechanical Resonators

text: This work theoretically investigates the stability and non-Abelian braiding statistics of Majorana zero modes (MZMs) in engineered heterostructures comprising a two-dimensional electron gas, a conventional s-wave superconductor, and a patterned ferromagnetic layer. Utilizing a self-consistent Bogoliubov-de Gennes (BdG) formalism, we map the phase diagram and identify a robust topological superconducting phase characterized by a nontrivial Chern number. We demonstrate that the skyrmionic texture in the ferromagnetic layer provides a reconfigurable platform for MZM localization and manipulation. By simulating adiabatic braiding operations through gate-voltage-controlled potential modulation, we explicitly compute the non-Abelian transformation matrices, confirming the expected fusion rules. Our analysis includes the effects of quasiparticle poisoning and non-adiabatic corrections, providing critical insights for the development of fault-tolerant topological quantum computation based on Majorana qubits and their unique exchange statistics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Protection and Braiding Statistics of Majorana Zero Modes in Ferromagnet-Superconductor Heterostructures

text: We present compelling evidence for the breakdown of the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH) in a one-dimensional system of interacting spinless fermions subjected to a quasiperiodic potential, described by the Aubry-André-Harper model. Using large-scale exact diagonalization and time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (tDMRG) simulations, we explore the many-body localization (MBL) transition. Our analysis reveals that in the MBL phase, the eigenstate-to-eigenstate fluctuations of local observables remain large across the entire spectrum, in stark contrast to the ETH prediction. We characterize this phase by a logarithmically slow growth of entanglement entropy following a quantum quench and the persistence of local memory. We further establish a detailed phase diagram in the interaction-disorder plane, demonstrating that the MBL phase persists for finite interaction strengths, thereby providing a robust counterexample to quantum thermalization in a deterministic, non-random system.
subject: Kuantum
title: Violation of the Eigenstate Thermalization Hypothesis in a Quasiperiodic Many-Body Localized System

text: We establish a direct connection between the emergent geometry of Anti-de Sitter (AdS) space and the entanglement structure of a critical quantum system using the Multiscale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (MERA). By interpreting the MERA tensor network as a discrete tessellation of hyperbolic space, we demonstrate that the Ryu-Takayanagi formula for holographic entanglement entropy arises naturally from the network's geometry. Specifically, the minimal bond cuts bisecting the tensor network correspond to the extremal surfaces in the AdS bulk. We extend this formalism to dynamic scenarios, showing that the causal structure of the boundary conformal field theory (CFT) is encoded in the light-cone structure of the MERA. This work reinforces the ER=EPR conjecture by providing a concrete, bottom-up construction where geometric connectivity in the bulk spacetime is directly manufactured from quantum entanglement on the boundary.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Spacetime from Entanglement Renormalization of a Quantum Critical System

text: We demonstrate a robust, high-fidelity two-qubit gate between a nitrogen-vacancy (NV) center electron spin and a proximate ¹³C nuclear spin in diamond, achieving fidelities exceeding 99.5%. Our protocol employs a sequence of shaped microwave and radio-frequency pulses derived from optimal control theory, integrated within a Carr-Purcell-Meiboom-Gill (CPMG) dynamical decoupling sequence. This nested approach simultaneously suppresses both hyperfine coupling to the ¹³N nuclear spin and magnetic field noise from the surrounding spin bath, which are primary sources of decoherence. Gate fidelity is benchmarked using quantum process tomography and randomized benchmarking. The demonstrated universal control over this hybrid spin register, combining the fast manipulation of the electron spin with the long coherence time of the nuclear spin memory, constitutes a significant advancement towards scalable quantum information processing and distributed quantum sensing networks based on solid-state spin defects.
subject: Kuantum
title: High-Fidelity Quantum Logic with Dynamically Decoupled Nitrogen-Vacancy Centers in Diamond

text: We experimentally investigate the interplay between Bell non-locality and Kochen-Specker contextuality in a high-dimensional quantum system encoded in the orbital angular momentum (OAM) of single photons. Utilizing spatial light modulators for projective measurements onto arbitrary OAM superpositions, we test the Collins-Gisin-Linden-Massar-Popescu (CGLMP) inequality for dimensions d=3 and d=5. Our results show a violation of the inequality by more than 10 standard deviations, providing a strong refutation of local-realist models. Furthermore, we construct a state-dependent contextuality witness based on a set of projectors that reveals contextual correlations within the same experimental setup. This unified demonstration shows that for qudits (d>2), non-locality can be viewed as a specific manifestation of a more fundamental quantum contextuality, highlighting the profound structural differences between bipartite qubit and qudit correlations and their implications for device-independent quantum information protocols.
subject: Kuantum
title: Generalized Bell Non-Locality and Contextuality in High-Dimensional Quantum Systems

text: This study experimentally verifies the generalized Jarzynski equality in a non-equilibrium quantum system under feedback control. Our system, a single trapped ¹⁷¹Yb⁺ ion, is subjected to a fluctuating, non-unitary evolution engineered via projective spin measurements and subsequent coherent rotations conditioned on the measurement outcomes. We demonstrate that the information gained from measurements, quantified by the mutual information between the system state and measurement records, can be used to extract work, seemingly violating the second law of thermodynamics. However, by incorporating the information-theoretic cost of erasing the measurement record, as dictated by Landauer's principle, into the thermodynamic balance, we recover a generalized fluctuation theorem. Our results provide a direct experimental confirmation of the intimate connection between quantum thermodynamics and information theory, with profound implications for the design of efficient quantum heat engines and nanoscale devices.
subject: Kuantum
title: Thermodynamics of Information in a Feedback-Controlled Quantum System

text: We present the variational quantum simulation of a frustrated transverse-field Ising model with a non-stoquastic catalyst term, a problem class intractable for classical Quantum Monte Carlo methods. Utilizing a 16-qubit superconducting processor, we implement a hardware-efficient ansatz for the Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) algorithm to determine the ground-state energy landscape. To mitigate device noise and limited coherence times, we employ a suite of error mitigation techniques, including zero-noise extrapolation and symmetry verification. Our results show excellent agreement with exact diagonalization for small system sizes and provide reliable estimates for larger instances where classical computation becomes prohibitive. We analyze the entanglement structure of the prepared ground states and identify signatures of a quantum phase transition. This work demonstrates the capability of near-term intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices to tackle challenging problems in condensed matter physics that exhibit the sign problem.
subject: Kuantum
title: Variational Quantum Simulation of Non-Stoquastic Hamiltonians on a Superconducting Qubit Processor

text: We observe the emergence of quantum Zeno dynamics and Hilbert space fragmentation in a strongly interacting Rydberg atom array. By applying a continuous, spatially inhomogeneous laser drive, we induce a strong effective potential that penalizes transitions between specific many-body states, akin to a continuous projective measurement. This strong driving effectively freezes the system's evolution within disjoint dynamical subspaces, suppressing thermalization. We probe this phenomenon by monitoring the constrained evolution of density-wave initial states, observing persistent oscillations and the non-propagation of local excitations, a hallmark of confinement. Our experimental results are well-described by an effective Hamiltonian derived from a Schrieffer-Wolff transformation. This technique of engineering interactions via strong, continuous driving opens a pathway for realizing novel non-ergodic phases of matter and robustly preparing entangled states through dissipation-free, Zeno-like confinement.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Zeno Dynamics and Subspace Confinement in a Driven Many-Body System

text: We investigate the profound connection between quantum entanglement and spacetime geometry, guided by the ER=EPR conjecture. This study extends the Ryu-Takayanagi formula by exploring the geometric dual of the entanglement of purification for mixed states in a conformal field theory (CFT). We construct an explicit tensor network model that simulates the dynamics of a traversable wormhole, demonstrating that the teleportation protocol is equivalent to specific manipulations of the bulk entanglement structure. Our analysis reveals that the causal architecture of the emergent bulk spacetime is constrained by the CFT's quantum error-correcting code properties. By calculating the out-of-time-order correlators (OTOCs) in our model, we show that information scrambling on the boundary is directly related to the gravitational redshift and causal horizons within the bulk. This work provides a concrete computational framework where bulk geometric objects are manifestly constructed from the entanglement patterns of a non-gravitational quantum system.
subject: Fizik
title: Geometric Duality and Entanglement Wormholes in AdS/CFT

text: The cosmological constant problem represents a fundamental tension between quantum field theory and general relativity. We propose a novel solution based on a non-local modification to the Einstein-Hilbert action, introducing terms that depend on the inverse d'Alembertian operator. This formulation dynamically sequesters all vacuum energy contributions, including those from matter-sector phase transitions, from the gravitational field equations. The mechanism relies on global integral constraints that enforce a decoupling of the effective cosmological constant from quantum loop corrections. We demonstrate that this non-local theory is classically stable, free of ghosts, and reduces to standard General Relativity on smaller astrophysical scales. Cosmological perturbation analysis shows that the model is consistent with Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) anisotropies and late-time accelerated expansion, offering a dynamically arising dark energy component without requiring extreme fine-tuning of fundamental parameters.
subject: Fizik
title: A Sequestering Mechanism for Vacuum Energy via Non-Local Gravitational Action

text: The mechanism of high-temperature superconductivity in cuprates remains elusive, particularly in the overdoped regime. We present a theoretical model where the pairing interaction is mediated by a strongly coupled, hybrid phononic-plasmonic mode. Using a non-perturbative Eliashberg formalism, we analyze the electron-boson spectral function, incorporating the dynamical screening of electron-phonon interactions by low-energy charge plasmons associated with a proximate charge-density-wave instability. Our calculations show that this hybrid boson creates a strong pairing potential that peaks at a finite momentum transfer, naturally favoring a d-wave superconducting gap symmetry. The model successfully reproduces the non-monotonic dependence of the critical temperature (Tc) on doping, the anomalous isotope effect, and the characteristic kink in the electronic dispersion observed in angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) experiments, providing a unified explanation for several key phenomena in overdoped cuprates.
subject: Fizik
title: Coupled Phonon-Plasmon Dynamics as a Pairing Glue in Overdoped Cuprates

text: We address the black hole information paradox by modeling the encoding of bulk quantum fields into Hawking radiation as a non-isometric quantum error-correcting code. Departing from the perfect isometry assumed in simple AdS/CFT toy models, we propose that the mapping from the black hole interior to the early radiation subsystem is inherently imperfect, with a code subspace that degrades over time. Information is not lost but becomes encoded in highly complex, non-local correlations between emitted quanta. We demonstrate that this state-dependent, approximate error correction naturally reproduces the Page curve for entanglement entropy without requiring firewalls or non-local interactions at the event horizon. The transition at the Page time corresponds to the point where the code's distance becomes too small to protect a typical interior operator. This framework suggests that the unitarity of black hole evaporation is compatible with semi-classical gravity, provided the quantum code structure is sufficiently complex.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Isometric Holographic Codes and the Retrieval of Black Hole Information

text: We present a novel analysis searching for sub-GeV dark matter via the Migdal effect, utilizing data from a cryogenic germanium detector. By exploiting the inherent anisotropy of the electron emission probability relative to the scattered nucleus's recoil direction, our method provides enhanced discrimination against isotropic electron-recoil backgrounds. A profile likelihood analysis of ionization signals between 100 eV and 2 keV reveals a statistically significant directional modulation (4.1σ) correlated with the Earth's galactic motion. This signal is consistent with an inelastic scattering interaction from a dark matter particle with a mass of approximately 500 MeV/c², potentially through a dark photon mediator. We meticulously characterize and subtract backgrounds from Compton scattering and surface alpha decays using a detailed GEANT4 simulation. These findings challenge conventional null results and demonstrate the power of anisotropic signatures in extending the reach of direct detection experiments to the low-mass frontier.
subject: Fizik
title: Anisotropic Migdal Scattering in Germanium Detectors as a Probe for Sub-GeV Dark Matter

text: Topological quantum computation promises fault tolerance by encoding information in the non-local properties of anyonic excitations. We theoretically investigate the realization and manipulation of Fibonacci anyons—a universal platform for quantum computing—in the ν=12/5 fractional quantum Hall (FQH) state achievable in bilayer graphene. Using density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) simulations on a cylinder geometry, we design a realistic interferometric protocol to perform braiding operations. We explicitly compute the non-Abelian braiding statistics by simulating the Berry phase accumulated during the exchange of quasiparticles. Our analysis incorporates the effects of realistic decoherence sources, including charge noise and non-adiabatic errors, finding that high-fidelity braiding (F > 0.999) is feasible within current experimental parameters. This work provides a concrete blueprint for constructing topologically protected quantum gates, demonstrating the viability of graphene-based FQH systems for fault-tolerant quantum information processing.
subject: Fizik
title: Coherent Braiding of Fibonacci Anyons in a Graphene-Based Fractional Quantum Hall System

text: We derive a generalized fluctuation-dissipation theorem (FDT) for non-equilibrium steady states characterized by broken time-reversal symmetry, focusing on active chiral fluids. By separating the microscopic dynamics into dissipative and non-dissipative (active) components, we establish a relationship between the linear response function of an observable and two distinct correlation functions: a standard symmetric correlator related to an effective temperature, and an antisymmetric correlator proportional to the local entropy production rate. This extended FDT reveals that the system's response is governed not only by thermal-like fluctuations but also by the degree of time-irreversibility induced by the active chiral torques. We validate our theoretical framework with numerical simulations of self-propelled particles with rotational activity, providing a powerful tool for probing the fundamental physics of driven systems far from thermal equilibrium and linking macroscopic response to microscopic dissipation.
subject: Fizik
title: Generalized Fluctuation-Dissipation Theorems in Active Chiral Matter

text: We explore the proposition that spacetime is an emergent property of quantum entanglement. A pre-geometric toy model is constructed based on a graph of entangled qubits, whose connectivity is dynamically determined by a Hamiltonian that favors minimal entanglement entropy across any bipartition, an information-theoretic analogue of a minimal surface principle. Using a tensor network representation, we demonstrate that small perturbations to the ground state's entanglement structure manifest as local deformations of the graph geometry. In the continuum limit, the effective dynamics of these deformations are shown to obey a linearized version of the Einstein field equations, where the Ricci tensor is proportional to the local entanglement density. This 'it from qubit' model provides a concrete realization of emergent gravity, where the gravitational field is not a fundamental entity but an effective description of the underlying quantum information geometry, explicitly linking the Ryu-Takayanagi formula to the system's fundamental dynamics.
subject: Fizik
title: Spacetime Curvature from Entanglement in a Pre-Geometric Holographic Model

text: The merger of binary neutron stars can produce hypermassive neutron star (HMNS) remnants, potent sources of gravitational waves and electromagnetic signals. We present high-resolution general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic (GRMHD) simulations that demonstrate extremely rapid magnetic field amplification in the HMNS interior. Differential rotation in the post-merger remnant drives a powerful turbulent dynamo, seeded by the magnetorotational and Kelvin-Helmholtz instabilities. Within 15 milliseconds, the initial seed field (10¹² G) is amplified by over four orders of magnitude, reaching a dynamically significant, saturated state with field strengths exceeding 10¹⁶ G. This process creates a large-scale, ordered poloidal field structure capable of launching a relativistic, Poynting-flux-dominated jet upon the eventual collapse of the HMNS to a black hole. Our results provide a robust mechanism for the central engines of short gamma-ray bursts and suggest that neutron star mergers are a primary formation channel for magnetars.
subject: Fizik
title: Turbulent Dynamo and Magnetar-Level Field Amplification in Post-Merger Hypermassive Neutron Stars

text: The transition between the ergodic and many-body localized (MBL) phases is a central, unresolved problem in quantum statistical mechanics. We challenge the standard picture of a sharp, energy-resolved mobility edge by investigating the eigenstate properties of a disordered one-dimensional Heisenberg spin chain using large-scale exact diagonalization and a time-dependent variational principle. Our finite-size scaling analysis of the participation entropy and the multifractal spectrum of eigenstates reveals an extended, non-ergodic critical region rather than a sharp transition. The multifractal dimension, Dq, exhibits a continuous, non-trivial dependence on the energy density across the entire MBL crossover, which is inconsistent with a simple ergodic-MBL dichotomy. These results suggest that the transition is governed by quantum Griffiths-like effects, where rare ergodic regions dominate thermalization dynamics, fundamentally altering the critical phenomenology and calling for a revised theoretical framework beyond current models.
subject: Fizik
title: Anomalous Multifractality and the Absence of a Sharp Mobility Edge in the Many-Body Localization Transition

text: The ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling complex EP400 plays a pivotal role in transcriptional regulation by catalyzing the exchange of histone H2A.Z for canonical H2A. We present the cryo-electron microscopy (Cryo-EM) structure of the human 650 kDa TRRAP-EP400 core subcomplex at 3.1 Å resolution. The structure reveals an intricate dodecameric assembly, where the TRRAP pseudokinase domain forms a central scaffold coordinating multiple EP400 subunits, including the Swi2/Snf2-family ATPase motor and the HSA domain. Our structural analysis identifies a previously uncharacterized actin-related protein module, ARP5-ARP6, which projects from the core and likely mediates nucleosome recognition. Importantly, we observe the ATPase domain in an ADP-bound, pre-hydrolysis state, providing mechanistic insights into the conformational changes that drive histone eviction. Functional assays using structure-guided mutagenesis confirm that disruption of the TRRAP-HSA interface abrogates H2A.Z deposition in vivo. This work elucidates the architectural principles governing a major class of chromatin remodelers and provides a framework for understanding their dysregulation in cancer.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Human TRRAP-EP400 Complex Reveals a Dodecameric Scaffold for Histone Variant Exchange

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are critical regulators of gene expression, often acting as molecular scaffolds. Here, we investigate the interaction between the lncRNA MALAT1 and the proto-oncogenic splicing factor SRSF1. Using a combination of chemical crosslinking, mass spectrometry (CLIP-MS), and NMR spectroscopy, we identify a highly conserved stem-loop structure within MALAT1 that functions as a high-affinity binding platform for the RNA recognition motifs (RRMs) of SRSF1. We demonstrate that this interaction sequesters SRSF1 within nuclear speckles, thereby modulating its phosphorylation state and availability for pre-mRNA splicing. Ribo-seq analysis following MALAT1 depletion reveals global shifts in alternative splicing, particularly affecting exons regulated by SRSF1. Our data show that MALAT1 acts as a dynamic repository for SRSF1, titrating its activity to fine-tune the cellular splicing landscape. This reveals a sophisticated mechanism of post-transcriptional control mediated by lncRNA architecture, with profound implications for oncogenesis driven by splicing dysregulation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Mechanistic Dissection of lncRNA MALAT1-Mediated Regulation of Splicing Factor Serine/Arginine-Rich Splicing Factor 1 (SRSF1)

text: The Mre11-Rad50-Nbs1 (MRN) complex is a central sensor and processor of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs). Its dynamic architecture is critical for activating the ATM kinase and initiating end resection. We employed single-molecule Förster resonance energy transfer (smFRET) to directly visualize the conformational dynamics of human MRN upon binding to DNA substrates mimicking DSBs. Our results reveal that in its apo state, the Rad50 coiled-coils are highly flexible. Upon ATP binding, Rad50 undergoes a zinc-hook-dependent dimerization, clamping the complex into a rigid, closed conformation. Subsequent engagement with DNA triggers ATP hydrolysis and a large-scale opening of the Rad50 arms, a state stabilized by the C-terminus of Nbs1. This open conformation is essential for the processive 3'-5' exonuclease activity of Mre11. These findings provide a real-time, molecular-level movie of the MRN catalytic cycle, linking ATP-driven conformational switching to the sequential steps of DSB processing and signaling.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Single-Molecule FRET Reveals Conformational Dynamics of the Mre11-Rad50-Nbs1 Complex During DNA Double-Strand Break Resection

text: Programmable epigenetic editing offers a powerful tool for dissecting gene regulatory networks and potential therapeutic applications. Here, we engineered a novel tripartite fusion protein consisting of a nuclease-dead Cas9 (dCas9), a Krüppel-associated box (KRAB) domain, and the methyl-CpG-binding protein 2 (MeCP2). We demonstrate that targeting this dCas9-KRAB-MeCP2 editor to promoter or enhancer regions induces robust and heritable transcriptional silencing. Chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) reveals that the editor establishes a stable repressive chromatin state, characterized by the deposition of H3K9me3 and H3K27me3 marks, DNA methylation, and recruitment of heterochromatin protein 1α (HP1α). Unlike transient repression by dCas9-KRAB, this silencing persists through multiple cell divisions even after cessation of editor expression. Applying this system to key developmental transcription factors, we achieved directed differentiation of embryonic stem cells, highlighting its utility for precise, long-term manipulation of cellular identity through engineered heterochromatin domains.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Targeted Epigenetic Silencing via dCas9-KRAB-MeCP2 Fusion Induces Stable Heterochromatin Formation and Lineage-Specific Gene Repression

text: Transcription factors often function within biomolecular condensates formed through liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS), but the link between phase separation and cell-type-specific gene expression remains unclear. We show that the B-cell master regulator PAX5 undergoes LLPS in vitro and in vivo. The process is driven by multivalent interactions mediated by its intrinsically disordered regions and is regulated by phosphorylation. Using super-resolution microscopy, we observed PAX5 condensates colocalizing with RNA Polymerase II and BRD4 at super-enhancers critical for B-cell identity. Perturbing PAX5 phase separation through mutagenesis of key residues in its disordered domains disrupts condensate formation, diminishes super-enhancer activity, and leads to a loss of B-cell-specific gene expression and aberrant differentiation. Our results indicate that PAX5-mediated LLPS functions as a physical mechanism to concentrate the transcriptional machinery at key regulatory loci, thereby establishing and maintaining a robust cell-type-specific gene expression program.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phase Separation of the Transcription Factor PAX5 Organizes B-Cell Identity by Forming Condensates at Super-Enhancers

text: The epitranscriptomic mark N6-methyladenosine (m6A) is primarily known for its roles in post-transcriptional RNA fate. We uncovered a novel function for m6A in co-transcriptional gene regulation. Using native elongating transcript sequencing (NET-seq) combined with m6A mapping, we found that m6A is deposited on nascent pre-mRNAs near polyadenylation sites. We demonstrate that the m6A reader protein YTHDC1 directly interacts with the Integrator complex, a key factor in the termination of non-coding RNA transcription. Depletion of the m6A methyltransferase METTL3 or YTHDC1 resulted in widespread transcriptional read-through at protein-coding genes and premature termination at long non-coding RNA loci. Our findings reveal that co-transcriptional m6A deposition serves as a molecular beacon for YTHDC1-mediated recruitment of the Integrator complex, which facilitates efficient transcription termination and 3'-end processing. This work establishes a direct link between RNA modification and the core transcriptional machinery, adding a new layer of regulatory complexity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: N6-methyladenosine (m6A) on Nascent Transcripts Recruits the Integrator Complex to Regulate Transcriptional Termination

text: Mitochondrial quality control is essential for cellular homeostasis, with mitophagy being a primary clearance pathway for damaged mitochondria. While the PINK1/Parkin pathway is a major mitophagy driver, alternative mechanisms exist. We identified the F-box protein FBXL17 as a novel E3 ubiquitin ligase that orchestrates PINK1-independent mitophagy. Upon mitochondrial depolarization, FBXL17 is recruited to the outer mitochondrial membrane via a direct, phosphorylation-independent interaction with the receptor TOM70. FBXL17 then mediates K63-linked ubiquitination of mitochondrial surface proteins, creating a scaffold for autophagy receptors such as NDP52 and Optineurin, thereby tagging the entire organelle for lysosomal degradation. Depletion of FBXL17 impairs clearance of damaged mitochondria in Parkin-deficient cells and sensitizes them to stress. This study elucidates a parallel mitophagy pathway that complements the canonical PINK1/Parkin system, providing new insights into the robustness and versatility of mitochondrial quality control mechanisms.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Novel Ubiquitin Ligase, FBXL17, Mediates PINK1-Independent Mitophagy through Direct Recognition of TOM70

text: The integrated stress response (ISR) enables cells to adapt to proteotoxic stress by globally repressing protein synthesis while selectively translating stress-related mRNAs. The molecular determinants of this selectivity are incompletely understood. We performed simultaneous ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) and quantitative mass spectrometry on cells undergoing endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress. Our integrated analysis revealed hundreds of mRNAs that escape global translational repression. We demonstrate that this escape is predominantly mediated by upstream open reading frames (uORFs) in the 5' untranslated regions. Under stress, phosphorylated eIF2α levels increase, promoting ribosome bypass of inhibitory uORFs and re-initiation at the main coding sequence. Using CRISPR-mediated uORF mutagenesis, we validate this mechanism for key ISR effectors like ATF4 and GADD34. Our genome-wide data provide a comprehensive catalog of uORF-mediated translational control and establish a general principle for how cells reprogram their translatome to mount an effective stress response.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrative Ribosome Profiling and Proteomics Reveal Widespread Translational Control by uORFs During Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress

text: Telomere integrity is maintained by telomerase, a reverse transcriptase that extends the G-rich 3' overhang. While G-quadruplexes (G4s) on the G-rich strand are known telomerase inhibitors, the role of secondary structures on the complementary C-rich strand remains obscure. Here, we demonstrate using NMR spectroscopy and circular dichroism that the human telomeric C-rich strand folds into intramolecular i-motif structures under physiologically relevant acidic pH conditions, such as those found in the tumor microenvironment. Using a reconstituted in vitro telomerase extension assay, we show that i-motif formation on the template strand potently inhibits telomerase processivity. We further identify the helicase DHX36 as a specific i-motif resolvase that promotes telomerase function. Depletion of DHX36 in cancer cells leads to telomere shortening and sensitizes them to G4-stabilizing agents. Our findings reveal the i-motif as a new regulatory element in telomere biology, creating a dynamic structural equilibrium that fine-tunes telomerase access and activity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: G-Quadruplex Structures in Telomeric C-Rich Strands Form i-Motifs that Regulate Telomerase Activity

text: The maturation of Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand requires the coordinated action of several enzymes to produce an intact DNA duplex. The final sealing of the phosphodiester backbone is catalyzed by DNA Ligase I (LIG1). We determined the cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of human LIG1 in complex with the PCNA clamp and a nicked DNA substrate at 2.9 Å resolution. The structure captures LIG1 in a catalytically competent state, encircling the DNA nick. The PCNA-interacting peptide (PIP) box of LIG1 anchors it to the front face of the PCNA ring, while a secondary non-canonical interaction site provides topological stability. This dual interaction orients the LIG1 catalytic core optimally over the nick. Our structure reveals how LIG1 distorts the DNA backbone, positioning the 5'-phosphate and 3'-hydroxyl groups for nucleophilic attack. These findings provide a detailed molecular blueprint for the final step of DNA replication and repair, explaining how PCNA orchestrates enzymatic succession.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural Basis for Okazaki Fragment Ligation by the Human DNA Ligase I-PCNA-DNA Complex

text: Cryptic speciation challenges our understanding of biodiversity, particularly in marine environments where morphological stasis is common. We investigated the genomic architecture of divergence in the copepod Eurytemora affinis across a brackish water salinity gradient. Using whole-genome resequencing from multiple populations, we identified a pattern of high background gene flow punctuated by discrete genomic islands of exceptional differentiation (high Fst). These islands disproportionately harbor genes related to osmoregulation and ion transport, implicating divergent ecological selection as the primary driver of reproductive isolation. Coalescent modeling supports a scenario of allopatric divergence followed by secondary contact, with evidence for reinforcement in sympatric zones. Our findings demonstrate that substantial genomic divergence and incipient speciation can occur despite high connectivity, highlighting the power of ecological selection to overcome gene flow and initiate the formation of species boundaries in the absence of overt morphological change.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Incipient Speciation in a Marine Copepod Metapopulation

text: The role of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) in eukaryotic evolution remains contentious, often considered a minor process compared to vertical inheritance. Through a comprehensive phylogenomic analysis of 30 deeply-branching microbial eukaryote lineages, we reveal a pattern of pervasive and ancient HGT from both Bacteria and Archaea. Our stringent pipeline, controlling for contamination and phylogenetic artifacts, identified thousands of high-confidence xenologous gene families integrated into host genomes. These acquired genes are non-randomly distributed, showing significant enrichment for metabolic functions, particularly anaerobic respiration and carbohydrate metabolism, suggesting HGT as a key mechanism for metabolic innovation and niche expansion. The functional integration of these xenologs into core eukaryotic pathways challenges the paradigm of a purely bifurcating Tree of Life and indicates that the genomes of early eukaryotes were highly dynamic, mosaic entities shaped significantly by inter-domain genetic exchange.
subject: Evrim
title: Pervasive Xenologous Gene Acquisition and Functional Integration in Early-Diverging Eukaryotes

text: Adaptive radiations exemplify the rapid coupling of ecological opportunity and phenotypic evolution. We explored the molecular basis of craniofacial diversification in a recent radiation of Central American cichlid fishes. Integrating geometric morphometrics with comparative transcriptomics of developing pharyngeal jaws, we demonstrate that divergence in jaw morphology is tightly correlated with differential expression of key developmental regulatory genes, including bmp4, eda, and members of the Wnt signaling pathway. Phylogenetic comparative methods reveal that the rate of transcriptomic evolution in these specific loci significantly exceeds neutral expectations and predicts the magnitude of morphological disparity. Our results provide strong evidence that cis-regulatory modifications, rather than changes in protein-coding sequences, constitute the primary molecular substrate for rapid, repeated, and parallel eco-morphological diversification, allowing lineages to efficiently explore novel regions of morphospace in response to ecological pressures.
subject: Evrim
title: Eco-Morphological Diversification Mediated by Regulatory Evolution in Neotropical Cichlids

text: Antagonistic coevolution between hosts and parasites is a powerful engine of biodiversity, often characterized by a molecular 'arms race'. We tracked this dynamic in real-time using time-serial population genomics of the wild flax Linum marginale and its fungal pathogen Melampsora lini. Our analysis reveals recurrent selective sweeps at plant resistance (R) loci, followed by counter-adaptive sweeps at corresponding avirulence (Avr) effector loci in the pathogen. Crucially, we show that these dynamics maintain high levels of polymorphism at both R and Avr loci across the metapopulation, consistent with the predictions of negative frequency-dependent selection, where rare alleles confer a transient fitness advantage. This coevolutionary chase, governed by reciprocal selection pressures, not only drives rapid molecular evolution but also acts as a potent mechanism for the long-term maintenance of genetic variation underlying disease resistance within natural populations.
subject: Evrim
title: Molecular Arms-Race Dynamics and Negative Frequency-Dependent Selection in a Plant-Pathogen System

text: The evolution of senescence remains a central puzzle in life-history theory. We test the long-standing antagonistic pleiotropy (AP) hypothesis using a combination of experimental evolution and population genomics in thousands of Drosophila melanogaster individuals. A genome-wide association study (GWAS) for lifetime reproductive success and longevity identified numerous quantitative trait loci (QTLs) with pleiotropic effects. We found a significant enrichment of loci where alleles conferring higher early-life fecundity were strongly correlated with accelerated late-life mortality and functional decline. These AP loci are disproportionately located in conserved metabolic signaling pathways, such as insulin/IGF-1 and TOR signaling, implicating energy allocation as the core physiological mediator. Our results provide robust genomic evidence that senescence evolves not as a direct adaptation but as a non-adaptive byproduct of strong positive selection on early-life reproductive fitness, constrained by fundamental metabolic trade-offs.
subject: Evrim
title: The Evolutionary Genomics of Senescence: Disentangling Antagonistic Pleiotropy and Locus-Specific Life-History Trade-offs

text: Reconstructing ancestral proteins offers a powerful method to directly observe the molecular mechanisms of evolutionary innovation. We investigated the origin of steroid hormone specificity by resurrecting the ancestral corticoid receptor (AncCR) from before the gene duplication event that gave rise to modern glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid receptors. Using phylogenetic ancestral sequence reconstruction, we synthesized AncCR and characterized its biophysical properties. In contrast to its specialized descendants, AncCR exhibited significant promiscuity, responding potently to both aldosterone and cortisol. Mutational analyses revealed that the evolution of glucocorticoid specificity was contingent upon a small number of key amino acid substitutions that were only effective within the permissive epistatic context of the ancestral protein scaffold. These findings illustrate how historical contingency and intramolecular epistasis constrain evolutionary trajectories, channeling functional divergence along specific, otherwise inaccessible, mutational pathways following gene duplication.
subject: Evrim
title: Resurrection and Biophysical Characterization of an Ancestral Glucocorticoid Receptor Reveals Epistatic Constraints on Hormone Specificity

text: The evolution of non-reproductive worker castes in eusocial insects represents a major evolutionary transition driven by kin selection. To elucidate the molecular architecture underlying this division of labor, we performed deep transcriptomic and whole-genome bisulfite sequencing on queen, worker, and soldier castes of the ant Pheidole morrisi. We identified thousands of differentially expressed genes, revealing a profound reprogramming of metabolic, neurogenic, and reproductive pathways between castes from a shared genomic background. Critically, we discovered extensive caste-specific DNA methylation patterns, particularly in promoter regions of key developmental genes and transcription factors. These differentially methylated regions (DMRs) are strongly predictive of gene expression levels, suggesting that epigenetic modifications, rather than genetic sequence, are the primary proximate mechanism for establishing and maintaining caste identity. This highlights a molecular pathway through which inclusive fitness can be realized via developmental plasticity.
subject: Evrim
title: Transcriptomic Basis of Caste Polymorphism and the Role of Epigenetic Regulation in Eusocial Hymenoptera

text: Whole-genome duplication (WGD) is a transformative event providing vast raw material for evolutionary innovation. We analyzed the long-term fate of duplicate genes (ohnologs) stemming from the teleost-specific WGD (3R) event approximately 350 million years ago, using a comparative genomic framework across 15 fish species. Synteny-based analysis revealed that nearly 20% of ohnolog pairs have been retained since the 3R event, a rate far exceeding neutral expectation. By analyzing tissue-specific expression atlases, we demonstrate that the predominant mode of retention is subfunctionalization, with ancestral expression profiles partitioned between the two duplicates. However, a functionally crucial subset of ohnologs, enriched for transcription factors and developmental genes, shows clear evidence of neofunctionalization, with one copy acquiring novel expression domains and accelerated protein sequence evolution. This dual-mode retention pattern illustrates how WGD facilitates both the preservation of ancestral functions and the evolution of novel complexities.
subject: Evrim
title: Subfunctionalization and Neofunctionalization Dynamics Following the Teleost-Specific Whole-Genome Duplication

text: The relative importance of deterministic adaptation versus stochastic processes in shaping macroevolutionary patterns remains a fundamental debate. We challenge the prevailing adaptationist viewpoint by analyzing a massive dataset of 50 morphological traits across a time-calibrated superphylogeny of 6,000 avian species. Using Bayesian model-fitting approaches, we found that for a majority of traits, models of neutral evolution, such as Brownian motion or phylogenetic drift, provided a significantly better fit than adaptive models incorporating selective optima (e.g., Ornstein-Uhlenbeck). Rates of trait evolution were largely decoupled from rates of lineage diversification, contrary to the predictions of adaptive radiation theory. Our results suggest that many large-scale patterns of phenotypic diversity are not the product of fine-tuned adaptation to specific ecological niches, but rather the cumulative outcome of stochastic, non-adaptive processes operating over vast geological timescales.
subject: Evrim
title: Stochastic Processes and Phylogenetic Drift Dominate Macroevolutionary Patterns of Trait Diversification

text: Sexual conflict, where the reproductive interests of males and females diverge, can fuel rapid, antagonistic coevolution. We investigated the molecular signatures of this conflict by examining the evolutionary rates of seminal fluid proteins (SFPs) and female reproductive tract proteins in the Drosophila melanogaster species complex. Using population-genomic data, we found that SFP genes exhibit some of the highest rates of positive Darwinian selection in the entire genome, with recurrent selective sweeps and elevated dN/dS ratios. This rapid evolution in male manipulative proteins is mirrored by accelerated evolution in a corresponding set of female-expressed proteins involved in sperm storage and remating behavior. This tit-for-tat dynamic, where adaptive changes in one sex impose selective pressures on the other, provides strong quantitative evidence for interlocus sexual conflict as a potent and relentless engine of molecular evolution and speciation.
subject: Evrim
title: Accelerated Evolution of Seminal Fluid Proteins Driven by Interlocus Sexual Conflict in Drosophila

text: We present a comprehensive theoretical investigation into the quantum dynamics of a central spin system coupled to a bosonic reservoir with a structured spectral density, focusing on non-Markovian effects and entanglement preservation. Utilizing a numerically exact path integral approach, specifically the hierarchical equations of motion (HEOM), we simulate the time evolution of the system's reduced density matrix beyond the weak-coupling and Born-Markov approximations. Our model incorporates a Lorentzian spectral density, characteristic of a damped harmonic oscillator or a photonic cavity mode. We demonstrate that reservoir memory effects induce significant revivals of quantum coherence and transient entanglement trapping, phenomena absent in standard Markovian treatments. The transition from Markovian to non-Markovian dynamics is characterized by analyzing the quantum information backflow, quantified by the Breuer-Laine-Piilo (BLP) measure. Our results reveal a complex interplay between the reservoir's correlation time, the system-reservoir coupling strength, and the non-monotonic decay of quantum correlations, offering critical insights for designing robust quantum information protocols in structured environments.
subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence and Entanglement Dynamics in a Non-Markovian Spin-Boson System Coupled to a Structured Reservoir

text: We report the experimental observation of many-body localization (MBL) in a one-dimensional chain of 18 interacting superconducting transmon qubits with programmable, quasi-periodic disorder. By initializing the system in a non-equilibrium state, specifically a charge-density wave, we monitor its subsequent unitary evolution. We measure the participation entropy and the imbalance between even and odd qubit sites as a function of time and disorder strength. For weak disorder, the system rapidly thermalizes, leading to entropy growth and decay of the initial imbalance, consistent with the ergodic hypothesis. Above a critical disorder threshold, we observe a dramatic suppression of transport and a persistent memory of the initial state, characterized by a saturation of the imbalance at a non-zero value and a logarithmic growth of entanglement entropy. These signatures provide strong, direct evidence for a phase transition from an ergodic to an MBL phase, demonstrating a breakdown of thermalization in an isolated, interacting quantum system and opening avenues for protecting quantum information from decoherence.
subject: Kuantum
title: Observation of Many-Body Localization in a Disordered Array of Superconducting Transmon Qubits

text: We theoretically and experimentally investigate the thermodynamics of a quantum feedback-control system realizing a Maxwell's demon. Our system consists of a single electron spin in a nitrogen-vacancy center in diamond, manipulated by microwave pulses and monitored via spin-dependent photoluminescence. We perform a projective quantum non-demolition (QND) measurement on the spin, acquiring information that is then used in a feedback loop to apply a conditional spin-flip operation, effectively extracting work from a thermal bath. By meticulously tracking the state evolution and energy exchanges, we verify the Jarzynski equality and a quantum generalization of the Sagawa-Ueda fluctuation theorem, which incorporates informational entropy into the second law of thermodynamics. Our results explicitly demonstrate that the apparent violation of the second law is resolved by the thermodynamic cost of information processing, providing a rigorous experimental validation of the fundamental link between information theory and quantum thermodynamics in a non-equilibrium, nanoscale system.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Fluctuation Theorems and the Thermodynamics of Information in a Maxwell's Demon Feedback-Control System
