text: The realization of non-Abelian statistics is a cornerstone for topological quantum computation. Here, we present experimental evidence for the braiding of non-Abelian anyons in the ν=5/2 fractional quantum Hall (FQH) state. We fabricated a Fabry-Pérot interferometer in a high-mobility GaAs/AlGaAs two-dimensional electron gas. Quasiparticles, presumed to be Ising anyons with charge e/4, are injected and guided to interfere after encircling a central island populated by a controlled number of localized quasiparticles. By measuring the transmission phase of the interferometer as a function of magnetic field and gate voltage, we observe discrete phase slips of π, in stark contrast to the 2π slips expected for Abelian statistics. This result is consistent with the non-trivial fusion rules and braiding phase of Majorana zero modes, predicted for the Pfaffian or anti-Pfaffian wavefunction descriptions of the 5/2 state. This demonstration of non-Abelian braiding provides a critical component for the construction of topologically protected qubits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Braiding Non-Abelian Anyons in a ν=5/2 Fractional Quantum Hall Interferometer

text: We report on a search for axion-like particles (ALPs) as dark matter candidates by utilizing a quantum-enhanced microwave cavity haloscope. The experiment searches for the resonant conversion of ALPs into photons in the presence of a strong 10 T magnetic field. To surpass the standard quantum limit (SQL) imposed by vacuum fluctuations, we inject a frequency-tunable squeezed vacuum state into the cavity's readout port. The resulting noise reduction in one quadrature of the electromagnetic field allows for an enhanced signal-to-noise ratio for the putative axion-induced photon signal. Operating the experiment at a temperature of 100 mK, we scanned a frequency range of 4.50-4.52 GHz. No statistically significant signal was detected, allowing us to set new, world-leading exclusion limits on the ALP-photon coupling constant, g_{aγγ}, improving upon previous SQL-limited searches in this mass range by a factor of 2.1. This work demonstrates the power of quantum metrology techniques to accelerate the search for new fundamental physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Axion-like Particle Electrodynamics with a Squeezed-State-Enhanced Resonant Cavity Haloscope

text: We investigate a large-N matrix model defined by a specific SU(N) gauge theory with bosonic matrices and a quartic potential, demonstrating the emergence of a two-dimensional spacetime geometry in the 't Hooft limit. By employing Monte Carlo simulations on the Euclidean lattice formulation of the model, we show that the eigenvalue distribution of the matrices dynamically generates a continuous manifold. The emergent geometry exhibits features of a two-dimensional black hole, including an event horizon and a singularity, whose properties are determined by the coupling constant of the potential. We compute the thermodynamic properties of this emergent black hole by analyzing the free energy of the matrix model. The calculated entropy scales with the area of the emergent horizon, satisfying a Bekenstein-Hawking-like relation. This non-perturbative result provides compelling evidence for the holographic principle in a simplified, analytically tractable model, suggesting that spacetime and its gravitational dynamics can emerge from fundamental quantum degrees of freedom.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergent Spacetime and Black Hole Thermodynamics from a Matrix Model with a Quartic Potential

text: We present a high-precision study of the chiral anomaly's effects on the thermodynamic and transport properties of the quark-gluon plasma (QGP) using first-principles lattice Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) simulations. Our calculations were performed on anisotropic lattices with 2+1 flavors of stout-smeared Wilson fermions, allowing for a detailed investigation of real-time phenomena. We compute the topological susceptibility χ_t at finite temperature, observing its suppression above the chiral crossover temperature T_c, which signals the restoration of the U_A(1) symmetry. Furthermore, by calculating the spectral function of the axial-vector current correlation, we extract the chiral magnetic conductivity—a key transport coefficient governing the Chiral Magnetic Effect (CME). Our non-perturbative results show a non-trivial temperature dependence of this conductivity, providing quantitative predictions for experimental searches for the CME in heavy-ion collisions at RHIC and the LHC. These findings offer crucial insights into the interplay between chiral symmetry, topology, and transport phenomena in strongly coupled QCD matter.
subject: Kuantum
title: Chiral Anomaly and the Non-Perturbative Dynamics of the Quark-Gluon Plasma via Lattice QCD Simulations

text: We explore the onset of quantum chaos and the validity of the Eigenstate Thermalization Hypothesis (ETH) in a periodically driven (Floquet) many-body quantum system, specifically the kicked Ising model. By numerically diagonalizing the Floquet unitary operator for finite-sized systems, we analyze the statistical properties of its quasienergy spectrum and eigenstates. We demonstrate a transition from a Poissonian to a Wigner-Dyson level spacing distribution as the driving parameter is varied, a definitive signature of the onset of quantum chaos. In the chaotic regime, we find that the expectation values of local observables in the Floquet eigenstates are smooth functions of the quasienergy, and their fluctuations decay polynomially with system size, in quantitative agreement with ETH predictions. However, we also identify a class of 'scar' states with anomalously low entanglement entropy that weakly violate ETH. These results elucidate the mechanisms of thermalization in isolated quantum systems driven out of equilibrium and highlight the subtle structure of chaotic many-body eigenstates.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Chaos and Eigenstate Thermalization in a Periodically Driven Floquet System

text: Determining the ground state properties of the two-dimensional Hubbard model is a central challenge in condensed matter physics, crucial for understanding high-temperature superconductivity. We employ a state-of-the-art infinite projected entangled-pair state (iPEPS) tensor network algorithm to variationally approximate the ground state of the model on the square lattice at intermediate coupling (U/t = 8) and near optimal hole doping (δ ≈ 0.125). Our simulation, which reaches a bond dimension of D=24, explicitly handles the fermionic sign problem and provides an unbiased description of long-range correlations. We compute the pairing correlation functions and find a clear power-law decay for d_{x^2-y^2}-wave pairing, while other pairing symmetries decay exponentially. The calculated superconducting order parameter exhibits a dome-like structure as a function of doping. The results strongly support the hypothesis that the Hubbard model contains the essential physics of d-wave superconductivity, providing a non-perturbative, numerically controlled benchmark for theories of unconventional superconductivity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Tensor Network Simulation of a d-wave Superconducting Ground State in the 2D Hubbard Model

text: We address the problem of estimating average treatment effects in high-dimensional observational studies where unobserved confounding violates the ignobility assumption. This paper introduces the Proximal Kernel Doubly Robust (PKDR) estimator, a novel semi-parametric method that leverages proxy variables for the latent confounders. The proposed methodology synthesizes proximal causal inference with modern machine learning techniques. We construct nuisance function estimators for the propensity score and outcome models using kernel ridge regression in a reproducing kernel Hilbert space, allowing for complex nonlinear relationships. The core of the PKDR estimator is a debiased moment function, constructed via Neyman-orthogonal scores, which ensures double robustness against misspecification of one of the nuisance models. We establish that our estimator is root-n consistent and asymptotically normal under substantially weaker identification conditions than competing methods. Theoretical results demonstrate semi-parametric efficiency bounds are achieved when both nuisance components are correctly specified. Simulation studies and an application to genomic data analysis confirm the method's superior finite-sample performance and robustness.
subject: İstatistik
title: Proximal Kernel Doubly Robust Estimation for Causal Inference with High-Dimensional Unobserved Confounding

text: This paper presents a Bayesian nonparametric framework for inferring community structure in dynamic, multilayer networks. We introduce the Temporal Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Stochastic Block Model (THDP-SBM), which models the evolution of latent communities over time and their dependencies across network layers. The framework posits that each node possesses a vector of latent community memberships, drawn from a shared, time-evolving Indian Buffet Process prior, which encourages temporal persistence in community assignments. Inter-layer dependencies are captured through a coupled prior structure on the block interaction matrices. For scalable posterior inference, we develop a stochastic variational inference algorithm that leverages natural gradient updates and subsampling, enabling analysis of large-scale network data. Our model obviates the need to pre-specify the number of communities and provides a principled means of tracking community births, deaths, and mergers over time. We demonstrate the model’s efficacy in capturing nuanced temporal dynamics in a multilayer social network and a multi-tissue gene co-expression network.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Community Detection in Multilayer Networks via Temporal Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Stochastic Block Models

text: Classical functional data analysis (FDA) methods often fail to capture complex topological and geometric features inherent in stochastic processes. We propose Persistent Homology Functional Principal Component Analysis (PH-FPCA), a novel method that integrates topological data analysis (TDA) with FDA. For each functional observation, we compute its persistence diagram, which summarizes multiscale topological features (connected components, loops). These diagrams, residing in a non-Euclidean space, are then mapped into a reproducing kernel Hilbert space using a stable persistence scale-space kernel. We subsequently perform functional principal component analysis in this feature space to extract the dominant modes of topological variation. We establish the theoretical consistency of the estimated topological principal components and demonstrate their utility. The PH-FPCA approach offers superior performance in clustering and classification of complex functional data, such as high-frequency financial time series and electroencephalography (EEG) signals, where traditional amplitude-based FPCA is insufficient.
subject: İstatistik
title: Persistent Homology Functional Principal Component Analysis for Topological Feature Extraction in Stochastic Processes

text: Gaussian processes (GPs) provide a principled framework for spatiotemporal modeling but are computationally prohibitive for large datasets, scaling cubically with the number of observations. We introduce a highly scalable and accurate approximation method, Structured Kernel Interpolation Variational Inference (SKIVI). Our approach combines the strengths of sparse and structured GP approximations. We use a set of inducing points to create a low-rank approximation, and crucially, we structure these inducing points on a grid, enabling the use of a Kronecker-structured covariance matrix. This structure permits highly efficient computations via the Fast Fourier Transform, reducing the per-iteration complexity of stochastic variational inference from cubic to quasi-linear. We provide theoretical bounds on the gap between the approximate and true evidence lower bound (ELBO) and demonstrate that SKIVI achieves state-of-the-art predictive performance and computational speed on several benchmark spatiotemporal datasets, outperforming existing sparse and deep GP models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Structured Kernel Interpolation Variational Inference for Large-Scale Spatiotemporal Gaussian Processes

text: We consider the problem of conducting statistical inference on low-dimensional parameters within high-dimensional survival models, such as the Cox proportional hazards model, where the number of covariates p can greatly exceed the sample size n. Standard estimation is often biased due to regularization. This paper develops a general framework for constructing debiased and asymptotically normal estimators for such parameters. The methodology employs Neyman-orthogonal moment functions and cross-fitting to mitigate the impact of regularization bias from estimating infinite-dimensional nuisance parameters (e.g., the conditional hazard function). We use flexible machine learning algorithms, like gradient boosting or neural networks, to estimate these nuisance functions, allowing for complex covariate interactions. The resulting estimator is root-n consistent, asymptotically Gaussian, and semi-parametrically efficient under mild sparsity assumptions. We demonstrate its application to estimating treatment effects and single-covariate coefficients, providing valid confidence intervals and p-values in settings where traditional methods fail.
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Machine Learning for Semi-Parametric Inference in High-Dimensional Survival Analysis

text: We introduce Wasserstein Barycentric Regression (WBR), a novel regression framework for scenarios where the response variable for each observation is a probability distribution. This extends beyond mean, quantile, or functional regression to model the entire conditional distribution as a function of covariates. We formulate the problem within the geometric space of probability measures endowed with the Wasserstein-2 metric. The regression function is defined as a mapping from the covariate space to the Wasserstein space, and the predicted conditional distribution is estimated as the Fréchet mean, or Wasserstein barycenter, of the observed response distributions. We develop a projection-gradient descent algorithm for estimation, leveraging entropic regularization and Sinkhorn iterations for efficient computation of barycenters. We establish the theoretical consistency of the WBR estimator under standard regularity conditions. The methodology is illustrated through an analysis of income distribution dynamics and its application to modeling cell population heterogeneity in cytometry data.
subject: İstatistik
title: Wasserstein Barycentric Regression: A Framework for Modeling Distributional Responses via Optimal Transport

text: The imperative for data privacy presents a fundamental challenge to traditional statistical inference. We develop a general methodology for constructing asymptotically valid confidence intervals and hypothesis tests for parameters defined via M-estimation under the constraint of $(\epsilon, \delta)$-differential privacy. Our approach, termed Differentially Private Debiased Influence Function (DP-DIF), operates by injecting calibrated Gaussian noise into the empirical influence function representation of the M-estimator. A key innovation is a subsequent debiasing step that corrects for the systematic attenuation bias introduced by the privacy mechanism, which is critical for achieving correct frequentist coverage. We derive the asymptotic distribution of our private estimator and provide a formal characterization of the privacy-utility trade-off, quantifying the increase in confidence interval length as a function of the privacy budget \epsilon. The framework is broadly applicable to a wide range of models, including logistic regression and robust location estimation, as demonstrated in our simulations.
subject: İstatistik
title: Asymptotically Valid Frequentist Inference for M-Estimators Under Differential Privacy

text: Standard conformal prediction provides distribution-free, finite-sample uncertainty guarantees but relies critically on the assumption of data exchangeability, which is violated in many settings like time series or clustered data. This paper introduces Conformalized Residual Prediction (CRP), an extension of the conformal framework that provides valid marginal predictive intervals for non-exchangeable data. The key idea is to define a non-conformity score based on the residuals of a conditional predictive model, which accounts for the local dependency structure. For time series, the score is based on one-step-ahead forecast errors from a model conditioned on the recent past. We prove that under mild mixing conditions or for conditionally exchangeable data, the CRP procedure attains valid marginal coverage. This result holds for any underlying predictive algorithm, making it a model-agnostic wrapper for uncertainty quantification. We demonstrate its superior performance over naive conformal methods in time series forecasting and longitudinal data analysis, yielding tighter and more reliable prediction intervals.
subject: İstatistik
title: Conformalized Residual Prediction: Achieving Finite-Sample Predictive Coverage with Dependent Data

text: Causal forests are a powerful non-parametric method for estimating heterogeneous treatment effects, but principled uncertainty quantification remains a challenge, often relying on asymptotic approximations like the infinitesimal jackknife. We propose the Bayesian Causal Forest (BCF), a fully Bayesian analogue that provides robust credible intervals for the Conditional Average Treatment Effect (CATE). The BCF model places a prior distribution over the ensemble of trees, encompassing the splitting rules, tree depth, and leaf-node parameters, building upon the Bayesian Additive Regression Trees (BART) framework. Posterior inference is performed via a tailored Particle Gibbs algorithm that efficiently explores the vast model space. The resulting posterior distribution over the CATE function naturally yields pointwise credible intervals and allows for formal inference on covariate interactions. We establish posterior contraction rates for the CATE estimator under smoothness and sparsity assumptions and show through simulation that BCF provides more reliable coverage and honest uncertainty estimates than existing methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Causal Forests for Credible Inference of Heterogeneous Treatment Effects

text: Multi-way longitudinal data, encompassing measurements across multiple subjects, time points, and modalities, pose significant analytical challenges, particularly with missing data. We propose a Penalized Probabilistic Tensor Factorization (PPTF) model for the simultaneous decomposition and analysis of such complex data structures. Our method models the data tensor with a low-rank CANDECOMP/PARAFAC (CP) decomposition within a probabilistic framework that naturally imputes missing entries. To enhance interpretability and incorporate domain knowledge, we introduce structured penalties on the latent factor matrices. For instance, a fused LASSO penalty on the temporal factor encourages piecewise constant patterns, while an L1 penalty on the modality factor induces sparsity. We derive a scalable variational expectation-maximization algorithm for posterior inference. We provide theoretical guarantees on the recovery of the underlying tensor under noisy and incomplete observations. The utility of PPTF is showcased by its application to a multi-modal neuroimaging study, where it effectively identifies shared and subject-specific trajectories of brain activity.
subject: İstatistik
title: Penalized Probabilistic Tensor Factorization for Analyzing Incomplete Multi-way Longitudinal Data

text: We investigate the conjecture that Einstein-Rosen bridges are equivalent to Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen entanglement (ER=EPR) within the framework of the AdS/CFT correspondence. By modeling the holographic state using a perfect tensor network, we demonstrate how the entanglement structure of the boundary conformal field theory (CFT) state geometrically constructs the bulk anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime. Our analysis focuses on the quantum error-correcting properties inherent in this holographic mapping. We show that logical operators corresponding to bulk observables can be represented by multiple, distinct physical operators on the boundary, a feature known as subregion duality. This operator redundancy provides a concrete realization of bulk locality and its protection from local boundary perturbations. We further utilize the Ryu-Takanayagi formula to calculate entanglement entropy, showing its direct correspondence to the area of minimal surfaces in the bulk, thereby solidifying the link between quantum information-theoretic concepts on the boundary and classical geometric properties in the bulk gravitational theory.
subject: Kuantum
title: Geometric Entanglement and Bulk Reconstruction in the ER=EPR Correspondence

text: We present a comprehensive numerical study of non-Abelian statistics in the ν=12/5 fractional quantum Hall (FQH) state, a prime candidate for hosting Fibonacci anyons. Employing the infinite-density matrix renormalization group (iDMRG) method on a cylindrical geometry, we create and manipulate quasihole excitations. By adiabatically transporting these quasiholes, we simulate braiding operations and compute the resulting Berry matrices, which form a unitary representation of the braid group. Our results explicitly confirm that the braiding statistics are consistent with the Fibonacci model, where the fusion rules and braid matrices satisfy the relations required for universal topological quantum computation. We further analyze the primary decoherence channels, including quasiparticle mislocalization and diabatic transitions to excited states, by introducing localized perturbations. This provides critical estimates for the topological protection gap and informs the physical requirements for constructing fault-tolerant qubits based on the ν=12/5 FQH platform, a significant step towards realizing topologically protected quantum information processing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Braiding Statistics of Fibonacci Anyons in a Fractional Quantum Hall System

text: We explore the dynamics of quantum information scrambling and thermalization in a variant of the Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) model featuring quenched disorder in the coupling constants. By calculating the out-of-time-order correlator (OTOC), we extract the quantum Lyapunov exponent, which characterizes the exponential growth of operators in the semi-classical limit. Our analysis reveals that while strong disorder can suppress the scrambling rate, the system remains maximally chaotic up to a critical disorder strength. We connect these findings to the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH) by examining the statistical properties of matrix elements of local operators in the energy eigenbasis. We find that the onset of chaos, as indicated by the OTOC, coincides with the emergence of ETH-compliant behavior. Furthermore, we discuss the gravitational dual, linking the Lyapunov exponent to the pole-skipping phenomenon in the shockwave geometry near the black hole horizon, thus reinforcing the holographic correspondence for chaotic quantum systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Information Scrambling and Eigenstate Thermalization in a Disordered SYK-type Model

text: The transition between a thermalizing ergodic phase and a many-body localized (MBL) phase represents a fundamental breakdown of statistical mechanics in a closed quantum system. We investigate the critical properties of this transition in a one-dimensional disordered Heisenberg spin chain using large-scale exact diagonalization and the time-evolving block decimation (TEBD) algorithm. In the MBL phase, we confirm the characteristic logarithmic growth of bipartite entanglement entropy following a quantum quench, a direct consequence of emergent local integrals of motion (l-bits). Approaching the transition from the localized side, we observe a sharp increase in entanglement growth and fluctuations. Our finite-size scaling analysis suggests the transition is governed by an avalanche mechanism, where thermalizing 'bubbles' locally seeded by rare non-local resonances catalytically thermalize adjacent regions. This mechanism implies that the MBL phase is unstable in dimensions higher than one and places stringent constraints on the universality class of the MBL-to-ergodic transition, challenging phenomenological real-space renormalization group theories.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Growth and Avalanche Instability at the Many-Body Localization Transition

text: We propose and analyze a quantum metrology protocol that achieves Heisenberg-limited precision in phase estimation using a multi-mode entangled state. The protocol employs an N-mode entangled squeezed vacuum state, generated via a network of parametric down-conversion crystals, injected into a parallelized Mach-Zehnder interferometer array. The quantum Fisher information for the differential phase is calculated, demonstrating a scaling of N², a quadratic improvement over the standard quantum limit (SQL) which scales as N. We show that this Heisenberg scaling is robust to moderate photon loss, a significant advantage over fragile NOON states. The protocol relies on performing homodyne detection on the output modes and using a maximum-likelihood estimator to extract the phase information. Our scheme provides a practical pathway for enhancing the sensitivity of gravitational wave detectors, quantum imaging systems, and atomic clocks beyond the constraints imposed by shot noise, pushing measurement precision to its fundamental quantum limits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Phase Estimation via Multi-Mode Entangled Squeezed States

text: We theoretically demonstrate the feasibility of observing the dynamical Casimir effect (DCE) in a realistic circuit QED architecture. Our proposed system consists of a coplanar waveguide terminated by a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) array, forming a metamaterial with a tunable effective plasma frequency. By applying a non-adiabatic, time-varying magnetic flux to the SQUIDs, the boundary condition of the electromagnetic field inside the waveguide is rapidly modulated. We perform a full quantum analysis using Bogoliubov transformations on the field operators, showing that this modulation leads to the creation of real photon pairs from the vacuum state. The predicted photon spectrum is non-thermal and directly dependent on the modulation frequency and waveform. Our numerical simulations, incorporating realistic system parameters and decoherence sources, indicate that the generated microwave photons should be detectable with current state-of-the-art single-photon detectors, providing an accessible platform to study quantum vacuum amplification.
subject: Kuantum
title: Photon Generation from Modulated Vacuum via a Flux-Tunable Superconducting Metamaterial

text: We construct a holographic model of a superconductor using the gauge/gravity duality in a background spacetime exhibiting Lifshitz scaling and hyperscaling violation. This gravitational setup is dual to a strongly correlated quantum system with a non-relativistic scaling symmetry and a non-trivial effective spatial dimension, characterized by the dynamical critical exponent z and the hyperscaling violation exponent θ. We study the condensation of a charged scalar field in this background, calculating the critical temperature of the superconducting phase transition as a function of z and θ. Subsequently, we compute the frequency-dependent AC electrical conductivity in the superconducting phase by analyzing Maxwell field perturbations. The conductivity reveals a superconducting gap, the ratio of which to the critical temperature (2Δ/k_B T_c) shows a strong dependence on the exponents, deviating significantly from the universal BCS value. This model provides a holographic framework for studying quantum critical points and unconventional superconductivity in non-Fermi liquids.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Superconductivity and AC Conductivity in Lifshitz Spacetime with Hyperscaling Violation

text: We present a scheme for the autonomous stabilization and error correction of a Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill (GKP) encoded qubit. The GKP code encodes quantum information in the continuous-variable Hilbert space of a harmonic oscillator, offering a hardware-efficient approach to fault tolerance. Our protocol utilizes a high-Q microwave cavity as the oscillator, dispersively coupled to a transmon ancilla qubit. The drive and dissipation of the ancilla are engineered to create a non-unitary process that autonomously corrects small displacement errors in the cavity state, effectively confining it to the GKP code subspace. This is achieved by designing a specific unconditional master equation whose steady-state manifold is the desired code space. The scheme obviates the need for explicit syndrome measurements and feedback loops, providing a passive, hardware-level protection against the dominant error channels, including both small shifts in phase space and single-photon loss. We analyze the scheme's performance and demonstrate its potential to significantly extend the coherence time of the encoded qubit.
subject: Kuantum
title: Autonomous Quantum Error Correction with Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill Codes in a Cavity-QED Architecture

text: We propose a novel detection scheme for axionic dark matter that leverages the strong coupling regime of a hybrid spin-cavity system. The proposed haloscope consists of a dense ensemble of spin-polarized nuclei (e.g., ¹²⁹Xe) embedded within a high-Q microwave cavity. In the presence of a strong static magnetic field, the axion wind induces a small, oscillating transverse effective magnetic field through the axion-nucleon coupling. This field drives coherent spin precession in the nuclear ensemble, which acts as a high-quality factor quantum magnetometer. The collective spin magnetization is strongly coupled to a resonant cavity mode, enabling efficient transduction of the spin precession into a detectable microwave photon signal. By operating in the Tavis-Cummings regime, the signal is coherently amplified by the square root of the number of spins, providing a significant enhancement in sensitivity. Our analysis shows this approach could probe the QCD axion parameter space in a currently unexplored mass range.
subject: Kuantum
title: Enhanced Axion Haloscope Sensitivity through Spin-Cavity Hybridization

text: This paper introduces a scalable inference algorithm for Hierarchical Dirichlet Process (HDP) mixture models, addressing the computational bottlenecks of traditional MCMC methods in large-data regimes. We develop a stochastic variational inference (SVI) framework that optimizes the evidence lower bound (ELBO) using mini-batches of data. A key contribution is the derivation of a natural gradient update scheme tailored for the HDP's nested structure, which significantly accelerates convergence by accounting for the geometry of the variational parameter space. Our SVI-HDP approach allows for the discovery of a latent number of clusters without prior specification while processing data streams. We provide theoretical analysis on the algorithm's convergence properties and demonstrate its empirical performance on massive text corpora and image datasets. Results show that our method achieves perplexity scores comparable to Gibbs sampling but with orders of magnitude reduction in computation time, enabling robust Bayesian nonparametric analysis at an unprecedented scale.
subject: İstatistik
title: Scalable Bayesian Nonparametrics: Stochastic Variational Inference for Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Mixture Models

text: We propose a novel Targeted Maximum Likelihood Estimator (TMLE) for the average treatment effect (ATE) when the confounder set is high-dimensional. The procedure leverages ensemble machine learning, specifically super learning, to flexibly and data-adaptively estimate the initial propensity score and outcome regression nuisance parameters. The core of our method is a targeted update step that optimizes the parameter of interest along a least favorable submodel, thereby reducing bias and achieving semiparametric efficiency. The proposed estimator inherits the double robustness property, ensuring consistency if either the outcome regression or the propensity score model is correctly specified—a crucial feature in high dimensions where model misspecification is likely. We establish the asymptotic normality and derive the efficient influence function under specific sparsity assumptions. Monte Carlo simulations and an application to genomic data demonstrate superior finite-sample performance, with reduced bias and improved confidence interval coverage over competing augmented inverse probability weighting (AIPW) estimators.
subject: İstatistik
title: Doubly Robust Targeted Maximum Likelihood Estimation for Causal Effects in High-Dimensional Confounder Settings

text: This work presents a novel framework for unsupervised anomaly detection in complex spatiotemporal systems by leveraging tools from topological data analysis (TDA). We construct a sequence of Vietoris-Rips simplicial complexes from time-evolving point cloud data and compute their persistent homology, which quantifies the birth and death of multiscale topological features. To facilitate statistical analysis, we map the resulting persistence diagrams into a reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS) using a stable, positive-definite persistence scale-space kernel. Anomalies are then identified as outliers in this feature space using a one-class support vector machine (SVM). This methodology effectively captures emergent, non-local geometric structures indicative of system-level anomalies. The efficacy of our approach is demonstrated on simulated chaotic systems and real-world climate data, where it successfully identifies critical transitions and extreme events that are obscured from methods based on conventional summary statistics or principal component analysis.
subject: İstatistik
title: Persistent Homology for Anomaly Detection in Dynamic Spatiotemporal Systems: A Kernel-Based Approach

text: We develop a novel method for Functional Principal Component Analysis (FPCA) tailored for sparse longitudinal data, where subjects are observed at few, irregular time points. Standard FPCA methods falter in this setting due to the difficulty of accurately estimating the covariance function from fragmented data. Our proposed method, Sparse FPCA (sFPCA), regularizes the covariance estimation by representing it as a bivariate penalized spline surface, which encourages smoothness and borrows strength across subjects. The eigenfunctions and principal component scores are estimated through an iterative procedure that alternates between conditional expectation and penalized likelihood maximization steps. This approach facilitates the reconstruction of individual functional trajectories from minimal data points. We establish asymptotic consistency and convergence rates for the estimated covariance operator and its eigenfunctions under mild regularity conditions. The superior performance of sFPCA in both prediction and interpretation is validated through extensive simulations and an application to a clinical trial dataset with highly irregular patient follow-up.
subject: İstatistik
title: Sparse Functional Principal Component Analysis for Longitudinal Data with Irregular Observation Schedules

text: This paper addresses the problem of learning high-dimensional graphical model structures when the data are not jointly Gaussian. We focus on the nonparanormal (or Gaussian copula) model, which posits that variables become jointly Gaussian after a set of unknown univariate monotone transformations. We propose a computationally efficient, rank-based, two-stage procedure for estimating the underlying conditional independence graph. In the first stage, the nonparanormal correlation matrix is estimated robustly using rank correlations such as Kendall's tau. In the second stage, we apply a graphical Lasso (glasso) algorithm to the estimated correlation matrix to learn a sparse precision matrix, thereby recovering the graph structure. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis, establishing a non-asymptotic error bound for the precision matrix estimator and proving model selection consistency under high-dimensional scaling where p >> n. Our method circumvents the restrictive Gaussianity assumption while maintaining the computational advantages of glasso, demonstrating superior performance in simulations and genomic data analysis.
subject: İstatistik
title: Semiparametric Estimation of High-Dimensional Gaussian Copula Graphical Models

text: Standard Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) methods exhibit suboptimal performance when sampling from posterior distributions with complex, non-Euclidean geometries. We propose an adaptive Riemannian Manifold HMC (RMHMC) algorithm that dynamically adjusts to the local curvature of the target density. By defining the kinetic energy via a position-dependent metric tensor, such as the Fisher-Rao information matrix, the algorithm generates proposals that follow geodesic paths, enabling more efficient exploration of challenging posterior landscapes characterized by strong correlations and varying scales. We develop a computationally tractable implementation using a simplified, diagonal metric tensor updated via a stochastic approximation scheme and a generalized leapfrog integrator that maintains symplecticity. Theoretical results demonstrate the algorithm's geometric ergodicity under weaker conditions than standard HMC. Empirical evaluations on hierarchical Bayesian models and neural networks show substantial improvements in sampling efficiency, as measured by effective sample size per gradient evaluation, over both Euclidean HMC and adaptive Metropolis algorithms.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Riemannian Manifold Hamiltonian Monte Carlo for Complex Posterior Geometries

text: Evaluating the value of dynamic treatment regimes (DTRs) from observational data is a central challenge in personalized medicine and offline reinforcement learning. We introduce a novel, semiparametric doubly robust estimator for off-policy evaluation in multi-stage decision settings. Our approach extends sequential augmented inverse probability weighting (AIPW) to accommodate flexible function approximators for the Q-function and propensity scores, which is essential for handling large state-action spaces. We formulate a locally robust loss function for fitting the Q-function, which ensures that the final policy value estimator is doubly robust: it remains consistent if either the sequential Q-function models or the sequential propensity score models are correctly specified. We provide rigorous theoretical guarantees on the estimator's asymptotic normality and derive its semiparametric efficiency bound. The method is evaluated in complex simulated environments and on a real-world clinical dataset for sepsis management, demonstrating substantially reduced bias and variance compared to standard importance sampling and direct Q-learning methods.
subject: İstatistik
title: Offline Policy Evaluation for Dynamic Treatment Regimes using Semiparametric Function Approximators

text: We introduce a Bayesian dynamic tensor regression framework for forecasting high-dimensional multivariate time series, where both the response and predictors are represented as tensors. This approach parsimoniously captures complex spatio-temporal dependencies by exploiting the inherent multi-linear structure of the data. The model specifies a state-space formulation for the tensor regression coefficients, allowing them to evolve stochastically over time. To ensure model identifiability and mitigate the curse of dimensionality, we impose a low-rank PARAFAC/CANDECOMP decomposition on the coefficient tensor and place structural priors on its factor matrices. A full Bayesian inference procedure is developed using an efficient Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm. We establish posterior consistency for the model parameters under suitable regularity conditions. The model's superior predictive power is demonstrated on large-scale neuroimaging (fMRI) data and financial asset returns, showing significant improvements in out-of-sample forecast accuracy compared to traditional vector autoregressive (VAR) models and other vectorized approaches.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Dynamic Tensor Regression for Forecasting High-Dimensional Multivariate Time Series

text: Classical models for competing risks, such as the Fine-Gray and cause-specific Cox models, are limited by their reliance on linearity and proportional hazards assumptions. This paper introduces a flexible, deep learning-based framework for modeling cause-specific hazards in the presence of time-varying covariates. We specify distinct neural networks for each cause of failure to learn complex, non-linear relationships between the covariate history and the instantaneous event risk. A recurrent neural network (RNN) architecture is employed to naturally process the temporal dependency of covariates. The model is trained by maximizing a discrete-time approximation of the partial log-likelihood, enabling efficient optimization via standard backpropagation algorithms. Through extensive simulations, we show our Deep Competing Risks (DeepCR) model provides more accurate predictions of cumulative incidence functions than traditional methods, particularly in scenarios with complex interactions and non-proportional hazards. The model's clinical utility is illustrated on a bone marrow transplant patient dataset.
subject: İstatistik
title: Deep Learning for Competing Risks Analysis with Time-Varying Covariates

text: Robust estimation of covariance matrices in high-dimensional settings (p > n) is fundamentally challenged by the curse of dimensionality and computational complexity. We propose a computationally efficient, high-breakdown point estimator that circumvents these issues through random subspace projections. The methodology involves projecting the data onto multiple, randomly generated low-dimensional subspaces, computing a classical robust covariance estimate (e.g., Minimum Covariance Determinant) within each subspace, and then aggregating these estimates to reconstruct the high-dimensional covariance matrix. This projection-pursuit-style approach avoids direct computation in the full ambient space. We provide a theoretical analysis proving that, under a cell-wise contamination model, the proposed estimator achieves a positive breakdown point and is consistent for the true covariance structure of the uncontaminated data. Its polynomial-time complexity makes it scalable to large p. Simulations and a real-data application in financial portfolio optimization demonstrate superior performance over existing methods in terms of both robustness and estimation accuracy.
subject: İstatistik
title: High-Breakdown Covariance Estimation in High Dimensions via Random Subspace Projections

text: We introduce a novel class of generative models based on score-matching with stochastic differential equations (SDEs) that explicitly enforces equivariance to continuous symmetries, represented by Lie groups. Standard diffusion models often struggle to learn data distributions with inherent geometric structures, leading to sample inefficiency and physically implausible outputs. By parameterizing the drift function of the reverse-time SDE on a manifold and employing equivariant neural network architectures, our model generates high-fidelity data that inherently respects these symmetries from sparse observations. The framework is demonstrated on complex generation tasks, including 3D molecular conformation and fluid dynamics simulations, where enforcing SO(3) and SE(3) equivariance significantly improves sample quality and likelihood scores. This approach provides a principled way to incorporate inductive biases from physics and geometry into deep generative modeling, paving the way for more robust and efficient scientific discovery.
subject: AI
title: Stochastic Differential Equation-Based Generative Modeling with Lie Group Equivariance

text: Estimating individual treatment effects from observational data is severely hampered by unobserved confounders. We propose a novel deep generative framework, the Deconfounded Variational Auto-Encoder (DeVAE), for robust counterfactual inference. DeVAE models the joint distribution of treatments, covariates, and outcomes by factorizing a latent space into three disjoint subspaces representing causal factors, confounding factors, and nuisance variables. To enforce this factorization, we introduce an orthogonalizing prior and a tailored evidence lower bound (ELBO) objective with a gradient reversal layer that promotes adversarial invariance to treatment assignment for the confounding subspace. This principled disentanglement allows for more accurate estimation of the counterfactual distribution p(Y(t)|X) by integrating over the learned confounder distribution. We demonstrate empirically on synthetic and semi-synthetic benchmarks that our model significantly reduces confounding bias and provides better calibrated counterfactual predictions compared to state-of-the-art methods in personalized medicine.
subject: AI
title: Deconfounded Counterfactual Inference via Latent Variational Auto-Encoders with Orthogonalized Priors

text: Standard Transformer architectures, operating in Euclidean space, are suboptimal for modeling data with latent hierarchical structures, such as natural language syntax or knowledge graphs. We introduce the Hyperbolic Transformer, a novel architecture where all key operations—self-attention, value aggregation, and position encoding—are formulated within a non-Euclidean hyperbolic geometry (Poincaré ball model). By leveraging gyrovector operations for attention score calculation and Möbius transformations for value propagation, our model can represent tree-like structures with significantly lower distortion and fewer parameters. The attention mechanism inherently prioritizes ancestors and siblings in the latent hierarchy. We demonstrate that the Hyperbolic Transformer achieves superior performance and parameter efficiency on tasks requiring hierarchical reasoning, including machine translation, textual entailment, and link prediction in large-scale knowledge graphs. Our results highlight the benefits of aligning model geometry with data geometry for improved inductive biases.
subject: AI
title: Hyperbolic Geometric Transformers for Hierarchical Data Representation

text: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) excel at learning from pairwise interactions but inherently fail to capture higher-order relationships within data. We propose Simplicial-Complex-Informed Neural Networks (SCINNs), a framework that generalizes GNNs to operate on simplicial complexes, which explicitly model multi-way relational structures. Our architecture leverages the Hodge Laplacian, a generalization of the graph Laplacian, to define separate message-passing channels along edges (1-simplices), triangles (2-simplices), and higher-dimensional simplicies. This allows the model to learn representations that are sensitive to topological features like cycles and cavities, which are invisible to standard GNNs. We derive theoretical results connecting our architecture to homological feature detection. Empirically, SCINNs establish new state-of-the-art results on molecular property prediction, where ring structures are critical, and in social network analysis for detecting cohesive community structures beyond simple cliques.
subject: AI
title: Simplicial-Complex-Informed Graph Neural Networks for Higher-Order Topological Feature Extraction

text: Federated Learning (FL) faces two critical challenges: statistical heterogeneity (non-IID data) and system heterogeneity (variable client resources). We propose an Asynchronous Federated Meta-Learning (AFML) framework that jointly addresses these issues. AFML employs a meta-learning paradigm to learn a global model initialization that can be rapidly adapted to each client's local data distribution. To handle system heterogeneity, clients perform updates asynchronously and report back to the server without waiting for stragglers. The core innovation lies in our personalized model aggregation strategy, where the server updates the global meta-model by weighting client updates based on a similarity metric between the client's model parameters and the global model, as well as the client's gradient divergence. This ensures that clients with dissimilar data distributions or stale updates contribute appropriately. AFML demonstrates significantly faster convergence and higher final accuracy on highly non-IID federated benchmarks.
subject: AI
title: Asynchronous Federated Meta-Learning for Non-IID Data via Personalized Model Aggregation

text: Offline multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) aims to learn effective collaborative policies from a fixed dataset of interactions, but is plagued by distributional shift. We introduce Conservative Offline MARL with Counterfactual Augmentation (COMARL), a novel algorithm that mitigates this challenge. COMARL incorporates a conservative Q-learning objective that penalizes out-of-distribution (OOD) joint actions, thereby regularizing the policy towards behaviors well-supported by the static dataset. To further enrich the data and improve generalization, we train a conditional generative model to perform counterfactual data augmentation, synthesizing plausible joint trajectories that could have occurred under alternative policies. This augmented dataset allows the critic to learn a more robust value function. We evaluate COMARL on challenging cooperative tasks in the StarCraft Multi-Agent Challenge (SMAC) and show that it significantly outperforms existing offline MARL baselines, learning near-optimal policies from highly suboptimal datasets.
subject: AI
title: Offline Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Conservative Policy Regularization and Counterfactual Data Augmentation

text: We present a neuro-symbolic framework for inductive program synthesis that combines the perceptual strengths of deep learning with the rigorous logic of formal methods. Our approach, Neuro-Symbolic Differentiable Abstract Interpretation (NS-DAI), trains a neural network policy to guide a symbolic search through the space of possible programs. The key innovation is a differentiable abstract interpreter that executes partial programs over abstract domains, yielding continuous, gradient-based feedback on program correctness. This feedback, representing the 'semantic distance' from the target specification, provides a rich training signal that circumvents the sparse rewards of traditional execution-based synthesis. By backpropagating through the abstract interpretation process, the neural policy learns powerful heuristics for pruning the search space. NS-DAI successfully synthesizes complex, recursive algorithms from input-output examples, demonstrating a significant improvement over both purely neural and classic search-based program synthesis techniques.
subject: AI
title: Inductive Program Synthesis via Differentiable Abstract Interpretation

text: Accurate uncertainty quantification is paramount for deploying neural networks in safety-critical domains. We propose a computationally efficient yet theoretically sound method for estimating epistemic uncertainty, termed Conformalized Gradient-based Ensembles (CGE). CGE approximates a posterior distribution over model weights by creating a functional ensemble from a single training trajectory, using checkpoints and gradients to induce diversity. This avoids the prohibitive cost of training deep ensembles. Critically, we apply split conformal prediction techniques to the variance of the ensemble's predictions, producing rigorous uncertainty intervals with guaranteed marginal coverage rates, a property lacking in most Bayesian deep learning methods. CGE yields well-calibrated epistemic uncertainty estimates that are highly effective for out-of-distribution detection and active learning, achieving performance comparable to deep ensembles at a fraction of the computational budget. We demonstrate its utility on medical imaging and autonomous driving perception tasks.
subject: AI
title: Calibrated Epistemic Uncertainty Quantification using Conformalized Gradient-based Ensembles

text: Self-supervised learning for video has largely focused on learning representations that are invariant to transformations. However, for understanding dynamic scenes, equivariance to spatio-temporal transformations (e.g., rotation, time-reversal) is more desirable. We introduce Spatio-Temporal Equivariant Contrastive Learning (STECL), a novel framework that learns representations that transform predictably under the action of a defined group of transformations. We formulate a contrastive objective in a latent space where augmentations correspond to group actions. The model is trained to minimize the distance between a transformed input's representation and the group-transformed representation of the original input. This forces the model to encode the intrinsic structure of the dynamics rather than just appearance. STECL learns powerful motion semantics, achieving state-of-the-art performance on downstream tasks like action recognition and video retrieval, particularly in low-data regimes, without relying on any semantic labels.
subject: AI
title: Spatio-Temporal Equivariant Contrastive Learning for Video Representation

text: Meta-learning algorithms often produce point estimates of task-specific parameters, failing to capture uncertainty and leading to overconfidence in few-shot settings. We propose Hypernetwork-Amortized Variational Inference (HAVI), a scalable Bayesian meta-learning framework. Instead of learning a prior distribution over model parameters directly, we train a hypernetwork that maps a task's support set to the parameters of an approximate posterior distribution over the task-specific model's weights. This amortizes the cost of variational inference, allowing for efficient, feed-forward generation of a posterior for any new task. By marginalizing over this predicted posterior during inference, our method provides robust predictions and well-calibrated uncertainty estimates. HAVI effectively mitigates the problem of meta-overfitting to the training task distribution and demonstrates superior accuracy and uncertainty calibration on challenging, cross-domain few-shot classification and regression benchmarks compared to existing probabilistic and deterministic meta-learning methods.
subject: AI
title: Bayesian Meta-Learning with Hypernetwork-Amortized Variational Inference

text: Intragenomic conflict is a potent evolutionary force, exemplified by meiotic drive systems where selfish genetic elements subvert Mendelian segregation. We investigate the coevolutionary dynamics between the segregation distorter (SD) locus in *Drosophila melanogaster* and the repetitive satellite DNA at its target, Responder (Rsp). Using high-throughput chromosome conformation capture (Hi-C) and population genomic analyses, we demonstrate that SD-induced chromatin condensation is modulated by the copy number and sequence composition of Rsp satellite arrays. We find that rapid, non-reciprocal expansion and contraction of these arrays create a dynamic fitness landscape, allowing host genomes to escape the deleterious effects of drive. Our results indicate a recurrent arms race, where centromeric satellite DNA evolution is not a neutral process but is instead driven by intense selection to suppress segregation distortion. This provides a mechanistic link between selfish gene evolution, heterochromatin dynamics, and the rapid evolution of genomic architecture, potentially contributing to postzygotic reproductive isolation.
subject: Evrim
title: Meiotic Drive and the Evolutionary Dynamics of Satellite DNA Expansion in Drosophila

text: The genetic legacy of archaic hominins in modern human populations provides a unique window into past adaptations. We present a comprehensive analysis of a novel introgressed haplotype of Denisovan origin, found at high frequency in Tibetan and Himalayan populations, which contains a paralog of the Endothelial PAS domain-containing protein 1 (EPAS1) gene, designated *EPAS1B*. Through functional genomics assays using CRISPR-Cas9 engineered cell lines and analysis of paleoproteomic data, we demonstrate that this archaic allele confers a distinct transcriptional response to hypoxic stress, dampening the erythropoietic feedback loop and preventing polycythemia. Coalescent simulations and scans for positive selection confirm the haplotype's Denisovan origin and subsequent selective sweep in ancestral high-altitude populations post-introgression. This discovery elucidates a clear case of adaptive introgression providing a complex physiological solution to a severe environmental challenge, underscoring the importance of admixture as a source of evolutionary innovation in human history.
subject: Evrim
title: Adaptive Introgression of an Archaic Denisovan Haplotype Confers High-Altitude Hypoxia Tolerance

text: The role of phenotypic plasticity in facilitating large-scale evolutionary diversification remains a central, unresolved question. We examined this phenomenon within the explosive adaptive radiation of African cichlid fishes, focusing on the development of their highly labile pharyngeal jaw apparatus. By integrating geometric morphometrics, transcriptomics, and diet-manipulation experiments across a robust phylogenomic framework, we demonstrate that ancestral plasticity in bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) and calmodulin signaling pathways precedes, and predicts, the primary axes of morphological diversification. Our phylogenetic comparative methods reveal that lineages occupying novel ecological niches exhibit a marked reduction in plasticity (canalization) following genetic assimilation of environmentally induced phenotypes. These findings provide strong evidence for the 'plasticity-first' hypothesis, where developmental plasticity acts not as a passive buffer, but as an active evolutionary engine that explores functional morphospace, thereby catalyzing rapid and repeated adaptive radiation in complex ecosystems.
subject: Evrim
title: Phenotypic Plasticity as a Catalyst for Adaptive Radiation: A Phylogenetic Comparative Analysis of Cichlid Jaw Morphogenesis

text: Host-parasite coevolution is often characterized by reciprocal, negative frequency-dependent selection, known as the Red Queen hypothesis. We tracked this dynamic at the molecular level in real-time using an experimental coevolution study between *Arabidopsis thaliana* and the oomycete pathogen *Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis*. By sequencing host and pathogen populations from time-shifted inoculations over 50 generations, we identified cyclical selective sweeps targeting plant nucleotide-binding leucine-rich repeat (NLR) resistance genes and corresponding pathogen avirulence (Avr) effectors. We observed a consistent pattern of costly resistance alleles rising in frequency, followed by the emergence and sweep of pathogen effector variants that evade recognition. This process results in a high genetic load and perpetual genomic turnover at coevolving loci, without a net increase in host resistance over time. Our results provide direct genomic evidence for an antagonistic coevolutionary arms race, validating a foundational model of biodiversity maintenance and disease evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Molecular Signatures of a Red Queen Dynamic in a Plant-Pathogen System Revealed by Time-Shifted Experimental Evolution

text: The precise phylogenetic relationships among early-branching metazoan phyla remain one of evolution's most persistent challenges. Systematic errors, such as long-branch attraction (LBA) and incomplete lineage sorting (ILS), have produced conflicting topologies from phylogenomic datasets. Here, we re-evaluate the placement of Ctenophora, Porifera, and Placozoa by applying a novel analytical pipeline to a curated dataset of over 1,500 single-copy orthologs from 120 species. Our approach integrates site-heterogeneous mixture models within a supermatrix framework and multi-species coalescent methods that explicitly model ILS. While coalescent analyses marginally favor a Ctenophora-sister topology, model adequacy tests reveal significant conflict among gene trees, particularly in deep internodes. We find that removing fast-evolving gene partitions, a common strategy to reduce LBA, paradoxically exacerbates discordance. Our results suggest that a simple bifurcating tree may be an inadequate model for the explosive radiation of early animal life, highlighting the profound impact of methodological choices and underlying biological complexity in deep phylogenomics.
subject: Evrim
title: Resolving the Metazoan Tree of Life: A Phylogenomic Approach Integrating Supermatrix and Coalescent Methods to Mitigate Systematic Error

text: Major evolutionary transitions, such as the origin of multicellularity, require the innovation of novel gene functions for processes like cell adhesion, communication, and differentiation. Using the volvocine green algae, a model system spanning from unicellular *Chlamydomonas* to multicellular *Volvox*, we traced the evolutionary fate of gene duplicates preceding the evolution of organismal complexity. Our comparative genomic and transcriptomic analysis reveals that tandem duplications of genes encoding extracellular matrix (ECM) components and cell-cycle regulators were rampant at the base of the multicellular volvocines. Functional characterization via CRISPR-mediated knockouts demonstrates that while one paralog typically retains the ancestral function (subfunctionalization), the other often acquires novel expression domains and functions related to germ-soma differentiation (neofunctionalization). Specifically, the neofunctionalization of a duplicated cyclin-dependent kinase, *regA*, was critical for the evolution of somatic cell terminal differentiation. This provides a clear genetic roadmap where gene duplication serves as a primary engine for generating the raw material for evolutionary innovation.
subject: Evrim
title: The Role of Neofunctionalized Gene Duplicates in the Transition to Multicellularity in Volvocine Algae

text: The evolution of complex traits often requires the fixation of multiple mutations, some of which may be individually deleterious, necessitating the crossing of a fitness valley on the adaptive landscape. We developed a series of multi-locus, forward-time population genetics models to investigate the mechanisms facilitating such transitions. Our simulations demonstrate that while stochastic tunneling—the near-simultaneous establishment of multiple mutations—is effective in large populations with high mutation rates, it is insufficient for traversing deep or wide valleys. We introduce the concept of 'epistatic scaffolding', where transient, compensatory mutations create a temporary ridge across the fitness valley, which is later dismantled once the primary adaptive combination is fixed. This mechanism dramatically increases the probability of complex adaptation in smaller, asexual populations. The model reconciles observed rates of multi-drug resistance evolution with theoretical constraints, highlighting the critical role of higher-order epistatic interactions in shaping evolutionary trajectories.
subject: Evrim
title: Navigating Fitness Valleys: The Interplay of Stochastic Tunneling and Epistatic Scaffolding in the Evolution of Complex Adaptations

text: Post-copulatory sexual selection, driven by sperm competition and cryptic female choice, is a major force in the evolution of reproductive traits. We investigated the coevolutionary interplay between male seminal fluid proteins (SFPs) and female reproductive tract (FRT) morphology in a clade of promiscuous seed beetles (*Callosobruchus*). Using RNA-seq and micro-CT scanning across a well-resolved phylogeny, we found a strong, phylogenetically-corrected correlation between the evolutionary rate of specific SFP families and the complexity of the female spermathecal duct. Functional assays using RNA interference to knock down rapidly evolving SFPs resulted in reduced sperm storage in females with complex FRT morphology, but not in females with simple tracts. These results suggest a lock-and-key coevolutionary dynamic, where female morphology evolves to create hurdles for sperm transport and storage, thereby biasing paternity, while males evolve novel SFPs to overcome these barriers. This provides a clear mechanism for sexually antagonistic coevolution driving rapid diversification of reproductive genes and morphologies.
subject: Evrim
title: Cryptic Female Choice and the Coevolution of Seminal Fluid Proteins and Female Reproductive Tract Morphology

text: The predictability of evolution is limited by the interplay between determinism, driven by natural selection, and contingency, arising from stochastic historical events. We leveraged the >75,000-generation *E. coli* long-term evolution experiment (LTEE) to dissect these forces. By re-evolving populations from different ancestral timepoints under identical selective pressures, we quantified the impact of historical mutations on subsequent adaptive pathways. We found that early, large-effect mutations in global regulators, such as *spoT*, constrained future evolution by creating epistatic dependencies that precluded alternative, and potentially more optimal, adaptive solutions from arising. In contrast, populations lacking these early mutations explored a wider diversity of adaptive pathways. These findings demonstrate that historical contingency, mediated by epistatic pleiotropy, can channel evolution down specific, non-optimal trajectories. The adaptive landscape is therefore not static but is dynamically reshaped by the very process of evolution, profoundly limiting predictability over long evolutionary timescales.
subject: Evrim
title: Contingency and Historical Constraint Shape Adaptive Trajectories in a Long-Term E. coli Evolution Experiment

text: Mass extinctions are hypothesized to be potent catalysts of adaptive radiation by creating ecological opportunity. We tested this by analyzing the macroevolutionary dynamics of early Paleocene mammals using a comprehensive fossil dataset and a time-calibrated molecular phylogeny. By applying Bayesian birth-death models and disparity-through-time analyses, we uncovered a striking decoupling of diversification rates. Lineage diversification (speciation rates) peaked immediately following the K-Pg boundary, consistent with the rapid filling of vacant ecospace. However, the rate of morphological innovation (disparity) in key functional traits, particularly dental and tarsal morphology, remained low for the first 5 million years of the Paleocene before accelerating dramatically. This temporal lag suggests that an initial phase of taxonomic diversification into broadly similar niches was followed by a subsequent, more prolonged phase of ecological specialization and morphological innovation. Our results challenge the classic model of explosive, simultaneous radiation and highlight the complex, multi-stage processes governing recovery from mass extinction events.
subject: Evrim
title: Decoupled Rates of Morphological and Lineage Diversification Following the Cretaceous-Paleogene Mass Extinction

text: This paper investigates the extremal number for specific families of r-uniform hypergraphs derived from iterated expansions. We define the k-th expansion H^(k) of a seed hypergraph H as the hypergraph obtained by iteratively replacing each vertex with a disjoint copy of H. We determine the precise Turán density π(F) for F=K_4^(3)(2), the second expansion of the complete 3-uniform hypergraph on 4 vertices. Our proof employs the hypergraph stability method of Pikhurko and Razborov, combined with a novel spectral delocalization argument to handle the complex intersection patterns inherent in H^(k). We establish that any F-free hypergraph on n vertices must be asymptotically contained within a Turán-type construction based on a specific equitable vertex partition. This result resolves a case of a broader conjecture regarding the Turán densities of hypergraph expansions and introduces techniques applicable to a wider class of non-uniform forbidden configurations.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Turán Density of Iterated Hypergraph Expansions

text: We establish new upper bounds for the bipartite Ramsey number BR(G, H), defined as the minimum N such that any red/blue edge coloring of K_{N,N} contains either a red copy of G or a blue copy of H. Focusing on the case where G is a complete bipartite graph K_{s,t} and H is a disconnected graph, specifically a forest of stars, we significantly improve upon existing exponential bounds. Our main tool is a refined application of the dependent random choice lemma, tailored for the bipartite setting, which allows for the embedding of sparse structures in dense subgraphs with strong neighborhood properties. For H being a matching of size m, we prove BR(K_{s,t}, M_m) ≤ (t+m)^{s+o(1)}, a polynomial bound in m for fixed s and t. This demonstrates the power of probabilistic methods in asymmetric bipartite Ramsey problems and provides a unified framework for handling various disconnected graph structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Bipartite Ramsey Numbers of Disconnected Graphs via Dependent Random Choice

text: We present a new combinatorial formula for the Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials P_{u,v}(q) for the affine Weyl group of type C̃_n. Our approach provides a realization of these polynomials as coefficients of a novel family of quasi-symmetric functions, constructed via a weighted summation over specific paths in the Bruhat graph. This formulation is manifestly positive and q-monotonic, confirming a long-standing conjecture in this case. The proof involves developing an algebraic framework connecting the Hecke algebra of type C̃_n to an algebra of quasi-symmetric functions equipped with a specialized coproduct. We demonstrate that this construction provides a characterization of the equivariant cohomology of certain Schubert varieties in the affine flag manifold, thereby bridging a gap between algebraic combinatorics and geometric representation theory. The methodology suggests a pathway for analogous results in other affine types.
subject: Matematik
title: A Quasi-Symmetric Function Realization of Kazhdan-Lusztig Polynomials for Affine Type C

text: We analyze the saturation problem within the sparse random k-uniform hypergraph G_k(n, p). We determine the sharp threshold for the property that every F-free subgraph can be made F-saturated by the addition of a single hyperedge, where F is a strictly k-balanced hypergraph. The proof integrates the hypergraph container method with a delicate second-moment argument, requiring precise control over the distribution of small subgraphs near the threshold probability. This result is then leveraged to establish new bounds on the 0-statement for asymmetric Ramsey properties of random hypergraphs. Specifically, we find a new range of edge probabilities p(n) for which G_k(n, p) arrow (F_1, F_2) with high probability, resolving a question posed by Kohayakawa et al. and demonstrating the deep connection between saturation phenomena and thresholds for Ramsey-type properties in random discrete structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Threshold Saturation and Asymmetric Ramsey Properties in Sparse Random Hypergraphs

text: We establish necessary and sufficient conditions for the existence of a resolvable group divisible design (GDD) of type g^u with block size k=4 and index λ=1, for all sufficiently large group sizes g. The proof synthesizes classical difference methods over finite fields with modern recursive constructions employing Wilson's fundamental construction for pairwise balanced designs (PBDs). A key innovation is the use of weighted path decompositions in Cayley graphs to construct the initial base designs, which circumvents limitations of previous multiplicative group approaches. This work completes the existence spectrum for λ=1, k=4, and g > g_0 for some effective constant g_0, leaving only a finite, albeit large, number of parameter sets for computational verification. Our results have direct applications in the construction of other combinatorial objects, such as resolvable balanced incomplete block designs and orthogonal arrays.
subject: Matematik
title: The Existence of Resolvable Group Divisible Designs with Block Size Four and Large Groups

text: This paper investigates the uniqueness of representations for cographic matroids over finite fields. While binary cographic matroids are uniquely GF(2)-representable, we demonstrate this property fails for larger fields. We construct an infinite family of 3-connected cographic matroids, each possessing multiple projectively inequivalent GF(q)-representations for any prime power q ≥ 3. The construction hinges on a novel connection between gain graphs associated with Dowling geometries and the structure of specific frame matroid minors. By identifying a forbidden minor configuration for unique representability, we prove that for any q ≥ 3, there exists a cographic matroid M such that the number of distinct representations grows with the size of the underlying graph. This refutes a widely held belief about cographic uniqueness and highlights the subtle interplay between graph structure and the algebraic properties of its cycle matroid.
subject: Matematik
title: Dowling Geometries, Biased Graphs, and the Non-Uniqueness of Cographic Matroid Representations

text: We establish a combinatorial result akin to Roth's theorem within the algebraic structure provided by the homotopy groups of Morava K-theory spectra, π_*(K(n)). Treating these graded rings as combinatorial sets, we prove that any subset A ⊆ π_*(K(n)) with positive upper density must contain a non-trivial three-term arithmetic progression. The proof circumvents the lack of a traditional additive group structure by developing a theory of 'higher-order Fourier analysis' adapted to the formal group law associated with K(n). This involves defining Gowers-type uniformity norms that respect the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence filtration, providing a bridge between stable homotopy theory and modern additive combinatorics. The result implies strong structural constraints on large subsets of these fundamental objects in algebraic topology, demonstrating the utility of combinatorial techniques in seemingly unrelated mathematical domains.
subject: Matematik
title: An Analogue of Roth's Theorem in the Homotopy Groups of Morava K-Theory

text: We introduce and study the DP-chromatic number of digraphs, χ_DP(D), a correspondence-coloring analogue for directed graphs. This parameter is defined via a cover-based formulation that naturally extends the DP-coloring of undirected graphs. Our primary result proves that for any graph G, its DP-chromatic number χ_DP(G) is equal to the maximum DP-chromatic number over all its possible orientations, max_{D ∈ Orient(G)} χ_DP(D). This resolves a conjecture of Bernshteyn and provides a powerful new tool for analyzing graph choosability. As a corollary, we show that this equivalence implies a directed version of the list-coloring conjecture for planar graphs, stating that every strong orientation of a planar graph has a directed 5-list-coloring. The proof involves constructing intricate correspondence assignments on the directed cover that encode the constraints of arc directionality, linking the problem to the topology of the underlying graph.
subject: Matematik
title: DP-Coloring of Orientations and the Directed List-Coloring Conjecture

text: We investigate the polyhedral structure of the asymmetric traveling salesman problem (ATSP) restricted to the class of Halin graphs. We prove that for this graph class, the Chvátal-Gomory (CG) rank of the subtour elimination polytope P_ATSP is exactly 2. The lower bound is established by constructing a fractional vertex of the linear programming relaxation that cannot be separated by any rank-1 CG inequality, a construction which relies on the specific planar embedding of Halin graphs. The upper bound proof is constructive, providing a polynomial-time algorithm that generates a sequence of rank-2 cuts to separate any such fractional point. This result is one of the few instances where the exact CG rank is determined for a non-trivial relaxation of an NP-hard problem on an infinite, non-trivial graph family, offering insights into the limited power of general-purpose cutting plane methods for structured instances.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Chvátal-Gomory Rank of the Asymmetric Traveling Salesman Polytope on Halin Graphs

text: We study the homology of ordered configuration spaces of n particles on a finite simplicial complex X, denoted Conf_n(X). Extending classical results for manifolds, we establish a homological stability theorem for this generalized setting, proving that for a fixed homological degree k, the group H_k(Conf_n(X); G) with twisted coefficients G is independent of n for n sufficiently large. Our proof utilizes a spectral sequence argument arising from a poset of partial configurations, which is analyzed via discrete Morse theory on its nerve complex. As a combinatorial application, we leverage this stability result to derive a new topological proof of a high-dimensional Tverberg-type theorem for maps from a k-dimensional complex into ℝ^d, providing tight constraints on the intersection patterns of images of faces of a simplex under a continuous map, thereby generalizing the classical colorful Carathéodory theorem.
subject: Matematik
title: Homological Stability of Configuration Spaces on Simplicial Complexes and Higher-Order Tverberg Partitions

text: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) excel at learning from relational data but are susceptible to spurious correlations, leading to poor generalization under distributional shifts. We propose the Causal Graph Convolutional Network (CGCN), a novel architecture that integrates principles from structural causal models directly into the message-passing framework. CGCN aims to learn the underlying causal generative process by variationally inferring a latent causal graph G* that is invariant to interventions. The model is trained via a bilevel objective that combines a supervised link prediction loss with a causal regularizer derived from do-calculus. This regularizer encourages the learned representations to be robust to simulated interventions on the graph structure. We evaluate CGCN on synthetic benchmarks with known causal ground truths and on real-world biological interaction networks subjected to perturbations. Our results demonstrate that by disentangling causal dependencies from mere correlations, CGCN achieves state-of-the-art performance and significantly improved out-of-distribution generalization compared to prominent GNN baselines.
