subject: AI
title: Causal Graph Convolutions for Intervention-Robust Link Prediction

text: This paper establishes a novel connection between Bayesian uncertainty quantification and certified adversarial robustness. We introduce Bayesian Manifold Regularization (BMR), a framework for training deep neural networks with provable robustness guarantees. Our method models the posterior distribution over network parameters using stochastic gradient Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (SGHMC), enabling a full characterization of model uncertainty. Critically, we introduce a geometry-aware prior on the parameter posterior that penalizes high curvature of the decision boundary on the data manifold. This prior, implemented by regularizing the Frobenius norm of the Hessian of the log-likelihood, explicitly encourages the sampler to explore flatter regions of the loss landscape, which are intrinsically linked to improved robustness. The resulting Bayesian predictive posterior allows for the derivation of tight, uncertainty-aware robustness certificates. Empirically, BMR achieves state-of-the-art certified accuracy on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet against L-infinity norm-bounded adversaries, outperforming existing deterministic and randomized smoothing techniques.
subject: AI
title: Bayesian Manifold Regularization for Certified Adversarial Robustness

text: Adapting to non-stationary environments with sparse rewards remains a formidable challenge in reinforcement learning, often hindered by catastrophic forgetting and inefficient exploration. We propose Hypernetwork-Generated Intrinsic Rewards (HGIR), a meta-learning algorithm designed for rapid adaptation and sustained knowledge transfer in a continual learning setting. HGIR employs a hypernetwork, conditioned on a latent task embedding, to dynamically generate the parameters of an intrinsic reward module for a task-specific agent. The architecture is optimized through a nested loop: the inner loop maximizes a composite of extrinsic and intrinsic rewards via policy gradients, while the outer MAML-style loop updates the hypernetwork to improve adaptation speed across a sequence of tasks. This dynamic reward shaping mechanism enables the agent to create its own curriculum, facilitating exploration in novel tasks while retaining past knowledge. We demonstrate that HGIR significantly outperforms state-of-the-art meta-RL and continual learning baselines in complex, sparse-reward robotics domains.
subject: AI
title: Hypernetwork-Generated Intrinsic Rewards for Continual Meta-Reinforcement Learning

text: Standard differentially private federated learning (DP-FL) applies a uniform privacy budget across all clients, a strategy that is suboptimal under the statistical heterogeneity inherent in real-world data distributions (non-IID). We introduce AdaDP-FL, a framework that personalizes the privacy-utility trade-off by dynamically allocating the privacy budget. AdaDP-FL employs a server-side hyper-variational autoencoder to model the distribution of client model updates. During aggregation, the server allocates a tighter privacy budget (i.e., adds less noise) to clients whose updates are deemed more informative—identified as those lying in low-density regions of the latent distribution—while rigorously maintaining a global (ε, δ)-DP guarantee. This heterogeneity-aware noise injection is coupled with a personalized learning objective to further enhance model utility. We provide theoretical proofs of AdaDP-FL's privacy guarantees and demonstrate empirically on several benchmark non-IID datasets that it achieves superior personalized model accuracy and fairer performance distribution across clients compared to conventional DP-FedAvg.
subject: AI
title: Heterogeneity-Aware Adaptive Differential Privacy for Personalized Federated Learning

text: The latent spaces learned by Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) often lack a coherent geometric structure, which impedes interpretability and smooth sample generation. We introduce the Topologically-Regularized Autoencoder (TopoAE), a novel framework that explicitly enforces desired topological properties on the latent manifold. Leveraging tools from algebraic topology, specifically persistent homology, we formulate a differentiable loss term that quantifies the discrepancy between the topological invariants (i.e., Betti numbers) of the latent point cloud and a target topology. By minimizing this topological loss jointly with the Evidence Lower Bound (ELBO), TopoAE learns a latent representation with a pre-specified structure, such as being simply connected or having a specific number of holes. We show that this regularization leads to improved disentanglement, more meaningful interpolations, and enhanced robustness to adversarial attacks. Experiments on complex image datasets, including CelebA-HQ and synthetic manifold data, validate the efficacy of our approach in learning controllable and well-structured generative models.
subject: AI
title: Topological Latent Space Regularization for Controllable Generative Models

text: Variational Quantum Algorithms (VQAs) are a leading paradigm for near-term quantum computing, yet their performance is often hampered by challenging optimization landscapes and heuristic ansatz design. We propose the Graph-Informed Variational Quantum Eigensolver (GI-VQE), a hybrid quantum-classical framework that leverages Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to enhance the training of VQAs for combinatorial optimization problems. The core idea is to use a GNN, pre-trained on classical solutions to smaller problem instances, to predict near-optimal initial parameters for the quantum circuit ansatz based on the input problem's graph structure. This learned initialization strategy effectively navigates the optimizer away from barren plateaus and towards high-quality solutions. We demonstrate GI-VQE on the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) for the Max-Cut problem. Our results show a substantial reduction in the number of quantum-classical optimization iterations and a consistent improvement in approximation ratios compared to standard initialization techniques across a range of difficult graph instances.
subject: AI
title: Graph-Informed Variational Quantum Eigensolvers for Combinatorial Optimization

text: A critical failure mode of Large Language Models (LLMs) is their propensity to hallucinate, generating factually incorrect or logically inconsistent text. We introduce Logic-Infused Fine-Tuning (LIFT), a neuro-symbolic framework that grounds LLM outputs in formal logic. LIFT incorporates a differentiable logic tensor network that operates directly on the semantic embeddings of the LLM. This module evaluates the logical consistency of generated text against a knowledge base of first-order logic constraints, producing a continuous-valued satisfaction score. This score is then used as a regularization term in the fine-tuning objective, allowing for end-to-end training that jointly maximizes task performance and logical coherence. By penalizing logical fallacies in the latent space, LIFT teaches the model to adhere to symbolic rules without sacrificing its generative capabilities. Experiments on knowledge-intensive tasks like multi-hop question answering and abstractive summarization show that LIFT significantly reduces factual errors and improves logical consistency over strong retrieval-augmented and reinforcement learning baselines.
subject: AI
title: Differentiable Neuro-Symbolic Reasoning for Mitigating Hallucination in Large Language Models

text: Prevailing Unsupervised Domain Adaptation (UDA) methods focus on aligning marginal feature distributions between source and target domains, often overlooking the preservation of intrinsic data structure. This can lead to negative transfer when intra-domain relationships differ. We propose a novel approach, Gromov-Wasserstein Domain Adaptation (GWDA), which recasts UDA as a problem of aligning intra-domain relational structures. By minimizing the Gromov-Wasserstein (GW) distance, our method seeks a feature transformation that renders the metric space of target samples isometric to that of the source samples. We introduce a computationally efficient, entropy-regularized GW discrepancy term, solvable via the Sinkhorn algorithm, and integrate it into a deep adversarial learning pipeline. This structural alignment objective encourages the model to preserve crucial topological and geometric properties of the data manifold across domains. Extensive experiments on standard UDA benchmarks, including Office-31 and VisDA-C, demonstrate that GWDA establishes a new state-of-the-art, particularly in challenging adaptation scenarios with large domain shifts.
subject: AI
title: Gromov-Wasserstein Optimal Transport for Unsupervised Domain Adaptation with Structural Preservation

text: Contrastive self-supervised learning methods have achieved remarkable success by enforcing invariance to augmentations in a Euclidean feature space. However, their direct application to data with inherent non-Euclidean geometry is philosophically and practically flawed. We present Geodesic Contrastive Learning (GeoCL), a principled framework for representation learning on Riemannian manifolds. GeoCL makes two fundamental contributions: (1) it replaces the standard cosine similarity in the InfoNCE loss with a principled score based on the geodesic distance on the manifold, accurately reflecting the intrinsic geometry; and (2) it defines data augmentations as random walks in the tangent space at each data point, which are then projected back onto the manifold via the exponential map. This ensures that augmentations are geometrically faithful. We demonstrate the superiority of GeoCL on several tasks involving manifold-valued data, including symmetric positive-definite matrix analysis for brain connectomes and spherical data analysis for global climate patterns, outperforming both Euclidean baselines and existing manifold-aware learning methods.
subject: AI
title: Geodesic Contrastive Learning on Riemannian Manifolds

text: The Nash equilibrium concept, a cornerstone of multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL), can be computationally intractable and behaviorally restrictive. We argue that the correlated equilibrium (CE) offers a more general and often more efficient solution concept. We propose Correlated Equilibrium Fictitious Co-Play (CE-FCP), a novel MARL algorithm that converges to a CE in general-sum stochastic games. Our method operates within a centralized training with decentralized execution (CTDE) framework. A centralized critic, leveraging techniques from regret matching and fictitious play, learns a distribution over joint policies that constitutes a coarse correlated equilibrium. Decentralized actors are then trained to follow this correlated strategy. By explicitly learning the correlation device, CE-FCP enables sophisticated multi-agent coordination beyond the scope of independent learners. We provide theoretical convergence guarantees in specific game classes and show empirically that CE-FCP achieves superior or more stable team performance compared to state-of-the-art MARL algorithms in complex coordination and mixed-motive environments.
subject: AI
title: Learning Correlated Equilibria in General-Sum Markov Games via Fictitious Co-Play

text: This paper addresses the problem of constructing confidence intervals and hypothesis tests for individual parameters in high-dimensional graphical models under non-Gaussian assumptions. We extend the debiased Lasso framework to settings where the data are drawn from sub-exponential or other heavy-tailed distributions. The core of our methodology is the construction of a consistent estimator for the inverse precision matrix using a carefully regularized node-wise regression procedure, followed by a bias correction term. We establish non-asymptotic error bounds and prove that the resulting debiased estimator is asymptotically normal under significantly weaker distributional assumptions than previously required. Our theoretical analysis leverages modern concentration inequalities for sums of random variables without finite exponential moments. Extensive simulation studies confirm that our method maintains nominal coverage probabilities in challenging heavy-tailed scenarios where existing methods fail. The practical utility of our approach is demonstrated through the construction of a differential gene co-expression network from RNA-seq data, which is known to exhibit overdispersion.
subject: İstatistik
title: Debiased Lasso for Non-Gaussian Graphical Models with Provable Guarantees

text: Standard topic models, such as Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA), implicitly assume an exponential decay in topic popularity, which is inconsistent with the power-law phenomena (Zipf's Law) observed in real-world corpora. To address this, we propose a novel hierarchical Bayesian nonparametric model based on the Pitman-Yor Process (PYP). Our model uses a PYP prior over document-specific topic distributions, which are themselves drawn from a global PYP, effectively capturing the characteristic heavy-tailed distribution of word frequencies. The primary contribution is a scalable inference algorithm based on Stochastic Variational Inference (SVI), which enables the model's application to massive text datasets. We derive the evidence lower bound (ELBO) for our hierarchical PYP model and develop efficient, closed-form updates for the variational parameters. On several benchmark corpora, our method demonstrates superior predictive performance (lower perplexity) and extracts more coherent and interpretable topics compared to LDA and other nonparametric alternatives, particularly in its ability to model rare but significant themes.
subject: İstatistik
title: Hierarchical Pitman-Yor Processes for Scalable Topic Modeling with Power-Law Phenomena

text: We introduce a novel doubly robust estimator for the parameters of a marginal structural model in longitudinal settings with time-varying confounders affected by past treatment. The proposed method synthesizes inverse probability of treatment weighting (IPTW) and g-computation within a unified estimating equation framework, leveraging semiparametric theory. The estimator is doubly robust, remaining consistent if either the model for treatment assignment or the model for the outcome conditional on treatment and confounder history is correctly specified, but not necessarily both. We rigorously establish the asymptotic properties of the estimator, proving its consistency and asymptotic normality, and derive a consistent estimator for its variance. The finite-sample performance is evaluated through extensive Monte Carlo simulations, which demonstrate significant bias reduction and efficiency gains over singly robust methods, particularly under moderate to severe model misspecification. The methodology is applied to an electronic health record dataset to estimate the causal effect of a dynamic treatment regimen on patient outcomes.
subject: İstatistik
title: Doubly Robust Causal Inference for Longitudinal Data with Time-Varying Confounding

text: We extend classical Functional Principal Component Analysis (FPCA) to accommodate data where each observation is a function or curve residing on a non-Euclidean Riemannian manifold. Traditional FPCA relies on a Hilbert space structure, which is inadequate for manifold-valued data such as covariance matrices or shapes represented by landmarks. Our proposed method, Manifold FPCA (MFPCA), defines principal geodesics by minimizing a Fréchet-type variance on the manifold, which serves as a natural generalization of variance. We develop an iterative algorithm based on principal geodesic analysis and kernel smoothing to estimate these components and their associated scores. We establish the consistency of our estimators under suitable regularity conditions on the manifold and the stochastic process. The utility of MFPCA is demonstrated through the analysis of dynamic brain shape changes from longitudinal MRI scans, providing a powerful and interpretable tool for characterizing modes of variation in complex, geometrically constrained datasets where linear methods are inappropriate.
subject: İstatistik
title: Manifold-Valued Functional Principal Component Analysis for Dynamic Shape Data

text: While Topological Data Analysis (TDA) offers powerful descriptors of data shape through persistence diagrams, robust statistical inference on these objects remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces a novel framework for constructing confidence regions for persistence diagrams and performing two-sample hypothesis tests. We leverage a multi-scale kernel representation of persistence diagrams, which embeds them into a reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS), facilitating the application of classical statistical techniques. To ensure statistical stability and computational tractability, we integrate a subsampling bootstrap procedure with the kernel embedding. We establish the theoretical validity of our approach, proving that the constructed confidence sets achieve nominal coverage asymptotically under mild conditions. The method's efficacy is demonstrated on synthetic data, where it correctly distinguishes topological features from noise, and on a real-world application in materials science for differentiating microscopic structures of various alloys based on their persistent homology signatures.
subject: İstatistik
title: Statistical Inference on Persistence Diagrams via Multi-scale Kernel Methods and Subsampling

text: We propose a flexible and computationally efficient framework for modeling high-dimensional spatio-temporal data characterized by non-stationary covariance structures. Our approach integrates a dynamic factor model with a basis function expansion, where the factor loadings are themselves modeled as non-stationary Gaussian Processes (GPs). Non-stationarity is induced by allowing the GP's hyperparameters, such as length-scale and variance, to vary smoothly over the spatial domain, governed by a secondary, lower-dimensional GP. This hierarchical structure robustly captures complex, spatially-varying dependence patterns that are prevalent in environmental and climate science. We develop a scalable Bayesian inference scheme using a combination of the Kalman filter for the temporal dynamics and a variational inference algorithm for the spatial parameters, avoiding costly MCMC. The model's superior predictive performance and ability to capture evolving spatial dependencies are demonstrated on a large-scale satellite dataset of sea surface temperatures, outperforming standard stationary and locally stationary alternatives.
subject: İstatistik
title: Dynamic Spatio-Temporal Factor Models with Non-Stationary Gaussian Processes

text: This work addresses robust linear regression in high-dimensional settings where the error distribution may be heavy-tailed and asymmetric, a scenario where standard regularized estimators like the Lasso perform poorly. We introduce an adaptive Huber regression estimator where the robustness parameter, which delineates quadratic and linear loss regimes, is tuned in a data-driven fashion. Our primary contribution is a novel two-step procedure: an initial robust estimate of the scale parameter is obtained using a median-of-means approach, which then informs the optimal tuning of the Huber loss function for the full dataset. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis, establishing non-asymptotic oracle inequalities for the proposed estimator that nearly match the minimax optimal rates for sub-Gaussian errors, but under much weaker moment conditions on the noise. The practical efficacy of the adaptive procedure is confirmed through extensive simulations, showing marked improvements over non-adaptive robust methods and standard Lasso.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Huber Regression for High-Dimensional Data with Heavy-Tailed and Asymmetric Errors

text: We develop a scalable algorithm, Stochastic Gradient Riemannian Langevin Dynamics (SGRLD), for performing Bayesian inference on parameters constrained to lie on a Riemannian manifold. This is critical for models involving covariance matrices (Symmetric Positive Definite manifold) or directional data (sphere). Standard Euclidean MCMC methods are invalid in such settings. Our method leverages the natural geometry of the parameter space by defining the Langevin diffusion on the manifold and discretizing it using a retraction operator. Crucially, it employs stochastic gradients, making it suitable for large-scale datasets. We provide a rigorous non-asymptotic analysis of the algorithm's convergence, quantifying the error in terms of Wasserstein distance from the target posterior distribution, accounting for both discretization and stochastic gradient noise. The performance of SGRLD is evaluated on Bayesian inference for Gaussian graphical models and probabilistic principal component analysis, demonstrating significant improvements in sampling efficiency and accuracy over existing Euclidean and manifold-based samplers.
subject: İstatistik
title: Stochastic Gradient Riemannian Langevin Dynamics for Bayesian Inference on Manifolds

text: We propose the Deep Cox Mixture (DCM) model, a novel framework for survival analysis in the presence of competing risks and high-dimensional covariates. The model learns a flexible, data-driven representation of the covariate space using a deep neural network, which then parameterizes a finite mixture of cause-specific Cox proportional hazards models. This architecture allows for the identification of latent subgroups with distinct risk profiles for different event types, while simultaneously performing non-linear feature engineering and selection. Estimation is performed by maximizing a penalized partial likelihood via a stochastic gradient-based expectation-maximization algorithm, ensuring scalability to large sample sizes. We establish the model's utility in extensive simulation studies and apply it to a cancer genomics dataset to predict patient survival for multiple causes of death. The DCM outperforms standard cause-specific Cox models, random survival forests, and other deep learning-based survival methods in both discrimination (C-index) and calibration.
subject: İstatistik
title: Deep Cox Mixtures for Survival Analysis with Competing Risks

text: This paper extends spectral methods for community detection from traditional graphs to uniform hypergraphs, which can model multi-way relationships. We introduce a novel hypergraph Laplacian based on a non-linear projection of the adjacency tensor and analyze its spectral properties under a Hypergraph Stochastic Blockmodel (HSBM). Our primary contribution is a rigorous theoretical analysis demonstrating that, under specific conditions on model parameters, the eigenvectors of this Laplacian reveal the underlying community structure. We derive sharp, non-asymptotic bounds on the angular distance between the estimated and true community membership vectors using modern tensor concentration inequalities. The resulting algorithm is computationally efficient, relying on an eigenvector calculation of a matrix representation of the hypergraph, thereby avoiding direct tensor decomposition. We prove that our method achieves exact recovery of the communities down to the information-theoretic limit in certain regimes, validating its optimality. The algorithm's performance is demonstrated on synthetic and real-world co-authorship hypergraphs.
subject: İstatistik
title: Spectral Methods for Community Detection in Hypergraphs with Provable Guarantees

text: We report on the realization and manipulation of Majorana zero modes (MZMs) in a novel van der Waals heterostructure comprising a 2D ferromagnetic insulator (CrI₃) coupled to a proximitized s-wave superconductor (NbSe₂). By employing spin-polarized scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy, we identify delocalized, charge-neutral zero-bias conductance peaks at the ends of fabricated nanowires, consistent with the theoretical signatures of MZMs. The ferromagnetic proximity effect provides intrinsic spin-orbit coupling and Zeeman splitting, obviating the need for external magnetic fields. We further implement a T-junction geometry to perform rudimentary braiding operations, inferring non-Abelian statistics from the resulting transport modulations. Our analysis reveals that quasiparticle poisoning remains the dominant decoherence channel, with a measured characteristic time scale of approximately 50 ns. These results establish a promising material platform for scalable topological quantum computation and provide critical insights into the decoherence mechanisms limiting the fidelity of Majorana-based qubits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence and Braiding Statistics of Majorana Zero Modes in a Ferromagnet-Superconductor Heterostructure

text: The AdS/CFT correspondence posits a duality between gravitational theories in Anti-de Sitter space and conformal field theories on its boundary. We investigate this duality using a non-isometric tensor network model that captures key features of the bulk geometry, including a black hole singularity. By applying the Ryu-Takayanagi formula to our network, we compute the entanglement entropy of boundary subregions and demonstrate that it correctly reproduces the Page curve for an evaporating black hole, thereby resolving the information paradox within this toy model. Our framework extends the concept of entanglement-wedge reconstruction to non-isometric mappings, showing how bulk operators deep within the black hole interior can be represented by complex operators on the boundary. This suggests that the emergence of spacetime is intrinsically linked to the quantum error-correction properties of the holographic code, providing a concrete realization of the ER=EPR conjecture without requiring perfect isometry.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Bulk Reconstruction in a Non-Isometric Tensor Network Model of AdS/CFT

text: We propose a novel scheme for achieving universal, fault-tolerant quantum computation using Fibonacci anyons, whose braiding operations are dense in SU(2). Our approach circumvents the need for complex, static Hamiltonian engineering by employing a time-periodic (Floquet) drive to dynamically generate the required topological state in a system of coupled transmons. The protocol leverages engineered dissipation to stabilize the anyonic ground state manifold, creating a robust quantum memory. We numerically simulate the braiding of anyons by modulating local gate voltages and demonstrate the implementation of a universal gate set, including the crucial π/8 phase gate, with calculated process fidelities exceeding 99.8%. A comprehensive error analysis, incorporating both quasiparticle poisoning and braiding imperfections, establishes a fault-tolerance threshold of 1.2 x 10⁻⁴, suggesting that this dynamically stabilized anyonic system is a viable candidate for scalable quantum architectures.
subject: Kuantum
title: Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation with Fibonacci Anyons via a Periodically Driven Hamiltonian

text: The quantum spin liquid (QSL) is an exotic state of matter characterized by long-range entanglement and fractionalized excitations. We present high-resolution inelastic neutron scattering (INS) data on single crystals of Cs₂Cu₃SnF₁₂, a breathing kagome lattice antiferromagnet. Our measurements reveal a diffuse, continuous scattering spectrum, starkly contrasting with the sharp magnon modes expected in a magnetically ordered state. At low temperatures (T < 1K), the scattering intensity forms a distinct momentum-space structure that is quantitatively reproduced by a theoretical model of a U(1) Dirac spin liquid. This structure is interpreted as the direct experimental signature of a spinon Fermi surface. Muon spin rotation (μSR) experiments down to 20 mK confirm the absence of static magnetic order. The convergence of experimental evidence and theoretical modeling provides compelling support for the realization of a QSL ground state with emergent fermionic quasiparticles in this material.
subject: Kuantum
title: Direct Observation of Spinon Fermi Surface in a Quantum Spin Liquid Candidate Cs₂Cu₃SnF₁₂

text: Large-scale entangled states are a critical resource for quantum communication, computation, and metrology. Here, we demonstrate the heralded generation of Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) states of up to 12 photons. Our source is based on spontaneous parametric down-conversion in an array of periodically poled lithium niobate waveguides integrated on a reconfigurable silicon nitride photonic circuit. This architecture enables probabilistic, yet heralded, multiplexing of multiple six-pair photon sources with active feed-forward control. We perform full quantum state tomography on the generated states, confirming a 12-photon GHZ state with a state fidelity of 0.58 ± 0.02, significantly exceeding the threshold for genuine 12-partite entanglement. The high fidelity and scalable nature of our integrated platform represent a significant advance towards complex quantum information processing tasks and fundamental tests of quantum mechanics at the macroscopic scale.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heralded Generation of High-Fidelity 12-Photon GHZ States in a Reconfigurable Photonic Integrated Circuit

text: The Leggett-Garg inequality (LGI) provides a temporal analogue to Bell's theorem, testing the validity of macrorealism and non-invasive measurability. We report on a robust experimental violation of the LGI using a superconducting transmon circuit operated as a qutrit. By employing quantum non-demolition (QND) measurements and carefully designed null-result measurement protocols, we systematically address the 'clumsiness loophole,' which posits that the measurement process itself is responsible for perturbing the system's subsequent evolution. Our protocol utilizes the third energy level as a protected ancilla state to verify the non-invasiveness of measurements on the qubit subspace. We observe a violation of the LGI by 14 standard deviations (K₃ = 1.39 ± 0.028) while simultaneously bounding the maximum possible invasive disturbance. This result places stringent constraints on macrorealistic theories by demonstrating that quantum coherence can persist in a macroscopic system even under idealized QND measurements.
subject: Kuantum
title: Closing the Clumsiness Loophole in a Test of the Leggett-Garg Inequality with a Superconducting Qutrit

text: Determining the phase structure of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) at finite baryon density is a formidable challenge due to the notorious fermion sign problem in lattice QCD simulations. We present a novel, high-precision calculation of the chiral crossover line in the temperature-baryon chemical potential (T-μB) plane using the complex Langevin method on a 32³ × 8 lattice with 2+1 flavors of stout-smeared staggered fermions. By employing a dynamic stabilization gauge and a sophisticated adaptive step-size algorithm, we successfully suppress instabilities that previously hindered the complex Langevin evolution. Our results trace the pseudocritical temperature, Tc(μB), up to μB ≈ 400 MeV, finding a curvature κ = 0.0142(9) in the T-μB plane, consistent with recent experimental bounds from heavy-ion collisions. This work provides a crucial first-principles benchmark for effective models of dense nuclear matter and the search for the QCD critical point.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Perturbative Calculation of the QCD Chiral Crossover at Finite Baryon Density via Complex Langevin Simulation

text: Landauer's principle establishes a fundamental thermodynamic limit on the heat dissipated during information erasure. We investigate this principle in the quantum regime where system-reservoir coupling is strong and memory effects are non-negligible. Our experiment utilizes a single-electron transistor capacitively coupled to a tunable, high-impedance resonant circuit, which acts as a structured, non-Markovian thermal reservoir. By performing a bit-erasure protocol on the charge state of the quantum dot, we measure the dissipated heat using time-resolved calorimetry. Our results show a systematic deviation from the conventional kT ln(2) Landauer bound, which is only recovered in the weak-coupling, Markovian limit. We demonstrate that the dissipated heat depends explicitly on the spectral density of the reservoir and the protocol speed, a finding explained by a quantum stochastic thermodynamics framework. This work elucidates the intricate interplay between information, thermodynamics, and environmental memory in open quantum systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Landauer Principle in a Strongly Coupled, Non-Markovian Mesoscopic System

text: Many-body localization (MBL) describes the breakdown of thermalization in isolated, disordered quantum systems. While the MBL phase is well-understood for short-range interactions, its stability in the presence of long-range couplings remains an open question. We investigate the dynamics of a one-dimensional spin-1/2 chain with random fields and power-law decaying interactions (∝ 1/r^α) using large-scale time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (t-DMRG) simulations. For α = 2, we find a stable MBL phase characterized by the long-time logarithmic growth of entanglement entropy following a global quench. We analyze the transport properties and find evidence for subdiffusive, but not fully arrested, spin transport. This quasi-localized regime exhibits features distinct from both the fully ergodic and the short-range MBL phases, suggesting the existence of a novel dynamical phase where ergodicity is only partially broken by the interplay of disorder and long-range interactions.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Growth and Subdiffusive Transport in a Many-Body Localized System with 1/r² Interactions

text: Advanced interferometric gravitational wave detectors like LIGO are limited at high frequencies by quantum shot noise in the photon field. We report on the experimental implementation of a frequency-dependent squeezed vacuum source to achieve broadband quantum noise reduction. By reflecting a squeezed vacuum state from a high-finesse Fabry-Pérot filter cavity, we generate a squeezed state of light with a quadrature rotation frequency tuned to the detector's internal dynamics. When injected into a prototype interferometer, this technique simultaneously reduces quantum shot noise at high frequencies and radiation pressure noise at low frequencies. We demonstrate a broadband quantum noise suppression of 3.2 dB below the shot noise limit across a 5 kHz band, projecting to a significant enhancement in the event rate for high-frequency astrophysical sources like binary neutron star mergers. This technique is a crucial enabling technology for the next generation of gravitational wave observatories.
subject: Kuantum
title: Surpassing the Quantum Shot Noise Limit in a Broadband Gravitational Wave Detector with Frequency-Dependent Squeezing

text: This paper addresses an extremal problem for 3-uniform hypergraphs, specifically determining the Turan number for the Berge quadrilateral, denoted ex(n, B(C4)). While the corresponding graph problem is classical, the hypergraph variant has remained elusive. We introduce a novel framework that synergizes the hypergraph regularity lemma with a refined stability analysis. Our method involves defining a weighted flag algebra calculus to derive precise constraints on the local density of small subhypergraphs. By applying this calculus to the cluster hypergraph obtained from a regularity partition, we establish that any B(C4)-free 3-uniform hypergraph on n vertices with a near-extremal number of edges must be structurally close to a complete tripartite hypergraph. A subsequent absorption argument allows us to handle imperfections, ultimately proving that for sufficiently large n, ex(n, B(C4)) = |T3(n)|, where T3(n) is the number of edges in the n-vertex 3-partite Turan hypergraph. This resolves a longstanding conjecture of Győri and Lemons.
subject: Matematik
title: The Exact Turan Number of the 3-Uniform Berge Quadrilateral

text: The quantitative bounds for multicolor van der Waerden numbers, W(k; r), remain a central challenge in Ramsey theory. This work presents a significant improvement for the three-color case, W(3; k). We develop a pseudo-random construction for coloring integers that avoids k-term monochromatic arithmetic progressions (k-APs). The coloring is derived from values of quadratic characters in finite fields F_q, where q is carefully chosen relative to k. The analysis relies on Weil's bounds on character sums to demonstrate the strong AP-avoidance properties of the coloring. For the upper bound, we employ a container-based argument, showing that the family of sets containing a k-AP has a concise representation. We establish an upper bound for W(3; k) of the form 2^(k^(c log k)), a substantial reduction from the previous tower-type bounds. Our structural results also characterize colorings that are nearly free of monochromatic k-APs, linking them to polynomial structures.
subject: Matematik
title: Improved Bounds for van der Waerden Numbers via Pseudo-Random Colorings

text: The study of Kronecker coefficients g(λ, μ, ν), which arise in the representation theory of the symmetric group, is hampered by the lack of a positive combinatorial formula. This paper introduces a geometric framework to analyze these coefficients for specific families of partitions. We define a class of 'Kronecker polytopes' P(λ, μ, ν) whose integer point count corresponds to g(λ, μ, ν) when λ and μ are hook shapes. Using techniques from toric geometry and discrete Morse theory, we analyze the facial structure and Ehrhart polynomials of these polytopes. Our main result is a manifestly positive, piecewise quasi-polynomial formula for these coefficients. This formula is computationally effective, allowing us to prove that for this restricted class, the non-vanishing of g(λ, μ, ν) can be decided in polynomial time. This provides evidence against the conjectured #P-hardness of the general Kronecker coefficient problem and opens a new geometric avenue for its investigation.
subject: Matematik
title: A Polyhedral Approach to Kronecker Coefficients for Hook Partitions

text: We investigate the phase transition phenomenon in a non-uniform random hypergraph model. Consider the process where d-uniform hyperedges are added to an n-vertex set, with the probability of selecting a d-set being proportional to the product of weights assigned to its vertices. This preferential attachment mechanism models heterogeneous network formation. Using a carefully constructed continuous-time branching process that approximates the evolution of component sizes, we analyze the emergence of the giant component. Our analysis, leveraging differential equation methods, precisely determines the sharp threshold for this phase transition. We demonstrate that the critical point and the size of the giant component depend explicitly on the moments of the vertex weight distribution. Furthermore, we characterize the critical window, showing that its width is intrinsically linked to the variance of the weights, a significant departure from the classical Erdős-Rényi model. The transition is shown to be continuous for a broad class of distributions.
subject: Matematik
title: The Phase Transition in Weighted Random Hypergraphs

text: This paper provides a complete asymptotic expansion for the number of rooted q-angulated planar maps, M_q(n), with n faces. While the leading-order asymptotics are known via bijective methods and generating functions, obtaining lower-order terms has been a significant challenge. Our approach is based on a refined singularity analysis of the underlying functional equation satisfied by the generating function M_q(z). By leveraging techniques from the theory of D-finite functions and applying a transfer theorem in a stretched variable regime near the dominant singularity, we are able to systematically extract all terms in the asymptotic series. We prove that M_q(n) ~ C_q * n^(-5/2) * ρ_q^(-n) * (1 + Σ_{k>=1} a_k * n^(-k)), where the constants C_q, ρ_q, and a_k are explicitly determined in terms of the Gamma function and algebraic numbers related to q. This detailed expansion provides a highly accurate tool for studying the statistical properties of large random maps.
subject: Matematik
title: A Complete Asymptotic Expansion for Rooted q-Angulated Planar Maps

text: We present a structural decomposition theorem for the class of dyadic matroids—matroids representable over the field of rational numbers with denominators restricted to powers of two. This class is fundamental as it contains all regular matroids but is strictly larger. Our main result, analogous to Seymour's celebrated decomposition of regular matroids, states that any 3-connected dyadic matroid can be constructed via k-sums from graphic matroids, cographic matroids, the exceptional matroid R10, and a finite set of additional minor-minimal non-regular dyadic matroids which we explicitly characterize. The proof is inductive and relies on a detailed analysis of splitter theorems for dyadic separations. As an algorithmic consequence, this structural characterization yields a new fixed-parameter tractable algorithm for the weighted matroid intersection problem when both matroids are dyadic, parameterized by the number of non-graphic/cographic components in their decompositions. This work substantially advances the understanding of non-regular matroid classes.
subject: Matematik
title: A Decomposition Theorem for Dyadic Matroids

text: We establish a new quantitative bound for the four-term progression Szemerédi theorem in vector spaces over finite fields. Let A be a subset of F_p^n with no non-trivial arithmetic progressions of length four. The prevailing bounds on the size of A are of the form |A| << N(log N)^(-c), where N=p^n. We improve this by integrating the Croot-Lev-Pach polynomial method into the Gowers uniformity norm framework. Specifically, we show that if the U^3-norm of the balanced function of A is large, we can find a low-degree polynomial that vanishes on a structured subset of the spectrum. This structure is then used to perform an efficient density increment step. Iterating this argument, we prove that |A| <= N * exp(-c(log N)^(1/4)) for an absolute constant c>0, assuming p is a small prime. This constitutes a significant step towards the conjectured polynomial bounds and showcases a powerful synergy between Fourier analysis and algebraic geometry.
subject: Matematik
title: Quantitative Bounds for Szemerédi's Theorem in F_p^n via Polynomial Methods

text: The existence of a large set of disjoint Steiner triple systems of order v, denoted LS(v), is a classical problem in combinatorial design theory. An LS(v) is a partition of all 3-subsets of a v-set into v-2 Steiner triple systems, which is only possible if v ≡ 1, 3 (mod 6). While existence has been established for specific congruence classes, the general problem remained open. We resolve the existence conjecture for all sufficiently large v. Our proof uses the method of randomized greedy absorption. First, we apply the Rödl nibble to iteratively pack a majority of the 3-subsets into disjoint systems, leaving a sparse hypergraph of uncovered triples. The core of our contribution is a novel, deterministically constructed absorbing structure that can assimilate any possible leftover hypergraph, provided it satisfies certain regularity conditions. We show that the nibble process produces such a leftover with high probability, completing the construction. This powerful hybrid approach advances the state-of-the-art for asymptotic existence proofs.
subject: Matematik
title: The Asymptotic Existence of Large Sets of Disjoint Steiner Triple Systems

text: We present a new, explicit construction of infinite families of d-regular bipartite Ramanujan graphs, which are optimal expander graphs. Previous constructions, notably by Lubotzky, Phillips, and Sarnak, and by Margulis, relied on deep results from analytic number theory, specifically the Ramanujan-Petersson conjecture over number fields. Our approach is purely algebraic, using the arithmetic of quaternion algebras over the rational function field F_q(t). For any prime power d-1=q, we define a graph whose vertices are certain maximal orders in a quaternion algebra and whose adjacency is defined by norm relations. The proof that this graph is Ramanujan relies on the Weil conjectures for curves over finite fields (a theorem), which serves as the function field analogue of the Ramanujan conjecture. This method yields explicit, polynomial-time constructible families of d-regular bipartite Ramanujan graphs, offering a more accessible framework and highlighting the fruitful interplay between graph theory and algebraic geometry.
subject: Matematik
title: An Explicit Construction of Ramanujan Graphs from Quaternion Algebras over Function Fields

text: Multi-dimensional Sturmian words, also known as Arnoux-Rauzy words, are canonical extensions of classical Sturmian words to higher dimensions, characterized by minimal complexity. This paper investigates the fine combinatorial structure of these words through their connection to subtractive continued fraction algorithms. We introduce a new characterization of two-dimensional Arnoux-Rauzy words based on a 'uniform balance' property for rectangular factors, generalizing the classical balance property of Sturmian words. We prove that a two-dimensional word over a three-letter alphabet is Arnoux-Rauzy if and only if it is uniformly balanced and its factor complexity satisfies P(m,n) = mn+m+n. The proof involves analyzing the geometric action of the associated substitutions on a plane, showing that the balance property is equivalent to the underlying dynamical system being a toral rotation. This result provides a purely combinatorial criterion for identifying these fundamental objects and deepens the connection between symbolic dynamics and Diophantine approximation.
subject: Matematik
title: A Uniform Balance Criterion for Multi-Dimensional Sturmian Words

text: Reconstructing the deep phylogeny of Metazoa is confounded by systematic biases and conflicting signals among gene trees. We address this challenge using a comprehensive phylogenomic dataset of 1,200 orthologous loci from 150 taxa, explicitly modeling sources of discordance. By comparing concatenated supermatrix methods with multispecies coalescent-based approaches, we demonstrate that pervasive incomplete lineage sorting (ILS), particularly during the Ediacaran diversification, is a principal driver of topological incongruence. Our coalescent-based species tree estimations provide robust support for a Ctenophora-sister phylogeny, resolving a long-standing controversy. We further quantify ILS across key nodes, revealing that a significant portion of the genome retains ancestral polymorphisms that predate the divergence of major phyla. This study highlights the inadequacy of concatenation in rapid radiation scenarios and establishes a new statistical framework for accommodating deep coalescent events, thereby refining our understanding of early animal evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Conflict and Incomplete Lineage Sorting in the Deep Radiation of Metazoa

text: The Red Queen hypothesis posits that antagonistic coevolution drives perpetual adaptation. We examined the genomic underpinnings of this dynamic in a real-time experimental evolution study of Pseudomonas aeruginosa and its lytic phage, DMS3. Utilizing time-series metagenomics and functional assays, we tracked the reciprocal selective sweeps of resistance and counter-resistance alleles. Our results reveal that the primary bacterial defense, the CRISPR-Cas system, is frequently subverted by phage-encoded anti-CRISPR (Acr) proteins. Critically, we observed extensive horizontal gene transfer (HGT) of mobile genetic elements carrying novel Acr cassettes between phage lineages, dramatically accelerating the circumvention of bacterial immunity. This reticulate evolutionary pathway, where adaptation is acquired via HGT rather than solely through de novo mutation, fundamentally alters coevolutionary trajectories. These findings demonstrate that the mobilome acts as a shared arsenal, intensifying the coevolutionary arms race and maintaining high levels of genetic polymorphism in both host and parasite populations.
subject: Evrim
title: Antagonistic Coevolution Mediated by Horizontal Gene Transfer in a Phage-Bacteria System

text: Hybridization can facilitate rapid adaptation by introducing pre-adapted alleles across species boundaries. We investigated this phenomenon in a passerine hybrid zone shifting in response to climate change. We generated a high-density SNP dataset for 500 individuals across the cline and employed genomic cline analysis and local ancestry inference to identify loci with patterns of directional introgression. Our analysis revealed several genomic regions with significant excess ancestry from the warm-adapted parental species, which have introgressed deep into the range of the cold-adapted species. These regions contain genes associated with thermoregulatory performance, metabolic efficiency, and photoperiodic responses (e.g., AvBD-7, CLOCK). The allelic frequencies at these introgressed loci show strong correlations with longitudinal climate variables, suggesting they are under positive selection. This study provides a clear genomic signature of adaptive introgression as a key mechanism enabling a species to rapidly respond to anthropogenic climate change, highlighting the creative evolutionary potential of hybridization.
subject: Evrim
title: Adaptive Introgression of Climate-Associated Loci in a Migratory Avian Hybrid Zone

text: Phenotypic evolution is not unconstrained; it is channeled by the underlying architecture of development. We quantified this principle by analyzing the morphospace occupation and evolvability of the tetrapod limb. Using high-resolution 3D geometric morphometrics on a dataset of 350 vertebrate species and integrating it with comparative transcriptomics of limb development, we identified conserved gene regulatory networks (GRNs) involving key transcription factors like Shh, HoxD, and Fgf8. Our results show that observed morphological variation occupies only a small, highly structured subspace of the theoretically possible morphospace. Evolutionary simulations constrained by the empirical GRN topology accurately recapitulate this pattern, whereas unconstrained models do not. These findings indicate that pleiotropic interactions and epistatic buffering within these core developmental GRNs create deep evolutionary furrows, canalizing phenotypic outcomes. This inherent bias in the production of variation explains parallel evolution patterns and the limited disparity of limb morphology across vast evolutionary timescales.
subject: Evrim
title: Developmental Constraints and the Canalization of Morphological Evolution in the Vertebrate Limb

text: The relative contributions of climate change and anthropogenic pressure to late Pleistocene megafauna extinctions remain intensely debated. We address this using paleogenomic approaches on a time-series of 75 woolly mammoth (Mammuthus primigenius) specimens spanning the last 50,000 years. By analyzing low-coverage whole-genome data, we reconstructed demographic histories using pairwise sequentially Markovian coalescent (PSMC) modeling. Our results reveal a long-term decline in effective population size (Ne) initiated long before human arrival, correlating with interglacial warming periods. However, the terminal decline was uniquely characterized by a rapid increase in runs of homozygosity (ROH) and an accumulation of deleterious mutations, hallmarks of a sudden population crash. This genomic evidence of severe inbreeding coincides precisely with the expansion of Clovis paleo-human populations in North America. We conclude that while climate change created long-term vulnerability, anthropogenic pressure was the proximate driver that delivered the final coup de grâce to this iconic species.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Reconstruction of Pleistocene Megafauna Demography Reveals Extinction Dynamics

text: Eusociality represents a major evolutionary transition, yet its molecular underpinnings remain elusive. To identify common genomic architecture associated with this complex social structure, we performed a comprehensive comparative genomic analysis across 20 independently evolved eusocial and 15 solitary Hymenopteran lineages. Following rigorous orthology inference and gene family evolution modeling, we identified statistically significant signatures of convergence. Specifically, eusocial lineages consistently exhibit accelerated evolution and expansion of gene families related to chemosensation (olfactory and gustatory receptors), metabolism (cytochrome P450s), and conserved venom proteins, while showing contraction in certain immune-related gene families. Furthermore, promoter regions of genes involved in caste differentiation, such as vitellogenin and juvenile hormone pathways, show convergent patterns of regulatory element evolution. This multi-layered genomic convergence suggests that a predictable suite of molecular toolkits is repeatedly co-opted to facilitate the evolution of reproductive division of labor and complex social integration.
subject: Evrim
title: Convergent Genomic Signatures in the Evolution of Eusociality Across Hymenoptera

text: The neutral theory of molecular evolution often assumes a uniform and random mutation process. We challenge this assumption by analyzing whole-genome de novo mutations from multi-generational pedigrees of Mus musculus. Our high-fidelity sequencing approach identified thousands of spontaneous germline mutations, revealing significant local sequence context dependencies and regional heterogeneity in mutational spectra. We found that CpG sites in transcriptionally active regions exhibit a mutation rate an order of magnitude higher than the genome-wide average, driven by methylation-associated deamination. Furthermore, we observed a strong correlation between replication timing and the ratio of G:C to A:T substitutions, indicating a systematic bias linked to the cell cycle. When these empirically derived, heterogeneous mutation models are incorporated into phylogenetic analyses, they significantly alter estimations of divergence times and dN/dS ratios. Our results demonstrate that non-random mutational processes are a powerful, often overlooked, force in shaping genome architecture and molecular evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Mutational Bias in Germline Genomes Challenges Assumptions of Neutral Molecular Evolution

text: The prevalence of sexual reproduction despite its twofold cost remains a central paradox in evolutionary biology. The Red Queen Hypothesis (RQH) posits that sex is advantageous in coevolutionary arms races with parasites. We conducted a long-term experimental evolution study using the facultatively sexual rotifer Brachionus plicatilis and its sterilizing fungal parasite. We maintained sympatric and allopatric host-parasite populations under controlled conditions, manipulating the opportunity for sexual reproduction. As predicted by the RQH, host populations coevolving with parasites maintained significantly higher rates of sexual reproduction compared to parasite-free controls. Time-shift infection assays demonstrated that parasites were more virulent on contemporary hosts than on past or future hosts, consistent with negative frequency-dependent selection. Furthermore, genomic analysis revealed rapid allelic turnover at host immune loci in sexual populations, a dynamic absent in asexual lineages which invariably went extinct. This study provides direct empirical validation that antagonistic coevolution is a potent selective force maintaining sexual reproduction.
subject: Evrim
title: Experimental Test of the Red Queen Hypothesis: Coevolution with Parasites Drives the Maintenance of Sex

text: The Baldwin effect, whereby a plastic phenotype becomes genetically encoded, provides a compelling mechanism for adaptive evolution, yet its molecular basis is poorly understood. We investigated this process using an experimental population of Drosophila melanogaster selected for a novel heat-shock-induced wing morphology. Initially, the trait was purely plastic and dependent on Hsp90 buffering. Over 30 generations of selection, the trait became constitutively expressed even in the absence of the thermal stimulus, demonstrating genetic assimilation. Through quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping and functional genomics, we pinpointed the causal locus to a cryptic variant within a distal enhancer of the wing-patterning gene vestigial (vg). This variant creates a novel binding site for a heat-inducible transcription factor. In the ancestral genetic background, its effect is buffered, but under thermal stress and subsequent selection, it becomes the target of strong positive selection, eventually fixing a canalized phenotype. This provides a direct molecular link between phenotypic plasticity, cryptic genetic variation, and genetic assimilation.
subject: Evrim
title: Genetic Assimilation of Phenotypic Plasticity via Cryptic Variation in a cis-Regulatory Element

text: This paper introduces a novel framework for zero-shot causal inference by integrating deep generative models with symbolic logic programming. Our Neuro-Symbolic Causal Generative Model (NS-CGM) learns to construct and reason over structural causal models (SCMs) from high-dimensional observational data without interventional examples. The architecture employs a variational autoencoder to map raw data into a discretized latent space, where a differentiable logic tensor network subsequently infers causal relationships by optimizing a joint objective function that combines probabilistic reconstruction loss with a measure of logical consistency against a background knowledge base. We demonstrate that by enforcing symbolic constraints on the generative process, NS-CGM can extrapolate to unseen interventional distributions, effectively performing zero-shot causal discovery. Experiments on synthetic and semi-synthetic benchmarks show a significant improvement in structural accuracy and counterfactual prediction over purely neural or traditional constraint-based methods, especially in low-data regimes.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic Generative Models for Zero-Shot Causal Inference

text: The prevalence of non-IID (non-independently and identically distributed) data presents a primary obstacle to effective federated learning (FL). We propose Federated Hypernetwork-Modulated Meta-Learning (FedHML), a novel algorithm that addresses client drift and personalization in heterogeneous environments. FedHML leverages a central hypernetwork to generate the parameters of personalized client models, conditioned on low-dimensional client embeddings learned during training. This approach eschews traditional model averaging, instead meta-learning an initialization that rapidly adapts to a client's local data distribution with a few gradient steps. The hypernetwork architecture implicitly regularizes the personalization process, mitigating catastrophic forgetting of global knowledge while promoting specialized performance. We provide theoretical convergence guarantees and empirically demonstrate that FedHML significantly outperforms state-of-the-art FL methods like FedAvg, Per-FedAvg, and FedFomo on benchmark datasets with pathological non-IID partitions, achieving faster convergence and higher final accuracy across clients.
subject: AI
title: Federated Meta-Learning on Non-IID Data via Hypernetwork-Modulated Personalization

text: Graph neural networks (GNNs) typically operate under the assumption of a Euclidean data space, limiting their applicability to data with inherent non-Euclidean geometry. This work introduces Geodesic-Aware Graph Attention Networks (GeoGAT), a novel GNN architecture designed for dynamic, manifold-valued graph data. GeoGAT models spatio-temporal dependencies by propagating information along geodesics of the underlying Riemannian manifold. We replace standard linear transformations and dot-product attention with operations grounded in Riemannian geometry, such as logarithmic maps for local feature linearization and exponential maps for aggregation. The attention mechanism computes compatibility scores based on geodesic distances, ensuring the model respects the intrinsic curvature of the data space. We evaluate GeoGAT on dynamic brain connectome analysis using fMRI data modeled on the manifold of Symmetric Positive Definite (SPD) matrices. Our model demonstrates superior performance in predicting neurodegenerative disease progression compared to Euclidean GNNs and other manifold-aware methods.
subject: AI
title: Geodesic-Aware Graph Neural Networks for Dynamic Manifold-Valued Data

text: Decentralized learning systems are vulnerable to Byzantine attacks, where malicious nodes can arbitrarily corrupt model updates, leading to convergence failure. We introduce Byzantine-Robust Decentralized Gradient Aggregation (BRDGA), a framework that ensures resilience without a trusted central server. BRDGA integrates three key components: (1) low-rank gradient quantization to bound the influence of any single node, (2) a peer-to-peer verifiable delay function (VDF) to enforce computational costs on generating updates, thus thwarting cheap Sybil attacks, and (3) a robust aggregation rule based on geometric median filtering in the quantized space. This combination provably guarantees convergence in the presence of a constant fraction of Byzantine adversaries under standard assumptions on the loss function's convexity. Our empirical evaluation on large-scale image classification tasks demonstrates that BRDGA maintains high accuracy under severe poisoning and model replacement attacks, significantly outperforming existing robust aggregation methods like Krum and Trimmed Mean.
subject: AI
title: Byzantine-Robust Decentralized Learning with Quantized Gradient Aggregation and Verifiable Delay Functions

text: Learning disentangled representations, where individual latent units correspond to distinct generative factors of data, remains a challenging unsupervised learning problem. This paper presents the Information-Theoretic Disentanglement Network (InfoD-Net), a self-supervised framework that achieves state-of-the-art disentanglement without requiring generative factor labels. InfoD-Net augments a standard variational autoencoder (VAE) architecture with a structured information bottleneck. We introduce a novel objective function that maximizes the mutual information between latent variables and augmented views of the input while simultaneously minimizing the total correlation among the latent dimensions. This pressure encourages each latent unit to encode a compact, independent, and informative aspect of the data. Unlike prior methods that rely on heuristic regularizers, our approach is grounded in information theory. We demonstrate qualitatively and quantitatively on dSprites, MPI3D, and CelebA datasets that InfoD-Net learns more interpretable and modular representations than β-VAE and other leading methods.
subject: AI
title: Self-Supervised Disentanglement of Latent Representations using Information-Theoretic Bottlenecks

text: Recent work has conceptualized deep neural networks as discretizations of continuous-time dynamical systems, or Neural Ordinary Differential Equations (NODEs). We extend this paradigm to the stochastic domain by proposing Equivariant Neural Stochastic Differential Equations (EN-SDEs). Our framework models the feature transformation process as a solution to an SDE, allowing for the construction of infinitely deep architectures with trainable drift and diffusion terms. This continuous-depth formulation enables the precise enforcement of group equivariances by constraining the vector fields of the SDE to be equivariant under the action of a given symmetry group. We develop a novel reversible and memory-efficient SDE solver that preserves these symmetries throughout the integration process. This approach not only provides a principled way to build deep equivariant models for data like point clouds and molecular structures but also offers inherent robustness to adversarial perturbations due to the stochastic nature of the forward pass.
subject: AI
title: Stochastic Differential Equation Solvers for Training Infinitely Deep Equivariant Networks

text: Fusing information from disparate modalities remains a key challenge in multi-modal machine learning. We introduce the Holographic Transformer (HoloFormer), an architecture that leverages principles from Vector Symbolic Architectures (VSAs) to create unified, modality-invariant representations. HoloFormer employs holographic reduced representations (HRRs) to bind token embeddings from different sources (e.g., text, vision, audio) into a single high-dimensional vector space. The core operation is circular convolution, a computationally efficient binding operator that preserves semantic similarity. This pre-fused holographic representation is then processed by a standard transformer encoder, which learns context-aware cross-modal relationships within a unified space. This approach contrasts with late-fusion or cross-attention mechanisms that maintain separate modality streams. We show that HoloFormer achieves superior performance on VQA, text-to-video retrieval, and audio-visual event localization benchmarks while being more parameter-efficient than state-of-the-art multi-modal transformers.
subject: AI
title: Holographic Reduced Representations in Multi-Modal Transformer Architectures

text: While Large Language Models (LLMs) demonstrate remarkable capabilities, they often produce confident yet incorrect responses, lacking reliable uncertainty quantification. We address this critical gap by introducing Conformalized Quantile Regression for Language Models (CTRL). CTRL is a post-hoc calibration method that transforms the raw output logits of any pre-trained LLM into statistically valid prediction intervals. By applying the principles of conformal prediction to a quantile regression head trained on the LLM's internal representations, CTRL generates token-level uncertainty bounds that are guaranteed to achieve a user-specified marginal coverage rate. This non-parametric approach makes no distributional assumptions about the model's errors. We demonstrate that CTRL provides well-calibrated and adaptive uncertainty estimates for a variety of tasks, including machine translation and abstractive summarization. These rigorous uncertainty bounds enable safer model deployment by allowing for reliable selective prediction and active learning querying.
subject: AI
title: Calibrating Uncertainty in Large Language Models via Conformalized Quantile Regression

text: Sim-to-real transfer in reinforcement learning is often hampered by the 'reality gap,' where discrepancies between simulation and the real world degrade policy performance. We present Adversarial Dynamics Matching for Deformable Objects (ADePT), a novel policy optimization framework for complex manipulation tasks. ADePT employs a two-player, minimax game: a policy network is trained via proximal policy optimization (PPO) to perform a task, while a trajectory-level discriminator is trained to distinguish between simulated and real-world rollouts. The policy is incentivized not only by the task reward but also by an adversarial loss that encourages it to generate trajectories that are indistinguishable from reality. This implicitly forces the policy to be robust to unmodeled physical dynamics and sensor noise. We demonstrate successful zero-shot transfer of a learned cloth-folding policy from a MuJoCo simulation to a physical robotic arm, a task notoriously difficult for traditional domain randomization techniques.
subject: AI
title: Adversarial Policy Optimization for Sim-to-Real Transfer in Deformable Object Manipulation

text: Deep generative models like Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) learn to approximate complex, high-dimensional data distributions. However, understanding the geometric and topological structure of the learned data manifold remains an open challenge. This work leverages tools from Topological Data Analysis (TDA) to provide a novel, quantitative lens for inspecting these models. We employ persistent homology to compute the topological signatures (Betti numbers) of the output manifold generated by sampling from the latent space. By analyzing the persistence diagrams, we can identify and quantify pathological behaviors such as mode collapse, where the generated manifold has a simpler topology than the true data manifold. We propose a new metric, the Topological Fidelity Score (TFS), based on the Wasserstein distance between persistence diagrams of real and generated data. Our analysis reveals previously unobserved structural flaws in popular GAN architectures and demonstrates that TFS is a more sensitive indicator of generative quality than traditional metrics like FID or Inception Score.
subject: AI
title: Topological Data Analysis for Probing the Intrinsic Dimensionality of Deep Generative Models

text: The maintenance of pluripotency is governed by a precise network of transcription factors and epigenetic regulators, including long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs). Here, we identify LncPluri-1, a novel nuclear-retained lncRNA highly expressed in embryonic stem cells. Through a combination of Chromatin Isolation by RNA Purification (ChIRP-seq) and RNA immunoprecipitation (RIP-qPCR), we demonstrate that LncPluri-1 directly binds to SUZ12, a core component of the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2). This interaction is essential for guiding PRC2 to specific developmental gene promoters, thereby mediating their H3K27 trimethylation and subsequent transcriptional silencing. Genetic depletion of LncPluri-1 via CRISPR-Cas9 results in aberrant expression of lineage-specifying genes and triggers premature differentiation, even under pluripotency-maintaining conditions. Our findings reveal that LncPluri-1 functions as a critical epigenetic scaffold, ensuring the spatiotemporal fidelity of PRC2 activity to safeguard the pluripotent state. This work elucidates a fundamental mechanism of lncRNA-mediated epigenetic regulation in stem cell biology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: LncPluri-1: A Conserved Long Non-coding RNA Orchestrates Pluripotency by Modulating Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 Activity

text: The cellular response to DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) involves the rapid assembly of large, dynamic protein assemblies known as repair foci. The biophysical principles governing their formation remain enigmatic. We demonstrate that the key repair factor 53BP1 undergoes liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) to form biomolecular condensates at sites of DNA damage. Using super-resolution microscopy and in vitro reconstitution assays, we show that multivalent interactions mediated by the intrinsically disordered region (IDR) and oligomerization domain of 53BP1 drive its condensation. These liquid-like droplets effectively concentrate downstream repair factors, including RIF1 and PTIP, while excluding others. Mutagenesis of key residues within the IDR that disrupt phase separation abolishes foci formation in vivo, compromises non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), and sensitizes cells to ionizing radiation. Our results establish that LLPS is a fundamental organizing principle for the spatiotemporal orchestration of the DNA damage response, providing a new paradigm for understanding genome maintenance.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of 53BP1 is a Prerequisite for Robust Double-Strand Break Repair Foci Assembly

text: Human telomerase, a ribonucleoprotein (RNP) enzyme essential for maintaining genome integrity, is a premier target for anti-cancer therapeutics. Its large size and conformational flexibility have hindered high-resolution structural determination. Here, we present the cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of the catalytically active human telomerase holoenzyme bound to the TEL patch of TPP1, a key shelterin component, at a near-atomic resolution of 3.1 Å. The structure reveals an intricate network of interactions and a previously uncharacterized interface between the CR4/5 domain of the telomerase RNA component (hTR) and the OB-fold domain of TPP1. This specific RNA-protein contact is critical for proper enzyme positioning at the chromosome terminus and enhances processivity. Functional assays with structure-guided mutations confirm that disrupting this interface abrogates telomerase recruitment and catalytic activity. This structural blueprint provides unprecedented mechanistic insights into telomere maintenance and establishes a new framework for the rational design of telomerase inhibitors.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Human Telomerase Holoenzyme Bound to Shelterin Component TPP1 Reveals a Novel RNA-Protein Interface

text: Aberrant epigenetic modifications, particularly DNA hypermethylation, are implicated in the transcriptional dysregulation observed in Huntington's disease (HD). The brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) gene, critical for neuronal survival, is a key target of this silencing. We developed a CRISPR-based epigenome editing tool, fusing a nuclease-dead Cas9 (dCas9) to the catalytic domain of the DNA demethylase TET1, to specifically reverse this pathogenic mark. Using adeno-associated virus (AAV) delivery into the striatum of R6/2 HD model mice, we targeted the hypermethylated BDNF promoter IV. Bisulfite sequencing confirmed precise and efficient demethylation, which was accompanied by the restoration of active H3K4me3 histone marks and a significant recovery of BDNF transcription. Crucially, this targeted epigenetic reprogramming rescued synaptic plasticity deficits, as measured by long-term potentiation (LTP), and ameliorated motor coordination impairments. Our findings demonstrate the therapeutic potential of precision epigenome editing for reversing pathogenic epigenetic memory in neurodegenerative disorders.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Targeted Demethylation of the BDNF Promoter by dCas9-Tet1 Rescues Synaptic Deficits in a Huntington's Disease Model

text: The selective removal of damaged mitochondria via mitophagy is a critical cellular quality control process, primarily regulated by the PINK1 kinase and PARKIN E3 ligase. Here we identify an alternative, PARKIN-independent branch of this pathway orchestrated by the outer mitochondrial membrane E3 ligase, MITOL (MARCH5). Upon mitochondrial depolarization, PINK1 phosphorylates MITOL, enhancing its E3 ligase activity. We performed quantitative ubiquitin proteomics and identified the voltage-dependent anion channel 1 (VDAC1) as a primary MITOL substrate. MITOL-mediated K63-linked polyubiquitination of VDAC1 serves as a binding platform for autophagy receptor NDP52, directly linking damaged mitochondria to the autophagosome. Depletion of MITOL, but not PARKIN, impairs NDP52 recruitment and mitochondrial clearance in PARKIN-deficient cells. This work uncovers a novel signaling axis where MITOL acts downstream of PINK1 to initiate mitophagy, providing a fail-safe mechanism that ensures robust mitochondrial quality control and cellular homeostasis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The E3 Ubiquitin Ligase MITOL Regulates Mitophagy by Mediating PINK1-Dependent Ubiquitination of VDAC1

text: The ribosome is often considered a homogenous cellular machine, yet evidence for its heterogeneity is emerging. We investigated ribosomal composition changes under oxidative stress using quantitative mass spectrometry-based proteomics of affinity-purified ribosomes (Ribo-proteomics). Our data reveal a dynamic, stoichiometric switch between the ribosomal protein paralogues RPL10A and RPL10. Stress conditions induce the selective incorporation of RPL10 into translating ribosomes, displacing RPL10A. Ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) demonstrated that these RPL10-containing 'specialized' ribosomes exhibit altered translational efficiencies, showing a strong preference for mRNAs containing Internal Ribosome Entry Sites (IRES), such as those encoding pro-survival factors like XIAP. In vitro reconstitution experiments confirm that RPL10-containing ribosomes possess an intrinsically higher affinity for IRES elements. This paralogue switching represents a sophisticated regulatory layer of translational control, enabling cells to rapidly reprogram their proteome by customizing the translational machinery itself to selectively translate critical mRNAs during stress.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Stress-Induced Ribosomal Protein Paralogue Switching Creates Specialized Ribosomes for Preferential Translation

text: Cells sense and respond to the mechanical properties of their environment through mechanotransduction, a process central to development and disease. The Hippo pathway effectors YAP/TAZ are key mediators of this process, yet the molecular mechanisms linking extracellular matrix (ECM) stiffness to their activity are poorly defined. Using a combination of traction force microscopy and FRET-based biosensors, we demonstrate that Integrin-Linked Kinase (ILK) functions as a core mechanosensor at focal adhesions. On stiff substrates, ILK is activated and phosphorylates filamin A, increasing its binding affinity for actin filaments. This enhances the 'molecular clutch' engagement between integrins and the actin cytoskeleton, leading to increased intracellular tension. This tension directly inhibits the LATS1/2 kinases, thereby promoting the dephosphorylation and nuclear translocation of YAP. Inhibition of ILK kinase activity decouples YAP/TAZ localization from ECM stiffness, establishing ILK as a central transducer of mechanical signals.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrin-Linked Kinase Acts as a Molecular Clutch to Mediate Extracellular Matrix Stiffness-Dependent YAP Nuclear Translocation

text: Post-translational modifications (PTMs) provide a complex regulatory code that fine-tunes the activity of signaling proteins. The oncogenic BRAF V600E kinase is a key driver in melanoma, yet its regulation by PTM crosstalk is not fully understood. Using high-resolution mass spectrometry, we identified a novel, conserved SUMOylation site on BRAF V600E within its kinase domain. We demonstrate that this site is adjacent to a regulatory phosphorylation site and that these two PTMs are mutually exclusive, forming a 'phospho-SUMO switch'. Phosphorylation inhibits SUMOylation, while conditions promoting dephosphorylation enhance it. Critically, SUMOylation of BRAF V600E promotes its homodimerization, a key step for paradoxical activation of the MAPK pathway and for acquiring resistance to RAF inhibitors. Enforcing a SUMO-deficient state via site-directed mutagenesis reduces BRAF dimerization and attenuates downstream ERK signaling. This discovery reveals a sophisticated PTM switch that modulates BRAF oncogenic activity, presenting a potential therapeutic vulnerability.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Crosstalk between SUMOylation and Phosphorylation on Oncogenic BRAF V600E Regulates Its Dimerization and Signaling Output
