text: The tumor microenvironment (TME) in glioblastoma (GBM) is a complex ecosystem that fosters immunosuppression and therapeutic resistance. To deconstruct this complexity, we performed single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) on 28 patient-derived GBM samples. Our analysis computationally resolved over 15 distinct cell states, including neoplastic cells and diverse immune and stromal populations. We identified a specific subset of tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs), characterized by high expression of SPP1 (Osteopontin), which forms a signaling hub within the TME. Ligand-receptor interaction mapping revealed that this SPP1+ TAM population communicates extensively with endothelial cells via integrin signaling to promote angiogenesis, and with malignant cells to enhance invasion. Furthermore, these TAMs exhibit a profoundly immunosuppressive phenotype, upregulating checkpoints like VISTA. This high-resolution cellular atlas of the GBM TME pinpoints the SPP1+ myeloid niche as a critical driver of malignancy and a promising target for combinatorial immunotherapies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: High-Dimensional Single-Cell Transcriptomic Atlas of the Glioblastoma Microenvironment Identifies a Pro-Tumorigenic Myeloid Niche

text: The activation of brown adipose tissue (BAT) thermogenesis is a promising strategy to combat metabolic disease. While transcriptional control of this process is well-studied, the role of post-transcriptional regulation by microRNAs remains less clear. Here, we show that the oncogenic miR-17~92 cluster is a potent negative regulator of thermogenesis. Adipocyte-specific knockout of this cluster in mice results in enhanced energy expenditure, browning of white adipose tissue, and profound resistance to diet-induced obesity. Using a combination of Argonaute-CLIP and 3' UTR luciferase assays, we identified the deubiquitinase USP13 as a direct target of miR-19b, a key member of the cluster. USP13 normally acts to deubiquitinate and destabilize PRDM16, the master transcriptional co-regulator of the thermogenic program. By repressing USP13, miR-19b effectively destabilizes PRDM16. Our findings reveal a novel miRNA-deubiquitinase axis that fine-tunes metabolic homeostasis and energy balance.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The miR-17~92 Cluster Post-transcriptionally Regulates Adipocyte Thermogenesis by Targeting the Deubiquitinase USP13

text: We investigate modifications to the thermodynamics of Schwarzschild black holes arising from non-perturbative quantum gravitational effects within a Loop Quantum Gravity (LQG) framework. By quantizing the spacetime geometry, we derive a polymer-corrected metric that resolves the classical central singularity. We then analyze the behavior of a massless scalar field propagating on this quantum-corrected background. The resulting Hawking radiation spectrum exhibits a discrete, Planck-scale signature and a modified temperature that halts the evaporation process, yielding a stable Planck-mass remnant. Our analysis employs a modified WKB approximation suitable for the deformed dispersion relations inherent to the polymer quantization scheme. The calculated Bekenstein-Hawking entropy is shown to acquire logarithmic corrections consistent with other quantum gravity approaches. These findings suggest a potential resolution to the black hole information paradox by demonstrating that information is not lost but is encoded in the correlations within the remnant and the modified outgoing radiation.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Perturbative Corrections to Hawking Radiation via a Loop Quantum Gravity Framework

text: The interplay of strong spin-orbit coupling and electron correlation in pyrochlore iridates presents a fertile ground for discovering exotic topological phases. This study combines first-principles density functional theory (DFT+U) calculations with high-resolution angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) to investigate the electronic structure of Y2Ir2O7. Our theoretical analysis predicts a transition from a topologically trivial magnetic insulator to a Weyl semimetal phase driven by uniaxial strain, which breaks essential crystalline symmetries while preserving time-reversal symmetry breaking through the all-in-all-out magnetic order. The calculations reveal pairs of Weyl nodes with opposite chirality located near the Fermi level. These theoretical predictions are corroborated by our ARPES measurements on strained thin films, which clearly resolve the characteristic surface Fermi arcs connecting the projected bulk Weyl nodes. This work establishes strained pyrochlore iridates as a robust platform for realizing Weyl fermions and exploring their associated anomalous transport phenomena.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergent Weyl Semimetals from Frustrated Pyrochlore Iridates: A DFT and ARPES Study

text: We present novel constraints on primordial non-Gaussianity, specifically the local-type trispectrum parameter τNL, derived from an analysis of Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) B-mode polarization data from the BICEP/Keck Array and Planck satellite. While the CMB temperature bispectrum has stringently constrained the fNL parameter, higher-order correlators like the trispectrum provide an independent and potentially more sensitive probe of multi-field inflation models. Our methodology employs an optimal estimator formalism applied to the B-mode power spectrum and cross-correlations with E-modes, which are sensitive to the non-Gaussian modulation of the tensor-to-scalar ratio. We perform a comprehensive analysis incorporating foreground mitigation and instrumental systematics, marginalizing over cosmological parameters. The resulting constraint, τNL = -5.8 ± 6.5 × 10^3 (68% CL), significantly improves upon previous limits from temperature data alone. This result disfavors a class of curvaton and quasi-single field inflation scenarios, demonstrating the increasing power of CMB polarization for fundamental cosmology.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraining Primordial Non-Gaussianity using Cosmic Microwave Background B-mode Polarization Anisotropies

text: We investigate the dynamics of a system relaxing toward equilibrium under long-range interactions, using the Hamiltonian Mean Field (HMF) model as a paradigmatic example. Through extensive N-body simulations and analysis of the Vlasov equation, we demonstrate the existence of dynamical phase transitions occurring out of equilibrium. These transitions are distinct from thermodynamic phase transitions and manifest as sharp changes in macroscopic observables during the system's evolution from an unstable initial state. Specifically, we identify a critical threshold in initial magnetization that separates two distinct relaxation pathways, characterized by divergent timescales for reaching the quasistationary state (QSS). We analyze the system's trajectory in phase space and compute the maximal Lyapunov exponent, revealing a non-monotonic dependence on energy that signals a complex interplay between chaotic mixing and collective behavior. Our findings challenge the conventional understanding of relaxation processes and provide a theoretical framework for identifying similar dynamical transitions in astrophysical and plasma systems.
subject: Fizik
title: Dynamical Phase Transitions in Non-Equilibrium Systems with Long-Range Interactions

text: We report the experimental realization of a programmable quantum simulator using a two-dimensional array of over 200 individually trapped 87Rb atoms, coherently coupled to Rydberg states. The van der Waals interactions between Rydberg atoms naturally implement an Ising-type spin Hamiltonian with tunable interaction strength and geometry, accessible via precise laser addressing and frequency modulation. We demonstrate high-fidelity preparation of complex ground states of frustrated antiferromagnetic Hamiltonians on triangular and kagome lattice geometries, which are intractable for classical computers. Furthermore, by performing quantum quenches, we study the subsequent non-equilibrium dynamics, observing the propagation of spin correlations and characterizing the growth of entanglement entropy. The system exhibits signatures of prethermalization and many-body localization for specific parameter regimes. This platform provides unprecedented control over quantum many-body systems, paving the way for explorations of quantum phase transitions, topological order, and complex non-equilibrium phenomena with certifiable quantum advantage.
subject: Fizik
title: Coherent Control of Rydberg Atom Arrays for Quantum Simulation of Spin Hamiltonians

text: We present a suite of general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic (GRMHD) simulations of asymmetric binary neutron star (BNS) mergers, focusing on the morphology and composition of the resulting ejecta. Our simulations utilize a mass ratio q=0.85, incorporating a realistic equation of state and neutrino transport via a leakage scheme. We find that the asymmetry significantly enhances the dynamical ejecta, particularly in the tidal tail, leading to a robust, lanthanide-poor component with high electron fraction (Ye > 0.25). This 'blue' kilonova precursor is launched primarily within the orbital plane. In contrast, post-merger disk winds and viscously driven ejecta contribute a more isotropic, lanthanide-rich 'red' component on longer timescales. By calculating synthetic light curves and spectra using time-dependent radiative transfer models, we show that merger asymmetry produces a distinct observational signature: a viewing-angle-dependent, multi-component kilonova. Our results provide a crucial theoretical framework for interpreting future multi-messenger observations of gravitational wave events like GW170817.
subject: Fizik
title: Numerical Relativity Simulations of Kilonova Ejecta from Asymmetric Binary Neutron Star Mergers

text: We formulate a continuum hydrodynamic theory for a two-dimensional active nematic liquid crystal to model the collective dynamics of the actomyosin cytoskeleton. The model couples a generalized Navier-Stokes equation with the dynamics of a nematic order parameter tensor, driven by an active stress proportional to local alignment. Linear stability analysis reveals a generic instability of the ordered state towards spontaneous flow, driven by the active stress. Numerical simulations of the full nonlinear equations demonstrate the emergence of a dynamically steady state of active turbulence, characterized by the continuous creation, motion, and annihilation of ±1/2 topological defects (disclinations). We analyze the defect kinetics and find that their statistical properties differ significantly from those in passive or thermally driven systems, with +1/2 defects exhibiting comet-like motility. The emergent flow fields and correlation functions from our model show remarkable quantitative agreement with in-vitro experiments on reconstituted cytoskeletal films, validating the framework's predictive power.
subject: Fizik
title: Topological Defects and Active Nematics: A Hydrodynamic Model for Cytoskeletal Dynamics

text: The Leggett-Garg inequality (LGI) serves as a temporal analog to Bell's inequality, testing the validity of macroscopic realism and non-invasive measurability. We present a robust experimental violation of the LGI using a superconducting transmon qubit subjected to weak, continuous microwave measurement. This approach allows us to track the quantum trajectories of the system's state without fully collapsing the wavefunction at each time step, thus minimally disturbing the system as required by the LGI's premises. By correlating measurement outcomes at different times, we construct the LGI correlation functions and demonstrate a statistically significant violation of S_3 ≤ 1, obtaining a value of S_3 = 1.38 ± 0.04. Our protocol carefully characterizes and mitigates the effects of measurement back-action and environmental decoherence, which can mimic a violation. This experiment probes the quantum-classical boundary in a macroscopic superconducting circuit and places stringent bounds on alternative macrorealist theories.
subject: Fizik
title: Experimental Test of Leggett-Garg Inequalities using a Superconducting Transmon Qubit with Weak Continuous Measurement

text: Grand Unification Theories (GUTs) predict the ultimate instability of the proton, providing a rare experimental window into physics at scales far beyond the reach of colliders. This paper reports on a search for proton decay via the channel p+ -> e+ π0 using 450 kiloton-years of data from the Super-Kamiokande water Cherenkov detector. We have developed an advanced event reconstruction algorithm that utilizes deep convolutional neural networks to improve the selection efficiency and background rejection for this signature decay mode, which is favored by minimal SU(5) models. No significant excess of events over the expected atmospheric neutrino background was observed. We consequently set a new lower limit on the partial lifetime of the proton of τ(p+ -> e+ π0) > 2.4 × 10^34 years at 90% confidence level. This result places the most stringent constraints to date on non-supersymmetric SU(5) and SO(10) GUTs, severely constraining their parameter space and motivating further exploration of supersymmetric or alternative unification scenarios.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Grand Unification Theories through Precision Measurements of Proton Decay Channels

text: This paper addresses the long-standing challenge of automating Schenkerian analysis directly from audio recordings. Traditional computational approaches often rely on symbolic data, failing to capture the nuances of performance that inform structural hearing. We propose a novel hierarchical attentional network that ingests multi-resolution Constant-Q Transform (CQT) spectrograms to learn a direct mapping from the acoustic surface to underlying contrapuntal structures. The model employs a multi-scale architecture to process features at the note, motive, and phrase levels, with a self-attention mechanism designed to identify long-range dependencies characteristic of melodic fluency (Zug) and bass arpeggiation (Bassbrechung). Trained on a curated dataset of annotated recordings from the common-practice era, our system demonstrates a significant capacity to identify middleground prolongations and approximate the fundamental structure (Ursatz). The results suggest that deep learning models can internalize complex, theory-driven listening strategies, offering a powerful new tool for computational musicology and large-scale structural analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hierarchical Attentional Network for Automated Schenkerian Analysis from Audio Signals

text: Conventional graph-based models of neo-Riemannian theory, while powerful, often fail to capture the higher-order geometric and topological properties of chromatic harmony. This research employs Topological Data Analysis (TDA), specifically persistent homology, to investigate the harmonic state-space of late-Romantic orchestral works. By converting chroma features from audio into high-dimensional point clouds, we construct a series of Vietoris-Rips simplicial complexes. The persistence diagrams derived from these complexes reveal topological invariants (Betti numbers) that characterize the connectivity and structure of the harmonic language. Our analysis of excerpts from Wagner and Liszt identifies persistent 1-cycles (loops) corresponding to recurring, non-functional triadic transformations and higher-dimensional voids that correlate with large-scale formal divisions. This TDA-based approach provides a quantitative, coordinate-free method for characterizing harmonic adventurousness and formal architecture, extending the Tonnetz beyond a simple planar graph into a complex, dynamically evolving manifold.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Data Analysis of Neo-Riemannian Harmonic Spaces in Late-Romantic Orchestral Music

text: The analysis of microtonal music presents a significant challenge for standard audio feature extraction methods, such as chroma vectors, which are predicated on 12-tone equal temperament. This paper introduces a novel method, Spectral Basis Projection (SBP), for deriving musically relevant pitch-content descriptors from audio of works employing alternative tuning systems. The SBP method constructs a custom projection basis from the theoretical frequency ratios of a given microtonal scale (e.g., 31-EDO, just intonation systems) and applies it to high-resolution STFT frames. We evaluate the SBP features on tasks of interval classification and modality identification using a synthetic dataset and recordings of works by Harry Partch and Ben Johnston. Results demonstrate a substantial improvement in accuracy over MFCCs and standard chroma features, which exhibit severe aliasing and quantization errors. The SBP framework offers a flexible and extensible tool for the computational analysis of a vast and often-neglected body of contemporary and world music.
subject: Müzik
title: Spectral Basis Projection Models for the Analysis of Microtonal Compositions

text: Automatic transcription and analysis of polyphonic music requires accurate separation of individual melodic lines, a task complicated by timbral similarity and voice crossing. This study proposes a deep learning model for contrapuntal voice separation that integrates music-theoretic constraints directly into the learning process. We employ a U-Net architecture, which excels at image-to-image tasks, to map a magnitude spectrogram to a set of voice-specific spectrogram masks. Crucially, we introduce a novel regularization term in the loss function that penalizes outputs violating principles of parsimonious voice leading, derived from Fuxian counterpoint rules regarding melodic step-motion and interval resolution. Tested on the Bach Chorales and a dataset of keyboard fugues, our musically-constrained model significantly outperforms baseline source separation architectures in both signal-to-distortion ratio (SDR) and, more importantly, in producing continuous, coherent, and musically plausible melodic lines. This hybrid approach demonstrates the power of combining data-driven learning with domain-specific theoretical knowledge.
subject: Müzik
title: Constrained Polyphonic Voice Separation using a Deep U-Net with Music-Theoretic Regularization

text: This research investigates the emergence of high-level formal structures from unlabeled audio data using self-supervised learning. We posit that innate temporal regularities and recurrences in music provide a sufficient supervisory signal for a model to learn features corresponding to music-theoretic formal functions. We adapt a temporal contrastive learning framework, training a deep convolutional network to identify whether two audio segments, extracted from a large corpus of classical music, are temporally adjacent or distant. The resulting learned embeddings are then evaluated on a downstream task of structural segmentation by applying k-means clustering. Without any exposure to formal labels, the system’s segment boundaries show a high degree of correlation with expert annotations of sonata and rondo forms (e.g., exposition, development, recapitulation). The findings suggest that large-scale formal archetypes have a robust acoustic fingerprint rooted in self-similarity, discoverable through unsupervised, data-driven methods, thus bridging the gap between acoustic representation and abstract musical structure.
subject: Müzik
title: Learning Musical Form: A Self-Supervised Approach to Structural Segmentation using Temporal Contrastive Learning

text: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) can synthesize musical instrument sounds with remarkable realism, yet the internal organization of their latent spaces remains poorly understood. This paper presents a systematic psychoacoustic and musicological investigation into the latent space of a pre-trained, high-fidelity timbre-synthesis GAN. By systematically sampling vectors along principal axes and geodesic paths within the latent space and generating the corresponding audio, we map its topology. We employ multidimensional scaling (MDS) on listener-rated perceptual dissimilarity data and correlate the resulting dimensions with a suite of psychoacoustic features (e.g., spectral centroid, roughness, attack time, inharmonicity). Our results reveal that the GAN has organized its latent space into perceptually coherent, continuous manifolds corresponding to abstract timbral qualities. This provides not only a deeper understanding of the generative model but also a framework for perceptually-grounded timbral manipulation and interpolation, moving beyond simple instrument imitation to principled sound design.
subject: Müzik
title: Probing the Latent Space of Timbre: A Multidimensional Scaling Analysis of a Generative Adversarial Network

text: The perception of hypermeter—metrical structures larger than the notated measure—is fundamental to musical experience, yet its automatic detection from audio remains an open problem. Existing autocorrelation-based methods are often brittle and sensitive to tempo fluctuations. We propose a novel approach based on multi-resolution analysis using the Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT). An onset detection function is first computed from the audio signal to represent its rhythmic surface. We then apply a CWT to this function using a Morlet wavelet, generating a scalogram that reveals periodicities across a continuous range of temporal scales. Peaks in the scalogram's energy integrated over specific scale ranges correspond to dominant periodicities at tactus, measure, and hyper-measure levels. Evaluated on a corpus of Beethoven piano sonatas, our CWT-based method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in identifying duple and quadruple hypermetric structures, proving more robust to expressive variations in tempo and dynamics.
subject: Müzik
title: Hypermeter Detection via Multi-Resolution Analysis with Continuous Wavelet Transforms

text: The analysis of post-tonal music, grounded in pitch-class set theory, has traditionally been a manual, labor-intensive process. This paper introduces a framework for automated structural analysis of atonal music using Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). We model musical excerpts as dynamic graphs where pitch-classes are nodes and edges are weighted by theoretical relationships, such as interval-class content and adjacency. A GNN is then trained on these graph representations to perform formal section classification and to identify recurring transformational networks. By learning to convolve filters over the graph structure, the model effectively learns to recognize transposed and inverted set-classes (T_n/I_n operations) and identifies abstract relationships like the Z-relation. Applied to works from the Second Viennese School, our GNN model achieves high accuracy in segmenting compositions based on underlying set-class usage, providing a powerful computational lens for exploring the complex symmetries and organizational principles of atonal music.
subject: Müzik
title: Graph Neural Networks for the Analysis of Pitch-Class Set Transformations in Atonal Music

text: Expressive performance practice involves nuanced deviations from the nominal score in dimensions of timing, dynamics, and articulation. This study presents a hierarchical Bayesian model to infer latent expressive intentions from acoustic evidence. The model posits that observed performance features (e.g., inter-onset intervals, RMS energy) are generated from a set of latent variables representing structural interpretation (e.g., phrasing boundaries, metrical accentuation) and performer-specific style. Using Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) for inference on a dataset of multiple performances of Chopin’s Preludes, aligned to a symbolic score, we can de-mix the contributions of shared structural interpretations from idiosyncratic performer choices. The inferred parameters provide a rich, quantitative characterization of performance practice, revealing consensus on phrase shaping while highlighting individual differences in rubato and dynamic range. This probabilistic approach offers a principled method for modeling the complex mapping from musical structure to expressive performance.
subject: Müzik
title: A Hierarchical Bayesian Model for Inferring Expressive Performance Strategies from Score-Aligned Audio

text: Drawing inspiration from advancements in natural language processing, this paper recasts the analysis of tonal harmony as a sequence modeling problem, solvable with a Transformer architecture. We investigate the capacity of the self-attention mechanism to learn the long-range dependencies and hierarchical relationships inherent in common-practice harmonic syntax. A model is trained on a large corpus of tokenized chord sequences to predict upcoming harmonies. We then perform a detailed analysis of the learned attention maps, which visualize the inter-chordal relationships the model prioritizes for its predictions. The results show that the attention heads learn to focus on structurally significant, non-adjacent chords, effectively identifying tonic-dominant axes, prolongational spans, and the syntactic antecedents of applied chords. This demonstrates that Transformer networks can autonomously discover core principles of music theory, such as harmonic function and voice-leading schemata, offering a data-driven complement to traditional Schenkerian and Riemannian theories of tonal structure.
subject: Müzik
title: Modeling Tonal Harmonic Syntax with Self-Attention: A Transformer-Based Approach

text: This paper investigates the Turan density, π(F), of r-uniform hypergraphs F constructed via specific expansion operations. We focus on the k-expansion of a graph G, denoted G^(k), where each edge of G is replaced by a complete r-graph K_r^r on a distinct set of k new vertices. We establish new upper bounds on π(G^(k)) by employing the flag algebra calculus combined with a refined stability analysis. Our results show that for certain classes of bipartite graphs G, the Turan density exhibits non-trivial behavior that deviates from the predictions of classical hypergraph Turan problems for complete hypergraphs. We introduce a probabilistic recoloring argument to demonstrate that our bounds are asymptotically tight for specific parameter ranges. This work bridges the gap between graph and hypergraph extremal problems, providing a framework for analyzing the density of locally constrained hypergraph structures and resolving a conjecture by Mubayi on the density of expanded triangles.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Turan Density of Expanded Hypergraph Configurations

text: We study the induced Ramsey number R_ind(G, H), defined as the minimum number of vertices n such that any graph on n vertices contains either G as an induced subgraph or H as an induced subgraph. This paper focuses on the case where G = kK_t and H = lK_s, disjoint unions of cliques. Previous results provided exponential upper bounds derived from the standard Erdős-Szekeres theorem. By developing a novel probabilistic construction argument combined with a concentration inequality for dependent random variables, we establish polynomial upper bounds for R_ind(kK_t, lK_s) for all fixed t, s. Our proof involves analyzing the distribution of monochromatic cliques in random colorings of the vertices of a host graph with a carefully controlled clique structure. This result significantly improves existing bounds and sheds light on the structural properties of graphs that avoid large independent sets of cliques.
subject: Matematik
title: Induced Ramsey Numbers for Disjoint Unions of Cliques

text: We present a novel geometric interpretation for certain coefficients in the Schur expansion of modified Macdonald polynomials H_λ(X; q, t). By relating these polynomials to the equivariant cohomology of flag varieties, we express the coefficients as intersection numbers on a specifically constructed moduli space of stable maps. This framework bypasses purely combinatorial techniques based on fillings and inversions, providing a new algebro-geometric proof of the Macdonald positivity conjecture for a significant subclass of partitions. Our method involves lifting the combinatorial action of Hecke algebra operators to geometric correspondences between Schubert cycles. This approach not only recovers known results but also offers a pathway to understanding the intricate (q, t)-symmetries inherent in the Macdonald basis by connecting them to the topological properties of the underlying geometric spaces, particularly their Poincaré duality and Thom classes.
subject: Matematik
title: A Schubert Calculus Approach to Macdonald Polynomial Coefficients

text: We analyze the Linial-Meshulam model Y_d(n, p) of random d-dimensional simplicial complexes. This paper establishes a sharp threshold for the appearance of a d-dimensional spanning acyclic subcomplex, defined as a minimal d-complex that is (d-1)-connected. Using a refined second moment method and tools from algebraic topology, specifically discrete Morse theory, we prove that this threshold occurs at p = c_d log(n)/n^(d-1) for a specific constant c_d. This critical probability coincides with the threshold for the vanishing of the (d-1)-th rational homology group, H_{d-1}(Y; Q). Our result constitutes a high-dimensional analogue of the classical result for the appearance of a spanning tree in the G(n,p) random graph model, and resolves a question regarding the coupling of topological and combinatorial connectivity in random simplicial complexes.
subject: Matematik
title: Threshold Phenomena for Spanning Acyclic Subcomplexes in Random Simplicial Complexes

text: We investigate the asymptotic enumeration of permutations avoiding layered patterns of the form π = 12...(k-1) ⊕ σ, where σ is a non-layered indecomposable permutation and ⊕ denotes the direct sum. By employing singularity analysis on the corresponding generating functions, derived from a structural decomposition of the permutation automata, we establish precise asymptotic formulas for several infinite families of Wilf-equivalence classes. Our results confirm a conjecture by Albert and Atkinson regarding the dominant exponential growth rate, showing it is determined by the smallest real root of the automaton's characteristic polynomial. The methodology involves analytic continuation and transfer matrix methods applied to the symbolic description of these classes, providing a robust framework for determining the asymptotic behavior of pattern-avoiding permutations with specific decomposable structures and contributing to the classification of their growth rates.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotics of Wilf-Equivalence Classes for Layered Permutation Patterns

text: The classical necklace splitting theorem guarantees a fair partition using a minimal number of cuts. We extend this result to necklaces with multiple types of beads and a larger group of symmetries. We formulate the problem in the language of G-equivariant maps from a configuration space (a product of spheres) to a representation sphere, where G is a product of cyclic groups. Using equivariant obstruction theory and calculations of Stiefel-Whitney classes in the associated vector bundle, we establish necessary and sufficient conditions for the existence of k-fair partitions for m measures. This provides a significant generalization of Alon's original combinatorial result, connecting it to the topology of moment-angle complexes. Our work demonstrates that the existence of such partitions is determined by the vanishing of a specific characteristic class, which can be computed combinatorially from the parameters of the problem.
subject: Matematik
title: Generalized Necklace Splitting via Equivariant Obstruction Theory

text: This paper examines the persistence of arithmetic structures in sparse subsets of integers. We introduce a notion of a pseudorandom measure that satisfies certain linear forms in configuration-type conditions, generalizing Roth's theorem to a sparse setting. By adapting the density increment argument and utilizing higher-order Fourier analysis, specifically the Gowers uniformity norms U^k, we demonstrate that any subset A of a dense pseudorandom set with positive relative density must contain k-term arithmetic progressions. Our main theorem quantifies the dependence of the required density on the pseudorandomness parameters of the host set, providing a bridge between Szemerédi-type results and the Green-Tao theorem for primes. The proof relies on a decomposition theorem that splits an arbitrary function into a structured part, which is uniform of high Gowers norm, and a pseudorandom part.
subject: Matematik
title: Higher-Order Fourier Uniformity in Sparse Pseudorandom Sets

text: Rota's conjecture posits a finite set of excluded minors for the class of matroids representable over a given finite field. We focus on the class of unimodular matroids (representable over both GF(2) and GF(3)). This work provides a complete structural characterization of unimodular matroids that exclude the uniform matroid U_{3,6} as a minor. By leveraging Seymour's decomposition theory for regular matroids and introducing a new k-sum operation adapted for non-binary matroids, we prove that any such matroid can be constructed via clique-sums from graphic matroids, cographic matroids, and a finite list of 12 sporadic examples. This provides a significant step towards understanding the structure of more general minor-closed classes and illustrates the power of decomposition theorems in classifying complex combinatorial objects. The proof is constructive and relies on analyzing connectivity properties within the matroid.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Structure of Unimodular Matroids with an Excluded Minor

text: The existence of resolvable balanced incomplete block designs (RBIBDs) is a central problem in design theory. We present a novel set of recursive constructions for t-(v, k, λ) designs, specifically focusing on resolvable group divisible designs (GDDs) as foundational components. By utilizing finite field arithmetic and properties of cyclotomic classes, we construct new infinite families of (k, λ)-resolvable GDDs of type g^u. These GDDs are then used as master designs in a generalized Wilson's fundamental construction to produce new t-designs with t ≥ 3. Our results asymptotically solve the existence problem for 3-(v, 4, λ) resolvable designs for a broad set of congruence classes of v, significantly expanding the known spectrum of parameters for which such designs exist and providing powerful new tools for the construction of highly symmetric combinatorial configurations.
subject: Matematik
title: Recursive Constructions for High-Rank Resolvable Group Divisible Designs

text: Katona's theorem provides a sharp lower bound on the size of the shadow of a k-uniform family of sets. We investigate the corresponding stability problem: which families are structurally close to the initial segment of the colexicographic order when their shadow size is close to the Katona bound? We establish a quantitative stability result using algebraic shifting and exterior algebra methods, demonstrating that any such family can be made isomorphic to the initial colexicographic segment by changing o(|F|) sets, where F is the family. Furthermore, we prove a supersaturation result, showing that if a family's shadow is of size |∂F| = ( (x), k-1 ) for a real x > k, the family must have size at least ( (x), k ) + g(x), where g(x) is a non-trivial error term. This confirms a conjecture by Frankl and provides an asymptotically tight coefficient.
subject: Matematik
title: Stability and Supersaturation for Katona's Shadow Theorem

text: We introduce a novel federated learning framework, Hybrid Privacy-Preserving Aggregation (HyPPA), designed to mitigate privacy risks and statistical heterogeneity challenges in decentralized environments. HyPPA integrates client-side differential privacy via calibrated Gaussian noise injection with a partial homomorphic encryption scheme for secure model aggregation. This hybrid approach ensures that individual client updates are obfuscated before transmission, while the central server can perform secure summation without decrypting constituent gradients, thus preventing inference attacks. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis of the privacy-utility trade-off, deriving convergence guarantees under non-IID data distributions. Empirical evaluations on the FEMNIST and CIFAR-100 benchmarks demonstrate that HyPPA achieves superior model performance and robustness against poisoning attacks compared to purely differentially private or encryption-based federated learning methods. Our framework establishes a new paradigm for practical, secure, and efficient collaborative machine learning over sensitive, distributed datasets.
subject: AI
title: Federated Learning with Hybrid Privacy: Combining Differential Privacy and Homomorphic Encryption for Resilient Non-IID Environments

text: Conventional data-driven generative models often fail to respect fundamental physical laws, limiting their applicability for scientific simulations. We propose the Physics-Informed Generative Adversarial Network (PI-GAN), a framework that synthesizes high-fidelity spatiotemporal data by explicitly embedding physical constraints into the adversarial learning process. The generator, a convolutional LSTM, produces sequential data fields, while the discriminator is a dual-stream network that assesses both statistical realism and physical consistency via a differentiable physics-based loss. This loss is formulated as the L2-norm of the residual of the governing partial differential equations (PDEs). We demonstrate PI-GAN's efficacy on complex fluid dynamics and quantum wave packet evolution problems. Results show that our method generates solutions that are not only visually plausible but also quantitatively accurate and consistent with the underlying physical principles, significantly outperforming standard conditional GANs and serving as a powerful surrogate model.
subject: AI
title: Physics-Informed Generative Adversarial Networks for High-Fidelity Spatiotemporal Dynamics Modeling

text: Addressing the challenges of non-stationarity and scalable credit assignment in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is critical for developing complex collaborative systems. We introduce the Spatiotemporal Graph Attention Network (ST-GAT), a novel architecture that models the dynamic, evolving relationships between agents. ST-GAT represents the multi-agent system as a dynamic graph, employing a series of temporal convolutional layers to capture historical context and graph attention mechanisms to weigh the influence of other agents adaptively. This approach facilitates efficient information propagation and allows for nuanced credit assignment within a centralized training with decentralized execution (CTDE) paradigm. We evaluate ST-GAT on challenging multi-agent coordination benchmarks, including the StarCraft II Multi-Agent Challenge (SMAC). Our method demonstrates superior performance and faster convergence compared to state-of-the-art value decomposition and communication-based methods, enabling the emergence of sophisticated cooperative strategies.
subject: AI
title: Spatiotemporal Graph Attention Networks for Emergent Cooperation in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning

text: We investigate the application of hybrid quantum-classical algorithms for solving NP-hard combinatorial optimization problems, specifically focusing on the Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) formulation. This work introduces a noise-resilient Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) architecture that employs a hardware-efficient, problem-agnostic ansatz. The parameterized quantum circuit is optimized via a classical Bayesian optimization loop, which is more robust to the stochasticity inherent in Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) hardware than standard gradient-based methods. We empirically analyze the algorithm's performance on instances of the Max-Cut problem, executed on both quantum simulators and real IBM-Q hardware. Our results demonstrate that the proposed method can find high-quality approximate solutions, outperforming classical simulated annealing in certain regimes, despite hardware limitations like limited qubit connectivity and decoherence. This study provides crucial insights into the practical capabilities of leveraging current quantum computing platforms.
subject: AI
title: Variational Quantum Algorithms for Combinatorial Optimization on Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum Devices

text: The ability of neural networks to learn sequentially without catastrophic forgetting remains a central challenge in continual learning. We propose Meta-Continual Learning with Orthogonal Gradients (MCL-OG), a novel framework that directly addresses the stability-plasticity dilemma. It leverages a meta-learning objective to train a model that can rapidly adapt to new tasks while preserving knowledge from previous ones. During task-specific adaptation, gradient updates are projected onto the null space of a basis spanning the gradients of past tasks, thereby preventing destructive interference. This basis is efficiently maintained using a low-rank approximation. The meta-objective optimizes for long-term performance across a distribution of task sequences. Extensive experiments on challenging continual learning benchmarks, including Split-CIFAR-100 and a sequence of Reinforcement Learning environments, show that MCL-OG significantly reduces catastrophic forgetting and achieves state-of-the-art performance.
subject: AI
title: Meta-Continual Learning via Orthogonal Gradient Projection for Mitigating Catastrophic Forgetting

text: Accurate uncertainty quantification is critical for the reliable deployment of deep learning models in high-stakes applications. We introduce Structured Amortized Variational Inference (SAVI), a scalable and expressive method for approximate posterior inference in Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs). Traditional mean-field variational inference methods often underestimate posterior uncertainty by ignoring correlations between model parameters. SAVI overcomes this by parameterizing the approximate posterior with a low-rank plus diagonal covariance structure, capturing significant parameter dependencies while maintaining computational tractability. This structured posterior is learned via an amortized inference network, enabling fast, single-pass uncertainty estimation. We demonstrate that SAVI yields well-calibrated epistemic and aleatoric uncertainty estimates on tasks including out-of-distribution detection and active learning. On large-scale benchmarks, SAVI achieves competitive predictive performance while providing significantly improved uncertainty quantification over existing variational and ensemble-based BNN methods.
subject: AI
title: Structured Amortized Variational Inference for Scalable and Well-Calibrated Bayesian Deep Learning

text: Fusing information from heterogeneous sensors such as LiDAR, camera, and RADAR is fundamental for robust perception in autonomous driving. We present the Hierarchical Cross-Modal Attention Transformer (CMAT), a novel end-to-end architecture for multimodal sensor fusion. CMAT processes raw sensor data through modality-specific convolutional backbones to extract low-level features. These features are then tokenized and fed into a series of hierarchical transformer layers. Each layer employs a cross-attention mechanism that allows tokens from one modality to attend to tokens from all other modalities, dynamically learning intricate inter-sensor correlations at multiple resolutions. This hierarchical approach enables the model to capture both fine-grained details and high-level semantic context. Evaluated on the nuScenes 3D object detection benchmark, CMAT sets a new state-of-the-art, demonstrating superior robustness to sensor degradation and adverse weather conditions compared to concatenation-based and point-level fusion techniques.
subject: AI
title: Hierarchical Cross-Modal Attention Transformers for Robust 3D Perception in Autonomous Systems

text: Estimating causal effects from observational data is a formidable challenge due to confounding and high dimensionality. We propose the Differentiable Causal Discovery Network (DCDN), a deep learning framework based on structural causal models (SCMs) that simultaneously learns the causal graph and infers interventional distributions. The model represents the causal graph as an adjacency matrix parameterized by a neural network and enforces the acyclicity constraint through a novel, continuously differentiable penalty function. This allows for end-to-end optimization via standard gradient descent, avoiding the combinatorial complexity of traditional causal discovery algorithms. The functional relationships within the SCM are modeled by flexible, invertible neural networks. We validate DCDN on synthetic and semi-synthetic datasets, showing it accurately recovers ground-truth causal graphs and provides unbiased estimates of average treatment effects (ATEs), significantly outperforming state-of-the-art methods based on propensity scores and meta-learning.
subject: AI
title: Deep Structural Causal Models for Interventional Inference from High-Dimensional Observational Data

text: We propose a neuro-symbolic framework, Logic-Guided Neural Reasoner (LGNR), that integrates subsymbolic perceptual learning with formal symbolic reasoning for enhanced explainability and compositional generalization. LGNR grounds visual inputs into a probabilistic scene graph using a pretrained object detector. This graph is then integrated with a background knowledge base expressed in first-order logic. We introduce a differentiable fuzzy logic semantics, enabling the model to reason over logical rules and learned neural predicates in a unified, end-to-end trainable manner. The model's reasoning process, which follows a chain of logical deductions, can be explicitly traced, providing human-interpretable explanations for its predictions. We evaluate LGNR on the CLEVR visual question answering dataset, demonstrating that it not only achieves competitive accuracy but also exhibits strong zero-shot generalization to novel rule compositions and provides high-fidelity, logical explanations for its answers, bridging a critical gap towards trustworthy AI.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic Integration with Differentiable Logic for Explainable Visual Reasoning

text: Unlocking the functional properties of proteins from their 3D structures is a core challenge in biology. We introduce a novel self-supervised learning paradigm, Geometric Equivariant Representation Learning (GERL), that learns powerful representations directly from unannotated protein structures. GERL operates on protein backbones as geometric objects on the SE(3) manifold. We design an SE(3)-equivariant transformer architecture that respects the rotational and translational symmetries inherent in molecular structures. The model is pre-trained on a large corpus of protein structures via a masked-atom prediction task, where it must predict the coordinates and chemical type of masked residues in their local reference frame. This pre-training objective forces the model to learn intricate geometric and chemical patterns. When fine-tuned on downstream tasks such as enzyme function classification and protein-protein interaction prediction, GERL significantly outperforms existing methods that rely on 2D graphs or handcrafted features.
subject: AI
title: Geometric Self-Supervised Learning on the SE(3) Manifold for Protein Representation

text: We theoretically propose and numerically validate a protocol for high-fidelity braiding of Majorana zero modes (MZMs) in semiconductor-superconductor heterostructures using time-periodic driving potentials. By applying Floquet engineering to a network of T-junctions, we dynamically modulate the tunnel couplings and local chemical potentials, effectively steering the MZMs along desired worldlines. This method circumvents the challenges of quasi-static adiabatic braiding, which is susceptible to decoherence from low-frequency noise. We employ a Floquet-Magnus expansion to derive an effective time-independent Hamiltonian, revealing the emergence of a robust topological phase protected by a dynamically generated gap. Our simulations, based on a realistic tight-binding model incorporating disorder and quasiparticle poisoning, demonstrate that the resulting non-Abelian geometric phases—the core of topological quantum computation—exhibit fidelities exceeding 99.9% for experimentally accessible driving frequencies and amplitudes. This work paves the way for fault-tolerant quantum gates based on the intrinsic topological protection of driven Majorana systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Floquet Engineering of Non-Abelian Geometric Phases in Majorana Nanowire Networks

text: This work establishes a novel connection between the AdS/CFT correspondence and the theory of quantum error correction by constructing a class of perfect tensor networks that precisely replicate the entanglement structure of a holographic boundary state. We demonstrate that the Ryu-Takayanagi formula for entanglement entropy emerges naturally from the network's minimal-cut-equals-max-flow property. Our construction allows for an explicit operator-level reconstruction of bulk local operators acting deep within the anti-de Sitter (AdS) geometry from their corresponding boundary conformal field theory (CFT) representations. This 'entanglement wedge reconstruction' is shown to be isometric, providing a concrete realization of the quantum error-correcting code properties of holography. We further explore the sub-AdS locality and the constraints imposed by the entanglement structure on bulk causality, offering a new perspective on how classical spacetime geometry can emerge from the quantum entanglement of a boundary theory.
subject: Kuantum
title: Bulk Reconstruction from Boundary Entanglement via Perfect Tensor Networks

text: We investigate the phenomenon of many-body localization (MBL) in a periodically driven, disordered Heisenberg spin-1/2 chain using large-scale exact diagonalization and time-evolving block decimation (TEBD) algorithms. Our study reveals a stable MBL phase in this Floquet system, characterized by a breakdown of thermalization and the preservation of local quantum information. We observe a hallmark logarithmic growth of entanglement entropy following a global quantum quench, a definitive signature of MBL that distinguishes it from both Anderson localization and ergodic quantum systems. By constructing an effective Hamiltonian, we demonstrate the existence of an extensive set of quasi-local integrals of motion (l-bits) that are responsible for this emergent integrability. We map out the phase diagram as a function of driving frequency and disorder strength, identifying a sharp MBL transition whose critical properties challenge existing theories based on avalanche instabilities, suggesting a distinct universality class for Floquet MBL.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Spreading and Emergent Integrability in a Disordered Floquet Spin Chain

text: We present a novel interferometric protocol that leverages multimode entangled states to achieve phase estimation at the fundamental Heisenberg limit. The scheme employs a balanced homodyne detection apparatus fed with a specially prepared two-mode squeezed vacuum state, which is subsequently passed through a network of beam splitters to generate a highly non-classical, multimode entangled probe. By calculating the Quantum Fisher Information (QFI) for this state with respect to the differential phase shift, we prove that the sensitivity scales as 1/N, where N is the mean total photon number, thus saturating the quantum Cramér-Rao bound. This represents a significant improvement over the standard quantum limit (1/√N). Our theoretical analysis, supported by numerical simulations of the Wigner function evolution, demonstrates robustness against moderate photon loss and detection inefficiencies, making it a viable candidate for next-generation gravitational wave detectors and quantum-enhanced sensing technologies.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Phase Estimation via Multimode Squeezed-State Interferometry

text: We report the experimental realization of a superradiant phase transition in a system comprising a transmon qubit ensemble coupled to a high-Q superconducting resonator, operating in the deep ultrastrong-coupling regime. Here, the collective light-matter coupling strength exceeds the individual qubit and resonator frequencies. By tuning the qubit frequencies into resonance, we observe a spontaneous emergence of a macroscopic photonic field in the resonator ground state, a hallmark of the Dicke superradiant phase. Crucially, the system's quantum nature manifests as a 'vacuum blockade' effect, where the discreteness of the photon field significantly alters the phase diagram from the mean-field prediction. Using in-situ dispersive readout and Wigner tomography, we characterize the entangled ground state, revealing a non-classical Schrödinger cat state of the electromagnetic field. This work provides direct access to the thermodynamics of a quantum phase transition and opens avenues for generating large-scale entangled states.
subject: Kuantum
title: Observation of a Vacuum-Blockade-Induced Superradiant Phase Transition in Circuit QED

text: The Jarzynski equality, a cornerstone of non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, relates the free energy difference between two equilibrium states to the work performed during arbitrary out-of-equilibrium processes. We present an experimental verification of this equality in a purely quantum regime using a single trapped 171Yb+ ion. The ion's internal spin states represent the thermodynamic system, while its motional state in a Paul trap acts as a work reservoir. We implement a quantum nanomotor protocol by applying a series of laser-induced state manipulations and controlled displacements, driving the system far from equilibrium. By reconstructing the full quantum work distribution from repeated measurements, we confirm the validity of the Jarzynski equality with high precision. Furthermore, we investigate the dissipation and entropy production in the quantum limit, providing direct experimental insight into the foundations of quantum thermodynamics and the arrow of time.
subject: Kuantum
title: Experimental Verification of the Quantum Jarzynski Equality with a Trapped-Ion Nanomotor

text: The superfluid weight, a measure of a superconductor's ability to support dissipationless current, is conventionally linked to the kinetic energy of charge carriers. Here, we present a theoretical framework demonstrating that quantum geometry of the Bloch states provides a significant, previously overlooked contribution to the superfluid weight in d-wave superconductors, particularly in the underdoped cuprates. Using a slave-boson mean-field theory of the t-J model, we calculate the Fubini-Study metric tensor of the Hilbert space of quasiparticle states. We show that the integral of this quantum metric over the Brillouin zone yields a geometric contribution to the superfluid density that is distinct from the conventional term derived from the band dispersion. This geometric term becomes particularly dominant in the pseudogap regime as the Fermi surface deconstructs into arcs, offering a compelling explanation for the observed robustness of superconductivity despite a low density of states at the Fermi level.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Geometric Contribution to the Superfluid Weight in d-Wave Superconductors

text: We analyze quantum information protocols for observers in non-inertial frames and curved spacetime backgrounds. Specifically, we investigate the 'entanglement harvesting' protocol, where two initially uncorrelated, accelerated Unruh-DeWitt detectors can extract entanglement from the vacuum state of a quantum field. Using Bogoliubov transformations, we compute the harvested concurrence for observers in Rindler spacetime, demonstrating a strong dependence on their proper acceleration and separation. We find a critical acceleration beyond which entanglement extraction becomes impossible. Subsequently, we study the fidelity of a quantum teleportation channel established between these accelerated observers using the harvested entanglement as a resource. Our results show a direct correlation between the degradation of teleportation fidelity and the thermal noise perceived by the observers due to the Unruh effect. This study elucidates the fundamental interplay between quantum information, relativity, and the structure of the quantum vacuum, with implications for communication near black hole event horizons.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Harvesting and Teleportation Fidelity in Curved Spacetime

text: We introduce a hybrid quantum-classical algorithm for computing topological features, specifically Betti numbers, of high-dimensional datasets. This method, termed Variational Quantum Homology (VQH), maps a simplicial complex derived from the data onto a series of qubit Hamiltonians whose ground state degeneracies correspond to the desired Betti numbers. We employ a Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) with a hardware-efficient ansatz to find these ground states on noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices. A key innovation is a symmetry-projection technique that mitigates the effects of noise and significantly reduces the required number of measurements. We demonstrate the protocol by successfully computing the Betti numbers of canonical topological objects (e.g., tori and spheres) on a simulated noisy quantum processor and an actual superconducting qubit device. Our work establishes a practical framework for leveraging near-term quantum computers to address classically intractable problems in topological data analysis and machine learning.
subject: Kuantum
title: Variational Quantum Algorithm for Topological Data Analysis on NISQ-Era Processors

text: Axion-like particles (ALPs) are a well-motivated dark matter candidate that can couple to photons through a Chern-Simons term, leading to unique signatures in cosmological observations. We present a comprehensive theoretical treatment of the frequency-dependent cosmic birefringence and dichroism induced by an oscillating background axion field. This interaction violates parity and CPT, causing a rotation of the linear polarization plane and a conversion of linear to circular polarization in the cosmic microwave background (CMB) and other astrophysical sources. We derive the transfer matrix for polarized light propagating through the axion dark matter background, accounting for temporal and spatial field fluctuations. By analyzing the latest CMB polarization data from Planck and ACT, we establish new, stringent constraints on the axion-photon coupling constant g_aγγ across a wide range of axion masses (10^-22 eV to 10^-12 eV), improving existing limits by up to two orders of magnitude in certain regimes.
subject: Kuantum
title: Cosmological Birefringence and Dichroism as Probes of Axion-Photon Coupling

text: Persistent homology has emerged as a powerful technique for characterizing the multi-scale topological features of data. However, a significant gap remains in performing rigorous statistical inference on these features. This paper develops a novel inferential framework for persistence diagrams, the primary output of persistent homology. We introduce a multi-scale bootstrap procedure for constructing confidence regions for topological features, such as connected components (0-dimensional holes) and loops (1-dimensional holes). By resampling from the empirical data distribution and computing bottleneck or Wasserstein distances between persistence diagrams, we quantify the variability of observed topological structures. We prove the asymptotic validity and consistency of our method under mild assumptions on the underlying data-generating manifold. The utility of our approach is demonstrated through simulations on synthetic point clouds sampled from tori and spheres, and an application to a complex biological dataset, where we successfully differentiate topological signals from sampling noise and perform hypothesis tests on the data's intrinsic shape.
subject: İstatistik
title: Topological Data Analysis with Persistent Homology: A Framework for Statistical Inference

text: The performance of standard high-dimensional estimators, such as the Lasso, degrades substantially under heavy-tailed error distributions or adversarial data contamination. We introduce Adaptive Huber Regression, a novel penalized method that provides robust estimation in high-dimensional linear models. The method minimizes a Huber-type loss function in tandem with an L1-penalty. Crucially, the robustness parameter of the Huber loss, which delineates between quadratic and absolute loss, is adaptively and iteratively estimated from the data. This data-driven tuning procedure obviates the need for manual parameter selection, a significant practical challenge for robust methods. We establish finite-sample oracle inequalities, proving that our estimator achieves near-optimal statistical error rates under minimal moment conditions on the error distribution. Extensive numerical experiments confirm that our method consistently outperforms the Lasso, SQRT-Lasso, and other robust estimators across a wide spectrum of contamination models, demonstrating its theoretical soundness and practical utility for modern data analysis.
subject: İstatistik
title: Adaptive Huber Regression for Robust Estimation in High-Dimensional Linear Models

text: The Stochastic Block Model (SBM) is a foundational tool for community detection in network data. However, standard SBMs are static and cannot incorporate node-specific attributes. We propose a dynamic mixed-membership SBM where node community affiliations evolve over time according to a hidden Markov model. Furthermore, the block interaction probabilities are modeled as a function of nodal covariates via a logistic link, providing interpretable explanations for community formation and evolution. To handle the computational challenges, we derive a scalable stochastic variational inference algorithm for approximate posterior computation, enabling application to massive, time-resolved networks. We establish theoretical guarantees on the consistency of community assignments under this framework. The model's efficacy is demonstrated on a longitudinal social network and a dynamic protein-protein interaction network, where it uncovers meaningful temporal shifts in community structure that are correlated with external events and node attributes, significantly outperforming static and covariate-agnostic models in link prediction tasks.
subject: İstatistik
title: Bayesian Inference for Dynamic Stochastic Block Models with Covariate Information

text: Functional Data Analysis (FDA) provides a powerful framework for modeling relationships between functional variables. A common challenge arises when functional covariates are observed sparsely and irregularly across subjects, precluding standard estimation methods. We propose a penalized estimation approach within a mixed-effects model framework to address this issue. The unknown functional coefficient is represented via a B-spline basis expansion, with a roughness penalty imposed on the basis coefficients to enforce smoothness, effectively regularizing the solution within a Sobolev space. We develop a computationally efficient Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm to handle the missing data structure inherent in sparse observations. Asymptotic properties, including consistency and convergence rates of the estimated coefficient function, are rigorously established. We show the estimator achieves optimal rates under certain conditions on the sampling design and the smoothness of the underlying functions. Simulations and an application to a clinical trial dataset demonstrate improved prediction accuracy over competing methods like imputation-based approaches and functional principal component regression.
subject: İstatistik
title: Regularized Functional Regression for Sparsely Observed Longitudinal Data

text: Constructing prediction intervals with valid finite-sample coverage guarantees is a fundamental statistical problem. Traditional methods often rely on strong, and frequently violated, distributional assumptions. This paper introduces Conformalized Quantile Regression (CQR), a methodology that synergizes the flexibility of quantile regression with the rigorous distribution-free guarantees of conformal prediction. The method first employs any quantile regression algorithm to estimate conditional quantiles, forming initial prediction intervals. These intervals are then calibrated on a separate calibration set using a non-conformity score based on the quantile loss. We prove that under the sole assumption of data exchangeability, CQR produces prediction intervals with guaranteed marginal coverage in finite samples, irrespective of the underlying data distribution or the accuracy of the initial quantile regression model. Extensive experiments demonstrate that CQR consistently achieves the target coverage rate where standard parametric and bootstrap intervals fail, while maintaining narrow, informative interval widths across diverse and complex regression tasks.
subject: İstatistik
title: Conformalized Quantile Regression for Distribution-Free Prediction Intervals

text: In survival analysis with competing risks, directly modeling the cumulative incidence function (CIF) is often more interpretable than modeling subdistribution hazards. We propose a novel, flexible regression framework for the CIF in the presence of high-dimensional covariates. Our approach is based on pseudo-values, which are constructed from jackknife leave-one-out estimates of the non-parametric Aalen-Johansen estimator of the CIF. These pseudo-values serve as responses in a generalized estimating equation (GEE) framework, allowing for the direct modeling of covariate effects on the CIF at specific time points. To accommodate high-dimensional predictors, we incorporate an elastic net penalty into the GEE estimation. We establish the asymptotic consistency and normality of the resulting estimators under suitable regularity conditions. Simulation studies show that our method provides accurate parameter estimates and superior predictive performance compared to high-dimensional adaptations of the Fine-Gray model. The method's utility is illustrated via an analysis of a cancer genomics dataset, identifying key prognostic biomarkers for cause-specific mortality.
subject: İstatistik
title: Pseudo-Value Regression for Direct Modeling of the Cumulative Incidence Function with High-Dimensional Covariates

text: Explaining the impressive generalization performance of over-parameterized deep neural networks (DNNs) remains a central challenge in statistical learning theory. We derive novel, data-dependent generalization bounds for DNNs within the PAC-Bayesian framework that are empirically non-vacuous for modern architectures. Our approach defines a posterior distribution over network weights that is concentrated in regions of the parameter space characterized by flat minima of the empirical risk landscape. The complexity of this posterior, measured via the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence from a data-independent prior, forms the core of our bound. We propose a practical algorithm based on Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (SGLD) to sample from this posterior and numerically evaluate the bound. We prove that the resulting bound is tighter than many existing complexity-based bounds (e.g., those based on Rademacher complexity or parameter norms) and scales favorably with network width. Empirical evaluation on benchmark image classification tasks demonstrates that our computed bounds are numerically tight and correlate strongly with observed test accuracy.
subject: İstatistik
title: Generalization Bounds for Deep Neural Networks via PAC-Bayesian Complexity and Langevin Dynamics

text: Bayesian non-parametric methods provide a flexible framework for inferring latent structure from data, notably avoiding the need to pre-specify the number of clusters. The Hierarchical Dirichlet Process (HDP) extends the Dirichlet Process mixture model to scenarios involving grouped or dependent data, allowing clusters to be shared across groups. This paper presents a refined HDP formulation and derives a novel, efficient collapsed Gibbs sampler for posterior inference. By integrating out the infinite-dimensional random measures at each level of the hierarchy, our sampler improves mixing and convergence properties compared to existing algorithms. We establish the theoretical underpinnings of the model and detail its posterior predictive distributions. The model's efficacy is demonstrated in two distinct domains: topic modeling in text corpora, where documents are grouped into a corpus, and cell-type discovery in single-cell RNA sequencing data, where cells are grouped by patient. In both applications, the HDP robustly infers shared latent structures and outperforms standard DP mixtures and finite mixture models.
subject: İstatistik
title: Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Mixture Models for Dependent Data Structures

text: This paper introduces a novel methodology for the automated analysis of late-Romantic chromatic harmony by mapping musical audio directly onto a Neo-Riemannian geometric space. We employ a deep learning architecture centered on a Transformer model with specialized attention heads trained to recognize triadic transformations (P, L, R) from Constant-Q Transform (CQT) spectrogram inputs. The model learns a high-dimensional embedding of harmonic progressions, which is then projected onto a 2D Tonnetz representation for visualization and analysis. We evaluate our system on a curated corpus of Wagner and Liszt, demonstrating its ability to trace complex modulatory pathways and identify non-standard harmonic syntax with significantly higher accuracy than existing HMM-based or rule-based systems. The results provide a robust computational framework for exploring parsimonious voice-leading and dualist harmonic theories directly from the acoustic signal, bridging a critical gap between signal processing and advanced music theory.
subject: Müzik
title: Geometric Modeling of Chromatic Harmony: A Transformer-based Approach to Neo-Riemannian Analysis

text: This research presents a system for deriving proto-Schenkerian graphs from polyphonic musical audio by integrating music-theoretic constraints into a signal processing framework. We utilize a constrained Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) algorithm where spectral templates are initialized based on instrumental timbre models and temporal activations are regularized using principles of voice-leading parsimony and metrical hierarchy. This source-separation front-end isolates individual contrapuntal lines from a complex audio mixture. Subsequently, a recursive reduction algorithm, informed by principles of melodic fluency and harmonic stability, identifies middleground structures and approaches the generation of a background Ursatz. Evaluated against a corpus of J.S. Bach's keyboard fugues, our method successfully identifies fundamental structural lines with a 78% correspondence to expert manual analyses, offering a significant advancement in the computational modeling of hierarchical tonal structures directly from audio recordings.
subject: Müzik
title: Computational Schenkerian Analysis via Constrained Non-Negative Matrix Factorization for Polyphonic Audio

text: This study investigates the nuanced relationship between theoretical tuning systems and performance practice in spectral music through high-resolution audio analysis. Utilizing a non-stationary signal analysis technique based on the synchrosqueezing transform (SST), we extract instantaneous frequency and amplitude data from recordings of seminal works by Gérard Grisey and Tristan Murail. Our method provides sub-cent pitch resolution and precise temporal localization of partials, enabling a direct comparison between performed inharmonic spectra and the composers' prescribed harmonic models derived from acoustic phenomena. We introduce a novel metric, the 'spectral deviation index' (SDI), to quantify the divergence between performed microtonal inflections and their theoretical targets. Our findings reveal systematic patterns of expressive deviation that challenge idealized interpretations of spectralism, suggesting that performer interpretation and instrumental affordances constitute a crucial, yet under-examined, layer in the realization of spectral compositions.
subject: Müzik
title: High-Resolution Spectro-Temporal Analysis of Microtonal Performance Practice in Spectral Music

text: We propose a perceptually validated timbral space for orchestral instruments by applying multidimensional scaling (MDS) to a comprehensive set of acoustic features. A feature vector comprising Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs), spectral centroid, spectral flux, and attack transient characteristics was extracted from a large dataset of isolated instrumental tones. Pairwise dissimilarity matrices derived from these features were used as input for the MDS algorithm, generating a low-dimensional Euclidean space. The resulting dimensions robustly correlated with established perceptual attributes, such as brightness, richness, and attack intensity. Crucially, the topological organization of instruments within this space aligns closely with principles from historical orchestration treatises (e.g., Berlioz, Rimsky-Korsakov), providing an empirical validation of traditional instrumental blending and family groupings. This work establishes a quantitative framework for computational orchestration and timbre semantics, linking digital signal processing with musicological inquiry.
subject: Müzik
title: A Perceptual-Acoustic Timbre Space for Orchestral Instruments using Multidimensional Scaling

text: This paper defines and validates a novel computational metric for rhythmic complexity, integrating both symbolic and sub-symbolic temporal features. The metric quantifies complexity as a weighted function of three components: a syncopation index based on metrical expectation, a polyrhythmic density measure derived from concurrent rhythmic stream analysis, and a microtiming variability coefficient calculated from statistical deviations from a quantized grid. We employ wavelet analysis for robust onset detection and microtiming extraction from audio signals. The proposed metric is tested on two stylistically distinct corpora known for their rhythmic intricacy: progressive jazz (e.g., Dave Brubeck Quartet) and Bulgarian folk music in asymmetric meters. The results demonstrate that our metric effectively differentiates between levels of perceived complexity and captures unique rhythmic signatures of each genre, outperforming existing models that rely solely on notational data.
subject: Müzik
title: A Multi-Feature Computational Metric for Rhythmic Complexity: A Cross-Corpus Study of Polyrhythmic Asymmetry and Microtiming

text: This research details the development of a generative model for creating stylistically coherent fugal expositions in the manner of J.S. Bach. The system operates on a symbolic level, utilizing a hierarchical probabilistic model derived from a statistical analysis of the complete Well-Tempered Clavier. A first-order Markov model governs the intervallic succession of the subject, while a higher-order model, conditioned on subject-answer relationships and harmonic context, manages the contrapuntal voice-leading of subsequent entries and the countersubject. The model incorporates constraints for tonal answers and avoids prohibited parallels through a constraint-satisfaction algorithm. We evaluate the generated expositions using both quantitative metrics (e.g., Kullback-Leibler divergence from the source corpus) and qualitative expert listener ratings. The system successfully produces novel and musically plausible expositions, demonstrating the efficacy of probabilistic methods in modeling complex contrapuntal procedures.
subject: Müzik
title: Probabilistic Models of Fugal Exposition: A Corpus-Based Generative System for Contrapuntal Music

text: This interdisciplinary study investigates the neural underpinnings of large-scale musical form perception by correlating computational audio analysis with electroencephalography (EEG) data. Structural segment boundaries in Mozart's piano sonatas were algorithmically identified using novelty detection on a Laplacian-segmented self-similarity matrix of chroma features. These computationally derived boundaries (e.g., exposition-development, development-recapitulation) were then used to time-lock and analyze EEG data recorded from musically trained and untrained listeners. Our findings reveal a distinct P300 event-related potential (ERP) component in trained listeners that is significantly larger at major formal junctures, particularly at the onset of the recapitulation. This suggests that the brain registers these structural articulations as significant, expectation-violating events. The results provide neurophysiological evidence for the perceptual reality of formal structures and validate the use of audio self-similarity as a plausible model for cognitive segmentation.
subject: Müzik
title: Neural Correlates of Musical Form Perception: An EEG Study Correlating Structural Segmentation from Audio Self-Similarity Matrices

text: We present a deep learning framework for the automated identification of atonal pitch-class (pc) sets directly from audio, circumventing the need for symbolic transcription. A bespoke Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture is trained to classify overlapping temporal frames of log-frequency spectrograms into their corresponding Forte numbers. The model utilizes a multi-task learning objective, simultaneously predicting the prime form and the interval-class vector to enforce theoretical consistency. To overcome data scarcity, we employ a sophisticated data augmentation strategy, synthesizing audio examples of pc sets with diverse instrumentations, dynamics, and articulations based on the RWC database. When tested on a dataset of recordings of works by the Second Viennese School (Schoenberg, Berg, Webern), the system achieves a 71% frame-level accuracy, demonstrating the feasibility of applying end-to-end learning to complex post-tonal music analysis and offering a powerful tool for large-scale atonal corpus studies.
subject: Müzik
title: End-to-End Pitch-Class Set Identification in Atonal Music using Spectrogram-Based Convolutional Neural Networks

text: This study explores the relationship between time-varying acoustic features and perceived emotion in film music. We employ a machine learning approach to predict continuous affective ratings along the dimensions of valence and arousal. A comprehensive feature set was extracted from a large corpus of film cues, including spectral features (centroid, flux, flatness), harmonic features (consonance/dissonance derived from a pitch-class distribution model), and temporal features (tempo, attack rate).
