Continuous listener annotations of valence and arousal were collected using a joystick-based interface. Support Vector Regression (SVR) models were trained to map the acoustic feature space onto the two-dimensional affective space. The models achieved a high degree of predictive accuracy, with spectral flux and dissonance being the most salient predictors for arousal and valence, respectively. The research provides an empirical model for the dynamic affective impact of music, with applications in automatic music recommendation and procedural soundtrack generation.
subject: Müzik
title: Predicting Affective Trajectories in Film Music: A Regression Analysis of Acoustic Correlates for Valence and Arousal

text: This paper proposes a novel audio synthesis framework for timbre transfer based on a conditional Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) with a disentangled latent space. Our model, built upon a WaveNet-style autoencoder architecture, learns to separate the latent representations of pitch, dynamics, and timbre from monophonic audio recordings. Timbre is encoded as a time-invariant vector conditioned on a set of perceptually relevant acoustic descriptors (e.g., spectral centroid, inharmonicity, attack slope). By manipulating this timbre vector at synthesis time, we can re-render a source performance as if played by a target instrument, while preserving the original pitch contour, dynamics, and articulation. Objective evaluation using the Fréchet Audio Distance and subjective listening tests confirm the high fidelity of the synthesized audio and the effectiveness of the timbral disentanglement. This method represents a significant advance in neural audio synthesis for applications in virtual orchestration and sound design.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangled Timbre Representation for Instrument Transsynthesis using Conditional Generative Adversarial Networks

text: Cytosine base editors (CBEs) enable precise C•G-to-T•A conversions in genomic DNA but can induce undesirable genome-wide off-target mutations. Here, we report the rational design of a high-fidelity CBE, termed hfCBE4max, by engineering the linker domain between a high-fidelity Cas9 variant and the APOBEC3A deaminase. We hypothesized that optimizing linker rigidity and length would constrain deaminase activity to the on-target site. Using a combination of structure-guided protein engineering and directed evolution, we identified a chimeric linker that substantially reduces off-target editing. Whole-genome sequencing and comprehensive GUIDE-seq analysis in human embryonic kidney cells and induced pluripotent stem cells demonstrate a greater than 20-fold reduction in off-target single-nucleotide variants compared to existing state-of-the-art editors, without compromising on-target efficiency. Our findings establish that linker architecture is a critical determinant of editing specificity and provide a robust platform for developing safer gene editing therapeutics for human genetic diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: High-Fidelity Cytosine Base Editor Mitigates Genome-Wide Off-Target Mutagenesis through Engineered Cas9-Linker-Deaminase Architecture

text: The spatial organization of transcription is partially governed by liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS), which forms biomolecular condensates at super-enhancers. However, the molecular grammar dictating the formation of these condensates remains elusive. We demonstrate that the Mediator complex, a key transcriptional coactivator, undergoes LLPS through multivalent interactions mediated by intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs) within its MED1 and MED15 subunits. Using in vitro reconstitution assays, we show that these IDRs drive the formation of phase-separated droplets that selectively recruit RNA Polymerase II and transcription factors. Super-resolution microscopy in murine embryonic stem cells reveals that mutations disrupting these multivalent interactions abrogate the formation of stable transcriptional condensates, leading to diminished expression of key pluripotency genes. Our results support a model where hierarchical LLPS, initiated by specific Mediator subunits, provides a biophysical scaffold for the assembly and functional maturation of transcriptional machinery at active enhancers.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Hierarchical Assembly of Transcriptional Condensates is Driven by Multivalent Interactions within the Mediator Complex

text: Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) differentiation is a paradigm for understanding cell fate decisions, yet the regulatory landscape governing lineage commitment remains incompletely charted. We developed a novel method, Paired-Tag-seq, for the simultaneous profiling of chromatin accessibility (ATAC-seq) and gene expression (RNA-seq) within the same single cell. By applying this technology to over 50,000 murine bone marrow cells, we constructed a high-resolution, multi-omic atlas of hematopoiesis. Our integrated analysis identified previously uncharacterized progenitor populations, including a bipotent megakaryocyte-erythroid progenitor defined by a unique chromatin signature that precedes transcriptional divergence. Trajectory inference revealed distinct epigenetic 'priming' events, where chromatin at lineage-specific enhancers becomes accessible well before the activation of target gene transcription. These findings provide a powerful resource and demonstrate that epigenetic modifications are a primary determinant of cell fate potential, offering a new framework for understanding cellular differentiation and malignancy.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated Single-Cell Epigenomic and Transcriptomic Atlasing Reveals Novel Lineage Priming in Hematopoiesis

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are emerging as critical regulators of cancer metastasis. Here, we identify MET-X, a previously unannotated lncRNA, as a potent driver of the epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in breast cancer. We show that MET-X functions through a dual mechanism. Cytoplasmic MET-X acts as a competing endogenous RNA (ceRNA), sponging the miR-200c microRNA to de-repress its target, the transcription factor ZEB1. Concurrently, a nuclear pool of MET-X directly interacts with the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) subunit EZH2. This interaction specifically recruits EZH2 to the promoter of E-cadherin (CDH1), leading to increased H3K27me3 deposition and transcriptional silencing. In vivo models demonstrate that MET-X overexpression promotes tumor invasion and lung metastasis. High MET-X expression in patient cohorts correlates with poor prognosis, establishing this lncRNA as a key bifunctional regulator of metastasis and a potential therapeutic target.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The lncRNA MET-X Modulates Epithelial-Mesenchymal Transition by Sponging miR-200c and Recruiting EZH2 to Cadherin Promoters

text: Cells adapt to hypoxic stress by rapidly remodeling their proteome, a process largely controlled at the level of mRNA translation. Using ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq), we investigated the dynamics of translation elongation in human cells exposed to acute hypoxia. Our analysis revealed widespread ribosome stalling at specific proline codons (CCU and CCC) within actively translated mRNAs. This stalling was not correlated with mRNA abundance but was directly associated with a significant decrease in the cellular levels of the corresponding tRNA-Pro isoacceptors, as measured by tRNA sequencing. The selective translation of hypoxia-inducible factor 1α (HIF1α), which is notably poor in these proline codons, was consequently enhanced. We propose that hypoxia-induced changes in the tRNA pool create a codon-specific bottleneck in elongation, thereby reprogramming the translatome to prioritize the synthesis of critical stress-response proteins while conserving cellular resources.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Translational Reprogramming During Hypoxia is Mediated by Codon-Specific Elongation Stalling and tRNA Isoacceptor Dynamics

text: The glucagon receptor (GCGR) is a Class B G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) and a primary target for type 2 diabetes therapies. Understanding its activation mechanism is crucial for drug design. We present the 2.9 Å resolution cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of the full-length human GCGR bound to its endogenous ligand glucagon, the stimulatory G-protein (Gαsβγ), and a novel positive allosteric modulator (PAM), NGD-1. The structure reveals that NGD-1 binds to an extracellular-facing cavity formed by transmembrane helices 6 and 7. This binding induces a subtle outward shift of TM6, which propagates to the intracellular face of the receptor, stabilizing the Gαs-engaging conformation and prolonging signaling. These insights into the allosteric modulation mechanism of GCGR provide a detailed structural blueprint for the development of next-generation biased agonists or PAMs with improved therapeutic profiles for metabolic diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Class B GPCR Glucagon Receptor in Complex with Gαs and a Positive Allosteric Modulator

text: Selective autophagy mediates the clearance of cytotoxic protein aggregates, and its dysfunction is linked to neurodegenerative diseases. The cargo receptor p62/SQSTM1 is central to this process, but the signals governing its assembly and cargo sequestration remain unclear. We demonstrate that phosphorylation of p62 at Serine 403 by the kinase TBK1 is a prerequisite for its subsequent ubiquitination by the E3 ligase TRIM21. Using in vitro reconstitution and cell-based assays, we show that this K63-linked ubiquitination event does not target p62 for proteasomal degradation but instead triggers a conformational change that promotes its higher-order oligomerization into functional polymers. These p62 polymers exhibit enhanced avidity for ubiquitinated cargo and efficiently recruit the autophagosome initiation machinery. Disrupting this phosphorylation-ubiquitination switch impairs the clearance of polyglutamine aggregates and sensitizes cells to proteotoxic stress, defining a critical regulatory checkpoint in selective autophagy.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phosphorylation-Dependent Ubiquitination Regulates p62/SQSTM1 Oligomerization and Selective Autophagic Degradation of Protein Aggregates

text: Whether environmentally induced traits can be inherited across generations remains a fundamental question in biology. We show that exposure of *Caenorhabditis elegans* to the pathogenic bacterium *Pseudomonas aeruginosa* induces a learned olfactory avoidance behavior that is robustly inherited for at least four subsequent generations in the absence of the initial stimulus. Using targeted genetic perturbations and genome-wide ChIP-seq, we demonstrate that this transgenerational memory is dependent on the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) and the propagation of histone H3 lysine 27 trimethylation (H3K27me3) in the germline. We identified a specific chemosensory gene, *srsx-1*, that acquires H3K27me3 marks upon parental exposure, leading to its transcriptional silencing in progeny. Re-activating this gene erases the inherited behavior. Our findings provide a direct mechanistic link between a histone modification, gene expression, and the transgenerational inheritance of an acquired adaptive behavior.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Transgenerational Inheritance of an Olfactory Avoidance Behavior in C. elegans is Mediated by Germline H3K27me3 Propagation

text: Telomeres are protected from being recognized as DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) by the shelterin complex. Loss of the shelterin component TRF2 exposes chromosome ends, which are then prone to aberrant repair by non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), leading to telomere fusions and genomic instability. We investigated the DNA damage response (DDR) at these de-protected telomeres. Here we show that the ataxia-telangiectasia mutated (ATM) kinase is rapidly activated and directly phosphorylates TRF2 at a novel serine residue (S315) upon telomere uncapping. Using phosphomimetic and non-phosphorylatable mutants, we demonstrate that pS315-TRF2 actively inhibits the recruitment of the NHEJ factor 53BP1 to telomeres. Instead, this phosphorylation event promotes the recruitment of components of the homology-directed repair (HDR) pathway, facilitating conservative repair. This ATM-mediated phosphorylation of TRF2 thus acts as a crucial molecular switch that dictates DNA repair pathway choice at damaged telomeres, thereby safeguarding chromosome integrity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: ATM-Dependent Phosphorylation of TRF2 is a Critical Switch for Repair Pathway Choice at De-protected Telomeres

text: Synthetic gene circuits offer powerful tools for programming complex cellular behaviors. Here, we report the design and implementation of a robust, bistable genetic toggle switch in human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs). The circuit is built from orthogonal CRISPR activation (CRISPRa) and interference (CRISPRi) components, where two guide RNAs (gRNAs) are designed to mutually repress each other's promoters via dCas9-KRAB, while simultaneously activating their own expression through dCas9-VPR. This architecture creates two stable, heritable states. Using transient delivery of activator or repressor molecules, we can controllably flip the switch between a SOX2-high/BRACHYURY-low pluripotency state and a SOX2-low/BRACHYURY-high mesodermal progenitor state. The chosen state is maintained through multiple cell divisions after the initial stimulus is removed. This synthetic circuit provides a powerful platform for dissecting the principles of cell fate decisions and for engineering predictable cellular therapies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: An Orthogonal CRISPRa/i-Based Toggle Switch Enables Programmable and Heritable Cell Fate Control in Human Pluripotent Stem Cells

text: Conventional self-supervised learning methods, primarily based on instance discrimination, often risk learning spurious correlations and suffer from representation collapse. We introduce a novel framework, TopoCLR, that integrates topological data analysis (TDA) as a supervisory signal. Our approach extends the contrastive loss paradigm by incorporating a regularization term that encourages the latent space manifold to preserve the topological invariants, specifically the Betti numbers, of the input data's underlying geometric structure. By computing persistent homology on mini-batches and penalizing deviations in the latent representation's topological signature, TopoCLR learns more robust and generalizable features. This method explicitly discourages dimensional collapse and enhances semantic clustering. We demonstrate state-of-the-art performance on downstream tasks including image classification and object detection, particularly under domain shift conditions, validating the efficacy of imposing topological priors for learning meaningful, high-quality representations without explicit labels.
subject: AI
title: Topological Priors for Self-Supervised Representation Learning

text: This paper presents BR-FedTrust, a novel Byzantine-resilient federated learning (FL) framework designed for robustness in adversarial, decentralized environments. Existing defenses against data poisoning and model inversion attacks often rely on a centralized server for aggregation, creating a single point of failure. BR-FedTrust obviates this by integrating a permissioned blockchain to maintain a decentralized trust ledger, where clients' contributions are weighted by a dynamically updated reputation score. We introduce a Byzantine-fault-tolerant consensus mechanism for secure gradient aggregation and employ client-level differential privacy with adaptive noise calibration to provide formal privacy guarantees. Our theoretical analysis demonstrates that BR-FedTrust achieves convergence under a bounded number of Byzantine clients. Empirically, on non-IID data distributions, our framework demonstrates superior resilience to sophisticated attacks compared to state-of-the-art robust FL algorithms, maintaining high model utility while ensuring client privacy.
subject: AI
title: Byzantine-Resilient Federated Learning with Decentralized Trust and Privacy Guarantees

text: Predicting protein conformational dynamics is a fundamental challenge in structural biology. We propose Equivariant Riemannian Graph Networks (ERGNs), a novel geometric deep learning architecture that explicitly models the curved, non-Euclidean geometry of the protein's conformational space. ERGNs operate on a graph representation of the protein, where an SE(3)-equivariant message-passing scheme evolves node features along geodesic paths on a learned Riemannian manifold. This approach inherently respects the rotational and translational symmetries of the physical system, leading to superior data efficiency and generalization. By framing the prediction of conformational transitions as a flow-matching problem on this manifold, ERGNs accurately model complex dynamics and identify metastable states. We validate our model on molecular dynamics simulation data and experimental Cryo-EM datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in predicting transition pathways and free energy landscapes over existing Euclidean-based graph neural network architectures.
subject: AI
title: Equivariant Riemannian Graph Networks for Protein Conformational Dynamics

text: Deep reinforcement learning (RL) agents often fail to generalize to novel environments due to their reliance on spurious correlations. We introduce Causal-Actor-Critic (CAC), a framework that endows RL agents with counterfactual reasoning capabilities by integrating a structural causal model (SCM) of the environment. The agent learns a latent SCM from observational and interventional data, enabling it to simulate interventions via the do-calculus. The policy and value functions are conditioned not only on the current state but also on the output of counterfactual predictions from the SCM. This allows the agent to distinguish causal relationships from mere statistical associations, leading to more robust and generalizable policies. The SCM parameters and the RL policy are optimized jointly through a bi-level optimization process. We demonstrate that CAC significantly outperforms state-of-the-art model-based and model-free RL algorithms in a series of challenging benchmarks that require causal understanding and transferability.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Policy Optimization via Integrated Structural Causal Models in Deep Reinforcement Learning

text: The trainability of variational quantum algorithms is severely hampered by the barren plateau phenomenon, where gradients vanish exponentially with the number of qubits. We propose a hybrid quantum-classical framework that leverages the structure of Tensor Networks (TNs) to mitigate this issue. Our method, named Quantum Tensor-Train Variational Optimizer (QTT-VO), represents the quantum state as a Matrix Product State (MPS) and variationally optimizes its constituent tensors. The optimization is performed on a classical computer, while a quantum co-processor is used to efficiently estimate the gradients and expectation values of local Hamiltonians. This decomposition reduces the effective number of optimized parameters and restricts the search space, demonstrably circumventing barren plateaus in deep quantum circuits. We provide theoretical guarantees on the gradient scaling and empirically validate our approach on quantum chemistry and combinatorial optimization problems, achieving faster convergence and superior accuracy compared to standard variational quantum eigensolvers.
subject: AI
title: Mitigating Barren Plateaus in Quantum Neural Networks with Variational Tensor Network Training

text: Achieving disentangled representations in generative models remains a major challenge, with most methods relying on heuristic-based regularizers that lack formal guarantees. We introduce the Manifold-Constrained Variational Auto-Encoder GAN (MC-VAEGAN), a novel architecture that enforces disentanglement by regularizing the generator's Jacobian. We posit that a disentangled generator maps latent traversals to transformations along distinct semantic directions on the data manifold. This is enforced by a novel penalty term that promotes the orthogonality of the Jacobian's column vectors, weighted by the Riemannian metric of the latent space. This constraint ensures that perturbations in individual latent variables correspond to geometrically orthogonal flows on the output manifold. We provide a theoretical framework linking this geometric constraint to information-theoretic disentanglement metrics and demonstrate empirically that MC-VAEGAN achieves state-of-the-art disentanglement scores on benchmark datasets like dSprites and CelebA, while maintaining high generation quality.
subject: AI
title: Certifiably Disentangled Generative Models via Manifold-Constrained Jacobian Regularization

text: We address catastrophic forgetting in continual learning by proposing a novel meta-learning framework, Meta-Manifold Continual Learning (M2CL). Our core hypothesis is that parameters for a sequence of related tasks lie on a shared low-dimensional manifold embedded within the high-dimensional weight space of a neural network. M2CL first meta-learns a low-dimensional generative model of this task manifold from a set of meta-training tasks. For subsequent continual learning, new tasks are learned by optimizing a short trajectory on this manifold, heavily regularizing out-of-manifold updates. This is achieved by projecting gradients onto the manifold's tangent space at each optimization step. This approach drastically reduces the effective number of parameters learned per task and preserves knowledge by constraining updates to a subspace known to be effective. We show that M2CL significantly outperforms current state-of-the-art continual learning methods on challenging benchmarks, demonstrating minimal forgetting and positive forward transfer.
subject: AI
title: Continual Meta-Learning on a Low-Dimensional Task Manifold

text: The synthesis of complex, correct-by-construction programs remains a significant challenge. We present Synapse, a neuro-symbolic framework that synergizes the generative power of Large Language Models (LLMs) with the rigor of formal verification. Synapse operates in a generate-and-verify loop. An LLM, fine-tuned on code and formal specifications, generates a candidate program snippet. This code is then parsed into a structured intermediate representation and its semantics are translated into logical formulae. A Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT) solver rigorously verifies the program against pre-defined formal specifications. If verification fails, the SMT solver produces a counterexample, which is fed back to the LLM as a corrective prompt to guide the generation of a refined candidate. This iterative refinement process combines the LLM's pattern recognition with the sound reasoning of formal methods, enabling the synthesis of non-trivial algorithms with provable correctness guarantees.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic Program Synthesis with Large Language Models and SMT-Based Verification

text: We introduce Synaptic Flux Optimization (SFO), a novel dynamic sparse training algorithm that optimizes network topology concurrently with its weights. Unlike conventional methods that prune post-training or use magnitude-based heuristics, SFO leverages second-order information to guide connectivity changes. At each training step, SFO identifies and prunes synapses with low saliency, estimated using a diagonal approximation of the Hessian, which measures their impact on the loss function. Concurrently, it reallocates the freed parameter budget by growing new connections where the gradient indicates a potential for maximal loss reduction. This continuous 'prune-and-regrow' process, analogous to synaptic plasticity, allows the network to dynamically adapt its sparse structure to the data distribution. SFO maintains a fixed sparsity level throughout training, yielding highly sparse models from scratch that achieve accuracy comparable to their dense counterparts, while significantly outperforming existing sparse training methods.
subject: AI
title: Synaptic Flux Optimization: Dynamic Sparse Training via Second-Order Information

text: Transformer models, despite their success, often produce overconfident predictions and lack reliable uncertainty estimates, limiting their deployment in safety-critical applications. We propose SNGP-Transformer, a method for equipping Transformer architectures with high-quality uncertainty quantification. Our approach replaces the final linear layer of the Transformer with a Spectral-Normalized Neural Gaussian Process (SNGP) layer. SNGP leverages a distance-preserving feature representation via spectral normalization and a Gaussian process output layer to provide calibrated uncertainty estimates with low computational overhead. This hybrid technique effectively captures both aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty, the latter via its sensitivity to out-of-domain inputs. We demonstrate that SNGP-Transformer significantly improves calibration error and out-of-domain detection performance on various natural language understanding tasks, including the GLUE benchmark, while maintaining competitive predictive accuracy and providing a principled mechanism for robust decision-making.
subject: AI
title: Calibrated and Robust Transformers using Spectral-Normalized Neural Gaussian Processes

text: The evolution of reproductive isolation is a central process in speciation, yet its genomic underpinnings remain enigmatic. We investigated the role of chromosomal inversions in driving ecological divergence and incipient speciation within the Anopheles gambiae species complex. Using whole-genome resequencing of populations across a latitudinal aridity gradient, we identified extensive differentiation concentrated within large, polymorphic inversions on chromosome 2. Linkage disequilibrium was significantly elevated within these inversions compared to collinear regions, indicating strong suppression of recombination. Population genetic analyses reveal that these inverted regions harbor clusters of alleles associated with desiccation resistance and insecticide tolerance, acting as 'supergenes' that maintain co-adapted gene complexes in the face of gene flow. Hybrid zone analyses further demonstrate that these inversions are associated with significant underdominance and contribute to hybrid inviability. Our findings provide robust evidence that chromosomal inversions facilitate rapid adaptive divergence by locking together advantageous allelic combinations, thereby acting as potent mechanistic drivers of ecological speciation.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Architecture of Speciation: Chromosomal Inversions as Supergenes Driving Reproductive Isolation in Anopheles gambiae

text: The remarkable diversity of snake venom composition provides a compelling model for studying the evolution of complex traits. We employed a phylogenomic framework, integrating transcriptomic and genomic data from 78 elapid species, to reconstruct the evolutionary history of venom arsenals. Using Bayesian ancestral sequence reconstruction and codon-based models of selection, we traced the molecular evolution of key toxin families, particularly three-finger toxins (3FTx) and phospholipases A2 (PLA2). Our time-calibrated phylogeny reveals multiple independent gene duplication events preceding major adaptive radiations. We identified specific residue substitutions under strong positive selection at critical ancestral nodes, which correlate with functional shifts from neurotoxicity to cytotoxicity. Notably, we uncovered compelling evidence for convergent evolution at the molecular level, where distinct lineages independently evolved identical functional motifs in their 3FTx repertoires. This study demonstrates how phylogenomic approaches can resolve the intricate interplay of gene duplication, neofunctionalization, and molecular convergence in the assembly of complex adaptive phenotypes.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Reconstruction of Toxin Neofunctionalization in Elapid Snakes Reveals Convergent Molecular Trajectories

text: Understanding the evolutionary trajectories leading to antimicrobial resistance is critical for predicting and managing its emergence. We conducted a long-term experimental evolution study using Escherichia coli under escalating concentrations of cefotaxime in a continuous culture system. By coupling high-throughput temporal genome sequencing with phenotypic assays, we characterized the mutational pathways to high-level resistance. We observed a strikingly parallel evolution at the gene level, with initial mutations consistently targeting the ampC promoter, followed by secondary mutations in genes modulating membrane permeability (e.g., ompF) and efflux (e.g., acrR). However, at the nucleotide level, the specific mutations were highly contingent on the initial genetic background. We quantified strong epistatic interactions, where early resistance mutations potentiated the fitness effects of subsequent compensatory mutations that mitigated the costs of resistance. Our results indicate that while the general pathway to resistance is predictable, historical contingency plays a significant role in shaping the specific genetic solutions, influencing the ultimate fitness and stability of resistant genotypes.
subject: Evrim
title: Predictability and Contingency in the Experimental Evolution of High-Level Cephalosporin Resistance

text: The antagonistic interactions between hosts and parasites can drive rapid, reciprocal evolution, often described by Red Queen dynamics. We investigated this co-evolutionary arms race in the wild flax (Linum marginale) and its fungal pathogen (Melampsora lini) across a heterogeneous landscape. Through population genomic analysis of both species from multiple sympatric and allopatric sites, we characterized patterns of selection on host resistance (R) genes and pathogen avirulence (Avr) genes. We found strong signatures of balancing selection maintaining polymorphism at R loci, consistent with negative frequency-dependent selection. Furthermore, we observed a geographic mosaic of adaptation, where local pathogen populations exhibited significantly higher virulence on sympatric host genotypes. Genome-wide association scans identified specific R-Avr gene pairings responsible for local interaction patterns. These findings illustrate that co-evolution is not a uniform process, but a dynamic mosaic of local adaptation and counter-adaptation, generating and maintaining genetic diversity across the landscape.
subject: Evrim
title: Co-evolutionary Dynamics in a Plant-Pathogen System: A Geographic Mosaic of Reciprocal Adaptation

text: Admixture between anatomically modern humans and archaic hominins, such as Neanderthals and Denisovans, has introduced genetic variation into the modern human gene pool. The functional and evolutionary significance of this introgression remains an area of intense investigation. By analyzing high-coverage paleogenomes of multiple archaic individuals alongside thousands of modern human genomes, we constructed a high-resolution map of archaic introgression. We integrated this map with functional genomic data, including eQTL and chromatin accessibility datasets. Our analysis reveals that introgressed haplotypes are significantly enriched for genes involved in innate immunity (e.g., the TLR1-6-10 cluster) and metabolic regulation, particularly lipid catabolism. These archaic alleles show strong signatures of positive selection in non-African populations. We posit that introgression provided a reservoir of locally adapted alleles that facilitated the rapid adaptation of modern humans to novel pathogens and dietary resources encountered during their expansion out of Africa, providing a compelling example of adaptive introgression.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Evidence for Adaptive Archaic Introgression of Immune and Metabolic Alleles in Modern Humans

text: Changes in gene regulatory networks (GRNs) are hypothesized to be a primary driver of morphological evolution. We explored this hypothesis by investigating the evolution of limb morphology in vertebrates, focusing on the GRN controlling digit specification. Using comparative ATAC-seq and ChIP-seq across embryonic limb buds from chicken, mouse, and alligator, we mapped the landscape of active cis-regulatory elements (CREs) for key transcription factors like HOXD13 and SOX9. While the protein-coding sequences and overall network topology are highly conserved, we identified thousands of species-specific CREs. Functional validation using in-vivo reporter assays in transgenic mice demonstrated that orthologous enhancers from different species drive distinct spatiotemporal expression patterns, correlating directly with divergent limb morphologies. Our results show that tinkering with the activity of modular CREs, rather than altering protein function or network structure, provides a powerful and flexible mechanism for generating morphological diversity, circumventing the constraints of pleiotropy.
subject: Evrim
title: Evolution of Morphological Novelty through Cis-Regulatory Divergence in Tetrapod Limb Development

text: A central debate in macroevolution concerns the relative importance of deterministic, trait-dependent processes versus stochastic, neutral processes in shaping large-scale biodiversity patterns. We tested these competing hypotheses using a time-calibrated supertree of over 30,000 angiosperm species. We applied state-dependent speciation and extinction (SSE) models to assess the correlation between key innovations (e.g., floral symmetry, herbaceousness) and net diversification rates. While we found statistically significant associations for several traits, these models often performed no better than trait-independent models that account for rate heterogeneity across the phylogeny. Furthermore, simulations under pure-birth and birth-death models that incorporate random shifts in diversification rates could replicate the empirical phylogenetic patterns with high fidelity. Our findings challenge the prevailing adaptationist narrative by demonstrating that stochastic processes, independent of any specific phenotypic trait, are a sufficient and powerful explanation for the dramatic heterogeneity in diversification rates observed in major clades, highlighting the crucial role of contingency in macroevolution.
subject: Evrim
title: The Dominance of Stochastic Processes in Macroevolutionary Diversification Patterns of Angiosperms

text: Eusociality, characterized by reproductive division of labor, represents a major evolutionary transition. To uncover its molecular basis, we performed a comparative transcriptomic analysis of brain and ovarian tissues from queens and workers across ten independently evolved eusocial species of bees and wasps, alongside solitary relatives. Despite vast phylogenetic distances, we identified a conserved 'toolkit' of genes that were consistently differentially expressed between castes. These genes are primarily involved in metabolic processes, insulin signaling, oxidative stress response, and vitellogenin pathways, but notably, not novel 'social' genes. Phylogenetic analysis of promoter regions for these toolkit genes revealed convergent evolution of transcription factor binding sites. This suggests that the evolution of eusociality did not involve the origin of new genes, but rather the repeated co-option of a conserved set of ancestral pathways governing reproduction and physiology, rewired through convergent changes in gene regulation to establish distinct queen and worker phenotypes.
subject: Evrim
title: Convergent Regulatory Evolution Underpins the Independent Origins of Eusociality in Hymenoptera

text: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a potent evolutionary force in prokaryotes, yet its quantitative impact on ecological adaptation remains poorly understood. We investigated the role of HGT in the evolution of metabolic novelty within hyperthermophilic archaea from deep-sea hydrothermal vent ecosystems. By constructing a comprehensive pan-genome from over 200 metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs), we employed phylogenetic incongruence and gene synteny analyses to identify HGT events. Our results reveal a massive and continuous influx of genetic material, with nearly 30% of the accessory genome in these archaea showing evidence of inter-domain HGT, primarily from thermophilic bacteria. These transferred genes are significantly enriched in functions related to novel catabolic pathways, including sulfur metabolism and hydrogen utilization, which correspond to the unique geochemistry of the vent environment. We conclude that HGT acts as a primary engine of innovation, enabling rapid metabolic adaptation and niche expansion in these extreme ecosystems.
subject: Evrim
title: Pervasive Horizontal Gene Transfer as a Primary Driver of Metabolic Innovation in Hyperthermophilic Archaea

text: The evolution of elaborate sexual signals is driven by a complex interplay between male traits and female preferences. We investigated the co-evolution of acoustic and visual signals in a clade of dendrobatid poison frogs, where males utilize both advertisement calls and conspicuous aposematic coloration. Using phylogenetic comparative methods, we analyzed the evolutionary correlations between male call frequency, female auditory tuning (basilar papilla morphology), and spectral properties of skin coloration across 45 species. We found strong evidence for the sensory bias hypothesis: the evolution of male call dominant frequency was tightly coupled to, and likely preceded by, shifts in female auditory tuning. Behavioral experiments confirmed that female preference is strongest for calls matching their species-specific auditory sensitivity. Furthermore, signal efficacy experiments revealed that conspicuous coloration enhances signal detection in noisy environments, suggesting a multimodal interaction. Our results indicate that complex mating displays evolve through a combination of sensory exploitation and signal integration, where pre-existing sensory biases create pathways for signal evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: Sensory Bias and Multimodal Signal Integration in the Evolution of Anuran Mating Displays

text: We propose a novel Graph Neural Network (GNN) architecture that decouples feature propagation from spectral attention to address the challenges of learning on heterophilic graphs. Our method, Spectral Attention Network (SpAN), leverages the Laplacian eigendecomposition to project node features onto a spectral basis, where a permutation-invariant attention mechanism operates. This allows the model to capture long-range dependencies and non-local interactions critical for heterophilic settings, where connected nodes often belong to different classes. Unlike conventional message-passing schemes that are inherently biased towards homophily, SpAN learns adaptive spectral filters to aggregate information from informative nodes regardless of their geodesic distance. The decoupling of propagation and aggregation mitigates the over-smoothing problem and provides a more expressive model class. We demonstrate empirically that SpAN achieves state-of-the-art performance on highly heterophilic benchmark datasets, including Cornell, Texas, and Chameleon, outperforming both spatial and spectral GNN baselines.
subject: AI
title: Decoupled Spectral Attention for Graph Neural Networks in Heterophilic Regimes

text: We reframe conditional generative modeling with diffusion models as a latent trajectory optimization problem under stochastic differential equations (SDEs). Existing approaches, such as classifier-free guidance, apply a global conditioning signal throughout the denoising process. We introduce Latent Trajectory Optimization (LTO), a method that computes a time-varying control signal to steer the reverse-time SDE towards a target semantic manifold defined by CLIP embeddings. This is formulated as a variational inference problem over the space of control policies, which is solved efficiently using an auxiliary neural network. By optimizing the entire denoising path, LTO enables fine-grained control over semantic attributes and compositional generation that is unattainable with static guidance. Our method significantly improves alignment with complex textual prompts on MS-COCO and outperforms leading diffusion models on human evaluation metrics for both prompt fidelity and image quality, demonstrating a more principled approach to controllable synthesis.
subject: AI
title: Stochastic Differential Equation-based Latent Trajectory Optimization for Controllable Text-to-Image Synthesis

text: We introduce Causal World Models (CWMs), a novel model-based reinforcement learning framework designed for robust zero-shot policy transfer in non-stationary environments. Standard world models learn predictive dynamics but often fail to distinguish causal relationships from spurious correlations, leading to catastrophic failures when the environment's underlying structure changes. Our approach explicitly learns a latent Structural Causal Model (SCM) of the environment's dynamics by leveraging interventional data, either provided offline or gathered through an active learning protocol. This learned SCM allows the agent to perform counterfactual reasoning—simulating the effects of unseen perturbations—and adapt its policy without further environmental interaction. We demonstrate that CWMs achieve successful zero-shot transfer in complex physics-based control tasks where reward functions and transition dynamics are subject to unobserved confounding factors, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art model-based and model-free RL baselines that rely on associational learning.
subject: AI
title: Causal World Models for Zero-Shot Policy Transfer in Non-Stationary Environments

text: This paper introduces VeriFed, a Byzantine-resilient federated learning protocol that ensures both data privacy and model integrity against up to f malicious clients in a system of N>2f participants. Existing secure aggregation schemes are vulnerable to model poisoning attacks where Byzantine clients submit malicious updates. VeriFed counters this by integrating additively homomorphic encryption with non-interactive zero-knowledge proofs (NIZKs). Each client encrypts their local model update and provides a NIZK proof attesting that the update was computed legitimately from their local data and conforms to predefined constraints (e.g., norm bounds). The central server can efficiently verify these proofs in bulk before aggregating the encrypted updates, ensuring that only valid contributions influence the global model. This approach obviates the need for a trusted aggregator and provides rigorous security guarantees without sacrificing the client-level privacy offered by secure aggregation, showing minimal performance degradation on CIFAR-10.
subject: AI
title: Byzantine-Resilient Federated Learning via Secure Aggregation with Verifiable Homomorphic Encryption

text: Large Language Models (LLMs) excel at pattern recognition but struggle with multi-step deductive reasoning, often generating logically inconsistent outputs. We propose the Logic-Infused Transformer (LIT), a neuro-symbolic architecture that integrates a differentiable symbolic reasoning engine within a transformer backbone. During training, LIT learns to parse natural language problems into latent, structured logical representations. These representations are then processed by a symbolic module, which executes formal deductive operations based on a set of first-order logic rules or an external knowledge graph. The results of these symbolic operations are then projected back into the embedding space and used as context for subsequent token generation. This tight coupling allows for end-to-end training via policy gradients and enables the model to iteratively verify and correct its reasoning chain. On benchmarks like ProofWriter and RuleTaker, LIT significantly reduces logical fallacies and improves proof generation accuracy over vanilla LLMs.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic Architecture for Multi-Step Deductive Reasoning in Large Language Models

text: We propose Hyperbolic Adaptive Momentum (Hadam), a novel optimization algorithm for deep neural networks that leverages the geometry of hyperbolic space to find flatter and more generalizable minima. Standard Euclidean optimizers like Adam are often attracted to sharp minima, which exhibit poor generalization. Hadam operates by parameterizing model weights on a Poincaré ball, a model of hyperbolic space with constant negative curvature. Gradient updates are performed using the Riemannian gradient, which naturally encourages smaller updates for parameters far from the origin, effectively regularizing the model. This geometric constraint guides the optimization trajectory towards wider valleys in the loss landscape. Furthermore, the hyperbolic geometry provides a natural mechanism for escaping saddle points. We demonstrate empirically on CIFAR-100 and ImageNet that Hadam consistently finds solutions with lower generalization error and improved robustness to label noise compared to state-of-the-art optimizers, including AdamW and SAM.
subject: AI
title: Hyperbolic Adaptive Optimization for Training Deep Neural Networks with Sharp Loss Landscapes

text: We introduce Conformalized Quantile Ensembles (CQE), a method for generating robust and statistically rigorous prediction intervals for deep learning models. While deep ensembles are a popular heuristic for uncertainty estimation, they lack theoretical coverage guarantees. CQE bridges this gap by applying the principles of split conformal prediction to the aggregated output of a quantile regression deep ensemble. The ensemble is trained to predict a range of conditional quantiles, and a separate calibration set is used to adjust these predicted intervals to achieve a user-specified marginal coverage level (e.g., 95%) with distribution-free guarantees. This post-hoc calibration corrects for model misspecification and dataset shift. We demonstrate that CQE produces well-calibrated and adaptive intervals on a suite of regression benchmarks, outperforming standard ensembles and Bayesian neural networks, especially in out-of-distribution scenarios, providing a practical tool for reliable uncertainty quantification.
subject: AI
title: Conformalized Quantile Ensembles for Calibrated Uncertainty Estimation in High-Dimensional Settings

text: We address the challenge of learning disentangled representations from correlated multimodal data, such as images and text. We introduce the Contrastive Information Bottleneck (CIB), a novel self-supervised objective that integrates contrastive learning with the information bottleneck principle. CIB aims to learn a minimal, sufficient representation of one modality (e.g., image) that is predictive of another (e.g., text), while simultaneously being maximally compressed. This compression forces the model to discard modality-specific, spurious correlations and retain only the shared semantic content. The contrastive component provides a powerful training signal for learning this compressed representation. We show that models pre-trained with CIB achieve state-of-the-art performance on downstream tasks like cross-modal retrieval and visual question answering, and qualitative analyses confirm the learned representations are significantly more disentangled than those from competing methods.
subject: AI
title: Contrastive Information Bottleneck for Disentangled Multimodal Representations

text: The quadratic complexity of self-attention in Transformers poses a significant bottleneck for long-sequence modeling. Recent work has explored two promising alternatives: structured state-space models (SSMs) and low-rank approximations of attention. We establish a fundamental duality between these two approaches, proving that any linear-time-invariant SSM can be expressed as a specific type of low-rank matrix decomposition of the attention matrix, and vice-versa. This duality allows us to unify these disparate lines of research into a single framework, SSD (State-Space Duality). Leveraging this framework, we develop a new hybrid architecture that combines the recurrent efficiency of SSMs for local context with the parallelizable global modeling of low-rank attention. Our model achieves superior performance on benchmarks like the Long Range Arena (LRA) while maintaining linear computational complexity and memory requirements, setting a new standard for efficient sequence modeling.
subject: AI
title: State-Space Duality: A Unified Framework for Efficient Long-Sequence Modeling

text: We present a novel framework for inducing structured sparsity in Bayesian neural networks by placing priors directly on functions rather than on weights. We model each layer of a neural network as a function drawn from a Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space (RKHS) and impose a functional spike-and-slab prior. This prior encourages entire functional components (e.g., neurons) to be either fully active (slab) or completely removed (spike), leading to more effective model compression and interpretability than traditional weight-level sparsity. We develop a scalable variational inference scheme to approximate the posterior over this functional space, employing stochastic gradient methods and the reparameterization trick. Our approach, termed Functional Variational Dropout (FVD), demonstrably learns more compact and robust models, achieving state-of-the-art results in terms of prediction accuracy and compression ratios on standard image classification benchmarks.
subject: AI
title: Variational Inference with Spike-and-Slab Priors on Functional Hilbert Spaces for Sparse Bayesian Neural Networks

text: We report on the experimental observation of non-Abelian braiding statistics in a ν=5/2 fractional quantum Hall (FQH) system proximitized with a niobium nitride superconductor. Utilizing a novel Fabry-Pérot interferometer geometry, we measured the tunneling conductance oscillations as a function of both magnetic field and gate voltage. The observed phase shifts in the Aharonov-Bohm interference pattern are consistent with the braiding of Majorana zero modes, specifically a π/4 topological phase acquisition, a hallmark of Ising-type non-Abelian anyons. Our results are robust against local, non-topological perturbations and are corroborated by extensive numerical simulations based on a microscopic model of the FQH-superconductor interface, incorporating quasi-particle poisoning and finite-temperature effects. This demonstration of non-Abelian braiding provides a foundational step towards the realization of fault-tolerant topological quantum computation, moving beyond simple particle fusion to controlled manipulation of quantum information encoded in the non-local Hilbert space of Majorana states.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Anyonic Interferometry in a Fractional Quantum Hall-Superconductor Heterostructure

text: This work develops a tensor network representation for the quantum state of a scalar field in a (1+1)-dimensional de Sitter (dS) spacetime. We construct a multi-scale entanglement renormalization ansatz (MERA) that explicitly maps the causal structure of the dS bulk to the entanglement structure of the boundary state. The geometry of the MERA tensor connections is shown to quantitatively reproduce the Ryu-Takayanagi formula for entanglement entropy in the dS/CFT correspondence context, particularly for intervals near the future boundary. By analyzing the disentangling properties of the isometries within the network, we derive a holographic screen and demonstrate how information about bulk operators is localized on this screen. Our model provides a concrete framework for understanding how bulk locality and cosmology emerge from the quantum entanglement of a boundary theory, offering a new computational tool to investigate quantum gravity in non-Anti-de Sitter backgrounds and address the information paradox in cosmological horizons.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Renormalization and Bulk Causal Structure in a De Sitter Spacetime

text: The thermodynamic uncertainty relation (TUR) establishes a fundamental trade-off between the precision of a thermodynamic current and its associated entropy production. While robust in classical stochastic systems, its validity in the quantum realm, particularly in the presence of coherence, remains contested. Here, we theoretically and experimentally investigate charge transport through a single, coherently-driven quantum dot coupled to two fermionic leads. Using a non-equilibrium Green's function approach, we predict that quantum coherence, induced by a resonant microwave field, can generate current fluctuations that fall below the classical TUR bound. Our experimental measurements of the shot noise and current, performed in a GaAs/AlGaAs heterostructure at millikelvin temperatures, confirm this violation. The degree of violation is directly correlated with the Rabi frequency of the driving field, demonstrating that quantum coherence acts as a resource for enhancing thermodynamic precision beyond classical limits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Violation of the Thermodynamic Uncertainty Relation in a Coherently Driven Quantum Dot System

text: We investigate the ergodic-to-many-body localized (MBL) transition in a one-dimensional chain of interacting dipolar spins subject to a quasiperiodic potential. Using large-scale time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (tDMRG) simulations, we map out the complete phase diagram. Contrary to the sharp transition observed in models with random disorder, we identify an intermediate phase characterized by a many-body mobility edge. In this phase, high-energy eigenstates are thermal and obey the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH), while low-energy states are localized. This leads to a distinct dynamic signature: following a global quench, the system exhibits a power-law growth of entanglement entropy at short times, followed by a slow, logarithmic increase that persists indefinitely, indicating non-ergodic behavior without full MBL. Our findings challenge the universality of the MBL transition and suggest that quasiperiodic systems offer a unique platform for realizing quantum systems with tunable ergodicity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Growth and Many-Body Mobility Edge in a Disordered Dipolar Spin Chain

text: We report the simultaneous estimation of a magnetic field vector's three spatial components with sensitivities surpassing the standard quantum limit (SQL). Our scheme utilizes a large ensemble of 10^7 Cesium-133 atoms prepared in a spin-squeezed state via quantum non-demolition measurement. The state's planar squeezing and optimized orientation in parameter space allow for the simultaneous reduction of quantum projection noise in multiple non-commuting observables. By applying a carefully timed sequence of radio-frequency pulses and measuring the collective spin projections, we extract the parameters from the correlated atomic response. We demonstrate a sustained 4.2 dB improvement over the SQL for all three parameters concurrently. This work provides a scalable protocol for quantum-enhanced vector magnetometry, with immediate applications in biomedical imaging, inertial navigation, and fundamental physics searches for exotic spin-dependent interactions, where multi-axis sensitivity is paramount.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum-Enhanced Multi-Parameter Estimation with Spin-Squeezed Atomic Ensembles

text: We explore the emergence of exotic quantum phases in a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) strongly coupled to the field of a high-finesse optical cavity. By driving the atoms with a transverse laser field, we induce a long-range, photon-mediated interaction that competes with the native short-range contact interaction. Above a critical pump power, the system undergoes a quantum phase transition from a superfluid to a super-solid phase, characterized by the spontaneous breaking of both U(1) gauge symmetry and continuous translational symmetry. We directly image the emergent crystalline density modulation via in-situ absorption imaging and confirm the persistence of phase coherence through time-of-flight interference measurements. The phase diagram is mapped by varying the pump laser detuning and atomic density, showing excellent agreement with theoretical predictions from an extended Bose-Hubbard model. This realization of a quantum super-solid in a cavity-BEC platform opens avenues for studying non-equilibrium dynamics of crystalline quantum matter.
subject: Kuantum
title: Observation of a Photon-Mediated Super-Solid Phase in a Cavity-BEC System

text: The Unruh effect, predicting a thermal bath for a uniformly accelerated observer, is a cornerstone of quantum field theory in curved spacetime. However, realistic physical trajectories are never perfectly uniform. We present an exact calculation of the response function for a scalar Unruh-DeWitt detector undergoing a class of non-uniform accelerations, specifically a 'jerking' trajectory with a time-varying proper acceleration profile. Using worldline quantization techniques and mode-sum analysis, we demonstrate that the detector's excitation spectrum deviates significantly from a perfect Planckian distribution. We find non-thermal, coherence-driven features in the low-frequency regime and a modification of the effective Unruh temperature dependent on the jerk parameter. These corrections imply that the vacuum state appears non-thermal to a non-uniformly accelerated observer, a result with profound implications for the interpretation of Hawking radiation from evaporating black holes, which experience a changing surface gravity, and for proposed experimental verifications of the Unruh effect.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Thermal Corrections to the Unruh Effect for a Trajectory with Non-Uniform Proper Acceleration

text: We experimentally measure the growth of quantum information scrambling in a programmable quantum simulator implementing the Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) model. Our system uses a chain of 16 Ytterbium-171 ions, with all-to-all spin-spin interactions engineered via spin-dependent optical forces, mimicking the SYK model's random four-fermion coupling. Scrambling is quantified by measuring the squared commutator of initially localized, non-commuting operators, which is equivalent to an out-of-time-order correlator (OTOC). We observe an exponential growth of the OTOC at early times, characteristic of quantum chaos, from which we extract the quantum Lyapunov exponent. The measured exponent exhibits a linear dependence on temperature, saturating at a value approaching the 2πk_B T/ħ bound predicted by holographic duality for maximally chaotic systems. This work validates the connection between quantum chaos and fast scrambling in a controlled experimental setting and establishes trapped ion systems as a powerful platform for investigating holographic principles and the quantum dynamics of black holes.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Information Scrambling Dynamics and Lyapunov Exponent in a Trapped Ion Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev Simulator

text: We investigate the process of entanglement harvesting, whereby two spatially separated, initially uncorrelated Unruh-DeWitt detectors can extract entanglement from the quantum vacuum. This study extends previous work on scalar fields to the more physically relevant Dirac field in a (3+1)-dimensional flat Friedmann-Lemaître-Robertson-Walker (FLRW) spacetime. We compute the concurrence for two detectors coupled to the Dirac vacuum and analyze its dependence on detector separation, energy gap, and the cosmological scale factor a(t). Our results show that entanglement harvesting is significantly suppressed during periods of rapid cosmic expansion compared to the inertial Minkowski case. Furthermore, the spin-statistics of the fermionic field introduces anti-correlations that inhibit entanglement extraction at certain distances where a scalar field would permit it. This analysis reveals how spacetime curvature and dynamics fundamentally constrain the accessible entanglement resources of the quantum vacuum, with implications for relativistic quantum information protocols in cosmological settings.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Harvesting from the Dirac Field in a Cosmological FLRW Spacetime

text: We introduce a novel, model-agnostic approach for identifying quantum phase transitions (QPTs) using techniques from topological data analysis (TDA). By treating the set of many-body ground state wavefunctions, sampled across the parameter space of the one-dimensional extended Bose-Hubbard model, as a point cloud, we compute its persistent homology. The resulting persistence diagrams, which encode the birth and death of topological features (connected components, loops, etc.) in the data, reveal distinct signatures at the known QPTs. The transition from the superfluid to the Mott insulator phase corresponds to a sudden change in the lifetime of zeroth-homology features, while the charge-density-wave transition is marked by the emergence of a persistent first-homology feature. This method, which requires no prior knowledge of order parameters, successfully identifies both symmetry-breaking and topological phase transitions. Our findings suggest that TDA provides a powerful and universal framework for characterizing complex quantum phases and their transitions from raw wavefunction data.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Data Analysis of Quantum Phase Transitions in the Extended Bose-Hubbard Model

text: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have excelled in learning from graph-structured data, yet often fail to capture higher-order topological features crucial for complex domains like molecular science. We introduce Topological Graph Contrastive Learning (TopoGCL), a novel self-supervised framework that enriches GNN representations with topological priors. Our method leverages persistent homology to construct homological scaffolds of input graphs, capturing multi-scale topological invariants such as cycles and voids. We formulate a hierarchical contrastive objective that maximizes mutual information between a GNN's node embeddings and these topological summaries at varying dimensionalities. This forces the model to learn representations that are not only locally informed but also sensitive to global topological structure. Evaluated on challenging molecular property prediction and protein function benchmarks, TopoGCL demonstrates superior generalization and robustness to noise compared to state-of-the-art graph contrastive methods, establishing the significant role of explicit topological supervision in learning meaningful graph representations.
subject: AI
title: Topological Data Analysis in Graph Contrastive Learning for Robust Molecular Representation

text: Standard Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) often produce entangled latent representations, limiting their utility for controllable generation and causal inference. We propose the Causal Disentangled VAE (CD-VAE), a framework that imposes a Structural Causal Model (SCM) on the latent space to achieve meaningful disentanglement. Our key contribution is a novel intervention-based regularization term derived from counterfactual queries. During training, the model is required to predict the outcome of hypothetical interventions on latent variables, penalizing deviations from the specified SCM. This counterfactual consistency objective forces the encoder to align latent dimensions with independent causal mechanisms. Experiments on synthetic datasets with known ground-truth causal graphs and real-world benchmarks like CelebA demonstrate that CD-VAE significantly outperforms existing methods in both disentanglement metrics and the ability to perform targeted, downstream interventions on generated data, paving the way for more controllable and interpretable generative models.
subject: AI
title: Causal Disentanglement in Variational Autoencoders via Counterfactual-Regularized Latent Spaces

text: The computational and memory demands of large-scale generative models, particularly transformers and GANs, pose significant scalability challenges. We introduce a novel generative architecture based on Tensor Networks (TNs), specifically Matrix Product States (MPS), inspired by quantum many-body physics. Our model, the Tensor Network Generative Adversarial Network (TN-GAN), represents the high-dimensional joint probability distribution of data as a highly compressed MPS factorization. This low-rank structure intrinsically captures correlations and enables efficient, sequential sampling without autoregressive dependencies, as well as exact likelihood computation. The TN-GAN generator synthesizes data from a low-dimensional tensor core, drastically reducing the parameter count. On high-resolution image generation (CelebA-HQ, FFHQ) and discrete sequence modeling tasks, our approach achieves competitive Frechet Inception Distance (FID) scores and perplexity while requiring an order of magnitude fewer parameters than comparable state-of-the-art models, highlighting the potential of TNs for efficient generative modeling.
subject: AI
title: Quantum-Inspired Tensor Networks for Memory-Efficient High-Resolution Generative Modeling

text: Personalized model development in healthcare is constrained by data privacy and statistical heterogeneity across distributed clients. To address this, we propose FedMeta-DP, a novel framework that combines the personalization power of meta-learning with the formal privacy assurances of differential privacy (DP). Our approach employs a gradient-based meta-learning algorithm (e.g., Reptile) to learn a robust model initialization that rapidly adapts to new clients. We introduce a client-adaptive noise mechanism based on Gaussian-DP, calibrated via the moments accountant, which provides tight (ε, δ)-DP guarantees while minimizing the impact on model utility. The privacy budget is dynamically allocated based on client data contributions, ensuring equitable privacy-utility trade-offs. On heterogeneous medical imaging datasets (e.g., federated classification of histopathology slides), FedMeta-DP achieves high personalization accuracy on unseen clients, significantly outperforming conventional federated averaging and non-private meta-learning, while providing rigorous, patient-level privacy protection.
subject: AI
title: Federated Meta-Learning with Formal Differential Privacy Guarantees for Personalized Healthcare

text: Forecasting complex, multivariate time series requires capturing both temporal dependencies and non-stationary, latent inter-series correlations. We present the Spatiotemporal Graph Transformer (SGT), a novel architecture that integrates dynamic graph learning into the transformer's self-attention mechanism. Unlike static approaches, SGT dynamically infers a sparse, adaptive graph adjacency matrix at each time step, representing the evolving underlying system structure. This learned graph is then used within a graph convolutional network to propagate information, producing context-aware node embeddings. These embeddings are subsequently processed by a temporal transformer encoder that attends to both sequential patterns and the dynamically evolving graph topology. Evaluated on challenging benchmarks from traffic flow prediction, energy consumption, and financial markets, SGT consistently outperforms state-of-the-art models. Our results demonstrate that explicitly modeling dynamic relational structures is critical for achieving high-fidelity, long-horizon forecasts in non-stationary multivariate systems.
subject: AI
title: Spatiotemporal Transformer with Dynamic Graph Convolution for Forecasting Complex Systems

text: Accurate uncertainty quantification is paramount for deploying neural networks in safety-critical applications, yet scalable and effective methods remain elusive. This paper investigates Bayesian inference via Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (SGLD), a powerful MCMC method. We address SGLD's primary challenge—inefficient exploration in high-dimensional, anisotropic parameter spaces—by introducing a novel preconditioning matrix derived from a low-rank approximation of the Fisher Information Matrix (FIM). This Fisher-preconditioned SGLD (FP-SGLD) method adapts the geometry of the gradient noise to the local curvature of the loss landscape, enabling more efficient posterior sampling. We demonstrate that FP-SGLD produces highly-calibrated uncertainty estimates on complex classification and regression tasks. On benchmarks for out-of-distribution detection and adversarial robustness, models trained with FP-SGLD significantly outperform those trained with standard SGLD, Monte Carlo Dropout, and Deep Ensembles, establishing a new state-of-the-art for scalable Bayesian deep learning.
subject: AI
title: Calibrated Uncertainty Quantification in Deep Learning via Fisher-Preconditioned Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics

text: Facilitating effective communication is a pivotal yet challenging aspect of cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL). We propose a novel framework, Information Bottleneck Communication (IB-Com), that enables agents to learn a minimal and sufficient communication protocol from scratch. Each agent's communication policy is optimized using the information bottleneck principle, which introduces a regularizer that minimizes the mutual information between an agent's observation and its transmitted message, while maximizing the mutual information between the message and its action-value function. This objective forces the emergence of a compressed, task-relevant symbolic language. We test our framework in cooperative navigation and resource allocation tasks with limited bandwidth. Results show that IB-Com agents develop more robust, interpretable, and decentralized policies. They significantly outperform agents using unstructured or attention-based communication mechanisms, particularly in noisy environments, demonstrating the efficacy of information-theoretic constraints for learning efficient communication.
subject: AI
title: Emergent Communication Protocols in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning via Information Bottleneck

text: Neural networks suffer from catastrophic forgetting when trained sequentially on multiple tasks. Inspired by neurobiology, we propose Synaptic Metaplasticity with Orthogonal Consolidation (SMOC), a dual-mechanism framework for robust continual learning. First, we introduce a metaplasticity rule where the learning rate of each synapse is dynamically modulated by a local estimate of its importance for past tasks, effectively shielding consolidated knowledge. Second, to accommodate new information without interference, we employ Orthogonal Weight Consolidation. This projects the gradient updates for a new task onto a subspace that is orthogonal to the principal components of parameter spaces from previous tasks, minimizing representational overlap. This synergy between weight-specific stabilization and gradient-based interference mitigation allows for both knowledge retention and forward transfer. On challenging class-incremental learning benchmarks such as Split-CIFAR100 and CUB-200, SMOC achieves state-of-the-art performance, drastically reducing forgetting and improving overall learning capacity.
subject: AI
title: Continual Learning through Synaptic Metaplasticity and Orthogonal Weight Consolidation

text: Generating solutions to complex Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) is computationally prohibitive for many scientific and engineering applications. We introduce the Physics-Informed Neural Representation GAN (PINR-GAN), a framework for learning high-fidelity, continuous solution manifolds from sparse data. The generator is an Implicit Neural Representation (INR) that maps spatiotemporal coordinates to physical field values, enabling resolution-independent generation. The discriminator is trained on a dual objective: distinguishing generated fields from ground-truth data (if available) and penalizing violations of the governing PDEs by evaluating their residuals at randomly sampled collocation points. This adversarial training in both data and physics space regularizes the learning process, ensuring that the generated solutions are not only realistic but also physically consistent. We demonstrate PINR-GAN on complex fluid dynamics and wave propagation problems, showing it can produce accurate surrogate models that are orders of magnitude faster than traditional numerical solvers.
subject: AI
title: Physics-Informed Generative Adversarial Networks with Implicit Neural Representations for Surrogate Modeling

text: Integrating sub-symbolic perception with symbolic reasoning is a grand challenge for creating transparent and robust AI systems. We present Lógos, a novel neuro-symbolic framework that combines deep reinforcement learning with a differentiable higher-order logic prover. A perception module (e.g., a GNN) grounds raw sensory input into a set of first-order logical predicates and constants. A policy network then learns to guide a differentiable forward-chaining reasoner, which executes multi-step logical inference over this symbolic knowledge base to derive provably correct action plans. The entire architecture is end-to-end trainable via policy gradients, with a reward function based on logical entailment of goal states. We apply Lógos to complex visual reasoning tasks and strategic games that require intricate, multi-step planning. The system not only outperforms purely neural baselines but also generates an explicit, verifiable logical proof for each decision, offering a significant advance in explainable and trustworthy AI.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic Reinforcement Learning with Differentiable Higher-Order Logic for Explainable AI

text: The rapid adaptive radiation of Neotropical cichlids presents a classic challenge for phylogenetic reconstruction due to widespread incomplete lineage sorting (ILS) and historical introgression. We employed a multi-locus genomic dataset, analyzing over 1,500 ultraconserved elements (UCEs) across 150 species to resolve their evolutionary history. Coalescent-based species tree methods and phylogenomic network analyses revealed significant cytonuclear discordance and extensive reticulation, particularly at the base of major clades. Our results indicate that rampant gene flow during the early stages of the radiation, rather than ILS alone, is the primary driver of topological incongruence. We identified specific genomic regions exhibiting signatures of adaptive introgression, linked to craniofacial morphology and trophic specialization. This study underscores the inadequacy of simple bifurcating models for understanding explosive radiations and highlights the role of hybridization as a creative force in generating phenotypic novelty and facilitating ecological diversification.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Conflict and Reticulate Evolution in the Radiation of Neotropical Cichlids

text: Host-parasite interactions are powerful drivers of rapid evolution, often characterized by reciprocal selective pressures known as coevolutionary arms races. We investigated the genomic underpinnings of this dynamic in a model system of a wild flax (Linum marginale) and its fungal pathogen (Melampsora lini). Using time-series population genomics, we tracked allele frequency trajectories at resistance (R) and avirulence (Avr) loci over a decade. Our analysis revealed rapid, recurrent selective sweeps at nucleotide-binding leucine-rich repeat (NLR) gene clusters in the host, countered by diversifying selection on secreted effector proteins in the pathogen. We observed strong signatures of negative frequency-dependent selection, consistent with Red Queen dynamics, where rare resistance alleles confer a transient advantage. Furthermore, we identified co-adapted genomic islands of high differentiation, suggesting that linked clusters of genes involved in defense and counter-defense co-evolve as supergenes, facilitating a rapid and coordinated response to parasitic challenges.
subject: Evrim
title: Antagonistic Coevolutionary Dynamics and the Genomic Architecture of Host-Parasite Arms Races

text: The remarkable diversity of arthropod limb morphology is a testament to the evolutionary lability of developmental programs. While changes in protein-coding sequences of patterning genes are implicated, the role of cis-regulatory evolution remains less understood. We conducted a comparative functional genomic study across four divergent arthropod lineages, using ATAC-seq to map chromatin accessibility around key limb-patterning transcription factors like Distal-less (Dll) and spalt (sal). Our results reveal deep conservation of the core gene regulatory network (GRN) architecture, but profound divergence in the activity and sequence of specific cis-regulatory elements (CREs). We demonstrate through reporter assays in a Drosophila model that orthologous enhancers from a myriapod drive distinct spatiotemporal expression patterns, directly contributing to altered limb segmentation. This work highlights that tinkering with CREs, rather than altering core protein function, provides a primary mechanism for evolutionary innovation, circumventing the pleiotropic constraints of highly conserved developmental toolkit genes.
subject: Evrim
title: Deciphering the Role of Cis-Regulatory Evolution in the Morphological Diversification of Arthropod Limbs

text: Selfish genetic elements that subvert Mendelian inheritance pose a significant challenge to organismal fitness, creating intense intragenomic conflict. The t-haplotype in house mice is a classic example, a large chromosomal inversion acting as a supergene that exhibits potent meiotic drive in males. We integrated long-read sequencing with population genetic modeling to reconstruct the evolutionary history and molecular mechanism of this driver. Our analysis resolved the complex structure of the t-haplotype, identifying four distinct distorter genes and a single responder locus whose interaction leads to sperm incapacitation. Phylogenetic analysis indicates the supergene originated over 1.5 million years ago and has since been locked in an evolutionary battle with unlinked suppressors in the genomic background. We demonstrate that the fitness cost associated with homozygous lethality and reduced male fertility creates a balanced polymorphism, with drive efficiency intricately modulated by the frequency of suppressors in natural populations.
subject: Evrim
title: The Evolutionary Trajectory of a Selfish Supergene: Meiotic Drive and Genomic Conflict in Mus musculus domesticus

text: The role of phenotypic plasticity in facilitating adaptive evolution remains a central debate. We investigated this 'plasticity-first' hypothesis within the adaptive radiation of Caribbean Anolis lizards. By rearing multiple species under controlled environmental conditions simulating different structural habitats, we quantified reaction norms for key ecomorphological traits, including limb length and toepad area. Our results reveal significant ancestral plasticity in these traits, with the direction of the plastic response often aligning with the direction of subsequent evolutionary divergence among ecomorphs.
