Using a comparative quantitative genetic framework, we found evidence for genetic accommodation, where initially plastic responses became canalized over evolutionary time. This process appears to unveil cryptic genetic variation, providing the raw material for selection to act upon. Our findings suggest that environmentally induced phenotypes can precede and guide genetic divergence, acting as a crucial first step that catalyzes rapid and repeatable ecological speciation in this iconic adaptive radiation.
subject: Evrim
title: Phenotypic Plasticity as a Catalyst for Adaptive Radiation: A Quantitative Genetic Analysis of Anolis Lizards

text: Reconstructing the deep evolutionary history of vertebrates has been hampered by gene tree-species tree discordance arising from rapid ancient radiations. Leveraging a massive dataset of 2,100 conserved protein-coding genes from 350 taxa, we constructed a robust, fossil-calibrated vertebrate phylogeny. Our analysis, using site-heterogeneous mixture models and coalescent-based methods, confidently resolves several contentious nodes, including the placement of turtles as sister to archosaurs and the monophyly of Afrotheria. Beyond resolving bifurcation patterns, our investigation uncovered strong signals of ancient reticulation. Specifically, we identified multiple instances of large-scale horizontal gene transfer (HGT) from non-metazoan sources into early vertebrate lineages, as well as evidence for a significant ancient hybridization event between the stem lineages of gnathostomes and cyclostomes. These findings challenge the purely bifurcating model of vertebrate evolution and suggest that inter-lineage genomic exchange played a more substantial role in early animal evolution than previously appreciated.
subject: Evrim
title: Deep-Time Phylogenomics of Vertebrates Resolves Contentious Nodes and Reveals Cryptic Ancient Hybridization Events

text: The repeated evolution of electric organs in distantly related fish lineages provides a powerful system for studying the predictability of evolution at the molecular level. We generated a chromosome-level genome assembly for the African elephantnose fish (Gnathonemus petersii) and compared it with the independently evolved South American electric eel (Electrophorus electricus). We discovered that while both lineages repurposed skeletal muscle tissue for electrogenesis, the underlying genetic toolkit exhibits remarkable convergence. A key voltage-gated sodium channel gene, Scn4a, shows parallel amino acid substitutions in functionally critical domains and evidence of neofunctionalization via duplication in both lineages. Furthermore, comparative transcriptomics and ATAC-seq revealed convergent evolution in the cis-regulatory landscape, with independent co-option of muscle-specific enhancer elements to drive massive upregulation of ion channel expression. This multi-level convergence, from gene sequence to regulatory architecture, demonstrates that a limited number of genetic pathways constrain the evolutionary trajectory towards this complex physiological innovation.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Scaffolding of a Non-Model Organism Reveals the Molecular Basis of Convergent Evolution in Electric Fish

text: The evolutionary transition to multicellularity is a pivotal event in the history of life, yet the initial selective pressures and genetic constraints remain debated. We conducted a long-term experimental evolution study using the unicellular alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, selecting directly for larger group size under alternating settling-selection and growth phases. Within 500 generations, all replicate populations evolved simple, undifferentiated multicellular clusters. Whole-genome sequencing of evolved clones revealed that the initial transition was consistently caused by mutations in genes controlling cell division and separation, often with pleiotropic effects on cell cycle regulation. These early multicellular forms exhibited significant life history trade-offs. However, subsequent evolution in a more complex, structured environment (ecological scaffolding) favored the emergence of rudimentary division of labor, mitigating these costs. Our results demonstrate that while the initial step to multicellularity can be genetically simple, overcoming the inherent pleiotropic constraints requires specific ecological contexts.
subject: Evrim
title: Experimental Evolution of Multicellularity: The Role of Pleiotropic Constraints and Ecological Scaffolding

text: Understanding the process of speciation in high gene-flow environments like the ocean is a major challenge. We investigated the genomic architecture of divergence across a 'speciation continuum' in the marine copepod Eurytemora affinis, which exhibits varying degrees of reproductive isolation among populations inhabiting different salinity regimes. Using whole-genome resequencing of individuals from freshwater, brackish, and saline habitats, we identified a heterogeneous genomic landscape of differentiation. While most of the genome remained porous to gene flow, distinct 'genomic islands of divergence' were evident, enriched for genes involved in ion transport and osmoregulation. The size and number of these islands increased proportionally with the degree of reproductive isolation, and linkage disequilibrium was significantly higher within islands. Our findings support a model of ecological speciation with gene flow, where selection on a few key loci creates barriers to recombination, allowing divergence to build up in linked regions, ultimately driving the progression from ecotype to distinct species.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Islands of Divergence and the Speciation Continuum in a Marine Copepod Metapopulation

text: The evolution of eusociality, characterized by reproductive division of labor, represents a major evolutionary transition and a persistent theoretical puzzle. Here, we develop a unified theoretical framework that synthesizes inclusive fitness theory with multilevel selection models to explore the conditions favoring the emergence of a sterile worker caste. Our agent-based model incorporates key parameters such as relatedness, ecological benefits of cooperation, and demographic stochasticity. We demonstrate that while high relatedness facilitates the initial spread of altruistic alleles, stable eusociality requires strong between-group selection to overcome within-group conflict. Critically, our model incorporates genomic constraints, showing that mechanisms like genomic imprinting can bias offspring to become workers, resolving parent-offspring conflict over caste fate. The model predicts distinct evolutionary trajectories for haplodiploid versus diploid systems, consistent with empirical observations across Hymenoptera and termites, providing a more nuanced understanding of this ultimate form of biological altruism.
subject: Evrim
title: The Evolution of Eusociality: A Theoretical Framework Integrating Inclusive Fitness, Multilevel Selection, and Genomic Constraints

text: Traditional Music Information Retrieval (MIR) systems struggle to capture the long-range hierarchical dependencies fundamental to Schenkerian analysis. This paper introduces a novel deep learning architecture, the Tonal-Syntactic Transformer (TST), which applies self-attention mechanisms directly to a Constant-Q Transform (CQT) representation of polyphonic audio. By leveraging positional encodings that are musically informed by metrical structure, the TST model learns to map spectral features to an abstract syntactic space representing prolongational hierarchies. We trained the model on a synthetic dataset generated from a probabilistic Schenkerian grammar and validated it against the Annotated Beethoven Corpus. Results demonstrate that the TST significantly outperforms recurrent neural network (RNN) and convolutional neural network (CNN) baselines in identifying structural prolongations and inferring the Ursatz. The attention maps produced by the model offer a new, interpretable visualization of voice-leading patterns and large-scale tonal connections, providing a powerful tool for computational musicology.
subject: Müzik
title: A Transformer-Based Model for Hierarchical Tonal Structure Inference from Raw Audio

text: This study pioneers the application of Topological Data Analysis (TDA) for the unsupervised characterization of orchestral timbre. We represent musical audio segments as high-dimensional point clouds derived from Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) and their temporal derivatives. By computing the persistent homology of these point clouds, we extract robust topological features—specifically, Betti numbers and persistence diagrams—that quantify the intrinsic shape and connectivity of the underlying timbral manifold. Our analysis, conducted on the RWC Orchestral Sound Database, reveals that these topological invariants effectively differentiate between instrumental families and playing techniques with greater accuracy than standard spectral centroid or flatness measures. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the persistence landscapes derived from our analysis correlate strongly with perceptual ratings of timbral similarity and blend, offering a mathematically principled framework for computational orchestration and timbral semantics that is invariant to linear transformations like volume changes.
subject: Müzik
title: Topological Data Analysis of Timbral Manifolds in Orchestral Music

text: We propose a novel self-supervised learning framework for discovering the implicit rules of species counterpoint directly from unannotated polyphonic audio. Our method, Contrapuntal Contrastive Embedding (CCE), utilizes a Siamese network architecture trained on pairs of spectrally and temporally augmented audio excerpts. The model learns a latent representation by minimizing a contrastive loss function, which forces embeddings of contrapuntally licit voice-leading dyads (e.g., perfect consonances approached by contrary motion) to be closer than those of illicit ones. We trained the CCE model on a large corpus of Renaissance polyphony. Without any symbolic data or explicit music-theoretic labels, the learned embedding space exhibits a clear geometric structure corresponding to Fuxian principles. Subsequent probing tasks show the model can classify contrapuntal motions and identify dissonant intervals with high accuracy, effectively reverse-engineering core syntactic principles of polyphony from the acoustic signal alone.
subject: Müzik
title: Self-Supervised Learning of Contrapuntal Syntax from Polyphonic Audio Recordings

text: Neo-Riemannian theory offers a powerful group-theoretic model for chromatic harmony, yet its application in audio analysis remains challenging. This paper introduces a Graph Neural Network (GNN) framework to identify neo-Riemannian transformations directly from chroma features. We model the tonal space as a Tonnetz graph, where nodes represent pitch classes and edges represent consonant triadic relationships. A custom-designed graph convolutional layer learns to recognize patterns of harmonic motion corresponding to Parallel (P), Leading-tone exchange (L), and Relative (R) transformations. Trained on the 'When in Rome' dataset of annotated chord progressions, our GNN model significantly surpasses baseline HMM and CRF methods in labeling chromatic sequences. This approach bridges the gap between abstract algebraic music theory and audio signal processing, enabling robust computational analysis of late-Romantic harmony without reliance on error-prone symbolic transcription.
subject: Müzik
title: Modeling Neo-Riemannian Transformations in Tonal Space with Geometric Deep Learning

text: This research presents a quantitative methodology for analyzing micro-level expressive timing, or agogics, in solo piano performance. We employ a Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT) with a complex Morlet wavelet to generate a high-resolution, time-frequency representation of the audio signal, allowing for precise onset detection and energy envelope characterization. From this representation, we extract a feature vector encoding note-level deviations from a notated metronomic grid. These features are then modeled using a Hierarchical Bayesian framework, which infers performer-specific agogic accent patterns while accounting for structural context (e.g., phrase boundaries, harmonic tension). Applied to a corpus of multiple recordings of Chopin's Preludes, our model successfully disentangles systematic expressive strategies from random performance fluctuations. The results provide empirical evidence for performer-specific 'timing signatures' and their correlation with harmonic and melodic contour, offering a new paradigm for computational performance analysis.
subject: Müzik
title: Quantifying Expressive Agogics in Piano Performance via Continuous Wavelet Transform and Hierarchical Bayesian Modeling

text: The generation of musically coherent atonal compositions presents a unique challenge for statistical models. We introduce the Set-Class Variational Autoencoder (SC-VAE), a deep generative model designed to learn and synthesize novel musical material adhering to the principles of post-tonal pitch-class set theory. The model's latent space is regularized using a custom loss function that encourages clustering based on abstract set-theoretic properties, such as the interval-class vector and Forte number, rather than raw pitch proximity. The decoder, a Transformer-based architecture, learns to map points in this structured latent space to piano-roll representations. Trained on the serial and atonal works of the Second Viennese School, the SC-VAE demonstrates an ability to generate novel compositions that exhibit sophisticated structural properties, including transpositional and inversional invariance and consistent use of a source set-class vocabulary, far exceeding the coherence of standard VAE and GAN-based models.
subject: Müzik
title: Generative Modeling of Atonal Pitch Structures with a Set-Class-Constrained Variational Autoencoder

text: This study introduces a cross-modal deep learning framework to investigate the alignment between musical structure and dramatic narrative in opera. We employ a dual-stream architecture: a recurrent segmentation network processes audio features (chromagrams, MFCCs) to perform unsupervised structural segmentation, identifying key changes and textural shifts. Concurrently, a pre-trained BERT model analyzes the libretto to extract time-aligned semantic vector representations and perform topic modeling. A cross-modal attention mechanism is then trained to learn a mapping between the musical segment embeddings and the semantic text embeddings. Applied to a corpus of Wagnerian music dramas, our system automatically identifies strong correlations between specific harmonic regions (e.g., leitmotif presentations, deceptive cadences) and dramaturgical events (e.g., character revelations, plot twists). This methodology provides an empirical tool for computational musicology to rigorously test theories of semiotic association in large-scale musico-dramatic works.
subject: Müzik
title: Cross-Modal Alignment of Musical Form and Narrative Semantics in Operatic Scenes

text: The spectral overlap of instruments in orchestral music poses a significant challenge for automatic harmonic analysis. This paper proposes a theory-informed Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) approach to disentangle timbral and harmonic components. Our model, Constrained Harmonic-Timbral NMF (CHT-NMF), decomposes a magnitude spectrogram into two sets of basis vectors: a fixed dictionary of spectral templates learned from isolated instrument samples, and a set of harmonic basis vectors representing pitch-class content. The temporal activations of the harmonic bases are constrained by a Hidden Markov Model (HMM) whose transition probabilities are derived from a corpus-based model of functional harmony. By simultaneously optimizing the factorization and the HMM state sequence, CHT-NMF achieves superior performance in both chord recognition and instrument identification tasks on complex orchestral excerpts compared to standard NMF and deep learning source separation baselines. The framework effectively regularizes the ill-posed decomposition problem by injecting music-theoretic domain knowledge.
subject: Müzik
title: Disentangling Timbre and Harmony in Orchestral Audio using Theory-Informed Non-Negative Matrix Factorization

text: The perception of hypermeter—meter at levels above the notated measure—is a critical aspect of musical experience, yet it is notoriously difficult to model computationally. We present a Dynamic Bayesian Network (DBN) for inferring hierarchical metric structure from audio features. The model's state space represents a multi-level metrical grid, tracking concurrent hypotheses for tactus, measure, and hypermeter periodicities. The observation model integrates acoustic evidence from an onset detection function, while the transition model incorporates musically-informed priors based on Lerdahl and Jackendoff's Metrical Preference Rules (MPRs), such as parallelism and stress alignment. We evaluate the model on a challenging dataset of music with metric ambiguity, including works by Stravinsky and American minimalism. Using the Viterbi algorithm for inference, our DBN significantly outperforms existing beat tracking and meter analysis systems in identifying salient hypermetric levels, providing a robust probabilistic framework for analyzing complex rhythmic organization.
subject: Müzik
title: A Dynamic Bayesian Network for Hypermeter Inference in Rhythmically Complex Music

text: The subjective nature of tonal ambiguity presents a challenge for traditional music perception research. This work introduces a novel experimental paradigm combining psychoacoustics with deep active learning to efficiently map the perceptual space of harmonic ambiguity. We employ a Gaussian Process classifier, fronted by a deep feature extractor pre-trained on a large music corpus, to model the probability that a musical fragment is perceived as tonally ambiguous. The active learning component uses an entropy-based query strategy to iteratively select the most informative stimuli to present to human subjects for labeling. This closed-loop system rapidly converges on the decision boundary separating stable and ambiguous tonal regions within a high-dimensional feature space derived from Krumhansl-Kessler key profiles and spiral array model coordinates. The resulting perceptual map reveals complex interactions between voice leading, dissonance, and cadential expectation, refining existing cognitive models of tonality with unprecedented efficiency and detail.
subject: Müzik
title: Probing Perceptual Tonal Ambiguity using Deep Active Learning and Psychoacoustic Feedback

text: Epigenetic modifications are fundamental to cell identity, and their dysregulation underlies numerous pathologies. We developed a multiplexable CRISPR-based epigenetic editing platform using nuclease-deactivated Cas9 (dCas9) fused to catalytic domains of TET1 and DNMT3A to achieve targeted DNA demethylation and de novo methylation, respectively. By directing these editors to promoter and enhancer regions of key pluripotency factors, we demonstrate bidirectional control over local chromatin states and transcriptional output in human somatic cells. Simultaneous targeting of bivalent domains with dCas9-TET1 and dCas9-DNMT3A induced a stable epigenetic memory, recalibrating the H3K4me3/H3K27me3 balance. This targeted epigenetic perturbation efficiently modulated cellular reprogramming trajectories, enhancing the efficiency of induced pluripotent stem cell generation without genomic alteration. Our findings establish a robust methodology for dissecting the causal link between specific epigenetic marks and cell fate decisions, offering a powerful tool for regenerative medicine and the study of epigenetic inheritance.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Precise Locus-Specific Epigenetic Reprogramming via dCas9-TET1/DNMT3A Fusion Proteins Modulates Cellular Plasticity

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are critical regulators of nuclear architecture and gene expression. Here, we identify CHROMA, a previously uncharacterized lncRNA that is essential for the silencing of a key developmental gene cluster. Using Chromatin Isolation by RNA Purification (ChIRP-seq) and Hi-C, we show that CHROMA acts as an architectural RNA, physically bridging distal regulatory elements. Mechanistically, CHROMA possesses intrinsically disordered regions that undergo liquid-liquid phase separation, forming biomolecular condensates that concentrate Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) and the insulator protein CTCF. This process facilitates the formation of a repressive chromatin hub, effectively sequestering the gene cluster within a transcriptionally silent compartment. Depletion of CHROMA disrupts this higher-order structure, leading to decompaction of the locus, loss of H3K27me3 marks, and aberrant gene activation. Our results unveil a mechanism whereby a lncRNA leverages phase separation to dynamically organize genome topology and enforce epigenetic silencing.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The lncRNA CHROMA Orchestrates Higher-Order Chromatin Looping via Phase Separation with PRC2 and CTCF

text: Transcriptional regulation often occurs within membraneless organelles formed by liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS). The FET family of RNA-binding proteins (FUS, EWS, TAF15) are implicated in this process, yet their direct role in assembling functional transcriptional condensates remains unclear. We demonstrate that the low-complexity domains of FET proteins are necessary and sufficient to drive LLPS in vitro and in vivo. Using high-resolution microscopy and fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP), we show these condensates are liquid-like and preferentially form at super-enhancers. These FET-driven compartments selectively concentrate RNA Polymerase II, the Mediator complex, and key coactivators like BRD4, thereby amplifying transcriptional output. Importantly, oncogenic FET fusion proteins exhibit altered phase behavior, leading to aberrant condensate formation and dysregulated expression of target genes. Our work elucidates a biophysical mechanism underpinning super-enhancer function and provides a framework for understanding how its disruption contributes to tumorigenesis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of FET Family Proteins Drives Transcriptional Condensate Formation and Super-Enhancer Activity

text: Cellular differentiation is a highly orchestrated process governed by dynamic changes in gene regulatory networks. To dissect these complexities, we performed simultaneous single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and assay for transposase-accessible chromatin using sequencing (scATAC-seq) on murine hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells. By integrating these multi-modal data, we constructed a high-resolution map of hematopoietic development, resolving previously ambiguous lineage commitment points. Pseudotemporal ordering revealed a precise temporal coupling between the expression of lineage-specifying transcription factors (TFs) and the opening of chromatin at their cognate binding motifs. We identified distinct regulatory elements that become accessible prior to transcriptional activation, a phenomenon we term 'chromatin priming.' Our integrated analysis uncovers the intricate choreography of regulatory events driving cell fate decisions, providing a powerful resource for understanding development and a blueprint for mapping other complex biological systems.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated Single-Cell Transcriptomic and Chromatin Accessibility Profiling Unveils Bifurcating Lineage Trajectories during Hematopoiesis

text: The maintenance of genome integrity relies on the accurate repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) through competing pathways like non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) and homologous recombination (HR). The choice between these pathways is tightly regulated by post-translational modifications. We report that the E3 ubiquitin ligase RNF168, a critical factor in DSB signaling, is dynamically modified by SUMO2/3. Using mass spectrometry, we identified a conserved SUMOylation site within RNF168's UIM domain. We demonstrate that SUMOylation of RNF168, mediated by the E3 ligase PIAS4, sterically hinders its interaction with the HR factor BRCA1, thereby promoting NHEJ. Conversely, de-SUMOylation by the SUMO protease SENP6 is required for efficient recruitment of BRCA1 to DSBs and subsequent HR initiation. Disruption of this SUMO-deSUMO cycle leads to genomic instability and hypersensitivity to PARP inhibitors, revealing a novel regulatory switch that fine-tunes DNA repair pathway choice with significant therapeutic implications.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dynamic SUMOylation of the RNF168 Ubiquitin Ligase Regulates DNA Double-Strand Break Repair Pathway Choice

text: G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) desensitization and signaling are critically mediated by β-arrestins. We present the cryo-electron microscopy structure of the human β2-adrenergic receptor (β2AR) bound to an engineered, monobody-stabilized β-arrestin-1, captured at 3.1 Å resolution. The structure reveals the receptor in a G protein-uncoupled conformation, with the intracellular loop 3 and transmembrane helix 6 adopting a distinct, arrestin-compatible state. The phosphorylated C-terminal tail of the receptor snakes through a positively charged groove in the N-lobe of β-arrestin, while the arrestin 'finger loop' inserts deep into the receptor's transmembrane core, a key interaction for stabilization. This high-resolution snapshot illuminates the molecular determinants of arrestin engagement following receptor phosphorylation, providing a structural basis for GPCR desensitization and the initiation of arrestin-mediated signaling pathways. These insights are crucial for the rational design of biased agonists with specific therapeutic profiles.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the β2-Adrenergic Receptor–β-Arrestin-1 Complex in a G Protein-Uncoupled, Phospho-Primed State

text: Messenger RNA stability is a key determinant of gene expression, yet the mechanisms linking translation dynamics to mRNA decay remain incompletely understood. Using ribosome profiling and mRNA half-life measurements in S. cerevisiae, we demonstrate that codon optimality directly dictates mRNA stability through a co-translational decay mechanism. We show that ribosomes stalling at clusters of non-optimal codons recruit the DEAD-box helicase Dhh1 (the human ortholog of DDX6). Dhh1, in turn, promotes the association of the CCR4-NOT deadenylase complex, triggering rapid deadenylation and subsequent 5'-to-3' exonucleolytic decay. Site-directed mutagenesis of codon clusters or depletion of Dhh1 uncouples translation elongation speed from mRNA turnover. This pathway represents a critical quality control mechanism that fine-tunes protein expression levels and ensures the rapid removal of potentially problematic transcripts, thereby safeguarding proteome homeostasis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Codon-Mediated Co-translational mRNA Decay is Regulated by Ribosome Stalling and the DEAD-box Helicase Dhh1

text: The mitochondrial genome contains small open reading frames (sORFs) that encode a novel class of signaling molecules known as mitochondrial-derived peptides (MDPs). Through a systematic bioinformatic and proteomic screen, we identified HNL7, a 21-amino-acid peptide encoded within the 16S rRNA locus. We demonstrate that HNL7 is actively translated and secreted from metabolically stressed cells. Functionally, secreted HNL7 acts as a paracrine signaling molecule, binding with high affinity to the formyl peptide receptor 2 (FPR2) on macrophages. Engagement of FPR2 by HNL7 triggers a signaling cascade that potently suppresses NF-κB activation and promotes a phenotypic switch from a pro-inflammatory M1 to an anti-inflammatory M2 polarization state. In vivo, administration of HNL7 ameliorates inflammatory tissue damage in a murine model of sepsis. Our findings reveal HNL7 as a novel mitokine that mediates intercellular communication, linking cellular stress to immunomodulation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The Mitochondrial-Derived Peptide Humanin-Like 7 (HNL7) Functions as a Paracrine Cytokine Regulating Macrophage Polarization

text: Translational control provides a rapid mechanism for cells to adapt to stress. We employed ribosome profiling with harringtonine treatment to globally map translation initiation sites (TISs) in human cells undergoing endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress. Our analysis revealed a profound reprogramming of the translatome, characterized by a widespread increase in translation initiation at upstream open reading frames (uORFs) within the 5' UTRs of hundreds of mRNAs. For canonical ER stress response genes, such as ATF4, this uORF-mediated repression is bypassed under stress due to eIF2α phosphorylation, allowing robust synthesis of the main protein. However, we discovered a new class of genes where stress-induced uORF translation serves as a dominant repressive mechanism to downregulate proteins involved in cell growth and proliferation. This global atlas of TISs uncovers a pervasive logic of translational control orchestrated by uORFs, which acts as a critical regulatory layer in the integrated stress response.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Global Mapping of Translation Initiation Sites by Ribo-seq Reveals Widespread uORF-Mediated Translational Control in Response to ER Stress

text: Cellular senescence is a state of irreversible cell cycle arrest implicated in aging and age-related diseases. While epigenetic dysregulation is a hallmark of senescence, the downstream consequences are poorly defined. We report that the progressive loss of epigenetic silencing in senescent cells leads to the transcriptional activation of long interspersed nuclear element-1 (LINE-1) retrotransposons. The resulting LINE-1 transcripts are reverse-transcribed in the cytoplasm, generating immunogenic DNA:RNA hybrids and extrachromosomal dsDNA. These nucleic acids are sensed by the pattern recognition receptor cGAS, which activates the STING pathway, leading to the production of type I interferons and other pro-inflammatory cytokines characteristic of the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP). Pharmacological inhibition of LINE-1 reverse transcriptase or genetic ablation of cGAS or STING significantly attenuates the SASP and delays the onset of senescence-related pathologies, linking retrotransposon activity directly to sterile inflammation in aging.
subject: Biyoloji
title: LINE-1 Retrotransposon Activation Triggers a cGAS-STING-Dependent Inflammatory Cascade Driving Cellular Senescence

text: We investigate multicolor Ramsey numbers for cliques embedded in geometric settings. Specifically, we establish a new super-polynomial lower bound for the technicolor Ramsey number R_k(K_n; q), denoting the minimum integer N such that any edge-coloring of the complete graph K_N with q colors contains a monochromatic K_n whose vertices form a specific geometric configuration. Our approach employs a novel probabilistic construction leveraging tensor products of Sidon sets in finite fields GF(p^r), which guarantees the avoidance of monochromatic geometric substructures. This algebraic method refines the classical Behrend construction for large sets free of 3-term arithmetic progressions. The result provides a significant improvement over existing bounds derived from the stepping-up lemma of Erdős and Hajnal and offers new insights into the notoriously difficult problem of determining Ramsey numbers for hypergraphs with forbidden geometric intersection patterns, linking this classical problem to questions in additive combinatorics and finite geometry.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Technicolor Ramsey Numbers for High-Dimensional Geometric Cliques

text: This paper addresses a generalization of the Erdős-Ko-Rado theorem concerning the maximum size of a k-uniform hypergraph on n vertices that forbids a specific family of intersection patterns. We introduce the concept of 't-avoidant' hypergraphs, where no collection of t edges has an intersection size belonging to a proscribed set L. Using a combination of the delta-system method, randomized shifting operations, and spectral techniques, we establish a sharp upper bound on the Turán density for several classes of t-avoidant hypergraphs. Our main theorem resolves a conjecture by Frankl and Füredi for large n, demonstrating that the extremal construction is either a sunflower or a complete subgraph. The proof involves analyzing the eigenvalues of the inclusion matrix associated with the hypergraph and provides a unified framework for solving a wide range of intersection-based extremal problems in set theory.
subject: Matematik
title: Extremal Problems for Hypergraphs with Forbidden Intersection Patterns

text: We analyze the threshold phenomenon for the emergence of non-trivial rational homology in the Linial-Meshulam model of random d-dimensional simplicial complexes, denoted Y_d(n, p). We pinpoint a sharp threshold p_c(n) for the vanishing of the (d-1)-th homology group H_{d-1}(Y; Q). The proof utilizes a refined analysis of the spectral gap of the combinatorial Laplacian acting on the space of (d-1)-chains and an extension of Garland's method for quotient complexes. This work extends the seminal results of Erdős and Rényi on graph connectivity (the case d=1) to higher-dimensional topological structures. Our methodology provides a precise characterization of the Betti numbers of random complexes around the critical window, demonstrating a phase transition from a homologically trivial state to a complex possessing a rich topological structure, thereby answering a central question in stochastic topology.
subject: Matematik
title: Homological Thresholds in Random Simplicial Complexes of Higher Dimension

text: A novel connection is established between the Schubert calculus of the flag manifold and the algebraic structure of a specific combinatorial Hopf algebra. We define a new basis for the algebra of decorated permutations, termed 'geodesic Stanley symmetric functions,' and demonstrate that its structure constants, under a specialized coproduct, precisely encode the intersection numbers of Schubert varieties. This framework provides a purely algebraic, monomial-free proof of the Pieri and Monk rules for Schubert polynomials. The construction relies on a representation-theoretic interpretation of the Bruhat order and offers a new algorithmic paradigm for computing Littlewood-Richardson coefficients for the cohomology of Grassmannians. Our results unify several disparate threads in algebraic combinatorics, including Stanley symmetric functions, non-commutative symmetric functions, and the geometry of flag varieties.
subject: Matematik
title: Schubert Polynomials, Decorated Permutations, and the Structure of Combinatorial Hopf Algebras

text: We derive a precise asymptotic formula for the number of permutations on n elements whose cycle lengths are all confined to a specified set S of integers. Our methodology integrates singularity analysis of multivariate generating functions with the saddle-point method, adapted to a logarithmic-analytic scheme. The main result establishes that the probability of a random permutation satisfying this restriction is governed by a function involving the Buchstab-de Bruijn function and the density of S. This refines the classical Erdős-Turán laws on cycle distributions and resolves a long-standing conjecture concerning permutations with only 'medium-sized' cycles. The proof hinges on a detailed analysis of the analytic properties of the underlying Dirichlet series associated with the cycle set S, providing a powerful tool for a broad class of enumerative problems with local restrictions.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotic Enumeration of Permutations with Restricted Cycle Spectra

text: We prove that the growth rate of any minor-closed class of matroids representable over a finite field GF(q) is a Pisot number. This extends Geelen and Whittle's result for graphs to the more general setting of q-ary matroids. The proof establishes a profound connection between matroid structure and formal language theory by encoding matroids as strings of circuit-cocircuit incidences and showing that minor-closed properties correspond to regular languages. A crucial component of our argument is a new decomposition theorem for 3-connected GF(q)-representable matroids, which asserts that any sufficiently large such matroid can be broken down into smaller components along a non-trivial 3-separation, unless it belongs to a well-defined family of 'turbo' matroids. This structural result is a significant step towards a Rota's conjecture analogue for finite fields.
subject: Matematik
title: Growth Rates of Minor-Closed Matroid Classes over Finite Fields

text: This work presents a novel recursive construction yielding infinite families of non-trivial t-(v, k, λ) designs with t ≥ 6. The method leverages the action of the projective general linear group PGL(2, q^n) on the points of the projective line PG(1, q^n). By identifying specific orbits of k-subsets whose pairwise intersection sizes are constrained within a narrow range, and applying a novel orbit amalgamation technique based on difference sets in the subfield GF(q), we construct new base blocks for the recursion. This process generates designs with parameters previously thought to be unattainable via standard group-theoretic or finite geometry approaches. Our findings affirmatively answer a long-standing question by Cameron and van Lint regarding the existence of an infinite family of 6-designs whose point sets grow exponentially, significantly advancing the landscape of combinatorial design theory.
subject: Matematik
title: A Recursive Construction for Infinite Families of Large-t Designs

text: We establish a quantitative version of the multidimensional Szemerédi theorem in finite, step-2 nilpotent groups of bounded nilpotency class. For any such group G and any subset A ⊆ G of density δ, we demonstrate the existence of a non-trivial k-term arithmetic progression, providing a polynomial bound on the size of G required to guarantee this. The proof introduces a 'non-abelian transference principle' that circumvents the direct application of Fourier analysis, which is problematic in this setting. Instead, we use Gowers uniformity norms and an inverse theorem for nilpotent groups to model A by a dense subset of an associated abelian group, where classical harmonic analysis techniques apply. This hybrid approach combines tools from higher-order Fourier analysis with the algebraic structure theory of nilpotent groups, yielding the first polynomial Roth-type result in a genuinely non-abelian context.
subject: Matematik
title: A Non-Abelian Transference Principle and Polynomial Bounds for Szemerédi's Theorem in Nilpotent Groups

text: We introduce a new class of valid inequalities for the asymmetric traveling salesman problem (ATSP), termed 'braid inequalities', which are derived from the polyhedral structure of a directed k-path relaxation. These inequalities generalize both subtour elimination and lifted comb constraints by forbidding certain interwoven path configurations within the underlying digraph. We prove that these inequalities are facet-defining for the ATSP polytope under mild coprimality conditions on the braid parameters. A key contribution is a polynomial-time separation algorithm for a significant subclass of these inequalities, based on a minimum-cut computation in an auxiliary network. Computational experiments on the TSPLIB benchmark library demonstrate that incorporating braid inequalities within a branch-and-cut framework leads to a substantial reduction in the integrality gap and significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art formulations for hard, structured ATSP instances.
subject: Matematik
title: Braid Inequalities and the Polyhedral Structure of the Asymmetric Traveling Salesman Problem

text: Let P be a finite partially ordered set. We study the chromatic number of the Kneser hypergraph of P, denoted KG^r(P), whose vertices are the r-chains of P and whose edges are collections of pairwise non-disjoint chains. By applying the nerve theorem and Forman's discrete Morse theory to the order complex of P, Δ(P), we establish a tight lower bound on χ(KG^r(P)) in terms of the topological connectivity of specific subcomplexes of Δ(P). This result generalizes Lovász's celebrated theorem on the chromatic number of Kneser graphs (the case where P is an antichain) and provides a unified topological framework for a wide range of problems in extremal set theory. As a direct corollary, when P is the Boolean lattice B_n, our method recovers the classical Erdős-Ko-Rado theorem as a statement about the non-colorability of a specific hypergraph.
subject: Matematik
title: Topological Lower Bounds on the Chromatic Number of Non-Disjoint Chains in Posets

text: We present a theoretical framework and experimental protocol for observing the quantum Zeno effect in a strongly correlated many-body system. Our model considers a Bose-Hubbard lattice gas coupled to a high-finesse optical cavity, where frequent, non-destructive measurements are implemented via projective photon counting of the cavity output field. We derive a non-Hermitian effective Hamiltonian that incorporates both the coherent tunneling dynamics and the measurement-induced back-action. Numerical simulations using time-evolving block decimation (TEBD) demonstrate that for measurement frequencies exceeding a critical threshold determined by the inter-site tunneling rate, the system's evolution is confined to a 'decoherence-free' subspace, effectively freezing the superfluid-to-Mott insulator quantum phase transition. Our analysis of the Liouvillian spectral gap reveals the scaling of this Zeno-protected state with system size and interaction strength, providing a robust pathway for engineering and stabilizing exotic quantum states against environmental decoherence through structured projective measurements.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Quantum Zeno Dynamics in a Strongly Correlated Many-Body System via Non-Destructive Cavity QED

text: We investigate the anisotropic modulation of Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) polarization B-modes induced by primordial non-Gaussianity of the local type, parameterized by f_NL. A spatially varying quadrupolar field, sourced by a long-wavelength scalar perturbation, introduces statistical anisotropies in the small-scale B-mode power spectrum. We compute the full trispectrum between two scalar modes and two tensor modes, ⟨ζζgg⟩, and derive the resulting off-diagonal correlations in the B-mode spherical harmonic coefficients. Using a separable modal decomposition, we formulate an optimal quadratic estimator for the quadrupolar amplitude, demonstrating its potential to constrain f_NL independently of the primordial bispectrum. Fisher matrix forecasts for next-generation CMB experiments like CMB-S4 indicate that this method could achieve a sensitivity of σ(f_NL) ≈ 5, providing a complementary and powerful probe of inflationary physics that breaks the statistical isotropy of the primordial gravitational wave background.
subject: Fizik
title: Anisotropic Signatures of Primordial Non-Gaussianity in Cosmic Microwave Background Polarization B-modes

text: We report on the theoretical realization of Majorana zero modes in a heterostructure comprising a quantum anomalous Hall insulator (QAHI) proximitized by an s-wave superconductor. The intrinsic chirality of the QAHI edge states, when gapped by the proximity effect, naturally gives rise to a one-dimensional topological superconductor without the need for external magnetic fields or fine-tuning of chemical potentials. We solve the Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations self-consistently for a realistic device geometry, demonstrating the formation of localized, spatially separated Majorana zero modes at the ends of the superconducting region. Furthermore, we calculate the non-local tunneling conductance matrix, revealing quantized zero-bias peaks characteristic of these emergent fermions. Our analysis of the braiding statistics confirms their non-Abelian nature, proposing a scalable and robust platform for topological quantum computation based on electrically controlled manipulation of chiral edge states.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergent Majorana Fermions and Non-Abelian Statistics in a Proximity-Coupled Chiral Superconducting Heterostructure

text: We explore the phenomenological consequences of quantum gravity-motivated departures from the classical black hole event horizon, such as firewalls or effective reflective boundary conditions. Using a Regge-Wheeler-Zerilli formalism modified with a partially reflective membrane located a Planck-length proper distance from the Schwarzschild radius, we compute the late-time gravitational wave signal following a binary black hole merger. Our time-domain analysis of the post-merger ringdown reveals a train of delayed, attenuated 'echoes' with a characteristic time separation dictated by the membrane's location. We develop a matched-filtering template bank to search for these echo signals in existing LIGO/Virgo data. By analyzing the morphology and frequency evolution of these echoes, we demonstrate the potential to constrain parameters of quantum horizon models, offering a novel observational window into the interplay between general relativity and quantum mechanics in the strong-field regime.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Wave Echoes from Planck-Scale Modifications to Black Hole Event Horizons

text: We propose a new method to constrain the existence of axion-like particles (ALPs) by examining their impact on the flavor composition of high-energy astrophysical neutrinos. PeV-scale neutrinos traversing extragalactic magnetic fields can stimulate the decay of ALPs into photon pairs via the Primakoff process, creating a resonant absorption feature in the neutrino flux. This process, ν + a → ν + γ + γ, depletes the neutrino energy spectrum in a flavor-dependent manner due to the distinct energy-loss profiles for electron, muon, and tau neutrinos. We perform detailed Monte Carlo simulations of neutrino propagation from distant blazars, incorporating ALP-neutrino interactions within a realistic intergalactic magnetic field model. By analyzing the expected spectral modulations in the flavor ratio (the 'flavogram') at detectors like IceCube and the future KM3NeT, we derive projected constraints on the axion-photon coupling g_aγγ that are competitive with, and complementary to, existing astrophysical bounds, particularly in the meV–eV axion mass range.
subject: Fizik
title: Constraints on Axion-Photon Coupling from Spectral Irregularities in High-Energy Astrophysical Neutrino Flavograms

text: We derive a set of generalized fluctuation theorems for a class of active matter systems characterized by non-reciprocal interactions, where action and reaction are not equal and opposite. Starting from a microscopic Fokker-Planck equation for self-propelled particles with asymmetric couplings, we identify the distinct contributions to the total entropy production rate arising from time-reversal symmetry breaking at both the single-particle and collective levels. Our formulation reveals a direct link between the violation of detailed balance and the emergent macroscopic currents and stresses that define the system's non-equilibrium steady state. We validate our theoretical results with agent-based simulations of a predator-prey model, demonstrating that the degree of non-reciprocity directly governs the probability distribution of entropy fluctuations. This framework provides a rigorous thermodynamic foundation for understanding the principles of self-organization and pattern formation in biological and synthetic active systems far from equilibrium.
subject: Fizik
title: Generalized Fluctuation Theorems and Entropy Production in Non-Reciprocal Active Matter Systems

text: We investigate the nature of entanglement entropy in de Sitter (dS) spacetime using the framework of the dS/CFT correspondence. By generalizing the Ryu-Takayanagi formula to a putative dS geometry with a Euclidean continuation, we calculate the entanglement entropy of a subregion within the dS static patch as perceived by a central observer. The minimal surface, anchored to the boundary of the subregion, probes the bulk geometry towards the cosmological horizon. Our results indicate that for sufficiently large subregions, the minimal surface undergoes a phase transition, leading to an entropy that scales with the thermal entropy of the cosmological horizon, consistent with the Page curve for an evaporating black hole. This suggests a holographic mechanism for the purification of Hawking radiation from the dS horizon, providing a resolution to the cosmological information paradox wherein the observer's causal patch remains a pure state over cosmic timescales.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy in dS/CFT and the Information Paradox in a Cosmological Horizon

text: We perform three-dimensional general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic (GRMHD) simulations to investigate the stability of Poynting-flux-dominated jets interacting with a surrounding accretion disk wind. Our simulations, executed with the HARM-PI code on a Kerr spacetime metric, reveal the development of a virulent Kelvin-Helmholtz (KH) instability at the interface layer, driven by the velocity shear between the ultra-relativistic jet (Lorentz factor Γ > 10) and the sub-relativistic sheath. The growth rate and saturation amplitude of the instability are strongly dependent on the magnetic field topology and magnetization parameter σ. For parallel magnetic fields, the instability evolves into magnetic reconnection events, disrupting the ordered field lines and facilitating particle acceleration via plasmoid formation. For perpendicular fields, the instability is partially suppressed but drives significant entrainment of baryonic matter, impacting the jet's propagation efficiency and radiative signature. These findings provide critical insights into jet collimation, stability, and non-thermal emission in active galactic nuclei.
subject: Fizik
title: Relativistic Magnetohydrodynamic Instabilities at the Jet-Sheath Interface of Active Galactic Nuclei

text: We demonstrate the existence of topological phonon modes and resulting chiral heat transport in a non-centrosymmetric Kagome lattice with tailored next-nearest-neighbor interactions. By breaking inversion symmetry, we lift the degeneracy of the Dirac-like phonon cones at the K and K' points of the Brillouin zone, opening a non-trivial bulk band gap. We compute the phononic Berry curvature, which acts as a fictitious magnetic field in momentum space, and calculate the associated phononic Chern number, confirming the topological nature of the gap. The bulk-boundary correspondence guarantees the existence of topologically protected, unidirectional edge states. Using non-equilibrium Green's function simulations, we show that these chiral edge modes enable robust, dissipationless heat transport along the system's boundaries, which is insensitive to lattice defects and disorder. This work establishes a viable pathway for realizing phononic topological insulators and controlling heat flow at the nanoscale through lattice symmetry engineering.
subject: Fizik
title: Topological Phonon Modes and Chiral Heat Transport in a Non-Centrosymmetric Kagome Lattice

text: We report a high-precision measurement of the Casimir force between a gold-coated sphere and a sinusoidally corrugated silicon surface, probing the limits of the proximity force approximation (PFA). Our experiment utilizes a high-Q silicon torsional micro-resonator to achieve sub-piconewton force sensitivity at separation distances ranging from 100 nm to 2 µm. The non-trivial boundary geometry introduces a significant, calculable deviation from the PFA prediction, which we analyze using a scattering matrix formalism that accounts for the exact Green's functions of the electromagnetic field. We find that the measured force is in excellent agreement (within 0.5%) with the exact theory, while deviating from the PFA by up to 15% at separations comparable to the corrugation wavelength. Our results provide a stringent quantitative test of quantum vacuum fluctuation theory in complex geometries and place new constraints on hypothetical non-Newtonian forces in the sub-micron range.
subject: Fizik
title: Precision Measurement of the Casimir Force in a Non-Planar Geometry Using a Torsional Micro-Resonator

text: Lactate, traditionally viewed as a metabolic byproduct, is emerging as a crucial signaling molecule in the brain. Here, we investigate the role of histone lysine lactylation (Kla), a novel epigenetic modification, in neuronal plasticity. Using chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) and quantitative proteomics in primary hippocampal neurons, we demonstrate that neuronal activity induces a rapid and transient increase in H3K18la at the enhancers and promoters of immediate early genes (IEGs), including c-Fos and Arc. This process is contingent upon lactate dehydrogenase A (LDHA)-mediated lactate production. Pharmacological and genetic inhibition of this pathway abrogates long-term potentiation (LTP) and impairs spatial memory formation in mice. Our findings reveal a direct mechanistic link between metabolic state and epigenetic regulation, positioning histone lactylation as a critical transducer of neuronal activity into lasting synaptic and cognitive changes, thereby providing a new axis for therapeutic intervention in neurological disorders.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Lactate-Dependent Histone Lactylation Modulates Synaptic Plasticity through Chromatin Remodeling of Immediate Early Genes

text: The CRISPR-Cas13 family of RNA-guided RNA nucleases offers powerful tools for RNA manipulation, yet off-target effects and temperature sensitivity limit their therapeutic application. Here, we report the discovery and characterization of a novel Cas13d ortholog, LmaCas13d, from a thermophilic archaeon. We present its 2.8 Å resolution cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure in complex with its crRNA and a target RNA molecule. The structure reveals a uniquely configured Helical-2 domain and a bifurcated HEPN nuclease active site, which collectively contribute to enhanced target specificity and reduced collateral RNA cleavage activity. Isothermal titration calorimetry and single-molecule fluorescence assays confirm sub-nanomolar binding affinity and a stringent protospacer flanking site (PFS) requirement. In human cell lines, LmaCas13d demonstrates superior on-target knockdown efficiency with a significantly improved specificity profile compared to existing Cas13 variants. This work elucidates the structural determinants of high-fidelity RNA targeting and provides a robust, thermostable effector for advanced RNA-based diagnostics.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure and Mechanistic Insights into a Thermophilic Cas13d Ortholog for High-Fidelity RNA Targeting

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are key regulators of nuclear architecture, often functioning within ribonucleoprotein (RNP) condensates. The paraspeckle, a subnuclear body formed around the lncRNA NEAT1, is a paradigm for such structures. We investigated the role of another abundant lncRNA, MALAT1, in modulating paraspeckle dynamics. Using super-resolution microscopy and fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP), we show that MALAT1 transiently localizes to the paraspeckle periphery, altering its liquid-like properties and reducing the exchange rate of core protein components like NONO and SFPQ. In vitro reconstitution assays demonstrate that MALAT1, through specific RNA-protein and RNA-RNA interactions, lowers the saturation concentration required for NEAT1-driven liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) and increases the viscosity of the resulting condensates. Depletion of MALAT1 leads to hyper-assembly of paraspeckles and altered retention of target mRNAs, suggesting MALAT1 functions as a dynamic rheostat for RNP granule homeostasis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The lncRNA MALAT1 Acts as a Molecular Scaffold to Modulate the Material Properties of Paraspeckles via Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation

text: Mitochondrial dynamics, the balance between fission and fusion, are critical for cellular homeostasis, and their dysregulation is implicated in numerous pathologies. Post-translational modifications, particularly phosphorylation, are known to regulate this process, but a systems-level understanding is lacking. We employed a stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture (SILAC)-based quantitative phosphoproteomics approach to map dynamic phosphorylation events during chemically induced mitochondrial fission. We identified over 2,000 unique phosphosites on mitochondrial and associated proteins, with a significant enrichment on proteins involved in membrane remodeling. Our analysis revealed a coordinated network involving Aurora Kinase A (AURKA) and Protein Phosphatase 2A (PP2A) that converges on the fission GTPase DRP1 at serine 616. Functional validation using kinase inhibitors and targeted mutagenesis confirms this axis as a critical regulatory switch. This comprehensive phosphosignaling map provides a valuable resource and uncovers a previously unappreciated regulatory network controlling mitochondrial morphology.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Multiplexed Phosphoproteomics Uncovers a DRP1-Centric Kinase-Phosphatase Network Governing Mitochondrial Fission-Fusion Dynamics

text: The endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation (ERAD) pathway ensures proteostasis by eliminating misfolded proteins. We have identified a novel membrane-embedded E3 ubiquitin ligase complex comprising RNF185 and the thioredoxin-related transmembrane protein TMX1, crucial for the disposal of misfolded luminal glycoproteins. Using co-immunoprecipitation coupled with mass spectrometry, we established the core components and interactome of this complex. Cryo-EM reconstruction of the human RNF185-TMX1 heterodimer revealed a unique architecture where the TMX1 redox-active site is positioned to engage substrates, while the RNF185 RING domain recruits E2 conjugating enzymes. Functional assays demonstrate that this complex specifically targets N-glycosylated proteins recognized by the lectin OS-9, facilitating their retro-translocation via the Derlin-1 channel. Depletion of either RNF185 or TMX1 results in the accumulation of ERAD-L substrates and sensitizes cells to ER stress. This work defines a new E3 ligase machinery in the ERAD-L pathway, providing mechanistic insight into substrate recognition.
subject: Biyoloji
title: RNF185-TMX1 Constitutes a Novel E3 Ubiquitin Ligase Complex for ER-Associated Degradation of Misfolded Glycoproteins

text: G-quadruplexes (G4s) are non-canonical secondary DNA structures that present formidable barriers to DNA replication. Helicases are essential for their resolution, but the underlying molecular mechanisms remain elusive. Here, we employ single-molecule Förster Resonance Energy Transfer (smFRET) to directly visualize the unwinding of telomeric G4 DNA by the human RecQ-like helicase, BLM. Our real-time trajectories reveal that BLM engages the G4 structure and utilizes an iterative, ATP-dependent translocation mechanism characterized by repetitive one-to-three base-pair steps. We observed frequent pausing and backtracking, indicating a stochastic 'trial-and-error' process before successful G4 unfolding. Mutation of the RQC domain disrupts this iterative process, leading to persistent stalling and incomplete resolution. These findings provide unprecedented mechanistic detail into how specialized helicases negotiate topologically complex DNA structures, highlighting a dynamic interplay between helicase translocation and G4 stability that is critical for maintaining genome integrity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Single-Molecule FRET Reveals Helicase Dynamics and Iterative Unwinding Mechanism at G-Quadruplex DNA Structures

text: N6-methyladenosine (m6A) is the most prevalent internal modification on eukaryotic mRNA, influencing RNA fate and function. We performed a comprehensive analysis combining m6A-seq and RNA-seq in patient-derived pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) organoids harboring KRAS mutations. We identified a distinct m6A landscape characterized by hypermethylation of transcripts associated with the cell cycle. Strikingly, m6A deposition within intronic regions near splice sites correlated with exon skipping events in a cohort of proto-oncogenes. We demonstrate that the m6A reader YTHDC1 preferentially binds to these methylated introns, recruiting the splicing factor SRSF3 and thereby repelling the core spliceosome machinery. Genetic depletion of the m6A writer METTL3 reverses these splicing patterns and attenuates tumor growth in xenograft models. Our study uncovers a critical epitranscriptomic layer of gene regulation in PDAC, linking m6A modification directly to oncogenic alternative splicing and providing new therapeutic targets.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Epitranscriptomic Profiling Reveals m6A-Dependent Regulation of Alternative Splicing in KRAS-Driven Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma

text: Pre-mRNA splicing is executed by the spliceosome, a dynamic macromolecular machine. The transition from the catalytically activated B* complex to the C complex is concomitant with the first catalytic step, generating a lariat-intron intermediate. We present the 3.4 Å resolution cryo-electron microscopy structure of the human C complex, capturing the spliceosome immediately after the first reaction. The structure reveals how the U6 snRNA catalytic metal-binding site is reconfigured and how the 2'-5' phosphodiester bond of the lariat is accommodated within the active site, stabilized by conserved proteins Prp8 and Prp17. Furthermore, the 3' splice site is positioned near the active center, primed for the second catalytic step. This structural snapshot provides critical mechanistic insights into the catalytic mechanism of splicing, the recognition of the branched intron intermediate, and the conformational dynamics that license the second transesterification reaction, a pivotal step in eukaryotic gene expression.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Human Spliceosome C Complex Reveals Mechanisms of Intron Lariat Formation

text: Synthetic biology requires tools for precise, user-defined control over gene expression. Riboswitches, cis-acting RNA elements that regulate gene expression in response to small-molecule ligands, offer a powerful platform, but their application in mammalian cells is hindered by a lack of orthogonality and dynamic range. We developed a computational design and high-throughput screening platform to engineer a suite of synthetic tetracycline-responsive riboswitches. By combining a computationally designed aptamer with a self-cleaving hammerhead ribozyme, we achieved over 100-fold induction with low basal expression. We demonstrate the utility of these orthogonal riboswitches by creating a dual-input AND gate that independently controls two components of a chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell signaling pathway. This work provides a robust and scalable framework for generating bespoke RNA devices, enabling sophisticated, multi-layered logical control over complex cellular behaviors for therapeutic and biotechnological applications.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Engineering Orthogonal, Ligand-Gated Riboswitches for Spatiotemporal Control of Gene Expression in Mammalian Systems

text: Cellular adaptation to metabolic stress involves complex interplay between signaling pathways. The unfolded protein response (UPR) and autophagy are key homeostatic mechanisms, but their crosstalk under conditions of lipotoxicity remains poorly defined. We employed a systems-level approach, integrating quantitative proteomics and untargeted metabolomics, to profile hepatic cells subjected to palmitate-induced ER stress. The analysis revealed a significant rewiring of cellular metabolism and identified the PERK-eIF2α-ATF4 branch of the UPR as the central hub. We demonstrate that ATF4 directly transcriptionally upregulates a suite of autophagy-related genes, including MAP1LC3B and SQSTM1, thereby promoting autophagic flux to clear lipid droplets and damaged organelles (lipophagy). Pharmacological or genetic inhibition of PERK abrogates this adaptive autophagic response, leading to exacerbated steatosis and apoptosis. Our findings delineate a critical transcriptional network linking ER stress sensing to autophagic clearance, providing a molecular basis for understanding cellular resilience.
subject: Biyoloji
title: PERK-Mediated ATF4 Activation Integrates the Unfolded Protein Response and Autophagy in Response to Lipotoxicity

text: We investigate the induced saturation number, indsat(H, G_n), for a fixed graph H in a sequence of host graphs {G_n} belonging to a hereditary property P. This work extends classical saturation problems by imposing an induced subgraph condition, which fundamentally alters the extremal landscape. We establish a general upper bound for indsat(H, G_n) when P is the property of being F-free, linking it to the Turán number ex(n, F) and the Ramsey number R(H, H). Our primary result provides tight bounds for H-saturation in K_t-free graphs, utilizing a novel variant of the dependent random choice lemma combined with a structural analysis of nearly regular subgraphs. We demonstrate that for certain bipartite H, the induced saturation number is polylogarithmic in n, a sharp contrast to the linear bounds in unrestricted host graphs. These findings resolve a conjecture by Martin and Smith and open new avenues in Ramsey-Turán theory for sparse hereditary classes.
subject: Matematik
title: Induced Saturation Problems in Hereditary Graph Classes

text: This paper establishes the Schur positivity of a new family of symmetric functions arising from skew-linked partition diagrams. We introduce the concept of a 'toric ribbon' structure and prove that the corresponding skew Schur functions expand with non-negative integer coefficients in the basis of Schur functions. The proof relies on a bijective correspondence between semi-standard Young tableaux on these skew shapes and configurations of a solvable lattice model, generalizing the well-known Robinson-Schensted-Knuth correspondence. As a corollary, we provide a combinatorial interpretation for the plethystic decomposition of the Frobenius character of certain graded representations of the symmetric group S_n. This resolves a longstanding problem in algebraic combinatorics concerning the representation-theoretic meaning of specific plethystic coefficients and provides a unified framework for several previously disparate positivity results, including those related to Macdonald polynomials at t=0.
subject: Matematik
title: Schur Positivity of Skew-Linked Partitions and Plethystic Decompositions

text: We explore generalizations of the Erdős-Ko-Rado theorem for k-uniform hypergraphs by considering intersection properties on multiple sets. A family F of k-sets is (s, r)-intersecting if any r sets in F have an intersection of size at least s. We determine the maximum size of such families for n > n_0(k, r, s), establishing a sharp threshold. Our proof integrates the Katona circle method with a refined algebraic shifting technique, allowing for precise control over the shadow of the family. A key innovation is the application of the Delta-system method in a probabilistic setting to handle the combinatorial complexity for small intersection sizes. This framework also yields a stability version of the theorem, demonstrating that near-optimal families are structurally close to a sunflower with s-petals. The results have direct implications for coding theory and the analysis of extremal problems on simplicial complexes.
subject: Matematik
title: Higher-Order Intersecting Families and the Delta-System Method

text: We analyze the spectral properties and dynamics of random walks on inhomogeneous random graph models, specifically the Chung-Lu model with power-law degree distributions. Our focus is on the sub-critical and critical regimes where traditional giant component analysis is insufficient. We establish precise asymptotic results for the spectral gap of the normalized Laplacian matrix, showing it scales inversely with a polynomial of the vertex count, with the exponent depending on the power-law parameter. This demonstrates the onset of anomalous diffusion, where the mixing time of the random walk deviates significantly from the O(log n) behavior seen in Erdős-Rényi graphs. The proof leverages Stieltjes transform methods for random matrices and a detailed analysis of local weak convergence limits of the graph sequence. Our findings provide a rigorous mathematical foundation for phenomena observed in complex networks, such as slow information propagation in scale-free architectures.
subject: Matematik
title: Anomalous Diffusion and Spectral Properties on Inhomogeneous Random Graphs

text: We prove that the Tutte polynomial T_M(x, y) of any matroid M that is representable over a field of characteristic zero satisfies a form of log-concavity along specific lines in the (x, y)-plane. This result is established by associating the matroid to a sequence of interlacing polynomials, constructed via a novel iterative deletion-contraction process. This framework generalizes recent breakthroughs on the log-concavity of the characteristic polynomial of a matroid, a conjecture by Rota. A key technical lemma involves demonstrating that the basis generating polynomial of a restricted minor of M maintains real-rootedness under certain operations, which is proven using the theory of strongly log-concave sequences and operator theory. This result provides a unified proof of several conjectures in combinatorial geometry and furnishes a powerful new tool for analyzing the algebraic structure of matroids and their associated valuations.
subject: Matematik
title: Log-Concave Polynomials and Interlacing Families in Matroid Theory

text: We derive precise asymptotic formulae for the number of directed convex polygons on the square lattice with a fixed perimeter n. The problem is approached through the construction of a multivariate generating function F(x, y, z) that encodes perimeter, area, and width. Using the kernel method, we solve the functional equation satisfied by F, revealing a connection to algebraic functions and D-finite series. Singularity analysis of the resulting algebraic expression for the perimeter generating function P(z) = F(1, 1, z) allows us to extract the dominant asymptotic term. We prove that the number of such polygons is asymptotically c * n^(-5/2) * μ^n, where μ is an algebraic constant. The methodology is robust and extends to other lattices, such as the triangular and hexagonal lattices, thereby unifying several disparate results in the field of lattice path enumeration and combinatorics of polyominoes.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotic Enumeration of Directed Polygons on Lattices via Multivariate Generating Functions

text: We investigate the topological properties of neighborhood complexes N(G) for vertices in generalized Kneser graphs K(n, k, t). Specifically, we determine the homotopy type of N(K(n, k, t)) for a wide range of parameters n, k, and t. Our main result establishes that for n sufficiently large relative to k and t, the complex is homotopy equivalent to a wedge of spheres of dimension k-2t-1. The proof employs discrete Morse theory, constructing an explicit acyclic matching on the face poset of the simplicial complex. A crucial step involves leveraging a stability theorem for intersecting families of t-intersecting k-sets. As a direct corollary, we derive new lower bounds on the chromatic number of these Kneser graphs, complementing the celebrated Lovász bound obtained via the Borsuk-Ulam theorem. This work highlights the deep interplay between combinatorial structure and algebraic topology in extremal combinatorics.
subject: Matematik
title: Homotopy and Collapsibility of Neighborhood Complexes in Kneser Graphs

text: This paper presents new constructions of non-isomorphic cyclic Steiner systems S(2, q+1, q^2+q+1), derived from the points and lines of the projective plane PG(2, q). By analyzing the action of Singer cycles on the flag variety of PG(2, q), we identify specific orbits that yield resolvable decompositions of the complete graph K_{q^2+q+1}. The construction hinges on a novel application of character theory of finite fields to constrain the possible intersection patterns of the resulting blocks. We prove that for certain prime powers q, this method produces designs with trivial automorphism groups, resolving a long-standing question on the existence of rigid projective planes. Furthermore, we demonstrate that these structures give rise to new families of difference sets in non-abelian groups, expanding the known catalogue of combinatorial designs with high degrees of symmetry and regularity.
subject: Matematik
title: Cyclic Decompositions of Projective Geometries and their Automorphism Groups

text: We establish a transference principle for polynomial progressions in sparse subsets of finite fields. Let A be a subset of F_p^n with density δ, and suppose A is 'pseudorandom' in the sense that it has small Gowers uniformity norms U^k. We prove that A contains the expected number of polynomial progressions {x, x+P_1(y), ..., x+P_m(y)} for a system of polynomials P_i with distinct degrees, provided δ is polynomially larger than the inverse of the Gowers norm bound. This extends the work of Green and Tao on linear progressions. The proof combines techniques from higher-order Fourier analysis with a density increment argument adapted for polynomial structures. A key innovation is the development of a polynomial version of the Koopman-von Neumann decomposition, which allows for an efficient decomposition of functions into a structured part and a Gowers-uniform part, thereby isolating the arithmetic structure.
subject: Matematik
title: Quantitative Bounds for Polynomial Progressions in Sparse Pseudorandom Sets

text: We prove a complete complexity dichotomy for the list homomorphism problem (ListHom(H)) for the class of reflexive directed graphs. We show that for any fixed reflexive digraph H, the problem of deciding whether a given reflexive digraph G admits a homomorphism to H with specified lists of allowed images for each vertex is either solvable in polynomial time or is NP-complete. The tractable cases are characterized by the existence of a 'minion' polymorphism satisfying a specific set of identities, namely those of a weak near-unanimity operation. This algebraic criterion unifies and generalizes all previously known tractable classes. The proof relies on the universal-algebraic approach to constraint satisfaction problems, establishing a connection between the relational clone associated with H and its computational complexity. Our result settles the dichotomy conjecture for this significant graph class and provides a template for analyzing similar problems on other relational structures.
subject: Matematik
title: The Complexity of List Homomorphisms for Reflexive Digraphs and Universal Algebra

text: Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome (HGPS) is a fatal pediatric disorder caused by a de novo c.1824C>T point mutation in the LMNA gene, leading to the production of a truncated, farnesylated prelamin A variant known as progerin. We investigated the therapeutic potential of in vivo cytosine base editing to correct this pathogenic mutation. Utilizing an adenine-avoiDAnce base editor (ABE8e) fused to Cas9 nickase and delivered systemically via adeno-associated virus 9 (AAV9), we targeted the pathogenic locus in an LmnaG609G/G609G murine model of HGPS. A single intravenous injection resulted in high-efficiency C-to-T correction in multiple tissues, including the aorta and liver, restoring canonical splicing and dramatically reducing progerin protein levels. This intervention significantly ameliorated hallmark HGPS-associated phenotypes, including prevention of aortic medial smooth muscle cell loss and adventitial fibrosis, and extended median lifespan by over 150%. These findings demonstrate the profound therapeutic efficacy of precision base editing for HGPS, providing a robust preclinical rationale for its clinical translation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Precision Cytosine Base Editing Ameliorates Lamin A-Associated Progeroid Phenotypes in a Murine Model of Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are critical regulators of chromatin architecture and gene expression, yet their precise molecular mechanisms remain largely enigmatic. Here, we identify CHROMA, a previously uncharacterized lncRNA, as a key scaffold for the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2). Using Chromatin Isolation by RNA Purification (ChIRP-seq), we show that CHROMA co-localizes with EZH2 and H3K27me3 marks at developmentally regulated gene loci. In vitro reconstitution assays and super-resolution microscopy reveal that CHROMA possesses intrinsically disordered regions that induce liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) upon binding to PRC2 components. This process forms biomolecular condensates that concentrate PRC2, thereby locally enhancing its histone methyltransferase activity and promoting robust H3K27 trimethylation. Genetic ablation of CHROMA in embryonic stem cells leads to de-repression of its target genes and defects in cellular differentiation. Our study uncovers a mechanism whereby a lncRNA scaffold drives epigenetic silencing through the formation of phase-separated nuclear compartments.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The lncRNA CHROMA Orchestrates Polycomb-Mediated Gene Silencing through Phase Separation with PRC2

text: Intratumoral heterogeneity is a major obstacle to effective glioblastoma (GBM) therapy. To dissect this complexity, we performed simultaneous single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and single-cell Assay for Transposase-Accessible Chromatin sequencing (scATAC-seq) on patient-derived xenograft models throughout treatment with temozolomide. Our integrated analysis resolved distinct cellular states, including a quiescent, therapy-resistant glioma stem cell (GSC) population characterized by a unique open chromatin landscape. Pseudotemporal trajectory inference traced the clonal evolution from chemosensitive progenitors to these resistant GSCs, identifying a transcriptional switch governed by the SOX family of transcription factors. We demonstrate that the epigenetic priming of specific enhancer elements precedes transcriptional reprogramming and resistance acquisition. Pharmacological inhibition of the epigenetic reader BRD4, which binds to these de novo enhancers, successfully re-sensitized resistant GBM cells to chemotherapy. This multi-omic approach provides unprecedented resolution of the dynamic cellular and molecular pathways driving therapeutic failure in GBM.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated Single-Cell Multi-Omics Delineates Clonal Evolution and Therapeutic Resistance in Glioblastoma
