text: The Fanconi Anemia (FA) pathway is a crucial DNA repair network that resolves interstrand crosslinks (ICLs). A central event in this pathway is the monoubiquitination of the FANCI-FANCD2 (ID2) complex at the site of DNA damage. We report the 2.9 Å resolution cryo-electron microscopy structure of the human ID2 complex bound to the E3 ubiquitin ligase FANCL core complex and a synthetic DNA substrate mimicking a stalled replication fork. The structure reveals how the DNA is threaded through a channel in the ID2 heterodimer, inducing a conformational change that exposes the FANCD2 lysine 561 residue for ubiquitination. The HEAT repeats of FANCL form an extensive interface with FANCI, correctly positioning the catalytic RING domain for ubiquitin transfer from the Ube2T E2 enzyme. This structural snapshot provides a detailed mechanistic basis for how DNA damage is recognized and transduced into a critical post-translational modification that orchestrates downstream repair events.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the FANCI-FANCD2 Monoubiquitination Complex Bound to a Stalled Replication Fork Mimic

text: Transcription in mammalian cells occurs in stochastic bursts, but the underlying molecular mechanism remains unclear. Here, we combine live-cell single-molecule imaging with optogenetic tools to investigate the link between transcriptional condensates and gene bursting kinetics. We show that super-enhancers recruit high concentrations of transcription factors and coactivators, including BRD4 and MED1, to form biomolecular condensates via liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS). These condensates function as hubs for RNA Polymerase II (Pol II) recruitment and are highly dynamic, with their assembly and disassembly correlating directly with the initiation and termination of transcriptional bursts. Mechanistically, we demonstrate that these condensates locally concentrate Positive Transcription Elongation Factor b (P-TEFb), leading to efficient phosphorylation of the Pol II C-terminal domain Serine 2 residue, which facilitates promoter escape and robust transcriptional elongation. Our findings suggest that the physical properties of phase-separated condensates provide a direct biophysical basis for the stochastic nature of gene expression.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Super-Enhancer-Associated Transcriptional Condensates Drive Stochastic Gene Bursting through Localized Pol II Phosphorylation

text: Viruses extensively remodel the host cell's translational machinery to favor viral protein synthesis. To delineate this process during SARS-CoV-2 infection, we performed ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) coupled with RNA-seq in human lung epithelial cells. Our data reveal a profound, time-dependent global host shutoff mediated by the viral non-structural protein 1 (nsp1), which physically obstructs the mRNA entry channel of the 40S ribosomal subunit. Despite this global repression, viral mRNAs are translated with remarkably high efficiency. We show that SARS-CoV-2 transcripts utilize specific 5' UTR structural elements and possess a codon usage pattern that is highly adapted to the tRNA pools of human cells, enabling them to outcompete host mRNAs for the limited pool of active ribosomes. Furthermore, our high-resolution footprinting identifies several previously unannotated, actively translated upstream open reading frames (uORFs) within the viral genome, suggesting additional layers of translational control. This translatomic map provides key insights into the molecular arms race at the ribosome.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Translatomic Profiling Reveals Widespread Host Shutoff and Codon-Optimized Viral Protein Synthesis During SARS-CoV-2 Infection

text: Dysfunctional mitochondria are potent triggers of sterile inflammation, but the mechanisms that prevent their aberrant activation of the innate immune system are not fully understood. Here, we elucidate the critical role of selective autophagy of mitochondria (mitophagy) in restraining the NLRP3 inflammasome. Using high-content imaging and biochemical assays in primary macrophages, we show that mitochondrial damage induces a PINK1-dependent recruitment of the E3 ubiquitin ligase Parkin, which ubiquitinates outer mitochondrial membrane proteins to tag the organelle for autophagic clearance. Genetic ablation of PINK1 or Parkin leads to the accumulation of damaged, ROS-generating mitochondria. This excess mitochondrial ROS (mROS) triggers the opening of the mitochondrial permeability transition pore, resulting in the release of oxidized mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) into the cytosol. This cytosolic mtDNA is then sensed by the NLRP3 inflammasome, leading to caspase-1 activation and robust IL-1β secretion. Our results establish that mitophagy is a fundamental homeostatic process that prevents inflammatory disease by clearing a key upstream trigger of inflammasome activation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: PINK1/Parkin-Mediated Mitophagy Suppresses NLRP3 Inflammasome Activation by Preventing Mitochondrial ROS-Driven mtDNA Release

text: The mechanisms underlying the transgenerational inheritance of environmentally induced traits remain a subject of intense debate. Using a Caenorhabditis elegans model, we demonstrate that a transient heat-stress response, characterized by the upregulation of specific chaperones, is heritable for at least three generations in the absence of the initial stimulus. We performed small RNA sequencing from dissected germlines and found that the F1 progeny of stressed animals inherit a distinct population of endogenous small interfering RNAs (endo-siRNAs) corresponding to the upregulated stress-response genes. These siRNAs are loaded into the germline-specific Argonaute protein HRDE-1, which is essential for transmitting the epigenetic memory. Chromatin immunoprecipitation revealed that the inherited siRNAs guide HRDE-1 to nascent transcripts, where it recruits histone methyltransferases to deposit repressive H3K9me3 marks, thereby silencing the stress-response locus in subsequent generations. This study provides a direct molecular link between an environmental experience, a heritable small RNA carrier, and a lasting epigenetic modification.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance of an Acquired Stress Response is Mediated by Argonaute-Bound Endogenous siRNAs

text: Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR)-T cell therapy holds immense promise but is hampered by life-threatening toxicities stemming from uncontrolled activation. To address this, we have developed a chemically-inducible, split CAR system based on orthogonal heterodimerizing domains from Arabidopsis thaliana. In this design, the antigen-binding scFv moiety is fused to one dimerization domain, while the T-cell signaling domains (CD28/CD3ζ) are fused to the other. In the absence of a specific small-molecule dimerizer, the components are segregated and the CAR is inactive. Upon administration of the bio-inert small molecule, the domains heterodimerize, reconstituting a functional CAR and initiating T-cell effector functions. In a murine xenograft model of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, we demonstrate dose-dependent control over tumor clearance, T-cell proliferation, and cytokine production. Importantly, withdrawal of the dimerizer resulted in rapid de-activation of CAR-T cells and reversal of activity, providing a robust and reversible safety switch for next-generation cellular immunotherapies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Engineering an Orthogonal, Chemically-Inducible CAR-T System for Tunable and Reversible Antitumor Activity

text: The shelterin complex protects chromosome ends from being recognized as DNA damage. A core component of this complex is the POT1-TPP1 heterodimer, which binds to the single-stranded G-rich telomeric overhang. We determined the 2.5 Å crystal structure of human POT1-TPP1 bound to telomeric ssDNA. The structure reveals that TPP1’s OB-fold domain does not just serve as an interaction scaffold for POT1 but also makes direct, sequence-specific contacts with the DNA substrate via a conserved loop, effectively clamping POT1 onto its track. This TPP1-DNA interaction allosterically enhances POT1's affinity for DNA and positions the 5' end of the telomeric sequence for processive binding by POT1's tandem OB-folds. Mutating the TPP1-DNA interface abrogates this cooperative binding, destabilizes shelterin at telomeres, and elicits a potent ATR-dependent DNA damage response in human cells. Our findings provide a high-resolution mechanistic model for how the POT1-TPP1 anchor ensures robust telomere integrity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural Basis for Telomere Tethering and Protection by the TPP1-POT1-ssDNA Ternary Complex

text: The epigenetic transition from multipotent progenitors to terminally differentiated neurons requires precise modulation of chromatin states. While the role of Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) in depositing the repressive H3K27me3 mark is well-established, the opposing demethylation process remains less characterized. Here, we investigate the Polycomb Repressive Deubiquitinase (PRD) complex, containing the demethylase KDM6B and the deubiquitinase BAP1, during in vitro differentiation of human neural stem cells. Using time-resolved ChIP-seq and single-cell ATAC-seq, we demonstrate that PRD is dynamically recruited to key neurogenic loci, including PAX6 and NEUROD1, preceding transcriptional activation. We show that BAP1-mediated deubiquitination of H2AK119ub is a prerequisite for KDM6B to efficiently access and demethylate H3K27me3. Disruption of the PRD complex via CRISPR-mediated knockout of BAP1 results in stalled differentiation, retention of repressive histone marks at enhancer regions, and failure to establish an accessible chromatin landscape permissive for neuronal gene expression, thus defining PRD as a critical orchestrator of epigenetic reprogramming in neurogenesis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Spatio-temporal Dynamics of H3K27me3 Demethylation by the Polycomb Repressive Deubiquitinase Complex during Neuronal Differentiation

text: The therapeutic potential of CRISPR-based gene editing is hampered by challenges in correcting multiple, distinct pathogenic mutations simultaneously without inducing double-strand breaks (DSBs). We engineered a dual-deaminase orthogonal base editing platform comprising a cytidine base editor (CBE) driven by Streptococcus pyogenes Cas9 and an adenosine base editor (ABE) fused to a smaller, distinct Cas12a ortholog. By designing specific protospacer adjacent motifs and guide RNAs, we achieved concurrent C•G-to-T•A and A•T-to-G•C conversions at independent genomic loci with minimal crosstalk. We applied this system to an induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) model of a complex genetic disorder, simultaneously correcting a nonsense mutation and a missense SNP on different alleles. Deep sequencing and unbiased whole-genome analysis confirmed high on-target editing efficiency (>60%) and a DSB-independent mechanism that yielded negligible off-target mutations or structural variants. This technology enables multiplexed, precise allelic corrections, offering a powerful strategy for treating compound heterozygous genetic diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Orthogonal Base Editing Systems Mediate Multiplexed, Allele-Specific Pathogenic SNP Correction in Human Pluripotent Stem Cells

text: Nuclear speckles are dynamic, non-membranous organelles that function as hubs for pre-mRNA splicing factor storage and assembly. The architectural principles governing their formation remain elusive. Here, we elucidate the central role of the long non-coding RNA MALAT1 as a molecular scaffold for nuclear speckle integrity via liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS). Using super-resolution microscopy and in vitro reconstitution assays, we demonstrate that multivalent interactions between MALAT1’s conserved triple-helix structure and serine/arginine-rich (SR) splicing factors drive the formation of biomolecular condensates. Targeted degradation of MALAT1 in living cells leads to rapid dissolution of nuclear speckles and mislocalization of core spliceosomal components like SRSF1 and U2AF65. Furthermore, CLIP-seq analysis reveals that MALAT1 directly binds to SR proteins, facilitating their recruitment and concentration. Our findings establish that MALAT1 is not merely a resident but a critical organizer of nuclear speckles, structuring a microenvironment essential for efficient spliceosome biogenesis and pre-mRNA processing fidelity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The Long Non-coding RNA MALAT1 Orchestrates Spliceosome Assembly through Phase Separation-Mediated Condensate Formation

text: Ubiquitination is a versatile post-translational modification where distinct ubiquitin chain topologies dictate different cellular fates. While K48-linked polyubiquitination is the canonical signal for proteasomal degradation, the function of non-degradative K63-linked chains in the unfolded protein response (UPR) is less understood. We developed a novel mass spectrometry-based proteomic method, termed Ub-Topology Interrogation by Parallel Reaction Monitoring (Ub-TIP), to globally quantify K48- and K63-linked substrates during tunicamycin-induced ER stress. Our data reveal a temporal cascade where an initial, widespread wave of K63 ubiquitination on ER-resident chaperones and folding enzymes precedes the subsequent K48-mediated targeting of terminally misfolded proteins to the proteasome. Inhibition of the E3 ligase Hrd1 abrogated K48 linkage formation but surprisingly augmented K63 chains on substrate-receptor complexes, suggesting K63 chains function as a quality control checkpoint. This dynamic topology switching represents a critical regulatory node in ER-associated degradation (ERAD), balancing protein triage and degradation decisions under cellular stress.
subject: Biyoloji
title: System-wide Profiling of K48- and K63-linked Ubiquitin Chains Reveals a Dynamic Crosstalk Regulating Endoplasmic Reticulum-Associated Degradation

text: Human telomerase, a specialized reverse transcriptase, maintains genome integrity by elongating chromosome ends. Its activity is tightly regulated by the shelterin complex, yet the structural basis for this interaction remains unclear. We report the 3.2 Å resolution cryo-electron microscopy (Cryo-EM) structure of the human telomerase holoenzyme (hTERT and hTR) bound to the TEL-patch domain of the shelterin protein TPP1. The structure reveals that TPP1 docks onto a composite surface formed by the TERT TEN domain and the hTR Ku-binding loop, positioned distally from the enzyme's active site. This interaction induces a significant conformational change in the hTERT RID1/RID2 domains, reconfiguring their interface with the RNA template and promoting translocation fidelity after nucleotide addition. Functional assays with structure-guided mutations confirm that this TPP1-induced allosteric switch is essential for telomerase processivity but not for its catalytic activity per se. This provides a molecular blueprint for understanding telomere length homeostasis and its dysregulation in cancer.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the Human Telomerase Holoenzyme in Complex with Shelterin Component TPP1 Reveals a Mechanism for Processivity Regulation

text: N6-methyladenosine (m6A) is the most abundant internal modification on eukaryotic mRNA, yet its role in the nervous system is just emerging. We investigated the function of m6A in synaptic plasticity, a cellular correlate of learning and memory. Using conditional knockout mice and neuron-specific AAV-mediated shRNA, we show that the m6A writer enzyme METTL3 is indispensable for long-term potentiation (LTP) in the hippocampus. m6A-sequencing combined with synaptoneurosome fractionation identified a cohort of plasticity-related mRNAs, including CaMKIIα and BDNF, that are heavily methylated in their 3' UTRs in a stimulus-dependent manner. Mechanistically, METTL3-deposited m6A is recognized by the reader protein YTHDF1, which recruits the translation initiation factor eIF3 to promote localized protein synthesis in active dendritic spines. Abolishing m6A deposition prevents this local translation surge and impairs the structural spine remodeling associated with LTP. Our findings uncover an epitranscriptomic layer of regulation critical for the molecular consolidation of synaptic memories.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The m6A Methyltransferase METTL3 Modulates Synaptic Plasticity by Regulating the Localized Translation of Dendritic mRNAs

text: The repair of DNA interstrand crosslinks (ICLs) presents a formidable challenge to genome stability, requiring coordination between DNA replication and repair machineries. The Fanconi Anemia protein FANCM, an ATP-dependent DNA translocase, is a key early responder at ICLs. Its precise molecular function at stalled replication forks, however, has been inferred primarily from bulk biochemical assays. Here, we use DNA combing and in vitro single-molecule imaging on Xenopus egg extracts to directly visualize FANCM's activity. We demonstrate that upon encountering an ICL, FANCM is rapidly recruited and utilizes its translocase activity to remodel the stalled fork into a four-way junction, a process known as fork reversal. Subsequently, FANCM remains bound to the reversed fork's junction, preventing its nucleolytic degradation by DNA2 and EXO1. This protective function is ATP-hydrolysis independent and crucial for providing a stable substrate for downstream repair factors. Our study provides direct visual evidence for FANCM's dual role in ICL repair: active fork remodeling followed by passive junction stabilization.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Single-Molecule Visualization of Fork Reversal and Protection by the FANCM Translocase at Interstrand Crosslink-Induced Stalled Replication Forks

text: Circadian rhythms are driven by a transcriptional-translational feedback loop, but the contribution of translational control to setting the clock's ~24-hour period is poorly defined. We performed time-series ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) in synchronized mouse liver cells to map translational dynamics across the circadian cycle. Our analysis revealed pronounced, periodic ribosomal pausing at specific codon pairs within the coding sequences of core clock genes, most notably PER2 and CRY1. This pausing, which correlated with the nadir of the cognate tRNA's abundance, significantly slowed the elongation rate, creating a built-in delay between transcription and protein accumulation. Experimental manipulation of tRNA levels using anticodon-edited tRNAs either shortened or lengthened the circadian period, confirming a causal link. This codon-mediated translational pacing acts as a critical post-transcriptional timing mechanism, insulating the core oscillator from transcriptional noise and ensuring a robust, ~24-hour periodicity. Our findings highlight codon optimality as a fundamental and previously unappreciated regulatory layer in the mammalian circadian clock.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Ribosome-profiling Reveals Codon-specific Translational Pausing as a Key Regulatory Node in Circadian Clock Gene Expression

text: Cells harboring a mixture of wild-type and mutated mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), a state known as heteroplasmy, exhibit variable disease penetrance. The mechanisms governing the selective elimination of mutant mtDNA are crucial for cellular health. We investigated this process in cybrid cell lines carrying the m.8993T>G pathogenic mutation, which impairs ATP synthase function. We demonstrate that the resulting decrease in mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨm) triggers oligomerization of the voltage-dependent anion channel (VDAC) on the outer mitochondrial membrane. This VDAC oligomer serves as a scaffold for the recruitment and activation of the PINK1/Parkin mitophagy pathway, independent of canonical PINK1 stabilization. Using single-cell allele-quantification PCR and live-cell imaging, we tracked a progressive, mitophagy-dependent reduction in the proportion of mutant mtDNA over time. Pharmacological inhibition of VDAC oligomerization or genetic ablation of Parkin prevented this heteroplasmic shift. This VDAC-mediated surveillance provides a direct link between mitochondrial bioenergetic dysfunction and selective organellar clearance, representing a key cellular defense against pathogenic mtDNA.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Heteroplasmic Shift of Pathogenic mtDNA Variants Driven by VDAC-dependent Mitophagy Selectively Eliminates Defective Mitochondria

text: The development of endocrine resistance is a major clinical obstacle in estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) breast cancer. To elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms, we performed an integrative analysis of ATAC-seq, ChIP-seq (for FOXA1, H3K27ac), and RNA-seq data from patient-derived xenograft models of acquired tamoxifen resistance. Our computational modeling of the resulting gene regulatory networks identified the pioneer transcription factor FOXA1 as a master regulator of the resistant phenotype. In resistant cells, FOXA1 is redeployed to a distinct set of genomic loci, where it establishes de novo enhancers, characterized by increased chromatin accessibility and H3K27ac deposition. These reprogrammed enhancers drive the expression of a pro-survival, ER-independent transcriptional program, including key effectors like BCL2 and IGF1R. Critically, genetic silencing of FOXA1 in resistant cells led to a collapse of this newly established enhancer landscape and partially restored tamoxifen sensitivity. This study reveals FOXA1-mediated enhancer reprogramming as a core mechanism of endocrine resistance, offering a potential therapeutic vulnerability.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrative Multi-omics Analysis Deciphers a Core Transcriptional Regulatory Circuit Governed by Pioneer Factor FOXA1 in Endocrine-Resistant Breast Cancer

text: We report on the theoretical demonstration and numerical simulation of non-Abelian braiding statistics in a heterostructure comprising monolayer graphene and a topological insulator substrate. By inducing a ν=5/2 fractional quantum Hall state via a perpendicular magnetic field, we show that the system's low-energy excitations are described by Ising anyons, specifically Majorana zero modes localized at defect sites. Utilizing a tight-binding model combined with a configuration interaction approach, we calculate the non-unitary braiding matrices (B-matrices) for a four-anyon system. Our results explicitly show the non-commutativity of braiding operators, a hallmark of non-Abelian statistics, and demonstrate robustness against moderate levels of quenched disorder and thermal fluctuations. This work provides a concrete blueprint for a topologically protected quantum computational gate, leveraging the unique electronic properties of graphene to realize fault-tolerant qubit operations. The calculated decoherence rates suggest that a topologically encoded CNOT gate could achieve fidelities exceeding 0.999 under experimentally accessible conditions.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Anyonic Braiding in a Graphene-Based Fractional Quantum Hall System

text: This study investigates the emergence of bulk AdS spacetime geometry from the entanglement structure of a boundary Conformal Field Theory (CFT), extending the ER=EPR conjecture. We introduce a novel tensor network ansatz, the Dynamic Multiscale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (D-MERA), which generalizes the conventional MERA by incorporating time-dependent isometries and disentanglers. By interpreting the tensor network geometry as a discrete representation of a spatial slice of the bulk, we demonstrate that the D-MERA naturally accommodates the Ryu-Takayanagi formula for entanglement entropy. Applying our formalism to a 2D CFT undergoing a quantum quench, we numerically reconstruct the corresponding bulk geometry, revealing the formation of a causal horizon and a time-dependent geodesic structure consistent with Vaidya spacetime. Our findings provide a constructive algorithm for spacetime reconstruction from boundary entanglement data, offering a concrete computational framework for exploring the deep connection between quantum information and gravitational dynamics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Renormalization and Bulk Spacetime Reconstruction from Boundary CFT Data

text: We propose and analyze a quantum metrology protocol that leverages multi-mode entangled squeezed coherent states to achieve sensitivity scaling beyond the Heisenberg limit for optical phase estimation. The protocol utilizes a cascaded sequence of Kerr nonlinearities and beam splitters to generate a highly non-Gaussian, multi-mode quantum state with strong inter-modal correlations. We derive the quantum Cramér-Rao bound for this system, demonstrating that the phase sensitivity scales as N^(-k), where N is the total mean photon number and k > 1, surpassing the standard Heisenberg scaling of N^(-1). Our theoretical analysis, supported by Wigner function-based numerical simulations, shows that the scheme is robust against moderate photon loss and detection inefficiency. This super-Heisenberg scaling arises from the specific non-linear correlations encoded in the multi-mode state. The proposed interferometric setup presents a viable pathway for next-generation gravitational wave detectors and atomic clocks, pushing precision measurements into a new quantum-dominated regime.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum-Enhanced Phase Estimation via Multi-Mode Squeezed Coherent States

text: We investigate the dynamics of many-body localization (MBL) in a periodically driven (Floquet) quantum spin chain with long-range interactions. Using large-scale time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (t-DMRG) simulations, we explore the transition from an ergodic thermal phase to a non-ergodic MBL phase. Our central finding is the observation of a distinct dynamical signature: in the MBL regime, an initial local quantum quench leads to a slow, logarithmic growth of entanglement entropy, in stark contrast to the linear growth characteristic of thermalizing systems. We construct an effective Hamiltonian using a Floquet-Magnus expansion and identify the emergence of quasi-local integrals of motion (l-bits) that are responsible for the system's memory of its initial state. The phase boundary is mapped out as a function of driving frequency and disorder strength, revealing a re-entrant MBL phase at high frequencies. This work elucidates the fundamental mechanisms of ergodicity breaking in driven quantum systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Entanglement Propagation and Ergodicity Breaking in a Disordered Floquet System

text: We report the experimental realization of a high-fidelity controlled-phase (CZ) gate between two spatially separated superconducting transmon qubits coupled to a common high-Q microwave resonator. The gate protocol operates in the strong dispersive regime of circuit quantum electrodynamics (cQED), where the qubit state induces a large frequency shift on the cavity mode. By applying a microwave pulse precisely tuned to a specific dressed state of the joint qubit-cavity system, we induce a conditional phase shift of π on the |11⟩ computational basis state. The gate operation is completed in 42 ns, significantly faster than the qubit coherence times (T1 > 80 µs, T2* > 100 µs). Utilizing quantum process tomography, we measure a gate fidelity of 99.2 ± 0.3%, with the primary infidelity attributed to residual ZZ coupling and qubit relaxation. This fast, high-fidelity entangling gate is a crucial component for building scalable quantum processors based on superconducting circuits.
subject: Kuantum
title: Coherent Quantum Phase Gate Mediated by a Single Photon in a Superconducting Circuit QED Architecture

text: A non-zero neutron electric dipole moment (nEDM) is a direct signature of Charge-Parity (CP) violation beyond the Standard Model's CKM mechanism. We present a high-precision, first-principles calculation of the nEDM induced by the QCD θ-term and the quark chromo-EDM operators using lattice gauge theory. The calculation was performed on a 2+1+1 flavor HISQ ensemble with physical quark masses and a lattice spacing of a ≈ 0.09 fm. We employ novel noise-reduction techniques and a spectral decomposition method to isolate the ground state matrix elements from excited-state contamination. Our result for the θ-term contribution is d_n(θ) = -3.9(2)(9) x 10⁻¹⁶ θ e·cm. By combining this with experimental nEDM limits, we place stringent constraints on parameters of various Beyond-Standard-Model scenarios, including axion models and supersymmetry. This work demonstrates the increasing power of lattice QCD as a tool for precision particle physics and the search for new fundamental symmetries.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Beyond-Standard-Model CP Violation via Lattice QCD Calculation of the Neutron Electric Dipole Moment

text: We theoretically investigate the emergence of classical objectivity through the mechanism of quantum Darwinism, where redundant information about a quantum system is imprinted onto its environment. We introduce a fully solvable model consisting of a central spin-1/2 system coupled anisotropically to a non-Markovian spin-bath environment. By exactly calculating the time evolution of the system-environment state, we quantify the proliferation of information by computing the quantum mutual information between the central system and progressively larger fractions of the environment. Our results demonstrate the formation of a 'redundancy plateau', where the mutual information saturates at the system's classical Shannon entropy value long before the entire environment is considered. This signifies the creation of multiple independent copies of the system's pointer-state information within the bath, rendering it objectively accessible. The analysis reveals a direct link between the interaction Hamiltonian's structure and the efficiency of this information encoding, providing fundamental insights into the quantum-to-classical transition.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum Darwinism and the Emergence of Classical Objectivity in a Solvable Spin-Bath Model

text: We report a stringent experimental test of macroscopic realism, the worldview that a macroscopic system possesses definite properties independent of observation, by testing a Leggett-Garg inequality (LGI). The experiment utilizes a superconducting transmon qubit whose state is continuously monitored via a weakly coupled microwave resonator. We employ a novel protocol of 'ideal negative result' measurements, which allows us to infer the qubit's state at intermediate times with minimal back-action, thus closing the 'clumsiness' loophole inherent in many LGI tests. By analyzing the temporal correlations of the measurement record, we observe a violation of the LGI by more than 12 standard deviations. The results are in excellent agreement with quantum mechanical predictions and strongly refute the postulates of macroscopic realism and non-invasive measurability. This experiment provides compelling evidence for the persistence of quantum coherence at the macroscopic scale and places tight constraints on alternative theories to quantum mechanics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Violation of a Leggett-Garg Inequality Using a Non-Invasive Continuous Measurement of a Superconducting Qubit

text: We analyze the fidelity of quantum information protocols between an inertial observer (Alice) and a uniformly accelerated observer (Rob) in (3+1)-dimensional Minkowski spacetime. Modeling the quantum field as an information channel, we quantify how the Unruh effect degrades entanglement shared between the observers. We calculate the fidelity of quantum teleportation for a Dirac field state, tracing over the inaccessible field modes beyond Rob's Rindler horizon. The analysis reveals that the fidelity decays as a function of Rob's acceleration 'a', approaching the classical threshold of 2/3 at finite acceleration, unlike the scalar field case which requires infinite acceleration. This degradation is a direct consequence of the thermal noise perceived by the accelerated observer (Unruh radiation) and the mode mismatch described by Bogoliubov transformations. Our results establish quantitative limits on quantum communication in non-inertial frames and provide a framework for studying relativistic effects in quantum information science.
subject: Kuantum
title: Entanglement Degradation for Accelerated Observers and the Unruh-Rindler Information Channel

text: We study the non-equilibrium dynamics of a one-dimensional transverse-field Ising model featuring competing ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic long-range interactions, decaying with distance as a power law r⁻ᵃ. By quenching the transverse field across a quantum critical point, we investigate the emergence of dynamical quantum phase transitions (DQPTs), identified by non-analyticities in the Loschmidt echo. Using a combination of time-dependent variational principle simulations and analytical arguments in the large-N limit, we map out the phase diagram for DQPTs as a function of the power-law exponent α and the interaction competition. We find that for α < 1, the system exhibits a novel type of DQPT characterized by a persistent, non-decaying order parameter, indicative of a prethermal time crystal. This work connects the concepts of DQPTs, localization, and prethermalization, revealing how long-range interactions can stabilize exotic non-equilibrium phases of matter with no equilibrium counterpart.
subject: Kuantum
title: Dynamical Phase Transitions in a Quantum Ising Model with Competing Long-Range Interactions

text: The practical application of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) is often constrained by the scarcity of labeled data for training. To mitigate this, we propose a novel self-supervised learning framework, GraphContrast, which learns robust node representations without relying on explicit labels. Our method employs a contrastive objective function that maximizes agreement between differently augmented views of the same graph structure. We introduce a suite of multi-scale graph augmentations, including node dropping, edge perturbation, and subgraph sampling, which generate challenging positive pairs for the contrastive loss. The architecture utilizes a momentum-based moving average encoder to maintain a consistent and large dictionary of negative samples. Extensive experiments on benchmark node classification and link prediction datasets, such as Cora, CiteSeer, and OGB, demonstrate that GraphContrast pre-training followed by linear fine-tuning achieves state-of-the-art performance, even outperforming fully-supervised GNNs in low-label regimes. Our work underscores the efficacy of contrastive self-supervision for learning powerful, generalizable graph representations.
subject: AI
title: Self-Supervised Contrastive Learning on Graph Neural Networks via Multi-Scale Augmentations

text: Collaborative training of deep learning models on medical data from multiple institutions is hampered by stringent patient privacy regulations. We present PrivFed-Med, a federated learning framework that enables decentralized training for medical image segmentation while providing formal privacy guarantees. Our approach integrates client-level differential privacy by injecting calibrated Gaussian noise into local model updates before their aggregation at the central server. The noise level is meticulously controlled by a privacy accountant to adhere to a predefined (ε, δ)-privacy budget. To mitigate the utility degradation typically caused by noise injection, we employ a secure aggregation protocol and a dynamic clipping strategy on the model gradients. On a multi-institutional brain tumor segmentation task using the BraTS dataset, PrivFed-Med achieves segmentation performance (Dice score) comparable to a centralized, non-private model, while providing rigorous mathematical assurances of patient data confidentiality. This framework presents a viable pathway for privacy-preserving, large-scale collaboration in clinical AI research.
subject: AI
title: PrivFed-Med: A Differentially Private Federated Learning Framework for Multi-Institutional Medical Image Segmentation

text: Combinatorial optimization problems, many of which are NP-hard, pose a significant challenge for classical computational paradigms. This research explores a hybrid quantum-classical approach to address such problems using Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) hardware. We formulate a solution strategy based on the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA), where the problem Hamiltonian is mapped to a parameterized quantum circuit. The circuit's parameters are optimized classically using a variational eigensolver (VQE) methodology. We implement and test this framework on the Max-Cut problem for non-planar graphs, executing the algorithm on a superconducting qubit-based quantum processor. Our results indicate that for specific graph topologies and problem sizes, the QAOA-VQE approach can find approximation ratios superior to classical heuristics like the Goemans-Williamson algorithm, even in the presence of inherent gate and readout noise. This work demonstrates the nascent potential of quantum machine learning for achieving quantum advantage in computationally intractable domains.
subject: AI
title: Hybrid Quantum-Classical Machine Learning for Combinatorial Optimization on NISQ-era Devices

text: Off-policy evaluation (OPE) in reinforcement learning is critical for assessing the performance of new policies using historical data, but standard methods like importance sampling yield high-variance and biased estimates in the presence of unobserved confounders. We introduce a novel framework, Causal Policy Value Estimation (CPVE), that integrates principles from causal inference to de-bias OPE. Our method first models the environment using a Structural Causal Model (SCM) to explicitly represent confounding variables that affect both the state transitions and the behavior policy. We then employ an instrumental variable approach, leveraging a doubly robust estimator, to derive a counterfactual policy value that is resilient to the confounding bias. In experiments on benchmark control tasks with synthetically introduced latent confounders, CPVE provides significantly more accurate and lower-variance policy value estimates compared to state-of-the-art OPE techniques. This research highlights the necessity of a causal perspective for robust and reliable policy assessment in real-world deployments.
subject: AI
title: Causal Inference in Off-Policy Reinforcement Learning for Debiased Policy Evaluation

text: Generative models for de novo molecular design face the dual challenge of producing chemically valid structures while optimizing for desired pharmacological properties. We propose Mol-CycleGAN, a novel generative adversarial network that leverages cycle-consistency to learn a bidirectional mapping between a low-dimensional latent space and the space of molecular graphs. The architecture features a graph convolutional network (GCN) as the generator and a relational GCN as a discriminator, which is conditioned on a vector of target properties (e.g., quantitative estimate of drug-likeness, lipophilicity). By enforcing cycle-consistency, the model learns a structured latent space that facilitates property-guided generation and optimization without paired data. We evaluate Mol-CycleGAN on benchmarks for property-targeting and constrained optimization. The model generates a high percentage of novel, valid, and synthesizable molecules, significantly outperforming variational autoencoders and standard conditional GANs in achieving target property distributions, thereby accelerating computational drug and materials discovery.
subject: AI
title: Mol-CycleGAN: A Cycle-Consistent Adversarial Network for Property-Conditioned De Novo Molecular Design

text: While large pre-trained language models excel at many NLP tasks, their performance diminishes in few-shot learning scenarios due to overfitting on small support sets. To address this, we introduce Prototypical-MAML, a hybrid meta-learning algorithm that synthesizes the strengths of optimization-based and metric-based meta-learning paradigms. The framework uses Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) to find a model initialization that is highly sensitive to fine-tuning on new tasks. Simultaneously, it incorporates a prototypical network loss during the inner-loop updates, which encourages the formation of a discriminative and well-clustered embedding space. This dual objective regularizes the meta-optimization process, preventing collapse to trivial solutions. Evaluated on the GLUE benchmark under N-way, K-shot classification settings (K≤5), Prototypical-MAML demonstrates superior adaptation capabilities, consistently outperforming standard fine-tuning, vanilla MAML, and Prototypical Networks. Our work illustrates the benefits of integrating complementary meta-learning strategies for enhanced data efficiency in natural language processing.
subject: AI
title: Prototypical-MAML: A Hybrid Meta-Learning Algorithm for Few-Shot Text Classification

text: Accurate long-horizon climate and weather forecasting is a formidable challenge, requiring models that can capture intricate, non-local spatio-temporal dependencies. We introduce the Geo-Temporal Transformer (GTT), a novel deep learning architecture designed explicitly for this task. GTT employs a factorized attention mechanism that disentangles spatial and temporal modeling. A stack of spatial transformers, operating on lat-lon grid patches, captures complex geographical teleconnections, while a subsequent temporal transformer models long-range dependencies in the learned time-series representations. We integrate learnable Fourier features for positional encoding to handle the spherical geometry of the Earth. On the WeatherBench dataset for forecasting geopotential height and temperature at a five-day lead time, our model significantly reduces the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) compared to state-of-the-art convolutional LSTM and vision transformer baselines. GTT demonstrates superior skill in predicting extreme weather phenomena, establishing a new performance benchmark for data-driven earth system modeling.
subject: AI
title: Geo-Temporal Transformer: A Factorized Attention Model for Long-Horizon Climate Forecasting

text: Standard deep neural networks deployed in safety-critical autonomous systems, such as self-driving vehicles, provide point estimates without quantifying model uncertainty, a significant limitation for robust decision-making. This paper presents a scalable Bayesian deep learning framework for quantifying epistemic uncertainty in real-time perception tasks. We employ Monte Carlo Dropout as a pragmatic approximation to variational inference in a deep convolutional neural network for semantic segmentation. We further propose an uncertainty-aware loss function that penalizes high-confidence predictions on misclassified pixels during training, encouraging the model to learn a better-calibrated uncertainty representation. In experiments on the Cityscapes dataset, our Bayesian network not only achieves competitive segmentation accuracy but also produces pixel-wise uncertainty maps that exhibit a strong correlation with prediction errors. This allows for the reliable detection of out-of-distribution objects and ambiguous scenarios, providing a critical signal for downstream risk assessment and fail-safe motion planning modules.
subject: AI
title: Bayesian Deep Learning with Epistemic Uncertainty Quantification for Safety-Critical Autonomous Systems

text: The performance of deep learning models often degrades under domain shift, where training and testing data are drawn from different distributions. We propose a novel unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) technique based on the theory of optimal transport. Our method seeks a domain-invariant feature representation by minimizing the Gromov-Wasserstein (GW) distance between the source and target data distributions. Unlike prior methods that match distribution moments or employ adversarial training, the GW distance aligns the relational structure of the data manifolds, making it robust to variations in modality and geometric transformations. The minimization is performed using an efficient entropic regularization and iterative Sinkhorn-like algorithm. We apply our Gromov-Wasserstein Domain Adaptation (GWDA) framework to benchmark datasets for image classification, such as Office-31 and VisDA-2017. Our approach establishes a new state-of-the-art, demonstrating superior performance especially in settings with significant domain discrepancy, thus providing a more principled geometric foundation for UDA.
subject: AI
title: Unsupervised Domain Adaptation via Gromov-Wasserstein Optimal Transport

text: The integration of subsymbolic learning and symbolic reasoning remains a central challenge in artificial intelligence. We propose the Neuro-Symbolic Graph Reasoner (NSGR), a novel framework that combines the representational power of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) with the formal inference capabilities of logic programming. The NSGR first uses a relational GNN to embed entities and relations from a knowledge graph into a continuous vector space. These embeddings then parameterize a differentiable logic programming module, which executes multi-hop relational queries expressed as first-order logic rules. The entire architecture is trained end-to-end using a policy gradient algorithm to maximize the probability of inferring correct answers. On complex, multi-hop question-answering datasets like MetaQA, the NSGR significantly outperforms purely neural and purely symbolic approaches. Critically, our model yields an explicit, interpretable reasoning trace for its predictions, bridging the gap between deep learning's pattern recognition and symbolic AI's explainable reasoning.
subject: AI
title: Neuro-Symbolic Reasoning on Knowledge Graphs via End-to-End Differentiable Logic Programming

text: We introduce a novel framework, the Causal Intervention Variational Autoencoder (CIVA), for learning causally disentangled representations from observational data. Traditional VAEs often fail to distinguish correlation from causation, leading to entangled latent factors. Our approach models the latent space as a manifold governed by a Structural Causal Model (SCM). We augment the standard Evidence Lower Bound (ELBO) objective with a regularizer that encourages alignment with interventional distributions approximated via a learned graph structure. By performing amortized inference on synthetic interventions within latent space, CIVA promotes a factorization of the posterior that aligns with the underlying causal mechanisms. This method bypasses the need for explicit interventional data during training. We demonstrate empirically on synthetic and semi-synthetic benchmarks that our model significantly outperforms state-of-the-art disentanglement methods in identifying causal variables and enabling robust counterfactual generation, thereby improving downstream task performance under distributional shifts.
subject: AI
title: Causal Disentanglement in Variational Autoencoders via Structural Intervention on Latent Space Manifolds

text: Federated Learning (FL) is susceptible to Byzantine attacks, where malicious clients disrupt model training by sending arbitrary updates. This problem is exacerbated by the non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) nature of client data. We propose Byzantine-resilient Aggregation with Privacy Preservation (BAPP), a robust server-side aggregation framework that provides formal security guarantees. BAPP integrates a variant of coordinate-wise trimmed mean for outlier rejection with a calibrated noise injection mechanism derived from differential privacy principles, specifically tailored for the federated setting. Our theoretical analysis proves convergence for non-convex objectives under a bounded percentage of Byzantine clients and non-IID data, establishing a formal trade-off between privacy budget, robustness, and model utility. Empirical evaluations on diverse benchmarks, including CIFAR-10 and a federated clinical dataset, demonstrate that BAPP maintains high model accuracy while providing certified resilience against sophisticated model poisoning and data inference attacks, outperforming existing robust FL algorithms.
subject: AI
title: Byzantine-Resilient Federated Learning with Differential Privacy Guarantees on Non-IID Data Partitions

text: Standard Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) are limited by the expressive power of the 1-Weisfeiler-Lehman (1-WL) test, confining their message-passing mechanism to pairwise interactions. To capture higher-order relationships inherent in complex systems, we propose Simplicial Complex Neural Networks (SCNNs). Our model operates on simplicial complexes, which generalize graphs to include multi-way relationships (e.g., triangles, tetrahedra). SCNNs employ a novel message-passing scheme across adjacent simplices of varying dimensions, guided by the Hodge Laplacian operator. This allows the model to learn representations that are sensitive to the underlying homological features of the data, such as cycles and cavities. We provide a theoretical analysis of SCNN's expressive power, showing its ability to distinguish topological structures that are indistinguishable to standard GNNs. On benchmarks for molecular property prediction and co-authorship network analysis, SCNNs demonstrate superior performance by effectively leveraging these higher-order relational inductive biases.
subject: AI
title: Higher-Order Graph Neural Networks for Capturing Simplicial Complex Topologies and Relational Inductive Biases

text: Solving complex cooperative tasks in multi-agent systems is challenged by credit assignment and effective coordination. We propose Counterfactual Communication for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (CC-MARL), a novel framework that integrates counterfactual reasoning with a learnable communication protocol. Operating under the paradigm of centralized training with decentralized execution (CTDE), our approach enables each agent to reason about its marginal contribution to the global reward by comparing the current team performance with a counterfactual baseline where its action is marginalized out. Concurrently, agents learn a low-bandwidth, differentiable communication protocol to share salient information from their local observations, dynamically shaping the multi-agent value function. This synergy allows for robust credit assignment even with sparse global rewards. We demonstrate in challenging coordination domains, such as StarCraft II micromanagement and multi-robot warehouse commissioning, that CC-MARL fosters sophisticated emergent strategies and significantly outperforms state-of-the-art MARL algorithms like QMIX and COMA in zero-shot coordination scenarios.
subject: AI
title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Counterfactual Credit Assignment and Emergent Communication Protocols

text: Existing knowledge graph completion (KGC) methods struggle with n-ary relations and generalizing to unseen entities, often relying on dense, entity-specific embeddings. We reframe KGC as a text-based, zero-shot inference problem addressed by pre-trained language models (PLMs). We introduce Hyper-Relational Contrastive Learning (HRCL), a self-supervised objective for fine-tuning PLMs on complex relational structures. Instead of predicting a single missing entity, HRCL trains the model to distinguish true hyper-relational facts (e.g., `(quarterback, Tom Brady, played_for, Tampa Bay Buccaneers, during, 2020-2021)`) from a set of hard negative samples generated by corrupting multiple fact components simultaneously. This forces the PLM to learn a deeper compositional understanding of relational semantics. By encoding facts as natural language prompts, our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on zero-shot KGC benchmarks like WikiPeople and JF17K, demonstrating a remarkable ability to complete complex, unseen relational instances without any direct supervision.
subject: AI
title: Hyper-Relational Contrastive Learning for Zero-Shot Knowledge Graph Completion with Pre-trained Language Models

text: Accurate uncertainty quantification is critical for decision-making in complex systems, yet traditional deep learning models often produce uncalibrated probabilistic forecasts. We present Conformalized Quantile Regression Forests (CQRF), a non-parametric method that generates well-calibrated prediction intervals with finite-sample marginal coverage guarantees. Our approach leverages the predictive power of quantile regression forests to estimate conditional quantiles and then applies a split conformal prediction framework to adjust these quantiles, ensuring rigorous distribution-free coverage. This two-stage process effectively decouples the estimation of aleatoric uncertainty (via quantile regression) from the correction for epistemic uncertainty and model misspecification (via conformalization). We evaluate CQRF on challenging high-dimensional spatiotemporal forecasting tasks, including weather prediction and energy load forecasting, where data exhibit non-stationarity and complex dependencies. The results show that our method consistently produces tighter, more reliable prediction intervals than Bayesian neural networks and other deep probabilistic models.
subject: AI
title: Conformalized Quantile Regression Forests for Calibrated Probabilistic Forecasting in High-Dimensional Spatiotemporal Systems

text: The quadratic complexity of the self-attention mechanism in Transformers remains a significant bottleneck for processing long sequences. We propose the Sparse Kernelized Attention (SKA) mechanism, a novel architecture that reduces the computational and memory complexity to linear time with respect to sequence length. SKA achieves this by combining two key innovations: first, a sparse, factorized attention pattern that approximates the dense attention matrix through a low-rank decomposition, focusing computational resources on salient tokens; second, a kernelized positional encoding scheme that replaces absolute or relative position embeddings with a continuous, translation-invariant kernel function. This allows the model to capture positional information implicitly within the attention calculation, improving generalization to sequence lengths unseen during training. We demonstrate that SKA-equipped Transformers match the performance of state-of-the-art models on long-document classification and autoregressive generation tasks while achieving up to a 10x speedup in inference.
subject: AI
title: Sparse Factorized Attention with Kernelized Positional Encodings for Linear-Time Transformer Inference

text: Few-shot learning algorithms aim to adapt to new tasks using minimal data. We propose Bayesian Manifold Meta-Learning (BMML), a novel framework that learns a low-dimensional latent manifold of tasks. During meta-training, our approach, built upon an amortized variational inference framework, embeds entire tasks into this manifold, where proximity reflects task similarity. For a new few-shot task, we infer its posterior distribution on the manifold and generate task-specific model parameters by interpolating the parameters of neighboring tasks along geodesic paths. This Bayesian formulation naturally quantifies epistemic uncertainty about the new task's location, enabling more robust adaptation. Unlike optimization-based meta-learners like MAML, BMML performs adaptation via a single forward pass, making it significantly faster at test time. We demonstrate superior performance on challenging few-shot benchmarks, particularly in cross-domain and out-of-distribution scenarios, showcasing the enhanced generalization capabilities of our manifold-based approach.
subject: AI
title: Task-Agnostic Manifold Interpolation for Rapid Few-Shot Adaptation via Bayesian Meta-Learning

text: Adversarial training is an effective empirical defense against adversarial examples, but it typically lacks formal robustness guarantees. Conversely, randomized smoothing provides certified robustness but often at the cost of significantly reduced standard accuracy. We introduce Latent Space Smoothed Training (LSST), a method that bridges this gap by applying the smoothing procedure in a learned latent space rather than the high-dimensional input space. LSST employs a denoising autoencoder to project inputs onto a lower-dimensional manifold where perturbations have a more semantically meaningful effect. Adversarial training is then performed on this smoothed latent representation. This approach allows us to derive a certified robustness guarantee in the input space, which is tied to the Lipschitz constant of the decoder network. Our experiments on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet show that LSST achieves certified robustness competitive with state-of-the-art smoothing techniques while largely preserving the high standard accuracy characteristic of adversarially trained models.
subject: AI
title: Adversarial Training with Certified Robustness via Randomized Smoothing over Latent Representations

text: Bridging the gap between sub-symbolic perception and symbolic reasoning is a central challenge in AI. We propose a Differentiable Inductive Logic Programming (∂ILP) framework that learns symbolic rules from perceptual data. Our model consists of two tightly integrated components: a neural perception module that grounds abstract concepts into vector representations from raw inputs, and a differentiable ILP module that performs forward-chaining deduction over a tensorized knowledge base. By formulating the ILP deduction process using continuous relaxations of logical operators (e.g., AND, OR), we enable end-to-end training with gradient-based optimization. This allows the system to simultaneously learn perceptual representations and induce explicit, interpretable first-order logic rules that explain the data. We demonstrate our framework's ability to solve complex visual reasoning and relational learning tasks, achieving superior compositional generalization compared to purely neural or symbolic approaches and inducing human-readable logical theories from noisy inputs.
subject: AI
title: Integrating Inductive Logic Programming with Gradient-Based Optimization for Neuro-Symbolic Concept Learning

text: Federated learning systems are critically vulnerable to Byzantine attacks, where malicious clients transmit corrupt model updates to sabotage the global model. Conventional defense mechanisms, primarily designed for Euclidean parameter spaces, often falter under the complex geometries of modern neural networks and the constraints of decentralized, non-IID data distributions. We introduce a novel Byzantine-robust aggregation protocol, FedRGM, which operates directly on the Riemannian manifold of model parameters. Our method computes the geometric median of local model updates, a provably robust estimator of central tendency, using a computationally efficient Weiszfeld-type algorithm adapted for manifolds. We provide theoretical guarantees on the breakdown point and convergence under heterogeneous data distributions. Empirically, we demonstrate on several benchmark vision and language tasks that FedRGM significantly outperforms state-of-the-art aggregation rules like Krum and Trimmed Mean in resisting sophisticated label-flipping and Gaussian noise attacks, while maintaining high model utility and communication efficiency in a fully decentralized topology.
subject: AI
title: Decentralized Federated Learning with Byzantine-Robust Gradient Aggregation via Geometric Median on Riemannian Manifolds

text: Standard Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) excel at synthesizing photorealistic images but lack mechanisms for semantically meaningful, controllable manipulation. We propose the Causal-Aware GAN (CA-GAN), a framework that integrates a Structural Causal Model (SCM) into the latent space to enable counterfactual image generation. By modeling the causal relationships between latent factors of variation, our model can perform interventions (`do`-operations) to generate samples under specific causal conditions. Furthermore, it can synthesize counterfactuals by answering queries of the form 'what would image X have looked like if attribute A had been a', a task beyond the capability of correlation-based models. We employ an identifiable VAE pre-training phase to align latent variables with causal factors and a graph-based adversarial loss to enforce the SCM structure. We demonstrate that CA-GAN generates high-fidelity, disentangled counterfactuals on CelebA-HQ and Synapse-MRI datasets, facilitating applications in data augmentation, fairness analysis, and explainable AI.
subject: AI
title: Causal-Aware Generative Adversarial Networks for Counterfactual Image Synthesis

text: Discovering efficient and high-performing neural architectures is a computationally prohibitive task. We introduce MetaPrune, a novel framework that leverages meta-learning to rapidly identify sparse, task-specific subnetworks from a dense parent architecture. Our approach formulates network pruning as a bilevel optimization problem where a hypernetwork learns to generate pruning masks by optimizing for post-adaptation performance on a distribution of tasks. This differentiable process allows for gradient-based optimization of the pruning strategy itself, bypassing expensive black-box searches. The hypernetwork conditions its output on task embeddings, enabling few-shot adaptation to new, unseen tasks by generating bespoke sparse architectures. Experiments on Omniglot and mini-ImageNet demonstrate that MetaPrune discovers highly compressed models that achieve competitive accuracy with significantly fewer parameters and FLOPs compared to dense fine-tuning and other leading pruning-at-initialization techniques, showcasing superior generalization and computational efficiency.
subject: AI
title: Meta-Learning Sparse Neural Architectures through Differentiable Network Pruning

text: Active learning (AL) is essential for minimizing annotation costs in specialized domains, yet traditional uncertainty-based methods often ignore structural dependencies inherent in sequence labeling tasks like Named Entity Recognition (NER). We propose a Graph-Based Active Learning framework (GBAL-NER) that explicitly models token-level relationships to improve query selection. We construct a dynamic graph where tokens are nodes and edges represent syntactic and semantic affinities. A Graph Attention Network (GAT) propagates information across this structure, producing context-aware representations. To quantify uncertainty, we employ Monte Carlo dropout to approximate the Bayesian posterior over model parameters, yielding robust estimates for both token and sequence-level ambiguity. Our novel acquisition function, Graph-aware Mutual Information (GMI), prioritizes instances that maximally reduce uncertainty across interconnected graph components. On several low-resource biomedical and legal NER datasets, GBAL-NER significantly outperforms standard AL strategies like BALD and entropy sampling, achieving higher F1 scores with the same annotation budget.
subject: AI
title: Probabilistic Graph-Based Active Learning for Low-Resource Named Entity Recognition

text: Reliable uncertainty quantification is critical for the safe deployment of deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agents in high-stakes environments. We present a principled and scalable method to decompose predictive uncertainty into its aleatoric (data) and epistemic (model) components within a DRL framework. Our approach leverages stochastic variational dropout, interpreting dropout as an approximation to a deep Gaussian process, to model the posterior distribution over the agent's value or policy network weights. By computing the variance of multiple stochastic forward passes, we derive separate estimates for aleatoric uncertainty, intrinsic to environmental stochasticity, and epistemic uncertainty, which reflects the agent's lack of knowledge. We demonstrate how this decomposition can be used to drive more efficient and safer exploration strategies. In continuous control benchmarks and a simulated autonomous driving task, our uncertainty-aware agent exhibits superior sample efficiency and avoids catastrophic failures by adopting risk-averse policies in states with high epistemic uncertainty, significantly outperforming ensembles and standard epsilon-greedy exploration.
subject: AI
title: Quantifying Aleatoric and Epistemic Uncertainty in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Stochastic Variational Dropout

text: Forecasting human trajectories in complex, multi-agent scenes is challenging due to intricate social interactions and inherent stochasticity. We propose the Spatiotemporal Graph Transformer (STGT), a novel architecture that captures these dependencies for accurate, multimodal trajectory prediction. Our model first constructs a dynamic graph at each timestep, where nodes represent agents and edges encode their spatial proximity. A graph attention network (GAT) is employed to learn socially-aware agent representations by aggregating information from neighbors. These representations are then fed into a temporal Transformer encoder, whose self-attention mechanism models long-range dynamics and inter-agent influences over time. To capture the multimodal nature of future paths, the decoder uses a set of learned anchor trajectories, generating a probability distribution over plausible futures. Evaluated on the ETH/UCY and nuScenes datasets, STGT achieves state-of-the-art performance, reducing final displacement error by up to 15% and demonstrating superior ability to predict diverse and socially compliant trajectories.
subject: AI
title: Spatiotemporal Graph Transformers for Multimodal Human Trajectory Forecasting

text: Solving inverse problems within a Bayesian framework provides a principled approach to uncertainty quantification, but is often intractable for high-dimensional, non-linear forward models due to the prohibitive cost of posterior sampling via MCMC. We propose an amortized inference framework that leverages conditional normalizing flows to directly learn a mapping from an observation to the corresponding posterior distribution. Our model, a conditional invertible neural network, is trained to minimize the Kullback-Leibler divergence between its output and the true posterior over a distribution of simulated data. Once trained, the network can perform inference for a new observation in a single forward pass, generating an arbitrary number of independent posterior samples instantly. This amortization strategy bypasses the need for per-observation MCMC. We demonstrate our approach on challenging inverse problems in computational imaging and geophysics, showing that it produces accurate, high-resolution posterior approximations orders of magnitude faster than traditional sampling methods.
subject: AI
title: Amortized Bayesian Inference for High-Dimensional Inverse Problems with Normalizing Flows

text: Learning disentangled representations—where distinct latent units capture independent factors of variation—is a key challenge in unsupervised learning. We propose a novel framework, Adversarially Guided Information Maximization (AGIM), that achieves robust disentanglement without requiring supervised data or extensive hyperparameter tuning. Our approach extends the InfoGAN objective by incorporating an adversarial regularizer that explicitly penalizes statistical dependence among latent variables. The model, based on a variational autoencoder architecture, maximizes the mutual information between observed data and a subset of the latent code, while a discriminator network attempts to predict one set of latent codes from the others. This min-max game forces the encoder to produce a factorial posterior, thus encouraging disentanglement. We provide theoretical justification for our objective and demonstrate empirically on dSprites, 3D Chairs, and MPI3D datasets that AGIM significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods like FactorVAE and β-TCVAE on established disentanglement metrics, while also yielding higher quality reconstructions.
subject: AI
title: Self-Supervised Disentanglement of Latent Representations via Mutual Information Maximization and Adversarial Feedback

text: Data with latent hierarchical structures, such as taxonomies or graph-based data, are poorly represented in Euclidean space due to its restrictive metric properties. Hyperbolic geometry offers a more suitable inductive bias, as its negative curvature and exponential volume growth naturally accommodate tree-like structures with low distortion. We introduce a fully end-to-end trainable framework for deep neural networks in the Poincaré ball model of hyperbolic geometry. Our key contribution is the development of a stable Riemannian optimization scheme, using a well-conditioned Riemannian Adam optimizer and a robust projection mechanism to ensure embeddings remain within the manifold. This enables the effective training of multi-layered hyperbolic perceptrons and graph neural networks. We demonstrate our framework's superiority on tasks involving hierarchical data, including node classification in large-scale graphs and textual entailment on WordNet, achieving new state-of-the-art results by more faithfully capturing the underlying data geometry than equivalent Euclidean models.
subject: AI
title: Gradient-Based Optimization of Hyperbolic Neural Networks for Hierarchical Data Embedding

text: The capacity for continual, lifelong learning is a hallmark of biological intelligence that remains a central challenge for artificial neural networks, which suffer from catastrophic forgetting. We propose a novel hybrid algorithm, Orthogonal Synaptic Intelligence (OSI), that synergistically combines two distinct mechanisms to protect consolidated knowledge while enabling plasticity for new tasks. First, it employs an online variant of Synaptic Intelligence (SI) to compute a per-parameter importance measure, dynamically regularizing changes to weights crucial for past tasks. Second, it utilizes Orthogonal Gradient Projection (OGP), which projects the gradients for the current task onto the null space of feature representations from previous tasks, minimizing interference in the learned representation space. This dual approach protects both the parameter-level and feature-level knowledge. We demonstrate on challenging continual learning benchmarks, including Split-CIFAR-100 and a sequence of Atari games, that OSI significantly outperforms existing methods, achieving a superior trade-off between stability and plasticity.
subject: AI
title: Continual Learning with Synaptic Intelligence and Orthogonal Gradient Projection for Mitigating Catastrophic Forgetting

text: We introduce a novel framework for learning disentangled representations that align with the underlying causal generative factors of data. Conventional VAE-based disentanglement methods often fail to recover identifiable representations without strong supervision, as they are agnostic to the causal structure. Our proposed model, the Causal Disentangled VAE (CD-VAE), leverages a structural causal model (SCM) prior and performs amortized interventional inference. By optimizing an evidence lower bound (ELBO) augmented with a term that encourages consistency with the principles of do-calculus, our model learns to separate statistically independent causal mechanisms. We demonstrate empirically on synthetic and semi-synthetic datasets that the CD-VAE can identify true causal variables from observational data, even with latent confounders. This approach not only yields superior disentanglement scores but also enables robust counterfactual generation, a critical capability for explainable AI and robust out-of-distribution generalization, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art non-causal methods.
subject: AI
title: Causally Disentangled Variational Autoencoders via Interventional Inference

text: Predicting protein folding dynamics is a grand challenge in computational biology, requiring models that respect the inherent geometric symmetries of molecular structures. We propose a novel equivariant graph neural network architecture that operates directly on a Riemannian manifold representing the conformational space of a protein. Our model explicitly incorporates SE(3) equivariance through the use of steerable filters defined via Lie algebra, ensuring that predictions are invariant to the protein's global rotation and translation. By parameterizing the energy landscape on this manifold, our model learns a physically plausible vector field that guides the simulation of folding pathways. We demonstrate that this geometric-aware inductive bias allows for significantly improved sample efficiency and generalization compared to standard GNNs operating in Euclidean space. The model accurately predicts folding trajectories and intermediate metastable states for several small proteins, providing a powerful new tool for understanding macromolecular dynamics.
subject: AI
title: Equivariant Graph Neural Networks on Riemannian Manifolds for Simulating Protein Folding Pathways

text: Federated meta-learning (FML) aims to train personalized models on decentralized, non-IID data. However, FML systems are vulnerable to both privacy leakage and Byzantine attacks, where malicious clients send arbitrary model updates to corrupt the global meta-model. We introduce FedMetaDP, a novel framework that provides simultaneous robustness and privacy. Our method integrates a robust aggregation rule based on geometric median to provably bound the influence of Byzantine clients, coupled with a client-level differential privacy mechanism applied during the local meta-adaptation phase. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis of the convergence guarantees and the end-to-end privacy budget under heterogeneous data distributions. Empirically, we show that FedMetaDP significantly outperforms existing robust and private federated learning strategies on benchmark personalization tasks, maintaining high accuracy even with up to 30% Byzantine clients while providing strong (ε, δ)-differential privacy guarantees for each participant.
subject: AI
title: Byzantine-Robust Federated Meta-Learning with Provable Differential Privacy Guarantees

text: We introduce a novel paradigm for certifying the adversarial robustness of neural networks based on topological data analysis. Existing certification methods predominantly rely on bounding the model's Lipschitz constant within L_p-norm threat models, which may not capture semantically meaningful perturbations. Our approach, Topological Robustness Certification (TRC), provides a certified radius of input perturbation within which the persistent homology of the model's intermediate activation layers remains stable. By enforcing topological invariance—specifically, the preservation of Betti numbers representing connected components and holes—we can guarantee that the model's high-level feature abstraction is structurally unchanged. This provides a more global and interpretable form of robustness than local gradient-based measures. We demonstrate that TRC can certify against complex geometric distortions and non-L_p perturbations where traditional methods fail, establishing a new frontier in provable adversarial defense.
subject: AI
title: Topological Certified Robustness against Adversarial Perturbations using Persistent Homology

text: Hyperbolic geometry provides a natural space for embedding hierarchical and tree-like data structures due to its negative curvature and exponential volume growth. However, existing hyperbolic neural networks often produce dense embeddings, limiting their interpretability and efficiency. We propose a Bayesian framework for hyperbolic networks that incorporates a spike-and-slab prior on the tangent space of the Poincaré ball model. This induces sparsity in the learned embeddings, effectively performing implicit hierarchical feature selection by pruning non-essential connections in the latent representation space. The model is trained via stochastic variational inference, where the Riemannian geometry is handled using parallel transport. Our experiments on graph-based benchmarks and large-scale text datasets demonstrate that this sparsity-inducing prior not only enhances model interpretability but also improves data efficiency and generalization performance on downstream tasks such as link prediction and node classification, by regularizing the model towards a more parsimonious latent structure.
subject: AI
title: Hierarchical Representation Learning with Sparsity-Inducing Priors in Hyperbolic Neural Networks

text: We explore the intersection of generative modeling and quantum many-body physics by proposing a novel class of models based on Projected Entangled-Pair States (PEPS). These tensor networks, originating from the study of entangled quantum systems, are capable of representing highly complex, long-range correlations in high-dimensional data. Our framework, the PEPS-GAN, uses a PEPS to implicitly define a probability distribution, from which samples can be drawn efficiently via tensor network contraction algorithms. We train the model by optimizing the tensor parameters to minimize the Wasserstein distance to the target data distribution, leveraging techniques from matrix product state calculus for efficient gradient computation. On benchmark image datasets and challenging physics-based distributions, our model demonstrates superior expressivity compared to classical deep generative models with a similar number of parameters, suggesting that quantum-inspired architectures provide a powerful inductive bias for modeling intricate data structures.
subject: AI
title: Generative Modeling via Entangled Quantum Circuits and Projected Entangled-Pair States

text: Zero-shot policy transfer between reinforcement learning environments with disparate state-action spaces is a formidable challenge. We propose a novel framework that leverages Gromov-Wasserstein (GW) optimal transport to learn a structural alignment between the latent geometries of different Markov Decision Processes (MDPs). The GW distance measures the discrepancy between intra-domain relational structures, making it invariant to isometric transformations and suitable for comparing spaces of different dimensions. Our method, Policy Transfer via GW (PT-GW), first learns separate low-dimensional embeddings of the state-action spaces for the source and target domains. It then computes an optimal transport plan that minimizes the GW distance between these embedding spaces, effectively learning a cross-domain policy mapping. We demonstrate that PT-GW enables successful zero-shot transfer in complex robotic manipulation tasks where domains differ in morphology and kinematics, significantly outperforming methods based on adversarial domain adaptation.
subject: AI
title: Unsupervised Reinforcement Learning via Gromov-Wasserstein Optimal Transport for Cross-Domain Policy Transfer

text: Deep learning models excel at perceptual tasks but struggle with compositional generalization, particularly in few-shot settings. We present a neuro-symbolic architecture that integrates the pattern recognition strengths of neural networks with the combinatorial reasoning of symbolic program synthesis.
