Our model first employs a vision module to parse raw input (e.g., images) into a discrete, object-centric symbolic representation. Subsequently, a program induction module, guided by a neural policy, searches over a domain-specific language to synthesize a latent program that solves the given task. By reasoning over this abstract program space, the model achieves strong compositional generalization. We evaluate our framework on challenging compositional reasoning benchmarks like CLEVR and demonstrate its ability to solve novel combinations of previously seen concepts from only a handful of examples, a regime where purely neural end-to-end models catastrophically fail, thereby bridging a critical gap between connectionist and symbolic AI.
subject: AI
title: Few-Shot Compositional Generalization through Neuro-Symbolic Program Induction

text: Reliable uncertainty quantification is paramount for the safe deployment of deep learning models in clinical settings. We propose a scalable Bayesian deep learning framework for medical image segmentation that yields well-calibrated uncertainty estimates. Our approach utilizes Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (SGLD) to sample from the posterior distribution of a segmentation network's (e.g., U-Net) weights. Unlike popular approximations like Monte Carlo Dropout or deep ensembles, SGLD provides a more principled and asymptotically exact method for posterior inference. We introduce a cyclical step size schedule for SGLD to enhance exploration of the complex, multi-modal loss landscape typical of deep neural networks. On challenging MRI and CT segmentation tasks, our method produces uncertainty maps that are highly correlated with segmentation errors and exhibit superior calibration scores compared to state-of-the-art methods. This enables clinicians to identify regions of high model uncertainty, facilitating more reliable diagnoses.
subject: AI
title: Calibrated Uncertainty Quantification in Medical Image Segmentation using Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics

text: Self-supervised learning on multimodal data, such as from autonomous vehicle sensors, is complicated by the asynchronous and heterogeneous nature of the data streams. We propose an attention-based contrastive learning framework, Asynchronous Multimodal Contrastive Network (AMCN), designed to learn robust, synchronized representations from non-aligned spatio-temporal data (e.g., video, LiDAR, and IMU). Our architecture uses a temporal cross-attention mechanism to dynamically align features from different modalities over a sliding time window, projecting them into a shared latent embedding space. A novel contrastive loss function is employed, which maximizes agreement between corresponding (but not perfectly time-aligned) cross-modal representations while pushing apart non-corresponding ones. AMCN demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on downstream tasks such as action recognition and object detection using multimodal datasets, proving its efficacy in learning powerful features without requiring explicit data synchronization or manual annotation.
subject: AI
title: Cross-Modal Contrastive Learning on Asynchronous Spatio-Temporal Data Streams

text: Transcriptional regulation is characterized by stochastic bursts of mRNA synthesis, yet the epigenetic mechanisms governing bursting kinetics remain poorly understood. Here, we integrate live-cell single-molecule imaging, chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq), and high-resolution microscopy to demonstrate that histone H3 lysine 27 acetylation (H3K27ac) is a critical determinant of transcriptional burst frequency. We show that targeted recruitment of the p300/CBP acetyltransferase induces hyper-acetylation at enhancer and promoter regions, leading to the formation of liquid-like transcriptional condensates enriched in BRD4 and Mediator. These phase-separated microenvironments do not significantly alter burst size but dramatically increase burst frequency by facilitating more efficient Pol II recruitment and pre-initiation complex assembly. Conversely, inhibition of deacetylases prolongs condensate lifetime and transcriptional output. Our findings reveal a direct mechanistic link between a specific epigenetic mark, the biophysical properties of chromatin-associated condensates, and the dynamic parameters of gene transcription, providing a quantitative framework for how histone modifications fine-tune gene expression noise and fidelity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dynamic Histone H3K27 Acetylation Orchestrates Transcriptional Bursting Dynamics via Phase-Separated Condensates

text: The functional repertoire of long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) in modulating signal transduction cascades is rapidly expanding. We have identified a previously uncharacterized lncRNA, termed LINCR-STAT3, that acts as a potent negative regulator of the JAK-STAT pathway. Using a combination of RNA pull-down assays coupled with mass spectrometry, we demonstrate that LINCR-STAT3 directly binds to the N-SH2 domain of the protein tyrosine phosphatase SHP-1. Structural and biochemical analyses reveal that this interaction induces a conformational change in SHP-1, allosterically enhancing its catalytic activity towards its substrate, JAK2. Consequently, ectopic expression of LINCR-STAT3 leads to attenuated STAT3 phosphorylation and downstream target gene expression in response to interleukin-6 stimulation. Conversely, CRISPR-mediated deletion of the LINCR-STAT3 locus in macrophages results in hyper-inflammatory responses. Our study uncovers an lncRNA-mediated allosteric regulatory mechanism, highlighting a novel layer of control in cytokine signaling with significant pathophysiological implications for inflammatory diseases.
subject: Biyoloji
title: A Novel Long Non-coding RNA, LINCR-STAT3, Modulates JAK-STAT Signaling through Allosteric Regulation of SHP-1 Phosphatase

text: The ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS) is essential for cellular proteostasis, yet the precise mechanism of substrate recognition and unfolding by the 26S proteasome remains structurally elusive. We present the cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of the human 26S proteasome captured in the act of engaging a poly-ubiquitylated, misfolded protein substrate at 3.1 Å resolution. The structure reveals that substrate binding induces a significant conformational rearrangement in the RPT ring of the 19S regulatory particle, creating a constricted pore that engages the substrate’s unstructured initiation region. The ubiquitin chain is recognized by the RPN10 and RPN13 subunits, which anchor the substrate while the ATP-dependent unfolding activity of the RPT hexamer commences. We observe a 'gating' mechanism whereby the pore dynamically cycles between open and closed states, coupled to ATP hydrolysis, suggesting a checkpoint for processive substrate degradation. These findings provide unprecedented structural insights into the initial steps of proteasomal degradation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the 26S Proteasome in Complex with a Poly-ubiquitylated Misfolded Substrate Reveals a Gating Mechanism for Unfolding

text: Precise control over gene expression is fundamental for dissecting complex biological processes. Current epigenome editing tools, however, lack acute spatiotemporal resolution. Here, we report the development of an optogenetic CRISPR-dCas9 platform, termed 'Opto-CRISPR-Edit,' for light-inducible gene regulation. This system utilizes a blue light-sensitive CRY2-CIB1 protein-protein interaction system to rapidly recruit transcriptional effector domains, such as KRAB for repression or VPR for activation, to specific genomic loci targeted by a guide RNA. We demonstrate robust, reversible, and highly localized control of endogenous gene expression in mammalian cells with single-cell precision using patterned illumination. Furthermore, we show that transient light induction can establish stable epigenetic memory, particularly at bivalent chromatin domains. Opto-CRISPR-Edit provides a powerful tool for interrogating the dynamic interplay between chromatin state and gene function, enabling functional genomic studies with unparalleled spatiotemporal fidelity and offering new avenues for programming cellular behavior and therapeutic interventions.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Development of a Light-Inducible CRISPR-dCas9 Epigenome Editor for Spatiotemporal Control of Gene Silencing and Activation

text: The Endosomal Sorting Complex Required for Transport (ESCRT) machinery mediates essential membrane remodeling events, including multivesicular body (MVB) biogenesis and cytokinesis. While its core components are well-defined, the regulatory signaling networks governing its assembly and activity remain incompletely characterized. Using quantitative mass spectrometry-based phosphoproteomics, we mapped the dynamic phosphorylation landscape of the entire ESCRT network in human cells following EGF stimulation. Our analysis identified over 200 regulated phosphorylation sites on 25 ESCRT proteins and associated factors. We uncovered a critical role for Casein Kinase 2 (CK2) in phosphorylating multiple ESCRT-III subunits, including CHMP4B at Serine 210. Functional validation using phosphomimetic and non-phosphorylatable mutants revealed that this modification is essential for the timely disassembly of ESCRT-III polymers by the AAA-ATPase VPS4. Integration of our data with kinase-substrate prediction algorithms and in vitro kinase assays delineates a complex signaling network that orchestrates the sequential and dynamic assembly of the ESCRT pathway, ensuring fidelity in membrane scission.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Phosphoproteomic Profiling Identifies a Kinase-Substrate Network Governing Endosomal Sorting Complex Required for Transport (ESCRT) Machinery Assembly

text: Liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) of RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) into biomolecular condensates is fundamental to cellular organization, but the mechanisms regulating their material properties are poorly understood. Here, we investigate the role of post-translational modifications, specifically arginine methylation, in modulating the phase behavior of FUS, an RBP implicated in ALS. Using in vitro reconstitution assays with purified components, we demonstrate that methylation of arginine residues within the low-complexity domain of FUS by protein arginine methyltransferases (PRMTs) systematically decreases its propensity to phase separate. Microrheology experiments reveal that methylation converts FUS condensates from viscous, liquid-like droplets into more dynamic, fluid states. This alteration in material properties correlates with enhanced mRNA mobility and translational efficiency within the condensates. We propose that arginine methylation acts as a dynamic 'valence-modulating' switch, controlling the strength of intermolecular interactions to tune the biophysical characteristics and downstream function of RBP condensates, a mechanism whose dysregulation likely contributes to pathological protein aggregation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Arginine Methylation Acts as a Valence-Modulating Switch to Control the Material Properties and Function of FUS-family RNA-binding Proteins in Biomolecular Condensates

text: The coordination between the CMG helicase and replicative DNA polymerases is critical for the fidelity and processivity of DNA replication. The dynamic nature of this coupling, however, is obscured in ensemble measurements. Here, we employed a multi-color single-molecule Förster resonance energy transfer (smFRET) assay to visualize the real-time conformational dynamics of the reconstituted eukaryotic replisome. Our data reveal that the leading-strand polymerase (Pol ε) is tightly coupled to CMG translocation, existing predominantly in a high-FRET synthesis state. In contrast, the lagging-strand polymerase (Pol δ) exhibits transient, stochastic dissociations from the replisome, consistent with its distributive synthesis of Okazaki fragments. Upon encountering a simulated DNA lesion, we observed frequent, short-lived backtracking of the entire replisome, a state characterized by a distinct FRET signature, which provides a kinetic window for lesion bypass or repair pathways to engage. These single-molecule insights illuminate the intricate choreography and error-correction mechanisms operating at the heart of the replication fork.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Single-Molecule FRET Analysis Reveals Helicase-Polymerase Coupling Dynamics and Backtracking Mechanisms at the Eukaryotic Replication Fork

text: Cells adapt to environmental stress by rapidly remodeling their proteome, often through translational control. To dissect the mechanisms underlying this adaptation to hypoxia, we performed ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) coupled with tRNA sequencing in human cells. Our analysis revealed widespread, codon-specific translational pausing at discrete sites across thousands of transcripts. This pausing was not correlated with general codon usage frequency but showed a strong inverse correlation with the abundance of specific tRNA isoacceptors, particularly those decoding proline (CCG) and glycine (GGC) codons, which become depleted under hypoxic conditions. We demonstrate that this tRNA scarcity-induced pausing leads to reduced protein output from specific transcripts enriched in these codons, including those encoding components of the mTORC1 signaling pathway. This selective translational throttling represents a novel, codon-based regulatory logic that allows cells to fine-tune protein synthesis and conserve resources, linking the tRNA pool directly to adaptive gene expression programs during cellular stress.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Ribosome Profiling Uncovers a Widespread Mechanism of Translational Pausing Mediated by Specific tRNA Isoacceptor Scarcity during Hypoxic Stress

text: The intricate architecture of the mitochondrial inner membrane, characterized by invaginations called cristae, is crucial for efficient oxidative phosphorylation. The molecular machinery governing cristae morphology is still being elucidated. We identify a novel 60 kDa protein, MITRAC60, as a key regulator of this process. Using quantitative proteomics and co-immunoprecipitation, we show that MITRAC60 is a core component of a stable complex with the MICOS machinery, specifically interacting with MIC19 and MIC25 at cristae junctions. Super-resolution microscopy and electron tomography of MITRAC60 knockout cells reveal severe disorganization of cristae, characterized by loss of junctions and the formation of concentric, onion-like inner membrane structures. Blue native PAGE analysis further demonstrates that the absence of MITRAC60 impairs the assembly and stability of respiratory chain supercomplexes, leading to a significant reduction in cellular respiration and ATP production. Our findings establish MITRAC60 as an essential factor linking cristae architecture to the functional organization of the electron transport chain.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The Inner Mitochondrial Membrane Protein MITRAC60 Regulates Cristae Architecture and Supercomplex Assembly through Interactions with the MICOS Complex

text: A significant fraction of cancers maintains telomere length through a telomerase-independent mechanism known as Alternative Lengthening of Telomeres (ALT), which relies on homologous recombination. The initiating events of ALT remain controversial. Here, we utilize advanced genomic and cellular assays to demonstrate that ALT is triggered by replication stress-induced DNA double-strand breaks at fragile telomeric sites. Using a novel assay to map break-induced replication (BIR) intermediates, we show that these breaks initiate a specialized form of BIR that utilizes homologous telomeric sequences on other chromosomes as templates for synthesis. This process generates characteristic ALT hallmarks, including extrachromosomal C-circles and heterogeneous telomere lengths. Critically, we find that depletion of key Fanconi Anemia (FA) pathway components, such as FANCD2, abrogates ALT-associated BIR and leads to telomere crisis, identifying the FA pathway as a critical regulator of ALT activity. This work provides a definitive molecular mechanism for ALT initiation and highlights a synthetic lethal vulnerability for ALT-positive cancers.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Alternative Lengthening of Telomeres is Initiated by Break-Induced Replication at Fragile Telomeric Sites and Regulated by the Fanconi Anemia Pathway

text: The developmental homology of pharyngeal arches across chordates belies significant evolutionary plasticity. This study investigates the genomic underpinnings of this divergence by integrating comparative transcriptomics, ATAC-seq, and functional genomics in amphioxus (Branchiostoma floridae), tunicate (Ciona intestinalis), and zebrafish (Danio rerio). We identified a core set of deeply conserved transcription factors but reveal extensive rewiring of their downstream cis-regulatory elements (CREs). Functional validation using CRISPR-mediated enhancer knockouts in zebrafish demonstrates that while orthologous CREs often regulate homologous genes, their spatiotemporal activity and quantitative outputs have diverged significantly. Our results indicate that pleiotropic constraints on core transcription factors are circumvented by evolutionary tinkering at the level of enhancers, allowing for lineage-specific modifications of a conserved developmental blueprint. This modularity in gene regulatory network architecture provides a powerful mechanism for generating morphological novelty while preserving essential developmental functions.
subject: Evrim
title: Cis-Regulatory Divergence and Pleiotropic Constraints in the Evolution of Chordate Pharyngeal Arch Patterning

text: The introgression of Neanderthal and Denisovan DNA into anatomically modern human populations is a known source of genetic variation. However, the selective pressures shaping the retention of these archaic alleles remain debated. We present a high-resolution analysis of 275 ancient Eurasian genomes spanning the last 10,000 years, focusing on introgressed haplotypes within immune-related loci, including the Toll-like receptor (TLR) gene cluster and OAS antiviral genes. Using a novel Bayesian framework to model allele frequency trajectories, we demonstrate that specific archaic haplotypes underwent strong positive selection during the Neolithic transition, coinciding with increased population densities and zoonotic disease exposure. These alleles are associated with altered cytokine responses in modern cell-based assays. Our findings suggest that archaic introgression provided a critical reservoir of pre-adapted immunogenetic variants, which were rapidly favored by selection, facilitating human adaptation to novel pathogenic environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Adaptive Introgression of Archaic Hominin Alleles Modulated Holocene-Era Pathogen Defense Landscapes in Eurasian Populations

text: Antagonistic coevolution between bacteria and their bacteriophage predators is a major driver of microbial diversity. Here, we investigate the molecular dynamics of this arms race by experimentally coevolving Pseudomonas aeruginosa with its lytic phage DMS3vir. Using time-series population genomics and shotgun proteomics, we uncovered a rapid and recurrent amplification of polymorphic toxin-antitoxin (TA) systems. Phages evolved sophisticated anti-toxin mimics to neutralize bacterial defenses, while bacteria responded by diversifying their toxin repertoires or modifying the toxin-antitoxin binding interface. Phylogenetic analysis reveals that these TA loci are frequently exchanged via horizontal gene transfer, acting as mobile defense cassettes. Our results demonstrate that the coevolutionary conflict imposes strong, fluctuating selection, maintaining a remarkable diversity of TA systems within bacterial populations. This dynamic interplay represents a key microcosm of Red Queen dynamics, where molecular innovation is continuously required to maintain relative fitness.
subject: Evrim
title: Reciprocal Antagonistic Coevolution Drives Rapid Diversification of Toxin-Antitoxin Systems in a Bacteriophage-Host Arms Race

text: The Cambrian Explosion represents an unparalleled burst of animal diversification, yet its tempo and underlying mechanisms remain contentious. We address this by generating a comprehensive phylogenomic dataset encompassing 70 animal phyla and subphyla, integrating 1,250 orthologous protein-coding genes with a new matrix of 210 fossil calibrations. Utilizing a Bayesian relaxed molecular clock with fossilized birth-death process priors, our analysis robustly places the origin of Bilateria in the late Ediacaran, significantly predating the fossil record of crown-group members. Trait evolution models, employing stochastic character mapping, indicate that the acquisition of key developmental toolkits (e.g., Hox and Wnt gene clusters) preceded morphological diversification. Our findings suggest that the 'explosion' was not a sudden origin of phyla, but rather the ecological release and morphological realization of deeply rooted genetic potential, likely triggered by a confluence of environmental factors like oceanic oxygenation.
subject: Evrim
title: A Fossil-Calibrated Phylogenomic Framework Reveals Cryptic Drivers of the Cambrian Explosion

text: The evolution of robustness, or canalization, against genetic perturbation is a fundamental property of biological systems, yet its origins are poorly understood. We developed a multi-locus, agent-based simulation to model population evolution on NK fitness landscapes of tunable ruggedness. Our model incorporates a quantitative modifier locus that controls the expression of epistatic interactions among fitness-determining loci. We demonstrate that populations evolving on rugged landscapes consistently evolve higher levels of canalization. This occurs through a process of 'epistatic ratcheting,' where stabilizing selection favors alleles at the modifier locus that mask the deleterious effects of mutations at other loci. This buffering allows populations to accumulate cryptic genetic variation. Critically, we show that periodic environmental shifts can then release this stored variation, facilitating rapid adaptation. This research provides a mechanistic explanation for how evolvability itself can be a direct target of selection.
subject: Evrim
title: Epistatic Ratcheting and the Evolution of Genetic Canalization on Rugged Fitness Landscapes

text: Understanding the genomic architecture of reproductive isolation is central to speciation research. We performed whole-genome sequencing of 150 individuals across a hybrid zone between two incipient species of Heliconius butterflies, H. cydno and H. melpomene. Using FST and Patterson's D-statistic scans, we identified multiple discrete 'genomic islands' of high divergence, which resist homogenization despite ongoing gene flow. Notably, these islands are significantly enriched for structural variants (SVs), particularly large inversions. One 3.5 Mbp inversion on chromosome 15 contains the optix transcription factor, a major determinant of wing color pattern, and multiple genes implicated in mate preference. We posit that these inversions act as supergenes, linking ecologically important traits with mate choice loci, thereby suppressing recombination and facilitating the buildup of Dobzhansky-Muller incompatibilities. Our findings highlight the critical role of SVs in coupling divergent selection and reproductive isolation, accelerating the speciation continuum.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Islands of Divergence and the Role of Structural Variants in Incipient Speciation of Heliconius Butterflies

text: Predicting evolutionary responses to complex, fluctuating environments is a major challenge. We subjected 100 replicate populations of Saccharomyces cerevisiae to long-term experimental evolution under conditions of oscillating glucose and galactose limitation. Through periodic whole-genome, whole-transcriptome sequencing, we tracked the adaptive trajectories in real time. We observed remarkable parallelism at the gene level, with recurrent mutations in key regulators of carbon catabolite repression, such as MIG1 and GAL80. However, at the network level, we found convergent evolution of distinct metabolic strategies. Some lineages evolved enhanced substrate switching efficiency through cis-regulatory mutations, while others adopted a more generalist strategy by constitutively upregulating both pathways, incurring a cost-of-carry. These divergent solutions to the same adaptive problem highlight the multifarious paths available on the fitness landscape and demonstrate that while genomic targets of selection can be predictable, the resulting network-level adaptations can be highly contingent.
subject: Evrim
title: Parallel and Convergent Evolution of Metabolic Networks in Experimentally Evolved Saccharomyces cerevisiae Under Oscillating Nutrient Stress

text: The evolution of eusociality, characterized by reproductive division of labor, represents a major evolutionary transition. To uncover its molecular underpinnings, we conducted a comparative transcriptomic analysis of brain tissue from queens and workers across 15 independently evolved eusocial Hymenoptera species. By controlling for phylogeny, we identified a core suite of 87 genes showing convergent caste-biased expression. These genes are significantly enriched for neuropeptide signaling pathways, including insulin/insulin-like growth factor signaling (IIS) and vitellogenin, key modulators of reproduction and foraging behavior in solitary ancestors. Our results suggest that the evolution of eusociality repeatedly co-opted and rewired these ancestral neuroendocrine pathways, repurposing them to regulate social behavior rather than individual reproduction. This molecular convergence provides a powerful example of how existing genetic toolkits can be evolutionarily redeployed to generate complex social phenotypes, offering a unifying framework for the origins of altruism.
subject: Evrim
title: Neurogenomic Correlates of Eusociality: Convergent Evolution of Neuropeptide Regulation in Hymenoptera

text: The role of non-genetic inheritance in adaptation remains a contentious topic in evolutionary biology. This study investigates the contribution of heritable epigenetic modifications to adaptive phenotypic plasticity in the threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus). We exposed isogenic F0-generation individuals to simulated predator cues and performed whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) on F0, F1, and F2 generations, which were not directly exposed. We identified hundreds of differentially methylated regions (DMRs) associated with predator exposure, particularly in genes linked to neurogenesis and stress response. A significant subset of these DMRs was stably inherited through to the F2 generation, correlating with heritable changes in anti-predator behaviors and defensive spine morphology. These findings provide compelling evidence for transgenerational epigenetic inheritance as a mechanism for rapid, adaptive parental effects, potentially bridging the gap between short-term plasticity and long-term genetic adaptation in fluctuating environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance of DNA Methylation Patterns Mediates Adaptive Phenotypic Plasticity in Threespine Stickleback

text: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a major evolutionary force in prokaryotes, but its role in the adaptive radiation of complex eukaryotes is considered limited. Here, we challenge this view through a comprehensive genomic analysis of the Attine ants, which evolved a sophisticated symbiosis with cultivated fungi. Our phylogenomic pipeline, rigorously controlling for contamination, identified over 250 genes of clear bacterial origin integrated into the ant genomes. These HGT-derived genes are not randomly distributed but form functional metabolic clusters, including pathways for cellulose degradation and novel amino acid synthesis. Expression analyses confirm these genes are highly active in the ants' metapleural glands, which secrete antimicrobial compounds. We conclude that a massive influx of bacterial genetic material provided the metabolic toolkit necessary for the Attine ants to transition to their unique fungivorous niche, demonstrating that HGT can be a potent engine of metabolic innovation in multicellular animals.
subject: Evrim
title: Massive Horizontal Gene Transfer of Bacterial Metabolic Pathways Catalyzed the Adaptive Radiation of Fungus-Growing Ants

text: We investigate the fault-tolerance threshold of a topological quantum computer based on Fibonacci anyons, whose braiding operations provide a universal set of quantum gates. Our study employs a Monte Carlo simulation of a surface code architecture adapted for non-Abelian statistics, incorporating a phenomenological error model that includes both local depolarizing noise and correlated errors arising from imperfect braiding. We introduce a novel decoding algorithm, the 'Homological Weighted Blossom' (HWB) decoder, which leverages the geometric structure of the anyonic worldlines to infer the most likely error chains. Our simulations reveal a significantly higher error threshold (p_th ≈ 2.1 x 10⁻³) compared to previous estimates using standard minimum-weight perfect matching decoders. This enhanced resilience is attributed to the HWB decoder's ability to correctly interpret complex error syndromes involving anyon fusion and annihilation events. These findings suggest that topological quantum computation with Fibonacci anyons is more robust against realistic noise models than previously anticipated, advancing its viability for scalable quantum information processing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Geometric Fault-Tolerance Thresholds for Non-Abelian Fibonacci Anyons in a Surface Code Architecture

text: The transition between an ergodic thermal phase and a many-body localized (MBL) phase represents a fundamental breakdown of statistical mechanics in isolated quantum systems. We theoretically and numerically investigate this transition in a one-dimensional disordered Heisenberg spin-1/2 chain using out-of-time-order correlators (OTOCs). By employing large-scale exact diagonalization and time-evolving block decimation (TEBD) methods, we compute the OTOCs to probe the scrambling of quantum information. In the thermal phase, we observe exponential growth of the OTOC, characteristic of quantum chaos, with a scrambling rate approaching the universal bound. Conversely, in the MBL phase, the OTOC exhibits only logarithmic growth, indicating the suppression of information scrambling and the persistence of local memory. We precisely map the critical disorder strength for the MBL transition by analyzing the scaling properties of the OTOC growth exponent, providing a new dynamical signature that distinguishes these fundamentally different phases of quantum matter.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing the Many-Body Localization Transition via Out-of-Time-Order Correlators in a Disordered Spin-1/2 Heisenberg Chain

text: We explore the relationship between entanglement entropy in a deformed conformal field theory (CFT) and the geometry of its dual anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime within the framework of the AdS/CFT correspondence. Specifically, we compute the holographic entanglement entropy using the Ryu-Takayanagi formula for a CFT perturbed by a relevant, spatially modulated operator. The deformation induces a non-trivial change in the bulk metric, leading to deviations in the minimal surface area. Our results demonstrate that for certain classes of deformations, the entanglement entropy exhibits non-local features that cannot be explained by a simple local quantum field theory, yet the causal structure of the boundary theory is preserved. This suggests a subtle encoding of sub-AdS scale locality within the entanglement structure of the boundary theory. We further analyze the entanglement wedge cross-section, providing a holographic dual for the entanglement of purification, and show its sensitivity to the deformation's length scale.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Sub-AdS Locality in Deformed Conformal Field Theories

text: We propose and theoretically analyze a protocol for generating macroscopic quantum superposition (Schrödinger cat) states in a toroidally trapped Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC). The protocol utilizes a time-modulated, spatially localized potential barrier to control the tunneling dynamics between two wells imprinted on the toroidal trap. By solving the multi-configurational time-dependent Hartree-Fock equations for interacting bosons, we demonstrate that a precisely tailored modulation frequency, resonant with the energy splitting of the two lowest-lying many-body states, can deterministically drive the system from its ground state into a macroscopic superposition of clockwise and counter-clockwise persistent currents. We characterize the generated state using the two-body correlation function and the Husimi Q-function, confirming the presence of strong non-classical correlations and macroscopic coherence. The scheme is shown to be robust against moderate fluctuations in atom number and trap parameters, opening a viable path toward exploring macroscopic quantum phenomena and quantum-enhanced sensing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Dynamical Creation of Schrödinger Cat States in a Toroidally Trapped Bose-Einstein Condensate via Modulated Tunneling

text: We report a robust experimental violation of a generalized Bell inequality tailored for high-dimensional quantum systems. Using spontaneous parametric down-conversion (SPDC) in a periodically poled KTP crystal, we generate photon pairs simultaneously entangled in polarization, orbital angular momentum (OAM), and time-bin degrees of freedom, creating a hyperentangled state in a 2⊗2⊗4 Hilbert space. By employing state-of-the-art spatial light modulators for OAM projection and fast electro-optic modulators for time-bin analysis, we perform a Clauser-Horne-Shimony-Holt (CHSH)-type measurement on correlated subspaces. Our results yield a Bell parameter S = 2.78 ± 0.04, violating the classical bound of 2 by over 19 standard deviations. This high-fidelity demonstration of non-locality in a large Hilbert space not only reinforces the foundational principles of quantum mechanics against local-realist theories but also establishes a critical resource for advanced quantum communication protocols, such as high-capacity quantum key distribution and dense coding.
subject: Kuantum
title: Violation of High-Dimensional Bell Inequalities using Hyperentangled Photon Pairs from Spontaneous Parametric Down-Conversion

text: Coherence times in state-of-the-art superconducting qubits are often limited by microscopic two-level systems (TLS) residing in amorphous surface oxides. While the impact of individual TLS on single-qubit decoherence is well-studied, their collective effect in multi-qubit systems remains poorly understood. We present a theoretical model and experimental evidence for spatially correlated dephasing induced by a shared bath of TLS defects in a linear array of five transmon qubits. By simultaneously measuring the Ramsey decay of multiple qubits, we observe strong temporal correlations in their frequency fluctuations, which cannot be explained by independent TLS interactions. Our model, which considers the overlapping electric fields of adjacent qubits coupling to the same TLS bath, quantitatively reproduces the observed cross-correlation spectral density. These findings reveal a significant, previously underappreciated channel for correlated errors in superconducting quantum processors, highlighting the necessity of mitigating TLS-induced crosstalk for achieving fault-tolerant quantum computation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Correlated Dephasing from Two-Level System Defects in Multi-Qubit Superconducting Processors

text: The Chiral Magnetic Effect (CME) posits the generation of an electric current along an external magnetic field in a system with chiral imbalance, a phenomenon of fundamental importance in heavy-ion collisions. We present a first-principles calculation of the CME conductivity using lattice Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) simulations with 2+1 flavors of dynamical quarks. By simulating QCD at finite temperature in the presence of a background magnetic field and a chiral chemical potential, we measure the vector current correlator. The conductivity is extracted from the low-frequency limit of the Euclidean correlator via analytic continuation using the Maximum Entropy Method. Our simulations, performed on fine lattices with physical quark masses, yield a non-zero value for the CME conductivity that is consistent with holographic and perturbative predictions in the weak field limit. This non-perturbative result provides robust theoretical evidence for the existence of the CME in the quark-gluon plasma.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Perturbative Determination of the Chiral Magnetic Effect Conductivity from First-Principles Lattice QCD Simulations

text: Achieving the ultimate precision in parameter estimation, dictated by the Heisenberg limit, is a central goal of quantum metrology. We demonstrate an adaptive Bayesian measurement protocol that achieves Heisenberg-limited scaling for optical phase estimation. The experiment utilizes path-entangled N00N states, specifically twin-Fock states |N,0⟩ + |0,N⟩ with N up to 6, generated via conditional measurements on a two-mode squeezed vacuum state. Unlike standard interferometry, our protocol iteratively updates the phase estimate using a Bayesian inference algorithm, which then dynamically adjusts the measurement basis for the subsequent round. This feedback loop optimally allocates quantum resources, allowing the phase uncertainty to scale as 1/(N+1), surpassing the standard quantum limit of 1/√N. Our method demonstrates a root-mean-square estimation error of Δφ ≈ 0.14/N, providing a clear path toward ultra-precise measurements for applications in gravitational wave detection and biological sensing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Phase Estimation via Adaptive Bayesian Inference with Twin-Fock States

text: Non-Abelian anyons are exotic quasiparticles whose braiding operations form the basis of fault-tolerant topological quantum computation. Realizing and manipulating these particles remains a major experimental challenge. We report the direct observation of non-Abelian braiding statistics in a programmable quantum simulator implementing the Kitaev honeycomb model. Our system consists of a 4x4 array of superconducting transmon qubits with tunable nearest-neighbor ZZ-interactions, allowing us to adiabatically prepare the gapped spin liquid ground state. By locally applying magnetic fields, we create and control pairs of Ising anyons (Majorana zero modes). We perform a complete braiding cycle by shuttling one anyon around another and measure the resulting holonomic transformation on the qubit subspace encoded by the anyons. The measured unitary operator, reconstructed via quantum process tomography, matches the theoretical prediction for Ising anyon braiding, providing unambiguous evidence of their non-Abelian nature. This work constitutes a crucial step towards implementing topological quantum algorithms.
subject: Kuantum
title: Direct Observation of Non-Abelian Braiding Statistics in a Programmable Kitaev Honeycomb Spin Liquid Simulator

text: Spontaneous collapse models, which postulate a fundamental mechanism for quantum state reduction, offer a potential resolution to the quantum measurement problem and a path towards unifying quantum mechanics and gravity. The Continuous Spontaneous Localization (CSL) model and the Diósi-Penrose (DP) model predict a mass-dependent decoherence rate that becomes significant for macroscopic objects. We present the results of a matter-wave interferometry experiment with 10⁷ amu silicon nanoparticles, pushing the exploration of macroscopic quantum superpositions to an unprecedented mass scale. By maintaining quantum coherence of the nanoparticle's center-of-mass motion for up to 2 milliseconds in a Talbot-Lau interferometer, we place stringent new bounds on the parameters of CSL and DP models. Our results exclude a significant portion of the previously unconstrained parameter space for these gravitational decoherence theories. This experiment narrows the plausible range for collapse model parameters, bringing us closer to either discovering or ruling out this class of modifications to quantum mechanics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Constraints on Spontaneous Gravitational Collapse Models from Matter-Wave Interferometry with Nanoparticles

text: This paper investigates the maximum spectral radius of a non-uniform hypergraph H on n vertices that forbids a specific family of intersection patterns. We extend the concept of the adjacency tensor and its principal eigenvalue to the setting of non-uniform hypergraphs, where hyperedges can have varying cardinalities. Our primary focus is on hypergraphs that are F-free, where F is a family of subhypergraphs defined by restrictions on the pairwise intersections of their edges. By employing the Lagrangian method for tensors and developing new spectral symmetrization techniques, we establish an upper bound on the principal eigenvalue of an F-free non-uniform hypergraph. This spectral result is then used to derive an asymptotic upper bound for the corresponding Turán number, ex(n, F). The extremal constructions are shown to be related to multi-partite structures, generalizing the classical Turán graph theorem to a broader spectral and non-uniform context.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Spectral Turán Problem for Non-Uniform Hypergraphs with Forbidden Intersection Patterns

text: We study the off-diagonal Ramsey numbers R(P_n^k, P_m^k) for k-uniform loose paths, where P_n^k denotes a path with n edges. For k ≥ 3, the linear bounds established in the diagonal case (n=m) do not trivially extend to the asymmetric setting. Our main result provides the first polynomial upper bound for these numbers, showing that R(P_n^k, P_m^k) ≤ C_k(n+m)k for n ≥ m. The proof integrates the hypergraph regularity method with a novel absorption strategy tailored for sparse hypergraphs. We develop a structural lemma for 2-edge-colored hypergraphs that guarantees either a robustly expanding matching structure, which facilitates the construction of the longer path, or a density condition that allows us to embed the shorter path using a dependent random choice argument. This work bridges a significant gap in the Ramsey theory of sparse hypergraphs and has implications for related Turán-type problems.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymmetric Ramsey Numbers for Loose Paths in Monochromatic k-Uniform Hypergraphs

text: We establish a novel connection between the Schubert polynomials of type A_n and the Ehrhart theory of a specific family of flow polytopes, termed Chan-Robbins-Yuen (CRY) flow polytopes. We construct an explicit, volume-preserving bijection between the 'pipe dreams' representing a Schubert polynomial and the lattice points within a corresponding CRY flow polytope. This correspondence provides a geometric interpretation of the monomial expansion coefficients of Schubert polynomials. Leveraging this geometric framework, we use techniques from toric geometry and Stanley-Reisner rings to provide a new proof for the log-concavity of certain sequences derived from these coefficients. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the Betti numbers of the associated toric variety are determined by specific evaluations of the Schubert polynomial, thereby uniting enumerative, geometric, and topological aspects of these fundamental objects in algebraic combinatorics.
subject: Matematik
title: Schubert Polynomials and the Toric Geometry of Flow Polytopes

text: This paper extends the classical Freiman-Ruzsa theorem on the structure of sets with small doubling to the non-abelian setting of solvable groups. We prove that if A is a finite subset of a solvable group G of derived length d, such that the product set satisfies |A^2| ≤ K|A|, then A is contained in a bounded number of cosets of a subgroup H which is nilpotent-by-abelian. The structure of H is precisely controlled: it contains a normal nilpotent subgroup N of bounded step and index such that H/N is abelian. The proof utilizes a multi-stage induction along the derived series of G, combining non-abelian Fourier analysis with a Plünnecke-Ruzsa type inequality for amenable groups. This result provides a quantitative structural characterization of sets with small doubling that interpolates between the abelian case and the more complex behavior in general non-solvable groups.
subject: Matematik
title: A Freiman-Type Theorem for Sets with Small Doubling in Solvable Groups of Bounded Derived Length

text: We investigate the homotopy type of the independence complex Ind(G) for the class of K_r-free comparability graphs. By associating each such graph G with a specific poset P whose comparability graph is G, we demonstrate that Ind(G) is homotopy equivalent to the nerve of a subposet of P's order ideals. Utilizing Quillen's Fiber Lemma and techniques from discrete Morse theory, we establish that for any r ≥ 3, the independence complex of a K_r-free comparability graph is either contractible or homotopy equivalent to a wedge of spheres of a single dimension. We provide an explicit combinatorial formula for the dimension of these spheres in terms of the structure of the defining poset. This result unifies and generalizes previous findings for chordal graphs (which are K_3-free) and provides a new framework for analyzing the topology of independence complexes in highly structured graph classes.
subject: Matematik
title: Homotopy Type of Independence Complexes of K_r-Free Comparability Graphs

text: We introduce and enumerate a new class of combinatorial objects, skew-angular plane partitions, which generalize both symmetric and cyclically symmetric plane partitions. By establishing a correspondence with dimer coverings (perfect matchings) of a specific weighted hexagonal graph with atypical boundary conditions, we derive a determinantal formula for their generating function. Using the saddle-point method and analyzing the associated variational principle for the dimer model's free energy, we determine the asymptotic number of such partitions as their bounding box grows. Furthermore, we prove that a uniformly random skew-angular plane partition converges to a deterministic limit shape after suitable rescaling. This limit surface is characterized as the solution to a degenerate elliptic PDE and exhibits a faceted boundary with both linear and curved segments, distinct from the classical arctic circle phenomenon, indicating a richer class of phase transitions.
subject: Matematik
title: Asymptotic Enumeration and Limit Shapes for Skew-Angular Plane Partitions

text: A large set of disjoint t-(v,k,λ) designs, denoted LS[N](t,k,v), is a partition of the set of all k-subsets of a v-set into N designs with parameters t-(v,k,λ). A fundamental open question concerns the rigidity of such partitions: can two non-isomorphic large sets exist for the same parameters? We provide an affirmative answer by developing a new algebraic framework based on the orbital matrices of group actions. By analyzing the tactical decompositions induced by specific automorphism subgroups, we devise a computational method to distinguish and construct non-isomorphic large sets. We apply this technique to construct the first known example of two non-isomorphic LS[3](3,4,10), resolving a long-standing problem in design theory. This demonstrates that the global structure of a large set is not uniquely determined by its parameters, opening new avenues for classification problems in combinatorial design theory.
subject: Matematik
title: On the Existence of Non-Isomorphic Large Sets of Disjoint t-(v,k,λ) Designs

text: The Kazhdan-Lusztig (KL) polynomial of a matroid M, denoted P_M(t), is a central object in algebraic and enumerative combinatorics whose properties are still largely conjectural. A key conjecture states that the sequence of coefficients of P_M(t) is log-concave for any matroid M. We prove this conjecture for the class of uniform matroids U_{k,n}. Our approach moves beyond purely combinatorial methods by realizing the coefficients of P_{U_{k,n}}(t) as intersection numbers in the Chow ring of a specific smooth projective variety associated with the Grassmannian Gr(k,n). By applying the Hodge-Riemann relations for this variety, we demonstrate that P_{U_{k,n}}(t) not only has log-concave coefficients but also satisfies the stronger property of having only real roots. This geometric perspective provides a new framework for attacking the general conjecture and illuminates deep connections between matroid theory and algebraic geometry.
subject: Matematik
title: The Log-Concavity of Kazhdan-Lusztig Polynomials for Uniform Matroids

text: We introduce a fractional analogue of Hadwiger's celebrated conjecture, positing that any graph G with fractional chromatic number χ_f(G) ≥ t contains a K_⌈t⌉ minor. We confirm this conjecture for several graph classes, including those with bounded treewidth and certain families of claw-free graphs. Our main result provides strong evidence via a spectral relaxation. We prove that if G is a d-degenerate graph whose normalized Laplacian has a principal eigenvalue λ_1(L(G)) satisfying a specific lower bound dependent on d and t, then G must contain a K_⌈t⌉ minor. The proof technique involves a novel potential function argument combined with spectral graph partitioning. During an iterative edge-contraction process, the potential function, which combines vertex degrees and local subgraph densities, is shown to be non-increasing on average, guaranteeing that sufficient density is maintained to form the desired clique minor.
subject: Matematik
title: Fractional Hadwiger Conjecture and Laplacian Eigenvalue Bounds for Degenerate Graphs

text: We investigate the quench dynamics of a one-dimensional Heisenberg spin chain with quenched random fields, a canonical model for many-body localization (MBL). Utilizing time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (t-DMRG) simulations on large system sizes, we analyze the post-quench evolution of bipartite entanglement entropy. For strong disorder, we observe a distinct slow, logarithmic growth of entanglement, a definitive signature of the MBL phase, which contrasts sharply with the linear, volume-law scaling characteristic of thermalizing systems described by the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH). Our numerical results demonstrate the persistence of local memory from the initial state and the suppression of thermalization due to quantum interference in the Hilbert space. This work provides robust numerical evidence for the logarithmic entanglement barrier that prevents thermalization, confirming a central tenet of MBL theory and its implications for quantum statistical mechanics in isolated, disordered quantum systems.
subject: Kuantum
title: Logarithmic Scaling of Entanglement Entropy in Disordered Many-Body Localized Systems

text: Topological quantum computation promises inherent fault tolerance by encoding quantum information non-locally. This study presents a theoretical framework and numerical simulation of quantum gate operations based on the braiding of Majorana zero modes (MZMs) in a network of p-wave superconducting nanowires. We detail the construction of logical qubits from four or more MZMs and demonstrate how their non-Abelian exchange statistics generate Clifford group operations. Specifically, we simulate the braiding sequence for a controlled-NOT (CNOT) gate, solving the time-dependent Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations to track the evolution of the many-body ground state. The gate fidelity is analyzed in the presence of realistic noise sources, including quasiparticle poisoning and non-adiabatic diabatic errors. Our findings indicate that gate errors decay exponentially with the MZM separation and braiding timescale, affirming the topological protection that underpins this computational paradigm.
subject: Kuantum
title: Braiding Non-Abelian Anyons: A Framework for Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation with Majorana Zero Modes

text: We propose and analyze a scheme for autonomous quantum error correction (QEC) of Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill (GKP) qubits encoded in a bosonic mode. The protocol leverages engineered dissipation within a coupled cavity system, where a Kerr-nonlinear ancilla resonator selectively couples to the error-syndrome components of the GKP state's Wigner function. This continuous, Hamiltonian-based feedback mechanism autonomously corrects for single-photon loss, the dominant error channel, without requiring active measurement or classical processing. Through master equation simulations, we demonstrate that the scheme can stabilize the GKP code space, achieving a logical error rate suppression that surpasses the break-even threshold for fault-tolerant quantum computation. This passive QEC architecture provides a resource-efficient pathway towards building robust logical qubits for continuous-variable quantum information processing, mitigating the overhead associated with conventional syndrome-based methods.
subject: Kuantum
title: High-Fidelity Quantum Error Correction via Autonomous Stabilization of Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill Qubits

text: Objective collapse models, which modify quantum mechanics to explain the emergence of classicality, predict a universal decoherence mechanism. We report on an experiment designed to stringently test these models, specifically the Continuous Spontaneous Localization (CSL) and Diósi-Penrose (DP) theories, using an optically levitated nanosphere in an ultra-high vacuum. By cooling the nanosphere's center-of-mass motion close to its quantum ground state and monitoring its subsequent heating rate with exceptional precision, we place new bounds on the parameters of these collapse models. Our data analysis, which carefully accounts for all known classical and quantum noise sources, reveals no anomalous heating. The resulting exclusion plot rules out a significant portion of the previously unconstrained CSL parameter space and directly confronts the parameter-free prediction of the gravity-related DP model, thereby imposing tight constraints on macroscopic quantum mechanics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Experimental Constraints on Spontaneous Wave-Function Collapse Models via Levitated Optomechanics

text: Non-Hermitian Hamiltonians, which effectively describe open quantum systems, exhibit unique topological features such as exceptional points (EPs). We report the experimental realization of a parity-time (PT) symmetric system in a duo of coupled photonic crystal L3 nanocavities. By incorporating erbium-doped gain material in one cavity and engineering absorptive loss in the other, we achieve a finely balanced non-Hermitian Hamiltonian. Using high-resolution transmission spectroscopy, we observe the PT-symmetry breaking transition, where the real parts of the eigenfrequencies coalesce and the imaginary parts bifurcate. At this transition point—the EP—the system's eigenvectors also coalesce. We further demonstrate the characteristic square-root response to perturbations near the EP, resulting in a giant enhancement in sensitivity. Our results provide a robust platform for exploring the fundamental physics of non-Hermitian systems and their applications in ultra-sensitive optical sensing.
subject: Kuantum
title: Observation of Parity-Time Symmetry Breaking and Exceptional Points in a Coupled Photonic Crystal Resonator System

text: The anomalous transport properties of strange metals, particularly the linear-in-temperature resistivity, defy explanation by conventional Fermi liquid theory. We employ the gauge/gravity duality to model this behavior by constructing a gravitational dual in an asymptotically Anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime. Our model incorporates a charged black hole and a scalar dilaton field, whose dynamics are coupled to a Maxwell field, breaking the translational symmetry of the boundary theory and allowing for finite DC conductivity. By calculating transport coefficients via linearized perturbations of the bulk gravitational and electromagnetic fields, we reproduce the characteristic T-linear resistivity and logarithmic corrections to specific heat observed in cuprate superconductors. This holographic approach provides a self-consistent, strongly-coupled framework that captures the essential phenomenology of quantum critical systems without relying on quasiparticle descriptions, offering new insights into non-Fermi liquid physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Strange Metals: A Gravitational Dual Approach to Quantum Critical Transport

text: We present a quantum metrology protocol that achieves phase sensitivity surpassing the Heisenberg limit. Our approach utilizes a multi-mode entangled probe state, generated by interfering multiple single-mode squeezed vacuum states on a linear optical network, coupled with a Bayesian adaptive measurement strategy. The core innovation lies in using photon-number-resolving (PNR) detectors, which provide richer information about the phase-imprinted quantum state than conventional parity or homodyne measurements. Theoretical analysis demonstrates that the Fisher information for an N-photon component of the probe state scales as N^2k, leading to a phase uncertainty scaling of N^-(k+1/2) with total mean photon number N, where k is the number of modes. This represents a significant improvement over the standard Heisenberg limit of N^-1. The protocol offers a viable path toward next-generation quantum-enhanced interferometers for applications in gravitational wave astronomy and fundamental physics.
subject: Kuantum
title: Sub-Heisenberg-Limited Phase Estimation using Multi-Mode Squeezed Vacuum States and Photon-Number-Resolving Detection

text: The conformal bootstrap provides a powerful non-perturbative method for solving strongly-coupled quantum field theories. In this work, we apply numerical bootstrap techniques to the 3D Ising conformal field theory (CFT) to determine its critical exponents with unprecedented precision. By imposing constraints of unitarity and crossing symmetry on the four-point function of identical scalar operators (⟨σσσσ⟩), we derive rigorous bounds on the scaling dimensions of the leading spin-zero (ε) and spin-two (Tμν) operators. Our analysis, leveraging semidefinite programming and a large-scale distributed computing cluster, carves out a miniscule allowed region in the (Δ_σ, Δ_ε) parameter space. From this region, we extract the critical exponents ν = 0.629971(4) and η = 0.036298(2), results that are orders of magnitude more precise than previous determinations and are in excellent agreement with experimental values for uniaxial magnets and liquid-vapor transitions.
subject: Kuantum
title: Precision Determination of 3D Ising Model Critical Exponents via Conformal Bootstrap

text: Simulating the real-time dynamics of lattice gauge theories is a key challenge for high-energy physics, one potentially solvable by quantum computers. We report the digital quantum simulation of a U(1) lattice gauge theory—a simplified version of quantum electrodynamics—on a 7-qubit superconducting quantum processor. The Hamiltonian is mapped onto qubits representing fermionic matter and gauge fields, with gauge invariance enforced by the system's structure. We implement the time evolution using a Trotter-Suzuki decomposition of the dynamics operator into a sequence of native single- and two-qubit gates. By preparing the system in its strong-coupling vacuum, we study the dynamics of Schwinger pair production, observing the characteristic propagation of particle-antiparticle excitations. We verify the adherence to Gauss's law throughout the evolution, demonstrating the successful enforcement of gauge symmetry. This experiment represents a critical step towards simulating complex field theories on near-term quantum hardware.
subject: Kuantum
title: Digital Quantum Simulation of a U(1) Lattice Gauge Theory with Superconducting Qubits

text: The remarkable efficiency of photosynthetic energy transfer has been hypothesized to exploit quantum mechanical effects. We investigate the role of electronic coherence in the Photosystem II reaction center (PSII RC) using ultrafast two-dimensional electronic spectroscopy (2DES) with sub-10-fs temporal resolution. The resulting 2D spectra map the flow of excitonic energy, revealing distinct cross-peaks that signify coherent coupling between spatially separated chlorophyll pigments. At cryogenic temperatures (77 K), we observe quantum beats in the cross-peak amplitudes that persist for over 600 femtoseconds, indicating long-lived electronic coherences. By modeling the data with the hierarchical equations of motion (HEOM) formalism, we demonstrate that these coherences are not merely spectroscopic artifacts but play a functional role in directing energy transport. Our results provide compelling evidence that the protein scaffold actively sustains quantum coherence, facilitating a highly efficient, non-classical energy transfer pathway.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Quantum Coherence in Excitonic Energy Transport through Two-Dimensional Electronic Spectroscopy of Photosystem II

text: The epigenetic state, particularly histone H3 lysine 27 trimethylation (H3K27me3), is a critical barrier to cellular reprogramming. Here, we developed a novel CRISPR-based epigenome editing tool by fusing a catalytically inactive Cas9 (dCas9) to the catalytic domain of the H3K27me3-specific demethylase UTX. Guided by sgRNAs targeting the promoters of core pluripotency factors OCT4 and SOX2 in terminally differentiated fibroblasts, the dCas9-UTX fusion protein induced robust and locus-specific removal of the repressive H3K27me3 mark. Chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) confirmed a significant reduction in H3K27me3 occupancy at targeted loci, concomitant with an increase in the activating H3K4me3 mark. This localized epigenetic remodeling led to the transcriptional re-activation of the pluripotency gene network and a partial reversion to a more primitive cellular phenotype. Our findings demonstrate the potential of precise epigenetic engineering to modulate cell fate decisions, providing a powerful tool for regenerative medicine and the study of developmental gene regulation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Targeted H3K27me3 Demethylation via a dCas9-UTX Fusion Recapitulates Pluripotency Gene Expression

text: Transcriptional regulation often involves the formation of biomolecular condensates at key genomic elements. We investigate the role of liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) in the function of the bromodomain and extraterminal domain (BET) protein BRD4 at super-enhancers. Using in vitro reconstitution assays and live-cell single-molecule imaging, we show that the intrinsically disordered region (IDR) of BRD4 drives its condensation into liquid-like droplets. This process is significantly enhanced by its association with acetylated histone H3 tails and the Mediator complex. Importantly, we identify a cluster of lysine residues within the IDR whose auto-acetylation by p300/CBP serves as a critical regulatory switch. Acetylation neutralizes charge, promoting homotypic interactions and stabilizing BRD4 condensates. Disruption of this acetylation event via mutagenesis or specific inhibitors dissolves BRD4 puncta, abrogates Pol II recruitment, and attenuates target gene expression, establishing a direct link between PTM-regulated LLPS and oncogenic transcriptional control.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of BRD4 at Super-Enhancers is Modulated by Post-Translational Acetylation

text: Circular RNAs (circRNAs) are emerging as critical regulators in neurodegenerative diseases, yet their specific mechanisms remain largely unknown. In this study, we identify a neuronally-enriched circRNA, derived from the SNHG14 host gene (circSNHG14), that is significantly downregulated in the hippocampus of 5xFAD mice, a model for Alzheimer's disease (AD). Using luciferase reporter assays and RNA immunoprecipitation, we demonstrate that circSNHG14 acts as a molecular sponge for microRNA-137 (miR-137), a known repressor of synaptic function. Sequestration of miR-137 by circSNHG14 de-represses its target, ATG5, a key component of the autophagy machinery. Lentiviral-mediated overexpression of circSNHG14 in 5xFAD mice restored ATG5 levels, enhanced autophagic clearance of amyloid-beta plaques, and rescued synaptic plasticity deficits. These findings uncover a novel circSNHG14/miR-137/ATG5 regulatory axis in AD pathogenesis, highlighting circRNAs as potential therapeutic targets for mitigating neurodegeneration through the modulation of autophagy.
subject: Biyoloji
title: circSNHG14 Sequesters miR-137 to Modulate Synaptic Autophagy in an Alzheimer's Disease Mouse Model

text: Cells respond to environmental stress by rapidly reprogramming their translatome. While global translational attenuation via eIF2α phosphorylation is well-established, codon-specific regulatory mechanisms remain elusive. Employing ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) in human cells subjected to endoplasmic reticulum stress, we uncovered profound, codon-specific changes in translational efficiency. Ribosome occupancy decreased at codons decoded by tRNA species that become limited during stress but paradoxically increased at specific non-optimal codons, particularly within the 5' leaders of stress-response transcripts like ATF4. This effect is independent of general amino acid starvation and correlates with stress-induced modifications of tRNA anticodon loops. We propose a model where tRNA modifications and availability create a codon-biased translational landscape that selectively favors the synthesis of key regulatory proteins. This 'translational filtering' provides an additional, refined layer of control within the integrated stress response, ensuring a precise and hierarchical proteomic adaptation to cellular insults.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Dynamic Codon-Specific Translational Reprogramming Orchestrates the Integrated Stress Response

text: Intratumoral heterogeneity is a major obstacle in glioblastoma (GBM) therapy. To dissect the molecular underpinnings of therapeutic resistance, we performed concurrent single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and single-cell Assay for Transposase-Accessible Chromatin sequencing (scATAC-seq) on patient-derived GBM xenografts before and after treatment with temozolomide (TMZ). Our integrated analysis identified a rare, pre-existing subpopulation of cells characterized by a distinct transcriptomic signature enriched for neural progenitor markers, including high expression of the transcription factor SOX2. This SOX2-high state was coupled with a unique epigenomic landscape, featuring heightened chromatin accessibility at loci associated with DNA damage repair and developmental signaling pathways. Following TMZ therapy, this progenitor-like clone underwent significant clonal expansion, dominating the resistant tumor population. Functional perturbation via CRISPRi-mediated knockdown of SOX2 re-sensitized resistant GBM cells to TMZ, validating this cell state as a critical driver of therapeutic failure and a promising target for combinatorial therapies.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Integrated Single-Cell Transcriptomic and Epigenomic Analysis Reveals a SOX2-High Progenitor State Driving Temozolomide Resistance in Glioblastoma

text: The Fanconi anemia (FA) pathway is essential for the repair of DNA interstrand crosslinks (ICLs), the most cytotoxic form of DNA damage. A critical step in ICL repair is the nucleolytic incision of the DNA backbone flanking the lesion, executed by the SLX4-scaffolded endonucleases. Here, we report the 3.1 Å resolution cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of the human SLX4IP-SLX1-MUS81-EME1-XPF-ERCC1 (SLX4-nuclease) core complex bound to a synthetic ICL substrate. The structure reveals how the SLX4IP subunit acts as a molecular clamp, organizing the three distinct nucleases (SLX1, MUS81-EME1, XPF-ERCC1) around the DNA junction. The DNA is sharply bent at the ICL, allowing the MUS81-EME1 catalytic site to position optimally for 3' incision. The architecture provides a complete structural blueprint for coordinated nuclease activity during ICL processing and explains how mutations in these components lead to genomic instability and FA-like syndromes, offering a template for structure-based drug design.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Cryo-EM Structure of the FANC-SLX4 Nuclease Complex Reveals a Mechanism for Interstrand Crosslink Resolution

text: Mitochondrial proteostasis is intrinsically linked to cellular health and organismal aging. The mitochondrial unfolded protein response (UPRmt) is a key surveillance pathway that mitigates proteotoxic stress. We investigated the role of the ATP-dependent LonP1 protease in this process using *Caenorhabditis elegans*. We found that mild overexpression of LONP-1 is sufficient to extend lifespan and enhance resistance to mitochondrial stressors. This pro-longevity effect requires the canonical UPRmt transcription factor ATFS-1. Using quantitative mass spectrometry, we identified a specific subset of mitochondrial matrix proteins that are selectively degraded by LONP-1 under basal conditions, preventing their aggregation. Upon stress, LONP-1 activity also processes pre-ATFS-1, liberating the fragment required for nuclear translocation and transcriptional activation of cytoprotective genes. Our results establish LONP-1 as a dual-function regulator of mitochondrial homeostasis, acting both as a direct chaperone-like protease and a critical upstream activator of the UPRmt signaling cascade that determines longevity.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The Mitochondrial LonP1 Protease Governs UPRmt Activation and Lifespan Extension in C. elegans

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are key architects of chromatin structure and gene regulation. We explored the function of HOTTIP, a lncRNA transcribed from the 5' end of the HOXA cluster, during hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) differentiation. Using ChIRP-seq and RIP-seq, we demonstrate that HOTTIP directly binds to the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2). In multipotent progenitors, HOTTIP expression is high, and it physically tethers the EZH2 subunit of PRC2 to the promoters of key lymphoid-lineage commitment genes, such as IKAROS and GATA3, leading to their H3K27me3-mediated silencing and favoring myeloid differentiation. Genetic ablation of HOTTIP in HSCs results in a loss of PRC2 occupancy at these specific loci, de-repression of the lymphoid program, and a skewed differentiation potential. These findings unveil a mechanism whereby a lncRNA acts as a locus-specifying scaffold for a generic chromatin modifying complex, thereby dictating cell fate decisions during hematopoiesis.
subject: Biyoloji
title: The lncRNA HOTTIP Acts as a Molecular Scaffold to Guide PRC2-Mediated H3K27 Trimethylation in Hematopoietic Lineage Commitment

text: The mechanistic Target of Rapamycin Complex 1 (mTORC1) is a master regulator of cell growth that is activated at the lysosomal surface in response to amino acids. Here, we uncover a novel post-translational modification crosstalk mechanism that governs its spatial and temporal activation. We show that Raptor, an essential scaffolding component of mTORC1, is monoubiquitinated at lysine 108 by the E3 ligase RNF168. This ubiquitination event is contingent upon prior phosphorylation of Raptor at serine 863 by Akt. Using proximity-ligation assays and super-resolution microscopy, we demonstrate that ubiquitinated Raptor directly interacts with the lysosomal p18/LAMTOR1 subunit of the Ragulator complex, a critical step for mTORC1 translocation. A non-ubiquitinatable Raptor mutant fails to localize to lysosomes and exhibits blunted downstream signaling, even in the presence of ample amino acids. This phosphorylation-dependent ubiquitination switch provides a crucial checkpoint, integrating insulin/growth factor signaling with amino acid sensing pathways to ensure precise mTORC1 activation.
subject: Biyoloji
title: An RNF168-mediated Ubiquitination Switch on Raptor Regulates mTORC1 Lysosomal Localization and Activity

text: Influenza virus hijacks host pre-mRNAs using a 'cap-snatching' mechanism, where its PA endonuclease cleaves capped host transcripts to prime viral mRNA synthesis. We determined the 2.2 Å cryo-EM structure of the full influenza A polymerase heterotrimer in complex with a capped RNA substrate and a novel small-molecule inhibitor. The structure captures the PA endonuclease domain in a catalytically active state, revealing how two divalent manganese ions coordinate the RNA phosphodiester backbone for cleavage precisely 10-13 nucleotides downstream of the cap. Our inhibitor does not bind the active site but instead occupies an allosteric pocket at the interface of the PA and PB1 subunits. Inhibitor binding induces a conformational shift that displaces a critical α-helix, misaligning the catalytic residues and abrogating endonuclease activity without preventing substrate binding. This discovery of an allosteric regulatory site provides a new paradigm for designing anti-influenza therapeutics with a potentially higher barrier to resistance.
subject: Biyoloji
title: Structural Basis of Cap-Snatching by the Influenza PA Endonuclease and a Novel Allosteric Inhibition Mechanism

text: We investigate the statistical properties of a stochastic gravitational-wave background (SGWB) generated by a first-order cosmological phase transition. While standard analyses focus on the power spectrum, higher-order correlators, particularly the bispectrum, can reveal crucial information about the underlying microphysics. Using a semi-analytic model incorporating sound waves and magnetohydrodynamic turbulence in the primordial plasma, we compute the expected non-Gaussianity signature. Our results demonstrate that the bispectrum exhibits a characteristic frequency dependence sensitive to the bubble nucleation rate and wall velocity. We establish that next-generation interferometer networks, such as LISA and the Einstein Telescope, possess the requisite sensitivity to constrain these non-Gaussian parameters for electroweak-scale phase transitions. A detection would not only confirm the cosmological origin of an SGWB but also provide a novel probe of beyond-Standard Model physics, discriminating between different inflationary and alternative cosmology scenarios by characterizing deviations from a purely Gaussian stochastic process.
subject: Fizik
title: Probing Non-Gaussianities in the Stochastic Gravitational-Wave Background from Cosmological Phase Transitions

text: This study explores the application of the AdS/CFT correspondence to a non-conformal, strongly coupled gauge theory with a dynamically generated mass scale, analogous to Quantum Chromodynamics. We construct a holographic dual model using a deformed AdS5 spacetime with a soft-wall warp factor, effectively breaking conformal invariance. Within this framework, we compute the entanglement entropy for a spherical subregion by calculating the area of the minimal surface extending into the bulk, as prescribed by the Ryu-Takayanagi formula. Our analysis reveals a phase transition in the entanglement entropy, which we interpret as a holographic signature of quark confinement. The calculated Page time and the behavior of the mutual information between disjoint regions provide quantitative insights into the thermalization dynamics and information scrambling in the dual field theory. These results bridge the gap between holographic methods and the non-perturbative dynamics of confining gauge theories, offering a new geometric perspective on entanglement structure.
subject: Fizik
title: Holographic Duality and Entanglement Entropy in a Non-Conformal Strongly Coupled Gauge Theory

text: We present a theoretical framework and numerical simulation for the manipulation of Majorana zero modes (MZMs) localized in the vortices of a chiral p-wave superconductor, a promising platform for fault-tolerant topological quantum computation. By solving the Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations for a realistic tight-binding model on a two-dimensional lattice, we confirm the existence of robust, spatially isolated MZMs. We then simulate the adiabatic braiding of these vortices by manipulating an external magnetic field array. The resulting unitary transformation on the ground-state manifold is shown to be a non-trivial representation of the braid group, explicitly demonstrating the non-Abelian statistics of the anyonic quasiparticles. We analyze the effects of finite temperature, quasiparticle poisoning, and geometric imperfections on the fidelity of the braiding operation, establishing critical parameters required for realizing a topologically protected quantum gate with error rates below the quantum error correction threshold.
subject: Fizik
title: Majorana Zero Modes and Non-Abelian Braiding Statistics in a Chiral p-wave Superconducting Vortex

text: We report on the experimental observation and theoretical modeling of an emergent magnetoelectric effect in the pyrochlore iridate Ho2Ir2O7, a candidate material for a quantum spin ice state. Using neutron scattering and terahertz time-domain spectroscopy under applied magnetic fields, we map the low-energy spin excitation spectrum. Our data reveal a spin-flip excitation continuum consistent with the propagation of emergent magnetic monopoles. Furthermore, we observe a distinct electromagnon mode, an excitation of the emergent electromagnetic field, which exhibits a strong, non-reciprocal directional dichroism. This finding is a direct consequence of the broken inversion symmetry of the local '2-in, 2-out' ice rule configurations. We develop a gauge field theory model that successfully describes the coupling between the emergent magnetic monopoles and the electric component of the terahertz field, providing a quantitative explanation for the observed magnetoelectric dynamics and solidifying pyrochlore iridates as a platform for emergent quantum electrodynamics.
subject: Fizik
title: Emergent Magnetic Monopoles and Magnetoelectric Effect in Pyrochlore Iridate Spin Ice

text: This work experimentally investigates the breakdown of equilibrium statistical mechanics in a non-equilibrium steady state (NESS). We utilize optical tweezers to confine a colloidal particle in a harmonic potential while subjecting it to a non-conservative, time-correlated stochastic force, mimicking an active bath. By simultaneously measuring the particle's position fluctuations and its linear response to a weak external perturbation, we directly test the Fluctuation-Dissipation Theorem (FDT). Our high-precision measurements demonstrate a significant, frequency-dependent violation of the FDT, which we quantify using an effective temperature. We show that this effective temperature is not a scalar thermodynamic quantity but a mode-dependent parameter reflecting the non-thermal energy injection spectrum.
