The experimental results are in excellent agreement with a theoretical model based on a generalized Langevin equation, providing a rigorous quantitative framework for understanding entropy production and energy flow in mesoscopic systems far from thermal equilibrium.
subject: Fizik
title: Violation of the Fluctuation-Dissipation Theorem in an Actively Driven Colloidal System

text: We perform fully general-relativistic, magnetohydrodynamic simulations of binary neutron star mergers to investigate the properties of the ejecta and their role in the nucleosynthesis of heavy r-process elements. Our simulations utilize a temperature- and composition-dependent nuclear equation of state and incorporate neutrino transport via a leakage-based scheme. We analyze the distinct ejecta components: dynamical ejecta from tidal tails, post-merger accretion disk outflows, and secular winds. For each component, we track the thermodynamic histories and electron fraction (Ye) of Lagrangian fluid elements to perform detailed nuclear reaction network calculations. Our results indicate that the dynamically ejected material, characterized by its low Ye, robustly produces the third r-process peak (A ≈ 195). In contrast, the neutrino-irradiated disk winds contribute predominantly to the lighter r-process elements. By synthesizing these components, we generate a composite kilonova light curve and spectral evolution model whose features are directly linked to the merger dynamics and progenitor properties.
subject: Fizik
title: Relativistic Hydrodynamics of Neutron Star Mergers and the Nucleosynthesis of r-Process Elements

text: We demonstrate the emergence of robust quantum subspace confinement in a periodically driven (Floquet) many-body quantum system via the quantum Zeno effect. We consider a one-dimensional chain of interacting qubits under a strong, rapid, and spatially inhomogeneous drive protocol. The drive is designed such that projective measurements onto a specific local state are effectively implemented stroboscopically. This engineered dissipation fragments the Hilbert space into disconnected dynamical sectors. We show analytically and through time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (t-DMRG) simulations that this Zeno-like mechanism suppresses entanglement growth and prevents thermalization, confining the system's evolution within a 'scarred' subspace of low-complexity states. This phenomenon provides a powerful mechanism for controlling quantum dynamics and protecting quantum information in interacting systems, offering an alternative to many-body localization by leveraging engineered dissipation rather than intrinsic disorder to evade ergodicity and thermal death.
subject: Fizik
title: Quantum Zeno Effect and Subspace Confinement in a Periodically Driven Many-Body System

text: A precise, non-perturbative determination of the quark and gluon contributions to the nucleon's energy-momentum tensor (EMT) is critical for understanding hadronic structure. We present a first-principles calculation of the EMT form factors using lattice Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) with N_f=2+1 flavors of dynamical quarks at the physical point. The calculation is performed on several lattice ensembles with varying lattice spacings and volumes to control systematic uncertainties. We employ a novel implementation of the Wilson-flow gradient method to renormalize the EMT operators, which circumvents the power-divergent mixing issues inherent in standard lattice regularizations. Our results for the momentum and angular momentum fractions carried by quarks and gluons are compared with phenomenological determinations and experimental constraints. This work provides benchmark values for the gravitational form factors D(q^2) and J(q^2), offering stringent tests of the Standard Model and insights into the mass and spin decomposition of the proton.
subject: Fizik
title: Non-Perturbative Renormalization of the Energy-Momentum Tensor in Lattice QCD

text: We experimentally realize a topological phase transition in a photonic system by engineering a synthetic gauge field for photons. Our platform consists of a honeycomb lattice of coupled silicon ring resonators, where the hopping phase between adjacent sites is dynamically modulated, creating an effective magnetic field. This breaks time-reversal symmetry and leads to the formation of photonic Landau levels and topologically protected edge states, analogous to the quantum Hall effect. By tuning the modulation parameters, we drive the system through a topological phase transition, characterized by the closing and reopening of the bulk band gap at the Dirac points. We directly image the localized, chiral-propagating edge states using a near-field scanning optical microscope. The transition is unambiguously identified by measuring the Chern number of the photonic bands via a quantum transport simulation based on the experimental parameters. This work paves the way for robust, reconfigurable photonic devices based on topological principles.
subject: Fizik
title: Topological Phase Transition in a Photonic Graphene Analogue with Synthetic Gauge Fields

text: We investigate the gravitational lensing signatures of traversable wormholes described by various metric solutions in general relativity and modified gravity theories, focusing on observables that can distinguish them from Kerr black holes. By performing relativistic ray-tracing in these spacetimes, we compute the deflection angles, magnifications, and time delays for lensed light sources. For a generic class of asymptotically flat, spherically symmetric wormholes, we find that the photon sphere is always located outside the throat, leading to an infinite series of relativistic Einstein rings. The magnification relations and packing structure of these rings differ significantly from the Schwarzschild case. For rotating wormholes, the shadow's shape exhibits a distinct asymmetry and size dependence on the throat parameter, which deviates from the predictions of the no-hair theorem for black holes. We propose observational strategies for the Event Horizon Telescope and next-generation instruments to probe these unique signatures, potentially providing evidence for exotic compact objects.
subject: Fizik
title: Gravitational Lensing by Wormhole Spacetimes and Differentiating them from Black Holes

text: The topography of fitness landscapes dictates evolutionary trajectories, yet is often conceptualized as static. We investigate the dynamic properties of these landscapes under negative frequency-dependent selection (NFDS), a ubiquitous evolutionary force. Using a multi-locus, agent-based simulation, we model the interplay between stochastic epistatic interactions and NFDS. Our results demonstrate that NFDS fundamentally alters the genetic architecture by maintaining polymorphisms at interacting loci that would otherwise be purged by directional selection. This interaction generates a fluctuating landscape where fitness peaks shift in response to changing allele frequencies, preventing fixation at any single optimum. The ruggedness of the landscape, quantified by the correlation function of fitness values, becomes a dynamic variable rather than a fixed parameter. We conclude that the synergy between epistasis and frequency-dependence acts as a potent mechanism for preserving genetic variance and promoting long-term evolvability, challenging models that rely on static genotypic fitness values.
subject: Evrim
title: Stochastic Epistasis and the Architecture of Fitness Landscapes under Frequency-Dependent Selection

text: The evolutionary origins of methanogenesis, a key metabolic innovation, remain contentious. We performed a comprehensive phylogenomic analysis of 250 archaeal genomes to reconstruct the evolutionary history of the methyl-coenzyme M reductase (MCR) complex and associated pathways. Using species-tree/gene-tree reconciliation methods and Bayesian inference on concatenated orthologous gene sets, we uncovered extensive incongruence indicative of rampant horizontal gene transfer (HGT). While the core MCR subunits exhibit strong vertical inheritance, auxiliary genes involved in coenzyme biosynthesis and electron transport show a mosaic pattern, with multiple HGT events detected across Euryarchaeota phyla. Our findings support a model of metabolic chimerism, where a conserved ancestral core pathway was repeatedly augmented by laterally acquired modules. This network-like evolution, rather than simple cladogenesis, drove the diversification of methanogenic metabolisms, highlighting the critical role of HGT in shaping microbial innovation across geological timescales.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Reconstruction of Archaeal Methanogenesis Reveals Cryptic Horizontal Gene Transfer and Metabolic Chimerism

text: The conservation of the pentadactyl limb across tetrapods despite vast ecological diversification suggests profound developmental constraints. We investigated the role of pleiotropy within the gene regulatory networks (GRNs) governing limb patterning. Employing comparative transcriptomics across key developmental stages in *Xenopus laevis* and *Gallus gallus*, coupled with targeted CRISPR-Cas9 perturbations of key transcription factors like *Hoxd13* and *Shh*, we mapped the downstream consequences. Our results reveal that central nodes in the limb-patterning GRN possess extensive pleiotropic linkages to fundamental cellular processes, including apoptosis and cell cycle regulation. Perturbations resulted not in viable alternative morphologies but in catastrophic, system-wide failures. This high degree of pleiotropic constraint provides a mechanistic basis for the observed canalization of limb development, severely limiting the accessible morphospace and explaining the long-term stasis of the foundational pentadactyl body plan.
subject: Evrim
title: Pleiotropic Constraints and the Canalization of Developmental Pathways in Early Tetrapod Limb Morphogenesis

text: Antagonistic coevolution drives rapid molecular evolution in host defense and parasite offense genes. We examined this evolutionary arms race between the fruit fly *Drosophila melanogaster* and its endoparasitoid wasp *Leptopilina boulardi* through population genomics. By analyzing whole-genome sequences from multiple sympatric and allopatric populations, we identified signatures of recurrent selective sweeps. In *Drosophila*, loci under positive selection were significantly enriched for genes involved in the Toll and Imd innate immune pathways, particularly recognition and effector proteins. Conversely, in *L. boulardi*, rapidly evolving genes were predominantly small, secreted venom proteins hypothesized to be immunosuppressants. Analyses of nucleotide diversity (π) and dN/dS ratios confirm that these specific gene classes are coevolutionary hotspots. Our findings provide a high-resolution genomic portrait of reciprocal selection, demonstrating how ongoing conflict shapes genetic architecture at the host-parasite interface.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Signatures of Antagonistic Coevolution in a Host-Endoparasitoid System

text: The Cretaceous-Paleogene (K-Pg) mass extinction profoundly reshaped marine ecosystems, but the selectivity of extinction remains debated. We applied Bayesian phylogenetic comparative methods to a large dataset of planktonic foraminifera, quantifying multitrait morphospace occupation across the K-Pg boundary. By modeling trait evolution on a robust molecular-clock-calibrated phylogeny, we tested for correlations between morphological traits and extinction probability. Our results indicate strong selectivity against ornamental complexity and larger test sizes, while species with simpler, globular morphologies had significantly higher survival rates. An Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model best fit the macroevolutionary dynamics, suggesting a post-extinction radiation into a narrower range of the previously occupied morphospace, consistent with a shift in stabilizing selection pressures in the depauperate early Paleocene ocean. This analysis demonstrates that extinction was non-random and phylogenetically constrained, systematically pruning specific branches of the foraminiferal tree of life.
subject: Evrim
title: Cretaceous-Paleogene Extinction Selectivity: A Bayesian Phylogenetic Comparative Analysis of Foraminiferal Morphospace

text: Female mate choice is often presumed to be driven by direct benefits or 'good genes'. We propose an alternative mechanism: the transmission of environmentally induced epigenetic information via paternal germlines. We developed a model system in the decorated cricket (*Gryllodes sigillatus*), where males provide a nuptial gift. Males were raised on nutrient-rich or nutrient-poor diets, and we analyzed sperm DNA methylation profiles using whole-genome bisulfite sequencing. We found significant diet-dependent differential methylation regions (DMRs) in genes associated with metabolic regulation and stress response. Critically, females provided with a choice overwhelmingly preferred males from the nutrient-rich treatment, and their offspring exhibited higher fitness, a benefit not explainable by gift size alone. This suggests that females may be selecting mates based on cues that honestly signal a favorable paternal epigenetic state, adding a new dimension of transgenerational inheritance to the study of sexual selection.
subject: Evrim
title: The Role of Epigenetic Paternal Effects in the Evolution of Nuptial Gifting and Female Mate Choice

text: The adaptation of human populations to high-altitude environments is a classic example of recent, strong positive selection. We investigated the role of archaic introgression in this process by analyzing high-coverage whole-genome sequences from Tibetan and Han Chinese populations. Using haplotype-based statistics, we confirmed that a critical allele of the *EPAS1* gene, which modulates the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) pathway, was introduced into the modern human gene pool from Denisovan-like hominins. Our analysis reveals that this introgressed haplotype is exceptionally long, indicating a recent and powerful selective sweep. Furthermore, functional genomic assays suggest the archaic variant provides a more buffered physiological response to hypoxia, preventing the maladaptive erythrocytosis seen in lowlanders. This case provides a compelling example of adaptive introgression, where archaic admixture provided pre-adapted genetic variation that facilitated rapid colonization of a novel, challenging environment.
subject: Evrim
title: Archaic Introgression and the Adaptive Evolution of the High-Altitude Hypoxia Response in Tibetan Populations

text: Parallel evolution offers a powerful framework for dissecting the predictability of adaptation. Marine populations of threespine stickleback have repeatedly colonized freshwater habitats, evolving similar phenotypes. We investigated the genomic basis of this parallelism by sequencing multiple marine-freshwater population pairs from distinct drainages. Using a combination of FST outlier analysis and quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping for osmoregulatory traits, we identified numerous genomic regions under divergent selection. While a small number of large-effect loci, such as *Eda* and *Atp1a1*, were recurrently selected across all pairs, the majority of the genomic architecture was lineage-specific. This indicates that parallel phenotypic outcomes were achieved through a mosaic of shared and unique genetic solutions. Our findings suggest that while adaptation may draw upon shared ancestral standing genetic variation for some key traits, the overall genomic response to a common selective pressure is highly contingent on the specific genetic background of the founding population.
subject: Evrim
title: Genomic Scaffolding of Parallel Adaptation to Salinity Gradients in Threespine Stickleback (*Gasterosteus aculeatus*)

text: A central problem in abiogenesis is the transition from a disorganized prebiotic soup to functionally integrated protocells. We explored the role of compartmentalization in the evolution of RNA-based autocatalytic networks. Using in-vitro compartmentalization systems with lipid vesicles, we encapsulated a diverse pool of random-sequence ribozymes. We demonstrate that stochastic encapsulation creates micro-environments with varied catalytic compositions. Vesicles containing more efficient or specific autocatalytic sets grew faster by sequestering substrates and products, leading to a form of protocellular-level selection. Over iterative cycles of growth and division, we observed a marked increase in the average catalytic efficiency and specificity of the encapsulated ribozyme populations compared to bulk-solution controls. This work provides empirical support for the hypothesis that compartmentalization was a critical, emergent step that imposed selection on prebiotic chemical systems, facilitating the evolutionary path toward cellular complexity.
subject: Evrim
title: Protocellular Compartmentalization and the Emergence of Catalytic Specificity in Prebiotic Autocatalytic Networks

text: Whole-genome duplications (WGDs) are major catalysts of evolutionary innovation. We analyzed the fate of duplicate genes (ohnologs) stemming from the teleost-specific WGD (TS-WGD) by comparing the genomes and multi-tissue transcriptomes of zebrafish (*Danio rerio*) and the basal actinopterygian spotted gar (*Lepisosteus oculatus*), which diverged before the event. Using a synteny-based framework to identify ohnolog pairs, we found that approximately 80% have been retained. By quantifying expression divergence, we determined that subfunctionalization, partitioned by tissue-specific expression, is the dominant fate. However, a significant subset (~12%) of ohnologs exhibit signatures of neofunctionalization, characterized by novel expression domains and accelerated rates of protein sequence evolution (elevated dN/dS). These neofunctionalized genes are enriched in functions related to neural development and immunity, suggesting the TS-WGD was pivotal in the evolutionary diversification of these complex systems in teleost fishes.
subject: Evrim
title: Subfunctionalization and Neofunctionalization Dynamics Following Whole-Genome Duplication in Basal Actinopterygii

text: We investigate the dynamics of quantum information in periodically driven, non-Hermitian topological systems. By engineering a two-dimensional lattice model with gain and loss, subjected to a time-periodic drive, we demonstrate the emergence of anomalous Floquet topological phases absent in Hermitian counterparts. Our analysis reveals the existence of topologically protected chiral edge modes that are robust against both Hermitian perturbations and non-Hermitian dissipation. A key finding is the stabilization of these modes at exceptional points in the Floquet quasienergy spectrum, leading to a non-Hermitian skin effect that localizes the majority of bulk states to the boundary. We show numerically that a quantum state encoded in these edge modes exhibits significantly suppressed decoherence rates compared to bulk states, providing a novel platform for topologically protected quantum state transfer. The proposed model is experimentally feasible in coupled photonic waveguide arrays or ultracold atomic systems with controlled dissipation, opening new avenues for robust quantum technologies.
subject: Kuantum
title: Topological Protection of Coherent States in Non-Hermitian Floquet Insulators

text: The transition from an ergodic thermal phase to a many-body localized (MBL) phase represents a fundamental breakdown of statistical mechanics in isolated quantum systems. We move beyond conventional diagnostics like entanglement entropy to probe this transition using entanglement spectroscopy. By applying large-scale density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) simulations to the disordered one-dimensional Heisenberg model, we analyze the full spectrum of the reduced density matrix. Our results reveal a qualitative change in the entanglement spectrum structure at the MBL transition: in the ergodic phase, it follows predictions from the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH) with a universal low-lying structure, while in the MBL phase, it exhibits a Poissonian level-spacing distribution and a distinct lack of universal form. The Schmidt gap, separating low-lying eigenvalues, closes at the transition point, serving as a more precise order parameter than entanglement entropy scaling. This spectroscopic approach provides a finer-grained characterization of the MBL transition and deepens our understanding of emergent integrability in disordered quantum matter.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Many-Body Localization Transitions with Entanglement Spectroscopy in Disordered Spin Chains

text: Lattice gauge theories are fundamental to modern physics, yet their simulation on quantum devices remains challenging. Here, we report the quantum simulation of a U(1) lattice gauge theory with emergent dynamical gauge fields in a two-dimensional programmable Rydberg atom array. By exploiting the Rydberg blockade mechanism to enforce local constraints, we engineer a Hamiltonian whose low-energy sector maps directly onto the gauge theory. Through precise temporal control of laser parameters, we observe the real-time evolution of particle-antiparticle pairs and the propagation of electric fields. Notably, our system exhibits Hilbert space fragmentation into dynamically disconnected sectors, leading to the appearance of fracton-like excitations with restricted mobility. These immobile and sub-dimensionally propagating quasiparticles are directly imaged by resolving the atomic positions. Our work establishes Rydberg atom arrays as a powerful platform for exploring constrained dynamics and non-ergodicity in models with connections to high-energy physics and quantum gravity.
subject: Kuantum
title: Dynamical Gauge Fields and Fracton-like Excitations in a Programmable Rydberg Atom Array

text: Lattice Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) at finite baryon density is plagued by the infamous sign problem, hindering first-principles calculations of the nuclear matter equation of state. We introduce a novel computational approach based on the Multiscale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz (MERA), a tensor network that provides a discrete realization of the holographic AdS/CFT correspondence. By constructing a MERA state that variationally approximates the ground state of a QCD-like theory, we bypass the sign problem entirely. The geometry of the tensor network itself serves as an emergent holographic dimension, where the entanglement structure of the boundary state encodes the bulk geometry. Our model successfully captures key non-perturbative features, including chiral symmetry breaking and confinement. We present a phase diagram at finite chemical potential, identifying a first-order phase transition line and a critical endpoint, whose location is consistent with experimental expectations. This holographic tensor network framework offers a computationally tractable method for probing strongly-coupled gauge theories in previously inaccessible regimes.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement Renormalization for Quantum Chromodynamics at Finite Baryon Density

text: Majorana zero modes (MZMs), exotic quasiparticles that are their own antiparticles, hold immense promise for fault-tolerant topological quantum computing. We propose and theoretically validate a novel platform for realizing MZMs using a zigzag graphene nanoribbon proximitized by a high-temperature d-wave superconductor. Solving the Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations self-consistently, we demonstrate the emergence of a robust topological superconducting phase hosting spatially separated MZMs at the nanoribbon ends. The spin-valley locking in graphene, combined with the anisotropic superconducting gap, eliminates the need for external magnetic fields and fine-tuning of chemical potential. We simulate an explicit braiding protocol by electrostatically moving the MZMs in a T-junction geometry. By calculating the non-Abelian Berry phase accumulated during the exchange, we confirm the B₂ = -iσ_y transformation characteristic of Majorana braiding statistics. This graphene-based architecture presents a promising route towards scalable and electrically controllable non-Abelian anyon platforms for topological quantum computation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Braiding Statistics of Majorana Zero Modes in a Hybrid Superconductor-Graphene Nanoribbon Device

text: The Leggett-Garg inequality (LGI) provides a temporal analogue to Bell's theorem for testing macroscopic realism and non-invasiveness of measurements. We report a robust experimental violation of the LGI using a macroscopic quantum system composed of a superconducting transmon qutrit dispersively coupled to a high-Q microwave cavity. We prepare a macroscopic superposition of coherent states (a 'cat state') within the cavity, where the state's phase is entangled with the qutrit's state. By performing sequential, high-fidelity projective measurements on the qutrit, we implement a protocol that tests the LGI for a three-time correlation function. Crucially, we utilize a quasi-ideal negative result measurement protocol to minimize back-action, a key loophole in previous experiments. Our results show a violation of the LGI by more than 12 standard deviations, providing strong evidence against the classical worldview of macroscopic realism even in large, engineered quantum systems. This work solidifies the quantum nature of macroscopic fields and demonstrates advanced coherent control.
subject: Kuantum
title: Violation of Leggett-Garg Inequalities using Macroscopic Superpositions in a Superconducting Qutrit-Cavity System

text: Surpassing the standard quantum limit (SQL) of measurement precision is a central goal of quantum metrology. We propose and analyze a scheme for achieving Heisenberg-limited magnetometry using squeezed states of magnons in a cavity-coupled ferrimagnetic sphere, such as yttrium iron garnet (YIG). By applying a strong parametric drive to the YIG sphere, we induce a two-mode squeezing interaction between two distinct magnon modes. This process generates a quantum-correlated state exhibiting reduced quantum fluctuations in a specific field quadrature, well below the vacuum noise level. We show that the phase-sensitive response of this squeezed magnonic state to an external magnetic field enables a measurement sensitivity that scales as 1/N, where N is the number of magnons, thus approaching the fundamental Heisenberg limit. Our theoretical model, including realistic dissipation channels, predicts a significant enhancement over the SQL for experimentally achievable parameters in cavity magnonic systems, paving the way for ultra-sensitive quantum sensors.
subject: Kuantum
title: Quantum-Enhanced Metrology with Squeezed Magnons in a Ferrimagnetic Insulator

text: The puzzle of how a classical spacetime emerges from a purely quantum-mechanical system is a central issue in quantum gravity. We investigate a pre-geometric matrix model, specifically the Ikeda-Kawai-Nishimura (IKKT) model, which has no a priori notion of space or time. By performing large-scale numerical simulations, we analyze the entanglement structure of the system's ground state. We define subsystems based on a partitioning of the matrix degrees of freedom and compute the entanglement entropy between them. Our central finding is that the entanglement structure encodes a consistent emergent geometry. We show that the mutual information between distant subsystems decays in a manner consistent with a power-law, defining an effective distance. Furthermore, the entanglement entropy of a region satisfies an area law with respect to this emergent geometry, providing a discrete analogue of the Ryu-Takayanagi formula from holography. This work provides compelling evidence that spacetime geometry is not fundamental, but rather an emergent property of quantum entanglement.
subject: Kuantum
title: Emergence of Spacetime from Entanglement in a Pre-geometric Matrix Model

text: Weyl semimetals are topological phases of matter hosting chiral, massless quasiparticles. While typically found in materials with broken time-reversal (TR) or inversion symmetry, we report the experimental realization of a type-II Weyl phase in a TR-symmetric photonic crystal operating at microwave frequencies. Our design, based on a metacrystal of coupled dielectric resonators, exhibits accidental degeneracies between TE and TM-like bands, which form pairs of Weyl points of opposite chirality. Using near-field scanning microscopy and angle-resolved transmission spectroscopy, we directly map the bulk photonic dispersion, resolving the tilted conical structure of the Weyl cones. We provide definitive evidence of the associated topological surface states—photonic Fermi arcs—which connect the projected Weyl points on the surface Brillouin zone. Furthermore, by introducing a synthetic gauge field via a spatial gradient in the crystal's parameters, we observe a frequency shift analogous to the chiral anomaly, demonstrating a non-conservation of chiral charge.
subject: Kuantum
title: Observation of Chiral Anomaly and Weyl Fermions in a Time-Reversal-Symmetric Photonic Crystal

text: Decoherence, the process by which quantum systems lose their coherence to an environment, is typically viewed as a monotonic decay. We challenge this view by demonstrating that decoherence can manifest as a sharp dissipative quantum phase transition (QPT). We study a model of a central spin ensemble coupled to a non-Markovian bosonic reservoir with a tunable spectral density. By employing a combination of Keldysh field theory and the numerical matrix product state methods, we map the system's phase diagram as a function of coupling strength and an environmental control parameter. We identify a critical point where the spectral gap of the system's Liouvillian superoperator closes, signaling a second-order QPT. This transition separates a phase of rapid, exponential decoherence from a phase where a protected decoherence-free subspace emerges due to a quantum Zeno-like effect induced by the structured environment. This work reframes decoherence and suggests novel strategies for quantum error protection through environment engineering.
subject: Kuantum
title: Decoherence as a Quantum Phase Transition in a Calibrated Open Quantum System

text: We introduce Geodesic Convolutional Networks (GCNs), a novel framework for deep learning on non-Euclidean data structured as Riemannian manifolds. Unlike traditional Graph Neural Networks operating in Euclidean space, GCNs leverage intrinsic geometric properties by defining convolutions along geodesic paths. Our approach employs a localized parallel transport mechanism to aggregate feature information, ensuring isometry invariance and respecting the underlying manifold curvature. We formulate a learnable Ricci curvature-based pooling operator that adaptively coarsens the manifold, enabling hierarchical representation learning. We demonstrate the efficacy of GCNs on tasks involving hyperbolic embeddings for complex networks and shape analysis on 3D meshes. By explicitly modeling manifold geometry, our model significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in graph classification and node embedding tasks where latent hierarchical structures are prevalent. The framework provides a principled extension of convolutional architectures to a broader class of geometric data, opening new avenues for representation learning in computational biology and computer vision.
subject: AI
title: Geodesic Convolutional Networks on Riemannian Manifolds for Hierarchical Data Representation

text: Estimating individual treatment effects (ITEs) from observational data is a fundamental challenge in causal inference, often confounded by high-dimensional covariates. We propose Adversarial Causal Networks (ACNs), a novel framework that leverages generative adversarial training to learn counterfactual distributions. The ACN consists of a generator that synthesizes potential outcomes under treatment and control, and a discriminator that enforces covariate balance between factual and counterfactual populations, thereby mitigating selection bias. By incorporating principles from structural causal models (SCMs) and do-calculus, our model architecture explicitly respects causal identifiability assumptions. We introduce a novel adversarial balancing loss function that minimizes integral probability metrics between treatment groups in a learned representation space. Empirical results on synthetic and real-world benchmark datasets demonstrate that ACNs achieve state-of-the-art performance in ITE estimation, providing more robust and accurate counterfactual predictions than existing methods based on propensity score matching or domain adaptation.
subject: AI
title: Counterfactual Estimation in High-Dimensional Observational Data using Adversarial Causal Networks

text: Privacy preservation in federated learning (FL) remains a critical challenge, susceptible to inference attacks on aggregated model updates. We introduce Hyb-FL, a hybrid privacy-preserving framework that synergistically combines fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) with calibrated differential privacy (DP). In our protocol, clients encrypt their local model gradients using an FHE scheme, enabling secure aggregation by the central server without decryption. Subsequently, a calibrated Gaussian noise mechanism is applied to the aggregated, encrypted update to satisfy a pre-defined (ε, δ)-differential privacy budget before decryption and model application. This dual-layered approach provides cryptographic security against server-side threats while offering formal privacy guarantees against information leakage from the final model. We analyze the trade-off between privacy budget, encryption overhead, and model convergence. Experiments on standard FL benchmarks demonstrate that Hyb-FL achieves robust privacy preservation with a minimal impact on model utility compared to DP-only or encryption-only baselines.
subject: AI
title: Hyb-FL: A Hybrid Framework for Robust Federated Learning via Homomorphic Encryption and Calibrated Differential Privacy

text: The convergence of continual and few-shot learning paradigms presents a significant challenge: adapting to novel tasks with minimal data while mitigating catastrophic forgetting of prior knowledge. We propose Continual Meta-Learning with Orthogonal Gradient Projection (CMOGP), a novel algorithm that explicitly decouples task-specific adaptation from shared knowledge preservation. Our approach maintains a set of task-agnostic meta-parameters and learns task-specific modulations. During adaptation to a new few-shot task, we constrain the gradient update to be orthogonal to the subspace spanned by the gradients of previously learned tasks, thereby preventing destructive interference. This is achieved via a computationally efficient projection mechanism integrated into a MAML-like episodic training framework. We demonstrate theoretically and empirically on complex benchmarks like Meta-Continual-Omniglot and Meta-Continual-CIFAR100 that CMOGP significantly reduces forgetting and improves forward transfer, setting a new state-of-the-art in few-shot continual learning.
subject: AI
title: Continual Meta-Learning with Orthogonal Gradient Projection for Few-Shot Task Adaptation

text: The exponential growth in parameters of large-scale language models (LLMs) poses significant computational and memory challenges. Drawing inspiration from tensor networks in quantum many-body physics, we introduce the Tensor-Train Transformer (T3), a novel architecture that dramatically improves parameter efficiency. The T3 model replaces the dense weight matrices in the multi-head attention and feed-forward layers with tensor train decompositions. This factorization reduces the parameter complexity from quadratic to linear in the embedding dimension, enabling the construction of deeper and wider models under a fixed parameter budget. We demonstrate that the inherent structure of tensor trains, characterized by low entanglement entropy, effectively captures the low-rank nature of linguistic correlations. On standard language modeling benchmarks, our T3 model achieves competitive perplexity scores with models like BERT and GPT-3 but with up to 80% fewer parameters, facilitating deployment on resource-constrained hardware.
subject: AI
title: Tensor-Train Transformers: A Quantum-Inspired Architecture for Parameter-Efficient Language Modeling

text: Accurate uncertainty quantification is critical for deploying neural networks in high-stakes applications. Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs) offer a principled framework, yet robustly approximating the high-dimensional posterior distribution over weights remains challenging. We propose Deterministic-Stochastic Variational Inference (DSVI), a novel method to improve posterior approximations. DSVI partitions the network weights into deterministic and stochastic sets. The deterministic weights, comprising the bulk of the parameters, are optimized via maximum a posteriori estimation, while a stochastic subset, strategically chosen based on Fisher information, is modeled with a rich, structured variational distribution (e.g., a normalizing flow). This hybrid approach mitigates the posterior collapse phenomenon common in mean-field VI and better captures complex dependencies. We demonstrate that DSVI yields superior calibration and out-of-distribution detection on regression and image classification tasks, outperforming standard VI techniques while maintaining computational tractability and providing more reliable epistemic uncertainty estimates.
subject: AI
title: Structured Posterior Approximation for Bayesian Neural Networks with Deterministic-Stochastic Variational Inference

text: Learning meaningful representations from vast streams of unlabeled multimodal sensor data is a pivotal problem in autonomous systems. We present a self-supervised framework, Cross-Modal Spatiotemporal Alignment (CMSA), designed to learn powerful representations by leveraging the natural co-occurrence of different data modalities, such as video, LiDAR, and IMU data. Our approach employs a multi-branch neural network with spatiotemporal attention mechanisms to encode each modality. We introduce a novel cross-modal contrastive loss, a variant of InfoNCE, that forces the representations of temporally aligned, cross-modal data snippets to be closer in the embedding space than misaligned or modality-mismatched snippets. This implicitly learns invariant features crucial for scene understanding. Through extensive experiments on autonomous driving datasets, we show that features learned via CMSA, when fine-tuned on downstream tasks like object detection and semantic segmentation, significantly outperform representations learned from single modalities or simpler fusion techniques, establishing a new baseline for self-supervised multimodal learning.
subject: AI
title: Cross-Modal Contrastive Learning for Spatiotemporal Representation of Unlabeled Sensor Data

text: The opacity of deep reinforcement learning (RL) policies hinders their application in safety-critical domains. To address this, we introduce the Neuro-Symbolic Policy Extraction (NSPE) framework, which integrates deep RL with differentiable probabilistic logic programming. An agent is initially trained using a standard deep RL algorithm (e.g., PPO). Concurrently, a symbolic module learns a set of first-order logic rules that approximate the neural policy's behavior. We employ a differentiable semantic loss function that minimizes the divergence between the neural policy's action distribution and the logical program's probabilistic inferences, enabling end-to-end training. The extracted symbolic policy is inherently interpretable and amenable to formal verification methods for proving safety and liveness properties. We demonstrate our approach in environments requiring complex reasoning and safety constraints, showing that NSPE agents not only achieve competitive rewards but also provide verifiable and explainable decision-making processes, bridging the gap between learning and reasoning.
subject: AI
title: Verifiable Reinforcement Learning through Differentiable Logic and Neuro-Symbolic Policy Extraction

text: The automated design of novel molecules with specific desired properties is a cornerstone of modern drug discovery. We frame this challenge as a structured object generation problem and propose the use of Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets). Unlike traditional generative models or reinforcement learning agents that aim to find a single optimal solution, GFlowNets learn a stochastic policy to generate a diverse set of candidate molecular graphs with a probability proportional to a reward function. This reward can be a multi-objective function encoding desired properties like binding affinity, synthesizability, and low toxicity. Our model constructs molecules sequentially by adding atoms and bonds, guided by a flow-matching objective that ensures the policy samples from the target distribution. Empirical results show that our GFlowNet approach discovers a more diverse and high-quality set of novel molecules compared to state-of-the-art MCMC, RL, and GAN-based methods, effectively navigating the vast chemical space.
subject: AI
title: Generative Flow Networks for De Novo Molecular Design with Multi-Objective Property Optimization

text: Vision Transformers (ViTs) have achieved remarkable success but their large size and quadratic complexity in self-attention hinder deployment. We propose Tensor-Factored Pruning (TFP), a structured pruning methodology that co-optimizes for sparsity and low-rank structure within ViT components. TFP represents the weight matrices of both the multi-head self-attention and feed-forward network layers using a low-rank tensor factorization. A learnable importance score is assigned to each rank-1 component, and an L0-norm penalty is applied during training to encourage sparsity at the rank level. This approach unifies weight pruning and low-rank approximation, allowing for the automatic determination of the optimal rank for each layer based on a global compression budget. Our method induces structured sparsity that is amenable to hardware acceleration. On ImageNet, TFP achieves a 4x reduction in model parameters and a 2.5x reduction in FLOPs for DeiT models with less than a 0.5% drop in top-1 accuracy, surpassing existing unstructured and structured pruning techniques.
subject: AI
title: Tensor-Factored Pruning: A Unified Framework for Compressing Vision Transformers via Low-Rank Approximation

text: We introduce a novel quantum error-correcting code, the Chiral Fibonacci Surface Code (CFSC), designed to leverage the computational power of non-Abelian anyons for fault-tolerant quantum computation. This architecture hybridizes the error resilience of the toric code with the rich statistics of Fibonacci anyons. Through extensive numerical simulations employing a density matrix formalism with both depolarizing and non-Markovian noise channels, we demonstrate a significantly higher error threshold compared to conventional surface codes. We calculate the logical error rate as a function of the physical error rate, showing a favorable scaling behavior. The braiding of defects, which correspond to Fibonacci anyons, is shown to implement a universal set of quantum gates protected by the topological order of the system. Our results suggest that the CFSC provides a promising pathway towards scalable topological quantum computing by directly embedding non-Clifford gates within the error-correction fabric, thus reducing the resource overhead associated with magic state distillation.
subject: Kuantum
title: Non-Abelian Anyonic Statistics in a Braided Chiral Fibonacci Surface Code

text: The stability of the many-body localized (MBL) phase against perturbations remains a central question in non-equilibrium quantum statistical mechanics. We investigate the fate of MBL in a one-dimensional disordered spin chain subject to quasiperiodic, power-law decaying long-range interactions. Using large-scale exact diagonalization and time-dependent density matrix renormalization group (t-DMRG) simulations, we map out the system's phase diagram. Our analysis, based on level-spacing statistics, participation entropy, and the time evolution of entanglement entropy, reveals a sharp transition from an MBL phase to an ergodic, thermalized phase. Contrary to the purely short-range case, the MBL phase is destabilized even for slowly decaying interactions. We identify a critical exponent for the interaction decay beyond which localization persists. This work elucidates the delicate interplay between disorder, quasiperiodicity, and interaction range, providing critical constraints on the robustness of MBL in physically realizable quantum systems, such as trapped ions or Rydberg atoms.
subject: Kuantum
title: Breakdown of Many-Body Localization via Quasiperiodic Long-Range Interactions

text: We explore the black hole information paradox within the framework of the AdS/CFT correspondence by analyzing a soluble model of two-dimensional Jackiw-Teitelboim (JT) gravity coupled to a conformal field theory (CFT). By performing a semiclassical path integral calculation, we compute the entanglement entropy of the Hawking radiation. We demonstrate that the inclusion of replica wormhole geometries, which are absent in the naive gravity path integral, leads to the emergence of a 'quantum extremal surface' and an associated 'island' in the black hole interior. The contribution of this island resolves the paradox by yielding a Page curve for the radiation entropy that is consistent with unitary evolution. Our analysis explicitly constructs the entanglement wedge of the radiation, showing it extends into the black hole interior at late times, thereby providing a concrete realization of the ER=EPR conjecture and the principle of entanglement wedge reconstruction for retrieving information from an evaporated black hole.
subject: Kuantum
title: Holographic Entanglement and Island Formation in a 2D Jackiw-Teitelboim Gravity Model

text: Frequency crowding and parasitic ZZ interactions present major obstacles to scaling superconducting quantum processors. We present the design and experimental characterization of a novel coupling architecture based on a flux-tunable coaxial resonator. This coupler mediates the interaction between two transmon qubits and provides an on/off ratio exceeding 10^3, enabling fast, high-fidelity two-qubit CZ gates while effectively nullifying static ZZ crosstalk in the idle state. We perform quantum process tomography and randomized benchmarking, achieving an average gate fidelity of 99.78% with a gate time of 38 ns. Furthermore, the coupler's wide tunability allows for the selective mitigation of spurious frequency collisions with higher transmon levels and other circuit modes. This architecture provides a robust and scalable solution for constructing large-scale, low-crosstalk quantum circuits, paving the way for high-performance quantum simulations and algorithms that demand high-coherence and precise gate control across the entire processor.
subject: Kuantum
title: Crosstalk Mitigation in a Multi-Qubit Processor using a Flux-Tunable Coaxial Resonator Coupler

text: We propose and theoretically analyze a quantum metrology protocol for magnetic field gradiometry that approaches the Heisenberg limit. The scheme utilizes entangled multi-mode N00N states generated in a network of coupled superconducting microwave cavities. A key innovation is an in-situ adaptive feedback loop, guided by a Bayesian estimation algorithm, which dynamically adjusts the phase accumulation time to maximize the quantum Fisher information in the presence of realistic noise sources, including photon loss and dephasing. We derive the quantum Cramér-Rao bound for our protocol and demonstrate, through Monte Carlo simulations, a scaling of sensitivity approaching 1/N, where N is the total number of photons, a significant improvement over the standard quantum limit of 1/√N. This work provides a practical blueprint for developing quantum-enhanced sensors capable of surpassing classical devices in applications requiring ultra-high spatial and temporal resolution, such as biomedical imaging and materials science.
subject: Kuantum
title: Heisenberg-Limited Magnetometry using Multi-Mode N00N States and Adaptive Bayesian Estimation

text: We predict a new class of three-dimensional higher-order topological insulators (HOTIs) which we term 'axionic hinge insulators'. Using a combination of ab-initio density functional theory calculations and low-energy effective k·p models, we identify candidate materials in the bismuth halide family. These materials are characterized by a gapped bulk and gapped surfaces, but host protected one-dimensional chiral modes localized on the hinges where surfaces intersect. The topological protection arises from the interplay between time-reversal symmetry and a C4 crystalline rotation symmetry. A defining characteristic of this phase is a quantized magnetoelectric response, where the hinge states act as chiral channels for an axionic field. We propose an experimental signature based on a non-local transport measurement that can uniquely identify the contribution of these one-dimensional hinge states, distinguishing them from trivial edge states or surface conductivity, thus opening a new avenue in topological quantum matter.
subject: Kuantum
title: Axionic Hinge Insulators: A Higher-Order Topological Phase Protected by Crystalline Symmetries

text: We investigate the performance of a quantum Otto engine whose working medium is a disordered quantum spin chain that can be tuned across the many-body localization (MBL) to ergodic transition. By numerically solving the system's dynamics using Floquet theory and quantum master equations, we analyze the engine's power output and efficiency. Our results reveal a significant performance enhancement when the engine operates near the critical point of the MBL transition. Specifically, we demonstrate that the suppressed thermalization on the MBL side of the transition minimizes dissipative losses during the quasi-adiabatic strokes, while the proximity to the ergodic phase allows for efficient heat exchange with the thermal baths during the isochoric strokes. This finding connects the abstract concept of ergodicity breaking to a tangible thermodynamic advantage and suggests a novel design principle for quantum thermal machines leveraging non-equilibrium phase transitions to outperform their conventional counterparts.
subject: Kuantum
title: Thermodynamic Enhancement in a Quantum Otto Cycle at the Many-Body Localization Transition

text: We analyze quantum particle production in a (2+1)-dimensional rotating fluid spacetime, which serves as a condensed matter analogue for a Kerr black hole. By calculating the Bogoliubov coefficients that relate the in- and out-vaccum states for a massless scalar field (phonons), we investigate the system's stability against superradiance. We find that for a specific range of rotational parameters, the system exhibits a superradiant instability, leading to an exponential growth of phonon modes and the spontaneous emission of a non-thermal particle flux. Our analysis goes beyond standard treatments by incorporating a realistic equation of state for a Bose-Einstein condensate, revealing a modification of the ergoregion and a corresponding shift in the instability threshold. These results provide quantitative predictions for verifying rotational superradiance and the associated particle creation phenomena in future tabletop experiments using swirling Bose-Einstein condensates, offering an accessible platform to probe fundamental aspects of quantum field theory in curved spacetime.
subject: Kuantum
title: Scalar Particle Production from a Superradiantly Unstable Kerr-like Acoustic Metric

text: We report the experimental realization of a circuit quantum electrodynamics (QED) system operating in the deep strong coupling (DSC) regime, where the coupling strength becomes comparable to the transition frequencies of the constituents. By coupling a fluxonium qubit to a 3D lumped-element resonator, we achieve a normalized coupling strength g/ω of 0.85. Spectroscopic measurements reveal a highly non-trivial energy-level structure, characterized by the breakdown of the rotating-wave approximation and the significant hybridization of qubit and cavity states. We observe clear signatures of a parity-protected ground state, where the system is dressed by virtual photons. By performing two-tone spectroscopy, we directly probe transitions between these dressed states, confirming predictions of the full quantum Rabi model. This platform enables the exploration of novel phenomena in quantum optics and offers a promising avenue for quantum simulations of light-matter systems and the development of robust, passively-protected quantum information schemes.
subject: Kuantum
title: Probing Ground-State Electrodynamics in the Deep Strong Coupling Regime of Cavity QED

text: We propose and analyze a protocol for a robust, loophole-free experimental test of quantum contextuality based on the Kochen-Specker theorem. Our system consists of a single nitrogen-vacancy (NV) center in diamond, where the electron spin and a strongly coupled ¹³C nuclear spin collectively form a qutrit. We identify a set of 13 measurement projectors, forming a Peres-Mermin square, that can be implemented with high fidelity using precisely timed microwave and radio-frequency control pulses. The protocol is designed to be robust against major experimental imperfections, including finite measurement fidelity and operational errors. By employing a sequential measurement scheme with non-destructive projective readouts, our protocol simultaneously closes the compatibility and detection loopholes that have affected previous tests. We perform a detailed theoretical analysis, including decoherence effects, showing that a statistically significant violation of the non-contextual bound is achievable with current technology, thereby placing stringent constraints on the ontology of quantum mechanics.
subject: Kuantum
title: A Loophole-Free Test of Kochen-Specker Contextuality using a Nitrogen-Vacancy Center Qutrit

text: The role of cryptic genetic variation (CGV) in macroevolutionary processes remains a subject of intense theoretical debate. We investigated the hypothesis that environmental shifts can trigger the decanalization of CGV, facilitating rapid phenotypic diversification and reproductive isolation. Using experimental evolution in Drosophila melanogaster populations subjected to novel thermal and dietary stressors, we observed a dramatic increase in phenotypic variance for key morphological traits previously buffered by Hsp90. Whole-genome sequencing of divergent lineages revealed that novel phenotypes were associated with the expression of pre-existing, rare alleles within developmental gene regulatory networks. These alleles became penetrant only under stress-induced Hsp90 titration. Furthermore, rapid pre-zygotic isolation evolved as a correlated response to this phenotypic diversification. Our results provide empirical support for a model where environmental perturbation unmasks CGV, creating an evolutionary capacitance that can fuel rapid, saltational speciation events, thereby connecting microevolutionary mechanisms to macroevolutionary patterns.
subject: Evrim
title: Decanalization of Cryptic Genetic Variation Drives Explosive Speciation Following Environmental Perturbation

text: Resolving the early branches of the Neoaves phylogeny has been a persistent challenge due to its rapid, near-simultaneous diversification. We employed a new phylogenomic approach, integrating exonic, intronic, and ultraconserved element (UCE) data from 363 avian species to reconstruct this radiation. Using coalescent-based species tree methods that explicitly model incomplete lineage sorting (ILS), we resolved several key contentious relationships within the avian tree of life. However, our analyses revealed extensive gene tree discordance concentrated at the base of major clades, a pattern not fully explained by ILS alone. Subsequent Patterson's D-statistic and PhyloNet analyses provided strong evidence for multiple episodes of introgressive hybridization among early neoavian lineages. These findings suggest that the explosive avian radiation was characterized by a porous Felsenstein zone, where reticulate evolution played a significant role in shaping the genomic architecture of modern birds. This complex history challenges purely bifurcating models of speciation.
subject: Evrim
title: Phylogenomic Reconciliation of the Avian Radiation Reveals Pervasive Incomplete Lineage Sorting and Introgressive Hybridization

text: The Red Queen hypothesis posits that antagonistic coevolution drives the rapid evolution of host resistance genes and pathogen virulence factors. We explored this dynamic at the molecular level by examining a polymorphic Nucleotide-binding Leucine-rich Repeat (NLR) gene cluster in Arabidopsis thaliana and its interaction with a suite of effectors from the oomycete Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis. Using population genomic analyses, we identified strong signatures of balancing selection maintaining divergent NLR haplotypes, alongside evidence for frequent, localized selective sweeps within individual NLR paralogs. In parallel, pathogen effector genes showed high rates of non-synonymous substitution and presence/absence polymorphism. Functional assays using transient expression in Nicotiana benthamiana confirmed a direct, recognition-dependent interaction matrix. Our results illustrate a multi-layered arms race, where balancing selection maintains a diverse host defensive repertoire while recurrent positive selection drives innovation in both host recognition and pathogen evasion, perfectly encapsulating coevolutionary escalation.
subject: Evrim
title: Antagonistic Coevolutionary Dynamics between a Plant NLR Gene Cluster and a Pathogen Effector Suite

text: The contribution of non-genetic inheritance to adaptation remains a pivotal question in evolutionary biology. We investigated the role of heritable DNA methylation in conferring adaptive potential to rapid environmental change. Using multi-generational experimental evolution with the coral reef fish Acanthochromis polyacanthus exposed to elevated pCO2 levels, we tracked epigenetic and transcriptomic changes via whole-genome bisulfite sequencing and RNA-seq. We identified a suite of stress-induced differentially methylated regions (DMRs) in F1 offspring that were stably transmitted to the F3 generation, even after a return to ambient conditions. These inherited epimutations were significantly associated with the regulation of genes involved in acid-base homeostasis and metabolic pathways. Critically, lineages possessing these epialleles exhibited significantly higher fitness upon re-exposure to high pCO2. Our findings demonstrate that transgenerational epigenetic plasticity can act as a rapid response mechanism, providing heritable variation that bridges the gap between short-term physiological acclimation and long-term genetic adaptation.
subject: Evrim
title: Transgenerational Epigenetic Inheritance Modulates Adaptive Potential to Climate Change

text: The introgression of archaic hominin DNA has provided a reservoir of adaptive alleles for modern human populations. We present a deep-coverage whole-genome sequence of a 40,000-year-old Denisovan individual from Denisova Cave and analyze its contribution to high-altitude adaptation in Tibetans. By employing a novel admixture mapping algorithm, we identified a large, deeply divergent haplotype on chromosome 1 spanning the Endothelial Pas1 (EPAS1) gene, which is present at high frequency in Tibetans but nearly absent elsewhere. This haplotype, containing multiple non-synonymous and regulatory substitutions, shows a perfect sequence match to our sequenced Denisovan genome. Functional luciferase assays and ChIP-seq analysis in a human endothelial cell line demonstrate that the introgressed allele possesses a unique enhancer element that modulates EPAS1 expression under hypoxic conditions. This provides a direct molecular link between archaic introgression and a classic example of human adaptation, illustrating how admixture can facilitate rapid evolution in novel environments.
subject: Evrim
title: Paleogenomic Evidence for Adaptive Introgression of an Archaic Denisovan Haplotype Regulating Hypoxic Response in Tibetan Populations

text: The transition to multicellularity represents a major evolutionary innovation, yet its genetic underpinnings are not fully elucidated. We reconstructed this transition using experimental evolution with the facultatively multicellular yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisiae. By selecting for larger, faster-sedimenting clusters, we evolved obligately multicellular lineages characterized by cell-cell adhesion, division of labor, and apoptosis. Integrating transcriptomics, proteomics, and chromatin accessibility data (ATAC-seq), we discovered that the evolutionary leap to multicellularity did not involve de novo gene evolution. Instead, it was driven by the wholesale co-option and rewiring of a pre-existing gene regulatory network (GRN) for nutrient-limitation stress response. Key transcription factors, previously controlling metabolic shifts, were repurposed to regulate cell adhesion and programmed cell death. This demonstrates that major evolutionary transitions can be facilitated by the recruitment of ancestral molecular machinery, providing a plausible and parsimonious pathway for the evolution of organismal complexity.
subject: Evrim
title: The Evolutionary Assembly of Multicellularity via Co-option of a Unicellular Stress-Response Gene Regulatory Network

text: Transposable elements (TEs) have long been considered junk DNA, but their role in shaping gene regulation is increasingly appreciated. We conducted a comprehensive comparative genomic analysis across 65 vertebrate species to quantify the contribution of TE exaptation to the evolution of cis-regulatory elements. Using phylogenetic footprinting and machine learning models trained on functional genomics data (e.g., ChIP-seq, CAGE), we identified over 200,000 TE-derived regulatory elements, including enhancers, promoters, and insulators. We found that specific TE families, such as MER and L2 retrotransposons, were repeatedly and independently co-opted into developmental gene regulatory networks at key phylogenetic nodes, coinciding with major morphological innovations like the evolution of limbs and the neocortex. Our results suggest that TEs are not merely genomic parasites but represent a vast, dynamic reservoir of sequence motifs that serve as a primary engine for regulatory innovation and macroevolutionary change.
subject: Evrim
title: Evolution of Genome Architecture: Transposable Element Exaptation as a Major Source of Vertebrate Regulatory Innovation

text: Ecological and evolutionary dynamics are often studied independently, yet they can interact on contemporary timescales. We tested the hypothesis that rapid evolution in a prey species can fundamentally alter community-level ecological processes. In a replicated mesocosm experiment with Trinidadian guppies (Poecilia reticulata), their predator (Crenicichla alta), and associated algal communities, we manipulated predation pressure. Real-time genomic monitoring of guppy populations revealed strong, rapid selection on loci associated with escape performance and cryptic coloration, with allele frequencies shifting significantly within 10 generations. This evolution directly altered guppy foraging behavior, reducing grazing intensity on algae. As a result, mesocosms with co-evolving guppies exhibited significantly higher primary productivity and a stronger trophic cascade compared to control mesocosms with non-evolving guppy populations. This demonstrates a tight eco-evolutionary feedback loop where predator-induced evolution in prey is not just a consequence of ecological interactions but a potent driver of community structure and ecosystem function.
subject: Evrim
title: Eco-Evolutionary Feedback Loops: Rapid Predator-Induced Evolution Drives Trophic Cascade Dynamics

text: The paradox of morphological stasis despite abundant genetic variation suggests that developmental processes may constrain evolutionary trajectories. We investigated the role of pleiotropic gene regulatory networks (GRNs) in canalizing the evolution of the tetrapod limb. By comparing single-cell transcriptomic atlases of limb development across five amniote species (chicken, mouse, anole, turtle, and alligator), we mapped the architecture of the underlying GRNs. We found that the core network topology involving key transcription factors like Shh, HoxD, and Fgf is extraordinarily conserved. In silico perturbation simulations of this network demonstrated that most mutations produced highly deleterious, non-viable phenotypes, severely limiting accessible morphospace. Viable evolutionary trajectories were restricted to modifications in peripheral, less-connected network modules or quantitative tuning of existing interactions. Our results suggest that the deep homology of this core GRN acts as a powerful developmental constraint, explaining the conserved bauplan of the tetrapod limb over 350 million years of evolution.
subject: Evrim
title: The Role of Developmental Constraints in Canalizing Morphological Evolution within the Tetrapod Limb

text: The evolution of altruism, where an individual incurs a fitness cost to benefit others, is a central puzzle in evolutionary theory. We examined this phenomenon in the social amoeba Dictyostelium discoideum, where some cells altruistically die to form a stalk. Using experimental evolution and population genomics, we tracked the fate of 'cheater' genotypes that avoid contributing to the stalk. In unstructured populations, cheaters rapidly fixated. However, in populations structured to promote high kinship and periodic group formation, we observed the maintenance of cooperation. Whole-genome sequencing revealed selection for a novel 'green-beard' gene, csaA, which mediates cell-cell adhesion. Alleles at this locus enabled cooperative individuals to preferentially adhere, excluding cheaters from chimeric fruiting bodies. This demonstrates how multilevel selection, acting on both individual cells and multi-cellular aggregates, can favor the evolution of genomic mechanisms for kin recognition and policing, thereby stabilizing altruistic behavior against selfish exploitation.
subject: Evrim
title: Multilevel Selection and the Evolution of Genomic Altruism in a Social Amoeba
